title: 'Annie' to Leave Alvin For ANTA This Month
description: ''Annie,'' the four-year-old musical hit about the famous comicstrip orphan, will switch theaters in mid-September, leaving the Alvin and moving across West 52d street to the ANTA.

title: TRENTON - Several of New Jersey's local, county and state officeholders, most of them Democrats, have recently offered some predictably unkind remarks about President Reagan's New Federalism, under which Federal aid programs for states and localities would be lumped into block grants. There is sufficient ''doomcasting'' in their statements to dissuade most citizens of the state from ever looking a jellybean square in the eye.
description: Perhaps the question that should be addressed is, given the direction of the last 20 years of categorical grants, can we, in our cities, counties and the country as a whole continue to stagger down that path of confusion, duplication and inequity?

title: U.S. REVISING ANTITRUST STAND
description: Attorney General William French Smith said yesterday that the Reagan Administration would seek to weaken or ''eliminate'' certain provisions of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act that prohibit ''conduct by foreign intermediaries that is generally accepted in other countries.''

title: Dow Falls to 14-Month Low
description: Despite a cut in the prime rate by two major banks, the stock market fell sharply yesterday as other leading institutions declined to follow. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 10.75 points, to 881.47, its lowest close in almost 14 months - on July 2, 1980, it finished at 876.02.

title: CANADA CUP HOCKEY PLAY STARTS TONIGHT
description: Many of the best hockey players in the world start competing tomorrow for national prestige and a bit of money in the second Canada Cup tournament.

title: A LEGAL GAUNTLET TO CHALLENGE LIBYA
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: 3 CHILDREN MISSING IN TEXAS FLOODS: Youngsers from a Houston day care center being evacuated to high ground yesterday after up to 16 inches of rain caused heavy flooding in southern Texas. Three children were reported swept away in town of Shiner. Rains were caused by remnants of a tropical storm.

title: ARMY DISPLAYS NAZI ART AT COLORADO WAREHOUSE
description: It is a most unlikely art museum: a onestory whitewash cinderblock warehouse at the far corner of a halfabandoned Army supply depot on the bleak High Plains of eastern Colorado.

title: GERMAN CROSSROADS
description: To the Editor:

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 1, 1981; The Economy
description: Confusion prevailed among banks and thrift institutions after an I.R.S. warning that it might not permit tax-free incentives for the new ''All Savers'' certificates. Many of the institutions, pending a final decision, suspended the packages, which are sold through a high-interest-bearing repurchase agreement. Those that did not require an automatic rollover into a savings certificate dropped their advertising but continued to sell the packages. (Page A1.)

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amoco Chemicals Corp., Chicago, has named Robert D. Cadieux executive vice president.

title: 5 HORSES DIE IN FIRE
description: Five horses died in a barn fire at the Kentucky Horse Center yesterday. About 150 were led to safety. Two throughbreds were among the victims.

title: 2 BUILDINGS FALL ON NINTH AVE., KILL WORKER
description: One man was killed and at least four persons were hurt yesterday morning when two adjoining four-story brick tenements collapsed in a racket of falling debris and clouds of dust behind the Port Authority Bus Terminal.

title: Surgery May Save Woman's Legs
description: A New Jersey woman whose legs were nearly severed in an accident was reported in fair condition at Bellevue Hospital after both legs were reattached in microsurgery.

title: Restart of Reactor In Jersey Delayed
description: A failure in the shutdown cooling system at the Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station has forced the postponement of its restarting, officials said.

title: FARM HOUSE FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 18
Samuel Orr Dies at 91; Former Assemblyman
description: Samuel Orr, one of five members of the Socialist Party ousted by the New York State Assembly in 1920, and later a deputy New York City comptroller and magistrate, died in Montefiore Hospital on Saturday night. He was 91 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Europe Sugar Aid Assailed
description: The Great Western Sugar Company today petitioned the Government to take action against the European Economic Community, charging that the Common Market was dumping subsidized sugar exports on world markets.

title: SOME DENTISTS SUFFER MERCURY BUILDUP
description: Some dentists who work with mercury may be suffering from a buildup of the metal in their bodies, experiencing problems with coordination, perception and stress, according to a University of Pennsylvania study.

title: RONCO TELEPRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
CLUB FOR MAGIC, FOOD AND FUN
description: A small gold owl with bright red eyes scrutinizes each visitor in the Magic Castle's foyer. Speak the magic words ''Open sesame!'' and the eyes blink. A bookcase lined with leather-bound volumes glides open to reveal a doorway. There, through the passageway, are dimly lighted rooms where anything from pianoplaying poltergeists to professional prestidigitation is not only possible but probable.

title: CONSOLIDATION COAL IN AUSTRALIA PACT
description: The Consolidated Coal Company, the Pittsburgh-based subsidiary of the Continental Oil Company, said it has agreed to buy a 49 percent interest in an Australian coal concern for an undisclosed price.

title: Canadian IS Accused Of Killing 9 Children
description: A 41-year-old man was charged today with eight counts of first-degree murder, bringing to nine the number of children he has been accused of killing.

title: Czechoslovakia is haunted by its past. On each anniversary of the Warsaw Pact invasion of Aug. 21, 1968, the country shudders slightly and draws the curtains. Bars close early in Prague on the eve of the anniversary, soldiers and security police flood the cities and the Government issues ritual incantations of thanks to the Soviet Union for ''rescuing'' the Czechoslovak people from counterrevolution.
description: But this year the invasion anniversary was an unusually tense and repressive time. The Czechoslovak Government had actually seen the ghost. Its name was Poland.

title: 120 VOLUMES ON BUDDHISM COMING OUT $15,000
description: The sacred writings of Buddhism, imperiled in recent decades by Communist takeovers in China and Tibet, have begun to be printed in a durable, comprehensive and historic form by Dharma Publishing in Berkeley, Calif. Last week, the first 120-volume collection was completed, marking the final stages of a monumental effort by Tibetan Buddhist scholars to preserve the ancient teachings.

title: S.& H. Green Stamps Goes to O.& M./2
description: S.& H. Green Stamps has announced that, beginning Nov. 1, Ogilvy & Mather/2, a division of Ogilvy & Mather International, will handle its advertising budget, which it estimates at $3 million a year.

title: Begin Stays at Home With a Knee Ailment
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel was confined to his home today after being treated in a hospital for a knee ailment.

title: TIGER'S FULL SERVICE GOAL
description: After years of ambitious spending and aggressive acquisition, Tiger International has closed in on its goal of providing a complete door-to-door cargo transportation service using truck, rail and aircraft. But there are a couple of big hurdles yet to clear.

title: Hospital Corp.  To Sell 18 Units
description: The Hospital Corporation of America, the world's largest manager of hospital operations, said it has agreed to sell 18 nursing homes to a California company for $46 million.

title: Cause of Menstrual Pain
description: Though for centuries menstruating women were accused of malingering when they complained of pain and other discomforts, recent evidence has shown that menstrual symptoms have a physiological basis.

title: Bomb for Reagan Found
description: A homemade package bomb containing dynamite and a blasting cap and addressed to President Reagan in Washington was found early today in a downtown mailbox and detonated on Belle Isle by the police bomb squad. A note was found inside the package, but the police refused to disclose its contents.

title: News Analysis
description: The political honeymoon here is called ''the state of grace,'' and for President Francois Mitterrand the grace is beginning to seep away.

title: LOGGERS CONFRONT SPOTTED OWLS ON PACIFIC NORTHWEST LANDS
description: The northern spotted owl, which prefers to live in the Pacific Northwest's old-growth forests, is causing a flap between environmentalists and timber interests.

title: MOHAMMAD ALI RAJAI, IRAN'S PRESIDENT
description: President Mohammed Ali Rajai of Iran, who was among those killed by a bomb that exploded on Sunday in the office of the Prime Minister in Teheran, became his country's President after rallying hard-liners to carry on a fundamentalist Islamic revolution.

title: NO ONE IS HURT AS U.S. SITES IN PERU ARE STRUCK BY BOMBS
description: A series of bombings here today struck the United States Embassy, the American Ambassador's residence and four companies with United States connections, causing damage but no injuries, the police said.

title: ORWELLIAN REAGAN POLICY ON JOB BIAS
description: To the Editor:

title: Australians End Oil Bid
description: Cultus Pacific, an Australian energy and minerals exploration company, said it would not proceed with its offer for two Canadian oil and gas companies, the Penn Energy Corporation and Justen Resources Ltd. The decision follows long delays in obtaining necessary approval from Canadian authorities and the subsequent need to re-evaluate the bids, Cultus added.

title: LATE COAST RESULT: WE WAS ROBBED
description: The final score was California 170, New York 150. ''But as they used to say in Brooklyn,'' said Judy Friess, ''just wait till next year.''

title: The 40 Percent Misunderstanding
description: Earn 30 percent interest! Take home 40 percent on your money! Such returns on savings, touted in the latest barrage of bank advertising, seemed too good to be true. The ads, in fact, were technically correct: it is possible to earn 40 percent, though only briefly. But according to an unusual weekend warning from the Internal Revenue Service, those who go for the big numbers may have a nasty tax surprise in store next year.

title: Accord at U. of Bridgeport
description: Professors at the University of Bridgeport voted 133 to 4 this evening to accept a three-year contract with average pay increases of 9 percent each year, averting a strike that had been threatened for the opening day of the fall session tomorrow, union officials said. The professors had gone on strike in the last two contract negotiations, walking out for three days in 1975 and for three weeks in 1978. The privately operated university has 7,000 students.

title: Suspect Held in Fatal Fire
description: A south Louisiana man has been charged with first-degree murder and arson in a fire that swept through a discotheque and killed five persons, the authorities said today. Lafourche Parish deputies booked David Paul Carrere, 21 years old, of nearby Houma, for aggravated arson and five counts of firstdegree murder in the June 28 blaze that leveled the Odyssey Lounge.

title: HIGH-STYLE BOOTS AT POPULAR PRICES
description: Boots are back. Just about every designer on both sides of the Atlantic showed boots with this fall's blousy tops and calf-length skirts and culottes. And the boots weren't shown only with daytime clothes. Soft suedes or metallic leathers were worn with everything short of a ball gown.

title: BLAST HURTS 20 AT U.S. BASE IN GERMANY
description: A powerful explosion went off today at the European headquarters of the United States Air Force in Ramstein, West Germany, injuring 20 people including an American general.

title: Two Umpires Are Fined
description: Charles Feeney, president of the National League, fined two umpires today for their part in an incident involving a television crew at a Philadelphia Phillies game, according to the lawyer for major league umpires.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: For the biographer, Joseph Conrad would seem the perfect subject: unlike most writers who spend the better part of their lives sitting in a room, turning sentences around, he spent some 20 years gathering experience and adventures as a sailor and explorer of strange, exotic places. The "shadowy country" of inextinguishable desires and fears" that shaped his fiction was not only a literary construct, but in many cases grew out of an actual landscape whose emotional and physical geography the author had explored himself.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO LIMIT QUESTIONABLE ART IMPORTS
description: The Customs Service is testing its ability to prosecute those who import antiques and artifacts that are claimed by other nations as part of their cultural heritage.

title: MICROSONICS CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
2 CLEVELAND SCHOOL OFFICIALS JAILED BRIEFLY FOR CONTEMPT
description: The president and treasurer of the Cleveland Board of Education were led from Federal court in handcuffs and jailed for nearly two hours today for failure to comply with orders from a court-appointed desegregation administrator.

title: DR. HAIM AGUS
description: Dr. Haim Agus, a specialist in internal medicine and a former attending physician at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, died yesterday at New York University Medical Center. He was 70 years and was a resident of Manhattan. He had lived for many years in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn, where he had a practice.

title: Prejudice and Agent Orange
description: Should a controversial statement by a scientist disqualify him from designing a sensitive study of the effects of Agent Orange on American troops in Vietnam?

title: PHILADELPHIA MUSEUM GETS GIFT OF $786,435
description: The Philadelphia Museum of Art has received its largest corporate gift, $786,435 from the SmithKline Corporation, Robert M. Scott, president of the museum, has announced.

title: Gaines Puts Himself on Injured Reserve
description: Clark Gaines said today that he did not deserve to be on the Jets' final roster, and he asked Coach Walt Michaels to put him on the injured-reserve list.

title: DR. EINSTEIN'S UNIVERSAL SCALE
description: To the Editor:

title: VTN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-After tax credits of $332,000 in qr and $208,000 for the yr...C-Net income

title: NIXON PAPERS STIR ACRIMONY AT DUKE
description: Duke University faculty members, frequently resorting to ridicule and harsh words, spoke out this afternoon against a proposal to build Richard M. Nixon's Presidential library adjacent to their campus.

title: ABA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: Yr-ago shrs outstndg and shr earnings adjusted for a 25 percent stock divd paid Jan 1981

title: Firebombs Strike Home of Accused
description: Four gasoline bombs were thrown early yesterday at the home of a Long Island man accused by Federal authorities of having persecuted Jews in Latvia during World War II, authorities said.

title: STEEL'S TRIGGER FINGER
description: To the Editor:

title: SAVINGS UNITS, CONFUSED, WAIT FOR I.R.S. MOVE
description: Banks and savings and loan associations across the country reacted in confusion yesterday to an Internal Revenue Service warning about their high-interest ''bonus'' programs aimed at lining up deposits for the new ''All Savers'' certificates.

title: Giants' Jeter Is Sidelined for 4 Weeks
description: Gary Jeter, the best pass rusher on the Giants' defensive line, underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee today and will miss at least the first four weeks of the season.

title: Mitchel, Schreiber Has New President
description: In the world of Wall Street, there are firms that deal only with other professionals on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. One of the largest of these firms is Mitchel, Schreiber, Watts & Company.

title: Louis I. Teicher, Ex-Director Of Music Operations for CBS
description: Louis I. Teicher, whose career with CBS spanned nearly 50 years, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Great Neck, L.I. He was 67 years old.

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: Genetic Prophecy: Beyond the Double Helix By Zsolt Harsanyi and Richard Hutton. 339 pages. Illustrated. Rawson, Wade Publishers, Inc., New York, $13.95.

title: Top Executive Is Appointed At Murjani's Vanderbilt Line
description: Jacki Nemerov, who began as a retail buyer and moved to the other side of the fence to sell apparel, has been named president of the Gloria Vanderbilt women's line. In taking the top job at Gloria Vanderbilt, one of four divisions of Murjani International Ltd., she succeeds Jan Butler, who resigned to join Hirsh-Evans, another clothing company, which is headed by Warren Hirsh, the former Murjani president.

title: ALLIED REPORTS FISHER BID RESULT
description: The Allied Corporation said it received about 2.64 million common shares and $22 million of 8 1/2 percent convertible subordinated debentures of the Fisher Scientific Company under its tender offer, which expired on Aug. 28.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Recalled Dan Ford, pitcher, from Rochester of Interna- tional League, and Mark Corey, outfield- er, from Springfield of American Associa- tion.  CALIFORNIA (AL) - Purchased Bob Davis, catcher, from Salt Lake City of Pa- cific Coast League.  KANSAS CITY (AL) - Dismissed Man- ager Jim Frey and named Dick Howser to succeed him. Announced waivers would be asked on Jerry Grote, catcher.  PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Placed Larry Christenson, pitcher
description: Torkelson, running back, and Larry Coombs, center. KANSAS CITY (AFC) - Waived Mark Miller, quarterback; Brad Oates, tackle; Ozzie Harrell, cornerback, and Deron Cherry, safety.

title: THE ENEMY IS APATHY
description: On Sunday, in the first television debate of the Mayoral primary campaign, Mayor Koch looked over at his two Democratic challengers, Assemblyman Frank Barbaro, a traditional liberal, and Melvin Klenetsky, a product of the right-wing U.S. Labor Party now masquerading as a Democrat, and said: ''My opponent is not either of these two gentlemen. My opponent is apathy.''

title: AFTER THE WOLF AND WEREWOLF, BEHOLD THE SNAKE
description: by Aljean Harmetz Hollywood, Aug. 30 - Slithering celluloid serpents seem certain to snake in circuitous circles across the screen of your neighborhood cinema movie theater soon.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: T HE week began with Lord Lewisham, the 32-year-old grandson of Barbara Cartland and the stepbrother of the Princess of Wales. He was giving a party at his East Side home for Davina Phillips, eight years his senior, mother of two, the former girlfriend of Prince Michael of Kent, and generally expected to become the new Lady Lewisham. She has, adds Lord Lewisham's friends, taught him how to dress. By 7:30, all the guests were there, including Countess Christina Wachtmeister, Lady Chapman, Kenneth Lane, the jewelry designer, and Fred Hughes, who manned the door. While they waited for Mrs. Phillips to arrive, Mr. Hughes said that he was searching for new offices for Interview magazine, Arianna Stassinopoulos broke her glass of Perrier, which everyone said was good luck, and Anthony Haden-Guest said his new book on Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, the convicted murderer, had been chosen as a Book-of-the-Month Club alternate selection.

title: EFFECTS OF BEAUTY FOUND TO RUN SURPRISINGLY DEEP
description: M INNEAPOLIS STUDIES of physical attractiveness show that people do, in fact, judge a book by its cover, often with dramatic effects on those being judged. The findings suggest that expectations based on physical attractiveness can become self-fulfilling prophecies that may strongly influence the course of a person's life.

title: Share Cheap Hydropower Equally
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Way for Youth
description: The Washington Bullets, committed to rebuilding with a new, younger team, have placed Austin Carr, 33, on waivers.

title: MAKING IT OVER THE MATH HURDLES
description: FEAR of mathematics has become something of a cliche and an excuse for failure, or for avoiding the subject altogether. In the latest attempt to deal with the problem, a group of educators from Harvard University and Milton Academy, a private college-preparatory school near Boston, next week will publish a special student text and teacher's guide to help pupils develop the proper study skills before they embark on algebra, that first of a succession of mathematics hurdles.

title: VOYAGER RUSHES TOWARD A VERY STRANGE PLANET
description: Uranus. Scientists know so little about Uranus that they have few preconceptions of what Voyager may find there.

title: BOND PRICES TUMBLE ON RATE FEARS
description: Fears of continued high interest rates and a heavy supply of new financing sent bond prices tumbling yesterday as numerous yields rose to record levels.

title: YOUNG PIANIST REMINDS THE WORLD VIETNAM IS A COUNTRY OF MUSIC, TOO
description: When Dang Thai Son found himself, against his own and everyone else's expectation, in the final round of last year's Chopin Piano Competition in Warsaw, his suit, which he had bought in the Children's World department store in Moscow, would no longer do. Formal dress was required, not easy to find on short notice in consumer societies, more difficult yet in Poland's Communist austerity, and impossible when it must fit a Vietnamese of boyish stature who had found his only Western suit on the children's rack.

title: RUSS TOGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Includes $654,000 extraordinary gain

title: OSHMAN'S SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: The shr earnings are adjusted for a 50 percent stock divd in July 1981

title: KHOMEINI ASSERTS 2 LEADERS' DEATHS WON'T DETER IRAN
description: Iran buried its slain President and Prime Minister today, and Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini vowed that their deaths would not change the course of the Islamic revolution.

title: ITT Telex Plan
description: ITT World Communications Inc., a unit of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, said it will enter the domestic telex market for the first time when it begins offering service within the state of New York on Sept. 8. The company said in a release that the new service resulted from the New York Legislature's action in July deregulating all carriers providing telegraphic services within the state. ITT World said subscribers in New York will have access to the more than 6,000 ITT teleprinter terminals in the state for a flat rate of 32 cents per minute.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Ashland Oil Inc. said Moody's Investor Service Inc. lowered its rating on Ashland's commercial paper to prime two from prime one.

title: U.S. VETOES REBUKE TO SOUTH AFRICANS
description: The United States, in a break with its allies, tonight vetoed a Security Council resolution strongly criticizing South Africa for its raid into Angola.

title: MAYER IN SPOTLIGHT AS U.S. OPEN STARTS
description: Gene Mayer has heard the whispers and jokes about his propensity to default matches because of injury at major tennis tournaments, but he remains convinced that he can succeed with his two-handed talent.

title: Merrill Lynch Uses 2 Bulls for Commercial
description: Merrill Lynch's expenditures for its two new 30-second spot television commercials, which have their debut Thursday, included $12,000 for the exclusive use of two bulls, with human attendants and other perquisites, for two weeks. Why two bulls when only one appears in the commercials?

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: What's For Lunch: Animal Feeding at the Zoo By Sally Tongren. 128 pages. 60 photographs. GMG Publishing, New York. Hardcover $12.95.

title: U.S. DRIVE FOR GRAIN EXPORTS STIRS DOUBTS BOTH HOME AND ABROAD
description: A lifeline of ships streamed out of United States ports last year with more than half of the grain in international trade, carrying wheat to the Soviet Union and China, animal feed to South Korea and corn to Mexico. More than ever before, the world depends upon American exports for its basic food needs. This country now exports more grain than Latin America and sub-Saharan Africa together produce.

title: ERRICO CITES ILLNESS, ASKS LESSER TERM
description: The lawyer for Con Errico, a former jockey who faces a 10-year prison term for his conviction in a race-fixing scheme, appealed yesterday for reduction of the sentence.

title: Advertising; Bookstore Chain's Gift Package
description: AFTER all his years on television, Alistair Cooke wouldn't seem to need more publicity. Nevertheless, he is likely to be a prime beneficiary of Waldenbooks' lavish 1981 holiday gift catalogue. It is costing $2.5 million to put out, the bookstore chain says, with book publishers providing roughly $1.5 million.

title: Chess: Ukraine Noses by Moscow To Win Soviet Team Event
description: The 1981 Championship of Soviet Teams was captured by the Ukraine with 43 points, a half-point ahead of Moscow. Gruziya was third, with 40 1/2. This was the first time since the series began in 1947 that Russia - which finished with 40 points - failed to take a medal.

title: 4.8% PAY INCREASE FOR U.S. EMPLOYEES URGED BY REAGAN
description: President Reagan recommended today that white-collar Federal employees receive a 4.8 percent pay increase Oct. 1. This is less than one-third the amount authorized by a 1970 salary law.

title: Alcoa Gives; Profit Outlook
description: The Aluminum Company of America foresees no upturn in earnings results before the first half of next year, W.H. George Krome, chairman of the board and chief executive officer, said.

title: FNI INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-Net loss after $2,478,854 loss from discontinued operations

title: CONTINENTAL BANK OF CANADA SHIFTS
description: The Continental Bank of Canada announced that its parent company, a finance company called IAC Ltd., will cease to exist on Oct. 31, 1982, as a final step in a five-year legal process by which the finance concern was transformed into a bank.

title: KOCH'S OPPONENTS CRITICIZE MAYOR'S LINKS TO LANDLORDS
description: Mayor Koch was criticized yesterday by his opponents in the mayoral race as being too kind to landlords and as an unwelcome intruder in another political party's ''family fight.''

title: Steel Production Up
description: Steel production rose to 2.348 million tons in the week ended Saturday, an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent from the previous week's 2.341 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: 3 THIVES TAKE CASH AND MILLION IN GOLD FROM A 37TH ST. LOFT
description: Three burglars lowered themselves by ropes from the roof of a 17-story midtown building to the ninth floor, entered a jewelry manufacturer's loft, broke into a safe and took $1 million in gold and $15,000 in cash, the police said.

title: COLE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Net income; shr earnings adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split paid July 2

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Garrett Receives Boeing Contract
description: The Boeing Company said it has awarded the first major subcontracts for its new Boeing 737-300 jetliner program to the Garrett Corporation, a unit of the Signal Companies.

title: Bronx Man Held In Son's Strangling
description: A Bronx man was arrested and charged with murder after he said he strangled his 2-year-old son, stuffed the body in a pillowcase and plastic bag, and threw it in the Harlem River, according to the police.

title: Interest Limit at Issue
description: On July 29, Congress passed a new tax law that provided for the issuance on Oct. 1 of a new financial instrument called the ''All Savers'' certificate.

title: NATIONAL VALVE & MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LA-Z-BOY CHAIR CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Japan Cut Cars To West in July
description: Japan's auto exports to the United States and Europe fell in July as a result of self-imposed restraints, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: American General To Lift NLT Stake
description: The American General Corporation said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it intends to increase its holdings in the NLT Corporation, a holding company with interests in insurance, radio stations, computer services and the Grand Ole Opry, to between 20 and 25 percent, from its current level of 9.1 percent.

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMER DOWN 2.1%
description: Prices paid to farmers for raw products dropped 2.1 percent in August and, for the first time in 14 months, averaged below the levels of a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: 2 BIG BANKS CUT PRIME TO 20%
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank and the First National Bank of Chicago yesterday reduced their prime rates to 20 percent from 20 1/2 percent, but a Chase spokesman warned that the half-point cut was ''not necessarily an indication of where rates are going from here on out.''

title: White Motor Completes Sale
description: The White Motor Corporation said it has completed the sale of the remainder of its heavy duty truck business to the Volvo White Truck Corporation, a subsidiary of Volvo of Sweden, for $17 million cash and $34.1 million in notes.

title: School Board in Chicago Adopts 3-Year Budget
description: After 15 hours of negotiation, the Board of Education approved a three-year financial plan and a balanced budget for 1981-82 early today, paving the way for classes to open on time Sept. 9.

title: SKETCHES OF KEY FIGURES IN TEHERAN GOVERNMENT
description: The deposed President of Iran, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, said last week in France, where he is living in exile, that the Iranian Government would fall if five men died. Two of those five, President Mohammed Ali Rajai and Prime Minister Mohammed Javad Bahonar, were killed on Sunday when a bomb exploded in the Prime Minister's office in Teheran. In addition to the remaining three, Behzad Nabavi is believed to be among the top leaders in Iran.

title: JOSEPH H. HIRSHHORN, DONOR OF ART MUSEUM, IS DEAD AT 82
description: Joseph Herman Hirshhorn, the wealthy stock speculator who was one of the country's great art collectors, died suddenly of a heart attack late last night after attending the theater in Washington. He was 82 years old.

title: Lufthansa Expects Loss
description: Lufthansa, the West German flag carrier, said today it expected a 1981 operating loss but hoped to offset it with moves such as the sale of some of its planes.

title: DIVING CREW PROVING ANDREA DORIA PROJECT WAS NOT TREASURE HUNT
description: The members of the Andrea Doria expedition held a long meeting late Sunday night to decide if they should continue their effort to find a safe that they believe is in the purser's office of the sunken liner - a safe that could contain many thousands of dollars. They had received assurances that they could have more operating funds and keep their rented boats and equipment a while longer.

title: No Grain Rise To China Seen
description: China will probably not commit itself to buying more grain from the United States than the agreed minimum for next year, foreign agricultural experts reported today.

title: THE TAXATION, CAPITALIZATION AND REGULATION OF THE BELL
description: SYSTEMTo the Editor:

title: PROVING A POINT
description: Having once worked as an advertising copywriter, Carol Greitzer said the other day, she learned the value of putting on a vivid demonstration to make a point.

title: Max Lapides, Lawyer, Served Jewish Agency
description: Max Lapides, a lawyer who served with the Jewish Agency for Israel for two decades and helped settle tens of thousands of European and Yemenite immigrants in Israel in the late 1940's and early 1950's, died Saturday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in West Haven, Conn., after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: A U.S. ENVOY ASSAILS BEGIN AS 'BLIND'
description: The outgoing United States Ambassador to Syria said today that he doubted that a Middle East peace settlement could be reached while Menachem Begin was Prime Minister of Israel.

title: U.S. TAKES RESPONSIBILITY IN LOSS OF JAPANESE SHIP
description: The United States said today that coincidental circumstances and faulty judgment by ''members of the U.S. Naval service'' were at fault in the sinking of a Japanese freighter in April after a collision with an American submarine, Japan's Foreign Ministry said.

title: ICE SHOW, LOSING TO CASINOS, MAY DROP ATLANTIC CITY VISITS
description: Casino gambling, dismal attendance figures and escalating operating costs will probably force the Ice Capades, a 42-year-old local summer institution, to abandon this resort.

title: BUS DRIVERS BALK AT LOSS OF A PAID LUNCH PERIOD
description: In protest against the Transit Authority for eliminating paid lunch periods for hundreds of bus drivers under the fall schedule, virtually all 3,757 drivers in Manhattan and the Bronx have refused to cooperate as they normally do in the assignment of runs.

title: HEAD OF YALE CALLS MORAL MAJORITY 'PEDDLERS OF COERCION' ON 'VALUES'
description: The president of Yale University attacked the Moral Majority and other conservative groups yesterday as ''peddlers of coercion'' in ''a radical assault'' on pluralism, civil rights and religious and political freedoms in the United States.

title: A UNION CHIEF MUSES ON LABOR AND THE CONTROLLERS
description: One day this month, on his way from Chicago to the summer home he maintains here on Cape Cod, Jerry Wurf faced a dilemma. Suffering pain from a disease of the nerve endings, he wished to fly to the cape. But the nation's air traffic controllers had gone out on strike, and, as a union man, he did not wish to cross their picket line.

title: Poison and the Parsnip
description: Many foods are known to be laced with toxic substances. The potato contains solanine, a relative of the poison in deadly nightshade.

title: Talking Business with Trautlein of Bethlehem Steel; For Big Steel, New Troubles
description: After a strong first half of steel shipments, steel executives were hoping that the trend would continue to the end of the year. Instead, demand in recent weeks has fallen off and the companies were forced to rescind a price increase on tin plate, though they are still seeking to push through increases on other products. Last week the industry was jolted again as steel imports for July came in at a high level, accounting for about 20 percent of the domestic steel market. Donald H. Trautlein, an accountant by training, joined the Bethlehem Steel Corporation in 1977, when it was coping with a severe downturn. Three years later Mr. Trautlein, who is 55 years old, took over as chairman of Bethlehem. Here, he discusses the uncertain state of the industry as it enters another downturn.

title: FRASER MORTGAGE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
FIRST FRESHMAN CLASS STARTS AT MIAMI SCHOOL
description: Miami's Florida International University has taken in its first freshman class, marking the end of a long struggle by local leaders to persuade the Legislature to make it a four-year school.

title: GEN. HUGH CASEY, SERVED MACARTHUR AS CHIEF ENGINEER
description: Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, a highly decorated Army engineer who served with Gen. Douglas MacArthur in the Philippines in World War II and was chairman of the New York City Transit Authority in the early 1950's, died Sunday of a heart attack at the Veterans Administration rehabilitation center in White River Junction, Vt. He was 83 years old.

title: Doubleday Book Clubs Appoint Maureen Egen
description: Maureen Mahon Egen has been named editorial chief of the Doubleday Book Club. She had been managing editor of the clubs since 1979 and editor in chief of the Literary Guild. Mrs. Egen, who joined Doubleday in 1964 as an editorial trainee, replaces Herman Gollob, who resigned last month to join Simon & Schuster.

title: Article 254418 -- No Title
description: A $1 million bonus, the largest single prize ever made available in sport, was offered yesterday to a professional tennis player who wins four straight designated women's tournaments. If she wins three of the four, she would get $500,000, The offer, by the Playtex company, is called the Playtex Challenge.

title: Index; International
description: U.S. Embassy and residence bombed in Peru, no one hurt A3 U.S. envoy foresees no Mideast settlement in Begin's term A3 Egyptian aide says Soviet was be- hind U.S.-Libya air clash A4 Text of draft Security Council resolution A4 Around the World A5 Sketches of the top leaders in Iran A6 Bani-Sadr says Khomeini is rea- son for bombing deaths in Iran A7 Government/Politics Maryland county title: KOCH RE-ELECTION STRATEGY: A SHIFT FROM FISCAL CONCERNS TO BETTER
description: SERVICES By FRANK LYNN

title: ACTION INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
W. Noel Hudson, a Specialist In Campaigns to Raise Funds
description: W. Noel Hudson, former vice president for development and university relations at Niagara University in Niagara Falls, N.Y., died Wednesday at Mount St. Mary's Hospital in Lewiston, N.Y., of injuries suffered in an automobile accident in June. He was 68 years old and lived in Lewiston.

title: UNRETIRED FOR NOW
description: Sparky Lyle of the Philadelphia Phillies, who has been unable to record a save in 32 appearances this season, became so frustrated over the weekend that he was quoted as having said he could quit ''tomorrow, the next day or the next week.'' Yesterday The Associated Press reported that he had changed his mind.

title: Sports of the Times; The Ken Stabler Issue
description: IN the National Football League player contract that Ken Stabler has signed with the Houston Oilers, the ''integrity of the game'' is defined.

title: Saver Rates Set To Rise Today
description: Starting today, the maximum allowable interest rate that thrift institutions are allowed to pay on small-saver certificates will increase to 16.5 percent from 15.9 percent, the Treasury announced yesterday.

title: Bomb Damages Plane At Beirut's Airport
description: A bomb damaged an empty Middle East Airlines Boeing 720 and halted traffic at Beirut's international airport today during violence marking the third anniversary of a Shiite Moslem leader's disappearance.

title: Ingmar Bergman to Quit Making Films
description: Ingmar Bergman said yesterday that he planned to quit making movies because ''I am starting to get old.''

title: CERTIFICATE CONVERSION RULING
description: Federal banking regulators ruled today that holders of six-month money market certificates can convert them into the new ''All Savers'' certificates on Oct. 1 without an early withdrawal penalty.

title: Hazing Reported At Old Westbury
description: Illegal fraternity hazing, including the ''branding'' of pledges, is a common practice at the Old Westbury campus of the State University of New York, according to a report released by District Attorney Denis Dillon of Nassau County.

title: A First for China
description: According to Arnold Palmer, there is not a single golf course in all of China, a nation of 800 million, but he's going to help do something to rectify that situation.

title: Del Mar Man: a Newcomer?
description: The oldest known inhabitant of La Jolla, Calif., known to archeologists as Del Mar Man, may have just become 37,000 years younger.

title: Miss Redgrave Sues
description: A $10 million damage suit was filed by Lynn Redgrave against Universal Television yesterday, saying she had been ''wrongly discharged'' from the CBS-TV series ''House Calls.''

title: Improvement Continues
description: Travis John, the 2-year-old son of Tommy John, the Yankee pitcher, has been taken off the critical list and moved from the Intensive Care Unit at New York University Medical Center. Dr. Fred Epstein, the hospital's chief pediatrician, described Travis's condition as satisfactory. ''He is taking food,'' Dr. Epstein said, ''and today fed himself for the first time.'' Travis suffered a ''severe cranial injury'' and went into a coma after he fell from a window Aug. 10 at the family's summer home in Bay Head, N.J.

title: DANGEROUS DISORDERS OF SWALLOWING ARE COMMON BUT SUBTLE
description: MANY of the estimated 8,000 to 10,000 people who choke to death each year in the United States are victims of subtle but progressive nerve and muscle problems that attacked their swallowing mechanisms for years, according to scientists at Johns Hopkins University. Moreover, such swallowing disorders may evolve so gradually, say the scientists, that they often go unnoticed or are misdiagnosed as other physical or psychological ailments.

title: Fletcher Retains Title
description: Frank Fletcher retained his United States Boxing Association middleweight title tonight by stopping Ernie Singletary in the eighth round.

title: GARFINCKEL, IN REVERSAL, TAKES RAISED ALLIED BID
description: After three weeks of resistance, Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc., a major retailer, announced last night that it had reached an agreement to be taken over by the Allied Stores Corporation in a deal worth about $233 million.

title: Spending And Security
description: The Reagan Administration's difficulty in deciding what to do about the MX missile is symptomatic of a larger problem - that a decision has been made to spend hundred of billions of dollars in a vast military buildup without a comprehensive study of what the money is most needed for, and how best to meet those needs.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bairnco Corp. said it purchased about 206,000 common shares of Lightolier Inc. under its offer to purchase any and all Lightolier shares at $28 each. This amount, together with the 294,000 shares previously purchased by Bairnco, constitutes about 28 percent of Lightolier's outstanding common.

title: Backing Stabler, Oilers Say
description: Ed Biles, coach of the Houston Oilers, said today that his quarterback, Ken Stabler, had the team's full backing despite reports that Stabler once had associated with a convicted gambler.

title: AEROFLEX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lilco Unit's Chief
description: Solar energy for residential use on Long Island is very much in the plans of the Long Island Lighting Company. The company has established an unregulated subsidiary, Lilco Energy Systems Inc., to market energy conservation and renewable resource equipment and has appointed Edward N. Baumann, 54, as its president.

title: BLOOMINGDALE'S CATALOGUES
description: Angora sweaters and Irish castles. Woolen suits and Afghan hounds. Helicopter tours of the Big Apple, taking in the skating rink and Christmas tree at Rockefeller Center.

title: ABRAMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Trial Set Over Thrift Rules
description: A dispute over whether nonprofit groups can have interest-bearing checking accounts at thrift institutions - with billions of dollars in deposits at stake -should be settled quickly by a nonjury trial, lawyers for Federal regulators and the American Bankers Association agreed today.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
ASTROS DEFEAT METS, 6-1
description: The New York Mets' second-half ambitions took another tumble tonight when they made three infield errors and suffered a 6-1 loss to the Houston Astros.

title: JULY SALES OF HOUSES UP BY 2.4%
description: Sales of new single-family houses recovered a bit in July, rising a seasonally adjusted 2.4 percent despite record mortgage interest rates, the departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development reported today.

title: Market Place; Analysts Reassess RCA
description: RCA has long been losing friends in the investment community. Once among the proudest banners in consumer electronics, RCA has lost much ground to the Japanese and has even had to offer through its distribution system the Matsushita videotape recorder because RCA did not develop such a machine itself.

title: PBA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings adjusted to reflect a 100 percent stock divd paid in July 1981

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HUMOROUS BACH Bach in a joking vein will wind up a festival devoted to the composer that has been under way Tuesday evenings in Brooklyn Heights. On the program are two secular works-the "Coffee Cantata" (No. 211) and the "Peasant Cantata" (No 212).

title: CITIES FIGHT TO KEEP GRIP ON CABLE TV
description: Mayors around the nation are trying to put together a broad coalition of public and private interest groups to defeat legislation pending in the Senate that would curtail local government control of cable television.

title: WESTCHESTER AIRPORT TO PROHIBIT LATE-NIGHT FLIGHTS
description: The Westchester County Board of Legislators voted 16 to 1 today to ban all flights between midnight and 7 A.M. at the Westchester County Airport, except in emergencies.

title: MORE AND MORE STREETS GET A CHANGE BUT IN NAME ONLY
description: With the stroke of a pen Stebbins Avenue in the Bronx became the Rev. James A. Polite Avenue. Summer Street on Staten Island gave way to Dennis Torricelli Sr. Street, and Stone Avenue in Brooklyn was renamed Mother Gaston Boulevard.

title: CHRYSLER RAISES PRICES OF 1982 MODELS BY 7.7%
description: The Chrysler Corporation has decided to increase prices of its 1982 model automobiles an average of 7.7 percent, or $622, above the 1981 models, but company officials are hinting that the increase may be reduced before the new cars are formally introduced on Oct. 1.

title: Sports People; Weaver Is Arrested
description: Earl Weaver, manager of the Baltimore Orioles, was arrested early yesterday by the Baltimore County police and charged with driving under the influence of alcohol.

title: ROYALS DROP FREY AND NAME HOWSER
description: Dick Howser, whose New York Yankees lost three straight games to Kansas City in the American League playoffs last year, was named today to manage the Royals after Jim Frey was dismissed. Howser, 45 years old, was given a three-year contract, the longest any Kansas City manager has received.

title: SALVADORAN URGES TALKS TO AVOID A LONG WAR
description: The leader of El Salvador's leftist political opposition said yesterday that neither the guerrillas nor the United States-backed Salvadoran Army forces are capable of a military victory in the short run.

title: Philippine Air Layoffs
description: Philippine Air Lines, the country's flag carrier, announced today that it would lay off or retire about 560 employees, about 7 percent of its total work force of 7,750, in a move to reduce losses. The airline said it had to cut back because ''the very survival of our company is at stake.'' It lost about $52.5 million last year.

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes gains of 22 cents a shr for 1981 and 24 cents a shr for 1980 from revisions of certain accounting estimates

title: NEUTROGENA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: 1980 shr earnings adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed Feb 18, 1981

title: Psychiatric Tests Set
description: Gary Templeton, the St. Louis Cardinal shortstop who was suspended indefinitely and fined $5,000 by his manager, Whitey Herzog, for making obscene gestures at fans last week, has been admitted to a hospital for psychiatric examination and rest. The incident occurred Aug. 26 after Templeton was booed for his failure to run to first base after a dropped third strike.

title: BANI-SADR CALLS KHOMEINI RESPONSIBLE FOR DEATHS
description: Iran's former President, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, said today that Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini was ''responsible'' for the bombing deaths yesterday of President Mohammed Ali Rajai and Prime Minister Mohammed Javad Bahonar.

title: PHILADELPHIA 'STING' LOSES POINT QUICKLY AS 'SECRET' GETS OUT
description: When the Philadelphia District Attorney's office tried to set up a ''sting'' operation last month in a local bar to catch unsuspecting burglars, it speculated that no one would know. It was wrong.

title: 'NICHOLAS NICKLEBY' TICKETS GO ON SALE AT $100
description: The opening of the box office yesterday morning for ''Nicholas Nickleby,'' which is offering the most expensive theater ticket in Broadway history -all seats are $100 - found 20 people waiting in line. It was a far smaller line than the one another British hit, ''Amadeus,'' drew the morning its box office opened last season. The explanation might have been found in the conversation among those in line: Everyone waiting outside the Plymouth Theater grumbled about the price - but all said they were willing to pay it because of the highly unusual nature of the production.

title: AFTER 40 YEARS, OCRACOKE GETS OWN DOCTOR AND HIS WIFE IS A NURSE
description: After nearly 40 years, Ocracoke's 625 residents finally have a doctor who not only lives on the island but even makes house calls.

title: Bonn's Arab Trade Up
description: West Germany's trade with Arab countries rose to 29.8 billion marks, or $12.2 billion, the first half of 1981, up 31.6 percent compared with the first six months of 1980, the Economics Ministry said today. The rise was due to a 28.8 percent increase in West German imports from the region, of which 91 percent was oil, and a 35.7 percent rise in its exports, it said.

title: Ex-President and the Chief Justice See the World
description: The former President, Richard M. Nixon, was touring the Wachau Valley in Austria yesterday. Mr. Nixon, who is halfway through a private two-week European trip, is traveling with his old friend Charles (Bebe) Rebozo and Nick Ruwe, his senior aide. There are about 25 other people in his entourage, which includes Secret Service agents and secretaries.

title: Q&A
description: Q. =Would a laser beam penetrate a mirror or would it be reflected? A. =Ordinarily a laser beam will be reflected by a mirror, but it may penetrate, depending upon the quality of the mirror and the intensity of the beam. A laser beam is an intense beam of ''coherent'' light, whose waves are of a single frequency and all in step with one another. The backing of the mirror and what it is coated with can determine whether the light is reflected or transmitted. Certain mirrors will partially reflect and partially transmit a laser beam. Some beams can damage a mirror by burning a hole through it.

title: Gasoline Price Leveling Seen
description: As competitive pressures ease, retail gas prices have apparently stopped their rate of decline and will level off, according to Dan Lundberg, publisher of the Lundberg Letter, an industry newsletter.

title: SHUTTLE ROLLS SLOWLY BACK TO LAUNCHING PAD
description: The space shuttle Columbia was rolled out to its launching pad yesterday in preparation for its return to space in October. Officials at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida expressed confidence that all the normal tests on the winged spaceplane would be completed in time to meet the scheduled liftoff date, Oct. 9. The original date had been Sept. 30.

title: U.S. Industry Outlays Up 5%
description: Propelled by nonpetroleum industries, capital appropriations by the country's 1,000 largest manufacturers rose to $29.1 billion during the second quarter, a 5 percent increase over the preceding quarter, the Conference Board said in a report scheduled to be released today.

title: Woman Dies 9 Minutes After Machine Is Stopped
description: Golda Yoder, whose last wish was that she be freed from life-support machines, died tonight nine minutes after a doctor unplugged the system.

title: MOHOMMAD JAVAD BOHONAR, IRANIAN PREMIER
description: When he was killed by a bomb Sunday at his offices in Teheran at the age of 47, Mohammed Javad Bahonar had been Prime Minister of Iran for a little less than a month. Although Dr. Bahonar was largely unknown in the West, former President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr had described him as one of the five most important men in Iran.

title: YANKEES' 12 HITS CRUSH TWINS, 7-0
description: The Yankees combined fine pitching and hard hitting again tonight for their fourth straight victory as Dave Righetti pitched eight innings and beat the Twins, 7-0.

title: CONCERT: JOHN HARBISON'S SONG CYCLE
description: By DONAL HENAHAN It is a great advantage to a composer to live in a time when music has been brought to a high state of codification, when boundaries of technique and taste are well established. A Beethoven or a Schubert can then pour his talents into the conventional forms, letting them spill over when necessary into pools of innovation. A composer in such a time never quite loses his footing, since he always knows what tradition he is moving away from. Schumann's vertigo, we know, was caused by the pox, not by the headiness of rebellion.

title: BUNDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PAPER TOWEL BATTLE: GENERIC SAVINGS VS. BRAND QUALITY
description: They are turning up more and more these days - plainly packaged products with nothing more than a stark description of the contents: peas, filter cigarettes, paper towels. No hint of any brand name.

title: SCIENCE LIBRARY
description: The Primordial Bond By Stephen H. Schneider and Lynne Morton. Plenum Press, New York. $15.95.

title: 2 Die in Copter Crash Northwest of Hartford
description: Two men were killed today when a rented helicopter crashed, apparently after breaking up in midair, the police said.

title: RESOLUTION AS PROPOSED
description: Following is the text of a draft resolution under consideration for presentation to the Security Council:

title: MARYLAND COUNTY BRACES FOR FIGHT OVER BID TO END INTEGRATION
description: Summer vacation ends tomorrow for students in the public schools of this affluent suburb in Montgomery County, but the start of the academic year is likely to be only the beginning of a clash between the school board and leaders of minority groups.

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After foreign currency exchange losses of 24 cents a shr for qr and 48 cents a shr for 9 mos...C-After foreign currency exchange losses of 9 cents a shr for qr and 4 cents a shr for 9 mos

title: TANNETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes $461,000 extraordinary gain...C-Net loss after $3,530,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: REALTY TAXES IGNITE PROTEST IN JERSEY
description: Members of the usually silent majority in this suburb have mounted an angry protest against rising property taxes that includes an attempt to throw the Tax Assessor out of office.

title: GIFTS TO FRESH AIR FUND SET $1.3 MILLION RECORD
description: They contributed for many reasons. Some because as city children they had longed to escape to the country in the summer but never got the chance. Others had managed to leave their asphalt-and-concrete environment for a bit of country living and now, years later and with children of their own, they wanted to provide a similar opportunity for others.

title: Norwegian Sailors Board Danish Fishing Vessels
description: Norwegian sailors boarded half a dozen Danish fishing trawlers today in North Sea waters claimed by both countries, warning the Danes to leave.

title: Sales Tax Goes Up To Benefit M.T.A.
description: An increase of one-quarter of a cent on the dollar in the state sales tax takes effect today in New York City and in seven surrounding counties.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.00-20.50Market closed a year ago for the Labor Day holiday.** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 3D BOOK FAIR SET FOR SEPT. 20
description: Nearly 150 exhibits by publishers, book sellers and libraries will highlight the third annual New York Is Book Country street fair, which will take over much of mid-Manhattan on Sunday, Sept. 20.

title: Pan Am Reported Planning Layoffs
description: About 380 Miami-based flight attendants of Pan American World Airways - or about one-fourth of Pan Am's Miamibased flight attendants who worked for National Airlines before the companies merged in 1980 - have been told they will be laid off in September, a union official said.

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Mariners End Skid, Win, 4-3
description: Lenny Randle's homer in the ninth inning gave the Mariners a 4-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight and snapped a 10-game Seattle losing streak. Randle drove in two runs in the second inning with a single. Randle's homer, his fourth of the season, came with two out off Sammy Stewart (3-5), who had replaced Scott McGregor in the second. Baltimore loaded the bases with two out in the bottom of the ninth off Larry Andersen (2-3), pitching in relief of Ken Clay, but Rich Dauer hit a fly to left to end the game.

title: Iran Bombs Iran
description: While the American hostages were still held captive, some Americans were so outraged they urged Jimmy Carter to bomb Iran - ''turn it into a parking lot.'' Now it is the former Iranian President, Abolhassan Bani-Sadr, who from his exile home in France suggests to his countrymen that bombs might be the right way to answer the governmental terrorism practiced by his former partners.

title: HANSON BUYS STAKE IN GULF RESOURCES
description: Hanson Trust, a diversified British manufacturer and services supplier, disclosed yesterday that it has purchased 449,500 shares, or 5.04 percent, of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation.

title: DOME SET TO FILE JAPAN GAS PLAN
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said it has informed the British Columbia Government that it intends to file by Dec. 1 a detailed proposal for a project valued at $3 billion (in Canadian currency) to supply liqueified natural gas to Japan.

title: Bridge: Hong Kong Team Winner; Of Tourney in Its Own City
description: In the Hong Kong team tournament last week, the focus of attention was the first meeting between players from China, represented by Shanghai, and players from Taiwan, represented by Taipei, but it was the host team that took the top honors. Four teams from the original entry of 12 reached the final playoffs, in which the standings were:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The nation is calm and assured that those who have been martyred would be replaced by volunteers ready to be martyred.'' - Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. (A1:6.)

title: U.S. Acts to Move Boyce From Jail to Medical Unit
description: The United States Attorney's office here said tonight that it had temporarily dropped an escape charge against Christopher J. Boyce, the convicted spy, so that he could be moved to a medical facility for Federal prisoners in Springfield, Mo.

title: Canadian Oil Talks Break
description: Federal Energy Minister Marc LaLonde, who has been haggling over an oil-pricing agreement with Alberta for the past six days, left for Ottawa today after a hurried meeting with his Alberta counterpart, Merv Leitch.

title: DESPITE FORECASTS, COLLEGE ENROLLMENTS GROW
description: THE 1980's were to be the disastrous decade in which enrollments in higher education plummeted, pushing more and more colleges and universities to the brink of disaster. There would be fewer high school graduates, and admissions officers would struggle to fill freshman classes.

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: 1980 results restated to reflect adoption of LIFO method of accounting

title: Fans Are Angry
description: About 20 disgruntled San Diego Charger fans picketed a suburban shoe store owned by John Jefferson to voice displeasure with him.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on the import- ing of antiquities did not fully specify the United States Customs policy. Cus- toms officials said they would continue to seize objects and prosecute art deal- ers in cases involving direct violations of American laws, such as undervalua- tion and misdescription. They say they are still debating a policy on material deemed stolen under foreign cultural property laws but brought into the United States in accordance with American laws and regulations.

title: Olympians Will Skate In Ice Show at Garden
description: Former Olympic skaters will be performing with the 46th edition of the Ice Follies and Holiday on Ice combined shows at Madison Square Garden from Tuesday through Sept. 13 and at the Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., Sept. 15-27.

title: BRONX'S FRIEDMAN NURTURES THE IMAGE OF TOUGH DEAL MAKER
description: At the end of a long night of political stories, before he put the last cigar to rest, Stanley M. Friedman remembered a line that had been recurring in his mind lately.

title: KOCH AND GOLDIN BACKED IN CITIZENS UNION RATING
description: Mayor Koch and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin received "preferred" ratings for renomination, along with some criticism, from the Citizens Union yesterday.

title: UNIVERSAL UNCLES
description: The last straw was the police waking me out of a sound sleep at 3 o'clock in the morning. They had caught a burglar going down the fire escape with my television set. ''So put the TV set back and shut the window,'' I s aid, in very bad humor.

title: U.S. Disclaims the Views Of Ambassador to Syria
description: The departing United States Ambassador to Syria was ''not speaking for the Administration'' when he said that a Middle East peace was unlikely while Menachem Begin was Prime Minister of I srael, the State Department said today.

title: Saudis Said To Cut Flow
description: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest exporter of crude oil, has carried out its promise to reduce production by about 1 million barrels a day, industry sources said here today.

title: Two More Braniff Directors Resign
description: Two directors of the Braniff International Corporation, the holding company for financially troubled Braniff Airways, said that they are resigning, bringing to three the number of board members who have quit in recent months.

title: Who's Hostile?
description: Except for linebackers, college football players are less hostile and aggressive than student nonathletes, according to to a study by Jack R. Nation and Arnold D. Leunes, Texas A & M psychologists.

title: DR. JAMES Z. APPEL EX-HEAD OF A.M.A. LED MEDICARE FIGHT
description: Dr. James Z. Appel, a former president of the American Medical Association who led the battle against Medicare and was later instrumental in getting physicians to accept it, died Monday at the Lancaster, Pa., General Hospital. He was 74 years old.

title: Stephens Is Among Last 8 to Make Jets
description: He needs a place to live and shoes that fit, but Steve Stephens is happy because he became the last of eight players to make the Jets' final roster today. Stephens, a free-agent tight end, was put on waivers yesterday. But as expected, the Jets got him back when no ot her team claimed him.

title: MASTERCARD-FIDELITY MONEY FUND DUE
description: In a move that could link thousands of banks and their customers to the lucrative money market funds, Mastercard International and the Fidelity Management Group said yesterday that they planned to offer a Mastercard Money Manager account.

title: A FUDGE BROWNIE AND A MEDICAL MILEPOST
description: A fudge brownie signified a major medical milepost yesterday at New York University Medical Center. It was the first such treat that Travis John had been able to eat since his Aug. 13 fall from a thirdfloor window in Bay Head, N.J.

title: U.S. Downs Sweden, 3-1, in Cup Opener
description: One of the newest United States citizens, Anthony James Esposito, formerly of Canada, played goalie for his new country's hockey team today as if he were made of rubber.

title: SURMAIN, STILL THE RESTLESS RESTAURANTEUR
description: on-the-shoulder abrasiveness that dared you not to enjoy yourself. Surmain is still Surmain. ''This is my joint,'' he says in English, French or just with the arch of an eyebrow. ''This is the way I do things. If you don't like my style, there will be no check. But don't come back.''

title: IRMGARD BARTENIEFF, FOUNDER OF NEW YORK LABAN INSTITUTE
description: Irmgard Bartenieff, founder of the Laban Institute of Movement Studies in New York and a movement theoretician, died on Thursday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 81 years old.

title: Beauty and the Blast
description: To the Editor:

title: Opposition Growing To South African Tour
description: Opposition to a Unit ed States tour by a Sou th African rugby team continued to grow yesterday. Rochester offici als said they were considering ways to prevent a game there, and players from the Eastern Rugby Union voiced opposition to a ga me in Albany.

title: PORT UNIT BLASTING CITED IN '79 SUIT ON 2 BUILDINGS
description: The owners of the two buildings whose front walls collapsed near the Port Authority Bus Terminal Monday had filed suit in September 1979 against the authority and its contractors, charging negligent blasting in the area over more than four years and seeking $1.75 million in damages, the owners' lawyer said yesterday.

title: Soviet Exit Visas for Jews Reported at a 5-Year Low
description: The number of exit visas granted to Jews seeking to leave the Soviet Union dropped to a five-year low in August, Western sources reported today. They blamed worsening relations between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Qaddafi Warns the U.S.  On New Aerial Incursion
description: Col. Muammar al-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, today threatened to attack American nuclear depots in Europe if the United States again entered the Gulf of Sidra.

title: U.S. TELLS SOVIET ANY ARMS PACTS MUST INCLUDE ON - SITE VERIFICATION
description: The Reagan Administration has told the Soviet Union that any future arms-control accords will have to include onsite inspection and other direct means of verification, according to Administration officials.

title: HMW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $431,000 for qr and $1,183,000 for 6 mos

title: Stuart's Head Will Stress New Drug
description: Stuart Pharmaceuticals, an ethical and over-the-counter drug manufacturer, received permission last month from the Food and Drug Administration to sell its Tenormin high blood pressure drug in the United States. And leading the sales drive for the product will be Hugh E. Miller, 46, who has just been named president of the Wilmington, Del., company.

title: WINFIELD A HOMECOMING HIT
description: Dave Winfield drove his silver Mercedes into the parking lot at the Minnesota State Fair Sunday night, then he wandered through the horticulture and dairy buildings, checked out the livestock and sheep exhibitions and mingled with the Future Farmers of Am erica.

title: FACTORY ORDERS UP 1.3% IN JULY
description: Factory orders for new goods rose 1.3 percent in July from June, the biggest jump this year, the Commerce Department reported today

title: TRITON OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-After tax credits of $565,000 in latest yr and $580,000 in prior period

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
OUTLET CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $183,000...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $1,450,000 for qr and $3.4 million for the 6 mos

title: CHINESE POETRY, ON PAGE AND PLATE
description: DURING her youth, fancy food was not important to Barbara Tropp; she never so much as scrambled an egg, and her mother's abilities in the kitchen had merely been ''adequate,'' she recalls. Her German grandmother offered a bit of inspiration, but it was mostly along the lines of sauerbraten and apple strudel.

title: FOOD PRICES EASE SLIGHTLY
description: THE average cost of feeding a family of four in New York City fell by 51 cents to $106.07 during the two-week period that ended Monday, according to the Department of Consumer Affairs. Still, the department's 41-item market basket survey found that shoppers paid $6.46 more for food than during the corresponding period last year.

title: TOWN & COUNTRY MOBILE HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THE GOLD IN OUR PAST AND IN OUR FUTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: GATES LEARJET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ELIAS J. BICKERMAN, A HELLENIC SCHOLAR ON COLUMBIA STAFF
description: Prof. Elias J. Bickerman, a historian and authority on the influence of the Greeks in the Middle East at the time of Jesus and before, died Monday in Tel Aviv, where he was on vacation. He was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Novo Net Up 96.8% in Half
description: Novo Industri, the world's leading producer of enzymes and the second-largest producer of insulin after Eli Lilly & Company, has reported that net income in the first half of 1981 soared 96.8 percent on an increase in sales of 48.7 percent.

title: THE ONLY PUNISHMENT FOR 'MAD-DOG KILLERS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Guatemala Gunmen Seize Cabinet Official
description: Unidentified gunmen kidnapped the Guatemalan Health Minister, Dr. Roquelino Recinos Mendez, tonight as he drove on a highway south of the capital, a government communique said.

title: Index; International
description: Human rights in Bolivia gain , but torture goes on A2 Mitterrand calls for aid to the poorest nations A3 Latins try to bury differences to pursue outside aid A3 Latin nations to criticize French- Mexican stance on Salvador A4 Around the World A5 General takes power in Central African Republic A7 Eight Indian unions join to fight ban on strikes A10 Government/Politics Reporter's Notebook: The Presi- dent's Men A16 Koch, Goldin get ''preferred'' rat- ings by Citizens Union B6 Pentagon aides confirm shift in budget thinking B7 General Around the Nation A14 Street abandonment plan stirs Alabama racial dispute A14 Controllers' union assails admin- istrative law judge A15 Messenger arrested in theft of $50 million in bonds B2 Witness says boat owner in L.I. crash was near panic B4 Obituaries Vera-Ellen, dancer on stage and in motion pictures A17 Dr. James Z. Appel, former A.M.A. president, dies A17 Dr. Robert A. Kann, historian A18 Prof. Elias J. Bickerman, Hel- lenic scholar A18 Education/Welfare Strike by Philadelphia teachers still seems likely A15 Teachers go to school to learn how to help students who fail B3 Religion Moral Majority denounces attack by Yale's p resident A16 The Living Section Food A sampling of the world's olive oils, from the pure to the purely sublime C1

title: COSMOS WORRIED BY PLAYOFF TONIGHT
description: The Cosmos will open the defense of their North American Soccer League title tomorrow, meeting the Tampa Bay Rowdies, who have always been difficult for them at Tampa Stadium.

title: Mexico Says It Found New Markets for Its Oil
description: President Jose Lopez Portillo announced today that Mexico had succeeded in finding new markets for its oil exports following the cancellation of numerous commercial contracts in a dispute last July over prices.

title: U.S.-Kenya Bank Accord
description: The Commercial Bank of Africa Ltd. announced today that a majority of its shares will be acquired by the Bank of America, subject to approval by the Kenya Government. Terms were not disclosed.

title: PEOPLE WANT TAX AID ON TUITION
description: Black people, one could easily conclude, speak with one voice on the issue of tuition tax credits - they are against them. This conclusion seems implicit in the nearly unanimous opposition to tuition tax credits of black politicians and other prominent blacks. The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson and Carl T. Rowan in their columns have gone on record against the idea. In addition, 10 of 11 black Congressmen voted against one version of the Moynihan-Packwood bill that would have started tuition tax credits. It seems clear that blacks overwhelmingly oppose tax incentives to increase nonpublic school enrollment. Nothing could be clearer, right? Wrong. There is substantial evidence that many blacks are in favor of aid to private and parochial schools.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LAY ON, SHAKESPEAREANS

title: PUBLIC WORKERS' CLOUT
description: To the Editor:

title: YOUNG DEMOCRATS REMAIN STAUNCHLY LIBERAL
description: To the Editor:

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: Shr earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split effective May 22

title: Espionage Court-Martial Postponed Second Time
description: The espionage court-martial of Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke of the Air Force was postponed again today to allow the defense time to file another petition for dismissal with the United States Court of Military Appeals.

title: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1981; International
description: The Soviet Union seems to be facing a poor grain harvest for the third straight year. If it is as bad as Western experts expect, Russian purchases on world grain markets could soar to a record total of 40 million metric tons. For American farmers, that could mean some of the biggest sales ever to Moscow. (Page A1.)

title: Stones' Concert Tickets Selling Well in Buffalo
description: Fans are buying tickets at a fast pace for the Rolling Stones concert on Sept. 27 at Rich Stadium in nearby Orchard Park.

title: Letter: On the Awacs Sale Why Give the Saudis the Sidewinder?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hoving Named Editor of Art Magazine
description: Thomas P. F. Hoving has taken yet another job, as editor in chief of The Connoisseur, the international art and antiques magazine published by the Hearst Corporation.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN I recently wrote a few words in praise of a pressure cooker and offered a recipe to be cooked in one, a neighbor of mine expressed delight in the thought that I was finally coming around to the 20th century. I reminded him that although I am heartily in favor of the pressure cooker's use and will use my version often in the years to come, I still prefer the old-fashioned methods of cookery, which is to say slow cooking either on top of the stove or in the oven.

title: BISSELL AND MISS KIRKLAND OUT OF BALLET THEATER PLANS
description: Gelsey Kirkland and Patrick Bissell will not perform with the American Ballet Theater this season. A spokesman for the two principal dancers said yesterday that Miss Kirkland had not been able to come to any contractual agreement with the company during several months of discussion and that Mr. Bissell had asked for a leave of absence.

title: NEGOIATING CUBAN REFUGEES' RELEASE
description: To the Editor:

title: John P. Hederman, 39, Dies; Specialist in Corporate Law
description: John P. Hederman, a partner in the New York City law firm of Mudge, Rose, Guthrie & Alexander, died Monday at the New York University Medical Center of complications following heart surgery. He was 39 years old and lived in Laurel Hollow, L.I.

title: Tied and Gagged Woman, 84, Is Found Dead on City Island
description: The body of an 84-year-old woman who had been bound and gagged was found yesterday morning in her home on City Island in the Bronx.

title: JERSEY CITY RENT CONTROL EASED TO SPUR HOUSING
description: In a raucous meeting that lasted until nearly dawn today, the City Council modified a strict eight-year-old rent-control law in the hope of attracting new private housing development to this once stable working-class industrial center.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Forest Hills Gardens comes as a surprise to sightseers. Coming through its big arching entrance gates from the buzz of Continental Avenue and the nondescript beige box apartment buildings of Queens Boulevard is like traveling to another time and place, a time and place in which everything was quiet, and beautifully landscaped, and full of imitation Tudor architecture.

title: Phibro Promotes Best of Salomon
description: When Salomon Brothers was bought by the Phibro Corporation last month, many analysts predicted that the investment bank would end up losing its most valued asset: the crop of young, aggressive traders, arbitragers and financiers that made Salomon Brothers an unusual, if not frenetic, banking house.

title: BERKSHIRE GAS CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
3 LATIN NATIONS FAULT MEXICO AND FRANCE ON SALVADOR ISSUE
description: Argentine diplomats said today that Argentina would join Colombia and Venezuela in issuing a statement supporting the Government of El Salvador and criticizing France and Mexico for recognizing the Salvadoran rebels as a political force.

title: ARMY TROPPLES LEADER OF CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC
description: The army in the Central African Republic took power today from the civilian Government of President David Dacko. The army's move came 23 months after a coup backed by the French that drove the self-styled Emperor Bokassa, a former army sergeant, into exile.

title: Pullman Car Plant
description: Wheelabrator-Frye Inc.'s Pullman Standard division announced that it will open a freight car parts plant in Asheville, N.C., by the year's end. A Pullman spokesman said that the plant will employ 45 to 60 people at the beginning and 250 workers when fully functional. Wheelabrator-Frye, a New Hampshirebased company, acquired Pullman Inc. through a merger last year.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bausch & Lomb, Rochester, N.Y., has appointed Jon M. Larson vice president-corporate manufacturing services.

title: ACETO CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
STUDY FINDS WOMEN ARE SYSTEMATICALLY UNDERPAID
description: Women are concentrated in low-paying occupations, are more likely to work for low-paying concerns than are men and are ''systematically underpaid,'' according to a study prepared for the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and released today.

title: Outlook for Japan G.N.P.
description: Japan will exceed the United States in percapita gross national product by 1990, a private economic research organization predicted today.

title: Volcano Hit by Earthquake
description: Mount St. Helens was jolted by a mild earthquake early today, according to scientists keeping a close watch there because of an eruption advisory last week.

title: Sports of The Times; Dick Howser Is Back in Uniform
description: THE first uniform was a T-shirt with the name Alfar Dairy on the front. Dick Howser wore it when he was 10 years old in an American Legion league in West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: B.P. Pays Tax Of $1.68 Billion
description: The British Petroleum Company today handed the British Inland Revenue office what it called the world's largestever tax payment - a total of $1.68 billion.

title: CHICKEN ROASTING PANS
description: NEARLY every cook you meet is under the impression that he can roast a chicken properly. But the evidence - the finished chicken - is often an indication that a cook esteems himself too highly. The errors that can be made are many.

title: 'Our Song' to Close Sunday
description: The musical ''They're Playing Our Song'' will close Sunday after the matinee at the Imperial Theater.

title: A Coup Intended to Clarify Ends up Muddling Things
