description: The oldest coup in the game, dating back to the days of whist - long before bridge was thought of - is named after the English watering place of Bath. It is a simple holdup play with A-J-x when the king is led. If the suit is continued, the ace and jack both score.

title: New Composers' Series Set by Kennedy Center
description: A series of six concerts, ''American Portraits,'' will begin in the 500-seat Terrace Theater of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington with the performance Sept. 9 of the works of Aaron Copland. Mr. Copland will be present to discuss his work.

title: CONSTRUCTION SPENDING DOWN
description: Construction spending fell 1.5 percent in July from June, the Commerce Department reported today, as high interest rates sent the nation's builders deeper into their second severe slump in two years.

title: WESTERN BEEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
No Lights for Wrigley
description: The new owners of the Chicago Cubs, The Chicago Tribune Company, announced today that there were no plans to install lights at Wrigley Field. Andrew McKen na, the team's new chairman, said the company had evaluated main taining day baseball andthat there would be no immediate move to inst all lights. ''The delightful thing about the purchase of this t eam is the ball park, and we plan to play here some time,'' McKenna said.

title: No Headline
description: The obituary of the author Anita Loos on Aug. 19 gave her birth date incorrectly in some copies. She was born on April 26, 1888, and was 93 years old at her death.

title: Market Place; I.B.M. Threat To Apple
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation's decision to enter the personal computer market this fall has some on Wall Street pondering the future of Apple Computer.

title: Shamateurism, Again
description: Adriaan Paulen, the 79-year-old Dutch president of the International Amateur Federation, warned against losing control of the sport to commercial sponsors.

title: CLOSE ASSOCIATE OF HITLER
description: Albert Speer, Hitler's architect, who became Minister of Armaments and War Production in World War II, died today at St. Mary's Hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: Ford Sets Higher '82 Auto Prices
description: The Ford Motor Company joined other United States auto makers today in announcing price increases for 1982 models. Auto dealers and Wall Street analysts expressed concern that these increases would abruptly end the current surge in sales.

title: Stabler Quizzed by N.F.L.
description: Warren Welsh, the National Football League's director of security, has questioned Ken Stabler, the Houston Oiler quarterback, concerning Stabler's reported association with a convicted gambling figure.

title: Mount Etna Heating Up
description: Scientists asked authorities today to keep tourists away from Mount Etna as the volcano emitted gases and steam. The volcano has been spewing black smoke and ashes since Friday, and today the smoke turned white, a sign that scientists say indicates the rock inside the crater is heating up.

title: STROKE, A MAIN CAUSE OF DEATH, IS SURROUNDED WITH MYTHS
description: True or false? Strokes happen only to older people. Strokes occur without warning. There is nothing you can do to prevent a stroke. Few who survive a stroke are ever normal again.

title: PAY LESS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Shr earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split paid in July

title: MITTERRAND URGES AID TO POOREST NATIONS
description: President Francois Mitter rand, opening a United Nations aid conference here, today urged indu strial countries to insure that the least developed not only surv ive but eventually prosper.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that there were pre-tax LIFO charges to earnings of $5 million and $9.7 million for latest qr and 6 mos respectively and $4,950,000 and $8.8 million for yr-ago qr and 6 mos

title: PENTAGON AIDES SEE A SHIFT BY REAGAN ON MILITARY
description: The chief spokesman for the Defense Department strongly indicated today that a fundamental change in approach to the military budget has taken place within the Reagan Administration, presaging a slower expansion in spending than had been planned.

title: INQUIRY INVOLVES CAREY'S BROTHER AND SALES TAXES
description: State tax officials are conducting a criminal investigation into the amount of sales taxes paid by Martin Carey, Governor Carey's brother, according to court papers on file in Westbury, L.I.

title: GRAND AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
INDIANA BELL BONDS SOLD AT 17.10%
description: A unit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the nation's largest borrower with a blue-ribbon credit rating, sold debt securities yesterday at a record yield, exceeding 17 percent for the first time.

title: Orioles' Palmer Gets Positive Report on Arm
description: A doctor gave Jim Palmer, the Baltimore Oriole right-hander, a positive report today, and Earl Weaver, the manager, said Palmer would be back in the team's starting rotation Thursday.

title: Gasoline Futures Trading Approved
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission agreed today to permit trading in futures contracts for gasoline, both leaded and unleaded.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Anatole Broyard SOCIAL STUDIES. By Fran Lebowitz. 147 pages. Random House. $9.95.

title: By MOIRA HODGSON
description: ACOUPLE of years ago, only a handful of brands of olive oil were on the market. Nowadays literally dozens are available, and many cooks are becoming as choosy about their olive oil as wine drinkers are about fine Bordeaux. And they should be, considering the prices some extra-virgin olive oils - those made from the first pressings of the best olives - are commanding. A one-liter bottle of Poggio al Sole, from the Italian province of Tuscany, sells for $20!

title: 3 Killed as Wall Collapses
description: Three persons were killed yesterday when a 30-foot-high retaining wall collapsed, crushing them under tons of rock as they sat in a car at a bank drive-up window, the authorities said. Heavy rains last month are believed to have contributed to the collapse, officials said, but there was no rain at the time of the accident.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.00-20.50.** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SLOWING OF RETIREE RATE MAY BRING WELCOME RELIF TO SOCIAL SECURITY
description: The American rush to retirement is apparently beginning to subside. Under the pressure of inflation, the number of people claiming Social Security benefits for the first time, which has risen almost every year since the program was founded in the New Deal era, has begun to taper off.

title: Advertising; A Growing Awareness Overseas
description: WHEN he played polo at Princeton in the 1950's, Alexander Brody was sometimes known as Ajax, after the strapping hero of the Trojan war. As it happens, Mr. Brody is more on the short side, but as president of Young & Rubicam International, he looms large in the overseas ad game.

title: PUPIL FAILURE IS ANALYZED FOR TEACHERS
description: Teachers usually are at the head of the classroom, standing at the blackboard or grading papers. But this summer, 1,500 New York City public-school teachers went back to school to learn how to deal with student failure, and they were the ones taking notes.

title: Washington Post Set To Buy Star Building
description: The Washington Post announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with Time Inc., to buy the plant formerly occupied by The Washington Star, along with most of the equipment in the plant. A spokesman for The Post declined to give the purchase price.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IT isn't that women are more emotionally self-sufficient than men, or is it? Earlier this summer a small, random, unscientific poll of women living with men seemed to indicate that the women rather enjoyed it when their husbands or companions went away, say on business trips, for a few days; indeed, a lot of them looked forward to it. It was a minivacation, a chance to let down, let up, relax, eat onions in bed, regain their own space. They gave only fleeting thought to th e absent loved one. As long as they knew he was returning in the near future, loneliness didn't enter the picture.

title: A Dispute Over Diary of Wallace's Assailant
description: A 184-page portion of the diary of Arthur Bremer, the man who shot George C. Wallace in 1972, is the center of a legal battle between Mr. Bremer and Sherman Griffin, a construction worker who found the diary in 1980.

title: 'Best Boy' to Open Run At Embassy on Sept. 14
description: ''Best Boy,'' the film about a 52-year-old retarded man that won the Aacdemy Award for best feature documentary in 1980, will play a return engagement, starting Sept. 14, at the Embassy Theater, Broadway and 72d Street.

title: STOEN IN TOP FORM AS ORIOLES WIN, 1-0
description: Steve Stone, in his second start after two and one-half months on the disabled list, combined with Tippy Martinez to hurl a tw o-hitter as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Seattle Marin ers tonight, 1-0.

title: BRIGADIER INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE STRONG REGIONAL AIRLINES
description: When the history of the air traffic controllers' strike is written, August will be remembered as the month in which the major airlines cut their regularly scheduled flights by an average 20 percent, laid off thousands of workers and watched their earnings plummet in tandem with their stock prices.

title: CALIFORNIA OFFICIAL FINDS PERU FLIES DEFINITELY TO BLAME FOR INFESTATION
description: A California official said today there was no longer any question that a reinfestation of the destructive Mediterranean fruit fly had been caused by the release of 50,000 or more purportedly sterile Peruvi an fruit flies. He suggested the Federal Gover nment was to blame.

title: A Cautious Driver
description: Neil Bonnett, noted for his daring in stock-car racing, said he had turned down three requests to drive an Indianapolis-type car. ''Everytime I turn on the TV,'' he said, ''they've got somebody on fire, and everybody's running around in circles trying to find the fire. It's just too dangerous right now.''

title: Marine Midland
description: The Marine Midland Bank, the nation's 13th-largest commercial bank, has opened an international banking office in Houston.

title: A NEW CITY UNIT WILL FIGHT BIAS IN CONSTRUCTION
description: Mayor Koch yesterday created a new unit within his office that he said was aime d at ending discriminatory hiring in the construction industry and extortion by any group seeking to get jobs for its members at co nstruction sites.

title: U.S. ART EXHIBITION ON VIEW IN PEKING
description: An American art exhibition opened here today after United States officials refused last-minute demands by their hosts to remove 13 modern abstract paintings. It is the first art show sponsored by the United States Government since the Communist takeover.

title: About Real Estate; SUBLEASING TOUGHER IN BOOMING OFFICE SPACE MARKET
description: The recent steep increases in Manhattan office rents are altering some of the traditional leasing relationships between landlords and tenants.

title: COMPANY NEWS; Sherwin-Williams, Gray Drug Plan Tie
description: The Sherwin-Williams Company and Gray Drug Stores Inc. said today that they have agreed to merge in a $54.8 million deal in which the paint and chemical concern would pay $21 a share for Gray Drug's outstanding common stock.

title: INDIA BARS SENIOR U.S. DIPLOMAT, STIRRING A DISPUTE
description: India has refused to accept a senior American diplomat in New Delhi, touching off a dispute with the Reagan Administration.

title: JOSEPH HIRSHHORN DIES; FINANCIER; ART PATRON
description: Joseph H. Hirshhorn, man of money, man of adventure, one of the shrewdest prospectors of gold, uranium and oil of his day and founder and benefactor of the museum in Washington that bears his name, died of a heart attack late Monday in Washington. He was 82 years old.

title: G.& W. Raises 2 Stock Stakes
description: Gulf and Western Industries has raised its holdings in the General Tire and Rubber Company and Munsingwear Inc. for investment purposes, the diversified company said in filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: WILLIAM TANDY YOUNG Jr.
description: William Tandy Young Jr., a former advertising executiv e, died Monday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: 8 INDIAN UNIONS JOIN TO FIGHT BAN ON STRIKES IN KEY SECTORS
description: A group of labor unions have decided to join forces to fight the Indian Government's decision to ban strikes in essential services, a move they feel poses a threat to union activity.

title: Coffee Producers Meet
description: The 47 producer members of the 72-nation International Coffee Organization plan to meet in London tomorrow to negotiate their shares in a world market undermined by tumbling prices and demand.

title: LIL' CHAMP FOOD STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: Yr-ago shr earnings reflect a 5 percent stock divd paid Dec 1980

title: TURNOVER UP
description: The stock market showed some resilience yesterday, with some prices rising slightly despite continued concern over high interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had tumbled 39 points in the preceding six sessions mainly because of investor concern over rising interest rates, rose 1.24 points, to 882.71. On Monday, the key average plunged 10.75 points, to 881.47, its lowest close in almost 14 months.

title: The Car Book Can Be Fi xed
description: Which car is safer in a 35-mile-per-hour crash, a Mercedes Benz 240D or a Ford Thunderbird? Which, on average, costs less to maintain for the first 45,000 miles: a Dodge Omni or a Chevy Chevette?

title: The Wrong Kind of Nuclear Power
description: The nuclear power industry is disintegra ting. All around the country nucle ar plants are being delayed or canceled because demand for electrici ty is sagging while costs and regulation are soaring. A plant near Ga ry, Ind., has just been scrapped even after expendituresof $200 milli on. Another in upstate New York is threatening to bankrupt one or more utilities. No new plants have been ordered in this country since 1978.

title: STATE P.S.C. WILL CONDUCT INQUIRY INTO FEASIBILITY OF A NUCLEAR PLANT
description: The State Public Service Commission yesterday unanimously ordered a public inquiry into the feasibility of continuing the construction of Nine Mile 2, a nuclear power plant near Oswego.

title: SMITH, MISS CASALS GAIN
description: John McEnroe was a disappointed four-set winner over Juan Nunez in his first-round match at the United States Open tennis championships yesterday, but Stan Smith and Rosie Casals were elated survivors.

title: Fred Fox, Comic Strip Author And Writer for Groucho Marx
description: Fred Fox, who brought life to the comic strip ''Freckles and His Friends'' and wrote material for Groucho Marx and other entertainers, died Thursday.

title: Coca-Cola Ends Aqua-Chem Sale
description: The Coca-Cola Company said that it has completed the previously announced sale of its Aqua-Chem unit to Societe Lyonnais des Eaux et de l'Eclairage of Paris.

title: MOSCOW IS IGNORING SOUTH AFRICA REPORT OF CAPTURED RUSSIAN
description: South Africa's statement that its forces have killed and captured Soviet soldiers in Angola drew no immediate reaction from Moscow today, but Soviet press organizations maintained their sharp criticism of the raid and also of the United States for supporting what they called ''international banditry.''

title: HINCKLEY'S REQUEST FOR BAIL TURNED DOWN BY U.S. JUDGE
description: A Federal district judge today denied an application for bail from John W. Hinckley Jr., who is awaiting trial on charges that he tried to kill President Reagan and assaulted three other men outside a Washington hotel March 30.

title: BERG ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes $13,026 or 1 cent a shr gain from discontinued operations for the qr and $85,029 loss from discontinued operations for the yr...C-Includes $71,250 or 5 cents a shr gain from a reduction in liability in connection with the sale of a subsidiary in an earlier yr and $104,760 loss on certain unusual and infrequent items

title: WINE TALK
description: THE menu, extracted from a heap of memorabilia, was from the Savoy Hotel in London, with its crest centered in red at the top. It offered several choices, including a lobster mousse and lamb chops, plus two recommendations for wine. Intended to accompany the lamb chops was a Chateau Mouton Baron Philippe 1967, a Bordeaux of good character. But the first was more interesting: a Petit Chablis 1970 intended to complement the lobster mousse.

title: U.S. Airmen Deliver F our F-16's to Israel
description: United States Air Force crews flew four F-16 Falcons to Israel today in the first delivery of the $14.5 million fighter-bombers to that country since President Reagan ended a two-month embargo.

title: L.B. Foster President Lands Big Rail Deal
description: One man's junk is another man's gold, at least for Warren Kearns, president of the L.B. Foster Company, a Pittsburgh-based rail salvager and supplier of industrial piping and tubular goods. Foster has just been awarded a three-year contract by the trustees of the bankrupt Rock Island and Pacific Railroad to dismantle and sell more than 3,000 miles of railroad track in 12 states.

title: THIRD YEAR OF POOR SOVIET HARVESTS INDICATED
description: The Soviet Union, plagued by mercurial weather, appears to be bracing for its third poor grai n harvest in succession. If the results are as bad as Western agricu ltural specialists here believe, they could send Soviet grain buyers into world markets for record purchases of as much as 40 million met ric tons. For American farmers, this could mean some of the largest sales ever to the SovietUnion after 18 months of a grain curtailment that President Reagan ended last June.

title: Scott Sets U.S. Mark O f 7:36.69 in 3,000 Run
description: Steve Scott set a United States record tonight in the 3,000-meter run, finishing in 7 minutes 36.69 seconds at an international track meet.

title: Sports People; Katz Seems to Be In
description: The National Basketball Association's 23 owners will meet Sept. 21 in Chicago and are expected to approve Harold Katz as the owner of the Philadelphia 76ers. The league's advisory and finance committee met Katz last week and voted unanimously to recommend approval. Katz, who earned his fortune in a diet and weight control business, purchased the team almost two months ago from F. Eugene Dixon.

title: A dangerous polarization threatens the Western alliance: the United States is steadily rearming and reasserting its power everywhere, while among its European allies a new fear of American toughness and of an arms race spreads. The more we emphasize military force, the more the voices of dissent rise, and the more American leaders are tempted to think that we are alone in our struggle to save the world, that only we understand the overwhelming danger of Soviet Communism and that in that mortal combat who is not for us is against us.
description: By that reckoning we may discover that the number who are for us is diminishing. Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria, who has impeccable anti-Communist credentials, recently spoke of ''a wave of pacifism sweeping over Europe.'' He is wrong in detail: there is very little principled pacifism of the pre-1939 variety in Europe today. There is, however, a shift of mood, especially in Northern Europe, a mounting apprehension about an arms race that seems out of control and about an American impetuosity that could provoke what it most wishes to avert.

title: 20 CHILDREN WRITE A BOOK ON DIVORCE
description: WHEN an elementary school teacher named Eric Rofes discovered that 14 out of 20 students in his class had parents who were divorced, he decided to form a discussion group. When the students in the discussion group discovered that all the divorce books in the local library were written from ''an older point of view,'' they decided to write a book. The result, ''The Kids' Book of Divorce: By, For and About Kids,'' is a 123-page manual on what it calls ''one of hardest times any child has to experience.''

title: DUO PROVES GUITAR HEROES CAN STILL BE FOUND
description: THE range of guitar styles in contemporary rock is impressively broad - much broader than in the late 60's, when it seemed that almost everyone wanted to be a guitar hero and you could hear an aspiring Jimi Hendrix or Eric Clapton on practically every street corner.

title: MEDEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ADVANCED SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
COMES FALL, CHANCE FOR SERIOUS MOVIES?
description: HOLLYWOOD IN Hollywood, autumn will start next week. No matter how hot the September heat wave, rows of adolescents scuffing classroom floors with their topsiders, Adidas or Stan Smith running shoes symbolize the end of summer.

title: Burlington Mayor Loses Suit Over Appointments
description: Mayor Bernard Sanders lost the latest battle in his continuing war with this city's Board of Aldermen when a judge dismissed his lawsuit against the Aldermen for their refusal to consider his appointees to top city posts. Judge James B. Morse of the Chittenden Superior Court ruled yesterday tha t the board's action was a political, rather than a legal, matter . Mr. Sanders said that there was ''a reasonable chance'' that he would appeal the ruling to the Vermont Supreme Court.

title: OF TABLE MANNERS, BAD HABITS, FOOD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- William Cole is a poet and anthologist and a book reviewer for Prime Time magazine. By WILLIAM COLE

title: Careers; Mock Job Interviews On Tape
description: ''Y OU ought to be in pictures.'' So goes the first line of a popular song, and it is timely advice these days for students at graduate schools of business administration: Make use of colored videotapes of mock job interviews.

title: NIGHTMARE
description: The Flxible's Not fxible.

title: COALITION ASKS REAGAN TO SCRAP MX PROGRAM
description: A coalition of environmental, religious and political groups urged President Reagan yesterday to stop deployment of the MX missile, saying that it would push the world close to nuclear holocaust.

title: TEHERAN APPOINTS PRIME MINISTER AND A PARTY HEAD
description: Iran announced the appointment today of a provisional Prime Minister and a new leader for the ruling Islamic Republican Party.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said it sold 91-day commercial paper at a rate of 17.695 percent at its weekly auction, compared with a 17.887 percent average rate last week.

title: Wednesday, September 2, 1981
description: INTERNATIONAL Iran announced the appointment of a provisional Prime Minister and a new leader for the ruling Islamic Republican Party to succeed officials killed in a bomb explosion Sunday. At least two more assassinations were reported in uneasy Teheran, and Ayatollah Khomeini urged his followers to exercise restraint. (Page A1, Column 1.) An oil accord was reached in Canada after long and bitter wrangling. The federal Government and Alberta, the chief petroleum-producing province, reached a five-year agreement that will permit Canadian oilprices to rise in stages. The energy-pricing fight has become a symbol of Canada's fractious federalism. (A1: 2.)

title: No Headline
description: U.S. PROTESTS NORTH KOREAN ATTACK: Rear Adm. James G. Storms 3d, seated at left, reading a protest statement yesterday to members of a North Korean delegation at meeting in Panmunjom.

title: DIOR HOPING TO FIND A NEW PARTNER
description: Christian Dior, for the last decade at the financial mercy of two ailing conglomerates, is hoping to find a new partner that will allow it greater freedom in its business ventures.

title: Diplomacy Against Drugs
description: Officially, Bolivia is all but bankrupt, but it's still possible for a Bolivian politician or military man to do very well off the books - by getting into the cocaine trade and the lush black market it generates.

title: Chile Energy Accord
description: The American Heliothermal Corporation, a Denver-based manufacturer and distributor of solar energy equipment, said today that it has formed a joint venture with its Israeli subsidiary and a group of Chilean investors to make and sell solar energy systems in the South American country.

title: Maureen McGovern Taking Lead in 'Pirates'
description: Maureen McGovern will make her Broadway debut, replacing Karla DeVito as Mabel in ''The Pirates of Penzance'' on Tuesday at the Minskoff Theater.

title: GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: MORAL MAJORITY TERMS ATTACK BY YALE PRESIDENT A 'DIATRIBE'
description: The Moral Majority yesterday denounced an attack by the president of Yale University as an ''unprovoked diatribe,'' saying he had ignored the truth.

title: VERA-ELLEN, DANCER IN MOVIES
description: Vera-Ellen, who danced across the screen with such stars as Fred Astaire and Gene Kelly during the golden era of Hollywood musicals, died of cancer at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center on Sunday. She was 55 years old.

title: ASTROS DEFEAT METS, 3-2
description: The Mets lost their third straight game tonight and the Houston Astros won their sixth straight on one of the most unpredictable and frustrating plays in baseball: a wild pitch.

title: Bank Messenger, 23, Is Arrested In Theft of Bonds in a 'Sting'; A bank messenger who said he had lost track of an envelope containing $50 million in negotiable bonds has been arrested in connection with the theft of the bonds, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday.
description: The F.B.I. identified the messenger as 23-year-old Michael A. Beckford of the High Bridge section of the Bronx. He was arraigned yesterday on charges of bank fraud and embezzlement before a Federal magistrate, Kent Sinclair Jr., and released on $4,000 bail.

title: Bulgarian Rower Fails Drug Test in Munich
description: The world rowing championships were hit by a drug scandal involving Bulgarian competitors for the second time in four months today

title: New Hearing Ordered On 42d Street Project
description: A judge ruled yesterday that the State Urban Development Corporation did not follow proper procedures last month in a public hearing on a proposal for the redevelopment of the 42d Street area.

title: MILWAUKEE WESTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
LEMON ICE KING KEEPS HIS RECIPE SECRET
description: TANNED couples returning from a Saturday morning at the beach begin lining up under the blue-and-white striped awning by 2 P.M. Leaning over the counter in a Haagen-Dazs T-shirt, a teen-ager orders ''two 40-cent lemons'' and takes the paper cups of white ice back to a waiting car.

title: THE GOLD IN OUR PAST AND INOUR FUTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions; BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Signed Joe Fer- guson, catcher.  CHICAGO (NL) - Placed Francisco Barrios, pitcher, on waivers.  DETROIT (AL) - Recalled Jerry Ujdur, Mark Fidrych, Dennis Kinney and Larry Rothschild, pitchers; Marty Castil- lo, third-baseman-catcher, and Darrell Brown, outfielder, from Evansville of American Association. Activated Champ Summers, outfielder. from the disabled list.  KANSAS CITY (AL) - Waived Jerry Grote, catcher.
description: serve. ST. LOUIS (NFC) - Waived Steve Neils, linebacker; Rod Phillips, running back, and Mike Fisher and Steve Rhodes, wide receivers. Placed Mel Gray, wide re- ceiver; Doug Marsh, tight end, and Kirby Criswell, defensive end, on injured re- serve.

title: WISCONSIN ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for 12 mos to July 31
ROBERT A. KANN, 75, PROFESSOR AND EXPERT ON AUSTRIA'S HISTORY
description: Dr. Robert A. Kann, former professor of history at Rutgers University and an authority on the history of Austria and the Hapsburg empire, died of a heart attack last Sunday in Vienna, where he lived. He was 75 years old.

title: PHILADELPHIA SCHOOL STRIKE LIKELY
description: School officials are pessimistic about averting a teachers' strike next Tuesday, despite a proposal by Mayor William J. Green last night that included a 10 percent increase in the city's property tax to help return the school system to solvency.

title: THIS VERLAINE IS A POET OF THE ROCK GUITAR
description: THE idea that the electric guitar was a magical lance and that guitarists were rock-and-roll heroes, began to get out of hand during the late 60's. Guitar solos, which had originally been short breaks in songs, grew long and bloated. The songs atrophied until they were flimsy excuses for endless displays of guitar prowess.

title: Penn State for NBC Pact
description: The president of Penn State says he will vote to approve a television contract between NBC and the College Football Association when member schools meet next week to ratify the pact.

title: Beneficial to Sell Spiegel
description: The Beneficial Corporation, the nation's largest consumer loan company, announced yesterday that it had reached agreement to sell its Spiegel Inc. catalogue subsidiary to a West German merchandising concern for more than $50 million.

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ALI SAYS HE'LL FIGHT BERBICK
description: Muhummad Ali said yesterday that he would fight Trevor Berbick Dec. 2 in Nassau, the Bahamas, and the promoter Don King said that Larry Holmes would defend his World Boxing Council championship in November against Renaldo Snipes, an undefeated heavyweight from White Plains.

title: SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for 13 weeks to Aug 2
description: B-After change to LIFO method of accounting increased loss by $205,000...C-Net income and after change in LIFO reduced net by $238,000

title: NOTEBOOK: STYLES OF THE PRESIDENT'S MEN
description: For most of this year, their closeness to President Reagan has made almost constant companions of Edwin Meese 3d and James A. Baker 3d, but Mr. Reagan's monthlong vacation provided evidence of the sharp differences in style and personality between the two.

title: AMERICAN-OWNED CARS SET AFIRE IN WEST GERMANY
description: Arsonists destroyed automobiles belonging to United States military personnel and set an office building afire today in incidents that West German investigators said had a clearly anti-American character.

title: Owens Purchase
description: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation said that it has purchased Electric Smith Inc., an electrical contracting and engineering business based in Spokane, Wash.

title: BROWN GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: The company said it had a pretax gain of $700,000 on the sale of real estate; shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared June 4, 1981

title: Albert Clay, 83, an Architect In Connecticut and New York
description: Albert George Clay, an architect in Niantic, Conn., died Monday at his home in Old Plack Point, Conn. He was 83 years old. Mr. Clay was born in Chicago and graduated from Yale University in 1921 and from its School of Architecture in 1923.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The number of dollars with which we have to work is finite and demands thereon seem to be infinite.

title: SCENE BEFORE BOAT CRASH RELATED
description: The operator of a disabled cabin cruiser was ''on the verge of panic'' befor e he sought help from the tug that is suspected of having caused his boat to sink in Long Island Sound last month, a boat owner wh o was near the scene of the accident testified yesterday. Tw o persons died in the accident and three are missing.

title: SOME ABUSES FADE IN BOLIVIA, BUT TORTURE GOES ON
description: The rats running over his face still haunt him. He is a priest who was taken from his church here two months ago by agents from the Government's Special Security Service. They took him to an interrogation center on an ordinary looking block guarded by policemen at each end in a neighborhood of expensive homes and embassies.

title: HMG PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TO BAIL OR NOT TO BAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. to Suspend Plant Renovation
description: The General Motors Corporation said that it would suspend indefinitely its planned renovation of the Broening Highway auto assembly plant here, a decision that places the future of nearly 2,000 laid-off employees in doubt. In an announcement, G.M. blamed the decision on ''changes in product planning.''

title: KOCH SAYS NEW HIRING MAY HAVE TO BE CURBED
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that in the next few months New York City might find itself unable to afford all the thousands of new municipal workers - including police officers, sanitationmen and teachers - who are supposed to be hired in his election-year budget adopted last June.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for 12 weeks to July 18
1. Traveler's Laundry
description: Smart travelers travel light, and one way they limit the amount they carry is to pack washables and launder them when necessary. A small laundry bag hung on a clothes hanger can help keep luggage organized. Soiled things are kept in one place and will not get mixed with clean apparel. Conspec Industries makes a pillowcase-size bag in striped cotton ticking with a zippered top that fills the bill. There is also a matching covered hanger with eight clothespins for wet underwear or whatever to facilitate drying over a tub or sink. The bag is $15, the hanger $10, in the travel-notions department on the eighth floor at Bloomingdale's.

title: N.&W. BUYS 8.2% STAKE IN PIEDMONT
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway, one of the nation's largest coal carriers, disclosed yesterday that it had purchased 8.2 percent of Piedmont Aviation Inc., a rapidly expanding regional air carrier based in Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: U.N. Council Presidency
description: Foreign Minister Carlos P. Romulo of the Philippines became president of the Security Council today, succeeding Foreign Minister Jorge Illueca of Panama. The post rotates monthly according to the English alphabetical order of the Council's 15 member nations.

title: MILITARY COST CUT SOUGHT BY REAGAN TO REIN IN DEFICIT
description: As part of its effort to hold down the Federal deficit, the Reagan Administration plans to ask Congress to cut $10 billion to $15 billion from the planned incr ease in the military appr opriation for the fiscal year 1982, Congressional sources repor ted today.

title: CANADA SETTLES INTERNAL DISPUTE ON PRICE OF OIL
description: After more than a year of wrangling, the Canadian Government and Alberta, the chief oil-producing province, today reached a five-year accord on oil prices that could end a period of economic uncertainty.

title: 'Boy From Bed-Stuy' Still Pursues Education
description: Since his 1970 release from state prison at Dannemorra, where he served seven years for a Nassau County robbery, Louis DeBour has already absorbed a lot of schooling. Starting Sept. 8, Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government will be the next stop for the 41-year-old executive assistant to the State Division for Youth.

title: Socal, Texaco Find
description: The Standard Oil Company of California said today that it and Texaco Inc. have made new oil discoveries totaling 4,220 barrels daily from three discovery wells so far this year near the Duri field in central Sumatra, Indonesia.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anglo Energy Ltd. said that it had completed its acquisition of S & G Construction North Slope Enterprises Inc., Anchorage, for a total of $11 million in cash and notes.

title: AMERICAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes $192,000 tax credit

title: SIGMOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SANDERS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GOLDWATER WOULD MEET P.L.O.
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, in a deviation from Reagan Administration policy, said today that he would be in favor of talking with the Palestine Liberation Organization if it would help reduce international terrorism.

title: Q&A
description: Q. You sometimes print recipes that call for canned tomatoes with tomato paste. Do you mean to use tomatoes that have been canned with tomato paste? Or do you mean canned tomatoes to which you add a quantity of tomato paste?

title: TOWN'S STREET PLAN STIRS RACIAL CLASH
description: A lame duck city council's decision to ''abandon'' nearly all of the streets in this tiny farm community, including the main road leading to Mississippi and the roads to the city softball field, has stirred a dispute over its motives and a frustrating fight by the new city leaders to get the roads back.

title: 16 Are Invited to Run In Marlboro Cup Race
description: John Henry, Genuine Risk, Pleasant Colony and Temperence Hill were among 16 stakes-winning thoroughbreds invited yesterday to run in the $400,000 Marlboro Cup Sept. 19 at Belmont Park.

title: CENTRAL AMERICAN NEEDS FOSTER UNITY
description: With severe financial problems aggravating internal unrest, the countries of Central America are trying to bury some of their sharp political differences in the hope of obtaining urgently needed outside economic aid.

title: CONTROLLERS ACCUSE JUDGE IN BARGAINING CASE
description: The Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization accused a Federal administrative law judge today of ''grossly improper conduct'' because he had recommended stripping the union of its bargaining rights.

title: DENT OUT
description: After overpowering the Twins, 11-6, tonight for their fifth straight victory, the Yankees found out that their shortstop, Bucky D ent, would be sidelined for several weeks with a broken right hand.

title: 2 Boys in Texas Ordered Returned to Their Father
description: A family judge today ordered two boys returned to their father in New York. Their mother, who had been accused of smuggling the boys to Texas in 1979 after losing custody in a divorce, was later hospitalized after apparently taking an overdose of drugs.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After income of $95,000 from discontinued operations

title: Economic Scene; Reagan Quest: What to Undo?
description: IS Reaganomics one more beautiful theory killed by an ugly little fact - that it doesn't work? It begins to look that way. Before President Reagan and his aides had a chance to savor the full fruits of their budget and tax triumphs in Congress, and enjoy a well-earned August vacation away from Washington, the stock market dropped 50 points, the long-term bond market looked as though it might be permanently dead, inflation came back to life, interest rates stayed very high and the economy started to sink into what could be another recession.

title: MAKING THE CHILI HOTTER YET
description: NEW DELHI In an advance that may seem like lily gilding to anyone who has choked through an incendiary Madras curry, an Indian company has discovered a process to extract more heat from chili peppers.

title: A MONEY FUND NEXT FOR SEARS
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, the nation's largest retailer, said today that it would start a money market fund this year as part of its continuing strategy to become a major national supplier of financial services. Bankers immediately complained about this specter of still more competition for their industry.

title: Air New Zealand
description: Air New Zealand said today that it lost more than $36 million in United States currency on airline operations in the 1980 financial year, and the company's annual report issued today predicted further big losses for at least the next 18 months.

title: SECOND INCOMES ENCOURAGED
description: There are no provisions in the new tax law tailored specifically to people with second jobs or outside incomes. But for freelancers or people who have hobbies that have turned into part-time vocations, the new law is peppered with measures that could save taxes, according to tax experts. Indeed, tax specialists suggest that these new tax provisions could make this an appropriate time to start a business. And for stay-athome spouses who have been wondering whether to enter the labor force, the new tax law offers a variety of measures that, taken together, could tip the balance.

title: I.R.S. SET TO DENY TAX-FREE STA TUS TO BONUS SAVINGS
description: The Internal Revenue Service will not grant tax-exempt status for savings certificates purchased as part of advance bonus programs that require depositors to buy the new certificates, Administration officials said tonight.

title: Quintuplets Born in Tokyo
description: A Tokyo woman gave birth today to quintuplets - three boys and two girls - and all are doing well, the Japan Red Cross Medical Cente r said. The infa nts, born to Nagako Tanaka, 34 years old, weighed from 2 pounds, 6 ounces to 4 pounds, 2 ounces. Mrs. Tanaka used a fertility drug to induce pregnancy, the attending obstetrician, Dr. Hiroshi Akamatsu, said.

title: DRUG WAS SHORTCUT
description: To the Editor:

title: FIXING ELECTION LAW
description: Terry Dolan, chairman of the National Conservative Political Action Committee, tersely summed up the utter lack of accountability inherent in the role groups such as his are playing in American politics.

title: Advertising; Magazine Renovation Success
description: LOUIS OLIVER GROPP says that he's all thumbs with a hammer, but he seems to be a handy fellow when it comes to renovating a homemaking magazine.

title: BOSTONIANS PROTEST IMPROPER TICKETING
description: Boston area residents marched by City Hall yesterday to protest what they said was the erroneous issuance of parking tickets to them and other Massachusetts drivers. The tickets call for tens of thousands of dollars in fines.

title: SHRIMP FARMER IN ECUA DOR INCREASES OU TPUT AND PROFITS
description: A shrimp traditionally suggests something small, but a California man who is growing them in bulk on Ecuador's Pacific Coast may change that notion.

title: YANKEES BEATEN ON 2-RUN 8TH, 4-3
description: Dave Winfield dropped a fly ball in the eighth inning tonight that led to a 4-3 Twins victory and an end to the Yankees' five-game winning streak. The loss capped a bad night for the Yankees, who had learned earlier that Bucky Dent was unlikely to return to the lineup in time for postseason play.

title: Work Force Radiation At a Record for 1980
description: Total radiation exposure of American nuclear reactor workers reached a record last year, increasing by 35 percent, and another big increase is expected this year, an environmental group said today.

title: MCDONNELL DOUGLAS GUILTY PLEA
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, which is under indictment on fraud and other charges in an overseas payment case, has agr eed to plead guilty and pay the Federal government more than $1.2 mil lion to settle pending civil and criminal proceedings, Justice Depar tment sources said today.

title: MRS. O'CONNOR REPORTS ASSETS AT $1.1 MILLION
description: Sand ra Day O'Connor, the first woman to be nominated to the Supreme Court, has reported that she and her husband have assets worth more than $1.1 million.

title: ON THE WRONG SIDE IN NAMIBIA
description: To the Editor:

title: Du Pont of France
description: The E.I. Du Pont de Nemours & Company. said that its Du Pont de Nemours (France) unit has signed a letter of intent with Chargeurs Reunis Group of France to acquire the agrichemicals division of the French company's unit, Societe d'Exploration des Produit pour les Industries Chimiques. Du Pont also signed a second letter of intent with Pricel Inc., the United States unit of Chargeurs Reunis, to sell Du Pont's cellulose sponge business.

title: United Press International
description: POLISH COMMUNISTS SCORE LABOR GROUP: Stanislaw Kania, standing, party chief, at opening session of Central Committee in Warsaw. Seated were Stefan Olszowski, Politburo member, and Gen. Wojciech Jaruselski, Prime Minister. Continuing its criticism of Solidarity, the party leaders accused that labor organization of creating anarchy and of blocking all attempts to lead the country out of its worsening economic crisis.

title: SPANISH PLOTTERS STIR SOME WHAT-IFS
description: If Gen. Jose Juste had not been wearing combat fatigues on Feb. 23, would Spain today be a military dictatorship? Spaniards have had the occasion to pose this and a few other unsettling what-ifs and might-have-beens of history after a summer of pretrial newspaper leaks of the testimony of soldiers involved in the unsuccessful coup in February.

title: Dem Dry Bones
description: Topic Aleph in Israel today is neither Awacs nor the continued threat of Syrian missiles in Lebanon, nor even in jest about whether America used Israeli parts in its attack on Libya. The subject making local headlines is the success of ultra-Orthodox religious leaders in stopping Israeli archeologists from poking around the Temple Mount and rattling what may be the bones of King David and his relatives.

title: Bridge Mark One Up for Kibitizer; At Final of a Tournament
description: At any tournament the conclusion of a pair championship usually leaves knots of players comparing notes about the boards played while waiting for the official scores. Their orderly progress through the 26 deals is sometimes interrupted when someone has a story to tell.

title: Chinese Find Large Diamond
description: Miners in Shandong Province have discovered the second largest diamond ever found in China, a 124.27-carat stone, the New China News Agency said. The report did not say when the latest find was made or what would happen to the diamond.

title: The City; Port Unit Doubts Blastings' Effect
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said it did not ''appear'' that blasting done in connection with the expansion of its bus terminal on Manhattan's West Side had caused the collapse Monday of two buildings behind it on Ninth Avenue near 41st Street. One person died and at least four were injured in the collapse.

title: Perkin-Elmer Net Increases
description: The Perkin-Elmer Corporation, a leading manufacturer of electronic analytical instruments and semiconductor production machines, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1981 ended July 31 increased 13 percent, to $22.6 million, or 52 cents a share, from $20 million, or 47 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: zf The City; Chase on Tracks Halts IRT Service
description: Service was disrupted on the West Side IRT during the evening rush yesterday as Transit Authority police officers pursued a man along the subway tracks.

title: Speer, Hess and Punishment
description: In an era when confession to sins real, imagined or as yet uncommitted is common, Albert Speer, the only Nazi leader tried at Nuremberg to admit guilt, may seem less a penitent than a man ahead of his time. And his much-praised defiance of Hitler's command to turn the defeated Germany into a desert can be construed as a kind of Pavlovian response to the order to destroy: It is the nature of the architect to build.

title: CAMBODIANS TRYING TO FORGE UNITED FRONT AGAINST HANOI
description: The leaders of anti-Vietnamese Cambodian groups arrived here today to search for a a common front against Hanoi's occupation of their country.

title: AIDING THE DISABLED: NO PITY, PLEASE
description: As an advocate for the rights of physically and mentally disabled people, I am acutely aware of how many people in our society consider the disabled to be childlike, helpless, hopeless, nonfunctioning and noncontributing members of society.

title: Index; International
description: Sadat poised to deal with religious militants A2 China's labor experiment: the threat of dismissal A3 Testimony on Madrid coup raises some might-have-beens A3 West German terrorists say they bombed U.S. air base A4 Around the World A5 Soviet paper implies U.S. fi- nanced Teheran bombing A7 Cambodians try to form common front against Vietnam A8 India denies Soviet influenced re- jection of U.S. diplomat A9 Government/Politics Black Mississippi lawmakers see redistricting plan as a setback A15 Democratic organization assails Reagan in fund-raising effort A17 City hopes to improve priority bus lanes in Manhattan B3 Bank attacks Goldin move to put city funds in minority banks B6 Mrs. O'Connor reports assets at more than $1.1 million B12 General Board rules longshoremen's boy- cott of Soviet broke law A13 Around the Nation A14 Hundreds of aspiring cousins lay claim on Hughes estates A14 The Region B4 Widow, 86, slain in her home on City Island in the Bronx B5 The City B10 Health/Science Expedition to Andrea Doria re- turns to port with safe A14 Medical care costs are rising faster than inflation rate A16 Rorschach Society casts business- like silhouette in capital B26 Obituaries Funeral service for Lowell Thomas attended by 800 B16 The Home Section Home Old-house decision: Restore, renovate or remodel? C1

title: Rangers Are Arranging Game at Meadowlands
description: The Rangers are expected to complete plans within the next few days to add a 10th exhibition game and play the Philadelphia Flyers Sept. 28 or 29 at the new Brendan Byrne Arena in the Meadowlands. It would be the first hockey game to played in the 20,000-seat arena, which opened in July.

title: ECONOMIC HEALTH IS A LONG WAY OFF
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET IS ABLE TO RAISE PRODUCTION OF OIL AND GAS, PENTAGON ASSERTS
description: The Defense Intelligence Agency, in its latest analysis of the Soviet economy, says that the Soviet Union's energy prospects for the rest of this century appear ''highly favorable,'' and that Moscow will be able to increase its oil production and exports for the foreseeable future.

title: Jobs Shrink In Europe
description: More than 2.6 million jobs in manufacturing have been lost in the European Economic Community since 1974, its headquarters reported today.

title: TRIAD SUES, ACCUSING 2 OF LARCENY
description: The Triad Energy Corporation and Everest Petroleum Inc. charged in court yesterday that two of their top executives, helped by a junior officer of the European-American Bank and Trust Company, had looted them of undetermined bank deposits and other assets. The two related oil companies are seeking damages of more than $5 million in the suit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Rise in Supply Of Gasoline
description: Gasoline supplies in the United States increased last week, running counter to the usual summer decline for the second week in a row, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday.

title: HOWMET BUYS UNIT OF NATIONAL STEEL
description: The Howmet Aluminum Corporation said today that it has agreed to buy the National Steel Company's cold rolling aluminum sheet business and will lease National's closed aluminum rolling mill at Hanesville, Ky., for two years with an option to buy it.

title: INDIA DENIES SOVIET PROMPTED BARRING OF DIPLOMAT
description: A spokesman for the Foreign Ministry confirmed today that India had vetoed the posting of a senior diplomat at the United States Embassy here.

title: Sports of The Times; Teenyboppers on Court 16
description: SOMEDAY they might be playing for the women's singles championship in the United States Open, but yesterday they were out there on Court 16, out there past the practice courts, out there in a far corner of the National Tennis Center, two pony-tailed teenyboppers in a firstround match - 16-year-old Kathy Horvath and 14-year-old Kathy Rinaldi.

title: The Region; Bontempo Loses His Newark Post
description: NEWARK (AP) - A former City Councilman whose job as security chief for Newark's Pequannock Watershed aroused controversy has been formally removed from his post as of last Dec. 31.

title: PEKING IS TESTING 'LABOR DISCIPLINE'
description: China is again tinkering with its system of guaranteed job and income security. For several months, China's leaders have been experimenting quietly in dozens of factories with notions that workers who do not work should be subjected to pay cuts and, if that fails, be dismissed.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., has named George M. Baker vice president, business development.

title: M.T.A. IS TOLD BY ARBITRATOR TO DELAY BUS RUN CHANGES
description: An arbitrator ruled yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had the right to impose changes in bus schedules in its effort to reduce costs, but that it could not make the changes until next year.

title: No Headline
description: Jim Frey, who was replaced by Dick Howser as the Kansas City Royals' manager Monday, has finally replied to the criticism of him that has been voiced by some former players in recent days. ''I keep reading what a bad guy I am and I feel awful about it,'' he said.

title: HOME PARTIES, WHERE THE SELLING IS EASY
description: THE setting is an Upper East Side co-op and the gathering is middle-aged preppy. Standing at the entrance to the elegantly furnished living room, Corinne Borrelli takes a plastic bowl from a table, seals it shut, then lifts the lid slightly to expel air.

title: Notes on People; Relieved of Command
description: An Army major at Fort Riley, Kan., was abruptly transferred last week after a few soldiers in his company shouted a barnyard epithet as they marched past a general's tent.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 3, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets on Namibia at 3 P.M.

title: Notes on People; Surgery for Schulz
description: In a four-hour operation, Charles M. Schulz, creator of the ''Peanuts'' cartoon strip (and subsequent industry), underwent quadruple-bypass cardiac surgery yesterday in Santa Rosa, Calif., his hometown 50 miles north of San Francisco.

title: BANK SUES GOLDIN OVER PLAN TO USE MINORITY-RUN BANKS
description: A Queens bank has filed suit to stop the Comptroller's office from depositing city money in banks that were selected, in part, because they are owned by black and Hispanic people.

title: Court Upholds Freeing Of Alabama Prisoners
description: The United States Supreme Court today let stand a lower court order that freed 222 Alabama prisoners last month and that, according to the state's Attorney General, might lead to the forced release of 500 more.

title: Home Beat; PORTRAYING PLACES
description: SHE doesn't do exteriors, although she would consider doing a detail of a corner. Susan Cohen paints portraits of houses, or parts of houses, focusing on a view she particularly likes or that means something to the people who commission her oil paintings.

title: MISSTATEMENT BY U.S. CAUSES A FUROR AT U.N.
description: The spokesman for the American delegation caused a diplomatic furor here today when he mistakenly announced that the United States would not take part in a special session on South-West Africa, which is also called Namibia. The statement was later recalled.

title: Biology Concern Sells 1% Stake
description: Collaborative Research Inc., of Waltham, Mass., said it had sold a 1 percent equity stake in the company to the Green Cross Corporation, of Osaka, Japan, for $1 million.

title: Market Place; Fund Formula: 50 Categories
description: THE Mellon Bank's commingled pension fund has been employing a formula-based technique of investing money to good effect recently. One aspect of the approach should interest individual investors.

title: MARIA TUCCI IS JOSEPHINE IN 'KINGDOMS'
description: Maria Tucci has been signed to portray the Empress Josephine in ''Kingdoms,'' Edward Sheehan's new play based on an actual incident in which Napoleon kidnapped Pope Pius VII in 1809 and took him to France. Roy Dotrice will be seen as the Pope and Armand Assante will be Napoleon.

title: Floods Force Families Out
description: More than 900 families were evacuated tonight after a heavy storm dumped several inches of rain in the area, causing flash floods. The police said there were no injuries or major property losses.About six inches of rain fell from 5 and 8 P.M., the National Weather Service said.

title: A NEW SPIRIT DETECTED AMONG MICHAELS AND HIS REVIVED JETS
description: Marty Lyons of the Jets said today that he had been intimidated in the past by Coach Walt Michaels but that feeling had changed because of a new attitude in Michaels and himself.

title: SPECIAL-INTEREST MONEY ASSISTS CITY CANDIDATES
description: Money from the real-estate and financial sectors likes Mayor Koch and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin. Bus company money likes Assemblyman John C. Dearie. Money from liberal unions likes Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro. Liberal, entertainment and feminist money likes Elizabeth Holtzman, and Brooklyn Democratic organization followers like Norman Rosen.

title: SADAT IS POISED TO DEAL WITH RELIGIOUS EXTREMISTS
description: The growth of Moslem fundamentalism in Egypt has created tension and violence between the Islamic majority and the country's minority of Coptic Christians.

title: Quality Inns Deal
description: Quality Inns Internatonal, a Manor Care Inc. unit that operates the seventh largest hotel chain in the world, said it has agreed with Crest Hotels, a unit of Bass Ltd. of Britain, to link their properties in the United States, Europe, Canada, Mexico and the Pacific through a jointly run reservations system. The accord joins Crest's 112 three-star and four-star hotels and 13,500 rooms, to the 368 hotels and 42,000 rooms in the Quality Inns International system.

title: Business People; President Gains Title at Home Life
description: Kenneth C. Nichols, the 57-year-old president of the Home Life Insurance Company, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer. He succeeds Gerald K. Rugger, who has retired at the age of 65 as chairman and chief executive of the New York-based mutual insurer.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Agency Rent-A-Car said it increased its share of Spencer Companies to 33.9 percent, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: IRAN'S NEW PRIME MINISTER ANNOUNCES HIS CABINET
description: Iran's new interim Prime Minister announced a new Government today hours after winning an overwhelming vote of confidence from Parliament.

title: FOUR TO WOMEN ADVANCE EASILY
description: For Bjorn Borg, it was little more than a workout, his first match since mid-July. Chris Evert Lloyd, Andrea Jaeger, Martina Navratilova and Pam Shriver all won easily, too, losing only five games among them.

title: Notes on People
description: Job for Mrs. D'Amato At Nassau Community College in Garden City, L.I. yesterday, Penelope D'Amato began her first full-time paid job as an adult at age 44. The wife of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato will be a $15,287-ayear technical assistant, helping computer-science students and instructors with their programming.

title: Soviet Coal to Japan
description: Japan's six largest steelmakers have signed a contract to import 700,000 to 750,000 metric tons of coking coal from the Soviet Union this year, the Nippon Steel Corporation said today. The price is $62.50 per ton, up 13.7 percent from a year ago, Nippon Steel officials said.

title: RACIAL SLAP BY BARBARO ROILS KOCH
description: Mayor Koch watched in tight-lipped anger yesterday as Frank J. Barbaro accused him of using inflamatory words to ''set off the races.''

title: SONDHEIM AND PRINCE TEAM UP AGAIN 'MERRILY'
description: IT is that magic moment, that wonderful moment - hope and expectancy congealed with cold fear. Actually, no one admits to fear; that would be against the rules. But consider that it is the first day of rehearsal for ''Merrily We Roll Along,'' and that many people are sitting in a rehearsal studio on lower Broadway, and that some of them are thinking, God forbid, what if this show is a turkey?

title: 800 HEAR PEALE PRAISE LOWELL THOMAS
description: A funeral service for Lowell Thomas at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church yesterday drew 800 people, including former President Gerald R. Ford, Vice President Bush and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: NAVY OUSTS 2,600 IN PROJECT DESIGNED TO IMPROVE MORALE
description: The Navy has ousted more than 2,600 sailors through a quick-purge program that commanders say improved the morale and fighting quality of other shipmates.

title: Seaver Defeats Expos
description: Tom Seaver pitched a two-hitter for eight innings, and George Foster hit a towering home run that landed 50 feet up the left-field foul-pole screen to spark the Cincinnati Reds to a 7-0 victory over the Montreal Expos tonight.

title: GOLD STOCKS GAIN
description: The stock market ended moderately higher yesterday in slower trading, with some of the gold mining and special situation issues registering the best gains.

title: Books of the Times
description: By John Leonard THE HOLOCAUST AND THE HISTO- RIANS. By Lucy S. Dawidowicz. 187 pages. Harvard. $15.

title: AUDIT PROMPTS PARK SERVICE TO IMPROVE RECORDS SYSTEM
description: The National Park Service unit responsible for many of this city's top tourist attractions said yesterday that it was improving its records systems in response to an audit estimating that $2.9 million in park property was missing.

title: Foremost Sets Melrose Takeover
description: Foremost-McKesson Inc., a company that sells drugs and health care products, has received Federal Trade Commission approval to acquire Melrose Distributors Inc., which sells cosmetics and toiletries.

title: PANDAS IN ITS PHOTOS PENNED, NOT IN WILD, GEO MAGAZINE SAYS
description: Geo magazine, the high-gloss, two-year-old magazine published here by a German company, has acknowledged that several photographs of giant pandas in its August issue were misrepr esented in headlines andcaptions.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.00-20.50 **Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 1627 Stolen Rubens Painting Worth $350,000 Is Recovered
description: A stolen Rubens painting valued at $350,000 was recovered yesterday from a motel room in Arlington, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: CHANGES EXPECTED IN REAGAN'S STAFF
description: President Reagan plan s to make a series of changes in his political, press office and co mmunications operations soon after he returns here tomorrow from his month-long vacation in California, White House officials said today.

title: Armed Iowa Prisoners H old Hostages 11 Hours
description: Two small groups of inmates armed with sawed-off shotguns and homemade knives took 15 persons hostage today at the Iowa State Penitentiary, officials said. All the captives were eventually released unharmed, but a prisoner was found stabbed to death afterward.

title: Country Gardener; WHAT TO DO THIS MONTH
description: Lawns. Even though the ground is dry, now is the time to repair old lawns or plant new ones because cooler growing weather, and hopefully, increased rainfall are in the offing. If established lawns have a good percentage of turfgrass growing, revive them with applications of fertilizer. Use mechanical dethatching and/or aerating machines to break up layer of dead grass (thatch) on top of the soil. Overseed lightly with top quality grass seed and keep soil moist with daily sprinklings until germination. Plant new lawns with high quality seed or sod but soil must be prepared properly, fertilized and limed first. Keep lightly sprinkled to aid germination or sod rooting.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yester- day about Sears, Roebuck's new money market fund incorrectly stated a position of the American Bankers Association. It has not endorsed proposals to amend Federal law to permit interstate banking.

title: Utility and Subcontractor Cited in Leak on Coast
description: A state agency has cited the Pacific Gas and Electric Company and a subcontractor in the gas and toxic chemical leak that forced 30,000 people to flee the business district eight days ago.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan's goal of a balanced budget by 1984 is unlikely to be realized, some Administration officials now acknowledge. (Page A1.) As Mr. Reagan ended his California vacation, his advisers said he would make deeper cuts in social and military spending in an effort to persuade Wall Street that his economic program would work. (B17.) If he has not done so in the next six months, both supporters and critics warn, the economy will be in serious trouble. (D1.)

title: METS LOSE FOURTH IN ROW, 8-0
description: There is something about the Astrodome that brings out the worst in the Mets, and it happened again tonight. They made only three hits off Bob Knepper, lost to the Houston Astros by 8-0, and suffered their fourth straight defeat while the Astros were winning for the seventh time in a row.

title: City Gardener; WHAT TO DO THIS MONTH
description: Street tree care.

title: WATT MAY LIFT BAN ON MINING NEAR PARK
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt is considering a recommendation to permit strip mining next to Bryce Canyon National Park in Utah, department officials and environmentalists reported today.

title: REAGAN'S DUBIOUS GESTURE TO NEW YORK LABOR
description: To the Editor:

title: The Risks of Indulging South Africa
description: Fresh from the Angola bush, South Africa's white hunters are all but displaying the mounted heads of Soviet military advisers killed in last week's invasion. ''Undeniable evidence'' of a Soviet military presence in Angola, says South Africa's Defense Minister.

title: RIVAL GROUPS OF WOULD-BE COUSINS MAKING THEIR CLAIMS FOR HUGHES ESTATE
description: Six years after Howard R. Hughes died and after his closest relatives agreed to divide his multimillion-dollar estate, two other groups of people named Hughes are trying to persuade a probate court jury that the agreement would deprive them of their just shares.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We have moved into an old house that has oak floors with slats about two inches wide. Some of these floorboards have begun to buckle and there is evidence that this has happened before (signs of extra nails having been driven in). When we step on these boards they go back down, but won't stay down. We were told that one of the floors got a drenching when a window was open during a storm. What causes the buckling, and what can we do to remedy it? -K.W.H., Peekskill, N.Y.

title: Maryland Man Seized In Threat to President
description: A man armed with three high-powered rifles was arrested today after he reportedly told the police that he was on his way to Washington to kill President Reagan, Secret Service agents said.

title: MIDWEST GOVERNORS JOIN TO HELP REGION'S INTERESTS
description: The governors of 10 Middle Western states, unsure about the effects of President Reagan's economic plan, today ended a meeting at which they decided to compete economically while uniting politically to fight for their region's interests.

title: MEDICAL COSTS RISE AT A RATE OF 12.6%
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - The cost of medical care in the United States hasbeen rising faster rate so far this year than consumer pri ces in general, Government figures show.

title: HOW PATCO CAN SALVAGE ITS MEMBERS' JOBS
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Apollo' Musical Opens S
description: ''The Apollo - Just Like Magic,'' a musical that, according to its producers, will ''bring back the glorious past'' of the famous theater on West 125th Street in Harlem, will begin its pre-Broadway tryout Sept. 23 at the Shubert Theater in Philadelphia.

title: DEMOCRATS ASSAIL REAGAN IN MAILINGS
description: The Democratic National Committee is trying to raise mone y by characterizing the Reagan Administration as a tool of the ''New Right,'' a collection of very conservative groups, on issues from S ocial Security to the Voting Rights Act to th e environment.

title: Rassett Captures Medal
description: Joe Rassett shot a three-over-par 73 on the Olympic Club's Ocean Course and won the medal today in the 81st United States Amateur golf championship. Rassett, a 23-year-old from Turlock, Calif., and Oral Roberts University, led the way into the match play tomorrow with 145. Hal Sutton, the defending champion, was among the 64 qualifiers for match play, with a 151.

title: FINDING AN UNUSUAL COFFEE TABLE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Melanie Fleischmann is a freelance writer who specializes in the home furnishings field. By MELANIE FLEISCHMANN

title: China Oil Find
description: An oilfield that could be the largest in China has been discovered off the south coast, according to a report today in Peking's English-language China Daily.

title: FUGITIVE WARRANT IS DROPPED
description: A fugitive warrant against the boxing promoter Ross Fields and his wife was dropped yesterday by the State of California at the request of the North Carolina authorities, who had charged them with writing a bad check for $196.10. Mr. Fields, who is also under indictment on charges of embezzling $21.3 million from Wells Fargo Bank, had been free on $150,000 bail in the North Carolina case. He contends the charges "were never true."

title: More Germans Jobless
description: Unemployment in West Germany rose to 1.29 million last month, the highest August figure in 29 years, the Government said today. The total, 5.5 percent of the work force, was up 43,000 from July. The nation's weak economy was blamed.

title: Painting by Rembrandt Is Recovered in London
description: The police recovered a stolen Rembrandt painting today and arrested four men they said had the painting with them in a taxi.

title: McEnroe Gets $5,000 Fine
description: The Men's International Professional Tennis Council has set a $5,000 fine against John McEnroe for his ''aggravated behavior'' at Wimbledon, an official source said yesterday.

title: ROHATYN PROPOSES A BOND SALE PLAN
description: With interest rates in the municipal bond market at record highs, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation proposed yesterday that, for the first time, New York City, the state and their agencies coordinate the $3 billion in borrowing they do each year.

title: OLD-HOUSE DECISION: RESTORE, RENOVATE OR REMODEL?
Sports People; Leonard Gets Injunction
description: Bobby Leonard, who was dismissed as coach of the Indiana Pacers after the 1979-80 season and replaced by Jack McKinney, has obtained a temporary restraining order prohibiting the Pacers from forcing him to work full time at a job yet undesignated.

title: THE DRAFT TOOK A BEATING AND SO MAY WE
description: The suspicion grows that the earliest we can expect the country to give the idea of a military draft the importance and urgency it deserves is when another nation declares war on us or otherwise shows signs that it means us immediate harm.

title: CHILD CARE: ELDERLY IN BERLIN FILL A VOID
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Ellen Lentz is a freelance writer living in West Berlin. By ELLEN LENTZ WEST BERLIN FACED with an increasing number of single p arents and a diminishing number of extended families, West Germans are coming up with new ways to involve older people in chil d care.

title: British Coal Funds
description: Two employee pension plans of Britain's National Coal Board disclosed that they have acquired a stake in Realty and Mortgage Investors of the Pacific of 155,300 shares, or 5.5 percent, for a price of $3.3 million. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the two funds, the National Coal Board Staff Superannuation Scheme and the Mineworkers' Pension Scheme, said that their holdings include 16,700 shares bought between Aug. 24 and Aug. 31 on the New York Stock Exchange at prices between $24 and $23.50 a share. The two funds said their purchases were for investment.

title: Israel Suspends a Dig At Site Near Jerusalem
description: The Israeli Minister of Education has suspended for two weeks a dig at the archeological site known as the City of David, south of Jerusalem.

title: Stay in Execution Denied
description: The Oklahoma C ourt of Criminal Appealstoday denied a stay of execution for Thomas L ee Hays, who could become the first person in the nation to die legally by drug injection. The execution is scheduled for Sep t. 14.

title: A HOSPITAL ON L.I. LOSES ACCREDITATION
description: The Kings Park Psychiatric Center in Suffolk County said today that it had lost its accreditation and, as a result, faced the loss of $16.5 million a year in Federal funds.

title: IN PEACE BID, N.C.A.A. MAY ALLOW SCHOOLS MORE TV CONTROL
description: In an attempt to resolve the growing struggle for control of football television rights, the National Collegiate Athletic Association may give the powerful football schools more authority over such rights, according to Walter Byers, executive director of the association.

title: William E. Sauro Dignitaries Are Among 800 Mourners at Lowell Thomas Funeral Former President Gerald R. Ford and his wife, Betty, being greeted by the Rev. Thomas D. Bowers, rector of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church after funeral service for Lowell Thomas. With them were Secretary of
description: State Alexander M. Haig Jr., at right, and his wife, Patricia, and, next to Mr. Haig, William S. Paley, chairman of CBS. The Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale delivered the eulogy at landmark church on Park Avenue. Page B16.

title: HOMES STILL AVAILABLE, NEW COAST DATA SHOW
description: Determined buyers will find available housing despite high interest housing despite high interest rates and a constricted supply of mortgage a constricted supply of mortgage financing, a new California Association of Realtors survey shows. ''Innovativ e, resourceful buyers are finding that the market offers consid erable variation in the size and housing,'' Art Godi, the group's p resident, said.

title: CRIMMINS RECEIVES 20-YEAR-TO-LIFE TERM FOR MET SLAYING
description: Craig S. Crimmins, the Metropolitan Opera House stagehand who was convicted of murdering a violinist there last summer, was sentenced yesterday to 20 years to life in prison.

title: Laker Airways To Lift Prices
description: Laker Airways, the British reduced-fare airline run by Sir Freddie Laker, announced that its Skytrain fares on trans-Atlantic routes will go up by as much as 14 percent on some flights on Friday.

title: Business People; Drug Distribution Aids On New Chief's Agenda
description: With wholesale drug distributors developing new techniques to cope with the demands of their customers, the Southwestern Drug Corporation, one of the largest wholesalers in the Southwest, intends to develop additional services in the years ahead. And the man just chosen to lead the Dallas company - a $116 million unit of the Gulf United Corporation - in these efforts is Gene Vykukal, 52, who has been named president and chief executive officer.

title: Sports People; Bushbeck Deemed Fit
description: Doctors yesterday gave Chuck Bushbeck, a place-kicker at East Carolina who is suffering from Hodgkin's Disease, permission to play football this season.

title: COSMOS WIN BY 6-3 FOR 1-0 SERIES LEAD
description: The Cosmos defeated the Tampa Bay Rowdies tonight, 6-3, taking another step toward defending their North American Soccer League title.

title: Critic's Notebook; PRAISE THE ACTOR WHO TAKES COMMAND
description: ONCE upon a time August was a month for ''layoffs'' on Broadway. To escape the box-office doldrums, productions would disband until the city filled up again in the fall; new shows wouldn't even dream of lighting their marquees.

title: BROOKS BROTHERS: KEY TO ALLIED DEAL WITH GARFINCKEL
description: Yesterday morning, three salesmen at Brooks Brothers were clustered near the sweater counter trading stories. The sedate, traditional clothing store on Madison Avenue was not, in fact, particularly busy, and salesmen and executives outnumbered customers at least 2 to 1.

title: IN LOVE WITH A VINTAGE RANGE
YESTERDAY'S COCKTAIL
description: To the Editor:

title: LINER'S SAFE IS AMID SHARKS FOR SAFETY
description: A Bank of Rome safe, chinaware, some ashtrays and three doors, all hard-won salvage from the liner Andrea Doria, reached land here today after resting 25 years at the bottom of the sea.

title: Multimedia Grows
description: Multimedia Inc., owner of 13 daily newspapers including the Greenville News and Greenville Piedmont, said it has acquired the stock of a cable tel evision system in Medicine Lodge, Kan., for an undisclosed pric e. The system, Medicine Lodge CATV Inc., has about 1,050 subscribers and passes 2,700 homes. Multimedia owns other cable facilities in Kan sas, Oklahoma, Illinois and North Carolina with more than 130,000 sub scribers.

title: Treasury Yields Near Highs; Funds Rate Jump Blamed
description: In the Government securities market, Treasury bonds fell about 1/4 point yesterday as yields increased once again to near-record levels. The bellwether 13 7/8's of 2011, for example, declined nearly 1/4 point to 94 3/8, to yield 14.71 percent. Short-term yields also moved higher.

title: Technology; On Marketing The Unknown
description: ''PEOPLE who buy these systems are conservative. They want to see it working somewhere else before they will invest in it.'' These were the words of a waste management expert i nterv iewed for the column that appeared here two weeks ago on treatment systems for organic wastes.

title: How to Pick a Borough President
description: To be president of one of New York City's five boroughs was once a job with some genuine authority, supervising street repair and maintenance of public buildings. But then waves of reform swept away the hiring and firing power, leaving each president with vague prestige, a large office, free flags for the waiting room and a vote on the Board of Estimate, the city's governing body.

title: Bel-Fran Cuts Tie To Gulf Resources
description: Bel-Fran Investments Ltd., which is controlled by the Belzberg family of Vancouver, Canada, said it and other affiliated companies have sold 263,500 shares of the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation on Aug. 18 and 19 at an average price of $26.50 a share.

title: Great Basins Sells Canada Holdings
description: The Great Basins Petroleum Company said it had completed the previously announced sale of its Canadian oil and gas operations to United Canso Oil and Gas Ltd. for $128 million (in United States currency), after deducting $8.4 million of indebtedness. Great Basins, in the process of complete liquidation, is seeking buyers for its remaining assets.

title: Business People; Top Clevepak Officer About to Retire Again
description: When Hubert J. McPherson, one of the founders of the Clevepak Corporation, returned as president and chief executive officer last December, the company said that he would fill the post ''on an interim basis.''

title: No Headline
