description: The commander of the Italian Air Force's aerobatic squadron, the Arrows, was killed today when his G-91 jet collided with another aircraft during a training flight, officials said. The pilot of the second G-91 managed to land his damaged plane.

title: GUNMAN WOUNDS GUARD AT SHERATON CENTRE
description: A unarmed security guard was shot last night at the Sheraton Centre Hotel when he tried to subdue a gunman who was attempting to rob guests on the upper floors of the hotel, the police said.

title: RESTORING THE FURNITURE WHEN IT'S SUN-FADED
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores antiques for dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: Hers
description: IS it possible for a woman to walk alone, footsteps echoing though the night city, without feeling as if she's performin g in a Brian De Palma movie? I can't. I've been conditioned into De Palma-style reflexes: twi tches and eye rolls, in response to any unlikely sight or sound. Wha t is that shape moving shadowlike in the alley? Is that a garbage bag or a man hunkered down in the service doorway? If I venture out a lone after midnight, I enter an atmosphere as different from the ever yday world as if I've gone under water. I can hear my own breathing , the hammering of my heart, the clickety-clack-clack ofmy heels on t he pavement. Unescorted, I am accompanied by fear, chaperoned by phantoms of my own imagination. Why has that man changed direc tion, just as I've turned the corner? Is that he now walking behin d me?

title: LONGSHOREMAN'S BOYCOTT IS RULED ILLEGAL BY LABOR RELATIONS BOARD
description: The National Labor Relations Board has ruled that the International Longshoremen's Association violated Federal law by boycotting Russian cargo and ships to protest the Soviet Union's military intervention in Afghanistan.

title: AFTER VACATION, REAGAN TURNS ATTENTION TO UNIONS
description: President Reagan ended his California vacation today and took up the task of trying to reassure organized labor and the financial community, two dissimilar groups that share strong doubts about his policies.

title: U.S.-SHUNNED MOSCOW BOOK FAIR OPENS
description: The third Moscow International Book Fair opened today with an American representation sharply reduced by past clashes over censorship and human rights and by low sales. Exhibitors, including American Jews, Protestants and Israelis, reported only a handful of seizures by customs officials, and the Soviet focus, as in past years, was, from the outset, on literature dealing with science and high technology.

title: Detroit Bank Sues Son Of Ex-G.M. President
description: The National Bank of Detroit today sued Thomas P. Estes, son of Elliott Estes, retired president of General Motors, to collect a $450,000 loan it made in June.

title: Ivie : A Player Who Was Afraid to Fail
description: ''I've got a problem,'' Mike Ivie was saying, ''but I'm going to conquer it.'' He didn't particularly look like a man with a problem as he sat on the Houston Astros' bench looking out at the nine acres of green carpeting under the 208-foot peak of the Astrodome. But at age 29, after three months on the disabled list in his eighth season in the big leagues, he spoke softly and openly on a subject about which others had been whispering during his career.

title: Funding Plan For Britain
description: The Confederation of British Industry today urged the Conservative Government to stimulate Britain's economy with an $11 billion package of measures designed to reduce unemployment.

title: CANADA OIL ACCORD IS PRAISED
description: Depite some reservations within the oil industry, Canadian business leaders hailed yesterday's energy pricing agreement between the federal Government and the major oilproducing province of Alberta and expressed hope that it would stimulate the faltering economy.

title: VW Unit Closes Plant
description: Triumph-Adler, a subsidiary of Volkswagenwerk, said today that it planned to close its factory here, resulting in the loss of some 3,000 jobs of the company's total employment of 8,700. The company, attributing the closing to a weak market for mechanical and electric typewriters, said it would concentrate on the electronic office machine sector. The company reported a loss of 79 million marks in 1980, or about $32 million.

title: Dancin' Dirden
description: While the Pittsburgh Steelers were watching films of Saturday night's exhibition game against the Giants, C oach Chuck Noll quietly walked over to the screen and used his hand t o cover the image of Johnnie Dirden doing his first end zone dance after he had caught a 15-yard touchdown pass. ''Those are strong ha nd signals,'' said Dirden, a wide receiver.

title: TUG CAPTAIN BACKED AT INQUIRY
description: A tugboat deckhand yesterday confirmed his captain's earlier testimony concerning the location of the vessel in relation to a disabled cabin cruiser that sank in Long Island Sound last month with the loss of five lives. A cement-laden barge towed by the tugboat, the David McAllister, is suspected of having collided with the cruiser, the Karen E.

title: Rosmar Sales Investigated
description: A Toronto investment firm sold securities in more than 40 states of the United States in which it was not registered to do business, the Ontario Securities Commission has beentold.

title: N.F.L., Citing Publicity, Wants Retrial Moved
description: The National Football League wants the retrial of the antitrust suit brought against the league by the Oakland Raiders and the Los Angeles Coliseum Commission moved from here because of publicity during the first trial.

title: THE PUBLIC PLAZAS THAT ARE NEITHER
description: To the Editor:

title: Helpful Hardware
description: In this age of shrinking living and working space, it seems that one can never have enough storage units. We have found three different types of storage units that may solve some of problems for you and are not too costly.

title: Westinghouse, I.T.T. in Pact
description: In separate ventures, the Westinghouse Electric Co mpany said it is teaming up with t he world's largest manufacturer of telecommunications equipment on a defense contract and with one of Japan's leading technological concerns on several projects.

title: All-White Jury Picked in Trial Of Avowed Racist in Slayings
description: An all-white jury of seven men and five women was selected today for the trial of Joseph Paul Franklin, an avowed racist who is charged with first-degree murder in the ambush slayings of two black joggers.

title: HARD ROCK: CRACK THE SKY QUINTET
description: ALTHOUGH Crack the Sky, the hard-rock quintet that played two shows at the Bottom Line on Tuesday, has u ndergone several personnel changes over the course of five albums, its e ssence is still determined by its principal songwriter and le ad singer, John Palumbo.A Middle Western hipster with a penchant for clever, paranoid songs about sexual and cultural antagonism, Mr. Pal umbo appeared at Tuesday's early show wearing a three-piece bu siness suit, dark sunglasses and an ominous smirk on his lips.

title: TV: YOUTH VIOLENCE IN AMERICA
description: PICKING up on the increasingly disturbing headlines of the last few years, CBS News examines, tonight at 10, several aspects of what is justifiably called a brutal trend: more crimes with guns, more random violence and younger criminals. Produced for ''CBS Reports'' by Irina Posner, ''Murder: Teenage Style'' is reported by Ed Bradley.

title: The City; 3 Jail Employees Face Drug Charge
description: Two correction officers and a civilian employee at the 300-bed Queensboro Correctional Facility in Long Island City were arraigned on charges they smuggled drugs into the facility, authorities s aid.

title: Jersey City Group Is Fighting New Eased Rent Control Law
description: Angry tenant groups today started a petition drive aimed at overturning the City Council's newly enacted law prohibiting rent controls in new housing and relaxing them in privately owned apartments. The latter group houses about 25 percent of the population.

title: JUDGE'S VIEWS ON SENTENCING
description: Following are excerpts from the comments of Acting Justice Richard G. Denzer of State Supreme Court on the sentencing of Craig S. Crimmins:

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1981
description: International Angola threatened again to call in its allies to help expel South African troops from its territory. The Marxist regime, whose allies include the Soviet Union and Cuba, assailed the United States for its veto Monday of a United Nations Security Council resolution condemning South Africa and demand ing a withdrawal of its forces. (Page A1, Col umns 2-3.) Preliminary arms talks have begun between the United States and the Soviet Union on the issue of how to verify compliance with future accords, the State Department spokesman said. He confirmed that Eugene V. Rostow, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, and Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, the Soviet charge d'affaires in Washington, met on Aug. 21 to discuss limiting strategic nuclear weapons. (A1:1.)

title: Grain Harvest Recovery Forecast
description: World cereal grain production is expected to recover this year after two years of bad harvests while trade in grains is expected to reach record levels, according to a report by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.

title: NEW TREND IN COLLEGE DESEGREGATION EMERGES
description: For the first time in more than a decade, state officials have opened the doors at the 16 schools of the University of North Carolina without worrying about Federal charges of running a dual system of higher education, one primarily for whites and the other for blacks.

title: Marchenko, a Dissident, Goes on Trial in Soviet
description: Anatoly Marchenko, who has spent 15 of his 43 years in prison camps and exile, went on trial today on charges of anti-Soviet agitation, the press agen cy Tass said.

title: SOVIET PAPER IMPLIES THE C.I.A. FINANCED BOMBING IN TEHERAN
description: The labor union newspaper Trud implied today that the Central Intelligence Agency had financed the assassinations of Iran's President and Prime Minister.

title: Dutch Premier to Try To Fashion a Cabinet
description: Queen Beatrix assigned Prime Minister Andreas A.M. van Agt today to form a coalition of his Christian Democratic Party, Labor and Democrats '66, the Government Information Office said. The party leaders have been negotiating for three months since Mr. van Agt's coalition lost a slim majority in Parliament in the May 26 election.

title: The Region; Residence Switch To Aid a Nominee
description: The state's Energy Commissioner is moving his residence from South Orange in Essex County to Long Beach Township in Ocean County and leaving a political problem behind.

title: No Headline
description: An article by The Associated Press printed yesterday on the Company News page in Business Day incorrectly identified a director of the Braniff International Corporation who is resigning. She is Pamela Harriman.

title: JERSEY BATTLING RESIDENTS TO GIVE PUBLIC A FOOTING ON PRIVATE BEACH
description: Since the Depression, the people in this small seaside resort have had their 1.25-mile Atlantic beach all to themselves.

title: Topics Clean Murder / State Drink
description: Guns, Youth and Life

title: Genetic Research Grant Set
description: Washington University and Mallinckrodt Inc. signed an agreement yesterday that will provide $3.88 million for genetic research. The research involves production of antibodies from artificially created cells called hybridomas.

title: Notes on People
description: In this corner, wearing the psychedelic trunks, Dr. Timothy Leary - the former Harvard instructor and 1960's guru of drug culture, now reveling in unconditional legal freedom for the first time in 15 years.

title: U.S. AIDING CITY IN IMPROVEMENT OF ITS BUS LANES
description: The New York City Transportation Department said yesterday that it hoped to improve the operation of an existing 12-mile network of priority bus lanes in Manhattan by next spring.

title: Notes On People; Role for Silverman
description: Fred Silverman, who filled the ABC television schedule with some of its most successful series, will have his own 13-week series beginning in January at Syracuse University's S. I. Newhouse School of Public Communications. More recently Mr. Silverman was chairman of NBC until he was replaced by Grant Tinker in July.

title: Help-Wanted Index Increases
description: An index of help-wanted advertising, an indicator of demand for labor, increased in July, its second straight monthly gain, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: Unions Urge Conrail Workers To Defer Raise and Save Jobs
description: The leaders of 10,000 Conrail employees in units of the Transport Workers Union unanimously recommended at a meeting in Philadelphia yesterday that the workers ratify an agreement reached with the Federal Government in May to defer indefinitely up to 12 percent in pay increases in their forthcoming contract.

title: News of Music; MET OPERA GEARS UP FOR GALA 100TH
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's centenary celebrations are still two years in the future, but plans are already afoot to make the season of 1983-84 one that operagoers will never forget. The festivities will begin in mid-September 1983 with an opening-night revival of Berlioz's epical ''Les Troyens'' starring Placido Domingo as Aeneas. About a month later, on Oct. 22, 100 years to the day since the Met first opened its doors with a performance of ''Faust,'' there will be a gala concert, and operatic luminaries all over the world have been asked to reserve the date so that they may participate.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Alaska Ai rlines is offering 1.1 million shares of common stock at$6.125 a shar e, to be sold through a Drexel Burnham Lambert group.

title: Tr BASEBALL YANKEES (AL) - Recalled Andre Robertson, sh ortstop, from Columbus farm club in American Associationto help fill in for Bucky Dent, regular shortstop. Dent will be out three to five weeks with broken right hand. BALTIMORE (AL) - Purchased con tract of Willie Royster, catcher, from Charlotte of Southern Leag ue. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Signed Joe Ferguson, reserve catcher and a free agent from the Los Angeles Dodgers. CHICAGO (AL) - Put Francis co Barrios, right-handed pitcher, on waivers to release him unconditi onally. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Manager Dave Garcia to new one-year contract. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Traded Grant Jackson, lefthanded re lief pitcher, to Montreal Expos for cash or player to benamed. ST. LO UIS (NL) - Sold Donnie Moore, left-handed pitcher with Springfield i n American Association, to Milwaukee Brewers. Recalled six players f rom Springfie
description: fifth-year safety who was released during training camp.TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Signed Theo Bell, wide receiver cut by the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Sports People; Surgery for Westphal
description: Thirty-year-old Paul Westphal, the All-Star guard for the Seattle SuperSonics who suffered his third stress fracture nine days ago in a pickup game, will undergo surgery tomorrow at Swedish Hospital in Seattle. He will have a screw inserted into his right foot.

title: BRAXTON VS. SCOTT: A RAHWAY GRUDGE
description: Proudly, Dwight Braxton w ill return Saturday to Rahway (N.J.) State Prison, where he took par t in the boxing program and, risking an opportunity for a world title fight, he will meet James Scott in a nationally televised light-h eavyweight match.

title: Arvida Gets Florida Bid
description: Amid speculation that the Prudential Insurance Company of America is negotiating the acquisition of the Penn Central Corporation's Arvida unit, a Florida investment group said yesterday that it had offered between $300 million and $350 million in cash for the landrich development concern.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Law and justice do not gauge the seriousness of a homicide by the caliber of the deceased victim.

title: DRUG MAY BE EFFECTIVE TREATING BREAST CANCER
description: Many women past menopause who have advanced breast cancer spreading to other areas of the body may avoid some of surgery by using a drug originally developed for other purposes, researchers reported today.

title: MISSISSIPPI'S REDISTRICTING PLAN UPSETS BLACKS
description: Over strong opposition from black legislators, the Mississippi Legislature has approved a Congressional redistricting plan that makes only minimal changes in the present five districts so as to equalize their populations.

title: Advertising; Del Webb, Hallmark Also Change Agencies
description: Del Webb Hotels has checked in with Wells Rich Greene for promotion, as well as advertising, effective yesterday. The business was worth $9 million last year, the client says.

title: JAPAN HINTS AT SHIFT ON IRAN PROJECT
description: The Japanese Government has approved the withdrawal of the Mitsui Group from its $3.17 billion petrochemical project in southern Iran, signaling an end to Japan's largest and most troubled foreign investment project, Japanese newspapers reported today.

title: Player's Suicide Disputed
description: Ron Settles, the Long Beach State football star, did not die by hanging himself, as the police said, but ''at the hands of another other than by accident,'' a coroner's inquest jury found today. The verdict came after nine days of testimo ny.

title: Design Notebook; VESTIBULE: THE TRANSITION INTO A HOUSE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paula Deitz, co-editor of The Hudson Review, is a guest columnist.

title: Going Out Guide
description: VONNEGUT REVIVAL Taking a li ttle of this and a little of that from his novels and stories, Kurt Vonnegut came up with a play, ''Between Time and Timbuktu.'' I t was first produced on public television in 1971 and starred Willi am Hickey. Then, in 1975, a stage version, also by Mr. Vonnegut, had its New York premiere at the New York Theater Ensemble,which will re vive the play starting tonight at 8.

title: Firestone Changes
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said it is combining its corporate development activity and diversified products operations into a new corporate development group.

title: Ralph Ostrove Is Dead; Clo thing Store Founder
description: Ralph Ostrove, founder and chairman of the board of Paul Stuart Inc., the men's clothing store at Madison Avenue and 45th Street, died Tuesday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after a brief illness. He was 83 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: Central African Military Forms a Government
description: The army chief of staff declared himself head of state today and named an all-military Government, one day after seizing power from President David Dacko. The chief of staff, Gen. Andre Kolingba, also took over as chief of government, Minister of Defense and MInister of War Veterans and VIctims.

title: SOURCES FOR TABLE TOPS AND BASES
description: Often all one ends up with is the base or legs for a future coffee table, so a good source for glass can prove helpful. Paramount Glass, 166 Lexington Avenue, between 30th and 31st Streets (532-0820), and Manhattan Shade and Glass, 1297 Third Avenue, between 74th and 75th Streets (876-2800), sell four colors of glass as well as clear. Black and white glass comes in thicknesses up to a quarter of an inch, and bronze, gray and clear glass comes in thicknesses up to three-quarters of an inch. The stores will cut it to your specifications, polish or bevel its edges and deliver in the New York area. A piece of clear glass, 18 inches by 24 inches, and three-quarters of an inch thick, costs about $85.

title: BANKS' PLEA ON PARIS TAKEOVER
description: Sitting in the ornate room on the Rue d'Antin, where Napoleon married Josephine in 1796, Pierre Moussa, head of the Banque de Paris et des Pays Bas, regarded as one of France's most dynamic investment banks, worries about divorce.

title: WHITES IN RICHMOND LOSE DISTRICTING PLEA
description: The Justice Department has approved a redistricting plan for the Richmond, Va., City Council over protests from white voters that it unfairly diluted their voting strength.

title: TERRORIST GROUP IN WEST GERMANY SAYS IT SET OFF BOMB AT U.S. BASE
description: A group identifying itself as the Red Army Faction, the name Andreas Baader and Ulrike Meinhof gave to their terrorist organization before they died, said today that it was responsible for the explosion Monday at the United States Air Base at Ramstein, West Germany.

title: Home Improvement; BASIC TOOL KIT: A MUST FOR EVERY HOME
description: BY BERNARD GLADSTONE In these days of high labor costs, hard-to-find professional help, and continuing problems of poor quality in both labor and materials, people who might never think of doing their own home repairs are finding that they really have no choice -- they have to do at least some of their own work themself.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's economic recovery program, despite the successes of his first seven months, appears to be entering its most critical and vulnerable phase, both supporters and critics of the program are saying.

title: The Region; Uprising Blocked At the Essex Jail
description: NEWARK (UPI) - Correction officers at the Essex County Jail Annex, acting on a tip from a prison informant, confiscated an arsenal of contraband weapons intended for use in an uprising, officials said.

title: No Headline
description: An article yesterday about a revival of the film ''Best Boy'' gave an incorrect date for its opening. It will start tomorrow at the Embassy Theat er, Broadway and 72d Street.

title: BRITAIN'S TRADE SURPLUS SET A RECORD LAST YEAR
description: Britain achieved a record balance of payments surp lus in 1980, the Central Statistical Office reported today in its annual report.

title: Advertising; New Shops for Emery, Pearle and Ponderosa
description: More major accounts, a surprisingly large number for this time of year, have moved to new agencies. Pearle Vision Centers, the Dallas-based chain of eye care centers, has moved its account, which bills about $15 million annually, to Foote, Cone & Belding/Chicago.

title: Indictment in Slaying Case
description: The wife of a key suspect in the slaying of a Federal judge has been charged with using a fictitious name to buy a rifle 12 days before the slaying. Jo Ann Starr Harrelson was arrested here yesterday, hours after she was indicted. The Federal authorities have identified her husand, Charles Harrelson, as a key figure in the investigation of the slaying of Judge John Wood Jr. on May 29, 1979.

title: A SHARP FOCUS ON WORLD OF RORSCHACH
description: No ink blot jokes, no ink blot happy hour, and, in fact, no ink blots were evident today as the International Rorschach Society cast a businesslike silhouette in convening to exchange the latest news about its 60-year-old diagnostic speciality.

title: U.S.-SOVIET TALKS ON ARMS PACT OPEN
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have opened preliminary talks on the key issue of how to verify compliance with future arms control agreements, the State Department said today.

title: A SURPRISING MOVE BY N.&W.
description: For decades, the Norfolk & Western Railway has been the lifeblood of much of the coal region of the eastern United States, transporting the coal from the mines across mountains and rivers to markets here and abroad.

title: Sports People; Pastorini in Demand
description: The Kansas City Chiefs have turned their attention to Dan Pastorini, the quarterback released by the Oakland Raiders. ''We've been in touch with his agent,'' said Jim Scharf, the Chiefs' general manager, ''and we are in the process of working out a date for him to come in next week.''

title: News Analysis
description: As he looks toward the likelihood of another four years of running City Hall, Mayor Koch faces the prospect that his tasks will be shaped by circumstances that appear quite different, and less favorable, than what they seemed only a few months ago.

title: No Headline
description: Long Island

title: HARTFIELD-ZODY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Sears Doubles Armstrong Stake
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company has doubled its stake in the Armstrong Rubber Company to 20 percent, but a Sears spokesman said that the move is an investment, not the first step in a Sears takeover.

title: TROUBLES IN ISRAEL'S DIAMOND TRADE
description: Israeli banks, which for years have profited by financing the diamond industry, are now facing large losses on those loans as the nation's biggest industrial export business falls on tough times.

title: Ailing Cananas 'Forced' to Play
description: Roberto Cabanas, the Cosmos midfielder who has been complaining of back spasms lately, said today that the club ''doesn't believe that I am injured.''

title: Advertising; Chrysler Ad Chief Opens Fire
description: DOYLE LOTT was a fighter pilot in World War II, and now, as the Chrysler Corporation's new advertising director, he and his lieutenant are looking to zap the competition.

title: Injury Ends Career Of Genuine Risk
description: There was an empty stall in Barn 26 at Belmont Park yesterday morning. Its former resident had eaten from the bale of hay that hung next to the door, sipped from her pail of bottled spring water, then stepped onto a trailer bound for Virginia. Genuine Risk, the whitenosed filly who last year won the Kentucky Derby and the affection of millions who rarely watch a horse race, was going home for good.

title: GUESTS AND HOSTS: HEAVY SEAS AHEAD
description: The weather? Warm. The sky? Luminous. The sea? A poem. There is nothing else like it, for men who go down to the sea in ships for the weekend: it is the Labor Day holiday, the last chance for sailors and their guests to bid farewell to the buoys of summer.

title: Books Of The Times
description: PRETENDER TO THE THRONE. The Further Adventures of Private Ivan Chonkin. By Vladimir Voinovich. Trans- lated from the Russian by Richard Lourie. 358 pages. Farrar Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: VAIL ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
EX-PATIENT HELD
description: A physician for the Veterans Administration was shot to death yesterday, apparently by a legless man in a wheelchair who had been waiting outside the doctor's office at the V.A. hospital at First Avenue and 24th Street, the police said.

title: Notes on People; Erich Segal Returns Home, to Yale
description: ''I feel just like Ulysses,'' said the classical scholar. ''It took him 10 years to come home, too.'' The scholar was Erich Segal, and yesterday he taught his first class at Yale since he left a decade ago to find fame, writing ''Love Story'' and other novels and films, and, not just coincidentally, also to find a few million dollars.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.00-20.50 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: New Face; BRINGING AN EERIE WARMTH TO 'MR. SLOANE'
description: IN the Off Broadway hit ''Entertaining Mr. Sloane,'' Maxwell Caulfield plays a most unusual character. ''Mr. Sloane'' - his first name is never given - is a lower-class young Cockney who lives with a middle-age landlady and her homosexual brother, both desperately lonely souls who viciously compete for Mr. Sloane's affections.

title: Rules Revoked on Suits Over Published Secrets
description: Attorney General William French Smith revoked Carter Administration rules today on suing Government employees for publishing official secrets without approval.

title: EGYPT ARREST MOSLEMS AND COPTS
description: The Egyptian Government today announced the arrests of Moslems and Christians accused of fomenting religious strife.

title: U.S. WELFARE PLAN TO REQUIRE CHECK ON FAMILY ASSETS
description: The Reagan Administration has devised a proposal that would require state agencies to assess most of the personal property and household effects of welfare recipients.

title: IN JAPAN, A TV STAR SEEKS TO REFORM EDUCATION
description: At the age of 6, Tetsuko Kuroyanagi was already labeled a problem child. Her elementary school teacher asked her mother to withdraw her from school for such offenses as staring out of the window and opening and closing her desk top too often.

title: Envoy's Car Is Bombed Near Russian Mission
description: A car with diplomatic license plates parked near the Soviet Mission to the United Nations was firebombed at 1:15 A.M. this morning, slightly damaging the car and causing no injuries, the police said

title: PUBLISHING: ETHNIC CLASSIC KEEPS COMING BACK
description: IN 1943, Houghton Mifflin published ''Mount Allegro'' by Jerre Mangione, an account of growing up in a Sicilian neighborhood in Rochester. The book has since had three other publishers and has come out as both fiction and nonfiction, as an adult book and as a book for young adults. Next month it will be reissued by Columbia University Press and, in what will be the third introduction to the book, the sociologist Herbert J. Gans describes it as ''a classic of American ethnic literature.''

title: FOR VAN ARSDALE, GLORY DAYS AS LABOR'S POLITICAL BROKER ARE NOW IN THE
description: PAST By MICHAEL ORESKES

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; DECOY ART ON 53D ST.
description: Decoys are indigenous to America; they are also examples of folk art. You may see them in the water and on the beach, in living rooms in Connecticut and in little shops on Third Avenue. If you want to see the best of the genuine article, however, visit the Museum of American Folk Art today. There are 70 decoys, not only for ducks, but for Canadian geese, mergansers, plovers and curlews, from New England, the Illinois River, the Delaware River, Chesapeake Bay and Long Island. Most of them are of wood, carved with simple tools in economical technique, but a few are made of canvas, leather or papier-mache, and they can be seen until Nov. 8. When you tire of decoys, look at the other exhibits in the museum, at 49 West 53d Street, which specializes in all kinds of folk art from Colonial times to the present. It is open today 10:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Admission is $1; for the elderly and students, 50 cents. For information, call 581-2474.

title: Around the World; Damascus Bomb Blast Is Reported to Kill 20
description: At least 20 people were killed and 50 wounded today in an explosion of a booby-trapped car in front of the Syrian Air Force headquarters in a busy section of Damascus, travelers from the Syrian capital said.

title: NOTED ARCHEOLOGIST AND MUSEUM CHIEF
description: Hugh O'Neill Hencken, a leading American archeologist who specialized in the Iron Age in Europe, died Monday at a nursing home on Cape Cod. He was 79 years old.

title: WILSON, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Name Changed By Shearson
description: Shearson Loeb Rhoades, the securities firm, has changed its name to Shearson/American Express, reflecting its acquisition last June by the American Express Company.

title: ART: SENDAK AND FRIENDS AT THE MORGAN LIBRARY
description: THE Pierpont Morgan Library has been big on maintenance this last week or two, and you can just about see your fa ce in the marble floor. But it 's what's on the walls that matters, and the good news is that the M organ has reopened with three very good exhibitions. They don't lo ok on paper as if they would work well together, but as it turns out they complement one another very well.

title: NIGHT OF FREE MOVIES IN CENTRAL PARK
description: A hill in Central Park will become a movie theater Sunday night, and when, at about 8:30, the house lights dim - the sun, that is - a program of short films by independent film makers will unfold on a giant screen.

title: General Host Sells Units to Bar-S
description: Bar-S Food Company, a newly formed Phoenixbased concern, disclosed that it has purchased two slaughterhouses, a half-interest in a processing plant and several regional distribution centers from the General Host Corporation for $28 million.

title: Giants Are Hurting, but Jets Are Hopeful
description: The Giants are not ready for the start of the season because of continuing position changes, some dictated by injuries, and the Jets begin with guarded optimism. Both will face formidable opponents Sunday, the Giants taking on the National Conference champions, the Philadelphia Eagles, at home, and the Jets playing on the road against the Buffalo Bills, the American Conference Eastern division champions.

title: Lampert Dancers Hope To Teach in Arkansas
description: A New York dance troupe that had planned to teach in Arkansas schools this year has moved to the state on faith that the Legislative Council will eventually approve its contract.

title: MAGNETIC CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After nonrecurring gain of $307,000 from sale of patent rights and know-how to Hewlett-Packard

title: 15% Pay Cuts At Bunker Hill
description: Union workers at the financially troubled Bunker Hill Company here have approved a 15 percent wage rollback and employee stock-buying plan aimed at saving the mining and smelting center. The United Steelworkers of America local joined six craft unions late Wednesda y night in approving the wage rollback and employee purchase plan .

title: Notes on People; Yellow-Brick Road
description: The road to Oz, Kans., starts with a single yellow brick, according to the visionary plans of Buddy Piper. He plans to lay it today on a bleak prairie 20 miles southeast of Dodge City.

title: SUN ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $655,000 and $200,000 in latest qr and prior period, respectively... C-Net loss after loss from discontinued operations of $2,079,000...D-After loss from discontinued operations of $283,000

title: No Headline
description: Connecticut

title: WHAT IS KILLING NEWSPAPERS
description: To the Editor:

title: WYETH AND A NEIGHBOR STRUGGLE OVER DAM AND CULVERT
description: Here, where arching trees shade the the historic Brandywine River as it flows past quiet glades and grazing cows, even the rippling of water through a culvert in a dam seems to whisper tranquillity.

title: Around the World; West German Assails Attack at U.S. Base
description: The West German Government has assured the United States of its ''abhorrence'' at Monday's bomb attack on the United States Air Base at Ramstein in a message from Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., a spokesman said today.

title: REAGAN AIDE TOLD MILITARY CUTS WOULD PERIL U.S.
description: Deputy Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci told Edwin Meese 3d, the Presidential counselor, in an unannounced meeting today that proposed cuts in planned military budgets would jeopardize national security and send the wrong signals to the Soviet Union and America's allies, officials in the Reagan Administration reported.

title: Auctions; Fall season previewed.
description: THE fall auction season, which begins next week, will offer possessions that once sweetened the lives of the titled and the famous. Among them are a sapphire-and-diamond necklace made in the 19th century for Queen Maria Christina de Bourbon of Spain, Martha du Pont's dolls, the Surrealist paintings collected by the art dealer Julien Levy, the Howard and Jean Lipman collection of American folk art and a Colt revolver worn half a century ago by Charles A. Lindbergh. In specialty sales between now and Christmas, the accent is on the offbeat, ranging from Disneyana and whaling artifacts to Chinese fan paintings.

title: Season with plays by both Shaffers a possibility in '82.
description: THE Shaffer twins of Britain, who have written their way to fame and fortune, could both have plays running on Broadway this season. Peter Shaffer already has a hit on the boards: ''Amadeus.'' His brother Anthony, the author of ''Sleuth,'' the long-running thriller, is aiming for an April opening of ''Whodunnit,'' his murder mystery that ran in London in 1979 under the title ''The Case of the Oily Levantine.''

title: ALEC WAUGH, 83, AUTHOR OF 'ISLAND IN THE SUN'
description: Alec Waugh, the author of 50 books during a career that spanned nearly 65 years and who was best known for ''Island in the Sun,'' died yesterday in Tampa (Fla.) General Hospital, two weeks after suffering a stroke. He was 83 years old.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After gains from the sale of rental properties of $141,000 in the latest qr and $93,000 in yr ago period and $151,000 for the current 6 mos and $1,593,000 a yr earlier...C-Net income; company does not report shr earnings

title: Crown Cork Signs Consent Decree
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused Crown Cork and Seal Company, a Philadelphia bottling manufacturer, of violating Federal securities laws through the payment of $5.9 million to a corporation controlled by a former official of the General Cinema Corporation.

title: Foreign Affairs; THE POOREST OF THE POOR
description: The way development problems have evolved and perceptions changed in the last decade is reflected in the current United Nations conference here.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Bolt Technology Corp. announced an initial public offering of one million shares of its common stock at a price of $13.75 per share, to be sold through an L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin group.

title: Bonn Reaches Accord On an Austerity Budget
description: After weeks of bitter public disputes among the Bonn coalition parties over ways to cut spending, the West German Government reached a compromise today on an austerity program for 1982 that is expected to net about $7 billion through savings and tax increases.

title: Union Delegates Focus On Controllers' Strike
description: Although President Reagan avoided mentioning the air controllers' strike until the end of his speech to the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners, the subject was foremost in the minds of many convention delegates.

title: S ports People; A Bitter Bobby Unser
description: Bobby Unser says he has become disillusioned with auto racing and may pass the Indianapolis 500 in the future. Unser won the race in May but was placed second, behind Mario Andretti, after he was penalized a lap for passing cars during a yel low caution period.

title: R.J. Reynolds Unit
description: Gerald H. Long, 53 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, the largest unit of R.J. Reynolds Industries. Effective Oct. 1, he succeeds Edward A. Horrigan Jr., 51, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer of the big Winston-Salem, N.C., company, the nation's largest producer of cigarettes.

title: Swedish Match Buying GAF Unit
description: The GAF Corporation, which has been undergoing a major restructuring, announced that it will sell its flooring business to Tarkett, part of the Swedish Match Group, for $56.6 million.

title: TIANT WINS HIS FIRST GAME FOR PIRATES
description: Bill Madlock hit two doubles and drove in two runs, leading a 15-hit Pittsburgh attack that gave Luis Tiant his first National League victory as the Pirates beat the San Diego Padres, 7-3, today.

title: 28 WAYS (AT LEAST) TO ENJOY LABOR DAY HOLIDAY
description: LABOR will have its first parade in New York in 13 years Monday morning, with marching plumbers shouldering their plungers like drill rifles, with pr inters in regulation apron-and -folded-paper-hat uniform, with dozens of floats, 150 bands and members of the several performing unions of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. singin g, dancing and acting their way up Fifth Avenue from 26th to 52d St reet.

title: Transactions;
description: BASKETBALL

title: Rensis Likert, Founder Of Social Study Group
description: Dr. Rensis Likert, a renowned social scientist who was the first director of the Institute for Social Research at the University of Michigan, died today. He was 78 years old.

title: Sharp Loss Reported at AGIP, B.P.; Dollar Strength Blamed in Part
description: Two of Europe's leading oil companies reported today a sharp deterioration in earnings, and both said the strength of the dollar was partly to blame. British Pet roleum, the world's sixth-largest oil company, said its profit in the second quarter was $388 million, about half its firstquarter earnings of $762 million. The earnings also were more than half tho se of the second quarter in 1980, when B.P. reported profits of $7 16 million.

title: BLACK HILLS POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CARTER, ENDING CHINA TRIP, STRESSES TAIWAN ISSUE
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said here today that differences over Taiwan now constituted the main obstacle in improving Chinese-American relations.

title: FRASER MORTGAGE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Yr to May 31

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. - I had hoped in college and graduate school to learn to read literature for its political meaning. But I found, in the years I was there - the late 1960's and early 70's - that the business got turned around. It was literature, the poetic imagination, that became the best guide to reading and understanding the often terrifying political events of those years.  Terror, I saw, was theater, and we all collaborated in its productions.
description: Those years, many thought, were a time of breakdowns - of imperial power, of social roles, of ''law and order.'' One epoch was ending but another far better one would be born. The long unexpressed desires of working people, women, blacks and the third world, of those who had too long been silent, would find expression. This season of change meant that it was a time of great anxiety for those who felt instability in their worlds. And this anxiety was felt in all classes and groups in America, even those that hoped to see their desires realized.

title: LOW RAINFALL IN AUGUST COULD PORTEND SHORTAGE
description: After four months of plentiful rainfall, a drastically dry August has renewed concern about a possible water shortage like the one that developed last winter.

title: Economic Scene; Wall St. Brake On Militar
description: MOSCOW must be in a state of utter confusion over the Reagan Administration's military planning. The Communist line has long maintained that capitalism could thrive only in an environment of war and aggression. Their argument was that, in capitalist countries, the rate of return on domestic investment tended to fall, causing the economy to founder; this stagnation could be cured only by increasing defense expenditures and foreign military adventures.

title: Money-Fund Assets Up, To Double Jan.1 Level
description: The nation's money market funds passed the $150 billion mark during the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute announced yesterday.

title: REAGAN MUST CURB WAGES AND PRICES
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop Jazz; JOHNNY COPELAND, A BLUES FIND FROM TEXAS, AT TRAMPS
description: JOHNNY COPELAND'S reputation preceded him a few weeks ago when he made an underadvertised appearance at Tramps, the intimate blues and soul club at 125 East 15th Street near Irving Place. Mr. Copeland's few recordings from the 1950's and 60's were little known, and he had made only one album, ''Copeland Special,'' recently released on the small Rounder label. But word had been circulating that Johnny Copeland was a blues singer, guitarist, and songwriter of uncommon talent and intensity, and ecstatic reviews were starting to come in. A sizable crowd turned out.

title: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1981; The Economy
description: Thrift institutions, acceding to the I.R.S., modified the bonus packages they are offering to promote the new tax-exempt savings certificates. They will continue to offer high-interest accounts as an incentive to purchase the certificates, but they will protect the tax-exempt status of the interest on the certificates by making their purchase optional. (Page A1.) The I.R.S. formally withdrew tax exemptions for any certificates bought as a requirement of the bonus plans rather than as voluntary purchases. (D4.)

title: CORNING SEEKS TO SELL OWENS-CORNING INTEREST
description: The Corning Glass Works said yesterday that it would attempt to sell its 23.9 percent interest in the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation. The announcement came after Corning abandoned its previously undisclosed efforts to arrange a friendly merger with the Toledo-based building materials company.

title: By Charlotte Evans
description: Westchester Music will fill the Labor Day weekend air S unday as seven county parks play host to the Citibank Summer Music Festival. The simultaneous musical events begin at 2 P.M., and admission is free. Leading things off will be a country and west ern concert at Muscoot Farm in Somers featuring the Southern Cooking Band. The five-member band, headed by Bob Sterling, has a preferenc e for hard country, Texas country and Waylon Jennings and Willie Nelson-type sounds, with a sprinkling of 1950's rock-and-roll.

title: NATIONAL UTILITIES & INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IDEAL TOY CORP reports earnings for 13 weeks July 30
HAITIANS FLEE AMID PROTEST AT HOLDING CENTER IN MIAMI
description: About 50 Haitians detained at a refugee camp south of here pushed through a barbed-wire fence early this morning and fled into the nearby swamps of the Everglades National Park, but by midafternoon all but five had been recaptured, Federal officials said.

title: 20 TONS OF MARIJUANA AND 33 SEIZED IN L.I. RAIDS
description: Coast Guardsmen and Federal agents armed with rifles and shotguns seized 33 men and 20 tons of Colombian marijuana early today in raids on a smugglers' beachfront landing ground here and a rusty, 80-foot trawler on Block Island Sound.

title: CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Index; International
description: Polish party insists on right to ap- point plant managers A3 Soviet denies maneuvers starting today are unusual A3 World scientists call for freeze on nuclear arms A3 Egypt announces arrests in reli- gious strife A3 Around the World A5 General Around the Nation A6 Fifty Haitian refugees flee deten- tion center near Miami A6 Supreme Court nominee assailed at anti-abortion rally A8 Thousands of letters roll off Am- trak's Night Owl mail car B2 Harlem church to build condo- minium development B3 Many developers expected to sub- mit plans for Times Sq. B3 Glory days are past for Harry Van Arsdale B3 HOLIDAY WEEKEND Monday is Labor Day. Following are holiday schedules: Parade - Begins 11 A.M., north on Fifth Avenue from 26th to 52d Street, then east on 52d Street to Third Avenue. Parking - Sunday regulations in effect; alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices -Closed. Post offices - Closed; only special delivery and express mail delivered. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Subways and buses on Sunday schedules; commuter rail lines on holiday schedules; special bus lanes suspended. Libraries - Closed.Schools - Closed.

title: 17.22 DROP PUTS DOW AT 867.01
description: Stock market prices plunged again yesterday, apparently because of renewed concern over high interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had managed slight gains on Tuesday and Wednesday, fell 17.22 points yesterday, to 867.01, its lowest level in almost 15 months.

title: RICHARD BAKER, 68, PROFESSOR WHO HELD PULITZER POST, DIES
description: Richard T. Baker, a professor of journalism at Columbia University for 34 years and retired secretary of the Pulitzer Prize Board, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old.

title: REAGAN ADDRESSES UNION CONVENTION
description: In his first speech to an organized labor group since he dismissed 12,000 striking air controllers, President Reagan told the convention of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners today that the members of the controllers' union had to be let go because they broke the law.

title: NEW UNIT TO FIGHT FOOD STAMP FRAUD
description: Officials of t hree Go vernment agencies have decided to set up a special unit, based here, to coordinate investigations of large-scale fraud in food s tamps around the country, Justice Department officials said to day.

title: Canadian Yield Dips
description: The average yield on this week's issue of 91-day tre asury bills fell slightly to 20.44 percent from last week's 20.82 percent, the Bank of Canada said today. Its bank rate, the country's official lending rate, fell to 20.69 percent from 21.07percent.

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After a loss of $42,000 from discontinued operations

title: I.R.S DENIES TAX EXEMPTION FOR SAVING TIED TO BONUSES
description: The Internal Revenue Service today announced a set of regulations for the new tax-free savings certificates that will permit banks and thrift institutions to continue to offer highinterest bonuses this month as an inducement to purchase the certificates on Oct. 1.

title: MOSCOW SAYS MANEUVERS NEAR POLAND ARE NORMAL
description: The Soviet Union said today that military maneuvers scheduled to start tomorrow near Poland were routine exercises and that Western statements to the contrary were ''malicious, anti-Soviet rumors.''

title: Sports People; Natt Wants an Answer
description: Calvin Natt and the Portland Trail Blazers are at odds. Natt, a young forward, wants the Trail Blazers to tel l him if he will be withthem before the season, and Stu Inman, the ge neral manager, cannot provide the answer.

title: ANGOLA CHARGES NEW DRIVE BY THE SOUTH AFRICAN FORCES
description: Angolan officials charged here today that South African troops had begun a new drive deep into southern Angola east of the area where the South African raid began on Aug. 24.

title: Crosby in Round of 16
description: Nineteen-year-old Nathaniel Crosby, son of Bing Crosby, was among the 16 survivors after two rounds of match play today at the 81st United States Amateur Championship. Crosby, of Hillsborough, Calif., beat a Walker Cup player, Frank Fuhrer of Pittsburgh, in the opening round, then beat Bob Wolcott of the University of Georgia, taking both matches 2 and 1. Joe Rassett, the Californian who won honors in the two rounds of medal qualifying, was eliminated in his afternoon match on the 6,679-yard Olympic Club Lake Course.

title: The Evening Hours
description: T HIS week is, as most weeks have been recently, Elizabeth Taylor time in the city. More so since ''The Little Foxes'' closes tomorrow night and there will be no more excitements such as her fire truck escort the other night.

title: Sports People; Martin Back in Exile
description: Billy Martin, who usually does not give up easily, has given up.

title: Plessey Profit Up
description: Plessey Inc., a London-based technology company, reported yesterday that its net income in the first fi scal quarter, ended July 3, rose 34.1 percent, to $29.9 million, or $1 .24 per American Depositary Receipt, from $22.3 million, or 93 cents an A.D.R., a yearearlier.

title: U.S. IS BEATEN BY CANADA, 8-3
description: After allowing the United States to play even for 50 minutes, Canada overwhelmed the Americans with five goals in the third period to win, 8-3, in their Canada Cup game at the Edmonton Coliseum tonight.

title: IN DEFENSE OF THE INSANITY DEFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
1-YEAR U.S. BILLS AT RECORD; 15.06% Yield At Auction
description: The Treasury yesterday sold one-year bills that determined the yield on the new tax-exempt savings certificates. The bills had a record rate of 15.06 percent on a discounted basis.

title: AILING STEEL PLANT RECOVERS
description: For John Durkin, a longtime steel executive, it has meant 12-hour days in a new career, when all he had in prospect was the hope of early retirement. For James A. Sepesky, the Mayor of this city, it has meant adding to services rather than dealing with a fiscal crisis.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I can't think of anything more insane than to carry out the advice of those who say that I should denounce him on a soapbox.

title: new york times reports earnings for kill this abstract
South Africans Say Guerrillas Killed 4 in a Black Homeland
description: Black guerrillas armed with automatic weapons and hand grenades stormed a police station last night in Bophuthatswana, a black homeland granted independence by South Africa, officials said today. They said four people, including two policemen and a 3-ye ar-old boy, were killed.

title: Newark Airport Reports Delays
description: NEWARK (AP) - Flight delays of up to two hours were reported at Newark International Airport.

title: INMATE IS SLAIN
description: An inmate was stabbed to death outside his cell at the Clinton Correctional Facility here, the state police said.

title: 20,000 LETTERS POUR ON TRACKS AS A DOOR OPENS IN ROWAYTON
description: It wasn't snow, rain, heat or even the gloom of night that stopped the mail dead on the tracks in Norwalk, Conn., yesterday - it was an open door on the mail car of Amtrak's Night Owl.

title: LANE BRYANT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Around the World; 3 Cambodian Factions A gree on Coalition Pact
description: The Communist forces of the former Cambodian Prime Minister, Pol Pot, and representatives of two other Cambodian factions agreed today on a joint statement of intention to form a coalition government to oppose the Vietnamese occupation of their country.

title: BANKS TO MODIFY HIGH-YIELD OFFERS
description: Banks and savings and loan institutions said yesterday that they would continue to offer consumers accounts yielding high interest as a lure to sell savings certificates on Oct.1. But they said they would protect the tax-exempt status of interest on the certificates by making their purchase optional.

title: CENCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After a tax credit of $2.4 million and $1,000 from discontinued operations...C-After a tax credit of $2 million and a gain of $746,000 from discontinued operations; 1980 results were restated due to company sale of various businesses

title: SCIENTISTS AT PARLEY URGE ATOM ARMS FREEZE
description: Alarmed over the intensification of the arms race, scientists from the United States, the Soviet Union and 38 other countries appealed here today for a freeze on the present levels of nuclear arsenals by the two major powers.

title: Fabric Flowers
description: Forty arrangements of flowers made of silk, cotton, gauze and velvet will be on view through next Thursday at the Nippon Club, 145 West 57th Street.

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: B-Net loss...C-LIFO adjustment produced a credit of $6.5 million in the qr and a $1.5 million charge for the yr

title: CRESTED BUTTE SILVER MINING INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
Books
description: Evil Among the Preppies By Randolph Hogan PEACE BREAKS OUT. By John Knowles. 193 pages. Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $10.95.

title: A WILDERNESS THAT EXPLORATION WOULD DOOM
description: To the Editor:

title: 47% RATE RISE GRANTED HACKENSACK WATER CO.
description: A 47 percent rate increase was granted today to the Hackensack Water Company, New Jersey's largest water supplier and the one most prone to shortages in periods of little rainfall.

title: At the Movies; Playing Joan Crawford's daughter.
description: AT the age of 26, Diana Scarwid is too young to remember most of Joan Crawford's fi lms. She saw ''Mildred Pier ce,'' in which she thought Miss Crawford's work was ''beautiful, '' but beyond that her knowledge of the late glamorous Hollywood que en is limited to what she has read in books.

title: SUI DOUBTS SAFETY OF NONPRESCRIPTION DRUGS
description: A lawsuit filed in Federal District Court here today asserts that ingredients contained in more than half the 300,000 over-the-counter drugs now on the market are of doubtful safety or effectiveness and seeks to force the Food and Drug Administration to ban the sale of all drugs containing these ingredients. Over-the-co unter drugs can be purchased without a physician's prescription and include pain killers, cough syrups, sleeping pills and cold reme dies.

title: Fed Declines To Intervene
description: The United States, pursuing an ''only when necessary'' approach toward intervening in foreign exchange markets, did not intervene at all for its own account in the second quarter, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said Thursday.

title: Judging the Prosecutors
description: Two contests for the office of district attorney, in Brooklyn and Queens, raise some of the most interesting questions and hardest choices of the quiet primary campaign. In both cases, the outcome of the Democratic primary is almost certain to determine the winner in November.

title: No Headline
description: Hudson Valley

title: Krugerrand Sales Down
description: International sales of the Krugerrand gold coin fell to 407,680 ounces in August from 1981's monthly peak of 447,080 sold in July, but were sharply above the 273,500 ounces sold in August 1980, the International Gold Corporation said today. The company, the gold marketing arm of the South African Government, said in a statement that sales for the year to date total 2.3 million ounces, against 1.7 million in the same 1980 period.

title: Sports of The Times; Television Feud
description: Acivil war is developing in college sports. Many of the top football schools are planning a new television liaison that could alter the structure of college athletics.

title: Jack Manning Transit Authority to Accept $20 Bills for Tokens John D. Simpson, center, president of the Transit Authority, and Daniel T. Scannell, left, vice chairman, conducting hearing yesterday in Br ooklyn.  The authority, spurred by complaints from City Council President
description: Carol Bellamy and others, decided to begin accepting $20 bills at subway token booths in about two weeks. The complainants reasoned that, since the fare rise to 75 cents, the $10 bill limit had become an anachronism.

title: News Analysis
description: Some years ago Maclean's, a prominent Canadian magazine, ran a contest challenging readers to complete the phrase, ''As Canadian as ...'' The winner was, ''As

title: SOUTH AND WEST LEAD THE NATION IN FERTILITY RATES
description: The Southern and Western states, their populations swollen by migration, also have higher fertility rates than other parts of the country, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: CHURCH IN HARLEM PLANS A TOWN-HOUSE PROJECT
description: A Roman Catholic church in Harlem, with city and Federal assistance, intends to build a 108-unit town-house development of duplex condominiums primarily for middle-income tenants.

title: WILTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After a tax loss carryforward credit of $104,000... C-After a liability reversal of $255,000 in qr and the 9 mos and tax credits of $319,000 in qr and $369,000 in the 9 mos...D-After a tax credit of $284,000

title: BUILDING UNION ENDORSES KOCH FOR RE-ELECTION
description: Praising Mayor Koch's support of big building projects like the Westway and the Third Water Tunnel, the operating engineers union yesterday endorsed him for renomination.

title: CLARK CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NIAGARA FRONTIER SERVICES reports earnings for Yr to June 27
CITY OPERA: 'SONG OF NORWAY' OPENS
description: ON Aug. 21, 1944, an operetta very loosely based on the art and life of Edvard Grieg, the patron saint of Norwegian music, opened on Broadway. For some reason, Norway did not immediately declare war on America. Or perhaps we just never heard about it. At any rate, ''Song of Norway'' went on to run for 860 performances and to find its way down through the years into theaters all over the world and even into the movies. Now it is back on Broadway, at Lincoln Center, where the New York City Opera last night revived the Robert Wright-George Forrest musical with exceptional attention to 40's style.

title: Boat Ride Starts Latin Music Weekend
description: Fans of salsa music can enjoy the show while sailing up the Hudson River on a crui se tonight, part of the sixth El Festival Latino, which is going on this weekend at various loc ations in the metropolitan area. The four-hour cruise aroun d Manhattan features El Gran Combo, Conjunto Clasico and Primitivo Sa ntos and leaves at 9 P.M. from the Dayliners' Pier 81, 12th Avenue and 41st Street; it returns at 1 A.M. Tickets are $17.

title: Japan Extends Loan
description: Japan has agreed to extend loans totaling 30.8 billion yen, or about $134 million, to India to help the country build a large fertilizer comp lex and three hydro-electricprojects, official sources said today.

title: No Headline
description: New Jersey

title: THEODORE ROSZAK, SCULPTOR OF EAGLE AT LONDON EMBASSY
description: Theodore Roszak, the sculptor known for his work in welded steel, died of a heart attack at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday. He was 74 years old.

title: McEnroe's Fine Clarified
description: The $5,000 fine levied yesterday against John McEnroe for ''aggravated behavior'' at this year's Wimbledon tennis championshipssurprised pra ctically no one, even McEnroe himself. Although a fine from the Men' s International Professional Tennis Council, which governs Grand Prix tournaments, was expected, there was some speculation a bout the possibility of a suspension for McEnroe, who won the Wimbl edon men's singles title.

title: B.A.T. Forms U.S. Subsidiary
description: B.A.T. Industries said today that it has formed an American subsidiary, the B.A.T. Capital Corporation, to raise short-term financing for working capital requirements in its American, British and West German operations.

title: PLESSEY CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings per American Depository Receipt; dollar amounts translated from pounds sterling at rate of one pound equals $1.90

title: Japan Car Sales Continue Slide
description: Japan's new automobile sales continued to decline during August, dropping nine-tenths of 1 percent from August 1980, the Japan Automobile Dealers Association said today. Sales for the month totaled 214,453, the association said.

title: NEW 'SONG OF NORWAY' AND ITS 2 EDVARD GRIEGS
description: The two Edvard Griegs now appearing on the stage of the New York City Opera don't look a thing like the original, but then operettas such as ''Song of Norway'' observe the right to decorate frail and vacillating protagonists with a few extra muscles - just to make the decor a little more romantic.

title: Elf Oil Find Off Angola
description: A French state-controlled oil company, Societe Nationale Elf Aquitaine, has struck oil with its first well in a new area off the coast of northern Angola, raising hopes of greater production from the African country, industry sources said today.

title: RADICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After tax credits of $707,400 for the qr and $1,100,000 for the yr...C-After a tax credit of $355,900

title: MERRILL SUES FOUR EX-OFFICIALS
description: Merrill Lynch says there are rustlers among the thundering herd. On Wednesday, the firm brought suit in New Orleans against four former account executives who left to work for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. According to Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, the nation's largest securities firm, the men used information from its customer files to lure clients to Drexel Burnham.

title: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1981
description: International Angola and South Africa exchanged charges over the raid by South African troops. Angolan officials in Lisbon charged that the troops had begun a new drive deep into southern Angola east of the area where the raid began on Aug. 24. A South African spokesman in Pretoria denounced the statement as ''ridiculous propaganda.'' (Page A4, Columns 1-2.) South Africa is withdrawing its forces from Angola, officials in the Reagan Admi nistration said, based on informat ion received in Washington. They said that if there was new f ighting in southeastern Angola it was between rival Angolans. (A1:2.)

title: LAMENT OF RECRUITER WHO GOT CAUGHT
description: It was late at night on Nov. 27, 1979, and Manny Goldstein was surprised to hear someone knocking at the door of his apartment. Goldstein, balding and paunchy, was then an assistant basketball coach at the University of New Mexico in Albuqurque. He opened the door and was met by two Federal Bureau of Investigation agents holding search warrants.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Bancshares, of Houston, said that it completed its merger with Jetero Bank.

title: Pan Am to Offer 2-for-1 Discounts
description: Pan American World Airways Inc., in an effort to increase ridership, said that it would offer two-for-one discount fares on certain overseas flights starting Sept.14.

title: Texas Lawmaker Is Indicted On Perjury Count in Shooting
description: State Representative Mike Martin was indicted toda y on charges of lying to a grand jury when he denied having himsel f shot.

title: Auto Layoffs Drop in Week
description: The number of temporary layoffs in the United States auto industry dropped sharply this week, but indefinite layoffs were virtually unchanged as domestic auto makers scheduled a 2.3 percent increase in production, according to industry reports released today.

title: Attempt to Rescue Karen E Described
description: A marina security guard testified that Richard K. Lublin, the sole survivor of a cabin-cruiser accident in Long Island Sound in which two persons died and three are missing, did not stay on the course the marina had ordered and did not wait for the marina's boat to rescue him.

title: Dow License Pact
description: The Dow Chemical Company said that ithas granted an exclusive license to market an d manufacture imbiber polymer products to an Arkansas-based polluti on control service company. Value of the accord was not disclose d. The license, obtained by EN-SCO Inc. of Eldorado, Ark., in cludes information on a number of patents on imbiber beads, fabricati on of valves, product usage and other items, the Midland-based comp any said. Imbiber polymers are used to absorb a variety of flui ds such as fuels, chlorinated solvents, and other similar mater ials.

title: BLOCK, SEEKING TO STABILIZE PRICES FOR WHEAT, TO CUT PLANTING 15%
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, in an abrupt reversal of his previous position, announced today that he would order a 15 percent reduction in 1982 wheat planting.

title: Meanwhile, Back in the Economy
description: It's a good thing President Reagan had a long California vacation back at the ranch. He'll need all the energy and imagination he can muster for the economic battle just ahead.

title: MRS. WILMA A. SZABO
description: Mrs. Wilma A. Szabo of Seekonk, Mass., a prominent breeder of Great Danes, died Monday at Marion Hospital in Providence, R.I. She was 44 years old. Mrs. Szabo owned the Juwil's Dane breeding kennel and was the former owner of the Tower Hill Pet Lodge, both in Rhode Island. She is survived by her husband, Paul, and her mother, Helen Gardzielick of East Rutherford, N.J. A service will be held at St. Peter and Paul Polish National Catholic Church in Passaic, N.J., tomorrow at 10 A.M.

title: FIRST PENNSYLVANIA MORTGAGE TRUST reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $23,298,000 from restructuring of debt and tax loss carryforward...C-Net loss

title: Plucknett Still Barred
description: The International Amateur Athletics Federation Council today rejected appeals for the reinstatement of two discus throwers, Ben Plucknett of the United States and Gael Mulhall of Australia, who were suspended after failing tests for unauthorized drugs at the Pacific Conference Games in New Zealand in February. The federation secretary, John Holt, said the council found no reason to lift the indefinite bans after an examination of the procedures used in the testing.

title: In the Nation; TOO HARD THE NOSE
description: The hard nose is a much-prized appendage among football players, Pentagon thinkers and political candidates. It is valued by Reaganites at par with cowboy boots. Jimmy Carter's lack of granite nostrils may have been his undoing, and no one may hope to be a conservative columnist without smearing concrete over his sinuses.

title: Former Machinist Rises To Be Chrysler Director
description: Three new directors were elected yesterday by the Chrysler Corporation. Two of them - J. Paul Sticht, chairman of R.J. Reynolds Industries, and John B. Naughton, executive vice president-sales and marketing of Chrysler - were names that might be found on any major corporate board. But the election of the third director, Stephan Sharf, Chrysler's executive vice president for manufacturing, marks what, in an earlier era, might have been a Horatio Alger story.

title: METS REGROUP AT HOME
description: The Mets limped home from Houston yesterday, and Manager Joe Torre conceded that their ambition to steal the second half of the split season had suffered a damaging week.

title: PLANS TO WEAKEN THE CLEAN AIR ACT CHARGED TO E.P.A.
description: After announcing a set of broad principles aimed at ''streamlining'' the Clean Air Act, the Environmental Protection Agency has gone on to draft detailed proposals that would weaken the law severely, several Congressmen said today.

title: U.N. Vote Would Deny Seat to South Africans
description: A special session of the General Assembly called to consider South Africa's refusal to grant South-West Africa independence today took the first step toward insuring that South Africa would not be heard.

title: Swiss Lift Bank Rates
description: The Swiss National Bank today tightened its grip on banks' liquidity in an anti-inflationary move that strengthened the Swiss franc significantly on currency exchange markets.

title: EXERPTS FROM REAGAN TALK TO CARPENTERS' UNION
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of President Reagan's speech to the convention of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters and Joiners in Chicago yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News.

title: TV Weekend; AN IRISH PATRIOT SPEAKS AND THE WASTE OF WAR
description: CAPPING the summer drought of new programming, this holiday weekend generally continues to mark time until the new season begins to dribble in over the next several weeks. Back on the schedule, perhaps bringing a measure of solace to the multitudes who are less than impressed with the truncated baseball season, is - are you ready? - football.

title: LABOR PARTY STARTS CRUCIAL CONTEST TO CHOOSE A SECOND IN COMMAND
description: The battle within the Labor Party moved into a new phase this week with the two sides firing their opening guns in the campaign for the deputy leadership.

title: Stabler Warrant Lifted
description: A California bench warrant for the arrest of Ken Stabler has been lifted, General Manager Ladd Herzeg of the Houston Oilers said today.

title: McCann Gets New Officers
description: Robert L. James, vice chairman of the Interpublic Group of Companies for the last year, is to become a vice chairman of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, Interpublic's largest operating unit.

title: JONES, QUISENBERRY STOP JOHN AND YANKEES, 3 TO 2
description: Dick Howser's Kansas City Royals beat the Yankees tonight, 3-2, and looked like a team ready to forget the first half of the season. It was Kansas City's third victory in four games under Howser, who replaced Jim Frey as manager on Monday.

title: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes $1,263,000 or 62 cents a shr from liquidation of LIFO inventories for the qr and $1,319,000 or 65 cents a shr for the 6 mos

title: ON 42ND STREET, A STREET FAIR THAT WORKS AT ENTERTAINING
description: At District 1199, small is not beautiful. The National Health and Hospital Workers Union, which seems incapable of doing anything on a small scale, is putting on its third annual Labor Day street fair. And even without fairgoers, the block on West 42d Street between Ninth and 10th Avenues will be crowded.

title: PUEBLO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for 13 weeks to Aug 1
description: B-After a pre-tax charge of $1,545,000...C-Net income

title: SOCIAL SECURITY'S KEYS TO ITS REHABILITATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Buys More U.S. Grain
description: The Soviet Union has purchased 400,000 more tons of American grain from private exporters, the Department of Agriculture said today. The 300,000 tons of wheat and 100,000 tons of corn are part of a recent flurry of purchases by the Kremlin under the newly extended grain agreement between the United States and Moscow. An additional 10 million tons or more will be made available for purchase by the Soviet Union, officials said.

title: Man Douses Wife With Gas And Sets Her Afire, Police Say
description: A Staten Island man doused his wife with gasoline and set her afire last night after an argument, the police said. The victim, Romona Pemberton, 33 years old, of 93 Winter Avenue in the New Brighton section, was treated for burns over 34 percent of her body at St. Vincent's Hospital on Staten Island and then flown by helicopter to the Jacobi Hospital burn center in the Bronx where she was listed in serious condition.

title: Around the Nation; Duke Faculty Unit Votes Against a Nixon Library
description: By a one-vote margin, Duke University's faculty representatives turned aside a personal appeal by the president of the university and voted today to urge the university's trustees not to build a Richard M. Nixon Presidential library next to the campus. The vote was 35 to 34.

title: POLAND AFFIRMING ECONOMIC CONTROL
description: The Polish Communist Party today indicated its intention to retain control over key issues in factories despite plans to decentralize management of the economy.

title: A Taste of the Past
description: There is a phenomenon visible to anyone who spends a Saturday at a New York City greenmarket. People familiar with snails, softshell crab and mu shi pork are mystified by lima beans in the shell.

title: Fenway's Longest Night
description: The longest game in the 69-year history of Fenway Park was suspended tonight after 19 innings with the Boston Red Sox and the Seattle Mariners tied at 7-7.

title: A SPECIAL FOLK NIGHT AT BOTTOM LINE
description: IN their nine years of performing together, the last three as a married couple, Mary McCaslin and Jim Ringer, who will be featured in a special night of folk music at the Bottom Line tomorrow, have come to exemplify a kind of musical integrity that may only flourish outside the mainstream of pop.

title: SANTA FE FESTIVAL: A NEW HARBISON PIANO QUINTET
description: THE Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival concert Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall offered an honest if not really distinguished performance of the Brahms Trio for clarinet, cello and piano in A minor (Op. 114) and a drab run-through of the Mozart Piano Quartet in G minor (K. 478). The Mozart was a particular disappointment, in that it featured Andre-Michel Schub. Compared to the sometimes wiry yet always intense and patrician account of the same piece recently at the Mostly Mozart Festival, this sounded slack and perfunctory.

title: Market Place; Put Options As 'Insurance'
description: IN its most popular application, the put option is a little like an insurance policy. If the underlying property is diminished in value, the option owner can recover the lost value.

title: Denial From Macro
description: James M. McLain, president of the Macro International Group, a New York commodity concern, yesterday denied charges in a lawsuit filed Wednesday by the Triad Energy Corporation and Everest Petroleum Inc. that Macro and William Hodgson, one of its salesmen, had helped Thomas and Samuel F. McNell loot the two companies. ''Neither Macro nor Mr. Hodgson performed any improper act, nor are they responsible for any losses suffered by Triad or Everest,'' Mr. McLain said.

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The 1980 figures were restated for an accounting change

title: Around the Nation; Little Rock Segregation Rejected by U.S. Judge
description: A Federal judge ruled today that the school district where one of the country's first desegregation battles was fought in 1957 could not return to segregated classes now to combat ''white flight.''

title: News Analysis
description: A month ago, President Reagan headed westward on vacation, riding the crest of big legislative victories, seeming almost politically invincible with the main pillars of his economic recovery program in place. His return to the capital today after his C alifornia sojourn was far less triumphant. He arrived by way of Chi cago, where he faced a tough union audience, endeavoring to explain away Wall Street's skeptical plunge over high interest rates and the prospect of inflationary budget deficits, under pressure to pull back from his own ambitious military buildup and confrontin g a tougher political climate. 'All This Gloom and Doom'

title: Sports People; But No Fatted Calf
description: Boise State has eased the penalty and is allowing Rick Rebozzi to return to school as a student if he chooses.

title: Sports People; Strike Talk Scotched
description: Ed Garvey, executive director of the National Football League Players Association, said the union preferred to settle its differences with the owners, rather than be forced into a strike.

title: BRITISH PETROLEUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: British at the rate of $1.93 to the pound; company did not report shr earnings

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A Giant From Princeton
description: Whatever happened to the Princetonclass of 1973 ? Ron Mancuso of Chicago is the youngest Cadillac dealer in the United States . Ed Swift is a successful novelist. Andre Schub won theVan Cliburn p iano competition. Brad Shingleton is chief resident in opthalmic sur gery at Massachusetts General Hosp ital. Charl es Scribner4th is in the family book-publishing business. Lisa Halaby is Queen of Jordan. And Carl Barisich, who holds a bachelor of scie nce degree in civil engineering, is a professional football player, t he only Princeton graduate in the National Football League.

title: ANN HARDING, ACTRESS HAILED FOR ROLES AS ELEGANT WOMEN
description: Ann Harding, who was known for her stage and screen portrayals of beautiful, aristocratic women in the 1920's and 30's, died Tuesday at her home in Sherman Oaks, Calif., after a long illness. She was 79 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A.B.A. Industries, Pinellas Park, Fla., has elected to its board Thomas A. James, president of Raymond, James & Associates.

title: Angola; Geography
description: With a 1,000-mile Atlantic coast that stretches from Zaire to South-West Africa, Angola has an area of 48l,000 square miles, larger than Texas and California combined.
