Rising from a narrow coastal plain, where Luanda, the capital is situated, most of Angola lies on a plateau at 3,000 to 5,000 feet above sea level. Natural zones include a desert in the south, tropical rain forest in the north and a temperate highland in the west and center .

title: About Real Estate; 48 OCEANFRONT TOWN HOUSES IN NASSAU
description: Nature has done Lawrence M. Reed a kindness. It has enlarged the oceanfront property he bought nine years ago in Atlantic Beach, a village of 2,500 year-round inhabitan ts just over the Queens line in Nassau County, by depositi ng three full acres of sand upon it.

title: Bechtel Contract
description: The Bechtel International Corporation announced it had received a $500 million contract to build a tourist resort in Sabah.

title: Clinton Americana
description: There will be an outdoor ''Salute to America'' with music and dance tomorrow night at 8 at the Clinton Historical Museum Village, 56 Main Street, in Clinton, N.J. The Talk of the Town Dancers, a group of professional and student dancers from Trenton, will dance to a medley of works by George M. Cohan, played by the Bob Smith Lamplighters, a band specializing in tunes from the 1940's and 50's.

title: A JERRY HERMAN SALUTE TO HIS MUSICAL WOMEN
description: ''I'M entertained twice as much when a lady's on stage as when a man's on stage,'' Jerry Herman was saying the other day. ''It began with Ethel Merman. My parents were very smart. The first show they took me to was 'Annie Get Your Gun.' I've been addicted to that kind of theater ever since.''

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 1981

title: GOVERNMENT'S PUBLICATIONS LIST TO KEEP SHRINKING
description: Gone is ''Careers in Medical Technology and Related Biological Sciences,'' a publication of the Veterans Administration. Gone is ''Strengthening Small Business Management,'' a 155-page guide for the aspiring entrepreneur. Gone, too, is ''Stewards of Your Public Lands,'' a photo album of Federal land management employees.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Tuesday incorrectly cited the position that A. Bartlett Gia- matti held before becoming president of Yale University. He was a professor of English, a Renaissance literature scholar and the first occupant of the university's John Hay Whitney Chair in the humani ties.

title: Litton Reports Higher Profits
description: Litton Industries, a major producer of military and industrial electronics goods, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1981 ended July 31 increased 13 percent, to $88.5 million, or $2.21 a share, from $78.3 million, or $1.97 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales advanced 19.1 percent, to $1.31 billion, from $1.1 billion.

title: Notes on People; Unable to Find a Model, Artist Turns to Herself
description: The fact that the Museum of the City of New York has bought one of her works for its permanent collection would be satisfying enough to Sherry Wolf, but what pleases her even more is that the woman depicted in her ''The Label Lady'' is herself.

title: Mobil Obtains Payment Stay
description: Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan today temporarily freed the Mobil Oil Corporation from paying other refiners about $50 million under the now-defunct oil price control program.

title: Notes on People; Comeback Attempt
description: Back in March 1980, when he suddenly resigned as president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in New York City, Samuel DeMilia said he had to leave the post because of ''an eye ailment.''

title: Bridge: Von Zedtwitz Final Put Off Until Players Get Together
description: Tennis matches are sometimes suspended for a couple of hours because of rain. Bridge matches may be interrupted - but more rarely - for a couple of weeks for less compelling reasons.

title: STAGE: 3 PIRANDELLO PLAYS WITH DANNY DE VITO
description: IN ''Taxi,'' one of television's better comedy series, a short, feisty actor named Danny De Vito plays a sour, abrasive cab dispatcher who deservedly wins a large share of the laughs. In theory, Mr. De Vito would seem to be the perfect star for the three one-act Pirandello plays that were revived at the Colonnades last night. These comedies, like the actor's television persona, are aflame with dark, angry humor. But so much for theories. Mr. De Vito's return to the New York stage - he was a founding member of the Colonnades Theater Lab - proves to be a washout. His work here is undisciplined and unfocused, as is virtually every aspect of the production that surrounds him.

title: Hockey at Byrne Arena
description: The Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers have scheduled an exhibition game for Sept. 28 at the Brendan Byrne Arena at the Meadowlands.

title: MOSCOW'S UN-FAIR
description: This week the Soviet Union is playing host to the Third Moscow International Book Fair, but as far as American book publishers are concerned, the Moscow Book Fair is dead.

title: SENATOR WILLIAMS AND THE ETHICS PANEL
description: To the Editor:

title: NOMINATION OF JUDGE O'CONNOR PROTESTED BY ABORTION FOES AT RALLY
description: While other anti-abortion leaders and representatives of broadly based conservative organizations attacked the nomination of Sandra Day O'Connor to the Supreme Court, the Rev. Jerry Falwell, president of Moral Majority, insisted today that it was too early to take a stand.

title: Restaurants; Cajun and Creole; Pre-curtain dining.
description: AMONG the cuisines virtually missing from the New York menu, none would be more welcome than Louisiana's, for surely the rich and heady specialties of Cajun and Creole kitchens make up this country's most original and best regional food. Three years ago, Abe de la Houssaye, a native of Breaux Bridge in Cajun country, began to fill the culinary gap somewhat at his small and polished restaurant, La Louisiana, on Lexington Avenue between 28th and 29th Streets. He combined highly stylized versions of Louisiana dishes and more-orless nouvelle cuisine interpretations of Continental food with results that were rated fair but promising when first reviewed.Recent visits indicate that early optimism was well-placed, for La Louisiana has improved to a one-star rating.

title: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 UP 26.5%
description: Spurred by rebates, dealer incentives and interest rate subsidies, automobile sales by the three major domestic manufacturers increased 26.5 percent in the last 10 days of August over the comparable period in 1980.

title: ESTATES AND GIFTS: PLANNING SIMPLIFIED
description: The estate and gift tax provisions in the new tax law benefit people with money to give to others by cutting the share taken by the Government. But they still leave the question of how to plan gift giving to take maximum advantage of the law. Although the answers are not obvious, tax advisers say that finding them has become much easier with passage of the new law. Many estates will now escape the Federal estate tax entirely.

title: PROTO-PUNK ROCK: IGGY POP AT THE SAVOY
description: FOR performers like Iggy Pop, the proto-punk rocker who appeared at the Savoy on Thursday and Friday, rock isn't just a style of music but a soul-exposing confrontation with oneself, one's audience and with fate. The aim is not merely to express oneself in the most uninhibited and spontaneous way possible but to consummate a spiritual union between audience and performer.

title: Carter Is Denied 3d Murder Trial
description: An appeal by Rubin (Hurricane) Carter, the former boxer, and John Artis for a third trial on murder charges has been denied by a judge in Passaic County, N.J.

title: Around the Nation; New Area in California Added in Fruit Fly Fight
description: A newly discovered fruit fly infestation was added today to pesticide spraying areas, and officials said that a dispute over prices was threatening their supply of bait laced with pesticides that is used to eradicate the pest.

title: Around the World
description: Archbishop Hilarion Capucci, the former Melkite Archbishop of Jerusalem who played a key role in the transfer of the bodies of the eight United States airmen killed in the unsuccessful attempt to rescue the American hostages in Iran last year, said today that he had been denied a visa to visit the United States.

title: Asian Artists Show
description: ''Five From the Orient,'' an exhibition of paintings, sculpture and collages by five Asian artists who live in the metropolitan area, will be on view through Sept. 27 at the Bergen Community Museum, East Ridgewood and Farview Avenues, in Paramus, N.J. The artists represented are Ming G. Fay, Yong-jin Han, Shiou-ping Liao, Masaaki Sato and Chi-hung Yang. Hours, Tuesday through Saturday, are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sunday, 1 to 5 P.M.; there will be a reception for the artists, open to the public, next Sunday at 2 P.M. Information: (201) 265-1248.

title: 5 TEAMS OF DEVELOPERS EXPECTED TO OFFER PLANS FOR TIMES SQ. PROJECT
description: At least five teams of real-estate developers and financiers, including some from the largest development concerns in North America, are expected to submit proposals today for the often-stalled renovation of West 42d Street and the Times Square area.

title: Tiger Beats at Trax
description: The Tiger Beats will perform rock-and-roll songs they've written in the style of the 1950's and 60's, and some works by others, tonight at midnight at Trax, 100 West 72d Street.

title: ABORTION CURBS FOUND TO HAVE LIMITED IMPACT
description: A law that nearly eliminated the use of Federal Medicaid funds for abortions has had little effect on the number of abortions obtained by poor women, according to a Federal study to be published today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Prudential Arvida Bid Is Confirmed
description: The Penn Central Corporation and the Prudential Insurance Company of America said late yesterday afternoon that discussions were under way regarding the sale of Penn Central's Arvida Corporation subsidiary, a land development concern in Boca Raton, Fla., for an undisclosed sum.

title: Air Florida Backed In Bid for Western
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today gave tentative approval for Air Florida to take over Los Angeles-based Western Airlines, although a final ruling is not expected until October. The C.A.B. in mid-July gave Air Florida permission to purchase up to half of We stern Airlines' stock as long as the shares were placed in a trust aw aiting final takeover approval.

title: IAC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MCENROE GAINS, 6-3, 6-1, 6-3
description: Only hours after he had been fined $5,000 for ''aggravated behavior'' at Wimbledon, John McEnroe defeated Tom Gullikson, 6-3, 6-1, 6-3, last night in the second round of the United States Open tennis championships.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 4, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets on Namibia at 10:30 A.M.

title: NEW ANGOLA DRIVE IS DOUBTED BY U.S.
description: Administration officials said today that as far as they knew South Africa was withdrawing its forces from Angola and that if there was new fighting in southeastern Angola it was between rival Angolans.

title: Fairness and Federal Pay
description: Congress, in its July budget reconciliation battle, slapped a 4.8 percent ceiling on pay raises for 1.4 million Federal white-collar workers. President Reagan, who issued his recommendation at that level this week, could have suggested a lower figure, or no raises at all. In that sense the recommendation illuminated a larger point: Federal pay schedules have become awesomely confused, complicated and unfair, to the detriment of the nation as well as Government employees.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-After extraordinary gains from sale of a subsidiary of $6 million for the current yr and $14 million for yr-ago period

title: CITY ISLAND FINDS THAT ITS CHARMS HAVE CAST A SPELL OVER DEVELOPERS
description: Masts sway on the shifting tides. Boat yards echo with the hammering of shipwrights. Sailmakers stitch sheets that carpet the floors of cavernous lofts, and up and down the main street, ship chandlers' windows are filled with marine supplies.

title: Going Out Guide
description: RAYON AND NUCLEAR POWER

title: DALCO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-Net income including $5 million pretax gain on the sale of subsidiary capital stock in Feb 1980

title: Books of The Times; THE PRIEST IN THE PUB
description: COLLECTED STORIES. By Frank O'Con- nor. 702 pages. Knopf. $20.

title: THE LION OF SWAZILAND CELEBRATES 60 YEARS AS KING
description: The 82-year-old King of Swaziland celebrated the 60th year of his reign today by acting out in ceremonial form the mix of tribal tradition and modern nationalism that has enabled him to survive as Africa's most durable ruler.

title: 'NIGHT THE LIGHTS WENT OUT'
description: ''The Night the Lights Went Out in Georgia,'' which was directed by Ronald F. Maxwell and opened yesterday at Loews State and other theaters, is based on a vaguely melodramatic song, and so the movie can't do without a certain amount of fuss and excitement. But the activity is kept to a bare minimum, in a film that is otherwise devoted to music, chat and whiling away time. Kristy McNichol and Dennis Quaid, as a mutually devoted sister and brother, are personable but idle in this largely uneventful tale.

title: Transactions BASEBALL
description: SAN DIEGO (NL) - Called up Mike Armstrong and Steve Fireovid, pitchers, and Alan Wiggins, outfielder, from Hono- lulu of Pacific Coast League. BASKETBALL NEW JERSEY NETS (NBA) - An- nounced resig nation of Charlie Theokas, executive vic e president.

title: UN EMPLOYMENT DIPPED IN NEW YORK CITY AND STATE
description: The unemployment rates in New York City and New York State dropped last month, but there was no increase in overall employment. In the city the jobless rate was 8.1 percent in August, compared with 9.5 percent in July, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional director of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, reported yesterday. The number of unemployed was 235,000 in August, down from 291,000 in July.

title: IN POVERTY, A CHURCH IS THRIVING
description: Although he had injured his right leg the day before in a touchfootball game and was limping noticeably in his office, the Rev. Johnny R. Youngblood had shown no sign of difficulty moving about during the service at St. Paul's Community Baptist Church in Brooklyn. It is part of his self-image as someone who must lead by example.

title: Astros Defeat Expos, 5-0, for 9th Straight
description: Nolan Ryan allowed just two hits before leaving in the eighth inning, and Cesar Cedeno collected four hits and drove in three runs as the Houston Astros defeated the Montreal Expos, 5-0, tonight for their ninth straight victory.

title: CITY OPERA: LIFE OF GRIEG IN 'SONG OF NORWAY'
description: On Aug. 21, 1944, an operetta very loosely based on the art and life of Edvard Grieg, the patron saint of Norwegian music, opened on Broadway. For some reason, Norway did not immediately declare war on America. Or perhaps we just never heard about it. At any rate, ''Song of Norway'' went on to run for 860 performances and to find its way down through the years into theaters all over the world and even theaters all over the world and even into the movies. Now it is back on Broadway, at Lincoln Center, where the New York City Opera on Thursday night revived the Robert Wright-George Forrest musical with exceptional attention to 40's style.

title: BROKER MAY BUY ACLI
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., the nation's seventh-largest publicly held securities firm, is reportedly considering the acquisition of all or part of ACLI International Inc., a familyowned commodity trading and brokerage firm.

title: Kuhn Said to Admit To Shaving Points
description: Rick Kuhn, a former Boston College basketball player facing trial on charges of fixing the outcome of games by shaving points, ''readily admitted his involvement in the scheme,'' a Federal prosecutor said yesterday.

title: INDIA CITES OIL FIND OFF BOMBAY
description: India has discovered a new offshore oil field close to the Bombay coast, the Government announced in Parliament today.

title: BROADER BILL URGED IN ANTITRUST CASES
description: William F. Baxter, the Administration's antitrust chief, asserted today that a Senate bill to create shared liability among companies in cases of illegal price fixing should be broadened to include ''antitrust violations in general.''

title: The Region; 1,200 Lose Power
description: Nearly 1,200 Westchester County customers of Consolidated Edison lost their electric power briefly last night, a spokesman for the utility said.

title: CDC in Bid For Aquitaine
description: CDC Petroleum Inc., a diversified energy concern partially owned by the Canadian Government, said it would offer $61.65 a share (in United States currency) for all the outstanding shares of Aquitaine Company of Canada Ltd. that it does not already own.

title: MICHAELS NAMES 4 CAPTAINS
description: Coach Walt Michaels surprised the New York Jets today by appointing new captains instead of allowing the players to vote, as they did in the past.

title: Soviet Buys More Grain
description: The Soviet Union has bought another 400,000 tons of American grain. The Agriculture Department said yesterday that the sales - 300,000 tons of wheat and 100,000 tons of corn -counted against the sixth year of the recently extended grain agreement, which begins Oct.1.

title: BRINKLEY TO RETIRE NEXT MONTH AFTER 38 YEARS AT NBC NEWS
description: David Brinkley, whose clipped wit, lucid style and distinctive baritone helped make him one of the most celebrated - and imitated - of all television newsmen, will retire next month at the age of 61, NBC News announced yesterday. Mr. Brinkley, who came to prominence after he was teamed with the late Chet Huntley at the 1956 Presidential co nventions, has been at NBC for 38 years, 14 of them as co-anchor of the ''Huntley-Brinkley Report.'' Since last year, he has been the an chor on ''NBC Magazine With David Brinkley,'' a weekly program fashi oned after CBS News' ''60 Minutes.''

title: Fuqua Sells I ts Lano Unit
description: Fuqua Industries Inc. said it had sold its Lano Corporation subsidiary for $69 million i n cash and notes and that it would post an after-tax loss of about $15 million on the transaction. Separately, the company announce d that J.B. Fuqua, chairman, had sold his 16.9 percent interest in the Cyprus Corporation for an undisclosed amount.

title: ROCOR INTERNATIONAL (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The yr-ago results have been reclassified for an accounting change

title: The City; Officer Dismissed In Corruption Case
description: A police lieutenant with 33 years of service was dismissed after being found guilty in a departmental trial of stealing several dozen pairs of jeans from property confiscated in December in a garmentcenter investigation.

title: South Africa Coal Plan
description: South Africa has raised the coal export quota to 80 million tons a year from 44 million tons, the minerals and energy affairs minister, F.W. De Klerk, told Parliament today.

title: ARTS FORUM SEPT. 13 IN CAPITAL
description: Some 500 representatives of 40 religious, business, labor and education organizations and government will examine the importance of the arts in American life at a four-day conference in Washington beginning Sept. 13. The forum, the Ameri can Town Meeting on the Arts, will al so explore how government, citizens and organizations can and shoul d contribute to cultural life.

title: PENN TRAFFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
WHERE NOT TO PLACE A METHADONE CLINIC
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; A BEHIND-THE-SCENES LIFE IN THE LABOR MOVEMENT
description: Young John Francis O'Donnell came to America in the winter of 1927 and found himself, in fairly rapid succession, working in the fields of elevator operations, adolescent education, journalism and labor law. The last inspired him most.

title: Observer; BURN HAY, NOT BUCKS
description: They laughed when I established the Institute of Lower Technology. In those days only two types of technology seemed conceivable: high technology an d higher technology. ''You are swimming against the tideof technology , dummy,'' everybody said.

title: BLACK TEEN-AGE JOBLESS BRING RISE IN U.S. RATE
description: A sharp increase in unemployment among black teen-agers caused a slight rise in the nation's total jobless rate in August, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Patents; A Way to Immobilize Microorganisms
description: A method of immobilizing microorganisms so they will continue to multiply and serve in the commercial production of such things as alcohol was patented this week for the Department of Energy. Alicia L. Compere and William L. Griffith, employees of the Union Carbide Corporation, which operates the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee, were granted patent 4,287,305.

title: The City; Queens Man Slain
description: An off-duty correction officer shot and killed a Queens man during an argument last night, the police said. The officer, Augustus Snowden, 34 years old, told the police that he shot the man, Donald Hankerson, 30, at 7:15 P.M. in front of Mr. Hankerson's home at 133-35 148th Street in Springfield Gardens after Mr. Hankerson threatened him with a knife. No charges were filed, pending a review by a grand jury, the police said.

title: MAY, DAVIS LIMIT ROYALS TO 3 HITS IN 4-0 VICTORY
description: Faced with the knowledge that their manager's job could still be in jeopardy, the Yankees rebounded from two straight losses tonight and beat the Royals, 4-0, behind the three-hit pitching of Rudy May and Ron Davis.

title: Nashville Officer Suspended For Actions During Shootings
description: An eight-year veteran of the Nashville police force was given a 20-day suspension without pay yesterday for his failure to take command of a situation in which his partner, an officer for three months, shot three innocent persons, killing one.

title: For Election to the City Council
description: In November, New Yorkers will elect 45 members to the City Council, but in some districts victory in Thursday's Democratic primary will be decisive. Here are our recommendations for those districts: MANHATTAN

title: PLANNING RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Sports of the Times; BEST SPORTING EVENT OF THE YEAR IN NEW YORK
description: THE United States Open might be the best sporting event of the year in New York. It is certainly the most constant. All the team sports depend on a good year from the locals to produce playoff frenzy, but the Open is always there - two weeks of tennis, early in September. You can plan your year on it, and some people do.

title: 2 Finns Confident of Making Rangers
description: The two Finnish hockey players signed to Ranger contracts Monday night believe they can make the team, which begins training in Scandanavia on Sept. 12.

title: The City; Amputee Charged In Doctor's Killing
description: A 55-year-old legless man was arraigned on a charge of seconddegree murder in the killing on Thursday of a physician at the Veterans Administration Hospital at First Avenue and 24th Street.

title: The Region
description: TRENTON (AP) - A three-judge state appeals court panel upheld Governor Byrne's executive order requiring inmates from overcrowded state prisons to be temporarily locked up in county jails.

title: F.A.A. PLANS TO HIRE 1,500 SHORT-TERM CONTROLLERS
description: The Federal Aviation Administration announced today that it would hire 1,500 people, many of them pilots laid off because of the air traffic controllers' walkout, to replace the striking controllers for two years.

title: COMPUTER TECHNOLOGY PERVADES LIF E IN JAPAN
description: At every turn here, one confronts overwhelming evidence that Japan, more than any other nation, has embraced advanced electronic and computer technology as a way to improve industrial productivity, save energy and, in theory, make day-to-day life more convenient, enriching and entertaining.

title: Bomb Kills a South African
description: A bomb exploded at a bus terminal near here yesterday, killing one man, the South African Press Association reported today. It said reports indicated that the man was waiting for a bus when the explosion occurred and that no one had claimed responsibility for the attack.

title: FLORIDIANS' MOUNTAIN DREAM LOTS REMAIN A DREAM
description: Now, in the bosky hollows of Tennessee summer, the South Floridians who bought their Smoky Mountain dream lots for $1,000 down and $125 a month are thinking about a search for the last honest developer.

title: ANECO REINSURANCE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CBS Cancels Kirkland Speech As Attack on Administration
description: The CBS Radio Network today denied Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O, permission to broadcast a Labor Day message ''almost entirely devoted'' to attacking the policies of the Reagan Administration.

title: Notes on People; A Widow's Decision
description: Before she married General of the Army Omar N. Bradley in 1968, Kitty Buhler Bradley was a Hollywood screenwriter who turned out scripts for f ilms starring John Wayne and Victor Mature, and for suchtelevision sh ows as ''Dragnet,'' ''My Three Sons'' and ''The Untouchables. ''

title: CACI INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISRAELI COURT LIFTS BAN ON JERUSALEM DIG
description: Israel's Supreme Court today lifted a Government ban on archeological excavations at what is believed to be the site of the ancient City of David, permitting work to r esume pending a fin al ruling in 10 days.

title: Your Money; Cashing In On Insurance
description: THE tendency among American consumers to borrow on their insurance policies is becoming harder to resist. High interest rates for bank deposits, certificates of deposit and the new tax-exempt saving certificates are expected to cause the practice to grow.

title: Tale of Amber Pass: Running Infirmary
description: It is said around the race track that before you bet a horse who looks like a good thing, count his legs. Amber Pass has four limbs, but two of them have holes the size of pennies drilled in them, and he is missing a few other parts.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 44. 1. In what city did a bomb blast A. damage the American Embassy? B. kill the country's top two leaders? C. injure an American general? 2. The Reagan Administration put forward a method of detecting welfare cheating that has not been widely used in decades. What is it?

title: A JOURNALIST'S FOCUS ON INTELLIGENCE SERVICES
description: To the Editor:

title: Getty Ending Case
description: A subsidiary of the Getty Oil Company has agreed to pay the Government $5.5 million to settle an oil overcharges case, the Energy Department said. Western Crude Oil Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Getty since 1980, agreed to the payment to settle charges that it had violated price control rules on crude oil sales it made in 1974 and 1975. The department said the consent agreement did not constitute an admission of guilt on the part of the company, which is based in Denver.

title: SHOW TIME AT PIZZA CHAIN
description: She leans forward seductively, and in a husky voice reminiscent of another singer, Pearl Bailey, says, ''Hello, handsome, why don't you sing along?''

title: JURY'S VERDICT ON HEIRS TO HUGHES WIPES OUT 500 RELATIVES' CLAIMS
description: Jurors today ruled a cousin of Howard R. Hughes was the true daughter of the tycoon's late uncle, rejecting the claims of about 500 distant relatives seeking a share of the billionaire's fortune.

title: B.M.I. Contest to Award $15,000 to Composers
description: The 30th Broadcast Music Incorporated Awards Competition for Student Composers will award $15,000 in order to encourage the creation of concert music. The deadline to apply for the next competition is Feb. 16.

title: Angola Mining Deal Set
description: Austromineral, an Austrian mining company that has been engaged in helping to revive the Kassinga iron ore mines in Angola, said today that it had an exclusive contract to produce 1.1 million tons of iron ore annually. A spokesman said the mines, shut down six years ago, would take some time to resume production and that large-scale deliveries could not be expected before the end of 1982.

title: Patents; Method of Transmitting Color TV Is Improved
description: Paul M. Levy of Dix Hills, L.I., was granted a patent this week on improvements to his method of transmitting two color television programs simultaneously over a single broadcast channel.

title: Notes on People; Hooked on Edsels
description: Yesterday was the 24th anniversary of the introduction of the Ford Motor Company's Edsel, a car with a name has come to take on the meaning of ''mistake'' or ''loser.'' But Shelley Cleaver of Jacksonville, Tex., is the proud owner of 14 of the 110,000 Edsels turned out.

title: Sports People; Theokas Leaves Nets
description: Charlie Theokas resigned yesterday as executive vice president of the New Jersey Nets.

title: Consumer Saturday; FRUIT FLY HAS LITTLE EFFECT HERE
description: NEW YORKERS don't seem to care about the Mediterranean fruit fly, and its stardom in the press and on television has had little effect on their purchases of fresh fruits and vegetables from California.

title: ANACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings adjusted to 5-for-4 stock split in June 1981; 1980 results restated for acquisitions accounted for as pooling of interests

title: Around the World; Greeks Say Turkey Asks For Details on Refugees
description: The Turkish junta has asked Greece to supply it with details on opponents who have sought political asylum here, implying that some should be extradited for criminal offenses. But Government sources said today that Athens was reluctant to do so, even though it is concerned about the growing number of Turkish refugees here.

title: U.S. ACTS TO SHRINK SCHOOL LUNCH SIZE IN ECONOMY MOVE
description: The Agriculture Department proposed today to reduce the amount of food served to children receiving federally subsidized lunches in schools throughout the country.

title: Patents; New Compounds Help Treat Hypertension
description: The National Foundation for Cancer Research, Bethesda, Md., received a patent this week for compounds that are useful in the treatment of hypertension and pain. Patent 4,287,205 was granted to Albert Szent-Gyorgyi, scientific director of the foundation's laboratory in Woods Hole, Mass., and Prof. Gabor B. Fodor of the University of West Virginia, an area director for the foundation.

title: Sports People; Starling's Jaw Broken
description: Marlon Starling, unbeaten in 19 welterweight bouts, suffered a broken jaw while sparring with Thomas Hearns, the World Boxing Association champion, in Las Vegas.

title: The Region;
description: Bail was set at $1 million each yesterday for 31 of 33 men arrested during raids Thursday in which the Coast Guard and Federal agents seized two ships and confiscated more than 20 tons of marijuana.

title: SOVIET MISSION SECURITY TIGHTENED AFTER SEVEN FIREBOMBS ARE FOUND
description: Security was increased yesterday around the Soviet Mission to the United Nations on the Upper East Side after seven firebombs, including one that exploded, were placed in the area over two days by a group contending to be part of the Jewish Defense League.

title: U.S. FRAUD UNIT TO START INQUIRY IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Attorney General William French Smith said today that a new Federal task force created to investigate serious abuses in the food stamp program would focus initially on charges of massive fraud in New York City.

title: WHY, THEN, IS THE PRESIDENT LAUGHING?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People
description: No Excuse, Sir? Tarkio (Mo.) College is trying a new approach in an effort to break its 27-game losing streak, the longest in the nation in college football.

title: De Gustibus; EX LIBRIS, CONTINUED
description: After suggestions for developing a basic cookbook library appeared here a few weeks ago, many letters were received from readers with requests for additional titles as well as from others who took issue with recommended choices.

title: NATO Official Praises Move By U.S. on Neutron Warheads
description: The Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Joseph M.A.H. Luns, said today that the recent American decision to produce neutron warheads would increase the deterrence potential of the United States and create stability in East-West relations.

title: Sports People; A Pool of Nontalent
description: Tony Lucadello, a major league baseball scout for 39 years, believes that talent has been on the decline for the last 20 years. ''It's getting worse all the time.''

title: F.A.A. DECIDES REGIONAL OFFICE WILL STAY OPEN
description: The Federal Aviation Administration announced yesterday that it had decided not to close its regional office in New York and merge it with one near Boston.

title: OPEC Talks Urged
description: Kuwait is trying to arrange an emergency meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to resolve the price differences among its members, a Kuwaiti newspaper reported today. The pa per, Al-Rai al-Amm, quo ted unidentified industry sources as saying a meeting of oil m inisters from the 13 member nations would be held during the last 10 days of September.

title: 'Gemini' Calls It a Run At 1,819 Performances
description: ''Gemini,'' the comedy hit by Albert Inaurato, will close with tonight's performance, ending a run of four and a half years at the Little Theater, 240 West 44th Street. It will have played 1,819 times.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1981; The Economy
description: The Government's Producer Price Index for finished goods, a rough measure of future inflation, rose just three-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Labor Department reported. The small increase, equal to a 3.6 percent rate annually, resulted in part from slight declines in meat and energy prices. (Page 1.)

title: Upstate Rugby Is Canceled
description: The Sept. 26 rugby match here involving the South African national team, the Springboks, was canceled today after backers ran into heavy opposition from opponents of South Africa's racial policies. The chief backer of the game said the match would be played on that date in an unspecified city.

title: GRACE PERIOD SET FOR INOCULATIONS OF CITY STUDENTS
description: The Board of Education and the city have reached an agreement that averts the possibility of hundreds of thousands of students being turned away from school next week because they have not been inoculated against childhood diseases.

title: Bridge; MATRIMONIAL RISKS INCLUDE PARTNERSHIP AT CARD TABLE
description: Whether husbands and wives can form effective bridge partnerships is a tricky question. Some can, but others fail quite conspicuously. The chances of success are distinctly improved, however, if the players have given their partnership a thorough test at the card table in advance of committing matrimony.

title: Superior Oil Chief Quits; Executive Rift Hinted
description: The Superior Oil Company, the country's largest independent oil and gas producer, announced late yesterday that Joseph E. Reid had resigned as the company's chairman and chief executive officer.

title: LFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 24
description: B-Net loss after %575,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: THE MAKEUP FOR FACES WORTH FORTUNES
description: Dream away about smiling out from a magazine cover, pirouetting across a stage, or being up there on the silver screen, larger than life. It isn't going to happen. Most of us are going to do all our beautiful dancing, incredible acting and drop-dead modeling in front of the bedroom mirror. It is the world's loss and, sadly, the world will never be the wiser.

title: BENEFITS OF A BOARD MEMBER
description: Marian Heiskell, a director of the Ford Motor Company, happened to mention at a board meeting late last year that she had a little problem with a bent license plate frame on her 1981 Mercury Cougar. The same day, a Ford engineer, tool box in hand, flew to New York to straighten it out.

title: A.M.C. to Offer $500 Cash Rebate
description: The American Motors Corporation announced that it is beefing up its late summer sales promotion by offering a $500 cash rebate on 1981 Concord cars through Sept. 23.

title: Padres 5, Pirates 4
description: SAN DIEGO (AP) - Gene Richards tripled to drive in two runs, highlighting a three-run rally in the seventh inning that gave San Diego the victory.

title: 11th '81 Atom Blast for U.S.
description: The United States conducted an underground nuclear test today in the Nevada desert, the Energy Department announced. It said in a statement that the explosion, the 11th such test this year, had a yield of less than 20 kilotons, equal to the explosive force of 20,000 tons of TNT.

title: SAUL F. LIVINGSTON
description: Dr. Saul F. Livingston, a surgeon in New York for more than 50 years, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The Region; State Being Sued Over Drawbridge
description: A Long Island woman who was trapped for more than two hours on a drawbridge raised by vandals last month sued New York State far $10 million in damages.

title: States' Rights - to Pay 15 Percent
description: Earn 15 percent, tax free, on Washington State Power bonds ... 15 1/2 percent on Louisiana Offshore Terminal bonds .... The business pages these days are chock full of enticing deals in tax-exempt securities. But good news for bond buyers is terrible news for bond sellers, like Felix Rohatyn, head of New York's Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think it's very important for critics of contemporary United States policies to understand that our judgments have to be based on what we do that is designed to bring about the objective which we all commonly seek: the earliest possible indepe nd ence for Namibia.'' - Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. (1:4 .)

title: 5 UNLICENCED CABDRIVERS ACCUSED OF BILKING NIGERIAN STUDENTS
description: Five unlicensed cabdrivers were arrested yesterday and accused of charging four college-bound Nigerian students $1,130 to drive them from Kennedy International Airport to La Guardia Airport, normally a 15-mile trip cost ing about $15.

title: Around the Nation; 11 Indicted in Tax Fraud Using 'Church' as Shelter
description: A Federal grand jury indicted 11 Texans today for tax fraud involving the creation of a spurious church. The indictment charged Jerome Daly, the ''archbishop, president and pope of the Basic Bible Church,'' and 10 Braniff Airlines pilots with 37 counts of defrauding the Federal Government.

title: RESPONSIBILITY FOR ARMS TALKS DISPUTED BY HAIG AND ROSTOW
description: A dispute between the State Department and the Arms Con trol and Disarmament Agency over which organization should have the chief responsibility for arms control negotiations became a public debate today.

title: PHOTOS AID STUDY OF SATURNIAN MOON
description: In a farewell glimpse of Saturn's worlds, Voyager 2 snapped more than 200 photographs yesterday of Phoebe, the little, outermost moon of the ringed planet and a possible key to the solution of several scientific mysteries.

title: MISS JAEGER UPSET BY ANDREA LEAND
description: Everything was proceeding in an orderly fashion yesterday in second-round play at the United States Open tennis championships when the shock came. Andrea Jaeger, the second-seeded player in women's singles, was eliminated.

title: FRENCH AMBASSADOR IS SLAIN IN BEIRUT
description: The French Ambassador to Lebanon was fatally shot by four gunmen today as he was being driven to his West Beirut residence for lunch.

title: BROADCAST COMMERCIALS FOR PRIMARY ARE CRITICAL, AND REVEALING
description: The accusations range from charges of sexism to criminal conduct. The level of accuracy varies from partial truth to outright falsehood. The frequency ranges from incessant to barely discernible.

title: Julie Sumpf Is Married To Vincent A. Ciulla Jr.
description: Julie Sumpf, daughter of William Sumpf of Menlo Park, Calif., and the late Fay Rochwerg Sumpf of Red Bank, N.J., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Vincent Anthony Ciulla Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ciulla of Westerleigh, S.I. The civil ceremony was performed in the Municipal Building.

title: 5 YOUTHS CHARGED IN ROBBERIES AFTER ROCK CONCERT
description: Five youths robbing their way through a crowd emerging from a rock concert were arrested outside Madison Square Garden late Thursday night on charges ranging from disorderly conduct to grand larceny, the police announced yesterday. Another you th was seized by Madison Square Garden security officers insi de the arena on a gun-possession charge, the police said.

title: U.S. TRANSFERS 120 HAITIANS TO PRISON IN NEW YORK STATE
description: More than 120 Haitians were transferred yesterday from a Federal refugee camp near Miami to a prison in Otisville, N.Y., following a demonstration against conditions at the refugee camp.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1981
description: International U.S. discussions with South Africa toward achieving the independence of South-West Africa have made considerable progress, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said in an interview. ''We're not where we want to be yet,'' he said, ''but we are farther ahead on where we want to be.'' (Page 1, Columns 4-5.) A combination of third world nations, the Soviet Union and its allies blocked an attempt to let members of the South African delegation to the United Nations General Assembly speak at a session called to protest South Africa's continued rule of South-West Africa, despite objections from the United States and other Western nations. The Assembly then rejected the delegation's credentials. The vote was 117 to 22 with 6 abs tentions. (4:1-2.)

title: U.S. SAYS RUSSIANS WITHHELD DATA ON SIZE OF MANEUVERS NEAR POLAND
description: State Department officials said today that the Soviet Union had withheld information on the number of troops involved in military maneuvers now being conducted in the Baltic region near Poland. Under the terms of the 1975 Helsinki accord s, notification of majormilitary exercises must include information o n the strength of the forces involved. This is the first time that the Soviet Union has failed to provide such information.

title: WHITE HOUSE PRIVILEGES BACK IN STYLE
description: John Rogers, the keeper of perquisites and privilege in the Reagan White House, says he is a bit puzzled by the austere ways of his predecessor, Hugh Carter Jr.

title: HUDSON GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
THE DOLLAR SOLUTION TO THE SHORTAGE OF NURSES
description: To the Editor:

title: QUAKE JOLTS SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA
description: Southern California's strongest earthquake in more than 10 years shook this area today, causing skyscrapers to sway and disrupting some telephone service. No injuries and only limited damage were reported.

title: SENATE FOES OF SAUDI AWACS DEAL SEEK SUPPORT AMONG COLLEAGUES
description: Thirteen Republicans and Democrats in the Senate urged their colleagues today to join them in sponsoring a resolution aimed at blocking President Reagan's plan to sell Saudi Arabia an $8.5 billion package of air defense equipment, including five airborne warning and control systems.

title: HOUSING AND LABOR ADVISOR
description: Langdon W. Post, whose long career in New York City politics and the Federal Government was highlighted by early efforts to improve housing and labor conditions, died Wednesday in San Francisco of heart failure. He was 82 years old.

title: TORK LINK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Apr 30
Coe and Moses Win In World Cup Track
description: Sebastian Coe, Edwin Moses and Evelyn Ashford scored impressive victories in the World Cup track and field competition today, but an injury to Carl Lewis in the 100 meters hurt the United States' chances of winning the men's team title.

title: Reagan Names Envoys To 3 Nations and U.N.
description: President Reagan announced plans today to nominate new ambassadors to Uruguay, Morocco and Switzerland and a new representative to a United Nations commission on the status of women.

title: News An alysis
description: An analysis published yesterday points up a number of aspects about abortion in this country that were not apparent when Federal funds were drastically diminished by a new law in 1977.

title: Around the Nation; Discovery May Extend Fruit Fly Quarantine
description: A new discovery of Mediterranean fruit flies in the San Joaquin Valley will force extension of a Federal quarantine, state officials said today.

title: The City; Health Care Group Resuming Service
description: The La Guardia Medical Group, serving 150,000 clients in Queens, is scheduled to resume normal service at all of its nine centers on Tuesday, according to Dr. Morris Fond, director of the group.

title: Around the Nation
description: Waves from Hurricane Emily pounded the Northeast coast today as the storm churned in the Atlantic 700 miles east of New York City, according to weather forecasters here.

title: HOP-IN FOOD STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a tax benefit of $115,000...C-Includes a tax debit of $465,000

title: Bertram L. Joseph, Stage Scholar
description: Bertram Leon Joseph, an authority on Shakespearean and other Elizabethan acting and the founder and chairman of the drama and theater department of Queens College, died after suffering a heart attack at his home in Glen Cove, L.I., on Thursday night. He was 66 years old.

title: Trial of Williams Is Delayed
description: A judge today postponed the trial of Wayne B. Williams, who is charged with murdering two of 28 young blacks who were slain here, saying that it would be impossible to rule on all pending motions within 30 days. Judge Clarence Cooper of the Superior Court did not set a new date for the trial, which was to have begun Oct. 5.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY RISES BY $1.5 BILLION
description: Prices of Government securities pushed slightly higher in late trading yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board reported a moderate increase of $1.5 billion in a key measure of the nation's money supply.

title: CAIRO POLICE USE TEAR GAS TO END PROTESTS ON ARRESTS OF SADAT FOES
description: The Egyptian police used tear gas to break up demonstrations at several Cairo mosques today after the arrests of at least 1,000 critics of President Anwar el-Sadat.

title: TEXAS AIR ALLOWED 67% OF CONTINENTAL
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today gave Texas International Airlines another boost in its nine-month effort to gain control of Continental Air Lines, ruling that the Houstonbased carrier could acquire up to 67 percent of Continental's shares outstanding.

title: Around the World; 3d I.R.A. Hunger Striker, Near Death, Ends Fast
description: For the third time this summer, one of the prison hunger strikers in Northern Ireland has stopped fasting as he neared death.

title: Checking on Families' Assets Is Approved for Welfare Plan
description: Under regulations approved today, a welfare recipient's personal property would be assessed to make sure its value did not exceed $1,000, excluding ''all those items necessary to day-to-day living.''

title: Annual Music Festival In Albany Sept. 19
description: Musicians ranging from Woody Herman and George Shearing to the rock group Blotto will perform at the Empire State Plaza here Sept. 19 in the second annual daylong Harvest of Music Festival, state officials have announced.

title: 14 Entered in Pegasus At the Meadowlands
description: A field of 14 was named today for the $227,200 Pegasus Stakes on Monday afternoon, the opening-day feature of the Meadowlands thoroughbred meeting.

title: SON HELD AS SUSPECT
description: A 72-year-old retired high school principal was found strangled in his home today, and the police arrested his 33-year-old son on a charge of murder.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS ARE EJECTED FROM U.N. NAMIBIA PARLEY
description: Despite protests from the United States and other Western nations, the General Assembly refused to let South Africa speak today and then ejected its delegation from the session called to protest its continued rule of South-West Africa.

title: THREE CAMBODIAN EX-LEADERS SIGN PACT ON ANTI-HANOI FRONT
description: Three former Cambodian leaders signed a joint statement today pledging their three groups to strive for a coalition to continue the struggle against the Vietnamese occupation of their country.

title: Noontime Shows Begin Sept. 17 on Wall Street
description: A series of eight free lunchtime performances of dance, music, poetry, theater and multimedia presentations will begin Sept. 17 at 12:30 under the sponsorship of the downtown branch of the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: Notes on People; Jeane Kirkpatrick Misses Fete for Husband
description: The United States Representative to the United Nations, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, was unable to be on hand at the New York Hilton Hotel when her husband, Evron M. Kirkpatrick, was honored as the retiring executive director of the American P olitical Science Association.

title: HAIG REPORTS U.S. MAKES PROGRESS ON NAMIBIA ISSUE
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said in an interview last night that the Reagan Administration had made considerable progress toward the independence of South-West Africa in behind-the-scenes discussions with South Africa.

title: Toshiba Delays Bond
description: The Toshiba Corporation said today that it has decided to postpone issuing a $100 million convertible Eurobond indefinitely because of poor market conditions. Bond market sources in London said Nomura International and Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. had been planning to start the 15-year bond this week with an indicated coupon of between 5 percent and 5 1/4 percent. Also today, Daiwa Europe Ltd. in London said poor market conditions caused it to reduce to $40 million the convertible Eurobond for the Minolta Camera Company Ltd., originally $50 million.

title: AT NEW YORK STATE FAIR, RURAL WAYS AND VALUES ARE THE PRIME ATTRACTIONS
description: The 135th New York State Fair is disproving the notion that nostalgia isn't what it used to be. A quarter of a million people - with at least that many more to follow before the fair ends Monday night -have already poured through the gates of the big parkland here a few miles from Syracuse to milk goats, race tractors, twirl batons, quilt robes, shuck corn, bake pies, strum banjos, dance polkas, shear sheep, rope cows, ice cakes, pull horses, pick guitars, fiddle bluegrass and consume huge quantities of foods ranging from roasted ox to 4-H fudge.

title: NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Sports People; Sizing Up a Problem
description: Mel Reed an d Bucky Hill, the big and little men of the Poca (W. Va.) High Sch ool football team, have made life difficult for the equipment man ager.

title: GEORGIA OPENS SEASON TODAY
description: Georgia, which went undefeated and was the top-ranked team in college football last year, will open the season tomorrow against Tennessee.

title: Index; International
description: Carter, in Japan, warns of ''oil shock'' and assails Khomeini 2 Haig-Rostow dispute becomes a public debate 2 Amid pageantry, Swazi King mar ks 60-year reign 2 Senators prepare to fight sale of planes to Saudi Arabia 3 Mexico rejects Latin charges of interference in Salvador 3 Three former Cambodian leaders pledge anti-Hanoi coalition 3 Excerpts from transcript of inter- view with Haig 4 Around the World 5 Israeli court lifts Government ban on dig in Jerusalem 5 Health/Science Voyager photos hint at origin of unusually dark moon of Saturn 44 HOLIDAY WEEKEND Monday is Labor Day. Following are holiday schedules: Parade - Begins 11 A.M., north on Fifth Avenue from 26th to 52d Street, then east on 52d Street to Third Avenue. Parking - Sunday regulations in effect; alternate-side rules suspended. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning. Federal, state and municipal offices -Closed. Post offices - Closed; only special delivery and express mail delivered. Banks - Closed. Stock and commodity markets -Closed. Transportation - Subways and buses on Sunday schedules; commuter rail lines on holiday schedules; special bus lanes suspended. Libraries - Closed. Schools - Closed.

title: Notes on People; Fast Action and a Slow Compactor Save Paintings
description: Quick thinking by some sanitation people and a sluggish compactor on a garbage truck apparently saved 17 paintings that Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis had picked up during a trip to India.

title: Around the World; 65 Czechs Killed in Mine; Toll Is Worst in 20 Years
description: Sixty-five coal miners died in a pit explosion in northern Czechoslovakia in the country's worst mining disaster in 20 years, the official C.T.K. press agency reported today.

title: HUSKY OIL OF CANADA TO SELL ITS U.S. UNIT
description: Husky Oil Ltd. of Calgary announced today that it will sell its United States subsidiary -with assets valued at nearly $1 billion - so that it can concentrate on its Canadian operations and on domestic exploration.

title: Alice Roosevelt Longworth, the doyenne of Washington who died in 1979, was an inveterate conversationalist on many subjects. Michael Teague interviewed her and transcribed some of the conversations for his book, ''Mrs. L: Conversations With Alice Roosevelt Longworth,'' from which this article is excerpted. Mr.  Teague is vice president of Downs & Roosevelt Inc., a Washington public relations firm.
description: I suppose my first real interest in politics began with McKinley's election in 1896. There were no telephones in Sagamore in those days and I can still hear the crunch on the gravel outside as Uncle Jimmy Gracie drove up from the village in a buggy with a lantern on the back to tell us that Bryan had been beaten.

title: REAGAN TO WEIGH ARMS OUTLAY CUTS
description: President Reagan received from the Defense Department today a package of possible cuts in his previously proposed military spending for the fiscal years 1983 and 1984, but a White House spokesman said he would make no decisions on the extent of th e cuts until next week.

title: Chrysler Restoring Executives' Pay
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it would restore the p ay of its senior executives to 1979 levels but said the managers woul d not recover all the wages they lost during a two-year pay cut.

title: STRONG RACES IN BRONX FADE AS PRIMARY NEARS
description: The Democratic primary races in the Bronx originally shaped up as head-to-head confrontations between the Bronx County Democratic organization and anti-Koch forces led by Herman Badillo, a former Deputy Mayor. After the petitions of a third of the original candidates were challenged, however, the races ended up as a mixed bag of personal grudges, feuds and uncontested races.

title: COURT PERMITS SHUBERTS TO BUY MORE THEATERS
description: The Shubert Organization has won its long court battle for the right to buy new theaters. The decision yesterday granted the Shuberts permission to purchase immediately two theaters in New York and an unlimited number out of town, and also lifted all restrictions on the number of theaters it can buy in New York as of January 1985.

title: The City; Hearing Is Set On Bus Schedules
description: A hearing was scheduled for Wednesday in a dispute over when the Metropolitan Transportation Authority may put into effect busschedule changes that would reduce runs and eliminate paid lunchbreaks for many drivers.

title: New York; CARTOONS AND PARALYSIS
description: Campaign rhetoric has a way of turning complex social issues into cartoons and complex voters into stick figures who can be made instantly happy or sad with the shout of the appropriate slogan.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 9. 1. A. Lima, Peru. B. Teheran, Iran. C. Ramstein, West Germany. 2. State agencies would be required to inspect and assess the personal property and household effects of welfare recipients. 3.

title: AN OFFICER CHASING YOUTHS IN BROOKLYN KILLS PASSING CYCLIST
description: A Transit Authority police officer, firing at two suspects fleeing a pickpocketing yesterday, shot and killed a 26-year-old man who was riding by on a bicycle, the police said.

title: Mitsubishi Light Metal
description: Mitsubishi Light Metal Industries will close its aluminium refinery at Naoetsu next month because of slow domestic demand and cheap imports, industry sources said today. The company declined to comment but the sources said it has already cut production at the plant, Japan's largest with 160,000 ton a year capacity, by about 50 percent. If Naoetsu closes, the Sakaide plant in western Japan, with a 76,000-ton-a-year capacity, will be Mitsubishi's only aluminium smelter in operation.

title: Around the World; Bolivian Military Junta Names a New Ruler
description: Gen. Celso Torrelio Villa today became the latest army commander to rule Bolivia after tense discussions with his partners in the outgoing military junta.

title: PEPPER ASSERTS WHITE HOUSE SUPPRESSED RETIREMENT STUDY
description: The chairman of the House Select Committee on Aging said today that the Reagan Administration had suppressed a Labor Department study because its conclusions on mandatory retirement did not support the President's recommendations for reducing Social Security benefits.

title: PRINCIPALS UNFIT TO SERVE IN GHETTO SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: Curb on Apple Sugar Asked
description: The Agriculture Department proposed yesterday to meet consumer demand for less sweetness by revising Federal grade standards to reduce sugar content in apple juices and applesauces. The proposed grade standards would permit less sugar in higher grades of apple juice and in applesauce.

title: MERGER BID IS SEEN FOR THRIFT UNITS
description: The United Financial Corporation plans to acquire the West Side Federal Savings and Loan Association of New York and the Washington Savings and Loan Association of Miami for about $70 million, industry sources said yesterday. An agreement is expected to be worked out over the weekend, they added.

title: WASHINGTON - Once again, Central America and the Caribbean are back in the headlines, but this time the Administration response is so muted that the public may well be puzzled.
description: Was the charge by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in February that the Communists had a ''hit list'' of Central American target countries as overblown as recent analysis of the State Department White Paper would suggest? Is the Secretary of State still under wraps for diverting attention from the President's domestic program? Or is there a more important reason - belated recognition that no credible American policy for the area is possible unless it takes into account the key element of the equation, Mexico.

title: Prime Cut in Canada
description: Two of Canada's biggest banks, the Bank of Montr eal and the Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, said today that th ey had lowered their prime lending rate to 22 1/4 percent, from 22 3/4 percent, effective next Tuesday. The rollback follows by on e day a reduction in the official bank lending rate to 20.69 percent , from 21.07 percent.

title: Feeney Offers Apology On Behalf of 2 Umpires
description: The National League president, Chub Feeney, apologized today to the general manager of a local television station for a run-in between two umpires and a television reporter after a game at Veterans Stadium.

title: HARRIS AND METS TURN BACK BRAVES, 4-2
description: The Mets defeated a pitcher named Niekro for the first time in over a year last night when they beat the Atlanta Braves and Phil Niekro, 4-1, before 15,021 fans at Shea Stadium.

title: DATA TERMINAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
KOCH AND BARBARO CLASH SHARPLY OVER POTENTIAL REAL-ESTATE TAXES
description: In the testiest exchange of the mayoral campaign, Mayor Koch and Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro accused one another yesterday of misstatements and misunderstandings involving millions of dollars of New York City real-estate taxes.

title: SMALL RISE HAILED
description: The Government's Prod ucer Price Index for finished goods, a rough measure of the level of inflation consumers will face in the future, rose only three-tent hs of 1 percent in August, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Sports People;
description: A Denver jury has awarded $400,000 to Fran Lynch, a Bronco running back in the 1970's, in his suit against a doctor whom he accused of negligence du ring surgery he performed on Lynch's knee. The award was$40,000 highe r than Lynch was seeking.

title: Pan Am Debt K eeps Rating
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it was maintaining its current ''speculative'' ratings on the creditworthiness of the outstanding debt of Pan American World Airways.

title: When the Thrifts Try Free Enterprise
description: To the Editor:

title: CARTER, IN JAPAN, WARNS OF ANOTHER OIL CRISIS AND ASSAILS KHOMEINI
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that the West and Japan faced ''the danger of a third worldwide oil shock'' unless oil-importing industrial nations shook off ''a deadly sense of euphoria'' over a current glut of oil on the international market.

title: TASTY KANGAROOS
description: To the Editor:

title: JLG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes foreign currency gains of $919,000 or 29 cents a shr for the qr and $1,444,000 or 45 cents a shr for the yr...C-After foreign currency losses of $313,000 or 11 cents a shr for the qr and $11,000 or 4 cents a shr for the yr

title: BRIEFS
description: * AZL Resources Inc. said it purchased through a subsidiary 25 producing oil wells in Colorado and Nebraska for $6.8 million.

title: Patents; Tiny Disks For Music Player
description: WASHINGTON AMUSIC player patented this week reproduces sound stored in the bubble memories of plastic disks the size of half-dollars. One of the little records may contain a million bits of information.

title: DOW LOSES 5.33 MORE, FALLS TO A 15-MONTH LOW
description: The stock market incurred another broad decline yesterday in accelerated trading as investors' apprehension over high interest rates grew.

title: Texaco Reports Natural Gas Find
description: Texaco Inc. reported a natural gas find that flowed at the rate of 9.9 million cubic feet a day from a deep zone of the Charlson Field in the Williston Basin in North Dakota's McKenzie County. The well, which also yielded 179 barrels of liquefied natural gas, was drilled to a total depth of 14,075 feet.

title: HOW NOT TO GET STUNG
description: You've planned a picnic for this Labor Day weekend, and along with the Brie, the French loaves, the chicken in pesto and the pasta salads and the California white in the cooler, you plan perhaps to bring a wedge of sweet and sticky gateau, some nice ripe fruit, maybe some sweetish soft drinks.

title: NIPPON TELEGRAPH IS BUYING ABROAD
description: Hisashi Shinto says he learned the difficulty of selling to foreign companies and countries as an international salesman for a Japanese shipbuilder.

title: BELL UPHELD IN RULING ON GROWTH
description: In a victory for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, a Federal District Court judge ruled yesterday that the nation's biggest telephone company was not restricted by a 1956 legal agreement from entering new fields of business.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.00-20.50 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DUKE TRUSTEES BACK NIXON LIBRARY PLAN DESPITE FACULTY PLEA
description: The executive committee of Duke University's board of trustees resolved today to reject ''the thoughtful advice of the faculty'' and to proceed with a Richard M. Nixon Presidential Library adjacent to the campus.

title: Sulfur Price Raised by Elf
description: By Reuters

title: WHERE NOT TO PLACE A METHADONE CLINIC
description: To the Editor:

title: Grain Elevator Blast Hurts 5
description: A grain elevator explosion spewed 30-foot flames today and injured five persons, two of them seriously, the Fire Department said. The explosion occurred at Lousberg Grain and Feed Inc.

title: 18,700 Renaults Called Back
description: The American Motors Corporation said today that it was recalling 18,700 1981 Renault 18i passenger automobiles to check for potential defects in the fuel lines.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
Charles Weinstein, Executive And Ph ilanthropist, Dies at 84
description: Charles Weinstein, an executive in an apparel concern and a trustee and benefactor of the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn, died at the hospital Wednesday after a brief illness. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: IDAHO WOMAN IS SOUGHT AS SUSPECT IN HARBORING OF FUGITIVE SOVIET SPY
description: Federal marshals are looking for a 40-yearold Idaho woman who they believe harbored Christopher John Boyce, the convicted Soviet spy, for much of the 19 months that he was a fugitive.

title: Patents; Making the Sparks Fly While Roller Skating
description: A spark generator for roller skates has been invented by David Bergstein of Pound Ridge, N.Y. When the user tilts the skate somewhat backward, a mechanism comes into contact with a grindstone wheel and the sparks fly.

title: EXERPTS FROM VIEWS EXPRESSED BY HAIG
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of an interview with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. last night:

title: MEXICO REJECTS ACCUSATIONS ON SALVADOR
description: Mexico today characterized as ''totally false'' accusations by nine Latin American nations that the declaration by Mexico and France last week recognizing El Salvador's guerrilla opposition constituted interference in that country's internal affairs.

title: Federal Parking
description: Since the invention of the automobile, Federal employees who drove to work had always parked free at Government installations. That policy was changed by Presidential order in October 1979.

title: URBAN FARMERS DEVELOP THEIR OWN MARKET
description: HARTFORD IT isn't so much a case of what to do with all those zucchini, as it is what to do with all those tomatoes. Tomatoes, it seems, grow like weeds in the urban gardens and greenhouses of the rugged North End here. So the Hartford Food System, organizers of this experiment in city gardening, started a cannery. The cannery was financed by Hartford's Community Renewal Team and opened a year ago. It is located in the center of the Stowe Village public housing pr oject and is just now catching on, as neighborhood residents begin their late summer harvest.

title: Miss Lewis Is a Bride
description: At the Huguenot Memorial Presbyterian Church in Pelham Manor, N.Y., yesterday, Barbara Logan Lewis, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John S. Lewis of Pelham, N.Y., was married to John Andrew Buchman, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Buchman of Canton, Ohio. The Rev. Donald Kocher performed the ceremony.

title: SERVING NOTICE
description: Eighty years ago, on July 1, 1911, a German gunboat anchored off the port of Agadir on the Atlantic coast of Morocco, and lighted a fuse that, three years later, exploded in World War I. After the Gulf of Sidra incident, it is worth recalling the Agadir crisis. No one expects historical parallels to fit exactly, but the similarities are too close for comfort.

title: SAUDI INVITATION TO PRE-EMPTIVE STRIKES
description: To the Editor:

title: A GIANTS FOLLOWER CAN ONLY LOOK BACK
description: WHEN the Yankees had made the final out in the last year's American League playoff, I felt despair, not just because my favorite baseball team had been beaten but also because I knew I had not even the chance of a championship to look forward to in New York that winter. Only another dreary season following the Giants.

title: Temple 42, Wm. and Mary 0
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Jim Brown ran for three touchdowns and caught one of three scoring passes from Tink Murphy to lead the Temple attack.

title: Li Chung Pei, Miss Johnson Are Married
description: Susan Gerd Johnson, daughter of Mrs. Glenn D. Johnson of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Mr. Johnson, was married yesterday to Li Chung Pei, son of Mr. and Mrs. I.M. Pei of New York. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Locust Valley.

title: Jet Is Hijacked and Released
description: A 26-year-old man armed with a knife hijacked a jetliner on a domestic flight today, but later freed the passengers and surrendered. A spokesman for Varig Brazilian Airlines said no one was injured in the incident. The hijacker, identified by the police as Paulo Manoel de Lima, took over the Boeing 737 on a flight from Curitiba to Sao Paulo.

title: REGULARS PRESSING ANTI-HOLTZMAN CAMPAIGN
description: The Brooklyn Democratic organization is waging an extraordinary campaign to elect Norman Rosen, a political unknown, as District Attorney and defeat Elizabeth Holtzman in Thursday's Democratic primary.

title: VILLAGE IN TIPPERARY IS CASHING IN ON RONALD REAGAN'S ROOTS
description: This agreeable little village in the hills of County Tipperary is happily cashing in on a valuable new asset - Ronald Reagan's roots.

title: Sound; STALKING 'PERFECT' ACOUSTICS
description: Along the upper reaches of Seventh Avenue big posters invite you to ''Listen to the Glorious Sound of Carnegie Hall.'' They don't tell you who is playing or what, as if it didn't really matter. It's the sound that's being advertised.

title: Stage View; FLEDGLING PLAYWRIGHTS ARE BEING LURED FROM THE STAGE
description: The New Yor k theater is lunging - or plunging, bull-like - into thenew season wi th all flags flying, with all of the vital signs that have marked i t for the past six years intact. Ever since 1975, when the legitimat e stage found itself mysteriously restored to public favor - at fi rst the sensation was an eerie one, but that quickly gave way to s heer exhilaration - it has grown in girth, if not always in wis dom and grace. It's had more patrons occupying seats, it's had more money in the till, it's had more fat on it. And who would tell it to slim down? Let us give thanks, in this instance, forlarge favors.

title: Television Week
description: Troubled Youth In addition to his role as the Fonz's enterprising cousin Chachi in ''Happy Days,'' Scott Baio is a young actor whose other television credits have included more serious characterizations. For instance, in ''Stoned'' he played a high school sophomore whose use of marijuana brought him to the brink of disaster.

title: CITY REASSURED BY U.S. ON NEW HOUSING RULE
description: A new regulation on eligibility for publicly assisted housing will result in no evictions in New York City, according to an official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development,

title: Salazar to Defend Title In N.Y. City Marathon
description: Alberto Salazar, University of Oregon senior, will defend his New York City Marathon title Oct. 25, it was announced yesterday by Fred Lebow, president of the New York Road Runners Club.

title: PHILANTHROPY FROM FRIENDLY PERSUADERS
description: Chinese authorities have long been reluctant to accept foreign assistance from private American agencies. Yet, a few months ago, they welcomed a gift of $7.6 million worth of pacemakers. In part, the Chinese were swayed by need: There is a waiting list for the devices. ''Send as many as possible; even thousands could be put to good use,'' a leading surgeon cabled from Shanghai when told that 3,220 pacemakers were available.

title: A CHEF'S DELIGHT: MEAL FOR JULIA CHILD
description: NEW HAVEN MOST people might panic at the idea of cooking for Julia Child, but Michel LeBorgne says he feels honored. He is the chef for the Sept. 25 Long Wharf Theater fund-raising dinner at which 150 guests are paying $150 each for the privilege of dining with Julia Child. Mrs. Child will be in town for two different three-hour demonstrations ($25 per session, 2 to 5 P.M.) on the Long Wharf main stage Sept. 26 and 27.

title: For Ed Koch, the Democrat
description: When Mayor Koch took office in 1978, not even fairy godmothers would have lent money to the City of New York. The budget was badly out of balance and the four-year prospects were worse; the deficit predicted for 1981 was $1 billion.

title: 2 Senators Caution Moscow Against Intervening in Poland
description: Two visiting members of the United States Senate warned the Soviet Union today that military intervention in Poland would further damage relations with the West.

title: Amtrak Replacing Trains
description: CHICAGO (AP), Sept. 5 - Amtrak is retiring six French-built Turboliners because they are too expensive to operate, a railroad spokeman said. The trains, purchased for $25 million and introduced in 1973, were used on runs from Chicago to St. Louis, Milwaukee and Detroit. They are to be replaced by regular Amfleet trains, probably this month.

title: A SINKHOLE DOOMS A BUILDING
description: A 24-unit apartment house built 13 years ago on a landfill over a marsh must be torn down because it is slowly sinking into the sandy soil of South Jersey, officials here say.

title: MORE POETRY THAN POEMS
description: SHADOW TRAIN By John Ashbery. 50 pp. New York: The Viking Press. Cloth, $8.95. Penguin Books. Paper, $4.95.

title: The Nation; The Price of Getting an Edge
description: McDonnell Douglas Corporation is about to become the latest firm to be penalized for not playing by the rules in its pursuit of overseas sales.

title: Guest Observer
description: Achieving Marital Harmony

title: Ideas and Trends; Hyde Amendment Has Little Effect
description: Perhaps no issue arouses more incendiary feelings than abortion, as demonstrated once again last week by an anti-abortion groups' rally in Dallas protesting the nomination of Judge Sandra Day O'Connor to the Supreme Court. But according to a study published in The Journal of the American Medical Association last week, legislation that might have limited the availability of abortions has fulfilled neither side's dramatic predictions thus far.

title: Recordings; NEW BANDS ON SMALL LABELS ARE THE INNOVATORS OF THE 80'S
description: Remember the wild-eyed musician who howls indecipherable streamof-consciousness rants over an accompaniment of random electronic bleeps and squawks and then wonders why he doesn't make the top 40? He's been a kind of running joke in pop music circles since the 60's, but he has a point. Some of the people who make pop music just want to be entertaining and to make money, but even the ones with the loftiest ambitions, the ones who want to make art, want to make popular art. Any discussion of the vitality of popular music has to take the vitality of what's popular into account, and when what's popular is mostly sophomoric, played-by-the-book hard rock, along with the usual smattering of sentimental pop ballads, popular m usic just co uld be in trouble.

title: SAVE A BUNDLE: CLOSE BY OCT. 1
description: Many New York City real estate owners are scrambling to close big sales they have in the works before Oct. 1. That's when the city starts collecting the new 10 percent capital gains tax on milliondollar sales of income-producing property.

title: THEFT OF SURF CLAMS BESTIRS STATE AIDES
description: ATLANTIC CITY STATE officials and coastal fishermen said last week that some of the 150 million to 200 million surf clams illegally harvested in the Atlantic Ocean this year were taken from an area closed to fishing because of pollution.

title: MINOAN HIGHWAY IS FOUND IN SOUTHERN CRETE
description: Archeological excavations on Crete have uncovered a major highway that is presumed to have connected the 15th-century B.C. Minoan city of Phaistos with its southern seaport of Kommos.

title: Nielsen Aide Is the Fiance Of Miss Dale
description: Kathleen Hamlin Dale, a media producer for United Methodist Communications in New York, and William Chaloner McNair, a marketing research account executive with A.C. Nielsen Inc., plan to be married Oct. 17 at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Antiques; MANY PARTICIPANTS IN ORIGINAL FLEA MARKET
description: SALISBURY ALWAYS excepting, of course, the settings for lovely pastoral oils painted by John Constable in Salisbury, England, some 170 years ago, to antiques collectors the best known of all cow pastures is one situated off Route 44 in Salisbury, Conn. The meadow here, as it has for 24 years, provides the site each September for the Salisbury Flea Market, the original outdoor antiques show. More than 2 00 antiques dealers from throughout the Eastern states will be in li ne early next Saturday - many arriving before daybreak -to enter the field and to begin setting up displays in time to greet visitors when the show opens at 10 A.M. The outdoor exhibit and sale will continue until 5 P.M.

title: ROY COHN ON THE LAW
description: AND WIN! By Roy M. Cohn. 334 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $13.95.

title: RECENT HOME SALES;
description: Nassau East Meadow Cobalt La. 4-bedroom, 2-bath expanded ranch $63,000 New kitchen. Taxes $1,850 Floral Park Revere Dr. West 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath Tudor $101,000 Brick and stucco construction [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] ; fireplace. Taxes $2,100 Lido Beach Greenway Rd. 3-bedroom, 3-bath split-level $110,000 Fireplace, Florida room, walk to ocean. Taxes $4,000

title: BEHIND THE TRIGGER AT E.F. HUTTON
description: F EW chief executives project such predatory intensity as Robert M. Fomon, 56, chairman and chief executive of the E.F. Hutton Group, parent of the nation's second-largest retail brokerage house after Merrill Lynch . That intensity is in Mr. Fomon's narrow eyes and his prowling mann er; his taste for ptarmigan shoots in Spain; his collections o f hunting scenes, and large volumes with titles such as ''Birds of Pr ey.''

title: Lung Problem Corrected With Baby Still in Womb
description: A newborn girl who was treated for an extremely rare lung problem while still in her mother's womb was in stable condition today, a Medical College of Virginia official said.

title: Art; SCULPTURES AT THE WALL FOCUS GALLERY
description: CHESTER THE people who run the new Wall Focus Gallery, which opened in April in Chester, are doing something right. At the moment, and only until Sept. 15, they are showing the work of a talented and not very well known sculptor named Mary Tarleton Knollenberg, who also happens to be 76 years old.

title: GEORGIA TROUNCES VOLS, 44-0
description: Herschel Walker picked up today where he left off last season, gaining 161 yards on 30 carries and scoring one touchdown as Georgia defeated Tennessee, 44-0, to open the season with its 14th consecutive victory.

title: Topics; Counterfeit / Coins
description: As Time Goes By

title: STILL ANOTHER BAD YEAR FOR DETROIT
