description: DETROIT I T has been two years of unrelenting misery for the American automobile industry. And what could well be the third, the 1982 model year, is beginning this month on the note of scaled-down production, a reluctant marketplace and few signs of a real rebound anytime soon.

title: BEWARE, RENTERS
description: TO many young people, owning a home seems about as attainable as winning the lottery. In fact, the lottery probably offers better odds. The only reasonable hope seems to be ''Let's Make a Deal,'' or ''Name That Tune.''

title: Moon in Kodiak
description: Eighteen months after the business branch of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church had opened the most modern fish cannery in Kodiak, the Alaskan town was reported tense.

title: DECLINE IN CITY SERVICES CITED IN EXODUS OF BRONX INDUSTRY
description: A deteriorated environment - caused and exacerbated by a decline in city services - is the most to blame for the exodus of manufacturing companies from the South Bronx, according to the director of a study conducted by Fordham University.

title: EDITOR'S CHOICE
The 'Other' Hardy
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET SIX SETS BACK U.S., 4-1
description: There was no vengeful gloating by the Soviet players today after their convincing 4-1 victory over the Americans in a Canada Cup match at Edmonton Coliseum. Nor was their any noticeably dashed pride among the losing Americans.

title: Practical Traveler; WHEN A TOUR'S PROMISES CAN'T BE MET
description: Little in the travel business is as murky as the question of what you are entitled to when a vacation package or tour is canceled or substantially changed because of an ''act of God.''

title: Susan Hatfield Is Wed To Dr. Jerrold Zeitels
description: Susan Mary Hatfield, daughter of Mrs. Malcolm Hatfield of St. Joseph, Mich., and the late Probate Judge Hatfield, was married in Chicago yesterday to Dr. Jerrold Roy Zeitels, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harry L. Zeitels of New Rochelle, N.Y. Circuit Judge Irving Eiserman performed the ceremony at the Bond Chapel of the University of Chicago.

title: A DASHING DELIVERY AT $99- AND UP
description: If you're a gentleman en route to Africa who suddenly found the need for a tuxedo from home, a bank executive with $50 million of checks sitting unproductively uncleared in Zurich, or a hustling television promoter in Britian trying to keep up the last-minute suspense on ''Who Shot J.R.?'' you have in common World Courier Service Inc.

title: The Free Market In Language
description: Jim Quinn's ''Watchdogs of the Word'' (On Language, July 12) nicely deflates the overblown criticisms of some language watchers. In espousing a sort of ''free market'' view of language, however, Mr. Quinn makes room for a serious abuse.

title: Wyoming 38 Cal State-Fullerton 13
description: The quarterback Phil Davis threw two touchdowns, and the Wyoming defense forced seven turnovers. Davis, a senior from Los Cerritos, Calif., hit James Williams, the tight end, for a 4-yard touchdown.

title: About Westchester
description: FLORENCE BOVELL is 61, but she looks older. She lives in a 12-by-15-foot room on the 11th floor of a federally subsidized apartment building in White Plains and leaves only to be taken to twice-a-week dialysis treatments at the Westchester County Medical Center. Once a vital woman, she spends her days propped against five pillows. She is the victim of kidney failure and a neurological condition. Her apartment is spotless, but crowded with mementos of holidays long past - Christmas cards, a toy Easter bunny; on the night table is a framed photograph of a son who lives in the Virgin Islands.

title: Older Travelers
description: To the Editor:

title: Opener '81: Host to Eagles
description: The Giants open their 57th season today with their 77th consecutive home sellout. More than 76,000 spectators are expected at Giants Stadium to watch the Giants oppose the Philadelphia Eagles, who lost last season's Super

title: Ideas and Trends; 'Women's Work' Still Pays Less
description: The forces of feminism and affirmative action have brought new cadres of women into the labor force. But, according to a study released last week, they have hardly won for these workers the benefits of equal pay.

title: Music; TRIP TO WOODSTOCK SHOULD BE OF VALUE
description: BECAUSE concert life in the county is basically at intermission during the first half of September, consider the easy drive up to Woodstock, N.Y., where one can still enjoy the final two programs in the 66th annual Maverick summer series.

title: CITY BUILDING BBOOM GENERATES NEW JOBS
description: New York City's current construction boom, greater than in any year since 1972, has given employment in the building trades a boost. However, minority-group members still contend that their progress in getting jobs in the industry has been disappointing.

title: MAYORAL RACES MARK TUESDAY PRIMARIES
description: HARTFORD THE first round in the race for municipal offices - in some places the only important round -takes place on Tuesday in 55 towns and cities. Nominations for offices ranging from mayor and selectman to town clerk are at stake in about 65 separate primaries, most of them Democratic.

title: CABARET
description: Tammy Grimes has a voice with a throaty, quivering lilt. It might be described as a lyric baritone - slightly higher than the rumbliing basso of Tallulah Bankhead but a bit below the firmly purposed cadence of Katharine Hepburn.

title: LOPEZ PORTILLO PROPOSES AND FOLLOWS CODE BANNING 'CANCER' OF CORRUPTION
description: The ranch sounded like an ideal retreat for an athletic former president, with its 150 acres of pastures and hills and its stables, shooting range, swimming pool, gymnasium, tennis court and artist's studio.

title: Navy Finds Missing Missile
description: Navy divers have found a missile with a ''highly explosive warhead'' from an Air Force F-111B jet that crashed off the Maine coast last fall, but have resubmerged it because of fears that it might explode, a Pentagon spokesman said today. The device is a training version of a short-range attack missile, the spokesman said.

title: CANTOR IN THE FAMILY TRADITION
description: NORWALK SOMETIMES when Cantor Deborah Katchko-Zimmerman is singing a portion of the Friday night Sabbath service at Congegation Beth El here, she says she feels a special awareness of her own family history and its deep immersion in Jewish music.

title: Pakistan Says 2 Afghan Jets Twice Strafe a Frontier Post
description: Two Afghan MIG jet fighters twice strafed a Pakistani border post today, injuring two civilians, the Pakistani Defense Ministry said.

title: Music View; PICKING UP MUSICAL RUBBLE AFTER THE EARTHQUAKE
description: One optimistic way to look at the state of creative music today is to stress the apparent eagerness of many young musicians to rebuild what appears to be a dest royed city. In the a ftermath of an earthquake, they are learning to make bricks out of clay, hammers outof sticks and rocks, and saws out of dinosaur 's teeth. They are finding it necessary to go back to the beginn ing and think through the reasons for music's existence and to rein vent a craft, if not an art. There certainly is hope in this, for reg eneration in the arts sometimes can come with startling swiftness. But how did we arrive atthis strange pass?

title: MICHAEL'S TEAM SEEKS RESPECT
description: THE New York Jets seem to be the most respected 4-12 team in football. This season, they may even respect themselves. It does not appear to be idle pr eseason locker-room talk when the players speak of a new attitude. That attitude, along with experienceand Freeman M cNeil at halfback, marks the significant differences between the 1 980 and 1981 clubs.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 4 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 2 3 6 THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Chief of Detectives (ret.) Edward X. Delaney on the trail of the elusive killer of out-of-town businessmen visiting New York. 3 2 18 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 4 4 22 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 5 5 11 THE GLITTER DOME, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow/Perigord, $12.95.) Two veteran homicide detectives trapped by the seductive vices of Hollywood. 6 6 13 GOODBYE, JANETTE, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Two randy sisters at large in the Parisian world of haute couture. 7 9 7 TRADE WIND, by M.M. Kaye. (St. Martin's, $15.) Love and death in exotic 19th-century Zanzibar.

title: Prison Guards' Protest Spreads as Some Return
description: As a walkout by guards spread to the state's top-security prison today, a dozen guards returned to work at another prison where the protest over working conditions began, officials said.

title: THERE'S A STING TO THE TAX BILL
description: W hile the Reagan tax bill will be a bonanza for many investors, a handful of little-known administrative provisions in the legislation will also cut the other way. These provisions will exact sharply higher interest charges from people who under pay their taxes and severely punish investors who purchase questi onable tax-shelters.
To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; An Assessment Of Jets and Giants
description: IN their National Football League seasons that begin today, the Jets believe they'll be better while the Giants hope they'll be better. That's the difference two years have made in the patient reorganization of these two New York teams that have been troubled for too long.

title: CADILLAC IS FEATURING A SMALLER ENGINE
description: ED KENNARD was in New York this week, rehearsing at the Wintergarden Theater. The sign on the marquee said ''42nd Street,'' but that show had long since moved on to the Majestic, and Mr. Kennard wasn't looking for his big break anyway. As Mr. Cadillac, he already had the starring role locked up.

title: U.S. Consulate Is Bombed
description: Three gasoline bombs were thrown at the American Consulate early today, causing minor damage but no injuries, the police said. Only two exploded.

title: Caroline Moody Lawyer's Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Elliott Moody of Haddonfield, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Carol ine Leisenring Moody, toRoy Bertram Simpson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Simpson of Greenwich, Conn.

title: SPORTS CENTER STILL ONE OF U.S.'S BUSIEST
description: WHEN Memorial Stadium was dedicated 50 years ago, it was expected that the new sports com plex, which still has the only rooftop covering in Westchester County, would receive liberal use from members of the community.

title: DEFICIT EXPECTED AGAIN
description: FINAL figures indicate that last year's deficit was slightly worse than anticipated, and numbers from the first month of the current fiscal year indicate that the state is working up anot her deficit of similar size.

title: HOW U.S. CUTBACK IN AID AFFECTS SCHOOLS
description: CHILDREN in the county face a calm school opening this week, with no teacher strikes, fewer closings of elementary schools reported and less impact from Federal cutbacks in funds than had been predicted last spring.

title: CENSUS TOTALS SHOW NATION IS DIVERSE AS NEVER BEFORE
description: WASHINGTON DURING much of its history, the United States has had an official policy of admitting immigrants of white European stock while barring those from Asian, African and Latin nations. In recent years, however, all that has changed. The inscription on the Statue of Liberty, unveiled in 1886, shortly after passage of the Chinese Exclusion Act and inviting ''your huddled masses yearning to breathe free,'' no longer has a hollow ring to people whose skin is black, brown or yellow.

title: 'I NEVER THINK OF POSTERITY'
description: From time to time The Book Review has invited both new and established writers to comment on various aspects of their craft: their imaginative and autobiographical sources, their practices of composition, the origin of their sense of vocation. These essays are intended to provide a forum for writers to consider the rewards and perils of their craft. By JOHN SAYLES

title: THE ISLES OF GREECE
description: To the Editor:

title: EPIDEMIC IN CUBA SETS OFF DISPUTE WITH U.S.
description: Cuba has been hit this summer by an epidemic of dengue fever that has made 340,000 people ill and has killed about 150. The epidemic has also spawned a bitter political dispute between the United States and Cuba.

title: THE C.I.A.'S UNCLASSIFIED LOOSE CANNONS
description: Can the United States prevent former C.I.A. agents from selling skills and knowledge acquired on the job to foreign governments or organizations? Does the Central Intelligence Agency inform other American Government branches when ex-agents, engaged in private business, falsely claim a continuing C.I.A. association? William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, has been asking these and related questions in the wake of disclosures that two former agents, Edwin P. Wilson and Frank E. Terpil, have been selling their expertise in intelligence, arms and explosives to the Libyan Government to train terrorists.

title: SHOULD WE (AND COULD WE) RETURN TO THE GOLD STANDARD
description: WASHINGTON KEYNES called it the ''barbarous relic.'' Lenin said it was fit only to adorn the latrines of the world. Ten years ago President Nixon, in effect, tore the world's currencies loose from it by pulling the dollar away from a gold peg. Still, gold has lost neither its romantic allure nor its practical attraction.

title: READING RESULTS GIVE THE SCHOOLS A LIFT
description: When Edward I. Koch went to the Board of Education building in downtown Brooklyn one sunny morning in May to participate in a news conference, it was one of the few times in recent years that a mayor of New York City made a public appearance at the school system's headquarters.

title: Sports of The Times; New Role in Sports For Peggy Fleming
description: PEGGY FLEMING was excited about two young comedians she had been scouting for her new ice show. They were, she was saying, ''so funny you could die.''

title: Managing Coffee
description: To the Business Editor: ''Pushing the Maxwell Product at General Foods'' (Aug. 16), concerning General Foods' brand manager, John Susko, makes Maxwell House look like a sinking ship. If Mr. Susko doesn't plan to stay with his product for more than a year, then maybe he knows something his superiors don't.

title: Sikh in British Army Is Lured T o a Belfast Flat and Is Killed
description: The Irish Republican Army took responsibility for the fatal shooting today of an off-duty British soldier who was killed after being lured to an apartment by two women.

title: GYPSY MOTH EGGS CONTINUING THREAT
description: RECENT preliminary air detection and on-the-ground reconnaissance surveys in the southern region of the Hudson Valley indicate some decline in the gypsy moth population, but the problem has not disappeared from Westchester County. Areas adjacent to those hardest hit show signs of increased population, according to Harry Decker, regional forester for the state's Department of Environmental Conservation in New Paltz.

title: Article 261132 -- No Title
description: A 19-year-old man turned out to be the luckiest of 2,000 ticket holders who paid $100 each in a boys' club raffle of a $113,000 home in Fairfax.

title: IN LIVELY MORELIA, THE STREETS ARE HARMONIOUS BY DECREE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- SARAH FERRELL is an editor on the staff of the Travel Section. By SARAH FERRELL

title: Connecticut Journal
description: RAIL freight service in Connecticut is moving with uncommon speed this fall - to get out of the state. If all goes as planned, Conrail will be out of Connnecticut, Rhode Island, and a large chunk of Massachusetts by early next year, under provisions of a bill signed by President Reagan last month. Last week the complicated job of finding another company to take over began.

title: Dale Smolen Married to Jeremy Ragus
description: Dale Fern Smolen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Smolen of East Meadow, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeremy Louis Ragus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Ragus of Scarsdale, N.Y. The couple were married by contract in a self-written and self-performed garden ceremony at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y.

title: Paul Levinger, Owner Of Speidel Corporation
description: Paul Levinger, former president of the Speidel Corporation, died yesterday at his home after a four-year illness. He was 77 years old.

title: LET WOMEN HAVE OWN SAY
description: To the Sports Editor: It is reassuring to know that women's collegiate athletics can turn to the National Collegiate Athletic Association for leadership. Undoubtedly the N.C.A.A. now realized that women deserve the same guidance that has made college football and men's basketball, not to mention a bevy of less-touted sports, what they are today: greedy slaves to television contracts and gate receipts, with coaches who would sell their mothers for a blue-chip recruit.

title: Change of Perspective On Woodmere Hostel
description: A number of salient facts were omitted from a recent Long Island Journal item on the attempt to establish a hostel for the mentally retarded in a small section of the unincorporated area of Woodmere by the New York State Office of the Mental Retardation and Developmental Disabilities.

title: 2 MORE OF TEHERAN'S LEADERS DIE AS CHALLENGE TO REVOLUTION GROWS
description: The theocratic rule of Iran's mullahs is facing its most determined internal challenges in two and a half years of postrevolutionary chaos, but the Islamic regime still appears to be held together by the powerful charisma of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Fruit Fly Checkpoints Delay California Holiday Travelers
description: Thousands of Labor Day weekend travelers were delayed up to an hour at Mediterranean fruit fly checkpoints today, and officials said quarantines might continue into January in some areas.

title: AIDING THE DISABLED
description: I F you think we're in trouble with Social Security retirement benefits, consider the problems we face with So cial Security disability benefits.

title: THE ROYAL FOREBEARS
description: In his delightful account of Britain's ruling family, R.W. Apple Jr. quotes Charles Kidd, editor of Debrett's Peerage, as saying the royal family can be ''conveniently restricted to the first 22 people in the line of succession to the throne.'' Despite the fact that Mr. Apple reports the crown's relations with the Lascelles family as ''chilled,'' the Earl of Harewood, oldest grandchild of George V, is 23d in line for the throne, followed by his three sons - Viscount Lascelles, the Hon. James and the Hon. Jeremy Lascelles.

title: YANKEES SUBDUE ROYALS, 2-1
description: Dave Righetti outpitched Larry Gura today as the Yankees scored a 2-1 victory over the Royals and ended Gura's domination over them. Graig Nettles scored both runs in the Yankees' seventh victory in their last nine games.

title: Gardening; UNHERALDED FLOWERING SHRUBS
description: THE bush cinquefoil is one of the unheralded flowering shrubs suitable for planting in the Northern garden. To be certain, it is well known and frequently used in the far North, where extremely cold winter weather limits the choice of flowering shrubs, but it is overlooked in favor of such shrubs as azaleas, rhododendrons and the like in our somewhat milder region. Yet, here it is late summer, and the cinquefoils are still in bloom. In fact, they have been flowering since June or July, and will continue to flower almost until the arrival of frost. Azaleas and rhododendrons, on the other hand, have long since lost their blooms and will not flower again until the arrival of another spring.

title: HUMANISTS BEGIN TO RALLY IN ANCIENT BATTLE OF
description: CREEDS by WRAY HERBERT

title: NANCY ASTOR'S 2D PLACE IN COMMONS HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SUN NEVER SETS ON HIS EMPIRE
description: PARIS P IERRE CARDIN has designed eveything from airplanes to zoot suits, from bijoux to bath towels. An impoverished dressmaker at the beginning of his career, he was a multimillionaire 20 years later with the largest number of licensees in designerdom, manufacturing scores of products under his name.

title: Paige Lescure Married To Stuart F. Smith 3d
description: Paige Lescure, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Motter Lescure Jr. of Cheshire, Conn., and Squirrel Island, Me., was married yesterday to Stuart Farwell Smith 3d, son of Mrs. Preston Reed of Farmington, Conn., and the late R. Graeme Smith. The Rev. Gordon Lind, an Episcopal priest of Edgecomb, Me., performed the ceremony at The Chapel on Squirrel Island.

title: MET PITCHERS STIFLE BRAVES, 4-1
description: After his Atlanta Braves had lost their second consecutive game to the Mets, 4-1, yesterday afternoon at Shea Stadium, Manager Bobby Cox paced back and forth about his office beneath the stands. He was annoyed and angry and bore a stern expression. The locker room had cleared, but Cox wanted to spend some time alone and try to figure out what happened.

title: East German Oarsmen Ga in 8 Spots in Finals
description: East Germany dominated today's s emifinal com petition in the world rowing championships, placing eight entries in the finals.

title: Television Week
description: Ordinary People

title: SALVATION ARMY VERONA-BOUND
description: AFTER 101 years, lower costs and the opportunity to consolidate all its national operations under one roof are luring the Salvation Army's national quarters from Manhattan to suburban New Jersey.

title: NEW TENNIS LAYOUT
description: WHILE overcrowding and the rising costs of court time are forcing many people to quit the sport, tennis buffs in Mercer County have been luxuriating this summer at their new 26-court public facility.

title: LISTENERS ARE READERS, TOO
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Sam H. Shirakawa writes frequently about recordings. By SAM H. SHIRAKAWA

title: Hungary Executes Murderer
description: Ferenc Morvai, 25 years old, was executed today for murdering an East German in 1980 and attempting to rape his victim's wife, the Hungarian press agency said. It said Mr. Morvai had met the East Germans in a restaurant, strangled the man with a belt and then tried with two friends to rape the man's wife. Last July the accomplices were given prison terms of five and three and a half years.

title: Essay; HAVING A CUP OF TEA
description: In a recent dispatch from the Middle East, it was pointed out in this space, that ''the tension growing between Moslems and Coptic Christians in Egypt is papered over by posters of a benevolent dictator.''

title: Environews
description: THE Federal Environmental Protection Agency cut short its investigation last March, when laborers swore that no dumping had occurred. At the same time, the state's Department of Environmental Protection said that it would not pursue its investigation.

title: MAN; 21,HELD
description: The partly disrobed body of a 16-year-old girl who had apparently been strangled in a sexual attack was found in a heavily wooded section of a cemetery in Brooklyn yesterday, and the police arrested a 21-year-old acquaintance for her murder.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Lane Kirkland, head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., recently compared President Reagan's actions in the air traffic controllers' strike to those of Hitler and Stalin. He would have been more accurate if he had mentioned Harry Truman.

title: WHY DO SOME STUDENTS CHEAT?
description: RESEARCH papers advertised for sale. Cadets dismissed in cheating scandals. Students hiding formulas in calculator cases. Most adults do not hesitate to castigate the students involved in actions like these. Yet, adults must assume some of the responsibility for student cheating.

title: MUCH BLOOD
description: THE THIRD DEADLY SIN By Lawrence Sanders. 444 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $13.95. By PETER ANDREWS

title: Wendy Thomas Bride of Banker
description: Wendy Sue Thomas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John I. Thomas of Las Cruces, N.M., was married yesterday to Ethan Carroll Stapleton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred B. Stapleton of Little Compton, R.I. The Rev. Dr. Robert P. Lawrence performed the Congregational ceremony in the garden of the Stapleton home.

title: DR. MARGARET A. FRENCH IS AFFIANCED TO A PHYSICIAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Millard R. French of Ludlow, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Margaret A. French, to Dr. Andrew Gettinger, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen A. Gettinger of Huntington Bay, L.I.

title: SCHOOLS' OPENING SPOTLIGHT AID CUTS
description: MONROE WHEN the schools reopened last Wednesday in this Fairfield County town, there were some changes that illustrate the financial pinch on schools all across the Connecticut in this new school year.

title: 13 Food Establishments Cited As in Violation of Health Code
description: Thirteen food establishments were found by the Health Department last week to be in violation of New York City's health code. The department also noted that one had been reopened following a final reinspection, and that another had been closed for failure to correct a violation.

title: The World; Crop News Sends Ripples Through Soviet Economy
description: Somebody - or something - up there isn't smiling on Soviet farmers again this year. Russia's hottest summer in 100 years, bracketed by heavy rains last fall that curtailed seeding and recent downpours that have flattened mature crops, threatened last week to produce one of the Soviet Union's worst grain harvests.

title: Television Week
description: Miss America Paul Whiteman, one of the most successful orchestra leaders of the 1920's and 30's, suggested to Albert A. Marx, president of the Atlantic City Chamber of Commerce in 1953 that the Miss America beauty contest, which had been held there since 1921, be televised. Mr. Marx agreed, and since 1954 the pageant has been available on the home screen - first via ABC, then CBS and now NBC. In 1966, NBC first televised the pageant in color.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an outdated announce- ment from the Stonewall Repertory Company, an article last Sunday in- correctly reported the casting for the company's first production of the sea- son, ''Risin' to the Love We Need.'' Andre De Shields will not be in it.

title: Phillies 5, Reds 4
description: PHILADELPHIA (AP) - A two-run single by Pete Rose capped a winning Philadelphia rally after two outs in the eighth inning. The Reds' Mario Soto (8-8) had two out and none on when Greg Gross walked and Manny Trillo singled.

title: Herbert Karlitz Weds Dorothy Marie Weber
description: Dorothy Marie Weber, daughter of Mrs. Wilfred Dube of Concord, N.H., was married yesterday to Herbert Stephen Karlitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Karlitz of Brooklyn. Rabbi Charles Mintz of Harristown, Pa., performed the ceremony at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hote l.

title: CRICKET: TOP RANK
description: EAST MEADOW DRESSED in white flannel uniforms and seemingly oblivious to the Sunday summer weather, the cricketers arrayed around the Eisenhower Park meadow applauded politely and bantered good-naturedly in Jamaican-flavored voices. Suddenly, the air was punctuated with sounds of jubilation as the Villagers defeated Doc's Eleven in a crucial Long Island Cricket League match.

title: The Isles of Greece
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET REPORTS 100,000 ON MANEUVERS NEAR POLAND
description: The Soviet Union reported today that nearly 100,000 troops were participating in military exercise that began yesterday in the Baltic region near Poland.

title: GREECE PROTESTS REPORT ON ATHENS DIG BY U.S. ARCHEOLOGISTS
description: The Greek Government has formally protested to the American School of Classical Studies over its unauthorized disclosure that it had discovered the famous painted stoa of Athens, a fifth-century B.C. building next to the ancient agora that served as a prominent center of art and intellectual thought in ancient Greece.

title: BEGIN VISIT MAY MAKE AMBIGUOUS ALLIANCE CLEARER
description: Beneath the formal agenda for Menachem Begin's visit to the United States, which begins today, a shadow issue colors the deliberations - the ambiguity of Israel's role in the American geopolitical strategy, the contradiction between Israel the American asset and Israel the American burden.

title: THE RISKY WORLD OF STRATEGIC METALS; I
description: N July, New York State authorities raided the Wall Street offices of the Mineral Resources Corporation, a strategic-metals trading concern, and charge d its salesmen with having obtain ed as much as $2 million from investors who paid for tantalum and instead were sold less expensive scrap metal.

title: KLEINDIENST TRIAL RECALLS NIXON ERA
description: Curious echoes of the Watergate era, including a revival of never-answered questions about the relationship between President Nixon and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, are being heard in a courtroom here.

title: CULTURE MAKES A CAPITAL GAIN
description: There is an oft-told tale here that when the Sadler's Wells ballet was booked to play Washington some years ago, the only place deemed suitable was Constitution Hall, the historic building owned by the Daughters of the American Revolution. Its maintenance crew prepared for the occasion by waxing the stage, with predictable results: Margot Fonteyn danced out, slipped on the highly polished floor and fell on her tutu.

title: A FEMINIST'S LAMENT
description: Anne Taylor Fleming's plea that we ''keep quiet about certain things'' and treat each other gently and generously is nothing more than a plea that we all remain ladies, and feminine and nice.

title: Another Effect Of Controllers' Strike?
description: The air traffic controllers must now look upon their precipitous strike action and the resultant dismissal notices as all a bad dream. Most citizens share a sense of sorrow for the many victims, who were drawn into this crisis because there was no provision for binding arbitration.

title: MUSEUMS BECKONING HOLIDAYERS
description: TRADITIONALLY, Labor Day weekend is the ''last big weekend'' of summer, and it is usually marked by outdoor activities. People head for the countryside for the ''last big picnic'' or to the seashore for the ''last big swim.''

title: GERMAN LEFTISTS TRY OUT A LITTLE RIGHT MUSIC
description: There is no Labor Day in Europe to mark a change of gears and speeds, no signal on the calendar that the soft, warm days are over. Rather, Europe glides back to work. So it was that Helmut Schmidt eased back into his office pretty much the way he's done for seven summers. Only this time, he discovered that while he was sailing and mowing the grass at his little house on a lake, things had gotten measurably out of hand.

title: Wilhelm Pauck, 80; Theologian and Author
description: Dr. Wilhelm Pauck, an internationally recognized theologian and expert on the Reformation, died Friday at Stanford Hospital after an extended illness. He was 80 years old.

title: OPERETTA: SECOND IN CAST IN 'NORWAY'
description: One of the strangest things about the 1944 Robert Wright-George Forrest musical version of Grieg's life, ''Song of Norway,'' being revived by the New York City Opera, is that it hardly seems to be about Grieg at all.

title: NINE CRITICS VIEW THE CHANGING STATE OF THE ARTS IN AMERICA
description: ealthy? Full of vitality? Moribund? Conservative? Innovative? Just plain commercial? Nine Times critics were asked to assess the state of the arts in America. What do they find?

title: Food; GROUND MEAT MADE GLORIOUS
description: For reasons that can only be guessed at, more ground meat is used in American kitchens each year than in all the kitchens of Europe combined. And much of it makes its way into meat loaves, dishes in which we have long had a special interest. One version of this ground meat specialty that we admire in particular is a French creation known as gateau de viande, or ''meat cake.'' The one we have in mind is best when made with a combination of beef, veal, pork, mushrooms and chicken livers. It is, in fact, a very basic form of pate. In our home kitchen, we recently prepared this one, as well as a meat loaf ''chinoise,'' or meat loaf Chinese-style, made with ginger, garlic, scallions and water chestnuts. At the same time, we also tried another version, an Italian inspiration made with chicken, veal and dried, imported mushrooms from Italy.

title: A PLEA ON SCHOOL FINANCING
description: DURING the last several months of the 1980-81 school year, school systems in small cities in the state (those under 125,000 population) struggled with a financial crisis in a ritual embodying all the features of a major dramatic production. With plots and subplots, climaxes and anticlimaxes and long lists of dramatis personae, they suffered through a series of conflicts, only reaching at the 11th hour the denouement in the form of a supplementary budget signed by the Governor on July 22.

title: Brigham Young 31 Long Beach State 6
description: Jim McMahon, the nation's leading passer last season, threw for 403 yards today but defense and running scored the Brigham Young touchdowns.

title: FIVE BLACK ARTISTS ARE FEATURED ON A NEW LABEL
description: Recordings play a vital part in any musician's career, both as a means to communicate with a broad audience and to achieve status recognition in an intensely competitive field. The barriers facing black musicians in this area are still formidable, particularly for instrumentalists who so far have not received sufficient opportunities to display their talents as recording artists. Since the situation will not be improved with the wave of a wand, special conditions are apparently necessary in order for black musicians to make records.

title: STRIKE BY HAWAII TUG CREWS SLASHES VITAL BARGE SERVICE
description: Striking tugboat operators and maintenance workers have forced a cutback of more than 50 percent in vital local barge service among the Hawaiian islands.

title: Iran Killings Reach the Top
description: Iran is running short of just about everything but ''martyrs.'' Pr esident Mohammed Ali Rajai and Prime Minister Mohammed Javad Ba honar were the ranking victims last week in a summer-long series ofgu errilla attacks whose deadliness has been exceeded only by that of th e Islamic Government's firing squads.

title: TV View; THE HOME SCREEN'S NEW FACE
description: With a new season fast approaching, television finds itself perched on two giant question marks. In terms of content, the three broadcast networks are caught in an uncomfortable squeeze. While they want desperately to compete directly with cable, which is much more permissive about subject matter and language, they are increasingly being forced to assure self-appointed watchdog groups like the Moral Majority that a lid will be clamped on the type of material those groups find objectionable.

title: BED-AND-BREAKFAST IDEA TAKES HOLD ON THE ISLAND
description: PORT JEFFERSO N KATHLEEN DE XTER and Marya Dodd, longtime friends and neighbors, have brought a touch of England, Germany and France to this North Shore communi ty, and with such success that they are about to export their idea to other areas of the Island.

title: The World; Another Military Man for Bolivia
description: Gen. Celsio Torrelio Villa, who last week became the latest army commander to assume the presidency of Bolivia, has a reputation for honesty. If he preserves that reputation despite the temptations of office, he will be an exceptional President indeed.

title: BEACH PLUMS READY TO PICK AND COOK
description: BEACH plums are unpredictable. The wild crop of small, tart, red and purple fruit that ripens in late summer near the shore can vary from scanty to bountiful, depending upon the year. This season the beach plums seem to be in good supply.

title: CAMPAIGNS IN BROOKLYN FOCUS ON CRIME AND KOCH
description: Vito P. Battista, whose efforts to lure news coverage have included posing with an elephant on Wall Street, was giving a speech in his campaign for the Republican nomination for City Councilman at Large from Brooklyn.

title: JOURNAL SQUARE: COMEBACK ROAD IS A LONG ONE
description: JERSEY CITY IT USED to be that if a resident of northern New Jersey wanted to go shopping in what was recognized as the best retail area in that part of the state, the automatic choice was Journal Square, the hub of Jersey City.

title: Michael MacKuen Weds Michele Matis Hoyman
description: Michele Matis Hoyman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Scott Mitchell Hoyman of Rutherford, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Bruce MacKuen, son of Brig. Gen. W.H. Bruce Erwin, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Erwin of Arlington, Va. The Rev. Dr. Philip Cato performed the ceremony at G race Episcopal Church in Rutherford, N.J. The Rev. GlennMarshall Mati s, a cousin of the bride, assisted.

title: Head of the Jesuit Order Leaves Rome Hospital
description: The Rev. Pedro Arrupe, the Superior General of the Jesuit order, was discharged from a Rome hospital today, a month after a stroke left him partly paralyzed.

title: Critics' Choices
description: FILM New York now has a movie theater devoted exclusively to films from Australia and New Zealand. The D.W. Griffith Theater, on 59th Street near Second Avenue, will launch its new policy this Friday, with an Australian Film Festival to commemorate the occasion.

title: DAYS LOST TO STRIKES EASE OFF
description: Thus far, 1981 has been a relatively peaceful one for the American workforce. Through July, the Department of Labor estimates that 19.6 million worker days have been lost due to strikes, down 5 percent from year-earlier levels.

title: NEW BLACK GROUP STRESSES EDUCATION
description: R THE black c ommunity in Mount Vernon has become the second in the country to or ganize a chapter of the New Union of Blacks to Improve America.

title: ATHLETE'S DEATH IN JAIL BRINGS $50 MILLION SUIT
description: Shortly before noon on June 2, Ron Settles, a 21-year-old star football player at Long Beach State University, was stopped for speeding. Three hours later he was found dead in a jail cell in Signal Hill, 20 miles from downtown Los Angeles.

title: OFF TO A GOOD START
description: ------------ --------------------------------------------------------Tickets to th e following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherw ise indicated. --------------------------------------------------------------------- ARMORY SHOW Sept. 9 - Though Claude Montana, the Paris designer, has come down to earth, as it were, after the futuristic extremes of former years, he hasn't lost his dramatic flair. His winter pret-a-porter collection presented by Bergdorf Goodman at the Seventh Regiment Armory at 8 P.M. has a softer look with luxurious leathers, furs and Donegal tweeds, but the outsize hats are still in evidence. Elaine Learson, a model, and Christopher Forbes, a member of the publishing family, are chairmen for show to benefit the Grey Art Gallery and Study Center of New York University. Committee members include such luminaries from the art world as Leo Castelli and Andre Emmerich, the gallery owners; David Hockney, James Rosenquist and Andy Warhol, the artists; Francesco Scavullo, the photographer, and Barbara Rose, the historian. The gallery is involved with all aspects fo the visual arts. Cocktails and hors d'oeuvres will be served. Tickets $35 per person, $50 per couple.

title: Notes; NEW SPECIAL-INTEREST TOURS OF CHINA AND SOME SEASONAL PRICE REDUCTIONS
description: Several new developments of interest to those planning to visit China have been announced, among them price reductions for fall and winter trips, special programs for elderly travelers and trips designed for admirers of Pearl Buck.

title: PLAIN TALK FOR ISRAEL
description: It is unfortunate that each side's domestic politics will largely shape the talks between Prime Minister Menachem Begin and President Reagan when they meet later this month. If we lived in what Don Marquis, the newspaper columnist of the 1920s', used to callan ''almost perfect world,'' the two leaders would concentrate on a realistic appraisal of their respective problems and interests. They would, among other things, consider how American policy could help Israel avoid the cul-de-sac toward which it seems headed.

title: Critics' Choices; Gene Thornton
description: PHOTOGRAPHY The problem that photography critics and gallery-goers alike will face this coming week is not making choices but finding time to fit all their choices in. From Tuesday to Saturday, six shows are opening, each one offering something that should not be missed.

title: Reagan Returns for A Somber Season
description: Returning East last week after a month in California, Ronald Reagan had more reason than most to feel a twinge of post-vacation letdown. The President and his staff were preoccupied with the economic consequences, and the political embarrassment, of budget deficits that Reaganomics was supposed to begin eliminating. White House spokesmen insisted officially that the budget would be balanced by 1984, as scheduled. But other advisers said that because the economy doesn't look to be poised for takeoff, an annual splash of red ink seems inevitable.

title: RETAILERS KEEP WATCHFUL EYE ON CAPITAL
description: IT is a huge industry, employing at last count 227,500 people, 15 percent of the state's work force. Last year, the industry recorded sales of $12.7 billion, according to the State Department of Revenue Services. And in the 12 months ending June 30, the industry collected $933 million in taxes for the state government, 48 percent of the total tax receipts.

title: WHERE SUPERPOWERS FLEX THEIR NAVAL MUSCLES
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESERVATION VS. PROPERTY RIGHTS IN ONE SMALL PLACE
description: ILIVED for eight years in Shrub Oak, a little village in northern Westchester County that even many Westchester residents have never heard of. Because it's small, forgotten and not close to any large town, it has retained some of its original 19th-century charm. The house I lived in, on Main Street, was about 150 years old when I bought it; it had a big two-story barn in back with several sheds attached, huge maple trees around it as old as the house and a large yard, almost an acre of land, with plenty of room for my vegetable garden.

title: Camera; PLANNING ESSENTIAL FOR SUCCESSFUL LANDSCAPES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Neubart is a freelance writer and photographer, and the author of a forthcoming book on nature photography.

title: GRAMBLING BEATS FLORIDA A. & M.
description: Grambling State University's Tigers maintained their near-perfect record in the New York Urban League Football Classic last night at Yankee Stadium, defeating Florida A.& M., 21-10.

title: The Region; Controls Eased In Jersey City
description: In shepherding through the City Council a measure to loosen rent restrictions in Jersey City last week, Mayor Gerald McCann contended that controlled rents led to abandoned buildings and that he was making sure the city ''will continue to live rather than die.'' Angry tenants groups argued that if the price is higher rents, there are worse fates.

title: Watergate Audio
description: When the National Archives invited the public to listen to the secret tapes of Richard M. Nixon in May 1980, more news reporters than curious citizens turned out initially. But within two months the sample of tapes - some of the juicier Presidential conversations recorded in the Watergate period -had become a Washington tourist attraction.

title: VIRGINIA BATTLING BUMPER CROPS O F MARIJUANA
description: Law-enforcement officers in Virginia, using informers and aerial reconnaissance, have opened a drive against marijuana growers whothe police say have been cultivating larger and larger fields.

title: HOW TAN WEA GET AND HOW IT GOES
description: A SUMMER tan is like a summer fling. It is a romance we have with our reflections in the mirror. Our eyes flash back at us luminously; our bodies enthrall us with their new allure; our teeth shine from the glass with sexy iridescence. Ah, how wonderful it is to be in love - even if only with ourselves.

title: STOCKS KEEP SINKING; MONEY SUPPLY GROWS
description: STOCKS FOUNDERED as Wall Street continued to express misgivings on President Reagan's economic program. The Dow Jones industrial average closed Friday at a 15-month low of 861,68,off30.54 points on the week.

title: REPRESENTED L.I. IN CONGRESS
description: Frank J. Becker, a United States Representative for 12 years and a New York State Assemblyman for eight, died at his home Friday in Lynbrook, L.I. He was 82 years old.

title: Connecticut Housing; STUDENTS FACE DORMITORY PINCH
description: WITH books, clothes, sports gear, records and all other ''basics'' of undergraduate life in tow, Wendy Lindstrom, who is entering her junior year as a medical technology major, has been spending the last few days moving into one of the new dormitories at Quinnipiac College in Hamden.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS Photo of author Colette Dowling; COLETTE DOWLING
description: Colette Dowling has become this year's person that feminists love to hate. The 43-year-old Miss Dowling is the author of the bestselling ''The Cinderella Complex,'' in which she declares that women, because of their social conditioning, have a hidden fear of independence. This results, she believes, in a deep wish to be taken care of, which she says is ''the chief force holding women down today.''

title: A FEMINIST'S LAMENT
description: Anne Taylor Fleming's article may have deeply touched yet another silent minority -those women who were successful before the flowering of the women's movement.

title: A CINEMATIC MAP OF JEWISH EXPERIENCE
description: When the Jewish Film Festival, the most ambitious program of independent features and documentary films on Jewish subjects ever assembled in the United States, opens Wednesday at the 92d Street Y for a run to Sept. 15, it will be the climax of more than 10 years of talk, proposals, false starts, limited efforts and a frenzied campaign that was born on the West Coast early last year, crisscrossed the country and dipped into Europe, Israel and Canada.

title: Education Needs
description: To the Business Editor: Lester Thurow underplayed the importance of education, particularly for minority groups and the children of the poor in ''A Liberal Looks at Income Distribution'' (Aug. 23).

title: The Region; Messenger Is Among the Stung
description: Sent to deliver $50 million in negotiable bonds last month, the messenger came back with bad news - he had set the bonds down on a bank counter for a moment and parties unknown had spirited them away. Michael A. Beckford, the messenger, had been under a cloud since he told that story, and last week he was charged with fraud and embezzlement in one of the largest stolen goods cases ever solved by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: LOCAL CONCERN AIDS MOVE OF THE NIXONS
description: PATRICIA NIXON did what most women do when a family moves, and the former President did what a lot of men do. She packed the books, the clothes and the family treasures, supervised the movers and sent a few things to her daughter - and Richard M. Nixon went off on a business trip, in this case to Europe.

title: EDGEHILL DEVELOPMENT LIVES UP TO ITS NAME
description: Although there are still times when Robert Feuerstein has to look out to the Hudson River to regain his balance, and there are nights when he wakes up wondering whether his project will still be poised on the cliff in the morning, he is pleased with the progres s of Edgehill, a 16-unit town house condominium development n earing completion here.

title: THE DOLLAR AND INFLATION
description: In spite of July's sharp uptick in consumer prices, economists continue to expect a further easing of inflationary pressures. And, while weakening oil and food prices played an important part in the decelerating trend through June, a strong dollar has been another major factor.

title: A STRIKE AGAINST INFLATION
description: I N drygulching the air controllers' union, President Reagan has successfully produced one of the major political coups in recent years. From all appearances, the primary reason for the President's stand was simply his anger at widespread law-breaking. He responded like Marshal Dillon cleaning up the entire gang of rowdies east of the Pecos.

title: DEMOCRATS' RACE TO FACE PURCELL IS TERMED CLOSE
description: DESPITE the advantage of organization support and a campaign treasury nearly four times as large as his opponent, John W. Matthews, many leading Democrats believe, is locked in a tight primary contest with Assemblyman Lewis J. Yevoli for the Democratic nomination for Nassau County Executive.

title: 'CAST ADRIFT' MAKES NONSENSE SENSIBLE
description: PORT JEFFERSON ''CAST ADRIFT'' is a revue in the manner of ''Saturday Night Live,'' which is how the folks at Theater Three are describing it, more or less. They needn't and they shouldn't. This show is better (qualitatively more and never less) than the television series, and it has an intrinsic musical score all its own. The comparison is to the theater's discredit.

title: Nixon's Town House Sold for $2.6 Million
description: The Syrian Government has purchased former President Richard M. Nixon's town house on East 65th Street as a residence for its chief delegate to the United Nations. The purchase price was reported to be $2.6 million.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: THE TASTE AND THE PRICE ARE RIGHT
description: ADD Giovanni Ristorante in Great Neck to your list of inflation fighters. This small, popular, crowded place specializes in honest, well-prepared food served in copious portions at very moderate prices.

title: 'I TRIED TO SHOW HOW YOU DESTROY THE INNOCENCE OF A CHILD'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Annette Insdorf, an associate professor at Yale, is currently writing a book on film and the Holocaust. By ANNETTE INSDORF

title: PAPA'S GAME By Gregory Wallance.  309 pp. New York: Rawson, Wade Publishers. $1 4.95.
description: IN late 1967, Robin Moore met with detectives from the New York City Police Department's elite narcotics squad who were helping him with his classic thriller on the cracking of the ''French Connection'' heroin ring. One of the detectives, Joseph Nunziata, enthusiastically suggested that Mr. Moore write a fictional sequel about confiscated heroin being stolen from the Department's Property Clerk's office.

title: 11 POLICE SUPERVISORS FACE DISCIPLINARY ACTION
description: Three New York City police lieutenants and eight sergeants will face departmental disciplinary action as a result of the arrest last June of five police officers on charges that they took payments to protect from arrest a man they believed was a cocaine dealer.

title: The World; Canada, Alberta Strike Oil Deal
description: They spoke in ringing phrases about federal, regional and provincial rights. But the great debate among Canadian officials was also about money, and a large part of that was settled last week when Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and Premier Peter Lougheed of Alberta reached agreement on dividing an expected $212 billion in oil revenues over the next five years.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday about forthcoming popular music events, the date was given incorrectly for the appearance of the Commodores at Radio City Music Hall. The punk rock group will perform Sept. 10 through 13.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: SOCIOLOGY REINTERPRETED An Essay on Method and Vocation.By Peter L. Berger and Hansfried Kellner. 183 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $12.95.

title: Realty News; TENANTS IN NEW BUILDING GET A REFUND
description: Tenant complaints about new apartments are nothing new in an age when owners want tenants to move in as quickly as possible. But rarely does an owner refund a portion of the rent as compensation for the inconvenience created by continuing construction.

title: THE CATHEDRAL WAS A COMPUTER
description: In a windowless basement room of the Data General Corporation in Westborough, Mass., engineers worked feverishly to produce a powerful new minicomputer vital to the company's future. Its archrival, the Digital Equipment Corporation of Maynard, Mass., had already introduced such a machine - a super minicomputer -forcing Data General to embark on a crash program in 1979 to design a powerful new mini of its own.

title: Home Clinic; DURABLE REPAIR TO CONCRETE AND MASONRY STEPS
description: WHEN a corner or edge on a concrete or masonry step breaks off or crumbles away when someone steps on it, repairs should be made as soon as possible in order to avoid the likelihood of someone's getting hurt by tripping or falling.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS' PUBLIC CONCERN
description: EDUCATORS have always considered September the month of the real New Year, though our solstice is unaccompanied by paper hats and noisemakers. The challenge of resolutions and fresh starts is rung in by school bells reactivated after summer's silence. This year, the siege of inflationary recession provided us a common challenge - survival. In private schools, as well as in public schools, programs have been slashed, plant use curtailed, teachers let go. How are private schools suiting up to deal with the challenge of survival? By providing what's wanted from us now.

title: Back To Work
description: As the financial markets keep sliding in the aftermath of the Reagan tax and budget-cutting victories, Congress and the Administration return to work this week with much to do, and little time to get it done.

title: Stamps; FOR NATHANAEL GREENE
description: The 200th anniversary of the battle of Eutaw Springs in South Carolina, which finally ended the British hopes of splintering the South off from the other Colonies in the American Revolution, is being observed by a commemorative postal card being issued this Wednesday. The card also pays tribute to Gen. Nathanael Greene, the brilliant commander who devised the tactics that frustrated the British effort.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: LABOR AND REAGAN REMAIN FAR APART
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.- C.I.O., is expected to lead thousands of people up New York's Fifth Avenue in a Labor Day parade celebrating his federation's 100th anniversary. But a prominent figure who is a centennial co-chairman for one of the federation's important member unions has neither sought nor received an invitation to the parade.

title: CHILDREN'S PROGRAMMING- A SEASON'S GUIDE FOR PARENTS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Alexis Greene is a freelance writer who frequently reports on children's television programming. By ALEXIS GREENE

title: Syracuse Is Beaten By Rutgers, 29 to 27
description: The debut of Dick MacPherson as Syracuse University's head football coach was dampened tonight as the Orangemen were beaten by Rutgers, 29-27.

title: Elizabeth Alice Johnston Married to Richard Lewis
description: In the First Congregational Church of Old Greenwich, Conn., yesterday, Elizabeth Alice Johnston, daughter of Joan S. Johnston of Riverside, Conn., and H. Frederick Johnston of Southport, Conn., and Warwick, Bermuda, was married to Richard Gerard Lewis. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Lewis of Brooklyn.

title: CLIFFORD IRVING TURNS PLAYWRIGHT
description: EAST HAMPTON CLIFFORD IRVING has written a play. And, he says, it is not autobiographical. Of course, he got the idea for ''Versus the I.R.S.,'' a comedy about a globe-trotting, free-sprited photographer's encounter with bureaucracy that he wrote with Maurice Nessen, a lawyer, from his own battle with the Internal Revenue Service. But that's all he and his hero have in common, he said during a rehearsal break at the John Drew Theater, where the play opens a two-week run on Friday.

title: Numismatics; NEW LEGISLATION TRIGGERS STRONG REACTIONS
description: The nation's rare coin sellers and buyers are concentrating on Washington these days, as industry leaders formulate their response to new legislation which many regard as a serious threat to their business.

title: Marjorie Weston Married
description: Marjorie G. Weston, an interior designer, was married last evening to Alan F. Doniger, a lawyer with the American Home Products Corporation.

title: The World; Sadat's Critics Are Rounded Up
description: Secular gov ernments and Islamic fundamentalists have been testing each other's strength since the ayatollahs seized power in Iran. Lastweek in Egypt , where sectarian violence has taken 60 lives in recent months, Presi dent Anwar el-Sadat struck back at them and, while he was at it, cr itics of several other stripes.

title: Abigail M. Wilson Wed at Princeton
description: Abigail Mira Wilson and Nathaniel Sawyer Howe Jr. were married yesterday at the Princeton University Chapel. The Rev. Eugene Y. Lowe performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title: Nassau County
description: AS another school year begins, Nassau County educators - again facing a decline in school enrollment, currently estimated at 5 percent a year, and a 10 percent increase in costs - say they are concerned about the curtailment in Federal financing for services that public schools are still mandated to provide.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: ACCUSED SLAYER UNDER TESTING
description: A 33-year-old man was being held for psychiatic observation at the Whiting Forensic Institute in Middletown, Conn., yesterday on charges of strangling his father, a retired high school principal.

title: BE CAREFUL OF CANCER CURE
description: To the Sports Editor: The value of exercise as a therapeutic measure is now becoming widely recognized on several fronts, not just in the battle against cancer ("Winning a Race Against Cancer," The New York Times, Aug. 23). But we should be cautious in our enthusiasm for these new findings and avoid being led to mistaken conclusions.

title: KRASNER-POLLOCK SHOW TRACES A PARTNERSHIP
description: EAST HAMPTON THE honest assessment of the role played by interdependent relationships between artists has been greatly hindered by the characterization of the creative spirit as private, isolated and essentially inward-looking. Beginning with the romantic 19th-century notion of the artist-bohemian and reaching its peak during the reign of Abstract Expressionism, this attitude gives highest accolades to individuality and elevates the artist to superhero stature.

title: SERVICE GROUP AIDS 12- TO 25-YEAR OLDS
description: IN the socia l services field, the 16-to 21-year-old age group is sometimes kno wn as the ''no-man's land.'' Its members are usually tooyoung for adu lt services and too old for the young population served by the Family Court and its adjuncts. In the county and throughout the state, th ere are few facilities designed specifically to counsel these young a dults.

title: September 6, 1981
description: NONFICTION THE FUTILITY OF FAMILY POLICY. By Gilbert Y. Steiner. 11 THE GEOGRAPHY OF THE IMAGINATION: Forty Essays. By Guy Davenport. 7 HOW TO STAND UP FOR YOUR RIGHTS - AND WIN.

title: Four Russians Killed, South Africans Report
description: A Soviet noncommissioned officer who was taken prisoner during South Africa's incursion into Angola was found beside the body of his wife, who died when their vehicle was attacked, a South African briefing officer said today.

title: N.C. State 27, Richmond 21
description: Joe McIntosh's 18-yard third-quarter touchdown run aroused a sluggish Wolfpack offense after Richmond had taken a 14-10 halftime lead on a 14-yard touchdown pass from Steve Krainock to Clayton White and a 1-yard run by Krainock.

title: Texas A & M 29
description: California 28

title: Dining Out; DIFFERENT PLACES UNDER ONE ROOF
description: LIKE the new kid in town, Jacqueline's, in Rye since early summer, appears unsure of the territory. Replacing the more sedate Gipfel's (though retaining essentially the same management and the same Swiss chef), Jacqueline's is really two places: a large, latticed, greenery-filled dining room on one side, a red-walled bar and disco dance floor with flashing lights on the other. Large mirrors altering perceptions of distance and mass bind this schizophrenic union. The kitchen, too, seems not sure of its intentions: serious efforts were often marred by incomprehensible shortcuts or outright gaffes.

title: Jennifer Shanks Bride in London
description: Jennifer Shanks, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Shanks of Los Angeles and New York, was married in London yesterday to Stephen Kingsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Klingopulos of Worcester Park, Surrey, England. The Rev. William Atkins performed the ceremony in St. George's Anglican Church, Hanover Square.

title: Lucy D. Schmidt Wed To Louis E. Perkins
description: Lucy Drusil la Schmidt and Louis Edward Perkins were married yesterday in an Episcopal ceremony at St. Cuthbert's Chapel at MacMahan Isla nd, Me. The bride's father, the Rev. Dr. Thomas Carson Schmidt of Wa shington, performed the ceremony.

title: Behr-Beech Team Wins In Datsun at Lime Rock
description: Steve Behr of New York City and George Beech of Greenwich, Conn., drove their Datsun 280ZX to an easy victory in an accident-shortened endurance race today at Lime Rock Park.

title: HOME SWEET HOLLYWOOD
description: MOVING PICTURES Memories of a Hollywood Prince. By Budd Schulberg. Illustrated. 501 pp. New York: Stein & Day. $16.95.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER, 6, 1981
description: International Stronger strategic ties with Israel that might include an American military presence in Israel and the sharing of American spy satellite data will be explored by President Reagan in talks this week in Washington with Prime Minister Menachem Begin, American and Israeli officials said. (Page 1, Column 6.) A bomb explosion in Teheran killed Iran's revolutionary prosecutor general, Hojatolislam Ali Qoddousi. He was the fourth senior Government official to be killed in a week. (1:1.)

title: PITT TURNS BACK ILLINOIS, 26-0
description: Dan Marino, unruffled by a shaky start, threw two touchdown passes and led Pittsburgh to a 26-6 victory over Illinois today.

title: THE ECLIPSE OF THE OLIGARCHS
description: Paul Heath Hoeffel writes frequently about Latin America. By Paul Heath Hoeffel he overland trip between San Salvador and Guatemala City has become a weekly routine for Francisco Schmidt Enriquez. Unlike many other members of his wartorn country's landed elite who have chosen exile, Francisco is tenaciously holding on to a way of life that is being challenged by the major sectors of society in El Salvador.
To the Editor:

title: LEARNING TO GOVE RN BETTER BY PRODUCING MORE FOR LESS
description: IN the daily tug-of-war over the state budget, there is an element long embedded within government that, to this point, has gone unnoticed.

title: COLLEGES NEED OFF CAMPUS SITES
description: To the Sports Editor: Viewed theoretically, the proposals contain ed in the article "Righting Colleges' Wrongs" (The New York Tim es, Aug. 30) would be difficult to quarrel with. A practical objec tion, however, pertains to at least one point.

title: Index; International
description: Around the World 4 Dengue fever epidemic in Cuba sets off dispute with U.S. 5 Irish village cashes in on Rea- gan's roots 7 Beatings of South Korean politi- cal prisoners are reported 9 On Lake Titicaca in the Andes, an Indian society thrives 12 In Paris, the Metro's first-class service may be ended 13 Greece protests to U.S. school over report on excavation 14 Minoan highway is found in south- ern Crete 15 Government/Politics Right wing seeks shift by Reagan 20 Computer changing the Library of Congress 28 Legislators hear voters' worries about Reagan's programs 30 Barbaro traces origins of his populist platform 34 Work program for ex-drug ad- dicts loses Federal financing 45 General Virginia cracks down on large- scale marijuana farmers 24 Parents suing over athlete's death in California jail 27 Tugboat operators' strike cuts Hawaii's vital barge service 28 Around the Nation 28 Watergate echoes heard at Klein- dienst trial 31 Hadassah prospers despite rising costs of its projects 32 Suspect seized in strangling of girl, 16, in Brooklyn 39 Obituaries Frank J. Becker, represented L.I.in Congress 36 Arts/Entertainment Joseph Hirshhorn leaves collec- tion to museum named for him 23 Haydn's ''Armida'' transplanted to Vietnam 49 Rick James, funk-rock star, plays at Garden 49 F raternity in itiation horror film ''Hell Nigh t'' opens 51 Second cast in ''Song of Norway'' 51 Health/Science Survival rates for cancer patients found to be rising, study says<

title: Nuclear Morality
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Journal
description: FOR nearly five weeks now, full volumes of water have been flowing safely through Newark's rebuilt aqueduct in the hills of Pequannock Township. However, postscripts are still being written to that incident of apparent vandalism, which destroyed two big sections of century-old pipeline on July 7 and came within two or three days of leaving the state's largest city without half of its daily water supply.

title: Speaking Personally; ANOTHER SUMMER WORTH REMEMBERING
description: THE end of summer is a bittersweet time. For me, it always harkens back to that momentous first day of school, when my mother would sing ''School Days'' in a shaky contralto while I hid, quivering, under the covers.

title: Table of Contents; New York Times Magazine September 6, 1981
description: William Safire 6 On Language Tsk Force Caryl Rivers 11 Guest Observer Achieving Marital Harmony Joanne A. Fishman 12 The Ultimate Nautical Marathon Paul Heath Hoeffel 20 The Eclipse of the Oligarchs After a century of control, El Salvador's ruling elite faces an uncertain future. Deborah Blumenthal 33 Beauty The Facts Behind the Aloe Mystique Craig Claiborne 34 Food with Pierre Franey Ground Meat Made Glorious 36 Fashion On the Brink of Autumn 38 Puzzles Answers, Page 44 Marilyn Bethany 42 Design After the Decorating Is Done 47 Letters Cover: Photograph by Alastair Black Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: 'SCAM' AIDS INCUMBENT MAYOR
description: ''You leave the pluses alone in politics - you try to neutralize the minuses,'' said John C. Mandanici, the embattled Mayor of Bridgeport, in his City Hall office. ''What's pl usis plus,'' he added.

title: Dining Out; QUALITY FARE, ROADHOUSE PLAIN
description: DANBURY DESMOND'S PUB, just outside Danbury on Route 37, is a restaurant whose prices appear to have more in common with the 1930's than the 1980's. An appetizer, entree and wine cost a prix fixe $11.95.

title: THE SHERATON MURDER CASE
description: y all accounts, the Sheraton Hotel, a waterin g hole for El Salvador's security-conscious elite, was fill ed with revelers the night of last January 3. Three top agrarian-r eform officials -MichaelP. Hammer, 42, and Mark D. Pearlman, 36, advi sers from the American Institute for Free Labor Development, and Jos e Rodolfo Viera, 39, a powerful peasant leader - had chosen the hote l's coffee shop for an emergency meeting that night. Viera, who was president of El Salvador's Institute for Agrarian Transformat ion (I.S.T.A.), wanted to advise the Americans of his decision to re sign from the post because of his frustration and fears for his life.

title: Art; FOCUSING ON SAN FRANCISCO
description: JERSEY CITY A CHARMING exhibition of architectural photographs is on view at the Jersey City Museum. Entitled ''Gift to the Street: A Patternbook of Victorian Architecture,'' the show focuses on th e myriad details of the Victorian buildings that can be found in San Francisco. It will be on view through next Saturday.

title: Slim Buildings
description: To The Editor: The article on thin buildings ('Slim Buildings Get Slim Designs,' Aug. 23) in The Times Real Estate Section, was illustrated by photographs of several ''splinters'' including the specimen at 177 East 79th Street.

title: JEWELRY FOR INDIAN SUMMER
description: Indian summer has arrived, fashionably early and heralded not by tom-toms but by the tinke and clank of handmade jewelry from the Navajos, Hopis and Zunis of the Southwest.

title: PUNK ROCK: RICK JAMES
description: Rick James, the funk-rock superstar, brought his Stone City Band to Madison Square Garden on Thursday, and turned the arena into a glittering celebration full of fireworks and musical and sexual energy. Though Mr. James calls his music punk-funk, the label is somewhat of a misnomer. For instead of having the strong nihilistic connotations it has had since the rise and fall of England's Sex Pistols, the term punk, for Mr. James, suggests a seamier version of the free-wheeling street-party atmosphere that Sly and the Family Stone evoked in the Woodstock era.

title: Fashion; ON THE BRINK OF AUTUMN
description: Just as the first yellow and orange leaves herald the coming of colder weather, dresses in new shapes and hues - in fabrics lightweight enough for Indian-summer days - are the fi rst signs that the new fashion season h as arrived. Here are several striped versions in silk tha t show off design elements that are bound to be plentifu l this autumn: voluminous skirts; slim, trim tunics, and div ided skirts.

title: Chess; A BLUFF THAT IS CALLED CAN BRING DISASTER
description: Bluffing is a low-percentage strategem because the bluff is too often called. The opponent thrives on a false show of strength, ready to exploit it at the first opportunity. It's the real threat that frightens him.

title: THE ISLES OF GREECE
description: To the Editor:

title: Anne C. Wright Married T o Charles Sellon, Banker
description: The marriage of Anne Caroline Wright, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Derek Ernest Wright of Bensleet, Essex, England, to Charles Houston Sellon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry Kimball Sellon of Bethesda, Md., took place yesterday in London. The Rev. Patrick Tuft performed the ceremony at St. Nicolas Anglican Church.

title: Nakano Wins 5th Title In World Cycling Races
description: Koichi Nakano of Japan won his fifth straight professional sprint title at the world cycling championships today. Nakano defeated Gordon Singleton of Canada in the finals in two straight races, in times of 10.88 and 10.91 seconds on the final day of competition.

title: Washington; REAGAN: BACK TO SCHOOL
description: Ronald Reagan came back to Washington with all the enthusiasm of a youngster going back to school. You have to give him credit (at 19 percent interest rates). He is the first American President in memory who said to hell with August and took an honest vacation without pretending he was working 18 hours a day at the ranch.

title: Abby M. Grossman Is Bride
description: The marriage of Abby Marcia Grossman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwyne Grossman of East Hills, L.I., to Michael Steven Modell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Modell of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., took place yesterday.

title: IT'S 'SAFETY FIRST' FOR ATHLETES
description: HACKENSACK OUTSIDE the health office at Hackensack High School one morning last month, members of the 1981 football squad laughed and jostled each other good naturedly.

title: BITTERNESS REMAINS AFTER PLANT CLOSING
description: MERIDEN WHEN the Webster Wilcox Company closed its silver holloware plant here in March, some employees said that it gave its 350 workers - average age 57, average service record 25 years - about 25 minutes notice.

title: Architecture View; CLASSICISM IN A CONTEMPORARY CONTEXT
description: The art of architecture is alive and well; it is neither in the doldrums, nor retreating into the neo-conservatism of the new esthetic right, nor suffering from creative block. If its practitioners seem to be subject to fits of pettiness and pique, that might most charitably be attributed to growing pains as modern architecture matures and moves toward a more complex style, or styles, and the beliefs and values of orthodox modernism collapse. The art of building at this moment is full of angst and uncertainty. But it is also showing all the signs of a very lively art in a provocative period of development and change. It is easy to believe that a significant chapter is being written in its history.

title: OVETT CAPTURES CUP
description: Steve Ovett of Britain won the 1,500-meter run today as expected in the second day of the World Cup track and field competition. Evelyn Ashford and Cliff Wiley scored convincing victories for the United States in the sprints, and Joao de Oliveira of Brazil won the triple jump in which the competition was worthy of that in the Olympic Games.

title: A Potpourri of Events
description: THE carving of waterfowl and shorebird decoys has long been recognized as a truly American art form, and some stunning examples of the work of the masters of yesteryear are now on display at the Museum of American Folk Art, 49 West 53d Street.

title: BARBARO TRACES ORIGINS OF HIS POPULIST PLATFORM
description: Frank J. Barbaro was asked the other evening where he tho ught his political ori gins lay. He was leaning back wearily in a restaurant booth near Br oadway and 72d Street, where he had been offering his right hand an d a pitch for his mayoral candidacy to those emerging from the IRT subway station.

title: The Nation; Two New Ways To Enforce Rules for Aid
description: Many Government officials, it is said, know waste, fraud and abuse when they see it. The problem is seeing it, and that, the Reagan Administration maintains, is one of the reasons Government is in the expensive mess it is in.

title: PARIS METRO ABOUT TO TRAVEL ALL SECOND CLASS
description: France's new Transportation Minister, Charles Fiterman, a Communist, wants to end first-class cars on the Paris subway, the Metro.

title: LAMAR UPSETS BAYLOR, 18-17
description: Ken Simon sprinted 51 yards for a touchdown with less than five minutes elapsed, and Alabama's untested backfield shaped up quickly as the Crimson Tide routed Louisiana State tonight, 24-7, for Bear Bryant's 307th coaching victory.

title: PLAN TO CONVERT CAMPUS INTO A PRISON DRAWS ATTACK UPSTATE
description: The impending sale of part of a college campus here for conv ersion into a state prison has aroused a controversy in this tiny, se rene Adirondack Mountain community near the headwaters of the St. Re gis chain of lakes.

title: Lisa Stewart Wed To G. A. Crisp,
description: Lisa Denise Stewart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Stewart Jr. of Glen Ridge, N.J., and Oak Bluffs, Mass., was married in Washington yesterday to Grayland Arlen Crisp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Crisp of Columbus, Ohio. The Rev. James O. West performed the ceremony in Calvary Episcopal Church.

title: Sheila Cowan Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bailey Cowan of Little Sydenhurst, England, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sheila Cowan, to Roger Alan Gins, son of Mrs. Sanford L. Gins of New York, and the late Mr. Gins.

title: VIKINGS BEATEN BY BUCS IN N.F.L. OPENER, 21-13
description: Doug Williams threw a 55-yard scoring pass to Kevin House, the wide receiver, and scrambled 10 yards up the middle for another touchdown tonight to lead the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to a 21-13 victory over the Minnesota Vikings in the National Football League's season opener.

title: GAINS FOUND IN CANCER VICTIMS' SURVIVAL RATE
description: The five-year survival rate for patients with the 10 most common forms of cancer showed a marked improvement from 1969 to 1979 in the United States, according to a study by the American College of Surgeons.

title: ARMS IN THE BALANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW BRUNSWICK: TODAY AND TOMORROW
description: NEW BRUNSWICK'S long-awaited ''tomorrow'' has taken seven years to arrive. Now that visible signs of rebirth - a Hyatt Regency Hotel, the new world headquarters of Johnson & Johnson and Middlesex General Hospital's modern expansion - are finally rising from the rubble, New Brunswick minorities are wondering if their ''tomorrow'' was ever in the plan.

title: LITERARY ANECDOTES
description: After browsing through Donald Hall's ''The Oxford Book of American Literary Anecdotes,'' which has just come out, I thought I might assemble a small anthology of my own. *

title: MANY TEARS
description: WOMEN'S WORK By Anne Tolstoi Wallach. 419 pp. New York: New American Library. $13.95 By CHARLOTTE CURTIS

title: Critics' Choices
description: POP MUSIC Teddy Pendergrass, who will be at the Westbury Music Fair, Thursday through next Sunday, attracted bemused attention several years ago with his concerts ''for ladies only'' and his exploitation of a cuddly-macho image - he is a tall, bearded man whose nickname is ''Teddy Bear.'' He has also been described as one of the last of the great black soul singers, those fervent, preaching vocalists who have been enlivening rhythm-and-blues and pop since the 60's.

title: SCHOOL FINANCING: A MAJOR ASSIGNMENT FOR THE LEGISLATURE
description: THE State L egislature recently restored $64 million of ''minimum aid'' to 231 educational districts, primarily the more-affluent suburbs. Gove rnor Byrne had proposed the cuts because, according to his analysis, the funds were not needed and because the state budget had to be cut and dollars shifted to other areas.

title: Terry Pavone Fiance Of Patricia Cacace
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Cacace of White Plains have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Cacace, to Emil A. Pavone 3d, son of Charlotte Pavone, also of White Plains, and Mr. Pavone Jr. of Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Dance View; EXPRESSION AND ECLECTICISM SPUR THE NEW DANCE
description: Dance being a repertory art, it is in the nature of the beast - of the form - to build up a body of works that is repeated from season to season. Continuity is the byword. Nonetheless, three major shifts in emphasis are affecting the vitality of dance at present. One is the astonishing rise in technique among American dancers. Another is the effect of unprecedented institutionalization by dance companies upon performers and creativity. The third concerns the artistic ideas that contribute to this creativity.

title: Television Week
description: Tennis Time As he has been for the past 13 years, Bob Dailey is assured of a seat at this year's United States Open tennis championships. He may be found sitting in a truck on a compound outside the main stadium of the National Tennis Center gazing into a collection of television monitors. Mr. Dailey is the director of CBS's coverage of tennis championships.

title: True Grit with Mr. Begin
description: When Menachem Begin meets for the first time this week with President Reagan, he may well encounter a void. The Israeli visitor's hard-line views are scarcely a secret; he advertises them in every available forum. But after eight months in office, Ronald Reagan's Middle East policy is still imponderable.

title: TEXT OF GIAMATTI LETTER TO YALE FRESHMEN
