description: Following is the text of remarks sent to freshmen at Yale University by A. Bartlett Giamatti, president of Yale. The text, released Monday, attacked the Moral Majority and other conservative groups as ''peddlers of coercion'' and drew w idespread news coverage.On Tuesday, a spokesman for the Moral Majorit y called Mr. Giamatti's remarks an ''unprovoked diatribe'' and denied that the organization had tried to coerce anyone or to shut off opp osing points of view.

title: IN APPRECIATION OF GENE MICHAEL
description: To the Sports Editor: Yankee fans know that any manager will be critically scrutinized by George Steinbrenner. It took us some time, however, to appreciate Dick Howser's accomplishment last season, and it has taken me some time to appreciate Gene Michael's expertise this season.

title: TEACHING POST GAVE CHINESE LESSONS IN AMERICAN CULTURE
description: For Hu Yun Huan, an English language specialist from China, teaching for a year in an exclusive private high school in Boston was an education he was not sure he fully understood.

title: Common Market Aides Holding Talks in Britain
description: Foreign Ministers of the 10 Common Market countries met today near London for two days of private talks on world political issues, including southern Africa, the Middle East, Poland and Afghanistan.

title: THE 'COLORADO MAFIA' PUTS ITS STAMP ON THE GOVERNMENT
description: DENVER WHEN Ronald Reagan began putting together his Administration last year, many were surprised by the number of appointments going to Colorado Republicans. First there was James G. Watt, the Denver lawyer picked as Interior Secretary. Then Mr. Reagan tapped Bob Burford, a third-generation rancher, to serve under Mr. Watt as director of the Bureau of Land Management. Finally, there was Anne M. Gorsuch, a Denver attorney who had served with Mr. Burford in the state legislature. She was named to head the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Ideas and Trends; Sorry Champ, It's A Split Decision
description: 'Twas brillig, and some 200 scientists did gyre and gimble last week in the wabe of debate concerning Champ, the creature said to haunt Lake Champlain. No jaws that bite, no claws that snatch were seen at their meeting in Shelburne, Vt.. Just a photograph, taken in July 1977 by a New Hampshire woman, showing what looked like the head and serpentine neck of a zeuglodon, a prehistoric forebear of the whale.

title: Horsing Around
description: To the Editor:

title: Music; FALL MUSIC SEASON ARRIVING FORTISSIMO
description: TWO happy endings and a number of promising starts are in the offing, as summer reluctantly gives way to fall and the Connecticut arts calendar begins to fill up.

title: OFFICE FIRE PUTS MARSHALL ISLES IN 'A REAL MESS'
description: The two-year-old government of the Marshall Islands, an American-administered trust territory about 2,000 miles southwest of Hawaii, lost its operational center and irreplaceable financial, legal and other records in a predawn fire Aug. 24, according to the government's liaison office here.

title: WHO MUST PROVE WHAT IN CITY PRIMARY
description: For many New York City politicians the most important question about Thursday's Democratic and Republican mayoral primaries is not whether Mayor Koch will turn the trick of winning two major-party nominations, but whether his margin of victory will be big enough to persuade Washington and Albany that he has a bipartisan mandate.

title: KOCH AND BARBARO IN SHARP EXCHANGE
description: Mayor Koch and Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro of Brooklyn confronted each other in another testy debate last night, but neither seemed to succeed in drawing much blood. And as they have in previous encounters, they virtually ignored Melvin Klenetsky, the third Democrat in Thursday's mayoral primary, except to ridicule him ocassionally.

title: The Nation; Lower Ceiling On Federal Pay
description: The White House last week said it would recommend that the Government's 1.4 million white-collar workers get a 4.8 percent pay raise next month, less than a third the amount authorized under a 1970 salary law.

title: FAIRFIELD COUNTY SHORT WATER
description: FOLLOWING one of the driest Augusts in memory, water shortages have been occurring around the state, but particularly in the southwestern area, where growth has outstripped the water systems.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN MARILYN BROWN'S nose turned skyward when she saw the interviewer's throwaway pen, which was provided free by his employer. We were old friends, so I didn't mind the implied insult.

title: COPTIC POPE DEPOSED IN SADAT CRACKDOWN ON RELIGIOUS GROUPS
description: President Anwar el-Sadat, denouncing religious factionalism, deposed the nation's Coptic Pope tonight and said he would dissolve Islamic groups that threaten national unity.

title: Rana Elizabeth Steinberg Wed to Dr. Douglas Binder
description: Rana Elizabeth Steinberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene R. Steinberg of Great Neck, L.I., was married there yesterday to Dr. Douglas J. Binder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ruby Binder of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson, performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-el. He was assisted by Cantor Barbara Ostfeld-Horowitz,

title: Clippers Waive Bibby, Sign Free Agent Guard
description: The San Diego Clippers waived Henry Bibby yesterday and signed the free agent guard John Douglas. Bibby, a former U.C.L.A. star, averaged 4.5 points in 74 games last season after joining the Clippers following four seasons in Philadelphia.

title: LEATHERNECK EXECUTIVES
description: From the Halls of Chase Manhattan To the desks of Merrill Lynch We fight the corporate battles. For ex-Marines, it is a cinch.

title: Sylvia Carewe, Artist, Dead; Noted for New York Scenes
description: Sylvia Carewe, an artist whose works were displayed in Europe and the United States, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 75 years old.

title: A PLOT FOR JEAN GABIN, LINES IN A RUSSIAN VOICE
description: LEAVING TAOS By Robert Peterson. Selected by Carolyn Kizer. 95 pp. New York: Harper & Row. Cloth, $9.95. Paper, $5.95. REASONS FOR GOING IT ON FOOT By William Pitt Root. 86 pp. New York: Atheneum. Cloth, $11.95. Paper, $6.95. GUMBO By George Barlow. 84 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. Cloth, $9.95. Paper, $6.95.

title: BURLINGTON AWAITS QUAKERS
description: BURLINGTON NEW JERSEY and Pennsylvania Quakers will meet in this historic city on Sept.19 to commemorate the beginning, 300 years ago, of their organizational structure for the region.

title: George Pathy, Headed Top Shipping Concern
description: George S. Pathy, the board chairman of Federal Commerce and Navigation Ltd., the leading Canadian shipping concern, died Thursday of a heart attack while on a business trip in Switzerland. He was 82 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Palm Springs, Calif.

title: Dining Out; THE KITCHEN COULD USE SOME HELP
description: THE Hyde Park was opened in a Fort Lee storefront 10 months ago by three young graduates of the Culinary Institute of America. They named it for Hyde Park, N.Y., the home of the institute, and not, as one would assume, for London's famous park.

title: POLISH UNION OPENS CONVENTION
description: Lech Walesa, the union leader, today opened the first national convention of Solidarity with a plea to the independent labor organization to remain united and strong so that Poland will be ''the way we have dreamed.''

title: WASHINGTON'S NO-APOLOGIES APPROACH TO THE THIRD WORLD
description: WASHINGTON THE Reagan Administration explained its decision to stand alone in the United Nations last week and veto a resolution condemning South Africa for invading Angola as part of a calculated gamble to achieve a breakthrough in Namibia. ''We have to dedicate ourselves to achieving rea l results,'' Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said. ''We're going to be measured in the final analysis by the nonaligned, a nd the (black African) frontline states on that and not on our rhetor ic, not on our United Nations voting record.''

title: Bomb Defused in Jerusalem
description: An Israeli police explosives expert defused a bomb found today near the Rockefeller Museum outside the walls of Jerusalem's Old City, the Israel radio said. It said the bomb was planted between the museum and a filling station in predominantly Arab East Jerusalem.

title: HADASSAH'S WORKS GAIN DESPITE INCREASING COSTS
description: Since the 67th annual convention last month of Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, the group's awareness of the challenges facing Israel has sharpened, officials of the organization say.

title: Suffolk County
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY'S 72 school districts will open the school year this week with a decrease in enrollment of about 5 percent, but with a 10- to 15-p ercent increase in budgetary expenditures compared with last year, ac cording to Michael Pick, president of the Nassau-SuffolkSchool Board Association.

title: HOW TO GAUGE THE JETS?
description: THE plain brown envelope is immediately recognized by the veteran subscriber because of its shape and return address, and thus it is pulled from among the bills and notices and ripped open with the nervous anticipation of a small boy the day the cereal-box giveaway finally arrives.

title: YORKTOWN: WHERE THE REVOLUTION WAS WON
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- HUGH O. MUIR is the East Africa correspondent for the Voice of America, based in Nairobi. By HUGH O.MUIR

title: BACK TO THE VINEYARD FOR A SECOND PRESSING
description: It was only last May that Congress approved a fiscal 1982 budget hailed as a singular victory for the President. Mr.Reagan had proposed a $695.3 billion spending ceiling, and he got $695.5. He wanted military outlays set at $188.8 billion, and Congress authorized precisely that amount, $30 billion more than the current budget and the largest peacetime increase in history.

title: The Region
description: Westchester County Airport will never be the biggest or busiest in the country, if certain Westchester and Fairfield County citizens groups have their way; in fact it may be one of the quietest, at least after midnight. Last week, after years of complaints, the Westchester County board of Legislators voted to ban all but emergency flights at the facility between midnight and 7 A.M.

title: Zemma Mastin, Edmund White Have Wedding
description: Zemma Crawford Mastin, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Charles O'Fallon Mastin of Easton, Md., was married there yesterday to Edmund James White, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Matthew White of Middlebury, Conn., and Brownsville, Vt.

title: CLERC AND LENDL WINNERS AT OPEN
description: Ivan Lendl and Jose-Luis Clerc defied smoke, water and some inspired opposition yesterday to advance to the fourth round of the United States Open tennis championships, but it was clear sailing for all but two of the other seeded singles players at the National Tennis Center. In the lone upset in men's play, 11th-seede d Peter McNamara of Australia lost a night match to Bruce Manson, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, 6-2. In the women's division, Virginia Ruzici of Ruma nia, seeded No. 9, was ousted by Duk Hee Lee of Korea, 6-1, 4-6, 7-5 . Miss Lee won the last four games in beating her opponent for the se cond time in the last two weeks. Her last victory over Miss Ruzici was in the Canadian Open.

title: RESTRICTION ON STUDENT LOANS IS TO TAKE EFFECT NEXT MONTH
description: Starting next month, a student attending the average public four-year college will be barred from the guaranteed student loan program if the student's family earns more than $33,875 a year. For a student attending the average four-year private college, the income cutoff is $46,375, according to the Education Department.

title: 'HELL NIGHT,' INITIATION RITE
description: ''Hell Night,'' which opened Friday at the Cinerama and other theaters, is not so bad as it might be. It is not so good as it might be, either, but remember that it is a horror film. As the popular culture declines, the horror film declines with it, and whereas the horror film was once spooky, now it is nauseating, measured by the barf, rather than the shiver. ''Hell Night,'' however, is only about half a barf, an improvement, therefore, over its kind.

title: CHINA AND U.S. SIGN PACT ON CULTURAL EXCHANGES
description: China and the United States signed an agreement today to broaden cultural exchanges but left unresolved complaints that American scholars are denied access to Chinese society and that the Chinese Government allows only a limited view of American society to filter down to ordinary Chinese.

title: Politics; JACKMAN FAULTS REDISTRICTING PLAN
description: ''POLITICAL fairness as it applies to Congressional redistricting is an illusive concept.'' With this observation, Christopher J. Jackman, Democrat of West New York and the Assembly Speaker, keynoted a long, critical letter that he sent last week to Dr. Ernest C. Reock Jr. of Rutgers University.

title: A FEMINIST'S LAMENT
description: Anne Taylor Fleming's marvelous lament was a poignant statement of the loss of innocence felt by many of us who were young in the early 1970's (''Women and the Spoils of Success,'' Aug. 2). We were strong in our conceit that we would effect change wi thout being changed - and we were wrong.

title: Slaton Loses No-Hit Bid, but Tops Twins
description: Jim Slaton of the Milwaukee Brewers didn't allow a hit for eight innings today, then needed help from Rollie Fingers in a three-hit, 5-3 victory over the Minnesota Twins.

title: VARIED FARE ON TAP FOR THEATERGOERS
description: FOR the state's theatergoers, one of the most welcome surprises of the summer was the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's presentation of ''Cymbeline,'' which will have its final performance tonight at Drew University in Madison.

title: J.F. MCALLISTER 3D WEDS ANN OLIVARIUS
description: Ann M. Olivarius, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth W. Olivarius of Harrington Park, N.J., was married yesterday in the Manchester College Chapel in Oxford, England to John F. McAllister 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. McAllister of Fairfield, Conn. The Unitarian ceremony was performed jointly by the Rev. Bruce Findlow, principal of Manchester College, and the Rev. Helen Campbell, minister of the North Oxfordshire Unitarians in Banbury, England.

title: Mary Kilcullen Is Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Kilcullen of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elizabeth Kilcullen, to Addison Lanier 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. L. Addison Lanier of Cincinnati.

title: A FEMINIST'S LAMENT
description: Anne Taylor Fleming bemoans the recent trend of a man's affection being tied to a woman's success - ''...our men pimp for us, in a way, by boasting of our accomplishments.''

title: N.F.L. KICKERS HAVE REASON TO WORRY
description: Jim Turner, a kicker for 16 seasons with the Jets and the Denver Broncos who has joined the NBC broadcasting team for National Football League telecasts, maintains that most kickers elicit little respect from head coaches and often have reason to feel they are disliked just because they are kickers. Turner, whose 304 field goals are second only to George Blanda's 335 in career totals, had contract battles with Weeb Ewbank over salary and with Red Miller at Denver over strategy, among other subjects. It was Miller who finally cut Turner last year.

title: Accord on Montana Site For Refugees Is Reported
description: Federal agencies and officials in Glasgow, Mont., have reached a tentative agreement to use a vacant Air Force base as a longterm resettlement site to house as many as 2,000 Cuban and Haitian refugees, The Los Angeles Times said today.

title: 12 BRIDGES RAISED TO AID FREIGHT
description: RESIDENTS of the many towns and villages along the Hudson River below Tarrytown have noticed construction crews raising a dozen bridges that cross the railroad tracks of Conrail's Hudson Division. Although it has inconvenienced some in their efforts to reach riverside parks and restaurants, the renovation work is expected to benefit the entire metropolitan area economically.

title: CASINO WORKERS PUSH FOR GAMING 24 HOURS A DAY
description: ATLANTIC CITY WITH an eye to the pending departure from office of their unwavering obstacle, Governor Byrne, casino workers here are organizing a drive to introduce 24-hour gambling.

title: The Region; Students Given Two Weeks to Take Their Shots
description: New York City school officials doubtless welcomed a state law aimed at preventing outbreaks of childhood diseases, but last week that law threatened to keep more pupils from returning to school Thursday than all but the most serious epidemics might have.

title: LIBRARY OF CONGRESS CARD CATALOGUE GIVING WAY TO COMPUTER TERMINALS
description: Past the Gutenberg Bible and beyond the serenity of the main reading room, book lovers were tapping out their needs to Scorpio and Mums, two helpful, rather chatty electronic memory systems that are now superseding one of the public treasures of the literate world, the card catalogue of the Library of Congress.

title: Ex-Judge Raymond Sherwin; Served as Sierra Club Leader
description: Former Judge Raymond J. Sherwin of the San Francisco Superior Court, who served two terms as national president of the Sierra Club, died here yesterday.

title: Photography View; CONSERVATISM HAS A COMEBACK
description: Photography has so recently begun to be taken seriously by museums, collectors and critics that it may be presumptuous to ask what its present state is. It has been recognized as art, hasn't it? For many of its devotees, that is still the best and only news, and anything else - anything that might sound like dissention in the ranks are ammunition for the skeptics who still are not convinced that photography is art -is not very welcome.

title: Crosby, Lindley Gain Amateur Golf Final
description: Nathaniel Crosby, whose only tournament victory was his home club championship, made a 2-foot, parsaving putt on the 17th hole today to take a 1-up lead over Willie Wood, then made another par on the final hole to reach the final of the United States Amateur Championship. Crosby will face Brian Lindley of Fountain Valley, Calif.

title: THE NEW BATTLE OVER NATURAL GAS
description: WASHINGTON

title: WHAT'S DOING IN THE DOLOMITES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- PAUL HOFMANN, a former Times correspondent, lives in Rome. By PAUL HOFMANN

title: A THEATER CHILD TAKES CENTER STAGE
description: Amanda Plummer seemed on the edge of tears. ''My mistakes are my mistakes,'' she said. ''My growth is my growth. I don't want to be compared to my parents.''

title: ON ISLAND IN BOLIVIA, AN INDIAN SOCIETY THRIVES
description: Nearing its island destination in Lake Titicaca, the crew cut the boat's engine and poled along a winding narrow channel through tall reeds. As the re e ds began to thin, several hundred Indians could be seen on a bl uff, dancing, singing and waving to greet the boat's arrival.

title: CHINAGLIA IS OVERRATED
description: To the Sports Editor: George Vecsey ("Chinaglia, Most Valuable" The New York Times, Aug. 16) is mistaken. Year after year Giorgio Chinaglia has been the North American Soccer League's most overrated player.

title: OPERA: HAYDN MOVED TO VIETNAM
description: A Haydn opera written in 1783 that deals with the recent American military involvement in Vietnam? Obviously strange things were afoot on the campus of Ke ene State College in New Hampshire on Thursday night when Haydn's ''Armida'' received its United States premiere as the final offering of his summer's Monadnock Music Festival.

title: 'Detective' Group Is Raided
description: Investigators from the Westchester District Attorney's office yesterday raided the Elmsford office of a group that had claimed to be raising funds for them. They seized records of the New York State District Attorney's Detective Investigators Police Benevolent Association, which had claimed to represent the Westchester investigators.

title: MASON SHARES 'ART' OF BUILDING THE STONE WALL
description: SOMERS STANDING in front of a weatherbeaten wheelbarrow filled with wellused but perfectly sharpened chisels, spades and sledgehammers, Mohammed Benaissa, an experienced mason who talks more like an artist, pointed to a nearby stone wall and said, ''I had a picture in my mind of what kind of wall I wanted here.''

title: CHURCH FILLS ROLE AS A BIBLE COLLEGE
description: HAWTHORNE ONE of the area's most active fundamentalist churches -it was started 56 years ago by the man who is still its pastor - has become an informal Bible college, attracting hundreds of people to nightly classes during the summer.

title: A FEMINIST'S LAMENT
description: I am 25 years old; a junior-junior executive in a major corporation. I am a 3 on a corporate scale that ranges from 1 to 30.

title: BRAXTON OUTPOINTS SCOTT IN PRISON BOUT
description: Dwight Braxton, who lived in the Rahway State Prison here nine years ago, returned today and, before suffering an attack of claustrophobia, scored a clear and unanimous decision over James Scott in a nationally televised light-heavyweight fight.

title: Mary Roberta Walsh Wed
description: Mary Roberta Walsh and Theodore John Robinson, 1978 graduates of the University of Notre Dame, were married in the Lady Chapel of the Sacred Heart Church on the Notre Dame campus in South Bend, Ind., yesterday. The Rev. Donald R. Campion performed the Roman Catholic ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Robert Emmett Walsh of Epoufette, Mich., and the late Mr. Walsh. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. A. Theodore Robinson of Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: CONTRASTS IN THE AGING GERMAN AVANT-GARDE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Joan Peyser is the editor of The Musical Quarterly and the author of two books on contemporary music. By JOAN PEYSER

title: Pretoria Sees Red, U.S. Casts A Lonely Vote
description: South Africa has long couched its reluctance to give up the resource-rich territory of South-West Africa in terms of anti-Communism. So it was with a certain satisfaction that Pretoria announced last week that its troops captured a Soviet sergeant major and killed several Soviet officers in attacks on South-West African guerrilla bases in Angola.

title: FARMERS FIND PROFIT IN THE CITY
description: WHILE many farmers continue to wholesale their produce and others set up roadside stands, a cluster of resourceful Long Island farmers have found New York City's Greenmarkets a profitable alternative for selling their crops. There a hungry audience awaits the farmers' newly picked tomatoes, vine-ripened melons, freshly cut flowers and other produce.

title: Managua Reports Coup Plot
description: Leonel Poveda Sediles, an Under Secretary of Commerce, and 11 other people were arrested and accused of plotting to overthrow the Government, the Interior Ministry announced.

title: Smith Breaks Finger; Edwards Is Called Up
description: Team Canada activated Don Edwards as goaltender after Billy Smith suffered a broken finger in practice today, hours before a Canada Cup hockey game ag ainst Czechoslovaki a.

title: The Nation; Fasting Spy Sent To Medical Unit
description: Like it or not, the convicted spy Christopher J. Boyce may be forced to live out his sentence. Mr. Boyce, who escaped from a maximum-security Federal prison in California 19 months ago, has refused to eat since he was captured last month in Port Angeles, Wash. ''Nobody wants to die,'' Mr. Boyce's lawyer quoted him as saying, ''but I don't want to go back to prison.''

title: THE ROYAL FOREBEARS
description: R.W. Apple Jr.'s excellent article on the royal family is marred slightly by repeating the assertion that the family can trace descent from George Washington (''An Informal Look at the Royal Family,'' July 26). No one can trace descent from George Washington for the simple reason he left no children of his own.

title: TRADE
description: Trade paperbacks are softcover books usually sold in bookstores and at an average price higher than mass-market paperbacks. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States.

title: Spanish Police Kill F ugitive Rebel Leader
description: A leader of a Spanish guerrilla group was shot and killed in a gunfight today after he refused to surrender, the police said.

title: Westchester Guide; CHILDREN'S ART SHOW
description: Ninety children from the tristate area, including several from the county, have provided original works of art, poetry and photography for a traveling show that may be seen Thursday through Sept. 21 in the White Plains Courthouse Community Gallery.

title: Fire Ruins Queens Factory
description: A three-alarm blaze caused extensive damage at a Queens box factory last night, fire officials said.

title: Michael Abrams Fiance Of Ginny Schwartzman
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Allen L. Schwartzman of Sands Point, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Ginny Elise Schwartzman, to Michael David Abrams, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Abrams of Washington. A June wedding is planned.

title: TRANSIT PROJECTS CALLED IMPERILED
description: High interest rates and the weakened municipal bond market may force the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to scale down the $5.8 billion package of capital improvements passed by the State Legislature in June, several officials said yesterday.

title: Jersey Man Who Tried To Swap Baby Is Freed
description: A Hunterdon County man who had been accused of trying to trade his infant son for a sports car was released after spending almost a year in jail awaiting trial.

title: PRISONER BEATINGS REPORTED IN SEOUL
description: Law enforcement authorities have been beating political prisoners and suspects in an attempt to repress dissent, according to relatives of prisoners and Christian activists here and abroad.

title: AFTER THE ARCHAIC
description: THE GEOGRAPHY OF THE IMAGINATION Forty Essays by Guy Davenport. 384 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. Cloth, $20. Paper, $10. ECLOGUES Eight Stories by Guy Davenport. Illustrated. 238 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. Cloth, $15. Paper, $7.50. By HILTON KRAMER

title: SCIENTIFIC AMUSEMENTS
description: LAWS OF THE GAME How the Principles of Nature Govern Chance. By Manfred Eigen and Ruthild Winkler. Translated by Robert and Rita Kimber. Illustrated. 347 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95. By JEREMY BERNSTEIN

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: ''the melodramatic style she too often allows herself, the heavy symbolism, the occasional esthetic miscalculation,'' yet it presents her religiousphilosophical view cleanly and dramatically. ''Whatever its faults, it is brilliantly written, a wonderful book.''

title: WORK PROJECT FOR EX-ADDICTS LOSES U.S. AID
description: Former drug addicts, ex-offenders and chronically unemployed men have been painting city courthouses and office buildings in a supported work project that lost its Federal financing in the recent budget cuts.

title: NATURE'S WAY
description: Autumn is coming, and, to celebrate, Richard P. Meyer, a naturalist and photographer, will conduct the first of a series of interpretive nature hikes today through the 145-acre preserve that houses the Nassau County Center for the Fine Arts in Roslyn Harbor. Not the entire 145 acres, of course, but enough to give the flavor of the place - the 60-year-old Pinetum with its 200 species of nonindigenous conifers and the former equestrian trails, alive with wildflowers. After the 1:30 P.M. wa lk, ''The Miracle of Autumn,'' a multimedia pr ogram, will be screened at 3:30 P.M. All is free; the center is off Northern Boulevard. IRONIC READINGS

title: SOUTH RISING AGAIN (IN JERSEY, THAT IS)
description: EGG HARBOR TWP. ''THE chair recognizes the sovereign state of South Jersey.'' The halls of Congress may never ring with that proclamation, but a zealous group of citizens below New Jersey's own version of the Mason-Dixon line is fighting a civil war, 1981 style.

title: Miss Bernhard, Student, Is Wed To David Cope
description: Elizabeth Anne Bernhard, a senior at Wellesley College, was married there yesterday to David Banks Cope, a doctoral candidate in physics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The Rev. Charles I. Wallace, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony in the Houghton Memorial Chapel on the Wellesley campus.

title: EX-C.I.A. AGENT'S ASSOCIATES RUN ARMS EXPORT CONCERNS
description: A series of interlocking businesses here that transfer advanced technology and sensitive military equipment to foreign governments, especially in the Middle East, are operated by a group of men once closely associated at the Central Intelligence Agency with Edwin P. Wilson, a former C.I.A. agent who has been charged with illegally shipping explosives to Libya.

title: Dollar, Dollar
description: To the Business Editor: In ''Our Dollar, Their Problem -Again?'' (Aug. 16) the Swiss are praised for their ''self-discipline'' in controlling inflation and maintaining the strength of the Swiss franc. The Swiss adapted the classical cure for inflation - tight monetary and fiscal policies which created a recession, forcing wages and prices to fall and unemployment to rise - but their success was aided by two advantages not mentioned in the article.

title: Design; AFTER THE DECORATING IS DONE
description: xperts usually agree that decor ought never to be thought of as completed. To remain lively, an interior should support an everchanging display of art, accessories, flowers, plants and other signs of life. Even in places that have been done by a decorator, this happy task falls to the inhabitants, free at last to express themselves. The moment they've been waiting for? Well, maybe and maybe not.

title: PERKINS FINDS THAT ROAD TO RECOVERY IS A SLOW ONE
description: IN 1979, the Giants abandoned their tradition of running a professional football team, a multi-million-dollar enterprise, with former players, former coaches and retainers.

title: A FEMINIST'S LAMENT
description: I was shocked by Anne Taylor Fleming's description of hostility and competition among professional women.

title: TAKING THE PULSE OF THE BOOK MARKET
description: ''ONE of the things you do in publishing,'' said Dan Green of Great Neck, ''is to translate what is unique in each book and how that uniqueness becomes attractive to another reader.''

title: OVERCHARGING FOUND IN EAST HARLEM
description: Inspectors from the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs have reported numerous short-weighting violations by merchants at La Marqueta, a five-block stretch of stalls on Park Avenue between 111th and 116th Streets under the Conrail tracks in East Harlem.

title: That Was No Gull In the Canal
description: I was fascinated by the reference to ''The Gull Who Fell in the Canal,'' the book that made Peter Spier, the illustrator of it, ''realize that that was what he really wanted to do.''

title: Art View; UNPRECEDENTED VITALITY HAS ITS PRICE
description: The single factor that most completely dominates and defines the art scene at the present moment is the sheer number of objects and events that crowd upon it. Any attempt to acquire a sense of the quality or vitality of art in the 1980's must therefore be seen in relation to the immensity and variety of the activity itself. We have literally known nothing like it in the past.

title: Playland's Woes Linked To Rise in Charges
description: The article in the Westchester Weekly section concerning Playland's declining attendance (''Playland Acts to Counter Drop in Attendance,'' Aug. 23) deserves public comment. Because I have visited Playland practically every summer of my life, as did my parents and grandparents, I feel qualified to comment.

title: Latin Music Fesitval Winding Up Tomorrow
description: The sixth El Festival Latino will wind up tomorrow with two concerts.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: New crime wave. This week, in bookstores across the country, cartons will be arriving that contain an assortment of eight paperbacks whose covers all bear a picture of the black bird that inspired an immortal poem by Edgar Allan Poe, father of the modern detective story. During the next several weeks, the stores will start displaying these Raven House Mysteries conspicuously in their win dowsand on their counters. In the next issues of Family Circle and other magazines that are favorites at supermarket c heckout counters, there'll be large ads announcing the new seri es. Soon there'll be spot ads for it on the radio. Beginning in No vember, four more Raven titles will be released each month, all of th em originals, all 220 pages long, all priced $2.25, all marketed as if they were Ivory Soapor Pepsi-Cola.

title: Headliners; A Mother's Complaint
description: Motherhood may be as American as apple pie, but some of its implications, according to Lynn Redgrave, are not always viewed with appropriate respect. The actress filed a $10 million damage suit against Universal Television last week, maintaining that she was ''wrongly discharged'' from the CBS-TV series ''House Calls'' because she insisted on breast-feeding her daughter on the set. Declining comment on the suit, which also charged breach of contract and intentional infliction of emotional distress, Universal spokesmen referred to an earlier statement by Robert Harris, president of Universal Television, which said that ''the major matters of difference'' have been financial.

title: EXCERPTS FROM INTERVIEW WITH HAIG ON MIDEAST
description: Following are excerpts from a Stat e Department transcript of an interview with Se cretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in which he discussed t he Middle East:

title: John Rogers Wadsworth Weds Kim Carla Stafford
description: Kim Carla Stafford, manager of the Land of the Condor Gallery in Dallas, was married in New York yesterday to John Rogers Wadsworth, also of Dallas, a fashion photographer and freelance writer.

title: 'RIGHT-TO-WORK' GROUP WINS SOLICITATION PLEA
description: A Federal appeals court has made it easier for contributions for political candidates to be solicited by a group backing laws that prohibit required union membership as a condition of employment.

title: Rev. Martha Melissa Weatherhead To Be the Bride of Warren Smith Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stephen John Knerly of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, have an nounced the engagement of Mrs. Knerly's daughter, the Rev. Martha Me lissa Weatherhead, to Warren Cummings Smith Jr., son of Mrs. John Br ady Marks and Mr. Smith, both of Portland, Ore.

title: Opener '81: At Buffalo
description: In only about three hours today, the Jets should discover some tr uths about themselves when they help open the season against the Bu ffalo Bills at Orchard Park, N.Y.

title: Cosmos Beaten, 3-2; Rowdies Tie Series
description: The fierceness of the rivalry between the Cosmos and the Tampa Bay Rowdies heightened tonight when the Rowdies beat the Cosmos, 3-2, in a shootout and evened the quarterfinal playoff series at one game apiece. The third and deciding game will be played here Wednesday night at 9 o'clock.

title: Miss Dewart Has Nuptials
description: Barbara Ashbrook Dewart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thompson Dewart 3d of Greenwich, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Scott Michael Williamson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Craig F. Williamson of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Rebecca Spencer performed the ceremony at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: ALTHOUGH their suit was recently dismissed by a State Supreme Court judge, a group of Eastport residents has decided to continue its battle to unite the divided village under a single town government. The Unite Eastport Movement, as the group is known, wants to merge the portion of the village within the bounds of Brookhaven Town with the part that is in the Town of Southampton.

title: Antiques; LABOR DAY NO DAY OF REST FOR ANTIQUERS
description: THREE events involving antiques are scheduled for tomorrow, Labor Day. They are inexpensive and fun, and could help to expand the learning process for every member of the family.

title: Skinning Cats
description: After a fur dealer in Bucks County, Pa., had circulated a price list offering 25 cents to $3.50 for the furs of house cats, the County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals warned pet owners last February to keep a close watch on their cats.

title: Leisure; GOLDENRODS HAVE MANY 'TREASURES'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Dr. Richard B. Fischer is a professor of environmental education at Cornell University. By RICHARD B. FISCHER

title: New Jersey Guide; PRINCETON DUAL EFFORT
description: The McCarter Theater and Princeton Art Association are uniting next Sunday for a four-hour open house-cum-festival, beginning at 1 P.M. The theater is offering both backstage tours and tours of its production shops. The cast of the season's opening show, ''Just Between Ourselves,'' will meet with visitors during its rehearsal break, and parents can sign up their youngsters for auditions for ''A Christmas Carol,'' which is being restaged this year.

title: THE ULTIMATE NAUTICAL MARATHON
description: Joanne A. Fishman frequently writes about yachting for The Times. By Joanne A. Fishman Somewhere in the North Atlantic, a fleet of 30 yachts is coursing southward in the first leg of the ultimate nautical marathon, the third Whitbread Round the World Race. By now, the leaders of the flotilla that set out eight days ago from Portsmouth, England, should have encountered the brisk northerly winds known as the Portuguese trades and will be sweeping down the coast of the Iberian Peninsula toward the Canary Islands. Before the boats sail back into Portsmouth harbor roughly seven months from now, they and their crews will have been pushed to their uttermost limits to cross more than 27,000 miles of ocean as fast as possible through some of the worst weather in the world.

title: SCIENTISTS DODGING COLLECTORS ON THE TRAIL OF ELUSIVE MOTH
description: Officials of the World Wildlife Fund, which has fought to preserve the giant panda in the mountains of China and the humpbacked whale in the seas off Hawaii, visited the lost colony of the rare and elusive prairie sphinx moth today at a secret site on the high plains of northeastern Colorado.

title: CAMDEN OPTIMISTIC ON PLANS FOR PRISON
description: CAMDEN A STATE prison to be built here in 1984 is expected to bring $8 million a year and 350 new jobs to this city, which fell nearly $5 million short of its current budget and which has an une mployment rate that its Mayor estimates at ''three or four times h igher than the national average.''

title: Sara Shea Sets Bridal on Nov. 7
description: Mr. and Mrs. Dale Coenen of New York and Ocean Reef, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Coenen's daughter, Sarah Shea, to David Young, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theo Young of Foulksmills, County Wexford, Ireland.

title: COBALT STILL BLUE
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to beef up stockpiles of strategic metals quickened the pulses of some cobalt traders earlier this year. They felt that rising demand from the government might pinch supplies, and send prices back toward levels reached in the late 1970's, when cobalt was selling for around $50 a pound.

title: CLARK GARDEN GETS 'CHALLENGE'
description: ALBERTSON THE days of keeping a low profile are over for the Clark Garden. A campaign is under way to make this horticultural educational center better known to the public and to institutions that can help bridge the financial gap that will widen as the garden's parent organization, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, gradually withdraws its subsidy over the next five to 10 years.

title: DELBELLO, BOARD AT ODDS ON COSTS IN POLICE MERGER
description: DEPENDING on whether one accepts the assessment provided by the County Executive's office or that provided by members of the Board of Legislators, the merger of the Parkway Police and the Sheriff's Office has saved the county $500,000 or it has cost the county that much in its first two years of operation.

title: REAGAN PLAN'S PAIN SETS IN FOR VOTERS
description: At a public hearing here, Senator Paul S. Sarbanes was told that high interest rates were destroying the construction industry and driving small business into the ground.

title: Film View; IT'S GETTING HARD TO BEAT THE BLAND
description: Late one chilly night last winter, I was standing on an Upper West Side street, talking to some dog-walking friends outside their brownstone, when their 12-year-old son, awakened by the conversation adjacent to his bedroom window, joined us, barefoot and in pajamas. Not bothering to say ''Hello'' or ''How are you?'' or even ''Longtime-no-see,'' but fixing me with the beady eye of the true movie fanatic, he attacked: ''Do you really mean to tell me...'' (pause, then furiously) ''that 'The Empire Strikes Back' strikes a bland note?''

title: EXPOS HOMERS SNAP ASTRO STREAK AT 19
description: Andre Dawson hit a two-run homer and Tim Raines also connected to support the eight-hit pitching of Ray Burris as the Montreal Expos defeated Houston, 5-2, today and ended the Astros' nine-game winning streak.

title: POND LIFE PERILED
description: HEWLETT THE heat and lack of rainfall in the last month may have been an excellent tonic for beachgoers, but they have brought sad tidings to aquatic life in this area. Twelve to 15 ducks in Nassau County's Grant Park Pond have perished along with hundreds of fish, largely as a result of weather conditions. And it is believed that wellmeaning residents who have turned out in large numbers to throw bread upon the waters have inadvertently contributed to the toll.

title: EAST HAMPTON
description: WHEN the parts don't come, what's a creative actress to do? Create them for herself - which is just what Phyllis Newman has been doing of late.

title: Topics; COUNTERFEIT COINS; Changing Behavior
description: It is true that bus people are less apt to carry tokens than subway people. But where is it writ, a friend of ours asks, that bus riders not hunt out their 75 cents until they are beside the farebox, blocking the door?

title: West Ham, 2 Others Stay Unbeaten in Soccer
description: West Ham, last year's Second Division champion, took over at the top of the English League's First Division today, one of only three soccer teams that remained unbeaten after the season's opening three matches.

title: CITY FEELS THE TORONTO TOUCH
description: If John H. Daniels had his way, he would knock down most of what is between Sixth and Eighth Avenues along 42d and 43rd Streets and build a world-famous work and entertainment center. He thought about putting whole blocks under a clear dome and filling the center's public ways with music, trees, fountains and promenades. He dreamed of something along the lines of Toronto's handsome Eaton Center, only bigger and better.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If we do not stay together, we will not win. If we remain strong as we did in August, we will win and make Poland the way we have dreamed because there can be no other Poland.'' - Lech Walesa, leader of Solidarity. (1:3.)

title: L.B. KAYE AND HANFIELD MERGE
description: L.B. Kaye & Associates, Ltd., the real estate brokerage concern, has acquired Hanfield Callen Ruland & Benjamin, Inc., one of the city's oldest property management companies, it was announced this week.

title: CORRECTION
description: A photograph in the Westchester Weekly section last Sunday was incorrectly identified. It showed a property in New Castle, known as the Cenacle, that is owned by the Unification Church.

title: Mary MacQueen Married in South
description: The marriage of Mary Gee MacQueen of Wilmington, N.C., to John R. Harrison of Lakeland, Fla., took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church of Wilmington. The Rev. Jerome Jones performed the ceremony.

title: Linda Schlichter Is Married to John Francis Reiser
description: Linda Jean Schlichter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Schlichter of Sudbury, Mass., was married there yesterday to John Francis Reiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Reiser of New Canaan, Conn., and Sag Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Robert Kealy, Judge of the Metropolitan Tribunal, Archdiocese of Chicago, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Martha-Mary Chapel at the Wayside Inn.

title: Antiques; GETTING HOOKED ON HOOKED RUGS
description: There is something poignant about early hooked rugs. They were meant to be walked on, after all, and given the wear and tear by sizeable Early American families, their life span was relatively short. Yet the women who fashioned them cared to make them fanciful and a delight to behold. Also, the extant examples we see today are likely to be the last works of those homemakers. The earlier ones would have been replaced when they were worn out and are lost to the past.

title: U.S. ISRAELI TALKS ON MILITARY LINKS ARE REPORTED SET
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel intend to explore the possibl e strengthening of strategic ties between their countries, inclu ding the staging of American military exercises in Israel and the sharing of spy satellite data, American and Israeli official s said today.

title: Migrant Aid Rule Contested
description: A suit has been filed in Federal court here on behalf of migrant farm workers who say they are being denied funds for medical treatment in Sandusky and Otta wa Counties. The two county welfare departments classify vehicles as personal property, which causes many families to exceed the $2,2 50 personal property limit to qualify for aid, the suit says.

title: Anti-U.S. Rally Held in India
description: More than 100 members of the youth wing of the opposition Lok Dal Party demonstrated outside the United States Embassy today to protest the Reagan Administration's military policies. There was no violence and no arrests were reported.

title: POL POT'S GROUP QUITS UNITY TALKS IN A HURRY
description: The Pol Pot delegation headed by Prime Minister Khieu Samphan left for its encampment along the Thai-Cambodian border today without naming its representative to the committee that is to prepare for a coalition government against the Vietnamese-sponsored regime in Phnom Penh.

title: RIGHT WING SEEKS A SHIFT BY REAGAN
description: The political right is demanding that the Reagan Administration turn its attention from economic legislation to ''moral issues,'' such as abortion and prayer in schools.

title: ICARUS LOBELL TIES MARK, TAKES PACE DERBY HEAT
description: Icarus Lobell tied a world record for 2-year-old pacers on a half-mile track tonight, covering the Louisville Downs mile in 1:57 2/5 in wining an elimination heat for the $200,000 Kentucky Pacing Derby to be run next Saturday.

title: NEW RING FOR THE OLD SCHOOL BELL
description: TRENTON THE school bell will ring again this week for about 1.2 million children throughout the state, but all the activity, especially after the first of the year, will not be confined to the classroom.

title: Janice M. Klumpp, Artist, Bride of Dennis H. Allee
description: Janice Merrill Klumpp, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Charles Klumpp of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Dennis Hammond Allee, son of Mrs. Alberta Allee of Bronxville, N.Y., and John Percy Allee of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Lucy Bartley of the Christian Baptist Church in Brooklyn performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Klumpp home.

title: Laura Ann Johnson, Boston Lawyer, Wed to Arthur Waterman Rogers 2d
description: Laura Ann Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Johnson of Cambridge, Mass., and South Harpswell, Me., was married yesterday to Arthur Waterman Rogers 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur A. Rogers of Deerfield, Mass. Justice of the Peace Bette Copeland of Brunswick, Me., performed the ceremony at the Union Church in North Harpswell, Me.

title: THE FIGHT GAME'S TURMOIL, AND THOSE WHO PROFIT
description: IT was Carl King's first confrontation with a margarita, and the tequila was off to a fast start when the heir apparent to Don King's boxing empire heard the name of Lennox Blackmoore, a junior-welterweight contender, mentioned in conversation around the table of a Minneapolis restaurant not long ago.

title: The World; Solidarity Meets, Situation Normal
description: The prelude to Solidarity's long-awaited national congress was predictably ominous: Soviet military maneuvers on the Polish border, hostile propaganda in the Soviet press, tough statements from the Polish Communist Party Central Committee and scattered strikes and strike alerts.

title: New Jerseyans
description: ON AN evening of bright, flat sunlight in 1955, Allan I. Ludwig and his wife, Janine, lost their way on the back roads of Connecticut. They were bound from Rhode Island, where they lived then, to a party when they took a wrong turn, one that proved to be an exceptionally right turn.

title: BARBARO AND ESPOSITO PRESENT THEIR VIEWS ON ISSUE OF CITY'S SCHOOL SYSTEM
description: Assemblymen Frank J. Barbaro of Brooklyn, candidate for the D emocratic nomination for Mayor, and John A. E sposito of Queens, candidate for the Republican nomination, were asked by The New York Times for their views on major issues confront ing New York City. Following are their replies on education: Barbaro

title: THE WORLD OF GODUNOV
description: It has been two years since Mr.Godunov, long a major Soviet star, defected from the Bolshoi Ballet when the company appeared in New York at the Metropolitan Opera in August, 1979. At the time, a minor diplomatic incident occurred at Kennedy International Airport when the dancer's wife, Ludmila Vlasova, a Bolshoi soloist, chose to return to the Soviet Union rather than remain with her husband. American authorities held up a Soviet jetliner bound for Moscow, wishing to make certain that Miss Vlasova, one of its passengers, was leaving of her own volition. Satisfied that the ballerina did indeed wish to return home, the Americans allowed the plane to depart after a delay of three days.

title: On Language
description: Tsk Force

title: Elizabeth L. Jeffrey Is Married in Ohio
description: Elizabeth Liscomb Jeffrey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hutchins Jeffrey 2d of Columbus, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Thomas Marshall Balderston, son of Prof. and Mrs. Frederick Emery Balderston of Berkeley, Calif. The Rev. Jane P. Mykrantz, godmother of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Broad Street Presbyterian Church.

title: Trial Is Set for Nov. 2 in Case Of Vandalized Water System
description: Trial has been set for Nov. 2 for four Pequannock teen-agers indicted in connection with vandalism that disrupted Newark's water supply system in July and cost the city millions of dollars for repairs.

title: Ideas and Trends; College Costs Are Up; So Is Enrollment
description: When Daniel Webster said his alma mater, Dartmouth, was ''a small college, and yet there are those who love it,'' he wasn't paying more than $11,000 a year to attend. This month, checks made out to more than a dozen East Coast colleges, Dartmouth included, will reflect increases (to as high as $12,030, at Bennington College in Vermont), according to a College Board survey of 1,060 four-year institutions.

title: THE PRESIDENT AND THE AIR CONTROLLERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Housing; 'ROBIN HOOD' FUEL PLAN FOR ELDERLY
description: AFUEL dealer in Yonkers calls himself a ''Robin Hood'' for taking oil from the ''haves'' and giving it to the ''have-nots,'' and his sponsors are trying to find more haves.

title: PCB CLEANUP STARTED AT BINGHAMTON OFFICES
description: A private contractor today began to install a special air filtration system in the the State Office Building here to rid it of toxic chemical contaminants.

title: Ideas and Trends; A Tougher Policy On Art Imports?
description: Ever since Lord Elgin took a fancy to some sculpted Greek marbles and decided to take them home to England, the expropriation of art works from their native countries has caused bitter disputes. Now, the Customs Service, in a case involving more than $1 million worth of pre-Columbian artifacts from Peru, is testing its ability to prosecute importers of art works claimed as national treasures by other countries.

title: Panty Raid Captures World Trotting Derby
description: Pant y Raid, a filly, captu red the first World Trotting Derby at the State Fair grounds today .

title: SHOT FATAL TO CYCLIST VIOLATED ADVICE ON FIRING
description: The transit police officer who accidentally shot and killed a 26-year-old bicyclist in Brooklyn Friday was firing at running suspects more than three times farther away than the Transit Police Department advises for maximum accuracy, a spokesman for the agency said yesterday.

title: LOOKING BACK WITHOUT ANGER
description: Twenty-five years ago last May, John Osborne's vitriolic drama ''Look Back in Anger'' shook the dust from the London theater scene and made ''angry young man'' the catch phrase for the frustration and malaise of postwar youth. In these excerpts from the first volume of his autobiography, ''A Better Class of Person,'' to be published by E.P. Dutton in the fall, Mr. Osborne sho ws how the play emerged from his experience. By JOHN OSBORNE

title: Candace L. Palter Is Wed To Joseph Allen Steiner
description: Candace Leslie Palter was married yesterday to Joseph Allen Steiner. Rabbi Paul M. Steinberg, dean of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion in New York performed the ceremony at t he Copley Plaza Hotel in Boston.

title: Pleasant Colony Wins Woodward
description: Pleasant Colony showed he was a superior 3-year-old when he won the Kentucky Derby and Preakness in May and finished a close second in the Travers last month. Yesterday he beat older rivals to stake a claim as the best horse of any age or sex in the country.

title: The Democratic Party deserved its losses in the 1980 election, and they will continue to lose unless they move clearly and decisively to the left. That shift should involve the extension of benefits to the entire population and substantial changes in the institutions that deliver services.
description: Between 1976 and 1980 President Carter and Congress kept none of their promises. The Federal Government did not take over welfare. No progress was made toward universal health insurance. The monthly unemployment figures regularly contradicted the commitment to full employment embodied in the 1978 Humphrey-Hawkins bill.

title: Elizabeth Visbeek Is Wed To James A. Carouso
description: Elizabeth Visbeek, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Visbeek of Green Valley, Ariz., was married yesterday in Newton, Mass., to James A. Carouso, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Carouso of Athens and New York. The Rev. Mark Clinger a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's sister, Lydia Rosenbaum.

title: A TENNIS PLAYER FINDS A WELCOME ON IRELAND'S COURTS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- WAYNE KALYN is assistant managing editor of World Tennis magazine. By WAYNE KALYN

title: Bridge; A 'COMPUTERIZED' PLAY
description: In the past two decades, the computer has made an impact upon bridge in a variety of ways. The simplest of these is dealing, for which the computer is admirably suited. Random deals can be provided in multiple copies and have proved most helpful. Some players, activated more by subjective heat than cool objective evidence, claim that computer deals are not quite equivalent to natural ones. But the only real problem arose when the same deals were used twice in two major events and one expert recognized them.

title: Beauty; THE FACTS BEHIND THE ALOE MYSTIQUE
description: Since the time of the pharaohs, the gel from the spiny gray-green leaves of the aloe vera plant has been doctoring sunburns, skin irritations, insect bites, psoriasis, dry skin, ulcers, baldness, headaches and even runny noses. Part of Cleopatra's cache of beauty secrets, the fleshy succulent is also said to have been the ''gift of Venus,'' responsible for the luxuriantly silky hair and velvety skin of young maidens of ancient times. In the past few years, interest in the aloe mystique has been rekindled. In a myriad assortment of sepia bo ttles, pastel tubes, flower-frocked palm-frond baskets and other p ackages, the ancient ''miracle gel'' has found its way into shampo os, hair conditioners, moisturizers, shaving creams and makeup as we ll as suntan lotions andburn medications, thanks to several aggressiv e young cosmetics companies.

title: MONEY TO EAT
description: To the Editor:

title: OLD GLORY An American Voyage.  By Jonathan Raban.  409 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.
description: TWO years ago a young Englishman named Jonathan Raban published an astonishingly good book, ''Arabia.'' At one bound, that book took him up into the company of T.E. Lawrence, Sir Richard Burton, Charles Doughty and Freya Stark. Mr. Raban was at pains, though, to disassociate himself from these earlier British Arabists. They had loved the desert Arab: the traditional romantic figure, wearing his burnous, riding his camel, living the ascetic life of a nomad. Mr. Raban's interest was in plump city Arabs, starting with those in London, and moving rapidly to Abu Dhabi, Sana (a little city in the middle of Yemen) and Cairo.

title: South Carolina 23 Wake Forest 6
description: SALEM, N.C. (AP) Terry Bishop ran and passed for 165 yards to lead South Carolina.

title: Soviet, West Germany Are Tied in Water Polo
description: The 15th European Swimming Championships opened today with the favorites, the Soviet Union and West Germany, held to surprise draws in the water polo tournament.

title: David Newberg to Wed Cecile Doelger
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Frank G. Doelger of New Canaan, Conn., and Chatham, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Cecile Marie Doelger, to David Allen Newberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Newberg of Brightwaters, L.I.

title: A SLEUTH FOR BILKED BUSINESS
description: Sherlock Holmes sniffed out crime and corruption in London's East End. For Martin and Pearl Tytell, the quarry is the same, but the locale is the corporate suite.

title: ART CENTER DRAWS HEAVILY ON COUNTY
description: THE County has a special place in its heart for the Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts. At least that is the opinion o f Alan Light, the center's managing director, who an ticipates that about 50 to 60 percent of all those who attend its 198 1-82 season of performances will be from Westchester.

title: Florida State 17, Louisville 0
description: Three freshmen, Mike Rendina, Billy Allen and Jesse Hester, scored all the points.

title: New Jersey Housing; RAYS OF HOPE FOR RETARDED ADULTS
description: SIX years ago, the Union County chapter of the Association for Retarded Citizens transformed a cottage that had once been used for recovering tubercular patients at John Runnells Hospital in Berkeley Heights into its first group home for retarded adults.

title: MASSACRE AT NEW LONDON: A LOOK BACK
description: TWO hundred years ago today, Connecticut's erring son paid his last visit home. At the head of 1,700 British troop s, he raided the privateering base at New London. The outcome of his homecoming: a garrison of m ilitia slaughtered, a busy port town burned, 100 Connecticut m en dead.

title: Westchester Journal
description: DISTRICT Attorney Carl A. Vergari unveiled last week a computer system his office is putting into use to keep track of 26,000 criminal cases being processed yearly in 43 courts in the county.

title: THE MONSTER WE CAN'T LIVE WITHOUT
description: IN conceiving the automobile, we have unwittingly created a monster far more threatening than Frankenstein's homely creature. It is harder than ever to share the enthusiasm of an earlier age, optimistic abou t the potential of the new ''horseless carriage.''

title: WORK AND PLAY: NOT JUST OPPOSITES
description: THE signs of summer's foreclosure were all along Main Street - the sales on bikinis and picnic baskets, bulk specials on lined notebook paper and ballpoint pens, college-bound youths running last-minute errands and hugging fond farewells.

title: Connecticut Guide; AIRPORT JUBILEE
description: The most enthusiastic booster attending the Tweed-New Haven Airport 50th anniversary observance Saturday will be Ch ief Jack Tweed of the Branford Fire Department, former assistant manager of the airport, son of the ai rport's founder, John H. Tweed, and great-grandson of William Marcy (Boss) Tweed, who, according to Jack, ''did a lot more for New York than the politicians are doing now.''

title: HIRSHHORN LEAVES ART COLLECTION TO MUSEUM
description: Joseph Hirshhorn, the patron of modern paintings and sculpture who died last Monday at the age of 82, left his entire private collection to the museum that bears his name on The Mall in Washington, according to Mr. Hirshhorn's will, filed for probate in Florida.

title: Tight-Fisted Boxing
description: Although thumbing is illegal in a professional fight, it has always existed, serving as a handy alternative to a left jab or a right cross. It sometimes inflicts great physical damage, especially to the eyes. Now thumbing has caught the eye of the New York State Athletic Commission.

title: FRENCH BANKS CUT RATES
description: French bankers hastily began cutting lending rates this weekend after sharp criticism by the country's new Socialist Finance Minister, Jacques Delors, and an unprecedented Government move to stimulate the economy by forcing down the cost of credit.

title: Powless Captures 45's Tennis Title
description: John Powless of Madison, Wis.; Russell Seymour of New Orleans and Charles Oliver, a West Point graduate, won the singles titles in the United States senior grass-court tennis championships today at the Germantown Cricket Club.

title: Crews Work to Clean Up Mississippi River Oil Spill
description: Workers using giant industrial vacuum cleaners today attempted to suck up 840,000 gallons of crude oil spilled into the Mississippi River in the collision of a Greek tanker and a string of grain barges.

title: CATHOLIC EDUCATION PROVING ATTRACTIVE TO NON-CATHOLICS
description: When classes resume Wednesday at St. Therese of Liseaux parochial school in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, the official enrollment of 526 children will include 90 non-Roman Catholics, or 17 percent of the school population. Five years ago every student was Catholic.

title: CBS'S STORY ON HAITI STILL I N LIMBO
description: SIX months ago, CBS's ''60 Minutes'' found itself the focus of the sort of controversy the program has long specialized in investigating. It was revealed that Morley Safer, a correspondent, had dropped plans to do a story about poverty and the political rule in Haiti when his colleague Mike Wallace expressed concern that such a segment might endanger members of his family who live in Haiti.

title: GARBAGE PIER IS WORTHY OF THE NAME
description: Jerry De Lucia, a Sanitation Department foreman, rested his foot on a metal-clad wooden sill beneath a large window at the 59th Street pier, overlooking empty garbage barges waiting in the green Hudson River.

title: INVADERS, GUANTANAMO BOUND, COME ONLY TO GRIEF
description: The battle plan, dubbed ''Mission Implausible'' by the Miami press, was a peaceful invasion of the United States Naval Base at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba by Cubans United, a minuscule exile group, to establish an anti-Castro government in exile.

title: 2d Flood Disaster of '81 Is Disclosed by China
description: China, disclosing its second major flood disaster of the year, said today that 764 people have been killed, more than 5,000 have been injured and 200,000 have been left homeless since mid-August in western Shanxi Province.

title: SCARSDALE, N.Y. - In growing numbers, American workers are voting for a new, more mature brand of unionism, one that matches the desires of a middle-class work force to the needs of today's economy. The new form retains the basic goals of the old: steadily rising standards of living, reasonable job security, freedom from arbitrary management action. To these it adds the pursuit of dignity through cooperation with management to achieve shared goals.
description: Unionists have long believed that they had to choose between opposition and capitulation. Bitter experience with capitulation and the reluctance of many employers to accept any form of union cooperation but acquiescence established antagonism as the nor m. Union activism is defined as reflex oppositio n to management.

title: Lay Teachers Plan Strike Vote Today
description: Lay teachers at six parochial high schools in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties were scheduled to vote today on whether to strike when the schools open Wednesday.

title: NEW PANEL ASKED ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: An unusual Republican proposal to entrust the drafting of sensitive Social Security legislation to an unofficial, bipartisan Congressional panel in order to avoid a polarizing interparty conflict will be made when Congress returns to the Capitol this week.

title: New York Seeking To Thin Out Deer
description: ALBANY (AP) - The State Department of Environmental Conservation will allow more hunters into the woods this fall to thin out deer herds, some of which it contends have grown dangerously large.

title: BRITAIN AWIATS 4-MONTH WAVE OF JAPANESE CULTURE
description: LONDON BRITAIN is about to experience four months of near-total exposure to the culture of another island nation: Japan. The occasion is an exhibition of treasures from the politically calm and culturally rich Edo period, from 1600 to 1868, when the country was almost closed to the West. More than 700 objects have been assembled for a show at the Royal Academy opening on Oct. 24. Sir Hugh Casson, the academy's president, describes the exhibition as ''the most ambitious, the most logistically complicated and the most costly that we have ever undertaken.''

title: EXECUTIVE TRANSFER: EASING THE STRAINS
description: High interest rates seem to be bringing the housing market to a standstill, but a handful of large real estate service companies are thriving on the largess of corporations that transfer thousands of workers and pay all costs -including the financial gimmicks often needed to buy or sell a home today.

title: Amy Ralston Wed To Howard Seife
description: Amy Ralston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Ralston of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday in the East Midwood Jewish Center to Howard Seife, son of Dr. and Mrs. Milton D. Seife of Yonkers. Rabbi Alvin Kass performed the ceremony.

title: Summer Ball
description: Coach Tom Penders of Fordham, with most of the basketball team that won 19 games and lost nine last season scheduled to return, is looking forward to the beginning of practice on Oct. 15. But topmost in his mind at the moment is the fate of the Franklin Cardinals in the New England regional tournament of the Men's Major Fast Pitch Softball tournament.

title: Body of French Envoy Returned From Lebanon
description: The body of Ambassador Louis Delamare of France, who was assassinated here two days ago, was flownback to Franc e today.

title: ROOKIE LEADS BY 1
description: Patty Sheehan, a rookie, shot a five-under-par 67 today and took a one-stroke lead into tomorrow's final round of the $125,000 L.P.G.A. Rail Charity Classic.

title: Loss Growing At Harvester
description: The International Harvester Company says that its fourth-quarter loss will be greater than originally expected because of persistent low demand for its farm machinery products.

title: WE CAN AFFORD TO SHOW WHAT HEAVEN'S FOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Jameela Wins Maskette As Love Sign Is Second
description: They're not as fast or famous as Affirmed and Alydar, but Jameela and Love Sign yesterday added another episode to what is becoming the closest and most consistent race track rivalry since the first two hooked up in 1978. Jameela proved the best this time to win the $108,800 Maskette Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN'S VACATION LED TO WHITE HOUSE DISCORD
description: As President Reagan begins a week of difficult policy decisions, White House officials are acknowledging reluctantly that one price of Mr. Reagan's vacation in California has been a display of internal rivalry and discord in the Administration that had been kept suppressed.

title: Jersey Aims to Cut Drawbridge Snarls
description: NEWARK (AP) - State transportation officials want permission from the Coast Guard to reduce the times drawbridges must be opened during commuter rush periods. At issue are the interests of mariners, motorists and harried railroad commuters.

title: Model of Old Gun Kills Boy
description: A 16-year-old boy was killed early today when a handmade copy of a pirate's cap and ball pistol accidentally fired, the police said. The youth, who was not immediately identified, was shot in the head at a friend's home and died during emergency surgery. The police said the boys thought the weapon was a toy.

title: FOR SENATE, A NEW ERA IN GROOMING
description: For nearly 20 years, Elbert Link's ears were privy to political deals and vote-swapping. His hands massaged some of the most famous jowls in politics, his clippers hummed through hair thick and thin and his straight razor, after a few slaps against a leather strap, scraped 5 o'clock shadows from the faces of the powerful.

title: Kingdom Quits Colorado Team
description: Scott Kingdom, senior quart erback, has quit the Colorado football team, apparent ly leaving the job to a sophomore, Randy Essington. Kingdom was the t eam's leading passer last season, compiling 619 yards.

title: PIONEERING INTERMAGNETICS SEEKS A NICHE
description: An intriguing thing happens when certain metals are cooled to extremely low temperatures. At about 415 degrees below zero Fahrenheit - close to what is called absolute zero because matter can get no colder - these metals lose all resistance to electricity.

title: Thinnest Steel Was Used At Hyatt, Paper Reports
description: Support beams that held the Hyatt Regency Hotel's skywalks were made of the thinnest steel commonly manufactured in the country, a newspaper reported today.

title: Civil Courts, Uncivil Campaigns
description: The most important point to make about the contests for Civil Court Judge in Thursday's Democratic primary, is that they shouldn't be taking place at all. Though New York State has elected most of its judges since the mid-19th century, the legal community has become uneasy with the process in recent years, for good reason. Many judgeships are decided well before Election Day in political party clubhouses. But even genuinely contested elections are a dubious way to choose judges.

title: Marsh Captures European Open
description: Graham Marsh of Australia shot a four-under-par 68 today and won the $210,000 European Open golf championship.

title: 18 Gallery Heads Pick 18 Artists for Exhibition
description: The directors of 18 New York art galleries have selected 18 artists for an exhibition organized by Pratt Institute's department of exhibitions and called ''For Love and Money: Dealers Choose.''

title: SCHOOLS OPEN WITH TROUBLE IN SOME CITIES
description: Declining in enrollment, financially troubled, transformed by ethnic shifts and, in some places, creeping once more toward segregation, many of the nation's public school systems are now struggling as they open for the new academic year.

title: Marjorie H. Corn Bride Of Alan Martin Dubow
description: Marjorie Helen Corn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Corn of New York, was married yesterday to Alan Martin Dubow, son of Mr. Arthur Dubow of Kew Gardens, Queens, and the late Mrs. Dubow. Rabbi Charles Lippman, national director of New Jewish Agenda, performed the ceremony at the St. Moritz.

title: Fiat Plans Major Layoffs
description: Fiat, Italy's largest private employer, announced it would lay off 70,000 workers for one to two weeks in October because of declining auto exports.

title: ARMS BUDGET DEBATE
description: The prospect that $10 billion to $15 billion will be cut from recently increased military appropriations for the fiscal year l982 has reawakened old arguments within the military over priorities in weapons and theaters of deployment.

title: U.S. STILL ADAMANT
description: On the eve of Labor Day, Reagan Administration and union officials exchanged charges today over the Administration's handling of the air traffic controllers' strike and the effect of the President's economic program on workers.

title: COMMODITIES
description: Kenneth W. Monfort, president of Monfort of Colorado, the world's largest cattle feeder and, consequently, a big corn user, remarked the other day that consumers could look forward before long to ''relatively cheap meat prices.''

title: EGYPT COPTS WARY AFTER SADAT MOVE
description: The deposing of Egypt's Coptic Pope by President Anwar el-Sadat caused some confusion and gloom among the nation's six million Coptic Christians today, but their overall reaction was muted and wary.

title: Sihanouk Cites Problems In Uniting Opposition
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, Cambodia's former chief of state, said today that he was having problems forming a coalition with leftist and rightist guerrillas to fight the Cambodian Government, which is backed by the Soviet Union and by Vietnam.

title: JAZZ: DETROIT IS PLAYING HOST TO A WORLD-CLASS FESTIVAL
description: ''There is not one place in the world that you can find more jazz musicians from than Detroit,'' the pianist Barry Harris told the audience last Thursday at the Detroit Institute of Arts during the Montreux-Detroit International Jazz Festival.

title: Israeli Comedy to Open Tomorrow at La Mama
description: ''Ya'acobi and Leidental,'' a comedy by the Israeli playwright Hanoch Levine, will begin a two-week American premiere engagement tomorrow at the La Mama Annex, 74A East Fourth Street. The play, about three unhappy people who have let life slip by, will be performed in English by the Cameri Theater of Tel Aviv, regarded as the national theater of Israel.

title: PANEL CITES FARM LOAN ABUSES
description: Congressional investigators have concluded that the Small Business Administration provided millions of dollars in improper and possibly illegal loans to farmers reporting crop losses because of drought.

title: YANKS ROUT ROYALS
description: The Yankees scored six first-inning runs today an d went on to beat the Kansas City Royals, 6-1, and give Bob Lemon a 1 -0 record in his second stint as the New York manager.

title: COSMOS TIED 1-1, WORK ON HOLIDAY
description: The Cosmos canceled the softball and backgammon games they had planned for their Labor Day recreation. They will be working at Giants Stadium instead to prepare for the third and deciding game of their quarterfinal series against the Tampa Bay Rowdies on Wednesday.

title: THE LOVE CANAL LEGACY: LAWSUITS AND BITTERNESS
description: Three years ago, the State Health Commissioner declared a health emergency in the Love Canal neighborhood here. A few days later, President Jimmy Carter declared it a Federal disaster area.

title: International
description: The United States trade deficit with Japan may exceed $15 billion this year, a record imbalance that is threatening to lead to new trade frictions between the two countries. The American trade representative, William E. Brock, is asking Japan for concessions. (Page D1.)

title: THE DANCE: 'RAW SILK,' SOLO WORK
description: SARAH BRUMGART dances with Laura Dean, and the way she moves reflects that choreographer's spare lucidity. But Miss Brumgart is a compelling performer in her own right, as her solo ''Raw Silk'' revealed Thursday at the Roulette loft-theate r in TriBeCa.

title: COWBOYS, PACED BY DORSETT, TRIUMPH OV E R REDSKINS, 26-10
description: Tony Dorsett made a statement today with his flying feet, his shoulder drives into tacklers and his second-half endurance on a hot, sultry afternoon.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A 'NEW LIFE'

title: An Understudy Finds a Country Nesting Spot
description: A couple of at-liberty ducks were among the performers who were dispersed when ''Scrambled Feet'' ended its long run in June. Hermione, the starring duck that garnered excellent notices, found a home immediately.

title: Question BoxS.
description: QUESTION: A player hits a broken-bat ground ball, and the runner from third, attempting to score, trips on a piece of the bat and is tagged out. Does the out stand?

title: DINKINS HOPES TO CAP A LONG CAREER
description: Sometimes it seems that the battle for Manhattan Borough President is being fought out over a field of pate and truffles at Zabar's. Last Wednesday, the challenger, David N. Dinkins, walked in among the imported cheeses and copper woks at the West Side delicacy shop in search of voters. Andrew J. Stein, the incumbent, has made the shop on Broadway a regular campaign stop.

title: Dana Meg Murphy Is Bride
description: Dana Meg Murphy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. I. Craig Murphy of Port Washington, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas John Scheuren of Manhasset, L.I., son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Scheuren of Pottsville, Pa. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. Richard H. Hall at All Saints Chapel by the Sea in Southport, Me.

title: Ties Not Necessary
description: The Ohio Valley and Yankee Conferences will not have any ties in their league football games this season as a result of a ruling adopted for Division I-AA teams by the National Collegiate Athletic Association in June. So far, only the Ohio Valley and Yankee Conference have decided to employ the tie-breaking procedure, but the Big Sky Conference is polling its eight members and will announce tomorrow if it will use the ruling this fall.

title: A Brady Visit Home
description: The White House press secretary, James S. Brady, got a dramatic welcome on his first visit home in the five months since he suffered a head wound during the attempted assassination of President Reagan. Although he was back in the hospital yesterday, Mr. Brady spent 10 hours Saturday with his wife and 2-year-old son.

title: REAGAN'S NEW CLOTHES
description: Barely a mo nth ago President Reagan was being hailed as the creatorof an economi c revolution. He had bent Congress to his will on a radically res haped budget and on massive tax cuts. Pundits wrote of a transformat ion in national economic policy, a new formula for higher growth and lower inflation; they foresaw a change as lasting as the New De al.

title: 2D REBEL GROUP REDUCES ITS ROLE
description: The solidarity of the Northern Ireland hunger strike was threatened today when another prisoner was taken off the fast by his mother, and one of the organizations behind the strike reduced the level of its participation.

title: Soviet Oil Output
description: Oil and gas production in the Soviet Union was slightly ahead of schedule during the first eight months of this year, Pravda reported today.

title: Deborah Page, Skater, Wed
description: The marriage of Deborah Lynn Page, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Page of Kings Point, L.I., to Patrick Joseph Hickey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald J.
