Hickey of Brantford, Ontario, took place yesterday. Msgr. Donald P. Marrokal of the Vatican performed the ceremony at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in Great Neck, L.I. The bride, a figure skater, is a member of John Curry's Ice Dance Company. Mr. Hickey, a professional hockey player, is with the Toronto Maple Leafs. He formerly played with the New York Rangers.

title: ROBING THE BENCH'S ELITE
description: WHEN Daniel J. O'Hern was named to the New Jersey Supreme Court not long ago, he boarded a train for New York to meet a shadowy figure in black who is familiar to most of the judges in the country, and whose dark embrace generally lasts a lifetime.

title: Mary Jo Metlitz Wed To Steven L. Kantor
description: At the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I., yesterday, Mary Jo Metlitz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merwin M. Metlitz of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., was married to Steven Lloyd Kantor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Kantor of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I. Rabbi Philip Berkowitz performed the ceremony.

title: RETIREMENT SHARPENS SINGER'S STING
description: At 63 years old Joe Glazer, known as labor's troubadour, continues to write and sing his songs of social commentary and protest.

title: FANS AT AIRPORT
description: When the Yankees arrived at Newark Airport late Sunday night, they were met by hundreds of fans and a dozen camera crews. The players, after a quiet flight, were amazed by the reception, which they said reminded them of returning after a playoff victory.

title: ACADEMICS DEBATE CHANGES IN PARTY LOYALTY
description: Political scientists, seeing a national shift to Republicanism developing in ways that do not match their expectations, are questioning their traditional theories.

title: MANY RAIDERS REPORTED AS KNOWING GAMBLER
description: Many Oakland Raiders knew the convicted bookmaker Nicholas Dudich, whose relationship with Ken Stabler is under investigation, former member s of the National Football League team said in an article publi shed today.

title: Labor Day is an idle Monday in search of an identity. We need a new Labor Day. We need - the Administration's economic revival plan demands - a refurbished and rehabilitated Labor Day. We need Labor Day for Plutocrats!
description: Admittedly, such a step amounts to a transvaluation of values. But this should pose no obstacle to an Administration that installed James Watt in the Interior Department. And think of the rewards.

title: CITY'S AMBULANCES REDUCE EMERGENCY-RESPONSE TIME
description: New York City's Emergency Medical Service, whose ambulances have been persistently criticized for responding more slowly than those of any other major city in the country, says it has reduced its average response time by nearly a third in the last year.

title: A battered and disconsolate labor movement arrives at Labor Day befuddled over direction posts for the Reagan years. Many, if not most, top unionists are convinced that labor's needs and those of the country in this period of fierce world trade competition, lagging productivity and finite resources bespeak a switch from the adversary course organized labor has traditionally pursued in its relations with industry.
description: Unfortunately, that conviction is opposed by an even more firmly held belief that inimical attitudes and actions by the Reagan Administration and large parts of the business sector make it inescapable that unions will take fresh recourse to muscle flexing and other expressions of low-voltage class warfare on both the economic and political fronts.

title: Abrams Asks State to Drop Proposal on Milk Wholesalers
description: Robert Abrams, the State Attorney General, has asked the State Agriculture Department to drop a proposal to require wholesale buyers of milk to get department approval before changing suppliers.

title: More's Still More for Defense
description: The wailing in the Pentagon suggests that President Reagan is trying to cut defense spending. Not a bit. Slower growth, maybe, but he still plans to ask Congress for the largest peacetime increase in military appropriations in two decades. So what's all the wailing about?

title: SPECIAL STRATEGIES
description: In the course of doing her job, which happens to be selling, Constance Levinson deals with horse-supply shops. She deals with fishing stores, scientific supply houses and garden centers. She talks to tribes of mail-order catalogue people, not to mention companies that rank high in the Fortune 500. Also, she is in contact with a veal grower and she sells to a casket company. One client is a store that only stocks goods that relate to unicorns.

title: COLTS WIN
description: Randy McMillan, a rookie, rushed for 146 yards and two fourth-quarter touchdowns today as the Baltimore Colts erased a 14-13 halftime deficit and edged the New England Patriots, 29-28, in an American Football Conference game.

title: Denny in 3d Straight Shutout
description: John Denny pitched a three-hitter for his third consecutive shutout, and the Cleveland Indians won their 10th game in the last 12 today with a 2-0 defeat of t he California Angels.

title: U.S. FINISHES THIRD IN WORLD CUP TRACK
description: The United States men's team won four of the five events on the final day of the 1981 World Cup track and field championships, but came nowhere near making up for its mishaps of the preceding two days.

title: PARENTS TO GET RAFFLED HOUSE
description: Two sons of a home improvement contractor said today that they would turn over a $113,000 house they won in a Boys' Club raffle to their parents, who will probably sell the home.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Stock and commodity exchanges and banks in the United States and Canada will be closed today in observance of Labor Day. Markets in Europe and Japan will be open.

title: Sports World Specials; Pal Joey
description: Like other children who idolize major league baseball players, an 11-year-old boy named Joey picked his special star and concentrated all his efforts on making a personal contact. Joey, who lives in a Bronx housing project, selected Willie Randolph, the Yankees' second baseman. At game after game, he would shout Randolph's name. After games, dressed in a Yankee jersey with Randolph's No. 30, he would wait outside the players' exit and hound Randolph for his autograph, following him to his car.

title: Common Market Presses Soviet on Afghanistan
description: Foreign ministers of the European Common Market decided today to continue to press the Soviet Union to withdraw its troops from Afghanistan. They also acknowledged that their search for a mediating role in the Middle East remained stalemated.

title: RACHEL CARSON AND THE WAR ON THE FRUIT FLY
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathryn Pinso n Married in Texas
description: The marriage of Kathryn Clay Pinson, daughter of Mrs. Frank C. Guthrie of Houston and the late Theo W. Pinson, to Daniel Pomeroy Davison Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Davison of Locust Valley, L.I., took place yesterday. The Rev. James Thomas Bagby, rector of St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Houston, performed the ceremony at the bride's family's ranch in Boerne, near San Antonio.

title: 4 Inmates Still at Large After Fleeing Kansas Jail
description: Seven heavily armed inmates overpowered a guard today and escaped from the Kansas State Prison, commandeering two cars and shooting an officer in their getaway, the authorities said.

title: Braves' 12 Hits Topple Mets, 5 to 2
description: The Mets failed to complete what would have been their first series sweep since June 1980, by losing to the Atlanta Braves, 5-2, yesterday at Shea Stadium in a game in which two players were making comebacks of sorts.

title: ARMY REPORTING KEY GAINS IN RECRUITING AND READINESS
description: A year after being called ''hollow,'' the Army is reporting significant gains in attracting recruits and in the readiness of its trained forces.

title: New Eruption Reported At Mount St. Helens
description: Mount St. Helens erupted again tonight, as the lava dome inside the volcano's cone burst open on one side, the United States Geological Survey said.

title: A MINING INDUSTRY BARRED FROM PREPARING FOR ITS NATION'S NEEDS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY PAKISTANI HEROIN IS NOT LIKELY TO HURT CHANCES FOR AID
description: Pakistan's role as a source of heroin for international drug trafficking is not likely to become an obstacle in the coming Congressional debates on the resumption of aid to that country, according to Congressional and Administration officials.

title: Haitians Protest Near Camp
description: About 500 protesters, including natives of Haiti, gathered today outside a refugee detention camp here. They chanted in Creole, ''Let my people go,'' but there was no repetition of the disorder on Thursday that led to mobilization of Border Patrol guards at the Krome North center on the edge of the Everglades.

title: Leslie M. Wyler Bride O f David Salembier Jr.
description: Leslie M. Wyler, a mathematics teacher at the Barnsable School in Glen Rock, N.J., was married yesterday to David J. Salembier Jr., a founder and headmaster of the school. The Rev. Dale Cranston performed the ceremony at All Saints Episcopal Church in Glen Rock.

title: Con Ed Backs Rehabilitation
description: The Consolidated Edison Company is urging state legislation to establish ''enterprise zones'' to aid redevelopment.

title: CONNORS DOWNS GOMEZ IN 5 SETS, GAINS ROUND OF 16
description: Jimmy Connors woke up the United States Open tennis championships yesterday by winning a lively five-set marathon against Andres Gomez of Ecuador that went to a decisive tiebreaker.

title: Rose Zoltek Is Bride of Dr. Todd Jick
description: Rose Rena Zoltek, daughter of Mrs. Adam J. Zoltek of Toronto and the late Mr. Zoltek, was married yesterday to Dr. Todd David Jick, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leon A. Jick of Lexington, Mass. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Harvey J. Fields at Temple Isaiah in Lexington.

title: Forecast on Rates
description: Interest rates will not fall much by the end of this year, Lee Gunderson, president of the American Bankers Association, said today.

title: Army Football Gets a Few Delicate Pointers
description: As West Point's visiting artist for the new academic year, Edward Villella has just given his first ballet demonstrations and lectures to 100 Army football players. Amid a certain amount of initial hilarity, he had most of them trying some basic ballet steps and movements.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Leonard Silk THE MATHEMATICAL EXPERIENCE. By Philip J. Davis and Reuben Hersh. 440 pages. Birkhauser. $24. BIBLICAL GAMES: A Strategic Analysis of Stories in the Old Testament. By Steven J. Brams. 196 pages. The M.I.T. Press. $15.

title: JETS ARE ROUTED
description: The Philadelphia Eagles, who were good enough last season to have gone to the Super Bowl, are still good. Their defense in general and their pass rush in particular led them to a 24-10 victory over the Giants today in their National Football League season opener.

title: Andrea Doria Dive Stirs Memories of a Survivor
description: If Peter Gimbel was surprised at the large size of the hole in the Andrea Doria's side, as he said near the end of his recent diving expedition to the sunken liner, his surprise surprised Linda Morgan Hardberger of San Antonio, Tex.

title: N.F.L. DIDN'T CHECK STABLER DEAL
description: National Football League Properties Inc. routinely approved a business deal in 1978 - without doing a background check on the individuals involved - that allowed Ken Stabler to become part of a potentially embarrassing business relationship with a man who later was identified as a member of an East Coast organized crime family.

title: CONTINENTAL AIR BILL IMPERILED
description: A bill to enable the employees of Continental Airlines to buy the company and block a takeover by Texas International Airlines apparently will not be voted on by the California Senate this year.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN DEFENSE CHIEF: ZEALOT OR PRAGMATIST?
description: When Gen. Magnus Malan exchanged the uniform he wore as chief of the South African Defense Forces for a Cabinet minister's pinstripes a year ago, there was an undercurrent of fashionable opinion that interpreted the entry of the first professional military man into a South African Cabinet as an important omen.

title: NAMIBIA SHIFT DENIED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: South African officials said today that their Government's basic position on independence for South-West Africa had not changed, but they avoided taking direct issue with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s statement that there had been progress on the issue.

title: Zimbabwe Fuel Stocks
description: Simbi Makoni, the energy minister, said today that Zimbabwe had only three days' supply of diesel fuel and only slightly more gasoline. Mr. Makoni said in a television interview that part of the problem was caused by rail congestion, but that South Africa was also contributing to the crisis, using its economic strength to try to change Zimbabwe's stand against apartheid. Almost all fuel supplies are imported from South Africa. Zimbabwe hopes to be independent of South Africa for transport fuel when repairs to a 180-mile pipeline from Mozambique are completed this year, permitting direct imports of a million tons of gasoline and diesel a year.

title: PHILIP WELTNER
description: Dr. Philip Weltner, a former chancellor of Georgia's university system who served nine years as president of Oglethorpe University, died yesterday after a long illness.

title: STEINBRENNER DISMISSES MICHAEL, NAMES LEMON AS YANK MANAGER
description: Gene Michael, the New York Yankee manager who had criticized the team's owner in public, was dismissed today by George Steinbrenner and replaced by Bob Lemon.

title: SURROGATE MOTHER: SPEAKING HER MIND
description: A surrogate mother says she misses the baby boy she gave away last year, but she'd be willing to bear an infant for a childless couple again.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: Elise Ingalls, Dancer, Bride
description: Elise Marie Ingalls, a member of the New York City Ballet Company, was married yesterday to Norman F. Swanton, chairman and chief executive officer of the Swanton Corporation. Lieut.

title: Letter: On Cable TV Franchises; The Community Needs Public Access
description: To the Editor:

title: THE JOKE AS HEALTHY AGGRESSION
description: It's an old joke, but a telling one. Awhile ago in the 21 Club, Peter Ustinov was having dinner with Dr. Martin Grotjahn, a professor of psychiatry, and they were trading jokes. ''Ustinov said, 'Have you heard the one about the deep-sea diver?' '' Dr. Grotjahn recalls. ''I said no, and he said, 'well, a hardhat diver was exploring a wreck deep under the ocean, when he got a call on the diving phone from his captain in the ship above. 'Come up! Come up now!' the captain said. 'Why?' asked the diver. 'Why? Because the ship is sinking!' ''

title: JUAN ENRIQUE RODRIGUEZ
description: Juan Enrique Rodriguez, a retired interpreter at the United Nations, died Saturday of complications after surgery at North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L.I. He was 66 years old and lived in New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: INDIANS AWAIT CONFRONTATIONS
description: Two groups of Sioux, both occupying parts of the Black Hills of South Dakota that they say were illegally seized from them more than a century ago, face confrontations with the Government this week over whether they can remain in their camps.

title: Andrea McArdle to Star In Revue Saluting Berlin
description: Andrea McArdle, who created the role of Annie in 1977 in the Broadway musical of the same name and won a Tony Award for her performance, will make her first appearance in New York since she left the musical a year later because she was too old. She was 13 years old when she came to Broadway.

title: U.S. FARM PRODUCTIVITY MAY BE LEVELING OFF
description: A WORLD TO FEED Fifth article of a series appearing periodically

title: FALCONS SPOIL DEBUT OF PHILIPS, ROGERS
description: Steve Bartkowski threw three touchdown passes and Kenny Johnson recovered a fumble and ran 35 yards for another score today as the Atlanta Falcons posted a 27-0 victory over the New Orleans Saints in a National Conference game.

title: Swiss Inflation Climbs by 1.5%
description: Switzerland's cost-of-living index jumped 1.5 percent in August, the largest monthly increase since 1974, authorities reported.

title: Index; International
description: South African defense chief: zealot or pragmatist A2 Shift in stance on Namibia is denied in South Africa A2 Invaders, Guantanamo bound, come only to grief A3 Heroin production rises in Pakistani border region A4 Officials say issue of aid to Pakistan won't hinge on drugs A4 Around the World A5 Government/Politics Political scientists debate shifts in party loyalties A7 Bipartisan panel suggested for Social Security bill A8 Manhattan's B orough President has his eye on a higher position B4 David N. Dinkins hopes to combine foes of Andrew J. Stein B4 Koch and Esposito debate Mayor's entry in G.O.P. race B5 SportsMonday Baseball: Yankees rout Royals C5

title: Yellow Flag For a No. 1
description: AS the third quarter was winding down in the Giants' 24-10 loss yesterday, Lawrence Taylor, their rookie linebacker and first-round draft choice, swooped down to cover the Eagles' fullback, Perry Harrington, on a pass pattern. Perry Harrington looked over his shoulder, caught a quick pass from Ron Jaworski, and then was bounced out of bounds by Lawrence Taylor at the Giants' 36-yard line.

title: Karen Kappelman Married to Richard Mendelsohn
description: The marriage of Karen Ruth Kappelman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Murray Kappelman of Baltimore, to Richard Seth Mendelsohn, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Mendelsohn of Kings Point, L.I., took place yesterday at the Belvedere Hotel in Baltimore. Cantor Melvin Luterman performed the ceremon y.

title: LOS ANGELES'S STREET OF RICH AND POOR
description: With the kind of modesty for which Los Angeles real estate hucksters have long been famous, promoters here are calling Wilshire Boulevard ''the most expensive residential street in the world.''

title: BOMB DAMAGES 21ST ST. BOOKSTORE
description: A small bomb exploded yesterday and smashed a two-foot hole in one of the display windows of the Four Continent Book Corporation, a store at Fifth Avenue and 21st Street that specializes in books published in the Soviet Union.

title: CABARET: A FOLK NIGHT
description: ON Saturday, the Bottom Line presented what amounted to a mini-folk festival, with four acoustically based acts, each performing six or seven songs, and the program culminating in a group sing-along. But what sounded like a wonderful idea in theory was only partly successful in practice, the main problem being the brevity of the individual sets.

title: CITICORP'S CHICAGO VENTURE
description: To the average customer, the only hint of Citicorp's deep involvement in the Central National Bank here is a colorful little sign on a counter advertising Citicorp travelers checks.
To the Editor:

title: Hamid Franjieh Dead; Former Lebanese Aide
description: Hamid Franjieh, a former Foreign Minister of Lebanon, died last night after a long illness, Lebanese newspapers reported today. He was 74 years old.

title: CROSBY CAPTURES AMATEUR TITLE
description: Nathaniel Crosby, youngest son of the late Bing Crosby, won two of the last three holes from Brian Lindley, then sank a 15-foot putt for a birdie on an extra hole and captured the 81st United States Amateur golf championship today.

title: Chandler Is Given Court Probation
description: Jeff Chandler of Philadelphia, the World Boxing Association bantamweight champion, has been placed on s ix months' p robation, stemming from an arrest on charges for possession of small amounts of marijuana and cocaine.

title: Labor Takes to the Streets
description: This was supposed to be a very special Labor Day in New York. For the first time in 13 years, the Central Labor Council has called on local unions to celebrate with a parade, up Fifth Avenue. It's to be a celebration of the labor movement's 100th anniversary and a protest against the social policies of the Reagan Administration.

title: MORE PARENTS TURNING AWAY FROM PUBLIC SCHOOLS TO MEET CHILDREN'S NEEDS
description: ''We know we have to pay it and that's that,'' said Ellen Lieberman, a New York attorney, who returned to the city this summer from Orange County and has been frantically trying to place her children in a private school. ''For us, that's the cost of living in the city. But then, now we don't have to pay for the other car, the cost of heating and live-in help.''

title: LABOR SPEAKS IN MANY VOICES AS THE CITY MARKS LABOR DAY
description: They are the people who built New York, and they are the people who make the city go. They put up the houses and apartment houses and skyscraper office buildings. They went down into the bedrock and built the subway system. They laid the concrete and asphalt for the streets, built the docks, manned the ships. They built the huge parks, planted the trees. They climb the buildings to wash the windows. They print the books and newspapers. They sweep the streets. They serve the drinks, make the beds, shine the shoes. They bring in the food, by ship and truck and train, and serve it and clear the tables and wash the dishes. They treat the sick, bury the dead.

title: Bridge: Internal Solidity I s Help ful In Deciding Between Sui ts
description: A delicate bidding decision arises when two plausible trump suits are available and they are equivalent in terms of rank and length. In such circumstances, the declaring side should try for internal solidity, but should be willing to play without the trump ace.

title: United Offers Travel Pass
description: United Airlines is offerin g a sp ecial discount pass to travelers from four Southern cities in an attempt to''stimulate air travel from those cities.''

title: Andrea Leand Is Suddenly a Celebrity
description: THE world is moving fast for Andrea Leand. Only a few months ago she took a chance on missing an important ten nis match because she didn't want to give up a sports jamboree at h er high school in Baltimore.

title: Guards End Brief Strike At 2 Tennessee Prisons
description: A full shift of guards, faced with the threat of dis missal for a walkout over security, reported for work today at two prisons.

title: Red Smith Straight as a Stick
description: GENE MICHAEL asked for it, and George Steinbrenner gave it to him. George patterns himself after a model of almost equal distinction who said: ''Ask, and it shall be given you.''

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 7, 1981
description: International Solidarity must provide a program that will lead Poland out of its economic crisis, the leaders of the independent trade union said at its first anniversary convention. An official statement said, ''We have become convinced that we cannot stand idly by looking on at a breakdown of the national economy.'' (Page A1, Col. 3.) The Ulster hunger strike protest against Britain was weakened when the mother of a striker ordered medical treatment for him, following a similar case on Friday, and when the Irish National Liberation Army, a smaller but more hard-line guerrilla faction than the Irish Republican Army, announced that it was scaling down its involvement. (A1:4-5.)

title: Beaucrest Ruffian Westchester Best
description: A big shaggy dog, one of the year's top winners, Ch. Beaucrest Ruffian, today was named best of 2,904 dogs at the Westchester Kennel Club's 64th Fixture, which drew 12,000 enthusiasts to Lyndhurst.

title: BEGIN ARRIVES IN NEW YORK HOPING REAGAN MEETING WILL BE 'FRUITFUL'
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, accompanied by a larger entourage than he has had in any of his 11 previous trips to the United States, arrived in New York City yesterday afternoon for the beginning of a 10-day official visit that will include his first talks with President Reagan.

title: IRAN BURIES 2 MORE BOMB VICTIMS
description: Chanting ''Death to America!'' Iranians marched through the streets of Teheran today for the burial of Iran's assassinated Prosecutor General and national police chief.

title: One Way to Keep College Standards High
description: A problem faced by the City University and other schools - how to maintain scholarly work while bringing ill-prepared students up to standard - was discussed from a different angle by Dr. Rafi Israeli, of Jerusalem's Hebrew University, during a weekend visit to New York.

title: Boy Who Hit Wire In Critical Health
description: A 14-year-old boy remained in critical condition at the Nassau County Medical Center yesterday, three days after his throat was slashed by a wire deliberately strung across a bicycle trail.

title: BACK TO NUCLEAR BASICS
description: A new round of Soviet-American nuclear talks is about to start. As usual, there are arguments both within the U.S. Government and among allies as they warily try to prepare for bargaining on excruciatingly complex issues.

title: Washington Watch; Stock-Option Tax Confusion
description: WASHINGTON TAX legislation of any kind in recent years has quickly been dubbed a relief act for lawyers and accountants. This year's is no exception as banks and thrift institutions have found out already in marketing tax-free savings certificates.

title: U.S. JAPAN FACE TRADE FRICTIONS
description: The huge and mounting United States trade deficit with Japan, expected to hit a record $15 billion this year, is threatening to lead to a new round of trade frictions between the two nations.

title: KOCH AND ESPOSITO DEBATE MAYOR'S ROLE IN G.O.P.
description: Holding up a small American flag and a paper king's crown, Assemblyman John A. Esposito said yesterday that he was opposing Mayor Koch, a Democrat, in the Republican primary to save America's two-party political system and block the Mayor's ''coronation.''

title: No Headline
description: Willie Sanchez, a 34-year-old butcher who lives in the Bronx, brought his two sons to his reading lesson the other night. For almost an hour the boys, aged 11 and 8, watched and listened as their father read from a book designed for adults who are barely literate. ''I will give them anything, anything, if they stay in school,'' he told his tutor. ''If they don't, I will beat them.''

title: 2 Brooklyn Youths Held in Mugging
description: Two Brooklyn teen-agers have been arrested and charged with mugging a 77-year-old widow in her Queens apartment as they were selling candy, the Queens District Attorney's office said. District Attorney John J. Santucci said the group that supplied the boys with the candy, the Youth Opportunities Program, might be only a front.

title: American Women Beat China, Japan
description: The United States women's softball team beat the national teams of China and Japan today, the second day of the first three-nation softball championship at Tokyo's Korakuen Stadium.

title: Some Police Homework
description: A 32-year-old Chicago police trainee, Christine Speros, made her first arrest during the holiday weekend - in her own home.

title: YANKEE MANAGER ONCE AGAIN: ROBERT GRANVILLE LEMON
description: Bob Lemon decided on Friday at his home in Long Beach, Calif., that he needed a haircut. While he was sitting in his barber's chair, he listened to NBC's Joe Garagiola interview Gene Michael, the Yankee manager. The interview touched largely on the difficulties that Michael was having with George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees. ''The barber was listening, too,'' said Lemon. ''He told me after it was over, 'You might be going back to work sooner than you think.' Then George called me later and asked me to come to visit him in Tampa, Fla. When I got there, George asked me if I wanted to manage the Yankees again. I said 'yep.'

title: JETS ARE ROUTED
description: It wasn't supposed to be like this for the Jets, who discovered today that virtually nothing worked in the real season as it did in exhibition play. They were defeated by the Buffalo Bills -a 31-0 decision that marked the worst opening-day defeat in the Jets' 22 seasons. And each time the Bills scored, the crowd of more than 79,000 fans roared as if their team was taking a step closer to the Super Bowl.

title: Marshall McComb, Ex-Judge On California Supreme Court
description: Marshall McComb, who was forced to retire from the California Supreme Court four years ago, has died at 87.

title: VINEYARD RACE TO RUNNING TIDE
description: Running Tide, Al Van Metre's 61-foot black sloop from Alexandria, Va., won the 274-mile Martha's Vineyard race on corrected time today.

title: THE MYTHS SURROUNDING GLOBAL HUNGER
description: To the Editor:

title: THE TRAGEDY OF A MIDDLEWEIGHT LOSER
description: ''How does it happen? There are three types of fighters. The first is the world contender. Then you have the trial horses or club fighters. And then you have your losers.'' - Joe Phillips, professional boxer, discussing the suicide of his brother Roger, also a professional boxer. By MICHAEL KATZ ''ROCKY'' was a movie. The world of boxing that Roger Phillips knew, the world of $40 paydays and bus trips to small arenas and dressing rooms the size of closets, was very real. In his world, clubfighters did not wind up in championship bout s; they wound up lookingfor the easy way to the canvas. Phillips knew that his world was controlled by hustlers, not by the legally em powered but most often impotent state and local commissions whose bu dgets sometimes prevent them from making long-distance telephone call s.

title: STEIN SETS HIGH GOALS FOR THE FUTURE
description: Andrew J. Stein is running for re-election as Manhattan Borough President as if it were a life or death matter. He must win with an impressive margin, he says, not only for the position he has in hand but for a larger job he wants in the future.

title: REDS TURN BACK PHILLIES BY 5-4
description: Ray Knight hit a two-out, two-run double in the ninth inning today to break a tie and lead the Cincinnati Reds to a 5-4 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: Joan E. Winerman, Nurse, Married to Robert Walder
description: Joan Ellen Winerman, daughter of Mrs. Pearl Winerman of Eastchester, N.Y., and the late Alex Winerman, was married yesterday to Robert Alan Walder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Walder of Peekskill, N.Y. Rabbi Michael A. Robinson of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Colonial Terrace in Peekskill.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I feel like a father scorned. I feel like I have a son who has done something wrong and isn't mature enough to admit it.

title: LABOR CELEBRATES ITSELF ON 42D STREET
description: Some workers hammered a building into existence, others made fur coats and still others gave physical checkups under cloudy skies on 42d Street yesterday in what has become an annual effort to ''rekindle the spirit of Labor Day.''

title: ART DEALER WAS 75
description: Aime Maeght, a printer who became one of the Western world's most influential art dealers, died of cancer Saturday in his villa at St. Paul-de-Vence, France. He was 75 years old.

title: Strikers 3, Kicks 0
description: Branko Segota scored his eighth and ninth playoff goals early in the second half today to lead the Fort Lauderdale Strikers to their second straight 3-0 victory over the Minnesota Kicks and a sweep of their quarterfinal series.

title: HEROIN OUTPUT UP IN PAKISTANI AREA
description: Western diplomats and law enforcement agents in Pakistan say that some of this country's officials are refusing to crack down on illegal laboratories producing heroin.

title: 2 Hurricanes in the Atlantic Posing Little Threat to Land
description: Hurricane Floyd, gaining strength rapidly, turned away from the Bahamas today while another hurricane, Emily, was falling apart in the North Atlantic.

title: TOWN HALL SEEKS FUNDS
description: To celebrate its 60th anniversary, Town Hall will begin a threeyear campaign to raise $2 million. The money will be used largely for restoration purposes, though $500,000 will be put in a fund to underwrite musical programs of a noncommercial nature.

title: SOLIDARITY PLANS TO BROADEN ROLE IN POLISH SOCIETY
description: Solidarity leaders said today that the union must expand its role and come up with a concrete program to lead Poland out of its economic crisis.

title: Susan Beth Kreisel Wed Upstate to Jeffrey Klein
description: Susan Beth Kreisel, daughter of Lois Field Kreisel of North Salem, N.Y., and Edward Kreisel of Millbrook, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Alan Klein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Klein of Parsippany, N.J. Rabbi H. Leonard Poller of Larchmont, N.Y., performed the ceremony at Ladd Farm, the home of the bride's mother.

title: LABOR DAY
description: Today is Labor Day. Following are holiday schedules: Parade - Labor Day Parade will begin at 10 A.M. Route is north on Fifth Avenue, from 26th to 62d Street, then east on 62d Street to Third Avenue.

title: Purchasers Cite Mixed Prices
description: Selected metals, chemic als and paper products were higher in price in August, a ccording to a survey of 225 industrial company purchasing managers. However, the National Association of Purchasing Management's latest monthly survey indicated that aluminum , wheat, corn and fuel, including gasoline, generally declined in p rice.

title: Beating the Line
description: One of the great myths about New York is that it's big enough to be spontaneous. There's a subway at the corner. Broadway's dazzle is just a short ride away. Restaurants and street life abound. The opera doesn't come for a one-week stand; two of them live here. This is not Kansas City.

title: SHOCKING CHANGE
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD'S WOES AID MAKER OF BANKNOTES
description: Political unrest, inflation and toppling governments: These are good tidings for the International Banknote Company, a New York corporation with highly secretive operations that has made a name for itself as a printer of currency for third world nations.

title: Nofziger to Quit White House; Denies He Is Unhappy in Job
description: Lyn Nofziger, President Reagan's chief political adviser, said yesterday that he planned to leave the White House Jan. 22, but denied that it was because of unhappiness with his role in the Administration.

title: LAY FACULTY TO STRIKE 6 SCHOOLS
description: Members of the Lay Faculty Association voted yesterday to stay off their jobs when school starts today at six Roman Catholic high schools in Queens and Nassau and Suffolk Counties. But the lay teachers at two parochial high schools in Brooklyn voted to ratify a new contract settlement with the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn.

title: Bridge: Inexperience Leads Player To Overbid Strong Hands
description: A failing common among inexperienced players, pointed out long ago by Skid Simon, the great English authority, is that they overbid strong hands and underbid weak ones. South could not be accused of the latter crime on the diagramed deal, for he bid freely at the four-level with a 2-point hand and later jumped to slam.

title: RALLY UNLIKELY, EXPERTS SAY
description: Participants in the fixed-income market return today from their Labor Day holiday to face the grim prospect that bond yields - already brushing record highs - are likely to move higher still.

title: Chess: Open Ends in a 5-Way Tie; Trophy Goes to Gheorghiu
description: The 1981 United States Open Championship in Palo Alto, Calif., ended in a five-way tie for first place among Florin Gheorghiu, a Rumanian grandmaster; Larry Christiansen, an American grandmaster ; Nick DeFirmian, an international master, and Jeremy Silman and John Meyer, national masters.

title: BONN DEFENSE AIDE SEES THREAT IN '82 BUDGET
description: West Germany's Defense Minister, detailing plans to slow the growth of defense spending, expressed concern today that Bonn's proposed 1982 austerity budget could hurt West German arms development and jeopardize the military's ability to cover its fuel needs.

title: Toxic Shock: Transmitted?
description: California physicians who simultaneously treated a woman and her husband for toxic shock syndrome say the cases suggest this sometimes-fatal disease can be spread from one person to another, perhaps through kissing or sexual contact.

title: Sports People; Soetaert Impasse Seen
description: The Rangers said yesterday that they had not worked out a compensation deal with Pittsburgh that would allow the Penguins to sign Doug Soetaert, the free agent goaltender. ''I don't know what route we will take with Soetaert at this point,'' said Craig Patrick, the Rangers' general manager.

title: PUBLIC SCHOOLS OPEN IN CITY WITH AIR OF CONFIDENCE
description: Better Reading Scores Helping to Generate Mood of Optimism By GENE I. MAEROFF

title: DOLLAR UP IN TRADING ABROAD
description: The dollar rose on foreign exchanges today, while gold prices drifted lower. Trading was slack with United States markets closed for Labor Day.

title: TWO ACTORS' UNIONS EDGING TOWARD A MERGER
description: HOLLYWOOD MORE than 60,000 actors spent the summer of 1980 on strike. That interminable strike against the movie industry by the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists may have been the bitter medicine that will cure a 44-year-long separation between the two unions and lead to their merger.

title: Reagan and a Welder Meet Over Hat Again
description: Last October when Basil Powell, a 50-year-old welder, handed Ronald Reagan a red hard hat at a campaign stop in midtown Manhattan, he could hardly have imagined that the White House someday would be calling upon him to stand along side Mr. Reagan as President. But yesterday Mr. Powell and Mr. Reagan met again, their hands clasping the edges of a giant symbolic check for $85 million to begin construction of the Westway highway project.

title: Sports of The Times; An 'Ideal' Manager For the Yankees
description: ON his return to the manager's office in the Yankees' clubhouse at Yankee Stadium yesterday, Bob Lemon was sitting at his desk, sipping hot tea and answering questions. The occupant of the office changes often. But except for the pin-stripe uniform with ''21'' on it on a hanger, the office looked the same as it had when Gene Michael was working there, and Dick Howser before that, and Billy Martin before that, and Bob Lemon before that. Some soft brown Naugahyde furniture, a few baseball books on a shelf behind the desk, a few pictures on the walls.

title: Eastern Skipper Wins
description: Herve Filion drove Eastern Skipper to an easy victory in the $118,469 James B. Dancer Memorial Pace for 3-year-olds today at Freehold Raceway.

title: AMB. KIRKPATRICK'S POSITION ON CHILE
description: To the Editor:

title: Trenton Girl, 2, Killed in Fire
description: TRENTON (UPI) - A 2-year-old girl was killed when a fire engulfed the bedroom where she was sleeping, fire officials said. The girl's father was seriously burned trying to rescue her, but three other members of the family escaped unharmed.

title: NO INFIGHTING, PLEASE
description: Senator William Armstrong of Colorado, a Republican, has an appealing idea that probably won't work - to turn Social Security legislation over to a special bipartisan Congressional group. But the proposal does dramatize the need for such legislation to go forward without the usual partisan infighting.

title: Butt of Inside Joke: Secretary of Interior
description: Interior Secretary James M. Watt, who has o ften been criticized by environmentalists for his advocacy of offshor e oil leases, strip mining and the exploitation of natural resour ces in national parks, bore the brunt of a quip by President Reagan yesterday at Gracie Mansion.

title: FOR BRAZIL DEMOCRACY IS CLOUDED
description: An outbreak of urban violence and a key change in the Government's top leadership have set the stage for a more contentious period in Brazil's contemplated passage from military rule to democracy.

title: LET' EM EAT JELLYBEANS
description: President Reagan's visit to New York yesterday seems an appropriate occasion to ask what benefit the city has enjoyed from our Democratic Mayor's cordial relationship with the Republican head of state.

title: SCIENTISTS STUDY GROWTH OF DOME
description: Earthquake activity at Mount St. Helens subsided today and the United States Geological Survey declared the latest eruption over.

title: Police Officer Shot Pursuing Brooklyn Burglary Suspects
description: A police officer was shot in the face and shoulder while chasing suspects in a burglary in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn yesterday.

title: Ex-Miss Texas U.S.A.  Dies in Scuba Accident
description: A 25-year-old former Miss Texas U.S.A. was scuba diving off the coast of Mexico when she saw something that frightened her into going to the surface so quickly that her lungs burst, a friend said.

title: Vincent Catoggio Dies; Former U.S. Magistrate
description: Vincent A. Catoggio, a former United States magistrate in the Eastern District of New York and a former assis tant District Attorneyof New York County, died Sunday at the Queens Hospital Center in Jamaica. He was 76 years old and lived in Jam aica Estates, Queens.

title: Market Holiday
description: Stock and commodity exchanges in the United States and Canada were closed yesterday in observance of Labor Day. Markets in Europe and Japan were open as usual.

title: Murray Is Reinstated For Council Primary
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court has reinstated Peter J. Murray as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the New York City Council. He is running in the First Council District on Staten Island in Thursday's primary election.

title: News Analysis
description: The 100,000 marchers in the Labor Day celebration on Fifth Avenue yesterday possessed the energy and solidarity that a lot of people, including many labor leaders, believed had evaporated from the nation's working class.

title: City Sets Up Hot Line For Facts About Polls
description: New York City voters in doubt about where to cast ballots in the primary elections Thursday can find out by calling 267-9800, according to Betty Dolen, executive director of the Board of Elections.

title: SINCE THE NEED FOR MX MAY BE GROUNDLESS
description: To the Editor:

title: AFGHAN TROOPS SAID TO CROSS INTO PAKISTAN AND SEIZE ARMS
description: Afghan troops crossed into Pakistan today and confiscated weapons in a house-to-house search at a border village in the southwestern province of Baluchistan, a Palistani Defense Ministry statement said.

title: Neighbor Shoots Host At Party, Guest, Himself
description: A man in this Philadelphia suburb broke up his neighbor's late party with gunfire early today, killing two persons and critically injuring two before shooting himself to death, the police said.

title: Long-Lived Pesticides
description: Many soil scientists have long held the theory that when most pesticides fall to earth they degrade relatively quickly in the soil into their harmless basic components. But research by scientists at Pennsylvania State University indicates that some widely used pesticides act quite differently and do not readily disintegrate in the soil.

title: LABOR HISTORY SLIGHTED, EXPERTS SAY
description: As the nation marked Labor Day and the labor movement observed what it calls the centennial of American labor, experts were saying that American labor history has been highly neglected in schools, that labor's historic sites are often not marked or maintained and that labor history has often been accorded second-class status.

title: BEGIN HAS LUNCH WITH VANCE
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel spent a quiet day in his suite at the Waldorf Towers yesterday, preparing for his first meeting with President Reagan tomorrow in Washington.

title: 8 Air Controllers at Amarillo Rebuffed in Offer to Return
description: Eight striking air traffic controllers at Amarillo International Airport announced today that they were giving up the strike.

title: PASSAIC RIVER'S 2 FACES: ONE DIRTY, ONE SENIC
description: ''It is a sea of unpleasant odors,'' said Frank Sudol, a canoeing enthusiast, recalling a trip he took down the Passaic River two years ago. But he added: ''It is also one of the more beautiful rivers in the New York metropolitan area.''

title: 15 Hurt in One-Car Accident
description: Fifteen people jammed into a passenger car were injured, one of them severely, when the vehicle overturned on Interstate 80 about six miles east of Fernley. The authorities said all were Vietnamese who spoke no English. The driver, Mut Van Bo, was cited for reckless driving.

title: A-Plant Restarted In Connecticut
description: The Millstone I nuclear power plant was restarted yesterday after being shut down for repairs over the weekend, a spokesman for Northeast Utilities said.

Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials A22

title: Dave Beck on Hoffa's Disappearance
description: For his Labor Day message, Dave Beck, a former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, talked yesterday about the case of one of his successors in that post, James R. Hoffa.

title: JACKSON STIRS DISPUTE
description: Bob Lemon, returning to Yankee Stadium on the second day of his second reign as manager of the Yankees, made a simple request. ''At least let me have two days without controversy,'' he said yesterday after the Yankees defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 4-2.

title: Tara Smith Wed To a Physician
description: Tara Kathleen Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Owen Smith of Heyworth, Ill., was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Dr. Theodore Tyberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Yehuda Tyberg of New York. Rabbi David Posner of Temple Emanu-El performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. James Freda.

title: AGGRESSIVE MOVE BY CORNI NG
description: When the Corning Glass Works announced last week that its 23.9 percent stake in the Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation was up for sale, the move was something of a surprise.

title: ON THE SAME TRACK
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, says he hopes his group will follow the lead of the International Amateur Athletic Federation and adopt reforms on the issue of amateur status. ''Our roads are very similar,'' Samaranch said in Rome, ''and I hope our decisions will be the same.''

title: 5TH AVE. MILE SET FOR SEPT. 26
description: The new president of track and field's world governing body today approved a mile race down New York's Fifth Avenue.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As any worker knows, a job is the best social program there is.'' -President Reagan. (A1:6.)

title: Football Anyone?
description: In Britain, sports enthusiasts prefer soccer and rugby. But that has not deterred the Queen's Rangers of the English Soccer League who want to stage an exhibition game between two National Football League teams.

title: Carnegie Hall Season To Open With Schub
description: Andre-Michel Schub, winner of this year's Van Cliburn piano competition, will perform as soloist with the American Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall on Oct. 4

title: Rijsbergen Returning
description: Wim Rijsbergen, who played a key role in the Cosmos' drive to the North American Soccer League championship last season, will be available for tomorrow night's third and deciding quarterfinal round match against the Tampa Bay Rowdies at Giants Stadium. Rijsbergen, a defender from the Netherlands, missed the first two games with a bruised left knee.

title: CHARGERS TROUNCE BROWNS
description: San Diego unveiled its 1981 team against the Cleveland Browns tonight and, as some had suspected, the Chargers had a new style and a new thrust.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1981
description: International State supervision of Egypt's mosques is to be imposed as part of President Anwar el-Sadat's effort to halt sectarian strife. The gradual takeover affects 40,000 mosques. A total of 1,536 persons have been arrested and accused of inciting violence, directly or indirectly, between the Moslem majority and the Coptic Christian minority. (Page A1, Column 1.) An aid for Saudi bombing capability is being studied by a Reagan Administrationn panel. The issue, involving whether Washington should sell advanced bomb racks for Saudi Arabia's F-15 jet fighters, is not expected to be decided until late this year or early next year, according to officials. Approval of the proposed sale is regarded as unlikely. (A8:1.)

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ISRAELI COMEDY IN TOWN

title: Giants' Perkins Retains His Optimism
description: Coach Ray Perkins of the Giants said today what he had been saying since training camp began:

title: A NETWORK OF LAWYERS
description: Harvey Sharinn is starting to go national. Mr. Sharinn, 42, and his partner Ron Lipshie, 47, in the Baldwin, L.I. law firm of Sharinn & Lipshie, specialists in collection activities for retailers and manufacturers, are trying to create a network of lawyers who do similar work, and they have just signed up their first out-of-state associate in Oakland, Calif.

title: HOWARD FREEMAN
description: Howard Freeman, a public relations executive and a major general in the National Guard, died of cancer at his home here yesterday.

title: REAGAN, IN NEWARK, BACKS KEAN AND SAYS HE'LL ENJOY GOVERNORSHIP
description: President Reagan brought a formal endorsement and a prediction of victory today to Thomas H. Kean, the R epublican candidate for Governor of New Jersey.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: E VERYONE had something to say last week. There was John Waters, the director of ''Polyester,'' whose new book, ''Shock Value,'' has just been published, saying that the best way to understand anyone is to look at his shoes. Diane Von Furstenberg was saying she's taking control. Helen Galland, the president of Bonwit Teller, had an announcement.

title: RIVAL DUTCH PARTIES PAINFULLY FORGE NEW COALITION
description: The formation of a Dutch government is a marriage ceremony by ordeal. So long, irritable and painful are the negotiations among the various parties trying to put together a coalition that, paradoxically, once formed the governments tend to last.

title: 29 Arrested in Protest At Nuclear Waste Site
description: Twenty-nine persons, including eight reporters and photographers, were arrested today during a peaceful demonstration at the site of a proposed nuclear waste plant.

title: MANSON OUSTS CLERC
description: The action was in the grandstand at the United States Open tennis championships yesterday as Vitas Gerulaitis stopped Ivan Lendl in five sets and Bruce Manson upset Jose-Luis Clerc, 6-3, 7-6, 6-3.

title: CONVICTS END TAKEOVER OF A POLISH PRISON AFTER 2 DAYS
description: In the latest of a series of prison uprisings throughout the country, 150 inmates barricaded themselves inside the main detention center here for two days, holding out over a list of grievances that ranged from poor shoes to torture.

title: ECONOMIC GAINS TIED TO ENDING OIL PRICE CURBS
description: Since the Reagan Administration removed controls on crude oil prices more than seven months ago, Americans have substantially curbed their demand for petroleum, oil imports have fallen by a fifth and evidence is mounting that decontrol may help stem the long decline in United States oil production.

title: SUMMING WINS PEGA SUS BY 2 1 2 LENGTHS AT THE MEADOWLANDS
description: Summing sat most of the race in fourth place behind Proud Appeal, Academy H. and Maudlin, accelerated past the tiring leaders at the top of the stretch and held off the late charge of Johnny Dance to win the $222,700 Pegasus Handicap by 2 1/2 lengths today in the opening of the thoroughbred meeting at the Meadowlands.

title: Rokeby Rose, Fell's 4th Winner, Takes Handicap
description: Rokeby Rose, the second choice, outran De la Rose, whom some call the best female turf horse in the country, to win the $112,000 Flower Bowl Handicap by 1 3/4 lengths yesterday at Belmont Park. The winner paid $7.80 for $2 to win after running the mile and a quarter in 2:01 3/5.

title: United Press International
description: 1 KILLED IN MANCHESTER BLAST: A fireman at the scene of an explosion yesterday in a solvent recovery plant near Manchester, England. One man was killed and more than 1,000 people were evacuated from the resulting fire, which took six hours to extinguish. Some chemical drums were hurled about 100 yards.

title: Sailor on Kitty Hawk Killed as Planes Collide
description: Two figh ter jets collided on theflight deck of the aircraft carrier Kitty Haw k, killing a sailor and knocking an F-14 overboard, a Navy spokesman said today.

title: The Westway Price Tag Still Subject to Change
description: Even though President Reagan yesterday gave the city and state of New York an oversized, symbolic $85 million check to purchase land on which the Westway will be built, the actual price tag of this socalled right of way is still under discussion.

title: Czechoslovak Visits Libya
description: President Gustav Husak of Czechoslovakia arrived in Libya tonight for a three-day official visit. He will also visit Ethiopia and Southern Yemen.

title: ACCOUNTS
description: * The Coty Division of Pfizer to Warwick, Welsh & Miller for its new fragrance for men. * Tuscan Dairies of Union, N.J., to Shapiro/Budrow & Associates.

title: St. Bart's 'Doll's House' Will Play Sept. 17-26
description: The St. Bart's Players will open their 1981-82 season with ''A Doll's House.''

title: TEST OF NEW FEDERALISM PLAN CHANGING KENTUCKY'S POLITICS
description: This cozy state capital in the limestone hills of Kentucky is providing an early indication of the kind of change that may take place in government and politics when Federal authority is returned to the states under the new federalism policies of President Reagan.

title: BENCH'S 2 HOMERS HELP SEAVER WIN 11TH
description: Johnny Bench homered twice, tying Joe DiMaggio for 27th place on baseball's career home run list, and Tom Seaver posted his 11th victory and fourth straight tonight as the Cincinnati Reds posted an 8-7 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: INTRODUCING THE NEW CONTINENTAL
description: ''I T'S somewhat surreal,'' said Young & Rubicam's Manuel Perez. ''It's sort of Hitchcockian. It's the kind of romance and elegance you'd find in a Jean Cocteau film.'' The complex confection that Mr. Perez, senior vice president in charge of television production, was analyzing was Y & R's upcoming commercial for Lincoln-Mercury's lighter, shorter 1982 Continental, which is billed as totally new.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an error by Kennedy Center, an article in Arts and Leisure on Sunday incorrectly identified the conductor of a performance of Leon- ard Bernstein's ''Mass'' scheduled there next Saturday. The performance will be conducted by John Mauceri.

title: Freud and His Mother TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: There is a curious and, I believe, significant omission in your article ''Scholars Seek the Hidden Freud in Newly Emerging Letters'' (Aug. 18). In the many columns of type and in the spaces allotted to photographs, there is not a single mention of Freud's mother.

title: ON A MOUNTAIN IN NEVADA ARCHEOLOGIST FINDS ANCIENT SUMMER REFUGE
description: SOME 6,000 years ago, aboriginal Americans found their way to the great meadow on Nevada's 11,949-foot Mount Jefferson, hunters from the parched lowlands in pursuit of game. They establishe d a permanentcamp, with pi t houses and hunting blinds of stone, to which they and their descend ants returned many a summer over the centuries.

title: POLISH UNION TO OPEN PUBLICITY OFFICE IN NEW YORK
description: A representative of Solidarity, Poland's in dependent trade union movement, marched in the Labor Day parade in New York yesterday and said that in two weeks he would open in New York the first foreign office of Solidarity.

title: FOUR ESCAPEES ELUDE SEARCH AFTER KANSAS OFFICER IS SHOT
description: Four heavily armed convicts were still at large tonight after seven inmates stole a guard's uniform yesterday and faked their way into a prison tower before escaping.

title: New Orleans's Water Supply Is Protected From Spilled Oil
description: It could be 12 days before water supplies here are free of the danger of conta mination by 840,000 gallons of oil spilled by a Greek tanker, the authorities said today.

title: SOVIET BARS KISSINGER'S BOOK AT FAIR
description: Soviet censors barred Henry A. Kissinger's White House memoirs from the Moscow International Book Fair, the book's American publisher said today.

title: FOR THE BOLIVIAN PEASANT, POLITICS ARE REMOTE
description: For Victoria Suxo, governments come and go but life never changes. In flounced skirt, shawl and bowler hat, she sits every weekend outside the shrine here selling candles to pilgrims who trek to this small, muddy town on the Peruvian border to pray to the Virgin of Copacabana.

title: SOVIET WARNING ON NEUTRON ARMS
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, declared today that his country would have a ''proper counterbalance'' to any new weapon in the Western arsenal.

title: 100,000 MARCH UP FIFTH AVENUE TO CELEBRATE CENTENNIAL OF LABOR
description: More than 100,000 union members, from striking air traffic controllers to high-kicking Rockettes and brawny ironworkers, marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday in this city's first Labor Day Parade in 13 years. Wearing blu e collars and white collars and, in the case of the Rockettes, no collars at all, the marchers staged an enthusiastic celebration o f the labor movement's 100th anniversary and expressed their determi nation to carry on through what they said were hard times.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Michael's Children Got News at Game
description: When Nancy Howser arrived at Royals' Stadium on Sunday, Sandy and Mark Michael were standing by the curb, waiting to pick up their tickets to the afternoon's Yankee game and eager to see their father manage his team to its eighth victory in 11 days.

title: SPORTS DEPARTMENT; Relief Managers
description: You may think there's something new about the split season that major league baseball has seized on to revive interest after the strike. Not at all.

title: SHORT LIST OF NEW ISSUES
description: Underwriters plan to offer a fairly limited supply of new corporate and municipal securities in this holiday-shortened week. Among offerings on the corporate calendar are $100 million of 10-year notes and $50 million of 20-year debentures for the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation.

title: PSYCHOLOGISTS TRAIN MINDS OF ATHLETES TO EXCEL
description: TODAY'S athletes are bigger, stronger and faster than ever, and they are probably better trained, too. So as more athletes reach the upper plateaus of their sports, the difference between winning and losing often seems to depend on emotional, rather than physical factors.

title: NEW DIMENSIONS FOR AN ANTIQUE CLOTHING BOUTIQUE
description: Cherchez, in just six years, has become the definitive source of antique clothing and potpourris for many East Side shoppers and collectors. The wares kept expanding until it seemed the walls of the narrow shop would burst. And, in a sense, they have. Cherchez recently expanded into the premises next door that were occupied for more than 30 years by the Murray Hill Meat Market.

title: 120,000 Ugandans Flee to Zaire
description: About 120,000 people have fled to Zaire because of fighting between guerrillas and Uganda Government troops in which at least 1,000 civilians have been killed, according to relief officials.

title: News Analysis
description: The bonds of compromise, opportunism and West German prosperity that have held the governing coalition of Social Democrats and Free Democrats together for more than 11 years are pulling apart.

title: PIRATES TAKE PAIR FROM METS
description: Remember Willie Montanez? The Mets and seven other former employers remember him for a lot of reasons: the onehanded swiping catch, the slow walk to first base on a walk, the turkey trot around the bases on a home run.

title: ALERT IN EFFECT AS HURRICANE NEARS BERMUDA
description: Hurricane Floyd, with winds up to 80 miles per hour, today pushed toward Bermuda, where more than 55,000 residents and tourists were put under an emergency alert.

title: The Tainted Ballot in El Salvador
description: Political solution: that is everyone's answer to the merciless civil war that has claimed as many as 20,000 lives in El Salvador. Even the Reagan Administration has muted its January call to arms and now talks about a political settlement of a conflict that it correctly describes as ''Salvadoran in nature.'' Then why is it so annoyed with France and Mexico for opening a new path to that very end?

title: CUBAN REFUGEE UNIT CLOSING IN MIAMI AFTER TWO DECADES
description: The 20-year-old Cuban Refugee Center will close at the end of this month, the victim of Reagan Administration budget cuts and a new Federal policy on refugees.

title: Asia Society's Washington Center Gets New Chief
description: The Asia Society has chosen a former diplomat and ''old Asia hand,'' William H. Gleysteen Jr., as director of its Washington center.

title: Reagan Denies Staff Differs On Cutbacks In Military Spending
description: President Reagan denied today that there was any bickering between his top advisers over military spending cuts, saying the aides were voicing their viewpoints but would all go along with his decision. On returning from a Labor Day trip to New Y ork, Mr. Reagan was asked about the reports of a tug of war betwe en Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and the budget director, David A. Stockman, over the need to slash Pentagon outlays to ac hieve a balanced budget in the fiscal year 1984.

title: A MIME IN THE BUSTER KEATON MOLD
description: A MAN in baggy pants and shirt and an exhausted felt hat shuffles through a softshoe number, unaware of the world around him. Drawn to his left as if by force of gravity, he struggles to center stage and starts again. And again. But the drift to the left is irresistible and finally he succumbs -limbs floundering and body flattened - gulped offstage by what might be some malevolent cosmic vacuum cleaner or vaudeville hook. The lights, piano and rehearsal litter are suddenly unnoticeable. The bumbling innocent at the heart of all men has met his inevitable fate.

title: NATO Says Soviet Withholds Details on Baltic Maneuvers
description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization said today that the Soviet Union violated the 1975 Helsinki accords by not telling the alliance how many troops are on maneuvers near Poland.

title: MORE FINDS FROM CHINA SITE
description: Chinese archeologists continue to make stunning discoveries in the ongoing excavation of the tomb of China's first Emperor, Qin Shi Huang Ti, which is proving to be an excavation of surpassing importance. Seventeen satellite tombs containing the remains of princes, princesses and ministers of the Emperor's court have been found east of the tomb where Emperor Qin was buried in 221 B.C.

title: L.I. Boy, 4, Shot in Accident
description: A 4-year-old Hempstead boy was accidently hit by an air-gun pellet today at the home of a neighbor.

title: A FARSIGHTED MAN OF FASHION STEPS DOWN
description: Robert Riley was packing up. The big, brownish portrait of Mme. Lanvin still hung over his desk and his bulletin board was still covered with a few dogeared pages of Vogue from the days when it used to illustrate the latest creations of Lelong and Schiaparelli, but the rest of his office had that closing-night look that said the show was over or, at least, moving on.

title: WHAT WILL MITTERRAND DO TO THE FRENCH SCHOOL SYSTEM?
description: PARIS IN his 1968 study of postwar France ''The New French Revolution,'' John Ardagh quotes a country priest as saying: ''The only people still interested in the public school debate are little pressure groups made up of the anticlerical teachers and old-guard priests. But the general public couldn't care less.''

title: Sports Department; Stadium Stand-Ins
description: Little boys have always gone to baseball games with gloves and caps, sure that these will enable them to catch balls hit into the stands. Now the practice has spread, apparently in reverse.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: AT the start of a new academic year, the public schools continue to face fewer pupils and fewer dollars, and a carping public. Criticism of the schools is rampant. ''Is there any hope for the public schools?'' has become a standard question. The answer, to judge from emerging trends, is a qualified yes. The schools are doing better but they are getting less support today because of yesterday's poor performance.

title: LAYTON DEFENSE SET TO BEGIN IN CULT MURDER TRIAL
description: Larry Layton, a onetime top aide to the Rev. Jim Jones and a survivor of the murders and suicides of more than 900 members of Mr. Jones's People's Temple cult in a Guyana jungle, is to open his defense tomorrow to a charge that he conspired to murder Representative Leo J. Ryan, Democrat of California.

title: Titles Seen Cheapened by Politicking
description: If Sugar Ray Leonard loses the welterweight championship Sept. 16, at least it would be in the ring to Thomas Hearns. In contrast, Tadashi Mihara, whose No. 1 ranking was called embarrassing by a World Boxing Association official, may not have to fight Leonard to get the junior-middleweight title. In boxing, championships are also won and lost in backrooms, and control of this highly international sport lies with two rival, but similar sanctioning bodies that decide how many titles there should be (the more the merrier) and who should fight for them.

title: ALBANY MUSIC DAY ON SEPT. 19
description: Musicians from Woody Herman and George Shearing to the rock group Blotto will perfor m on Sept. 19 at the Empire State Plaza here in the second Harvest of Music Festival, state officials have announced.

title: JAPANESE START TO SPEAK OUT ON TOUCHY ISSUES
description: Naohiro Amaya is a new force in Japan, someone who speaks his mind. ''Japan is seriously concerned with the United States policy which gives undue priority to Israel,'' according to Mr. Amaya. ''Such a policy could easily bring down the hostility of the Arab world upon the free world'' and cause ''the collapse of the entire free world economy,'' he said at a conference here.

title: SPECTOR OF '80 LOOMS OVER JETS
description: All winter the Jets, knowing they had the third choice in the draft, coveted Freeman McNeil, the running back from U.C.L.A.

title: GENE THERAPY: SCIENTISTS TAKE FIRST STEPS TOWARD CURING THE 'INCURABLE' DISORDERS
description: GENETIC diseases are among the most tragic human afflictions, particularly so since the discoveries of modern science have made it clear that a single seemingly minor chemical change in a gene can produce pain, deformity and death.

title: WELFARE ROLES TO SHRINK BY 11% NEXT MONTH
description: The rolls of the nation's most expensive welfare program are to shrink by 11 percent next month when budget-cutting eligibility changes sought by the Reagan Administration take effect.

title: Effects of Beauty TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: I wish the article ''Effects of Beauty Found to Run Surprisingly Deep'' (Sept. 1) had gone on a bit further to tell the fuller story. One of the effects of attractiveness which is not mentioned but should, I think, be touched upon is that being attractive is not the bed of roses that the article implies.

title: Another Ulster Inmate Joins Hunger Strike
description: A 25-year-old convicted killer joined the Irish nationalist fast in Maze Prison today.

title: RELIGIOUS LEADERS OBJECTING TO NUCLEAR ARMS
description: In this hub of beef cattle and nuclear weapons production, Bishop Leroy T. Matthiesen of the Roman Catholic diocese here, has begun an unpopular, one-man campaign against the neutron bomb. It is a cause being espoused by an increasing number of American churchmen alarmed by the arms race.

title: ALBERTANS AWAIT NEW OIL BOOM
description: While the rest of Canada worries about economic growth and jobs, Alberta officials are concerned about an overheated economy as a result of the energy agreement signed with the f ederal Government last Wednesday. From Premie r Peter Lougheed of Alberta to Mayor Ralph Klein of Calgary, the talk is exclusively of a resumption of the boom that hasmade this oil - and gas-rich province the fastest-growing area in the country.

title: GEORGE SHEARING QUINTET LIVES AGAIN, AT CARNEGIE
description: FOR nearly 30 years, the George Shearing Quintet was one of the most famous and successful groups in jazz. The sound of Mr. Shearing's piano with vibraphone and guitar, combined with Mr. Shearing's solos in the ''locked hands'' technique, in which he played identical chords with left and right hands, and his virtuosity as an unlocked soloist quickly developed a devoted following for the group that supported it year after year.

title: TRANSCRIPTS OF SPEECHES BY K OCH AND REAGAN ON THE WESTWAY PROJECT HERE
description: Following is a transcript of the addresses of Mayor Koch and President Reagan at Gracie Mansion yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times. Mayor Koch

title: U.S. FARES SLASHED BY LAGGING PAN AM
description: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it would cut fares sharply on all its domestic flights. Industry analysts said t hecuts were aimed at improving Pan Am's flaggin g domestic financial performance.

title: New Kidney Treatment
description: The National Institutes of Health has set up a patient registry to evaluate the benefits and complications of a new method of treating chronic kidney failure called continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis. Since it was developed three years ago, it has been used by a small but growing number of patients whose kidneys no longer function and who otherwise would need treatment with an artificial kidney or a kidney transplant.

title: Gas Tank Explodes in Flames At an Oklahoma Oil Refinery
description: A gasoline tank exploded in flames that raged out of control for more than an hour late last night and burned two men, one critically. A 55,000-gallon gasoline tank exploded and burned at the Sun Oil Company refinery, injuring William Knowles, 32 year old, and Randy Robinson, 31, both of Tulsa.

title: Fewer 'Boat People' Afloat
description: The number of Vietnamese ''boat people'' arriving in East and Southeast Asian countries in August was the lowest in 11 months, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees reported today.

title: Market Place; Rising Stocks: 3 Key Factors
description: A NEW study suggests that the stock market is about as hip as a Shirley Temple movie. The study, conducted by a Cambridge, Mass., consulting firm, examined shareholder attitudes toward major corporations and found that investors clearly preferred companies with rapid profit growth relative to the investment in the business.

title: Mitterrand's Saudi Visit Set
description: President Francois Mitterrand will visit Saudi Arabia September 26-28, a presidential spokesman said today. The spokesman said last month the visit would take place at the end of September but the dates had not been set.

title: NEW CHIEF AT ATKINS
description: Ferd O. Lawson Jr., 55, has been elected president and chief executive officer of Frederick Atkins Inc., a major New York retail buying office, effective Oct. 1. He will succeed Charles W. Veysey, 65, who will become vice chairman until his retirement at the end of next year.

title: Educators in Suburbs Facing Battles with Shortages of Funds
description: The suburban school systems, long regarded as the bastion of good schools and innovative programs, are reopening in the New York metropolitan area in the grip of a financial squeeze that is forcing rapid changes in how they operate and what they offer.

title: BOSTON TEACHERS POSTPONE STRIKE
description: The teachers' union voted tonight to strike the city's 119 schools in two weeks unless its leadership can work out a new agreement with school officials.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard GOLDEN GIRL. By Juan Marse. Trans- lated from the Spanish by Helen R. Lane. 195 pages. Farrar Straus Giroux. $10.95.

title: VICTIMS OF CRIME GET LEGAL AID AND HELPING HAND
description: The elderly woman, her cane resting at her side as she leaned forward in her chair, recalled what she had found when she returned to her Brooklyn apartment after a short shopping trip. ''My apartment was ransacked,'' she said. ''The drawers were pulled out.''

title: CORRECTION
description: In th e Goin g Out Guide on Saturday, the date for the ''Oriental World of Self Defense,'' a martial arts event at Madison Square Garden, was g iven incorrectly. The event will be on Sept. 13.

title: DEARBORN CAMPAIGN LOOKS BACK TO HUBBARD ERA
description: ''I like Maureen,'' a white-haired man paused along Michigan Avenue to say. ''I think you can tell she learned her lessons from Mayor Hubbard.''

title: TRAFFIC IN CANT
description: The most persistent and resourceful of all singleissue g roups - the gun lobby - is at it again, mounting an unusually bit ter attack on the Department of the Treasury's Bureau ofAlcohol Tobac co and Firearms.

title: KEEP NUCLEAR ARMS FROM GOING INTO ORBIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesian Volcano Erupts
description: Mount Rokatenda, a volcano on Palu Island in eastern Indonesia, has erupted for the second time this year, but no casualties were reported, the Meteorological Institute said today. Rokatenda blasted lava and burning rocks into the air repeatedly on Aug. 22, the institute said.

title: Nets Fill Post
description: Mike DiTomasso, a former National Basketball Association referee, and once the attorney for the referees in their contract negotiations with the league, will embark on a new career on Oct. 1 with the Nets. DiTomasso will become a fulltime employee and represent the Nets in player contract negotiations.

title: TV: 'PEOPLE'S COURT,' 'REALITY' IN THE MORNING
description: COURTROOM drama has long been a television staple, from the early days of the ''night court'' re-creations specializing in divorce and disturbing-the-peace cases to the successes of ''Perry Mason'' and his imitators. Now, trying to cash in on the medium's new ''reality'' trends, along comes ''People's Court,'' a weekday series that had its debut on WABC-TV yesterday morning at 10:30. As in much of the new reality scene, including such things as ''Real People'' and ''That's Incredible!,'' the line between hard fact and pure entertainment becomes exceedingly fuzzy, if not invisible.

title: Graphic Scanning's Quiet Rise
description: Its business is communications, but the Graphic Scanning Corporation does not communicate very much. It does not issue annual reports to its shareholders. It rarely talks to the press or cooperates with analysts.

title: Ouster Brings Mixed Reviews
description: Fan reaction at Yankee Stadium yesterday to the dismissal of Gene Michael by George Steinbrenner indicated that many followers of the Yankees were confused by the action. But a random sampling revealed that some fans, although they considered Steinbrenner a difficult man to work for, think he has a successful record with the Yankees since taking over the team in 1973 and is entitled to make any moves he considers necessary.

title: Ford Grants of $773,000 To Aid Desegregation
description: The Ford Foundation said today it would award $773,000 to help speed desegregation of higher education systems in states that have negotiated with the Federal government to end dual systems.

title: Bonnett, in a Ford, Wins Southern 500
description: Neil Bonnett held off a late bid by Darrell Waltrip and won the Southern 500 Grand National stock car race today.

title: THE U.N. TODAY
description: Sept. 8, 1981 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets on Nambibia at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Stamp to Honor Chief Crazy Horse and a Sculptor
description: A 73-year-old sculptor who has spent almost half his life blasting into a mountain to create a monument to Chief Crazy Horse has become the first living American to be honored with a postage stamp.

title: DO SUPPLY SIDERS KNOW WHAT THEORY DEMANDS?
description: To the Editor:

title: QUEENS PROSECUTOR RACE FOCUSES ON CONVICTIONS
description: When District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens walks to and from his office in the Criminal Courts Building in Kew Gardens, he walks beneath the watchful eyes of Irving Schwartz.

title: Training Missile Lost in 1980 Is Recovered by Navy Vessel
description: A missile that plunged from a jet bomber into the ocean off Maine last year has been recovered and brought ashore, a Navy spokesman confirmed today.

title: CRIPPLED, HE WROTE WITH TOE
description: Christy Brown, the crippled Irish author who wrote by typing with the little toe of his left foot, choked to death Sunday while having dinner at home in Parbrook, a village in Somerset, in western England. He was 49 years old.

title: Talking Business with Emery of Emery Air Freight; Balancing Act For Air Cargo
description: The air cargo industry is currently trying to balance a pattern of expansion, on one hand, against an air traffic controllers' strike, a weakening national economy and a changing regulatory atmosphere, on the other. Emery Air Freight is the largest of the major airforwarding companies, as well as a major factor in the international air cargo field. Revenues in 1980 came to $533 million, while net income was $21.6 million.

title: SMUGGLERS' PLANES DODGE ALONG BUSY AIRLINES
description: Smugglers carrying drugs and illegal aliens are dodging the authorities in airplanes, mostly old, that fly without lights, skim low over the ocean and ''hide'' behind commercial aircraft, according to aviation officials.

title: REAGAN VISITS CITY TO PRESENT CHECK FOR THE WESTWAY PROJECT
description: In a ceremony embroidered with economic significance and political nuance, President Reagan went to Gracie Mansion yesterday to present a stage-prop check symbolizing his Administration's commitment to the Westway project on Manhattan's West Side.

title: U.S. WINS, 6-2, GAINS CANADA CUP SEMIFINALS
description: The United States rallied from a two-goal deficit by scoring six consecutive goals to beat Czechoslovakia, 6-2, tonight at the Forum and clinch a berth among the final four of the Canada Cup hockey tournament.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: 25,000 UNABLE TO HOOK $1 MILLION
description: This time the one that got away really was a big one. A salmon that would have been worth $1 million to the one who could hook it eluded 25,000 intent anglers yesterday in Puget Sound between Seattle and Tacoma.

title: JUAN ENRIQUE RODRIGUEZ
description: Juan Enrique Rodriguez, a retired interpreter at the United Nations, died Saturday of complications after surgery at North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L.I. He was 66 years old and lived in New Hy de Park, L.I.

title: WEALTHFARE? NO.
description: The Reagan Administration is awakening to what s hould have been obvious. Unjustified expansion of armaments s pending, elimination of social programs that may throw more people o nto welfare rolls and large tax cuts will generate deficits and t hrottle the nation's chances for economic recovery.
