If a sane a pproach to the military budget emerges, that will help, but the P resident's team is calling for still greater reductions in domestic p rograms in 1982.

title: Iranian Prime Minister Asks Foes to Yield Arms
description: Iran's new Prime Minister appealed today to opposition groups to lay down their arms as guerrillas struck in two major cities and killed two supporters of the Government.

title: TOP OFFICERS NAMED AT BANK'S NEW UNIT
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, the country's fourth-largest bank holding company and parent of the big Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York City, is planning to merge its three upstate banks at the beginning of next year. Manufacturers Hanover N.A. - the new, Rochester-based entity with 38 branches and assets of $467 million - will be headed by William A. Buckingham, 38 years old, as president and chief executive officer, and Ray W. Manuszewski, 56, as chairman.

title: SALE OF F-15 GEAR TO SAUDIS STUDIED
description: A Government committee studying the question whether the United States should agree to sell Saudi Arabia specialized bomb racks for its F-15 fighter planes is not expected to reach a decision until ''late this year or early next year,'' an official said.

title: EGYPT WILL ASSUME DIRECT REGULATION OF 40,000 MOSQUES
description: The Egyptian Government announced today that it would gradually take over the supervision of 40,000 mosques as part of President Anwar el-Sadat's crackdown on mixing politics and religion.

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1981; The Economy
description: U.S. oil imports have dropped by one-fifth as Americans have curbed their demand for petroleum since the Reagan Administration lifted controls on oil prices in January. Evidence is mounting that higher crude prices may help stem the long decline in U.S. crude output. Although the White House considers oil decontrol a major victory, some energy analysts suggested that longer-term trends may have caused the present situation. (Page A1.)

title: Salvador Getting Generators To Replace Damaged Plants
description: The United States is giving El Salvador 30 diesel generators to make the nation less vulnerable to power shortages caused by guerrilla attacks, a spokesman for the American Embassy said today.

title: LAST MINUTE TRAFFIC CRUSH MARKS END OF SUMMER FUN
description: The last holdouts of summer surrendered mountain retreats, roaring sea beaches and quiet country hideaways for the autumn realities of home, office and classroom yesterday, as the long Labor Day weekend and countless vacations drew to a close under fittingly overcast skies.

title: O.T.C. MARKET MOVING TO UNIFIED STOCK DATA
description: The over-the-counter stock market, that boundless arena where securites of up to 10,000 companies are traded daily by telephone rather than on the floor of an exchange, is making early steps toward combining trading information with the major stock exchanges. The prospect is already making some securities dealers nervous.

title: AFGHAN OFFICIAL, IN INDIA, ESPOUSES NEW FLEXIBILITY
description: The Foreign Minister of Afghanistan arrived here for a daylong visit and told Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today that his Government was ''flexible'' on procedural matters involved in the search for a political solution to the fightin g in his country.

title: ZAIRE'S PROGRESS ON THE MILITARY AND ECONOMIC FRONTS
description: To the Editor:

title: 24-HOUR COMMODITY MARKET
description: When commodity traders are not talking about plummeting grain prices or wondering when interest rates will drop, the hot topic is the need to expand trading hours on the nation's major commodity exchanges.

title: A Second Career Worth Singing About
description: It's vacation time again for Bobbi Rogers, a registered nurse on the staff of Middlesex Memorial Hospital, in Middletown, Conn., and for the second year in a row, she'll spend her holiday working in her second career, as a nightclub singer.

title: Can It Already Be Time to Trim the Tree?
description: Over the Labor Day weekend, Nancy Reagan had her staff put up and trim a Christmas tree in the family quarters of the White House. That's right.

title: Divers Say They Found Wreck of Luxury Yacht
description: Divers say that they have found the sunken wreck of the Alva, which in the late 1800's was considered one of the most luxurious yachts afloat.

title: Cooney-Holmes Due in March
description: Larry Holmes will defend his World Boxing Council heavyweight title against Gerry Cooney, the No. 1 contender, next March at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., after first defending it against Renaldo S nipes Nov. 6 at a site yet to be determined, D on King, the promoter, said today.

title: SPREAD OF FLY IS FEARED DESPITE COAST CAR INSPECTIONS
description: Holiday travelers in California jammed Mediterranean fruit fly checkpoints again yesterday and officials warned that tons of quarantined fruit might have slipped past harried inspectors and spread the infestation. No fertile Mediterrean fruit flies or fruit fly larva were discovered ov er the Labor Day weekend, but that may be the calm before the st orm, said Jeff McCracken, a spokesman at Medfly Project headquarters in Los Gatos, Calif.

title: CONGRESS RETURNING TO ISSUE OF SOCIAL SECURITY SOLVENCY
description: Congress returns to the job of preserving the solvency of the Social Security system this week, with President Reagan pressing for far-reaching fiscal reform but lawmakers of both parties hesitant to antagonize older voters by reducing or postponing benefits.

title: For New York City Comptroller
description: The winner of the Democratic contest for New York City Comptroller in Thursday's primary election is almost sure to win in November. It will thus be up to Democratic voters to choose a candidate likely to do a professional job without allowing personal ambition to tarnish his skills.

title: Man Killed by Car On Parkway Berm
description: A 22-year-old man was struck and killed by an auto as he was walking his disabled motorcycle along a shoulder of the Garden State Parkway, the police said.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: AN operation first done by Dr. William S. Halsted in 1882 in New York and repeated millions of times since then has become one of the most debated procedures in the history of medicin e. The operation - known as the Halsted radical mastectomy - was devised only 36 years after the introduction of anesthesia, when su rgery was just beginningto become more science than magic.

title: CONDEMNED MAN APOLOGIZES AS HE DENIES GUILT IN KILLING
description: Colin Clark, who is condemned to die in Louisiana's electric chair within 60 days, wants to apologize to the family of the man he was convicted of killing.

title: Utility Loses Bid To Cut Credit Risk
description: The State Public Service Commission has rejected a request by the New York Telephone Company to emphasize bank- and credit-reference requirements in its screening of first-time customers.

title: CITY PRIMARIES IN CONNECTICUT SPURRING WIDE VOTER INTEREST
description: Voters in 55 Connecticut towns and cities go to the polls tomorrow in municipal primaries, and the signs are that interest is greater than usual in at least some of the contests.

title: No Headline
description: Q. Does hot food contain more calories than cold food, assuming that the ingredients are the same?

title: DESCENDANTS OF IMMIGRANT RENEW PENNSYLVANI A FIGHT OVER HIS VAST ESTATE
description: The story of a legacy of bitterness and strife of an immigrant without formal education who built a fortune in real estate will soon grow a new chapter, to be written in Pennsylvania's highest court.

title: Susan Lieberman Bride O f Dr. Marc Joel Levine
description: Susan Gail Lieberman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Lieberman of Springfield, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Marc Joel Levine, son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Levine of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club.

title: RESILIENCE IS SEEN FOR ECONOMY
description: Although interest rates are near record levels, the nation's economy appears to be resisting recession, according to a wide range of Government and private-sector economists. The economy's considerable resilience this quarter, they said, could complicate President Reagan's economic recovery program.

title: New Trial Allowed In S.I. Girl's Death
description: An appeals court cleared the way for a new trial for a Staten Island man on charges of sexual abuse and felony murder in the death of a 16-year-old girl last year.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 9, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Eighth emergency special session meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: CHYRON CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Feb

title: STORM STRIKES PUERTO RICO WITH HEAVY RAINS
description: Tropical Storm Gert lashed Puerto Rico with heavy rain and strong winds tonight as its center began passing over the eastern end of the Caribbean island.

title: Territorial Waters Extended by Syria
description: Syria announced today that it was extending its territorial waters from 12 to 35 nautical miles off its Mediterranean coast. The report gave no reason for the new law.

title: Speakers Assail Arms Sale Plan
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Mayor Koch, Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn and other leaders denounced President Reagan's proposed $8.5 billion arms sale to Saudi Arabia last night before 800 people at Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn's Brighton Beach section.

title: CEDENO FIGHTS WITH FANS
description: Cesar Cedeno, the Houston first baseman, was ejected in the first inning of a game tonight between the Astros and the Altanta Braves after he went into the stands and fought with two spectators. The Braves beat the Astros, who lead the Western Division of the National League, 3-2, when Chris Chambliss delivered a two-run double in the bottom of the ninth.

title: Sioux Protesters Leave One Site in Black Hills
description: A group of Oglala Sioux who had been encamped in the Black Hills since August to press Indian claims to the land evacuated the site at Sheridan Lake and the Government called off a court hearing today on a suit to evict them.

title: Neal Boenzi and Fred R. Conrad
description: In the windup yesterday of the mayoral primary campaigns, Mayor Koch presided at a Police Department promotions ce remony, while his principal opponent for the Democratic nominat ion, Frank J. Barbaro, addressed rally near City Hall.

title: HOLLYWOOD IS JOYOUS OVER ITS RECORD GROSSING SUMMER
description: Happy days are here again in Hollywood. When ''Superman II'' reached $100 million in ticket sales last week it was a joyous confirmation that a box-office slump that lasted two and a half years had ended with the biggest summer in the history of the movies.

title: Robert M. Dunn Jr.
description: The current debate over United S tates economic policy has developed a case of gold fever.

title: WESLEYAN, IN 150TH YEAR, FINDS MUCH TO CELEBRATE
description: Wesleyan University is beginning its 150th anniversary year this month with fireworks, lectures, history exhibits and something not seen on its campus for a decade: a balanced budget.

title: Losing Proposition?
description: Vanderbilt has not won a Southeastern Conference football game in five years and has an overall record of 9-46 over that span.

title: Baltimore Gas Plant
description: The Baltimore Gas and Electric Company said today that it planned to build a fossil fuel power plant, expected to cost about $1 billion. The plant, near Perryman, Md., will house a single generator with a cap acity of 800,000 kilowatts and is scheduled to be placed in se rvice in 1992.

title: Two Saved on Mountain; A Third, Diabetic, Dies
description: Two people stranded at the base of Capital Peak were brought off the 14,130-foot mountain today, but a third man, suffering from diabetes, died before rescuers could reach him.

title: The Election Law's Unwelcome Blade
description: Running hard is not the best way to win a primary election in New York City, like the one tomorrow. Instead, stand by quietly until your lawyers find a guillotine in the election law with which to chop off your opponent's chances. The law has a reasonable purpose - to keep frivolous or deceptive candidates off the ballot. But it has a sharp edge.

title: Jets' Lynn Questionable
description: Only the cornerback Johnny Lynn remained questionable today as the Jets prepared for Sunday's game with the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: MONDALE AND THE DEMOCRATS
description: It seems a little soon and maybe even a little crazy, but the Congressional elections of 1982 and even the Presidential election of 1984 have already started.

title: Buitoni Frozen Foods
description: Buitoni Foods of South Hackensack, N.J., said that it will spend about $1 million on a test advertising campaign for its Italian frozen foods in New York between Sept. 10 and January. The agency is Compton Advertising.

title: Georgia's All-Universe
description: Four Atlanta businessmen have come up with a plan to make money off the fame of Herschel Walker, the University of Georgia football star, but it may not be within National Collegiate Athletic Association rules. The group has printed and plans to place on sale posters featuring a black football player in a Georgia uniform with the words ''The Georgian Star.''

title: OCCIDENTAL MAKES BID FOR ZAPATA
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation is offering $754 million in stock for the Zapata Corporation, a major oil services company, Zapata disclosed in Houston yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.00-20.50 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: DIRECTED AFRICA UNIT FOR CHURCH COUNCIL
description: Canon Robert C. S. Powell, an official with the division of overseas ministries of the National Council of Churches, died of a heart attack Sunday during a service at Riverside Church in Manhattan. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: LYNCH BEATS TIANT AS METS END SLIDE
description: The New York Mets broke a three-gam e slide tonight when they defeated the Pittsburgh Pir ates, 3-1, in their first encounter with one of the folk heroes o f the business, the 40-year-old Luis Tiant.

title: Woody Hayes, Author
description: Woody Hayes, the former Ohio State football coach who is recovering from surgery performed last spring, says he is ready to re-embark on what he calls his third career. ''I figure every man has three careers during his life,'' said Hayes.

title: Advertising;  Growth In Direct Marketing
description: THE special art known as direct marketing is flourishing, a prominent practitioner, Michael Slosberg, reported the other day, suggesting that in some ways it was ''the fastest game in town.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday in Connecticut Weekly incorrectly reported the date for a celebration marking the 50th anniversary of Tweed-New Haven Airport. The event will be this Sunday.

title: British Car Output
description: Automobile production in Britain rose to 56,000 cars in August from 51,000 a year earlier but was below the 73,000 in July, Industry Department figures show.

title: Q & A
description: Q. While I was buying chickens at my local poultry market another customer asked for and got -free - several cockscombs, the red, fleshy crest that is found on the heads of poultry. It is illegal to sell cockscombs for the same reason - logical or not - that poultrymen are not allowed any longer to sell chicken feet on sanitary grounds. ''What,'' another customer wanted to know, ''could you possibly do with cockscombs?''

title: T.W.A. MATCHES PAN AM FARES TO MIAMI
description: Trans World Airlines announced yesterday that it would match Pan American World Airways' new cut-rate fare between New York and Miami while other airlines said they were considering price reductions to ''stay competitive'' with Pan Am.

title: MADRID DEFENDS MOVE TO JOIN NATO
description: Widening a debate on the Government's decision to bring Spain rapidly into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Foreign Minister Jose Pedro Perez Llorca said today that alliance membership would be a significant improvement on the long-standing treaty with the United States.

title: South Africa Opens Case Against U.S. Newsman
description: Nat Gibson, chief southern Africa correspondent for United Press International, appeared in court today to face criminal charges that he spread alarm and despondency in a story about race riots 14 months ago.

title: DR. WERNER NATHAN
description: Dr. Werner Nathan, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, died Sunday at his home in South Salem, N.Y. He was 70 years old. He was born in Berlin, studied at the University of Wurzburg and earned his medical degree at the University of Rome. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Elizabeth W. Shelden, also a psychiatrist.

title: JEWELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Loss in both yr-ago periods included a charge against income of $1,209,000 for loss of settlement of company's interruption insurance claim

title: Angolans Chant A nti-U.S. Slogans
description: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators shouting ''Death to Reagan!'' paraded through the Angolan capital of Luanda today to protest the South African attack, the official Angolan press agency reported.

title: BILL M'CLANAHAN
description: Bill McClanahan, an editorial cartoonist, who joined The Dallas Morning News in 1930, has died at the age of 73.

title: AIR FORCE STUNT TEAM'S CHIEF DIES IN CRASH POSSIBLY CAUSED BY BIRDS
description: The leader of the Air Force Thunderbirds precision flying team died today when his T-38 jet crashed, apparently after it lost power when its engines sucked up several seagulls on takeoff.

title: 14 ARTISTS IN DOCUMENTARY AT FILM FORUM
description: MICHAEL BLACKWOOD and Nancy Rosen's ''14 Americans'' is a lively and informative feature that marks the re-emergence of the Film Forum, open in a new location after a year's hiatus and still programming independent features. A documentary, ''14 Americans'' is a look at a group of the most highly regarded artists of the 70's, providing each with a few minutes to discuss and demonstrate his or her work. Without narration or other commentary, it offers clear, illuminating glimpses of the artists and manages to present them in fresh and varying ways.

title: Swedish Plan for Jobles s
description: Sweden is planning a $300 million employment program, sources at the Economics and Budget Ministry said today.

title: More Nostalgia
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Reading Avery Corman's article ''When Dining Out Was Hardly Sumptuous'' (Aug. 19) evoked a warm feeling of nostalgia. Trips to Manhattan for us also included lunch at the Automat; however, instead of a subway ride we took a long leisurely walk ''across the bridge.''

title: REAGAN APPROVES CUTS OF $10-15 BILLION FOR 1982
description: Congress, which left town exhausted after a long, hard-fought dispute over Federal spending and tax policies, will return from its summer recess tomorrow to face a cluster of difficult issues and a new confrontation with President Reagan.

title: THE NUCLEAR ANSWER TO ENVIRONMENTAL WORRIES
description: To the Editor:

title: APPEALS COURT CHOICE: LAWRENCE WARREN PIERCE
description: Judge Lawrence W. Pierce has spent most of his career in Federal, state and city positions in New York, with the last 10 years in Federal District Court. Yesterday, the White House announced its intention to nominate him for the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit to fill the seat vacated by the death of Judge Murray I. Gurfein. Lawyers describe the 56-year-old Mr. Pierce as capable, careful and thoughtful, fair but firm, and considerate in court. His outside interests include sailing, gardening, museums, opera and ballet. He is a Republican.

title: ICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POKER MACHINE STATE PROPOSES IS RULED ILLEGAL
description: New York State's Attorney General declared yesterday that a proposed lottery game using electronic blackjack and poker machines would violate the State Constitution and lottery laws.

title: SENATE RETAINS 2D COUNSEL FOR CASEY INQUIRY
description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence has retained a former senior Justice Department official, Irvin B. Nathan, as special minority counsel for its investigation of William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence.

title: Careers; Private Vocational Schools
description: IN recentyears, technical vocational schools that train individuals quickly for a job have become popular, not only among high school graduates but also among individuals looking for new careers.

title: 30-YEAR U.S. BONDS HIT 15%
description: Long-term Treasury bond yields rose briefly to 15 percent yesterday, but even that record yield for a 30-year bond backed by the United States Government was not enough to attract much investor buying.

title: BEST MEDICINE DURING RECOVERY: FRIENDS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Leonard Probst, a former television drama critic, is the author of ''Off Camera,'' a book on show business people, and a producer with NBC News. By LEONARD PROBST

title: POLISH UNION ASKS FOR A REFERENDUM ON WORKER RIGHTS
description: The Solidarity union asked today that the Government hold a national referendum on workers' rights in running factories. It also voiced support for other East European workers who might seek to set up their own independent unions.

title: William E. Sauro Motherly Love Flourishes on the Campaign Trail
description: Anna Goldin, right, mother of Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, handing out leaflets in the Bronx extolling the virtues of her son. In Brooklyn, below, Grace Dearie, mother of John C. Dearie, told voters they should choose her son in the Democratic primary for Comptroller. About New York, page B4.

title: Stake in Asarco
description: M.I.M. Holdings Ltd. has increased its stake in Asarco, Inc. to 3,922,563 shares, or 15.1 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, M.I.M. said its holdings included 280,300 shares bought on the New York Stock Exchange between Aug. 17 and Sept. 2 for an aggregate price of $11,001,248.

title: A HISTORY OF THE CONTROVERSY LEADING TO RULING ON PRIMARY
description: The injunction against the citywide primaries that was granted yesterday was based on a finding by three Federal judges that ''the city has not done all it could to comply'' with the Federal Voting Rights Act of 1965, a law requiring electoral changes in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx to be approved by the Government before they are put into effect.

title: Mairead Corrigan, Peace Prize Winner, Is Wed
description: Mairead Corrigan, a co-founder of Northern Ireland's Peace People movement and a winner of the 1976 Nobel Peace Prize, was married in Rome yesterday to Jackie Maguire, the widower of the bride's sister, Anne Maguire, who helped inspire the effort to end religious conflict in Northern Ireland. The Rev. Thomas Ryan said the couple had ma rried in Rome because they wanted a quiet ceremony.

title: Car-Rental Concerns Start New Campaigns
description: There has been some shifting among car-rental companies. Hertz is getting a new television ad campaign under way, beginning Saturday.

title: TAX SHELTERS' CHANGING ROLES
description: On Jan. 1 the maximum tax rate for individuals will tumble from 70 percent to 50 percent, one of the biggest rate cuts in the new tax law. This reduction in the top rate will slice hundreds of millions of dollars from the tax bills of upper-income Americans. At the same time, it could cut deeply into the traditional market for tax shelters, used by people in tax brackets greater than 50 percent.

title: RONALD JACKSON: SPARK PLUG OF DECODING SOCIETY
description: RONALD SHANNON JACKSON is best known as a jazz drummer of the first rank, having worked with both Ornette Coleman and Cecil Taylor. But he is becoming better known as the leader, composer and arranger for the Decoding Society, one of the most progressive and influential jazz-rock bands now performing and recording. The brand of amplified music the Decoding Society dispenses is derived from the work Mr. Coleman began doing with his own electric band, Prime Time, in the mid-70's; Mr. Jackson was Prime Time's original drummer. But while Mr. Coleman has recorded and performed infrequently, Mr. Jackson has set about the arduous task of building a reputation for his performing group and getting its music on disks.

title: People
description: * Rea Brown named a senior vice president at Geer, DuBois Inc.

title: E.E.C. Steel Exports Up
description: European Economic Community steel exports to the United States in the first half of 1981 totaled 2.4 million metric tons, up 21.4 percent from the similar period of 1980, American diplomatic sources said today.

title: STEVENS OPTIMISTIC FOR ARTS
description: The outlook for Government support of the arts under the Reagan Administration ''is not anywhere near as bad as it has been painted,'' Roger L. Stevens, director of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, said today.

title: FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1981; The Economy
description: Further budget cuts of $10 billion to $15 billion were authorized by President Reagan. The White House called the reduction a ''hardline'' effort to limit the deficit for fiscal 1982 to the $42.5 billion projected. (Page A1.) Mr. Reagan is expected to propose an innovation to achieve the cuts: an omnibus appropriation bill that would afford a single yes-or-no vote on the whole package of cuts. (A1.)

title: China Output Up 'Slightly'
description: China's industrial output increased ''slightly'' in the first eight months of the year although heavy industrial production declined, the official New China News Agency reported today.

title: Vandals' Work at Synagogue Painted Out in Town Project
description: In a ''service of resanctification'' at a synagogue desecrated by vandals, Christians joined Jews yesterday to strip and repaint the temple's walls.

title: Economic Scene
description: Falling stock and bond prices, persistently high interest rates, a widening budget gap and fears that worse inflation may lie ahead have forced President Reagan to reconsider his planned buildup in military spending.

title: FIRE IN NUCLEAR PLANT SOWED RADIOACTIVITY ACROSS DENVER IN '57
description: A fire at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant in 1957 sent radioactive material drifting through the Denver area, and high levels of enriched uranium were later found at two schools near the plant, a lawsuit has revealed.

title: Jerome T. Orans Dead at 52; A Trial Lawyer in Manhattan
description: Jerome Theodore Orans, a New York trial lawyer for 27 years, died of a heart attack Monday in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: KIT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
LAYTON DEFENSE TO REST CASE IN GUYANA CONSPIRACY TRIAL
description: Lawyers for Larry Layton announced today that the former People's Temple member would offer no defense to charges that he conspired to kill Representative Leo J. Ryan and Richard Dwyer, deputy chief of the American Mission in Guyana.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: President of Bernstein

title: Marathon May Sell 2 Canadian Units
description: The Marathon Oil Company said today that it was considering the sale of two Canadian subsidiaries - Marathon Petroleum Canada Ltd. and Pan Ocean Oil Ltd.

title: Egypt Oil Cut Denied
description: The Egyptian Oil Ministry today denied reports that it had ordered a production cutback by the Petrobel consortium from its Gulf of Suez oilfields because of storage problems.

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: IN this col umn I have tended to discuss the smaller items that go in the kitche n - the pots and pans, the tabletop machines and so forth. In the next few weeks, I want to balance things out a bit by talking about the big pieces in my kitchen -refrigerator, stove and the like -and why I chose the ones I did.

title: APPEAL IS TO BE FILED TODAY
description: A special three-judge Federal court last night prohibited New York City from holding any primary voting tomorrow in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx for all offices, including Mayor and Comptroller.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE license plate on the Toyota Land Cruiser driven by William Hill reads ''MTN WINE,'' and it is entirely appropriate. Mr. Hill is a California entrepreneur and grape grower who believes the best wines come only from vineyards high on mountainsides.

title: RISE BELOW RIVALS
description: The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would increase the price of its 1982 models an average of 4.8 percent, or $430 a car, which is less than its domestic competitors.

title: OPTIONS ON FUTURES APPROVED
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today approved, by a 3-to-0 vote, a three-year pilot program for the trading of options on futures contracts on the regulated commodity exchanges.

title: Juliana Und ergoes Surgery
description: Princess Juliana of the Netherlands, who abdicated the Dutch throne last year on her 71st birthday, successfully underwent an operation today, a Government statement said. No details of the operation were given, but a Government spokesman said the illness was of a nonmalignant nature.

title: N.C.A.A. Calls Convention on TV Policy
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association Council yesterday called a special convention for early December to consider rule changes that would give schools with the top football programs more control over television rights to their games.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Routs Miss Mandlikova
description: Roscoe Tanner is back in Bjorn Borg's path, but Chris Evert Lloyd turned aside Hana Mandlikova's challenge in the United States Open tennis championships yesterday.

title: PANEL'S DIRECTIVE TO WATT ON OIL LEASES CHALLENGED
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt acted without legal authority when he reluctantly complied June 1 with a House Interior Committee's directive that he ban oil and gas leasing in a Montana wilderness area, the Justice Department said in court papers filed today.

title: EMIR'S VISIT UNDERLINES TURKEY'S TURN TO MIDEAST
description: Turkey's military rulers, who seized power a year ago, have intensified the nation's efforts to play a more active r ole in the Middle East.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Second of two articles.

title: IS WILLIE NELSON THE TOP BALLADEER?
description: WHY is Willie Nelson, who wears his long, graying hair in braids, dresses like a hippie and was singing honky tonk music in Texas roadhouses as long ago as the l950's, America's most admired pop balladeer?

title: $5.68 BILLION WILL AID OIL SEARCH
description: The International Monetary Fund has tentatively approved an innovative $5.68 billion loan to India next month, the largest in the fund's history, officials of the agency said yesterday.

title: TAKING THE CUBE ROUTE
description: On my birthday Steadman gave me a Rubik Cube. ''This will drive you mad,'' he promised. I was touched by Steadman's concern. Most people would have been content to give a bottle of champagne. ''Steadman,'' I said, ''do not think I am ungrateful, but the Rubik Cube will have to be put away in the drawer for awhile.'' ''Suit yourself,'' said he. ''Don't be miffed.'' ''If I could afford to give you a gold wristwatch, you wouldn't hide it in a drawer.'' ''Don't be hurt, please. I am dying to be driven mad, but right now it's simply impossible.'' Steadman's attitude was not softened. ''Look, Steadman,'' I said, ''I am one of the slow people. I have to take things one at a time. Right now I am still trying to understand the Laffer Curve. How can I ever master the Laffer Curve if the Rubik Cube drives me mad?''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said an average rate of 17.296 percent was set at the weekly auction of 91-day Citicorp commercial paper, down from a 17.695 percent rate last week.

title: FRIENDLY FROST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $32,000 for the qr and $104,000 for the 6 mos and a tax credit of $190,000 for both periods...C-After income from discontinued operations of $78,000 for the qr and $150,000 for the 6 mos and tax credit of $15,000 for both periods

title: Mortgages at Record 17.27%
description: WASHINGTON Sept. 8 (AP) - The interest rates charged for loans on new homes rose to a record in August, reaching an average 17.27 percent on long-term, fixed-rate mortgages, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: CITY'S HOMELESS REJECTING SHELTER IN THE CATSKILLS
description: A high proportion of the homeless men being sent to a Catskills shelter by New York City under the terms of a recent court agreement are rejecting it and returning to Manhattan.

title: FRUIT-FLY VICTIM: LEMONS IN JAPAN
description: A few weeks ago, most Japanese viewed the Mediterranean fruit fly as a problem that belonged to California alone, if they thought of the crop-threatening pest at all.

title: RACKETY OLD SUBWAYS CAN BE QUI ETED DOWN
description: To the Editor:

title: IMMUNITY BID RENEWED IN CASE ON MISSILE DATA
description: Attorneys representing Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke of the Air Force, the missile crew member accused of making unauthorized visits to the Soviet Embassy and of conveying information to the Russians, moved today that the charges be dismissed because the defendant had received immunity.

title: CAR HITS 4 ON 39TH ST., KILLING ONE
description: A woman was killed and three other pedestrians were injured yesterday in midtown Manhattan when a station wagon careered out of control on East 39th Street and hit a hand truck, a taxicab and then the four passers-by, the police said.

title: World Swim Mark Set
description: Ute Geweniger of East Germany broke her world record in the 100-meter breaststroke with a time of 1 minute 8.60 seconds in winning the event at the European Swimming Championships today. Miss Gewenig- er, broke her previous mark of 1 09.39, set in July in East Berlin.

title: OTTO HAASS, OFFICIAL IN SEVERAL CONCERNS, WAS GRISTEDE'S CHIEF
description: Otto P. Haass, former president of the Gristede Brothers grocery chain in the metropolitan area, died of a heart attack Friday in Saudi Arabia. He was 61 years old and lived in Amagansett, L.I.

title: The Bird Man of Westwood, N.J.
description: Back in 1968, when the town of Westwood, N.J., decided to ban pigeon-keeping, an exception was made for Rudy Opatovsky.

title: zf Banks Firm On Polish Plan
description: The 21-member b anking task force on Polish debt has told Polish officials it will not substantially change its proposals for rescheduling Poland' s 1981 commercial debt, task force members said today.

title: PHILADELPHIA SCHOOL STRUCK IN TEACHER' PROTEST OF CUTS
description: picketing teachers , undeterred by rain showers, gathered outside the Philadelphia S chool District's administration building before daybreak today to begin a strike that one leader said ''could very well last till C hristmas.''

title: KOREA DISSIDENT FASTS TO PROTEST NEW ARRESTS
description: A leading South Korean Protestant minister has been on a hunger strike in prison since mid-Au@gust to protest the policies of President Chun Doo Hwan, according to Japanese Christian leaders.

title: CATHOLIC S CHOOLS HIT BY WALKOUT OF LAY TEACHERS
description: Lay teachers at four Roman Catholic high schools on Long Island and two in Queens went on strike yesterday and formed picket lines at the schools.

title: WHITE IS LUCKY
description: The police in South Africa are so polite, so gentlemanly, so civilized, wh en they arrest you.

title: METHODE ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
F.C.C. Orders Are Upheld By Court
description: Two key orders by the Federal Communications Commission designed to inject competition into the domestic telex and telegraph industry have been upheld by the United States Court of Appeals here.

title: Bright Ready to Play
description: The tackle Jeff Weston rested a pulled hamstring today and may be ready for the Giants' game Sunday at Washington.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's decision to cut $10 billion to $15 billion more from the 1982 budget is a deliberate signal to the financial markets that he is willing to sacrifice some of his ambitious military buildup to hold down budget deficits and regain credibility for his economic program. The President has not yet made a final decision on specific budget cuts, but the message he conveyed to his economic advisers this morning was a harbinger.

title: REP. COTTER OF CONNECTICUT DIES AT 55
description: Representative William Ross Cotter, a member of the House of Representatives since 1970 and a former Connecticut Insurance Commissioner, died this morning in East Lyme, Conn., at the home of his sister. Mr. Cotter, who was 55 years old and lived in Hartford, had been suffering from cancer of the pancreas.

title: RULING PARTIES' YOUTH WINGS PLAN TO PROTEST HAIG'S WEST BERLIN VISIT
description: To the embarrassment of the West German Government, the youth organizations of the Social Democratic and Free Democratic Parties are going ahead with plans to demonstrate Sunday in West Berlin while Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. is visiting.

title: JACKSON AND LEMON TALK AMID RAINOUT
description: There was no game at Yankee Stadium last night because rain prevented the Yankees from playing the Milwaukee Brewers; the teams will try and play a twilight-night doubleheader beginning at 5:30 P.M. today.

title: 'THERE ARE TWO POLITICAL PARTIES'
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics; Closing Their Doors
description: Cabbies' Capistrano The Belmore Cafeteria is not a building of architectural distinction. Its cuisine, though hearty, does not merit inclusion in a culinary hall of fame.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Former Aides At E.P.A. Go Into Business
description: Today will be a big day for Douglas M. Costle, administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency under President Carter and now a founder of the Environmental Testing and Certification Corporation, which is opening in Edison, N.J. Mr. Costle, 41, will be chairman of the executive committee at the company.

title: Bridge: British International Team Puts the Accent on Youth
description: For the last two decades the British representatives in in ternational championships have been among the oldest, with an av erage age often around 50. Recently, however, a crop of bright yo ungsters has challenged the dominance of the old guard.

title: Pressure on Cosmos In Decisive Playoff
description: Giorgio Chinaglia says the Cosmos are feeling pressure. They face the Tampa Bay Rowdies in the third and deciding game of their quarterfinal playoff series tomorrow night at Giants Stadium.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: THERE is in Manhattan a Street With No Name. It is seven blocks long. Buildings line both flanks, but without entrances onto this street. The intersections have traffic lights, but name signs for the cross-streets only. City maps show the street, but without a name.

title: Parsons Joining Saudi Oil Project
description: The Parsons Corporation said it had signed an agreement with Saudi Arabia for construction of an oil refinery on the Persian Gulf coast, adding that it would receive about one-third of the proceeds.

title: WILLIAM YORK TINDALL, JAMES JOYCE SCHOLAR
description: William York Tindall, the James Joyce scholar who taught at Columbia University for 40 years, died yesterday in Salisbury, Md. He was 78 years old.

title: REAGAN DISCUSSES AGENDA FOR BEGIN
description: President Reagan conferred at lunch today with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger on military and other questions that are expected to arise in talks starting tomorrow with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1981
description: International Defiance of Poland's leadership was expressed by the Solidarity union. The 890 delegates at the union's national convention in Gdansk asked the authorities to hold a referendum on the right of workers to manage factories. The unionists also suggested that other workers of the Soviet bloc create unions free of Communist Party control. (Page A1, Column 1.) An anti-U.S. protest in West Berlin is set for Sunday during the visit by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. To the embarrassment of the Bonn Government and the dismay of many West Germans, the youth groups of the two parties in the ruling coalition vowed to proceed with the demonstration against what they see as an aggressive and reactionary American foreign policy. (A8:3-6.)

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We suppor t those of you who have decided to enter the difficult road of strug gle for free and independent unions.'' - Polish labor convention, t o others in Soviet bloc. (A1:1.)

title: Fugitive From Kansas Prison Caught as 3 Remain at Large
description: A convicted murderer who escaped from the Kansas State Penitentiary was recaptured today, and the authorities were still searching a rural area for three other escapees.

title: Books Of The Times
description: Michiko Kakutani THE CHILD SAVERS: Juvenile Justice Ob- served. By Peter S. Prescott. 244 pages. Knopf. $12.95.

title: ENERGY, IN ROUND 8
description: After years of a largely futile political struggle to create Government solutions to energy problems, the nation appears to be ready for a fundamentally different approach. There is strong support, for example, for President Reagan's view that past failures were the result of Government insistence that energy problems always require political solutions.

title: MORE WORK FOR THE ELDERLY IS URGED IN STUDY
description: A corporate tax cut aimed at stimulating production, like the one President Reagan persuaded Congress to enact, will not provide much economic help for people 65 and older, according to a private study commissioned by the forthcoming White House Conference on Aging.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Agency Rent-A-Car Inc. said it had increased its share in Spencer Companies to 619,355 shares, or 36.2 percent, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: GREENMAN BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-After tax credits of $43,000 for the qr and $315,000 for the 6 mos...C-After tax credits of $69,000 for the qr and $440,000 for the 6 mos

title: Ford-Cuba Pact Near
description: Negotiations are nearly complete to allow the export of ''several thousand Ford vehicles'' to Cuba, according to Jose Courard, the president of Ford Argentina. Mr. Courard did not specify whether the vehicles would be automobiles, trucks or buses. ''We are coming to an end of the negotiations and foresee the export of several thousand Ford vehicles,'' he told a news conference yesterday. Ford Argentina, a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company of the United States, is the largest producer of motor vehicles in the Argentine market, producing approximately 50 percent of the vehicles sold in Argentina.

title: ROY WILKINS, 50-YEAR VETERAN OF CIVIL RIGHTS FIGHT, IS DEAD
description: Roy Wilkins, leader of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and an activist in the cause of civil rights for more than 50 years, died yesterday at the age of 80.

title: 26 REBUILDING PROPOSALS SUBMITTED FOR TIMES SQ.
description: Developers from five states and Canada have filed 26 proposals - far more than expected - for the renovation of West 42d Street and the Times Square area, New York City and state officials announced yesterday.

title: U.S. AGENCY NEWSLETTERS HAILED AS MORALE BUILDERS
description: The United States Forest Service, through its weekly ''Friday Newsletter,'' told its employees last winter that they could wear field pants made from cotton and synthetic polyester fiber.

title: ON THE HUSTINGS, SHE'S A CANDIDATE'S BEST FRIEND
description: The women at the Boston Secor Senior Citizens Center in the Bronx were convinced. So were the penny poker players at the Stars and Stripes Democratic Club in the Dyker Heights section of Brooklyn.

title: BEST BUYS
description: The season is winding up with low prices and plentiful supplies of such summer vegetables as eggplant, green peppers, tomatoes, zucchini and corn. Because we've had these in such abundance this year, now is a good time to look for imaginative ways of serving them, and to use fresh herbs while they are still available.

title: A NEON EYESORE, NOT URBAN WILDERNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: SAMUELS ART IS SOLD PRIVATELY
description: The art and antiques collection of Leslie R. Samuels, a philanthropist, was sold privately over the weekend for an undisclosed amount by Sotheby Parke Bernet. The collection, which was to have been auctioned by Sotheby's and was expected to fetch about $5 million, was formed over 30 years by Mr. Samuels, who earned his money in retail outlets in the Middle West, and his late wife, Fan Fox Samuels, an heir to a mercantile fortune who died at the age of 84 last April. The identity of the woman who purchased the collection was not disclosed.

title: PEP BOYS, MANNY MOE & JACK reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net includes an after-tax gain of $298,000 or 24 cents a shr on sale of real estate

title: THE GUIDE TO NEW YORK COOKING SCHOOLS: WHERE TO LOOK TO LEARN WHICH CUISINE
description: The cooking schools on these pages were reviewed by Florence Fabricant and Moira Hodgson. This article was written by Mrs. Fabricant.

title: WILLIAMS DISMISSED IN EXPO SHAKE-UP
description: The Montreal Expos dismissed Dick Williams as manager yesterday. John McHale, the Expos' president, said the dismissal was made to improve discipline on the team and to help it finish first in the National League East's second season.

title: New Office Projects in Fort Lee
description: ANALOGIES can be deceptive, but that didn't stop an office builder here who the other day ventured to describe Fort Lee as the ''White Plains of New Jersey.''

title: Montgomery Ward P icks a New Chief
description: Stephen L. Pistner, a 49-year-old retailer who joined Montgomery Ward & Company as president about six months ago, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer of the retailing and catalogue chain. He succeeds Edward S. Donnell, 61, who will continue as chairman of Ward, the Chicago-based subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation, until he retires next March 1.

title: WATSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Ainge Order Extended
description: Federal Judge Lee Gagliardi yesterday extended for 10 days a temporary restraining order barring the Boston Celtics from negotiating with infielder Danny Ainge of the Toronto Blue Jays. The ruling, given in United States District Court in Manhattan, prohibits Ainge from any dealings with the Celtics until a hearing in Judge Gagliardi's courtroom Sept. 18.

title: Shot at Prowler Kills Friend
description: It was 3:30 in the morning and Eugene Kozdras did not wait to ask questions of what he thought was a prowler lurking near his motorcycle. According to police, a single shot wounded his close friend, Mitchell Myers, 21 years old, Monday.Though Mr. Kozdras took Mr. Myers to a hospital, the man died within hours. Mr. Kozdras, 25, was charged with homicide and a gun violation.

title: ACCORD SET IN APPLICATION ACQUISITION
description: Schlumberger Ltd., a leader in the manufacture of specialized oil drilling equipment, yesterday announced its third acquisition in the field of computer technology, a major growth area.

title: A Familiar Face Returns to Arkansas
description: He is 71 years old now and his shoulders are stooped, but Orval E. Faubus is back in Arkansas, and he is talking about running for Governor again.

title: THE CHANCELLOR AND THE WOULD-BE PRINCIPALS
description: To the Editor:

title: Pacers and N.B.A. Stars Plan Benefit for Turner
description: The Indiana Pacers will play a benefit game against other National Basketball Association players Sept. 19 to raise money for Landon Turner, the injured Indiana University forward.

title: 49ers Sign Matt Bahr
description: The San Francisco 49ers today signed Matt Bahr, the former Pittsburgh kicker. He will replace Ray Wersching, who injured a hip muscle during warmups last Sunday.

title: Price-Fixing Ruling
description: A Federal appeals court refused today to overturn verdicts agai nst three plywood manufacturers found guiltyof price fixi ng.

title: Market Place; Looking Over A Suit Maker
description: HART SCHAFFNER & MARX is riding the coattails of Johnny Carson, Pierre Cardin and Christian Dior. Meanwhile, the company is weaving a bolder pattern of profitability as the nation's population ages.

title: Reagan Backers in Suit To Quash Panel Audit
description: The Federal Election Commission argued today that release of an audit of President Reagan's campaign finances should not be blocked ''merely because it might be embarrassing to certain persons.''

title: PROTESTING AGAINST EXCAVATIONS
description: Orthodox Je ws outside the Israeli Embassy in London yesterday. They were prot esting against archeological work near Jerusalem and Israe l's treatment of Jews opposed to the project.

title: Interstate Thrift Unit Merger Backed
description: The merger of three New York, Florida and California savings and loan associations into what would become the nation's largest federally chartered savings and loan association was approved by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: JORDAN EXPECTED TO LEAVE URBAN LEAGUE POST
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr. p lans to announce his resignation as presidentof the Nation al Urban League today, sources close to the civil rights leader said yesterday.

title: National City Ends Gray Drug Offer
description: National City Lines, Inc., said it had terminated its offer to purchase up to 650,000 shares of Gray Drug Stores Inc.

title: DROP IN CONSUMER CONFIDENCE
description: Consumer confidence in the United States economy fell in August after a five-month climb, the Conference Board reported yesterday. But the business-supported research group also said its survey showed that b uying plans expanded in August. ''The lates t dip in confidence, although small, is unsettling sinceall of the de cline represents increasing consumer concern about the future,'' the Conference Board said of its latest survey, which covers 5,000 households nationwide.

title: HARLEM CROWD CHASES YOUTHS
description: A crowd of more than 20 men and boys chased two teen-agers fleeing from a clothing store robbery in Harlem yesterday and, in an exchange of gunfire, one of the suspects was killed, the police said.

title: U.S. BARS CHALLENGE TO A LAW RESTRICTING SCHOOLING FOR ALIENS
description: The Justice Department has filed a brief in the Supreme Court backing away from its previous position that a Texas law that would deny free public education to illegal alien children should be struck down as unconstitutional.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LYRICS AND LASAGNA

title: Knicks Sign Cook
description: The Knicks signed Greg Cook, their first choice in last June's college draft, to a two-year contract yesterday. The Knicks, without a first-round selection, got Cook, who played for Louisiana State, on the second round. Noted for his defense, Cook, a 6-foot-9-inch foward, averaged 9 points and six rebounds a game last season.

title: OIL ENTITLEMENT PROGRAM IN TURMOIL
description: A number of oil companies might be asked to pay hundreds of millions of dollars to cover the ''disappearance'' of low-priced oil from the Government entitlements program in its final months.

title: Muncie New Force I n Charger Offense
description: Sam Rutigliano, the coach of the Cleveland Browns, said that the offensive display last night by the San Diego Chargers was awesome, as devastating as anything he had seen in pro football in quite a while. And as for Chuck Muncie, Rutigliano asked, how was any team going to stop him?

title: FRENCH HOPE 'REAL' CHEESE CAN HOLD ON
description: Roland Dutond, 26 years old and weighing 222 pounds, triumphed over 31 contestants this weekend to win the annual cheese-eating contest that was the highlight of the four-day Foire Internationale aux Fromages, one of France's largest cheese fairs.

title: ABKCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CBS CHIEF ASKS END TO RULES ON AIRING OTHER SIDE OF ISSUES
description: CBS Inc. has called for repeal of Federal regulations requiring broadcasters to present opposing views on controversial issues and rules that place similar obligations on those controlling the airwaves.

title: Gems Are Stolen in London
description: Thieves have stolen four blue sapphires worth more than $25,000 from a room in which a cobra was guarding a far more valuable jewel, the London police said today. A crowd was gathered around a cabinet in the Commonwealth Institute looking at a snake coiled near a $1.8 million, 393-carat sapphire when someone went up to another cabinet and took the gems, a spokesman said.

title: RICHES GONE, INDIA PRINCESS REIGNS IN RAIL STATION
description: For nearly 10 years, by living at a railroad station here with her son and daughter, seven servants and 13 watchdogs, the Begum Wilayat Mahal, the head of the long deposed royal house of Oudh, has been hoping to shame the Government of India into redressing her grievances.

title: 'I AM THE ONLY FULL-FLEDGED DEMOCRAT
description: RUNNING'To the Editor:

title: Belated Birthday Award
description: His birthday was back in July, so the ceremony was a little late, but Gian-Carlo Menotti, the composer, was on hand at New York's City Hall yesterday to receive a special 70th birthday award from Mayor Koch.

title: HEINZ, H J, CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 29
description: B-Includes $7,061,000 representing a reduction in the tax provision in connection with the forgiveness of certain previously deferred Britain's income taxes

title: CANAL-RANDOLPH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Marsteller Post
description: Marsteller Inc. has announced the election of Bert Rosenberg, 48 years old, as executive vice president. He had been senior vice president and director of marketing.

title: GREYHOUND OFFICER HAS 2 ROLES: CHIEF AND HEIR APPARENT
description: In what amounts to a challenge to John W. Teets, who becomes chief executive officer of the Greyhound Corporation on Oct. 6, the company's chairman, Gerald H. Trautman, is proclaiming in advertisements that ''Greyhound is really going places in the 80's.''

title: Penny Wise, Penny Foolish
description: In baseball, When a great player's skills fade, rather than be remembered as a stumbler he steps down and his past exploits are memorialized by retiring his number. Something like that is in order for the penny.

title: French Assembly Begins Session
description: The French National Assembly opened its autumn session today with the Socialist majority determined to push through a program of social, economic and political change. The session will continue until Dec. 20, with members debating and voting on a s weeping program of change prepared by the Socialists, who this year ended 23 years of conservative rule by winning the presidency in May and an absolute majority in the assembly a month later.

title: Louisiana Panel Accepts Plan for Desegregation
description: A three-judge Federal panel accepted a compromise today to desegregate Louisiana's colleges and universities, despite arguments by black leaders that the proposals would not work. The decisio n ended the threat of a trial in the seven-year-old case.

title: DOW DOWN BY 10.56 ON RATE FEARS
description: Stock prices plunged yesterd ay to their lowest level in more than 15 months as investors' apprehension over high interest rates and increasing ma rgin calls continued to unsettle the market.

title: Iran Cancels 1954 Oil Pacts
description: Iran has canceled all contracts signed with multinational oil companies before the 1979 Islamic revolution, the Iranian Oil Ministry announced today.

title: Officials Share the Romance in Their Souls
description: It took some high-level intervention from Chinese authorities, but Gervais Lavoie, a Canadian anthropologist, said yesterday that he had finally married the Mongolian dancer whose family had reportedly abducted her to frustrate their romance.

title: Sports of The Times; The Gunslinger and the Poet
description: WHEN Roscoe Tanner was 15 years old, he was short and fat, by his own admission . The next year he grew eight inches, and with them camethe gift.

title: BAR GROUP BACKS JUDGE O'CONNOR ON EVE OF CONFIRMATION HEARINGS
description: Judge Sandra Day O'Connor ''has the professional qualifications required of an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States'' despite a relative lack of ''extensive or challenging'' judicial experience, a committee of the American Bar Association told the Senate Judiciary Committee today.

title: COPTIC CHURCH IS ANCIENT AND ISOLATED
description: One of the oldest Christian communities in the world, Egypt's Coptic Christian Church traces its spiritual heritage to the preaching of St. Mark, but because of a fourth-century theological dispute it has had little contact with the rest of the world's Christians for more than a thousand years.

title: JACLYN INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
MOSCOW BOOK FAIR PLEASES OFFICIALS AND PILFERERS
description: The third Moscow International Book Fair closed today after a relatively uncontroversial week. Soviet organizers claimed unprecedented successes, those Americans who did come expressed satisfaction and many book-starved Muscovites succeeded in making free additions to their libraries.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: No matter how many sweaters a woman owns, there always seems to be room in her wardrobe for one more. Charivari has had a versatile style knitted up in Italy of a cuddly wool-angora blend in a range of tempting colors: ivory, red, pale gray, baby blue, pink, red, khaki and black. It's a ribbed pullover with a high round neck and a matching triangular scarf that may be tucked into an epaulet on one shoulder, tied around the neck in any number of ways, or worn on the head like a babushka. It's $85 in the Chariva ri stores at 58 West 72dStreet (corner of Columbus Avenue) and 2307 B roadway (between 83d and84th Streets).

title: ISRAELI TO SUCCEED DALE AS BARNUM
description: Mike Burstyn, an American-born actor who is a popular star of films and television in Israel and the Netherlands, has been signed to replace Jim Dale in the leading role in the Broadway musical ''Barnum.'' Mr. Dale will give his last performance on Oct. 11, when his contract expires, and Mr. Burstyn will go into the show at the St. James Theater on Oct. 13.

title: Heinz Net Up 26.5%
description: The H.J. Heinz Company reported yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 26.5 percent, to $48.2 million, from $38.1 million in the comparable period of 1980. Per-share earnings rose to $2.05 from $1.65.

title: Bahrain Refinery
description: The Ras Tanura refinery of the Arabian American Oil Company, known as Aramco, has brought new naphtha and pentane-extraction installations into operation, increasing the capacity for gasoline output by as much as 10,000 barrels a day, Aramco said today. The new plant allows more low-octane products to be included in the gasoline blend, and thus increases production, it said.

title: EDWIN A. LINK, 77, INVENTED INSTRUMENT FLIGHT SIMULATOR
description: Edwin A. Link, inventor of the Link flight simulator used to train pilots and other airmen under instrument flying conditions, died of cancer Monday at his home in Binghamton, N.Y. Mr. Link, who was 77 years old, also lived in Fort Pierce, Fla.

title: WOMAN IN SPY CASE GIVES UP
description: A woman accused of harboring Christopher Boyce, the convicted spy, turned herself in to the United States Marshal's office this afternoon, as had been promised by her attorney.

title: TOURISTS AND BUSINESSMEN FLOCKING TO SMALL AIRLINES' FLIGHTS
description: Vacationers, business people and other travelers are being attracted in large numbers to several aggressive small airline s that are offering no-frills, low-cost travel that is sometimes che aper than driving.

title: Two in Casino Bombing Plead Guilty in Bargain
description: Two sons of the accused mastermind of a Lake Tah oe casino bombing pleaded guilty today to conspiracy fortheir part in the $3 million extortion attempt.

title: A Coaching First
description: Cheryl Roberts, a 23-year-old recreation therapist, has been named an assistant to Wil Jones, basketball coach at the University of the District of Columbia in Washington.

title: Racism Was the Enemy
description: Roy Wilkins made history, and made America a more just and decent place, for whites as well as blacks.

title: AN OLD SPECTER RETURNS TO HAUNT BRAZIL'S GENERALS
description: Critics are fond of accusing the Brazilian military of imagining that Communism lurks behind every bush, but recently some generals said they had discovered it in full view in the heart of Brasilia.

title: A COOL, SOLID AND RESPECTED LEADER
description: When the question was asked, it did not bother him. It had been brought up, in general by younger blacks, at nearly every convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People since the civil rights movement spawned the black power movement.

title: PROFESSIONAL GROUPS FOR THE INSTRUCTOR
description: The cooking schools s were reviewed by Florence Fabricant and Moira Hodgson. This article was written by Mrs. Fabricant. THERE are now two professional associations to which cooking instructors in the New York area may belong, although whether an instructor displays or advertises membership in either of the organizations is no guarantee of his or her ability - the groups have not refused membership to any applicant. This is likely to change, however, because both organizations are developing standards for membership.

title: Index; International
description: Princess in India unbowed by life in rail station A2 The Coptic church: Ancient and isolated A3 Khomeini says Parliament may be next bomb target A4 Turkish turn to the Mideast underlined by visit of Ku waiti A6 South Korean theologian said to be on hunger strike in prison A7 Around the World A9 Moscow says Polish union seeks political power A10 Madrid defends move to join NATO A11 Government/Politics U.S. agency hailed as morale builders A16 House panel's directive to Watt on oil leases is challenged A20 Senate panel retains minority counsel for Casey inquiry A26 CBS executive calls for repeal of F.C.C. fairness rules A28 Mayor of Hartford wins disputed Democratic primary victory B1 Primary candidates in New York City, Nassau and Suffolk B4 General Suit in Colorado discloses 1957 fire spread radioactivity A12 Tropical storm in Caribbean a threat as two others weaken A13 Around the Nation A14 Mediterranean fruit fly stirs Texas-California feud A18 A car jumps a curb in Manhattan, killing one and injuring three B2 Obituaries Otto P. Haass, former head of Gristede Brothers chain B7 Edwin A. Link, inventor of flight simulator B7 William R. Cotter, Representative from Connecticut B7 Canon R.C.S. Powell, National Council of Churches official B6 The Living Section Food Nearings: Simple food and good life C1

title: TV: 'AMERICA- BALCK AND WHITE'
description: FOR 90 minu tes this evening, beginning at 9:30, NBC News examines the status of blacks in the United States and comes to the conclusionthat ''Americ a still remains in many ways two nations -black and white.'' Clea rly inspired by the country's new conservatism and the Reagan Admini stration's budget cuts, this ''NBC White Paper,'' ''America - B lack and White,'' was written by Garrick Utley, who anchors the p rogram, and Emery King, who is a reporter along with Mr.Utley. The ex ecutive producer is Anthony Potter.

title: Aircraft Contracts
description: The General Dynamics Corporation announced it had won an additional $778.5 million Air Force contract for 180 F-16 aircraft. The Grumman Corporation's aerospace division also announced it had received Navy contracts totaling $113.7 million for parts for A-6E aircraft and E-2C pilot-training simulators.

title: Indian Minister Blames U.S.  In the Worsening of Relations
description: Foreign Minister Narasimha Rao told Parliament today that relations with the United States had descended into a ''temporary phase of bitterness'' over India's refusal to accept an American diplomat and Washington's retaliation.

title: WITNESS LATE, PROSECUTOR IN CONTEMPT
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Queens - angered at what he called the inefficiency of the Queens District Attorney's office - yesterday ordered a prosecutor held in contempt because his witness in a robbery case was late for court.

title: LETTERS
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Regarding Mr. Corman's nostalgia on eating, although my borough was Brooklyn and my eatery Meyers, the situation was entirely the same.

title: U.S. REPORTS GAINS IN FRUIT FLY FIGHT
description: The Department of Agriculture said today that aerial spraying of the pesticide malathion over 1,200 square miles of farm land infested by the Mediterranean fruit fly ''is showing results,'' and predicted that the pest would be eradicated.

title: New Magazine Offers 'Salute to New York'
description: The Business Council, a business-interest lobbying group financed by many of the state's industries and businesses, has unveiled a magazine it says will be ''a salute to New York.'' The first issue of the magazine, New York Alive, was introduced here today.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes gain on sale of southern division of $241,041

title: MOSCOW ASSAILS UNION' AIMS
description: The Soviet Government's press agency Tass said today that Solidarity, the independent labor union, had shown at its convention in Gdansk that it was out to seize political power in Poland.

title: Bus Drivers' Pigeons
description: Thoughts from a different corner, the one that the half-empty bus just raced past, leaving a crowd to push into the next bus, already packed:

title: A STAKE IN CANADIAN PACIFIC
description: When Paul Desmarais was in business school some 30 years ago, he wrote a research paper on how someone could take over Canadian Pacific Ltd., the giant corporate conglomerate so intimately tied to Canada's history.

title: Head of Bond Group Named
description: Rocco J. Marano, president of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, today was named chairman of a new citizens' committee to promote voter approval on Nov. 3 of two bond issues, totaling $450 million, to pay for improvements to the state's water suppl y system and cleaning up hazardous waste sites that threaten water quality .

title: News Analysis
description: Like any number of cunning, seasoned traders in the Middle East, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, is a past master at weaving psychological tricks, intricate arguments and often brilliant acting to achieve his ends. Of late, Sheik Yamani has been resorting to old-fashioned threats.

title: McDonnell Douglas Plea ds Guilty on Payoffs
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the St. Louis-based aircraft manufacturer, pleaded guilty today to charges of fraud and filing false statements with the Federal Government in a case involving millions of dollars in questionable overseas payments.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bankers Trust Company has elected G. Lynn Sostack senior vice president and head of the Personal Financial Management division of the Fiduciary Department.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: In a review of two biographies of Nancy Astor last Wednesday, she was incorrectly described as the first woman elected to the House of Com- mons.

title: Tenneco Unit Has Oil Find in Tunisia
description: Tenneco Inc. said its Houston Oil and Minerals subsidiary had made an onshore oil discovery near Sfax, Tunisia.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: NOT many years ago professional chefs in America and abroad were reluctant to share their secrets or recipes with home cooks for the simple reason that most chefs considered home cooks incapable of understanding professional technique. That, of course, is no longer true.

title: Restraint Denied In Account Suit
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said on behalf of four of its New Orleans account executives named in a suit last week by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith that Merrill Lynch's application for a temporary restraining order had been denied.

title: 2 Shuttle Astronauts Prepare For a Countdown Rehearsal
description: Joe H. Engle and Richard H. Truly prepared today to board the space shuttle Columbia for a final countdown dress rehearsal before their scheduled liftoff Oct. 9.

title: 'P' Car Delay Is Reported
description: A cash shortage has forced the General Motors Corporation to delay introduction of its sporty ''P'' car until the autumn of 1983, according to a published report.

title: Pouches and Cans
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Regarding Bryan Miller's article (''Will the Pouch be the New Tin Can,'' Aug. 12), if the pouch replaces the tin can, how does one store it on a shelf conveniently? Can you put contact paper around it and use it for a pencil holder? Can you punch a hole in its bottom and use it to transplant cuttings? It may be cheaper, and the food tastier, but I am not looking forward to it. I hope some things still come in cans in the future. SHEILA STEMBER Manhattan

title: Barbara Walters Signs 2d 5-Year ABC Pact
description: Barbara Walters, who went from NBC-TV to ABC-TV five years ago for a reported salary of $1 million a year, has signed her second fiveyear contract with ABC News.

title: KHOMEIMI SEES NEW BOMB PERIL
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini warned today that Iran's Parliament could be the next target of anti-Government bombs.

title: Oil Policy Shift Cited by Paper
description: The President's Cabinet Council on Natural Resources is considering a change in the restrictions on exports of refined petroleum products, an oil trade publication reported this week.

title: TYLAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Australians Will Investigate Export of Kangaroo as Beef
description: The Australian Government announced today that a commission would be set up to look into the meat scandal set off by the discovery last month of horse and kangaroo meat being exported as beef.

title: CROSBY'S SON MATURE CHAMPION AT 19
description: A few minutes after he won the United States Amateur golf championship Sunday, Nathaniel Crosby was asked, ''If your father could walk into this press room, what do you think he would say?'' Without hesitation, Crosby, 19 years old and the youngest son of the late Bing Crosby, replied: ''Don't let it go to your head.''

title: News Analysis
description: Hundreds of thousands of hastily printed ballots are being circulated throughout Egypt for Thursday's referendum on President Anwar el-Sadat's crackdown on religious extremists and on his political opponents.

title: Rangers Trade Soetaert Rights
description: The Rangers traded the rights to Doug Soetaert to the Winnipeg Jets yesterday for future considerations. The club also signed Don Maloney, a left wing, to a multiyear contract.

title: NEARINGS: SIMPLE FOOD AND GOOD LIFE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lorna J. Sass 's latest cookbook, ''Christmas Feasts,'' will be published thi s month by Irena Chalmers Cookbooks and the MetropolitanMuseum of Art . By LORNA J. SASS

title: IOWA SCHOOL DISTRICT VOTERS REJECT BIBLE AS SUPPLEMENTARY TEXTBOOK
description: Voters in the Clear Creek School Distict have overwhelmingly defeated a proposal to adopt the Bible as a supplementary textbook.

title: Double Bass Proves Doubly Rewarding
description: There are times when Jacqueline and Marjorie Danilow must wish they had taken up the flute or perhaps the piccolo. Those times, 27-yearold Jacqueline said the other day, are when the sisters are trying to maneuver their bulky bass fiddles onto a bus or into a cab.

title: APPROVAL OF REAGAN AND ECONOMY PLAN FOUND STABLE IN POLL
description: Public approval of President Reagan's handling of his job and optimism about the impact of his economic program have remained remarkably stable throughout the summer, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: THE POOR SEERS AMONG OUT POOR READERS
description: To the Editor:

title: DONALDSON, LUFKIN TO ACQUIRE ACLI
description: ACLI International Inc., a multibillion-dollar commodity and security brokerage firm, will be acquired by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Wall Street's seventh-largest publicly held securities house, the companies announced yesterday.

title: Northwest Industries Bid
description: Northwest Industries Inc. of Chicago, a producer of industrial, consumer and chemical products, said its directors had authorized a cash tender offer to purchase three million shares of its common stock at a net price of $55 a share with the discretion to purchase an additional two million shares. The offer is expected to begin Sept. 11 and expire Oct. 1.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My sofa bed smells so musty that everyone who sleeps on it complains and seems to pick up the musty smell themselves. Also, sheets used on this sofa bed have to be washed several times to get rid of the smell. Is there a way to get the smell out of the mattress, or do I have to buy a new one? - K.E., Hopewell, N.J.

title: HOW REDISTRICTING PLAN EVOLVED IN THE COUNCIL
description: The New York City Council worked slowly and carefully to put together the redistricting plan that has been challenged in Federal court.

title: Return, and Renewal, in the Schools
description: When campaigning politicians identify with the public schools, educators must be doing something right. So Mayor Koch's television advertisements touting improvements in New York City's schools, which open today, are a welcome indication of their returning health.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's not the end of the world. I frankly don't think that the minds of the people on the issue of how they will vote will be changed, whether the election is held tomorrow, a week from tomorrow or a month from tomorrow.''

title: Taking the Heat Off Synfuels
description: Synfuel fever: remember the bandwagon that started late in the Carter Administration, while angry motorists waited in line for gasoline? Politicians and columnists embraced synfuels as a way out of the nation's energy problems. American ingenuity and managerial skill would take abundant resources like coal and oil shale and convert them into badly needed liquid fuels. Reliance on imported oil would diminish, giving America firmer control of its fuel prices and its foreign policy.

title: ABSENCE OF FLIES RAISES NEW HOPES
description: Despite several incidents of spraying the wrong areas with pesticide and a possible shortage of the bait that makes the pesticide effective, officials of California's program to eradicate the Mediterranean fruit fly said today that they believed they were winning the battle against the destructive pest.

title: DOW UP 2.76 IN SHORT SESSION
description: In a trading session shortened by 30 minutes because of a power failure, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 2.76 points yesterday, its first increase in a week of dropping stock prices resulting from high interest rates.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alco Standard Corp. said it has entered into a purchase agreement that would increase its stake in the Strother Drug Co. to 323,311 shares, or 38.3 percent.

title: Tandy, Datapoint Link Computers
description: The Tandy Corporation personal computers will be able to link together in a network using technology provided by the Datapoint Corporation, the two companies announced.

title: Cunningham Accepts Patriot Terms
description: Sam Cunningham, a fullback and a free agent for more than 19 months, has agreed to a new contract with his former team, the New England Patriots, the National Football League club announced today.

title: 15,000 SOUTH AFRICAN TROOPS NOT PULLED OUT, ANGOLAN SAYS
description: Angola's chief delegate to the United Nations said today that there were still about 15,000 South African troops in the southern part of his country and that they intended to remain there.

title: RUNNER-UP TO CHALLENGE VOTE FOR HARTFORD MAYOR
description: The runner-up in yesterday's Democratic mayoral primary here said today that he would go to court to challenge the victory of Mayor George A. Athanson, who won by 94 votes.

title: FOR NEW YORKERS, A REPRISE OF OLD BLACKOUT ADVENTURES
description: With bewilderment, rage, gallows humor and perhaps most of all a sense of deja vu, New Yorkers resigned themselves yesterday to their latest municipal crisis.

title: SYNTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BULLS OUTNUMBER WALL STREET'S BEARS BUT RATES AND DEFICIT WORRY
description: EXECUTIVES By ROBERT J. COLE

title: Around the World; 160 Beached Whales Die in Tasmania
description: At least 160 pilot whales beached themselves and died despite a rescue effort by hundreds of volunteers who massaged and bathed the huge mammals, wildlife officials said today.

title: TEXT OF JUDGE O'CONNOR'S STATEMENT TO PANEL
description: Following is the prepared text of Judge Sandra Day O'Connor's opening statement today as the Senate Judiciary Committee began confirmation hearings on her nomination to the United States Supreme Court:

title: Distress Signal From Egypt
description: Egypt is not Iran, and Anwar Sadat is hardly the hapless Shah. But there is a parallel now between Cairo and Teheran. Islamic fundamentalists and secular leftists are winning allure as martyrs, as a pro-Western regime claps them in prison. There is much at stake: if President Sadat has miscalculated, the results could be calamitous for Egypt's allies as well as for Egypt. At the same time, his foreign partners share some responsibility for what has gone wrong.

title: Not Fit to Be Tied
description: There has not been a tie game played in the Big Sky Conference since 1976. Nevertheless, the eight-team conference has voted, 7 to 1, to eliminate tie games in football and adopt a tiebreaker system for league games.

title: SIGMAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CANADA DEFEATS SOVIET BY 7-3 AND WILL FACE U.S. IN SEMIFINAL
description: The United States team will play Canada, and the Soviet Union will take on Czechoslovakia Friday night in the semifinals of the Canada Cup hockey tournament.

title: MUSIC: VIOLIN-PIANO DUO
description: SUNG IL LEE, who is a violinist, and his wife, Me Hyon Moon, a pianist, made their New York debut as joint recitalists at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night.
