Miss Moon opened the program with Bach's French Suite No. 5 and offered Liszt's Hungarian Rhapsody No. 12 as her other solo later in the evening. Mr. Lee's unaccompanied works were Bach's Chaconne in D minor and two of Paganini's Caprices (Nos. 5 and 17).

title: News Analy sis
description: Many Bolivians say they would laugh at their revolving governments if their poverty did not make them cry. Boliva got its third Government in little more than a year Sept. 4 when the ruling junta, which less than two weeks before had declared its three members to be co-presidents, made one of them, Gen. Celso Torrelio, the army commander, the single President.

title: Dutch Jobless Up
description: The Dutch seasonally adjusted unemployment rate rose by 5,300 people in August to reach a new postwar high of 392,700 jobless, or 9.2 percent of the work force, the Social Affairs Ministry announced today.

title: COSMOS TOP ROWDIES, 2-0, TO TAKE SERIES
description: The Cosmos played a disciplined game tonight and defeated the Tampa Bay Rowdies, 2-0, in the third and deciding game of their quarterfinal playoff at Giants Stadium.

title: Redshirting Blues
description: Jim Dickey, Kansas State football coach, has said that he will redshirt eight seniors, including seven scheduled starters, this season. Redshirting, the wi thholding of players from competition for a season, is a common practice at many colleges, since N.C.A.A. rulespermit an ath lete five years to complete four seasons of eligibility.

title: SPANG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Advertising; People
description: * Karen Kershner named senior vice president of Golberg/Marchesano & Associates, Washington.

title: RUSSIANS IN ANGOLA- THIS IS NEWS?
description: South Africa is heralding the results of its raid into Angola as proof of the Soviet Union's strategic involvement in Southern Africa.

title: FEAR OF GAS PRICE DECONTROL CHALLENGED
description: If the price of natural gas is decontrolled, it will not rise to the level of world oil prices, concludes a report to be presented to a Congressional committee today.

title: BRENNAND-PAIGE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WALL ST. WARNED BY 2 G.O.P. LEADERS
description: Angry at Wall Street's skepticism to ward President Reagan's economic program, reflecte d in high interest ratesand the plunging stock market, Republican lea ders today threatened to seek new restrictions on the financial mar kets, such as credit controls and a windfall profits tax on intere st.

title: U.S. AIDE FAULTS SAFETY STUDY
description: A private study concluding that the chemical indust ry had the nation's worst health record in the 1970's failed to inc orporate ''the minimal requirements of objective analysis,'' a Labor Department memorandum says.

title: Bank Merger Talks End
description: The American City Bank and the United Overseas Bank of Singapore announced that they had ''mutually agreed'' to break off merger talks.

title: Around the Nation; Kleindienst Is Acquitted Of 2 of 14 Perjury Counts
description: A Superior Court judge today ordered that Richard G. Kleindienst be acquitted of two of 14 perjury counts after hearing the prosecution's case against the former United States Attorney General.

title: GRAND CENTRAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MRS. THATCHER IS TARGET AT BRITISH UNION CONGRESS
description: Embattled and angry unionized workers, facing unemployment of nearly three million, have opened their most determined attack yet on Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her austere economic policies.

title: Argentine Meets Pope
description: Argentina's Foreign Minister, Oscar Camillion, met with Pope John Paul II today to discuss his country's territorial dispute with Chile, Vatican sources said. No details were announced on the meeting, which was held at the Pope's summer retreat at Castel Gandolfo.

title: CASE CHALLENGING LINES FILED IN JUNE IN BROOKLYN
description: The Federal case that led to the disruption of today's primaries began last June 16 when a voter named Melville Herron of Brooklyn filed suit in Federal District Court. He claimed that the city's new district lines for City Council seats violated the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: POWER FAILURE DISRUPTS BIG BOARD AND AMEX
description: A power failure in the Wall Street area yesterday afternoon forced the New York and American Stock Exchanges to end trading 30 minutes early and disrupted business in the nation's financial center.

title: DELAY OF MONTHS IN BOTH PRIMARY AND ELECTION COULD RESULT FROM DECISION
description: The Supreme Court decision upholding the prohibition of primary voting in three of New York City's boroughs today could delay for months the nomination and election of many officials, election-law experts said last night.

title: Violence and Women
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Laura Cunningham's ''Hers'' columns are always exemplary, but the recent discussion of violence as experienced by women was even more compelling than usual (Sept. 3). Violence against women, and the taboo against women speaking on the subject, are curious factors in contemporary life.

title: WALLACE BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
STATISTICS SUGGEST U.S. FACES NEW DRUG ABUSE PROBLEMS
description: The growing presence of a high-grade heroin in some cities, an increase in overdose cases and new patterns of addiction are being reported by Federal, state and local officials, who suggest that drug abuse is again rising in the nation after declining for almost a deca de.

title: DISPUTED COAST ATOMIC PLANT NEAR LICENSING
description: The appeals board of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in Washington today cleared the way for final authorization to license a nuclear power plant that has been the object of a long battle between the company that owns the facility and groups opposed to nuclear power.

title: GUARD, BELIEVED A THIEF, KILLED BY TWO OFFICERS
description: An unarmed security investigator at a Bronx health food store was fatally shot Tuesday by two plainclothes police officers who mistook him for a robber.

title: Rothmans Sees No Takeover
description: Rothmans, the British tobacco company, dismissed conjecture that Philip Morris of the United States would take it over in the near future.

title: Index; International
description: Helen Suzman, apartheid foe, keeps battling on A2 James L. Buck ley leaves Paki- stan, refus es press conference A4 Around the World A5 Khomeini calls for stepped-up fight against guerrillas A6 U.S. outlines joint aid program for Caribbean basin A7 Bolivian labor leaders live on the run A12 U.S. signs two aid accords with Nigeria A13 Angolan says 15,000 South African troops remain in his country A14 Government/Politics Vernon Jordan resigns as presi- dent of National Urban League A20 Civil rights commission backs ex- tending Voting Rights Act A21 Reagan hears both sides on plans to cut military budget B11 G.O.P. leaders vow to seek power for Reagan to impound funds B13 House defeats effort to cut Fed- eral support for legal aid B15 Health/Science Cornell professors to check stu- dent's cancer findings A24 General Around the Nation A18 Louisiana opens first alligator season in 18 years A18 Eight nuclear facilities warned on reactor hazard A26 Panel told commercial flights will be held at 75% in 1982 A29 2 officers slay guard they mistake as a robber B2 Blackout knocks out some Wall Street computer systems B9 Education/Welfare Iowa school district rejec ts Bible as supplementary textbook A18 Striking teachers arrested briefly in Philadelphia A25 The Home Section Home On the vertical: An innovative three-level loft C1

title: Around the Nation; Shuttle Exercise Delayed But Goes Well Otherwise
description: Joe H. Engle and Dick H. Truly, who will pilot the space shuttle Columbia on its second mission, climbed into the cockpit of the spac e ship this afternoon for a final checkout.

title: Japan-E.E.C.  Car Trade Off
description: Exports of Japanese cars to the European Economic Community dropped in July compared with the preceding month and with July 1980, according to Japanese figures released today.

title: U.S. to Mourn Wilkins
description: President Reagan today ordered American flags to be flown at half-staff on all Government buildings and installations in honor of Roy Wilkins, the civil rights leader who died in New York yesterday at the age of 80.

title: Lucas Out of Net Plans
description: The New Jersey Nets are still interested in strengthening their backcourt, but apparently John Lucas is no longer under consideration, according to Larry Brown, their coach.

title: Indonesia Seeks Gas
description: The Indonesian state-owned oil company, Pertamina, will spend $200 million to explore for natural gas in West Java, a company spokesman said today. The g as, if found, will be supplied to industries now using oil as their basicfuel.

title: Cedeno Is Suspended
description: Cesar Cedeno, the Houston Astros' first baseman, was placed on indefinite suspension by the National League today for going into the stands and scuffling with a fan during the first inning at Atlanta Stadium last night.

title: Shavers in Comeback
description: Earnie Shavers, 37 years old, began a comeback today, stopping Mike Rodgers of Chicago at 1 minute 38 seconds of the second round in a scheduled 10-round heavyweight bout.

title: POLISH PARTY ASSAILS APPEAL BY UNION
description: Poland's Communist Party attacked the Solidarity union organization today, saying that its declaration of support for any independent unions elsewhere in the Soviet bloc was ''an attempt at interference in the internal affairs of other states.''

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bonds Hits 2 as Cubs Beat Cardinals, 7-3
description: Bobby Bonds hit two home runs for the second time in three games, and the Chicago Cubs had 14 hits to beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 7-3, tonight.

title: Japan Plans Coal Plant
description: Japan is planning to build a coal liquefaction pilot plant capable of processing up to 500 tons of coal daily, the semigovernmental New Energy Development Organization said here today.

title: Around the World; Shipyard Workers Jostle B ritish Defense Secretary
description: Scores of workers, angry at the prospective loss of 6,000 jobs at a naval maintenance facility here, surrounded Defense Secretary John Nott today, kicked and punched him and threw eggs and rocks in his direction until he fled.

title: Market Place; Bond Harvest In Retirement
description: HERE'S a paradox for investors who fear the devastated bond market. Individuals who are about to retire can invest their pension money in debt securities through an Individual Retirement Account and be virtually assured of doubling their money in five years.

title: 8 NUCLEAR PLANTS WARNED ON REACTOR HAZARD
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has identified eight nuclear plant reactors that it believes are most vulnerable to developing cracks that could let radiation escape into the atmosphere.

title: Hers
description: WHEN I heard she was coming to stay with us I was pleased. At age 8 I thought of ''grandmother'' as a generic brand. My friends had grandmothers who seemed permanently bent over cookie racks. They were a source of constant treats and sweets. They were pinchers of cheeks, huggers and kissers. My own grandmother had always lived in a distant state; I had no memory of her when she decided to join the household recently established for me by my two uncles.

title: Texaco Unit Cites Oil Find
description: Texaco Ltd., the British affiliate of the third-largest United States oil company, anno unced what it termed a ''significant '' oil find in the North Sea.

title: 2 One-Acters at the Frankel
description: The Gene Frankel Theater Workshop, in association with Carol Fink, will present two one-act plays about families - ''Mary Goldstein and the Author,' ' written by Oyamo, and ''Sunday Picnic,'' written and directed by Abbie Fink - beginning Oct. 2 and running for three weekends.

title: MARSHALL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Justice Dept. to Warn Youths Who Fail to Register for Draft
description: Young men who fail to register for a potential draft will receive a second warning before facing prosecution, a spokesman for the Justice Department said today.

title: GRAINING: WOOD WITH A FALSE FACE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores antiques for dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: HULL SHOWS SPIRIT IN RANGER TRYOUT
description: Bobby Hull, one of the most prolific goalscorers in the history of professional hockey, made his unofficial debut on ice as a New York Ranger today.

title: HARSH ARMY RULE IN BOLIVIA KEEPS LABOR LEADERS ON RUN
description: A dense haze filled a one-room back-street apartment here as three men, chain-smoking cigarettes, held a clandestine meeting.

title: ON THE VERTICAL: AN INNOVATIVE 3-LEVEL LOFT
description: LOFTS are truly all-purpose residential living spaces: They can be converted to suit a range of tastes and needs. Raw loft spaces can become extravagant single rooms or can be transformed into more conventional apartment layouts.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THREE-JUDGE PANEL'S DECISION ON PRIMARY IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Following are excerpts from the ruling by the special three-judge Federal court Tuesday night on the New York City primary: This three-judge district court has been convened to hear claims in three cases, consolidated for this purpose, that certain plans of the City of New York with respect to its primary and general elections scheduled for Sept. 10 and Nov. 2, 1981, respectively, violate Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, as amended.

title: Oil Output Cuts
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said it was studying ways to scale down its huge Pernis refinery in Rotterdam because of plunging demand for refined products. The refinery, the largest in the Netherlands, can process about 500,000 barrels a day of crude oil but is now operating at only 50 percent of capacity. The other European-based oil giant, the British Petroleum Company, has announced plans to reduce its refinery capacity in Europe and that it plans to close a major refinery in Britain.

title: COMPUTER AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Hartford Unit Stalled In Redistricting Task
description: The state's Reapportionment Commission, alternately meeting and recessing all afternoon, made little progress today in its effort to redraw the maps of Connecticut's six Congressional Districts.

title: UNITY BUYING SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CONSUMER DEBT ROSE DURING JULY
description: American consumers bought $1.95 billion more on credit than they repaid in July, taking on new installment debt more slowly but also paying off old debt at a slower pace than in June, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: B-After a $12,927,000 charge for the prior yr effect of a change to LIFO method of accounting; there were 13 weeks and 52 weeks in latest qr and yr, respectively and 14 weeks and 53 weeks in previous qr and yr respectively

title: Business People; W.& J. Sloane Chain Appoints President
description: W.& J. Sloane, the furniture and home furnishings specialty store chain whose parent, the City Stores Company, emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings in June, has named Daniel P. Barbo, 48, as president and chief executive officer. The presidency has been vacant since last February when Theodore Chaudron, 46, resigned.

title: KHOMEINI CALLS FOR THE CAMPAIGN AGAINST REBELS TO BE STEPPED UP
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called today for the increased use of force to subdue leftist guerrillas in Iran.

title: Maree Wins Mile In 3:48.83
description: Sydney Maree, a South African who is now a Philadelphia resident, outkicked Steve Ovett of Britain over the last 100 yards tonight and ran the fifth fastest mile in history at an international track meet. Maree, celebrating his 25th birthday, finis hed in 3 minutes 48.83 seconds, 1.5 seconds slower than Sebastian Co e's world record.

title: FLAGG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HOME IMPROVEMENT COURSES: FROM CARPENTRY TO MECHANICS
description: THEY can last a day or several months but whatever the duration, the home improvement courses around town this fall can help the curious city dweller get an apartment or house into shape. Here is a sampling of "how-to" classes. Registration is now underway. "Excellence in Woodworking," a three-day exposition featuring tools, machinery and materials of the craft, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Suspect Held on Coast In Firebombing of Car
description: A 20-year-old man was arrested Tuesday in Los Angeles in connection with the firebombing on Friday of an automobile near the Soviet mission to the United Nations in New York.

title: U.S. SIGNS TWO AID AGREEMENTS WITH NIGERIA
description: The United States and Nigeria today signed two technical aid accords and announced steps to improve commercial relations.

title: Neo-Nazis Preparing to Defend Rugby Springboks
description: A hundred members of a neo-Nazi group will ''use violence if necessary'' to protect a South African rugby team and its fans from demonstrators at a scheduled Sept. 19 match, a spokesman for the group says.

title: PROSPECTS FOR ALASKA'S GAS
description: Alaska could develop economically a ''world-scale'' petrochemicals and liquefied-gas industry as early as the late 1980's, according to a yearlong study directed by the Shell Oil Company and the Dow Chemical Company. The 10-volume study, conducted at a cost of $5.5 million, was released yesterday. ''These pro jects are economically feasible in the late 1980's or early 1990's, under the right conditions,'' it states. However, th e study cast further doubt on a multibillion-dollar pipeline to b ring Alaskan natural gas to the lower 48 states. The report specif ically raised doubts that both projects ''could take place at the same time'' without putting an excessive burden on Alaska's econ omy and construction capabilities.

title: Reginald Johnson, 78, Urban League Official
description: Reginald A. Johnson, a housing expert and former official of the National Urban League, died yesterday at the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home in Manhattan. He was 78 years old.

title: Israeli Gem Trade Protest
description: Israeli diamond merchants, hard hit by high interest rates and lagging demand for precious gems, threatened today to close down the industry here unless the Government granted them improved bank credit terms.

title: POP: SINATRA AT CARNEGIE
description: FRANK SINATRA has embarked on an 11-performance run at Carnegie Hall, and one, rather high-falutin', way to describe his work there Wednesday night would be ''great.'' Another way, perhaps closer to his own tough-guy view of himself, would be ''classy.'' The two adjectives aren't so far apart; indeed, Mr. Sinatra in his own purely American way makes them one.

title: In Need of Credit
description: Tucking his tongue firmly in cheek, Gov. Robert D. Orr of Indiana answered a form letter from the Harris Bank of Chicago offering him a credit card and asking whether the card could handle his credit needs.

title: DIGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After a tax loss of $95,000 for the qr and $629,000 for the yr

title: Tropical Storm Is Broken Up By Dominican Republic Hills
description: Tropical Storm Gert broke up yesterday in the mountains of the Dominican Republic, but it was expected to reorganize over open water and was still considered a potential hurricane, forecasters at the National Hurricane Center said.

title: Quotations Unavailable
description: Because of a power failure in lower Manhattan yesterday, the daily quotations for the publicly traded New Bond Issues were not available for publication.

title: U.S. OUTLINES AID PROGRAM FOR CARIBBIAN AREA
description: The Reagan Administration outlined a program for the Caribbean and Central America yesterday that emphasizes private investment to deal with the region's economic and social problems.

title: COMPUTERS LOSE DATA CAPABILITY IN POWER FAILURE
description: The blackout in lower Manhattan yesterday struck one of the nation's largest concentrations of computer and communications equipment, shutting down the New York and American Stock Exchanges and upsetting the operations of several major banks and brokerage houses.

title: Sundstrand Pact
description: The Sundstrand Corporation said it had entered into an agreement to acquire the Vandling Corporation of Van Nuys, Calif., for 58,950 shares of Sundstrand's common stock.

title: ISLANDERS UPROOTED BY A-TEST S FIGHT AID CUT
description: Isolation and hunger have apparently ended for the displaced people of radioactive Bikini Atoll in the Marshall Islands, but their American attorney says they now face financial problems and a legal struggle with the United States Government.

title: Eurobond Rate Sets a Record
description: Transcanada Pip elines is raising $100 million (United States) through a seven-year Eurobond carrying a record 17.50 percent coupon for United States dollar bonds, market sources said today.

title: THE DECLINE AND FALL OF TICKY BURDEN
description: If there is a time that Luther Burden will always remember, one that he will always cherish, no matter how things turn out, it is his boyhood in Albany. That is when he met Mike Elam, his closest friend.

title: Alfred U. Gets Collection Of British Literature
description: An extensive collection of modern British literature, valued at $250,000 and including first editions signed by prominent writers, has been donated to Alfred University byEvelyn Tennyson Openhym of Wellsville, a 1924 graduate.

title: THE REGION
description: Governor Byrne signed legislation creating a fund, expected to reach $6 million, to finance refuse recycling programs in New Jersey. The bill, sponsored by Assemblyman Daniel J. Dalton, Democrat of Camden, was signed during ceremonies at Glassboro State College.

title: SPANISH AIDE'S REMARKS
description: Following is the text of a statement yesterday by Inigo Cavero, Spanish Minister of Culture, on the transfer of Picasso's ''Guernica'' to Spain:

title: Metromedia Sells Station to Hearst
description: The Hearst Corporation has agreed to pay $79 million in cash to purchase KMBC-TV in Kansas City, Mo., from Metromedia Inc., the two companies announced. The sale of the station must be approved by the boards of both companies and by the Federal Communications Commission.

title: O'CONNOR HEARINGS OPEN ON A NOTE OF FRIENDSHIP
description: Judge Sandra Day O'Connor appeared today to move easily toward confirmation as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, emphasizing before a generally appreciative Senate Judiciary Committee her belief that ''the proper role of the judiciary is one of interpreting and applying the law, not making it.''

title: OSHAWA GROUP LTD reports earnings for 16 weeks to Aug 8
description: B-After special gain of $86,000...C-After special gains of $620,000 in qr and $1,376,000 in later period; the company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: c. 1981 N.Y. Times News Service
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Menachem Begin were reported today to have agreed on the need to strengthen strategic ties between the United States and Israel to counter what is seen as a Soviet threat to the Middle East.

title: AWACS SAFEGUARDS ARE OF USUAL TYPE
description: Some of the limitations on the use of five Airborne Warning and Control System Aircraft that the Reagan Administration wishes to sell to Saudi Arabia are what one senior American official calls ''standard strictures'' common to all sales of military equipment to foreign Governments, rather than special concessions by the Saudi Government.

title: Croatian Dissident Jailed
description: A Zagreb court today sentenced Marko Veselica, a Croatian dissident, to 11 years in jail after a seven-day trial. Mr. Veselica, 45 years old, was found guilty of spreading hostile propaganda in interviews with Western news organizations and maintaining contacts with emigre groups.

title: Pitcher's Father Dies
description: Charles Burns, father of Britt Burns, the Chicago White Sox pitcher, died today from injuries suffered when he was struck by a car last July 16 in front of his home in Birmingham, Ala.

title: Floods Damage China Crops
description: Flooding has wiped out more than two million acres of wheat and soybeans in Manchuria, the New China News Agency said today. About 2,000 people were killed by summer floods throughout China. The United States Embassy said it had donated $25,000 to help flood victims in Sichuan Province, which suffered the largest number of casualties.

title: MONEY FOR LEGAL SERVICES SURVIVES ATTACK BY CONSERVATIVES IN HOUSE
description: The House defeated a new effort by conservatives to kill Federal support for legal aid for the poor today. After the 272-to-122 vote against the amendment to a $8.8 billion appropriation for the Departments of State, Justice and Commerce, the House went on to pass the money bill.

title: SKETCHES OF 3 JUDGES WHO PROHIBITED PRIMARY
description: Amalya L. Kearse President Carter named Amalya L. Kearse, now 44 years old, to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in 1979. She was the first woman, and the second black person after Thurgood Marshall, now Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, to join that court.

title: Accountant Named To Head Korvettes
description: Michael Sherman, a 34-year-old certified public accountant, has been named chairman of Korvettes Inc. and assigned to the task of completing the liquidation of the retail chain, now operating under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act. Mr. Sherman, who joined Korvettes in 1980, was also named president of Gany Inc., the American holding company established by the Agache-Willot Group of France, which has owned Korvettes since 1979.

title: SOVIET SEES POLAND'S ALLIANCES IMPERILED
description: The Soviet Union accused Poland's independent labor union today of attempting to subvert the Polish Communists' Constitution and system of alliances.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Frontier Airlines said it was withdrawing its registration statement for a proposed public offering of $40 million of convertible subordinated debentures because of deteriorating market conditions.

title: TWO NEWSPAPER COMPANIES AGREE TO MERGE
description: Directors of the Minneapolis Star and Tribune Company and the Des Moines Register and Tribune Company have agreed in principle to merge the two companies, a spokesman for the Minneapolis company said today.

title: TAKEOVERS BY FRANCE APPROVED
description: France's new coalition Government of Socialists and Communists today approved a sweeping new nationalization law to take over 36 privately owned French banks, effectively putting 95 percent of all deposits under state control. The law also permits the takeover of 11 of the country's biggest industrial groups.

title: Home Beat; RUGGED PINE ANTIQUES
description: MANY antiqu es shops specialize in the rugged pine pieces that date from the mid- to late 19th century and early 20th century, and the current selec tion in the ninth floor Corner Shop at Macy's Herald Square is par ticularly noteworthy. English, Irish and Danish tables, hutches, corn er cupboards and chests, which have been stripped in acid baths, r ange from $195 for kitchen chairs to $7,500 for a spectacular E nglish breakfront that dates from about 1820.

title: Jersey Faces Oct. 1 Cut In U. S. Aid for Health
description: New Jersey will lose at least $13.2 million in Federal health-care funds by Oct. 1, the State Health Commissioner, Dr. Joanne Finley. said today.

title: Design Notebook; VICTORIAN MANSION THAT WOULDN'T DIE
description: EVERY summer renter knows by this point in the season that there are houses that sing and dance, houses that speak in a soft low voice and houses that just lie down and die.

title: U.S. to End Grain Quotes
description: The Agriculture Department said today that it would end market news quotations based on cash grain rail trading in Chicago next April 1 because the volume ''has declined so much it is no longer representative'' of the national grain market.

title: JORDAN QUITS POST IN URBAN LEAGUE
description: Vernon E. Jordan Jr. said yesterday that, ''based on the belief that it is time for a change, personally and institutionally,'' he would resign as president of the National Urban League to become a partner in a law firm in Washington. Mr. Jordan announced his resignation, to be effective Dec. 31, at anews conferen ce at the organization's headquarters at 500 East 62d Street.

title: NEEDLESS CHALLENGE TO A LIBYAN CLAIM
description: To the Editor:

title: COOPER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $8 million from sale of equity securities, a foreign exchange loss of $364,000 and extraordinary credit of $39 million from sale of internal medicine business; latest qr net is after foreign currency loss of $400,000 compared with a foreign currency gain of $41,000 a yr ago; latest 9 mos is after foreign currency loss of $485,000

title: Mets Win, 5-3; Wilson Injured
description: The Mets staged a remarkable rookie show tonight as they defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates again, 5-3, and crowded three other teams for the lead in the National League's East.

title: REAGAN LIKELY TO DECIDE TODAY ON ARMS CUTS
description: President Reagan listened today as his budget director and Defense Secretary presented arguments and counterarguments for cutting military spending levels in the fiscal years 1983 and 1984. But White House officials said the President was not likely to choose the extent of the cuts himself until tomorrow.

title: HISTORY OF A WEST SIDE SOLAR SYSTEM
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Margaret O'Brien Steinfels is a writer and ed itor. By MARGARET O'B. STEINFELS

title: News of Music; OPERA ORCHESTRA TO DO BOITO'S 'NERONE' IN CONCERT
description: MANY operagoers who have enjoyed the New York City Opera's production of Boito's ''Mefistofele,'' a popular item in the company's repertory for more than a decade, must have wondered about the composer's other opera, ''Nerone.'' Partly as a result of the work's tremendous scenic demands, productions have been scarce, but New York will finally have an opportunity to assess the music of ''Nerone'' when Eve Queler conducts the American premiere in concert form with the Opera Orchestra in Carnegie Hall on April 12.

title: TV: 'PRE-PREMIER' OF 'BEST OF THE WEST' COMEDY
description: THE official premiere date for ABC-TV's ''Best of the West,'' a new situation-comedy series scheduled for Thursdays at 8:30, is Sept. 24. Meanwhile, though, two ''special premieres'' of the show can be sampled tonight and next Thursday, both at 8 P.M. The pocketbook, as well as the heart, undoubtedly has its reasons.

title: PICASSO'S ANTIWAR 'GUERNICA' QUIETLY LEAVES U.S. FOR SPAIN
description: In deep secrecy and with no opportunity for farewells, ''Guernica,'' Picasso's monumental antiwar mural on loan to the Museum of Modern Art for 42 years, left New York for a final home in Spain last evening.

title: JUDGE FORESTALLS CITY BUS TIE-UP OVER SCHEDULES
description: The threatened disruption of bus service in Manhattan and the Bronx next week was sidetracked yesterday when a State Supreme Court justice entered a labor dispute between a union and the Transit Authority over the loss of paid lunch periods for some drivers.

title: A Designer's Complaint
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I was disappointed to read in the article ''Old House Decision: Restore, Renovate or Remodel?'' by Norma Skurka (Sept. 3) that my design, the significant work of my office and 20 working drawings signed by the clients for the Hoffman-Gaulke restoration in Salisbury, Conn., had been diminished to ''also hired ... to help.'' Although th e house may have ''talked'' to Mrs. Hoffman, Mrs. Hoffman talke d to me.

title: Petroleum Data Delay
description: The weekly American Petroleum Institute figures were not available yesterday because the gathering of statistics was delayed because of the Labor Day holiday. The figures are to be released today.

title: CA R SUBMERGED, DRIVER, 65, DIES TRYING TO SWIM
description: A thunderstorm that flooded highways and caused power breakdowns throughout the metropolitan region Tuesday night led to the death of a man in the Bronx after he was rescued from his partially submerged car.

title: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Scientific American increasing its advertising rates 11.6 percent, effective with the January issue.

title: CON ED BLAST SNARLS LOWER MANHATTAN
description: Electric power failed in much of lower and midtown Manhattan yesterday afternoon, blacking out City Hall and major buildings, trapping people in elevators, stopping and delaying subways and snarling travel on streets where traffic lights went dark.

title: Suit Mentions 3 Types Of City Political Units
description: There are three sets of political divisions mentioned in the legal challenge to the primary election in New York City. They consist of election districts, Assembly districts and City Council districts.

title: Critic's Notebook; MOONSTRUCK WITH THE GLORY OF SITTING FOR HOLBEIN
description: THE great scandals in the arts are a thing of the past - in the West, at any rate. The great passions, likewise. Rare in our time is the man who, like the French l9th-century composer Camille Saint-Saens, goes to Wagner's own theater in Bayreuth, sits down in his seat, hears the first measures of the prelude to ''Tristan und Isolde'' and falls in a dead faint at the sound of the first big cello entry. Today's audience knows the piece by heart from records and tapes and may even have been listening to it on head sets while walking up the hill.

title: WHEN PARTIES DEPRIVE VOTERS OF A CHOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Brezhnev Meets Cambodian
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, today received Pen Sovan, the head of the Vietnamese-backed Cambodian regime in Phnom Penh. The Soviet press agency Tass said the session with Mr. Pen Sovan, who is both head of the ruling People's Revolutionary Party and the Prime Minister, was marked by a ''friendly, heartfelt atmosphere.''

title: 20 Shops in San Salvador Damaged in Bomb Explosion
description: A bomb explosion damaged or destroyed 20 shops in an upper-class section of this capital city today, owners said.

title: HARVESTER TO DROP 2,000 TO TRIM LOSS
description: The International Harvester Company, beset by mounting losses despite a series of cost-paring moves earlier this year, announced yesterday that it wil l dismiss up to 2,000 managers and salaried employees in the next several months while reorganizing its five operating div isions into three more centralized units.

title: M.A.C. Plans Bond Offering
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation intends to proceed with a bond sale later this month, despite record high interest rates, officials said after yesterday's board of directors meeting. The new issue might go on sale next week, according to M.A.C.'s board chairman, Felix Rohatyn.

title: Errico's Sentence Is Cut
description: Judge Jack Weinstein of the United States District Court ordered Conn Errico's sentence in a horse-race fixing scandal reduced from 10 years to five years yesterday and offered the former jockey immediate parole if he cooperates with authorities investigating the case.

title: U.S. Justice Rebuffs Indiana in Rights Suit
description: A Supreme Court Justice has refused to free Indiana from spending millions of dollars to help cover the costs of desegregating public schools in Indianapolis.

title: Back to Show Biz
description: Before he was famous, Wally Amos worked for seven years as an agent with the William Morris Agency in New York and then spent seven more as a personal manager, a career he abandoned in 1975. Now, six years and a few million chocolate chip cookies later, Mr. Amos is getting back into show business.

title: MCENROE AND GERULAITIS REACH SEMIFINALS AT OPEN
description: John McEnroe, admitting he might have underestimated his opponent, recovered from a slow start yesterday and advanced to the semifinals of the United States Open tennis championships at the National Tennis Center.

title: Abroad at Home; GOD AND JONAH AT YALE
description: The prophet Jonah, the Rev. Jerry Falwell, A. Bartlett Giamatti and William F. Buckley Jr.: what an unlikely melange. But there they all were the other day, mixed up together in an entertaining and instructive episode -more instructive than at least one of them knew.

title: BOWNE & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 10 1981

title: A Vote Delayed, a People Denied
description: In place of the customary recapitulation of endorsements for today's primary election, we can offer only a bitter denunciation of the Federal court decision that upset this important democratic rite.

title: Coffee Nations Set Up Survey
description: The 47 coffee-growing nations in the International Coffee Organization set up a group today to survey world markets.

title: U.S. Cautions On Repo Ads
description: Savings and loan associations were cautioned today about wording their advertisements for high-paying retail repurchase agreements.

title: TONE IS TESTY AS FOUR MAYORAL CANDIDATES DEBATE
description: Before learning that there would be no citywide primary election today, the four candidates for Mayor finished a series of broadcast debates yesterday in the expectation that, sooner or later, voters would have to choose among them.

title: Essay; SIX GOLDEN APPLES
description: Here's good news: you don't have to break your head trying to figure out whether or not we should go back on the Gold Standard. Nor do you have to add the ''Eurodollar overhang'' to your list of worries, or wonder if opening the ''gold window'' while the ''window of vulnerability'' is still open will cause a military draft.

title: George Wallace Marries Again
description: In March Lisa Taylor, daughter of a wealthy Alabama coal mine operator, said in Montgomery that she would marry former Gov. George C. Wallace in late summer or early fall. Now they have gone and done it.

title: Around the World; French Airman Named For Soviet Space Mission
description: Lieut. Col. Jean-Loup Chretien, a 41-year-old fighter pilot, was chosen today to participate in a French-Soviet space mission.

title: Seaboard Allied, Cargill in Talks
description: Cargill Inc. and the Seaboard Allied Milling Company are negotiating the sale of Seaboard's domestic flour-milling operations to Cargill, company officials confirmed.

title: BANNER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After a tax credit of $2,539,492 for the qr and yr and an extraordinary charge of $5,889,492 for write-off of trans- portation operating rights before Federal income tax benefits of $2,539,492 for the current yr...C-After an extraordinary gain of $27,000 for the qr and $432,000 for the yr from an insurance settlement

title: G.M. Rehiring Seen
description: The General Motors Corporation will recall about 1,500 laid-off workers at its plant here next month to increase production of its new ''J'' cars, officials of the local United Automobile Workers union said.

title: ATLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After tax loss carryforward of $223,000 for the qr and $190,000 for the yr

title: Helpful Hardware; EXTENSION LADDERS
description: MORE and more homeowners are taking on repair and maintenance of their own dwellings, and one of their most important and helpful tools is a sturdy, safe ladder. We have found two ladder systems that can be used for both large and small jobs.

title: BARON RENGERS
description: Daniel Wilco van Welderen baron Rengers, a former official of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, died Monday at a Savannah hospital. He was 66 years old.

title: Jonathan Logan To Close Plant
description: Jonathan Logan Inc., citing losses from falling demand for doubleknit clothing, said it would close its textile manufacturing plant in Spartanburg, S.C. About 1,200 employees will lose their jobs, according to Richard J. Schwartz, company chairman and president.

title: NORDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
description: The company had unrealized foreign currency exchange losses in the latest qr of $1,011,000 against a gain of $1,434,000 in the yr-earlier period

title: Ban on Demonstrators At Court Found Illegal
description: A 1976 law banning all demonstrations in the Supreme Court Building or on sidewalks surrounding it is unconstitutional, a panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has ruled.

title: NASDAQ QUOTES INCOMPLETE
description: Because of the power outage in lower Manhattan, the volumes published for some NASDAQ over-the-counter quotations are incomplete. The New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange tables include consolidated trading through the early close of the New York exchanges at 3:30 P.M. and the close of trading at the regional exchanges, the last of which, the Pacific Exchange, remained open until its normal closing time of 5:30 P.M., E.D.T.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1981; The Economy
description: An electric power failure disrupted Wall Street yesterday afternoon, forcing stock exchanges to close a half hour early and upsetting the operations of some banks and brokerage houses. (Page D1.) Major department stores also closed early, major buildings were blacked out and subways were delayed. Consolidated Edison said a generator exploded from unexplained causes. (A1.) Backup power supplies at many companies eased the impact, however. (B9.)

title: PIERSALL TAKEN OFF AIR FOR REMARKS ON SHOW
description: The Chicago White Sox tonight suspended indefinitely the broadcaster Jimmy Piersall because of what the club considered Piersall's disparaging remarks about players' wives during a recent television interview.

title: Ley Hangs Up Skates
description: Rick Ley, the last of the original Whalers from the World Hockey Association, took a practice skate earlier this week and when he found ''my knee would not stand up under the pressures of playing pro hockey,'' he ended his playing days. Ley, the Hartford captain for the last six seasons, played in only 16 National Hockey League games last season before undergoing surgery.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Belk Stores Services, Charlotte, N.C., has named Robert N. Wildrick vice president and general manager of its New York buying office.

title: TO RELIEVE PRESSURES, TRY AN ISOLATION TANK
description: A scientist and a handful of entrepreneurs here are offering what they say is relief from urban pressures and from the force of gravity itself.

title: BRINKLEY DENIES HE'S LEAVING NBC OVER FEUD WITH SMALL
description: David Brinkley is leaving NBC after 38 years because the network picked Roger Mudd and Tom Brokaw as co-anchors for next year's ''Nightly News'' instead of him.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.00-20.50N.A. Not available because of a power failure ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: How to Weigh a Baby Elephant, or (A+B)
description: A=B Officials at the Bronx Zoo yesterday trying to weigh Astor, an elephant born Aug. 20 at the zoo. When the recalcitrant pachyderm refused to step onto the s [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] cale, he was weighed together with his mother (5,396 pounds). The mother was then weighed alone (5,033 pounds), allowing the baby's weight to be calculated (363 pounds).

title: THE PALESTINIANS ARE READY TO WAIT FOR A 'TRULY JUST SOLUTION'
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN THE LIGHTS WENT ON AGAIN
description: It ended with a sudden blaze of incandescent white, in shuttered stores, candlelit restaurants, dim apartment buildings and up and down New York City's streets.

title: GALLERIES DISPLAY CURRENT CRAFTS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Stone is a freelance writer with an interest in contemporary crafts. By MICHAEL STONE MANY of the leading contemporary American craftsmen are representedin a new exhi bition of handmade furniture at The Elements gallery, 766 Madison A venue near 66th Street.

title: Advertising; D.D.B.  Surveying 'Worries'
description: RUTH ZIFF has a hunch that, among American consumers, ''worries about the future loom larger, and in different directions, than they did in the past.'' And her colleagues at Doyle Dane Bernbach agree.

title: HIDEKI YUKAWA, PHYSICIST, DIES AT 74
description: Hideki Yukawa, one of the world's foremost theoretical physicists and Japan's first Nobel Prize laureate, died Tuesday at his home in Kyoto, the city in western Japan where he had set out to discover one of the innermost secrets of the atom. He was 74 years old.

title: FARM LOAN ABUSE IN SOUTH MAY TOTAL $100 MILLION
description: The Senate Small Business Committee has identified ''possibly hundreds of millions of dollars'' worth of improper Federal disaster loans made to drought-stricken farmers from 1977 to 1980. The panel o pened hearings today on questionable farm loans made by the Small Bus iness Administration. One committee aide said that the agency ''didn 't know silos from sows.''

title: CALENDAR: TOURING BOERUM HILL HOUSES
description: 16th Annual Boerum Hill House Tour, Box 212, Times Plaza Station, Brook- lyn, N.Y. 11217.

title: 17 Sect Members P lead Not Guilty
description: Seventeen of the 18 members of the New World of Islam who were indicted last month on Federal racketeering and bank robbery charges pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court here to all 19 counts in the indictment. The l8th man accused of taking part in a conspiracy to rob 17 banks and stores over the last two years, Keith Monroe of East Orange, N.J., has not been caught.

title: Japan Ford Sales
description: The Toyo Kogyo Company Ltd., the manufacturer of Mazda vehicles, said it planned to create a new sales network to market the Ford Motor Company cars in Japan. The new company, as yet unnamed, will sell subcompact models that Toyo Kogyo produces to Ford specifications for overseas sales, the company said. PU COMPNEWS FOLOS

title: DRINKING IN PREGNANCY: THE DANGER IS DISPUTED
description: A recent Surgeon General's warning that pregnant women should comp letely avoid alcoholic beverages may be exaggerate d, a researcher said yesterday. ''The danger from light drinking has not been demonstrated and should not be overstated,'' said Dr. Henr y Rosett, director of the Fetal Alcohol Education Program at Bo ston University. Light drinking is defined as less than one ounce of pure alcohol.

title: LAGGING JAMAICAN INVESTMENT
description: It has been almost a year since Prime Minister Edward P.G. Seaga was elected in a landslide victory, with a popular mandate to tilt the country's economy away from socialism and back toward private enterprise. Today, hopes are still high that the shift will bring prosperity back to the island, and indications are that the worst of a long economic decline may be over. As yet, however, the shattered economy here has shown few signs of revival, as potential investors continue to h old back until they are convinced that stability has really returned.

title: CHARLES RIVER BREEDING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
CAYMAN DISMISSAL OVER MUIR
description: The Cayman Island Reinsurance Corporation said yesterday that an executive committee had dismissed Michael C. Scott, Cayman's chief executive, because of the possibility that he had misled the directors in transactions involving John Muir & Company, a securities firm in the process of liquidation.

title: COURTESY OF A GIANT
description: To the Editor:

title: Merging Hurts F luor's Profit
description: The Fluor Corporation reported today that earnings in its third fiscal quarter, ended July 31, fell to $20.5 million, or 42 cents a share, from $36.2 million, or 75 cents a share, a year before. Revenues were $1.5 billion, up from $1.3 billion.

title: IOWA SUES FEDDERS ON CHARGES IT MADE DEFECTIVE PRODUCTS
description: The State of Iowa yesterday sued the Fedders Corporation, charging that the manufacturer of air conditioners and heat pumps knowingly produced defective products.

title: Casino Panel Corrects Errors
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The Casino Control Commission officially eliminated the surrender option in blackjack and approved new rules allowing casinos to set their own betting limits and entertainment policies.

title: UNITED TAKES CHANCE ON AIR EXPRESS
description: Faced with flat demand and continuing losses in its passenger airline operations, United Airlines is looking to improve its financial performance by entering the lucrative air express package delivery service.

title: C.A.B. Chief On Decontrol
description: The chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, Marvin S. Cohen, told a House panel today that the airline deregulation program should continue desp ite the air traffic controllers' strike.

title: ICE EXTRAVAGANZA VISITS THE GARDEN
description: IGNORE the title. The ice show at Madison Square Garden insists on calling itself the Ice Follies and Holiday on Ice Combined Shows, a mushy corporate appellation if ever you heard one. Think of it just as the ice show, and what's not to like about that? It is lavish and splendidly produced, a refrigerated hymn to tasteful glitz. It opens with girls in lime busbies and feathers; it closes with the band playing ''God Bless America,'' while everyone waves American flags. It doesn't choke you up, but it is fun.

title: Business People; Changes Set At Witco Chemical
description: The Witco Chemical Corporation has named William J. Ashe, 60, president and chief operating officer, effective Oct. 1. He will succeed Henry Sonneborn 3d, 63, who was appointed to the new post of vice chairman and chairman of the executive committee of the New York-based chemical and petroleum company.

title: Forced Busing Starts in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO (UPI) - Public schools opened here without incident despite a court-ordered desegregation plan that included the forced busing of some 3,200 students.

title: PRIMARY VOTING IN MAJOR RACES POSTPONED AS SUPREME COURT, 7-0, REJECTS CITY APPEAL
description: The United States Supreme Court turned down a request by New York City last night that would have permitted primary elections to be held today for Mayor, Comptroller and other local offices.

title: GIANTS GET STOKES, VETERAN TACKLE
description: The Giants, troubled by injuries and inefficiency on the offensive line, brought in help today. They signed Tim Stokes, an eighth-year offensive tackle dropped by the Green Bay Packers in training camp, and they said he might start Sunday against the Redskins at Washington.

title: PEORIA SALOON DEFIES CITY'S MODERNIZATION
description: Standing all alone in the heart of Peoria's downtown urban renewal area, Matthew Ryan's saloon is surrounded by a leveled acre. The saloon is the last bit of faded red brick on a block earmarked for mirrored glass and steel.

title: AVEMCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After capital gains of $98,000 for the qr and $135,000 for the 6 mos...C-After capital losses of $37,000 for the qr and $3,000 for the 6 mos

title: REMARKS BY KOCH AND AIDES ON CRISIS
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire, Deputy Inspector Robert F. Littlejohn, commander of the New York City Office of Civil Preparedness, and Mayor Koch at a news conference at 5:15 P.M. yesterday on the blackout:

title: Around the Nation; Nuclear Panel Is Cited For Disregarding Ban
description: A Federal district judge held the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in contempt today for disregarding his ban on secret budget meetings, but did so without reviving his earlier threat to jail the commissioners.

title: APARTHEID'S DIE-HARD FOR FIGHTS ON AGAINST ODDS
description: Over lunch in Johannesburg's financial district not long ago, a few executives toyed with a notion that constitutional and racial reforms might be imminent because a split in the governing National Party might force Prime Minister P.W. Botha to enter a coalition with the Progressive Federals. ''Helen will stay out, of course,'' one remarked.

title: C.F.A. Delays Deadline
description: The College Football Association yesterday postponed until Sept. 18 the deadline by which its 61 members must declare whether they will go along with the group's NBC television agreement or the National Collegiate Athletic Association's plan. The original deadline was today.

title: FOR A CURBED FED, NOT A GOLD STANDARD
description: To the Editor:

title: Rape Victim, 9, Helps Police Arrest Suspect
description: A 9-year-old rape victim who said she followed advice given in a television documentary helped the police arrest a suspect by recording a license tag number and describing the man, officers said today.

title: Powell Is Ailing For Jets
description: Marvin Powell, the all-pro offensive tackle, fell down a flight of stairs yesterday and became the latest victim in a series of off-the-field injuries that have affected key performers on the Jets.

title: CHILDREN'S EARNINGS: LEARNING TO SAVE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Victoria Balfour is a freelance researcher and writer. By VICTORIA BALFOUR

title: RAMADA ARRANGES CASINO REFINANCING
description: Ramada Inns Inc., which has had major cost overruns at its casino-hotel project here, announced refinancing steps today that it asserted would cost the company money now but improve chances for future profits.

title: Falwell Won't Pursue Suit
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, founder of Moral Majority, will not pursue a $50 million lawsuit against Penthouse magazine and two freelance writers, a spokesman for the evangelist said today. Mr. Falwell filed suit, which has since been dismissed, because the magazine published interviews of him by the writers.

title: RIGHTS COMMISSION BACKS VOTING ACT
description: The United States Commission on Civil Rights reported today that the essential goals of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 remained unfulfilled. It said that Congress should therefore extend the law, with some changes to strengthen its enforcement, for at least 10 years.

title: STAMPEDE INTERNATIONAL RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $295,666 in latest yr and $175,207 in yr-ago period

title: ARAPAHO PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
PLANTS AS THERAPY ARE MORE POPULAR
description: ALTHOUGH the pleasures of working with green plants have been known for centuries, the use of horticulture in therapy programs is now gaining professional status. Trained personnel working with the emotionally and mentally handicapped, senior groups, nursing homes, inner city youths, the blind and the disabled are ''converting persons with needs into resources,'' Nancy Chambers said.

title: Technology; Compressing Information
description: WNTD: Engnr. w/ exp. in cndnsing mssges 2 save $. When people pay to communicate by the word or line, as in a classified ad or telegram, English suddenly becomes very inefficient. All sorts of schemes can be used to get the same message across in less space.

title: Yanks Beat Brewers, 5-2, Then Lose, 5-3
description: Tommy John, on the eve of experiencing great emotional satisfaction, and Jerry Mumphrey, on the verge of experiencing great economic satisfaction, combined last night to spark the Yankees past the Milwaukee Brewers, 5-2, in the first game of a doubleheader at Yankee Stadium.

title: 'King of Hearts' to Open Equity Library Season
description: The Equity Library Theater will open its 39th season on Sept. 24 with ''King of Hearts'' by Jean Kerr and Eleanor Brooke.

title: FLUOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Around the World; Turkish Leader in Plea For Peace With Greece
description: Gen. Kenan Evren, the chief of state, declared today that Turkey ''does not claim an inch of its neighbors' land'' and wants to live in peace with Greece.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard OLD GLORY. An American Voyage. By Jonathan Raban. 409 pages. Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: Navy Job Nominee Is Named
description: President Reagan plans to nominate James F. Goodrich, board chairman of the Bath Iron Works, to be Under Secretary of the Navy, the White House announced today. A statement said that Mr. Goodrich, 68 years old, of Cumberland Foreside, Me., would succeed Robert J. Murray. The nomination is subject to Senate confirmation.

title: Ronson Unit Sold
description: The Ronson Corporation said today that it had sold its British subsidiary, Ronson Products, as part of a program of concentrating its resources on its more profitable operations.

title: AMREP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PRESIDENT WARNED O N HIGH RATES
description: President Reagan's senior economic advisers have warned him that continuing high interest rates could cut deeply into the economy across a broad front, weakening the economic expansion forecast for 1982 and driving unemployment higher.

title: Bridge: World Champion to Offer Free Workshop Tomorrow
description: Players with limited experience have an unusual opportunity tomorrow night at the New York Hilton Hotel. Judi Radin, who owns one world title and will try for another next month, will conduct a free workshop for players with fewer than 20 master points. The evening will include a lecture, play of pre-duplicated deals illustrating the points in the lecture, and a question-and-answer period.

title: New U.S. Head At Geers Gross
description: Peter W. Barnes has been named president and chief operating officer of Geers Gross Advertising Inc.'s United States operations, which report annual billings of $100 million.

title: SILENT BUCKLEY LEAVES PAKISTAN
description: Under Secretary of State James L. Buckley, who three months ago negotiated a $3 billion military and economic package for Pakistan, left for Washington from a military section of Islamabad airport today after failing to attend a scheduled meeting with reporters.

title: Around the Nation; Church of Scientology Wins U.S. Settlement
description: The Government has agreed to pay the Church of Scientology $13,900 in attorneys' fees and litigation costs to settle an old dispute centering on the Freedom of Information Act.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Tuesday on the opening of New York City's public schools attributed a read- ing score to the wrong school district. The average reading score of 30.6 was achieved by Community School Dis- trict 9 in the Bronx. District 8, also in the Bronx, had a score of 42.6.

title: CELEBRATES 94th BIRTHDAY
description: Alf Lan don, the Rep ublican Presidential candidate in 1936, receiving a gift yesterday from students at the school named after him in Topeka, Kan. Member s of the Landon Middle School b [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] and played ''Happy Birthday'' for the G.O.P.'s elder statesman.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 10, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Eighth emergency special session meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Morality Campaign
description: Since he has always had a reputation for moral rectitude, it may come as no surprise that Roger Staubach, who retired last year as the Dallas Cowboys' quarterback, has lent his name to a fund-raising drive for an organization that fights what it calls smut on television.

title: Toyota Ordered by Jury to Pay $5 Million in 1979 Crash Suit
description: A jury has ordered the Toyota Motor Company to pay more than $5 million in damages to the parents of three sisters killed when their Toyota was hit from behind and burst into flames.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 10, 1981
description: International Stronger U.S.-Israeli strategic ties will be devised to counter any Soviet threat to the Middle East, under an agreement reportedly reached by President Reagan and Prime Minister Begin in their first day of talks at the White House. (Page A1, Column 5.) Anwar el-Sadat defended crackdowns and the ar rest of 1,536 religious dissidents and political opponents. The Egypt ian President displayed anger and mordant humor in reacting to critic ism in the foreign pressover his drive to halt what he insists is ''s ectarian strife.'' (A10:3-4.)

title: TELECREDIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in Mar

title: AIR FORCE GENERAL ASSAILED ON IMMUNITY DEAL
description: In the second day of pretrial hearings, attorneys for Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke of the Air Force, who is accused of passing information to the Soviet Embassy in Washington, contended today that an Air Force general had unilaterally changed the conditions of an immunity agreement.

title: Home Improvement; FLUOESCENT LIGHTS HAVE ADVANTAGES
description: FLUORESCENT lights generally are more expensive to buy and install than incandescent lamps and bulbs. But they are much more energyefficient and in the long run actually cost less because the bulbs last much longer than incandescent ones.

title: Netherlands Agrees to Give Dutch-Built Fighters to U.S.
description: The Netherlands has agreed to an American request to deliver two or three Dutch-built F-16 fighter planes to the United States Air Force, the Defense Ministry said today.

title: COUNCIL WEIGHS $250-A-DAY FINE FOR LANDLORDS FAILING TO SUPPLY PROPER HEAT
description: Landlords w ho fail to provide heat and hot water for their tenants will be subje ct to fines of $250 a day under a bill approved yesterday by the City Council's Housing and Buildings Committee. The current fine is $25 a day.

title: LOUISIANA'S BAYOUS SEE THE BITER BIT
description: Paul Ronquille, who cannot see very well because he has cataracts, and Vanesse Dufrene, who cannot hear very well and doesn't say why, nosed their skiff up next to one of their traps this morning and found themselves in possession of an 11-foot alligator. Handicaps designating duty, Mr. Ronquille pulled on the line to get the creature to surface and Mr. Dufrene pulled on the trigger to blow it out of existence.

title: Output Down In 6 Nations
description: Foreign industrial production declined at an annual rate of 3.1 percent during the April-June quarter of this year, the Commerce Department said today in its survey of output in seven industrialized nations.

title: FRIEDA FISHBEIN, BOOK AGENT
description: Frieda Fishbein, a literary and theatrical agent since 1929, died Sunday in as nursing home in Manhattan. She was 95 years old and had suffered a stroke in February.

title: Credit Markets; INTEREST RATES DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates declined modestly yesterday, but for most credit market participants the day's real excitement came about 3:30 P.M. when a power failure hit lower Manhattan.

title: Fujitec in U.S.
description: Fujitec Company Ltd., a Japanese elevator and escalator manufacturer, said it planned to build a $30 million factory in Lebanon, Ohio, to make elevators and escalators for the United States market. The factory, to be completed by December 1984, will have an annual capacity of about 3,000 elevators and 600 escalators, the company said. The products would be sold through the company's wholly owned American sales subsidiary, Fujitec America Inc., the parent said.

title: LEISURE DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After an extraordinary tax credit of $38,000... C-After a tax credit of $484,000 for the qr and $1,739,000 for the 6 mos

title: Concert on Sept. 20 To Open Merkin Hall
description: A concert to mark the dedication of the newly named Merkin Concert Hall at the Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street, will take place Sept. 20 at 7:30 P.M. The hall has been n amed for Mr. and Mrs. Herman Merkin of New York for their endowment of the hall.

title: Holmes-Snipes Bout Set
description: Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council's heavyweight champion, will defend his title Nov. 6 against undefeated Renaldo Snipes. The bout, whose site is yet to be announced, will be the third defense of the year for Holmes.

title: SADAT, WITH ANGER AND SARCASM, DEFENDS HIS CRACKDOWN ON FOES
description: Before an audience of foreign journalists, President Anwar el-Sadat today strongly defended his recent crackdowns and the arrests of 1,536 religious dissidents and political opponents.

title: FLIGHTS LIKELY TO BE 75% OF NORMAL NEXT YEAR
description: Commercial flights will probably be held to about 75 percent of normal through most of next year as the Government rebuilds the air traffic control system with new employees, J. Lynn Helms, the Federal Aviation Administrator, said today.

title: Correction
description: A review of ''Golden Girl'' by Juan Marse Tuesday listed the wrong publisher. The publisher is Atlantic/Little, Brown.

title: Gardening; DRYING FLOWERS TO SAVE SUMMER BEAUTY
description: the last of summer's flowers - can have an almost limitless life if they are cut from the garden now and dried. This tradition to ''preserve something from summer's ephemeral beauty'' dates from Colonial times, when colorful arrangements of flowers, herbs and wild grasses were used to brighten the home in winter.

title: CITY IS 'VERY CONCERNED,' WITH RESERVOIRS AT 63%
description: With New York City reservoirs at 63.5 percent of capacity, or 17 points below normal for this time of year, the amount of rainfall in the next few weeks will determine whether a ''drought watch'' will once again be imposed on the city.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED ON RESTORING PALM COURT OF THE BILTMORE HOTEL
description: The owners of the Biltmore Hotel and private preservationists disclosed an agreement yesterday to restore the demolished Palm Court while retaining the East 43d Street entrance and the marble-clad main lobby as part of a new office building.

title: JAPAN FARMERS LEFT OUT OF ECONOMIC MIRACLE
description: Masayasu Okita's hands were paint-stained as he returned to his farm to pick fruit. He had spent the morning painting as part of a construction team and had not had time to clean up.

title: REPUBLICANS PLEDGE TO SEEK POWER FOR PRESIDENT TO IMPOUND FUNDS
description: Republican Congressional leaders threatened today to seek to give President Reagan limited powers to impound funds if Congress declined to approve additional reductions in the budget for the fiscal year 1982.

title: REAGAN AIDE MAY HEAD ARTS AGENCY
description: President Reagan plans to appoint Francis S.M. Hodsoll, a senior White House aide, as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, according to Administration officials.

title: Going Out Guide
description: A DANCE ENCORE

title: U.S. STUDY GROUP'S PROPOSALS ASSAILED BY COUNCIL ON CRIME
description: A Federal study group's recommendations on violent crime were assailed here yesterday by a public affairs group, which suggested that the proposals had been ''influenced by White House calculations about a politically attractive campaign'' but were unlikely to reduce crime.

title: PUBLIC FACILITIES HELD FACING CRISIS
description: A national crisis is developing because the nation's transportation, sewage, water and other public works facilities are wearing out faster than they are being repaired or replaced, urban affairs and economic development specialists warned Congress today.

title: WESTWOOD INC reports earnings for 13 weeks to June 27
Redskins Share Giants' Woe
description: If you think the Giants have problems with their offensive line, you should look at the Redskins, whom the Giants play Sunday at Washington.

title: JOHN W. STEVENS
description: John W. Stevens, a former American League umpire who was assigned to World Series play in the 1950's and 1960's, died in a Philadelphia hospital yesterday.. He was 69 years old and lived in Chester. Mr. Stevens umpired four World Series - in 1951, 1954, 1960 and 1967 - and six All-Star Games and on several tours in Japan. He retired in 1967 but continued to work with the league as an assistant supervisor of umpires.

title: Quaker Oats Starts 3d Line
description: The Quaker Oats Company plans to start a third business line, probably to grow from its current specialty retailing and mail order units, William D. Smithburg, president, told analysts.

title: Index; International
description: Harassed Sri Lanka minority hears call to arms A2 Iran names new police chief as Teheran clashes continue A3 U.S. reporter is ordered out of Egypt A3 44 senators reported to sponsor resolution against Awacs sale A4 Japanese Prime Minister views disputed Soviet islands A6 Around the World A7 Waldheim says he would welcome a third term A8 Turks worry about plans for re- turn to democracy A9 Bonn agrees to discuss U.S. troop support A11 Government/Politics U.S. reported working on plan to reuse atomic fuel A20 Immigration agency temporarily halts deportation of Haitians A24 Board finds canceled election also poses logistical problems B8 Senate again refuses to halt anti- busing filibuster B11 Judge O'Connor praised as she ends her testimony B12 General Around the Nation A16 Plan to share cleanup cost at Three Mile Island advances A21 Industry/Labor Volkswagen takes top position in fuel-efficiency ratings B10 List of Government ratings of fuel economy on '82 cars B10 Education/Welfare I.S. 231 in Queen appears to have qualfified for a $300,000 grant B2 Features/Notes Questions and answers on the New York City primary A1 About New York B3 Notes on People B19 Sports People D22 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 East Side, West Side - fairs are all over town C1 Guide to the pick of the region's apple crop C13 Governor's Cup yacht race set for tomorrow C28 Theater: Broadway C2

title: FILM: 'PIXOTE,' SLICE OF SAO PAULO LIFE
description: ''Pixote'' was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Filmsseries at the Museum of Modern Art. Following are excerpts from a review by Vin cent Canby in The New York Times on May 5, 1981. The film opens to day at the Cinema Studio I, Broadway and West 66th Street.

title: OCEANEERING INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After tax credits of $150,000 for the qr and $450,000 for the 9 mos

title: THE PITFALLS OF PUBLIC-SECTOR ARBITRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 11, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Eighth emergency special session meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: MAGICALLY, METS ARE IN A PENNANT RACE
description: In the strange arithmetic of baseball's split season, the Mets found themselves in a pennant race today as they headed for St. Louis and three games with the first-place Cardinals.

title: LEONARD HAS A FRIEND IN HEARN'S CORNER
description: He said he didn't want to be here for the fight he never wanted to happen, and certainly, Dave Jacobs, who used to help train a 14-year-old amateur named Ray Leonard, didn't want to be working in the corner of Thomas Hearns.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard THE CARE OF TIME. By Eric Ambler. 277 pages. Farrar Straus Giroux. $11.95.

title: PRESLEY COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Revs for the latest qr and 6 mos include $5.3 million from disposition of a school site resulting in a contribution of $2.1 million to net income

title: PLANS FOR OUTLAYS RISING IN STEP WITH INFLATION
description: Business officials are stepping up their plans for spending on new plant and equipment this year, but the total is likely to be little changed from last year after adjustment for inflation, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CHICAGO ARCHBISHOP UNDER U.S. INQUIRY ON FUNDS
description: John Cardinal Cody, who became head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago 16 years ago, is under investigation by a Federal grand jury here on charges of ''improper diversion'' of church funds, Federal officials said today.

title: Market Place; Liquidation Candidates
description: AT least tw o companies with stockpiles of gold and silver and one with major ho ldings of diamonds have a compelling reason to consider liquidation s oon under a little-noticed asset-shelter provision in the tax law.

title: Sports People; Broken Leg for Bowie
description: Sam Bowie, Kentucky's 7-foot-1-inch center, has been walking aroundon a broken leg and did not know it.

title: AN AIRLINE PRICE WAR CUTS FARES ON FLIGHTS TO FLORIDA AND COAST
description: An airline price war yesterday drove down fares between New York and Miami and New York and the West Coast. By the end of the day, a traveler was able to pay just $69 to get from New York to Miami in economy class and only $179 to fly from New York to the West Coast on a standby basis.

title: ART: DUTCH PRINTMAKERS OF 17TH CENTURY AT MET
description: THE title of the new show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art - ''Four Dutch Printmakers of the 17th Century'' - may not be one to make the pulse beat faster, yet in the works of art that have been brought together under this quiet rubric there are some very remarkable images, and in many of these images there is reflected one of the decisive historical changes in the outlook of Western art. It was in the Dutch art of the 17th century that the realist impulse - the tendency of the artistic mind to give priority to the observable over the imaginary - was manifested with particular force. Much that we still take for granted in pictorial art, especially the pleasure we take in an unidealized, realistic representation of the world around us, had its true beginning in the Dutch painting, drawing and printmaking of this great period.

title: 44 SENATORS ARE SAID TO SPONSOR A RESOLUTION AGAINST AWACS SALE
description: Forty-four senators have agreed so far to co-sponsor a resolution aimed at vetoing President Reagan's proposal to sell five Awacs planes and other military equipment to Saudi Arabia, according to Senate staff assistants.

title: No Headline
description: The Angolan Government estimates that 130,000 people were driven from their homes by the latest South African invasion of Angola, according to a senior United Nations official. The official, Stig Andersen, head of a United Nations disaster relief mission visiting Angola, said he hoped to fly to the southern war zone tomorrow to study the condition of the refugees.

title: A MUSICAL BIRTHDAY CARD TO HAYDN AND STRAVINSKY
description: THANKS to a lucky stroke of zodiacal chance, New York is about to savor the music of Haydn and Stravinsky in quantity during the coming season. In 1982, both composers will reach one of those roundnumbered anniversaries so beloved by music programmers - it will be Haydn's 250th birthday and Stravinsky's centennial - and the festivities in their honor will get off to an early start as the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society begins a weeklong Haydn-Stravinsky Celebration at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night.

title: TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BUSING FOES LOSE 4TH CLOTURE VOTE
description: The Senate refused today to shut off a three-month filibuster that is blocking anti-busing legislation. After the vote, the majority leader, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., tried to placate conservatives with an offer of debating time on such emotional domestic issues in November.

title: TV CLERIC EXPANDING NETWORK
description: The Rev. Pat Robertson, the polished, dapper head of the Christian Broadcasting Network, the most successful of the recent entries into religious television, outlined the rapid expansion of his enterprise yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the National Academy of Television Arts and Sciences at the Copacabana.

title: CANADA CUP DRAWS FEW FANS
description: Canada's hockey team may finally be establishing itself as the best in the world, but Canadians are not buying it. Thousands of seats for the Canada Cup games have gone unsold, and even last night's long-awaited confrontation between Canada and the Soviet Union did not fill the Montreal Forum.

title: A CITY UNWILLING TO FILL ITS OWN POWER GAP
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUTH ATLANTIC FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $752,638...C-After an extraordinary credit of $1,450,000

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Kleindienst, on Stand, Denies Perjury Charges
description: Former United States Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst testified in his own behalf today and broke into sobs as he denied the perjury charges aginst him.

title: ANTI-SEMITISM IN AMERICA: THE GOOD NEWS AND THE BAD
description: To the Editor:

title: ARTHUR SMITHIES, ECONOMIST AND EXPERT ON BUDGET, DIES
description: Arthur Smithies, a Harvard economist who was an authority on the United States budget and the fiscal policies of developing countries, died of a heart attack Wednesday afternoon at the Cambridge Boat Club after rowing on the Charles River. He was 73 years old.

title: PUBLISHING: VISIT WITH J.D. SALINGER
description: LAST summer several newspapers recounted how Betty Eppes, a reporter for The Baton Rouge Advocate, managed a brief interview with J.D. Salinger by writing him a letter and asking a clerk at the post office in Windsor, Vt., to give it to the reclusive writer when he crossed the Connecticut River from his home in Cornish, N.H., to pick up his mail. In that interview, Mr. Salinger, who has not had anything published since 1965, said he still had no plans to have anything published, but that he continued to write regularly for his own pleasure.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We do not interfere in the discussions between two branches of the American Government.

title: Business People; FORMER AVIS HEAD JOINS AMERICAN EXPRESS UNIT
description: Last month the American Express Company merged its credit card and traveler's check divisions into a single consumer financial services group. And now it has appointed James F. Calvano, a 44-year-old executive who resigned in August as president and chief executive of Avis Inc., as president of the group's U.S.A. unit.

title: U.S. JUDGE UNDOES POLICE INDICTMENT
description: A Federal district judge today dismissed brutality indictments against six New Orleans police officers and a former officer that arose in the investigation of the slaying of a policeman last November.

title: 2 MINISTERS CHARGED WITH CARRYING GUNS
description: At least 23 American ministers attending a religious convention in nearby Detroit have been arrested on charges of carrying firearms into Canada, the police here said today.

title: CABARET: SYLVIA SYMS
description: SYLVIA SYMS is taking up the cudgels for the women who write songs in her program at Marty's, Third Avenue at 73d Street, where she will be singing through Sept. 26.
