This approach makes for an interesting mixture of the familiar and the relatively unfamiliar, seasoned with Miss Syms's personal relationships with some of the songs during the 40 years that she has been performing.

title: Lanier Products
description: Lanier Business Products Inc. announced the introduction of eight new products, including two video display word processors. Other new products introduced were a family of microcassette dictation products, a telephone answering system and a small business computer. Lanier also announced it was expanding its manufacturing capabilities and producing both the computer and a new word processor at its Thomaston, Ga., facility.

title: AMAREX INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
About New York; 4TH-GRADERS AT P.S. 119 ENTER NEW TERRITORY
description: The public schools opened in New York City yesterday, just as schools always have. It is almost unnecessary to enumerate the old familiar ingredients. The book bags were unblemished and concave, because they were empty. The black-and-white marble-covered copybooks gave off the clean odor of paper unerased, pages ungraded, tests not taken. There were new shoes, new clothes, new haircuts.

title: PLAN TO CLEAN UP ATOM PLANT GAINS
description: Executives of the electric power industry today endorsed a joint effort by the industry and the Government to clean up the radioactive wreckage of the damaged Three Mile Island nuclear reactor before the end of the decade.

title: LITTLE ANTHONY TOPS ROCK-OLDIES BILL
description: The early years of rock-and-roll were a time of un-self-conscious mastery in a newly discovered and enriched field of the popular arts. All kinds of musical styles that had been kept out of the Tin Pan Alley mainstream - country music, blues, urban soul - suddenly found themselves in top-40's favor.

title: Notes on People; A Welcome Aboard and a Sudden Turnabout
description: The Moody College branch of Texas A.&M. University and James H. Petrie seemed made for each other. The Galveston school is one of the few in the country that trains merchant marine officers, and that's just what Mr. Petrie wanted to be.

title: Ford Says Carburetors Need Repair on 390,000 New Cars
description: The Ford Motor Company is telling owners of 390,000 Ford and Mercury cars that their carburetors need repair, but the automobile maker insists it is not a recall.

title: Arthur Casagrande, Teacher And Innovator in Dam Design
description: Arthur Casagrande, a former Harvard University professor who developed design principles over the past 40 years that changed the construction of earth and rockfill dams throughout the world, died Sunday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 79 years old and lived in Belmont, Mass.

title: SCRAP 'TRICKLE-DOWN' FOR 'OOZE-UP'
description: To the Editor:

title: Business People; INVESTORS GROUP SELECTS NEW LEADER
description: E. Robert Kinney, 64 years old, who will retire on Jan. 1 as chairman of General Mills Inc., will become president and chief executive officer of the Investors Group of Companies at that time. Investors Group is the nation's largest collection of mutual funds, with assets of more than $6 billion.

title: energywatch
description: SEPT. 4, 1981 Crude oil inventories dropped 4.9 million barrels to 371.7 million barrels, mainly because of reduced imports. Summer driving was lower than normal, causing gasoline supplies to rise 4.4 million barrels to 241.5 million barrels. Distillate stocks continued to increase in advance of the winter heating season, rising 2.8 million barrels to 207.1 million barrels.

title: MIME-COMEDY: THE ART OF BILL IRWIN
description: A CHANCE to rave over a performance is occasional, if not rare. Now that a fresh spirit of a mime-comedian named Bill Irwin is in town, the opportunity to toss out superlatives should not be passed up.

title: MACARTHUR MEMORIAL DEDICATED AT PENTAGON
description: Amid the boom of cannon and the beat of drums, President Reagan came to the Pentagon this sunny afternoon to dedicate a memorial to General of the Army Douglas A. MacArthur and to remind the nation that ''in war, indeed, there can be no substitute for victory.''

title: SARGENT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $1,013,000 for the latest qr and $855,000 for yr-ago period

title: Sports of the Times; THE QUIET WEAPON OF THE COSMOS
description: IT was a clear night in New Jersey, not nearly cool enough to justify Giorgio Chinaglia's long beige trenchcoat. ''If we lost, I would have worn it like this,'' Chinaglia told some friends after the Cosmos' 2-0 playoff victory over Tampa Bay Wednesday night - and he pulled the trenchcoat over his face, like a cartoon version of a spy.

title: U.S. MAY AID QUEENS RACIAL PLAN
description: Intermediate School 231 in southeastern Queens, the focus of a racial integration battle last spring, appears to have attracted enough white pupils this fall to qualify for a $300,000 Federal grantto promote desegregation.

title: CHEKHOV'S 'SHOOTING PARTY,' RUSSIAN STYLE
description: ''THE SHOOTING PARTY,'' a Mosfilm adaptation of Chekhov's littleknown second novel, written in 1884 when he was 24 years old, is so rich in its imagery and its sense of heedless, prerevolutionary decadence, and it's so full of associations to the great, far more c ondensed works Chekhov would write for the t heater a few years later, that to watch it is a fascinating, alm ost intoxicating experience. It comes close to being too much, in the way that an evening of drinking nothing but dangerously p otent liqeuers might be.It's less real than surreal - a hallucination . That's meant as high praise.

title: G.& W. Increases Two Stock Stakes
description: Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that it had increased its holdings of stock in both the Brunswick Corporation and the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company for investment purposes.

title: AMERICAN LEISURE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DEMOCRATS' STIRRINGS
description: Ever since the unhappiness of Election Day, the Democratic Party has been buffeted by a succession of uncontested ''truths'' -they include its imagined new, lowly place in the nation's ''realigned'' political structure and the supposedly quixotic nature of Democratic philosophy.

title: JERSEY TIGHTENS STATUTE ON ACTS OF DESECRATION
description: Governor Byrne traveled today to a temple in Teaneck that was once desecrated with swastikas and anti-Semitic slogans and signed into law a bill against such acts. Its sponsors called it the toughest in the nation.

title: Afghan Riots Reported Over Call-Up Plan
description: Street protests erupted in the Afghan capital of Kabul this week, including one in which four people were wounded when the police opened fire, diplomatic sources said here today.

title: ISRAEL AND THE U.S. SEE 3 LIKELY AREAS OF COLLABORATION
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States and Israel had agreed on strategic collaboration that would probably include joint naval maneuvers, the stockpiling of American medical supplies in Israel and joint planning to counter the Soviet Union.

title: Hatleigh to Study Sale of Oil Stake
description: The Hatleigh Corporation, a Torontobased restaurant and race track operator, and its controlling shareholder, 403372 Ontario Ltd., announced jointly that ''they intend to explore'' the possible sale of their combined 47.5 percent interest in North Canadian Oils Ltd.

title: PEAVEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Company said that the earnings were restated to reflect changes in accounting; in 1981, the company said the assets of its Brownberry division realizing a net gain of $1,132,000 or 20 cents a shr and established a reserve for a loss on disposition of U.S. Floor Systems Inc of $601,000; 1980 results include a nontax-deductible charge of $1,369,000

title: EGYPT ORDERS U.S. TV REPORTER OUT
description: A reporter for ABC News was given 24 hours to leave Egypt tonight after the Government showed other foreign correspondents television tapes in which the reporter interviewed an outspoken critic of the policies of President Anwar el-Sadat.

title: JACQUES LACAN, 80, A LEADER OF PSYCHOANALYSIS IN FRANCE
description: Jacques Lacan, a psychoanalyst who created a nd later abolish ed the Freudian School of Paris, died here yesterday. Hewas 80 years old.

title: POLICE OFFICIAL CHARGED WITH DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: The head of the Nassau County Police Academy was arrested yesterday morning on drunk driving charges after a car he was driving on the Long Island Expressway crashed through a temporary barrier and ran down a workman, the Suffolk County police said.

title: SERVICE CORP INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Medical International, Beverly Hills, Calif., said Dr. John H. Moxle y 3d, former Assistant Secretary of Defense for Health Services, had joined the company as vice president, st rate gic planning.

title: Richard Chamberlain In Warner TV Deal
description: Richard Chamberlain's production company, CHAM Enterprises, has entered into a two-year partnership with Warner Bros. Television. Warner Bros. Television will have exclusive rights to Mr. Chamberlain's acting services in series and television films.

title: REAGAN ORDERS CABINET TO ACT ON BUDGET CUTS
description: President Reagan today exhorted his Cabinet and the Wall Street financial community not to lose faith in his economic recovery program. He also parceled out to his Cabinet officers responsibility for making specific decisions on how to cut $74 billion from the budgets for the fiscal years 1983 and 1984.

title: KENAI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
THE COMMODORES BRING SOUL TO THE MUSIC HALL
description: soul sextet, who will be singing tonight, tomorrow and Sunday night at 8 at the Radio City Music Hall, are probably today's most successful black cross-over group, having scored hits in all three major categories - pop, rhythm and blues, and country. Their 11th album, ''In the Pocket,'' is now in the top 20, and the disk's first single, ''Lady (You Bring Me Up),'' their biggest hit in two years, recently hit the top 10.

title: HARASSED SRI LANKA MINORITY HEARS CALL TO ARMS
description: The latest outbreak of ethnic rioting in Sri Lanka, which claimed 12 lives last month, has subsided, but suspicions between the island's two culturally distinct linguistic groups remain.

title: Sports People; Jays Sign Espinosa
description: Nino Espinosa, the former Met released by the Philadelphia Phillies two weeks ago, was signed as a free agent by the Toronto Blue Jays yesterday. Espinosa, 28, a right-handed pitcher, was released Aug. 31 after compiling a 2-5 record and a 6.08 earned run average in 14 games.

title: Notes on People; A Tribute in Hartford to Ribicoff
description: The building in Hartford is very familiar to Abraham A. Ribicoff.

title: A GUIDE TO THE PICK OF THE APPLE CROP
description: The McIntosh apple crop has matured about a week earlier than usual in the orchards north of New York City, making the fruit available this weekend and for the rest of the month for pick-it-yourselfers, and providing an opportunity to combine a rewarding activity with some sightseeing in the countryside.

title: POLAND'S UNION MEETING ASKS FREE ELECTIONS TO PARLIAMENT
description: Poland's independent union, Solidarity, called today at its national convention for free elections to Parliament and local legislative bodies.

title: Chutist Lands Unhurt Atop the Trade Center
description: A 35-year-old unemployed construction worker parachuted from an airplane yesterday and landed unharmed on the observation deck of the 1,325-foot south tower of the World Trade Center. It was the first parachute landing on the twin towers.

title: At the Movies; Adventures of a teen-age film star.
description: KRISTY McNICHOL, everybody's favorite kid on television's ''Family,'' is 18 now, and she was in New York to hustle ''The Night the Lights Went Out in Georgia.'' She had come with an entourage (her boyfriend, Joey, who's also her hairdresser; her girlfriend Allison; her girlfriend's boyfriend, Mark), and they sat in their hotel suite eating cornflakes and discussing Miss McNichol's sore throat. Miss McNichol theorized about the throat's origin. ''Last night, we were having pillow fights and jumping on the beds, and by the end of it, I was sweating to death, plus having wet hair, and the air conditioning was blowing, so I woke up with a couple of lumps on the side of my neck.''

title: FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan ordered his Cabinet officers to make $75 billion in budget cuts for fiscal years 1983 and 1984. He also called on them and the Wall Street financial community not to lose faith in his economic recovery program. (Page A1.) The Administration has drafted a budget resolution that includes further cuts in education and other programs for next year. (D6.)

title: No Headline
description: A House Judiciary subcommittee today approved legislation authorizing a $170 million program of Federal assistance to local law-enforcement efforts.

title: PANIC IN REAGANLAND
description: The true measure of the economic and political trouble in which President Reagan predictably finds himself is not in the criticisms of ''stagflationists'' or ''discredited Keynesians.'' Rather it is in the panic of those who have followed Mr. Reagan not wisely but too well.

title: Eight More Cuban Refugees Are Freed From U.S. Prison
description: Eight more Cuban refugees were released yesterday from the Federal penitentiary here, bringing to 75 the number of detainees from freed in the last three weeks.

title: EGYPTIANS VOTE ON THE SADAT C RACKDOWN
description: Egyptians voted today in a nationwide referendum that was expected to endorse President Anwar el-Sadat's measures against Moslem fundamentalists, Coptic leaders and political opponents.

title: DEMOCRATS CHOOSE MATTHEWS TO VIE FOR TOP NASSAU POST
description: Nassau County Democrats voted today to endorse John Matthews as their candidate for Nassau County Executive to run against the Republican incumbent, Frances T. Purcell, in the general election. Mr. Matthews was the choice of party leaders.

title: Sports People
description: Ed Marinaro Marinaro Unscofflawed

title: Wayward Lass Scores
description: Wayward Lass reasserted her leadership of the 3-year-old filly division by catching Highest Regard, an outstanding older sprinter, and winning the featured allowance race at seven furlongs yesterday at Belmont Park. Heavenly Cause, last year's 2-year old filly champion, finished fourth.

title: MUSIC: MEHTA OPENS
description: IN past generations, one of the few works that conductors could depend on to set any audience cheering was Beethoven's ''Eroica'' Symphony, a musical force so powerful that it can survive almost any interpretation and almost any performance from mediocre on upward.

title: SUSPECT SEIZED IN 39TH ST. CRASH KILLING WOMAN
description: A 27-year-old man with a criminal record was arrested yesterday and charged with being the hit-and-run driver who killed a woman and injured three other pedestrians in mid-Manhattan on Tuesday.

title: Advertising; People
description: * John R. Cuneo has been appointed president and chief executive officer of Silton/Turner Inc., Chicago.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Athlone Industries announced its purchase of 10,400 shares of its own common stock in the open market for $269,100.

title: STOP & SHOP COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 15
description: B-Net loss; 1980 figures restated to reflect sale of meat packing plant

title: Advertising; Women In Public Re lations
description: IN the smoke-filled rooms of the Public Relations Society of America, the king makers - or, rather, queen makers - have done their work. Judith S. Bogart, now the society's secretary, has been nominated as president-elect.

title: Pan Am Unit Sale
description: Pan American World Airways Inc. said that it had completed the sale of its Intercontinental Hotels Corporation subsidiary to Grand Metropolitan Ltd.

title: SPAIN SAYS BIENVENIDA TO PICASSO'S 'GUERNICA'
description: At 10:08 A.M. the movers in blue overalls deposited the huge wooden crate - stamped with the admonition ''Use No Hooks'' in English - in the stone pavilion a block away from the Prado museum. Civil Guards with submachine guns looked on. A helicopter clattered overhead.

title: WALDHEIM SAYS HE WOULD WELCOME A THIRD TERM
description: Kurt Waldheim, the Austrian diplomat who has run the United Nations bureaucracy for 10 years, said today that he would welcome an unprecedented third term as Secretary General.

title: Sports People; Prison Term Resumed
description: George Rogers Sr., father of last year's Heisman Trophy winner, has resumed serving a life prison sentence after his parole was revoked by the Georgia State Board of Pardons and Paroles. Mr. Rogers, who was released last year after he had served eight years of his sentence for a murder conviction, lost his parole as a result of being charged with vehicular homicide, driving under the influence of alcohol and failure to obtain adequate automobile insurance. These charges stemmed from an automobile accident July 31 in which two persons were killed.

title: Auctions; Some wares of modest price.
description: THE fall auction season opens this weekend with sales and exhibitions of next week's events at all of New York's major houses. At least one is of major interest to collectors of the miniature Japanese carvings called netsuke. The presale exhibition of netsuke from the collection of the late Mary Louise O'Brien goes on view tomorrow, and the sale is at 2 P.M. next Thursday at Sotheby Parke Bernet's York Avenue galleries, at 72d Street.

title: Notes on People; City College Medal
description: City College's 1981 John H. Finley Medal for ''distinguished service to the City of New York'' will be presented Nov. 18 to A. M. Rosenthal, executive editor of The New York Times.

title: Parker Is Symbolic of Pirates' Problems
description: The organist still plays snake charmer's music when Dave Parker goes to bat in Three Rivers Stadium. But many people suspect that the cast and the music of the Pittsburgh Pirates will undergo a radical change before the next season.

title: POWER TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WITH VIOLENCE AT EBB, LEBANESE TAKE EXAMS
description: About 40,000 Lebanese high school students have just completed three weeks of tests, with many of them taking major risks to get to examination halls guarded by troops and security forces.

title: A FAULTY TRANSFORMER SWITCH TIED TO 4-HOUR POWER FAILURE
description: A faulty transformer feeder switch led to the explosion and fire that caused Wednesday's four-hour power failure in parts of lower and midtown Manhattan, fire marshals said yesterday.

title: DOW CLIMBS BY 8.56, TO 862.44
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges reopened normally yesterday after Wednesday's power failure caused an early closing and, afterward, equity prices rose briskly. Strong groups included energy, airline, brokerage, mining, defense, utility and semiconductor issues. The Dow Jones industrial average, scoring its best advance in five weeks, climbed 8.56 points, to 862.44. Gainers on the Big Board outnumbered declines by almost a 3-to-1 ratio .

title: VOLUME MERCHANDISE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Bridge: Triathlon in All Its Variety Will Start This Afternoon
description: An event that was developed in New York City and has found surprisingly few imitators, begins today at the New York Hilton Hotel. It is the triathlon, in which four players compete as a team, as pairs and as individuals, with overall rankings in all three categories.

title: MONTANA GETS FLASHY NEW YORK WELCOME
description: Bergdorf Goodman kicked off the fall fashio n season Wednesday nightwith a suitably lavish mega-fashion productio n for Claude Montana at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Lexington Aven ue - a literally explosive tribute to one of the most explosiv e young fashion talents around. The show proved not only that the arm ory is one the best places in town to give a party, but also that Mr. Montana's clothes, always exciting, are, in fact, quite wearable .

title: IRAN NAMES POLICE CHIEF AS CLASHES CONTINUE
description: Iran today announced the appointment of a new police chief as clashes were reported continuing between revolutionary guards and guerrillas in Teheran.

title: SOME ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS ON PRIMARY
description: The following are questions and answers on New York City's delayed primary elections. The answers were compiled in interviews with city and state officials involved in the case. Q. When will the primary be held?

title: SERIOUS CRIMES UP 9% FOR THE YEAR IN F.B.I. REPORT
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation's index of reported serious crimes rose by 9 percent in 1980 over the previous year.

title: THE PRIMARY CRISIS: DEGREE OF DANGER WAS UNFORESEEN BY KOCH OFFICIALS
description: Koch administration officials acknowledged yesterday that they had never even seriously considered the danger that civil-rights complaints could block the entire New York City primary. And they said they had left most of the important work to others.

title: Nicaragua Declares Economic Emergency
description: The leftist junta declared a state of economic and social emergency last night in an attempt to salvage Nicaragua's hard-pressed econony.

title: U.S. SAID TO PLAN ATOM FULE RE-USE
description: The Reagan Administration is devising a plan under which the Government would reprocess spent fuel from nuclear power plants for its own use, including making weapons, Administration sources and other officials said today.

title: ADMINISTRATION SUPPORTS END TO MINIMUM PENSION
description: The Reagan Administration maintained in Congressional testimony today that complete elimination of the minimum Social Security benefit would not have a significant adverse effect on any of the three million retired Americans now protected by the income guarantee.

title: ENERGY CRISIS: IS IT ALL OVER?
description: A PROMINENT energy expert, an oil company public relations man and a newspaper energy correspondent were recently dining in the sort of expense-account palace that the self-styled energy ''community'' has come, in recent years, to consider its due. The conversation took a disturbing turn.

title: City to Continue to Bar Out-of-Context Quotes
description: The city's Department of Consumer Affairs has decided not to change a regulation of the Consumer Protection Law regarding the use of out-of-context quotes.

title: The Times Square Gamble Pays Off
description: Conventional investment wisdom has long held that New York City should take whatever is offered for redevelopment of Times Square and the 42d Street area and consider itself lucky. So the city's decision to create a comprehensive redevelopment plan and invite competitive proposals involved both an act of bravado and a conscious gamble.

title: EXTENDED ENGAGEMENTS; 'Guernica' as Art
description: The value of Pablo Picasso's great ''Guernica'' is incalculable, both as art and as symbol. Picasso painted it in 1937, soon after the start of the Spanish Civil War, and asked that it not be returned to his native Spain until ''the re-establishment of public liberties'' there. Wednesday, 42 years after it arrived in New York, ''Guernica'' was finally sent to the Prado in Madrid.

title: Restaurants; Two kinds of food good for the soul.
description: THE restaurants reviewed this week both offer friendly and cooperative service and well-prepared, diverting food at very moderate prices. The simple, hearty and savory dishes originating with poor blacks in the South is the most characteristic soul food served at Jack's Nest on Third Avenue between 23d and 24th Streets, where the menu includes fried chicken, smoked barbecued ribs, ham hocks, fried fish, chitterlings, corn bread, collard greens, black-eyed peas and yams, to name only a few of the classics. But at the six-month old Souen on the Avenue of the Americas at King Street, another sort of soul cooking is based on the macrobiotic principles laid down by George Ohsawa as a guide to both spiritual and physical harmony with nature. Macrobiotic cookery features grains, vegetables, and noodle and bean curd combinations cooked in the Japanese style. Some fish and occasional frying apparently are permitted for the less orthodox devotees.

title: U.S., IN SHIFT, URGES HIGH COURT TO BACK AN ANTIBUSING LAW
description: The Justice Department urged the Supreme Court today to uphold a Washington State antibusing law that two lower Federal courts had found unconstitutional. If the law is upheld, it would end an integration program that was voluntarily adopted by local school boards in Seattle and two other cities.

title: Warner Cable
description: Warner Amex Cable Communicat ions Inc. said that it had purchased Kingman Telev ision Company Inc., a 7,600-unit cable system currently under constru ction in Kingman, Ariz., for an undisclosed price. Warner Amex, a jointly owned company of Warner Communications Inc. and the Ameri can Express Company, operates 144 systems in 27 states serving more than 800,000 subscribers.

title: Auto Layoffs Slip in Week
description: The number of auto workers on indefinite and temporary layoffs dropped slightly this week despite a 26 percent decline in production, caused mostly by the Labor Day holiday, according to industry reports released today.

title: EXTENDED ENGAGEMENTS; Critical Triumph
description: By popular demand, Regulation 520, a star of stage and screen since 1972, has been given a new lease on life.

title: Third World Lands Ask Boycott of South Africa
description: In a bitterly worded draft resolution, 45 third world countries called today for the total isolation of South Africa and a worldwide trade boycott to punish it for its refusal to grant independence to South-West Africa.

title: BONN AGREES TO DISCUSS A U.S. TROOP-SUPPORT PLAN
description: West Germany, after deliberating for 10 months, has given a reluctant and largely inconclusive reply to an American plan on cost and stationing arrangements for United States forces over the next 30 years.

title: Broadway; Coast directors coming east to stage plays.
description: TWO of Hollywood's best-known directors, William Friedkin and Robert Altman, will be working in the New York theater for the first time this season. Mr. Friedkin, who directed such hit films as ''The Exorcist'' and ''The French Connection,'' has already announced plans to stage Tom Kempinski's ''Duet for One,'' starring Anne Bancroft and Max von Sydow. This two-character drama, with Miss Bancroft as a violin virtuoso stricken with multiple sclerosis and Mr. von Sydow as her psychiatrist, will open Dec. 17.

title: Advertising; Carillon Assigns Bombay Gin to TBWA
description: Carillon Importers has named New York-based TBWA Advertising Inc. as the agency for Bombay Gin, replacing the Chester Gore Company.

title: SECRETS OF BUYING PERFUME
description: Sniff, sniff, what a terrific scent on that woman! You must get the name. You do get the name. Chop, chop, down to the store to buy the scent. And then, alas, it's like a completely different fragrance on you.

title: Sharp Cutbacks At British Air
description: State-owned British Airways said today that it would cut its work force by 9,000 employees in the next nine months and scrap its cargo fleet to stem mounting losses and to stay in business.

title: Advertising; Homelite and Agency End Relationship
description: Textron Inc.'s Homelite division, based in Charlotte, N.C., and Henderson Advertising of Greenville, S.C., have agreed to terminate their five-year-old relationship.

title: ASIAN IMMIGRANTS CHANGING THE CHARACTER OF CALIFORNIA'S CITIES
description: Bright-eyed Nhan Dung is fascinated by the words com ing out of the earphones he is wearing, even though he does not know what they mean.

title: SUZUKI VIEWS DISPUTED SOVIET-HELD ISLES
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki visited Japan's northern island of Hokkaido today in what seemed to be an effort to dramatize a long-running dispute over islands seized by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II in 1945.

title: F.T.C. STAFF IS REBUFFED ON CEREALS
description: An administrative law judge at the Federal Trade Commission has ruled that the agency's antitrust staff failed to prove its charges against the nation's three largest breakfast cereal producers. The staff had accused them of operating a ''shared monopoly'' in violation of Federal law.

title: ARROW AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: B-Net income...C-Includes cumulative effect of accounting change of $863,000

title: ABC NEWS PROTESTS
description: Roone Arledge, president of ABC News, protested yesterday ''in the strongest possible terms'' the explusion of Chris Harper. The protest came in a letter to Ashraf A. Gorbal, Egypt's Ambassador to the United States.

title: LINCOLN CENTER'S WORN PLAZAS TO BE RESTORED
description: The park, plazas and other outdoor spaces at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, where the pavement has deteriorated badly since the center was built 20 years ago, are to be renovated next year with $6 million in New York City funds.

title: Bernadette Devlin in France To Gain Support for I.R.A Fast
description: Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, the Irish nationalist, was expelled from Spain and flew to Paris today to seek support for the hunger strike in Northern Ireland.

title: METROCARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After extraordinary credit of $12,000 in the latest qr and $3,000 in earlier period...C-After extraordinary credits of $47,000 in the latest period and $6,000 in yr- ago 6 mos

title: SPARTAN MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for 13 weeks to Aug 1
Business People; LENOX NAMES PRESIDENT OF ITS KEEPSAKE BRAND
description: About $600 million worth of diamond engagement rings was sold last year to be worn by the nation's brides-to-be, yet only about 10 percent of these sales were in brand-name products. But Lance P. Wimmer, 37, the man Lenox Inc. just appointed president and chief executive officer of Keepsake Inc., the company that sells more than 50 percent of the brand-name rings, has high hopes of increasing this market share.

title: PLAY: ADAPTED MEMOIRS OF TENNESSEE WILLIAMS
description: IT'S no use pretending that the long dry spell in Tennessee Williams's career has ended with ''Something Cloudy, Something Clear,'' his new play at Off-O ff Broadway's Bouwerie Lane Theater. This autobiog raphical drama - seemingly lifted directly from the pages of his 1975 ''Memoirs'' - falls right into the traps that have capsized its recent predecessors. Here again are the stylized ghosts,the splintery sentimental vignettes, the watered-down appropriations from past tri umphs and the baldly announced (yet undramatized) themes. While we're often told that this work is about ''the exigencies of despair,'' the despair, if not the exigencies, vanishesbehind the de nse clouds of Mr. Williams's circumlocutionary theatrics.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; ETHNIC ARTS IN THE VILLAGE
description: The Balkan Arts Center has changed its name to the Ethnic Arts Center, and now it's changing its domicile, moving today to 179 Varick Street. As always, however, it will specialize in folk-dance classes, workshops, films and music, and as always it will propagate the traditional music and dance of the Albanians, Italians, Greeks, Poles, Croatians, Serbians, Rumanians, Bulgarians and Jews. Tonight the center will hold its weekly Folk Dance Friday, and tomorrow, at noon, 2 and 4 P.M., it will offer workshops in Rumanian folk dance. The instructor, Ancu Giurchescu, was for 25 years a dance researcher at the Institute of Ethnographic Research in Bucharest. There are also films at 8 P.M. tomorrow, followed by dancing at 9:30 P.M. Admission is $3 for each workshop and $3.50 for the films and dancing. The new site is between Charlton and King Streets, three blocks north of Canal Street in southwestern Greenwich Village. For information, call 225-0550.

title: PROOF SOUGHT INFLATION WILL BE CONTROLLED
description: The bond market has collapsed so badly in recent months that dealers no longer make any effort to mask their pessimism. Requests to discuss the bond market with traders are met with such responses as: Call back next year. What bond market? Or, are you wearing a life preserver?

title: Savings Unit Shifts Urged
description: Richard T. Pratt, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today that the nation's savings and loan associations will lose up to $5 billion this year and they ''can no longer afford to subsidize home buyers.''

title: No Headline
description: The Czechoslovak Communist Party newspaper Rude Pravo said today that Soldarity's pledge of support for free trade unionism throughout the Soviet bloc was an attempt to export counterrevolution.

title: IMMIGRATION AGENCY DELAYS HAITIAN DEPORTATION ACTION
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that it had temporarily stopped all deportation proceedings against Haitians not represented by attorneys.

title: Police Reportedly Use Force To Break Up Polish Crowds
description: The police used force to disperse angry crowds in the western Polish city of Konin today as violence flared after clashes between local youths and gypsies, the official Polish press agency said.

title: Jet Ground Game Up in the Air
description: Marion Barber tried to shake away the dizziness that returned today. He could not. He walked off unsteadily to the Jets' treatment room and sat down, holding an ice pack to his head.

title: AMERICAN BUILDING MAINTENANCE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July
TRIAL BUD GET PLAN WOULD CUT FURTHER INTO EDUCATION FUNDS
description: The Reagan Administration has drafted a trial budget resolution for the fiscal year 1982 that would require further cuts in education and other programs.

title: FOREIGN AUTOS RANK HIGH FOR FUEL ECONOMY
description: Foreign cars once again dominate the list of fuel economy leaders for the 1982 model year, but one American entry, the Chevrolet Chevette diesel, broke into the top 10, the Government said today.

title: Prisoner Seeks Execution
description: Colin Clark, a condemned prisoner who has dropped his appeals and seeks death in Louisiana's electric chair, has asked a Federal district judge to lift his stay of execution.

title: Institutional Holdings
description: Major institutional investors held an estimated total of $440.2 billion in stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange at the end of 1980, accounting for 35.4 percent of all listed stocks, according to a study released yesterday by the exchange.

title: Comfortable, in the Dark
description: Like Colette, who said she always spent her wars in Paris, a friend of ours claims she always spends her blackouts in pleasant surroundings. And, she adds, she's starting to feel guilty about it. ''In 1965, if I had been where I was supposed to be, I would have been stuck in my office elevator. Instead, two friends and I had sneaked out t o a movie on 58th Street. When the lights went out, one of them - an elderly gentleman of Edwardian sensibilities -said 'Let's go to the Plaza. They'll know what's happening.'

title: Campbell to Buy Snow King Assets
description: The Campbell Soup Company said that it had agreed to buy the assets of Snow King Frozen Foods Inc., a Pennsylvania-based producer of uncooked frozen specialty meat products, for an undisclosed price.

title: Ailing ICL Ltd.  In U.S. Link
description: ICL Ltd., Britain's huge but troubled computer maker, said that it had signed an agreement for technical cooperation with the Three Rivers Computer Corporation, a small computer maker based in Pittsburgh.

title: CORRECTION
description: An illustration provided by the Sas- son Corporation for the Advertising column of Aug. 28 was part of a mock- up for planned television advertising, and it incorporated clippings from publications depicting other manufac- turers' clothes. Sasson did not intend to present the designs as its own.

title: DENNY WINS, BUT ALLOWS RUN
description: John Denny's scoreless pitching streak was snapped at 342/3 innings tonight, but he and Dan Spillner combined to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 4-1 .

title: Woman Trapped in Pool as Ceiling Collapses in Great Neck Health
description: Club Firemen examining a decorative ceiling that collapsed yesterday, trapping Kim Homalla, 40 years old, for 90 minutes in the pool of t [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] he Sports Connection Health and Fitness Center in Great Neck, L.I. Mrs.Homalla, another patron and two employees were treated for minor injuries. The cause of the mishap was not determined.

title: UNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes pretax gain of $321,000 on settlement of litigation; the latest qr revs includes commission income of $696,000 against $564,000 a yr ago; the 1981 revs includes commission income of $2,809,000 compared to $2,731,000 in earlier period

title: News An alysis
description: When the City Council began to redraw the boundaries for its districts early this year, Mayor Koch made it clear that he would walk a political tightrope.

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE LOWER
description: Short- and long-term interest rates fell yesterday, but market participants agreed that trading was limited to speculators, with most institutional buyers waiting on the sidelines.

title: Warrant Is Issued for Rabbi I n Disappearance of Girl, 13
description: A warrant for the arrest of a Brooklyn rabbi was issued today after he failed to show up in State Supreme Court here to tell what he knows about the disappearance of a 13-year-old girl.

title: HOW TO SEE THE 'PEOPLE'S' YACHT RACE
description: New York Harbor will be a sparkling panorama of color and form tomorrow when a record fleet of 161 yachts is expected to cross the starting line off the Battery at noon in the eighth annual Governor's Cup Race.

title: Forecast on Cotton Rises
description: Cotton specialists in major American cotton-producing states estimated yesterday that 1981-82 cotton production would total 14.96 million 480-pound bales, up 2 percent from an earlier estimate of 14.66 million bales, according to a survey by Commodity News Service.

title: PUROLATOR GUARDS CARGO-HANDLING NICHE
description: The company helicopter connecting the headquarters of Purolator Inc. in Piscataway, N.J., with some of its outlying offices has been busy this week. At a series of meetings, executives have been planning company strategy and discussing the latest earnings figures.

title: WORLD OF SALLIE WILSON, A CELEBRATION IN DANCE
description: It isn't often that a dance summarizes both a personality and a career. But Patrice Regnier's ''First Solo,'' a celebration of Sallie Wilson to be performed by Miss Wilson herself tonight and tomorrow in a program by the Rush Dance Company at Marymount Manhattan Theater, is such a dance.

title: FILM: 'MADE IN U.S.A.'
description: ''Made in U.S.A.'' was shown as part of the 1967 New York Film Festival at Lincoln Center. Following are excerpts from a review by Richard F. Shepard in The New York Times on Sept. 28, 1967. The film opens today at the Thalia Theater, West 95th Street and Broadway.

title: Leaded Gas Futures Set
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange's board of governors voted yesterday to begin trading the New York leaded gasoline futures contract Oct. 5, according to Jayne Ball, senior vice president.

title: Notes on People; Back From a Honeymoon and Back to Reality
description: A pair of honeymooners returned to the United States yesterday and promptly ran into reminders of the realities of everyday life. The couple, Governor Carey and Evangeline Gouletas-Carey, were ending a vacation in Greece and Ireland.

title: DOLPHINS TRIUMPH OVER STEELERS, 30-10
description: David Woodley threw a 13-yard scoring pass to Tony Nathan and Tommy Vigorito, a rookie, returned a punt 87 yards for a touchdown to help the Miami Dolphins to a 30-10 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers before a sellout crowd of 74,190 tonight.

title: Pope Chooses Peace Theme
description: Pope John Paul II has chosen ''peace, a gift from God'' as the theme of the world day of peace marked by the Roman Catholic Church on Jan. 1, the Vatican announced today.

title: JETRONIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ALBANY'S COSTLY LEFTOVER FROM WORLD WAR II
description: To the Editor:

title: Wadkins Leads by 2
description: Lanny Wadkins shot a 5-under-par 66 today and took a two-stroke lead after the first round of the $300,000 Pleasant Valley Classic.

title: Israeli Gem Settlement
description: The Israeli Government, together with a number of banks and the diamond industry, will set up a multimillion-dollar credit fund to aid the nation's ailing diamond industry, it was announced today.

title: U.S. Imposes Sugar Fees
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block today imposed import fees on sugar in response to falling prices resulting from a potentially record world sugar crop. The fees are intended to bolster prices for domestic sugar producers.

title: Bond Set for 2 Suspects In Tucson Bank Robbery
description: Bond was set at $150,000 each today for two men arrested here yesterday on charges of participating in what the authorities said was the nation's largest bank robbery, the taking of $3.3 million in Tucson, Ariz., April 22.

title: REPUBLIC RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
News Summary; FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 11, 1981
description: International Planned U.S.-Israeli strategy accords were discussed by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. after two days of top-level talks in Washington. Mr. Haig said that the initial agreements would probably include joint naval maneuvers, the stockpiling of American medical supplies in Israel and joint planning to counter any Soviet or Soviet-backed intervention in the Middle East. (Page A1, Column 1.) Pressure for democracy in Poland accelerated at the national convention of the independent union Solidarity. It called for free elections and for the right of citizens to keep their passports until the expiration date. Under present rules, the document must be surrendered within seven days of a traveler's return from abroad. Also, a majority of the workers at the largest steel mill in Poland urged the dismissal of the plant manager. (A1:2-3.)

title: PITTSBURGH BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes an extraordinary credit of $134,754 from net operating loss carryforward for the qr and $242,723 for the 9 mos; yr-ago net and shr earnings have been restated to reflect a cumulative effect of prior yrs accounting change

title: Finder Keeps Bremer 'Diary'
description: A diary purportedly written by Arthur H. Bremer, who tried to assassinate George C. Wallace in 1972, belongs to Sherman R. Griffin, a worker who found it at a construction site, Circuit Judge David Willis ruled today. Mr. Bremer, 31 years old, is serving a 63-year sentence. Mr. Wallace, then Governor of Alabama, was campaigning for the Presidency at Laurel, Md., when he was shot. He is now paralyzed below the waist.

title: AGS COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
About Real Estate; THE SLOW TRANSFER FROM CITY TO PRIVATE OWNERSHIP
description: People living in tax-foreclosed residential property usually don't appreciate having city government for a landlord. Government can be slower than the private owner was in responding to their needs.

title: NATO'S POLITICAL GAP
description: President Reagan will soon be facing two sets of momentous decisions crucial to the long-range security and well-being of the U.S. and the world as a whole.

title: GENERAL MAGNAPLATE CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
400 ACRES FOR A BEETHOVEN MARATHON
description: This weekend's Beethoven Festival at Oyster Bay, L.I., will be a lavish outdoor supermarket in sound. There will be three evening concerts in the usual sense; but during the day tomorrow and Sunday, vi sitors to the Planting Fields Arboretum can stroll through its grounds choosing a variety of morsels from th e Beethoven repertory astheir wants and whims dictate.

title: GERMANY'S G.N.P. OFF 1.3% IN HALF
description: With its economy in recession, West Germany's gross national product shrank 1.3 percent in the first half of 1981, the Government reported today.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the guide to New York City cooking schools that appeared in The Living Section on Wednesday, an incorrect telephone number was listed for Sandra Smith's Culinary Concepts. The correct number is 864-1750. Also, Virginia Lee has canceled her Chinese cooking course that was scheduled to begin in mid-October.

title: REV. ANGELO MARTINI
description: The Rev. Angelo Martini, a Roman Catholic Church historian, died today after a long illness, the Vatican radio said. Father Martini, a 68-year-old Italian, helped edit an 11-volume collection of church documents that was issued during World War II.

title: Gold Mine Explosion Kills Three Men in Idaho
description: The bodies of three men were pulled from a gold mine today in the aftermath of an explosion that ripped through the operation last night, the authorities said.

title: Pop Jazz; JIMMY SMITH, ARTIST OF THE JAZZ ORGAN, PLAYS FAT TUESDAY'S
description: THE wooden console of Jimmy Smith's Hammond B-3 organ is weathered and chipped from constant loading and unloading. But the 55-year-old Mr. Smith, who is at Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue and 17th Street, through Sunday, seems none the worse for wear, despite a nonstop touring schedule that will take him to Japan soon and to South Africa, for the second time, in the fall. The other day, he was playing in the empty club with his accompanists, the guitarist Ray Crawford and the drummer Kenny Dixon, testing the sound of the room and trying to match the massive sound of his organ to it. And he was playing hard. Sweat poured as his fingers flew over the keys and his left foot pumped the organ's pedals.

title: FINANCIAL LEADERS REJECT G.O.P. CHARGES
description: Executives of Wall Street brokerage and investment houses said yesterday that Republican leaders in Congress were mistaken in casting them as the villains perpetrating high interest rates.

title: JUDGE O'CONNOR WINS PRAISE AT HEARING
description: Judge Sandra Day O'Connor, her confirmation to the Supreme Court all but assured, completed a second day of testimony at Senate Judiciary Committee confirmation hearings today.She answered questions about her views on subjects from criminal law to women in military combat as members of the committee praised her record, her stamina and her prospects to become the first woman to serve on the Court.

title: MOSCOW CALLS UNION SESSION AN 'ANTI-SOVIET ORGY'
description: The Soviet Union today accused Solidarity, Poland's independent trade union, of engaging in ''an antisocialist and anti-Soviet orgy'' at its convention in Gdansk and again said that that the union was preparing for a ''a seizure of power.''

title: LOSSES FORCE WIEN INTO TRUSTEESHIP
description: Moving to protect some 10,000 customers of a financially troubled brokerage house, M.S. Wien & Company, Federal Judge Frederick B. Lacey yesterday placed the old-line Jersey City firm in the hands of a trustee.

title: Cosmos Will Play The Strikers Next
description: The Fort Lauderdale Strikers, losers to the Cosmos in the Soccer Bowl last year, will play the Cosmos in the semifinal round of the North American Soccer league playoffs.

title: Midland Bancorp Details Bad Loans
description: Midland Bancorp Inc. said that its operating results for the third quarter will include substantial nonrecurring charges from bad loans that will result in ''a material loss'' for the quarter and all of 1981.

title: KEOGH PLAN'S NEW ATTRACTIONS
description: For the self-employed, or for people with any kind of freelance income, the new tax law greatly expands the opportunity to accumulate tax-deferred savings for retirement through a vehicle known as a Keogh plan. Beginning in 1982, a self-employed person may put twice as much money into a Keogh as the amounts allowed currently. In general, the new maximum will be $15,000 a year, up from $7,500. (In a specific kind of Keogh known as a defined benefit Keogh plan, the sums may go higher.)

title: 3 Air Force Officers Testify in Cooke Case
description: Attorneys for Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke of the Air Force elicited testimony today from three more officers who supported the defense contention that the Air Force offered immunity to the lieutenant, then broke its promise.

title: ART: PAUL BURLIN, A CASE OF DECEMBER FLOWERING
description: PAUL BURLIN (1886-1969), a participant in the 1913 Armory Show, was a Social Realist for most of his career, influenced at first by the Ashcan School and later by Cubism. Then, at the age of 70, he turned to Abstract Expressionism. In the works following the conversion, Burlin, though a native New Yorker, painted in a manner that was somewhat European, and he tended to harass his paint with gestures that often look more considered than automatist. But, possibly affected by Minimalism, he began to thin his color and simplify his shapes, achieving images that were both lucid and expressive.

title: Sports People; Imlach Seriously Ill
description: George (Punch) Imlach, the 63-year-old general manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs, was in serious condition at Toronto General Hospital yesterday after suffering chest pains during the Leafs' rookie training camp.

title: TOCOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Big Bad Wall Street
description: So now there is a Republican conspiracy theory: the villain is Wall Street. It's that recently sacred Republican cow - The Market - that's been spreading the economic gloom. It's a cabal of Eastern financiers that is driving up interest rates and undermining the President's program.

title: Dutch Parties Agree On a New Coalition
description: Leaders of three Dutch political parties reached agreement on a new left-of-center coalition Cabinet today after three and a half months of negotiations, a Government spokesman said.

title: Funds' Assets Up $2.48 Billion
description: Assets in money market funds rose $2.48 billion, to $152.8 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Since Jan.1, $78.2 billion has flowed into the funds, an average of $2.2 billion a week, the institute said.

title: KOCH IS OPTIMISTIC ON SOME PRIMARIES WITHIN TWO WEEKS
description: Mayor Koch expressed optimism yest erday tha t primaries for major citywide and borough offices - but not the Ci ty Council - would be held within the next two weeks as city attorn eys met twice yesterday in Washington with Justice Department lawyers .

title: FOR THE ELECTION BOARD, A LOGISTICAL PULLBACK
description: A New York City election is a major logistical operation. But the preparations did not culminate yesterday in the familiar chaos of a vote. Instead, at sites all over town, voting machines sat silent and unopened.

title: Honecker Visiting Mexico
description: Erich Honecker, the East German Communist Party leader, met with President Jose Lopez Portillo for two hours today at the start of his four-day official visit to Mexico.

title: Soviet Grain Sale
description: The Agriculture Department reported that private exporters have sold another 400,000 tons of American grain to the Soviet Union.

title: POLITICAL FUTURE IS WORRYING TURKS
description: A year after sei zing power, Turkey's armed forces are taking the first steps towar d eventually restoring civilian rule. Although no timetable has been given, the expectation is that general elections may be held in 1983 .

title: NEW YORK VOTING DISTRICTS
description: The Federal court ruling canceling yesterday's scheduled primary election, upheld by the Supreme Court, dramatically brought to a head a controversy that has simmered all summer. At issue is the City Council's redistricting plan that was signed into law by Mayor Koch in early June.

title: Homicide Trial Site Shifted
description: A change of venue was ordered yesterday in the trial of three Limestone County sheriff's officers charged with negligent homicide in the June 19 drowning deaths of three black youths. Acting on a defense motion, a Limestone County judge moved the trial to Falls County, a county clerk's spokesman said.

title: GELCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $11.5 million or $1.12 a shr from change in method of accounting for income on vehicles purchased for lease investment tax credit; 1981 first yr included currency gains of $18.1 million compared to currency loss of $1.2 millio in previous fiscal yr; current qr reported a currency gain of $7.6 million compared to a currency loss of $1.1 million in yr- period

title: JETS FAVORED, BUT GIANTS FACE STRUGGLE
description: The Giants and the Jets, who lost opening games to division champions, the Eagles and Bills, face more malleable foes Sunday. The Giants play the Redskins in Washington and the Jets play Cincinnati at Shea Stadium.

title: STRESS-RESPONSE CHEMICAL OF BODY DUPLICATED
description: A long-elusive substance that may be a key to the body's response to stress has been artificially duplicated by scientists at the Salk Institute for Biological Studies after they succeeded in determining its complete chemical structure for the first time.

title: LIST OF GOVERNMENT RATINGS OF FUEL MILEAGES FOR 1982 AUTOMOBILE MODELS
description: Following is a list made public today by the Environmental Protection Agency of its fuel economy ratings for 1982 model year vehicles sold in all states except California.

title: TV Weekend; THE GENE BOOM, DRUGS AND A UNION
description: TONIGHT at 10 on Channel 7, ABC News spends an hour in a documentary produced by Stephen Fleischman and anchored by Marshall Frady, surveying some of the ramifications of the geneticengineering revolution. The program begins with some of the promises, including new drugs that could expand the quality and length of human life. It ends with some of the moral and ethical questions being raised when, as one religious man puts it, ''scientists begin to be able to tamper with the kind of basic mystery of life that we have accepted as God's gift.''

title: The Evening Hours
description: T HE veiled woman dressed in black, looking as though she should be kneeling at Valentino's grave, led the group of 30 or so men and women into the Waldorf Towers suite, where they talked quietly among themselves until Betsy von Furstenberg screamed out a chandeliershaking ''The Cartier crystal apple! It's gone!''

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: YANKEES (AL) - Announced it would call up five players from Columbus after completion of the International League playoffs: Bill Castro and Gene Nelson, pitchers; Mike Patterson, outfielde [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] r; Brad Gulden, catcher, and Tucker Ash- ford, infielder. CHICAGO (AL) - Acquired Jerry Hair- ston, outfielder, from Mexico City of Mexi- can League for cash. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Aquired Doug Bair, pitcher, from Cincinnati for Neil Fiala, in-

title: NEW YORKERS REAP HARVEST OF AUTUMN FAIRS
description: AS if to make up for the lazy look of the city in August, New Yorkers in droves will take to the streets in celebration this weekend and so will a lot of their suburban neighbors. No one cause is prompting the merriment. Everything from autumn to Grandparents' Day will be hailed in a cornucopia of fairs and festivals ranging in size from a block to a mile.

title: Michael Harris Dead; Publishing Executive
description: Michael Harris, senior vice president of John Wiley & Sons, the publishing house, died Monday in Norwalk, Conn. He wa s 65 years old.

title: BORG, CONNORS WIN, WILL MEET IN SEMIFINALS AT OPEN
description: After all the speculation about Jimmy Connors playing too poorly this summer and Bjorn Borg not playing enough, the two tennis stars will meet tomorrow in the semifinals of the United States Open championships.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.00-20.50 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: VIDEO LOTTERY PLAN SCRAPPED
description: The director of the New York State Lottery said today that a plan to allow poker and other card games on computerlinked video machines in offtrack betting parlors had been dropped because the State Attorney General had ruled that he believed the machines to be illegal.

title: THE REAGANS SALUTE LIONEL HAMPTON
description: Lionel Hampton, whose jazz has given good vibes to Republican politics ever since he first campaigned for a young California Congressman named Richard M. Nixon, was at the White House today for what he called, with some emotion, ''the greatest honor I've ever had.''

title: Sports People; Campus Espionage?
description: The law library at the University of North Carolina is supposed to be used to study the law. But some people use it for spying, according to Dick Crum, the Tar Heel football coach.

title: OLD GRANDMASTER PROVES HE STILL HAS THE TOUCH
description: Samuel Reshevsky, a few months shy of his 70th birthday, will sit down today in Jacksonville, Fla., with two other grandmasters half his age for a playoff to determine the third American contender for the 1984 world chess championship.

title: DISPARATE INTERESTS JOINED IN FIGHTING NEW DISTRICTS
description: In the nighttime shadows of the United States Supreme Court building on Wednesday, three lawyers of disparate bac kgrounds who hadcome together in a common cause declared in virtual unison: ''This isa civil-right s victory.''

title: Notes on People
description: Albin Krebs and Robert McG. Thomas Leaving Hospitals With a Kiss and a Drawing

title: Fans Love, Batters Hate LaRoche's Lob
description: The way Dave Righetti, Rick Reuschel and Ron Guidry have been pitching, Dave LaRoche can't count on getting into one of the three games those three will start against the Boston Red Sox at Yankee Stadium this weekend. But if LaRoche does get called, Carl Yastrzemski and Jim Rice might be able to count on being part of baseball's newest form of entertainment.

title: HUBBARD REAL ESTATE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes $468,267 or 12 cents a shr from gains on the sale of real estate and a payment from the W.T. Grant bankruptcy estate

title: French Steel Output Off
description: French production of crude steel totaled 14.21 million tons in the first eight months of 1981, a decline of 13.9 percent from the corresponding period last year, the Steel Industry Association said today. Pig iron output dropped 15.3 percent, to 11.65 million tons. August crude steel output rose 1.2 percent compared with August 1980, to 1.44 million tons.

title: Solidarity Marches On
description: With breathtaking boldness Poland's union, Solidarity, has defied one after another of the Soviet strictures for Communist political life. The first truly independent convention ever held in Communist Europe has called for democracy, workers' control of industry and solidarity with free labor unions elsewhere. The Kremlin, as its ominous threats suggest, well understands what all this means. The Polish revolution is far from spent.

title: Sports People; Time Out for Music
description: Basketball coaches are noted for singing the blues. But Joe B. Hall of Kentucky, Bobby Knight of Indiana and Al McGuire, who coached Marquette before he turned sports broadcaster, are going country-western and plan to cut an album Monday in Nashville.

title: A DRIVE TO STOP CRIME
description: In a wild, midday chase in downtown Manhattan yesterday, Commissioner James F. Capalino of the Department of General Services used his city car to help pursue an armed robbery suspect who was fleeing on foot.

title: IN SINAI, JEWS DIG IN TO RESIST FINAL ISRAELI PULLOUT
description: Occupied Sinai, Sept. 8 - A movement of militant Jewish settlers determined to resist Israel's final return of Sinai to Egypt is growing amid the rolling dunes of the desert.

title: President Nominates Deputy Patents Chief
description: President Reagan has nominated Donald J. Quigg, retired patent counsel of the Phillips Petroleum Company, Bartlesville, Okla., to be Deputy Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks.

title: VAN EXPLOSION KILLS ARIZONA CHURCHMAN AND INJURES 3 OTHERS
description: A bomb blew up a church van belonging to a religious group that has been the center of periodic local tension, killing one man and injuring three others last night. The authorities said today that three unexploded bombs were found in the wreckage.

title: New York; THE STORY OF A DEAL
description: It might be helpful, amid the wailing and finger-pointing over the Federal Court's postponement of the city's primary election this week, to push aside the rhetorical underbrush and retell the story from the beginning so as to better understand the ending: to wit, the city's political club tried to cut a deal and got caught.

title: ALBANY SET TO ACT WEDNESDAY
description: The Justice Department last night gave New York City clearance to hold its primary elections Sept. 22 for all municipal and judicial offices except the City Council. Governor Carey said he would call a special session of the Legislature next Wednesday to approve the date.

title: NEW IDRIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $348,000...C-Net income and after gains of $24,000 from accounting change in qr and $98,000 in yr; the net income for the yr 1980 is also after a gain on disposal of discontinue operations of $183,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $562,000

title: Ottawa Group to Open Festival of Orchestras
description: The Nationa l Arts Center Orchestra of Canada will open Carnegie Hall's annual International Festival of Orchestras series on Oct. 9 at 8 P.M.

title: NATIONAL DATA COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net income; the 1980 shr earnings were restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid Feb 1981

title: FEDERAL PANEL PROPOSES TO RELAX SAFETY RULES ON GENE-SPLICING
description: TECHNOLOGY By HAROLD M. SCHMECK Jr.

title: A SURGE IN HOUSING IN HARLEM PROMPTS HOPES FOR A RENEWAL
description: Church and community groups are renovating thousands of apartments and newcomers are buying scores of private town houses in Harlem. City officials, housing experts and community leaders hope the activity is the beginning of a revitalization that could change the neighborhood's makeup.

title: CANADIAN SIX TOPS U.S., 4-1
description: Canada scored three goals in the opening period tonight and then coasted the rest of the way to defeat the United States, 4-1, in the semifinals of the Canada Cup hockey tournament.

title: Ovett Is Far Off Record In Winning 2-Mile Race
description: Steve Ovett of Britain scored a convincing victory in a two-mile race tonight. The presence of Ovett, holder of the 1,500-meter record, helped to draw a crowd of 17,000 to an international meet, sponsored by Coca-Cola, at the Crystal Palace.

title: Sound and Light Show At Dia Art Foundation
description: An electronic sound and light environment titled ''The Opening Chord From the Well-Tuned Piano'' and ''The Magenta Lights'' by La Monte Young, composer, and Marian Zazeela, light artist, will open tomorrow at the Dia Art Foundation, 6 Harrison Street. The hours are 4 to 8 P.M. on Thursdays and 2 to 6 on Saturdays, through Oct. 31.

title: Jan Stephenson, on a 66, Takes a 2-Stroke Lead
description: Jan Stephenson shot a seven-under-par 66 and took a two-stroke lead today after the first round of the 54-hole $125,000 United Virginia Bank golf tournament.

title: SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CHARLES SHELDON, CONGRESS ADVISOR
description: Dr. Charles S. Sheldon 2d, an adviser to Congress and a respected authority on the Soviet space program, died of cancer yesterday at Arlington Hospital in Virginia. He was 64 years old.

title: Letter: On Nuclear Power
description: The Trouble With Plutonium To the Editor : Although yo ur editorial ''The Wrong Kind of Nuclear Power'' (Sept. 2) makes the important point that commercial reprocessing of spent nuclear fuel would pose problems for controlling the spread of nuclear weapo ns, it understates the dangers that reprocessing would create. These dangers are so significant that no economic argument can justify c ommercial reprocessing. (There is also a serious question as t o whether reprocessing ever could be economical.)

title: Blaze on Freighter Fought
description: A burning Japanese freighter carrying 538 automobiles listed 12 degrees today after a United States research ship plucked 17 seamen from lifeboat 700 miles westsouthwest of San Francisco. Five crewmen remained aboard to fight a blaze in the holds of the Liberian-registered freighter Blue Hawk, owned by the Chung Gai Ship and Management Company and traveling from Japan to Panama.

title: 2 COUNCILMEN DEBATE REDISTRICTING ISSUE
description: Black and Hispanic residents have spread through New York City so uniformly that it is all but impossible to draw political boundaries to increase their numbers in the City C ouncil , Councilman Theodore Silverman said yesterday. Nonsense, s aid Councilman Gilberto Gerena-Valentin. Politicians, hesaid, had ign ored a huge rise in the black and Hispanic population and simply re arranged the lines to protect their own jobs.

title: ADVICE AND CONSENT
description: Benjamin Franklin jokingly suggested that the Constitutional C onvention let lawyers nominate Supreme Court Justices. As Madison r elates it, Franklin thought lawyers could be expected to select ' 'the ablest of the profession in order to get rid of him, and share h is practice among themselves.'' But the Convention gave the power tot he President, to be exercised ''by and with the Advice and Consent o f the Senate.''

title: EDUCATION DEPT. IS STOPPING FUNDS FOR A PUSH PROGRAM
description: The Department of Education announced today that it would no longer provide funds for an Operation PUSH program set up nearly six years ago by 4le Rev. Jesse L. Jackson to increase the academic performance of disadvantaged high school students.

title: STAGE: ISRAELI COMEDY AT LA MAMA ANNEX
description: ''A question must be faced - what is the human race?'' So goes an early song lyric in Hanoch Levine's ''Ya'acobi and Leidental,'' a contemporary Israeli comedy running at the La Mama annex through Sept. 20. For the next two hours, Mr. Levine forces us to face his answer to thi s question -and a happy answer it is not. In this playwright's scheme of things, to be human is to suffer an endless, humiliating b out with anxiety and loneliness. Life is a tedious journey that not even God, friendship, love or sex can redeem.

title: Ex-Claimer Is Now Winning Acclaim
description: ''You want to see him?'' Dominic Imprescia asked a visitor in Barn 16 at Belmont Park yesterday morning. ''Come on,'' he said, not waiting for an answer, ''let me show him to you.''

title: Rise Is Urged In Debt Ceiling
description: The national debt will surge nearly $75 billion above the $1,000 billion level in the upcoming fiscal year, the Reagan Administration told Congress today.

title: CAMPANELLI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Company reported a break-even second qr

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alco Standard Corp. said it had begun its previously announced tender offer to acquire the common stock of Strother Drug Co. for $16 a share.

title: News Analysis
description: Since the United States Constitution guarantees freedom of religion and separation of church and state, a Federal investigation of a prelate's use of church funds is raising questions in the minds of religious leaders.

title: Sports People; Not Bearish Enough?
description: Gerry Cheevers vowed at the opening of the Boston Bruins' rookie camp that his players would see a tougher, stricter style of coaching. ''I think I was too passive,'' Cheevers said of his first coaching season.

title: Results of Bid for Page
description: The Guthrie Corporation said today that its cash tender offer of $57.65 a share for Page Airways of Rochester had reulted in acceptances covering 1.04 million shares, or 88.3 percent of the total shares outstanding. The offer remains open until Sept. 25, it added.

title: REJUVENATED 'NAPOLEON' SHOWN IN ROMAN RUINS
description: Abel Gance's epic silent film ''Napoleon,'' first shown in Paris 54 years ago and reconstituted recently from butchered prints found around the world, had a highly successful modern-day European premiere last night nestled amid the ruins of ancient Rome in a festival-like atmosphere that was not even dampened by sporadic rain and lack of enough seats.

title: PRESIDENT WEIGHING TWO IDEAS TO SPEED CUTBACKS IN BUDGET
description: The Administration is considering two le gislative measures that would bypass the normal appropriations pr ocess. This would force Congress to take a single vote on the sp ending cuts necessary to hold the budget deficit for the fiscal ye ar 1982 to the level favored by President Reagan.

title: Texas Air Nears Co ntinental Merger
description: Texas International Airlines, coming closer in its effort to take over Continental Air Lines, said today that it had bought an additional 300,000 shares of Continental stock, raising its holdings to 50.3 percent, a majority.

title: Soviet Delays U.N. Vote On South African Issue
description: The General Assembly was set to vote tonight on a harsh resolution to isolate South Africa when the Soviet Union discovered that the language was too strong for Moscow to accept. The balloting was put off until Monday.

title: Index; International
description: Militant Jewish settlers in Sinai are digging in 2 Pentagon aide warns of repercus- sions if Awacs sale is blocked 3 Senator refus es to end opposition to Awacs sa le 3 U.S. concerned about commercial development of rockets 4 Around the World 5 Government/Politics Education Dept. cuts off funds for PUSH-EXCEL program 6 Westchester County and Town of Rye sign accord on airport 26 Matthews, winner in Democratic primary, takes on Purcell 26 New York City to sell $200 million in notes next Wednesday 27 Thomas P.
