Sheldon, authority on Soviet space program 16 Zelina Brunschwig, leader in the design comm unity 16 Jane West, editor and publisher 16 900 attend funeral in Manhattan for Roy Wilkins 16 Sports Miss Navratilova beats Mrs. Lloyd to gain final at Open 17 Cards defeat Mets, 4-2 17 Yanks beat Red Sox, 4-1, as Righ- etti strikes out 11 17 Canada ousts U.S. in cup hockey, 4-1 17 Timely Writer, once a claimer, now winning acclaim 17 Miss Potter finds gain in her loss to Miss Austin 19 Ira Berkow on food for the pro football bettor 19 Strikers, Cosmos' next opponent, a hot playoff club 19 Cubs win 4th straight, beating Expos, 6-5 20 Features/Notes Going Out Guide 12 Notes on People 14 Saturday News Quiz 15 Sports People 19 Health/Science F.D.A. approves an artificial heart implantation 7 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes a $2.6 million capital gain resulting from the compa sale of 370,000 shrs of Boston Digital Corp stock

title: SEES SIGNS OF ANTITRUST VIOLATIONS
description: A Federal judge refused today to dismiss the Justice Department's historic antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. He said the evidence he had heard so far showed that the ''Bell System has violated the antitrust laws in a number of ways over a lengthy period of time.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.00-20.50 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. Nathaniel Crosby, son of the late Bing Crosby. 2. Delegates at a convention held by Poland's Sol idarity union voted to send workers in other Soviet bloc countries a message voicing suppo rt for their efforts to set up their own independent unions.

title: Cedeno Suspension Lifte d
description: Cesar Cedeno of the Houston Astros was fined $5,000 but his suspension was canceled yesterday by the president of the National League, who partly exonerated him for entering the stands to confront a fan in Atlanta Tuesday night.

title: Cubs Top Expos, 6-5, for Fourth Straight
description: Ken Reitz drove in two runs with a home run and a sacrifice fly, and Bill Buckner had a single and triple today to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 6-5 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: ROBERT P. ANDERSON
description: Robert P. Anderson, retired news editor of The Baltimore Sun and a former Associated Press bureau chief, died at a nursing home Wednesday after a long illness.

title: Sports People; From Air to Ground
description: Last year, Billy Allen was an Air Force sergeant training dogs for military police work at Lakenheath Air Base in England and leading the base football team to the Air Force European championship. Tonight, Allen will make his first start at tailback for Florida State, against Memphis State.

title: RECORD PAYMENTS DEFICIT IS FORECAST
description: A senior Reagan Administration official said today that high United States interest rates were causing ''extensive damage'' to the American economy and would help push the United States into a record balance-of-payments deficit of $15 billion to $20 billion next year, weakening the dollar.

title: ZELINA COMEGYS BRUNSCHWIG, CHAIRMAN OF FABRIC COMPANY
description: Zelina Comegys Brunschwig, a leader in the design community and chairman of the board of Brunschwig & Fils Inc., a converter and importer of decorative fabrics and wall coverings, died Thursday at her Manhattan home. She was 84 years old.

title: Around the Nation; Nabisco to Pay $5 Million In Sex Rights Agreement
description: In one of the largest sex discrimination cases, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission announced today that a $5 million settlement had been reached with Nabisco Inc., one of the nation's major food and baking concerns.

title: CARDINAL CODY INVESTIGATION IS NOW THE TALK OF CHICAGO
description: At noon the pealing bells atop Holy Name Cathedral in downtown Chicago welcomed 75 people to the spiritual headquarters of John Cardinal Cody. Genuflecting and making the sign of the cross, they went about the daily mass as if nothing had happened. The only hint of crisis was in the homily.

title: Folger's Producer Quits In Anger Over Budget
description: Lewis W. Scheeder, producer for the last eight years of the Folger Theater Group, today announced his resignation in protest over a sharp cut in the budget of the troupe, one of the country's leading Shakespearean theaters.

title: CABARET: AL CARMINES PERFORMS AT COOKERY
description: For a man who was a full-time minister at the Judson Memorial Church over the past 20 years, the Rev. Al Carmines often appeared to have more relationship to show business than to religion as he wrote scores for and performed in a seemingly endless succession of musicals for which he won three Obies, a Drama Desk Award and the Vernon Rice Award.

title: SENATOR REJECTS REAGAN APPEAL ON SALE TO SAUDIS
description: President Reagan intervened personally today in the controversy over his proposal to sell Awacs surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia, urging a Republican Senator to stop his effort to enlist a majority of the Senate as sponsors of a resolution aimed at blocking the sale.

title: Sports of the Times; FOOD FOR THE FOOTBALL BETTOR
description: FOR years, the National Football League headquarters has issued a strange news release before the weekend glut of games. It details player injuries. The wire services carry it, many newspapers publish it, and some news broadcasts relate parts of it.

title: 3 Are Said to Top List For Humanities Chief
description: Three persons have emerged as leading candidates to become the next chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, a White House official said yesterday.

title: C.A.B. Delays Airline Ruling
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board, acting on a request from President Reagan, decided today to postpone an order that would end the antitrust immunity that American trans-Atlantic air carriers have had for decades. The C.A.B. had been expected next Tuesday to order that the airlines no longer be exempt from antitrust laws.

title: Notes on People; A 50th Birthday That Would Be Hard to Forget
description: When John Marshall breaks solemn promises, he breaks them in a big way. Before Mr. Marshall's wife, Lea, turned 50 years old Tuesday, she made him promise he would not say a word about it.

title: Toyota Prices Up
description: The Toyota Motor Company Ltd. said its 1982 cars and trucks will cost 6.8 percent, or an average of $451 a vehicle, more than 1981 models.

title: Going Out Guide
description: ANCHORS AWAY

title: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1981; Companies
description: The judge in the A.T.& T. antitrust case rejected the company's motion to dismiss the Government's charges. The judge, using strong language, said evidence he had heard so far showed that the Bell System had violated the law in several ways over a long time. The company stressed that the ruling was not a finding of guilt. (Page 1.)

title: The Week of the Un-election
description: When Congress passed the Voting Rights Act in 1965, the inspiration was the South, not the South Bronx. But the letter of the law also applied in a few places outside the South - including New York City. New York's generally excellent record of encouraging minority groups to vote does not excuse the city from clearing election law changes with the Department of Justice. But it does inspire reflection on the Week of the Un-election.

title: M.T.A. PLAN TO SAVE MONEY: SELL BUSES, RENT THEM BACK
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced plans yesterday to sell 620 buses and 12 commuter rail cars to private corporations and then lease them back in a novel move that would provide tax benefits to the corporations and savings to the authority.

title: Notes on People; Diller Undisguised
description: About a year ago Phyllis Diller, the comedian, asked a Hollywood costume designer to whip up an outfit for her to wear while traveling, one that would keep her from being recognized. To match her reputation for zaniness, the designer suggested a nun's habit, which Miss Diller wore with eyeglasses and no makeup.

title: UNIFLITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net income and after an extraordinary item of $1.6 million in the 9 mos period; 1980 periods reflected a nonrecurring gain from litigation settlements, business interruption and other insurance proceeds from the Bellingham, Wash., plant fire in April 1980; the shr earnings were restated for effect of a 5 percent stock divd declared Oct 23, 1980

title: Rev. Vincent S. Kearney, 68, Associate Editor of America
description: The Rev. Vincent S. Kearney, a Jesuit priest who for 32 years was an associate editor of America, the national Catholic weekly review, died Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TWO GUIDES ON ABUSE OF WIVES
description: Two recent publications intended to aid women who are the victims of domestic violence take different approaches to the goal. One, a ''Handbook for Beaten Women,'' is a guide for those physically abused by their husbands or housemates. It was published by the Brooklyn Legal Services Corporation, a federally financed agency providing legal aid for the poor.

title: FEDERAL DRUG INVESTIGATION FOCUSES ON YOSEMITE PARK
description: Beneath soaring granite cliffs sculpted eons ago by powerful glaciers in Yosemite National Park, Federal agents are investigating charges of extensive drug trafficking, beatings, murder and a high-level cover-up.

title: CAUTIOUS VIEW OF CERTIFICATES
description: NOW that the uproar over the issue of ''bonuses'' paid on the new tax-exempt savings certificates has subsided, consumers face the question of whether to buy them.

title: Books of The Times
description: Directing a Novel B y ANATOLE BROYARD VOICES IN THE GARDEN. By Dirk Bo- garde. 340 pages. Knopf. $12.95.

title: CITY PROCEEDS ON NOTE SALE DESPITE DOUBTS ON PRIMARY
description: New York City's fiscal officers announced yesterday that they would sell $200 million in short-term notes next week, as Mayor Koch warned that prolonged uncertainty over the city's elections could hurt its chances of borrowing money.

title: BAYSWATER REALTY SEEKS MAJOR SIMPLICITY STAKE
description: The Bayswater Realty and Capital Corporation, a company headed by Carl C. Icahn, the New York financier, disclosed yesterday that it intended to seek a controlling interest in the Simplicity Pattern Company - despite a recently announced merger agreement between Simplicity and NCC Energy Ltd., a British energy and minerals concern.

title: MINI-COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TEKTRONIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 22
F.D.A. APPROVES PLAN TO USE ARTIFICIAL HEART
description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a University of Utah proposal to implant an artificial heart in a human, a procedure already performed by Dr. Denton Cooley without the drug agency's appproval.

title: UNMATCHED COUPLE IN 'LOVERS AND LIARS'
description: Quite soon after they meet semicute in Rome and don't make it in the cramped front seat of his Alfa-Romeo, Giancarlo Giannini turns to Goldie Hawn and says, ''We can try again.'' To which she replies, ''It's not a match made in heaven.'' As usual, Miss Hawn is so right.

title: De Gustibus; INSTITUTIONAL FOOD: WHAT'S THE FUTURE?
description: One of the fastest growing segments of the food service industry is institutional food, an unappetizing label for what generally turns out to be unappetizing meals. Institutions, in this context, include schools, hospitals, prisons, employee cafeterias, some private clubs and executive dining rooms, airlines, chain restaurants, motels, many summer camps for children and the banquet departments of some large hotels. Food industry analysts have estimated that by 1990 three of every five meals in the United States will be eaten away from home, and of those, half will be in institutional environm ents. As these operations become more widespread, they will mean a huge increase in business for catering companies that handle s uch facilities for managements reluctant to undertake the prepar ation and serving of food.

title: PAGEANT STAYS POPULAR IN GOOD TIMES AND BAD
description: The competition is keen inside the Convention Hall this week as 50 women compete for the title of Miss America in a pageant that has never been more healthy or popular. Much of the popularity of this year's contest - a record 80,000 women entered a record number of local pageants - is attributed to the difficult economic times.

title: RAMPAGE BY 15 AT ATTICA ENDED WITH TEAR GAS
description: Fifteen state prison inmates locked in solitary confinement here broke windows and pelted guards with excrement today, but their rampage was quickly broken up by officers using tear gas, a prison spokesman said.

title: CLARKSON POTTER HEAD WAS 42
description: Jane West, an editor and publisher who was known for the literary and artistic as well as the commercial quality of her books, died Wednesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 42 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Federal land managers must follow state water laws and procedures except where Congress has specifically established a water right or where Congress has exp licitly set aside a Fed eral land area with a reserve water right. If they need more water for their programs, theymust take their place in line like any citize n and let state authorities decide.'' - Interior Secretary Ja mes Watt. (9:3.)

title: GAINS FOR MISS POTTER IN A LOSS
description: For several sleepless hours Thursday night, Barbara Potter lay in bed and made her plans. Miss Potter was not naive enough to believe that she would beat Tracy Austin in their semifinal match at the United States Open yesterday, but she was determined, she said, ''to come off the court with more ideas about how to move forward as a player.''

title: WATT SAYS U.S. DEFERS TO STATES ON WATER RIGHTS
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt announced a series of policy changes today including a reversal of a policy allowing the Federal Government to pre-empt state water rights.

title: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 12, 1981
description: International Solidarity was denounced in the Soviet Union at meetings held in factories in Moscow, Leningrad and other cities for actions at its convention this week. Soviet workers were assembled to approve open letters that spoke of a bid by the Polish union for a ''counterrevolution.'' The letter, approved in Moscow, accused Solidarity of trying to provoke workers in the Soviet Union and in other Easternbloc nations to ''betray'' Communism. Soviet leaders were apparently trying to arouse indignation against Solidarity among Soviet workers. (Page 1, Column 1.) Moslem demonstrations in Cairo were broken up the police, who used tear gas. They were protesting at two mosques against President Anwar el-Sadat's recent moves against religious sects that he said were mixing politics and religion. (4:-1-3.)

title: Spaniards Seize Legislator
description: A Socialist member of Parliament was beaten and held for six hours by about 1,000 angry villagers while he was campaigning to create a national park in the Sierra Nevada range in southern Spain, the police said today. The villagers of Guejar-Sierra, who want a tourist resort built instead, freed Angel Diaz Sol early today after he signed a document opposing the park.

title: COOKE ORDAINS PRIEST WHO LEFT EPISCOPAL FOLD
description: A former dissident priest of the Episcopal church who vigorously opposed that church's decision to allow female priests has been ordained by Terence Cardinal Cooke for service in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

title: Midland Lowers Prime
description: Marine Midland Bank of Buffalo lowered its prime lending rate yesterday to 20 percent from 20 1/2 percent, the third major bank to do so. The move followed similar action last week by Chase Manhattan Bank and First National Bank of Chicago. The State National Bank of Connecticut cut its prime rate yesterday to 19 3/4 percent from 20 percent.

title: MATTHEWS, DEMOCRATIC VICTOR, TAKING ON PURCELL
description: John Matthews, winner of yesterday's Democratic primary for Nassau County Executive, was out campaigning early this morning against the incumbent, Francis T . Purcell, whom he will face in the fall election.

title: Canada Bond Rate Up
description: The 1981-82 issue of Canada savings bonds will pay 19.5 percent interest in the first year, the highest ever offered, and 10.5 percent for the remaining six years to maturity, the Finance Ministry announced today. The new rates will also apply to all outstanding issues of bonds.

title: Bridge: A Club, R eopening, Offers Duplicate Play Every Day
description: A handful of clubs in the metropolitan New York area cater to the needs of duplicate players on a seven-day-a-week basis. One of these, the Bridge Deck at 183 South Central Avenue, Hartsdale, N.Y., reopens today under the management of Mimi and Joel Bieber.

title: UNITED NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After tax credits of $223,000 in the qr and $5,000 for the 9 mos

title: SENATE PASSES BILL PROVIDING MILITARY RAISES OF UP TO 22%
description: A military pay bill that would give large raises to noncommissioned officers in midcareer passed the Senate today by a vote of 81 to 0 and headed for a crucial test next week in the House.

title: ATLANTA TENSION OVER DEATHS EASING
description: When 12-year-old Owen Malone returned to school here along with thousands of other area youngsters, he found something distinctly different about the atmosphere at the Dobbs Elementary School.

title: CURTAILING ARCING ON COLOR TV
description: WASHINGTON VIEWERS of color television have been troubled by electric flashes in the picture tubes. A cathode ray tube invented by an RCA scientist substantially suppresses the flashing, or arcing, and is being manufactured by the company.

title: Notes on People; Perlman on Barriers
description: Asked by the National Easter Seal Society what message he would like to convey to the public about architectural barriers to the handicapped, Itzhak Perlman, the violinist, came up with a quick answer: ''I hate steps.''

title: MOBIL DOESN'T WANT TO 'GUT' THE CLEAN AIR ACT
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; British-French Meeting Ends on a Positive Note
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today ended two days of talks that they described as ''excellent'' and ''fruitful'' despite some continued differences, particularly on economic policies.

title: EGYPT'S POLICE QUELL 2 ISLAMIC PROTESTS
description: Egyptian riot police using tear gas today broke up two demonstrations by Moslem fundamentalists protesting President Anwar el-Sadat's crackdown on mixing politics and religion.

title: WACHTELL LAWYER IS OUT IN INSIDER-TRADING CASE
description: A New York law firm specializing in takeovers disclosed yesterday that it had requested - and received - the resignation of one of its partners. It said he had admitted trading in stocks of several of the firm's client companies, but did not explain his actions.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Sept. 2 failed to state a restriction involved in taking a marital deduction under the new tax law. The deduction may be claimed by a person employed by his or her spouse only if the business is a partnership or is incorporated, but not if it is a sole proprietorship in which the employee does not pay Social Se- curity tax.

title: Musical Hirshbein Play To Mark His Centenary
description: In celebration of the 100th anniversary of the birth of Peretz Hirshbein, his comedy ''The Blacksmith's Daughters'' will be presented in a musical version with music by Simon Tanowsky and lyrics by Yitzak Yanasovich. It will open Oct. 10 at the Norman Thomas Theater under the aegis of Ben Bonus.

title: OVER THE FOURTH AMENDMENT'S DEAD BODY
description: To the Editor:

title: Device Purifies Water Electromagnetically
description: An electromagnetic water treatment device for use with a well or on a much larger scale was patented this week by Miguel F. Brigante of Miami. Discussions are under way with public officials concerning removal of toxic copper waste near mines in Chile and purification of river water in Nigeria.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the obituary Thursday of Frieda Fishbein, the play agent, the name of the author of the 1948 Broadway adaptation of Jean-Paul Sartre's ''The Respectful Prostitute'' was incorrect. It was Eva Wolas.

title: RESULTS ON L.I.
description: Following are complete unofficial results of the principal races in Thursday's primary elections in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Asterisk (*) denotes incumbent. NASSAU COUNTY DEMOCRATS COUNTY EXECUTIVE John W. Matthews11,560 Lewis J. Yevoli 9,800 GLEN COVE Mayor-Supervisor Vincent A. Suozzi1,394 Anthony D. Galluccio 549 REPUBLICANS GLEN COVE Mayor-Supervisor Alan M. Parente*982 Michael J. Hansen228 SUFFOLK COUNTY DEMOCRATS COUNTY LEGISLATURE 15th District Wayne Prospect*1,296 Martin J. Feldman 675 REPUBLICANS COUNTY COURT Joel L. Lefkowitz15,483 Kenneth K. Rohl16,712 COUNTY LEGISLATURE Fourth District John F. Sorli* 876 Rose Caracappa1,612 Robert J. Jones 920 10th District Michael J. Grant*1,108 Peter J. McGowan1,800 BROOKHAVEN Supervisor Henrietta Acampora8,736 John Ray2,272 SOUTHAMPTON Supervisor Martin Lang*3,384 Albert J. Essay Jr.1,535 CONSERVATIVES County Legislature Second District John Rosso* 85 Margaret A. Bell111

title: NEW OFFICE BOON: VOICE MAIL
description: Last month David S. Swaffer, an assistant vice president for global systems in the London office of the American Express Company's banking division, was introduced to the company's new voice mail system. He is already sleeping more soundly.

title: 2 ERRORS HURT METS IN 4-2 LOSS TO CARDS
description: The Mets misplayed two key fielding chances in the first inning and wasted several scoring opportunities in a 4-2 loss tonight to the Cardinals. The defeat dropped the Mets two and a half games behind the Cardinals, leaders in the National League East.

title: Observer; GIPPER, SCROOGE AND SANTA
description: To speak of ''President Reagan'' merely deepens the puzzle. It conjures up a face, a figure. We see a smile. The smile glides easily from warm good feeling to modest self-effacement. We think of jellybeans. We imagine a man smiling contentedly as he surveys his cowboy boots.

title: BERNARD L. GLASER
description: Bernard L. Glaser, Eastern advertising and publicity director for the Avco Embassy Pictures Corporation, died Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

title: HONG KONG IS PAYING DEARLY FOR ITS SUCCESS
description: To the Editor : In his mini ature Socratic dialogue on ''Hong Kong's Success'' (Op-Ed Aug. 2 ), Stephen Beckner suggests that Hong Kong's fierce rateof economic g rowth is the colony's salutary and ingenious response toits peculiar geopolitical situation.

title: Rouse-Trizec Pact
description: The Rouse Company of Columbia, Md., said it had agreed in principle to a five-year agreement under which the Trizec Corporation, a real estate holding and management concern based in Calgary, Alberta, would be permitted to increase its stake in Rouse to 20.5 percent from a current 7 percent.

title: WHY GATEWAY SUPPORTERS OPPOSE A PLAN FOR THE HOMELESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports People; Female Jockeys Angry
description: Female jockeys plan to picket Del Mar track in California on Sept. 20 and hope to shut it down on that date unless the track schedules a parimutuel race solely for female riders.

title: GAS LINE PLAN ENDED BY BRITISH
description: The British Government announced today that it had abandoned plans to build a $4.9 billion gas pipeline in the North Sea, largely because of a reluctance to increase the Government's debt.

title: THE ITKINS RIDE THE 'WORK STATION' BOOM
description: Almost half a century ago, three brothers from Brooklyn joined forces as office furniture repairmen, pushing dolleys laden with freshly repaired goods along New York city's trolley tracks. Canvassing skyscrapers floor by floor, the Itkin brothers ventured into sales, and gradually succeeded in unravelling the tight-knit fraternity of office furniture dealers.

title: Oil Price Cut By Indonesia
description: Indonesia, a key member of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and a major supplier of oil to the United States, trimmed the effective price of its top-grade crude oil by 25 cents a barrel, an Indonesian oil official said yesterday.

title: John Prinz to Join Staff Of Ballet Theater School
description: John Prinz, a former principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will join the staff of the American Ballet Theater School. The announcement was made by Patricia Wilde, director of the school. Mr. Prinz's position will involve teaching and the organization of lectures and demonstrations.

title: INTEREST RATES FALL SHARPLY
description: Interest rates declined sharply yesterday and the Federal Reserve announced that a key measure of the money supply had fallen by $1.1 billion in the week ended Sept.2, a new sign that money growth is remaining within or near Fed targets.

title: Simon and Garfunkel In Central Park Concert
description: Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel, the 1960's singers who split up 11 years ago, will be reunited for the first time in Central Park next Saturday.

title: DART DRUG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The 1981 figures include the operations of Crown Books West, a joint venture with the Thrifty Corp

title: Dome Petroleum I n Japan Gas Pact
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., an energy producer based in Calgary, Alberta, said it had reached an agreement with the Nissho-Iwai Company, a Japanese trading house, to supply 400 million cubic feet of liquefied natural gas a day to four Japanese utility companies. The value of the accord, to run for 20 years from 1985, was not disclosed.

title: Notes on People; Dick Gregory Fasts Again, This Time for Research
description: The last time Dick Gregory ate solid food was July 21, and yesterday marked his 46th day on a water-only fast he has embarked on for hunger research.

title: Five Burned at Sun Ship
description: Five men working on a drydocked ship at the Sun Ship Inc. shipyards were burned today when propane gas leaked from a tank and exploded, the authorities said. The explosion produced a flash fire on the top deck of the Lurline, which is being overhauled.

title: ABORTION FOES ASSAIL JUDGE O'CONNOR
description: Leaders of the anti-abortion movement told the Senate Ju diciary Committee today that Judge Sandra Day O'Connor should be dis qualified from service on the United States Supreme Court because she had not promised to vote to overrule the 1973 Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion.

title: YANKEES DEFEAT RED SOX
description: The Boston Red Sox played the Yankees last night for the first time this year. They probably would not have minded waiting another day. They encountered Dave Righetti, and the rookie pitcher dazzled them for seven innings as he sparked the Yankees to a 4-1 victory. Graig Nettles provided the power, driving in two runs with a single and a home run.

title: Notes on People; Royal Search
description: That old complaint that ''it's hard to find good servants these days'' is one being faced by the Prince and Princess of Wales.

title: NATIONAL RETAIL SALES ROSE BY 0.6% IN AUGUST
description: Sales by the nation's retail merchants rose a modest six-tenths of 1 percent in August, a performance that did not keep pace with inflation, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Joyce Powell Gernert Is Bride of D. Broward Craig
description: Joyce Powell Gernert, widow of Robert E. Gernert, was married yesterday in the All Saints Chapel of Trinity Episcopal Church to D. Broward Craig of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The Rev. Robert R. Parks, the rector, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Jack S. Miller of the Mount Kisco (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

title: KHOMEINI AIDE KILLED BY GRENADE IN NORTHERN IRAN
description: Another leading Iranian clergyman was slain today as a grenade was detonated during prayers conducted in a square in the northwestern city of Tabriz.

title: Around the Nation; Kleindienst Concedes Payment for Influence
description: Former United States Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst, testifying in his perjury trial, confirmed today that he had been paid $125,000 for using his influence with Frank E. Fitzsimmons, former head of the teamsters' union.

title: PENTAGON AIDE LINKS NEW STRATEGY TO AWACS DEAL
description: A senior official of the Defense Department said today that strategic cooperation with Israel and additional military assistance to that nation would be ''jeopardized'' if a proposed sale of advanced radar surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia was blocked.

title: Phone Drive to Push Pupil Immunization
description: The city school system is about to begin a telep hone campaign to encourage parents to sign and return consent forms that will enable their children to be immunized in school. Schools Cha ncellor Frank J. Macchiarola and Joseph G. Barkan, president of the Board of Education, said yesterday that children whodid not meet the new state immunization requirements and who failed to return sig ned consent forms by Sept. 23 faced expulsion from school after that date.

title: U.S. UNEASY OVER MILITARY POTENTIAL OF COMMERCIALLY PRODUCED ROCKETS
description: The Reagan Administration has become concerned that rockets being developed commercially for ostensibly peaceful purposes could also be used to deliver nuclear or chemical warheads.

title: SOVIET ASSEMBLES WORKERS TO ASSAIL THE POLISH UNION
description: The Soviet Union's campaign against the Polish independent trade union, Solidarity, took a new turn today as meetings were held at factories in Moscow and elsewhere at which Solidarity was denounced for actions at its congress this week.

title: New System Monitors Freight Car Traffic
description: Jerome H. Lemelson, president of the Licensing Management Corporation, New York, who has more than 360 patents, is co-inventor of a freight car scanner. Discussions are under way for developing the system to code and track the more than 1,700,000 freight cars in the United States.

title: Cosmos Meeting Hot Club
description: The Fort Lauderdale Strikers, who play the Cosmos here tomorrow night in the opener of a two-of-threegame semifinal series, have been by far the most impressive team in the North American Soccer League's playoffs.

title: ADVANCE THIRD IN ROW
description: A decline in short-term interest rates and a brisk rally in bond prices kept the stock market's three-day recovery alive yesterday as the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 10.37 points, to 872.81.

title: DWG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $2.8 million on sales of marketable securities...C-Net loss

title: POP: X, IN THE FAST LANE
description: rock quartet from Los Angeles, brought its austere brand of new-wave music to the Ritz on Thursday. It was the first time the band has played in a large hall in the New York area, and though the house was far from filled, it scored impressively.

title: U.S. Raises Rate Ceilings
description: The Government will raise the interest ceiling Monday on most federally insured loans on single-family homes to 17.5 percent, the fourth increase to a record level in five months, officials of the Department of Housing and Urban Development said today.

title: Record Eurobond Yield
description: The seven-year Eurobond for Tr anscanada Pipelines Ltd. will carry a 17.75 percent coupon, a re cord high for United States dollar-denominated Eurobonds, the jointle ad manager, Salomon Brothers International, said today.

title: Duke Faculty Opposes 'Glorification' of Nixon
description: Duke University's Academic Council voted unanimously today to ''categorically reject the creation of any museum or memorial designed to foster the glorification of the former President as part of a Nixon Presidential Library'' on or adjacent to the Durham campus.

title: Tomorrow marks the 10th anniversary of the gunfire in which State Police and prison guards shot 128 people, killing 39, including 10 hostages, as they retook the Attica prison from inmates who had rebelled four days earlier. Perhaps heeding a lesson of Attica, the officers at the 1980 riot at the New Mexico State Penitentiary, which left 33 dead, did not shoot anyone.
description: Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, who had ordered the police assault on Attica, announced immediately afterward, and before any investigation, that the troopers had done a ''superb job'' and that their killings had been ''justifiable homicide.'' During the years that followed, the special Attica prosecutor whom he appointed indicted 62 inmates (inmates had killed four persons) and, late and briefly, one trooper.

title: Susan MacEachron Wed to Bruce Patrick
description: Susan MacEachron and Bruce Douglas Patrick, who are tax lawyers for the Exxon Corporation in Houston, were married yesterday in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. George William Webber, president of the New York Theological Seminary, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. David W. MacEachron.

title: U.S. to Force Farmers To Repay Disaster Aid
description: Ninety-nine debt collectors will go to the Southeast as part of an intensified effort to collect millions of dollars in improper and delinquent farm disaster loans, Reagan Administration officials said yesterday.

title: BABES AT THE ZOO
description: Astor, the baby elephant, made the headlines when he was born at the Bronx Zoo last month, but he was not the only new arrival. Other youngsters at the zoo include, counter-clockwise from left, a giraffe, a gibbon, a yak and a duck.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: METS (NL) - Called up Charlie Puleo and Jesse Orosco, pitchers; Brian Giles, infielder, and Mike Howard, outfielder, from Tidewater of International League. NATIONAL LEAGUE - Fined Cesar [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] Cedeno, first baseman of Houston, $5,000 for entering the stands and confronting a fan in Atlanta Sept. 8; his suspension was canceled.; BASKETBALL CLEVE LAND (NBA) - Signed Kenny Page, guard from New Mexico and fifth- round draft choice, to multiyear contract.; COLLEGE SETON HALL - Announced that Ed

title: Conflict-of-Interest Charges Delay a Genetic Study Grant
description: A university dean has suspended a $2.5 million genetic study grant because of reports of a conflict of interest involving a professor of genetic engineering.

title: Consumer Saturday; HANDLING EVICTION NOTICES
description: A N eviction notice, taped to one's front door, has a certain unpleasant quality that inclines some law-abiding, rent-paying tenants to toss it out with their junk mail. That is rash, however, because the next taped message may state that the dwelling must be vacated within 72 hours and a sheriff might enforce it.

title: TORONTO EXCHANGE ACTS TO BAR BACHE CANADA
description: Bache Halsey Stuart Canada Ltd., one of three foreign-owned securities dealers operating here, has been denied continued membership on the Toronto Stock Exchange, Canada's largest, as a result of the acquisition of its United States parent by the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

title: Noel Meets Gonzalez F or Lightweight Title
description: Claude Noel of Trinidad takes on Rodolfo (Gato) Gonzalez of Mexico tomorrow for the World Boxing Association's lightweight title, which was stripped from Sean O'Grady last month.

title: New Way to Identify Microorganisms
description: A method of identifying microorganisms has been developed for Pfizer Inc. by members of its laboratory staff in Groton, Conn.

title: Corpus Christi Oil Plans Gas Pipeline
description: The Corpus Christi Oil and Gas Company, a privately held energy transmission company based here, said it planned to build a $500 million, 250-mile-long natural gas pipeline off the Texas coast in the Gulf of Mexico, starting next spring.

title: News Analysis
description: The decision to join with Israel in a ''strategic collaboration'' represents a gamble by the Reagan Administration that the political windfall will more than offset the expected damage to American interests in Arab countries.

title: Bache Loses 'Raiding' Suit
description: A judge here dismissed a lawsuit filed by the brokerage firm of Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. against a competitor for ''raiding,'' or hiring away members of, its staff.

title: Around the World; French Eject Protesters At British Consulate
description: Policemen ejected about 20 young people from the British Consulate today when they refused to leave after distributing pamphlets in support of Irish nationalists imprisoned in Northern Ireland, a British spokesman said.

title: YOUNG, ON THE RIGHT AND RESPONSIBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF CITY CABLE TV
description: To the Editor:

title: YOUTH IS GIVEN 6 YEARS IN ORCHARD ST. CRASH
description: A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth who pleaded guilty to driving a stolen gypsy taxicab into a crowd of Sunday shoppers on Orchard Street on the Lower East Side last spring was sentenced yesterday to six to 18 years.

title: OF ENGLAND AND HATE
description: I never really knew why my father hated England. I was brought up in a home that taught love and respect -except for that one small compartment my father reserved for Albion. It seemed to contradict the whole atmosphere in which I was reared.

title: Around the World; Finnish President Ailing; Premier Assigned Duties
description: President Urho Kekkonen, 81 years old, is under doctor's orders not to work for a month while he recuperates from a fever and slight respiratory problem, the President's office announced today.

title: Sports People; McKoy to Europe
description: The Knicks consider three of their choices in last June's draft - Wayne McKoy of St. John's, Frank Brickowski of Penn State and Marty Headd of Syracuse - not quite ready for the National Basketball Association, but will watch their progress. All have signed with European teams, but New York will retain rights to them for two years because the Knicks offered them contracts.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA BEATS MRS. LLOYD AND GAINS FINAL
description: Martina Navratilova rebounded to defeat Chris Evert Lloyd, 7-5, 4-6, 6-4, yesterday and reach the women's singles final of the United States Open tennis championships for the first time.

title: HOUSTON NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
Around the World; Von Bulow Asks Court To Dismiss Charges
description: A defense attorney for Claus C. von Bulow has filed motions to dismiss charges that he twice tried to kill his wife, Martha von Bulow, with injections of insulin. The motions argued that Mrs. von Bulow was a victim of her tendency to abuse drugs, alcohol and sweets.

title: UNEXPECTED FUNDS PERMIT LIBRARIES TO EXPAND HOURS AND STAFF
description: Public-service hours for New York Public Library branches will increase by 18 percent over last year's winter schedule beginning Monday, with 95 additional staff members allocated among the 83 branches in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island, as a result of unexpected funds.

title: Constructive Step on Construction Jobs
description: The anti-discrimination policies of President Reagan and Mayor Koch, neither one a fan of affirmative action, are converging. Although the White House is watering down Federal compliance rules, Mr. Koch is fortifying local enforcement.

title: 900 ATTEND ECUMENICAL RITES FOR WILKINS
description: An ecumenical funeral service yesterday for Roy Wilkins, the former head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, brought together more than 900 mourners, headed by Vice President Bush and other leaders in government, politics, civil rights and business. Mr. Wilkins died Tuesday at the age of 80.

title: TURKEY'S ECONOMIC 'MIRACLE'
description: There is beginning to be talk about a ''Turkish miracle'' - a dramatic turnabout in a nation that not so long ago was facing economic disaster.

title: EVANS-ARISTOCRAT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 16. 1. ''I hope to handle whatever success I have the same way he did,'' this 19-year-old golfer, pictured after winning the United States Amateur championship, said about his father. Who is he, and who was his father?

title: PUCCIO FAVORED FOR NOMINATION TO FEDERAL POST
description: Thomas P. Puccio, the chief Abscam prosecutor and one of the most controversial Justice Department lawyers in the country, is expected to be nominated by President Reagan for the key post of United States Attorney for the District of Columbia, Administration sources said yesterday.

title: EMPTY TANK CAR EXPLODES
description: Some of the 19 railroad cars destroyed Thursday when one of them exploded.

title: MACNEIL AND LEHRER TO PRODUCE TV PROGRAMS
description: Robert MacNeil and Jim Lehrer of public television's ''The MacNeil-Lehrer Report'' have formed a partnership with the Gannett Company to produce television news, specials, documentaries and cable programs.

title: PACT ON AIRPORT SIGNED BY WESTCHESTER AND RYE
description: Westchester County and the Town of Rye agreed today to some limitations on the operations and development of Westchester County Airport. Rye residents had long complained of the noise and activity at the adjacent airport, one of the busiest in the state.

title: REALTY INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A RECORD GRAIN CROP IN '81 FORECAST BY U.S.
description: The Agriculture Department today forecast a record 1981 grain crop that could mean lower prices for consumers but higher farm subsidy payments for the Reagan Administration, which is struggling to hold down spending.

title: MISSONI AT THE MET
description: For years, Missoni knitted clothes, with their myriad textures and colors, have been considered an art form. Ottavio Missoni's watercolors and gouaches that serve as blueprints for his marvelously intricate stitches have, indeed, been framed and hung on the walls of his home and his friends' homes. While he settles the colors and the patterns, his wife, Rosita, shapes them into the easy clothes that are both contemporary and lasting.

title: Around the World; Britain and Soviet Seek Gold on Ship Sunk in '42
description: Britain and the Soviet Union have begun a joint effort to recover five and a half tons of gold from a Royal Navy cruiser sunk by a Nazi submarine in the Arctic in 1942, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today.

title: Around the Nation; Judge Bars F.A.A. Move A gainst Backers of Strike
description: A Federal District judge today ordered the Federal Aviation Adminstration not to interfere with nonstriking Government employees who actively supported the walkout by air traffic controllers.

title: BROOKLYN YOUTH, 15, FATALLY SHOT BY OFFICER INVESTIGATING BURGLARY
description: A police officer shot and killed a 15-year-old Brooklyn youth inside a closed and darkened grocery store early yesterday while responding to a report of a burglary in progress, the police said. Two other youths, one 15 and the other 18, were arrested at the scene.

title: S.E.C. Charge On Reports
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said it had charged Tiffany Industries with violating Federal securities law by filing misleading financial reports in 1976 and 1977.

title: UNIVERSITIES' ACCORD CALLED RESEARCH AID
description: A recently concluded arrangement between two California universities and a bioengineering concern formed last month could give these and other universities a major share of any capital gains or dividends the company may generate.

title: Leisure; ORIENTAL POPPIES HAVE REGAL ELEGANCE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Lynn Lewis Monroe is a freelance writer. By LYNN LEWIS MONROE

title: HOUSE SALES SLOWEST IN 6YEARS
description: For the past three months William Stark, a 35-year-old accountant, has been experiencing what he considers to be something of a nightmare. Because he could not find a buyer for his ranch-style home in suburban Detroit, he did not have enough cash to purchase a home near his new job in Stamford. So he has been living in a motel room in Fairfield and visiting his family four days a month.

title: BOXING'S BIGGEST BONANZA HAS UNLKIELY PROMOTERS
description: Outside the temporary headquarters in Caesars Palace of the richest sports event in history, the electric sign flashes: ''Frosty Acres.''

title: Polly Franchine Bride O f George S. Sexton 3d
description: Polly Franchine, daughter of Mrs. William Larson of Baltimore and the late Charles Franchine, was married in Washington yesterday to George Stuart Sexton 3d, son of Mr. Sexton Jr. of Annandale, Va., and the late Elizabeth Sexton. Judge Reggie B. Walton of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: Parachutist Dies in Training
description: An Army sergeant who jumped out of a C-130 transport plane at 1,250 feet plummeted to his death when his parachute did not hold air, the military authorities said today. Sgt. 1st Class Miguel A. Mitchell, 33, was killed in training exercises yesterday. The cause of the parachute malfunction was not known.

title: U.S. NUCLEAR PACT WITH EGYPT GAINS
description: An agreement to supply Egypt with materials and technology to develop a nuclear energy program passed a crucial House subcommittee test this week and appears headed for approval by Congress. The pact is regarded as a model for future nuclear-export accords.

title: FROM NAIROBI TO MOMBASA, KENYANS JAM THE TRAINS AT NIGHT
description: A 21-car train glided to a stop at a totally unlighted village in the middle of a moonless , cloudy night in the equatorial highlands of Kenya.

title: RETAILING: THE DEMISE OF THE ELEVATOR
description: SAN FRANCISCO The first thing that strikes a visitor to the new Saks Fifth Avenue store in downtown San Francisco is the store's central core of eight pale pink escalators. As a customer ascends the five floors between waist-high walls, almost every bit of merchandise in the store is on view, as well as all the other customers on their shopping odysseys.

title: Token Agents to Make Change for a $20 Bill
description: Subway token agents will accept $20 bills beginning tomorrow because of the 75-cent fare instituted in July.

title: Miss Thomas W ed in South
description: Patricia Conway Thomas, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah L. Thomas Jr. of Richmond, was married there yesterday to Douglas Lewis Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene M. Brown of New York and East Hampton, L.I. The Rev. Frederick J. Feusahrens performed the ceremony at St. Bridget's Roman Catholic Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Robert A. Nunn of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: POLITICIANS ASSESS MESSAGE OF PRIMARIES
description: POLITICIANS and voters searching for lessons from the primary elections across Connecticut last Tuesday might consider at least three:

title: COSTS STILL RISING FOR RIOTS AT WESTCHESTER JAIL
description: Toothpaste worth $294.50 and $521.65 in board games such as Monopoly have been added to damage costs resulting from the riots last July at the Westchester County Jail in Valhalla. The county has also filed claims for two Ping-Pong tables worth a total of $298 .70 that were wrecked during the three days of disturbances that began July 10. It also wants to replace a $240 ''executive p osture'' chair, a $700 institutional kitchen mixing bowland scores of cots, mattresses, portable televisions, sheets and items of clot hing.

title: Columbus Clippers Beat Rochester In Playoffs
description: The Columbus Clippers defeated Rochester, 2-1, in 10 innings today in the fifth and deciding game of their International League playoff series.

title: SAILS, BUT NOT THE SPECTATORS, ARE RUFFLED AT A RACE ON BAY
description: Thousands of the curious spectators along the sunny shores of New York Bay yesterday did not realize at first that the sailboats stretched out before them were competitors in the eighth annual Governor's Cup Race.

title: Margaret Campbell Becomes a Bride
description: Margaret Randolph Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Campbell of Hamden, Conn., and Fishers Island, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard Hunter Lamere, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Richard Lamere of Duxbury, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Andrew E. Fiddler at the Trinity Episcopal Church on-the-Green in New Haven.

title: New Jersey Housing; A LITTLE INGENUITY, BIG DIVIDENDS
description: WEST CALDWELL THIS is a story about ingenuity. Douglas and Heather Holloway now live in an apartment in Caldwell in which their 6-month-old son, Graham, sleeps in the dining room. Soon, however, they will be moving into a 60-year-old blacksmith's shop in West Caldwell that they are renovating into a three-bedroom home.

title: Film View; SCAVENGING TO MAKE NEW MOVIES
description: ''Comin' at Ya'' is such an amateurish western that it wouldn't be of interest to anyone were it not being shown in 3-D. So the producer and director of the film, who are also its two stars, spoke with commendable candor in a recent television interview when they acknowledged the motives that had guided them. No, they indicated, they were not out to make a great film or even a particularly good one. They simply realized that it had been 25 years since 3-D had last been around and that a whole new movie audience might be ready to enjoy an old trick.

title: SRI LANKA TRIES TO REVIVE SAGGING TEA OUTPUT
description: Sri Lanka is trying to restore tea production after a drop in output during the 1970's. Tea was first planted in Sri Lanka more than a hundred years ago and is now one of the mainstays of the economy, along with rubber, gems and tourism.

title: INDIA'S ROPE TRICK: PRESERVING U.S. TIES
description: As the global perceptions and strategic concerns of India and the United States grow farther and farther apart, officials of both countries are trying to keep the deterioration from undermining a wide range of economic, cultural and scientific links.

title: Residents of San Bernardino Shaken by Minor Earthquake
description: A minor earthquake rocked this community today but seemed to cause no damage.

title: LYME DISEASE HITS NEW AREAS
description: IT started earlier this summer with a little red spot on the boy's cheek. No one thought anything of it - until weeks after he had left Fire Island for camp in New England. Then, suddenly, the 11-year-old fell ill with flu-like symptoms and had to be hospitalized for arthritic pains.

title: THE HAPPY HOMECOMING OF YOUNG TRAVIS JOHN
description: EVER since Travis John woke up after having been in a coma for nearly two weeks, his doctors had wondered if he would remember everything that had been a part of his little world. The 2-year-old son of the Yankee pitcher Tommy John was discharged Thursday from the New York University Medical Center and he rode in the back seat with his mother, Sally, as their father drove out across the George Washington Bridge to the quiet, shady street in Franklin Lakes, N. J., where they live. As the car eased into the driveway, Travis's mother turned to see him staring at the garage.

title: SOVIET WINDS UP MANEUVERS, RELIEVING TENSIONS
description: Nine days of Soviet military maneuvers near Poland ended today, relieving some of the ten sion over actions taken by the Polish labor union's convention in Gda nsk.

title: ECONOMIC AFFAIRS; IN THE WINGS, THE GOLD STANDARD
description: T WENTY years ago those advocating a pure gold standard were called gold bugs or gold nuts. They were considered to be at least eccentric an d at worst slightly deranged. When President Richard M. Nixon endedthe last vest ige of the gold standard in 1971 by eliminating officialsales and pur chases of gold at a fixed price, the intelligentsia generally che ered the abandonment of the barbaric golden relic of a more primitiv e society.

title: Children's Books
description: LETTERBOX The Art and History of Letters. Written and Illustrated by Jan Adkins. 48 pp. New York: Walker & Co. $10.95. (Ages 12 and Up) By KARLA KUSKIN

title: TO A KENYAN, LITERARY LIFE TURNS BITTER
description: When Karen Blixen, better known as Isak Dinesen, wrote her classic memoir ''Out of Africa,'' she immortalized a man called Kamande Wa Gature in a book that began : ''I had a farm in Africa, at the foot of the Ngong Hills.''

title: SSSSH! 'INVENTOR ON THE JOB
description: ALIST of summer ''inventions'' appeared recently on this page, and several inquiries about the items have been received, most of them requesting information on where the ''inventions'' could be obtained. Interest was greatest in the Hard-Rock Scanner Jammer, an electronic device to cause static on radios playing hard rock at the beach.

title: PROSPECTS quarter 1981-4th quarter 1982
description: Every Little Bit Helps

title: Suzanne Stern Wed to Peter Kunhardt
description: The marriage of Suzanne S. Stern to Peter W. Kunhardt took place yesterday in Katonah, N.Y., in the garden at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hart Rice, stepfather and mother of the bride. The bridegroom's brother, the Rev. Philip B. Kunhardt 3d of St. Asaph's Episcopal Church in Bala Cynwyd Pa., performed the ceremony.

title: FRANK MCHUGH, 83, AN ACTOR KNOWEN FOR SUPPORTING ROLES
description: Frank McHugh, the stalwart supporting actor best known for his sidekick roles in scores of motion pictures, died Friday after a short illness at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Cos Cob, Conn.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Asia Society gets its 1981-82 performing seas on off to a start this week with a fabulous taste of Japan. What mor e could one ask than traditional and modern Japanese dance, theate r and music - performed by the Classical Performing Arts Friendship M ission of Japan, a smidgeon of graphic arts, and intermission fe eding on delicacies fromJapan.

title: HOW THE KLANS ARE ORGANIZED
description: In the past, the Ku Klux Klan was basically a white, Protestant, adult-male organization. Today's Klans often include women and Roman Catholics in leadership positions and chapters for young boys and girls from age 10 up.

title: CANDIDATE SAYS VOTING PLAN VIOLATES COURT ORDER
description: A candidate for City Council in a newly created district in Queens asserted yesterday that the city's agreement with the United States Justice Department on the primary election violated an order issued last Wednesday by a State Supreme Court justice in Queens.

title: THE PINELANDS PROTECTION LAW MUST BE AMENDED
description: ON JUNE 22, after more than seven months of intensive behind-thescenes negotiations with Governor Byrne, State Senator Steven P. Perskie, Democrat of Atlantic City, introduced a lengthy and complex bill to amend the Pinelands Protection Act.

title: IS SEARS, AT LONG LAST, ON THE MEND?
description: CHICAGO C OULD Sears, Roebuck & Company, that giant of American retail chains, finally be rising from a long deep sleep? For five years, Sears seemed to mark time. Its customers drifted off to livelier competitors, and profits sagged under the weight of an overloaded management staff.

title: Sound; BRUSHING UP ON BASICS
description: David Henry Thoreau once admonished his audience to ''read not the Times, read the Eternities.'' We take comfort in the fact that he wasn't referring to this newspaper, which had not yet been founded. But the sage of Walden Pond had a point that concerns us. In the effort to cover timely developments in the audio field, we may have neglected the underlying and enduring principles by which these innovations must be judged. At any rate, a number of readers have let us know that they feel in need of a refresher course.

title: No Headline
description: I feel a great sorrow for the children of Northern Ireland.

title: A.T.&.T. LOSES A BIG ROUND IN ANTITRUST CASE
description: A.T.& T. lost a motion to dismiss the Government's antitrust case against it. Judge Harold H. Greene, using unusually strong language in denying the bid, said that the Government had demonstrated that the Bell system ''had violated antitrust laws in a number of ways over a lengthy period of time.''

title: Peter Stark Weds Miss Hitchcoc k
description: Deborah Suzanne Hitchcock, daughter of Harriet W. Hitchcock of Fair Haven, N.J., and William Paige Hitchcock of Purchase, N.Y., was married yesterday to Peter Callum Stark, son of Dr. and Mrs. David C.C. Stark of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. The Rev. Foster C. Wilson performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Rumson, N.J.

title: 'NEON' LOOKS TO LIFE ON BROADWAY
description: BELLPORT THE Island isn't the usual route for a Broa dway-bound musical, but ''Neon,'' which is trying out at the Gateway Playhouse starting Wednesday, is being presented by Phil Oesterm an, who isn't the usual kind of producer.

title: Strong Defense, Not Wrong Defense
description: Finally, th e Reagan Administration seems to realize it cannot increase defe nse spending as dramatically as it expected. The budget knives are ou t - but in the wrong part of the Pentagon.

title: Honecker Due in Cuba Today
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader, will make a brief visit here tomorrow after his four-day visit to Mexico, the daily newspaper Granma said today. Granma said Mr. Honecker would be stopping off on the invitation of Fidel Castro, the Cuban leader.

title: Seeing the Sequoias
description: To the Editor:

title: EXHIBIT FROM ITALY WELCOMED BY NEW HAVEN
description: An exhibition of Ital ian art, photography and industry sponsored by a Turin-based foundation has ins pired two weeks of Italian cultural offerings in this city, where al most 50 percent of the population is of Italian descent.

title: BROOKLYN UTILITY CITES COST OF U.S. SEWER AID
description: Federally financed sewer and water projects are causing ''unfair increases in New York City gas consumers' bills,'' the Brooklyn Union Gas Company has charged in a new campaign seeking Federal or state legislation to change the situation.

title: Fire Aboard Freighter Ruins Honda Autos Bound for U.S.
description: A fire that had burned for two days aboard a freighter loaded with thousands of Japanese cars headed for the United States was extinguished today by a Coast Guard vessel, the authorities said.

title: Protesters Mass for Rally At California Atom Plant
description: Protesters opposed to the Diablo Canyon Atomic Power Plant continued to gather at a valley campsite near here today, although organizers would not say when their threatened land and sea blockade of the plant site would begin.

title: Washington; REAGAN AND BEGIN
description: The first meeting bet ween President Reagan and Prime Minister Begin of Israel ended - as most summit meetings do - in a cloud of amiable ambiguities.

title: Scout Leader Sentenced
description: A 36-year-old Explorer Scout leader, convicted of killing a member of his troop, has been sentenced to 10 to 15 years in prison for manslaughter and two years on a firearms charge, officials said. Richard Lynn Fernald of Royal Oak received the maximum sentences yesterday from Oakland County Circuit Judge George LaPlata. Mr. Fernald was convicted in the shooting of 14-year-old Joseph Lemke after a night of drinking on Aug. 29, 1980.

title: New Jersey Guide; CIVIL WAR RECALLED
description: Although it ended 116 years ago, the Civil War is continually being re-enacted by large numbers of would-be Rebel and Union soldiers.

title: Headliners; Cardinal Under Suspicion
description: In one of the touchier cases of its kind, Government lawyers confirmed last week that a Federal grand jury was investigating John Cardinal Cody, head of the nation's largest Roman Catholic archdiocese, Chicago, on allegations of ''improper diversion'' of $1 million from two church discretionary funds. The lawyers declined to name the Cardinal's accusers, but did name the supposed beneficiary of his munificence - 74-year-old Helen Dolan Wilson, a St. Louis woman who, the cleric says, and Mrs. Wilson confirms, is his cousin by marriage. Cardinal Cody has denied the charges, issuing a statement through the archdiocese calling the allegations ''erroneous and tragically painful.''

title: 'CHAPTER TWO FAILS TO KEEP ITS CHARM'
description: LINDENHURST ISN'T it time to close the book on ''Chapter Two'' - at least for, say, a season? To call Neil Simon's autobiographical comedy drama overdone is to understate the case. Productions of it have reached epidemic proportions -which wouldn't be all that hazardous if the play were indestructible.

title: 40 Invade Moon Camp Seeking Irish Woman
description: An Irish farmer who came to the United States to recover his daughter from the Unification Church invaded a church ranch today with about 40 Irish-American supporters, officials said.

title: Art; 2 PHOTOGRAPHERS, 2 PERCEPTIONS OF THE PINELANDS
description: Washington Corridor, only one major wilderness exists and that is the Pine Barrens of New Jersey.

title: Miss Arkansas Named Miss America of 1982
description: Miss Arkansas, Elizabeth Ward, was crowned Miss America of 1982 tonight. The 20-year-old Miss Ward is a junior majoring in accounting at the University of Arkansas.

title: FLOODS ON YELLOW RIVER THREATEN DAM PROJECT
description: The Yellow River has flooded its upper reaches, threatening a hydroelectric project, the People's Daily saidtoday.

title: CAPTURING THE ISLAND AS IDYLL
description: SOUTHAMPTON FOR painters of the American landscape, the period of relative peace between the end of the Civil War and the outbreak of World War I was one of enormous advance ment. The pionee ring work of the Hudson River School and the topographical studies of Western explorers had already legitimized the native scene as a wor thy subject, and the growth of a domestic art market fostered prof essional training and the establishment of museums and galleries.

title: HOW TO RELIEVE THE ANXIETY OF HAVING NO LAWN TO MOW
description: IN the last couple of years, Port Jefferson was hit by condominiomania, an ever-spreading disease. I never knew how great my little village was until I read the real-estate ads: ''The View, The Water, The Woods, The Air, The Tennis, The Sky, The Harbor, The Golf, The Privacy, The Nature Trails, The Railroad, The Marina, The Parks, The Scenic Ferry to Connecticut ...'' (I still can't understand why the Port Jeff bars are always full when there is so much to do out there).

title: REAGAN CUTS PLAN FOR ARMS SPENDING BY 20 TO 21 BILLION
description: President Reagan announced today that he would trim his projections for military spending by $20 billion to $21 billion in the next three years to help meet his goal of balancing the Federal budget by 1984.

title: Ford Settles Suit in Crash
description: The families of three men who were killed when the gas tank of a Ford Mustang exploded in a crash and a woman who survived the resulting fire agreed yesterday to accept a total of $400,000 from the Ford Motor Company rather than pursue their $113.8 million lawsuit. The accident involving the 1965 Mustang occurred March 12, 1978.

title: BOAT BUYERS FACE HIGH COST IN LOANS
description: By JOANNE A. FISHMAN

title: DEBATING THE WELFARE STATE- ITS FORMS, ITS FUNCTIONS
description: AS the White House struggled last week with hard numbers for a second round of spending cuts, the debate contined on the meaning and effect of President Reagan's ''economic revitalization'' program for the economy and for the nature of government in America. Four political scientists and one economist - Theodore J. Lowi of Cornell University, Frances Fox Piven of Boston University, Aaron Wildavsky of the University of California at Berkeley and Leonard Silk of The New York Times - explored such issues earlier this month, at the plenary session of the annual meeting of the American Political Science Association. Excerpts of the panel, called ''The State of the Welfare State'' and moderated by Dr. Lowi, follow.

title: Jersey Jail Plan Approved
description: The New Jersey Commission on Capital Budgeting and Planning endorsed a plan today to spend $21.9 million to aid counties that house state prisoners in county jails. The next move in getting money to Mercer, Union, Passaic and Camden Counties would be approval of an appropriations bill by the Legislature, said a commission official.

title: Argentine Admiral Named
description: Adm. Jorge Isaac Anaya, 55 years old, has taken over as commander of Argentina's Navy, becoming a member of the junta.

title: CREATIONS THAT BRIDGE THE PASSAGE OF TIME
description: ROSLYN HARBOR WHILE marching into the future with a deliberate and defiant step, certain avant-garde factions in recent times made an unexpected about-face and began marching into the past.

title: LIFE AND FLOODING ALONG THE BANKS OF THE
description: THAMES By STEVEN RATTNER

title: REPORT WARNS OF CUTS IN EMISSIONS PROGRAM
description: New York's program for inspecting 3.9 million cars in the metropolitan region to reduce their air-pollution emissions has been operating well in its first six months, but its future is threatened by a loss of funds, according to a report by a public-interest organization.

title: ADVICE FOR LATE PAYERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary L. Jachym, Artist, Is Married
description: Mary Louise Jachym, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Jachym of Windsor, Conn., was married yesterday to Steven Casper Henry Citron, son of Mrs. John Harmon Noble Jr. of Pasadena, Calif., and Essex, N.Y., and Casper H. Citron of New York and North Salem, N.Y. The Rev. Daniel Miner performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: RARE STORK ATTRACTING BIRD WATCHERS TO TEXAS
description: Armed with cameras and telescopes, bird watchers from across the nation are converging on the salt marshes that border the Cayo del Oso, a bay on the south edge of this city.

title: 5 VIE TO SUCCEED HARWOOD
description: WITH the County Executive primary out of the way, Nassau Democrats now turn to the next skirmish in the intraparty battling - the choice of a new county chairman.

title: TOYS TO CURE BABY'S BOREDOM
description: TEN years ago, when Kent Garland Burtt of Darien and Karen Karlkstein of Stamford met as mothers of children attending the same nursery school, they never expected their friendship to develop into a professional collaboration. Three years ago, Mrs. Burtt mentioned an idea she had for a book on toys for babies.

title: WATT PLEASING THE WEST'S GOVERNORS
description: Western Governors meeting here this week agree that it is too early to pass judgment on the performance of Interior Secretary James G. Watt. But, after a daylong meeting with him here yesterday, many of the Governors say that so far he seems to be doing just fine.

title: Practical Traveler; TAILORED TRIPS WITH PRECISE PRICES
description: If you want to know the total cost of a trip in advance, including the minor daily expenses that can quickly add up to a considerable figure, you can have your travel agent put together your own tour package, with each day scheduled and each expenditure calculated in advance, down to the morning paper at the door of your hotel room. Putting together such a package allows travelers to avoid the sort of surprises that can quickly unbalance a budget.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: * Rates restricted by state usury laws

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Action for Children's TV Issues a Viewing Chart
description: Action for Children's Television, a group that notes flaws in programming, promotes improvements and endeavors to limit excessive viewing, has devised an ''ACT TV Time Chart'' to enable children to record the time spent at a set over a period of several weeks. The chart is being distributed to parents, teachers and physicians.

title: Monkeys Transferred After Abuse Charges
description: The Montgomery County police seized more than a dozen monkeys from a research laboratory yesterday and took them into ''protective custody.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Reagan Administration, like its predecessors, will continue the traditional American policy of strong support for Yugoslavia's independence, territorial integrity and national unity.

title: WALL ST. WASN'T SCARED STIFF BY DEFICITS
description: For the second time in 18 months, sinking bond and stock markets have forced a President to order politically disruptive spending cuts in hopes of pulling the Federal budget into the black.

title: Lucy Look Is Married to Pieterjan Kat
description: The marriage of Lucy Look, daughter of David Townsend Look of Far Hills, N.J., and the late Charlotte MacDougall Sears Look, to Pieterjan Kat took place yesterday in Bernardsville, N.J. The Rev. Thomas G. Cleveland performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Pieter J. Kat of Malaga, Spain, formerly of Amsterdam.

title: Ethnic History
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining Out; ITALIAN FARE IN MEDITERRANEAN AURA
description: BRANFORD CLAUDIO'S, on the Green in Branford, offers something relatively rare in Connecticut: an Italian restaurant whose white-washed Mediterranean decor evokes images of Italy.

title: The Quiet Repeal
description: To the Business Editor: In their comment on the quiet repeal of the corporate income tax, ''Taxing Profits: The Unseen Burden'' (Aug. 16), Norman Robertson and Ronald J. Talley make much of the fact that nonfinancial corporations last year paid taxes on some $62 billion of ''phantom profits'' - the amount of Commerce Department adjustments for underdepreciation and inventory gains. They fail to mention that this sector excluded from its taxable income some $56 billion in net interest payments, most of which is a phantom expense.

title: Quake Shakes Japan's North
description: A moderate earthquake shook the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido today but there were no reports of damage or casualties, the Meteorological Agency reported.

title: Bank Robbery in Hong Kong
description: Three robbers who threatened tellers with firebombs, pistols and knives stole more than $20,000 from a Hong Kong branch of the Chase Manhattan Bank today, a police spokesman said. The thieves waved bottles of what they said was a flammable liquid and threatened to set the bank on fire. After the robbery, they fled in car, the spokesman said.

title: N.F.L. FINDS GOLD AT PITT
description: By WILLIAM N. WALLACE

title: STILL WATERS AWAIT TROUT FISHERMEN
description: Outdoors/Nelson Bryant That happy time of year approaches when still water fly fishing for trout in the Northeast is superlative. In many areas of the region, lack of rain and summer's heat have turned streams into warm tickles where trout gather about cold springs in order to survive, and although the still waters - the lakes and ponds - suffer similarly, the effect is less severe, and cool days and cold nights will soon have the trout in them moving about and feeding with a zest they have not displayed since early June.

title: RED SOX ROOKIE LOSES NO-HITTER IN 9TH
description: In the 79-year history of the Yankees, only six pitchers have thrown no-hitters against them. Bob Ojeda, a 23-year-old rookie for the Boston Red Sox, came within one inning of becoming the seventh yesterday.

description: Mexico upset by oil price drop and criticism on Salvador policy 3 In Ulster's antiterrorism courts, the jury box is always empty 4 Around the World 5 Pol Pot forces were intransigent at Cambodian conference 6 From Nairobi to Mombasa, Ken- yans jam the trains at night 8 Isak Dinesen's old African re- tainer recalls the past 9 Alberta Premier looks to next battle with Ottawa 12 Israeli's remarks bring Egyptian charge of meddling 16 Mecca may attract two million pilgrims this year 24 Government/Politics Western Governors seem satis- fied with Watt's performance 30 Mayor Young of Detroit is heavily favored for third term 43 House changes plan to limit travel at D.C. airport 102 Energy OPEC aides said to negotiate on a single crude-oil price 22 Study rates 15 nuclear plants' per- formance 'below average' 48 Indian Point investigation de- layed by N.R.C. 65 Obituaries Frank McHugh, actor known for supporting roles 52 Allen Skinner Hubbard, expert in corporate law 52 General Around the Nation 30 Son of woman friend of Cardinal Cody gets $150,000 30 Rare stork attracting bird-watch- ers to Texas 34 Four members of Philadelphia police decoy squad are indicted 36 One of three escaped Kansas con- victs is caught 38 Defendant in Utah jogger slay- ings plays lawyer's role 40 Revised hotel design urged to save two theaters 54 Coast Guard starts search in L.I. title: OPEC IS SAID TO NEGOIATE ON A UNIFIED PRICE
description: Representatives of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries were said to h a ve begun negotiations today aimed at setting a single price for cru de oil that would stabilize the market in the face of a worldwi de surplus.

title: A GUIDE TO CONNECTICUT'S FALL COOKING CLASSES
description: IT'S back-to-school time for adults as well as children. During the summer, many cooking school instructors - and their students - can't stand the heat, so they temporarily get out of the kitchen.

title: THROUGH CANADA'S NORTH BY DOGSLED
description: Physically, he stood about five feet tall in his caribou-skin boots. His hands were dark and wide, the fingers scarred, the thick nails nicked and bent. His face, heavily lined, was free of expression as it peered from under the peak of a battered baseball cap. But the old eyes, even behind bifocals, were sharp and clear.

title: The Region; Close Count In Hartford
description: The office of Mayor of Hartford is largely ceremonial, but the primary contest for it last week was anything but. Having trailed the incumbent in pre-election polls, State Repres entative Thirman Milner seemed to sur prise everyone but the incumbent George A. Athanson, whocontended he was the underdog, by coming within 95 votes of taking the Democrati c nomination.

title: Major News; Economics Is Mostly What's On Congress's Mind
description: ''Within 90 days,'' said Robert H. Michel last week, ''something's got to give.'' The House Minority Leader's specific reference was to record-high interest rates. What followed gave some hint of another complaint. ''I'm a political creature,'' Mr. Michel continued, ''and our political futures (require) there's got to be some movement before spring.''

title: THE FATE OF WOMEN OF GENIUS
description: This introduction to ''A Room of One's Own'' will appear in the new edition of the book to be published in November by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich in honor of the centennial of Virg inia Woolf's birth. By MARY GORDON

title: MAKING OF A LITERARY SHOGUN
description: Paul Bernstein is a freelance writer based in California. By Paul Bernstein efore the end of World War II, James Clavell was shot in the face, and wandered lost in the jungle for days. A Malay village eventually took the British Army officer in as one of its own, but he was later captured by the Japanese, and he is convinced to this day that, if it had not been for the atom bombs dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki to end the war, he would have died in a Singapore prison camp called Changi. Food amounted to a quarter-pound of rice per day, one egg per week and occasional vegetables. Flies, heat, disease and unimaginably harsh living conditions killed off 14 out of every 15 prisoners.

title: SHIRT STYLE
description: Shirts and ties fall into the furnishings and accessories category of men's clothing, but, in fact, they play a major part in the way a man looks. The staid and serious businessman's uniform includes solid color or subdued striped shirts, and regimental stripe or small-pattern ties in muted colors.

title: Critics' Choices
description: NEW MUSIC ''New music'' is a catch-all term, but in New York it usually applies to the experimental-music scene in lower Manhattan, and that scene most definitely includes styles that are not derived from the mainstream Western classical-music tradition. This week offers three especially striking and varied examples of ''new music'' that is in no way classical, yet is hardly unabashedly popular, either.

title: Pamela Richards Bride OfThomas Griffin Kern
description: Pamela Jeanne Richards, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Richards of North Caldwell, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas Griffin Kern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Kern of Garden City and Westhampton Beach, L.I. The Rev. Gerard W. Sogliuzzo performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in Caldwell, N.J.

title: 6 1 The Region By Richard Levine and Carlyle C. Douglas; 6 Minutes Faster Not Fast Enough
description: It may seem of small comfort to those who need a hospital in a hurry, for whom any wait is bound to be too long, but officials of the New York City Emergency Medical Service said last week they had cut ambulance response time by more than six minutes on serious calls.

title: Chess; DON'T BE IN A HURRY TO GIVE UP THE SHIP
description: There is a player on the international tournament circuit who is notorious for prematurely resigning. Unwilling to suffer - as one must in a clearly inferior position - he gives up at the first provocation.

title: The World; Look Ahead With Anger
description: British union leaders met in Blackpool's Opera House last week to sound off against Margaret Thatcher, lament their own decline and echo radical policies. But the most important arias were sung sotto voce offstage by rivals for leadership of the Labor Party seeking union backing.

title: U.S. SETTLING DAMAGE CLAIM IN RELEASE OF GAS
description: William Tanner remembers working on a ranch less than a mile west of Igloo amid clouds of yellowish-gray gas that ''stunk like hell'' and burned his nose and throat.

title: WALL STREET, FEARING DEFICITS, FINDS REAGAN MIXED BLESSING
description: The Reagan Administration is struggling to decipher an apparent and annoying contradiction: Why, if Mr. Reagan has done so much for business, isn't its applause rolling in? Why, if Wall Street supported his tax cuts, budget cuts and restrictive monetary policies, is the Street now so critical of the Reagan program and driving down the values of stocks and bonds?

title: Musical Hirshbein Play To Mark His Centenary
description: In celebration of the 100th anniversary of the birth of Peretz Hirshbein, his comedy ''The Blacksmith's Daughters'' will be presented in a musical version with music by Simon Tanowsky and lyrics by Yitzak Yanasovich. It will open Oct. 10 at the Norman Thomas Theater under the aegis of Ben Bonus.

title: TV View; THESE PRODUCTIONS STRUGGLE TO BE PROVOCATIVE
