description: Television, sometimes referred to as ''global village,'' has an irritating habit of conveying images of the world that are either questionable or grossly inadequate. Two notable examples are at hand this week. One takes the form of documentary: ''Women of Russia,'' a syndicated package of three half-hour programs that can be seen Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday on WPIX/Channel 11 at 8 P.M. The other is an ''entertainment'' in the form of a television movie: ''Fly Away Home,'' on the ABC network this Friday evening at 9. Both are defeated by inflated promises.

title: EXPERT ADVICE ON SHOPPING
description: SHOPPING By Jani Wooldridge Although the days of the knowledgeable, seasoned men's-wear salesman may seem to be long past, at many fine men's stores and departments there are still trained professionals of the old-time order who can help a man wind his way through the often confusing business of shopping. Among these are three stores that have been dressing men for more than 40 years - Barney's, Brooks Brothers and Paul Stuart.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: POLITICIANS will be getting into the swim of things on Tuesday when the Mid-Island Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in Plainview holds a ''Pol-ympics,'' a charity swim meet, beginning at 11:30 A.M. to celebrate the opening of its $4 million Health and Physical Education Building.

title: A LIGHTER-THAN-AIR BUSINESS
description: BURLINGTON PART of Kathy and Brian Boland's work means dropping in, literally, on strangers. The Bolands are hot-air balloonists and, because it is difficult to make pinpoint landings with the lighter-than-air craft, they usually float down on any lawn, park or pasture that is convenient.

title: Reagan Is Criticized On Air Traffic Situation
description: Through frequent travels north of Exit 10 (the Perth Amboy area) on the New Jersey Turnpike, I have never ceased at being both amazed at and gratified by the human and technological skills brought to bear in controlling air traffic as it weaves its convoluted patterns over New Jersey's most famous highway.

title: TRACING L.I. LIFE 3,000 YEARS AGO
description: STONY BROOK WHAT Edward Johannemann, director of the Long Island Archeological Project at the State University at Stony Brook, characterizes as a 3,000-year-old weapons factory is being excavated in the Stony Brook area. The site, d iscovered last November during an envir onment al impact study, appears to have been a chipping station where quart z lance points, scrapers and knives were manufactured. In addition , it may also have contained a men's house.

title: IF THE FOOD EQUALED THE WINE...
description: THE Carriage Pond Inne in Port Jefferson is one of the prettier restaurants in this area, and it boasts a brief but astonishingly sophisticated and reasonably priced wine list. So far so good. The cooking, however, does not measure up to the decor or the wines.

title: WHEN UNCLE SAM IS THE BABY SITTER
description: A LTHOUGH the Reagan tax bill provides generous tax breaks for the wealthy, it also contains several provisions that could substantially trim taxes for the average American family. One is an easing of the marriage penalty. Another is a provision that could greatly aid many two-income households with children, but is still virtually unknown outside a tight coterie of tax experts.

title: ALBERTA PREMIER LOOKS TO NEXT BATTLE WITH OTTAWA
description: The first round of a battle against the centralization of power in Ottawa has been fought and won, according to Premier Peter Lougheed of Alberta, who is expecting round two shortly.

title: MURALS TO REPLACE FIRE-RUINED GLASS
description: YONKERS THREE valuable Tiffany stained-glass windows, destroyed by fire at St. Andrew's Community Center here, will be replaced temporarily by murals painted on plywood by local schoolchildren, if the center directors can work out one problem.

title: Westchester Guide; OLD FILM CLASSICS
description: A film series for children and young people that may also interest older movie lovers is soon to begin at Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville.

title: Behind the Best Seller s; LYNN SHAHAN
description: ''Through the walls of my condominium I hear Beverly's muffled, heartrending sobs ...'' Beverly, recently widowed, is living alone and not liking it. But now, ready to take her up the mountain and show her that ''once you reach the top, the view is great!'' is Lynn Shahan, author of a new best seller, ''Living Alone and Liking It.'' The book begins with Beverly's plight.

title: COMMENTS BY ISRAEL'S CHIEF OF STAFF IRRITATE EGYPT
description: A diplomatic dispute has erupted between Egypt and Israel over remarks by the Israeli chief of staff that the peace treaty between the two nations ''will come to an end'' if President Anwar el-Sadat's Government collapses.

title: Lesleigh F. Ladd Bride of Lawyer
description: Lesleigh Fazzio Ladd, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert L. Fazzio of Oakland, Calif., was married yesterday to William Holmes Forsyth Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Forsyth of Princeton, N.J., and Salisbury, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Charles Amstein, a Presbyterian minister, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Stein in Peekskill, N.Y.

title: HANDICAPPED TESTING ARRAY OF DEVICES
description: THE New Jersey Library for the Blind and Handicapped has begun a program to help the state's 750,000 handicapped people evaluate the array of devices designed specifically for them.

title: CHILI EVENT TO BENEFIT NATURE SITE
description: THE first New York State chili championship will be held at Playland Sept. 26 to raise mon ey for refurbis hing the Rye Nature Center's museum building. And surprisingly, t here will be no beans onthe premises. The Saturday contest, sanctione d by the Chili Appreciation Society International, follows s trict rules.

title: PALISADES PARK: JUST A MEMORY
description: CLIFFSIDE PARK TEN years ago this week, Palisades Amusement Park ended its summer season by closing forever. Within two years, the park, which boasted the world's largest saltwater swimming pool and more than 200 rides and attractions, was sold and demolished.

title: UTAH DEFENDANT HAS LAWYER ROLE
description: Each day since his trial began last week, Joseph Paul Franklin has donned an expensive-looking, darkblue, three-piece suit, picked up a handful of fresh legal pads and joined an entourage of beefy law enforcement officers for the elevator ride from the basement-level Salt Lake County Jail to a fifthfloor courtroom.

title: Block Says Development Aid Will Go to 'Truly Rural Areas'
description: Federal aid for rural development programs will be concentrated in ''truly rural areas'' rather than in those that are becoming more urban, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today.

title: Westchester Journal
description: ''WISH I could play tennis like those guys,'' said a slender man, nodding his head in the direction of two muscular, sun-tanned men engaged in an intense series of volleys on the tennis courts at the Stouffer's Inn in Harrison one recent afternoon.

title: Around the Garden
description: This Week:

title: BRIDGES OVER RAIL LINES IN POOR SHAPE
description: DETAILED engineering reports on 44 of the 104 vehicular bridges spanning commuter railroad lines throughout the state confirm what the Department of Transportation and NJ Transit have suspected since they took over the bankrupt carriers: Most are in extremely poor condition.

title: DANCE: SALLIE WILSON WITH RUSH COMPANY
description: Patrice M. Regnier's Rush Dance Company has good dancers, as eminent a guest artist as Sallie Wilson and choreography by Miss Regnier that tends to be disconcerting.

title: HOUSE CHANGES ADMINISTRATION AIRPORT PLAN
description: In a defeat for the Reagan Administration, the House has voted to overturn a Transportation Department plan to limit passenger traffic at crowded Washington National Airport.

title: GEORGIA BEATS CALIFORNIA, 27-13
description: Buck Belue scored one touchdown and passed for another, and Herschel Walker gained 167 yards as Georgia beat California, 27-13, today.

title: Coat of Arms for Zimbabwe
description: The Government today unveiled a new Zimbabwean coat of arms, showing a hoe and a Soviet-designed AK-47 assault rifle, with the motto, ''Unity, freedom, work.''

title: PUTNAM TAKES ON MASS TRANSIT WITH A 3-BUS FLEET
description: A trolley car rolled through Putnam County 50 years ago, from the Peekskill train station to Westchester County. It stopped running when people started buying their own cars and its profits fell.

title: DIVERSITY HELPS L.I. ECONOMY TO HOLD ITS OWN
description: ALTHOUGH interest rates are very high, the Island's economy appears to be resisting threats of a recession, according to both government and private economists and business leaders. The diversi ty of economic activity from Great Neck to Montauk Point, with a harvest that ranges from computer chips and jet airplanes to potatoes and shellfish, has provided the Island with a resilience th at has eluded many other areas of the country.

title: Jane Ackerman Bride Of Theodore Mitchell
description: Jane Benson Ackerman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Ackerman of New Vernon, N.J., and Lake Placid, N.Y., was married yesterday to Theodore Reed Mitchell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Robert Mitchell of San Rafael, Calif. The Rev. Dr. George E. Chorba performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of New Vernon.

title: ALLEN S. HUBBARD, 90, LAWYER
description: Allen Skinner Hubbard, retired senior partner of the Wall Street law firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed, died Friday at his home in Vero Beach, Fla., where he had lived for the last several years. He was 90 years old.

title: KEEPING TABS ON THE MOSQUES CAN'T BE EASY
description: From the perspective of Westerners accustomed to the giveand-take of democracy, President Anwar el-Sadat went overboard when he cracked down on his weak secular opposition. It's much harder to gauge whether the Egyptian leader was also overreacting to the challenge of Moslem fundamentalism.

title: UNTOLD STORY OF COAST IMMIGRATION CENTER UNFOLDS
description: Paul Chow vividly recalls his father's admonition of ''Angel Island. Shhh!'' ''I heard that so much, it's almost like one word,'' he says. From 1910 to 1940, about 175,000 Chinese came to the United States. Most, including the elder Chow, awaited entry to Gam Saan, the Golden Mountain, as they called California, at the Federal Immigration Station on Angel Island.

title: FALL FESTIVALS
description: No matter what the meteorologists may produce, this is fair weather on the Island. And today dedicated fairgoers have a veritable plethora in which to indulge their fancies - or fantasies.

title: Politics; HOW STUDIES DIFFER ON POLICE MERGER
description: SEVERAL weeks ago, a task force appointed by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello to study the problem-plagued Department of Public Safety Services issued its $80,000 report. It recommended many changes in the merged police agency, including one that the commissioner be appointed by the county executive to serve ''at his pleasure'' for an indefinite term.

title: Music; CHANCES ABOUND FOR ARTISTS-TO-BE
description: IF anything surpasses the joy of listening to music, it is the deep satisfaction of making it yourself. Fortunately, Westchester is full of opportunities for would-be Perlmans and Pavarottis to express themselves in performance.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL CHALLENGES RAID ON INDIAN-RUN FOOD FACILITY
description: An official of the Interior Department has said that he wants an investigation of what he called an ''irresponsible'' state raid that shut down an Indian-run food warehouse. ''I find it irresponsible to do that withou t the common courtesy ofinforming us about the problems down there,'' Roy Sampsel, Deputy Secretary of the department, said of Wednesda y's raid in Greenwood. S.D.

title: Rangers 3, Angels 2
description: Bill Sample and Mario Mendoza scored runs with singles in the second inning for Texas and Dave Schmidt, a reliever, sto pped a late California rally. The Angels lost their eighth straig ht game.

title: Tax-Exempts
description: To the Business Editor: What was not evident from y our article, ''Moribund Bonds'' (Aug. 30), is the t remendous cost to business.

title: 107% MALPRACTICE-INSURANCE RATE RISE URGED
description: Each of the state's two largest medical malpractice insurance writers for New York doctors should be allowed 107 percent rate increases, according to a report by a private actuary.

title: Missile Said to Explode Near Italian Cargo Plane
description: The authorities are investigating a report that a missile exploded near an Italian civilian cargo plane on a flight between Palermo and Rome last month, air control officials said today.

title: Dining Out; WHERE DINERS ARRANGE THE MEAL
description: RENEE'S EATERY in Scarsdale is one of a growing number of places that have termed themselves ''eateries'' rather than restaurants. This new hybrid seems something more than a luncheonette and something less than a conventional restaurant, and the space is often shared with some other related enterprise, a bakery, a cheese shop, a fishmongery or, as in the case of Renee's, a small-scale delicatessen. Combining such food operations has its obvious advantages: it assures rapid turnover and is thus a natural way of having free ingredients always on hand. Although not all the dishes that Renee's Kitchen produced were successful, the failures did not lack refulgently fresh ingredients.

title: GOOD-NEIGHBOR POLICY HELPING STATE COLLEGE
description: DANBURY CARVED out of a rolling countryside, a new 315-acre campus is being prepared for Western Connecticut State College that seems serene, secluded and far removed from the thriving, congested city of Danbury just a few miles away.

title: Notes; THE GROWING FIELD OF TRAVEL FOR THE DISABLED
description: The specialized field of travel for the disabled is growing. Wings on Wheels of Lynnwood, Wash. was started in 1962. Flying Wheels Travel of Owatonna, Minn. began in 1970. Each has been a leader in the field. Now there is Whole Person Tours in Bayonne, N.J.

title: INDIANS' SACRED ART DEFACED BY MODERN TRAVELERS
description: Travelers on their way to the California gold rush of 1849 scrawled their names on rocks at Hueco Tanks, three rugged volcanic formations on an open prairie 30 miles east of here.

title: Ideas and Trends; Government Pulls Back on Two School Cases
description: The Justice Department served notice last w eek that the Government wants to abandon its advocacy of minority-gro up children in two Supreme Court cases involving the right to eq ual education. The actions switched signals sent by the Carter A dministration and may have placed the Reagan Administration in the position of siding with state governments and, in at least one instan ce, opposing local officials and residents.

title: R.L. Nype Weds Martha E. Foley
description: Martha Elizabeth Foley, daughter of Mrs. David Carey MacNichol of Cumberland, Me., and Frederick Joseph Foley of Cape Elizabeth, Me., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Russell Lawrence Nype, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell H. Nype of New York and Kennebunkport, Me. The Rev. Stephen Foote performed the ceremony at St. Mary the Virgin Episcopal Church in Falmouth Foreside, Me.

title: THE PLAYER WHO NEEDS ENEMIES
description: THE kid needs enemies. Even as he hobbled to his feet, testing the ankle he had just twisted, John McEnroe wanted to hear malice in the applause of the crowd.

title: Pop-Up Books
description: To the Business Editor: By the figures quoted in your article, ''Publishing: How Colombia Popped Up From the Crowd'' (Aug. 30), some 850 Indian women produce some $7 million in overseas sales for Carvajal annually at a labor cost of just $1.3 million, or only 18.9 percent of sales. Since a decent, two-room, furnished apartment with cold water, small bath and two-cubic-foot refrigerator costs upwards of $500 monthly, it is difficult to see how the people of Colombia are benefited by foreign exchange or the Carvajals.

title: Timothy Harmon Greene Marries Caryn Ann Ahern
description: The marriage of Caryn Ann Ahern, a flight attendant with Pan American World Airways, to Timothy Harmon Greene, a petroleum landman, took place at the Keystone (Colo.)

title: 4 Die in Small-Plane Crash
description: A twin-engine Cessna 320 plane crashed yesterday shortly after takeoff near here, killing the four people aboard, the Federal Aviation Administration said. The names of the victims were withheld pending notification of their families. Republic is 90 miles northwest of Spokane.

title: Martha S. Doyle Is Bride
description: At St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Hingham, Mass., yesterday, Martha Sutcliffe Doyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Layton Doyle of Hingham, was married to George Gampfer Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Jay Schwartz of Rowayton, Conn. The bride's father, a deacon in the Roman Catholic Church, performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass celebrated by the Rev. John Arens.

title: Smoking Aloft
description: To the Editor:

title: LET'S LET BUSINESS HELP RUN THE CITIES
description: R ELYING primarily on public services to meet many of the needs of society has not stopped the near disastrous decay in inner cities or poverty-stricken rural areas. It hasn't alleviated the shamefully high levels of unemployment among disadvantaged youths - nor has it changed the unresponsiveness of our educational system or improved our antiquated, overcrowded prisons.

title: Politics; A 'WARNING' ON THE BUDGET
description: THE difficulties facing the General Assembly when it meets in special session, probably in November, to try to cope with cuts in Federal aid were underscored the other day by a budget analysis prepared by Representative Gardner E. Wright Jr., co-chairman of the legislature's Appropriations Committee.

title: Engineer in Building Collapse Gives Up His Florida License
description: The engineer who had primary responsibility for the Cocoa Beach, Fla., condominium that collapsed last spring, killing 11 construction workers, surrendere d his licensetoday and said he would never practice again.

title: DANCE: JENNIFER THIENES O FFERS GE NTLE PROGRAM
description: Although Jennifer Thienes choreographed nothing specifically about ice cream, Friday night's program by Jennifer Thienes and Dancers at the Merce Cunningham Studio nevertheless brought ice cream to mind. Like ice cream, Miss Thienes's dances were smooth, sweet and mildly refreshing on a warm summer evening. But, also like ice cream, they were not really very substantial.

title: French Diplomat Says China Holds His Fiancee
description: A French diplomat said today that the police were holding his Chinese fiancee.

title: U.S. REVERSES MOVE TO AID RIGHTS SUIT
description: Justice Department officials have rejected a staff recommendation to file a legal brief in support of blacks alleging a violation of their v oting rights in Edgefield County, S.C., the bir thplace of Senator Strom Thurmond.

title: Camera; PORTRAITS ARE BETTER IN NATURAL SURROUNDINGS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Fred W. Rosen and George Schaub are freelance writers and photographers.

title: Connecticut Housing; HOME-RAFFLE LAW CALLED 'UNFAIR'
description: THE first raffle in the state in recent times to have a house as a prize will be held in Glastonbury this fall, as a result of a raffle law passed this year by the General Assembly.

title: The World; Playing Defense On Afghanistan
description: The Soviet Union likes to consider itself the ''natu ral ally'' of the third wor ld, but since 85,000 of its troops invaded Afghanistan in 1979, foru ms dominated by developing countries have condemned Moscow with a s much regularity as South Africa and Israel. In an apparent effo rt to keep this year's session of the United Nations General Assem bly, which opens Tuesday, from voting yet another rebuke, Sovie t and Afghan diplomats have been professing new ''flexibility '' on the Afghan issue.

title: Brewers 6, Orioles 3
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Ted Simmons made three singles and drove in three runs for Milwaukee. Randy Lerch (5-8) pitched five and one-third innings to gain the victory. He got relief help from Reggie Cleveland and Rollie Fingers, who pitched the ninth inning for his 24th save and was backed by the Brewers' fifth double play of the game.

title: SUSPECTS IN BOMBING OF ITALY RAIL STATION CAPTURED IN LONDON
description: Seven fugitives who are wanted by Italian authorities on terrorist charges have been captured in a series of raids in north London, police officials said today.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Delaine Heliotis suggests that the Social Security tax rate could be drastically lowered, to 2 percent, if the ceiling on earnings subject to the tax were removed (only the first $29,700 earned by any one person is taxed now).

title: THE SHRINKING 2X4
description: With the housing industry in the doldrums, these are difficult times for lumbermen, who traditionally ship about 45 percent of their products to homebuilders. Not surprisingly, demand for an important product, the 2*4 board, is also depressed.

title: POL POT GROUP UN YIELDING AT CAMBODIAN TALKS
description: The Cambodian Communist movement led by the deposed Prime Minister, Pol Pot, was intransigent and self-assured throughout the conference last week in which it and two non-Communist factions agreed to work toward a coalition against Vietnam's occupation of Cambodia.

title: Land Mine Blast Kills 20 on Bus in Uganda
description: Twenty civilians were killed today when their bus was blown apart as it hit a land mine in a forest five miles east of here, the Uganda radio reported.

title: A TIME TO STOP BRACKET CREEP
description: I HAVE heard dire predictions that if income tax indexation is adopted in this country, everything bad from the collapse of the economy to the infestation of the Northeast by the Mediterranean fruit fly would occur. But upon reading your article, ''What Indexing Income Taxes Produced for Canada'' (Aug. 23), I was pleasantly surprised to learn that the problems besettin g Canada today have resulted not so much from indexing, but rathe r from that country's inability to adopt and implement a budget to control the Government'sspending.

title: LECTURER OVERCOMES BLINDNESS AND DEAFNESS
description: Geraldine Lawhorn never hears the soothing Bach she plays on her piano. She never sees the eager faces of the students who sit in her classroom or the smiles of people who attend her lectures.

title: FOUR POETS
description: A WORLD OF DIFFERENCE By Heather McHugh. 53 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. Cloth, $9.95. Paper, $5.95. BARN FEVER And Other Poems. By Peter Davison. 59 pp. New York: Atheneum. Cloth, $11.95. Paper, $5.95. SCENES FROM ANOTHER LIFE By J.D. McClatchy. 63 pp. New York: George Braziller. Paper, $4.95. FOR THE SLEEPWALKERS By Edward Hirsch. 84 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. Cloth, $10.95. Paper, $5.95.

title: The World; Will New Dutch Cabinet Last?
description: After three and a half months of doing without, the Netherlands had a Government last week. But the arduously formed coalition was expected to last only as long as it could evade United States pressure to plant 48 nuclear cruise missiles among the canals and polders.

title: JOHN IRVING'S WORLD
description: THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE By John Irving. 401 pp. New York: A Henry Robbins Book/E.P. Dutton. $15.50.

title: Memories Of Kharlamov
description: To the Sports Editor: I read recently that Valery Kharlamov, the star forward of the Soviet national hockey team, was killed in a car crash in Moscow. His death both saddened me and brought images of games past to mind.

title: Ideas and Trends; Ordination Tests Church Relations
description: One denomination's heresy can be another's doctrine - a situation that, throughout the ages, has led the clergy to change affiliations. But last week's re-ordination of a former Episcopal priest as a Catholic touched on sensitive contemporary disagreements between the two churches.

title: The World; South Africa Ignores a Cue
description: South African officials left the Reagan Administration out on a limb last week, declining to back up Washington's explanation for going easy on Pretoria in its widely criticized incursion into Angola.

title: OFF TO SCHOOL BUT NOT EXACTLY ON SCHEDULE
description: HOW did the opening of school go this year? This is how. Labor Day: Everything under control. New shoes, pressed jeans and crisp shirts are in the closets. Checked with older kids in neighborhood and purchased all necessary school supplies to avoid first-day, afterschool crush. New knapsack for fourth-grade son, new schoolbag for son entering half-day kindergarten. It is wonderful being organized.

title: CURFEW OPPONENTS WEIGH COURT SUIT
description: LEGISLATION to help reduce nighttime noise in the skies over Westchester and Connecticut was signed last week, but quiet on the ground seemed to remain elusive. Each side in the long battle over nighttime air traffic at Westchester County Airport continued its arguments even as the bill was signed into law last Tuesday by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello.

title: Polly Wall Is Married
description: At Grace Episcopal Church in Providence, R.I., yesterday, Mary Brooks Wall, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Winthrop Wall of Providence, was married to Livy Marion Coe 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Coe Jr. of Centralia, Ill. Retired Bishop John Seville Higgins of Rhode Island performed the ceremony.

title: GUARD IS CALLED OUT TO HUNT KANSAS FUGITIVES
description: National Guardsmen were called out today to reinforce 200 law-enforcement agents scouring southwest Missouri for two escaped convicts after a third convict was captured earlier in the day.

title: INMATES REBEL IN ELIZABETH, TAKING 6 HOSTAGES
description: Inmates broke out of their cells at the Union County Jail tonight and took six guards hostage before they were forced back into their cells, authorities said.

title: Cape Cod Arts Festival 4 Days This Week
description: The third f all arts festival will take place in Provincetown, Truroand Wellfleet , Mass., Thursday through next Sunday. The festiva l will offer a program of visual, performing and literary arts .

title: No Headline
description: As the conflicts in Ireland continue amidst curious speculations by intellectuals as to the political, social, economic and religious reasons they exist, an impending resolution to the state of affairs seems no closer. The ''Lost Generation'' born in Ireland seem as apathetic to the world that studies them as do the minds that probe their existence. Whether Roman Catholic or Protestant, king or peasant, can't we for once address ourselves to impending solutions rather than rehashing the same things we've seen in Ireland for so many years? Can't we, for once, stop commenting on religious or political ideals we neither fully understand nor are able to shed an objective light on? VICTORIA BIGLIANO, Newton, Mass.

title: WATER-POWER SITES IDENTIFIED
description: USING water power to generate electricity could lessen slightly the state's dependence on foreign oil but could not significantly reduce the use of coal and nuclear energy, according to a report recently released by the New England River Basins Commission.

title: FLOOD INSURANCE
description: Federal efforts to curb flood losses date back to the Great Depression of the 1930's, when Congress launched a nationwide dam-building program specifically to control floods. By the 1960's, it had become clear that dams, levees, and other engineering solutions were not enough.  There were fewer floods, but flood damage rose faster than ever. Construction in hazardous flood plains accelerated, in part becaus e owners assumed that their property would not be flooded but that public funds would bail them out if disaster ever struck.

title: The Nation; A Judicious Nominee Keeps Her Own Counsel
description: For those who expected Sandra Day O'Connor to provide a preview of her thinking about decisions she would make as an Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, last week was a disappointment.

title: REALTY NEWS
description: EAST SIDE

title: Ideas and Trends; Medfly Has Been Stymied - Maybe
description: The Mediterranean fruit fly replaced earthquakes this summer as California's most feared natu ral enemy; but l ast week, there were signs that efforts to contain it were at last meeting with some success.

title: POP-SOUL: SHOUTER AT WESTBURY
description: By the time Teddy Pendergrass left the Philadelphia soul group Harold Melvin and the Blue Notes several years ago to go solo, he had established himself as the most important pop-soul shouter since the Four Tops' Levi Stubbs. But Mr. Pendergrass's powerful baritone was even rawer and raspier.

title: THE ROLLING STONES GATHER NO MOSS
description: In Bridgehampton, Mass., where the Rolling Stones are rehearsing for their first tour anywhere since 1978, a church has put up a handpainted sign that is visible from the highway. It says ''God Speed to the Rolling Stones.'' ''God Speed'' to the rock and roll band that wrote and recorded ''Sympathy for the Devil,'' was involved in some of the most heavily publicized drug arrests of the 60's and 70's, and has always seemed to stand for rebellion and anarchy? Next year the Rolling Stones will be celebrating their 20th anniversary as a band. Can it be that rock's bad boys have become respectable?

title: Paperback Talk
description: The Beatles live on. This week, B. Dalton, the chain that helped revolutionize the book business by bringing supermarket-style stores to nearly every section of the country, is opening a large new store in Manhattan's Greenwich Village, the legendary heart of American bohemia. To mark the occasion, it is holding a press party this evening to mark the publication of a new book about the Beatles, the rock-and-roll group that symbolizes much of the spirit of the generation that came of age during the past 25 years. Next month Waldenbooks, Dalton's arch-rival in supermarket bookselling, will be proclaiming ''October Is Beatles Month'' in its nationwide chain.

title: Editors' Choice
No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Sarah Colquitt Is Married To Harry N. Barfoot 3d
description: Sarah E. Colquitt, daughter of Col. Rawlins M. Colquitt Jr., U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Colquitt of Manlius, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Harry Norman Barfoot 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Barfoot Jr. of Newtown, Pa.

title: BRIDGEPORT BRIBE CASE IS SHIFTED TO U.S. COURT
description: The case of an F.B.I. operative charged with attempting to bribe this city's Police Superintendent in an undercover operation that backfired was transferred today to Federal District Court.

title: The Careful Shopper; Webster of Hartsdale Clearing Out Stock
description: The storewide inventory clearance at Webster Men's, Boy's and Gal's Shop includes a possible bid for the fixtures, with delivery in abeyance. Meanwhile, prices are dropping on Sergio Valente, Bonjour, Jordache and Carabine jeans (to $27.50), on Lee flares and riveted Levis (to $17.95, on Lee straight leg rider corduroys (to $16.95) and on Lee workpants (to $15.50). Sizes are men's 6 to 48 and for women 3 to 15.

title: Salvadorans Report Capture Of a Base Camp for Guerrillas
description: Government troops backed by special United States-trained units captured a guerrilla base camp used by about 400 rebels, culminating six days of fighting in eastern El Salvador, the operation's commander said today.

title: Ideas and Trends; 'Guernica' Goes Home to Spain
description: Few paintings have had the artistic or political impact of Picasso's anti-war mural, ''Guernica.'' For 42 years it hung in New York, a sort of conscience-in-exile, waiting for the right time to take its intended place in the painter's native Spain.

title: A Judge Well Chosen
description: Sandra Day O'Connor's confirmation hearings for appointment to the Supreme Court were more of a challenge to her stamina than her intellect. She was, if anything, overprepared for the fumbling, tedious questions of the Senators on the Judiciary Committee, leaving single-issue inquisitors in utter disarray.

title: Miss McDonnell Engaged to Wed William Genge
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward McDonnell of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Mary McDonnell, to William Dean Genge, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Harrison Genge of Pittsburgh.

title: Photography View; CHINESE PORTRAITS AND SOUTHERN VIEWS
description: Nothing in photography is more fascinating - or more frustrating - than the rediscovery of 19th-century commercial photography that is now going on. It is fascinating because so much good and interesting work continues to surface. It is frustrating because we know so little about the work and the photographers who produced it.

title: Court in Virginia Rules Public Can Attend Pretrial Hearings
description: Judges cannot ban the press and the public from pretrial hearings without strong evidence that an open hearing would prejudice a defendant's rights, the Virginia Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

title: 10 DEAD IN CRASH ON TAIWAN
description: A truck carrying a dozen people on a religious pilgrimage ran through a railroad crossing in northern Taiwan today and was hit by a train, the police said. Ten people were reported killed and two were seriously injured. The authorities said the 41-year-old truck driver, who was killed in the crash, apparently ignored warning signals at the crossing.

title: MIDWEST SEEKING TO REGAIN WELCOME
description: Four years ago, Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio proposed to the Legislature a bill to cut taxes on businessess in depressed, inner-city areas. The bill was attacked as a big-business giveway and went nowhere.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 13, 1981
description: International The AWACS plane sale to Saudi Arabia is still expected to be approved in Congress, Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia was told by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. In a visit to the prince's villa on Spain's southern coast, Mr. Haig said that the Reagan Administration expects victory despite strong opposition in Congress and from Israel. (Page 1, Column 1.) A challenge to Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, is coming from a breakaway Palestinian guerrilla organization secretly backed by Syria, according to American officials and sources in the Middle East. The group, which is said to have begun terrorist operations, is headed by Abu Nidal, who split with the Arafat organization in the early 1970's. Austrian authorities say the Abu Nidal faction is responsible for the attack on a Vienna synagogue on Aug. 29. (1:4.)

title: SEARCH IS BEGUN FOR THE WRECK OF THE KAREN E
description: The Coast Guard began an unusual search this morning for the wreck of a 36-footcabin cruiser that sank a month ago, killing five persons.

title: Art; TERENZIO CANVASES, PONSOLD PORTRAITS SHOWN IN STORRS
description: THE William Benton Museum has opened its new season with two exhibitions of considerable interest (University of Connecticut, Storrs, through Oct. 4). The larger of the displays, more than 60 canvases and numerous drawings, is by Anthony Terenzio, who taught at the university from 1955 to 1979; the other consists of 71 black and white portraits - of artists, mainly - taken by the photographer Renate Ponsold.

title: CARDS BEAT METS, 4-2, ON HOMER IN 13TH
description: There was a full moon here tonight so maybe it was not surprising that some strange things happened in Mets' gameagainst the C ardinals.

title: FISTS FULL OF DOLLARS: HEARNS TAKES ON LEONARD
description: Michael Katz is the boxing writer of The New York Times. By Michael Katz ike all prizefighters, Sugar Ray Leonard had taken his share of verbal punches from opponents. There had been the cracks about his courage and boxing ability, the insinuations regarding his manhood, the occasional shots at his wife and child. All that he had put up with stoically. But at a recent press conference, Leonard's most dangerous rival to date threw a blow much closer to his ego. ''After fighting me on Sept. 16,'' Thomas Hearns threatened, ''your softdrink commercials are goin' down the drain.''

title: Antiques; BIRD DECOYS ARE LURING COLLECTORS
description: Decoys. Tall, short, fat and skinny; exotically plumed and devoid of feathers; boasting broadbills and pin-like beaks - these are the grand deceivers, the tools the hunter uses to pull birds out of the sky. After surviving surf, sand and stray bullets, the best of the vintage ducks, geese and shorebirds have, in recent years, become the target of another sort of attention - the admiration of collectors.

title: REDSKINS TO TEST NEW OFFENSE ON GIANTS
description: When Joe Theismann was growing up in South River, N. J., near New Brunswick, and when he was going to Notre Dame, he rooted for the Giants. When the Washington Redskins play the Giants here tomorrow, Theismann will be the Redskin quarterback, trying to master a new offense for a new coach.

title: CALL IT SUIGENOCIDE
description: MX Prescription for Disaster. By Herbert Scoville Jr. Illustrated. 231 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. Cloth, $15. Paper, $6.95. By THOMAS POWERS

title: KNITS FOR FALL
description: The British call them pullovers; Americans call them sweaters, and,next to jeans, they are probably the most-oft en-worn part of what could be called our national dress.

title: Jersey Physician Sentenced To Prison in Murder of Wife
description: A. physician convicted of killing his wife and burying her under a picnic table at their Vineland, N.J., home was sentenced to 18 to 20 years in state prison today. The doctor, Harry Sugar, said he plans to appeal the sentence, handed down b y Judge Nicholas Scalera of Superior Court. Dr. Sugar, 57 years old, was convicted last Aug. 4 of murdering hissecond wife, Joan, 40, following a five-hour quarrel at their home onJuly 9, 1979.

title: 38 Dispensers of Food Facing Health Charges
description: Thirty-eight food establishments were cited last week for health code violations by the New York City Health Department in its weekly report.

title: FOR BANGUI, A NEW RULER WITH OLD PROBLEMS
description: Under a mango tree in one of Bangui's poorer districts, a small group of Africans sits around drinking millet beer out of calabashes and talking politics.

title: At Age 18, Idle Dice Still Clears Hurdles
description: Ike - or Idle Dice, as he is formally known - is old by horse standards. At the age of 18, he could be compared with Harrison Dillard, now 58, going over the hurdles 15 or 20 years hence the way he did in the 1952 Olympics. But Idle Dice is still going over the horse show hurdles on the Grand Prix circuit and doing it very well. He has already won more than $300,000 for his owners, Mr. and Mrs. Ha rry Gill, who believe that had Idle Dice been winning the current i nflated purses when he started 13 years ago, the figure would surpas s $1 million.

title: HOPES RISE WITH THE CURTAIN
description: IN many ways, the scene was a backstage classic. There were the aspiring entertainers, practicing in the dressing room mirrors. There were the parents, wishing luck and talking about the prize. And there was the young woman who said of a stage career, ''It's in my blood.''

title: FOUR JERSEY COUNTIES MAY GET FUNDS FOR JAILS
description: A state commission has approved a Byrne administration plan to allow four counties to share $21.9 million in bond funds to upgrade their jails or build new additions in exchange for housing state prisoners.

title: RUTGERS DEFEATS COLGATE, 13-5
description: Rutgers' offense, impressive in the 29-27 opening victory over Syracuse last Saturday, was spotty today, scoring only one touchdown. But with Alex Falcinelli providing 7 points on his kicking, the Scarlet Knights managed a 13-to-5 triumph over Colgate.

title: THE TV PORNOGRAPHY BOOM
description: Tony Schwartz writes about the television industry for The New York Times. She was in her early 20's and she was wearing a short, powder blue terry-cloth j umpsuit that buttoned up the front. If the jumpsuit had been bright p ink or had hugged her body a bit more tightly, it might have seemed d eliberately seductive. Instead, on a young woman with a pleasant, ope n face, it was simply girlish - a cool answer to a scorchingly h ot Saturday afternoon.

title: WEST GERMANY AND ITALY CALL FOR EARLY SOVIET - U.S. PARLEY
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and Prime Minis te r Giovanni Spadolini today called on the superpowers to begin arms co ntrol negotiations and said that Western Europe had a right to be c onsulted by the United States on defense and economic issues.

title: Ulster's Lost Generation
description: In his article ''Ulster's Lost Generation'' (Aug. 2), John Conroy tells of a young ''hood'' s aying that he ''felt sorry'' for the members of a British patrol killed in a bomb attack in the Divis Flats. Jack H olland, in his recent book ''Too Long a Sacrifice,'' gives a simil ar account of Irish women praying over the body of a slain Scots s oldier whom they had hated as an enemy only minutes before.

title: Home Clinic; A MANUAL OF ARMS FOR CAULKING GUN
description: ONE of the best weapons a homeowner can use to defend his house against attack by the elements is a caulking gun. On the outside, caulking compound is used to seal out water, cold drafts and insects; inside, it is used to close gaps around showers, bathtubs and sinks.

title: Barbara Samuels Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Barbara Christie Samuels to Raul Luciano Katz has been announced by Howard J. Samuels of New York and Barbara Christie Samuels of New York and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jorge M. Katz of Buenos Aires.

title: CURFEW FAILS TO END DEBATE ON AIRPORT
description: LEGISLATION to help reduce nighttime noise in the skies over Fairfield County was signed last week, but quiet on the ground seemed to remain elusive.

title: SHOPPING CENTERS, SHOWING AGE, SEEKING NEW LOOK
description: T HE Gardiner Manor Mall is a 22-year-old, rather large shopping center in Bay Shore, L.I., 30 miles east of New York City. A driver set out last week to find it and on his first pass along Sunrise Highway, he overshot the turnoff, unmarked because of laws against road signs, by two miles.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: 1968) , blind from the age of 2, and Anne Sullivan Macy (1866-1932), the pa rtially sighted woman who was her teacher and companion in a relati onship that resulted in many advances in the instruction of the handi capped and the role of women in American life. Our reviewer Joseph F eatherstone called this biography, based on much fresh material, ''a deeply absorbing portrait of two intertwined lives whose meani ngs can't be understood separately.''

title: YOUNG IS FAVORED IN DETROIT VOTING
description: This year alone, Mayor Coleman A. Young has increased Detroit's income tax rate by 50 percent, twisted the arms of municipal unions to win pay freezes and reduced city services. He is also considered a shoo-in for re-election this fall.

title: ANTINEOMALTHUSIAN
description: THE ULTIMATE RESOURCE By Julian L. Simon. Illustrated. 415 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $14.50. By B. BRUCE-BRIGGS

title: WALL STREET: A STRATEGY FOR GENTLEMEN WARRIORS
description: He slew his first foe at the age of 13, and went on to kill 60 more in one-to one-combat. He was a painter, a writer, a calligrapher, philosopher and a spiritual leader. His name is Miyamoto Musashi, a legendary Japanese samurai warrior who is suddenly a hot issue on Wall Street.

title: GETTING A SOLID FOOTING
description: SHOESBy Alan J. Flusser Alan J. Flusser is a men's-wear designer and the author of ''Making the Man,'' from which this excerpt was taken. It will be published this month by Simon & Schuster. Copyright c 1981 by Alan J. Flusser fashion authorities have long been in agreement that shoes can be the quickest giveaway to a man's style sense and social position. George Frazier, former columnist for Esquire magazine and The Boston Globe, would often remark, ''Wanna know if a guy is well dressed? Look down.'' Diana Vreeland, Frazier's counterpart in the women's fashion world, now head of the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, concurs. Speaking of developing a wardrobe, she advises, ''First, I'd put money into shoes. No variety, just something I could wear with everything. Marvelous shoes and boots. Whatever it is you wear, I think shoes are terribly important.''

title: Follow-Up on the News; Greenwich Allure
description: Faced with declining enrollments and budget problems, the Board of Education in Greenwich, Conn., last June invited out-of-town students to attend its public schools - but at private school tuition rates.

title: Guest Observer
description: Patrick McDonnell

title: Leather; WHEN THE OCCASION IS FORMAN
description: here are far fewer events calling for formal wear now than in decades past, but a man may still need a tuxedo for formal business or social occasions.

title: FIRE I. LYME CASES SPUR TICK ALERT
description: IT started this summer with a little red spot on the boy's cheek. No one thought anything of it -not until weeks after he had left Fire Island for camp in New England. Then suddenly the 11-year-old fell ill with flu-like symptoms and had to be hospitalized for arthritic pains.

title: 6 Killed, 35 Hurt in a Wreck Involving 3 Portuguese Trains
description: Six persons were killed and 35 were injured in crashes involving three trains north of Lisbon last night, national railroad authorities said today.

title: DRESSING IN STYLE FOR THE CITY
description: A securities analyst, Warren Hamer spends his workweek in classic, three-button suits, a white shirt and a low-key four-in-hand tie. He likes classic clothes and is not looking for anything stylish, and he firmly believes that "you should stay with what looks good on you."

title: Nancy McGregor Wed To Thomas W. Janes
description: Nancy Dangerfield McGregor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack E. McGregor of Bedford, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Thomas Warham Janes, son of Dr. and Mrs. G. Sargent Janes of Lincoln, Mass. The Rev. Thomas Hughart performed the ceremony at the Bedford Presbyterian Church.

title: JERSEY AGENCY HELPS YOUTH IN TROUBLE BEAT THE ODDS
description: It is Friday morning in a cozy office across the corridor from the police Juvenile Aid Bureau and a stone's toss from the Town Hall. Eight men and women gathered around a table are talking together, as they do every Friday, about the children of West Orange who are in trouble.

title: OIL AND SALVADOR ISSUES UPSET MEXICO
description: After three years of rapid economic growth and rising international prestige, Mexico's self-assurance has suddenly been shaken by the drop in world oil prices and sharp regional criticism of its policy toward the civil war in El Salvador.

title: The Mothers of Slain Children Start a New Group in Atlanta
description: The mothers who started the Committee to Stop Children's Murders after their children were killed in a string of slayings have left the group to form a new corporation, a lawyer announced yesterday.

title: COSMOS DEFEAT STRIKERS BY 4-3
description: The Cosmos continued their domination over the Fort Lauderdale Strikers with a 4-3 victory tonight in the opening game of their North American Soccer League semifinal playoff series.

title: LITTLE ROCK SCHOOLS, TRAILBLAZERS IN INTEGRATION, NOW DRAWING WHITES BACK
description: This city's boosters have just made a film designed to entice industry here. Entitled ''One in a Million,'' it is a handsomely mounted 17 and a half minutes of fresh-faced Southerners at work and at play in central Arkansas. The film doesn't have much time for black people, and no time at all for schools, the two elements of Little Rock that once held the world's attention and the two elements that to this day form the hottest issue in town.

title: The C.I.A. and Lumumba
description: I share Madeleine Kalb's fear of the ''plausible deniabiltiy'' made available to our elected leaders (''The C.I.A. and Lumumba,'' Aug. 2). I would go one step further in suggesting that much of the clearly illegal and immoral actions of such agencies as the C.I.A. are condoned by American citizens, as they retreat further from the pressing issues of the world at large.

title: ARAB LENDING ON RISE
description: Despite slow economic growth and high interest rates in industrial countries, worries about whether the international financial system can cope with the rising debts of developing countries after the 1979-1980 run-up in oil prices seem to be easing.

title: AND THE BOX OFFICE ACCEPTS COCONUTS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Phyllis Ellen Funke is a freelance writer with a special interest in the theater. By PHYLLIS ELLEN FUNKE PORT MORESBY, Papua New Guinea As the sago palms rustle at the edge of the jungle, the villagers descend the long ladders of their thatched huts-on-stilts and congregate in a clearing. Some are wearing ski parkas and balaclavas; others, merely blades of grass sprouting from G-strings.

title: SEPTEMBER MEMORIES: BACK TO SCHOOL
description: IT was September 1965, and I had just turned 17 years old. I was in the driveway pitching a tennis ball against the garage door. It was the bottom of the ninth inning, three men on base. I was Whitey Ford, working with a one-run lead against the Boston Red Sox for the pennant.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN TAIPEI
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- HENRY KAMM is chief Asian diplomatic correspondent of The Times. By HENRY KAMM

title: A Better Plan For Playoffs
description: To the Sports Editor: I agree with the Reds' manager, John McNamara (The New York Times, Aug. 30), in that he is correct in his assessment that baseball's plan renders his team's excellent performance in the first half a futile effort. I have a simple plan that should satisfy him and the other second-place teams from the first half: the second-place team of the first half should play the second place team of the second half in a one-tgame playoff.

title: New York Times Magazine September 13, 1981
description: William Safire 16 On Language See You Later, Allegator Edward B. Fiske 30 Guest Observer Supply-Side Holidays Jane Rosen 38 Sidney Blumenthal 42 Marketing the President Tony Schwartz 44 The TV Pornography Boom Paul Bernstein 46 Making of a Literary S hogun John Russell 55 Atget John Kelly 100 Bridging America's Drug Gap Jani Wooldridge 134 Fashion When Leather Gets Silky Martin Filler 138 Design/Food and Moira Hodgson Dining, Executive Style Michael Katz 142 Fists Full of Dollars: Hearns Takes on Leonard 148 Puzzles Answers, Page 150 158 Letters Cover: Photograph by Evelyn Hofer/Archive Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: Reading and Writing; NEW YORK, NEW YORK
description: Like so many other New Yorkers, I had accustomed myself to thinking of the city as ugly, even taking satisfaction in the thought, elaborating an esthetic of ugliness, arguing that the face of New York is ugly with character just as certain celebrities -Igor Stravinsky or Truman Capote as photographed by Richard Avedon - are ugly. Rationalizing on behalf of New York - a whole new branch of sociology - I had cultivated a romance of squalor, a nostalgie de la boue, a poetics of friction and risk. Like the latest version of Spengler's ''intellectual nomad,'' I had tried to adopt an ironic, rueful, tragicomic attitude toward a city that had changed in my lifetime from a wonderful place to live to a test of the human condition.

title: Pesticide Findings Threaten Montana's Waterfowl Season
description: Pesticide contamination threatens waterfowl hunting in Montana this fall, and state officials here are notifying 16 other states that tainted ducks and geese may be headingtheir way.

title: A SURVIVOR'S STORY
description: TRENTON EXCEPT for a pea-soup fog, the night of July 26, 1956, on the Andrea Doria was like many other nights aboard the liner. On the Tourist Class deck, Louis DelToro had just finished playing cards with three friends and was on his way to the bar. Music welled as merrymakers d anced to an orchestra.

title: A 50-ROLE STALWART OF THE LONG WHARF
description: BECAUSE I had seen him so often at the Long Wharf, I had felt safe in assuming two things about Emery Battis: that he was under contract to the Long Wharf and that he was British. In a recent interview with him, I found that I was wrong in both cases. As to contract, his answer was: ''No. In the earlier years when the company was more stable, and there was less jobbing-in of actors, there were several of us - William Swetland, Joyce Ebert, and myself come to mind - who did have a seasonal contract, but that has not been operative for a number of years. Now we are signed from play to play.''

title: UT ILILTY MUST REFUND $2.9 MILLION TO CUSTOMERS
description: The New Jersey Boar d of Public Utilities has ordered the Public Service Electric and G as Company to return $2.9 million to customers because of the 1979 shutdown of its Salem nuclear generating station.

title: TENOR: BYUNG SUN SOH
description: There was an odd sensation listening to Byung Sun Soh sing in Alice Tully Hall on Friday night. He had an unusually pleasing, occasionally even sweet-tempered tenor instrument, with a solid and focused middle range that seemed to let the music of Schubert and Bizet lay comfortably against his vocal chords.

title: Gene-Watching
description: Does exposure to certain chemicals damage human chromosomes? If damage is found, should that person avoid the chemicals? Questions like these arose in the mid-1970's after medical researchers at the Dow Chemical Company in Freeport, Tex., reported that some Dow workers exposed to benzene and epichlorohydrin were showing an unusual rate of chromosome breakage. The chief researcher, Dr. D. Jack Kilian, believed that such changes in chromosomes, the rod-shaped bodies that contain genes, might be a harbinger of cancer and birth defects.

title: AILING HOTEL REFLECTS TOGO'S ECONOMIC PLIGHT
description: Approaching Lome by road across themarshy plains of neighboring Ghana, the 30-story Second of February Hotel and Con ference Center suddenly appears on the horizon.

title: AUCKLANDERS PROTEST SOUTH AFRICA VISIT
description: Battles erupted today between the police and anti-apartheid demonstrators protesting a tour of New Zealand by a South African rugby team, the Springboks. The tour ended today.

title: Dance View; CUNNINGHAM'S MUSICAL CHOICES
description: Over the ye ars, Merce Cunningham has taught people to look at dancein new ways. But one aspect of his productions is still troublesome: the music. Th e scores he dances to continue to bother people. And they bothered people once again at the Cunningham company's spring season at Cit y Center.

title: Jersey and Utility Join In a Solar Heating Pla n
description: The New Jersey Energy Commissioner and utility regulators have approved a plan from the state's largest utility to supply and install solar water heating systems in homes.

title: A FULL MENU OF CLASSES IN THE CUISINE OF YOUR CHOICE
description: IN today's food-conscious world, learning to cook means more than a course on how to boil water. The cuisines of the world - northern Italian, regional Chinese, Moroccan - can be learned without traveling many miles, and the Island's cooking school teachers are once again obliging with an eclectic offering of classes this fall.

title: CHERRY HILL TRACK STILL A STORM CENTER
description: MORE than four years have elapsed since the grandstand and clubhouse at Garden State Park in Cherry Hill burned, and, although there may be some action in the Legislature soon to rebuild the horse racing track, it still could be a while before any construction takes place.

title: ELDERLY BILKED AND ABUSED, INQUIRY FINDS
description: One was a retired circus dancer, one a retired General Motors engineer, another a former housemaid. Most were old. What they had in common was a regular income and a world that had forgotten them until five women from Florida were dumped at a hospital here a month ago and reported that they had been kept in a basement in suburban Detroit.

title: THEODORE ROSZAK RECALLED
description: To the Editor:

title: Title to U.S. Women
description: The United States women's softball team played Japan to a scoreless nine-inning tie today and clinched the title in a three-nation tournament.

title: Miss McHale, John Silliman Are Married
description: Jennifer Ann McHale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas McHale of London and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to John Emory Silliman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Silliman Jr. of Wilmington, Del. The Rev. James Allen performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church on Nantucket.

title: SOVIET JEWS CHOOSING U.S. PUT ISRAELIS IN A QUANDRY
description: Outsiders who deal with the opaque bureaucracy of the Soviet Union often imagine that they have found the formula to smooth the way. Western businessmen and politicians have frequently shunned contact with dissidents in Moscow. Some American professors and film-makers in need of official cooperation have avoided being seen with controversial American correspondents. Likewise, Israel, despite vilification in the Soviet press and the absence of diplomatic relations, has cautiously sought to maintain the momentum of Soviet Jewish emigration. In the mid-1970's, for example, Jerusalem sent warnings through travelers to Jewish activists in Moscow to stay away from Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and human rights advocate, fearing that association with him would endanger the emigration movement.

title: ITALIAN POET WON NOBLE PRIZE
description: Eugenio Montale, the Italian poet who won the 1975 Nobel Prize for Literature, died last night, the ANSA news agency reported. He was 84 years old.

title: No Headline
description: On July 27, 1960, I covered the arrival of Patrice Lumumba at Washington's National Airport and his 30-minute news conference at the State Department. At the time, I was television correspondent for United Press-Fox Movietone Newsreel, with 120 domestic televison stations and 30 foreign networks. The State Department news conference was arranged following my request and that of the CBS correspondent assigned to the story. (The ''regulars'' on the beat were for the most part relaxing in between the political conventions of the Democrat and Republican Parties.)

title: French Start Dismantling A Napoleonic System
description: The National Assembly voted today to withdraw most of the powers of the prefects of France's 95 departments in the first step toward dismantling the centralized political system that has dominated France since Napoleon. The Government also scrapped a plan by the previous administration to provide all residents with computerized identity cards.

title: Westchester Housing; A RESIDENCE FOR SINGLE WOMEN
description: SINGLE women need ''someone to come home to'' and ''a place where it's O.K. to be single,'' the Rev. Dorothy Payne decided several years ago - and that is what she is providing in a large old house in White Plains.

title: CARDINAL TERMS ALLEGATIONS 'INNUENDOS AND HALF TRUTHS'
description: John Cardinal Cody asserted today that a newspaper's articles about him were innuendos and half truths, but the paper published new charges saying that a woman with close personal ties to the Cardinal was the beneficiary of a $100,000 insuran ce policy on his life and had borrowed $60,000 on it.

title: SUBTLETIES OF POWER
description: THE CARE OF TIME By Eric Ambler. 277 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95. By JULIAN SYMONS

title: MEMORIES CLICK ALONG THE PUTNAM LINE
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR IN this scenic, midwestern region of the county, where the terrain is rolling and the surroundings bucolic, this town's old railroad station, through which hundreds of Putnam Division commuters once passed, still serves the public - as a library.

title: Helen Harris Walker B ride of Brian Nolan
description: Helen Harris Walker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Walker of Haverford, Pa., was married yesterday to Brian Thomas Nolan, son of Mrs. John T. Adams and the late Bernard J. Nolan of Cochituate, Mass. The Rev. Dr. David Watermulder performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Bryn Mawr (Pa.)

title: CALIFORNIA CURBS MENTAL STATUS AS TRIAL DEFENSE
description: The voluntary manslaughter conviction of Dan White, the San Francisco Supervisor who sought out and shot Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk in 1979, left many Californians uneasy about the ''diminished capacity defense'' that was successfully employed at Mr. White's murder trial.

title: S. W. Serenbetz W eds Jean Butler
description: Jean Louise Butler and Stuart Weygand Serenbetz, who received master's degrees in 1979 from the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College, were married in Larchmont, N.Y., yesterday. The Rev. Richard B. Martin performed the ceremony at the Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Killing Linked to Robbery
description: Detectives said today that robbery was the apparent motive for the slaying of Phillip Frandson, 56 years old, a dean from the University of California at Los Angeles, in his home in Laurel Canyon, a rustic Hollywood Hills neighborhood. A coroner's spokesman said that Dean Frandson's nude body was found in bed Wednesday.

title: A WAKE-UP CALL AT QUALITY INNS
description: T HINGS are afoot in the lodging business. A dynamic duo is on the loose, boasting of nothing less than turning the industry upside down. Breathing enthusiasm, the two men -Robert C. Hazard Jr. and Gerald W. Petitt - say they are out to take Quality Inns, an also-ran among the top chains, and thrust it into the big time.

title: Bridge; THE POLES SET A SNARE
description: Three years ago, Poland won the Rosenblum Cup at the Olympiad in New Orleans and it seemed likely that a new forc e had arrived on the world scene and would challenge for supremacy . That promise was confirmed in July in Birmingham, England, whe n the Poles won the European Championship.

title: Judith Beere Is Married
description: Judith Hennessey Beere was married yesterday to Beekman Verplanck Beavers of Darien, Conn.

title: State Dept. Aide Visits Peru To See Development Projects
description: Thomas O. Enders, Assistant United States Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, began a fourday visit to Peru today with a tour of development projects in the central jungle region.

title: The World; Sadat Defends Arrests of His Opponents
description: Besides peace in the Middle East, Anwar el-Sadat has often said that he would like to bequeath to his people democratic institutions. So far, the Egyptian leader seems better at the theory than the practice.

title: U.S. Envoy to Jordan Injured
description: The United States Ambassador to Jordan, Richard N. Viets, was hospitalized today with a broken arm and a fractured pelvis after falling off a horse, according to officials at the American Embassy here. Mr. Viets, 51 years old, was reported ''doing fine.''

title: T. W. Smith Weds Juliet Richardson
description: Juliet Richardson and Terence William Smith, architects in Princeton, N.J., were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston. The ity Episcopal Church in Boston.

title: THEY SWING TO 'BIG BAND'SOUND
description: MASSAPEQUA PARK WHEN the Big Band Association appears at, say, Old Westbury Gardens, the Cherry Valley Country Club or the North Shore Veterans Hospital, the spirited sounds resemble those of musicians enjoying a holiday rather than playing a workaday date.

title: Virginia Maynard Wed To Robert Egan Swain
description: Virginia Maynard, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin P. Maynard 3d of Chestnut Hill, Mass., and Prouts Neck, Me., was married yesterday to Robert Egan Swain, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Swain of Tulsa, Okla. The Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger performed the ecumenical service at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill.

title: Miss Mitchell, Dancer, Marri ed
description: Katherine Mitchell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Mitchell of Redding, Conn., was married there yesterday to David B. Cooper Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Cooper of Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio. Justice of the Peace Ann Huntoon of Ridgefield, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Mitchell home.

title: The Nation; School's In, With Many Exceptions
description: Labor Day in recent years has come to mark the end of summer and the start of the picket-line season at many of the nation's public schools. The lines were up again last week in scores of communities as hard-pressed school systems, typically facing declining enrollments and pressures to hold down spending, clashed with teachers who want more pay.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: ALTHOUGH the developer of the $1.25 billion Berry's Creek Center in the Hackensack Meadowlands is optimistic about starting work on the project, merchants in communities around the site are battling to prevent construction because they fear it will hurt local shopping.

title: ATGET
description: By John Russell John Russell is an art critic for The New York Times. It is now just 50 years since it was first suggested that an unsung old Frenchman named Eugene Atget was one of the greatest photographers who ever lived.

title: Small Colleges Attract 34,876
description: Willie Jackson and Greg Goldstein scored touchdowns and the defense thwarted a fourth-quarter threat as Wayne State edged Slippery Rock, 14-13, today.

title: Water Proposal Is Made
description: The State Board of Public Utilities today proposed a change that would mean some water company customers will not have to pay towards the cost of replacing water lines and extensions. The board proposed that water companies eliminate depreciation on ''contributed property'' as an expense to be passed to customers.

title: Inmates' Silence Mark s Revolt in Attica in '71
description: Nearly 2,000 state prison inmates here sat in silence through their meals yesterday and today, apparently to mark the 10th anniversary of the bloodiest prison uprising in United States history.

title: Noel Takes Lightweight Title
description: Claude Noel of Trinidad captured the vacant World Boxing Association lightweight title today on a unanimous 15-round decision over Rodolfo (Gato) Gonzalez.

title: SEOUL DISSIDENT BLAMED IN PART FOR HIS PLIGHT
description: Kim Dae Jung, the jailed dissident leader, is regarded by his supporters as the wronged victim of judicial manipulations by the military rulers of South Korea. But some also say that he is partly responsible for his plight.

title: CAN VERDI'S EARLY OPERAS WIN LASTING POPULARITY?
description: The fact that the New York City Opera is opening its regular season on Thursday with Verdi's ''Nabucco'' will not send shock waves of surprise through the musical community. Nor is anyone likely to be astounded that the same company is offering a new production this spring of Verdi's ''I Lombardi.'' Verdi is one of the undisputed masters of opera, after all, and especially in the Rudolf Bing regime at the Metropolitan his operas dominated the repertory of that company as well.

title: MOTHER'S DAY AT THE MOVIES -A DREAM AND A NIGHTMARE FAYE DUNAWAY AS
description: HOLLYWOOD TERROR By JENNIFER DUNNING

title: PIANIST: HARRIET SERR
description: It takes a certain amount of musical bravura to begin a piano recital with Beethoven's final piano sonata in C minor (Op. 111), and then to follow it with Schubert's final piano sonata in B-flat (Op. Posth.).

title: 'Suspicious' Fire Drives 200 From th
description: A smoky four-alarm fire that officials called ''suspicious'' forced 200 guests and employees to flee the Annapolis Hilton Hotel early this morning.

title: BACH AND CHOPIN IN CONCERT
description: What do the contrapuntal webs spun by Johann Sebastian Bach in ''The Well-Tempered Clavier'' have in common with Frederic Chopin's set of sometimes elegant, sometimes stormy Preludes, Opus 28? Some say plenty, citing Chopin's reported habit of playing preludes and fugues from the ''Well-Tempered'' before launching into his own concerts, and insisting that Chopin not only patterned his own collected explorations of the major and minor keys after the Bach work, but that several of his preludes contain deliberate thematic illusions to Bach's. Others contend that the two composers are as different as night and day - that one was a supreme intellectual and the other a sentimentalist - and that the century between the composition of ''The Well-Tempered Clavier'' and the Chopin Preludes represents an unbridgeable stylistic ocean.

title: The Region; Just Another Black Wednesday In New York
description: If New Yorkers seem unfazed by life's bleak surprises, it is perhaps because they have so many of them. There was yet another on Wednesday, when an explosion at a Consolidated Edison Company generating station left much of lower and midtown Manhattan without electricity.

title: 3 CITIES LINKED IN HISTORY
description: THREE communities as different from each other as any in New Jersey could be - Garfield, Hoboken and Elberon -are linked by history to an event whose centennial is being marked this week: the assassination of a President.

title: Topics; REACTIONS, OVER AND UNDER; Less Wind
description: Will Rogers once said that when the legislature is in session, people feel the same ''as when the baby gets hold of a hammer.'' He would have been amazed by the actions of Christopher Jackman, Speaker of New Jersey's Assembly.

title: Operetta Opens Sept. 22 At the Gramercy Arts
description: The first New York production of ''La Corte de Faraon,'' or ''The Pharaoh's Court,'' a comic operetta, with book and lyrics by Perrin and Palacios and music by Vicente Lleo, will be presented by Gilberto Zaldivar's Repertorio Espanol.

title: Susan Schick Is Married to Matthew E. Galligan
description: Susan R. Schick and Matthew E. Galligan, who are with the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, were married yest erday at the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church in Plainfield, N.J . Rev. Richard Van Deusen and the Rev. John J. Paris, a Roman Ca tholic priest, performedthe ceremony.

title: IRISH DEFEAT L.S.U. IN FAUST'S DEBUT
description: Gerry Faust's debut as Notre Dame's head football coach was an unqualified success today as the Irish scored twice within the first eight minutes and rolled to a 27-9 victory over Louisiana State.

title: Rebecca Kirby Is a Bride
description: At the Wellesley (Mass.) Congregational Church yesterday, Rebecca Ann Kirby and David Paul Rizzo, marketing representatives with the International Business Machines Corporation in Boston, were married by the Rev. Philip J. Mayher. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Marvin G. Kirby of Chicago and Mr. and Mrs. Paul Rizzo of Armonk, N.Y.

title: DANCE: CLASSICAL PIECES FROM SOUTHERN INDIA
description: Malini Srirama, an Indian classical dancer who lives in Michigan, and Meena Alagappan, still in high school in New York but trained in classical dance in her native India, joined forces Friday night for a charming program of Indian dance in the Dag Hammarskjold Auditorium at the United Nations.

title: GRANT'S CIVIL WAR CABIN SET TO MOVE
description: The log cabin where Gen. Ulysses S. Grant plotted the end of the Civil War is being returned to Virginia before vandals and termites destroy the structure.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Newman Breaks Mark In Sports Car Qualifying
description: The actor Paul Newman broke his lap record by racing 2.85 miles in 1 minute 43.219 seconds today in a Pioneer/Datsun 280 ZX.

title: U.S. COURT REJECTS 2 DEATH PENALTIES
description: A Federal court has set aside the death penalties of two Texas men convicted of murder. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ordered lower courts to impose reduced sentences or conduct new sentencing proceedings for Kenneth Granviel, who was convicted in 1976 of murdering a 2-year-old, Natasha McClendon, and for Billy Joe Battie, who was convicted of killing a store clerk and a customer in a Fort Worth robbery Jan. 13, 1975.

title: About Connecticut
description: SOMETIME in the next week or so, Governor O'Neill is expected to call for a special election so that the First Congressional District seat held by the late William R. Cotter can be filled when the second session of the 97th Congress convenes in Washington in January.

title: U.S. Beginning Inquiry On Surplus Cash in Texas
description: A special Federal investigations team has been formed to look into possible links between organized drug trafficking and millions of dollars in cash that is being deposited in banks in south Texas, Federal officials say.

title: WASTE IN THE PENTAGON
description: WASHINGTON Cutting $27 billion, or 5 percent, out of the $544 billion military budget planned for fiscal years 1983 and 1984 without slicing into military muscle ought to be easy. But political and bureaucratic obstacles are formidable. As former Defense Secretary Harold Brown once said, ''One man's waste is another man's job.''

title: Recordings; NEW DISKS MINE KURT WEILL'S RICHES
description: The almost total neglect of Kurt Weill's music after his death in 1950 is perhaps not altogether surprising. A composer so intensely concerned with reflecting the temper of his environment and serving his audience would inevitably be considered passe by the following generation, especially in the 1950's when such populist concerns were unfashionable in the serious music community. A reassessment of Weill was equally inevitable, because like all great composers his best music reaches out far beyond its original utilitarian or p arochial purposes.

title: Linda Joan Stamm Is Bride of John Andrew Willig
description: Linda Joan Stamm, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Julian Stamm of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Sag Harbor, L.I., was married there yesterday to John Andrew Willig, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Willig of Manhasset, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Judge Joseph Duffy of the East Hampton (L.I.) Town Court at the Long Island home of the bride's parents.

title: Stamps; U.N. FLAG SERIES CONTINUES
description: The United Nations is issuing on Sept. 23 another group of 16 stamps displaying the flags of its member states. This is the second group in a continuing ''Flag'' Series that will go on for years - until the flags of all the nations in the U.N. have appeared on stamps.

title: MORE RETIREES SEEKING JOBS, BUT GETTING HIRED IS NOT EASY
description: MINEOLA CHARLES ALB ANESE, hired two years ago by the Rolev Corporation in Port Washingt on as a maintenance man, is now plant manager. Harry Ernenwein, a retired banker, works for the same company, assisting in making fin ancial decisions.

title: Explosives Found in Belfast
description: The police said today that they may have foiled plans by the outlawed Irish Republican Army for a major bombing campaign in Northern Ireland after finding and removing more than 1,300 pounds of explosives from a furniture warehouse yesterday. On Thursday, 300 pounds of explosives were uncovered in the back of a van.

title: SANSONE LEADS POST TO A 29-9 VICTORY
description: Dan Sansone threw for three touchdowns and ran for a fourth to lead C.W. Post to a 29-9 victory yesterday over East Stroudsburg State in Brookville, L.I.

title: Priscilla Smart, Editor, Bride
description: Priscilla Smart, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Bruce Smart Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., was married in St. Timothy's Episcopal Church there yesterday to Peter Maximilian Schwarzenbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Schwarzenbach of Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. Robert L. Bast, rector of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Music View; CELEBRATING THE ART OF HAYDN AND STRAVINSKY
description: If the science of geriatrics were further advanced, Franz Joseph Haydn and Igor Stravinsky would still be with us, the former at age 250 happily touring the world and accepting honorary doctorates, the latter at 100 busily signing his name to waspish magazine articles and erudite books. But it is not, and they are not. So, in their unfortunate absence all we can do is pay them homage by celebrating their joint anniversary in the way all composers would prefer: by playing and listening to lots of their music. A good start in that direction will be made tonight when the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center begins its 1981-82 season at Alice Tully Hall with a week of concerts marking the Stravinsky-Haydn year. Looking beyond this September festival, the Society will be offering at least one Haydn work on each of its 14 subscription programs during the season. A number of Stravinsky tributes are scheduled elsewhere, among them a night at the Whitney Museum on Sept. 30, when the performing artists will include Virgil Thomson, who himself will be celebrated this season as he turns 85.

title: Jill Blum Married to Dr. Michael Millis
description: Jill Elisabeth Blum and Dr. Michael Brian Millis were married yesterday in the East Dennis (Mass.) Community Church. The Rev. Dr. Edwin D. McLane, former associate minister of the First Congregational Church in Chappaqua, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

title: Dining Out; A TEAM ENTERPRISE IN LAMBERTVILLE
description: A FEW years ago, restaurants like Cafe Renni in Lambertville were as rare as a pearl in an oyster. Now, however, small enterprises run by a husband-and-wife team, with one managing the dining room and the other the kitchen, are opening with increasing frequency.

title: POLICE CRACK DOWN ON SUBWAY-FARE CHEATS
description: The Transit Authority police caught more than 60,000 ''fare beaters'' during the first six months of 1981 in an effort to collect thousands of dollars in revenues believed lost each year, authorities said.

title: RISKS GROW AS SOLIDARITY GETS POLITICALLY BOLDER
description: ''We want life free from poverty, exploitation, fear and lies in a democratically organized and self-governing society.'' So began the final document last week from the Solidarity union's national congress - an extraordinary convocation that was supposed to be largely procedural but ended by adopting ringing declarations and demands that read like a bill of rights for Eastern Europe. The six-day session in Gdansk was heard round the world, with indignation and anger in the Soviet East and with admiration, but also anxiety, in the West.

title: Connecticut Guide; A BUSINESS OF CARDS
description: The Canton Library has on exhibition through this month a portion of the collection of 17,000 business cards amassed by Benjamin B. Klau, a 13-year- old eighth-grade student at Avon Middle School.

title: KHOMEINI SAYS U.S. 'LACKEYS' KILLED HIS AIDE
