description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini today characterized the assassination of his personal representative in Tabriz as the work of United States ''lackeys'' and vowed that ''the people would take revenge,'' the Teheran radio reported.

title: TOM SEAVER ON HOW BASEBALL TURF HAS SPEEDED UP BASEBALL
description: THE biggest change in baseball in the last 15 years has been the em ergence of team speed as a vital offensive and defensive weapon. Th e introduction of artificial or synthetic surfaces, now in use in ni ne of the 26 major league ball parks, has played an important role in quickening the game. Artificial turf plays faster than grass. Bo uncers bounce higher and farther, line shots in the outfield get to the wall sooner. Fielders and base runners must run faster than ev er to keep pace with that bouncing ball.

title: Fashion; WHEN LEATHER GETS SILKY
description: eather is usually thought of as tough stuff, the sort of material appropriate for jackets and coats, shoes and boots, gloves and hats - things that protect the body from the cold and the rough. This fall, its image is bound to change, for top designers both here and in Europe have taken leather at its softest and draped and shaped it into all kinds of clothes for both day and evening wear. So unexpectedly soft and sensuous are the results of their manipulation of this material that ''Is that leather?'' may become the most often repeated fashion query of the season.

title: Paula Smith Wed to Dr. Roland Smith
description: Paula Judith Smith, daughter of Rhoda Smith of Port Washington, L.I., and Lawrence S mith of Floral Park, Queens, was married yesterday to Dr. Roland Theodore Smith, son of Dr. and Mrs. Roland Smith of Jopl in, Mo. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Osborne of th e Plandome (L.I.) Unitarian Church at the home of the bride's mothe r.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Gifts to U.S.
description: Every year foreign governments shower some officials of the United States with gifts. A stuffed boar's head from the Soviet Union, an Oriental rug from Pakistan, a $100,000 diamond ring from Zaire and dozens of watches, silver tea sets, engraved cigarette boxes and carved elephants were among 1,200 such gifts stored by the General Services Administration in a vault in Washington in February 1978.

title: TRUCE IN BRANDYWINE DISPUTE
description: A fragile truce has been reached in a feud that has simmered for 13 years between the artist Andrew Wyeth and a Chadds Ford neighbor over a flood-prone creek.

title: Pleiade Editions
description: To the Editor:

title: On Language
description: Kimble Mead

title: TEXAS CATHOLIC BISHOPS REJECT NEUTRON BOMB
description: All 12 Roman Catholic bishops in Texas have adopted a statement attacking President Reagan's decision to assemble the neutron bomb.

title: Pirates 6, Phillies 2
description: PITTSBURGH (UPI) - Jason Thompson drove in two runs with a double and a bases-loaded walk to pace Pittsburgh. Eddie Solomon (7-4) held the Phillies to six hits in six innings before leaving the game with a blister on his pitching hand.

title: Topics; Reactions, Over and Under; Cairo Truth
description: Having arrested 1,600 people, closed seven publications, arbitrarily transferred journalists and professors, dissolved religious societies and removed Pope Shenuda III as head of the Coptic Church, President Anwar Sadat of Egypt last week also expelled a reporter, Chris Harper of ABC, for daring to film a critical interview with a previously expelled British correspondent - in Beirut. The film was stolen from an air package at Cairo airport a month ago in what must have been the result of an elaborate secret police operation.

title: Stage View; A SLIGHT BUT SUNNY WORK, WITH A DASH OF SIGNIFICANCE
description: The world changes, behavior patterns change, I suppose even styles in bicycles follow mysterious shifts of fashion. (I don't have a bicycle, so cannot be dogmatic about the matter, but there are three bicycles on stage in the popular Off Broadway play called ''Key Exchange,'' and they don't look exactly like the ones my kids used to ride.)

title: AN OMINOUS U.S. TILT IN AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOLS SEEKING TO COUNTER KU KLUX KLAN
description: TO COMBAT a rising tide of racial incidents and increasing efforts by the Ku Klux Klan to reach out to youngsters, New Jersey schoolchildren will be studying the Klan's history and tactics this year.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE red-haired man with the black tote bag and the Durer medal, the clasped hands, on a chain around his neck, shuffled down the stairs to Track 17 and made the 10:40 in time to get a window seat. He settled in for the ride to Rockville Centre and started to read a newspaper. He had had a long day.

title: A LITERARY CULT FIGURE
description: A LITTLE ORIGINAL SIN The Life and Work of Jane Bowles. By Millicent Dillon. Illustrated. 464 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $18.95. By SUSAN JACOBY

title: Refund of $8.9 Million Is Being Paid by Con Ed
description: The first $8.98 million of an expected $16 million in refunds to Consolidated Edison Company customers will begin this month. The utility said the refunds - which will go to customers of electricity, gas and steam - resulted from a United States Supreme Court decision invalidating a Louisiana tax on off-shore gas.

title: WAY OF THE SAMURAI, PATH OF THE TEDIOUS
description: MUSASHI By Eiji Yoshikawa. Translated by Charles S. Terry. Foreword by Edwin O. Reischauer. 970 pp. New York: Kodansha Inte rnational/Harper & Row. $17.95. By SHELDON FRANK

title: Gabriella Plimpton Married in Maine T o Harold Ressler of Foreign Service
description: The marriage of Gabriella Plimpton, former publicity woman at Coward, McCann & Geoghegan, the New York publishers, to Harold Kirkby Ressler, a Foreign Service officer, took place in Camden, Me., yesterday. The Rev. J.F. Titus Oates performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: POLISH AIDE IS CRITICAL OF UNION
description: A member of Poland's ruling Politburo today accused Solidarity, the independent labor union, of seeking to seize power and called for a ''resolute rebuff to extremists'' in the union.

title: Mailbox; A Perfect Staff For the Giants
description: To the Sports Editor: One of the effects of being a Giant fan is that one need never worry about running out of things to criticize.

title: Honduras Holds 3 From U.S.  In Marijuana-Smuggling Case
description: Three United States citizens are being detained in connection with the seizure of a small American fishing boat that had some 15,000 pounds of Colombian marijuana aboard, a Honduran Navy spokesman said today.

title: ENDURING CHARM OF A SOUTHERN BELLE
description: Savannah is a city of squares, a city whose rhythms change softly from block to diminutive block. Uncommonly pleasant to visit, it seems to have been planned for those who care to take their time and stroll quietly through the 19th century.

title: A STABLE TRANSIT FUND IS NEEDED
description: NEW JERSEY's transportation system, which has survived on a ''crisis-to-crisis'' basis for years, is rapidly approaching complete collapse - a collapse that can be reversed only by the establishment of an adequate and stable source and process to pay for the maintenance of highways, bridges and means of transportation itself.

title: MCENROE, BORG IN FINAL
description: John McEnroe and Bjorn Borg are back in the men's singles final of the United States Open tennis championships for a second consecutive year.

title: Crafts; THREE ARE FINALISTS FOR WORKS IN GLASS
description: THREE area residents, who pitted their stained-glass creations against more than 350 other works in the Fourth Glassmasters Guild Annual Stained Glass Competition, have been selected among the 50 finalists.

title: A BIG VOID LEFT BY MCGRAW HILL FILLS UP AT LAST
description: 889-2148 By MICHAEL SPECTER

title: Katharine Lindsay Wed to S. R. Lake
description: The marriage of Katharine Hawes Lindsay, a reporter for The Daily News, to Stephen Randall Lake, director of marketing for the International Gold Corporation, took place yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church. The Rev. Hays Rockwell performed the ceremony.

title: REVISED HOTEL DESIGN URGED TO SAVE THEATERS
description: In a last-minute effort to save two legitimate theaters - the Morosco and the Helen Hayes - opponents of the Portman Hotel project have come up with an alternative design for the hotel-and-theater complex expected to rise just north of Times Square.

title: 'WELCOME TO SOCIAL WORK'
description: BEFORE coming to the State University at Stony Brook to study social welfare, I lived the typical life of an upper-middle-class, cultured young man. Residing in a small, lovely house in Bayside Hills with my parents, I had studied creative writing and the philosophy of art at Queens College for five years.

title: ERICK HAWKINS- CELEBRATING THE BODY AND THE SPIRIT
description: ''I'm glad I did what I did, damn it,'' the choreographer Erick Hawkins said, gesturing across the table with eager intensity. His sense of the rightness of his artistic vision is reflected by the room in which he sits in his Greenwich Village apartment. It is a room filled with the kinds of clear shapes through which his dances flow. A sprig of purple flowers rises from a jar of such rounded definition as the poet Wallace Stevens wrote of: a ''port in air'' taking ''dominion everywhere.'' But, reflective maverick of the dance world, Mr. Hawkins has reached a point where he is no longer so content with a quiet sense of pride in the achievements of 44 years as a major choreographer of American modern dance.

title: LIKE THE DOW, EARNINGS ARE TUMBLING
description: P RICES are n ot the only thing falling in the stock market. Corporateearnings esti mates - the engine that typically pulls equity prices along - have also been heading downhill and prospects seem to favor afurther slide .

title: GREEK WOMEN GAIN IN ELECTION ROLE
description: Greece's women, statistically shown to be more socially and economically discriminated against than their counterparts in any other Western country, have mobilized to an extent that will make them a determining factor in next month's general elections.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Instant Wealth
description: With tears of joy streaming down their faces, Edward Henry, a 40-year-old, $11,000-a-year telephone technician, and his wife, Kathleen, accepted in March 1971 the first million-dollar prize to be awarded by the New Jersey Lottery. They were guaranteed $50,000 a year for 20 years.

title: THE ARTS IN BRITIAN ARE PENNYPINCHING, TOO
description: LONDON When Margaret Thatcher was elected Prime Minister of Great Britain two years ago, the arts world here - heavily dependent on the public spending Mrs. Thatcher had pledged to reduce - gave a shudder. Then Britain plunged into its worst decline since the Great Depression, and the shudder became near-panic. There was even talk of ending government sponsorship of the arts (although the proposed cuts had been far more modest than those recommended in the United States by President Reagan).

title: The Nation; Deal With Spy Suspect Disputed
description: Whether Air Force Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke is guilty of espionage was a question of secondary interest last week as pretrial hearings began at Andrews Air Force Base.

title: CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY FINDS POCKETS OF PROSPERITY
description: WITH monotonous regularity, the releases stream out of the Department of Economic Development in Hartford. ''Construction in Connecticut headed for all-time high,'' read the May report. ''Construction in Connecticut crosses the $1 billion mark,'' said the August release, which also noted that contracts through the first seven months of 1981 increased 32 percent over the 1980 figure, nearly triple the rate recorded nationally. ''This is going to be the biggest year in construction in the state's history,'' said Edward J. Stockton, the Commissioner of the department.

title: A HARVARD OUTLINE FOR FITNESS
description: HARVARD'S FITNESS OUTLINE FITNESSBy Jane Ogle What are the basic fitness requirements needed to keep a man at his peak? And, with time at such a premium, what has priority? The answers to these key questions were outlined at a recent seminar on nutrition and fitness at the Harvard Club of New York City. The session was coordinated by Dr. Jose Luis Barbosa-Saldivar, endocrinologist, nutritionist and associate in clinical medicine at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. Among the panelists were Dr. W. Virgil Brown, professor and director of the division of atherosclerosis and metabolism at Mount Sinai School of Medicine; Dr. Sami Hashim, director of the division of metabolism and nutrition at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center and professor of nutrition at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons; Dr. George Sheehan, cardiologist, medical editor of Runner's World and a member of the stress-testing laboratory at Riverview Hospital in Red Bank, N.J., and Michael O'Shea, director of the Sports Training Institute in New York. The program these experts recommend is set forth here in the form of a classic Harvard outline. I. NUTRITION GUIDELINES

title: HE'S GETTING INTERFERENCE 1970-1981
description: ATLANTA W HEN broadcasting entrepreneur Ted Turner learned that Westinghouse and ABC were planning to take on his Cable News Network with a jointly-owned, faster-paced cable headline news service, his response was immediate and typically Turner. He would, he said, begin his own faster-paced cable news service, CNN II. And, he said, ''I think we're going to beat their brains out.''

title: Miss Gallagher, F.J. Erickson Jr., Architect, Marry
description: Barbara Faith Gallagher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Gallagher of Locust Valley, L.I., was married yesterday to Frank J. Erickson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Erickson of Windham, N.Y. The Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove, L.I. Bishop John R. McGann of the Rockville Centre Diocese celebrated the nuptial mass.

title: Gardening; SEASONAL CARE OF TREES AND SHRUBS
description: WHILE we were not inundated with rain this summer, it was sufficient early on. Then came August with its usual dry weather. By the third week, trees beyond the reach of irrigation systems began to turn color, especially their innermost foilage, and leaves began to fall.

title: POLITICS OF SURVIVAL WAS MOST DANGEROUS, AFTER ALL
description: Ameasure of the messy politics that resulted in the cancellation of New York City's primary election last week is that one of the people who asked a Federal court to declare Council district lines racially biased was a council member who had voted to approve them.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: FAST TIMES AT RIDGEMONT HIGH A True Story. By Cameron Crowe. 253 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $5.95.

title: Barbara Hale Is Married
description: Barbara Wright Hale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee M. Hale of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to John Charles Ricker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank T. Ricker, also of Westfield. The Rev. Robert Pryor performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church in Westfield.

title: A Correction
description: In a Views of Sports article in last Sunday's New York Times, it was stated that ''Jet Stream,'' the official New York Jets' newsletter, is available by paid subscription. It is sent free to all season ticket subscribers and other fans who request it.

title: ISABELLE: KEY TO LAB' FUTURE
description: UPTON AS officials of the Brookhaven National Lab oratory put the case forcontinued financing of the multimillion-dolla r Isabelle project to Washington, it was clear that more than the c onstruction of an accelerator was at stake. For Brookhaven, the nation's oldest and one of the world's most prestigious research laboratories, the question is: Can it survive without Isabelle?

title: About Westchester
description: PEEKSKILL IN a county where ''residential'' has become something of a password, a full-fledged resort, with its mood of recreation, tourism and transience, seems a surprise. Yet here on Furnace Wood Road, at the end of a long rural lane lined with modest homes, is just that: a resort whose entrance is hung with a gaily painted wood sign of a cowboy with a lariat and letters that read, Welcome to Peekskill Dude Ranch.

title: Drive-In Traffic Court Opening in California
description: Motorists ticketed for traffic violations will eventually not even have to leave their cars to pay their fines here.

title: No Headline
description: IOWA UPSET NEBRASKA, 10-7

title: Critic' Choices
description: ART Anyo ne who is interested in new kinds of musi c and new kinds of performance knows the space called The Kitche n, which stands at 484 Broome Street in SoHo. The Kitchen consistent ly and for some years now has been putting on work that would have been welcome nowhere else.

title: MEADOWLANDS TRAFFIC STALLED BY SUCCESS
description: When the racetrack opened here five years ago, Tony Rosamilia would set up shop in a windy perch atop the grandstand. From there, Mr. Rosamilia, chief of traffic and parking for the Meadowlands Sports Complex, used a walkie-talkie to tell aides on the ground when to close lots that were full and entry roads that were clogged.

title: INDIAN PT. INQUIRY DELAYED BY N.R.C.
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has delayed at least until next week the appointment of a three-member licensing board to investigate the safety of the Indian Point nuclear power plant.

title: I got a kick out of the article ''Dressing for the Top'' because it perpetuates the myth that the way a woman can get ahead in business is by looking the way the secretaries did in early movies. (They were after the boss, of course, not his job, but the idea is the same.)
description: Unfortunately, or fortunately, depending on your point of view, certain things will be with us forever.

title: P.L.O. SENDS 2 NEW UNITS TO SOUTH LEBANON
description: Guerrilla leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization have sent two heavy weapons units into southern Lebanon to reinforce their positions.

title: COMPANY PUSHES ROOFTOP JOGGING
description: STAMFORD THE Champion International Corporation is one company that does not seem to mind the idea of its employees running in circles. In fact, the company is encouraging the practice.

title: Expos Top Cubs, 2-0, as Rogers Gets 10th
description: - Chris Speier singled and scored the goahead run and Larry Parrish belted his seventh home run in support of Steve Rogers's 10th victory today as the Montreal Expos defeated the Chicago Cubs, 2-0.

title: OF SPEER AND HESS AND TROTSKY AND STALIN
description: To the Editor:

title: THE U.N.'S MAN IN THE MIDDLE
description: Jane Rosen is the United Nations correspondent for The Guardian of London. By Jane Rosen lmost every weekday morning around 8:30, a plainclothes security guard steps out of an East Side town house and scans the block. A few minutes later, a tall, angular man in his early 60's emerges, formal in a dark suit, head bent, face preoccupied, strung tight. United Nations Secretary General Kurt Waldheim strides quickly downtown, full of energy, and the guard falls into step beside him. There isn't much conversation. ''Occasionally,'' the guard says, ''he'll talk about the new plan for the U.N. garden or the weather or how he wishes he could stay home some night.''

title: SUIT ON SCHOOL IS VOIDED
description: AGROUP of New Rochelle parents have lost the battle to keep four of the city's 10 elementary schools opened. The parents had filed a suit against the city's Board of Education to prevent implementation of a school-reorganization plan adopted by the Board in April.

title: AN OUTSIDER ENTERS BOXING'S INNER CIRCLE
description: K ID ROBERT wanted me to know he was into participatory journalism. ''You can't write about boxing,'' the Kid said earnestly, unless you know somethin' what it feels like to climb into a ring and then to climb out.''

title: M.A. Purdy Weds Constance Doyle
description: Constance Karen Doyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Doyle of Garrison, N.Y., was married yesterday to Mark Addison Purdy, son of Mrs. Alan Bradford Purdy of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., and the late Mr. Purdy.

title: Club Told to End Male Show
description: A popular nightclub has been given 40 days to abandon its ''ladies only'' strip shows featuring male dancers or lose its liquor license. The State Department of Alcoholic Beverage control ruled Thursday that Chippendale's discriminated against men by barring them from the male strip shows. Chippendale's owner had argued that male patrons would inhibit the all-female audience.

title: UNPROCESSED PARKING TICKETS PLAGUE AGENCY
description: Of the 9.6 million parking tickets issued in New York City last year, representing $157 million in fines, one-third cannot be processed by the city. This means that some $50 million in fines will probably never be collected.

title: THE NIXON WITHIN US
description: To the Editor:

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 5 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 2 3 19 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 3 2 7 THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Chief of Detectives (ret.) Edward X. Delaney on the trail of the elusive killer of out-of-town businessmen visiting New York. 4 4 23 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 5 6 14 GOODBYE, JANETTE, by Harold Robbins. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) Two randy sisters at large in the Parisian world of haute couture. 6 8 3 THE LAST DAYS OF AMERICA, by Paul Erdman. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.) International intrigue and dirty financial wheeling-and-dealing in 1985. 7 5 12 THE GLITTER DOME, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow/Perigord, $12.95.)

title: VICTORY EXPECTED ON SALE OF AWACS, HAIG TELLS SAUDIS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. told Crown Prince Fahd of Saudi Arabia today that the Reagan Administration expected to win the battle over selling radar surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia despite strong opposition on Capitol Hill and from Israel.

title: OPEN HEARINGS ASKED FOR MURDER SUSPECT, 15
description: The Vermont Supreme Court had been asked to breach the practice of secrecy in juvenile court by letting the public attend the trial of a teen-ager accused of torturing and killing a 12-year-old girl.

title: OF CABBAGES, VILLAINS AND REWARD
description: I NO longer sympathize with Peter Rabbit. My allegiance is with the Mr. McGregors of this worldprotecting their cabbages and lettuce from th e ravages of pesky rabbits and other critters. If Beatrix Potter 's tale represents the struggle of the underdog against the Establis hment, the haves versus the have-nots, the underprivileged confrontin g the landed capitalist,I don't give a fig, a currant or even a goose berry. That's how a season at the community garden plays havoc wi th one's values.

title: GETTING IN STYLE WITH ACCESSORIES
description: GETTING IN STYLE WITH ACCESSORIES One of the great myths about men is the ''man who has everything.'' In fact, he is a scourge visited upon uni@maginative gift givers.

title: Ideas and Trends; Fight or Fligh
description: Discovering a biochemical substance is not tantamount to understanding it, as at least 15 teams of scientists well know. They've been trying to understand corticotropin releasing factor - a substance produced in the brains of animals, and supposedly humans, that may regulate the body's response to stress.

title: OF SPEER AND HESS AND TROTSKY AND STALIN
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 MARATHONS GAIN PRESTIGE IN STATE
description: WHEN someone who runs meets someone who does not, it isn't difficult to predict how their conversation will begin. If the meeting occurs between November and April, the sedentary being will ask the ambulatory one, ''Are you running Boston?'' If the two are talking between May and October, the question will be, ''Are you running New York?''

title: BRIBE INQUIRY INVOLVES EX-C.I.A. AIDE'S COMPANY
description: This article continues an investigation by The Times into the transfer abroad of advanced technology and military equipment by former United States intelligence agents and military officials.

title: by John Kelly
description: DRUG PART 1 John Kelly is co-author of ''The Secret Life of the Unborn Child.'' By John Kelly For most of his life William Ristow suffered from severe asthma. As a boy, he was near death twice, and later as a teen-ager he was bedridden and exhausted for months at a time. Even during the good periods when his breathing grew strong and rhythmic, his illness kept him from the swimming, running, dancing and other activities that young men of his age take for granted. Then, in 1975, at the age of 24, Mr. Ristow was introduced to a drug called albuterol. ''I'd been taking 90 inhalations a day of my old medication, which was 10 times the recommended dosage,'' he says, ''and that was just barely keeping me ambulatory. I not only needed a lot less albuterol - my daily intake fell to 15 inhalations - but it produced an almost magical change in my quality of life. It was as if I had woken up one morning and my asthma suddenly had been cured.''

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: CIVIL RIGHTS: PAST GAINS, PRESENT UNCERTAINTY
description: When Vernon E. Jordan Jr. announced his resignation as president of the National Urban League last week, a day after the death of Roy Wilkins at the age of 80, he said that there ''is no appropriate time to do what I am doing.''

title: Elizabeth Anne Reese Bride of Carl Morgan Eifler
description: Elizabeth Anne Reese, daughter of Eleanor Bailey Reese of Pittsburgh and Charles David Reese Jr. of Sewickley, Pa., was married in New York yesterday to Carl Morgan Eifler, son of Mrs. Neal Allen of Woodstock, Vt., and Robert K. Eifler of Bethesda, Md. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church.

title: September 13, 1981
description: NONFICTION ENVOY TO NEHRU. By Escott Reid. 16 FAST TIMES AT RIDGEMONT HIGH. By Cameron Crowe. 16 THE FISH IS RED: The Story of the Secret War Against Castro.

title: CONVICT SEEKING FREEDOM BLAMES VIETN AM FOR SLAYING
description: Duane Samples majored in psychology at Stanford University, was voted president of his fraternity, boxed as an amateur and skied on weekends. That was in 1964.

title: No Headline
description: Jack Renner, hurried by lightning and thunder near the end of his round, tied Tommy Valentine for the third-round lead by two strokes today in the $300,000 Pleasant Valley Jimmy Fund Classic.

title: By Philip Nanzetta
description: ON Nov. 10, 1978, President Jimmy Carter signed the National Parks and Recreation Act, which defined a Pinelands National Reserve and promised Federal money for planning and land acquisition. To qualify for the money, New Jersey had to establish a Pinelands Commission and adopt a regional planning framework acceptable to the Secretary of the Interior. The Federal Act has no direct regulatory force.

title: Arabs Condemn U.S.  O ver Ties With Israel
description: Arab commentators strongly criticized the United States today for agreeing to ''strategic collaboration'' with Israel in the Middle East

title: TERRORISM COURTS ASSAILED IN ULSTER
description: The judge, resplendent in a scarlet robe, sits facing the defendant, who is guarded by two policemen. The lawyers wear curly gray wigs and starchy white dickeys, and the crier opens the trial by intoning, ''God Save the Queen!''

title: NEW WATER LEAK IS STOPPED AT THREE MILE ISLAND REACTOR
description: The source of a new leak in the cooling system at the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear reactor was discovered and stopped today, officials said.

title: RABBIT'S LIVE OVA PRODUCED IN LAB
description: Rabbit ovaries, surgically removed and then kept alive in the laboratory, have produced egg cells that were then inserted into other rabbits and fertilized, resulting in normal offspring. It is believed to be the first such achievement in a mammal.

title: Antiques; ALL ROADS LEAD TO MORRISTOWN
description: MORRISTOWN THE story of how David Willis of Plainfield became an antiques dealer is typical of many such dealers. ''Both my wife and I grew up with antiques - accepting them, but not really knowing what they were,'' he said in an interview. ''When we got married and bought a big old house, it became a natural depository for the family antiques.

title: 15 NUCLEAR PLANTS' OPERATION RATED 'BELOW AVERAGE'
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission's first national survey comparing the performance of the country's operating atomic power plants lists 15, including five in the New York-New Jersey area, as ''below average'' in such areas as management control, maintenance, radiation and fire protection and overall compliance with operating regulations.

title: GETTING IN STYLE FOR FALL
description: Fifteen years after the men's-wear revolution, the dust has settled and a new conservatism has begun to surface across the country. As a result, the classics in men's wear have re-emerged, looking better than ever with a new, stylish snap. In one sense, the classics never really went away, but this season, they have gone through a refinement process and have been updated in both shape and color.

title: FIVE TOP NARCOTICS LAWYERS ASSESS THEIR CALLING
description: Ivan Fisher is a successful lawyer who defends major narcotics dealers, earns large fees for his work and makes no apologies for it. He has no moral qualms about handling drug cases, Mr. Fisher said, expressing vehemently a view shared by several other New York lawyers who were interviewed about their defense of narcotics traffickers.

title: 4 IN PHILADELPHIA POLICE DECOY SQUAD ARE INDICTED
description: Four city police officers from an antimugging squad have been indicted by a Federal grand jury that said they had framed eight suspects on robbery charges, beaten two of them and unleashed an attack dog on two others.

title: Los Angeles Bans Pet Snake A fter an Owner Is Hopitalized
description: City officials have ordered pet shop owners to remove red-neck keelback snakes from their shelves and warned snake owners to take the reptiles, previously thought to be harmless, to animal shelters.

title: Astros 5, Giants 2
description: HOUSTON (AP) - Joe Niekro hit a two-run single and combined with Dave Smith on a seven-hitter for Houston. Alan Ashby made a single, double and home run for the Astros.

title: Jan Stephenson Maintains 2-Stroke Lead
description: Jan Stephenson mixed six birdies with four bogeys for an up-and-down round of 71 today and maintained her two-stroke lead over Jane Blalock after two rounds of the $125,000 Suffolk golf tournament.

title: A HISTORY OF ILLUSIONS
description: SENTIMENTAL IMPERIALISTS The American Experience in East Asia. By James C. Thomson Jr., Peter W. Stanley, and John Curtis Perry. 323 pp. New York: Harper and Row. $17.50. By GADDIS SMITH

title: ABDICATING RESPONSIBILITY FOR EDUCATION
description: THE Wilton Board of Education has decided to impose a fee for participation in interscholastic athletics. Didn't we just have a big constitutional battle over the right to a free public education? But you say interscholastic football is not education. It is, but not in Wilton. Or at least the taxpayers are paying for it through their local education budget.

title: No Headline
description: For Randy Rasmussen, the return to Shea Stadium today will be as comfortable as putting on an old shoe. But Richard Todd hopes that no one picks it up and throws it at him. It will be noisy at 4 P.M. around Shea, whe re the Jets stage their home opener against the Cincinnati Bengals. A cross the street, a full house is expected to watch the final pro gram of the United States Open tennis championships. Airplanes w ill drone overhead. There will be cheering.

title: Arson Brings 100-Year Term
description: A man who pleaded guilty to setting a hotel fire that killed five people was sentenced yesterday to 100 years in prison. Clyde Buford Atchley, 24 years old, who told police he set the fire at the Swiss Inn in January 1980 because he was ''mad at the world,'' was ordered to serve four concurrent 60-year terms and a fifth 60-year term to begin after 40 years in prison.

title: Elise Smith Affianced to Cole Heyniger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Huntington Smith of South Dartmouth, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elise Griswold Smith, to Cole Heyniger, son of Mrs. Brendan Griswold of Buffalo and South Dartmouth and the late Frank Kingsbury Heyniger of Lawrenceville, N.J.

title: INDUSTRY ENTERS A TWILIGHT ZONE
description: Unshackling free enterprise and bolstering national security have been two primary goals of the Reagan Administration. But President Reagan has been discovering of late that the requ irements of the free market and national defense are not always compatible.

title: 2 POLES LEARN WAYS OF L.I. FARMING
description: WHEN news of severe food shortages in Poland hits the airwaves, it's of more than passing interest to Jacek Slusarczyk and Andrej Grzybowski, farm workers in Southold. To them it's not just information on Eastern European turmoil, it's news of home. They left Poland six months ago and will be returning in as much time after spending a year on an agricultural exchange program operated by the National 4-H Council.

title: Twins 3, White Sox 1
description: Hosken Powell had a triple and single, and Pete Redfern and Doug Corbett combined on a seven-hitter as Minnesota won its fifth straight.

title: A NEW SOVIET MOOD
description: The prevailing view in the United States is that the Soviet Union is able and determined to gain exclusive control over the third world's natural resources. But this is not how the matter is perceived and pursued in Moscow.

title: FALL PREVIEW 1981
description: As surely as glossy department store catalogues announce that Labor Day is here and Christmas is coming, the fall and winter catalogues of publishers descend upon the desks of bookstore owners, talk-show hosts and reviewers to remind them of the seasonally high hopes of the book business. But unlike fleecy bathrobes or the latest in Walkman stereos, books remain a mystery until we or someone we trust turn their pages. Some insiders, like Simon and Schuster publisher Dan Green, predict a ''heady'' season this fall: ''Sometime around June, we became aware that more people were in the bookstores and that more books were being sold. The trend continued throughout the summer - and advance orders for the fall season are up from last year.'' No one can say with certainty what the season will bring, and yet the impulse to predict remains.

title: GRAND DRAGON SAYS HE'S A 'FAMILY MAN'
description: ''WE have our own tailor in Pennsylvania who makes standard Klan robes like the ones from the 20's,'' said Clarence South, the New Jersey Grand Dragon for the Confederation of Independent Orders, Invisible Empire, Knights of the Ku Klux Klan. ''They're very good quality.''

title: AS SUMMER ENDS, DRYNESS DEEPENS
description: THE recurrent theme of Westchester's climate this year is drought. This past winter the bare bottoms of Westchester's reservoirs were visible after the driest back-to-back December and January in the 121-year precipitation record of the Croton Watershed. In northern Westchester, January was the third-driest on record and March was the second-driest. The intervening spring months gave us normal, but not bountiful, rainfall and then the adequate rainfall ended the first week of July. It did so w ith a certain degree of showmanship. The July 4 weekend was a washout , with nearly three inches of rainfall in most parts of the county du ring the first five days of July. The rain gods ended their show on Independence Day by packing up and leaving - not to return throug h the month of August.

title: BRITISH MUSEUM REARRANGES EXHIBIT OF EGYPTIAN SCULPTURE
description: After five years of preparation, the British Museum has unveiled the first rearrangement of its collection of ancient Egyptian sculpture in nearly half a century.

title: Ship Capsizes Off San Juan
description: The Duo, a cargo ship flying under a British flag, capsized late yesterday as it left San Juan, flipping over on its side near a United States Coast Guard station. The 12 crew members were rescued unhurt. Hamlet Harrington, the skipper, blamed shifting cargo for the accident.

title: PRIZE SHRINKS: FISH STILL FREE
description: ''John Beresford Tipton,'' the coho salmon that eluded 25,000 eager anglers in a million-dollar fishing derby last Sunday, has declined in value but is still worth hooking.

title: A GUIDE TO FALL COOKING CLASSES
description: WITH the arrival of autumn, home entertaining moves inside. Cooking for company is made easier this fall by several cooking schools in Westchester that offer classes with party menus in mind. Other courses concentrate on how to use specific kitchen equipment such as microwave ovens and food processors.

title: Susan Ellen Sing Is Wed To George Vance Ganter
description: Susan Ellen Sing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. An Van Sing of New York, was married yesterday to George Vance Ganter, son of Mrs. George E. Ganter of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and the late Mr. Gant er. The Rev.Robert B. Min nick, a Dutch Reformed minister, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: LANDSCAPERS' PARKING UPSETS WESTBURY
description: WESTBURY FIVE o'clock on a summer's evening, and the landscapers' trucks start rolling into Westbury, most of them bound for Breezy Hill, a pocket-sized community of abundant flower beds and modest homes tucked into the heart of the village. Here, in their own enclave, a closely knit group of immigrants from the central Italian village of Durazzano have established new lives -many of them as landscapers.

title: Rise in Syphilis Cases Put at 33.4% for 1980
description: Federal health investigators said today that there was a sharp increase in the number of syphilis cases reported last year in the United States.

title: Essay; REACTING TO CRITICISM
description: Israel's Prime Minister came to town this week amidst an unprecedented barrage of newsmagazine criticism. Newsweek topped Time's classic ''Begin (rhymes with Fagin)'' ethnic slur with a Star of David made of rifles, adding ''Obstacle to Peace?'' to this unintended desecration, and joining Time in demanding that Mr. Reagan ''get tough'' and ''confront'' Israel.

title: DESPITE WARNINGS, LINES FORM AT SPRING
description: IT is not Lourdes but Yonkers, and people line up, sometimes 20 deep, to fill their plastic milk bottles, wine jugs, apple juice jars, thermos bottles, carboys and even demijohns with the spring water that gurgles from a pipe in the side of a hill a couple of hundred feet from the Saw Mill River Parkway. A Westchester County Health Department official dubs this spring ''infamous.'' And indeed, at one point in its turbulent history, water gatherers engaged in fistfights over its cold, crystal-clear water.

title: Major News; Begin Notes a Warming Trend
description: After a summer of stress, Israeli and American officials were apprehensive that the first meeting between their leaders would be chilly. But President Reagan's promises of closer ''strategic cooperation'' between the two countries, although largely symbolic, helped produce the ''warmest atmosphere I ever enjoyed in Washington,'' Prime Minister Menachem Begin said.

title: HERB BROOKS TAKES CHARGE AND HE PROMISES EXCITEMENT
description: HEINOLA, Finland HERB BROOKS led the New York Rangers into the seclusion of the Finnish countryside yesterday, determined to teach them a new way to win hockey games.

title: COUNTRY STYLE
description: An amiable giant of a man, Arthur Edelman spends most of his time in the country on a 60-acre spread in Connecticut.

title: No Headline
description: We are told that ''a briefcase and jacket are mandatory,'' that ''clothes in bright hues may be a problem.'' Well, well, well! I thought I was in America. Even the Chinese are getting, to their great delight, out of the Mao uniforms. Where are we heading for? DIVNA CIPRIS, Morristown, N.J.

title: Elsie McCabe Jersey Bride Of a Banker
description: Elsie Brewster McCabe, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Emmet McCabe of Englewood, N.J., was married there yesterday to William Tredick McIntire Smith. He is the son of Mrs. George Robert Leslie of Englewood and Fishers Island, N.Y., and Hudson Ashley Smith of Alpine, N.J., and Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: The Region; Getting Serious In Times Square
description: Like come-ons for the peep shows of 42d Street, the various plans to redevelop the Times Square area have promised more than they delivered. The latest round of such proposals, which developers submitted last week in response to city and state invitations, seem more sober and realistic, but that, quite literally, remains to be seen.

title: Rutgers Approves Budget
description: Rutgers University's Board of Governors approved a $224.3 million budget request today for the 1982-83 fiscal year, $20 million higher than the previous period.

title: Major News; Primarily Confusing
description: The term ''voting-rights violations'' may still evoke memories of sheriffs with shotguns, but these days it's likelier that the circumstances are more mundane. That was the case last week, when a Federal court ruled - and the Supreme Court q uickly agreed - that New York City had violated the Voting Rights Act.

title: BUSINESS CONDITIONS retailing, 1970-1981; BUSINESS FAILURES INCREASE
description: While most large companies are managing to cope with slow economic growth and high interest rates, smaller companies are having a rough time. Through the week ended Sept. 3, business failures, according to Dun & Bradstreet, the business information and service company, stood at more than 11,000, up 42 percent from a year earlier.

title: BRITISH FUNDS TURNING TO AMERICA
description: In a few months, a shiny new skyscraper will begin to rise at 40 Broad Street near the New York Stock Exchange in the heart of New York's financial district. To the average Wall Street worker, it will seem just like another office tower, but it also is the latest in a string of investments in American real estate by British pension funds.

title: LEONTYNE PRICE RETURNING
description: NEW BRUNSWICK TO THE delight of her fans on this side of the Hudson, Leontyne Price will return to New Jersey tomorrow after an absence of 15 years. She will open the 1981-82 concert series at Rutgers University in a recital beginning at 8 P.M. in the Rutgers Gymnasium.

title: TOKYO AND SEOUL AGAIN FAIL TO AGREE ON AID
description: Japan and South Korea failed again yesterday to agree on a Korean request for $6 billion in economic aid over five years.

title: YOUNG HEROES ARE HONORED BY THE PRESIDENT
description: A building in Jerome Dale's Baltimore neighborhood was engulfed in flames, and two children and their mother were trapped behind a wall of fire inside.

title: MECCA BRACES FOR 2 MILLION AT PILGRIMAGE
description: Thousands of Moslems are streaming into Saudi Arabia for the annual pilgrimage to Mecca, an ancient ritual that is expected to draw two million people to the holy city where Islam was born.

title: Alouette Coach Is Dismissed
description: Nelson Skalbania, the team's majority owner, dismissed Coach Joe Scannella today after his Montreal Alouettes suffered their eighth consecutive loss, 26-10, this time to the Hamilton Tiger-Cats.

title: FOR FAMILIES OF ABDUCTED ITALIANS, A LAST HOPE
description: Anguished relatives of kidnapping victims are turning to newspaper advertisements as a last resort to obtain their release - or at least get their bodies back. The father of 30-year-old Augusto Rancilio, kidnapped two years ago, appealed in an advertisement for the kidnappers to return ''at least the bon es of my son so we can bury him and cry for him.''

title: Carol A. Gross Is Bride Of Dr. James Wolff Jr.
description: Carol Ann Gross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Earl Gross of Boston, was married in Edgartown, Mass., yesterday to Dr. James Alexander Wolff Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Wolff of New York and Edgartown. The Rev. John A. Greeley, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Wolff home.

title: Television Week
description: 'Mass' Encore Ten years ago, Leonard Bernstein's ''Mass'' opened the $70-million John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington. At the time, Mr. Bernstein described his work as a theater piece for singers, dancers and players. More than 200 participants were employed on stage; the production ran almost two hours. In the story, the priest-celebrant, a Christ figure, is a symbol of orthodox religion.

title: Cynthia Johnson Bride of William A. Bruckman 3d
description: At St. Catherine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J., yesterday, Cynthia Joan Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce A. Johnson of Spring Lake and Delray Beach, Fla., was married to William A. Bruckman 3d. He is the son of Mrs. E. Bronson Lyon of Lake Forest, Ill., and the late Mr. Bruckman Jr. of Rumson, N.J. Msgr.

title: 67 COUNTIES LINKED TO OAKLAHOMA KICKBACKS
description: Federal investigators say that allegations of millions of dollars in kickbacks on county road equipment purchases have now touched 67 of the state's 77 counties and may eventually ensnarl more than 200 persons.

title: Politics; NOVEMBER'S BALLOT A LONG ONE
description: TRENTON THOSE planning to go to the polls on Nov. 3 should pack a light lunch; it could take a while to get to the voting booth. In addition to electing a Governor from a field that includes the two major party candidates and 11 independents, voters will elect a State Senator and two Assemblymen (a total of 120 will be chosen across the state); county officials, such as Freeholders, sheriffs and clerks, and local officials, including mayors and council or committee members.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire in Brazil Destroys Part of a National Park
description: About 31 square miles of Brazil's oldest national park have been destroyed in a forest fire that officials said they believed had been started deliberately.

title: Antiques; COLLECTION OF FOLK ART AT WILTON SHOW
description: WILTON OLD militia drums, hobby horses, quilts and hatboxes, whirligigs and tavern signs will be included in a colorful group of 50 examples of mostly 19th-century American folk art to be exhibited a week from today at the Wilton Historical Society Heritage Museum on Danbury Road.

title: Gallery View; A FRESH INSIGHT INTO DUTCH LANDSCAPES
description: In relation to its size, Holland has produced more great landscape painting than almost anywhere else we can think of. It was in the 17th century above all that Dutch painters showed us what could be done with northern natu re. But towards the end of the 19th century Vincent van G ogh drew a new and somber music from that same landscape, an d at the beginning of our own era Piet Mondrian proved that it could work no less well in a context of strong color and hectic emotio n.

title: COMMODITIES: A LACKLUSTER START FOR SUNFLOWER SEEDS
description: Ralph Hayenga, president of the Minneapolis Grain Exchange, follows the progress of the exchange's newest commodity as intently as the head of the sunflower is said to follow the sun from East to West. Well he might. Sunflower futures are the subject.

title: MIME: LAVINIA PLONKA IN 'LOOSELY WRAPPED'
description: Lavinia Plonka mimed her way through an assortment of modern manias in ''Loosely Wrapped,'' her Wednesday night show at the Jan Hus Presbyterian Church. Subtitled ''a mime cabaret,'' it consisted of solo and group sketches, and most of them concerned people who were at least slightly goofy.

title: O'NEILL PRESSES NAUTILUS BID
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill is seeking to have the Nautilus, the first nuclear-powered submarine, designated as a national historic landmark. In a letter to Interior Secretary James G. Watt, released today, Mr. O'Neill noted that the ship was built by the Electric Boat Division of General Dynamics Corporation in Groton, Conn., and launched there Jan. 21, 1954. The submarine, now retired, is scheduled to be returned to Gorton for display.

title: ORTHODOX BODIES IN CHURCH DISPUTE
description: Not yet fully recovered from a controversy over grants to liberation movements in southern Africa in which a member denomination withdrew in protest, the World Council of Churches now faces criticism on another front.

title: THE ANCIENTS HAD WATER POLITICS, TOO
description: Mankind's earliest civilizations lived and died for water, a fluctuating resource they managed with varying degrees of sophistication. Its vital importance to the fate of entire societies has recently been underscored anew by intensive archeological explorations in the Mesopotamian plain, carried on by Western and Islamic archeologists despite political hazards thrown in their path by revolution and war.

title: Resistant Gonorrhea Strain Spreading in the Miami Area
description: A penicillin-resistant strain of gonorrhea brought to the United States from the Philippines is sweeping Dade County, giving the Miami area the fastest-growing rate and the second-highest reported number of cases in the nation, health officials say.

title: Art; EXHIBITION OF WALKER EVANS EXTENDS HIS REPUTATION
description: BRONXVILLE ALARGE and important exhibition of photographs by Walker Evans is on view until Sept. 24 in Bronxville. Entitled ''Walker Evans: Photographs of New York State,'' the show is at the Raushenbush Library of Sarah Lawrence College.

title: ABSTRACT ART IS NOT FOREIGN TO CHINA
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW AGE DAWNING IN U.S. FOR THE ELDERLY
description: FOR about 24 million of us in the United States, the latter part of the 20th century will be a new age. We will make up 13 percent of the country's population and will have created changes in all aspects of our society. Who are we? We are the people 65 years and older - today's elderly citizen, tomorrow's new ager.

title: TIGERS SINK INDIANS ON A HOMER IN 12TH
description: A two-run homer by Lance Parrish in the 12th inning off Sid Monge sent the Detroit Tigers to an 11-9 victory over the Cleveland Indians today.

title: CANADAIR JETS
description: To the Business Editor: Contrary to a statement in ''Behind the Trigger at E.F. Hutton'' (Sept. 6), the Canadair Challenger is very much a competitor to the Gulfstream III in the top-level business jet market.

title: The Region; Jersey Outlaws Some Outrages
description: No one, of course, can stop a bigoted thought, but la st week New Jersey enacte d stiff new penalties for those who display them on buildings.

title: Environews
description: A PIONEER in research on the links between asbestos and respiratory diseases will present new findings at the eighth annual New Jersey Environmental Congress in Summit next month.

title: HE LOOKS AT EUROPE AND SEES A PATTERN
description: ''THE book,'' said Richard F. Kuisel, professor of history at the State University at Stony Brook, ''was conceived as a scholarly work, and it became topical mainly because of the Socialist victory in the spring elections.''

title: Cheryl Carlesimo Married
description: Cheryl Petra Carlesimo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Carlesimo of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married there yesterday to John Pearce McCally, son of Richard K. McCally of Old Lyme, Conn., and Mrs. W. Bradley Morehouse of Fairfield, Conn. Msgr. Arthur J. Kaschenbach performed the ceremony at St. Cassian's Roman Catholic Church. The bride, who will retain her name professionally, is a film maker, as is Mr. McCally.

title: TO UNDERSTAND A PROSPECTUS, EXPERTS SAY, GET EXPERT HELP
description: The State of New York has had for nearly 15 years a law requiring that sponsors of cooperative and condominium apartments fully disclose pertinent financial data. The data is compiled and published in a fat compendium known as an offering plan or prospectus, which is filed with the office of the state Attorney General and distributed to would-be purchasers.

title: GIVING IMMIGRANTS A NEW START
description: EAST ORANGE ''GO TO Millburn.'' That is what many Soviet Jews advise each other after being allowed to emigrate. It is not Millburn itself that is talked about, but the Jewish Counseling and Service Agency here. It cares for Soviet Jews as an agent of the United Hias Service, the international resettlement organization familiar to millions of Jewish immigrants for more than a century.

title: MARKETING THE PRESIDENT
description: Sidney Blumenthal, author of ''The Permanent Campaign,'' is writing a book on the economic and intellectual roots of Reaganism. By Sidney Blumenthal s Washington sweltered through a July heat wave, Richard S. Beal was working on the outline of a

title: No Headline
description: Georgia Tech Beats Alabama

title: Speaking Personally; SELLING YOUR HOUSE - IT'S A SONG-AND-DANCE
description: AFTER three months of playing ''Show and Tell'' in an effort to sell our home in North Jersey, we've decided to take the show off the road - or at least off the listings of realtors.

title: Cabanas Has S pine Injury
description: Roberto Cabanas, the Cosmos' second leading scorer, has two broken bones in his spine and will be inactive at least three months, the team said today.

title: COMPETITION IS ROUGH FOR SCHOOL FUNDS
description: TRENTON THE school year that began last week for about 1.2 million New Jersey public-school students promises a renewed and intensified struggle among the education community's many special-interest groups for a shrinking money supply.

title: INSTILLING THE 'LIVING BREATH OF THEATER' INTO AN OPERA SCORE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- William Mayer is the composer of the opera ''A Death in the Family'' and other works. By WILLIAM MAYER

title: SOCIAL SECURITY SYSTEM LARGELY FOR THE RICH
description: To the Editor:

title: LA GUARDIA'S TOWER IS CALLED NORMAL
description: Before the air traffic controllers walked off their jobs on Aug. 3, Frank J. Bombace, the chief of the La Guardia Airport tower, held a staff meeting every Wednesday morning in his office on the sixth floor of the tower. After the controllers struck, there was no time to hold the meetings.

title: CABLE TV IS 'RESCUING' THE MAKERS OF SHORT FILMS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Leslie Garisto is a freelance writer with particular interests in film and television. By LESLIE GARISTO

title: REDEVELOPMENT PLANNED ON MILLION DOLLAR PIER SITE
description: In the first major non-casino project on the Boardwalk in Atlantic City since casinos were authorized in 1976, the once famous but now dilapidated Million Dollar Pier will be demolished and replaced by a shopping and restaurant center in the shape of an ocean liner.

title: NOW IT'S DEFENSE VS. THE DEFICIT President Reagan in March and September 1981 (p.24)
description: At first, it seemed that the moment of truth for President Reagan was at hand. He had pushed his huge budget and tax cuts through the Congress in early August and gone off to vacation in California. But the latent conflict over the rapidly growing defense budget reared up behind him.

title: BUS LANES ON THIRD
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics; REACTIONS, OVER AND UNDER; Vest Race
description: It is known that police, secret servicemen, even Presidents gain some security by wearing bulletproof vests in dangerous places. Now that just about everywhere seems dangerous to many people, it's hardly surprising that a New York entrepreneur is trying to market a whole line of bulletproof clothing to the general public.

title: Grenade in Jerusalem Kills an Italian Pilgrim
description: A Christian pilgrim from Turin, Italy, was killed by a grenade in East Jerusalem this evening. A police spokesman said the grenade had been thrown at a group of 47 pilgrims fro m Italy.

title: Susan Stanley Is Bride
description: Susan Lueza Stanley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas O. Stanley of New York and Mantoloking, N.J., was married yesterday to William Mark Quinlan, son of Doris M. Rohe of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and the late John D. Quinlan of Coral Springs, Fla. The Rev. Norman J. Catir performed the ceremony at the Episc opal Churc h of the Transfiguration(Little Church Around the Corner.) The bride' s father is vice president, research programs, at RCA Laborato ries in Princeton, N.J.

title: Dr. Newman Wed To Dr. David Bell
description: Dr. Katherine Kincaid Newman and Dr. David Hartman Bell were married yesterday at the First United Methodist Church in Sacramento, Calif. The Rev. John M. Germaine performed the ceremony.

title: FOR 100 STUDENTS CLASSES ARE AT SEA
description: NEW HAVEN SALT spray, wind, rain and choppy waters may be as much a test of a student's mettle as his achievements on a history assignment during the new school year in New Haven. Nearly 100 high school students here have gone to sea in pursuit of their diplomas.

title: Lisa A. Meshier Wed T o Alan J. Sinsheimer
description: Lisa Anne Meshier, a third-year medical student at the University of Texas, was married yesterday to Alan J. Sinsheimer, a New York lawyer. The Rev. Frederick Bryson, chaplain of Southern Methodist University, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Capt. C.W. Meshier, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Meshier of Dallas.

title: Dressing for Success
description: Jani Wooldridge's article ''Dressing for the Top'' (July 26) gives the impression that clothes make for success.

title: THREE FIRSTS
description: HUB By Robert Herring. 227 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $12.95. CHANGING STATES By Barbara Rogan. 205 pp. New York: Doubleday & Company. $11.95. SOUVENIRS By W.D. Wetherell. 196 pp. New York: Random House. $10.95. By ELEANOR FOA DIENSTAG

title: Numismatics; IS THIS REALLY THE END OF THE ANTHONY DOLLAR?
description: The United States Mint appears to be abandoning the Susan B. Anthony dollar. Mint officials won't admit the "mini-dollar" coin is dead, but they've dropped it completely from production plans and they're no longer studying possible modifications aimed at winning public acceptance.

title: THINK GLOBAL, ACT LOCAL
description: THE POLITICS OF THE SOLAR AGE Alternatives to Economics.By Hazel Henderson. Illustrated. 433 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ Few jazz pianists have been associated with as many of the giants of classic jazz as Don Ewell. His first job when he got out of the Army after World War II was with Bunk Johnson's band at the Stuyvesant Casino, the only white musician that Johnson used regularly in his band.

title: THE THRILLING ERIC AMBLER
description: THE publication of ''The Care of Time'' offered a chance to talk to Eric Ambler about the books he has been writing since the late 1930's. ''In England they're called thrillers,'' he said, ''and in America booksellers shove them into the mystery corner or get them mixed up with novels. When I was published by Knopf, the word 'intrigue' was applied to them. I don't like the word 'suspense' as an adjective - any novel needs suspense.

title: WHY STOCK PRICES FALL
description: To the Editor:

title: Irish Martini Takes Futurity by a Nose
description: Irish Martini's snout was thrust down and f orward at the same instant that Herschelwalker's was pointing up , and that position decided the $187,675 Futurity Stakes for 2-ye ar-old colts at Belmont Park yesterday. Irish Martini won the photo f inish from the lateclosing Herschelwalker by a nose, with Ti mely Writer, the 4-5 favorite, 2 1/2 lengths back in third.

title: Children's Books
description: THE ISLAND KEEPER By Harry Mazer. 165 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $8.95. (Ages 11 to 15 ) By FEENIE ZINER

title: O'Neill to Seek Foreign Trade
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill will head a trade mission to France, West Germany and England later this month to seek additional foreign investments for Connecticut, the Governor's office announced today. The Governor and his party will leave on Sept. 25 and return Oct. 6.

title: PALESTINIAN FACTION, USING TERROR TACTICS, SAID TO FIGHT ARAFAT
description: A breakaway Palestinian guerrilla organization secretly backed by Syria has begun terrorist operations apparently aimed at challenging the leadership of Yasir Arafat and his mainstream Al Fatah organization, according to Administration officials and sources in the Middle East.

title: BUDGET BLUES REAGAN UPS THE ANTE BUT CONGRESS GETS THE SHAKES
description: WASHINGTON AS captain of the economic ship, President Reagan has surprised both supporters and critics by holding firmly to course. As the waves of high interest rates and the inflationary fears of the financial com munity threaten to swamp Mr. Reagan's hopes for economicrecovery, his sextant remains firmly fixed on the stars he chose early in last year's Presidential campaign.

title: Design Food; DINING, EXECUTIVE STYLE
Kevin K. McLean Is Bride
description: Kevin Kearns McLean, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Kearns of Brandon, S.D., was married yesterday to James L. Abernathy, son of Caryl N. Abernathy of Key West, Fla., and the late James L. Abernathy of Kansas City, Mo. The Rev. Stephen M. Bolle performed the Episcopal ceremony at the couple's home in Bedford Hills, N.Y.The bride is director of admissions at the International Play Group, a nursery school in New York. Mr. Abernathy is vice president of corporate affairs of the American Broadcasting Companies Inc. His previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bride's.

title: POLICE INVESTIGATE BLAST AT MEXICAN CONSULATE
description: A special antiterrorism task force was investigating a bomb explosion early yesterday in midtown Manhattant that damaged a gate outside the Mexican Consulate and Mission to the United Nations.

title: No Headline
description: To address Madeleine Kalb's first premise that the C.I.A. be shackled by microscopic examination by Congress and an array of committees prior to covert operations is utter nonsense. Granted we can remember times such as the Lumumba incident where the C.I.A. compromised the rights of other nations. I often wonder, though, how many times the C.I.A. has been successful in changing world situations to insure our inalienable rights and maintain the ideology fostered in the Constitution of the United States. GEOFFREY H. GILL, Providence, R.I.

title: Reds 6, Dodgers 5
description: CINCINNATI (UPI) - Dave Concepcion of Cinci nnati hit a sacrifice fly with the bases loaded in the 11th inning for the decisive run.

title: YOU DON'T NEED TREES TO MAKE PAPER
description: K ENAF is a plant, a denizen of frost-free climates and a relative of roselle, marijuana and cotton. However little known in the United States, it is used regularly in more than 20 countries like jute, for making cordage. Today, a far more ambitious future is envisaged for kenaf. It could, its advocates contend, bail the paper-making industry out of periodic shortages of trees.

title: Manhattan Doctor Is Charged In L.I. Inquiry on a Sex Group
description: A neurologist at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and an accounting professor at Marietta College in Ohio were arrested yesterday on charges of having sex with young boys. They were accused of being part of a group that had sex with boys 8 to 15 years old.

title: MOTHER LOSES
description: I HAVE sad news for Claudette Russell, who wrote the article about her son's first day of school. (''School Days: How to Survive,'' Aug. 23): It isn't any easier 12 years later. This week I said goodbye to my firstborn as he set out in our rusted Pinto for a college many hours distant. Talk about anxiety and thinking about the hazards that might befall a kindergarten pupil cannot compare.

title: AFRICAN LEADERS IN LAGOS BID SOUTH AFRICANS LEAVE ANGOLA
description: The leaders of six African countries headed home today after issuing a communique calling on South Africa to remove its troops from Angola.

title: PRIMARY DATE SET CANDIDATES BEGIN 'SECOND CAMPAIGN'
description: With a new primary for New York City's citywide and boroughwide offices tentatively set for Sept. 22, candidates embarked yesterday on their second campaigns and, in many cases, began trying frantically to raise additional funds to pay for them.

title: Balcha of Ethiopia First in Marathon
description: Kebede Balcha of Ethiopia won the third annual Montreal International Marathon today in 2 hours 11 minutes 10 seconds, a track record.

title: G.O.P. SENATOR SAYS CONGRESS DESIRES DEEPER ARMS CUTS
description: ''A majority of the Congress are looking for larger cuts'' in planned military spending than those announced last night by the White House, Senator Pete V. Domenici, the Republican chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said today.

title: 51 Percent Unemployed, and Counting
description: For a decade, the unemployment rate for black youths has hovered around 40 percent. Last month it leaped to a record rate of nearly 51 percent. That was di smaying news. But even more dismaying was the White House's react ion. Thoughts of new remedies were dismissed; the Administratio n's economic miracle would solve all. Besides, said the President's s pokesman, black teen-age unemployment was always a problem.

title: ASTROS 3, GIANTS 0
description: The Astros extended their Western Division lead to three games as Bob Knepper (8-3) and Frank LaCorte combined to shut out the Giants on nine hits. Knepper allowed six hits and struck out six in seven innings of work. LaCorte, who gained his fifth save, gave up three hits in the two innings he pitched.

title: The Economy
description: Congress will look for bigger cuts in military spending than those announced by the White House, a key Republican Senator said. Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, said that increases in spending for Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security needed to be pared. President Reagan defended the relatively small reductions in military spending. (Page A1.)

title: THE DAY OF T.R.'S WILD RIDE
description: Hardly a man is now alive who remembers the famous ride of Theodore Roosevelt on that fateful day 80 years ago when he became President of the United States.

title: GIFT TO AMHERST COLLEGE REQUIRING BLACK PROFESSOR STIRS DEBATE
description: The debate at Amherst College does not exactly rage. ''Everyone here is very polite,'' says Mary Catherine Bateson, the dean of faculty. She smiles.

title: Bridge: Jones Cap tures Two Titles At Triath lon Competition
description: The annual New York Triathlon, in which three sessions of pair, team and individual play are combined, may produce as many as seven winners, but duplications can reduce the number to four. When play ended at the New York Hilton Hotel Saturday night, there were six winners.

title: David T. Miralia, 74, Municipal Bond Expert
description: David T. Miralia, a leading authority on muncipal bonds, died at New York Hospital Friday after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y., and in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: MOTHER OF ONE CHILD IS LOOKING FOR 75 MORE
description: One 8-month-old baby might seem child enough for a working mother, but not for Lois Andrews. She's looking for 75 more, and wants them all by the first of the year.

title: Special Vote in Pennsylvania
description: Louis Wade, a Democrat, will face Robert C. Wright, a Republican, and two independents in a special election Tuesday to fill the state House seat left vacant by the death in July of Representative Arthur Earley, a Republican. The independents are Joseph Goetz and William Grayson. The winner will represent Chester and Eddystone.

title: BRAZIL'S CHURCH AND STATE LOCKED IN A FRESH FEUD
description: Fourteen months after the visit of Pope John Paul II brought relative peace to relations between the politically active Brazilian church and the country's military-controlled Government, the two sides have fallen into a new angry feud.

title: Bonn Minister Is Optimistic
description: A new downturn in the West German economy is unlikely, and a distinct upswing can be achieved in 1982, Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff said.

title: Newman Second In Sports Car Race
description: Paul Newman finished second to Ken Slagle today in the 45.60-mile nationals this afternoon at the Bridgehampton Road Race Circuit and failed to qualify for the Sports Car Club of America runoffs Oct. 23-25.

title: Southern Yemen Sees Threat
description: Marxist-ruled Southern Yemen has ''upgraded'' its military forces to cope with what it sees as an American threat in the Indian Ocean, the Persian Gulf, Oman and Somalia, the Southern Yemen Defense Minister, Salih Muslih Qasim, was quoted today as saying. He said in an interview that his country was ''poised'' to face the threat of the spread of United States military bases in the Gulf region, but did not elaborate.

title: NUCLEAR PROTESTERS PREPARE TO START BLOCKADE
description: A tent city of protesters outside the gates of the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant grew to 3,000 people today as the group awaited word from the Abalone Alliance on starting its planned blockade of the nuclear generating plant.

title: AUTO SAFETY, DEREGULATION AND 'THE CAR BOOK'
description: To the Editor:

title: OUR FRIEND IN OTTAWA
description: To the Editor:

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Chinese Report a 'U.F.O.'
description: The Peking Evening News said today that it was swamped with telephone calls from people reporting an ''unidentified flying object'' over the city. The bright round object spotted yesterday turned out to be a research balloon reflecting the sunlight, the newspaper said.

title: CHINESE WARN U.S. ON TAIWAN
description: Chinese-American relations will be ''gravely impaired'' if the Reagan Administration continues its staunch support of Taiwan, according to an article published today in an offical magazine.

title: WELCOME MAT WEARS THIN IN CONNECTICUT TOWN
description: Country chic may be what vacationing New Yorkers consider this verdant corner of Connecticut, but country cheek is their gift to the local people, according to one side of a five-week debate going on in the area's weekly newspaper.

title: Greeks Prepare for Elections
description: President Constantine Caramanlis today accepted Prime Minister George Rallis's timetable for dissolving Parliament and preparing for general elections. A Government spokesman said Mr. Rallis had proposed that his Government resign on Tuesday, that a caretaker cabinet under Mr. Rallis take over two days later for the pre-election period, that Parliament be dissolved Sept. 19 and that elections be held Oct. 18.

title: CONRAN PARENT SEES STOCK OFFER AS SPUR TO U.S. EXPANSION
description: Since 1977, Habitat Design Holdings has had stores in the United States, but as the company's chairman sees it, its American operations have not had sufficient prominence - nor have they shown a profit.

title: Expos 10, Cubs 6
description: The Expos took sole possession of second place in the Eastern Division, two and one-half games behind St. Louis, as Andre Dawson got four hits that drove in three runs. Larry Parrish also drove in three runs with two hits. For the Cubs, who collected 13 hits off three Montreal pitchers, including Scott Sanderson (8-6), the hottest bat belonged to Bill Buckner, who lined two doubles and two singles in four times at bat, driving in three runs.

title: BRITAIN STILL SEEKS LESSON FROM RIOTS
description: Two months after rioting tore through urban areas across Britain, peace prevails in the country's inner cities, but the days of fiery violence remain a sharp and influential memory.

title: POP: GENTEEL COMMODORES
description: WHILE it is common practice for many rhythm and blues groups these days to perform R-rated material, often as suggestively as possible, the Commodores, who appeared at the Radio City Music Hall last Thursday through Sunday, belong to the more genteel 60's Motown tradition that stresses upward mobility over flashy bravado. Their show on Friday had the energy and sustained high spirits of a pep rally, with the six Commodores grouping and regrouping gingerly to perform most of their hits of the last seven years.

title: CABARET: BOBBI ROGERS SINGS RICHARD RODGERS
description: THE program called "Rogers on Rodgers" that will be at Michael's Pub for the next two weeks refers to Bobbi Rogers, a singer, and Richard Rodgers, who wrote songs.

title: NOEL DRU FRACKMAN WED TO DAVID F. PYNE
description: Noel Dru Frackman and David Frederick Pyne were married yesterday by Judge Louis C. Palella of the Family Court, State of New York, County of Westchester, at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 14, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Thirty-sixth session - 3 P.M.

title: A CHURCH DIVIDED BY METHODIST TIES
description: For almost four years in this town of horse farms and sedately elegant homes, a dispute, which has included the physical barring of a minister from preaching, has raged over control of the Round Hill Community Church.

title: ALEC NAGLE
description: Alec Nagle, senior producer for the Cable News Network, died Thursday in New Orleans, apparently of a heart attack. He was 36 years old.

title: MOYNIHAN, IN REVERSAL, ASKS REDUCED TAX CUT
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who less than two months ago voted for the Reagan Administration's tax cut bill, yesterday assailed that legislation and said he would introduce a bill tomorrow to reduce the size of the cut.

title: MISS STEPHENSON WINS BY 3 ON 205
description: Jan Stephenson won her third tournament of the year today, capturing the $125,000 Suffolk L.P.G.A. Classic by three strokes from Sally Little and Janet Alex, who tied for second.

title: A TENSE AIR IN COURTSIDE CROWD
description: Shortly before 4 P.M., the door to the men's locker room at the National Tennis Center opened and the solemn procession began. Bjorn Borg and John McEnroe, surrounded by security guards, friends and hangers-on, pushed through the crowd outside Louis Armstrong Stadium and into the underground passageway leading to the court. Their faces were expressionless and their shoulders squared as they approached another of their classic confrontations, the final of the United States Open championships.

title: ANN LEWIS BRIDE OF RICHARD SELTZER
description: Ann Elizabeth Lewis and Richard Mark Seltzer, graduates of the Columbia University Law School and former Assistant Manhattan District Attorneys, were married yesterday. Rabbi Milton J. Kain performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour D. Lewis, parents of the bride, in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: f GLOSSARY OF BUDGET TERM S
description: The authority Congress gives to a department or agency to make commitments to spend money, generally the same as budget authority. Sometimes the appropriation and the resulting outlays occur in the same fiscal year.

title: Rhode Island Teachers Facing Ouster in Strike
description: After a futile effort to reach agreement with striking teachers, the School Committee today repeated its vow to dismiss any teacher who failed to report for work tomorrow.

title: Rightists Said to Shell A Port in Lebanon
description: Israeli-backed Christian militiamen fired three artillery shells into Tyre today, the Palestinian press agency said.

title: MARILYN ALOI WED TO DAVID RIVKIN
description: The marriage of Marilyn Frances Aloi, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Aloi of Brockton, Mass., to David Wolfe Rivkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Rivkin of New York, took place in New Haven yesterday. Judge Luther M. Swygert of the United States Court of Appeals in Chicago performed the ceremony in the Dwight Memorial Chapel at Yale University.

title: CHARGERS DEFEAT LIONS
description: Because of their emphasis on the pass under Coach Don Coryell, the San Diego Chargers have come to be known by the nickname Air Coryell. They lived up to the reputation yesterday by defeating the Detroit Lions, 28-23, at San Diego for their second victory in two games.

title: PAMELA ANDERSON BRIDE OF SAM RADIN, LAWYER
description: Pamela Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. B. Robert Anderson of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Sam Radin, son of Mrs. Clarence Radin of Paterson, N.J., and the late Mr. Radin, by Rabbi Melvin Sirner, assisted by Cantor Lawrence Avery, at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: NEW CARS COMING GRADUALLY
description: New model introduction time is rapidly approaching, the annual autumn ritual during which the automobile companies display their shiny new products, pronounce them the best ever and issue optimistic sales forecasts.

title: RANGER GOAL IS TOGETHERNESS
description: Outside the Ice Hall at the Finnish Sports Institute here it is so quiet that the sound of mushrooms growing beneath 50-foot pine and birch trees seems almost real. Inside the hall late this afternoon, the sound of grown men panting was audible, as Coach Herb Brooks of the New York Rangers accelerated the business of getting his players in shape to play at least 90 hockey games between Wednesday and next April.

title: BENGALS DEFEAT JETS BY 31-30
description: The Jets didn't even leave themselves the luxury of an excuse yesterday. This time they committed so many mistakes, while equaling the club record for penalties and losing leads of 14-0 and 17-3, that they said they knew they deserved the 31-30 defeat to the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: GIFT TO KEEP 2 LIBRARIES OPEN
description: An expected gift of $200,00 to the New York Public Library for a two-year period by B. Dalton Bookseller, the Minneapolis chain, will be used to keep the doors open at two heavily used branch libraries in Manhattan where service has been curtailed because of reduced government aid.

title: THE NEGLECTED HALF OF THE DRUG PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: PIANIST AND VIOLINIST
description: YURI GEZENTSVEY, a violinist born in Russia, and Harriet Serr, a pianist and a native of New York, appeared in concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night. Both musicians live in Caracas, Venezuela, where Mr. Gezentsvey serves as concertmaster of the Caracas Philharmonic Orchestra and Miss Serr is active as a performer and teacher.

title: Woman Charged With Taking In fant From Atlanta Hospital
description: A girl stolen from her hospital crib six weeks ago when she was less than 12 hours old has been turned over to the authorities, the police say.

title: Durden Accepts $20,000 for Run
description: Benji Durden of Stone Mountain, Ga., pulled away from the field over the last four miles today to win the $100,000 Nike Marathon.

title: Cape Cod Arts Festival To Begin on Thursday
description: The third Fall Arts Festival will take place in Provincetown, Truro and Wellfleet, Mass., from Thursday through Sunday.

title: Australia Captures Field Hockey Cup
