description: Australia won the international women's field hockey tournament for the American Cup by defeating Britain, 4-3, today at Franklin Field.

title: EAGLES DOWN PATRIOTS, 13 TO 3
description: The Philadelphia Eagles defeated the New England Patriots today, 13-3, and the victory for the champions of the National Conference fell into a familiar style. The Eagles were efficient, rather than flamboyant, and deadly.

title: THE U.N. AND AFGHANISTAN
description: In the near future, the United Nations General Assembly will debate Afghanistan, the third such discussion since the Sov iet intervention in December 1979. The result, a condemnation of the Soviet role, is a foregone conclusion. No doubt the West will hail it as another victory. It may also see it as relief from o ther less-welcome motions on such issues as Namibia or the Middle Ea st.

title: Quick Exit For Borg
description: ''WHERE did he go?'' A tournament official scurried through a tunnel underneath the National Tennis Center last night, searching for Bjorn Borg. Borg had bolted from the court after his last shot lofted over the baseline and before he could be presented with the runner-up trophy. His coach and constant companion, Lennart Bergelin, moved quickly through the crowd and down a passageway.

title: MAX BRAND'S WESTERN RIDES ON
description: ALMOST 40 years after Frederick Schiller Faust was killed while covering World War II as a correspondent on the Italian front, two more of his books will be published Friday. It will bring to 201 the number of books of fiction by Faust, who wrote under more than a dozen pen names but is best known as Max Brand, author of the western classic ''Destry Rides Again'' and as the creator of Dr. Kildare. More of Faust's books are said to have been translated into more languages than those of any other American writer except Upton Sinclair.

title: U.S. IN A REVERSAL UPHOLDS NEW YORK ON CLEAN AIR PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration, rejecting a position taken by the Administration of Jimmy Carter, has approved a controversial plan to meet air quality standards in the New York City region.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * A.M. International Inc., Chicago, has elected Terry S. Boyce vice president, human resources.

title: C ELIA BOCKHOFF MARRIED TO CHARLES J. FLATEMAN
description: Celia Marie Bockhoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Bockhoff of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, and Charles Jacob Flateman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Flateman of Upper Saddle River, N.J., were married yesterday, by Mayor Elias Eliasoff at the Flateman residence.

title: Japan Exports O f Kit Cars Up
description: Japanese exports of vehicles in kit form for assembly abroad have increased following voluntary Japanese curbs on car exports to the United States and Western Europe, Japan Automobile Maufacturers Association officials said Friday.

title: Search for Karen E Goes On
description: The Coast Guard's search for the wreckage of the Karen E, a 36-foot cabin cruiser that sank in Long Island Sound last month, with the loss of five persons, continued yesterday without result. A hulk located by sonar Saturday night was found by divers yesterday to be an old barge. The search was being conducted between Brookhaven, L.I., and Old Saybrook, Conn., where the cabin cruiser is believed to have sunk Aug. 9.

title: TOWNSPEOPLE JOIN TO FIGHT DRILLING
description: JACKSON Wyo., Sept. 13 -From militant conservationists to Chamber of Commerce businessmen, citizens here say they are nearly unanimous in their opposition to oil and gas drilling in the wilderness areas of the surrounding mountains.

title: HELEN HUMES, SINGER OF BALLADS AND BLUES, 68
description: Helen Humes, whose high-pitched, sweet-toned voice was heard with Count Basie's orchestra for four years and who subsequently had a long career as a singer of both ballads and blues, died of cancer at a Santa Monica, Calif., nursing home yesterday. She was 68 years old and maintained homes in Louisville, Ky., New York and Los Angeles.

title: Israelis to Step Up Security After the Slaying of a Pilgrim
description: The Israeli Government said today that it would step up security for pilgrims after a terrorist explosion killed an Italian tourist and wounded 24 others in his group.

title: Courtside to Court
description: One week ago, when all the Federal courts were closed for the Labor Day holiday, Amalya L. Kearse, a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, went to Queens to watch play in the United States Open.

title: Buljan Bright Spot for Cosmos
description: Ivan Buljan, acquired in the middle of the season by the Cosmos and almost written off as a failure three weeks ago, has emerged as an integral part of the Cosmos' lineup in the North American Soccer League playoffs.

title: A SWITCH IN STRATEGY
description: What was to have been a triumphant solving of the problem presented by the Atlantic bonito's frequently displayed disdain for lures or bait turned into a lesson in humility and adaptability for Eli Ohlhausen and me.

title: WALL STREET EXPERTS SKEPTICAL ABOUT CUTS' ECONOMIC EFFECT
description: President Reagan's decision to trim military spending over the next three years as part of a drive to balance the Federal budget by 1984 evoked cautious reactions among Wall Street economists yesterday.

title: TRAINING SESSIONS
description: Sports World Specials Training Procedure

title: JODY BLATT IS MARRIED TO DR. ROBERT SHEPARD
description: Jody Blatt, an intern with the United States Public Health Service in Boston, was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Charles Shepard, a resident at the Boston Veterans' Administration Medical Center. Rabbi Melvin Sirner performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in New Rochelle, N.Y. The bride, daughter of Mrs. Priscilla Blatt of White Plains, and the late Dr. Lester J. Blatt, was graduated magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa fr om Brown University and received her master's degree in public health from Harvard University.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AND A HEARTY HI HO SILVER

title: RCA Plans Campaign For Its Video Units
description: RCA is mounting what it calls its ''biggest advertising and merchandising effort ever'' for its Indianapolis-based Consumer Electronics division during last four months of this year.

title: Old Restaurant Up for Sale
description: The owners of Tujaque's are asking $1.25 million for the old restaurant-bar in the French Quarter, which has attracted luminaries ranging from Theodore Roosevelt to the tennis star Bjorn Borg in its 125 years. The decision to sell was made last week on a vote of 3 to 2 by the five heirs of Philip Guichet, who ran the establishment for 45 years before his death in 1975.

title: Market Place; Profitability
description: KIMBALL International was a leading piano company before the Civil War and in the days before radio when pianos were fixtures in wellappointed middle-class homes. The melody lingers on.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 14, 1981
description: International The use of poisonous chemicals in Southeast Asian conflicts is demonstrated by evidence in the possession of the United States, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said in a speech in West Berlin intended to boost West European morale and invigorate the Western alliance. He said the acquisition of the evidence followed ''continuing reports'' that the Soviet Union and its allies had been using ''lethal chemical agents'' in Southeast Asia and Afghanistan. (Page A1, Column 5.) Mr. Haig's visit to West Berlin set off demonstrations by thousands of people protesting United States foreign policies. The police estimated that as many as 30,000 demonstrators turned out; the protest organizers said 80,000 had taken part. It was probably the biggest street demonstration in West Berlin since the Vietnam War, the police said. (A9:1.)

title: IN U.N. SESSION, DECISIONS WILL BE MADE AT LUNCH
description: The 36th General Assembly session begins here Tuesday, but most diplomats will watch events outside rather than inside the blue-domed Assembly hall.

title: McENROE DEFEATS BORG FOR 3D TITLE IN ROW
description: John McEnroe frustrated Bjorn Borg in four sets yesterday and won his third consecutive United States Open singles title. The 4-6, 6-2, 6-4, 6-3 victory made McEnroe the first player since the legendary Bill Tilden (1920-1925) to win three straight national crowns. It also assured him the No. 1 ranking for the year, widening the gap between other challengers. But the fury and dimension of previous McEnroe-Borg duels were missing in this match at the National Tennis Center.

title: WINNING FRIENDS IN PRESIDENTIAL BOX
description: The Reagan White House, like previous Administrations, has discovered the quiet power of velvet and champagne to court new friends and remember old ones.

title: NORWEGIANS BEGIN TWO-DAY ELECTION
description: Voting began today in a general election that is expected to end eight years of Labor Party rule in Norway. Every public opinion poll taken in the last two weeks indicates that Prime Minister Gro Harlem Bruntland, who took office in February, has been unable to reverse her party's long-term decline in popularity. It will almost certainly win the largest share of the vote in the balloting, which ends tomorrow evening, but not a share large enough to govern.

title: OWNED CONSERVATIVE PAPERS
description: William Loeb, the ferve ntly conservative pu blisher of The Manchester Union Leader and The New Hampshire Sunday News, died yesterday afternoon at the Leahy Clinic in Bu rlington, Mass. He was 75 years old.

title: TRANSIT AGENCY AND UNIONS DIFFER ON COST-OF-LIVING PACT
description: Facing a deadline less than three weeks away, officials of the Transit Authority and the unions representing its employees say that they are still far apart in reaching final agreement on cost-ofliving wage increases for 35,000 bus and subway workers.

title: AUTO SAFETY, DEREGULATION AND 'THE CAR BOOK'
description: To the Editor:

title: STEEL PRICE CHALLENGED BY E.E.C.
description: A top Common Market official is expected to press the Commerce Department this week to let European steel producers sell steel in the United States at prices below the official import, or trigger, price.

title: U.S. Juniors Win
description: The United States defeated Britain, 17-11, in a two-day international junior tennis challenge match that concluded today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy. The American players won seven of eight singles matches. The teams tied, 8-all, in the opening matches yesterday.

title: ANDREA LEE FRIEDMAN BRIDE OF BARRY NEWBURGER
description: Andrea Lee Friedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee J. Friedman of Sands Point, L.I., and Barry Philip Newburger, son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Newburger of Rye, N.Y., were married yesterday by Rabbi Bonnie Steinberg at the Sands Point Bath and Racquet Club.

title: Hurricane in Atlantic On an Uncertain Course
description: Hurricane Harvey, the eighth and so far the largest tropical storm of the 1981 season, appeared to be moving toward the United States today, but forecasters said its course could quickly change.

title: Advertising; Soft Sell A Secret Document
description: THE latest captured document from the advertising wars is a strategic treatise about the soft-sell commercial. It was taken from a straggler who was left behind in the Hamptons after Labor Day.

title: SAINTS UPSET RAMS
description: Thanks largely to George Rogers, the New Orleans Saints, who last year did not get a victory until their 15th game, won yesterday in their second as they upset the Los Angeles Rams, 23-17, at New Orleans.

title: Use of Toxic Insecticide S aid to Be Cleared by U.S.
description: Federal officials approved widespread spraying of crops with the insecticide endrin even though they had known for years that the chemical was lethal, a state wildlife official asserted yesterday.

title: Pie Factory Struck
description: A bakers' union struck the Table Talk pie plant yesterday, idling 450 workers.

title: 3 European Accounts For BBDO Affiliates
description: BBDO International Inc. says its companies in three European countries have acquired new accounts, with billings totaling $15 million, to wit:

title: Kiev in Danish Waters
description: The 38,000-ton aircraft carrier Kiev, the biggest vessel in the Soviet Navy, steamed north through Danish waters today, a day after the formal closing of the Soviet maneuvers. The Danish Navy reported that the Kiev was escorted by a missile-carrying frigate. The Kiev, normally stationed in the Black Sea, was amon g the first vessels to join the Soviet Baltic fleet for the nine days of air, land and sea maneuvers.

title: Templeton Se eks Return
description: Garry Templeton, the shortstop who has been hospitalized for psychiatric observation since Aug. 31, may rejoin the St. Louis Cardinals in another week, Manager Whitey Herzog said yesterday.

title: News/Analysis; SCHOOL FUND: NEW INTENT
description: The national school lunch program was established by an act of Congress in 1946 as ''a measure of national security'' in response to the poor nutritional status found among potential recruits for World War II. It was also meant to help stabilize the economy through Government purchase of agricultural surpluses.

title: From a Polish Trip, a Long-Awaited Reunion
description: When the Erie County Executive, Edward Rutkowski, went to Poland earlier this month as part of a 28-member delegation from the Buffalo area, the purpose of the tour was to express support for the independent Polish labor movement.

title: COSTA RICA ASKS TALKS ON DEBT
description: The Costa Rican Government has announced that it will request that a meeting be held with its principal creditors in New York later this month to seek renegotiation of its $2.4 billion foreign debt.

title: COUNTY FAIR GOES URBAN ON 3D AVE.
description: Louis Truscelli of Fort Lee, N.J., came to Manhattan for the Third Avenue County Fair yesterday, keeping pace with the 100,000-plus throng that surged in both directions along the avenue between 14th and 34th Streets, like a schizoid school of fish.

title: SOVIETS WIN, 8-1, TAKE CANADA CUP
description: The Soviet Union defeated Canada, 8-1, tonight to win the Canada Cup hockey tournament in convincing fashion. Vladislav Tretyak, the goaltender, blocked 26 of 27 shots and Sergei Shepelev scored three goals and Igor Larionov two for the Soviet team.

title: BROOKHAVEN GIRDS FOR FINAL WORK ON ATOM SMASHER
description: Will Isabelle survive? Did the big breakthrough come in time? Or does disaster lurk just beyond the next fiscal year? Are jealous rivals plotting a surprise? And is it true what they say about Isabelle and the director?

title: Amex Sets Unit For Gold Coins
description: The board of governors of the American Stock Exchange on Friday announced a pilot program for the trading of gold bullion coins through a newly created subsidiary, the American Gold Coin Exchange.

title: Earthquake Expert Takes Over Lamont-Doherty
description: Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory in Palisades, N.Y., has a new director.

title: ANGELA SUPPLEE WED TO DON CHESSER
description: Angela Turner Supplee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cochran B. Supplee of New York, was married yesterday to Don F. Chesser, son of Mrs. Ermel F. Chesser of Athens, Ohio, and the late Mr. Chesser.

title: NATO WAR GAMES OPEN TODAY IN DENMARK
description: The Atlantic alliance's fall war games open officially tomorrow in Denmark, a few hundred miles from the Baltic region where the Soviet Union has just held one of its biggest exercises since World War II.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Presidential panel studing how compensation might be paid to the Americans who were held hostage in Iran is concerned that the eventual awards not seem as outsized as the national outpouring that greeted their homecoming.

title: The Masters Of Mistakes
description: THE Jets deserve a new logo. Instead of their green or white airliner, the Jets should be identified by that little yellow flag that National Football League officials always seem to be throwing when a penalty hurts the most.

title: REAGAN GREETING IS READ AT GALA
description: A message of greetings from President Reagan was read by Roger L. Stevens, chairman of Kennedy Center, to the audience gathered in the Opera House for its 10th anniversary celebration and party. Representing the President were Secretary of Energy James B. Edwards; Larry M. Speakers, White House spokesman and David Swanson of the White House Congressional liaison staff.

title: Operetta Opens Sept. 22 At the Gramercy Arts
description: The first New York production of ''La Corte de Faraon,'' or ''The Pharaoh's Court,'' a comic operetta, with book and lyrics by Perrin and Palacios and music by Vicente Lleo, will be presented by Gilberto Zaldivar's Repertorio Espanol.

title: PRESSURES ON COUPLES IN ALCOHOL RECOVERY
description: Living with an alcoholic is a stressful existence. But living with a recovered - or recovering - alcholic is not without stress, as those who know will attest.

title: DANCE: DOWNTOWN GROUP HAILS MISS DUNCAN
description: ONE never knows what to expect of tributes to Isadora Duncan for, over the years, all sorts of daft things have been done in the name of this mondern-dance pioneer. No wonder, then, that suspicions were raised when the Downtown America Dance Arts Theater, where an "Art of Isadora" concert was offered on Saturday night, proved to be a cramped airless studio. What kind of tribute could possibly be held there?

title: IRANIAN SAYS SECRETARY TO PREMIER HID FATAL BOMB IN TEHERAN OFFICE
description: A man who worked as a secretary in the office of Prime Minister Mohammed Javad Bahonar placed the bomb that killed Mr. Bahonar and President Mohammed Ali Rajai on Aug. 30, the office of Iran's Prosecutor General said today.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "It's like a Rubik's Cube. If you move one thing, you have to move evertyhing else." -Marvin Marcus, head of a Citizens' commission on the redistricting of the City Council.

title: TWINS OR TRIPLETS: HOW FAMILIES COPE
description: Cristina Oliva of Scarsdale was certain that she would have twins when she went into the delivery room on Nov. 3, 1978. ''I heard the doctor say, 'It's a girl!' '' she recalled the other day. ''Two minutes later I heard him say, 'It's a boy!' I was overjoyed. All my hopes were fulfilled. Then I heard him say, 'Oh, my! There's another baby!' I thought he was jok ing.'' He was not joking: a second boy wasabout to be d elivered.

title: CREATING STYLES FOR DISABLED
description: Some days Teresa White's joi nts are so stiff that she cannot stand to pull on pants. She must l ean against a wall. A social worker who worked in rehabilitation of the disabled and elderly, Mrs. White now knows - and lives - t he daily frustrations ofher former patients. She suffers with rheumat oid arthritis.

title: THE THEATER: 'Q.E.D.' A 2-CHARACTER COMEDY
description: Some playwrights search for truth and beauty. Some want to remake the world. Others have a simple ambition: they just want to concoct a joke-packed, small-scale comedy that will have the commercial allure of "Some Time Next Year." Into this last category, it seems, falls Ben Starr, the author of a two-character, one-set play called "Q.E.D.," which opened at the 78th Street Theater Lab last night.

title: EUGENIO MONTALE, ITALIAN POET WHO WON NOBEL PRIZE IN '75
description: Eugenio Montale, the Italian poet who won the 1975 Nobel Prize for Li terature, d ied of heart failure Saturday night in a Milan hospital,the ANSA news agency reported. He was 84 years old.

title: LEONARD
description: ''My kid is going to be the puncher. Ray will definitely knock out Hearns.

title: AUTO SAFETY, DEREGULATION AND 'THE CAR BOOK'
description: To the Editor:

title: DODGERS BEAT REDS, TAKE SECOND PLACE
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers, who won the first-half title in the National League's Western Division by a half-game from the Cincinnati Reds, took second place in the second-half standing, moving past Atlanta, with a 4-2 victory over the Reds yesterday in Cincinnati.

title: INTEGRATION LIES AT HEART OF DISPUTE ON PRIMARY
description: Two questions are at the heart of the dispute that led last week to the postponement of New York City's primary elections: Is the city more integrated now than a decade ago, and are changes in the city's racial makeup fairly reflected in the City Council's new redistricting plan.

title: Beth Heiden Wins Cycling Event
description: Beth Heiden set a women's record and Steve Pyle of Riverside, Conn., was the men's winner today in the Mount Washington Hill Climb, one of the most grueling bicycle races in the country.

title: 49ers 28, Bears 17
description: Although Walter Payton of the Bears scored the 72d touchdown of his career, he was upstaged by his lesser-known cousin, Ricky Payton, who caught a touchdown pass and scored on an 11-yard end run on fourth down in the fourth period and help the 49ers even their record at 1-1 and drop the Bears to 0-2. Chicago scored on a 2-yard run by Payton, a 37-yard field goal by Bob Thomas and a 12-yard pass from Vince Evans to Robin Earl.

title: Polish Union Threatens To Build a TV Station
description: Lech Walesa, the Solidarity union leader, was quoted today in the official press as saying that his union would build its own television transmitter if the Communist authorities continued to restrict the union's access to air time. ''We already have our own equipment and cameras,'' he said.

title: Upsala Downs Trenton State
description: Larry Simms threw two touchdown passes, one to John McAleavy for 43 yards in the opening quarter and the other to Joe Carson for 26 in the second period, to give Upsala a 19-8 victory over Trenton State yesterday at Wantage, N.J.

title: COUNCIL TO FIGHT ON REDISTRICTING
description: The extent of integration in New York City is a key factor in the dispute over redistricting. Pa ge B8. By ROBIN HERMAN

title: BRITONS SEEK 6 TONS OF GOLD IN WAR WRECK
description: Nearly 800 feet below the sub-Arctic waters of the Barents Sea, a team of British divers has begun what could be one of the most lucrative treasure hunts of all time - an attempt to recover about $90 million of gold that was or iginally destined for the United States.

title: ELIZABETH FREEDGOOD WED
description: Elizabeth Jane Freedgood and John F. Breyer Jr., graduates of the Tulane University Law School and lawyers in Washington, were married in Brooklyn Heights yesterday.

title: Yanks Trounce Red Sox, 10-6
description: The way the Yankees are playing, Dave Winfield said at his bravado best, ''everybody's in trouble.'' For once, the Yankee pitchers did not intimidate anyone yesterday, but the Yankee hitters did, and that's what Winfield meant. Powered by Winfield's awesome line-drive home run and Bob Watson's mammoth fly-ball home run, the Yankees outslugged the Boston Red Sox, 10-6, for their 12th victory in the last 16 games.

title: VIOLENCE IN BERLIN MARKS HAIG'S VISIT
description: The loudspeaker truck played ''The Star-Spangled Banner,'' but it was Jimi Hendrix's moaning, mocking guitarsolo version. A girl carried an American flag, but it had the shape of a pig, its hocks and ribs, red and white stripes, its head and eyes, a mosaic of misshapen stars.

title: Parsons Is First
description: Benny Parsons held off Harry Gant in the final lap for a close victory today in the Wrangler 400 Grand National stock car race at Fairgrounds Raceway. It was the third first-place finish of the year for Parsons, a Ford driver from Ellerbe, N.C.

title: EUROPEANS CITING SIGNS OF WEAKNESS IN DOLLAR
description: European economists, confused and divided over United States fiscal and monetary policy, have become equally uncertain about whether American interest rates will decline.

title: JAZZ: MISS CAIN AND ROY KRAL
description: In their recent apparances in New York in such rooms as Michael's Pub and Marty's, Jackie Cain and Roy Kral have usually stressed the cabaret side of their performing style, not only concentration on their vocal work but also emphasizing the use of lyrics as opposed to the scat singing that has been an important element in their duets since they came together in Charlie Ventura's Orchestra more than 30 years ago.

title: Admiral Nominated As Maritime Head
description: President Reagan has nominated a retired four-star admiral, Harold Shear, to head the Maritime Administration. The 62-year-old Mr. Shear has spent some 40 years as a naval officer, in a career that was devoted largely to the undersea world of submarines.

title: Merchants at the Summit
description: You would have thought that when Ronald Reagan and Menachem Begin finally held their long-planned summit they would get serious. Do they really have a common sense of the realities in the Middle East? Does holding Egypt and drawing other Arab nations into an anti-Soviet coalition require an early answer to the Palestinian question? How could American and Israeli military power protect the area against further Soviet advance and shield conservative Arab regimes against domestic threats? What are the possibilities, and limits, of America's special ties to Saudi Arabia? How can Lebanon be pasted together again?

title: Suzuki to Visit Okinawa
description: Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki will fly to Okinawa tomorrow for a two-day visit, the first by a Japanese chief executive since the island was returned to Japan by the United States in 1972, the Kyodo News Service said today.

title: A Faultless Ride
description: Paul Schockemoehle of West Germany, with a faultless ride on Deister, won the individual competition at the European show jumping championships today. Malcolm Pyrah of Britain, on Towerland, won the silver medal with 2.03 penalty points. Bruno Candrian of Switzerland, aboard Van Gogh, was third with 5.24.

title: 2 OIL COMPANIES MAY FACE STATE TAX-EVASION CHARGES
description: Tax-evasion charges against two oil companies involved in a bitter feud have been turned over to the New York State Attorney General for possible criminal prosecution, according to state officials.

title: By Jack Rosenthal
description: The Editorial Notebook The Timeliest Watch

title: Casinos' Winnings At Record
description: Atlantic City's eight legal casinos continued to take in gamblers' money at a record-s etting pace in August, winni ng $132.3 million, or an average of $4.3 million a day, the state rep orted Friday.

title: South Africa's Rugby Players In Honolulu on Way to Coast
description: South Africa's national rugby team arrived today after demonstrators opposed to South Africa's policy of apartheid gave them a hostile sendoff in New Zealand.

title: Shrinking Lunch, With Relish
description: More than 26 million children eat Federally subsidized lunches at school. More than half either pay reduced fees, because their families typically earn less than $16,000 a year, or no fee at all, because their families earn less than $11,000. Some of the children will eat everything; some reject any vegetable that isn't a carrot. Many thus get the only nutritious meal of the day. Some would otherwise go hungry.

title: A PISTOL'S ROUTE INTO A JERSEY JAIL IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: Officials here began an investigation today to dete rmine how an automatic pistol was smuggled to an inmate at the Union County Jail. The weapon was used yesterday in a two-hourtakeover of t he eight-story jail by scores of inmates who overpoweredsix correctio n officers and held them hostage during the siege.

title: GIANTS SET BACK REDSKINS
description: In the first half today, the Giants were terrible. In the second half, the Washington Redskins were terrible, and the Giants made three big plays and capitalized on all of them to score a 17-7 victory.

title: POSTSCRIPT TO A CLASH OVER THE GULF OF SIDRA
description: To the Editor:

title: VERY REAL SOVIET PRISONERS OF ANGOLA'S UNITA
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: On an attempted steal of second base, the runner's hard slide as he beats the throw forces the bag out of the ground. The runner dives for the bag again, but is tagged before he can reach it. Is he out?

title: MISS TRUBIN BRIDE OF RICHARD LEWIS
description: Priscilla Jo Trubin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Trubin of New York and Bellport, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Lewis, son of Mrs. Jack Lewis of Little Neck, Queens, and the late Mr. Lewis. Rabbi Kenneth Emert of Smithtown, L.I. performed the ceremony at the Trubin home in Bellport.

title: Twins 7, White Sox 6
description: Minnesota rallied for four runs in the ninth inning to overcome a three-run deficit and give Bob Veselic (1-0) his first major league victory. Veselic, a right-hander, allowed one hit in three and two-thirds innings in relief of Don Cooper, who gave up five runs.

title: B.P. Stake in Brazil
description: The British Petroleum Company will take a stake in a Brazilian mining subsidiary of Brascan Ltd., of Canada, Brascan said in a statement. The move is intended to help develop the tin industry in Brazil, the statement Friday said. Brazil is the world's fifth-largest tin producer.

title: MISS BIKOFF BRIDE OF JAMES D. PETTIT
description: Nancy Lois Bikoff was married yesterday at the home of her parents, Dr. and Mrs. David M. Bickoff of Patchogue, L.I., to James Duncan Pettit, son the Rev. and Mrs. Jack Pettit of Council Bluffs, Iowa. Rabbi Bart Shalett performed the ceremony.

title: ASSUMPTIONS BY TWO SIDES SHAPE BUDGET
description: One of the confusing factors in the budget debate now preoccupying Washington is that the White House and Congress do not argue from a common set of numbers or assumptions, experts on the subject say.

title: BEGIN TALKS WITH CHRISTIAN AND JEWISH GROUPS
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel spent a busy day in New York yesterday seeking approval from sectors of opinion made wary by recent events in the Middle East while at the same time reassuring his followers that nothing had changed.

title: Commerce Department Economist
description: Robert Ortner, senior vice president at the Bank of New York, is not quite sure who in the Administration was behind his appointment last week as the new Commerce Department chief economist, but he has a good idea why he was tapped for the job.

title: U.S. Women Take Softball Tourney
description: The United States captured the three-nation women's softball championship today, winning one game and tying one at Osaka Stadium.

title: BUSINESS CARDS: A JAPANESE RITUAL
description: ''Your meishi is your face,'' trumpets an advertising billboard. ''Meishi is most necessary here,'' said Akio Morita, chairman of the Sony Corporation. ''It's absolutely essential.'' ''A man without a meishi,'' Marshall R. Louis Jr., press officer in the United States Embassy, explained, ''has no identity in Japan.'' Indeed, it would be difficult to exaggerate the importance in Japan of the meishi, or name card. People in other countries do, of course, carry and exchange name cards or, as they are often called, business cards, particularly corporate executives and government officials. But in Japan, even the bar girls have them.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: It is Humphrey Carpenter's bad luck that his biography of W. H. Auden should appear just two months after the publication of "Young Auden" by Edward Mendelson (Viking). Although Mr. Mendelson stops in 1939, when Auden and Christopher Isherwood abandoned England for the United States, he has already made an impressive case for the continuity of a career. According to this case, Auden shrugged off modernism. He even came to suspect symbols. He rid himself of family, ghosts, trolls, landscapes, history and pure form. Inside his exacerbation, he sought the words to praise. The end of his quest, "the real world," was rootless America. Mr. Carpenter, while he emphasizes the chur ch to which Auden returned as if to his difficult mother, finds in the career less continuity than hodgepodge. He would seem to agree with Stephen Spender: "One of Auden's characteristics is t o make a cult of whatever he happens to be doing, which become s to him what the poet must do." Mr. Mendelson and Mr. Carpenter ag ree on the invidious influences - Icelandic Sagas and English boar ding schools; Hardy, Eliot and Yeats; D.H. Lawrence and Georg Grod deck; John Layard, HomerLane and Gerald Heard; Kierkegaard, Berth and Reinhold Niebuhr; undigested Marx and Freud - but one, the fast idious critic, is looking for literary heroism and the other, a delicious gossip, is looking for good copy. Last Great Eccentric

title: Texas-El Paso Dismisses Coach
description: Bill Michael was dismissed as head football coach today by the University of Texas-El Paso.

title: EGYPT OUSTS FRENCH REPORTER BECAUSE OF 'INSULTING' ARTICLES
description: The Egyptian Government announced today that it was expelling the correspondent here for Le Monde, and accused him of ''insulting and distorting the image of the Egyptian people and Government.''

title: ESHETE TRIUMPHS
description: Getachew Eshete of the Millrose Athletic Association, a civil engineering student at City College, won the Mazola-Y.M.C.A. 10-Kilometer run yesterday at Central Park.

title: What to Do With the Catch
description: The sea robin, the various puffers or blowfish, the horned pout or the catfish all present the problem to those preparing them for the table: they have to be skinned, deheaded and gutted in the most expeditious manner possible.

title: MILITARY SAYS CUTS WON'T HURT PLANS
description: President Reagan's decision to trim planned military spending over the next three years will hardly hamper efforts to strengthen the nation's armed forces, senior Defense Department officials and military officers asserted today. To absorb the relatively small cutbacks of $13 billion in outlays and $21 billion in appropriations from the pr ojected increase in military spending, military officers said the Army, Navy and Air Force would recommend making some reductions in the procurement of new weapons and the creation of new forces. T hose reductions would belikely to entail delaying the construction of an aircraft carrier, holding off the formation of a new combat div ision or slowing down the purchase of aircraft.

title: SUSAN SCHAFFER BRIDE OF FRANCIS RYAN
description: Susan Gail Schaffer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Schaffer of Woodbridge, Conn., Palm Beach, Fla., and Washington, was married in Woodbridge yesterday to Francis A. Ryan, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Ryan of Chicago. Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony in the garden at the Schaffer home.

title: ROLE REVERSAL IN THE REA GAN CABINET
description: The two men seem to enjoy their role reversal. After a lifetime in the Army, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. displays fondness for stylishly cut, diplomatically striped suits. He delights in lecturing on the nuances of foreign policy.

title: Paar's Rigid Schedule
description: He was once known as the king of late-night televison, but Jack Paar has little use for television at any hour these days. He says he's too busy with his hobbies, which range from planting vegetables to raising lion cubs.

title: WEST SIDE RENEWAL
description: If Robert Moses were alive, what would he say about the West Side urban renewal plan, announced 25 years ago and still unfinished? How would he handle the fact that the fifth amended plan has been sitting in Washington for more a year awaiting a supposedly routine approval?

title: Eclipse Awards: A Wide-Open Field
description: On Oct. 14, local thoroughbred racing moves to Aqueduct and the best local horses start scattering south for the winter. That leaves four weeks at the Belmont fall meeting for the top horses to solidify their bids for divisional titles. The ballots for Eclipse Awards are not filled out until December, but the voters will probably make most of their decisions on the basis of the 10 remaining weekend stakes at the Belmont meeting.

title: I.M.F. Finds Inflation Easing
description: The spurt of inflation that marked the world economy in 1979 and 1980 seems to be easing, but high interest rates and slower growth are causing increased unemployment and uncertainty, the International Monetary Fund said today in its annual report.

title: CARDINAL SAYS CRITICS SEEK TO HARM THE CHURCH
description: The Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, John Cardinal Cody, today sharpened his attack on those who accuse him of misusing church funds, declaring that they intended ''to destroy'' and ''to vituperate'' the church by ''striking at the shepherd.''

title: Building Collapses in Cairo
description: A four-story building collapsed in the heart of Cairo's business and shopping district, killing three people, the police said today. Construction going on adja cent to the 20-year-old building damaged its foundations and caused i t to collapse, police sources said.

title: NO INTEREST IN JUSTICE
description: The Reagan Administration has long since made clear its radical character: its break from long-settled ideas of the public interest. Its policies on the environment and public health are widely-observed examples. But for me the most striking example came in a brief filed last week in the Supreme Court.

title: EXCERPTS FROM HAIG'S BERLIN SPEECH
description: Following are excerpts from the prepared text of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s speech today before the Berlin Press Association, as made public by the State Department: Special to the New York Times

title: BEETHOVEN: JOHANESSEN AT PIANO
description: GRANT JOHANESSEN has been a busy and highly visible pianist on the New York concert scene for more than 30 years. While he is most strongly identified with the French repertory - no doubt a legacy from his mentor, Robert Casadesus - he has played music in virtually every style one would care to mention. Even for so wide-ranging a musician as Mr. Johannesen, an all-Beethoven program is something he had never ventured before in this city, but that omission was rectified yesterday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall.

title: CARDS HELPED BY BALK, SWEEP METS, 4-2
description: Some 15 hours after having suffered a wrenching, 13- inning defeat, the Mets lost ag ain to the St. Louis Cardinals this afternoon. The Cardinals swept the three-game weekend series by identical 4-2 scores.

title: Curry Engineers Upset of Alabama
description: Coach Bill Curry of Georgia Tech, whose team beat Alabama, 24-21, for one of Saturday's four major upsets, said: ''I don't think upsets come about by mistake. If they do, it is very rarely.''

title: RULING CLOUDS THE RACE FOR MAYOR IN ATLANTA
description: New Yorkers were not th e only people to get a surprise just before the primary elections. A tlantans, preparing for their own citywide nonpartisan primary on Oct . 6, got their own shock.

title: ROYALS 6, A'S 5
description: The Royals extended their Western Division lead to two games over the A's, who won the first-half title. Willie Wilson of the Royals broke up a 5-5 tie in the 12th inning with a bloop single off Dave Beard (0-1), Oakland's fourth pitcher.

title: Honduran Leader Visits Mexico City for Talks
description: President Policarpo Paz Garcia of Honduras met today with President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico for discussions that reportedly centered on the political violence in Central America. In a brief airport welcoming speech, Mr. Lopez Portillo said there is a need for ''political goodwill'' and ''peaceful solutions'' to regional problems in these ''dark and critical moments.''

title: 3 From Navy Helicopter Missing in Crash at Sea
description: A Navy helicopter crashed in the Atlantic about 360 miles off Virginia today, and three crewmen were rescued.

title: PAPAL ENCYCLICAL ON WORKERS DUE TOMORROW
description: Pope John Paul II announced today that a new encyclical dealing with the nature of work and the rights of the working class would be be published Tuesday.

title: Philippine Blast Wounds 8
description: Eight people were wounded, three of them seriously, by a grenad e that was thrown into arestaurant here tonight, the police said. The identity and motive of the attacker were not immediately known.

title: THE HEAT WILL BE ON FOR HEARNS AND LEONARD
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. IT will be hot. By the opening bell, the sun will have slipped behind the Sierra Nevada foothills, but the desert cools slowly and Sugar Ray Leonard and Thomas Hearns will fight Wednesday night in what will feel like a combination oven and grill.

title: CHIEFS 19, BUCCANEERS 10
description: At KANSAS CITY, Mo. - Four field goals by Nick Lowery after an 8-yard touchdown run by Ted McKnight, helped the Chiefs (2-0) to their best start since the 1969 season, when they won their only Super Bowl game.

title: Washington Watch; Discordance I n Gold Study
description: WASHINGTON IT was probably inevitable, given the passion the subject arouses, but the group set up by the Government to study a possibly greater monetary role for gold is a discordant one indeed.

title: Brewers 5, Orioles 0
description: The Brewers, in third place, three games behind Detroit, used three pitchers to shut out the Orioles on six hits. Pete Vuckovich (12-4) allowed only three hits in seven innings, and Jamie Easterly and Bob McClure preserved the shutout with one inning each of scoreless relief.

title: LORRI HAM, SINGER, MARRIED
description: At the Woodlawn Presbyterian Church in St. Petersburg, Fla., yesterday Lois-Marie Ham, daughter of Albert William Ham of Huntington, Conn., and Mary Mayo Ham of New York, was married to Michael Hafer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hafer of St. Petersburg. The bride, known as Lorri, is a pop and jazz singer. The bridegroom is a jazz organist.

title: WASHINGTON TIME can put a patina of significance and value on improbable objects: an Etruscan coin, an Art Deco cocktail shaker, a beer-bottle cap.  Or, perhaps, on Leonard Bernstein's "Mass"?  That seemed an entertainable possibility before his once-celebrated "theater piece for singers, players and dancers" was revived on Saturday evening in a completely restaged version at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.
description: "Mass," you may recall, was the work with which the Kennedy Center was inaugurated on Sept. 8, 1971, and here it was, back for a 3 1/2-week run in a $975,000 production as part of the center's 10th anniversary festivities. This time around it was staged by Tom O'Horgan of "Hair" and "Jesus Christ Superstar" fame, with choreography by Wesley Fata, another "Hair" alumnus.

title: 9-2 Shot Scores
description: Our Captain Willie, a 3-year-old son of Little Current named for Willie Stargell, the Pittsburgh Pirates' captain, took command at the top of the stretch to win the $81,750 Lawrence Realization for 3-year-olds on the grass yesterday at Belmont Park. The colt is owned by Daniel M. Galbreath, whose family also owns the Pirates.

title: News Analysis
description: As teams of investigators and prosecutors reconstruct the activities of Edwin P. Wilson, a former American intelligence agent charged with illegally exporting explosives to Libya, a handful of other officials have been quietly studying some of the national and international issues the case raises.

title: TIGERS SET BACK INDIANS, 8-6
description: Rick Peters, a 25-year-old outfielder with the Detroit Tigers, is used to winning. He played in the College World Series with Arizona State in 1977 and then helped Evansville, Ind., and Montgomery, Ala., to pennants in the minor leagues.

title: Soviet Said to Explode Nuclear Device in Siberia
description: The Soviet Union detonated its most powerful underground nuclear explosion of the year today, the Swedish Seismological Institute reported.

title: Hirshhorn Memorial Service In Washington on Wednesday
description: Artists, art critics and politicians will meet here on Wednesday to pay final tribute to Joseph H. Hirshhorn, the patron of modern art who died here on Aug. 31 at the age of 82.

title: Commodities; Price of Copper as Indicator
description: ECONOMIC forecasters gaze at the gross national product and the Consumer Price Index to assess the health of the nation's economy. Commodity brokers have a simpler test - the price of copper.

title: Prost Wins Italian Grand Prix
description: Alain Prost of France won the Italian Grand Prix in a Renault today, and Carlos Reutemann gained valuable points toward the world championship when rival Nelson Piquet had to withdraw with engine trouble moments before the finish.

title: TESTIMONY TO BEGIN IN TRIAL OF NURSE IN DEATH OF PATIENT
description: Testimony is expected to begin this week in the murder trial of a 44-year-old nurse charged with injecting a fatal dose of morphine sulfate into a cancer patient crying out in pain.

title: Control Data Computer
description: The Control Data Corporation said it had introduced a microcomputer and its first software packages in a new series of small business, education and training applications.

title: 'HILL STREET BLUES' SWEEPS EMMYS
description: "Hill Street Blues," the NBC police station drama in serious ratings trouble, scored a record eight Emmys last night, including best drama series and top performers, at the 33d Television Academy awards presentation.

title: U.S. BORROWING IS HEAVY THIS WEEK
description: High interest rates continue to deter many corporate and tax-exempt borrowers, but borrowing by the United States Treasury remains heavy and promises to grow. This Wednesday the Treasury is scheduled to sell $4.75 billion of new two-year notes, with a $5,000 minimum unit.

title: Top Scientology Officials Removed From Church
description: The Church of Scientology, reacting to recent adverse publicity, much of it a result of criminal convictions of some top officers, said today that it was replacing some of its leaders.

title: Last of Kansas Jail Escapees Recaptured Without Struggle
description: Law-enforcement officers and National Guardsmen tracked down and captured two convicts today who the authorities said had been involved in a number of crimes since escaping Sept. 6.

title: THINKING OF ISRAEL'S FUTURE
description: Recent columns about Israel have brought an unusually large number of letters from readers, mostly irate and in some cases shrilly insulting and even menacing. It is a surprising and saddening attitude from Americans.

title: DREDGING AGAIN IN THE YUKON
description: Gold-mining methods in Canada's Klondike have come a long way since the days of the bearded prospector, crouching beside a stream and patiently swilling water around in a shallow pan. Most gold operations now use bulldozers and sophisticated sluice boxes.

title: A New Jet Defense
description: Soon, bubble gum card collectors may be trading a J. Edgar Hoover for a Pete Rose. The latest wrinkle in the card business involves the New York City Police Department and the Jets football team.

title: Needham Resignation
description: Needham, Harper & Steers Inc. has announced that Brad Roberts, president of NH&S/West, Los Angeles, and vice chairman of the company's board, has resigned. He is being succeeded as head of NH&S/West by Gerrold R. Rubin, who has been senior vice president, management representative at NH&S/Chicago.

title: Short-Term Rates Have Backed Off Backed Off
description: While interest rates for maturities of one year and more are still near their record highs, there has been a decided drop in short-term rates over the past week and month.

title: Job of a Lifetime
description: It was a $5 house burglary back in 1922, but in those days night burglary was considered a capital crime in Dillon County, S.C., and John Davis wa s given a life sentence.

title: A GUIDE TO STATUS OF CITY'S PRIMARY ELECTIONS
description: A variety of city elections, aside from the City Council races in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx, remain shrouded in uncertainty, in some cases because of pending lawsuits and in others because of the conflicting interests of politicians.

title: Ballas Takes Title
description: Gustavo Ballas of Argentina captured the title in the newly created World Boxing Association juniorbantamweight category yesterday by stopping Suk Chul Bae of South Korea in the eighth round. Ballas had a clear advantage, and by the eighth round had managed to close the right eye of the South Korean. The victory raised Ballas's professional record to 53-0-1.

title: U.S. SAYS DATA SHOW TOXIN USE IN ASIA CONFLICT
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States now had ''physical evidence'' tha t poisonous chemicals have been used in Southea st Asia in apparent violation of international agreements banning their use.

title: Temperence Hill Draws Marlboro High Weight
description: Temperence Hill, the 1980 Belmont Stakes winner who has earned morethan $1 milli on, drew high weight of 127 pounds yesterday for Saturday's $4 00,000 Marlboro Cup, a mile-and-a-quarter invitation handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Belmont Park.

title: Italian Car Sales Off
description: Italian car sales fell to a provisional 80,000 units in August, from 171,000 in July and 98,000 in August of last year, according to figures issued today by the National Motor Manufacturers' Association. But cumulative sales of 1.22 million units for the first eight months were 2.5 percent more than the 1.19 million sold in the same 1980 period, the gro up said.

title: Chess: U.S. Junior Title Captured By a San Francisco Master
description: Jay Whitehead, a 19-year-old San Francisco master, won the 1981 United States Junior Championship in Scottsdale, Ariz., scoring 6-1 to top a field of the eight highest-ranking players under the age of 20. FINAL STANDINGS Player W.L. D. Pts. Whitehead 5 0 2 6 Root 3 1 3 4 1/2 Adam 3 1 3 4 1/2 Orfalea 3 2 2 4 Youngworth 1 3 3 2 1/2 Brown 1 3 3 2 1/2 Wada 1 3 3 2 1/2 Schroer 1 5 1 1 1/2

title: Weightlifting Crown To Bulgaria's Manolov
description: Bloslav Manolov of Bulgaria set one world record and tied another to take the featherweight title tonight in the World Weightlifting Championships.

title: RAMPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes a capital gain of $162,000 or 6 cents a shr... C-Includes nonrecurring deferred interest income and loan repayment penalties of $461,000 or 24 cents a shr

title: SCHLUMBERGER LOOKS PAST OIL
description: In 1927, two French brothers lowered an electrical probe down an oil well on a wire and made a discovery as valuable as oil itself. Conrad and Marcel Schlumberger, who had been experimenting with using electricity to prospect for minerals, found that they could measure the electrical resistance of rock formations at various depths to obtain a picture of the underground geology.

title: WARKOW IS RESIGNING AS CARNEGIE DIRECTOR
description: Stewart J. Warkow, executive director of Carnegie Hall, has resigned effective March 31, 1982. Mr. Warkow was appointed in 1978, and had previously been Carnegie Hall's house manager for 10 years. He tendered his resignation yesterday in order to pursue, he said, his ''personal and professional interests.''

title: A 1960'S RERUN
description: As Andy Warhol sees it, the 1980's are shaping up as a replay of the 1960's. ''It's sort of exciting,'' he explained yesterday.

title: Electronics Concern Gains
description: The General Instrument Corporation, a leading manufacturer of wagering equipment and cable television products, reported yesterday that net income in the second quarter of the 1982 fiscal year ended Aug. 30, soared 37 percent, to $22.6 million, or 75 cents a share, from $16.5 million, or 62 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Revenues climbed 12.2 percent, to $227.5 million, from $202.7 million.

title: An Expensive Victory
description: Nelson Skalbania, owner of the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League, invested more than $1 million in 1981 salaries to lure five outstanding talents, including Vince Ferragamo from the Los Angeles Rams. But only Billy (White Shoes) Johnson and James Scott, wide receivers, have done well for him.

title: IN ALBINO STUDIES, SCIENTISTS SEARCH FOR PIGMENT ERROR
description: MINNEAPOLIS BORN with a defective ability to form pigment, albinos are conspicuous people. Their whitish hair and skin and pale, squinting eyes often cause them to suffer more from social stigma than from their actual physical disabilities.

title: MFY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AUTO 'PASS-FAIL' RATINGS DROPPED IN CRASH TESTS
description: The automobile safety branch of the Department of Transportation said today that it would no longer report whether new car models ''pass'' or ''fail'' annual crash tests, although the tests will continue and statistical results will be published.

title: CONSUL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Z. WAYNE GRIFFIN
description: Z. Wayne Griffin, who produced the ''Burns and Allen'' show on radio and ''General Electric Theater'' on television, died last Thursday.

title: TII INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: B-Includes tax credits of $51,000 in qr and $137,000 in yr... C-Includes tax credits of $84,000 in qr and $162,000 for the yr; the shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split

title: INVENTORIES UP BY 1.1% IN JULY
description: Inventories rose 1.1 percent for American manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers in July, the Commerce Department reported today, in a new indication of weakness in the national economy.

title: Market Place; Bright Hopes For Research
description: LAST spring the nation's largest brokerage house offered the first public shares of an enterprise bearing the earmarks of a rank speculation. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith lent its name to a concern called the Nelson Research and Development Company, with eight full-time and six part-time employees - an enterprise that lost money in 1980 and had a net tangible book value of 1 cent a share before its public debut.

title: U.N. VOTES TO ISOLATE SOUTH AFRICA OVER NAMIBIA
description: The General Assembly today voted overwhelmingly, 117 to 0 with 25 abstentions, to isolate South Africa and to arm the guerrillas fighting to make South-West Africa the independent nation of Namibia.

title: Paper Ad Revenues Up 21.6% in July
description: July advertising revenues for the nation's newspapers were up 21.6 percent, to $1.4 billion, over the same month last year, according to estimates by the Newspaper Advertising Bureau.

title: GASOLINE SELLERS KEEP SALES TAX, STATE AIDE SAYS
description: The State's Commissioner of Taxation and Finance said yesterday that New York State and its local governments were losing $40 million to $50 million a year because retail gasoline dealers and distributors were not paying all the sales taxes they owed.

title: RYKOFF, S E, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The 1980 shr earnings adjusted for a 25 percent stock divd Aug 3, 1981

title: U.A.W. TO STRESS JOB SECURITY IN '82 BARGAINING, FRASER SAYS
description: The United Automobile Workers will concentrate on job security rather than wage gains in negotiations with the ailing automobile industry next year, the union's president, Douglas Fraser, said today.

title: STATUE-CLIMBER IS ARRESTED
description: A homeless, 21-year-old man climbed onto the crown of the Statue of Liberty yesterday morning to proclaim himself a write-in candidate for Mayor of the City of New York. He clung to his perch for two hours before the police brought him down.

title: AFTER LAYOFF, DAVIDSON MUST PROVE HE IS TOP RANGER GOALIE
description: John Davidson, the Rangers' tall, soft-spoken goaltender, slammed his stick on the crossbar of the goal and grunted angrily through his red, white and blue mask.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 15, 1981
description: International Charges that toxic chemical weapons were used by the Soviet Union and the Vietnamese in Southeast Asia and possibly Afghanistan in violation of international agreements were backed up with evidence produced by the State Department. The evidence, which the department termed ''significant, although preliminary,'' relied heavily on analysis of one leaf-and-stem sample collected in Cambodia near the Thai border. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) Russians will have to pay more for gasoline, vodka, jewelry and other ''nonessentials,'' the head of the State Committee on Prices announced. In explaining the increases, Nikolai T. Glushkov, said ''corrections'' in some prices were necessitated by ''conditions of production, the growing cost of the extraction of raw materials and the need to ensure the rational use of resources and certain commodities.'' Mr. Glushkov said the cost of ba sic foods would remainthe same and some commodities, such as medici nes, would be reduced. (A1:1.)

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allegheny and Western Energy Corp. and Independent Exploration Co. of Houston said they had signed a letter of intent to merge. Under the agreement, Independent Exploration will become a subsidiary of Allegheny Western.

title: Fuel Tax Studied By Shell Canada
description: Shell Canada Resources Ltd. said its proposed $13 billion (Canadian currency) Alsands oil sands project in northern Alberta did not appear to be economically viable under Canada's new national energy agreement.

title: Opening Session for Islanders
description: The gray sweatsuit lay neatly folded, untouched, in front of Bob Bourne's locker in the Islander dressing room. The locker was empty except for an incongruous bumper st icker pasted to it that read, ''I'm Proud to be a Farmer.''

title: Fodor to Open Series At Lehman Hall Oct. 24
description: The Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx will begin its 1981-82 music season on Oct. 24 at 8 P.M. with a recital by the violinist Eugene Fodor.

title: Dow Chemical In Loan Talks
description: The Dow Chemical Company said that it was negotiating with European banking sources to raise at least $500 million in the form of a fiveyear revolving line of credit.

title: Bridge: Sontag Team Shows Way In Grand National Contest
description: An event that has, in spite of a small handicap, increased steadily in popularity since it w as initiated three years ago is the Grand Nationa l Pair Championship. The preliminaries are held in clubsin August, th us excluding many vacationing players, but nevertheless 180 pairs of qualifiers showed up Sunday at the New York Hilton Hotelfor the local final, surprising the organizers, who had to scramble for extra tab les.

title: ANTIQUE HUNT TRAPS TWO IN JEWEL THEFTS
description: ''Wouldn't it be funny,'' the White Plains woman said to her husband while ''antiquing'' Aug. 18 in Bucks County, Pa., ''if I found some of the jewelry I lost in the burglary?''

title: Apology Made By Templeton
description: Garry Templeton apologized today for making obscen e gestures to heckling fans, and he was reinstated by the St. Louis Cardinals. The team suspended h im almost three weeks ago before placing him on the disabled list.

title: MUSIC: LA MONTE YOUNG'S 'WELL TO-TUNED PIANO
description: THE tuning of strings has always been associated with other tunings - with the proportioned music of celestial spheres or the delicate balances in the soul itself. So when La Monte Young first retuned to the standard piano some 15 years ago in ''The Well-Tuned Piano,'' his desire to create a musical language, opening novel psychological regions, was not simply the dream of a musician wound up in the consciousness-transforming fashions of the period.

title: McEnroe, Miss Austin Meet President Reagan
description: John McEnroe and Tracy Austin, the singles champions of the United States Open, attended a gathering of Administration officials and tennis celebrities addressed by President Reagan today. Mr. Reagan was treated to a tennis lesson from members of the Davis Cup and Wightman Cup teams Mr. Reagan also watched an exhibition match between Stan Smith and Marty Riessen, Davis Cup members.

title: B.F. SKINNER NOW SEES LITTLE HOPE FOR THE WORLD'S SALVATION
description: CAMBRIDGE,Mass. FOR decades, B. F. Skinner has written about and preached his behavioral theory of human psychology. Thoughts, emotions and actions, he contends, are exclusively products of environment; free will, according to the Harvard University psychologist, simply does not exist. He envisioned utopian societies, and described one in his book, ''Walden II,'' that resulted from tightly controlled systems in which people were motivated solely by the manipulation of what he called positive and negative reinforcements.

title: MEMORIAL TO DR. KING DEBATED
description: In an angry debate, House conservatives today fought to block an effort to place a statue of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the halls of Congress.

title: AT LARGE COUNCIL MEMBERS SEEK PLACE IN ELECTION
description: At-large members of the City Council tried yesterday to get their positions put on the voting machines in the rescheduled New York City primary election.

title: Transactions;
description: BASEBALL

title: Too Much And Too Little
description: Having first cut taxes too much, President Reagan cut his planned military spending increases too little to avoid big political trouble at home. But even the minor cut he did make may have undermined the central element of his dubious strategy toward the Soviet Union.

title: 3 Killed in Jail Riot in Brazil
description: About 200 policemen used rifle fire, tear gas and attack dogs to break up a prison riot in this southeast Brazilian city today. Three prisoners were killed and 22 inmates and three policemen were injured, the police said.

title: No Headline
description: Senate Majority Leader Howard H. Baker said today that the Senate leadership intended to consider the expulsion of Senator Williams in early November.

title: Faubus Returns to a Role In Arkansas Government
description: Former Gov. Orval Faubus, remembered by many for his decision 24 years ago to use the National Guard to bar blacks from entering Central High School here, was sworn in today to a new state job.

title: G.O.P. RESISTANCE PUTS BUDGET CUTS IN SOME JEOPARDY
description: President Reagan ran into trouble today from Congressional leaders of his own party as he sought to build a legislative coalition to pass a second round of budget cuts. The cuts are needed, his advisers say, to hold the 1982 deficit to Mr. Reagan's goal of $42.5 billion.

title: The Air: Clearer, but No Cleaner
description: Washington has backed down. After a decade- long battle with state and city officials over plans to clean up New York's air, the Environmental Protection Agency says the city won't have to invest more in mass transit; nor will the state lose Federal funds for failure to comply with the Clean Air Act.

title: OH, THAT BUNDY
description: Had his name been a simple one like, say, John Smith, McGeorge Bundy, the historian and former government official and Ford Foundation president, might not have found himself the center of a case of wildly mistaken identity.

title: Lisbon Leader Offers 3-Year Austerity Plan
description: Prime Minister Francisco Pinto Balsemao presented Parliament with a proposed three-year austerity program today aimed at reviving the economy and bringing Portugal into the European Economic Community.

title: WALL ST. ASKS NEW BUDGET TRIMS AND CHANGES IN REAGAN PROGRAM
description: A broad range of Wall Street economists said yesterday that President Reagan's cuts in military spending did not even qualify as a ''gesture'' toward easing the concerns of the financial markets that his economic program will be inflationary.

title: Poisoning by Spray Gun
description: Accidents with high-pressure paint spray guns have caused serious injuries to workers. But, according to a report from physicians at Mount Sinai School of Medicine in Manhattan, the aftermath of a Navy Yard worker's injury was unusual.

title: FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
APPEALS COURT OVERTURNS F.A.A. ON GROUNDING OF FOREIGN DC-10'S
description: The Federal Aviation Administration exceeded its authority in temporarily grounding foreign-registered DC-10 airliners after a 1979 crash in Chicago that killed 273 people, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: VIETNAM DEAD HONORED IN BOSTON CEREMONY
description: Several thousand people participated yesterday in ceremonies in Independence Park honoring the 25 South Boston men who lost their lives in the Vietnam war.

title: NEW YORK RETAILERS REPORT SLOW 7.6% AUGUST SALES GAIN
description: Seven major New York department stores reported that August sales continued the slower pace of July, registering an average gain of 7.6 percent over August 1980, a spot-check found yesterday.

title: Leonard Wins a Toss, Will Make Grand Entry
description: Sugar Ray Leonard won a coin flip today that gives him the grand entrance for his fight Wednesday night against Thomas Hearns.

title: EXILED WRITERS HOLD OWN BOOK FAIR
description: Less than a week after the third Moscow International Book Fair in the Soviet Union, which closed Sept. 8 and which was shunned by all but a handful of American publishers, publishers, several hundred guests and a Who's Who of dissident Soviet writers gathered amid tears and laughter last night. The place was the stately Trustees Room of the New York Public Library and the occasion was the third Moscow Book Fair Reception in Exile.

title: Miners' Union Calls Protest 'Convention'
description: The leadership of the United Mine Workers union will call a two-day ''special convention'' this weekend to encourage its 170,000 members to attend the national labor movement's Solidarity Day protest against the Reagan Administration on Saturday.

title: No Headline
description: The Yankees announced Monday that box and reserved seat tickets for the American League Eastern Division playoff games at Yankee Stadium would go on sale at the Stadium starting Saturday at 9 A.M. Box seats cost $10 each and reserved seats $7. There is a limit of four tickets per game per person, and tickets may be purchased for individual games or all games.

title: Paraguay-Japan Plan
description: Paraguay has proposed building an aluminium refinery in a joint venture with Japan, the Japan Aluminium Federation said here today. The Paraguayan Government has asked for a Japanese survey team to conduct a feasibility study on the proposed project, the trade group added. The proposed refinery, with 150,000 tons of annual capacity of primary aluminium, could use low-cost electric power from the Itaipu hydropower station now being built jointly by the Brazilian and Paraguayan Governments, but would require a supply of alumina for production, the federation said.

title: I.B.M. Displays New System
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a new finance communication system, the IBM 4700, that it said offered better performance and more main storage capacity than its present I.B.M. 3600 finance system.

title: Service for Edith Skinner
description: A service for Edith Warman Skinner, a teacher of speech for the theater who died July 26, will be held Sept. 26 at 11 A.M. in the Drama Theater of the Juilliard School, 144 West 66th Street.

title: ZAPATA BARS BID BY OCCIDENTAL
description: The Zapata Corporation's board has unanimously rejected last week's merger proposal by the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, B. John Mackin, Zapata's chairman and chief executive officer, announced late yesterday.

title: APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After tax credits of $353,000 in the latest qr and $590,000 for the yr-ago qr...C-Reflects a pretax charge of $6.5 million from closing of company's retail packaging operation...D-Net income

title: BRIEFING
description: T URF conflicts are inevitable in Washington, but this one has a new twist. The Republicans, who hold a four-year lease on the real estate, are saying Democrats are at fault.

title: Venezuelan Oil Price Up
description: Venezuela raised the export price of its re sidual fuels by 15 cents to 50 cents a barrel, to a range of $24.35 to $28 a barrel, the Energy M inistry said today. It did not explain the reasons for the rise, whi ch takes effect tomorrow, but officials said last week that a n increase was imminent because of the end of the warm season in the Northern Hemisphere. Venezuela exports about 500,000 barrels daily of residual fuels, which are used mainly for heating, mostly to the United States for use in the N ortheast.

title: PROLER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Raines Sidelined
description: Tim Raines, the Montreal Expos' rookie who leads the major leagues in steals with 69, fractured a bone in his right hand during a fifthinning slide at Chicago Sunday. Raines will be unable to play regularly for three to six weeks - meaning perhaps the rest of the season - but is expected to be used as a pinch-runner when his heavy ca st comes of f in two days and is replaced by a lightweight model.

title: Escape From East Germany
description: Two young couples and their two children slipped past East German frontier patrol boats in the Baltic Sea in a sailing dinghy to escape to West Germany today, the Federal border police reported.

title: A HEAVEN MADE IN MARRIGE
description: Eighteen months ago Reginald St. Clement promised his bride-to-be that they would have ''a marriage made in heaven.'' And so it came to pass last weekend that Mr. St. Clement and Courtney Shawne Tolson were joined together ankle-deep in clouds, created by 500 pounds of dry ice and three fog-making machines. The couple stood between the upper stories of the Empire State and Chrysler Buildings, actually 18-foot models. And there was, of course, a ring bearer - whose white wings were the work of a Long Island taxidermist. A hired musician played the harp.

title: New Denver Morning Edition
description: The Denver Post, the city's afternoon newspaper, published its first issues of a new morning edition today. The newspaper will continue to publish its regular afternoon editions.

title: News Analysis
description: At the White House this morning, a group of Southern Democrats told President Reagan that they would go along with his plans for a modest slowdown in military spending, leaving domestic programs to bear the brunt of the new budget cuts to be proposed by the Administration.

title: SAIGON AIDE: 'THEY SAY, HOW ARE YOU, MR. GOLDBERG?'
description: When sales are slow at Goldberg's Delly, Bui Diem sometimes sits behind the cash register and wonders how he wound up selling pastrami sandwiches.

title: Ford Will Close Unit in Flat Rock
description: The Ford Motor Company said it will close its huge Michigan Casting Center in Flat Rock by mid-December, idling about 2,400 workers. Slow sales of large cast-iron auto engines and the fact the plant cannot easily be adapted to newer products have forced the closing, Mike Davis, a Ford spokesman, said.

title: Talking Business with Wolf of
description: Peter Wolf Associates Buying Land: The Dangers

title: NEW JERSEY RAISES QUESTIONS ABOUT NUGGET'S CHIEF
description: The State Attorney General's Division of Gaming Enforcement reported today that ''troublesome information has been uncovered'' linking Stephen A. Wynn, chairman of Golden Nugget Inc., with cocaine use and the acceleration of stock options for favored employees.

title: STRIKE DISRUPTIONS ARE EASING AS AIRLINES AND AIRPORTS COPE
description: Before the air traffic controllers' strike, the Greater Pittsburgh International Airport handled as many as 110 flights an hour. Today the airport handled 77 flights from 9 to 10 A.M.; it was the busiest hour of air traffic since the strike began six weeks ago.

title: Solving Mystery of Rocks
description: Throughout most desert regions there are rocks that weather in such a way that they seem to have been given a coat of varnish long ago by some passing traveler. The phenomenon is known as desert varnish.

title: CHAMBER: HAYDN AND STRAVINSKY
description: THE best chamber music practices a stern economy, avoiding when possible the duplication of instrumental lines or doubling of parts. But pairing off and doubling up can offer its own joys and justifications, as the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is out to prove this week. The society is taking advantage of this season's simultaneous anniversaries of Haydn and Stravinsky to present a series of concerts, lectures, films and exhibits paying tribute to the two composers. Haydn died 250 years ago, come March; Stravinsky would have been 100 years old next June.

title: LEATHER, THE NEW FASHION DARLING
description: The leather juggernaut is under way. Having scored a major success in early fall selling, it is now consolidating its position for resorts, and designers working on their spring collections promise that leather will be strongly represented.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 20.00-20.50 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: France to Continue Study Of Neutron Arms Project
description: Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy said today that the Government ''has decided to continue studying'' development of a neutron warhead tested by France last year.

title: Resolutions Cited In Claims Cases
description: Seven of the 12 challenges to advertising claims investigated in August by the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus were closed when the advertisers either discontinued the advertising or changed the claims.

title: Fox Film to Sell Stake in Units
description: The 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation said it would sell an undivided one-half interest in several of its major divisions to Urban Diversified Properties Inc., a subsidiary of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, under its previously announced reorganization plan.

title: United Arab Emirates Leader Reported to Be Ill in London
description: Sheik Rashid bin Said al-Maktum, Prime Minister of the United Arab Emirates, is hospitalized in London and is believed to be seriously ill, a spokesman at Wellington Hospital said today.

title: RATES FALL FED ADDS RESERVES
description: Short-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday as the Federal Reserve continued to increase the supply of bank reserves. At the weekly Treasury bill auction, three-month and six-month issues dropped more than a percentage point from the previous auction on Sept. 4, to a new average of 14.412 percent and 14.657 percent, respectively. ''The Fed h as been slowly putting more and more reserves into the banking syste m, which is bringing down short-term rates,'' one government se curities analayst said. The additional reserves make more money av ailable to banks for loans, thus easing the pressure on interest rate s. Fed Buys Securities

title: SUFFOLK LEADER SEEKS LAYOFFS AND HIGHER TAXES IN BUDGET
description: Peter F. Cohalan, the Suffolk County Executive, yesterday proposed a 1982 county budget that would require the laying off of 600 county employees, a reduction in county services and a property-tax increase.

title: Leukemia in Milk
description: A study by a team of scientists at the University of Pennsylvania has found that cow's milk that contains bovine leukemia virus can transmit the virus to other animal species, as well as to the cows' offspring. The virus, found in nearly 20 percent of dairy cows, is universally regarded as the causative agent of the form of bovine leukemia that is the most common fatal malignancy of dairy cattle.

title: Stake in Sytek Is Acquired
description: The General Instrument Corporation, a leading supplier of cable television equipment, said yesterday that it would acquire a 45 percent interest in Sytek Inc., a private data communications company based in Sunnyvale, Calif., at a cost of $6 million.

title: CITY'S SHORT TERM NOTES WIN MOODY'S 2D HIGHEST RATING
description: Moody's Investors Service, one of the natio n's principal securitiesrating agencies, yesterday gave New York City 's short-term notes the firmest endorsement they have enjoyed since t he start of the fiscal crisis in the mid-1970's.

title: NORWAY'S RIGHT TOPPLES LABOR GOVERNMENT
description: The Labor Party, which has dominated Norwegian politics for almost half a century, was defeated in parliamentary elections yesterday by a resurgent right.

title: CARDINAL'S FRIEND DENIES RECEIVING CHURCH FUNDS
description: The lawyer for Helen Dolan Wilson said today that his client had been the victim of character assassination in reports suggesting she profited from funds improperly diverted from church accounts by John Cardinal Cody, the Archbishop of Chicago.

title: WELLCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Yr to June 27
description: B-After tax credits of $400,000 in latest yr and $133,500 in earlier period; results also included unusual credits of $139,214 in 1981 and $132,602 in 1980 relating to an adjust- ment to long-term pension liability, 1981 and the final adjust- ment of the 1979 provision for realignment program, 1981 and 19

title: DIGITAL RESOURCES DRIVEN BY SUCCESS INTO MAJOR CHANGES
description: When Gary Kildall inspects his company's production floor and shipping dock, he walks through a kitchen, out to a patio where the company cat is sunning itself and into a former carriage house.

title: NICHOLS, S E, INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Julia Elizabeth Hayden, Writer On Staff of The New Yorker
description: Julia Elizabeth Hayden, a writer and daughter of the late Charles Hayden and Phyllis McGinley, the poet, died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a short illness. She was 42 years old.

title: U.S. AND JAPANESE ARE URGED TO SHARE MORE RESPONSIBILITY
description: The Japanese-American relationship has been mutually beneficial in recent years but should be readjusted if it is to function most effectively in future, Graham Allison, dean of Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government, said yesterday.

title: SOUTHLAND ROYALTY STUDIES TIE OR SALE
description: The Southland Royalty Company, a major independent oil and gas producer and exploration company based in Fort Worth, announced yesterday that it would hold ''exploratory discussions'' with a limited number of companies concerning the sale or possible merger of the company.

title: Refined Sugar Trading
description: The Midamerica Commodity Exchange said today that it was seeking Government approval to trade a domestic refined sugar futures contract.

title: RAIDERSSET BACK VIKINGS BY 36-10
description: The Oakland Raiders, the Super Bowl champions who had lost their opening game to Denver, defeated the Minnesota Vikings, 36-10, tonight.

title: NEW YORK'S COST ON WEST VALLEY MIGHT INCREASE
description: New York will probably have to pay $23 million extra for the cleanup of a defunct nuclear fuel reprocessing plant at West Valley, the State Energy Commissioner said today.

title: Richard T. Sullivan, Novelist And Notre Dame Professor
description: Richard T. Sullivan, professor of English at the University of Notre Dame and a novelist and book reviewer, died Sunday. He was 72 years old.

title: SEEMS OSHA'S WASHING ITS HANDS OF FARM WORKERS' BASIC SANITATION
description: WASHINGTON

title: Associated Press; FEDERAL BUILDING IN CONNECTICUT NAMED FOR RIBICOFF
