description: Former Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff cutting a ribbon yesterday during ceremony renaming the Hartford Federal Building in his honor. Joining the three-term former U.S. Senator from Connecticut were his wife, Lois, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, right, and Gov. William A. O'Neill. About 300 invited guests attended the ceremony.

title: UNITED MCGILL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Summer People, Summer Money
description: In the small towns of many years ago, the term ''summer people'' referred to rich folks from the city who opened their big houses on Memorial Day, closed them on Labor Day and, unlike the natives, always charged their groceries. They provided employment and entertainment for the ''locals,'' and their only conspicuous flaw was a congenital reluctance to pay their bills. On the whole they were harmless, the stuff of winter's anecdotes.

title: BRUSHING OVER THE OLD ROOFTOP LANDSCAPES
description: To the Editor:

title: MILDRED LIEBOWITZ
description: Mildred Liebowitz, a former assistant to the letters editor of The New York Times, died Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a long illness.

title: Erie Legislator Accuses Bills of Holding Tickets
description: Erie County legislators will consider a resolution Thursday, asking Buffalo Bills management to answer a charge that it withheld tickets to assure a television blackout of their season opener Sept. 6 against the Jets.

title: CABINET SHUFFLED BY MRS. THATCHER
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, making a comprehensive shuffle of her Cabinet, served notice today that she is not contemplating any significant change in the economic course that her Government has set.

title: Borg Calls Off an Appearance
description: Two dozen tennis fans and lunchtime shoppers clustered around the hastily prepa red sign in front of Macy's fifth-floor Pro Shop yesterday. '' We are sorry Bjorn Borg will not be appearing today,'' it read, and those who had come with cameras and autograph books shrugged, gri maced, accepted free posters and went home.

title: Soviet Grain Snags Seen
description: The United States agricultural attache in Moscow said yesterday that the Soviet grain harvest was drawing to a close in some areas, but that a shortage of trucks to haul grain to the elevators and the poor quality of the harvest were causing concern.

title: Kleindienst Denies Knowing About Illegal Insurance Deal
description: Richard G. Kleindienst insisted in his perjury trial today that he was never aware that a $1.8 million insurance company dividend was handled improperly.

title: Saudis Cling To $32 Price
description: Saudi Arabia hopes to hold its oil price at $32 a barrel until the end of 1982, according to Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi oil minister.

title: Jersey Team Joins M.I.S.L.
description: The New Jersey Rockets were introduced today as the 13th team in the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: A 'NONANNOUNCEMENT' BY A NONCANDIDATE
description: Quite a few names have been mentioned in recent months as contenders for the 1982 Republican nomination for Governor of New York, but yesterday one of the leading possible candidates, Sol Wachtler, took himself out of the running.

title: Griffey to Test Value
description: Ken Griffey says he has made a definite decision to become a free agent after the season rather than sign another contract with the Cincinnati Reds. ''It's nothing personal,'' said Griffey, a 31-yearold outfielder who has a .307 batting average this year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TIMER

title: More Time on Itel Debt
description: The Itel Corporation said today that a Federal bankruptcy court had approved its request to extend by 60 days its deadline for filing a plan to restructure $1.3 billion of debt.

title: PIANIST: FRANCES WALKER
description: FRANCES WALKER took on a program of heroically scaled piano music on Sunday night in Carnegie Recital Hall. The first half of the program was devoted to the young Brahms - his ''Hungarian'' Variations (Op. 21, No. 2), Ballade in B minor (Op. 10, No. 4) and Sonata in F minor (Op. 5) - a tall order for any pianist, considering the fistfuls of notes crammed into these dense scores.

title: DETROIT'S MILLION-DOLLAR POLICE HELPER
description: Car 10XR was patrolling an area of Detroit heavily infested by narcotics when the call came in. A man had been seen hiding a bag believed to contain narcotics behind a bush. Car 10XR was closest to the scene. Bobby Butkines, Car 10XR's driver, is a traffic enforcement officer with the 10th Precinct of the Detroit Police Department. He responds to all accidents, and of cours e to any officer-in-tr ouble runs.

title: Cunningham Returns
description: Help is on the way for the New England Patriots, who have been outrushed, 469-260, in their losses to Baltimore and Philadelphia. Sam (Bam) Cunningham, the 230-pound fullback who sat out all of last year and the first two games this year in a salary dispute, signed a contract yesterday that will reportedly pay him $450,000 for two years.

title: SWAN IS READY TO TRY AGAIN
description: It was barely two hours before the first pitch in St. Louis, where the Mets were playing the Cardinals Sunday afternoon, and the rain was pouring down. Rube Walker, the Met pitching coach for almost 14 years, stood beneath the shelter of the dugout. In such periods, a coach has time to contemplate, make evaluations and decisions, which Walker was doing.

title: DOGS TO PATROL SUBWAY YARDS
description: Mayor Koch, declaring that New Yorkers were ''fed up'' with graffiti on the subways, announced yesterday that German shepherds would patrol the subway yards, where most spray-can vandalism takes place.

title: Text of the statement, page A6.
description: The State Department today produced what it described as ''significant, although preliminary'' evidence to support charges that toxic chemical weapons have been used in Southeast Asia and possibly Afghanistan, in violation of international agreements banning their use.

title: Boston Symphony Gets A $1 Million Bequest
description: The Boston Symphony Orchestra has received a bequest of $1 million, the largest in its 100-year history, to set up an endowment for the music director's chair.

title: FOOTHILL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
150 YEARS OF TECHNOLOGY: FASTEST TRAIN AND OLDEST SET TO ROLL
description: PARIS AT 6:15 A.M. on Sept. 27, a sleek, low-slung orange-colored passenger train will glide swiftly out of the Gare de Lyon here and head down a clear track toward Lyons, 300 miles to the south.

title: BEGIN PROCLAIMS A NEW U.S.-ISRAELI ERA
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, nearing the end of his first visit to the United States since the Reagan Administration took office, said yesterday that his talks with the President about strategic cooperation had inaugurated a new stage in relations between the countries.

title: THE ROUGH EDGE OF COUNCILMANIC POLITICS
description: To the Editor:

title: CHICAGO IS CHILLY TO SOUTH AFRICANS
description: Chicago officials gave the South African national rugby team, the Springboks, a chilly reception after the team's arrival here today at dawn. The City Council unanimously passed a resolution, sponsored by Mayor Jane M. Byrne, ''condemning'' the South Africans' intent to play in Chicago.

title: VENEZUELA STRIVES TO END SLUMP
description: The oil is still flowing to foreign customers and billions of dollars are still rolling in. But Venezuela's economy is in a serious slump.

title: Yorktown Observance Set
description: At a White House ceremony today, President Reagan signed a proclamation designating Oct. 19 for the observance of the 200th anniversary of the surrender of Lord Cornwallis and his British troops to Gen. George Washington at Yorktown, Va.

title: New President Chosen At Cadillac Fairview
description: At the Cadillac Fairview Corporation, North America's largest publicly owned real estate developer, Bernard I. Ghert, 42, has been elected president and chief operating officer. He succeeds Neil R. Wood, 50, who resigned after seven years as president ''to pursue real estate development for his own account.'' John H. Daniels, 54, continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the Torontobased company. Its principal shareholders are Charles and Edgar Bronfman of the Seagram empire.

title: HARD LUCK RUNNER
description: Bad luck continues to plague Jaime Covington's football career at Syracuse University.

title: JUDGE DISMISSES IRAN'S MOVE FOR SHAH'S NEW YORK ASSETS
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed Iran's suit to get the New York assets of the late Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi and his widow and $56.5 billion in damages.

title: 'PROTEGES' TO PERFORM AT WHITE HOUSE
description: Nancy Reagan announced today that the White House would be the setting for four televised performances on PBS by young American musicians, singers and dancers who will be introduced by established stars, who will also perform.

title: NAVY MAY GIVE SUBMARINE PACT TO GROTON YARD
description: The Navy said today that it was willing to negotiate with an antagonist, the Electric Boat Company, to build the ninth Trident submarine.

title: THREE STABBED AT ATTICA
description: About 1,900 inmates at the Attica Correctional Facility were confined to their cells after a fight today left three prisoners with minor knife wounds.

title: EDUCATION
description: those in urban settings - that have special problems of their own.

title: U.N. ASSEMBLY RESOLUTION ON THE ISSUE OF NAMIBIA
description: Following is the text of the resolution on Namibia approved today by the General Assembly:

title: GENERAL INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: 1980 figures were restated to reflect a 3-for-1 stock split in July 1981

title: Letter: On Decontrolling Fuel
description: Don't Tie Up Natural Gas Prices To the Editor: Your Aug. 31 editorial, ''Natural Gas, Unnatural Cost,'' failed to consider several important points. The nation's dependence on foreign oil will be reduced if our alternative fuels are developed at prices which are competitive with the artificially high prices set by OPEC. Natural gas could be such an alternative.

title: Hurricane Might Pose A Threat To Bermuda
description: Hurricane Harvey, with winds up to 130 miles per hour, appeared to be headed today toward Bermuda, although it posed no immediate threat to land, forecasters said.

title: TWO TALES, ONE TALL
description: Last week, according to Israeli newspapers, Israel's Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, used a personal anecdote to help underscore Israel's security problems to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: 2 PLANNED TOWNS FLOURISH IN LAISSEZ-FAIRE TEXAS
description: They are as different in some ways as their names and settings hint: The Woodlands, a ''new town'' carved out of the dense pine forests just north of here, and Las Colinas (The Hills), created out of whole cloth on the mesquite-covered prairie outside Dallas.

title: CITY DROPS PROPOSAL TO CHARGE BRIDGE TOLLS
description: Mayor Koch, hailing the decision by the Reagan Administration to uphold New York's clean-air plan, said yesterday that there was now no need to place tolls on the bridges across the East River and Harlem River.

title: International Controls in Talks
description: The International Controls Corporation, a Fort Lauderdale, Fla., company that was once headed by Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, announced that it had been approached by and was currently holding merger discussions with an unnamed company listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SADAT SAYS SOVIET URGED HIS FOES ON
description: President Anwar el-Sadat said tonight that a dozen of the 1,536 people he had arrested in recent days would be charged with ''conniving'' with the Soviet Union to undermine his regime.

title: MONDALE, IN THE WINGS, RELISHES 'RE-EDUCATION'
description: Walter F. Mondale has already made one important decision about 1984, says a close friend and adviser: ''He's not going to be out there fighting it out with Ted Kennedy to be King of the 60's.''

title: ULSTER'S DEMOCRACY DIES HARD, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: SELIGMAN & LATZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Frazier-LeDoux Bout Seen
description: Joe Frazier, who has not fought in five years, is expected to sign a contract to fight Scott LeDoux, a man who is ''a little disappointed'' that the 37-year-old former heavyweight champion is making a comeback.

title: THER APISTS CHOOSING THERAPISTS: WHAT THEY LOOK FOR
description: What does a psychotherapist look for in choosing a therapist for himself? Dr. Henry Grunebaum, a Harvard Medical School psychiatrist, asked 23 psychotherapists how they had chosen their own therapists. ''If psychotherapists learn anything from their years of experience,'' he reasoned, ''it may be how to select a therapist.'' Among the most important factors for the respondents, who included psychologists, psychiatrists, psychoanalysts and social workers, was the therapist's reputation for competence. They relied on the recommendations of friends and colleagues and knew their potential therapist's reputation in the professional community, Dr. Grunebaum reports.

title: U.N. Conference Ends W ithout Schedule on Aid
description: A plan to increase aid from developed to developing nations was worked out during a two-week United Nations conference that ended here today, but no timetable for the increase was announced.

title: 2 Die in Crash of Band's Bus
description: A drummer in the band of Freddy Fender, the country singer, and another man were killed today in a collision, the police said. The victims were Joseph Lambert, 39 years old, the drummer, and Joseph Parker, 45, the driver of the band's bus. The two were killed when the bus and a tractor-trailer collided, the police said. Mr. Fender was not aboard the bus.

title: Alberta Gas Joins In Methanol Plant
description: Alberta Natural Gas Company Ltd. said it and two other unidentified companies had filed for Alberta regulatory approval to build a $600 million (Canadian currency) methanol petrochemicals plant near Scotford, Alberta.

title: HOUSE PANEL RESISTS BID TO ERODE ITS BUDGET POWER
description: ''We're not eunuchs yet, but we've lost a lot,'' said Representative Silvio O. Conte, a Massachusetts Republican, the ranking minority member of a committee that, more than any other, has been circumvented by the new Congressional budget process.''They really have done a job on us. We've gone far enough.''

title: LINCOLN CENTER HOME TO ANOTHER ORCHESTRA
description: It has an Asian-born conductor, its president is a woman, and it is a resident orchestra at Lincoln Center. So it must be the New York Philharmonic, right?

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-No shr earnings due to preferred stock divd requirements

title: 2 More Banks Set 20% Prime
description: The Crocker National Bank in San Francisco, the nation's 12thlargest commercial bank, and UMB Bank and Trust of New York lowered their prime lending rates yesterday to 20 percent from 20 1/2 percent, joining three other leading banks that made the move in the la st two weeks.

title: Fire in Tanker in Oregon Yard Kills One Welder and Injures 2
description: Fire erupted tonight in an empty oil tanker undergoing repairs here, killing a welder and injuring two others, officials said.

title: A THUMB IN OUR EYE
description: The City Council apparently thinks it was not enough to have insulted the voters by producing a deeply flawed, politically cynical, racially imbalanced redistricting plan.

title: Salvadoran Army Begins Drive Against Rebels
description: Army troops have begun ''search and destroy'' missions against guerrillas in 8 of El Salvador's 14 provinces, military spokesmen said today.

title: CHI-CHI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes a $74,000 nonrecurring tax benefit

title: No Headline
description: Saudi Arabia strongly objects to a military cooperation pact between Israel and the United States because it threatens peace in the Middle East, the official Saudi press agency said today.

title: SCIENTIFIC LEASING INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
16 ARE INJURED DURING A CLASH BETWEEN BLACK AND HISPANIC INMATES AT
description: RIKERS ISLAND By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

title: Auto Dealers Cut Inventories
description: New-car dealers reduced their domestic inventory by almost 200,000 units during August, the trade publication, Automotive News, reported today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt SAVING GRACE. By Celia Gittelson. 229 pages. Knopf. $10.95.

title: CORRECTION
description: The obituary of William Loeb that appeared yesterday failed to list a surviving daughter, Penelope K. Loeb of Amenia, N.Y. Miss Loeb's mother, the former Eleanore McAllister, was Mr. Loeb's second wife.

title: OIL COMPANIES REDUCE INVENTORIES
description: As the winter heating season approaches, soaring interest rates are forcing the world's oil companies to reduce crude oil inventories because they are too costly to maintain during a period of weakening demand.

title: FOOD IS STAKE IN SOMALIA'S REFUGEE NUMBERS GAME
description: There are 15,000 people here - or 68,000. The higher figure is the official estimate of the Somali Government, the lower was provided by some of those running this refugee camp.

title: Schaefer and Piel's Transfered to MCA
description: MCA Advertising, that fast-growing shop with the new approach to agency structure, has now won the Schaefer and Piel's beer accounts from the Stroh Brewery Company, Stroh confirmed yesterday afternoon.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: I T is as if fashionable New Yorkers had done nothing all summer but wait for Labor Day to be over so they could go out at night wearing cashmere again. Despite an unexpected downpour last Tuesday night, they appeared by the hundreds at a party the Zoli model agency gave at the Ritz to celebrate a new film called ''Model,'' directed by Frederick Wiseman, which is supposed to be about modeling but is really about Zoli. But the models' collective appearance at the party supported a suspicion that either they do not know how to dress or they are too sick of clothes to care. They wore Jordache and ankle straps and expected the film to be shown. It wasn't. But it will be tomorrow at 8 P.M. Channel 13.

title: PLANS MOVE AHEAD FOR CRITICAL TESTING OF SPACE SHUTTLE
description: Kennedy Space Center officials went through final preparations today for a critical tanking test and simulated launching of the space shuttle Columbia. The shuttle is scheduled to be launched for the second time on Oct. 9.

title: ROYAL PALM BEACH COLONY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TENOR AT MET OPERA IN THE 30'S, IS DEAD
description: Sydney Rayner, a tenor at the Metropolitan Opera in the 1930's, died yesterday at his home at East Patchogue, L.I. He was 86 years old.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 15 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Thirty-sixth session opens at 3 P.M.

title: Red Sox Defeat Tigers
description: Jerry Remy hit a two-run, bases-loaded single that broke a 2-2 tie in the sixth inning and led the Boston Red Sox to a 5-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight.

title: NEWPORT PHARMACEUTICALS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July
TV: 2 PROGRAMS ON WCBS LOOK INTO THE FUTURE
description: TELEVISION'S eagerness to cash in on the popularity of sciencefiction movies is reflected, almost shamelessly, in two new magazine formats this evening. One, being syndicated locally on WCBS-TV, is ''Omni,'' an offshoot of the magazine bearing the same name. The other, a pilot for a possible series on the CBS-TV network, is ''The Future: What's Next?'' a look to 2000.

title: WHY STOP AT A TRIAD?
description: The argument that the United States must preserve its triad of strategic nuclear forces is bogus. It is bogus because it only concerns what weapons we possess, not what they must achieve. The real issues are, What is the objective of the triad, and does it take a mix of three strategic-weapons systems to achieve it? How about two? Or maybe four?

title: ULSTER'S DEMOCRACY DIES HARD, TOO
description: To the Editor:

title: Book of Tuchman Essays
description: Barbara W. Tuchman, two-time winner of the Pulitzer Prize in history - for ''The Guns of August'' in 1962 and ''Stilwell and the American Experience in China'' in 1971 - will describe her techniques and interests in ''Practicing History,'' a collection of essays to be published Sept. 30 by Alfred A. Knopf. In the book, she writes that narrative is the ''life-blood of history,'' giving illustrations from her own books and articles over the last 35 years. They include her writings from Spain in the 1930's to modern Israel.

title: Nippon British Venture
description: The Nippon Electric Company said today that it would begin marketing small business computers in Britain next month. The company declined to disclose its sales projections. It said that about 50,000 such computers were now being used in Britain and that the market was expected to grow by 25 to 30 percent annually.

title: Canadian Pride Is Dented
description: Today was not a good day to talk hockey with a Canadian. The hangover of last night's 8-1 trouncing by the Soviet Union in the Canada Cup championship game would not disappear easily, not after all the pregame talk by followers of Canada. They had been confident that the best of the nation's players could beat the Soviet national team. The tournament had been billed as one that would settle the qu estion of world supremacy in the sport that Canada considers its ow n. It was supposed to make up for past embarrassments, such as the on e of two years ago, when two Soviet teams outplayed some of the topcl ubs in the National Hockey League; or the one of five years ago, wh en not only the Russians but also the Czechoslovaks outperformed th e Canadians in the first Canada Cup; or the embarrassments of all th ose world championships and Olympic games the Canadians never won.

title: STANDARD LOGIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
PERKINS IS BUOYED BY GIANTS' DEFENSE
description: Ray Perkins of the Giants, like most other coach es, has a philosophy for every occasion, and today hefound one to explain the Giants' 17-7 victory over the Redskins at Washington ye sterday.

title: HAIG EXHORTS WEST ON U.S. ARMS STAND
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that he believed the protests against his visit to West Berlin yesterday demonstrated that Western leaders had to be ''more aggressive'' in explaining the reasons the West must seek a military balance with the Soviet Union.

title: Minor Quake Hits Caribbean
description: A minor earthquake shook Puerto Rico and the Dominican Republic at 8:45 A.M. today. There were no reports of damage or injury from the tremor, with its center in Mona Passage between Mona Island and the Dominican Republic, 100 miles west-southwest of here. The quake measured 5.6 on the Richter Scale.

title: MICHAELS ANGERED BY LOSS
description: His words were slurred and his sentences rambling today after he had stayed up most of the night looking at films of yesterday's loss, but Coach Walt Michaels made it clear: He held himself blameless for the latest Jet defeat.

title: NEW POST FOR JOYCE
description: Joseph F. Joyce Jr., president of Arlington Park and senior vice president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, which owns the Chicago track, has resigned both positions effective before the end of the year. Joyce will then join the General Instrument Corporation as vice president and general manager of the Amtote Systems Division, a company involved in manufacturing of equipment for offtrack and lottery wagering. Joyce was the counsel to the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation in 1971 and later its executive vice president.

title: Contact Lens Approved
description: The Dow Corning Corporation has received the approval of the Food and Drug Administration to market the first silicone-based contact lens for extended wear by cataract patients. The approval came just two months after Dow Corning was given permission to sell such lenses for daily use, capping a research and development struggle that took more than a decade.

title: Nashville Schools Open After a 3-Week Delay
description: School opened for 67,000 pupils today after being d elayed for three weeks by conflicting court orders on desegregation .

title: TEXT OF U.S. STATEMENT ON POISONOUS CHEMICALS
description: Following is the text of a statement by Walter J. Stoessel Jr., Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, on the reported use of poisonous chemicals in Southeast Asia:

title: TOXIN IS CALLED A PILLAR OF SOVIET ARSENAL
description: A book to be published this fall singles out trichothecene toxin - the chemical said to have been found on foliage on the Thai-Cambodian border - as a pillar of the Soviet chemical warfare arsenal and a probable ingredient of ''yellow rain,'' which reportedly was sprayed from aircraft, killing thousands of Meo people in Laos.

title: DOW DOWN 6.66, ENDING RALLY
description: Renewed concern over the size of the Federal budget deficit sent stock prices lower yesterday, ending a brisk three-session rally. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 6.66 points, to 866.15, after having advanced 21 points in the final three days of last week.

title: No Headline
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. made a new attempt today to convince the public in Western Europe that the Reagan Administration is committed to arms reduction and consultation with its allies.

title: A FANNIE MAE 'SPECIAL SECURITY'
description: Banks and savings and loan associations will be able to take the deposits resulting from their new taxexempt savings certificates and reinvest the money in securities offered by the Federal National Mortgage Association, an association official said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: Less-developed countries have demanded that the Soviet Union set aside 0.7 percent of its gross national product to aid the third world, not 7 percent, the figure given in Elizabeth K. Valkenier's article ''A New Soviet Mood,'' on Sunday's page.

title: STOCKHOLM DEVALUES CROWN TO AID ECONOMY
description: Sweden devalued its currency by 10 percent today and presented a tough economic package to revive the flagging economy. The crown was last devalued in August 1977.

title: VISITING EDUCATORS POSE SOME TOUGH QUESTIONS
description: A visiting delegation of Nigerian educators was being welcomed yesterday morning by New York City school officials, all of whom had prepared polite remarks on the administration of the public school system. The Nigerians, however, wanted to - and did -ask questions.

title: Niece of Byrd Charged
description: Federal prosecutors today charged a niece of the Senate minority leader, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, with embezzling more than $12,000 from the Senate post office, where she was chief clerk until told to resign Sept. 1. Barbara Bowman, 44 years old, of Fairfax, Va., was charged with theft of Government property and covering up her embezzlement by replacing some of the funds before an audit by the General Accounting Office.

title: RCA's New Head Of Entertainment
description: The RCA Corporation has consolidated its entertainment operations, except for the National Broadcasting Company, into one group and has named Herbert S. Schlosser to head the new division. Mr. Schlosser, 55 years old, is an RCA executive vice president.

title: L.I. Faculty Accepts Pact
description: Faculty members at Dowling College in Oakdale ratified a two-year contract tonight and ended their twoweek strike.

title: MORE GUNS MEAN WAR ON CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: The Economy
description: President Reagan's planned cuts in arms spending are too small to relieve the financial markets' fears that his economic program will be inflationary, Wall Street economists said. (Page A1.) Two Cabinetrank officials, Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, sought to persuade the Federal Reserve to let the money supply grow a little faster, easing interest rates. (A1.)

title: Ilford Inc. to Creamer From Warner, Bicking
description: Creamer announced yesterday that it had won the account of Ilford Inc., the United States marketing arm of the Ilford Group of London, a manufacturer of black and white film and photographic chemicals that is a subsidiary of Ciba-Geigy.

title: REAGAN NAMES AMTRAK CRITIC AND 6 OTHERS TO INTERIM UNIT
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis, who has spoken out strongly in favor of slashing Amtrak operations, has become a new interim member of the National Railroad Passenger Corporation's 13-member board, along with six other officials of the Department of Transportation.

title: Citicorp Sharply Cuts Power of Its Treasurer
description: Donald S. Howard, executive vice president, chief financial officer and treasurer of Citicorp, has been stripped of much of his power, a spokesman for the nation's largest bank holding company confirmed yesterday. Within the banking industry, Mr. Howard is known as one of the most innovative and aggressive treasurers.

title: Japan's Trade Balance Rises
description: Japan posted a $739 million trade surplus on a customs clearance basis in August, bringing the January-August trade balance to $3 billion in the black, the Finance Ministry reported today.

title: S.& P. Lowers B raniff Rating
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation, a major debt-rating service, said it had lowered the ratings on Braniff Airways' long-term de bt obligations because of the airline's recent p oor financial performance.

title: Coffee Surplus in Kenya
description: Kenya has a coffee surplus of more than one million bags and has exhausted its export quota allocated by the International Coffee Organization, a spokesman for the Coffee Board of Kenya said today.

title: Q & A
description: Q. A baby giant panda born in captivity in Mexico was crushed by its much larger mother. Why are newborn pandas so small?

title: UNDERSTANDING EUROPE'S NERVES
description: To the Editor:

title: YANKS ROUT CALDWELL, DEFEAT BREWERS BY 10-2
description: His continued success against the Yankees, Mike Caldwell was saying before tonight's game, gives him more confidence each time he encounters them. On the other hand, the pitcher said, ''They know I've beaten them so they probably try harder.''

title: WALTER (FURRY) LEWIS
description: Walter (Furry) Lewis, a blues guitarist who helped W.C. Handy make Beale Street and the Memphis Blues a legend, died at City of Memphis Hospital today.

title: COAST NUCLEAR PROTESTERS PLAN ACTION TODAY
description: Leaders of an estimated 2,000 protesters encamped here in preparation for a demonstration against the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant said today that they would begin their attempt to blockade the reactor tomorrow.

title: MORGAN GRENFELL'S AMBITIONS
description: In the dark, wood-paneled partners' room of Morgan Grenfell & Company, it would seem that little has changed since the firm took over the gray stone headquarters in 1924.

title: SWANTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FARMER BROS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''They're going to have a hard job getting further cuts in 1982.

title: Sports of The Times; Fewer Officials, More Disputes
description: FIFTY weeks is too long to wait for another United States Open. If there were a button to press, I would start another glorious festival this morning at Flushing Meadows: the crowds streaming in from the boardwalk, players from all over the world, fresh croissants and roasted coffee and seven varieties of championship topspin on a side court.

title: ASPIRANTS IN JERSEY COVET SENATOR WILLIAM'S JOB
description: While voters in New Jersey will elect a Governor this year, much of the talk among politicians concerns the United States Senate seat that Harrison A. Williams Jr. is fighting to hold after his conviction in the Government's undercover investigation into political corruption.

title: Harvester Layoffs
description: The International Harvester Company said it would lay off 400 production and clerical workers here on Friday as part of a national retrenchment effort announced last week.

title: Air Force Says Officer Was Wrong on Immunity
description: Air Force prosecutors said today that ''a series of misunderstandings and mistakes'' led Second Lieut.

title: LOOKING BACK AT NINEVEH: THE NATURE OF ANGER AND OF PENITENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: To End the Anarchy at Sea
description: It is not immoral, illegal or fattening for the United States to defend free navigation on the high seas. In fact, in the view of the World Court, the failure to challenge a disputed maritime right can amount to forfeiting it. As Representative Bill Green points out, it's a case of use it or lose it. Without a clearer international law, some confrontations, like those with Libya in recent months, may well be necessary. But that is surely a peculiar and dangerous way to deal with nettlesome international quarrels. A better way is in sight.

title: WHITE HOUSE EASES EFFORT TO REDUCE FARMER SUBSIDIES
description: As the Senate began debate on a new farm bill, the Reagan Administration agreed today to a compromise that could raise farm price supports at least $4.1 billion above the President's projected budget over the next four years.

title: PATRICK PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
IMMIGRATION CASE TAKING ODD TWIST
description: Ernest J. Hupp, an Immigration Court judge, has trouble maintaining a cool, judicial demeanor when he is reminded of the two Federal agents who followed him in a black automobile last May 22, so intimidating him, he said later, that he withdrew from a deportation case he was hearing.

title: RUSSIANS VIE FOR 'LUXURIES' AS PRICES RISE
description: After buying up all the gasoline, vodka and jewelry they could lay their hands on, Soviet citizens officially learned today what they had know n for days - prices for th ose and other ''nonessentials'' are about to go through another ro und of steep increases.

title: Steel Output Down
description: Steel production fell 1.7 percent last week, to 2.24 million tons, from the previous week's 2.28 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: TRIPLE CHECK INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After a cumulative effect of an accounting change of $57,694; the 1980 figures were restated

title: MOSCOW SAYS TOXIN CHARGE MADE BY HAIG WAS A 'BIG LIE'
description: The Soviet Union today described as a ''big lie'' the allegation in a West Berlin speech yesterday by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. that the Soviet Union has been supplying poisonous chemicals for use in warfare in Afghanistan, Cambodia and Laos.

title: News Analysis
description: Judicial intervention in New York City primary elections is more of a tradition than a rarity. The Democratic and Republican regular party organizations often use the state courts to, in effect, call off local district primaries by eliminating the opposition. What makes last week's decision postponing the primary unusual is th at it was made by a Federal court and that it represented a turn of the legal tables. ''The outs'' - minorities, insurgents an d civic groups - successfully used the Federal court against the p olitical establishment - the city's Board of Elections, the Corporati on Counsel, the City Council and, ultimately, the two major politic al parties.

title: IRAN REPORTS 44 HAVE REGISTERED FOR PRESIDENTIAL RACE NEXT MONTH
description: Iran announced today that 44 people had registered to run for the presidency in a special election Oct. 2, among them the leader of the dominant Islamic Republican Party.

title: Merrill Lynch Unit Pays Canada Fine
description: The Investment Dealers Association of Canada said that Merrill Lynch Royal Securities Ltd., a unit of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., had agreed to pay a $250,000 (Canadian currency) fine to settle charges that its Calgary, Alberta, office did not adequately supervise trading in shares of Brent Petroleum Industries Ltd.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Abbott Laboratgries, Chicago, has elected Laurence R. Lee senior vice president, administration; Lael F. Johnson vice president and general counsel; John C. Kane corporate vice president, chemical and agricultural products, and James G. Andress corporate vice president, planning and development.

title: BUDGET PROBLEM: WHO GETS THE BLAME?
description: It may not sweep the country, but the newest phrase heard at the White House is ''reality therapy.'' An aide to President Reagan observed ruefully the other day that the Administration was getting an unpleasant dose of it this month.

title: I.T.T. HOLDS RAYONIE SALES TALKS
description: Preliminary talks are under way for the sale of ITT Rayonier Inc., a leading forest products company, the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday. There were indications that Rayonier's assets could be worth $2 billion or more.

title: LABOR LEADERS JOIN TEACHERS AT PHILADELPHIA RALLY
description: Labor leaders representing police officers, firefighters, air controllers and other workers joined striking Philadelphia teachers today in a rally aimed at mobilizing public support to stop officials from breaking a school contract signed after a three-week walkout a year ago.

title: Advertising
description: THE management of the Southland Corporation in Dallas confirmed yesterday that its new ad agency for its 7-Eleven stores would be Young & Rubicam, America's largest.

title: AMEX TO EXPAND FLOOR BY 35%
description: The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of governors had approved a $6.98 million construction project to expand its trading floor capacity by 35 percent.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: JAY SOMMER had his first taste of teaching in 1945 in a displaced persons camp in Italy. He would see little children wandering about aimlessly without going to school, and so he gathered them together to tell them stories. Casting about for a place to meet in bad weather, he found a war-damaged room with one of its four walls blown out. Young Sommer, then 18, rebuilt the missing wall, thereby sufficiently embarrassing the camp officials, who had ignored the children's educational needs, to proclaim the room a school. Since Mr. Sommer's schooling had ended with fourth grade, he was deemed fit only to teach gymnastics.

title: Iron Shipments Increase
description: Great Lakes iron ore shipment tonnage increased by 36 percent in August over shipments in August 1980, the American Iron Ore Association said today. The association reported August shipments at 10.7 million tons, compared with 7.93 million tons a year ago. Shipments from January through August from 11 United States and Canadian ports totaled 50.2 million tons, compared with 44.7 million tons during the first eight months of 1980, the association said.

title: Brain Surgery for Infant Delayed by Oregon Court
description: The Oregon Court of Appeals said today that the state could order brain surgery for a 15-month-old girl despite her parents' religious objections, but the state Supreme Court stayed the order for two days while it decides whether to hear the parents' appeal.

title: House, 386-16, Votes Memorial to Dr. King
description: On a vote of 386 to 16, the House today approved and sent to the Senate a resolution authorizing a memorial in th e Capitol to the Rev. Dr. Marti n Luther King Jr.

title: U.T.C. Enters Data Field
description: The United Technologies Corporation, a Hartford-based conglomerate that is one of the nation's biggest defense contractors, announced its entry into the telecommunications field with the introduction of a telephone system that simultaneously transmits voice and data signals.

title: DR PEPPER TO ACQUIRE CANADA DRY
description: The Dr Pepper Company has agreed in principle to acquire the business and most of the assets of Norton Simon Inc.'s Canada Dry subsidiary, the two companies announced late yesterday.

title: WHEN A CHEF FEEDS HIS COOKS
description: One recent afternoon, in the quiet time between the end of lunch and the beginning of dinner, 13 men sat down at a long table in the pale green Art Deco dining room of the G. Lombardi restaurant in Little Italy for a meal consisting of a salad of mussels, squid, shrimp, flaked codfish and black and green olives dressed with olive oil and lemon, a pasta with pesto and a main course of veal, chicken and mushrooms in Marsala.

title: ROCK: NO LONGER 'DEVIL'S MUSIC'?
description: WHEN rock-and-roll enjoyed its initial surge of popularity in the mid-50's, many fundamentalist Christians recoiled in horror. To them, rock's ''savage rhythms,'' and the thinly concealed sexual double entendre of many rock-and-roll lyrics, made it ''the Devil's music.'' A number of churches encouraged their younger members to participate in record burnings, in which quantities of rock-and-roll disks were dutifully tossed into bonfires. Many of the earliest rock-and-roll performers were raised in fundamentalist environments, and they reacted to Christian attacks on rock-and-roll in a variet y of ways.

title: Savings Unit Has to Merge
description: The Government today took another savings and loan association off its list of troubled financial institutions, forcing it to merge with a stronger partner to form the largest thrift institution in South Dakota.

title: Leafs' Owner Is Fed Up
description: The start of the National Hockey League season is three weeks away, but Harold Ballard, the Toronto Maple Leafs' owner, has already threatened to trade everyone.

title: A DISSENTER'S VIEW OF CALIFORNIA WINES
description: I used to be among those who were constantly trying to write something perceptive and flattering about California wines. ''The California miracle...30 years ago an industry in ruins...up from the ashes of Prohibition...new wineries every week...better and better...more and more'' - not original, but heartfelt.

title: T.W.A. Sets $69 Fare to Florida
description: Trans World Airlines lowered its weekday New York-to-Florida fare to $69, matching the fare announced last week by Air Florida in the latest round of a fare war on the busy North-South route.

title: Dow Declines by 7.80, to 858.35
description: Takeover situations produced price swings for selected stocks yesterday, while the general market continued to retreat amid worries over the size of the Federal budget deficit.

title: AIRLINES' BID TO WIDEN FARE AUTHORITY DENIED
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board by a vote of 3 to 2 rejected today a request by the airlines for greater latitude in raising fares without C.A.B. approval.

title: Cleveland Councilman Shot
description: Councilman Lonnie L. Burten, who represents the city's impoverished 12th Ward, was shot three times in the right leg on the porch of his home today, apparently by a distraught job-seeker.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Special Request

title: Artist in Residence
description: President Reagan habitually doodles through Cabinet and staff meetings. He favors a felt- tip pen and often gives his signed work - reminiscent of movie stars of the 1940's and comicstrip characters such as Maggie and Jigg s and Dick Tracy - to Cabinet members.

title: Midsize Renault Production Begun
description: Renault, France's state-owned auto maker, began production of its R-9 model in Europe and said it expected worldwide production to reach 2,000 cars a day.

title: SUAVE IRAQI AT U.N. HELM
description: Ismat Kittani, a sophisticated practitioner of the convoluted diplomacy at the United Nations, grew up as a barefoot boy in a Kurdish mountain village in western Iraq. He never saw an electric light until he was 12 and recalls that he was awed by his visits as a youth to Baghdad.

title: WILL THEY REMEMBER THE JOAN CRAWFORD ERA?
description: HOLLYWOOD EARLY in June, Paramount realized it would have an unexpected problem marketing one of its fall movies. ''We had been slightly deceiving ourselves for a year in assuming there were more moviegoers familiar with Joan Crawford than was the case,'' said Paramount's marketing vice president, Laurence Mark. ''Mommie De arest'' - a portrait of the late movie star as a childabuser t aken from a book written by her daughter, Christina - will open Fri day in New York and nationally on Sept. 25. According toMr. Mark, it was Life magazine that disabused the studio of the idea that the publ ic was eagerly waiting for a film on the private life ofone of the gr eat movie queens of the 30's.

title: PROSECUTION RESTS IN PEOPLE'S TEMPLE GUYANA PLOT
description: Larry Layton, the former People's Temple member accused of helping to plan and carry out the murder of Representative Leo J. Ryan and the wounding of an American diplomat, calculatedly passed himself off as a defector from the cult in an attempt to get close enough to shoot Mr. Ryan, the prosecution maintained today in final arguments.

title: CASTOFFS PLAY KEY ROLE IN RAIDERS' VICTORY OVER THE VIKINGS
description: Odis McKinney and Burgess Owens, who played on several losing teams in New York, are now the regular safeties for the league champions, the Oakland Raiders, and they exemplify the harvest the Raiders reap from players other teams give away or reject.

title: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan, after threatening to veto an appropriations bill, won a key House test vote. (Page A1.) He also scored a victory over the dairy lobby when the Senate adopted his plan for lowering milk price supports. (A25.) Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige acknowledged implicitly that the economy was likely to be weaker nextyear than the Administration forecast two months ago. (D1.)

title: Capote Collapses
description: Truman Capote, the author, who has been plagued by ill health all summer, collapsed yesterday and was taken by ambulance to New York Hospital. Late yesterday, he was listed in stable and satisfactory condition.

title: Addendum
description: * Borman/Williams Inc., a new public relations company at 222 Park Avenue South.

title: EXECUTIVES BACK BACHE CANADA ROLE
description: Top executives of the Bache Group Inc. and its 100 percent owner, the Prudential Insurance Company of America, urged today at a hearing before the Ontario Securities Commission that Bache's wholly owned Canadian subsidiary be allowed to continue as a registered securities dealer in Ontario.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average price of feeding a family of four dipped slightly in the two-week period that ended Monday. The market basket was down 3 cents to $106.04, according to the Department of Consumer Affairs. But shoppers paid $5.77 more for food than during the corresponding period last year.

title: Suzy and Red vs. the Graffiti Painters
description: A friend reports that a recent ride through Manhattan on an E train was unusually pleasant. The air-conditioning rendered a comfortable chill and only a faint trace of graffiti could be seen on the walls of the freshly scrubbed car. Encouraging news, yes, but also a sad reminder of the extent to which the mobile spray-painted horror shows of graffiti ''artists'' demoralize straphangers.

title: AIR FORCE CHIEF STAFF SAYS U.S. CAN AFFORD SPENDING FOR MILITARY
description: Gen. Lew Allen Jr., the Air Force Chief of Staff, said today that the United States ''can afford the expense of defense'' and warned against ''false economies'' in the military budget.

title: Bush, In Mexico, Meets Lopez Portillo
description: Vice President Bush held private talks with President Jose Lopez Portillo here today shortly after he arrived to attend celebrations marking the 171st anniversary of Mexican independence.

title: THE PLEASURES AND PRACTICALITIES OF STUFFED FOODS
description: WHILE dipping my fork recently into a fancy filling for stuffed striped bass, it occurred to me that after exploring the world of food for more than three decades I had never stopped to seriously consider the subject of stuffed foods. To my knowledge, a stuffed foods cookbook does not exist. In fact, I have rarely seen so much as a cookbook that has ''stuffed foods'' as an index category, except in a limited sense.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Grand Banks Energy Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an initial offering of 500,00 shares, underwritten by a Wheat First Securities group.

title: Piersall's Season Over
description: Jimmy Piersall, the Chicago White Sox broadcaster who was suspended indefinitely last week for a flippant remark about players' wives, will not be reinstated for the rest of the season.

title: G.T.E. CHOOSES HEAD FOR PHONE OPERATIONS
description: At the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, the telephone operating group is the largest of its major units and the one responsible for more than 60 percent of its income. But until now, the highest-ranking officer of the group held the title of executive vice president.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Agency Rent-A-Car Inc. said it had increased its stake in Spencer Companies to 659,255 shares, or 38.5 percent, through the acquisition of 39,900 shares bought on the American Stock Exchange between Sept. 2 and Sept. 9 at prices ranging from 14 5/8 to 15 1/2 a share.

title: GULF OIL APPOINTS NEW TOP EXECUTIVE
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation elected Edward B. Walker 3d, 59 years old, president and chief operating officer effective Dec. 1. He will succeed James E. Lee, 59, who had already been named as the successor to Jerry McAfee, when he retires as chairman and chief executive officer at age 65. In addition, Harold H. Hammer, 61, who, like Mr. Walker, is a Gulf executive vice president, will also become chief administrative officer of the Pittsburgh-based corporation, the world's seventh-largest oil company.

title: BANKS CUT PRIME TO 20% REFLECTING LOWER COSTS
description: Businesses across the country received a bi t of relief from high interest rates yesterday as scores of banks l owered their prime lending rates half a percentage point, to 20 percent. The reduction reflected a sharp decline in what banks must pay for their own funds,giving them leeway for further reductions in the interest rates they charge their customers.

title: End of Line for Collins?
description: Doug Collins, plagued by injuries since the Philadelphia 76ers made him their first choice in the 1973 college draft, tore ligaments in his right knee Monday while practicing at the University of Pennsylvania. The injury, which will require surgery, is expected to end his eight-season career.

title: LIGHTNING HITS A NUCLEAR PLANT, BUT IT'S JUST FOR PRACTICE
description: Schools close to the plant were being closed, farmers were advised to take their cattle and livestock inside and school buses were dispatched to assist with a general evacuation. A mock general emergency had just been declared at Unit No. 1 of the Nine Mile Point nuclear station, seven miles northeast of Oswego.

title: NUCLEAR PROTESTERS FAIL TO BLOCKADE PLANT ON COAST
description: About 200 opponents of nuc lear power crossed a barbed wire fence at the main gate of the Diablo Canyon nuclea r power plant today, and 100 others scaled the perimeterfence at othe r places around the plant.

title: MEGADATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After credits of $24,000 in qr and $259,000 in the 9 mos

title: 3 BROADWAY PLAYS TO BE OFFERED IN SUBSCRIPTION
description: In a novel marketing scheme, three new Broadway plays are going to be offered to the public as a discounted subscription series. This kind of sales approach is a common one for nonprofit theaters in New York, but is unusual for the commercial Broadway theater.

title: NEW YORK SCHOOL LUNCH SUIT IS SETTLED
description: A settlement has been been reached in a three-year-old class action suit brought by Consumers Union in an effort to force the City of New York to improve the nutritional quality of its school lunch program. In light of the Reagan Administration's recent proposals to lower the requirements for the national school lunch program and the improvements already made in the city's program, however, the settlement may be moot.

title: Advertising; Agency Promotions Abound
description: THERE was a lot of promotional activity yesterday at SSC&B in New York and Campbell-Mithun in Minneapolis. That's promotion of people, by the way, not of sales.

title: AMETEK'S RESEARCH INTO SOLAR ENERGY BEGINS TO PAY OFF
description: On the table was a portable nine-volt radio, about the size of a thick novel. It had no batteries or electric plugs to run it, only a thin film photovoltaic cell. When a cover was lifted, exposing the cell to the light in the room, the radio began to play.

title: PANEL APPROVES JUDGE O'CONNOR
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved the nomination of Sandra Day O'Connor as an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court. Confirmation by the full Senate could come as soon as Friday.

title: E.E.C. Sets Fabric Duty
description: The European Economic Community today announced a definitive antidumping duty on imports of textured polyester fabric from the United States.

title: COMPARISON SHOPPING: WHAT'S THE VALUE OF IT?
description: IS comparison shopping for groceries really worthwhile? The answer is yes - if you have strong arches, patience to spare, a love of detail and unlimited time. It also helps if you live in a metropolitan area where you have the luxury of shopping at several stores without adding to the cost of food every time you turn on a car's ignition.

title: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I've often wondered why nobody ever mentions the obvious, simple way to butter corn on the cob. You simply take a small piece of bread and butter it - then butter your ear of corn with the buttered piece of bread - using it something like a paintbrush. So much for Emily Post. This method of buttering corn was taught to me by my grandmother, and if any readers of The Times can come up with a more satisfactory solution to the problem, I'd like to know what it is.  WILLIAM J. LAUBENSTEIN
description: Hoboken, N.J.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Nothing does as much for a room as a bouquet of flowers. But live flowers are expensive and have short lives, while fake ones are too obvious. A happy medium is a bouquet of dry flowers. Excellent ones are to be found in a very attractive new shop called Galerie Felix Flower tucked into the architecturally interesting building that was formerly the Engineers Club. The shop's arrangements are made of real flowers, but they have been dried in a special way to retain their colors and are arranged without the usual foam plastic base. The flower-drying and arranging technique was worked out by Felix Blume, who owns similar shops in Hamburg and Dusseldorf in Germany. Mr. Blume trained Madi Heller in the craft and now Miss Heller sells arrangements in the shop's white ceramic vases or will custom make a bouquet in a customer's own vase or basket. Bouquets range from $35 to $120, plus $14 to $28 for the vase. The shop also sells unusual wreaths made of at 32 West 40th Street, Suite 3B, telephone is 944-7327. It is open Monday through Thursday, from noon to 6 P.M.

title: JOHN BULL BALKS AT CEREMONY
description: The Smithsonian lovingly prepared the world's oldest working locomotive for a ride today on its 150th anniversary, but the little engine refused to budge when the moment came.

title: Reagan Orders U.S. Agencies To Aid Black College Efforts
description: President Reagan today signed an executive order directing the Government to help black colleges and universities obtain equal opportunities in federally sponsored programs.

title: RAMPART GENERAL INC reports earnings for Yr to Mar 31
GOLDWATER VOWS TO FIGHT TACTICS OF 'NEW RIGHT'
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, accused Moral Majority and other members of the ''new right'' today of undermining the basic American principle of separation of church and state by using the ''muscle of religion towards political ends.''

title: ELSINORE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results for the latest periods include a loss $1.9 million attributed to start-up costs at the Playboy Hotel & Casino in Atlantic City and other expansion programs

title: STUDY DISCERNS DESEGREGATION BENEFIT
description: Desegregation of schools has had positive effects for all children, especially for minority students, and has improved educational opportunity, the director of a federally financed study on how to make it more effective declared in New York yesterday.

title: NUGGET OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Council Acts to Push Students' Registering
description: The City Council yesterday passed by a 43-to-0 vote a bill that requires the Board of Education and private schools to provide voter registration forms to eligible students.

title: Rail Rate Rise Sought
description: The nation's railroads are seeking a 1.4 percent rate increase, effective Oct. 1, on most joint-line traffic, an Interstate Commerce Commission spokesman said today. The proposed increase is based on a quarterly forecast that the Association of American Railroads submitted to the I.C.C. The agency's spokesman said it would announce a decision on whether to permit the increase later this week.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ENGLISH VERSION OF THE POPE'S ENCYCLICAL 'ON HUMAN WORK'
description: Following are excerpts from the official English version of the encyclical of Pope John Paul II ''On Human Work'':

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Interest Rates Drop Slightly By MICHAEL QUINT

title: Chicago Schools Boycotted
description: Black and white parents kept their children out of school for a second day today to protest the integration o f two South Side elementary schools located just nine blocks apart. Only 133 of the 942 pupils enrolled reported at the predominantly black Hendricks Elementary School and at the predominantly white Graham Elementary School.

title: THE GUN CLUB MARRIES PUNK ROCK TO THE BLUES
description: MOST of the American musical idioms that preceded and shaped rockand-roll were regarded ''the Devil's music'' at one time or another - especially the blues. Early blues lyrics are rife with satires on preachers, who are depicted as hypocrites with their minds on adultery and financial gain, and often the most uncompromising blues have suggested their own pragmatic value system as an alternative to Christian values.

title: Transactions;
description: COLLEGE

title: Market Place; Utility Stresses Tax Benefits
description: FIVE years ago, the Citizens Utilities Company won the right to recapitalize on a tax-sheltered basis. That is, the dividends of only one of the two new classes of common stock were subject to income taxes.

title: VERNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WILLIAM E. BERCHTOLD EX-ADVERTISING AIDE AND AVIATION EDITOR
description: William E. Berchtold, former senior vice president and chairman of the plans review board of the McCann-Erickson Inc. advertising agency, died of cancer Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old.

title: DONALD BARTHELME'S COMPLEX WORLD
description: IN one of Donald Barthelme's earliest stories the narrator says: ''I am free associating, brilliantly, brilliantly, to put you into the problem. Or for fear of boring you: which?''

title: NEW U.S.-ISRAELI STEP MAY ISOLATE ARAB ALLIES
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to join with Israel in a ''strategic collaboration'' appears likely from official and editorial comment to increase polarization within the Arab world, provide a rallying point for Soviet interests and isolate America's allies, particularly Saudi Arabia.

title: MIAMI TO HOLD 23-DAY ARTS FESTIVAL
description: A $4.7 million 23-day arts festival with 30 world premieres, including new plays by Edward Albee and Tennessee Williams, a new opera by Robert Ward and Daniel Lang and new music and dance works, is being planned for June in Miami.

title: DIVERSIFIED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $210,000 for the qr and $510,000 for the 9 mos; the 9 mos net includes income of $3,455,000 from settlement of claims...C-After an extraordin tax loss carryforward credit of $1,346,000 for the qr and $3,600,000 for the 9 mos

title: No Waiting
description: Two top high school basketball prospects, before starting their senior seasons, have decided where they will go to college and have removed their names from the recruiting lists of college coaches and scouts. Jim Dolan, a 6-foot-8-inch forward at St. Joseph's in Toms River, N.J., who averaged 27.2 points, 14 rebounds and six assists last season, will attend Notre Dame.

title: Economic Scene; The Pressure On the Fed
description: THE Secretary of the Treasury, Donald T. Regan, and the chairman of the Council of Ecomomic Advisers, Murray L. Weidenbaum, have both begun to suggest in their public orations that the Fed might make the money supply grow a bit faster, even if Wall Street takes fright.

title: Conagra Net Up 13.2%
description: Conagra Inc., a diversified agricultural products company, said today that it earned a record $7.7 million, or 60 cents a share, in the first fiscal quarter, a 13.2 percent increase from the $6.8 million, or 57 cents a share, earned in the first fiscal quarter a year ago. The company said sales rose 70.8 percent, to $520.1 million, from $304.4 million. Charles M. Harper, president and chief executive officer, said Banquet Foods and Singleton Foods, acquired in the second half of the fiscal year 1981, accounted for much of the first-quarter sales increase and were significant contributors to earnings.

title: DANIEL GILMARTIN, LABOR LEADER, DIES
description: Daniel Gilmartin, former president of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, died yesterday at his retirement home in Venice, Fla., after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

title: LAWERNCE J. WASHINGTON, 67, HEAD OF N.A.A.C.P IN DETROIT
description: Lawrence J. Washington, President of the Detroit branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, died yesterday after suffering an apparent heart attack.

title: A DISPUTED COUNCIL DISTRICT WONDERS WHY
description: Jean Powell was just standing there, waiting for her husband to pull the car around in front of their house so they could return the rented carpet shampooer, when she got the word.

title: Greek Cabinet Modified To Prepare for Elections
description: The Greek Cabinet today formally submitted its resignation and was then immediately given a mandate to form a slightly modified Cabinet to conduct next month's elections.

title: Polish Union Seeks Right To Propose Legislation
description: Leaders of Solidarity are seeking the right to initiate legislation in the Polish Parliament, the independent union's Warsaw branch said today.

title: SEDCO INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $9.2 million... C-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $318,000 and a gain from the disposal of discontinued operations of $4.6 million

title: HARTFORD BANK TIE OPPOSED
description: The largest stockholder in the Hartford National Corporation, parent company of the Hartford National Bank, sent a letter today to the 8,000 other shareholders urging them not to approve a merger with the Connecticut National Bank.

title: TAIWAN DENOUNCES OVERTURES BY PEKING FOR TALKS
description: Taiwan today denounced as a ''trick'' Peking's latest overtures for talks and its plans to celebrate on Oct. 10 the 70th anniversary of the overthrow of the Manchu dynasty and founding of the Republic of China by Sun Yat-sen.

title: ''You can get anything you want at Alices Restaurant.'' - Arlo Guthrie.
description: You can't get anything you want at Zhang Shuqin's restaurant. Jiaozi, in fact, is the only dish on the blackboard menu that hangs above the four tables for customers opposite an ancient mastadon of an American refrigerator that serves as conversation piece and beercooler.

title: Agent Says 6 Nazis Planned 'Week of Terror'
description: A Federal undercover agent testified today that six avowed Nazis on trial for conspiracy to commit terrorist acts planned to blow up parts of Greensboro, N.C., in ''a week of terror.''

title: COOK UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 15
Mobs in Mexico Burn Buses To Protest Increases in Fares
description: Rioters angry over unauthorized bus fare increases burned eight buses and damaged about 70 in an uprising that left one person dead and an estimated 500 injured, the police said today.

title: Higher Debt Ce iling Cleared
description: The Senate Finance Committee today approved the Administration's request to raise the Government's borrowing authority to $1,079 billion through the next 12 1/2 months.

title: CHINAGLIA IS M.V.P. IN LEAGUE
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, who has led the North American Soccer League in scoring in four of his six seasons, today was named the league's most valuable player for the first time.

title: Washington; FORGOTTEN QUESTIONS
description: In recent days President Reagan has been concentrating on economic problems at home, military problems with the Russians and strategic problems in Europe and the Middle East.

title: YANKS DEFEATED BY BREWERS, 2-1
description: The Yankees, who keep playing games that have little significance, including tonight's 2-1 loss to the Milwaukee Brewers, also keep losing players who have great significance.

title: REAGAN VICTORIOUS ON MILK SUBSIDIES
description: President Reagan scored a solid victory over the politically powerful dairy lobby today when the Senate adopted the Administration's plan for lowering the level of milk price supports paid to farmers.

title: T.W.U. VOTES A DELAY IN RAISES IN AN EFFORT TO SAVE CONRAIL JOBS
description: As part of an agreement designed to save thousands of jobs, Conrail employees in the Transport Workers Union have voted to accept deferrals of wage increases over the next three years, union leaders announced yesterday.

title: MILITARY FEARS LOSS OF FLIGHT CONTROLLERS TAKING CIVILIAN JOBS
description: The military may lose a significant number of its air traffic controllers to higher-paying civi lian jobs created by th e Government's dismissal of almost 12,000 striking controllers.

title: MacNeil and Lehrer Will Share Journalism Award
description: For the first time in its 33 years, the William Allen White Foundation Award for Journalistic Merit will be shared. The award is to be presented to Robert MacNeil and Jim Lehrer, co-anchormen of the Public Broadcasting Service program ''The MacNeil/Lehrer Report,'' on Feb. 10 at the University of Kansas, in Lawrence.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GOLDWATER REMARKS
description: Following are excerpts from remarks inserted into the Congressional Record today by Senator Barry Goldwater:

title: BALDRIGE FORECASTS LONGER LAG
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige, implicitly acknowledging that the economy is li kely to be weaker in 1982 than the Administration predicted just two months ago, said today that '' any real pickup'' would not occur until summer.

title: CAREY BACKS CANCELING DISPUTED RUGBY MATCH
description: Governor Carey said today that he hoped a rugby match here next week involving a South African team would be canceled and that he was seeking to discover ''what I can do under the police powers available to me'' about the match.

title: KILLEARN PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After a tax credit of $81,300...C-After a tax credit of $162,000

title: NOW Order Narrows Use
description: A Federal judge today nullified regulations that would have allowed all private nonprofit groups and government organizations to own interest-bearing checking accounts in savings and loan associations.

title: Senator Moynihan Gets a Challenger for 1982
description: The campaign for the 1982 New York Senate election got an early start yesterday when Bruce F. Caputo, a 38-year-old former United States Representative, announced that he was a candidate for the Republican nomination to oppose the incumbent, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat.

title: DE BEERS: THE LUSTER FAD ES
description: These are tough times at De Beers, the world's largest marketer of diamonds. With the industry in the midst of a severe slump, the company appears hard-pressed to convince consumers of its claim that diamonds are, indeed, forever.

title: 12 COURTS SHUT IN MANHATTAN BY TEMPORARY JUROR SHORTAGE
description: A severe shortage of trial jurors forced the closing of 12 courtrooms in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday, causing the postponement of criminal trials and leaving judges and courtroom staffs idle.

title: Tonight, the Showdown for the Most
description: It finally happens tomorrow night. Sugar Ray Leonard and Thomas Hearns will meet in a 20-foot ring built atop a tennis court across the road from the desert. The words will stop and the punches will begin.

title: Libya Buys 10 Airbuses
description: Libya's state airline has signed a contract to buy 10 wide-bodied European A310 Airbus jets, the official Libyan press agency, Jana, reported from Tripoli today. It did not give the value of the purchase, but the planes, which are manufactured by the European consortium Airbus Industrie, typically cost $35 million each with spare parts. Jana said the first two airliners would be delivered in June 1982, with the rest to follow at the rate of two a year over five years.

title: DELTA QUEEN STEAMBOAT CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FILIPINOS OPEN CAMPAIGN FOR PRESS FREEDOM
description: A movement for freedom of the press has been started here to honor a woman who resigned her editorial job two months ago because of Government pressure.

title: UNIVERSAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $8,911 in the qr and for the 9 mos a loss from discontinued operations of $27,744 and a tax loss carryforward of $5,179

title: Dizzy Gillespie Featured In WNET-TV Portrait
description: The trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie and how he wrote the jazz classic ''A Night in Tunisia'' are the subject of a 30-minute television documentary to be broadcast on WNET-TV, Channel 13, tomorrow at 10:30 P.M.

title: ENVOY OF MOSCOW EXPELLED BY EGYPT
description: President Anwar el-Sadat today expelled the Soviet Ambassador and six members of his staff, two Soviet journalists and more than a thousand Soviet technicians working on projects throughout the country.

title: FREQUENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Shrs and shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Sept 26, 1980 and a 2-for-1 stock split effective Apr 13, 1981

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard ON THE STROLL. By Alix Kates Shulman. 301 pages. Knopf. $12.95.

title: N.F.L. Asks Court to Restrict Cable TV
description: The National Football League, contending that the basic structure of pro football was at stake, asked the Supreme Court today to restrict cable telecasts of games.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: Senator Thurmond and the Witnesses

title: FIRST CONTINENTAL REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT T reports earnings for Qtr to Aug
News Summary; WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 16, 1981
description: International The Pakistani Government has accepted a six-year $3.2 billion military and economic aid package offered by the United States after the Reagan Administration found a way to speed up delivery of F-16 fighter planes. The announcement of the agreement came on the eve of a hearing to consider the Administration's arguments for ending a ban on aid to Pakistan even though Pakistan has refused to rule out developing the ability to produce nuclear devices. (Page A1, Column 1.) An assassination attempt in Germany that was aimed at Gen. Frederick J. Kroesen, t he United States Army's European commander, failed with the general a nd his wife escaping with only minor cuts. Terrorists believed to b e member of the Red Army faction fired an antitank grenade and g unshots into the General's automobile. It was the fourthattack on Ame rican personnel and installations in West Germany in three weeks. (A1:2.)

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: BEFORE the advent of nouvelle cuisine a decade and more ago, the French kitchen thrived on legends that had to do with various dishes, and one of the most popular - and one of the most repeated - of these legends had to do with chicken Marengo. It is worth recounting because this is an excellent and tasty dish that is easily made within an hour.

title: 5 LODGES: A MAGNET FOR V.I.P.'S
description: Francis S.M. Hodsoll, the Presidential assistant who is in line to become chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, took his wife and daughter to Virginia's Shenandoah National Park for a four-day vacation over the Labor Day weekend. They walked in the mountains, paused by the Rapidan River, slept in a lodge with one of the most breathtaking views of the Blue Ridge and paid $208.

title: MONTANA PESTICIDE SPRAYING PERILS WATERFOWL HUNTING IN 17 STATES
description: High levels of an acutely toxic pesticide, sprayed on 200,000 acres of wheat land in eastern Montana, have been found in several species of game birds and, a Federal official said today, may cause hunting seasons in 17 states to be canceled becaus e of the risk to humans who mi ght eat the affected birds.

title: BRIEFING
description: S TRATEGISTS at the Democratic National Committee, trying to look beyond the endless issue of the troubled economy, have concluded that the Reagan Administration may soon attempt to revive the politicians' evergreen: the issue of crime in the streets.

title: PROFESSIONAL RANGES
description: When home cooks get serious they start to cast covetous eyes on their neighbors' professional ranges. The restaurant range they usually buy, when they do decide to splurge, is a Garland. When I set up my own kitchen several years ago, I chose a Wolf instead.

title: C.P.A. Ethics Amendment
description: Abrasive forms of solicitation by accountan ts would be banned underan amendment to the C.P.A.'s code of ethics t hat has been proposed by a special committee of the American Instit ute of Certified Public Accountants.

title: Less Messy Corn
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: William Cole's description of eating corn on the cob made me grin (''Of Table Manners, Bad Habits, Food,'' Sept. 2).

title: By Sports of The Times; Is Sugar Ray a Gladiator?
description: SOME boxers have the soul of a gladiator. Put them in the Colosseum in ancient Rome with a lion and they would never even ask how much money they were getting. Joe Frazier was like that when he was the heavyweight champion. So was Roberto Duran until he walked out of the ring in New Orleans last year. So is George Chuvalo, the Canadian heavyweight who was born 2,000 years too late. The night in 1972 when George Chuvalo lost a 12

title: Soviet Culture, in Exile
description: No Moscow Book Fair is complete without one clumsy instance of censorship and one episode calculated to show the Soviet system at its worst. In those terms the third fair, which ended last week, was a success: Henry Kissinger's memoirs were removed from a display rack, and during the festivities a leading Soviet writer, Anatoly Marchenko, was sentenced to 10 years in prison and 5 in exile.

title: Talking About Illness
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I read, with great interest, Leonard Probst's article on his social experiences as a result of being a cancer patient (''Best Medicine During Recovery: Friends,'' Sept. 9).

title: TEMPLETON RETURNS TO CARDS, HAS 4 HITS
description: Garry Templeton, r eturning to the St. Louis lineup for the first time since he was suspended Aug. 26 for making obscene gestures at fans, had four hit s to lead the Cardinals to a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Expos in t he first game of a doubleheader tonight.

title: Arco to Spend $27.6 Billion
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said it will spend $27.6 billion on capital projects between 1982 and 1986, mostly for exploration and development of domestic energy sources.

title: News Analysis
description: The encyclical letter that Pope John Paul II issued yesterday on the subject of work and human dignity is the Pope's third major statement relating Roman Catholic doctrine to modern problems.

title: U.S. JUDGE RENEWS RESTRAINT ON OUSTER OF STRIKE BACKERS
description: A Federal district judge today renewed a temporary restraining order prohibiting the Federal Aviation Administration from dismissing employees who voice support for striking air tr affic controllers.

title: Real Estate; A Standard Property Contract
description: SOMEWHERE in Manhattan an apartment building is being sold for more than $20 million and a lawyer is smiling. The lawyer is Edward B. Schoen of Robinson Silverman Pearce Aronsohn & Berman, whose firm represents the buyer. The sales contract that the seller's lawyer brought around for the buyer to sign was none other than the new standard-form document that Mr. Schoen helped a subcommittee of the Bar Association of the City of New York draft.

title: U.S. CHARGES 7 IN CHECK THEFTS FROM MAILBAGS
description: Seven suspects were charged yesterday with systematically stealing bags of mail, which contained more than $3 million in negotiable checks, from the lobbies of Manhattan office buildings in the last three years.

title: 39 Indicted in Virginia In Food Stamp Inquiry
description: A six-month Federal investigation into illegal food stamp trafficking in southeastern Virginia culminated today in the indictment and arrest of 39 persons.

title: ORBIT INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
No Higher Bid By Occidental
description: Armand Hammer, chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, said that Occidental had ''no intention'' of increasing its $36-ashare stock offer to buy the Zapata Corporation, a Houston oil services company. Zapata shares fell in heavy trading by $3.625 a share, to $30, on the news.

title: Spain Says Drug Trade Rises
description: Spain's Attorney General, Jose Maria Gil-Albert, said today that drug trafficking in the country had ''increased to very high levels'' last year. In his annual report to Spanish judges, the Attorney General said the narcotics police had seized about 11 tons of marijuana, 128 pounds of cocaine, 13 pounds of heroin and 14,868 doses of LSD. He said 9, 176 people had been charged with drug possession or trafficking a nd that 30 had died fromdrug overdoses.

title: Universities Due $10 Million In a Novel Plan for Research
description: Stanford University and the University of California will get $10 million to finance genetic engineering and biotechnology research over four years in a novel arrangement with a new concern, Engenics Inc.

title: PAPERS INCREASE CAPITAL COVERAGE
description: In a town of people who are compulsive about knowing the news, the demise of The Washington Star last month left addicts gasping. Now, others are moving in to meet their need.
