title: THE EDUCATION OF A GENTLE GIANT
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli-Egyptian Talks On Links Near an End
description: Israeli and Egyptian representatives today ''practically completed their deliberations'' on the technical arrangments for tourism, communication, civil aviation and transportation links between the two countries, according to Zvi Kedar, an Israeli delegation spokesman who is director of the Foreign Ministry's Egyptian Division.

title: PAKISTAN AGREES TO A U.S. AID PLAN AND F-16 DELIVERY
description: Pakistan announced today that it had formally agreed to a six-year, $3.2 billion military and economic aid package offered by the United States. The agreement came after the Reagan Administration had worked out a plan to speed delivery of F-16 fighter planes that Pakistan is to purchase in a separate deal.

title: AI DES' MEMO CAST LIGHT ON REAGAN-CARTER BATTLE
description: In the 1980 Presidential campaign, both major candidates were told privately that the voters faced a choice between an incumbent they did not like and a challenger they feared.

title: Q & A
description: Q. A question about Nesselrode, a fish-baked-in-pastry creation, was recently answered here. Now a friend asks if a pudding called Nesselrode, which he recalls eating as a youngster, has the same origin?

title: TAX RATE CUTS VS. INFLATION
description: In just two weeks and a day, the much-heralded cuts in income tax rates begin. Tax advisers caution, however, that people should not expect to see big reductions in their tax bills after the cuts are phased in from Oct. 1, 1981, to July 1, 1983. ''We're not really cutting taxes for most people - we're simply preventing their taxes from going higher,'' said Leon M. Nad, a partner at the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse & Company.

title: CONAGRA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
Licenses Urged For Waste Haulers
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The state should begin licensing and investigating solid-waste hauling companies to eliminate organized crime's control of large sectors of the industry, Attorney General James R. Zazzali said. Mr. Zazzali told a special legislative subcommitee that stricter regulation of the industry was needed to restore competition and lower hauling costs.

title: A Female-Jockey Race Awarded in California
description: The Women's Jockey Association, after threatening to shut down the track, said today that it had been awarded a race with only female jockeys at the Expo Meet Sept. 24. A spokesman said it would be the first such professional race with parimutuel wagering held in the state.

title: REAGAN THREATENS TO USE VETO IN BID FOR SPENDING CUTS
description: President Reagan, increasing his pressure on Congress to cut spending below the ceilings it imposed earlier this year, today issued his first threat to veto an appropriation bill. A key test vote in the House of Representatives immediately demonstrated that he probably had the power to make good on his threat.

title: MRS. THATCHER WILL HOLD RAISES TO 4%
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher moved decisively today to reinforce the hard-line direction of her day-old Cabinet shuffle by announcing that pay increases for Government workers would be held to 4 percent next year, a sharp reduction from this year's levels.

title: Xerox to Offer Desk-Top Copier
description: The Xerox Corporation said it was introducing a low-priced desk-top reduction copier, the Xerox 2350, into the United States market.

title: IRAQI IS PRESIDENT OF U.N. ASSEMBLY
description: Ismat Kittani of Iraq became President of the United Nations 36th General Assembly today through an unusual election that was decided by lot.

title: Jersey Gas Leak
description: A cloud of hydrogen bromide - a caustic and potentially lethal gas - escaped from a ruptured quarter-inch tube in a chemical factory here, forcing about 100 people to leave the pl ant and the area around it for two hours, officials said.

title: SUN CITY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Unions do not have the character of political parties struggling for power; they should not be subjected to the decision of political parties or have too close links with them.'' - Pope John Paul II. (D26:4.)

title: Carey Appoints Commission on Overseas Trips
description: Still confronting criticism that the Greek and Irish Governments had helped pay for his belated honeymoon, Governor Carey defended his actions again yesterday, but said he would appoint a commission to determine the appropriate allocation of travel expenses for future overseas trips.

title: AN F.A.A. MISTAKE
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has been quietly circulating among the airlines its air-traffic interim operations plan for reducing air traffic in order to maintain safety with fewer air-traffic controllers.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: NURSING homes have been the subject of considerable public scandal and private agonizing in recent years as their number has vastly increased in response to reimbursement by Medicare and Medicaid. Those Federal and state programs have made nursing-home care a possibility for growing numbers of ailing Americans, mostly the aged, who can no longer care for themselves or be cared for at home. Well over a million Americans, 90 percent of them over age 65, are residents of nursing homes.

title: FRENCH JOB STIMULUS IS OUTLINED
description: The Mitterrand Government opened a major campaign today to deal with what it calls its most crucial objective: reducing unemployment.

title: 2 PREMIERES AT MANHATTAN THEATER CLUB
description: The Manhattan Theater Club will open its 10th anniversary season Oct. 20 with two New York premieres. ''Crossing Niagara'' by Alo nso Alegria, former director of the Peruvian Nati onal Theater, will open the five-play series in the club's Downstage Theater.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Bridge: Shades of '65 Crisis Return To Haunt British Captain
description: An old, cold controversy generated new heat last week when a player accused of cheating 16 years ago was barred by the World Bridge Federation from acting as a nonplaying captain in the world championship, scheduled to begin in Port Chester, N.Y., on Oct. 20.

title: SAL CABLE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Excerpts from encyclical, page D26.
description: Pope John Paul II declared today, in the third encyclical of his pontificate, that labor unions were ''an indispensable element'' of modern industrialized society and a vehicle ''for the struggle for social justice.''

title: CULT IN CASTLE TROUBLING MONTCLAIR
description: A guru from India wheels into town in a Rolls-Royce, buys the biggest house in the community - a castle, actually - and places an advertisement in Time magazine preaching spirituality through sex.

title: WHEN PATIENTS WANT TO LOOK AT THEIR MEDICAL RECORDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Subway Sneaker Ad Is Assailed by Cuomo
description: Offended by what he thinks are the negative racial stereotypes presented in a subway advertising campaign for Pro-Keds sneakers, Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday asked the Transit Authority to remove the advertisements from New York City subways.

title: Index; International
description: South Africa displays captured Soviet arms A2 Begin's visit ends with airport meeting with Haig A3 Around the World A5 Islamic Party is said to back clergyman in Iran's elections A6 Iraqi becomes U.N. Assembly President after drawing of lots A9 Move to curb U.S. funds for Unesco is planned A9 Taiwan denounces overtures by Peking for talks A14 Government/Politics F.C.C. head seeks repeal of rules on airing issues A21 Thornburgh seeks budgets cuts and layoffs in Pennsylvania A24 Military facing loss of its air traffic controllers A28 Order prohibits dismissals of air controllers' supporters A28 Carey urges cancellation of a controversial rugby match B2 Strategists' memos cast light on Reagan-Carter race B7 House votes across-the-board pay rise for military B8 Air Force Chief of Staff say U.S. can bear military spending B8 Washington Talk Long feuds and short memories A10 Rustic retreats are bargain for Washington's political elite A10 Briefing A10 Required Reading A10 General Around the Nation A16 Nuclear protesters frustrated in California A16 Prosecution presents its closing statements in Layton trial A17 Local and distant newspapers increase coverage of Washington A21 Mock emergency tests responses at Oswego, N.Y., nuclear plant B2 30 world-class runners entered in first Fifth Avenue Mile B3 Living Section Food Comparison shopping: What's the value of it? C1

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Going to Lengths for a Real Haydn Sound For a couple of pieces on the Haydn-Stavinsky program at Alice Tully Hall last night and tonight, Charles Wadsworth, artistic director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, and Kenneth Cooper, the guest keyboard artist, needed a very special instrument.

title: ISLAMIC PARTY IS SAID TO BACK CLERGYMAN IN IRAN'S ELECTIONS
description: Iran's dominant Islamic Republican Party has reportedly endorsed the clergyman that leads it as its candidate for the presidency in next month's elections.

title: 30 OF WORLD'S TOP MILERS ENTER FIRST 5TH AVE. RACE
description: Fifth Avenue, renowned for its elegant shops and such public spectacles as the Easter Parade, will soon be the site of a new event involving some of the world's greatest runners - the Fifth Avenue Mile.

title: SETTLEMENT IS REACHED IN COSTLY CONSTRUCTION STRIKE IN ILLINOIS
description: Contractors and the union representing heavy equipment operators reached a tentative agreement today on resolving an eight-week-old labor dispute that has been characterized as one of the region's most costly and violent strikes in recent years.

title: Coaches Hard to Get
description: Richard Keenan, a physical education teacher, and Jame s O'Neil, a teacher of so cial studies, have sued in Superior Court in Morristown,N.J., against the Hanover Park (N.J.) Regional District Board of Education. Th ey are contesting their selection as assistant football coaches at Wh ippany Park High School without their consent.

title: CENVILL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: 1980 figures were restated

title: BORMAN'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 15
description: B-Includes loss from sale of discontinued operations of $1,194,000 for the qr and $2,485,000 for the 28 week period and a gain on disposal of those operations of $2,045,000 for the qr and 28 weeks...C-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $163,000 for the qr and $484,190 for the 28 weeks

title: Careers; Typing Skill Still Crucial
description: ''I TURNED down an M.B.A for a job in my department because he could not type,'' Lynn Holley said. She is director of university relations at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., the nation's oldest engineering and technical school, where she heads a group of 12 persons, including seven writers.

title: COLLINS & AIKMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of New York has named Gerard P. Dougherty, Brian P. Reilly and Robert J. Wolf vice presidents.

title: Doctors Disagree On Suspect's Death
description: A coroner's jury learned today that pathologists disagreed over what caused the death of a young black man who died while in police custody last July.

title: CLUE TO BREACHING THE AIR CONTROLLER IMPASSE
description: To the Editor:

title: DISHING IT OUT
description: News item: A group of open-handed millionaires has given the Reagans $822,641 to redecorate the White House, and Mrs. Reagan has just spent $209,508 of it to buy dishes.

title: GOING OUT GUIDERETURN TO GO
description: It is easy to get the impression that the Riverside Dance Festival is a nonstop year-round event, but it is really not so. The festival, at the Theater of the Riverside Church, West 120th Street and Riverside Drive (864-2929), has, since 1978, run for six to nine months under the direction of David K. Manion, but it does knock off for summertime.

title: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 UP BY 9.5%
description: The nation's Big Three auto makers said today that sales of their new passenger cars rose 9.5 percent in the first 10 days of September compared with the same period last year, when sales were unusually weak.

title: A SHEA & GOULD LAW PARTNER
description: Leonard M. Wallstein Jr., a partner in the law firm of Shea & Gould and a former assistant New York City corporation counsel, died yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. He was 71 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: The Fairness Doctrine A Subject at Seminar
description: Yesterday morning, when Stephen Sharp, general counsel of the Federal Communications Commission, noted that the F.C.C. would ask Congress to eliminate the fairness doctrine as part of its legislative recommendations, his seminar audience at the Grand Hyatt Hotel broke into applause.

title: SOVIET HINTS AT TOUGH STANCE IN TALKS NEXT WEEK
description: The Sovie t Union, offering a long review of its perspecti ves on arms issues, indicated today that it was likely to adopt a to ugh stance when Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.and the Sovie t Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, meet in New York next week for the first top-level talks since the Reagan Administratio n took office.

title: RANGERS TO GET ANSWERS SOON
description: After three days in isolation at a sylvan training camp, Coach Herb Brooks and the first, uncut version of the 1981-82 Rangers arrived in Helsinki today, aching to play five exhibition games in the next eight days.

title: MAYOR YOUNG AN EASY VICTOR OVER 10 IN PRIMARY IN DETROIT
description: To no one's surprise, Mayor Coleman A. Young easily took f irst place in the city's mayoral primary today, putting him in Novemb er's general election and a step closer to a third fouryear term .

title: Let Them Eat Price Supports
description: With interest rates near record highs, the bond market catatonic and budget deficits looming, no Federal programs are immune from further cuts. No programs, that is, save those that protect the income of farmers.

title: TALK WITH HAIG ENDS BEGIN'S U.S. VISIT
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin and Secretary of State Alexander M. -81/A/ / /WM Haig Jr. held a last-minute meeting at Kennedy International Airport last evening before the Israeli leader flew home after a 10-day visit to the United States.

title: Jerseyan Admits Killing Officer
description: NEWARK (AP) - A 20-year-old Newark man has pleaded guilty to murder charges in the shooting death of an Essex County sheriff's aide. He will be sentenced on Oct. 21.

title: GENERAL HYDROCARBONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CABLE TV INDUSTRIES reports earnings for QTr to July 31
Landsdowne Wins Duro-Test and Division
description: Landsdowne Advertising, a division of the J. Walter Thompson Company, announced that it had landed the Duro-Test Corporation, formerly with Lawrence Butner Advertising, and its Duro-Lite Lamps, the home-lighting division that was formerly at Albert Frank/FCB.

title: Sibson Flattens Minter In 3d, Keeps His Title
description: Tony Sibson of Britain retained his European middleweight boxing title by knocking out Alan Minter in the third round at Wembley Arena tonight.

title: KIDNA PPERS ASK $10 MILLION, UNAWARE VICTIM WAS FREED
description: The 86-year-old owner of a jewelry store was kidnapped yesterday morning by two men in a car while on his way to a synagogue near his home on the Upper West Side, the police said.

title: MCCORMICK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Yr-ago figures were restated to reflect adoption of the LIFO method of accounting

title: OLD POLICY FEUDS NEVER D IE
description: This is a town with very short institutional memories and very long political memories. The new people shuttling in and out of key jobs in the Pentagon, State Department and National Security Council staff rarely remember what their institutions did before them. The old Washington hands who pass through the turnstiles as Administrations change rarely forget what has been done to them.

title: 2 Deny Slaying 3 Guards in 1979
description: Two men charged with the slaying of three Purolator security guards during a $1.9 million robbery nearly two and a half years ago pleaded not guilty yesterday to three counts of felony murder after a judge ruled out the death penalty.

title: Ashton Choreographing Two Roles for the Met
description: Sir Frederick Ashton, former director of London's Royal Ballet, will choreograph the parts of the Nightingale and the Fisherman in the Metropolitan Opera's production this fall of Stravinsky's ''Le Rossignol.''

title: Southland Up 8 1/4 On News of Merger
description: The Southland Royalty Company, which disclosed on Monday that it was a willing target in what could become an estimated $2 billion takeover, surged 8 1/4 points in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday to close at $34 a share. The Fort Worth-based oil and gas company said it was holding exploratory merger talks with a limited number of companies.

title: Mets to Face Double Jeopardy Tonight
description: As if they didn't have enough trouble, the Mets were rained out of the opening game of a home stand last night and were forced to face the double jeopardy of Steve Carlton and Dick Ruthven of the Philadelphia Phillies in a doubleheader tonight.

title: News Analysis
description: For a time, it seeme d that Social Security legislation had become the political equivale nt of the weather: everyone in Washington was talking about it, but no one seemed bold enough to do something about it by stepping f orward and exercising leadership.

title: MACY, R H, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: The 1981 figures were for 53 weeks compared with 52 weeks in 1980

title: HAYES-ALBION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Heavy Metal Magazine To Increase Advertising
description: Now that there has been a successful ''Heavy Metal'' movie and a successful ''Heavy Metal'' record album, Leonard Mogel, publisher and editor of Heavy Metal magazine, has decided to go after advertising seriously.

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TOWERMARC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After operating losses carryforward of $280,000 in qr and $611,000 for the 9 mos...C-After operating losses carryforward of $64,000 in the qr and $193,000 in the 9 mos the company said included in the third-qr income was the recovery of a prior loan loss of $423,830

title: Quarter Net Up 28.5% at Macy
description: R.H. Macy & Company, one of the nation's leading department store chains, reported yesterday that its net income in the fourth fiscal quarter, which ended Aug. 1, rose 28.5 percent on a sales increase of 16.6 percent.

title: 40 Hurt as Korean Jumbo Jet Veers off a Runway in Manila
description: A Korean Air Lines jumbo jet veered off the runway during takeoff tonight and crashed through a fence at the Manila International Airport, injuring at least 40 people, authorities said.

title: ACCORD ON PRIMARY INCLUDES AT-LARGE CITY COUNCIL SEATS
description: Governor Carey, Mayor Koch and legislative leaders agreed last evening to broaden next week's primary election to include at-large members of the City Council and political party officers unless the United States Justice Department objects. However, the primary would still exclude nominations for 35 district members of the City Council.

title: WHAT TO DO ABOUT VOTE FRUSTRATES CITY COUNCIL
description: The City Council held a regularly scheduled public meeting yesterday and spent 30 minutes conducting the routine business of government. Then the members held a private meeting and spent nearly an hour passionately debating the subject nearest to their hearts - the postponed primaries.

title: VW AND NISSAN AGREE TO BUILD CARS IN JAPAN
description: Volkswagen, West Germany's largest auto maker, today announced an agreement with Nissan Motors of Japan for joint production of 60,000 Volkswagen sedans annually in Japan beginning in October 1983.

title: NBC IN A RARE TV-RATINGS VICTORY
description: TV, its performance bolstered by the Miss America Pageant and a television movie, won the networks' ratings race for the first time since the World Series 47 weeks ago.

title: 2 Million in the State Found Abusing Drugs
description: More than two million people in New York State are abusing drugs and a million more are either mixing drugs or taking them in combination with alcohol, a state official said yesterday.

title: MANHATTAN TRANSIT WITH A PATH KEY To the Editor:     Now that President Reagan's monial presentation of the down payment to New York City indicates that Westway will be a reality, it is no longer necessary to trade off Westway for the M.T.A. We now have an opportunity to have both Westway and improved, expanded rapid transit.
description: To the Editor:

title: CONGRESSMAN PLANS AMENDMENT TO CURB PAYMENTS TO UNESCO
description: A Republican Congressman, running contrary to Reagan Administration policy, intends to introduce on Thursday a measure that would cut off United States funds to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization if the organization takes steps to restrict the world's press.

title: U.S. GENERAL SAFE IN RAID IN GERMANY
description: Terrorists fired an antitank grenade and gunshots today into the automobile of the United States Army's European commander, Gen. Frederick J. Kroesen, but the assassination attempt failed.

title: MODERN DANCE: THE HAWKINS TROUPE RETURNS
description: THE Erick Hawkins Dance Company has not performed in New York City for several years, and this has clearly been New York City's loss. Since the 1950's Mr. Hawkins has pursued a thoroughly independent course that set him apart from other modern-dance innovators. One misses the freshness of his ideas, the very difference between him and others.

title: TV: WISEMAN CAPTURES THE WORLD OF MODELING
description: ENTERING Frederick Wiseman territory is always a special experience. His documentaries, nine of which have been produced for WNET-TV during the last decade, make no concessions to the short attention span and visual gimmicks that are supposed to be the hallmarks of television-watching.

title: CALLED TOO HARSH AND TOO EASY, A PANEL JUDGING JUDGES IS FACING JUDGEMENT
description: Six years after it was established to uproot corrupt and abusive judges, the New York State Commission on Judicial Conduct is being criticized for its tactics, its record and its plans for the future.

title: Profit Margins Up at Factories
description: The Federal Trade Commission reported today that manufacturers' after-tax profits averaged 5.5 cents per dollar of sales in the second quarter of 1981.

title: To the Editor:     While the legal rights of patients to see their medical records are extremely limited, workers are guaranteed access to all medical records held by their employer under regulations promulgated by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA). According to the regulation:
description: * Employees have the right to examine and copy their own medical and/or toxic exposure record held by their employer. Union representatives have access to the records of a particular employee if they have written consent from the employee.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 16, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: General Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: DOCUMENT INDICATES DRYFOOS DIDN'T FILE DATA IN '80 VOTE
description: City Councilman Robert J. Dryfoos failed to file a required financial disclosure report in 1980 when he first ran for his seat, according to documents kept by the City Clerk. Mr. Dryfoos , a Democrat, is seeking re-election from his district on Manhattan' s Upper East Side. The filing question was raised by David A. Gold stein, a former prosecutor who is running against Mr. Dryfoos. Mr. Goldstein also charged that Mr. Dryfoos had failed to register with the state as an attorney, also a legal requirement.

title: Harper & Row
description: Harper & Row Publishers Inc. said it had signed a previously announced definitive agreement to buy all of the 1.02 million shares of its common stock owned by the Minneapolis Star and Tribune Company at $20 a share. The shares represent about one-third of Harper & R ow's common stock outstanding. Harper & Row' s common stock closed yesterday at $11.25 bid, unchanged, in over-t he-counter trading.

title: 2 Named to Public TV
description: President Reagan today appointed R. Kenneth Towery of Austin, Tex., and Sonia Landau of New York to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. Both will serve out vacant terms expiring March 26, 1986. Mr. Towery is president and founder of an Austin business and political-consulting firm. Miss Landau, a public-relations specialist, was on Mr. Reagan's Presidential transition team.

title: OPINIONS AND BETS ABOUND
description: In a town glutted with betting propositions, from the hushed elegance of baccarat slots to the nadir of nickel slots in restrooms, the Sugar Ray Leonard-Thomas Hearns fight for the unified welterweight championship of the world has gained a privileged place in the gaming sun.

title: DON'T HANDICAP OUR FISHING INDUSTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Denies Immunity Deal Was Offered by the Air Force
description: Brig. Gen. Claude Teagarden of the Air Force testified today that he had not offered immunity from prosecution to Second Lieut.

title: Tremor Shakes Naples Area
description: An earth tremor of medium strength today hit the mountain region east of Naples that was devastated by an earthquake last November, the police reported.

title: F.C.C. CHIEF TO SEEK REPEAL OF TWO RULES ON AIRING OF ISSUES
description: Mark S. Fowler, the new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that he was prepared to push for Congressional repeal of rules that require broadcasters to present the other side of controversial issues.

title: Bishops' Leader Urges Speed in Cody Inquiry
description: Archbishop John R. Roach, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, today urged a ''speedy and just resolution'' to allegations that John Cardinal Cody diverted up to $1 million in church funds to Helen Dolan Wilson, a lifelong friend.

title: HOUSE VOTES A RAISE OF 14% FOR MILITARY REGARDLESS OF RANK
description: The House voted today to give all military personnel a 14.3 percent across-the-board pay increase, rejecting a Senate-passed proposal to give larger increases to more experienced enlisted personnel and officers.

title: 5 KILLED AS GAS TRUCK HITS TRAIN IN ALABAMA
description: Five persons were killed today when a gasoline tanker truck struck a freight train in a rainstorm at a busy intersection and exploded, engulfing four automobiles in flames, the authorities said.

title: THORNBURGH OUTLINES BUDGET CUTS AND LAYOFF PLAN IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: Gov. Dick Thornburgh today proposed state budget cuts and layoffs, but avoided calling for a tax increase, to offset a $267 million reduction in Federal aid caused by President Reagan's ''Program for Economic Recovery.''

title: SPORTSWEAR, PAST AND PRESENT, AT BENEFIT
description: century style. And Lord & Taylor was at the forefront of the movement back in the 193 0's to carry the freedomand comfort of golf and tennis clothes into m ore formal activities. So it was altogether fitting that the store s hould begin its fall fashion activities with a salute to American sportswear designers - 14 of them arranged alphabetically, from Adri to Frank Smith.

title: 11 ARRESTED AT STONES CONCERT
description: Bottles sailed through the air and 11 persons were arrested as hundreds of screaming, rain-soaked rock fans gathered at a small nightclub where the Rolling Stones were giving a ''secret'' concert for the holders of 300 free tickets.

title: Miss Kirkland Guest Artist
description: Gelsey Kirkland will join the Eglevsky Ballet Company as resident guest artist for the troupe's fall and spring series. She will appear with the company at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I., on Sept. 25, 26 and 27 and Oct. 30, 31 and Nov. 1 and at C.W. Post in Upper Brookville, L.I., on Oct. 17. Miss Kirkland will perform a Tchaikovsky pas de deux and another piece.

title: JAYARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After tax credits of $39,000 for the latest qr and $49,000 for yr-ago period

title: FUQUA TURNS DOWN BID BY FOUNDER, PLANS OWN
description: Fuqua Industries announced yesterday that its board had rejected a $258 million takeover bid from a management group headed by Fuqua's founder and chairman, J.B. Fuqua. The deal would have made the Atlanta-based conglomerate a private company.

title: AMERICAN SPORTS ADVISORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
BELL & HOWELL SELECTS NEW PRESIDENT
description: Robert B. Huff, 39, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Bell & Howell Company. He succeeds Donald N. Frey, 58, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Nassau Seeks to Oust Arrows From Facilities
description: Nassau County Executive Francis Purcell has asked Nassau Community College to evict the New York Arrows indoor soccer team from its facilities. The Arrows have been practicing at the college since 1979.

title: SALVADOR' OPPOSITION
description: When President Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico and President Reagan meet in Grand Rapids, Mich., on Friday at the opening of the Gerald R. Ford Library and Museum, the explosive Central American situation will have changed substantially since their last meeting, in Washington in June. The new factor is the joint Franco-Mexican declaration, issued Aug. 28, recognizing the opposition in El Salvador as a ''representative political force.''

title: SOUTH AFRICANS DISPLAY THE SPOILS OF ANGOLA RAID
description: West Africa, Sept. 14 - A hand-lettered poster in Portuguese is tacked on a wall of the officers' club at this South African Army base 25 miles from the Angolan border. ''To fight the South African enemy means defending not only the Angolan people but all the oppressed peoples of the world,'' it proclaims

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: F.T.C. DROPS TRUST SUIT AGAINST 8 OIL CONCERNS
description: The Federal Trade Commission today dropped its broad antitrust case against the nation's eight major oil companies, saying further proceedings in the eight-year-old case "are not in the public interest."

title: COMPUSCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes a tax loss carryforward of $39,000 for the latest qr and $16,000 for the yr-ago period

title: Texas Air Asks Board Meeting
description: Texas International Airlines, which last week gai ned majority control of Continental A ir Lines, has asked a Federal court to force Continental to hold a special shareholders' meeting so Texas Air can add six members to i ts board of directors.

title: Vornado Loss Sharply Wider
description: Vornado Inc., o perator of the Two Guys discount department store chain, report ed yesterday that it had a loss of $10.3 million in the second fiscal quarter of 1981, ended Aug. 1, more than nine times theloss of $1.1 million recorded in the similar 1980 quarter.

title: REDISTRICTING: HOW JUSTICE DEPT. ARRIVES AT RULING
description: The process of arriving at a decision on whether New York City's Council district lines are discriminatory will begin in a cluttered corridor here where New York maps, thick with plastic overlays, are tacked to the walls.

title: KDT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
PAKISTAN BLAST COULD END AID
description: A senior Administration official said today that, although Pakistan had refused to foresake its nuclear development program, its leaders ''totally understand, without a doubt,'' that a nuclear detonation could cost the Pakistanis the $3.2 billion aid package just agreed upon with the United States.

title: Sports People; TV Role for Esposito
description: Phil Esposito, who won the National Hockey League scoring championship five times in 18 seasons with the Chicago Black Hawks, the Boston Bruins and the Rangers, will be the color commentator for the Rangers' televised games this season, sources at Madison Square Garden have confirmed. Madison Square Garden Network will make the announcement next Wednesday. Esposito replaces Bill Chadwick, who will work in the network's public relations and promotions department.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It may be easier to cut off the head of the Federal Reserve, but when you have the Federal Reserve running around headless, you'll still have the same problem you started with.'' -Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. (A1:4.)

title: VETERINARY SERVICES DURING LATE HOURS
description: WHAT do you do if your dog or cat gets sick or is injured late at night or on a weekend? An increasing number of animal hospitals in New York City now offer a range of after-hours emergency veterinary services.

title: News Analysis
description: New York state and city officials are increasingly realizing that they must shift their emphasis from building new projects to restoring their existing transportation, water and other basic facilities if their economies are to survive.

title: LESOTHO SEES PRETORIA'S HAND IN SHADOWY CONFLICT
description: Geography practically dictates that Lesotho, an internationally recognized black state implanted in the heart of South Africa, has to be a focus of intrigue. Now the intrigue is thickening daily in a deadly counterpoint of bombings and political murder.

title: Oppenheimer Moves To Rosenfeld, Sirowitz
description: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz & Lawson has emerged as a winner in what must have been a very creative competition for the Oppenheimer Management Corporation account, which last year billed about $2.5 million.

title: SENATE AWACS FOES IDENTIFIED
description: The list of senators who have signed the resolution of disapproval of the sale of Awacs radar planes to Saudi Arabia shows a representation of liberals, moderates and conservatives. Thirty Democrats and 14 Republicans are on the list.

title: ATTENTION GETTERS; Out of Service
description: Residents of the area around Logan Circle in Washington are eager to get prostitutes and drug dealers out of their rebounding community. So they have persuaded the City Council to favor an antiloitering law that prohibits repeated ''beckoning'' to motorists and repeated attempts to talk to pedestrians.

title: U.S. Denies Visas To 4 Cuban Officials
description: Four Cuban officials who had been invited to a trade seminar were denied visas because of Cuba's military involvement in Africa and elsewhere, the State Department said today.

title: AN ODD COUPLE: THE CLIENTS AND THE DECORATOR
description: SHE thinks he is not attentive enough. He finds her impossible to please. She contends that all she wants is someone to talk to about her troubles. He knows that she really needs much more than that. She suspects he is only in it for the money. He wishes she would realize that a man has to eat. She does not trust him. Without her trust he can't perform. In the end they will probably part amicably, but, in the meantime, they will hurt each other and violence may even cross their minds.

title: News An alysis
description: In proposing only marginal cuts in military spending and further major cuts in domestic spending, President Reagan has decided to remain faithful to his central campaign pledges and has taken the biggest gamble of his young Administration.

title: LEONARD STOPS HEARNS AT 1:45 OF 14TH FOR UNIFIED TITL E
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, behind on points on all three official cards, his left eye nearly closed, suddenly slammed an overhead right to Thomas Hearns's head in the 13th round tonight. Then, after sending Hearns to the canvas three times in that round - twice on pushes - Referee Davey Pearl stopped the bout at 1:45 of the 14th, with Hearns on his feet but defenseless.

title: YANKS' RIGHETTI BOWS TO BREWERS, 3-2, AS FINGERS STARS AGAIN
description: The New York Yankees encountered Rollie Fingers for the third time in eight days toni ght and emerged with thesame result, a defeat.

title: Reagan Plan Is Praised
description: Wall Street is bullish on the Reagan Administration's economic program, the nation's investment community has informed the White House.

title: MUSIC: HAYDN ODDITIES AND SURPRISES
description: NOT every concert that is heavy with oddities and surprises turns out successfully. So, Tuesday night's program at Alice Tully Hall, the only all-Haydn program of this week's Haydn-Stravinsky Celebr ation by the Chamber Music Society of L incoln Center, had to beapproached with caution. Of the five pieces, only the ''Emperor'' String Quartet could be said to be really fam iliar. That can be asserted confidently even though the final wo rk was, nominally, the ''Surprise'' Symphony.

title: STERLING EXTRUDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-net income and it reflects reduction of income taxes arising from carryforward of prior yr's operating loss of $28,000 for the qr and $26,000 for the 9 mos

title: Singapore Port Fees
description: Singapore is considering increases in its port charges of up to 200 percent next year, shipping companies said here today. A port spokesman confirmed that the Government was considering raising some charges, saying that the funds would go toward a $500 million program to improve facilities.

title: News Analysis
description: At the same time that Pakistan formally accepted terms of the United States military sales and aid package yesterday, the Government in Islamabad summoned the Indian Ambassador, Natwar Singh, and presented him with a proposal for talks on troop reduction along the border and on the possibility of a nonaggression agreement.

title: VORNADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Includes tax credits of $900,000 or 17 cents a shr in qr and $4,800,000 or 90 cents a shr for 6 mos

title: VOLCKER APPEALS FOR SPENDING CUTS Metzenbaum
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, counseled Congress today to get on with further spending cuts as the best way to shrink the budget deficit and bring down high interest rates.

title: GEICO SELLING UNIT TO BRITISH INSURER
description: The Geico Corporation, the large automobile insurer, said yesterday that it would sell its 66 percent interest in the Government Employees Life Insurance Company for $140 million in cash to Legal and General Group Ltd., a major London-based holding company in the insurance and pension field.

title: 2 More Heirs Certified By Judge in Hughes Case
description: Two paternal stepcousins of Howard R. Hughes were certified today as the last heirs to his fortune, but the judge said it could be a decade before any of the 22 heirs became rich.

title: ENNIS BUSINESS FORMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
STOLEN TRUCK OVERTURNS, TYING UP TRAFFIC FOR MILES
description: A stolen trailer truck loaded with 17 1/2 tons of frozen chickens hit an abutment and tipped over on the lower level of the George Washington Bridge before the morning rush hour. The accident created major tie-ups all morning for traffic heading across the Hudson River for New York City, Westchester County or New England.

title: German Steel Dispute
description: The West German Government said today that a decision by the country's steel producers to postpone a price increase agreed to by the European Economic Community was ''irresponsible.''

title: Transactions
description: AUTO RACING

title: AMERICAN TELEPHONE & TELEGRAPH CO INC (AT& reports earnings for Qtr to Aug
Mets Beat Carlton, Gain Split
description: In their best quixotic fashion, the Mets survived 15 strikeouts by Steve Carlton last night and then beat him on an eighth-inning home run by John Stearns, who hadn't hit one in two years.

title: Envoy to Brazil Confirmed
description: The Senate today confirmed by voice vote Langhorne A. Motley as Ambassador to Brazil. Mr. Motley, 43 years old, is president of an Anchorage, Alaska, company and was Alaska's commissioner of commerce and economic development from 1975 to 1977.

title: CULT MEMBER CRIES OVER PLEA TO JURY
description: Larry Layton, a former member of the People's Temple, broke into tears today at his trial on charges of conspiring to commit murder as his attorney told jurors not to make him a scapegoat ''for the horror of Jonestown.''

title: WASHINGTON TALK BRIEFING
description: A T the White House, President Reagan's advisers have carefully weighed the best way to react to the first major anti-Administration march protesting the budget cuts and labor policy. The labor ''solidarity'' demonstration, on Saturday, is expected to lure tens of thousands of demonstrators to Washington.

title: Burmah Suit I s Abandoned
description: The Burmah Oil Company said today that it had abandoned its appeal for $1.8 billion in compensation from the Bank of England. The suit stemmed from a financial rescue operation of Burmah by the bank in 1975.

title: Charges Against Mother Sought in Cancer Death
description: An Allegheny County coroner recommended today that a woman who had her daughter's bone cancer treated by a Christian Science practitioner be charged with involuntary manslaughter.

title: Tenneco Eurobond Set
description: Tenneco Inc. is raising $100 million through an eight-year Eurobond, Morgan Stanley International, the lead manager, said here today. The bond is being issued on fixed terms with a 17 percent coupon at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 17.12 percent, it added. The Tenneco International bond is callable in 1986 at a price of 101 and at par thereafter, Morgan said.

title: A WELCOME FOR TEMPLETON
description: When the Cardinals scored in the first inning of the opening game of a doubleheader last night, the entire St. Louis bench rose and smothered the player who had scored with highfives and head slaps usually reserved for someone who had homered.

title: News of Music; NOV. 4 GALA TO HONOR GEORGE LONDON
description: A GALA featuring 14 opera singers will honor George London, the bass-baritone and arts administrator, at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington on Nov. 4. The setting could not be a more appropriate one. Mr. London, whose career was abrubtly ended in 1977 as a result of a permanently damaging cardiac arrest, had many artistic ties to Washington.

title: SCAASI: THE MUNIFICENCE IS THE MESSAGE
description: ''IHAVE no particular message this time,'' said Arnold Scaasi. ''So I just decided to make pretty clothes.'' That is indeed a message in itself and it was thoroughly appreciated by the women who crowded into his couture salon at 681 Fifth Avenue, near 54th Street, yesterday afternoon. Women who wear custom-made clothes, like the people who own yachts, don't have to worry about price tags, so they need not be distracted from their search for styles that make them look and feel pretty.

title: FULTON MARKET BESET BY CRIME AND COMPETITION
description: On the surface, it is business as usual at the Fulton Fish Market. Trucks still rumble in at night with fresh fish to be unloaded and sorted for the buyers who throng South Street in lower Manhattan at dawn. During the day the market is quiet, the pavements hosed down, the glistening piles of fish gone but for the ineradicable smell of the waterfront stalls.

title: MODERATE CAR SALES GAIN SEEN
description: The American automobile industry is anticipating only a moderate recovery in 1982 from the sales depression of the past two years, and some Wall Street analysts doubt it will do even that well.

title: Which Bangs? How Many Bucks?
description: The great debate over defense spending, alas, is still not about defense. It's about economics and politics. How much and what kind of defense the nation needs hardly figures in President Reagan's decision to slow the sharp growth of military spending by a mere $13 billion over three years, instead of the $30 billion urged by his Budget Director.

title: Attack on Libyan in U.S.  Discussed by Defendant
description: A former member of the Green Berets charged with attempted murder said today that he visited a Libyan dissident last year under orders from the Central Intelligence Agency and fired at the other man only in self-defense.

title: Sports People; Lauda Back on Track
description: Thirty-two-year-old Niki Lauda of Austria, the former world driving champion, drove a McLaren more than 40 laps around the Donnington Park track in London yesterday as part of a test to determine if he will come out of retirement next year. Lauda later said he was ''quite pleased'' with himself and the car. Lauda, who won the 1975 and 1977 driving championships in Ferraris, suffered near-fatal burns in a crash during the 1976 German Grand Prix.

title: CODY INQUIRY SHARPENS PRESS RIVALRY
description: The disclosure that a Federal grand jury is investigating allegations of financial impropriety by John Cardinal Cody, the leader of Chicago's 2.4 million Roman Catholics, has revived a news scramble in what was already one of the country's most journalistically competitive cities.

title: Michael V. DiSalle, 73, Former Governor of Ohio
description: Michael W. DiSalle, a former Governor of Ohio and champion of the Kennedy political fortunes for more than 20 years, died Tuesday while vacationing in Italy. He was 73 years old.

title: NEW RIGHT LOSES ON JUDGE BUT GAINS NEW ZEAL
description: The cries of outrage and betrayal with which the religious right greeted the nomination of Sandra Day O'Connor to the Supreme Court 10 weeks ago had turned to whimpers by the time the television lights were shut off yesterday in the Senate Judiciary Committee hearing room.

title: Leach of Flyers Quits Camp in Pact Dispute
description: Reggie Leach, who has scored 340 goals in his 12-year career, walked out of the Philadelphia Flyers' training camp today after efforts to renegotiate his contract were unsuccessful.

title: INVESTMENT BANKING FIRM IS STARTED ,
description: The American bond market is in the midst of a debacle that has led to large losses at many firms, but t hat has n ot stopped James J. Lowrey from starting a small investment banki ng concern that seeks its own niche in the market.

title: French Say Sea Profits Will Aid Third World
description: The Government today adopted a draft law to require French companies exploring for seabed minerals in international waters to share any profits with third world countries.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have oak kitchen cabinets that were painted with a very thin coat of white paint so the grain shows through. They are turning yellow. Do you know what I can do to clean them? - I.M., New York

title: ESTATE TAX CUT MAY HURT SALES OF LIFE INSURANCE
description: When Dr. Joseph Paris opened his practice some years ago as an obstetrician and gynecologist in the Bronx, he purchased a substantial life insurance policy to help pay estate taxes after his death.

title: James Beard on Syrup
description: James Beard, the cooking guru, will add his voice next month to the selling effort behind Camp Pure Maple Syrup, which says it is the best-selling pure map le syrup in the East.

title: MALE CONTRACEPTIVE IS TESTED BUT SIDE-EFFECTS PROHIBIT USE
description: Researchers reported today that the testing of of a birth control drug for men had shown some success butthat the drug 's side effects, which included impotency and loss of sex drive, ma de it unacceptable for use in its present form.

title: Advertising; Is Eastern Changing Its Agency?
description: OUT of gossip-prone Madison Avenue yesterday came an unusual rumor, one that may have a grain of truth in it: Eastern Airlines is about to move to Campbell-Ewald.

title: SMITH'S OFFICIAL SECRETS
description: A potentially far-reaching step toward greater secrecy in government was taken the other day by the Attorney General, William French Smith. His action drew little notice, very likely because the meaning of what happened was not immediately understood.

title: KDT to Close 50 Kings Stores
description: KDT Industries Inc. said it will close 50 of its Kings Department stores by the end of the year because of declining unit volume. But the company also said it would continue to operate about 200 stores in 16 Eastern and central states and Puerto Rico with an estimated annual volume of more than $700 million.

title: Swiss Loan to Belgians
description: A group of Swiss banks led by Credit Suisse has granted a $180 million long-term loan to Societe Nationale de Participation et de Financement a la Siderurgie, a Belgian holding company set up to aid that country's ailing steel industry, a Credit Suisse spokesman said today. Interest will be paid at a floating rate based on Euromarket conditions, the spokesman added, but gave no other details.

title: JOANNE WOODWARD HAD 'A MOVIE-STAR DREAM'
description: AS a rehearsal of Shaw's ''Candida'' broke for lunch the other day at the Circle in the Square, a secretary walked over to Joanne Woodward, who is playing the love-torn title character, and handed her a blue envelope with her paycheck inside. ''What's this?'' the actress exclaimed. ''Why are they giving it to me here? They should have sent it to the business.''

title: Hers
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For several weeks it will be written by Claudia Wright, who lives in Washington and is American correspondent for The New Statesman of London.

title: Allied Subsidiary's Garfinckel Stake
description: The Allied Stores Corporation said that its subsidiary, ASC Stores Inc., had received a total of 2,961,291 common shares of Garfinckel, Brooks Brothers, Miller & Rhoads Inc. through its recently expired tender offer.

title: Contact Lens Advance Cited
description: Two contact lens manufacturers announced today that they had developed soft bifocal contact lenses to correct vision for people with distance and reading difficulties.

title: AFTER 20 CUBAN YEARS
description: People often ask me about my impressions of New York City, returning as I have after a 20-year absence. They are also curious about those 20 years.

title: WEINBERGER URGES DECISION BY STAGES ON STRATEGIC ARMS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has suggested to President Reagan a gradual approach to deployment of the MX missile and other new arms to strengthen the nation's strategic deterrent, Administration officials reported today.

title: Personal-Safety Items
description: Garrity Industries, in Stamford, Conn., wants you to know that it is in a position to help you feel safer. That is why it has hired Gordon & Shortt to tell you about its products: a disposable flashlight and a purse-size tear-gas dispenser named Fight Back, which the company says is legal in 45 states. The budget, which previously went through McCurdy Inc. in New Haven, should come to $1 million.

title: BELL'S SATELLITE-TV PLAN RULED ILLEGAL BY F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission said today that the manner in which the American Telephone and Telegraph Company proposed to enter the satellite-television transmission business was unlawful.

title: Reagan and Maronite Meet
description: President Reagan met today with Anthony Khoraich, the Patriarch of Maronite Catholics in the Middle East, for a discussion of the Lebanese situation. An official who asked not to be identified said Mr. Reagan ''affirmed his personal interest in all the people of Lebanon.''

title: Public Employee Union Gains
description: A Tentative Accord in Jersey

title: Young Concert Artists To Open Season Nov. 3
description: The 21st season of Young Concert Artists, which presents promising young performers in showcase engagements, will open Nov. 3 at the 92d Street Y, and will continue through April 6.

title: AILEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $226,000...C-Net income and after an extraordinary credit of $293,000 for the qr and $2,433,000 for the 9 mos

title: PUTTING A HIGH POLISH ON YOUR FURNITURE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores antiques for dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: COURT IS EXPECTED TO UPHOLD KHEEL ON BUS SCHEDULE ISSUE
description: A State Supreme Court justice is expected to rule today that Theodore W. Kheel, the labor arbitrator, acted within his powers when he delayed changes in New York City bus schedules, a court official said yesterday.

title: CITIES GAIN IN SENATE TV BILL
description: Senator Barry Goldwater, chairman of a subcommittee on communications, offered an amendment today to delete controversial cable television provisions from a Senate bill that would deregulate much of the telecommunications industry.

title: Loss of Five Teams Reduces Soccer League to 16
description: The North American Soccer League will be reduced to 16 franchises next season, Commissioner Phil Woosnam announced yesterday after five of the league's 21 franchises failed to post a $150,000 performance bond by midnight Tuesday.

title: Bridge: The World Oympiad Book Is Now Available to Public
description: For those who like to follow the activities of players at the highest levels, the publishing event of each year for almost three decades has been the American Contract Bridge League's world championship book. The book of the 1980 World Team Olympiad, played in Valkenburg, the Netherlands, almost a year ago, is fully worthy of this tradition.

title: PABST NAMES CHIEF; CHAIRMAN SELECTED
description: At the Pabst Brewing Company, the nation's third-largest brewer, William F. Smith Jr., 46 years old, has become president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Thomas N. McGowen Jr., 55, a director of Pabst since 1973, who has held the position at the Milwukee company on an interim basis since July and who was elected chairman.

title: A Scene Studded By Stars
description: A big fight has the gravitational pull of a Nova in that it seems to suck all loose glitter to it. The pull, of course, is to create the illusion one belongs in its compelling orbit. Egos are crushed by distance. The difference between sitting in a $500 seat at Caesars ringside or 20 rows back in the $300 section could be measured only in psychic light years.

title: Market Place; Margin Debt's New Pressure
description: HEAVILY leveraged margin accounts could touch off a good deal of selling in the near future in the event of further weakness in share prices. This was clearly implied by figures released yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange. The figures disclosed that margin debt in accounts with less than 40 percent equity jumped to 38 percent of the total at the end of August, up from 25 percent in July.

title: PALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: The latest qr and yr figures exclude gain of $2,508,000 due to forgiveness of prior yr's Britain's stock relief

title: A.T. & T. EARNINGS ROSE BY 22.3% IN 3D QUARTER
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday reported a 22.3 percent rise in third quarter net income - its strongest quarterly increase in the past three years. The company said business growth and record rate increases had contributed to the rise in profits.

title: NEWPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $10,000 and an extraordinary credit of $2,000...C-After income from discontinued operations of $70,000 or 3 cents a shr in qr and $85,000 or 4 cents a shr in yr and also extraordinary credits of $69,000 or 3 cents a shr in qr and $340,000 or 14 cents a shr in the yr...D-After net from discontinued operations of $105,000 or 5 cents a shr and an extraordinary credit of $224,000 or 10 cents a shr; the 1980 results adjusted for a 50 percent stock divd declared in Aug 1981

title: TOPICS
description: Topics Attention Getters Subway Shoes

title: Helpful Hardware; WALL SHELF HANGERS
description: SOMETIMES a very small, odd piece of hardware can solve some very large problems. One such problem, which almost every householder has, is mounting shelves or cabinets on the wall.

title: New Caltex Chief
description: The Caltex Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday the appointment of William E. Tucker as its chair man and chief executive officer, succeeding James M. Voss, who has be en chairman and chief executive office since 1970. Mr. Tucker has b een president for six years. Mr. Voss will complete 35 years with t he company when he retires Nov.1. Howard V. Yergin Jr., executiv e vice president of Caltex since 1979, will succeed Mr. Tucker as president of the company.

title: BELL, W, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
ROSARIO AND AYALA WIN PRIMARIES
description: Edwin Rosario, one of the finest 18-year-old boxers in the world, was taken the distance for the first time in his professional career but achieved a one-sided decision over James Martinez tonight in a preliminary bout to the Sugar Ray Leonard-Thomas Hearns welterweight fight.

title: Fawcett and Harper's Name Their Agencies
description: Fawcett Books is going to have its advertising done by D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius.

title: VESTAUR SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Arms-Related Trade Control
description: The United States today asked its allies to be more cooperative in stopping the East-bound flow of advanced technology that has the potential to help the Soviet Union improve its war machine. The Adminis tration called for tighter export controls to avoid the drain of mili tary-related technology to the Soviet Union, while endorsing mor e East-West trade ''if the Soviets act responsibly.''

title: 'TIM,' A ROMANTIC DRAMA FROM AUSTRALIA
description: LIKE the characters in a daytime television serial, the people in Michael Pate's Australian romantic drama ''Tim'' appear to exist solely in terms of a few implauisible problems that have been imposed on them by their sponsors. They have names and speak dialogue but, with a couple of exceptions, they are no more or less believable or interesting than the people you see on television soaps, or even people in television commercials who sing with enthusiasm about the latest breakthrough in sugar-free cola drinks.

title: POP: SHANNON AT CARLYLE
description: FOR the last 30 years, the two pre-eminent men who classified themselves as saloon singers have been Bobby Short and Hugh Shannon. Initially, Mr. Shannon was the better known of the two, building an international following during long engagements on Capri, in the Virgin Islands and the Hamptons while Mr. Short was trying to find a foothold in New York. But since Mr. Short got a two-week engagement at the Cafe Carlyle in April 1968, and built it into a 13-year run, his career has soared and the relative positions of the two singers has been reversed.

title: Voters Reminded to Register
description: Governor Byrne today proclaimed Sept. 21 through Oct. 5 Voter Registration Weeks in New Jersey, and urged eligible residents who have not yet registered to vote to do so either in person or by mail.

title: Bribery, Rainmakers and the Law
description: The 1977 law forbidding American business to bribe foreign officials has probably saved the United States untold embarrassment.

title: ARRESTS TOTAL 713
description: Another 150 protesters demonstrating at the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant were arrested today, bringing to 713 the number being held on trespassing and related charges.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allis Chalmers Corp. said it had won a contract of about $185 million to supply 20 turbines for a hydroelectric project planned on the Argentina-Paraguay border.

title: Home Beat; THE ITALIAN TRADE CONNECTION
description: ACCORDING to the architects, Jon Michael Schwarting, above left, and Piero Sartogo of Design Collaborative, who did the planning, the ground floor and basement spaces that are part of the Italian Trade Commission, in the new I.M. Pei & Partners building at 499 Park Avenue at 59th Street, is ''about making connections.'' ''It's always more pleasant to enter something going up than going down,'' said Mr. Schwarting of the access to the large basement exhibition area and the way it can be approached through the ground-floor lobby.

title: Kleindienst's Defense Rests in Perjury Trial
description: The defense rested today in the perjury trial of former United States Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst, and jury deliberations could start Monday.

title: SENATE, 61-36, ENDS FILIBUSTER ON BUSING ISSUE
description: The Senate took an important step today toward passage of severe restrictions on school busing for racial integration by voting to end a three-month filibuster against the legislation.

title: 2 SALVADORAN LEFTIST GROUPS SEEK ROLE AT U.N.
description: A clandestine guerrilla radio station said today that two anti-Government leftist groups wanted to be represented at the United Nations General Assembly.

title: Canadian for Donating Hockey Cup to Soviet
description: George Smith, owner of a trucking company, with the honor of his country on his mind, has decided on a campaign to raise $10,000 to send the Soviet hockey team a reproduction of the Canada Cup trophy.

title: GLOSSER BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Air Florida Cuts Four Routes
description: Air Florida announced that it is eliminating service to four Southern cities as it increases flights to the Northeast in an attempt ''to meet the challenges and demands'' created by the air traffic controllers strike.

title: SKIN-DEEP CULTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: State Police Caution Carey on Rugby Game
description: Governor Carey received a state police report today saying that hundreds of state troopers and possibly National Guard personnel might be needed if a rugby match involving a South African team scheduled here next Tuesday is held.

title: Outlet Merger Wins Approval
description: Columbia Pictures Industries and the Outlet Company announced that their respective boards had approved the previously announced merger of Outlet into a Columbia Pictures unit.

title: Critic's Notebook; BALLET TROUPE CHALLENGE: STAY ALIVE (AND KICKING)
description: OFTEN the world's great ballet companies seem so firmly established as to be well-nigh indestructible. Generations of mere mortals may come and go, yet these companies live on.

title: ONE-STOP BOUTIQUE: FABRICS TO PAINTS
description: AT Macy's, the retail description for it is ''cross-classification merchandising,'' which means selling heterogenous products in the same space. But Inger McCabe Elliott, the president of China Seas, a home furnishings design concern, simply calls it ''Home Port.''

title: EXXON WILL BUILD INDONESIAN PLANT
description: The Exxon Corporation has been awarded a $2 billion contract from Indonesia to build a petrochemical plant in northern Sumatra, the Government announced today.

title: LEGISLATURE, SPLITTING RACIALLY, VOTES BILLS FOR CITY PRIMARIES
description: uf1095 New York City's economy slowed in the first half of 1981, a study finds. But the city completed a surprisingly strong sale of notes. Page B1. By E. J. DIONNE Jr. Speci al to the New York Times

title: AFSCME BACKS PATCO
description: To the Editor:

title: A CUSTOMER'S RAGE LEADS TO THE ARREST OF BOARD OF UTILITY
description: The three commissioners of an electric company in Norwalk, Conn., were arrested yesterday and charged with diverting hundreds of thousands of dollars to their personal use - and all because the company refused a customer's request to itemize the electric bills that she thought were too high for her seven-room house.

title: Ford Sales Up In Germany
description: Ford, West Germany's third-largest car manufacturer, today reported a sharp sales increase for the first seven months of 1981, but officials said they still did not know whether the company would show a profit this year.

title: U.S. AIDE SEES BREAKTHROUGH ON NAMIBIA PLAN
description: Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for Africa, told a House subcommittee today that the Administration had suceeded, through continuing talks with South Africa, in reviving a ''dead'' initiative on independence for South-West Africa. He said there was now hope for a breakthrough by early next year.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advest Inc., Hartford, has named William E. Blankenburg Jr. group vice president.

title: Pechiney Aluminum
description: Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann said today that its Aluminium Pechiney unit would reduce aluminium production at the St. Jean de Maurienne refinery by 14,000 tons a year for an unlimited period because of general slack demand and high stocks. Pechiney said the reduction would lower its total French aluminium capacity to 440,000 tons a year.

title: BLACKS PLAN RALLY FOR CARDINAL CODY
description: CHICAGO Sept. 16 - A group of black Roman Catholic priests announced today that they were sponsoring a rally in support of John Cardinal Cody, the beleaguered Archbishop of Chicago, and asked that diocesan schools in the city's 80 black parishes be closed Friday morning so students could join other church members in ''a positive, mammoth tribute'' to the Cardinal.

title: WARNER EXECUTIVE INDICTED IN WESTCHESTER BRIBERY
description: An executive of Warner Communications was indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal charges involving cash bribes to buy stock in a Westchester County theater that was controlled by organized crime.

title: INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT OFF BY 0.4%
description: The nation's industrial production dropped by four-tenths of 1 percent in August, the Federal Reserve reported today. It was the biggest monthly decline since last year's recession and it mostly reflected cutbacks in the manufacture of autos and appliances.

title: Sports People
description: John Elway Elway Versus Elway

title: THE OTHER SHOE
description: On July 6, 1972, William Sullivan - who had been removed from the top echelons of the F.B.I. by J. Edgar Hoover - sat in the office of the new F.B.I. Director, L. Patrick Gray. Mr. Sullivan wanted to get back into law enforcement, and passed on to Mr. Gray his suspicions about ''Fedora,'' a Russian at the U.N. who was supposedly passing secrets on to the F.B.I.

title: Notes on People; Who Did What First
description: For more than two years, Dennis Sanders labored to make a list of ''facts on firsts'' with the hope that a lot of people are really interested in knowing such things as ''the contact lens was first invented by A. E. Fick, a Swiss physician, in 1887.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Bankers Trust New York Corp. intends to enter into an agreement with Morgan Stanley Inc. to exchange up to 650,000 new shares of its common stock for up to $23.4 million principal amount of 4 1/2 percent capital notes due 1988 issued by the Bankers Trust Company and owned by Morgan Stanley as principal.

title: Guatemalan Gunmen Kill a U.S. Missionary
description: Gunmen believed to be leftist guerrillas shot an American Mennon ite mission ary to death and wounded another, a spokesman for the United S tates Embassy here said today.

title: JURY SAID TO STUDY CHARGES ON SCHUMER'S CONGRESSIONAL RACE
description: A Federal grand jury is looking into accusations that Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn illegally used New York State Assembly aides in his Congressional campaign last year, sources familiar with the inquiry said yesterday.

title: DIAL CORP. IN ACCORD ON MERGER
description: The Northwest Bancorporation, which operates banks in the Midwest, has reached agreement to acquire the Dial Corporation, a leading consumer loan company, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Sports of the Times; TWO FOR HISTORY, WITH A TWIST
description: round decision, he probably would have lost. pu first ad

title: BEGIN'S VISIT LIFTS AWACS FOE'S HOPES
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's opposition to President Reagan's proposed sale of five Awacs radar planes and other air warfare equipment to Saudi Arabia has kept alive the possibility that Congress might vote to block the sale, according to leaders of groups opposing and favoring the sale.

title: CENTER FOR HUMANITIES DEDICATED AT COLUMBIA
description: The Heyman Center for the Humanities, the first of its kind on Morningside Heights, was dedicated yesterday as the final component in Columbia University's $28.7 million residential complex on the east campus.

title: Sting 2, Sockers 1
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Karl-Heinz Granitza scored both Chicago goals as the Chicago edged San Diego and evened their two-of-three semifinal series at one game apiece.

title: WESTPORT CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After a tax loss carryforward of $8,277,000 or $3.21 a shr... C-After the estimated cost of settlement of a lawsuit of $750,000 and a tax loss carryforward of $8,277,000...D-Net loss and after an income tax credit of $141,000 and gains on asset exchange of $166,000

title: Sports People; Bird Unfazed by Trial
description: Larry Bird, the Boston Celtic forward, said at the start of his trial in San Antonio that he was confident of winning the jury's verdict in a $1.3 million suit that a fan of the Spurs has filed against him, Dave Cowens and the Celtics. ''This is just part of being in the public eye,'' Bird said.

title: ROCK: BOW WOW WOW
description: THE history of popular music is full of puppet manipulators, from Col. Tom Parker to Phil Spector to Kim Fowley. These are the brilliant impresarios, the Diaghilevs of rock-and-roll. Indeed, sometimes their machinations become so spectacular that the enemies of rock try to adduce them as proof that rock musicians themselves have nothing to offer. But often as not, they do - even if the manipulators themselves think otherwise.

title: TAB PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BUSH IS GUEST AT INDEPENDENCE FET E IN MEXICO
description: In a gesture apparently aimed at symbolizing improved United States-Mexican relations, Vice President Bush today accompanied President Jose Lopez Portillo during celebrations marking the 171st anniversary of Mexico's independence.

title: PEANUTS MEASURE SPLITS FARM BLOC
description: The customary solidarity of the farm bloc was fractured today when the Senate refused to kill an amendment eliminating a program of peanut crop support s cherished by Southernsenators.

title: HARVESTER TO MAKE DIESELS FOR FORD
description: The International Harvester Company, which has been beset by heavy losses and has made sharp cutbacks in its staff and operations, announced yesterday that it had signed a five-year, $500 million agreement to supply the Ford Motor Company with a 6.9-liter diesel engine.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Pan Am Union Vo tes Pay Freeze
description: The last of three major unions representing 1,300 London-based employees of Pan American World Airways has voted to forgo an annual 8.3 percent bonus and accept a pay freeze through 1982, the airline said. The latest union to accept the pay cut represented supervisory personnel.

title: 2 Starters Demoted by Giants
description: Coach Ray Perkins, upset by the Giants' lethargic offense in the first two games of the season, demoted two starters today.

title: 2-Year U.S. Notes Yield 16.12%
description: The Treasury sold new two-year notes yesterday at an average yield of 16.12 percent, down slightly from the record high 16.26 percent at last month' s two-year note auction.

title: Dr. Koop Is Nominated To Be Surgeon General
description: President Reagan today formally made his long-delayed nomination of Dr. C. Everett Koop, a prominent pediatric surgeon who has been active in the anti-abortion movement, to be Surgeon General of the United States.

title: Bache Canada Clients Offer Testimony
description: In the second day of a hearing into a Toronto Stock Exchange attempt to cancel the operating license of Bache Halsey Stuart Canada Ltd., counsel for the securities company today called institutional clients to the stand to try to prove that the research service it offers to Canadian clients is unique.

title: POLISH COMMUNISTS ASSERT THE UNION INVITES A 'TRAGEDY'
description: In its strongest attack so far, the Communist Party accused the Solidarity union tonight of turning into a political opposition that was pushing Poland toward a ''new national tragedy.''

title: A WRITER OF ELEGANCE AND ORIGINALITY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Susan Brownmiller, author of ''Against Our Will: Men, Women and Rape,'' gardens on her city terrace. By SUSAN BROWNMILLER

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS OFFERING 'AMNESTY' TO DEFECTORS
description: House Democratic leaders offered what they described as ''amnesty'' today to party members who helped President Reagan gain his tax and budget victories this summer, but they warned that those who consistently ''connive'' with Republicans would not have important committee assignments renewed.
To the Editor:

title: Starett Picks Its President From Within
description: Richard Bassuk, 40 years old, has been named president of the Starrett Housing Corporation, a major builder and developer of single-family homes, multi-family housing and office and commercial buildings. He succeeds Henry Benach, 61, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the New York-based company.

title: Filipino Students Protest Martial Law Anniversary
description: Thousands of students protesting American support for President Ferdinand E. Marcos converged on downtown Manila today and clashed with policemen who drew their guns to stop them.

title: PUZO WRITING FILM ON COTTON CLUB
description: Robert Evans and Mario Puzo, who were teammates on ''The Godfather,'' are teaming again, this time to make an $18 million to $22 million movie about Harlem's Cotton Club. Mr. Evans -the former Paramount head of production who bought Mr. Puzo's 30-page treatment, ''Mafia,'' and then helped nurse it into an Academy Award-winning blockbuster - purchased rights to the Cotton Club story last December and has already raised European tax shelter money to make the film, which will be written by Mr. Puzo over the next eight months.

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Shr earnings adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid July 31, 1981

title: Rangers Show Pluses In 4-1 Defeat by Finns
description: Herb Brooks, t he Ranger coach, sat in the press box at the Ice Hall tonight as his team lost, 4-1, to Helsinki IFK, one of Finland's better teams. It was the Rangers' first exhibition game, and the first appearan ce of a National Hockey League team in this country.

title: Technology; Using Plastics In Batteries
description: SOMETIMES technology moves forward by focusing on what a material does poorly instead of what it does well. For instance, a number of researchers have noted that plastics are poor conductors of electricity and have wondered how they might be modified to make them more electrically active.

title: 60 LEADERS PLAN STUDY OF FUTURE OF ARTS IN U.S.
description: Public policy affecting the arts will come under scrutiny in New Haven Sept. 24-27 in a Northeast Assembly on the Future of the Performing Arts.

title: The Region; County Criticized On Valhalla Riot
description: A preliminary report on the July riot at the Westchester County Jail in Valhalla by the State Commission on Correction criticized the county on low staffing levels at the jail, inadequate planning for a rumored disturbance, the transfer of an inmate leader and faulty communications.

title: Notes on People; The Picture of Wealth
description: It was all for a good cause, but Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, now wishes he had not posed in white tie and tails for the cover of a Washington society magazine. The picture of the nation's chief welfare official dressed to the nines at an opulent banquet table has proved irresistible to critics of the Reagan Administration's @budget-cutting policies.

title: Met Fund-Raising Gala On WQXR Sunday
description: The Metropolitan Opera will present a preseason fund-raising gala on Sunday.

title: NATIONAL SERVICE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Index; International
description: Pakistan intensifies effort to en- force Islamic law A2 2 Salvadoran groups seek U.N. representation A3 British Liberals in pact with new party A3 Afghan draft order said to cause an exodus from Kabul A4 Around the World A5 Sponsors of anti-Awacs resolution named A6 Begin's visit lifts Awacs foes hopes A7 Hope for Namibian independence plan seen A9 Lesotho sees Pretoria's hand in shadowy conflict A10 Bush is guest at Mexico independ- ence day fete A11 Government/Politics House Democratic leaders offer ''amnesty'' to defectors A21 Goldin-Dearie confrontation fails to end audit dispute B4 Jury studying charges on Schumer's Congressional race B5 Washington Talk Washington politicians hone their skills at the ''drop-by'' A20 Briefing A20 General Around the Nation A16 More arrested at California nu- clear plant as protests continue A16 Siamese twins with only months to live are returned t o parents A23 Warners Communications execu- tive indicted in bribery A25 Microscope bought in 1734 stolen from Yale University library B2 Fulton Fish Market beset by crime and economic problems B3 Inquiry on Cardinal sharpens press rivalry in Chicago B11 Industry/Labor Air traffic controllers ask panel to order new talks A19 Home Section Home An odd couple: The client and the decorator C1

title: DANCE: CLASSICAL MISSION OF JAPAN
description: THE Classical Performing Arts Friendship Mission of Japan, which is appearing at Asia House through tomorrow night, turns out be a splendid group of performers assembled and presented under very unusual circumstances.

title: Home Improvement; TWO SMOKE DETECTORS
description: ALTHOUGH smoke detectors have been on the market for years and fire prevention experts have long insisted that thousands of lives would be saved every year if every home and apartment had them, many still do not.

title: The Region
description: An application by Phoenix House, the Manhattan-based drug-treatment foundation, to open a school in the northern Westchester town of Yorktown received what county officials considered a setback.

title: Sports People; Korean Pitcher Sought
description: Major league baseball will have its first Korean-born player if the Toronto Blue Jays succeed in signing 23-year-old Don Won Choi, a right-handed pitcher for the South Korean national team.

title: REAGAN WEIGHS NEW BENEFIT CUTS, INCLUDING ONE FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
