description: President Reagan is considering proposals for new cuts in Federal benefit programs, including a one-time, three-month postponement of cost-of-living ra ises for recipients of Social Security beginning Oct. 1, 1982, Admin istration officials saidtoday.

title: CALENDAR: LECTURES ON EARLY INTERIORS
description: ''Home Sweet Home: The American Interior, 1750-1850,'' Fraunces Tav- ern Museum, 54 Pearl Street.

title: Household to Sell Japanese Offices
description: Household International Inc. said it had agreed to sell its Household Finance unit's Japanese consumer finance operations to the Associates Corpora tion of North America, a su bsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries.

title: The Region; Search for Karen E
description: Coast Guard divers were unable to reach an underwater wreck that they believe may be the Karen E, the cabin cruiser that sank last month in Long Island Sound with the loss of five lives. A barge towed by a tugboat is suspected of having collided with the 36-foot pleasure boat and caused it to sink.

title: HOUSTON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
GOO D EATING AND GOOD POLITICKING (IN 20 MINUTES)
description: Here is Representative Robert McClory. His eyes are blue. His head is bald. His necktie is covered with elephants, and his hands are filled with jumbo shrimp from a buffet table.

title: GERMANS FIND PLOT AGAINST A U.S. BASE
description: The police found and defused two time bombs today that had been placed on a rail spur used to carry supplies in and out of a United States air base in Frankfurt.

title: DANCE: ROCKVILLE GROUP
description: ROCKVILLE sounds like the name of a small town in almost any state. But the Rockville Dance Company, which appeared Tuesday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio, hails from New York City and has its spiritual home in a state of mind. What specific state of mind the company was in could be judged from the fact that it danced to records by such groups as the B52s and the Sex Pistols and the entire second half of its concert featured live and rambunctious music by the Linda Hudes Power Trio.

title: NCC Energy Buys Oil and Gas Wells
description: NCC Energy Ltd., a British energy concern, said it had acquired 73 oil and gas wells in Ohio and a half interest in another 65 wells in West Virginia from the Launderman Oil and Gas Drilling Company.

title: 2 Civil War Battleships Found in Virginia River
description: Underwater archeologists today reported finding the wreckage of two Civil War warships, calling the discovery the most historically significant of this field since the ironclad Monitor was found.

title: BIT OF YALE HISTORY STOLEN
description: NEW HAVEN (AP) - A microscope purchased in 1734 and considered one of the first scientific instruments used in the American Colonies has been stolen from Yale University's Sterling Memorial Library, school officials said.

title: TEXAS AIR'S TAKEOVER EFFORT SHIFTS TO PACIFIC ISLAND SERVICE
description: The bitter struggle over Texas International Airlines' bid to take over Continental Air Lines shifted today to a network of Pacific islands that are now served by Continental.

title: Foreign Bribe Curb Altered
description: The Senate Banking Committee voted 11-4 today for changes in the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, eliminating what sponsors called excessive rules imposed on American exporters.

title: Renault Unit Cutback
description: Renault Vehicules Industriels, the truck-building subsidiary of the French auto maker, will put 29,000 employees on shortened hours for a maximum of 11 days before the end of the year because of falling truck sales, the company said today. Sales of trucks weighing more than five tons fell 20 percent to 25 percent in France in August compared with the same month a year earlier, the company said.

title: Officer Challenges Document Outlining an Immunity Offer
description: The Strategic Air Command's top legal adviser today challenged the authenticity of a document outlining an offer of immunity that was said to have been made to a missile officer accused of espionage.

title: TIMES NATIONAL EDITION TO BE PRINTED IN FLORIDA
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that it would begin printing the national edition of The New York Times at a second location, Lakeland, Fla., to permit morning delivery of the paper to Southeastern states and expansion of its circulation in the Miami area.

title: Notes on People; First, the Bad News
description: When his touring company of ''Barnum'' folded unexpectedly a few weeks ago, Stacy Keach was all but inconsolable, according to his friends.

title: POP: LEO SAYER AT SAVOY
description: WHEN the English pop star Leo Sayer first performed in this country in the mid-1970's, he wore Pierrot makeup and played the role of a sad clown. It was the age of glitter rock, and performers like Elton John and David Bowie were enjoying great success mixing rock with English music-hall theatricality.

title: New Delta Route
description: Delta Air Lines said it would begin serving Pittsburgh next month with four daily round-trip, nonstop flights from here. The announcement said Delta's first flights to Pittsburgh will begin Oct. 25. Three of the flights will use Boeing 727 aircraft and the fourth will use a Lockheed L-1011 wide-body craft, Delta officials said.

title: ONE ACCOMMODATING DESIGNER
description: THE costs of having an established interior designer ''do a room'' are legendary. ''These days, spending $18,000 on a room is not money - $30,000 is,'' said Arthur Ferber, a New York designer.

title: Ohio Ferro-Alloys Signs Merger Pact
description: The Ohio Ferro-Alloys Corporation, a producer of silicon base ferroalloys and silicon metal for the metal and chemical industries, said it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by the Fesil Group, a Norwegian ferro-alloy producers association, for $17 a share in cash or notes, or about $35.7 million.

title: Gardening; WAYS OF GROWING HERB PLANTS INDOORS
description: THERE'S a certain frenzy now as gardeners race to dry or freeze a supply of herbs that will last until next summer. The cold months bring lean times, since herb plants grown indoors can be quite temperamental. They just do not like air that is hot and dry and short winter days with weak sunlight.

title: AIR CONTROLLERS ASK PANEL TO ORDER NEW TALKS
description: The union representing striking air traffic controllers asked the Federal Labor Relations Authority today to order the Federal Aviation Administration to resume bargaining with the union. But the avi ation agency immediately rejected the idea. Dolph Sand, an F.A.A. att orney, said the labor agency did not have the power to issue such an order, and if it did it would be sanctioning strikes byFederal emplo yees.

title: Walking in Fear
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Laura Cunningham asks (Hers, Sept. 3) whether it is possible ''for a woman to walk alone, footsteps echoing through the night city, without feeling as if she's performing in a Brian De Palma movie.'' The answer is no, as she points out, but is it any different for men?

title: DOW OFF 6.75 AS VOLUME RISES
description: Stock prices sank yesterday across a broad front, as the Dow Jones industrial average barely missed setting a closing low for the year. The Dow fell 6.75 points, finishing at 851.60. Earlier, it had been down more than 9 points. This indicator closed at a 15-month low of 851.12 on Sept. 8 amid investor worries over high interest rates and the size of the Federal budget deficit.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 17, 1981
description: International The Solidarity union was accused, in the strongest attack so far by the Communist Party in Poland, of turning into a political opposition that was pushing the country toward a ''new national tragedy.'' The party leadership charged that the union had broken year-old agreements that gave birth to the first independent trade union in the Soviet bloc. (Page A1, Column 1.) A nuclear detonation by Pakistan could cost it the $3.2 billion aid package it just agreed to accept from the United States, and its leaders understand this ''without a doubt,'' a senior Reagan Administration official said. Under Secretary of State James L. Buckley made his statements in testimony before the House Foreign Affairs Committee. (A1:1-2.)

title: The Region; Rebates Ordered On Jersey Gas Bills
description: NEWARK (UPI) - About 1.85 million natural-gas consumers in New Jersey will be receiving rebates ranging from $9 to $19 under an order requiring four utilities to pass along $32 million in refunds to their customers.

title: OIL CONCERNS CHA LLENGE CANADA ACCORD
description: Canada's major petroleum companies declared today that to achieve the national goal of energy self-sufficiency in the next decade they would need more revenue than the federal and Alberta governments planned to allow them.

title: U.S. LABOR'S FRIEND IN THE WHITE HOUSE
description: To the Editor:

title: FORMER FOX FILM CHIEF FILES A $20 MILLION SUIT; Former Fox Film Chief Fi les a $20 Million Suit
description: Less than three months after leaving his post as chairman and chief executive officer of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation, Dennis C. Stanfill has filed a suit claiming more than $20 million in general and punitive damages from the company, its owner, Marvin Davis, and unspecified others.

title: SIAMESE TWIN BOYS RETURNED TO CUSTODY OF PARENTS IN ILLINOIS
description: A judge ruled today that a pair of severely deformed 4-month-old Siamese twin boys should spend their few remaining months with their parents, who were once deprived of custody and accused of trying to kill them.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE OXFORD BOOK OF AMER ICAN LITERARY AN ECDOTES. Edited by Donald Hall . 360 pages. Oxford. $15.95.

title: Design Notebook; A RARE URBAN GIFT: PRIVACY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- David Lowe, a freelance writer and author of ''Chicago Interiors: Views of a Splendid World,'' is a guest columnist.

title: Sports People; Seahawks Sign Miller
description: The Seattle Seahawks signed Terry Miller, a free agent running back cut earlier in the year by the Cleveland Browns. Miller went to the Browns in an offseason trade with Buffalo.

title: JETS, 0-2, CAUTIOUS OVER STEELERS, 0-2
description: Without a victory after the first two games, the Jets began preparing for the Pittsburgh Steelers today by tightening security: they barred students from watching practice at the Hofstra U niversity stadium and curtailed the time allowed for reporters to interview players in the locker rooms.

title: A GOLD STANDARD'S SPECTER OF HURTFUL DEFLATION
description: T o the Editor: Advocates of a gold standard claim that a gold-backed dollar will result in low inflation, low interest rates, high growth rates, a strong dollar and increased social cohesion. These claims are not historically su pported; past gold standard regimes have been subject to inflation, recession and panics.

title: WHAT THE TAX LAW WILL DO FOR CHARITY
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHAAK ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CALIFORNIA G.O.P. PLANS FIGHT TO BALK REDISTRICTING
description: Angry Republicans, facing a redistricting package that would all but insure Democratic dominance of the State Legislature and the state's Congressional delegation for at least a decade, laid plans today for a state referendum to turn redistricting over to the courts.

title: FAIR LANES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Company said the latest yr and qr net includes a one-time after tax charge of $238,000

title: The Economy
description: Paul A. Volcker advised Congress to get on with new cuts in spending as the best way to reduce the budget deficit. The Fed's chairman opposed an immediate tax rise proposed by some Democratic Senators as a me ans of cutting back the deficit. He called monetary restraint ess ential to curtailing inflation. (Page A1.).

title: Extortion Case Plea Denied
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit has refused to reconsider the convictions of Elizabeth Eagleton Weigand and her attorney, Stephen E. Poludniak, on charges of trying to extort $220,000 from Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, who is Mrs. Weigand's uncle.

title: COUNT-OFF FAILS TO RESOLVE GOLDIN-DEARIE DISPUTE
description: They did not get around to counting angels dancing on pins, but the two men vying for the Democratic nomination for Comptroller engaged yesterday in a political version of that ancient theological debate.

title: CONWED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEW HEROINES: TEEN-AGERS
description: These are the names of some of their heroines: Mariah, Lisa, Ellynne. These are their problems: a first love who is seriously ill (Mariah); an awful fear of not being as beautiful as Rick Brewster's steady girlfriend (Lisa); how to hook Kip, the most gorgeous boy in the world, who already is dating cute, bouncy Merri (Ellynne).

title: ANIXTER BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: 1980 shr earnings restated for a 100 percent stock divd paid July 1981

title: A JUROR SHORTAGE HALTS MORE TRIALS
description: A continuing shortage of jurors - the result of a computer error - halted all trials yesterday in the Civil Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan and eight trials in the court's Criminal Division.

title: ATTENTION GETTERS; Heads Up
description: Let's see. First there was the day, a few years ago, that a man named Philippe Petit stretched a tightrope between the World Trade Center towers and walked from one to the other.

title: CPS CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
WHAT OF OUR EYE-FOR-AN-EYE DETERRENT?
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBERT PARKER WAKEMAN, 67
description: Paul Marks, managing director of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and an authority on national and international musical performing rights, died Tuesday in New York. He was 52 years old.

title: NEW CREDITS BRIGHTEN SOLAR SALES FUTURE
description: DESPITE the Government's reduced support of solar energy, and despite record interest rates for mortgages and home-improvement loans, the residential solar energy business is booming.

title: DEATHS PUT AT 212 IN QUAKE IN 2 NORTH PAKISTAN VALLEYS
description: The death toll from an earthquake that struck two northern Pakistani va lleys last weekend has risen to 212, officials said today.

title: 3 FOR CHINAGLIA
description: The Cosmo s reached the Soccer Bowl for the fourth time in five years with a 4-1 victory tonight over the Fort Lauderdale Strikers at Giants S tadium. The victory completed a two-game sweep of their semifinal series.

title: DETROIT MAYOR'S SUCCESS AT THE POLLS SHOWS THE POWER IS DOWNTOWN
description: Thomas Celeskey was outside the St. Christine Parish Hall yesterday, getting political. ''You've got to get political these days,'' he said. ''That's the way the system works. That's how Coleman Young does it, right?'' So Mr. Celeskey stood there on Fenkel Street, handing out voter palm cards recommending his nephew, George T. Celeskey, for city district judge.

title: FED'S POLICY OF TIGHT MONEY
description: With bankruptcies running at double last year's rate, the housing industry in a shambles and small businesses hanging on for dear life, Congressmen, economists and even a few Cabinet members have begun to wonder out loud about where the Federal Reserve is leading the country.

title: Physician/Salesman Tells Us About Barnum
description: After his usual morning rounds at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, Dr. H. James Barnum Jr., physician and marketing man, sat in his 500 Fifth Avenue office and explained over coffee and a low-tar Carlton just what the new Barnum Group was all about.

title: Paper Offering By Connecticut
description: The State of Connecticut is trying to protect itself from the ravages of high interest rates in the tax-exempt market by becoming the first state to issue tax-exempt commercial paper.

title: Article 015425 -- No Title
description: In what was believed to be the biggest theft of cash in Britain since the Great Train Robbery, bandits ambushed an armored car today and stole more than $1.8 million meant for London banks.

title: THREE LUTHERAN GROUPS FAVOR STEPS FOR MERGER
description: Three of four major Lutheran church denominations bodies have announced that their members are overwhelmingly in favor of merger and predicted that union plans would be approved by the churches' 1982 conventions.

title: HEALTH RESEARCH GROUP ASKS ORDER AGAINST DRUG CONCERN
description: The Public Citizen Health Research Group asked the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday for an order that would force a Philadelphia-based drug comp any to correct what the commission said were violations of the Se curities Exchange Act.

title: CONSCIENTIOUS PRISONER
description: To the Editor:

title: LABOR'S OFFICIALDOM VS. THE RA NK-AND-FILE
description: 2WASHINGTON - The A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s secretary-treasurer, Thomas R. Donahue, made headlines by saying that the Administration is ''scornful of organized labor.'' He may be right if he has in mind labor's bureaucratic officialdom here. What deserves greater play is how labor, if not outright ''scornful'' of its rank-and-file, at least ignores those members who increasingly question the liberal domestic agenda the A.F.L.-C.I.O. supports.

title: Boeing Jet Sales Off 38% From '80
description: Sales of Boeing commercial jets are down 38 percent from a year ago because of a sharp decline in 727 and 747 purchases, according to the company.

title: HELDOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BRITISH LIBERALS IN PACT WITH NEW PARTY
description: The Liberal Party, in a move that it hopes will change th e face of British politic s, voted overwhelmingly today to form an electoral alliance with the new Social Democratic Party.

title: PAKISTAN'S GRIM ISLAMIC LAW IS NOT JUST A THREAT
description: An 18-year-old high school student and the 24-year-old school bus driver with whom she eloped were ordered recently to be flogged and then stoned to death for adultery.

title: Going Out Guide
description: PARKING

title: ISSUE OF NOTES SELLS STRONGLY
description: New York City's economy slowed in the first half of 1981, with unemployment up and once-sturdy retail sales lagging behind the national growth rate, according to a Koch administration report issued yesterday.

title: N.C.A.A. Sets Meeting On Reforming Divisions
description: A special convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association will be held Dec. 3 in St. Louis to consider restructuring the top two football divisions, 1 and 1A, officials said today.

title: Memorial for Roger Baldwin
description: A memorial service for Roger Baldwin, founder and longtime director of the American Civil Liberties Union, will be held next Thursday at the Community Church, 40 East 35th Street, at 5 P.M.

title: AZTEC MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BONN BUDGET CUTS QUESTIONED
description: Despite the Government's adoption last week of an austerity program to curtail spending and borrowing - a strategy designed to promote more private borrowing in the capital markets - there is a growing sense of uneasiness in West Germany's financial community.

title: PRESERVING THE URBAN PAST- IN ALASKA
description: ANCHORAGE THE initial response of Michael E. Carberry to the concept was negative but he reconsidered while flying back to Texas and decided that ''they needed to preserve what they had.'' So he took the job compiling a historical inventory in Anchorage's municipal planning department. Out of that grew his book, ''Patterns of the Past: An Inventory of Anchorage's Heritage Resources.''

title: 'CBS EVENING NEWS' PLANS APPEARANCES BY CRONKITE
description: Walter Cronkite is scheduled to appear in the near future on ''The CBS Evening News,'' CBS News said yesterday. Geraldine Sharpe-Newton made the announcement in response to inquiries.

title: Mesa Files Suit
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said that it had filed a $1.3 billion counterclaim suit in a Tulsa, Okla., Federal court, accusing the Cities Service Company of interfering with Mesa's efforts to take over or buy a large number of shares in Cities Service. The action was a response to an earlier suit in the United States District Court in Tulsa by Cities Service.

title: JAWORSKI'S PASSING AND EAGLE DEFENSE THWART BILLS, 20-14
description: The Philadelphia Eagles pride themselves on being stronger and better than their opponent in the second half of their games, an ability they credit to the workaholic program dictated by Coach Dick Vermeil. Tonight, they played a stronger and better second half than did the Bills en route to a 20-14 victory over Buffalo. It was Phil adelphia's best game of their current unbeaten season, according to Vermeil. ''We're getting better,'' he said. ''This was aheck of a goo d game, one that will add depth to our confidence. We could do more things with our offense.''

title: The City; The Police Blotter
description: Bradford L. Peery of Westport, Conn., a candidate for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate ne xt year, was robbed at kni fepoint in the IND subway station at 72d Street and Central Park West. Mr. Peery, 43 years old, said three young men took about $1 00 and other valuables ... Henry DeColuenaere, the ownerof a Manhatta n jewelry shop, was robbed by two men of diamonds that he valued at $2 million. The robbery occurred in the eighth floor offices of So ucol Limited, 580 Fifth Avenue ... A pedestrian who was fatally shot Wednesday by a motorist on Park Avenue South was identified as Cruz Silva, 31, of the Bronx. The shooting occurred after the dri ver, who is still being sought, narrowly missed running into Mr. Cruz .

title: DANCE: '2D' ALVIN AILEY
description: THE dance season at the Theater of the Riverside Church got under way Wednesday night with a program by the Alvin Ailey Repertory Ensemble. Directed by Sylvia Waters, this group is the Ailey organization's ''second'' company. But it proved capable of giving a first-rate performance.

title: Loan to Ivory Coast
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that it would lend $132 million to the Ivory Coast to help compensate for a projected export shortfall this year. The I.M.F. said most of the expected shortfall was a result of declines in the export values of coffee and cocoa brought on by falling world market prices. Smaller shortfalls are expected for exports of petroleum and petroleum products and other agricultural exports, the I.M.F. said.

title: Pemex Financing
description: The six-year financing package for the Mexican state oil company, Petroleos Mexicanos, or Pemex, is almost certain to be cut to $200 million from $500 million, because of current market conditions, the European Banking Company, manager of the financing, said here today. The deal has progressed slowly since its start about one month ago, the bank added, becuase of competing Pemex borrowings, the unusual type of facilit y and the August holidays.

title: DEL ELECTRONIC (CO) reports earnings for Yr to July 31
Fans Greet Leonard
description: Sugar Ray Leonard returned home tonight from his welterweight title bout in Las Vegas, Nev., and was greeted by fans at National Airport.

title: 20 DIE IN LEBANON IN ANTILEFT BOMB
description: A guerrilla command center of the Palestinian-Lebanese leftist alliance was destroyed by a car bomb today in the southern port city of Sidon. More than 20 people, most of them civilian passers-by, were reported to have been killed by the explosion.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan Goals And Labor
description: ORGANIZED labor will take to the streets in Washington tomorrow (called ''Solidarity Day,'' echoing Polish labor's protest, reinforced by a papal encyclical) to oppose what it sees as the antilabor and antisocial policies of the Reagan Administration.

title: 'CONTINENTAL DIVIDE,' A COMEDY
description: WHAT a bright and surprising romantic comedy ''Continental Divide'' is, with its ingratiating stars, its clever direction and its witty screenplay. He (John Belushi) is a famous, street-smart Chicago newspaper columnist, and he isn't anything like the facetious wise guys Mr. Belushi usually plays. She (Blair Brown) is a dedicated ornithologist living alone in the Rocky Mountains, and she has the best role of any heroine in ages. They meet. They fall in love. Commuting is a problem, or it ought to be. In a movie that works as buoyantly as ''Continental Divide,'' every problem has its own screwball solution.

title: Notes on People; Committee for New York Names New Head
description: The Citizens Committee for New York City has a new chairman. She is Marietta Tree, an urban planner and a former delegate to the United Nations.

title: BUILDERS PLAN 237 HOMES IN NORTHERN WESTCHESTER
description: TWO builders from Rockland County are building along with Mitch Miller, the sing along man of television, at a new development called Green Briar in northern Westchester.

title: Associated Press Alan Jones; Challenging a Fixture
description: Since 1890 the Army-Navy football game has been played the Saturday after Thanksgiving. But tradition will be broken this year if the service academies agree to a proposal by ABC that the game be moved up a day to Friday, Nov. 27, to avoid conflicts with several other top televised games, such as Pittsburgh-Penn State and Alabama-Auburn.

title: A MAVERICK QUITS PABST BOARD
description: When Irwin L. Jacobs, the 39-year old Minneapolis multimillionaire, elbowed his way onto the Pabst Brewing Company board, he was viewed as an unfriendly interloper, at best.

title: DYNEER CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
FAIR-TEX MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Pleasant Colony Is 8-5 In Post 6 for Marlboro
description: Pleasant Colony got post No. 6 and was made the 8-5 morning-line favorite as a field of nine was drawn yesterday for the $400,000 Marlboro Cup at Belmont Park tomorrow.

title: REAGAN MEETS 2 NEIGHBORING LEADERS
description: President Reagan conferred here today with Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada and Jose Lopez Portillo of Mexico, and an Administration official said afterward that the meetings had lessened the strain between the United States and Mexico over Mexico's support of leftist rebels in El Salvador.

title: OIL OUTPUT UP 2.6% IN AUGUST
description: Crude oil production in the lower 48 states of the United States increased on a year-to-year basis for the third consecutive month in August, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

title: VIDEO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Yr to June 30
STANDUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-After a gain of $1,379,000 on sale of investment for the qr and 9 mos and a tax credit of $250,000 for the 9 mos

title: Q&A: JOSEPH A. CALIFANO ON REAGAN AND THE GREAT SOCIETY
description: Joseph A. Califano was chief domestic adviser at the White House under President Johnson and served for 30 months as secretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare under President Carter. In an interview this week in his large but modestly furnished law office just a few blocks from the White House, he had some positive comments about President Reagan's handling of the nation's domestic affairs but was sharply critical of his social cutbacks and civil rights policies. Excerpts of the conversation follow:

title: Global Marine Offering
description: Global Marine Inc. is offering $100 million of 16 percent, 30-year senior subordinated debentures, priced at 88.44 to yield 20 percent, the lead underwriter, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, said in New York yesterday. The proceeds will bolster the offshore driller's capital outlays.

title: FAYE DUNAWAY PLAYS 'MOMMIE DEAREST'
description: SHE looks a little like Faye Dunaway, albeit a Faye Dunaway with overpowering eyebrows, angry red mouth and the steeliest of gazes. But she is Joan Crawford, as Miss Dunaway gives the uncanny, meticulous Crawford imitation that is at the heart of ''Mommie Dearest.'' The movie itself has nothing like the brilliance of the impression, which is why it remains an impression and can't altogether rise to the level of a performance. But on its own terms Miss Dunaway's work here amounts to a small miracle, as one movie queen transforms herself passionately and wholeheartedly into another.

title: EARNINGS
description: The Seagram Company yesterday reported record operating results for the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 1981, ended July 31. Net income rose 113 percent, to $92.3 million, or $2.63 a share, compared with $43.3 million, or $1.23 a share, in the final quarter last year.

title: Communists Say Caracas Sends Salvador Advisers
description: The Communist Party said today that the Venezuelan Government had sent military advisers to El Salvador to help the United States-supported junta against opposition guerrillas. ''There are up to 30 Venezuelan military men in El Salvador,'' the Communist leader, Radames Larrazabal, said.

title: National Steel To Expand Plant
description: The National Steel Corporation said that it would expand its tubular products plant in Liberty, Tex., by 50,000 tons a year.

title: COURT UPHOLDS KHEEL IN DECISION DELAYING REDUCED BUS SERVICE
description: A reduction in bus service in Manhattan and the Bronx will not go into effect this fall, as planned, because of a decision handed down yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn. Unless the decision is overturned on appeal, the changes will go into effect instead in January, offficials said.

title: BLACK ECONOMIST RIDES WITH THE REAGAN VICTORY TIDE
description: ''I woke up in Chicago and I'm going to sleep in Washington,'' Thomas Sowell said cheerfully yesterday as he descended to street level in a crowded elevator. Mr. Sowell, the conservative black economist, social theorist and polemicist, had just given a luncheon speech for 80 people at the private Century Club on West 43d Street.

title: Shell Unit Rejects Bid
description: Shell Australia Ltd., a unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group of companies, said today that it would decline a Government invitation made Aug. 12 to sell 25 percent of its equity to t he Australian public because of current market conditions. T he company did not indicate whether it would consider anequity sale a t a later date.

title: Ryder Cup Gives Rival Golf Pros a Chance to Play as a Team
description: Only a victory in the United States or British opens could make Ben Crenshaw happier than he is this weekend. After nine seasons on the professional golf tour, he has finally achieved what he calls his loftiest honor: membership on the United States Ryder Cup team.

title: GULF ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net income after an extraordinary gain of $34,000

title: REVUE: IRVING BERLIN
description: ''THEY Say It's Wonderful,'' the musical re vue saluting Irving Berlin that began a four-week engagement at t he St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel's King Cole Room on Monday, isn't as co nsistent as the club's recent tributes to Lerner and Loewe and Rodge rs and Hammerstein for reasons that have more to do with the compose r than with the production. For Mr. Berlin's catalogue of mor e than 3,000 songs doesn't lend itself readily to the small revu e format in which individual songs are turned into thematic med leys.

title: Rail Tonnage Down
description: Railroad freight tonnage last week was about 16.7 billion ton-miles, down 6.9 percent from a year ago, the Association of American Railroads estimated t oday. The association said that car loadings, on which ton-mileage estimates are based, totaled 384,645 last week, compared with 451, 744 the previous week and 452,048 in the comparable week of 1980. I t said car loadings for the year to date totaled 15,454,464, compared with 16,040,351 a year ago.

title: U.S. SUING TO RECOVER ABSCAM PAYOFFS
description: First the Government gave them the money, now it wants it back. The Justice Department is demanding that four former members of Congress return their ill-gotten gains - the tens of thousands of dollars they were convicted of taking in illegal payoffs from undercover agents in the Abscam operation.

title: Hobby Horse of Gold
description: The same crew that gave us the supply-side tax cut is off on a new tack: the answer to our economic troubles, they say, lies in a return to the gold standard. Representative Jack Kemp of New York, aided by the economist Arthur Laffer and Jude Wanniski, a consultant, are pushing this idea on anyone in Congress who will listen. Only when the nation returns to the gold standard, says Mr. Laffer, will it have a credible anti-inflation policy. ''Gold is the only thing,'' chimes in Mr. Wanniski.

title: Leonard Rematch Unlikely
description: They were both hiding their bruises behind dark glasses today, winner and loser, just as last night when Sugar Ray Leonard and Thomas Hearns had to be helped out of the ring, Leonard with both versions of the welterweight title, Hearns with tears in his eyes.

title: HOUSING STARTS FALL TO '75 PACE
description: New construction of single-family houses in August plunged 16.4 percent from July to its lowest level since the Government began keeping records more than two decades ago, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: INSIDE WORKERS
description: In the same breath, people complain about declining productivity and poor-quality workers. They're half right. We do have a productivity problem but there is nothing wrong with the workforce. Any crisis of reduced output is directly caused by the poor management that has characterized our organizations in recent decades.

title: Art People; A Picasso to fill gap left by 'Guernica.'
description: THE departure last week for a permanent home in Spain of ''Guernica,'' the powerful 1937 antiwar mural by Picasso that had been on long-term loan to the Museum of Modern Art, leaves a yawning gap in the museum's collection. But officials at the Modern, knowing that they would not have ''Guernica'' forever, took an important step some time ago to diminish the loss.

title: United American Has New System
description: The United American Service Corporation said that it had developed a new computer system, using an I.B.M. Displaywriter, that will be sold to banks for use by small businesses and professionals.

title: Alcoa Makes Changes In Its Top Executives
description: Charles W. Parry, 57, has been elected president of the Aluminum Company of America, succeeding William B. Renner, 61, who was named a vice chairman. The giant Pittsburgh corporation also established an office of the chairman, which will include Mr. Parry, Mr. Renner, Marvin E. Gantz, 62, who was appointed a vice chairman in July, and W.H. Krome George, 63, chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Restaurants; Fiery wonders from South India.
description: IT often se ems that the worst enemies of the vegetarian way of lifeare the advoc ates of that philosophy who too often prepare dishes that bear no relationship to food as most people know it. Presented with unfamili ar, unfoodlike dishes, the nonvegetarian is unlikely to become a conv ert or even risk an occasional foray into a restaurant known to be v egetarian. Rather than inventing unlikely combinations of foods that make most people uncomfortable, it would seem wiser to rely on the e normous range of vegetarian dishes traditional to so many ethnic c uisines.

title: Resolution Is Adopted On Bills' Ticket Policy
description: The Erie County Legislature passed a resolution today asking the Buffalo Bills to explain their ticket sale policy and answer a charge that the team withheld tickets to assure a television blackout of their season opener. The vote was 19 to 1.

title: CONSPIRACY CHARGES IN GUYANA SLAYINGS SENT TO A COAST JURY
description: The Government's case against Larry Layton, a People's Temple survivor, went to a Federal court jury tonight for a decision on whether he conspired to murder United States Representative Leo J. Ryan and to try to murder Richard Dwyer, deputy chief of the United States mission to Guyana.

title: LARSEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SISSY SPACEK IN 'RAGGEDY MAN,' A VIOLENT MELODRAMA
description: ''RAGGEDY MAN'' is something like a country-and-western ballad that relates a supposedly sad, melodramatic story but whose simple, repetitive, upbeat rhythms effectively deny the awfulness of the events being sung about.

title: RETIRED NEW SCHOOL PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Alfred Kahler, professor emeritus of economics of the New School for Social Research in Manhattan, died last Saturday in Little Rock, Ark., where he had gone to attend the wedding of a grandchild. He was 81 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Jones's Farewell Season
description: Alan Jones, the 1980 world driving champion, said he would retire from Formula One auto racing at the end of the season. Jones, a 34-year-old Australian, currently in third place in the driver standing, said he was determined to leave the sport as the champion.

title: COMPTROLLER ASKS CAREY TO DELAY SOME BORROWING
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, facing $2.1 billion of financing requests from the state and its authorities over the next three months, today asked Governor Carey to ''postpone borrowing for all low-priority projects.''

title: ART'S WAY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: B-Net income; 1980 figures have been restated to reflect the spinoff of Weigh-Tronix

title: Story of Writing at Cooper-Hewitt
description: Visitors to the Cooper-Hewitt Museum this weekend will be judging books by their covers, in addition to the materials they're made of and the implements used in writing them, at a new exhibition called ''Writing and Reading,'' which runs through January. The exhibition covers the many varieties of written communication, from ninthcentury Islamic textiles with woven inscriptions to delicately embellished 19th-century letters.

title: 7 PIANISTS WIN JUILLIARD SCHOLARSHIPS
description: Three pianists were named winners in the first category of the Gina Bachauer Memorial Competition yesterday at the Juilliard School, and four won in the second category. Among the first-category winners was Zhu Daming, the 30-year-old pianist from China, who last June placed sixth in the Van Cliburn Competition in Texas.

title: U.S. ANALYST SEES BRIGHTER CITY ECONOMIC PICTURE
description: New York City's job market is not so troubled as a report issued by the Koch administration Wednesday indicated, a Federal analyst said yesterday.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company said latest second qr included a pretax gain of $2.1 million from unrealized foreign currency

title: U.S. ENDING PROGRAM OF SUMMER INTERNSHIPS
description: The summer intern program, which annually brought 1,100 college students into the Government, is being scrapped.

title: Pan Am to Cut Fares to Hawaii
description: Continuing its fare-cutting policy, Pan American World Airways said that it would reduce its fares between the cont inental United States and Hawaii by as much as 20 percent. The route was not included in Pan Am's dome stic fare reductions announced Sept. 7 and additional reductions ma de three days later.

title: MITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
New Face; A PROPER DASH OF VITALITY IN SHAW'S 'MISALLIANCE'
description: DRAMATICALLY speaking, philosophical debates need a dash of vitality for leavening. In the current production of George Bernard Shaw's ''Misalliance'' at the Roundabout Theater, it is the exuberant performance of Jeanne (pronounced JEAN-ee) Ruskin that provides just that dash.

title: Steelers' 0-2 Mark Is an Unusual Start
description: The last time the Pittsburgh Steelers lost their first two games of the season, Terry Bradshaw was a rookie who w ent on to lose his job as the starting q uarterback. And Coach Chuck Noll was trying to find a way out of a 16-game losing streak that started the previous season.

title: GRACE BUMBRY IN 'NABUCCO' OPENS SEASON
description: AFTER three weeks of warming up with ''The Student Prince'' and ''The Song of Norway,'' the New York City Opera got down to more serious business last night, presenting its new production of Verdi's ''Nabucco.'' This is the work that made Verdi a national hero, mainly because its plot concerns a people enslaved and ultimately liberated. That struck home with Italians, whose country was under enemy occupation at the time. The soaring chorus of the last act, ''Va, pensiero,'' became a national hymn. All this, you probably know.

title: SAN JUAN RACING ASSN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Notes on People; Lynn Redgrave Replaced in TV Series
description: A follow-up: In this season's most vocal dispute between a television show producer and a star of a hit series, Lynn Redgrave has been replaced by Sharon Gless in the CBS situation comedy ''House Calls.''

title: GRAND RAPIDS DEDICATING FORD'S MUSEUM IN AURA OF PROSPERITY
description: Bob Hope is in town, as everyone here knows. He took a cab 15 miles out of town last night to see a broadcast of the fight between Thomas Hearns and Sugar Ray Leonard, and, since he wanted the cab to wait, he invited the driver in to watch the bout.

title: SCOTT & FETZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NATIONAL BERYLLIA CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After a tax loss carryforward credit of $41,400 or 6 cents a shr

title: 2 Suspects Die From Fumes
description: Two men believed to be burglarizing a house that had been sealed off and fumigated for termites died from the fumes, the authorities said today.

title: The Region; Indian Point Plant Operating Again
description: Consolidated Edison announced that it had returned its Indian Point 2 nuclear-power plant in Buchanan to service after replacing a reactor coolant-pump motor.

title: Broadway; For Richard Kiley, a mean look to go with his new role.
description: AFTER years of playing Don Quixote, that well-intentioned old soul who tilts at windmills, Richard Kiley is transforming his lip into a snarl and his eyes into a scowl so he can play Scrooge. Mr. Kiley, who has made something of a career touring in ''Man of La Mancha,'' but has been looking in recent years for a new Broadway show for himself, is going to star as Dickens's notorious pennypincher in the new musical ''A Christmas Carol.''

title: WALKER-SCOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
PUBLIC BROADCASTING ELECTS PRESIDENT
description: Edward J. Pfister, p resident and general manager of the public broadcasting stations i n Dallas-Forth Worth, was elected president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting today. He pledged to improve public televi sion and radio d espite sharp cuts in Federal funds.

title: Benton & Bowles Signs RCA Music Services
description: They were hearing music at Benton & Bowles yesterday, courtesy of RCA Music Services division, which has decided to have the agency and its B&B Direct unit do its advertising.

title: Auctions; Museum sells entire stock.
description: CHRISTIE'S will auction the entire contents of the World Museum in Tulsa, Okla., next week in what it describes as the largest ''on premises'' sale ever held in this country. The seven-session sale may also be the most unusual. The event, which takes place Monday through Thursday, will offer hundreds of objects, many of which are far from conventional collectibles - including the front wall of a house from New Guinea, 70 tons of petrified wood, a Papuan war canoe, four shrunken heads, 14 vintage automobiles and some Dore paintings that are so large a wall of the museum will have to be taken down to remove them.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 18, 1981
description: International Opposition to the sale of Awacs radar planes and other air warfare equipment to Saudi Arabia gained as a clear majority of the Senate publicly lined up against President Reagan's arms sale proposal. While the development did not spell final defeat for the President, it clearly threatened the possibility of a serious political defeat for him and a possible setback in relations with Saudi Arabia. (Page A1, Col.6.) The Russians demanded the silencing by Polish authorities of an ''unbridled'' anti-Soviet drive by Solidarity and other dissidents that had reached ''dangerous limits.'' (A1:5. )

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 20.00 20.00 12.25 DISCOUNT RATE* 14.00 14.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 15.80 15.73 10.85 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.29 14.33 10.05 6-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.37 14.48 10.45 7-YR. TREASURY NOTES 15.28 15.47 11.56 30-YR. TREASURY BONDS 14.24 14.44 11.48 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 16.28 16.37 12.37 MUNICIPAL BONDS 13.10 13.17 9.35 6-MONTH SAVINGS 14.907 CERTIFICATES * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Protesting the Springbok Tour
description: The current American tour of the Springboks, the visiting South African rugby team, is more a propaganda stunt than a legitimate series of sports events, and it is partly financed by a South Africanbusinessman w ith obvious political intentions. The visit thus rightlyoffends many Americans and raises the possibility that the Soviet Union and man y third-world nations will withdraw from the 1984 Olympics in L os Angeles.

title: FASHIONS, IN THE PUBLIC EYE
description: The grandeur of the fall fashion scene was celebrated by Saks Fifth Avenue on Wednesday night in a gala entertainment that had many facets. One woman and four men were the heroes of the fashion show. Each was asked to suggest his favorite charity. So there were five beneficiaries of the evening's events, for which tickets cost $125.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. said that its board has authorized the purchase of up to 3 million shares of its stock in either private or open-market transactions.

title: CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TV Weekend; BERNSTEIN'S 'MASS,' 'ANSON 'N' LORRIE'
description: LEONARD BERNSTEIN'S ''Mass'' will get another television presentation, live from Washington's John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts tomorrow at 8 P.M. The ''theater piece for singers, players and dancers'' proved remarkably suited to the electronic medium several years ago when it was taped for public television's ''Theater in America'' series. This time around, being carried on WNET-TV, the Celebrant/Troubador is being played by Joseph Kolinski, who will lead his hippyish congregation through an intricate blend of Roman Catholic liturgy and a musical score encompassing everything from rock to jazz to ballads. The director is Tom O'Horgan, whose credits include, appropriately enough, the stage versions of ''Hair'' and ''Jesus Christ, Superstar.''

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard SAUCE FOR THE GOOSE. By Peter De Vries. 232 pages. Little Brown. $11.95.

title: Pacific Gas Sale
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said today that it would offer the public up to 10 million common shares within the next six months at a price not yet decided.

title: Top Officers Leave FSC
description: The FSC Corporation, a rapidly growing asset-management company with an important stake in petroleum refining, announced yesterday that four of its top officers and directors had resigned and were replaced by four officers of the Spartan Manufacturing Company, of St. Louis. The changes were called part of FSC's effor ts to reverse ''serious liquidity and cash flow problems threatening the company's viability.''

title: The Region; Yale Recovers Stolen Microscope
description: NEW HAVEN (AP) - An antique microscope, considered one of the first scientific instruments used in the American Colonies, has been found intact after it was reported stolen, Yale University officials said yesterday.

title: WRONG WAY TO COMBAT FEDERAL DISTRICTS
description: To the Editor:

title: HOW BENEFIT DEFERMENT PLAN ON THE COST OF LIVING WORKS
description: The cost-of-living adjustment for Social Security benefits was established nine years ago as much to prevent Congress from exercising its baser political instincts as to protect the income of retired people.

title: Article 018002 -- No Title
description: James L. Emery, the Assembly minority leader and a potential Republican candidate for Governor, charged today that, based on a comparison with California taxation figures, New York State and its local governments lose $3 billion a year through faulty collection of sales taxes.

title: FOOD PROGRAM'S ADVOCATES FEAR CUTBACKS WILL WIPE OUT GAINS IN NUTRITION
description: In 1967, six pediatricians were dispatched to the South on a search for hunger, and they found it in appalling quantity. Ten years later a second medical team came here for a look and concluded that although the diet of America's poor would still displease nutritionists, there was food in the icebox. The doctors agreed that in the decade that had passed, the corner would not have been turned without huge increases in the budget for Federal food aid programs. Since 1967, the budget for such programs has risen about 3,000 percent, from $585.5 million to about $16 billion. However, in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, the programs will be cut by $3 billion, a move that would, among other things, disqualify one million of the 23 million Americans now receiving food stamps and reduce the amount of food stamps for the remaining recipients by about 10 percent.

title: Valenzuela Ties Mark With 8th Shutout
description: Fernando Valenzuela became the first 13-game winner in the National League as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Atlanta Braves, 2-0, tonight. He also tied a major league rookie record by hurling his eighth shutout. Valenzuela (13-4) helped himself by singling in a run off Rick Mahler (5-6) in the sixth. He allowed three hits and struck out six.

title: Sports People; Colquitt's Complaint
description: Craig Colquitt's 40.3-yard career punting average has dropped almost 3 yards this season, and the Pittsburgh Steeler punter blames a new National Football League rule for the reduction. For four seasons, Colquitt tied his kicking shoe so that the knot was off to the side.

title: BADEN IS HIRED IN CORONER POST ON LONG ISLAND
description: Dr. Michael M. Baden, whom Mayor Koch removed as New York City's Chief Medical Examiner two years ago, has been appointed the chief deputy medical examiner for Suffolk County.

title: GEOFFREY PARSONS, NEWSMAN, IS DEAD
description: Geoffrey Parsons Jr., editor of The International Herald Tribune from 1944 to 1950 and a retired vice president of the Northrop Corporation, died today at his home in Benisa, Alicante Province, Spain. He was 73 years old.

title: P.L.O. BID SEEN AT WORLD BANK-I.M.F. TALKS
description: Arab members of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund have launched a drive to enable the Palestine Liberation Organization to attend the joint annual meetings as an official observer, Administration and fund officials said today.

title: The City; Judge Commits 'Village' Slayer
description: The former Transit Authority police officer who killed two men and shot six others during a shooting spree in areas frequented by homosexuals in Greenwich Village was committed to a maximum-security mental institution.

title: At the Movies; Head over heels about the news.
description: WHEN Richard Jordan discovered that Blair Brown was pregnant, he fell downstairs and broke his ankle. ''That was his adult response to the situation,'' says Miss Brown, her small, pretty face agleam with merriment. Miss Brown is Mr. Jordan's girl, or lover, or housemate - whatever it is that protocol has us calling unmarried roomies these days - a condition that has prevailed since the two worked together in the television miniseries, ''Captains and the Kings.''

title: FIFTH AVENUE TURNS BOOK FAIR COUNTRY ON SUNDAY
description: FROM Alistair Cooke to Santa Claus, from James Beard to Wonder Woman, celebrities will be out in force at the third annual New York Is Book Country street fair on Sunday.

title: 98 NARCOTIC SUSPECTS ARE ARRESTED IN A POLICE SWEEP OUTSIDE SCHOOLS
description: Ninety-eight persons were arrested for possessing or selling narcotics, mostly marijuana, outside scores of public high and junior high schools across New York City yesterday as part of a Police Department crackdown on drug sales in parks, playgrounds and other areas.

title: FOSSIL OF UNKNOWN MAMMAL FOUND IN WEST
description: The fossil jaw of a small mammal never before known to man has been found on the Navajo Indian reservation in northeastern Arizona, the Harvard University paleontologist who led the discovery team reported yesterday.

title: HEADED PILLAR OF FIRE CHURCH
description: Bishop Arthur K. White, president and general superintendent of the Pillar of Fire Church in Zarephath, N.J., died Monday at his home in Zarephath. He was 92 years old.

title: TALKS EASING ADIRONDACK PARK CONTROVERSY
description: A decade of controversy over how best to protect the huge upstate wilderness areas of Adirondack Park is yielding to a behind-the-scenes effort at compromise between opponents and supporters of the toughest state land-use regulations in the country.

title: McEnroe in Davis Cup
description: John McEnroe, Peter Fleming, Roscoe Tanner and Eliot Teltscher have been named to the United States Davis Cup team for the semifinal round against Australia.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationally, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by both sales and radio air play. An asterisk indicates an especially fast-selling record. Albums ThisLast WeekWeek 1 4 Tattoo You* Rolling Stones 2 1 Escape Journey 3 3 Bella Donna Stevie Nicks 4 2 4 Foreigner 5 5 Precious Time Pat Benatar 6 6 Long Distance Voyager Moody Blues 7 22 Innocent Age* Dan Fogelberg 8 9 Don't Say No Billy Squier 9 11 Street Songs* Rick James 10 10 Pirates Rickie Lee Jones Singles 1 1 Endless Love Diana Ross & Lionel Richie 2 2 Queen of Hearts Juice Newton 3 5 Who's Crying Now* Journey 4 3 Urgent Foreigner 5 7 Medley* Beach Boys 6 6 Stop Draggin' . . . Stevie Nicks & Tom Petty 7 8 Step by Step* Eddie Rabbitt 8 14 Arthur's Theme* Christopher Cross 9 4 Slow Hand Pointer Sisters 10 11 Hold On Tight* Electric Light Orchestra

title: ADVERTISING
description: People

title: Fearless Al Williams
description: ''After what the night fighter's been through,'' said Billy Gardner, the Minnesota Twin manager, ''what's he ever going to be afraid of on the mound?'' Gardner was talking about Al Williams, a native of Nicaragua who fought there for 16 months with the Sandinista rebels. Williams, a pitcher who beat Toronto Wednesday night for his fifth victory of the year, joined the Sandinistas in 1977 when, because of the Nicaraguan revolution, he was unable to leave the country to join the Pittsburgh organization, to which he then belonged.

title: Baldwin-United Al ters Sperry Plan
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation of Cincinnati and the Sperry & Hutchinson Company of New York said that they had agreed to amend a previously announced merger plan to allow Baldwin to begin a $36-ashare cash tender offer for all the outstanding Sperry & Hutchinson shares that it does not already own.

title: Sony's Profits Drop by 14.3%
description: The Sony Corporation, the Tokyo-based maker and marketer of electronics products, said yesterday that its third-quarter profits fell 14.3 percent from a year ago, mainly because of the dollar's appreciation in relation to the yen.

title: M.P.A. Magazine Ad Competition Begun
description: Any ad appearing in any magazine published in America this year is eligible for a $25,000 prize given for the most creative and effective magazine ad of the year, in a new competition being started by the Magazine Publishers Association.

title: THE POLICY BLIND
description: One advantage of a ne w problem is that it shrinks the memory of old ones. The current s ystem of providing crucial foreign policy advice to the Presiden t is a sorry example.

title: Pretrial Arguments End In Cooke Espionage Case
description: Defense and prosecution lawyers today rested their cases in pretrial hearings on whether a court-martial should proceed for Second Lieut. Christopher Cooke, who is charged with passing secrets to the Soviet Union.

title: MIXED CAPITAL SPENDING PLANS
description: When the Champion International Corporation broke ground last May on a new $483 million pulp mill in Quinnesec, Mich., the goal was to get the mill operating by September 1984.

title: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
description: Yr-ago shr earnings were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in Nov 1980

title: Rate Forecast By Wriston
description: One of the nation's leading bankers said today that Wall Street was not responsible for high interest rates, and he predicted that interest rates would come down ''if we hang in there with the President's program.''

title: LENIN'S 'USEFUL IDIOTS' IN SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: THE TREAS URES OF EARLY BUDDHIST ART DISPLAYED AT JAPAN HOUSE
description: JI, the legendary Buddhist temple complex that occupies 32 acres of the countryside to the south and west of the Japanese city of Nara, was founded by the Imperial Prince Shotoku in 607 A.D. Although it still functions as a monastery, its fame now derives from the renowned art collections that have reposed there since the seventh century. These are well known to art historians and connoisseurs the world over, but - until now - none of these treasures has ever been loaned for public exhibition outside the temple area.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advanced Systems Inc., Arlington Heights, Ill., has appointed Gareth G.R. Morris general counsel and secretary.

title: EXXON FOUNDATION GIVING SCHOOLS AID
description: A $15 million program to help engineering colleges deal with a critical shortage of faculty members was announced yesterday by the Exxon Education Foundation. It will both support doctoral students headed for teaching careers and provide salary supplements for untenured professors.

title: Oil Company Borrowings
description: American oil companies borrowed a record $27.5 billion from banks in July, more than four times the amount borrowed by all United States corporations in the previous two years, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: Bridge: Bob Wakeman Did Much To Help Others in Jersey
description: Barring those who make bridge their full-time occupation, few have done more for the development of the game in their own area than Bob Wakeman of Upper Montclair, N.J., who died earlier this week.

title: Chargers' Jefferson Traded to Packers
description: The Green Bay Packers acquired the all-pro receiver John Jefferson from San Diego today in a deal contingent upon their signing him within a period that was not specified.

title: Advertising; Fate Acts A s Catalyst A t Shapiro
description: year-old president of Shapiro/Budrow & Associates, formerly Centipede Inc.

title: KOCH CALLS BARBARO COMMERCIAL AN APPEAL TO BIAS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday denounced a radio commercial by one of his opponents in the Democratic primary, Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro, as ''despicable'' and an ''appeal to racial prejudice.''

title: THE USE AND ABUSE OF THE TAX POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. DRAFTS PLAN ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Senate Republicans who will begin drafting Social Security legislation next week will use as a foundation the program that President Reagan submitted to Congress last May, only to be met with strong bipartisan opposition.

title: Franklin Pierce Home Burns
description: Fire early this morning destroyed thehouse on Sout h Main Street here where Franklin Pierce spent his last three years. Mr. Pierce, the only New Hampshire politician to become President, li ved at the house until his death in 1869 at the age of 65.

title: 'HUNGRY I REUNION'
description: THE great days of the hungry i, Enrico Banducci's San Francisco nightclub that introduced Mort Sahl and other offbeat entertainers to the public in the 50's and 60's, are vividly and movingly recalled in ''The hungry i Reunion,'' producer-director Thomas Cohen's documentary about a reunion of hungry i performers in the summer of 1980. The feature will be shown at the Paramount Theater today at 9:30 P.M. and Monday at 3 P.M. in the ''Movies for Cynics'' series, a small festival sponsored by the Film Society of Lincoln Center as a curtain-raiser for the 19th New York Film Festival that will start next Friday.

title: Arrests Exceed 900 In Coast Nuclear Protest
description: Dwindling ranks of antinuclear protesters, estimated at 1,500 in all, continued their attempt to blockade the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant for a third day today, but sheriff's deputies cleared the way for workers by arresting demonstrators, increasing the number of those jailed to more than 900.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL MILWAUKEE
description: (AL) - Named George Bamberger coordinator of player develop- ment, Ray Poitevint director of player procurement and Bruce Manno coordina- tor of minor league operations.; BASKET [ TEXT OMITTED FROM SOURCE ] BALL DENVER (NBA) - Traded Ron Valen- tine, forward, to Washington for future considerations. GOLDEN STATE (NBA) - Named Ken Macker executive vice president.; COLLEGE C.W. POST - Named Debbie Intorcia volleyball coach.; FOOTBALL MINNESOTA (NFC) - Placed Steve

title: DUTCH IN THE VANGUARD OF EUROPE'S MISSILE SKEPTICS
description: Sometime in the next few months, the Netherlands will give its partners in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization a message that will neither please nor surprise them. In one form or other - probably somewhere between postponement and refusal - it will tell them that it cannot commit itself to installing the 48 cruise missiles that were its share of the nuclear modernization program agreed to in 1979.

title: FOUR AMERICAN SOPRANOS TAKE ON THE PASSIONATE ROLES AT THE CITY OPERA
description: FOUR passionate soprano roles at the New York City Opera this weekend should generate enough heat to steam up every window in Lincoln Center. Tonight and Sunday afternoon, Marilyn Zschau portrays Puccini's ''Tosca,'' a heroine undone by circumstance and her own jealousy. Tomorrow at 2 P.M., Ashley Putnam as Mary, Queen of Scots, and Maralin Niska as Queen Elizabeth I of England face each other in Donizetti's ''Maria Stuarda,'' -a confrontation that leads to blo odshed.

title: SIMON AND GARFUNKEL TAKE ON CENTRAL PARK
description: SIMON and Garfunkel are back from what Paul Simon calls ''the boulevard of broken duos.'' At least they are back for an evening, for a free concert tomorrow at 6:30 P.M. on the Great Lawn in Central Park. The rain date is Sunday. The event is expected to attract thousands of people; it would be best to arrive early.

title: NOTION OF REVIVING GOLD STANDARD DEBATED SERIOUSLY IN WASHINGTON
description: The gold standard, a time-honored bulwark against inflation but an idea that most economists have abandoned as a relic of a less sophisticated past, is suddenly the subject of serious economic policy discussion.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 18, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: SEAGRAM GO LTD reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $6,802,000 and interest income of $180,187,000 made operating income $285,632, or $8.14 a shr; also after extraordinary credits of $1,238,125, and a gain from foreign currency translation of $35,856,000... C-After income from discontinued operations of $68,105,000 made operating income $142,447,000 or $4.06 a shr; also after income from extraordinary credit of $15,770,000 and a loss from foreig currency translation of $13,564,000; all amounts are in U.S. currency

title: JETS ARE UNDERDOGS
description: The Giants take on a role unusual for them in their next game. They will be the favorites, by 3 points, Sunday against the New Orleans Saints at Giants Stadium (Channel 2, 4 P.M.).

title: U.S. GEO IS SOLD TO KNAPP
description: Geo magazine, the glossy ''human geography'' publication with the lime green cover, was sold yesterday by Gruner & Jahr to the Knapp Communications Corporation, the publishers of Architectural Digest and Bon Appetit.

title: The Promise of Awacs
description: There is understandable alarm in the Reagan Administration as it bids for time to justify supplying Saudi Arabia with $8.5 billion worth of top-of-the-line weapons. A building majority of Congress now recognizes that the sale of five Awacs, plus fuel tanks and potent missiles for F-15's, risks a further arms race in the Middle East, reduces Israel's military superiority and only weakens American bargaining power in the region.

title: NATO CHIEF GLUM ON ALLIES' RESOLVE
description: The chances that the NATO allies will raise military spending and enhance their ability to meet a Soviet invasion with conventional forces ''do not look very good,'' Gen. Bernard W. Rogers, the alliance's supreme commander, said today.

title: Issue and Debate; PROVIDING SHELTER FOR NEW YORK CITY'S HOMELESS
description: Settling on stoops and in vestibules, on park benches and in subway entrances, New York City's tens of thousands of homeless men and women are too numerous and widespread to ignore. As a group they are unsightly, dirty and disheveled, given to unsocial if not aberrant behavior. Many were formerly patients at state psychiatric hospitals.

title: Chargers Trade Jefferson
description: The San Diego Chargers traded John Jefferson, the all-pro receiver, to the Green Bay Packers for draft choices and other considerations.Page A33.

title: OPEC Price Discussions
description: Indonesia's oil minister, Subroto, the current president of OPEC, said today that he foresaw a ''50-50 chance'' that the oil cartel would hold a price-setting meeting before its regularly scheduled meeting Dec. 7 in Abu Dhabi.

title: LEGAL ABORTIONS ARE STILL IMPERILED
description: To the Editor:

title: SONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The U.S. dollar amounts shown were translated from the yen at the rate of 233 yens equals one U.S. dollar; B-Net is after pretax foreign exchange loss of $34,695,000 compared with a gain of $21,094,000 in the yr-ago qr... C-Nine mos net is after pretax foreign exchange gains of $1,090,000 in the latest yr and $5,069,000 for the yr-ago 9 mos

title: F.C.C. ASKS END OF FAIRNESS DOCTRINE
description: The Federal Communications Commission today urged Congress to abolish the rules that compel broadcasters to provide air time to politicians, opportunities to reply to attacks and to examine opposing sides of significant events.

title: REVOLUTIONARY ENSEMBLE REUNITING
description: THE Revolutionary Ensemble, a jazz trio of violin, bass and drums, built a worldwide following during its seven years of existence. It disbanded four years ago, having developed a remarkably responsive group interplay and wholly original style - without ever enjoying substantial commercial rewards. The violinist Leroy Jenkins, the bassist Sirone and the drummer Jerome Cooper went their separate ways and have been active participants in j az z as soloist and group leaders.

title: Belgian Jobless Rate
description: Belgium's unemployment rate, based onth e number of jobless drawing unemployment benefits, rose to 9.7 pe rcent at mid-September, from 9.5 percenct at the end of August and 7. 8 percent at the end of August 1980, according to unadjusted fi gures released today by the national employment office. The number of jobless was 400,833, against 396,419 and 316,494, respectively, th e office said. This is the first time unemployment has topped 40 0,000, it added.

title: WASHINGTON TALK BRIEFING
description: O NE of the first blows struck by the White House in the contest over selling Awacs radar planes to Saudi Arabia was sharp-edged and counterproductive. This is the assessment of surprised Senate Republicans who have complained privately at the sort of Administration pressure put on Senator Bob Packwood, the Oregon Republican who is leading the Awacs opposition.

title: By Sports of The Times; The Matador Was the Bull
description: THE philosophy is as old as boxing itself, the philosophy of the matador and the bull. In grimy gyms all over the world, gray

title: M.I.T. Faculty Debates Taking $7 Million Gift
description: Faculty members at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology are debating an offer of $7.5 million from a Connecticut industrialist. The gift is controversial because acceptance would obligate the school to offer faculty appointments to senior scientists hired and paid by an independent institute created by the industrialist.

title: Index; International
description: Dutch, balking at missiles, mir- ror Europe's Unease A2 NATO commander pessimistic on allies' military spending A3 Iran executes 19 more foes of re- gime A4 Around the World A5 Smuggled Chinese document tells of life in prison camps A6 Awacs resolution and statements by Haig and Senators A10 Government/Politics Environmental agency terms bird pesticide level safe A12 Prosperous Grand Rapids is honoring its favorite son A12 Postal rate agency again rejects bid to raise postage rate A16 Republicans following Reagan plan on Social Security A22 How Reagan plan on adjusting benefits would work A22 Democrats to meet in Philadel- phia next June A24 Adirondack Park dispute yielding to compromise efforts B1 Comptroller asks Carey to post- pone some s tate borrowing B4 Washington Talk Briefing A18 When it comes to books, Washing- ton likes the facts A18 The National Rifle Association vs. the U.S. Government A18 Q&A with Joseph A. Califano on Reagan and the Great Society A18 General Around the Nation A12 People's Temple case goes to jury in California A13 Dr. Michael Baden gets a new job in Suffolk County B2 98 seized in drug sweep outside city schools B3 Health/Science System tested to ease shock of space shuttle's blastoff A13 Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Tour of Chester A. Arthur's New York C24 Big book fair on Fifth Avenue Sunday C28 Theater: Broadway C2

title: HOUSE THREATENS A UNESCO CUTOFF
description: The House voted 372 to 19 today to cut off United States financial support for Unesco if the United Nations agency adopts a policy of fostering official controls over the press, particularly in third world countries.

title: U.S. TRADE SURPUS OFF FOR 2D QUARTER
description: The nation's current account - the broadest measure of financial dealings with the rest of the world - showed a $1.1 billion surplus in the second quarter of this year, down about two-thirds from the first quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Jazz Benefit at Hurley
description: Jazz musicians from the United States and abroad will appear at an outdoor festival tomorrow, from 1 P.M. until dark at the Creative Music Studio, off Route 28 in Hurley, N.Y. The performers will include John Abercrombie, Chick Corea, Anthony Braxton, Baikida Carroll, Dave Holland, Howard Johnson, Lee Konitz, Pat Metheny and Miroslav Vitous.

title: Night Flower
description: Night owls are a common enough species in New York City, but so too, at this time of year, are night flowers. Around sundown, as TV moves into its prime time, the evening primrose blooms.

title: Chad and Libya Report Gains Against Rebels
description: Government and Libyan troops drove guerrillas of former Defense Minister Hissen Habre out of an eastern Chadian town, it was reported here today.

title: DISPARATE CASTILES
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Allis-Chalmers Corp. said its credit unit had completed a $100 million, three-year revolving credit agreement with 16 U.S. banks, including Citibank as agent.

title: British Divers Recover 7 Gold Bars From Sea
description: A team of 12 divers recovered seven gold bars today from a torpedoed British cruiser that sank in the Barents Sea in 1942 with as much as $83 million in bullion aboard, the Defense Ministry announced.

title: The Scope of the Tax Series
description: This 14-part series has looked into the direct and indirect effects that the new tax law will have on all facets of American life: how it could influence choices of jobs and investments, alter family relationships, affect charitable giving and encourage new savings.

title: CUSHIONING SYSTEM TESTED FOR SPACE SHUTTLE
description: A water-spray system designed to cushion the space shuttle Columbia against a shock wave in blastoff has been successfully tested, increasing the chances that scientific instruments can be sent aloft on its Oct. 9 mission.

title: A $1 Billion Credit For Dow Chemical
description: The Dow Chemical Company has acquired a $1 billion line of credit from 22 United States and foreign banks to help pay off about the same amount of short-term debt, the company announced today. Terms of the accord were not disclosed, but European banking sources said that the loan would carry a rate linked to the London interbank offered rate.

title: RECITAL: VIOLIN AND PIANO DUO
description: INNOVATIVE recital programs can do two things - either surprise us with their unknown or forgotten treasures or confirm our suspicions that rarely heard music is rarely heard for good reason. The violin and piano duo of Charles Libove and Nina Lugovoy at the Abraham Goodman House on Wednesday evening did a little of both.

title: THE GUN LOBBY VS. THE GOVERNMENT
description: When G.R. Dickerson became chief enforcer of the nation's firearms laws in early 1979, he raised a white flag and stepped gingerly into the sights of the National Rifle Association to talk peace.

title: First Test for Before Dawn
description: The uncertainties of the race track and the fragility of the thoroughbred make those who train and ride horses prone to understatement. They call a prolific winner ''a nice horse who can run a little,'' an older runner who wins under grueling weights ''an honest sort,'' and a brilliant young colt only ''a prospect,'' at least until he makes it to the Kentucky Derby.

title: HAROLD COFFIN
description: Harold Coffin, a former humor columnist for The Associated Press, died Saturday of a heart attack in Capitola, a small town near Santa Cruz, south of San Francisco.

title: LABOR GROUP GIRDS FOR CAPITAL RALLY
description: Excitement, long hours, the scurrying of men and women from desk to desk, the constant ringing of telephones, talk of buses, trains and cars: This is the atmosphere in Room 311 of the huge, marble headquarters of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, the planning center for Solidarity Day this Saturday.

title: MATT LYNCH
description: Matt Lynch, president of the Tennessee State Labor Council for 33 years, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack.

title: DIMINISHED LURES
description: To the Editor:

title: Blue Injures Thumb
description: The San Francisco Giants, in the middle of a division race in the National League West, have a new injury to be concerned with.

title: UNION CHIEF DENOUNCES U.S. PLAN TO CUT MINE SAFETY FUND SHARPLY
description: A Congressional reco mmendation that Federal mine safety funds be cut by as much as 50 per cent requires an ''expression of outrage'' by coal miners, Sam M. Church Jr., president of the United Mine Workers, said th is morning.

title: Bach at St. Joseph's
description: A Bach Festival will open the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble's 1981-82 season tomorrow at 8 P.M. at St. Joseph's Church, 371 Avenue of the Americas, at Waverly Place.

title: CRASH KILLS EX-CANDY OFFICIAL
description: Robert D. Heath, former president of the company that manufactures Heath Bar candy, died yesterday in a two-vehicle accident. He was 53 years old. Mr. Heath, president of L.S. Heath & Sons, Robinson, Ill., for 18 months beginning in December 1969, was a grandson of the company's founder. He is survived by his wife, Jean, and three sons.

title: PRESIDENT TO SEEK DEFERRALS IN RISES FOR 8 KEY BENEFITS
description: President Reagan plans to seek a deferral of cost-of-living increases in at least eight benefit programs, from food stamps to Social Security to veterans' pensions, and he wants a 12 percent cutback in nonmilitary appropriations for the next fiscal year, Administration officials said today.

title: Rape Suspect Didn't Receive Resuscitation From Officers
description: One of three arresting officers testified today at a coroner's inquest here that they ''didn't think it was necessary'' to perform cardiopulmonary resuscitation when they noticed a rape suspect was having difficulty breathing, but they did use an ammonia capsule and summon paramedics, he said.

title: JULIUS HERFORD
description: Julius Herford, a teacher of Lukas Foss, Robert Shaw, Roger Wagner and a number of other conductors - particularly choral specialists - died yesterday at his home in Bloomington, Ind.

title: 'THE FRENCH LIEUTENANT'S WOMAN'
description: WE are in Dorset, Thomas Hardy country. More specifically we are in the South English fishing village of Lyme Regis, on Lyme Bay, and, to be more specific still, we are on the quay, looking out over the ancient, handsome, serpentine seawall known as the Cobb. The weather is appropriately dour and the sea beyond the Cobb looks thick and heavy with time, its movements having less to do with weather than with the momentum it shares with the planets.

title: AGENCY SAYS BIRDS IN WEST DON'T POSE PESTICIDE DANGER
description: The pesticide levels being found in game birds in the West are well below the danger point for human health, the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: INCOME UP BY 1.1% IN AUGUST
description: Americans' personal income in August rose more than a full percentage point for the second consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: THE MAILMAN COMETH
description: The most widely distributed computer letter of all time may have been sent by Ronald Reagan (My election to serve you and our country is the highest honor I will ever have ...) to what appears to be every American over six months of age living between Nome and Key West, including prison inmates, ex-CETA jobholders, welfare mothers and Democrats.

title: IRANIAN FIRING SQUAD EXECUTES 19 FOES OF REGIME
description: The Iranian state radio said today that a firing squad had executed 19 more opponents of the Islamic Government, among them a man whose mother had reported him to the authorities.

title: Holmes Plans March Defense
description: Don King and Sam Glass, the copromoters, and Harry Wald, president of Caesars Palace, confirmed today at a news conference that undefeated Larry Holmes would defend his World Boxing Council heavyweight title against the undefeated No. 1 contender, Gerry Cooney, here sometime next March.

title: HILL BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 2
