description: B-Net income; 1981 fiscal figures include a loss from the disposal of the company's swimming pool and irrigation equipmen of $562,548 and a loss of $174,830 for similar operations in preceding yr

title: BRUNCH GOAL: CHIC IDENTITY, NOT JUST FOOD
description: Sunday brunch in New York is quite a bit more than a weekend meal at leisure. It assumes, as do so many of our urban appurtenances, a measure of social significance, and so the selection of where one eats brunch, where one makes a brunch appearance, becomes in many cases far more important than the quality of the food to be consumed because in a real sense when you choose your brunch you choose your caste, you opt for a certain set. If you must have a late, late breakfast, then why not have it with other young single people like yourself at the Spring Street Bar or Central Falls in SoHo, or at Boodles?

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE PONDERS FUTURE WITHOUT POWERFUL, CONSERVATIVE PUBLISHER
description: In a memorial service this afternoon, William Loeb was consigned to his Lord by a Baptist preacher, and the question in New Hampshire now is what his passage will mean to the secular affairs of the state he dominated for 35 years but never lived in.

title: RESOLUTION ON AWACS AND REMARKS AT CAPITOL
description: Following is the text of a resolution in the Senate expressing opposition to the Reagan Administration's proposal to sell military equipment to Saudi Arabia. It is followed by excerpts from remarks today by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and excerpts from the responses of four members of the panel: Senators John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio; Bob Packwood, Republican of Oregon; Rudy Boschwitz, Republican of Minnesota, and Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware. Resolution Proposed in Senate

title: MOSCOW ORDERS POLES TO CONTROL 'AN TI-SOVIETISM'
description: The Soviet Union today delivered a harshwarning to Po land's leaders to silence what it called an ''unbridled'' anti-Soviet campaign being waged by the independent trade union, Solidarity, and by Polish dissidents.

title: Equitable Appoints A New President
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, founded in 1859 and now the country's third-largest life insurance company, has taken the first step in determining its forthcoming management succession by naming John B. Carter, 47 ye ars old, as president, effective April 1. Mr. Carter was all but ass ured that he will subsequently become the next chief executive officer of the company.

title: Pop Jazz; BOB STEWART AND A NIGHT TO BRING NEW GLORY TO THE TUBA
description: IN 1939, Jimmy Blanton joined Duke Ellington's Orchestra and revolutionized the way the string bass was played in jazz groups. Before Mr. Blanton, the bass was usually ''walked'' in a continuous series of quarter notes as an element, along with piano, guitar and drums, of the rhythm section. Mr. Blanton showed that the string bass need not be limited to a supporting role, that it could also be used to improvise harmonic patterns and melodic lines like a trumpet or a saxophone.

title: TEXAS ENERGIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Texas Energies Inc became a publicly owned company in December 1980

title: FESTIVAL SALUTES BLACK CLASSICS OF DANCE
description: A dancegoers fondest memories would have to include the small black modern dance companies that enlivened the New York dance scene from the mid-1950's through the 60's. The intimate theaters and auditoriums where they danced vibrated with works of deep commitment, performed by a core of charismatic dancers who brought to an accomplished technique an attack that made each step seem as if it were the last and best spin, jump or fall in the city. Alvin Ailey's ''Revelations,'' first performed in 1960 at the 92d Street Y, is probably the best known of those works.

title: Pirelli Buys Galite
description: The Pirelli Cable Corporation, a producer of electrical wire and cable, said it had acquired Galite Inc. of Wallingford, Conn., for an undisclosed price.

title: ALBANY CALLS OFF SPRINGBOKS MATCH
description: Mayor Erastus Corning 2d today canceled a scheduled rugby match featuring the South African national team, the Springboks, after Governor Carey said there was ''imminent danger of riot.''

title: G.O.P. MODERATES MAY REBEL OVER ARMS CUT
description: About two dozen moderate Republicans from Frost Belt states threatened today to vote against President Reagan's next round of budget cuts unless military spending was cut by $9 billion in the fiscal year 1982, $7 billion more than the President's latest proposal.

title: Notes on People; Steve Ross Welcomes and Is Welcomed
description: You would have thought no one had ever come home before, judging by the welcome back party for Steve Ross.

title: CHAMBER: STRAVINSKY AND HAYDN
description: CONCERTGOERS today are so accustomed to having musical importance defined by big Romantic scores of the 19th-century that the Haydn-Stravinsky concerts being offered this week by the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society must inevitably strike some people as disappointingly insubstantial. So much the worse for such conditioning of musical responses. The music by the two composers on Wednesday night's program in Alice Tully Hall prodded the mind and stimulated the senses in a way that could hardly fail to delight any civilized 18th- or 20th-century sensibility.

title: DOW TUMBLES 11.51 CLOSING AT 840.09
description: News of a sharp drop in housing starts sent stock prices on the New York Stock Exchange down yesterday to their lowest level in almost 16 months and increased investors' concern that the nation was headed for a recession.

title: SENATE DEFEATS MOVE TO END SUGAR SUBSIDIES
description: The old coalition of farm state senators regrouped today as the Senate rejected a consumer-backed amendment that would have prohibited price supports for sugar.

title: AGENCY AGAIN REJECTS A BID TO RAISE POSTAGE RATE TO 20
description: The Postal Rate Commission, for the third time this year, has turned down a request by the Postal Service to raise the basic postage rate for letters to 20 cents from 18 cents.The Postal Service's nine-member board of g overnors is scheduled tomeet next Tuesday and could impose the 20 cen ts anyway, providing it can muster a unanimous vote to do so.

title: NONFICTION GETS VOTES OF BUYERS
description: Whether they're tucked in a briefcase for whiling away a commuter's time or piled on a bedside table for before-lights-out reading, in Washington or New York, the novels are likely to be the same: James Clavell's ''Noble House,'' John Irving's ''The Hotel New Hampshire'' and Stephen King's ''Cujo.''

title: KO CH REPORT SAYS CITY'S SERVICES HAVE IMPROVED
description: The Koch Administration yesterday released a new management report that finds New York City streets cleaner, taxis newer, finances more stable and overall city services improved.

title: Matthew Thomas, 55, Announcer for WQXR
description: Matthew Thomas, an announcer on WQXR AM-FM since 1966, died of a brain aneurysm at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center yesterday. He was 55 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: Report Says Canadian Bought 50% of Rockies
description: A one-half interest in the Colorado Rockies franchise has been sold by Peter Gilbert to a Canadian businessman, newspaper reports said today.

title: The Economy
description: New construction of single-family houses fell in August to the lowest level in more than two decades, the Commerce Department reported. It said that overall housing starts had hit the lowest rate since February 1975. High interest rates were blamed. The Federal Reserve Board said U.S. factories operated at 79.2 percent of capacity in August, the lowest level in almost a year. The reports were consistent with other indicators of a slumping economy. (Page D1.)

title: WOLF, HOWARD B, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes tax credit of $44,972 or 4 cents a shr

title: JOHNSTONE PACES RANGER ROUT
description: The victory was the first of the exhibition season for the Rangers, who lost by 4-1 last night to Helsinki IFK, one of Finland's better teams, in Helsinki. The Rangers play three more games in Sweden, including one Sunday night against the Washington Capitals, before returning to the United States next Thursday. And though exhibition games are rarely memorable events, Johnstone and two rookies, Reijo Ruotsalainen, a defenseman, and Steve Weeks, a goalie, are likely to remember their first Ranger game in Stockholm.

title: Malaysian Rebels Surrender
description: The Malaysian authorities announced today that eight Communist guerrillas had surrendered and taken advantage of a Government amnesty.

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE LOWER
description: Short- and long-term interest rates fell yesterday, though credit market participants said they were not convinced that the declines of the last week would last for long. They stressed that dealers and investors were cautious, and that uncertainty was the prevailing sentiment.

title: Barclays Plans Sale of Notes
description: The Barclays American Corporation, the United States subsidiary of the British-based Barclays Bank International, said today that it would file with the Securities and Exchange Commission a public offering of $200 million of zero-coupon senior notes due in 1990.

title: 2 British Parties Differ on Arms Plan
description: Britain's Liberal Party today revealed differences with its new Social Democratic Party partners on military policy less than 24 hours after voting in favor of an electoral alliance.

title: TAX LAW: GETTING FULL BENEFIT
description: For individual taxpayers, there is an opportunity to save more than $550 billion in taxes over the next five years, according to Congressional budget analysts, but the burden is on the individual to do so. That is the clear message from tax experts who have pored over all 292 pages of provisions in the new tax law, known as the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981.

title: Baby Gets Surgery Her Parents Opposed
description: Surgeons operated today on a hydrocephalic 15-month-old girl and successfully relieved the pressure of fluid on her brain after her parents failed in court to stop the operation on religious grounds.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; FILM CYNICS ON WEST SIDE
description: A sardonic look at the way things are is offered in ''Movies for Cynics,'' a series of American films being shown at the Paramount Theater, Broadway at 61st Street, through Tuesday as part of the 19th New York Film Festival. Today's batch includes a couple of White House farces - at 2 P.M., ''First Family,'' (1980), about an American Presidential family, featuring Bob Newhart, Gilda Radner, Madeline Kahn and Harvey Korman, and at 4:30, ''Winter Kills'' (1979), about the aftermath of a President's assassination, with Jeff Bridges, John Huston, Richard Boone, Dorothy Malone and Anthony Perkins. Charlie Chaplin's ''The Great Dictator'' (1940) is on at 7 P.M, and at 9:30 ''The hungry i Reunion'' (1981), which records a reunion at the San Francisco nightclub that spawned such satirists as Lenny Bruce and Mort Sahl. Tickets are $2.50 for each matinee film, $3.50 for evening showings. Information: 877-1800, extension 489.

title: Market Place; Older People: Lens Potential
description: WALL STREET, always interested in a concept that will sell shares, has seized upon the fact that some companies will do better as the population grows older. For example, the Street has sold customers on shares of nursing home operators and on those of Hart Schaffner & Marx, which has been talked up as appealing to business people who are entering middle years.

title: A ONE-PARTY TOWN AND ITS OUTSIDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATS TO MEET IN PHILADELPHIA NEXT JUNE
description: After quieting Congressional fea rs that the event would h urt more than it would help, the Democratic Party's leadership de cided today to hold a national party conference before next year's e lections.

title: CHESTER ARTHUR TOUR OF OLD NEW YORK
description: There are two New York City buildings where Presidents of the United States took their oath of office. One is Federal Hall on Wall Street, with a handsome columned portico and a statue of George Washington on the front. The other is 123 Lexington Avenue, which now houses the Kalustyan Orient Expert Trading Corporation and the pungent odors from its bins of spice.

title: Recital at the Galleria
description: Music by Mozart, Bach, Prokofiev and Hindemith will be performed by a pianist and flutist today at noon in the atrium of the Galleria at 115 East 57th Street.

title: NEWMONT SOLICITATION SAID TO WIN OIL INTEREST
description: The Newmont Mining Company, quietly extending invitations to a select group of wealthy American corporations to save it from a possible takeover, has received expressions of interest from two big California oil companies, sources close to the discussions said yesterday.

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
DEWITT J. PAUL, 79, WAS CHIEF EXECUTIVE FOR BENEFICIAL CORP.
description: DeWitt J. Paul, former board chairman and chief executive officer of the Beneficial Corporation, a diversified holding company, died Tuesday at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 79 years old and had previously lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Bourne, Islanders Still Apart
description: Bob Bourne did not sign a contract today. That was the only news emerging from an Islander training camp at which about 50 players took an early-morning skate and the rookies prepared for tonight's exhibition game with the Ranger rookies at the Playland rink in Rye.

title: Notes on People; Convicted Murderer, a Poet, to Get New Trial
description: A poet who is a contributor to the current issue of The New Yorker has been released from the Maine State Prison on $10,000 bail pending his new trial on charges of killing his wife.

title: Soviet Asks Egyptians To Leave in One Week
description: - The Soviet Union retaliated today for the expulsion of its diplomats and advisers from Cairo by ordering Egyptian military personnel to leave Moscow within seven days, Tass, the official press agency, said.

title: Guidry Back to His '78 Form
description: Ron Guidry feels good these days, which means opposing hitters have a bad case of deja vu. Guidry recognizes the symptoms.

title: THE U.S. AND CHINA
description: Some people always think ''Communist China and the capitalist United States would be irreconcilable.'' The relationship between different social systems is indeed a question to be explored and considered carefully, for the question arose right from the day of victory in the Russian October Revolution led by Lenin, and it will remain for a long time to come. This is historically inevitable and no one can write it off even if he tries. However, a serious study of the theory of Communism and a concrete analysis of the changes in postwar international relations will show that the above-quoted view is not well-founded.

title: Money Funds' Assets Increase Increase
description: The assets of the nation's money market mutual funds climbed $3.42 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the 16th consecutive weekly increase, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. Investors a re attracted to the higher yields paid by the money funds, compar ed with other investment instruments such as six-month savings certi ficates.

title: FOES OF AWACS SALE ASSERT 51 SENATORS BACK THEIR EFFORT
description: Opponents of President Reagan's proposal to sell $8.5 billion worth of air warfare equipment to Saudi Arabia said today that a majority of the Senate had lined up against the sale.

title: News Analysis
description: The first salvos of the long-anticipated debate on the sale of Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia have now been heard, and they seem to have put the Reagan Administration on the defensive.

title: The Evening Hours
description: N O one can deny that Frank Hunter has led an interesting life. He was a Wimbledon tennis champion in the 1920's, owned a string of newspapers, and was president of 21 Brands for 35 years before he retired in 1962. He also had a collection of 601 hunting and fishing trophies, all earned, which he sold for $400,000 because of space limitations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have been a supporter of the President's program, but there is a difference between taking our fair share of budget cuts and gutting aid to the cities.'' - Mayor William H. Hudnut III of Indianapolis. (A26:1.)

title: HAMMERMILL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 6
Notes on People; Cats on His Mind
description: The secret is out: Skip Morrow, author of the best-selling books ''The Official I Hate Cats Book'' and its current sequel, ''The Second Official I Hate Cats Book,'' is a closet ailurophile.

title: BLOUNT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May

title: PHILLIES DEFEAT METS, 3-2
description: Dickie Noles won his first game of the season when the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Mets, 3-2, last night at Shea Stadium. Noles gave up three singles and struck out six in the seven scoreless innings he pitched. Jerry Reed and Sparky Lyle relieved and allowed two runs in the eighth on a pinch-hit single by Ellis Valentine. Then Lyle needed last-out help from Ron Reed, who struck out Dave Kingman. The save was Ron Reed's seventh of the year.

title: TO STING AN APIARIST
description: To the Editor:

title: KEVEX CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
Northgate Ends Patino Purchase
description: Northgate Exploration Ltd. said that it had completed the purchase from Patino N.V. of all of Patino's Canadian mining assets and Patino's 34 percent interest in Edper Equities Ltd., which, in turn, holds 48 percent in Brascan Ltd.

title: CHAIRMAN IS NAMED AT ASHLAND OIL
description: Ashland Oil Inc., the nation's largest independent oil refiner, has named John R. Hall, 48, chairman and chief executive officer. He will succeed Orin E. Atkins, 57, who will retire Sept. 30 ''to pursue personal business interests'' and become a consultant to the company for the next three years.

title: LUNCH CUTS RAISE LEGAL ISSUE
description: Democratic members of a House education subcommittee warned today that reducing the size of federally subsidized school lunches, as proposed by the Agriculture Department, might be illegal. The Representatives said that the proposal, which would eliminate requirements that the meals provide one-third of a child's daily nutritional needs, could violate terms of the budget package approvedby Congress in August. The budget legislation asked the Agriculture Secretary to investigate possible savings in the lunch program''without impairing the nutritional va lue of the meals.''

title: SMUGGLED CHINESE DOCUMENT TELLS OF LIFE IN PRISON CAMPS
description: A Chinese dissident has smuggled out of the prison camp where he is held a document that provides an account of life in the penal camps where prisoners receive ''education through labor.''

title: The Region; NJ Transit Cites Rise in Ridership
description: NEWARK (UPI) - Improved service on NJ Transit's buses and trains has led to increased ridership despite sharp rises in fares, according to the state agency. In his monthly report to NJ Transit's board of directors, Jerome Premo, the agency's executive director, cited ''an encouraging picture'' that shows the state's ''investment in transit is beginningto pay off and the established stereotypes ab out terrible service have less and less truth to them.''

title: Air Oregon Continues Operations
description: Air Oregon, a commuter airline, said yesterday that it would continue operations despite an attempt by Justin Colin, a New York financier, to shut it down.

title: CHRISTOPHER ANDREWS
description: Christopher E. Andrews, vice president in charge of administration of Jaguar Rover Triumph Inc. of Leonia, N.J., died Sept. 9 at Doctors Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: MUCKRAKING EDITOR A CONSTANT BARB TO MRS. GANDHI
description: Since the return to power of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, nothing has been as upsetting as the writings of Arun Shourie.

title: Notes on People; Success Story: Daddy Warbucks Buys Real Estate
description: Life does, indeed, imitate art, in the view of Reid Shelton, the actor who created the role of the billionaire Daddy Warbucks in the Broadway hit ''Annie.''

title: Going Out Guide
description: DROPPING

title: BOWL AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DR. YORIHIKO KUMASAKA
description: Dr. Yorihiko Kumasaka, an attending psychiatrist at Kings County Hospital-Downstate Medical Center, died of a heart attack Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: HILLER BUYS AN OPTION ON 17% OF KAISER STEEL
description: A California investor acquired the option yesterday to buy 17 percent of the Ka iser Steel Corporation for $50 a share, a total of about $59 mil lion.

title: A THOUGHT FOR YOUR PENNIES
description: To the Editor:

title: PLANTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $193,000

title: Du Pont Unit Plan
description: The E.I. Du Pont de Nemours & Company said that its German subsidiary was considering shutting down production of dacron polyester filament yarn at the Unentrop works near Hamm, West Germany, because of losses.

title: TEXT OF THE SOVIET MESSAGE TO POLAND
description: Following is the text of the Soviet message to Poland's leaders published in Warsaw today, as translated by the English-language service of the official Polish news agency P.A.P.:

title: PATENTS
description: An electronic voting system that can be used to query audiences was patented this week for the General Electric Company, Schenectady, N.Y., by three staff members. Persons in the audience can answer questions by pressing buttons on hand-carried radio instruments, and their votes can be counted and displayed.

title: A.M.C. Sets '82 Price Rise
description: The American Motors Corporation said today that it was raising the prices of its 1982 cars and Jeeps an average of 3.8 percent from comparable 1981 models.

title: Notes on People; Walter Annenberg Pays His Own Way
description: As the multimillionaire publisher of TV Guide and former publisher of other magazines and newspapers, Walter L. Annenberg is a man who needn't bother hiself with some of the more mundane concerns of other mortals.

title: Sports People; End of a Career
description: Madeline Manning, the American record-holder in the women's 800-meter run and a three-time Olympian, has decided to abandon her running career and perhaps have a second child. Miss Manning, who is 33 years old, won a gold medal in the 800 meters at the 1968 Olympics in Mexico City and a silver medal in the 1,600-meter relay at the 1972 Games in Munich.

title: Attacks in Germany Lead U.S.  To Increase Security Abroad
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - Security at United States Government installations overseas is being increased as a result of the latest of 40 terrorist attacks against American interests over the past year, the Defense Department says.

title: CBS to Stop Issuing Li st Prices on Records
description: CBS Records has abolished the traditional practice of publishing suggested list prices for its products.

title: No Easing for Europe Steel
description: European steel producers will not be given special clearance to sell their products in the United States at prices lower than the trigger price, the maximum price at which steel may be imported, a Commerce Department source said yesterday. Although th e issue was raised when Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige met yesterday with Viscount Etienne Davignon, industrial commissioner for the European Industrial Commission, the European representativ e did not insist on any special arrangement, a source said.

title: SEARCHING FOR ROMANCE IN THE LAND OF SINGLES
description: For many people, being unattached in New York City is a little like diving off the high board for the first time as a child: It's a lot easier to appreciate when it's over and you are laughing about it with your friends than when it's happening and you are stranded in midair.

title: Sports People; A Break for Martin
description: Richie Phillips, the lawyer for the Major League Umpires Association, said he would withdraw a complaint against Manager Billy Martin of the Oakland A's and ask that a warrant for Martin's arrest in Toronto be dissolved.

title: Around the Nation; 6 Nazis Convicted in Plot To Bomb Greensboro
description: A Federal court jury tonight found six self-avowed Nazis guilty of conspiring to blow up parts of the city of Green sboro last year. A judge sentenced three, whom he calledthe leaders, to prison terms.

title: Allied Plan Vote
description: Allied Supermarkets Inc., which operates 80 supermarkets in five states under the names, Scott, Humpty and Ideal, and one K mart food store, said its stockholders had approved the plan of reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act submitted by management. The plan would give unsecured creditors a choice of receiving 30 percent of their allowed claims in cash or a combination of cash and stock.

title: Youth Fired Upon In a Schoolyard
description: A youth was shot at in the schoolyard of the Edgar D. Shimer Intermediate School at 142-10 Linden Boulevard in Jamaica, according to the District Attorney's office in Queens. Two other youths were arrested later.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ADDRESS BY REAGAN
description: Following are excerpts from President Reagan's address to the National Federation of Republican Women in Denver yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Output Down For OPEC
description: Oil production by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries fell nearly 25 percent, to 19.1 million barrels a day, in mid-September from 25.4 million in September 1980, an authoritative Paris-based trade publication reported today.

title: APPLIED DEVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $392,000...C-After loss from discontinued operations of $1,436,000...D-After loss from discontinued operations of $1,019,000

title: Renault's Volvo Stake
description: Regie Nationale des Usines Renault, France's state-owned auto maker, has increased its stake in Sweden's Volvo Car Corporation to 15 percent from 10 percent, Volvo France said today. Renault paid 170 million Swedish crowns, or about $31 million at current exchange rates, for a 10 percent stake in Volvo Car in 1979 and has now converted half the 160,000 convertible bonds it also bought then into shares in the company.

title: MISDIRECTED OUTRAGE OVER THE ELECTION DELAY
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: 68 ARE ARRESTED IN 2D DRUG RAID OUTSIDE SCHOOLS
description: The Police Department's new narcotics street-enforcement unit made another sweep of drug pushers near public schools throughout New York City yesterday. They arrested 68 persons for selling and possessing drugs, mostly marijuana and a variety of pills.

title: BOOMING ORLANDO WONDERING IF GROWTH IS WORTH THE TROUBLE
description: A little statistical music, please: The new, $300 million airport opens tomorrow. Walt Disney's $800 million Environmental Prototype Community of Tomorrow opens a year from next month, the 10th anniversary of Walt Disney World, which is next door and which draws 13 million visitors a year and is expected to draw 22 million when Epcot, as it is called, is completed. MCA Studios just announced it is going to open a $200 million duplicate of its Los Angeles attraction, Universal Studios, on 300 acres south of town. A $500 million amusement park called Little England will open next year. Sea World has a $100 million expansion going on. Sixty percent of all the capital investment in the state of Florida went into this area last year.

title: VISITORS TO PLAY RUGBY IN PRIVATE
description: Members of the visiting South African rugby team, the Springboks, vowed today to play the games on their United States tour in private because officials here, in California and in New York have blocked their use of public stadiums.

title: Officer Dismissed
description: A 41-year-old New York City police officer was dismissed by Police Commisioner Robert J. McGuire after a departmental trial found the officer guilty of ''wrongfully'' shooting and killing an unarmed 19-year-old man.

title: Mima Jausovec Gains Tokyo Tennis Semifinal
description: Top-seeded Mima Jausovec of Yugoslavia, third-seeded Bettina Bunge of West Germany and Kathy Horvath and Ann Kiyomura of the United States won quarterfinal matches tonight in the $175,000 Toray Sillook tournament.

title: TEAMSTERS AGREE TO REOPEN TRUCKING PACT
description: Responding to appeals from trucking companies that say they are in financial trouble, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters said today that it had agreed to reopen negotiations on its master contract, which was due to expire March 31, 1982.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. They are done by President Reagan, who habitually doodles through C abin et and staff meetings and then presents the signed drawings to C abinet secretaries.

title: Around the Nation; Chicago Priests Present Plaque to Cody at Rally
description: Making a last-minute change in plans, John Cardinal Cody, the head of Chicago's Roman Catholic archdiocese, appeared at a rally today to accept a plaque from the Black Catholic Clergy of Chicago.

title: Process May Increase Semiconductor Capacity
description: A process invented by scientists at Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J., is expected to help manufacturers of microelectronic devices, including radio and other communications equipment, as well as computers.

title: Briefing
description: C HARLES B. RANGEL is angry. Angry at the Reagan Administration, which is hardly unusual for a liberal Democratic Congressman from Manhattan. Angry at the Pakistani Government, which is unusual for a legislator whose 10 years on Capitol Hill have focused on the housing and social welfare needs of his constituents in Harlem and on the upper West Side.

title: Coast Thrift Units Agree on Merger
description: Two California savings and loan associations, the Glendale Federal Savings and Loan Association and Alameda Federal Savings and Loan Association, announced jointly that they had agreed to apply to the Federal Home Loan Bank Board for permission to merge.

title: Two in Auto Worker Protest Over Taxes Get Prison Terms
description: Two men who led a tax protest among automobile workers, contending that Federal tax laws were unconstitutional, have been sentenced to prison for violating those laws.

title: Letter: On Three Mile Island  Financial Fallout for Nuclear Plants
description: To the Editor: Your Sept. 2 editorial ''The Wrong Kind of Nuclear Power'' touches upon a serious omission in the nuclear policy plan now under discussion within the Administration.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Let me say we did not sweat and bleed to get the economic package passed only to abandon it when the going gets a little tough.'' - President Reagan. (1:6.)

title: Solidarity Today; What Tomorrow?
description: This could be a grand day for organized labor. As Solidarity Day dawns on Washington and marchers from all over the nation collect at the Monument grounds to protest the President's social and economic policies, the labor movement has every reason to hope for a memorable event.

title: OPERA: GRACE BUMBRY IN 'NABUCCO'
description: After three weeks of warming up with ''The Student Prince'' and ''The Song of Norway,'' the New York City Opera got down to more serious busin ess Thursday night, presenting its new production of Verdi's ''Nab ucco.'' This is the work that made Verdi a national hero, mainly because its plot concerns a people enslaved and ultimately li berated. That struck home with Italians, whose country was under ene my occupation at the time. The soaring chorus of the last act, ''V a, pensiero,'' became a national hymn. All this, you probably know .

title: DOW FALLS 3.90 MORE, TO 836.19
description: The stock market continued to retreat yesterday and set new lows for 1981 with selling pressure particularly evident on the American Stock Exchange. The broad setback encompassed virtually all market groups.

title: Around the World; French Lawmakers Vote To End Death Penalty
description: France's Chamber of Deputies voted by a 3-to-1 majority today to abolish the death penalty after 192 years in which the guillotine has been used to execute about 4,600 people.

title: Competrol Raises Stake in Thermo
description: Competrol (BVI) Ltd., a British Virgin Islands corporation that is 50 percent controlled by a member of the Saudi royal family, said it had increased its stake in the Thermo Electron Corporation of Waltham, Mass., to 250,000 shares, or a 5.7 percent interest.

title: Horse Race Sponsors Still Rare in U.S.
description: It took nine years and $2.6 million in purse money, but Philip Morris Inc. finally got what it wanted from CBS. When CBS televises today's feature race at Belmont Park, it will not call the $400,000 event the M Cup, the Cup or the Belmont Cup, as it has in the past, but the Marlboro Cup.

title: TOWER WEST: WHERE OWNERS AND THE TENANTS WAGE A WAR
description: A guard is stationed in the lobby, which is strictly functional in design, and the concrete plaza, which includes a play area for children and a few trees struggling to survive in discolored concrete planters, are clean, though not spotless. The building, Tower West, the 29-story beige brick and concrete apartment building at 65 West 96th Street, just east of Columbus Avenue, looks very much like scores of others high-rises throughout the city.

title: REGAN OUTLINES PLANS TO EASE BANKING RULES
description: Secretary of the Treasury Donald T. Regan today outlined a sweeping approach to deregulation of financial institutions that would let banks open branches across state lines and might gradually erase the distinction between commercial banks and savings institutions.

title: Canada and Britain in Talks
description: The Canadian Secretary of State for External Affairs, Mark MacGuigan, met the British Foreign Secretary, Lord Carrington, today for talks on East-West relations, Poland and the Caribbean. A Foreign Office spokesman said the talks also touched on Canada's wishes to take control of its Constitution. Britain now has constitutional responsibility under the British North America Actpassed by the British Parliament in 1867.

title: Today's Games at a Glance; HOMEVISITING1980; Team(Record)Team(Record)ScoreComment; LOCAL
description: Army(0-1)V.M.I.(1-0)-It is just a matter of spelling; the Cadets vs. the Keydets. Columbia(0-0)Harvard(0-0)6-26

title: Walesa Nominated for Pri ze
description: Lech Walesa, leader of the Polish union Solidarity, has been nominated for the 1981 Nobel Peace Prize, it was announced today. The winner is to be named on Oct. 14.

title: ALLIGATORS- FROM SWAMP TO THE HOME PLATE
description: Louisiana recently opened the first statewide alligator-hunting season in 18 years, so naturally we turned to a native, Ron Guidry, the Yankees' left-handed pitcher, to get the lowdown. One afternoon, during a home stand, we sat in the dugout with him and talked about hunting and trapping alligators. Here are some of the things he had to say.

title: WELLESLEY INAUGURATES 11TH PRESIDENT
description: With a flourish of trumpets and the chime of camp us bells, Wellesley College inaugurated Nannerl O. Keohane as it s 11th president today.

title: NEW REPUBLIC EDITOR LEAVES STAFF TO TAKE TOP POST AT HARPER'S
description: Michael E. Kinsley, the 30-year-old senior editor of The New Republic, has been named editor of Harper's magazine, the publisher, David Michaels, announced yesterday.

title: Around the Nation; Unneeded Smallpox Shot Causing a Serious Illness
description: Unnecessary smallpox vaccinations are causing serious illness, especially among military personnel, the national Centers for Disease Control reported today.

title: L.I. Police Rescue 8 From House Fire
description: Three police officers rescued eight people, including a 3-month-old girl, from a house fire that officials said might have been set.

title: De Gustibus; WHEN THE MAIN ITEM AT THE MEAL IS HOW YOU EAT IT
description: By now most of us are used to the idea that we should eat certain foods to improve our appearance, whether because of calorie count or of the effects of nutrients on skin, hair and muscle tone. But what may be a newer and less talked about concern is the image we project while we are eating, most especially in restaurants.

title: FLAWS IN A DISCOURSE ON REAGAN'S LAUGHTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Teachers on L.I.  Reach an Accord
description: The 480 teachers in the Lindenhurst school district reached a tentative agreement on a three-year contract that would end the threat of a strike against the district's 11 schools.

title: WHITE HOUSE PLANNING TO KILL FIREARMS ENFORCEMENT UNIT
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to eliminate the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and shift its functions to other Federal law-enforcement agencies, Administration officials said today.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Called up Terry Harper, outfielder; Matt Sinatro, catcher; Ken Smith, first baseman; Bob Walk, pitcher, and Paul Runge, shortstop, from Richmond of International League.; BASKETBALL GOLDEN STATE (NBA) - Named Coach Al Attl es vice president, Peter Mieuli assist ant to the president, and Robert Bestor director of marketing and communica tions.; FOOTBALL MIAMI (AFC) - Placed Bill Barnett, defensive end, on injured reserve.

title: M.T.A. Continues Sessions on Transit Authority; Revitalization
description: John D. Simpson, president of the Transit Authority, speaking yesterday at meeting of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's committee on operation. The; session, one of a series on a five-year capital revitalization program for the Transit Authority, addressed potential concerns and questions of the Legislative review panel. City Council President Carol Bellamy, a member of the board of the M.T.A., is at right in foreground.

title: Obeying the Law, Reagan Style
description: Usually, opponents of school busing for racial balance assail the courts for forcing it upon their communities. The Reagan Administration has now taken a dismaying further step: It is willing to act against communities that bus if they have not been ordered to do so.

title: NEW LIFE FOR OLD SHOES: REPAIRS SURVEYED
description: Remember when having new lifts put on women's shoes cost a quarter and very good shoes could be had for $30? One might as well get nostalgic about 10-cent subway fares. Prices have gone through the roof and stores are not in the least shy about displaying $250 price tags on the shoes in their windows. The Italian sandals one bought each summer for about $25 are now in the three-figure bracket, and there seems to be no ceiling on the price of boots.

title: Aqueduct Found in Italy
description: A 2,000-year-old Roman aqueduct has been uncovered during excavation for an automobile plant at Pratola Serra near here, the authorities said today. Alfa Romeo and Japan's Nissan Motor Corporation, partners in the new plant, said they would restore the well-preserved aqueduct.

title: THE RIGHT WAY TO PICK A SCHOOL PRINCIPAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes on People; A Novelist and His MSS
description: When a group of feminists founded Ms. magazine a decade ago, one of the potshots taken at them was that they were unwisely giving the publication a name the dictionary defines as ''manuscript,'' not as an honorific replacing ''Miss'' and ''Mrs.''

title: London Port Authority Plans To Shut Last Enclosed Dock
description: The Port of London Authority has announced that it will close the last of the enclosed Thames River docks.

title: FISCAL PRACTICES IN NEWARK TO GO UNDER SCRUTINY
description: The Essex County Prosecutor said today that a broad inquiry would be started soon into possible fiscal improprieties in Newark's city government. The new inq uiry is an outgrowth of an investigation of a former Newark City C ouncilman who held a $24,500-a-year city job although helived in Flor ida.

title: AN OLD PAPER'S NEW LOOK FALLS FLAT
description: Change does not come easily to this community. When the 110-year old Greenwich Time, the local newspaper, redesigned its format, the change elicited scathing responses from readers. Now some of those changes have been reversed.

title: IMPERIAL OIL FAULTS CANADA ENERGY PACT
description: The president of Imperial Oil Ltd., Canada's biggest integrated oil concern, said here today that Canada's new energy agreement with Alberta was based on unrealistic assumptions and did not justify reactivating the company's proposed $10 billion (United States) synthetic oil project at Cold Lake, Alberta, James Livin gstone said, however, that the company had not made a final decisio n whether to abandon the project, which had been delayedwhile the Alb erta and federal governments negotiated the new oil pricing and r evenue sharing agreement.

title: Observer; NOW IT CAN BE TOLD
description: In the literary world it is open season on the Hollywood dead, and at last I am able to speak. Until now I have thought it indelicate to disclose that I am Mae West's twin sons. Recently literary allegations that Joan Crawford was a rotten mother and Errol Flynn a homosexual Nazi agent, however, encourage me to believe that the American public is hungering for thenasty facts behind the glamorous myths. My la wyer, moreover, assures me there is no way Mae West can sue from the grave.

title: No Headline
description: James Scott Kemper was very rich and very Republican and very successful in the insurance business. Starting as a junior clerk at the age of 18, Mr. Kemper singlemindedly built one of the most f lourishing careers in the history of Am erican insurance. At his death he headed a group of companies tha t made up one of the world's largest fire-and-casualty underwriting organizations and that also included several life insurance con cerns.

title: DEATH COMES TO A FEDERAL AGENCY
description: The signs are everywhere. The end is near at the Community Services Administration. There is nervous talk in the elevators. There are job notices in the corridors. A secretary wonders if her typewriter will be repaired bef ore she, i n the rather inelegant phrase that has become fashionable i n Washington these days, is terminated.

title: News Analysis
description: In the years since Russian troops occupied much of Eastern Europe there have been few occasions when the Kremlin has verbally manifested the degree of fury over developments in the Soviet bloc that it did in its letter to Polish leaders demanding that action be taken to end ''anti-Sovietism.'' The letter's existence was confirmed tonight by Tass, the official press agency, nearly 24 hours after it was published in Poland. Tass said the Soviet Ambassador to Poland, Boris I. Aristov, had called on the Polish leaders ''in connection with the provocative activities of antisocialist forces in Poland.'' The agency went on to give an extensive summary of the contents of the letter. Diplomats Wary of Forecasts

title: TEXAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Loans Sought By Costa Rica
description: Costa Rica, with its foreign-exchange reserves exhausted, has asked its creditor banks abroad to lend it $1.25 billion more in the next 15 months to help save the nation's economy, banking sources said here today. Costa Rica's foreign debts already total about $2.6 billion, or more than $1,000 per capita.

title: Sports People; Templeton Bandwagon
description: Mayor Carl Officer of East St. Louis issued a proclamation urging residents to give a rousing welcome to Garry Templeton when the St. Louis Cardinals return to Busch Stadium next week.

title: Seoul Buys Mexico Oil
description: South Korea has contracted to buy 20,000 barrels of Mexican crude oil a day at current prices of $28.50 to $34 a barrel, the Mexican state petroleum company, Petroleos Mexicanos, announced today. Pemex said the contract was for one year, renewable annually, and called for renegotiation of prices every three months.

title: models, FASTER PICKUP BACK IN STYLE AS AN OPTION
description: For years it was a t abo o subject as gasoline prices increased and all efforts were directe d toward improving fuel economy. But now performance is making a mode st comeback in the American automobile business.

title: DR. HARRY FEIGENBAUM
description: Dr. Harry Feigenbaum, chief of proctology and director of surgical education at the Jamica (Queens) Hospital, died Saturday at Albert Eisntein Hospital in the Bronx. He was 68 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Drop in Soviet Gold Sales Seen
description: The Soviet Union will probably sell only about 60 tons of gold in the West this year, compared with 90 tons in 1980 and an estimate of 199 tons in 1979, the Bank Credit Suisse said today.

title: Court Continues Restraints on N.C.A.A.
description: Federal Judge Luther Eubanks extended a temporary restraining order today preventing the National Collegiate Athletic Association from starting disciplinary proceedings against Oklahoma and Georgia.

title: New York; ADDING UP UNDERDOGS
description: What with all the hullabaloo in the local papers about my Red Sox taking four straight from the front-running Tigers, you may have missed some of the other meaningful events that occurred this week. They are being repeated here as a public service.

title: Sports of The Times; Umpires Still Feel Scars of '79 Strike
description: THREE umpires were walking down a midtown New York street earlier this season. They were in a mellow frame of mind until the subject was switched to the minor league umpires who worked when the regular umpires walked out in 1979.

title: 1,000 Held at Indian Protest Seeking Party Chief's Release
description: The police reported more than 1,000 arrests today in the southern state of Tamil Nadu where members of a regional party burned buses and held street protests to demand the release from detention of a party leader.

title: DIGNITARIES PRAISE FORD AT MUSEUM DEDICATION
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford had just finished giving President Reagan a personal tour of the new Ford Presidential Museum this morning when a bystander called out, ''Mr. President, what were your impressions?''

title: * To the Editor:$
description: Bertell Ollman is entitled to his opinion of President Reagan, but I object to his trotting out Samuel Johnson's epigram about patriotism without reference to the attendant remarks of the man who preserved the oft-misused quotation. In his ''Life of Dr. Johnson,'' Boswell wrote, under the date of Friday, April 7, 1775:$''Patriotism having become one of our topicks, Johnson suddenly uttered, in a strong determined tone, an apophthegm, at which many will start: 'Patriotism is the last refuge of a scoundrel.' But let it be considered, th at he did not mean a real and generous love of our country, but that pretended patriotism which so many, in all agesand countries , have made a cloak for self-interest.'' E. WARREN SMITH Brooklyn, Sept. 6, 1981 *

title: Japan Auto Export Drop
description: Exports by Japan's two biggest auto makers, the Toyota Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company, declined in August, showing the sharpest drop this year.

title: POSTAL INSTANT PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in August

title: TOUT PARIS OFFERS ITS 'HOMMAGE A GENE KELLY'
description: Gene Kelly, the Frenchman's quintessential American in Paris, was feted last night at a starry love-in that marked the 50th anniversary of the American Center, an organization devoted to updating that naive, Hollywood-musical image of Americans by transporting the American avant-garde to France.

title: Sports People; A Disgruntled Indian
description: Miguel Dilone, denied a starting job with the Cleveland Indians this year after a team-record 61 stolen bases and a .341 batting average in 1980, is angry and demands to be traded ''to a team where I can play.'' Dilone, who has shared left-field duties with Joe Charboneau, made his request after a meeting with Gabe Paul, the team's president, and Phil Seghi, the general manager, both of whom accused him of using sore thumbs as an excuse for poor play.

title: CASINO PRESIDENT DENIES HE CONDONED NARCOTICS
description: The president and chairman of Golden Nugget Inc. denied today that he had condoned drug trafficking in the Golden Nugget Casino in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Dr. Max Kamen, Osteopath And a Lawyer in Manhattan
description: Dr. Max L. Kamen, a lawyer and osteopathic physician, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 years old. Dr. Kamen graduated from Brooklyn Law School and while a practicing lawyer began the study of medicine.

title: THE CITY;
description: A former New York resident rendered paraplegic by a 1975 car crash on the Queensboro Bridge reached a $2.3 million settlement in a suit against the city.

title: IS CENTRAL PARK FOR SOLITUDE OR FOR CELEBRATION OF THE CITY?
description: Since he became Parks Commissioner in 1978, Gordon J. Davis has cut back sharply on the use of Central Park for mass events and what, in an earlier day, were sometimes called ''happenings.''

title: TIGERS LOSE TO INDIANS, FALL FROM FIRST
description: Bo Diaz hit a two-run home run and John Denny (9-4) gained his sixth straight victory as the Cleveland Indians defeated the Detroit Tigers, 8-4, tonight.

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Results for the latest 6 mos included revs of $7.5 million and net income of $4 million or 43 cents a shr from the sale of an apartment complex in the first qr of fiscal 1982

title: No Headline
description: Alex Falcinelli, a 150-pound junior, kicked a 37-yard field goal with 3 minutes 2 seconds to play tonight, giving Rutgers a 3-0 victory over Virginia at Giants Stadium. Falc inelli did the same thing last season, hitting a 41-yarder wit h 33 seconds left.

title: TWO NEW YORK PROJECTS TO COMBAT HABITUAL FELON AND STREET ROBBER
description: Two new crime-fighting programs -one aimed at 6,000 violent, ha bitual street criminals and the other at street robbers in pa rticular - were announced yesterday. Both will emphasize the use of detectives instead of uniformed patrol officers.

title: GOLD PANEL OFF TO SLOW START
description: The Gold Commission today began to consider whether the United States should return to a gold standard. It found afte r four hours of discussion that the issue was complex.

title: Around the Nation; 2 Killed in Plane Crash; Political Figures Hurt
description: A small airplane crashed into two Detroit houses today, killing two men on board the plane and critically burning two others in the craft, the authorities said.

title: Device Checks Spelling Of Newspaper Articles
description: In a modern newspaper office, the text of copy about to be printed is displayed to editors on a video terminal. If the computer operators suspect that a word is misspelled, it will be underlined for the editors' attention.

title: Sports People; Bird, Cowens Cleared
description: A jury in San Antonio yesterday cleared Larry Bird and Dave Cowens of charges in connection with a scuffle after a game at the HemisFair Arena two years ago. The 12-member jury, in refusing damages to John Merla, a fan of the San Antonio Spurs, found that Bird, the Boston Celtic forward, had acted in self-defense in hitting Mr. Merla with a gym bag and that Cowens, the team's former center and coach, had not assaulted Mr. Merla.

title: DR. MIRIAM LENDING
description: Dr. Miriam Lending, director of pediatric ambulatory services at the Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center in the Bronx, died of cancer Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital.

title: METS DEFEAT CARDINALS BY 8-1
description: Ed Lynch was not around at the end of the Mets' 8-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals last night at Shea Stadium. But he was the winning pitcher, helped by the relief pitching of Jesse Orosco.

title: U.S. AND STATE AGREE TO CLEAR NUCLEAR WASTE
description: A new agreement to remove 600,000 gallons of radioactive waste from West Valley, N.Y., was signed today by Federal and New York State energy officials.

title: Consumer Saturday; DOUBTS FAIL TO BLOCK THE SALE OF AIR CLEANER
description: DESPITE widespread doubts that negative-ion generators do anything worthwhile, they are back on the market. The devices, which cost $50 to $250, are designed to add negatively charged electrons to oxygen molecules. That, the manufacturers assert, makes those in the room where a device is placed feel ''great, revitalized and alert.''

title: YANKEES, WITH 3 HOMERS, SET BACK RED SOX BY 6-4
description: The Red Sox should have known. As soon as they creep close enough to move into first place with one victory, the Yankees come to Fenway Park and beat them.

title: Italy Planning Early Releases To Ease Overcrowded Prisons
description: The Government announced today that because of prison overcrowding it would deduct two years from the sentences of convicts who are not terrorists, Mafia criminals or ''habitual delinquents.''

title: Candidate Criticizes Brown
description: State Attorney General George Deukmejian, calling himself an heir of the Ronald Reagan legacy in California, announced today that he would seek the Republican nomination for Governor. He is expected to have a tight race with Lieut. Gov. Mike Curb, but his announcement speech was mainly aimed at Gov. Edmund P. Brown Jr., who is to run for a seat in the United States Senate.

title: USAir's Profit Fell in August
description: USAir Inc. said today that its profit in August fell sharply, to $1.04 million, from $7.27 million a year earlier, mainly because of the air traffic controllers' strike.

title: Carolina Wins A.S.L. Title
description: Hugh O'Neill scored a goal with five minutes left in the second overtime tonight to give the Carolina Lightnin' a 2-1 victory over New York United in the America's Soccer League championship game.

title: Allied Van Board Votes Stock Plan
description: Allied Van Lines Inc., one of the few public companies in the moving industry, announced that its board had approved a plan for the company to become a privately held concern owned by its agent operators.

title: Around the World; Ulster Petitioners Pelted With Eggs in London
description: Bystanders threw eggs and scuffles broke o ut whe n relatives of jailed Irish nationalist hunger strikers in Northern I reland arrived at Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's residence tod ay to present a petition.

title: MORRIS IUSHEWITZ, AN OFFICIAL OF THE A.F.L.-C.I.O. COUNCIL
description: Morris Iushewitz, a union leader in New York City for several decades and a member of city and state education bodies, died yesterday at Cabrini Medical Center after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Errico Shifts Stand, Testifies in Inquiry
description: Con Errico, the former jockey convicted last year of racketeering in connection with a race-fixing case, reversed his position yesterday and testified before a Federal grand jury seeking evidence against others allegedly involved in the scheme.

title: Soviet Holds Missile Tests
description: The Soviet Union said today that it had ended 12 days of missile tests in the Pacific east of Japan. The official Tass press agency said the tests involved launch tr ials for booster rockets.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $1.1 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve is adding funds to the banking system and thereby encouraging lower short-term interest rates, data released by the Fed late yesterday showed.

title: SOME GENES LINKED TO CANCER PROCESS
description: In recent months several groups of research scientists, working independently, have discovered evidence for the existence of individual genes in the cells of some human cancers that can switch on the cancer process in other normal, living cells.

title: Associated Press
description: 6,000 RALLY AGAINST MARCOS IN MANILA: Part of the crowd that gathered yesterday in Manila's Bonifacio Park to denounce President Ferdinand E. Marcos and Filipino ties to the United States. For the first time, Government schoolteachers took part in a demonstration against Mr. Marcos. The rally was peaceful.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 33.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; NEWS SUMMARY; SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1981
description: International Poland's ''independent existence'' is threatened by the Solidarity labor union, the Government said. The warning followed a sharp message from the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party, which demanded immediate action against what it said was the union's politicially inspired campaign of anti-Sovietism. The Council of Ministers in Warsaw told Solidarity that the Government was prepared to take ''all means'' at its disposal and ''definite measures that might become necessary for the defense of socialism.'' (Page 1, Col. 1.) The U.S. accused Moscow of ''interference with Poland's internal affairs'' in a response to Moscow's note to the Warsaw Government. It was the sharpest American statement to the Soviet Union since Moscow stepped up its campaign against the Solidarity union's influence in Poland. (4:-3-6.)

title: U.S. SAYS SOVIET MESSAGE IS INTERVENTION IN POLAND'S INTERNAL AFFAIRS
description: The United States charged today that the Soviet Union, in calling on Poli sh leaders to crack down on the Solidarity la bor movement, was intervening in Poland's domestic politics.

title: GERMAN COAL PLANT DEAL EXPECTED WITH SOVIET
description: Top West German and Soviet officials are expected to outline a far-reach ing plan at meetings in Moscow next week for Bonn to deliv er sophisticated coal processing plants to the Soviet Union in retu rn for energy supplies, a West German Government official said today.

title: KOCH FIGHTS NEW BUDGET CUTS
description: Mayor Koch yesterday attacked additional budget cuts proposed by President Reagan, saying if they were adopted by Congress they ''could have a drastic effect on the lives of the poor and could put excessive pressure on the already strained finances of some state and local governments.''

title: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1981; The Economy
description: The nation's economy stagnated in the third quarter, the Commerce Department said. Its preliminary figure for the G.N.P., after adjustment for inflation, shows a decline at an annual rate of 0.5 percent. The G.N.P. declined at a revised 1.6 percent rate in the first quarter. Officials expect the rate of inflation, as measured by the G.N.P.'s fixed-weight price index, to hold at 7.9 percent. (Page 29.)

title: Around the World; Rebels Not a Threat, Chad's President Says
description: President Goukouni Oueddei of Chad said today that rebel forces fighting for a former Defense Minister were no longer a threat to his Government. He said his forces were now fighting ''Sudanese irregulars.''

title: AIR EXPRESS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After tax credits of $141,400 in the qr and $1,406,400 for the yr; 1981 includes net exchange translation losses of $378,000 compared with gains of $400,000 in 1980

title: Cozza's Yale Squad Ivy Favorite Again
description: Yale has 709 football victories, more than any other college in the nation. Carmen Cozza has coached the Eli to 105 of those victories for the most successful record at the school. Yale and Cozza are favored to achieve Nos.710 and 106 today when the eight Ivy League schools open their season and Yale meets Brown in Yale Bowl. Yale also is the choice to win the Ivy championship again.

title: THEATER: FROM JAPAN
description: For the second part of its engagement at Asia House, the Classical Performing Arts Mission of Japan turned to the classical theater of Noh and Kyogen. The first two nights had been devoted to music and dance of Kabuki origin.

title: THE HARD-WORK ETHIC OF HELEN DILLON
description: Dwarfed by the Jet players, Helen Dillon, the team's other owner, will board the team plane today. She will laugh easily, tell jokes and ask how the new baby is at home or wonder whether someone wants another bag of potato chips.

title: ISRAELI-EGYPTIAN TALKS LEAVE SOME TOURISM ISSUES UNSETTLED
description: Israeli and Egyptian officials today ended four days of talks here on the technical aspects of carrying out the peace treaty of March 1979, but they failed to resolve a number of points concerning tourism between the two countries after Israel's final scheduled withdrawal from Sinai in April.

title: Sports People; Ovett Takes a Bride
description: Everyone watching on television as Steve Ovett won the 800-meter run at the Moscow Olympics last year saw him send loving messages to his girlfriend, Rachel Waller. Yesterday, in the British seaside town of Brighton, Ovett sought a bit more privacy and married Miss Waller, a model, at the registry office. Ovett's next race will be the Fifth Avenue Mile in New York Sept. 26.

title: Ali and Berbick Agree On December in Nassau
description: Muhummad Ali and Trevor Berbick gave credence to the report that they will meet in the ring by showing up in New York yesterday and saying they had signed contracts to fight in a 25,000-seat arena being built in Nassau, the Bahamas, early in December.

title: NATHAN'S HUNT FOR AN UPTURN
description: Almost every day at rush hour this summer, Nathan's Famous deploy edsquadrons of green-and-yellow uniformed teen- agers in Times Square tohand out coupons and promote the New York hot -dog institution's 65th birthday celebration. But at summer's end, Mu rray Handwerker, the sonof Nathan, the restaurant's founder, stood up before angry stockholders at the company's annual meeting and could think of nothing celebratory to say.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: To the Editor:

title: Index; International
description: An editor's muckraking roils Mrs. Gandhi's Government 2 Car bomb believed set by under- ground group kills three 3 6,000 demonstrate against Marcos in Manila and assail U.S.3 U.N. votes to let Pol Pot faction retain Cambodia's seat 3 Around the World 4 Text of Soviet message to Po- land's leaders 5 Israeli-Egyptian talks leave tour- ism issues unresolved 6 Government/Politics U.S. and Albany sign accord for removal of radioactive waste 26 Golden Nugget chief denies con- doning drug dealing 26 At-large Council seats cannot be included in Tuesday primary 27 Washington Talk Briefing 7 The dying days of the Community Services Administration 7 Health/Science Linking genetic controls to the cancer cells 11 Industry/Labor A new editor is named at Harper's magazine 24 Teamsters agree to renegotiate trucking pact 24 General Around the Nation 8 South African rugby team to play games in private 8 Bodies found in Laos aren't those of U.S. servicemen 8 Extensive development is caus- ing problems in Orlando 8 Dignitaries attend dedication of Gerald R. Ford Museum 9 Tower West: where landlord and tenants battle 25 The Region 26 In Greenwich, Conn., an old paper's new look is criticized 26 The City 27 68 arrested in second drug sweep of New York City schools 27 Arts/Entertainment ''Love: Emotion, Myth and Meta- phor,'' by R. Solomon reviewed 11 Ensemble Company in ''Salute to Black Classics of Dance'' 11 Paris offers its homage to Gene Kelly 13 City Opera season opens with Grace Bumbry in ''Nabucco'' 13 Classical Japanese theater at Asia House 15 Mehta and Philharmonic play Mahler's Symphony No. 2 16 ''El Salvador: Another Vietnam'' at the Paramount 48 ''Making Dances,'' a documen- tary at the Public Theater 48 Style Consumer Saturday 12 New life for old shoes: Repairs surveyed 12 The new furs: Spectacular 12 De Gustibus: When the main item at the meal is how you eat it 12 Obituaries James S. Kemper, insurance ex- ecutive 21 Rafael Mendez, trumpeter 21 Sports Islanders' No.1 draft choice must play a waiting game 16 European pros lead U.S. as Ryder Cup golf opens 17 Red Sox, back in division race, play host to Yankees 17 The work ethic of Helen Dillon, a Jets owner 17 Errico reverses stand, testifies in race-fixing inquiry 17 Commercially sponsored events still rare in U.S. horse racing 17 George Vecsey sees umpires still scarred by '79 strike 19 Yale favored to reward Coach Cozza again 19 N.C.A.A. vote on television rights called unfair 19 Ali and Berbick lay plans for December bout in Bahamas 20 Valentine focuses on consistency after a 66 in Texas 20 Features/Notes Saturday News Quiz 14 Going Out Guide 14 Notes on People 15 Sports People 16 About New York 25 News Analysis John F. Burns on stern Soviet let- ter to Polish leaders 1 William Serrin d iscusses Lane Kirkland, l abor leader 11 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: Rates Fall in Canada
description: The Royal Bank of Canada and the Bank of Montreal, two of Canada's largest banks, lowered their prime lending rates today by half a percentage point, to 21 1/4 percent. Their move followed the lead of the Toronto Dominion Bank after the Bank of Canada reduced its bank rate to 19.67 percent yesterday.

title: FOUNDED M AJOR INSURER
description: James Scott Kemper, who built one of the nation's largest diversified insurance and financial companies, died yesterday at the age of 94, the company announced today.

title: Europe Leading U.S. in Ryder Cup Golf
description: Europe's team of professional golfers, who have been hearing and reading all week that they had no chance to beat the American team, outplayed the United States today in the first session of the 24th Ryder Cup Matches. The Europeans won four matches, the Americans three, and one match was tied. That left the Europeans ahead, 4 1/2 points to 3 1/2.

title: REAGAN WILL FIGHT 'TO THE LAST BLOW' FOR SPENDING CUTS
description: President Reagan, defending his economic recovery program in the aftermath of the stock market's plunge to a 16-month low, vowed today to ''fight to the last blow'' for his new round of spending cuts.

title: Lanford Wilson to Get Honorary Degree
description: Lanford Wilson, author of ''Fifth of July,'' ''Talley's Folly,'' ''The Hot l Baltimore'' and other plays, will receive an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters from the University of Missouri at Kansas City tomorrow.

title: POL POT GROUP WINS AT U.N. FOR 3D YEAR
description: For the third year, the General Assembly has decided that Cambodia's seat at the United Nations should be retained by the deposed Communist Government that was headed by Pol Pot.

title: Humanist Session Monday at Wesleyan
description: The humanities will come under study at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., from Monday to Wednesday in ''The Humanities in American Culture and Society,'' the first of 10 symposiums and colloquiums during Wesleyan's Sesquicentennial year. Attention will focus on humanists and their disciplines' transformations.

title: PARADE TODAY
description: The annual Steuben Day Parade will take place today beginning at noon. Marchers will proceed up Fifth Ave- nue from 63d to 86th Street and then turn east to Second Avenue.

title: News Analysis
description: The man who will lead the first mass protest against the economic and social policies of the Reagan Administration, the man who, his associates say, thought up the notion of having it, who gave it its name,

title: RUNNING JUDGES
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes on People; Some Disunity Along the United Way
description: For the kickoff of the 40th annual Chittenden County United Way fund-raising drive in Burlington, Vt., the sponsors considered themselves fortunate to have as guests Mayor Bernard Sanders of Burlington and Gov. Richard Snelling of Vermont.

title: MACDONALD, E F, CO reports earnings for 16 weeks to Aug 16
description: B-Net income; the company sold foreign exchange losses of $286,467 in the qr for compared to a gain of $94,298 in earlier period; in the latest 28 weeks foreign exchange losses of $455,819 compared to a gain of $47,802 in yr-ago period

title: BODIES FROM LAOS SAID TO BE ASIAN, NOT AMERICAN
description: The Defense Department said today that remains turned over to the United States authorities in Thailand in July and August were not those of eight American servicemen missing in Laos.

title: FRENCHMAN SIGNS IRANIAN CAVIAR PACT
description: Since 1979, what is arguably the world's finest caviar has been generally unavailable in the Western world. But a former French chef, in something of a gastronomic coup, has concluded a contract with the Iranian Government that could put the delicacy back on gourmet grocery shelves in the next month.

title: MUSICIAN PERFORMED FOR HEADS OF STATE
description: Rafael Mendez, a trumpeter who played for Pancho Villa as a boy in Mexico and went on to appear before presidents and kings, has died of a heart attack. He was 75 years old.

title: JOHN ROBERT McDOWELL
description: John Robert McDowell, 59 years old, assistant Sunday editor of The Indianapolis Star, died Tuesday night a few hours after collapsing at his desk.

title: G.O.P. LEADERS STUDYING ALTERNATIVE BUDGET CUTS
description: Republican Congressional leaders expressed misgivings today about President Reagan's proposal to cut back several benefit and pension programs and began drafting their own alternative package of budget cuts.

title: IRAN PLANS TO SPEED UP EXECUTIONS OF ITS FOES
description: Iran, intensifying its crackdown on dissidents, announced new rules today for quicker executions. The Chief Justice, Ayatollah Abdulkarim Musavi Ardebeli, said in an interview broadcast by the Teheran radio that demonstrators and political dissidents would be tried immediately upon their arrest and would be put to death if two people testified against them.

title: Bridge: Young St ars Are Hungry, As Are S ome Older Ones
description: The world of tournament bridge is full of hungry young players, as witness a 17-year-old boy who won a major title at the Summer Nationals and a 13-year-old who recently became the youngest-ever life master. But the other side of the picture should not be overlooked: There are some hungry older players winning titles, some of them born half a century before the teen-agers now making their mark. An example is the New York partnership of A l and Rita Rand, who have been following the tournament trail for the last decade with unfailing enthusiasm and constantly improving results. Al Rand was a member of a team that reached the semifinal o f the Spingold knockout teams in Boston recently, and together they w on a Swiss team event inNew York last Sunday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Athlone Industries Inc. said it had purch ased 10,000 shares of its own common stock in the open market for $ 257,500.

title: EL SALVADOR AT WAR
description: The current small festival at the Paramount Theater is called ''Movies for Cynics,'' but some of the offerings have less to do with cynicism than with vigorous outrage. This is especially true of ''El Salvador: Another Vi etnam,'' a new version by Glenn Silber and Tete Vasconcellos of their earlier ''El Salvador: Another Vietnam?'' whichwas shown on public television last January.

title: Around the World; 12 Poles Hijack Airliner And Fly to West Berlin
description: Twelve Polish students armed with firebombs hijacked a Polish airli ner today and flew to a United States air ba se in West Berlin. They were pursued by a Soviet jet fighter that was forced away by two American helicopters.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Million-Dollar' Fish Reeled in at $10,000
description: A ''million-dollar salmon'' that eluded hundreds of participants in a fishing derby last week was caught today in Commencement Bay, the authorities said.

title: ALL COUNCIL RACES WILL BE DELAYED
description: Elections for at-large City Council members cannot be included in the New York City primary that has been rescheduled for Tuesday, the Justice Department ruled last night.

title: ISLANDERS' TOP PICK FACING LONG WAIT
description: Paul Boutilier was the No.1 draft choice of the Islanders this year, but the chances of the 18-year-old defenseman making the roster of the Stanley Cup champions this season are remote.

title: Notes on People; The First Fonda Opening Night Without Fonda
description: In his half-century as an actor, Henry Fonda had made it a matter of pride that he never missed a scheduled opening night, but Thursday night he finally had to spoil his record.

title: IN SEARCH OF CANCER'S KEY
description: The idea that the genetic controls of cells must be a key to the cancer process in humans has lured scientific thought for many years. The view was implicit in the observation that cancer cells were changed from the normal state in their biology and even their behavior. These cells grow abnormally and often seem to escape the body's controls that normally prevent invasion of adjoining tissues.

title: BLACK DANCE: SALUTING THE CLASSICS
description: The Negro Ensemble Company offered a ''Salute to the Black Classics of Dance'' on Thursday night at Theater Four. But anyone who therefore expected unrelieved solemnity would have been surprised by the exuberant items assembled by John Parks, the event's coordinator. Similarly, anyone hoping for a scholarly historical account of black dance would have been disappointed, for the program never even made a pretense of attempting such a survey.

title: JOHN AZARY
description: John Azary, captain of Columbia University's undefeated basketball team in the 1950-51 season and winner of the Haggerty Award as the metropolitan area's outstanding player, died in his sleep in Washington Tuesday after apparently having a heart attack. He was 51 years old.

title: Acquittal Voted In Customs Case
description: A Federal jury acquitted a Staten Island man of charges that he helped plot to steal $1 million in customs duties.

title: REAGAN SUFFERS SETBACK ON SENATE FARM BILL VOTE
description: The Senate, rejecting the Reagan Administration's call for the return to a free market farm economy, today approved a new farm bill with price support a nd subsidy sections that would cost at least $10.8 billion in the next four fiscal years. The vote was 49 to 32.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: TORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes a loss from continuing operations of $4,849,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $5,000...C-Includes loss from continuing operations of $5,180,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $4,000...D-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $473,000...E-Net income and after a loss frm discontinued operations of $407,000; the yr-ago figu were restated to reflect the divestiture of Barefoot Grass Lawn Service Inc

title: EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Rain Brings C lippers Flag
description: Because of rainouts last night and tonight, the remainder of the International League's championship series was canceled today and the Columbus Clippers were declared the winner of the Governor's Cup.

title: ANOTHER CAR BOMB EXPLODES IN BEIRUT, KILLING 3
description: A car bomb exploded in Beirut today, killing three persons and wounding three others, and an anonymous telephone caller said it had been set off by the same underground group that was responsible for two similar blasts yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ENVIROTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Mar 31
description: B-After loss from discontinued operations of $45,498,000 in the qr and $50,031,000 for the yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,547,000 in the qr and $15,897,000 for the yr

title: BARGAIN LOANS FROM G.M.
description: ALL the big auto makers have resorted to ploys to increase sagging car sales, and among the most imaginative is the one taken by the General Motors Corporation.

title: WARSAW DECLARES UNION JEOPARDIZES NATION'S EXISTENCE
description: The Polish Government warned the Solidarity union today that its actions were jeopardizing the ''independent existence'' of the country.

title: Neal Boenzi
description: BIG APPLE'S LITTLE APPLES SHINE IN SHOW: Marjorie Tsholakian and her son, David-Aran, admiring city-grown apples on exhibition at the Fall Harvest Festival of the Horticultural Society of New York. The show, which runs through tomorrow, celebrates efforts by backyard, vacant lot and community gardeners.

title: MUSIC: MEHTA'S MAHLER
description: The New York Philharmonic has a great Mahler tradition. It started with Mahler himself, when he led the orchestra in his last years, and continued through Bruno Walter to Leonard Bernstein. Zubin Mehta might seem to be carrying on that tradition by programming Mahler in the first two weeks of the current season. But though the audience greeted the performance of the ''Resurrection'' Symphony No. 2 Thursday night at Avery Fisher Hall with cheers, his interpretation did not seem so convincing as those of his predecessors.

title: FLAGGING ALLEGIANCE
description: At the start of a new school year, when our students are rebelling against school and society, I find myself recalling the solemn loyalty we pledged to our flag long ago, when I was a schoolgirl here.

title: THE NEW FURS: SPECTACULAR
description: Even the weather cooperated to make the Fendi fur show a smash hit the other night; the rain held off until the last model got off the runways built by Bergdorf Goodman around the Pulitzer Fountain. All Thursday long, Bergdorf executives bit their nails and gazed nervously at gray skies. They had already been rained out on Tuesday and there were 1,000 people expected. Jamming a crowd of that size into the store's main floor was a horrendous thought.

title: MOSLEM PROTESTERS CLASH WITH CAIRO POLICE AGAIN
description: Moslem demonstrators, protesting President Anwar el-Sadat's crackdown on religious fundamentalists, clashed with the police today in the third successive Friday protest since Mr. Sadat ordered the arrests of 1,536 people opposed to his policies.

title: PANEL IN HOUSE WILL INVESTIGATE EX-C.I.A. AGENT
description: The House Select Committee on Intelligence has decided to conduct a full-scale investigation of the activities of a former American intelligence agent charged with illegally exporting explosives to Libya, committee members said today.

title: FILM: 'MAKING DANCES'
description: Because dance is a nonverbal art, the myth has developed that dancers are nonverbal people. Quite the contrary. Dancers are often extremely articulate. And just how articulate they can be is demonstrated in ''Making Dances,'' the fine documentary that opens this afternoon at the Public Theater as part of the ''Film at the Public's'' Public Service Program.

title: A FRIEND OF LABOR
