description: A few weeks ago, bound for the airport, I noted a forlorn group of pickets from the traffic controllers' union. Since I was mainly concerned with making my flight, their presence barely registered. Later, however, it occurred to me that 30 years ago I would as soon have crossed that picket line as I would have walked through the airport without pants. I had considered myself a friend of labor - and now labor and I were barely on nodding terms.

title: The Bible, in Brief
description: Some of the world's most famous books never get read all the way through. Take ''War and Peace,'' for instance, the novel that always ends that sentence that begins ''This is the summer I'm finally going to finish ...'' Or ''Remembrance of Things Past,'' which starts, and very often stops, with ''Swann's Way.''

title: Court Overturns Drug-Case Ruling
description: A Federal appeals court in St. Louis yesterday reversed a lower court ruling that had set free a former New York City police detective who was convicted of selling heroin in the ''French Connection'' case.

title: EMPIRE INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
IMPROVING A COPYING PROCESS
description: WASHINGTON ROBERT W. GUNDLACH, a veteran inventor for the Xerox Corporation, was granted a patent this week on features of ''Dixy,'' or dipole xerography, a new method of developing patterns for the copying process.

title: Canadian Bank Bonds
description: The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce plans a $100 million (United States) issue of Eurobonds, market sources said here today.

title: Mrs. Cooperstein Wins
description: Judy Cooperstein of North Shore won the women's Long Island match play championship at the Meadow Brook Club today by defeating Nancy Platzer of Muttontown, 5 and 4, in the 36-hole final.

title: ECONOMY STILL WEAK IN QUARTER
description: The nation's economy is continuing to stagnate in this year's third quarter, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: GENOVESE DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 14
description: 1980 periods of net income and shr earnings reflect change to LIFO accounting method

title: Around the Nation; One Philadelphia School Opens in Teacher Strike
description: Pickets shouted ''sham'' and ''scab, scab'' today as the Board of Education opened one of 268 schools that have been closed 11 days by a teachers' strike.

title: Abraham Gevirtz, 91, Real-Estate Executive
description: Abraham Gevirtz, a New York real-estate executive and dress manufacturer, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. Mr. Girvitz was 91 years old and a longtime resident of Scarsdale, N.Y. He moved to Miami Beach in 1976.

title: Arco Oil Pact
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said it had signed an accord with Morocco for offshore oil prospecting in 4,450 square kilometers, or about 1,718 square miles, off the Atlantic Coast near Agadir in southern Morocco. The cost of the program is estimated at $50 million, to be financed by Atlantic Richfield, company officials said. Production-sharing terms of the accord were not disclosed.

title: Connecticut Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday assigned a prime-1 rating, its highest, to commercial paper to be issued by Connecticut. The state said Thursday that it would sell $115 million of such paper through Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Books of The Times
description: Quizzing Love By ANATOLE BROYARD LOVE: EMOTION, MYTH AND META- PHOR. By Robert C. Solomon, 347 pages. Anchor Press/Doubleday. $15.95.

title: NEWARK'S NEW SCHOOL CHIEF PUTS SAFETY FIRST
description: In his first interview since taking over this city's school system three weeks ago, Dr. Columbus Salley said his primary objective was to make the schools safe. He said he would deal severely with those who disrupted the educational process.

title: 36 Die in Bolivia Truck Crash
description: An open truck carrying tin miners and their families overturned on a highway in southeast Bolivia, killing 36 people and seriously injuring three, national highway officials said yesterday.

title: DRUG AGENTS' TAKING OF SUITCASE HELD IN ERROR
description: A divided Federal appeals court in Manhatta n has ruled that narcotic agents violated a traveler's constit utional rights by seizing his suitcases at La Guardia Airport a nd keeping them for a later search.

title: Music; IT'S THE HALLS OF IVY FOR MUSIC THIS FALL
description: NEVER mind the youngsters - it's back-to-school time for music lovers of all ages who have discovered that some of the most interesting concerts in Connecticut take place amidst halls of ivy. ''Music is filling the air in New Milford on Canterbury Hill,'' said Roderick Clarke, headmaster of the Canterbury School, and his counterparts at Yale, the University of Bridgeport and other centers of learning are equally proud of their music schedules.

title: AVOWED RACIST IS CONVICTED OF MURDERING 2 BLACKS JOGGING IN UTAH
description: Joseph Paul Franklin, an avowed racist who argued that his only fault was to have been ''in the wrong place at the wrong time,'' was convicted today on two counts of firstdegree murder in the sniper slayings of two black joggers.

title: Architecture View; CLASSICAL CLARITY IN AN ACADEMIC DESIGN; CAMBRIDGE, Mass.
description: It is fashionable now to find echoes of other periods and styles in new buildings, as evidence of a cultivated architectural mind and the creative use of the past. It is possible to find reminders of the California architects Greene and Greene and their debt to the Japanese way with wood, Mackintosh and the Glasgow School, and Otto Wagner and the Vienna Secession in the handsome new headquarters of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences in Cambridge, Mass. What it is not possible to find is any resemblance to the architects' most noted previous work, the Boston City Hall - the competition-winning design by Kallmann, McKinnell and Knowles, now the Boston firm of Kallmann, McKinnell and Wood.

title: Barry Bronfman, Architect, Is Fiance of JoAnn Steiner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Steiner of North Hills, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, JoAnn Steiner, to Barry Allen Bronfman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Bronfman of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Jersey Utility Is Fined For Hazard at A-Plant
description: The Jersey Central Power and Light Company has agreed to pay an $80,000 Federal fine that resulted from a potentially hazardous condition at the Oyster Creek nuclear power plant near Forked River, N.J., last April.

title: A STUDY OF AMBITION AND MORALITY TO OPEN THE FILM FESTIVAL
description: At the moment this is being written I haven't yet seen any of the 26 programs in the 19th New York Film Festival that opens at Lincoln Center Friday night with the English ''Chariots of Fire.''

title: CHICAGO ARCHDIOCESE: CENTER OF STRIFE UNDER CODY
description: The grandeur that the Archdiocese of Chicago once enjoyed is encapsulated in a remark attributed in legendary fashion to George Cardinal Mundelein more than five decades ago. As he gaz ed over a religious gathering of 100,00 Roman Catholics in Soldier Field , he is said to have replied to an awestruck foreign prelate, ''Th ink nothing of it; we're planning to hold the last judgment here .''

title: The Region; Subway Vandals Get the Bite
description: There have been campaigns before to rid New York City subway cars of graffiti, but the spray-painted evidence suggests that they have been, on the whole, toothless. Not so a program Mayor Koch announced last week: Six German shepherds are to patrol a Queens subway yard where cars are kept overnight and where vandals do much of their damage.

title: SOLO DEBUTS FOR ROCK STARS
description: Asolo album by a member of a rock band is always fraught with a certain danger. The very act of deciding to make such a disk can put a strain on the band's sense of itself as a communal enterprise. If the record proves successful, the harmony may be further disrupted. If it fails, the individual loses credibility both within the group and with the public.

title: DO BAR HOURS AFFECT AUTO FATALITIES?
description: WOULD closing bars a few hours earlier reduce the number of alcohol-related traffic fatalities on Long Island? Supporters of such a proposal, which was rejected recently by the Nassau and Suffolk Counties Alcohol and Beverage Control Boards, concede that closing bars two hours earlier would not eliminate cases of intoxicated drivers who drink at private parties or somewhere other than a bar. Many, however, like Patrick McCarthy, whose daughter was killed by a drunk driver, feel it would go a long way toward reducing the number of highway tragedies.

title: EUROPE TRADE VISIT FIRST BY A GOVERNOR
description: HARTFORD GOVERNOR O'NEILL'S 11-day trade mission to France, West Germany and Britain, to begin Friday, will mark the first time a Connecticut Governor has gone abroad specifically to seek additional foreign investment for the state.

title: Numismatics; HIS UNUSUAL COLLECTION CONSISTS OF 'FAKE COINS'
description: Most coin collectors never possess great rarities, but Michael Wyatt of Long Branch, N.J., a 23-year-old grocery clerk, has hundreds of them - on paper. In fact, he probably has the finest collection in existence, one which includes four 1933 eagles, three Brasher doubloons, two 1894-S Barber dimes, an 1804 silver dollar and a 1913 Liberty Head nickel.

title: STUDY OF WAYS TO REDUCE HEART ATTACK RISK IS PROVING OUT
description: Middle-aged men participating in a major national study have succeeded in changing their habits to reduce their risk of suffering a heart attack, according to a series of newly published reports on the study's progress.

title: Press Notes
description: Having said it was interested in buying United Press International, Reuters, the London-based news service, is now trying to figure out the precise benefits and liabilities involved in acquiring the moneylosing American news service.

title: BONN SEEKS TO CUT COMMON MARKET PAYMENT
description: The West German Government, which is contending with a stalled economy and facing heavy budget cuts next year, said yesterday that it would seek a sharp reduction in its Common Market budget payments.

title: HOW THE NEW TAX LAWS AID HOMEOWNERS
description: If you own a home and plan to keep it, have one you want to sell, or are looking for one to buy or rent, chances are that the new tax law will benefit you directly.

title: SEOUL SAID TO HOLD 15,000 IN CAMPS WITHOUT TRIAL
description: The South Korean Government keeps 15,000 people in army detention camps without trial and with no charges brought against them, according to a prisoner's account smuggled out of a camp and published here.

title: SOVIET FINDS APPETIZING USES FOR STALE BREAD
description: The display at Bread Store 886 in a new housing development on the western edge of Moscow was as appetizing as it was unusual.

title: N.F.L. Players Set Their Sales Pitch
description: Gene Upshaw, president of the professional football players' union and the 36-year-old left guard for the Oakland Raiders, recognizes that the extreme demands the union are likely to make upon the team owners at the end of the current season will require a super salesman.

title: The World; New Premium on Life's Pleasures
description: The dearth of things worth buying makes for a lot of loose rubles in the Soviet economy; billions of dollars worth find their way into the black market, savings accounts and babushka's mattress. In an effort to attract more into official coffers, the Soviet Government last week sharply increased the prices of the relatively few consumer ''nonessentials'' it produces that Soviet citizens actually want.

title: BILL WOULD FORBID AID TO TERRORISTS
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen, a member of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said today that he would introduce legislation next week that would bar United States citizens from aiding international terrorism.

title: A THIRD PLAN TO HELP YONKERS BUDGET
description: YONKERS ATHIRD plan for the county to come to the aid of this city's beleaguered budget surfaced last week and immediately became entangled in the thickets of election-year politics.

title: Boston College 13 Texas A & M 12
description: Leo Smith went 5 yards for the winning touchdown two plays after a Texas A & M fumble in the fourth quarter to upset the Aggies.

title: 100 Gold Bars Raised From British Warship
description: Divers have raised at least 100 gold bars with an estimated worth of $20 million from the torpedoed World War II cruiser Edinburgh in the Barents Sea, the British Government said today.

title: Wedding Is Held For Lisa Monzani
description: Louise Foster Monzani, daughter of Mrs. F. Kelso Davis of Essex and Fenwick, Conn., and the late John T. Monzani of New York and Plainfield, N.J., was married yesterday to William Sargent Clough, son of Allison C. Clough Jr. of Essex, and the late Elizaabeth Sargent Clough. Canon Richard J. Hardman, rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Westfield, N.J., performed the ceremony in the St. Mary's by the Sea Chapel in Fenwick.

title: 12-1 NOBLE NASHUA CAPTURES MARLBORO
description: Noble Nashua proved it was no fluke that he ran the fastest mile in the history of Belmont Park three weeks ago by carrying his speed an extra quarter-mile yesterday and winning the $400,000 Marlboro Cup by 3 3/4 lengths at Belmont.

title: ANTIABORTION PLAN: WHERE IS JUSTICE?
description: IT is a scene I am not likely to forget - ever. The year was 1969. I was a junior in college, and abortion was illegal. The girls in the dormitory talked about it all the time, of course - what we would do if it happened to us, where we would go, who we could trust - or if we could possibly raise a baby on our own or survive a hasty marriage. But none of us really believed it would happen. We were intelligent and careful; we used contraceptives and prayed a lot. But Peggy became pregnant anyway.

title: WHY HIGH RATES DON'T KILL
description: WASHINGTON HIGH interest rates, the economic handicappers had thought, should have shut down the economy long before now. It hasn't happened. Not that things are all that bright. The securities markets are reeling. Detroit is depressed, and so are the homebuilders. Unemployment has remained around 7 percent for almost a year and a half. And over all, the economy is no better than sluggish. By the second quarter of 1981, the nation's gross national product, after adjustment for inflation, was just slightly above the level of the first quarter of 1980, and third quarter, according to preliminary figures released last week, will be no better.

title: No Headline
description: The Gender Defenders I want to congratulate Cyra McFadden for her courage in writing ''In Defense of Gender'' (On Language, Aug. 2). Her revulsion at the spaying-slash-gelding of the language is shared by many.

title: Home Clinic; DISCARDING A GARDEN HOSE? IT ISN'T NECESSARY
description: GARDEN hoses probably take more abuse than almost any other piece of equipment used frequently outside the house, so it is not surprising that they often need repair or replacement.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We have come too far, struggled too long, sacrificed too much, and have too much left to do, to allow what we have achieved for the good of all to be swept away without a fight. And we have not forgotten how to fight.'' -Lane Kirkland, president of the AFL-CIO. (1:6.)

title: ESKIMOS WORRIED ABOUT IMPACT OF OIL BOOM
description: Leaders of the 20,000 Eskimos in the Canadian Arctic say they are concerned over the impact that major oil development in the next decade will have on what is left of their people's traditional ways of life.

title: 2 RUNNING EVENTS ON MARK
description: WHITE PLAINS TWO colorful road-running events are scheduled for the county in the next two weeks. The first one, the annual BMW 15-kilometer run, will be held in the town of Harrison next Sunday. On the following Sunday, the Westchester County Run-for-Life Minimarathon, a 20-kilometer race, will be held in the White Plains area.

title: JAPAN WITHDRAWS FISHING FLEET FROM KIRIBATI
description: The Japanese have withdrawn their fishing fleet from the tuna-rich waters around these Pacific islands, unable to reach an agreement on licensing terms with the two-year-old Republic of Kiribati.

title: A COLLEGE TIBUTE TO JOAN BENNETT
description: HER voice is still husky, her eyes are as arresting as ever, her mouth remains painted in a cupid's bow. She continues to perform in occasional movies, plays and television shows. Yet Joan Bennett, an actress who has been in more than 75 films and who was part of Hollywood's most glamorous period, today describes herself as ''just keeping house.''

title: IOWA STATE 23, IOWA 12
description: The quarterback John Quinn and Dwayne Crutchfield, the tailback, each scored a touchdown, and Alex Giffords got three field goals to lift Iowa State.

title: Index; International
description: Brazilian President suffers heart attack 3 Around the World 4 Seoul said to hold 15,000 in deten- tion camps without charges 5 NATO war games: orange invad- ers versus blue defenders 6 Bonn seeking cut in contribution to Common Market budget 7 Eskimos worried about effect of oil boom on traditional ways 8 Iran says President's assassin is at large, not dead 10 Shah's niece says only gets fun out life 78 Shamisen solo and a Hayashi en- semble at Asia House 79 Joao Carlos Martins plays Bach after his own fashion 79 Chamber Music Society plays at Alice Tully Hall 79 Style 121 lovely faces launch an earl's picture book 81 Obituaries Ellery Wheeler Stone, ex-I.T.T. executive 44

title: Around the World; 3 Officials Dismissed From Rumanian Cabinet
description: The Rumanian Agriculture Minister, another high-ranking economic official and the head of the state radio and television were dismissed by President Nicolae Ceausescu today in a Cabinet shuffle reflecting concern over continuing food shortages and ideological problems.

title: AT HOME
description: ''Walk softly and carry a big radio.'' - Graffiti beneath the Manhattan Bridge in New York

title: Ideas & Trends; Cardinal Cody Strikes Back At the Critics
description: Hardly anyone in Chicago can be counted on to turn the other cheek, as The Chicago Sun-Times discovered last week when supporters of John Cardinal Cody, Archbishop of Chicago, accused the newspaper of yellow journalism in its expose of the prelate's financial practices.

title: Art View; AN AUDACIOUS INAUGURAL EXHIBITION; AKRON, Ohio
description: To inaugurate its new building - a former post office that has been adroitly redesigned to serve its new function - the Akron Art Museum has mounted a timely exhibition called ''The Image in American Painting and Sculpture, 1950-80.'' Organized by Carolyn Kinder Carr, the museum's curator, the exhibition consists of 40 works of art ranging from Willem de Kooning's ''Woman VI'' (1953) and Jasper Johns's ''Flag on Orange Field II'' (1958) to Jonathan Borofsky's ''Running Man at 2,550,116'' (1978-79) and Malcolm Morley's ''Landscape With Bullocks'' (1981). The purpose of the show is to examine what I. Michael Danoff, the director of the museum, describes as the ''continuity of styles which depend upon recognizable images'' in the painting and sculpture of the last three decades. It is Mr. Danoff's belief that in contemporary art ''the momentum now is away from abstraction and with the image,'' and this exhibition attempts to sort out and clarify the principal esthetic impulses that have contributed to this development.

title: Developer Is Slain in Attempt To Prevent Rape of Daughter
description: A prominent businessman who went to the aid of his daughter and her male friend while they were struggling with a would-be rapist was shot to death early today, the police said,

title: SCUFFLES INTERRUPT GAME OF RUGBY IN WISCONSIN
description: The visiting South African rugby team played its first match on American soil today before about 400 cheering, beer-drinking spectators.

title: Colts Sever Unitas Ties
description: Johnny Unitas, a retired quarterback who gives betting tips in the gambling magazine ''The Huddle,'' has been dropped as a speaker and representative for the Baltimore Colts at the request of Pete Rozelle, commissioner of the National Football League.

title: RUTHERFORD
description: SECURE in the sense of its own specialness, Rutherford will begin celebrating its 100th birthday today with a spry 91-year-old, rather than a teen-age beauty, as the centennial queen and with its status as a saloon-less, alcoholically ''dry'' community still intact - although somewhat breached by beer.

title: Nebraska Trounces Florida State, 34-14
description: Roger Craig rushed for 234 yards, including a 94-yard touchdown, as Nebraska beat Florida State today, 34-14.

title: VISUAL WORK GAINS A SONIC DIMENSION
description: PURCHASE OPENING today at the Neuberger Museum of the State University of New York here is a formidable display that should be not just a howling success but a whirring, clicking, chiming, humming, even melodic one, too. ''Soundings'' is the show's name, the use visual artists have made of sounds (actual or implied) its game. Conceived and orchestrated by the Neuberger's director, Suzanne Delehanty, the survey is the first of its kind to be staged in the United States. It will run thro ugh Dec. 23.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE uprising at the Union County Jail last weekend, in which inmates used a smuggled pistol to take over a wing and hold six correction officers hostage for two hours, was the latest of the recent riots, escape attempts and other troubles that county jail officials attribute largely to overcrowding.

title: Television Week
description: A New High Robert Evans is the filmmaker who produced ''The Godfather,'' ''Love Story,'' ''Chinatown,'' ''Marathon Man,'' ''Urban Cowboy'' and ''Popeye.'' A year ago, U.S. District Judge Vincent L. Broderick sentenced him to one-year's probation on a misdemeanor charge of cocaine possession. Judge Broderick said the record would be expunged if Mr. Evans ''used (his) unique talents to look for a breakthrough where others have failed in this horrible thing of drug abuse to children.''

title: NEW U.S. POLICY MAY CUT LOANS TO SMALL BUSINESSES
description: HARTFORD CHANGES in Federal tax policy may sharply limit or eliminate two programs that over the last eight years have enabled Connecticut companies to raise about $1 billion in low-cost loans.

title: Robert Edmond Wilkes Jr.  Weds Katherine Banisch
description: Katherine Frances Banisch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Francis Banisch of Charlotte, N.C., was married yesterday to Robert Edmond Wilkes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilkes of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Walter Taylor performed the ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien.

title: Around the Nation; 2 Idaho Police Officers Arrested in Phoenix
description: Two law-enforcement officers, including the police chief of Blackfoot, Idaho, have been arrested and booked for investigation of charges of solicitation of stolen property and attempted traffic in stolen property, officials said.

title: Children's Books
description: CHESTER CRICKET'S PIGEON RIDE By George Selden. Illustrated by Garth Williams. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95. (Ages 6 to 9) By KARLA KUSKIN

title: HACKENSACK WATER PLANS ITS LARGEST EXPANSION 26)
description: HARRINGTON PARK THE future bills of the Hackensack Water Company will present, in stark dollars and cents, the financial legacy of the 1980-81 water shortage: A 47 percent increase for tens of thousands of homes and industries that were forced by state law to save water from last September to May.

title: TRENTON SHIFTS SCHOOL POLICY
description: TRENTON THE state's Department of Education and the State Board of Education have offered early evidence that they would like to devote more energy this school year to fine-tuning the laws they have promulgated over the last three years and less to adopting new rules.

title: U.S. TO CURB RISE IN FLIGHTS GUIDED FROM GROUND
description: In an effort to head off potential strain, the Federal Aviation Administra tion has taken steps to put a lid f or now on any further expansion of air traffic receiving control fr om the ground.

title: Francine H. Schepps Wed
description: Francine H. Schepps, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Lew Schepps of Scarsdale, N.Y., and David E. Alexander, son of Lawrence Alexander of West Hartford, Conn., and Colleen Alexander of Phildelphia, were married yesterday at the Old Oaks Country Club in Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony.

title: Camera; MAKE YOUR OWN DUPLICATE SLIDES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Martin Hershenson is a freelance writer and photographic consultant. ''If only I had made a duplicate of that slide'' - these words are often spoken when an irreplaceable slide is lost or damaged. This can happen in many ways - because of an accident, because it got lost in the mail when you sent it in as a contest entry, or because it was not returned when you sent it to a publisher for possible use.

title: WORK INNOVATIONS IMPROVING MORALE
description: The development of new and varied work schedules in the last decade has resulted in improved employee morale and performance as well as benefits for the community at large, according to a study by the Work in America Institute.

title: James Evans 3d Weds Mary Metz
description: Mary Selden Metz, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Ronald Irwin Metz of Washington and Seal Harbor, Me., was married yesterday to James Frederick Evans 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans of Cazenovia, N.Y. Canon Roger S. Smith performed the ceremony at St.-Mary's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Northeast Harbor, Me.

title: No Headline
description: If an individual gives a gift to a legislator in return for a vote, it is called bribery. What is it called if a Presid ent, just before amajor vote, gives Congressmen ''cuff links, s eats in the PresidentialBox at Kennedy Center ... backing for sugar-p rice supports, or a slowdown on mandatory conversion to coal for industrial boilers in oil-producing states''? JEAN RICHARDS New York City ------

title: KRISTY MCNICHOL- 19 AND GROWING UP
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Stephen Farber is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles. By STEPHEN FARBER LOS ANGELES

title: Ideas & Trends; Toward Easing Broadcast Rules
description: In a move that brought comfort to television broadcasters and disquiet to the ranks of public affairs groups, the Federal Communications Commission last week voted 4-2 to urge Congressional repeal of the ''fairness doctrine'' and ''equ al time'' laws. The regulations require broadcasters to balance c onflicting views on public affairs issues and to give politicians air time to respond to their opponents.

title: YANKEES BEATEN, 8-5
description: It has been said that all good things come to those who wait, and that philosophy worked well today for the Boston Red Sox. They patiently waited for Ron Guidry to leave the game, then scored seven runs in the eighth inning and an 8-5 victory over the Yankees.

title: Topics; I.O.U.'s; Pay Thaw
description: The pay of the Federal Government's senior executives has been frozen for four years. And with inflation still going up about 9 percent this year, not even the 4.8 percent raise that the Reagan Administration now proposes for them amounts to much.

title: ANTHONY BLISS: CULTURE AND COMMERCE AT THE MET
description: Bernard Holland is a music critic for The New York Times. By Bernard Holland Once there was an opera company that knew a lot about singing but not much about making money. When it needed more, it went to the world of commerce and held out its hand. Commerce was shocked by opera's unbusinesslike ways, but in its own way it hungered for beautiful things, and it helped as best it could.

title: AUTUMN PLEASURES: MORE THAN LEAVES
description: IF April mixes memory and desire, as T.S. Eliot said, surely October produces an equally heady brew, distilled from the reds and golds of the landscape, the first sniff of mothballed twe ed, the lastbrilliant ski es before winter, a nip in the air and the anticipation of a new seas on of entertainment.

title: PETRO-LEWIS PLANS AN OFFER FOR MCRAE
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to acquire McRae Consolidated Oil and Gas Inc. for $483 million in cash. Under terms of the proposal, Petro-Lewis would pay $31 for each of McRae's 15.6 million common shares.

title: ISRAELI ASSERTS U.S. PLANS BROAD LINKS
description: The United States and Israel plan a broad spectrum of air, sea and ground cooperation under the new doctrine of strategic collaboration,according to a ranking Israeli official.

title: September Staggers
description: THE Old Man would have loved it. On a weekend when the late Casey Stengel was honored in his old ball park, his beloved Metsies terrorized the Cardinals three straight times.

title: DIXON SURPASSES DISTANCE RECORD
description: Rod Dixon, formerly of New Zealand now living in Reading, Pa., lowered his record from 1 hour 3 minutes 39 seconds to 1:02:12 today in winning the Philadelphia Distance Run of 13.1 miles for the second straight year.

title: Noble Nashua's Owner Hedges on Plans
description: After Noble Nashua won the Marlboro Cup Saturday at odds of 12-1, his owner said the colt was definitely through for the season and would not contest the Jockey Club Gold Cup on Oct. 10. Yesterday, the colt's owner gave shorter odds that he would change his mind.

title: J.G. KRAMER WEDS SARAH E. ORDOVER
description: Sarah Elizabeth Ordover, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Ordover of New York, was married yesterday to James George Kramer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Kramer of Sands Point, L.I. Rabbi Helen Ferris performed the ceremony at The Players, a private club at Gramercy Square South.

title: Shark Attack Is Confirmed
description: An autopsy confirmed that a New Jersey man who tried to swim three miles acro ss Tampa Bay on a bet was attacked by a shark and bled to death, Ma natee County officials said yesterday. Mark Meeker, 26 years old, wh o was originally reported as staying in Tampa and whose hometo wn was unknown, sufferedan eight-inch shark bite. He was the second p erson this year to die from a shark attack off Florida.

title: Charles Scharfe Sr., 86, Led
description: Charles L. Scharfe Sr., principal owner of L. K. Comstock & Company, the fourth largest electrical contracting concern in the United States, with headquarters in Danbury, Conn., died Saturday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after a short illness. He was 86 years old and lived in Fresh Meadows, Queens, and in Fort Lauderdale.

title: 14 DISSIDENTS MAY BE TRIED IN CZECHOSLOVAKIA
description: Czechoslovakia's dissident movement, already cramped in its activities by Government pressure, faces the prospect of a trial of many of its most active members that could completely immobilize it.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Baybanks Inc. said Stuart W. McBride, president and chief executive officer of Baybank United, Taunton, Mass., would also become president and chief executive officer of Baybank Merchants, New Bedford. * Black & Decker elected Eugene V. Allen corporate secretary.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 21, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Relationships; CHILDREN WITNESSING CHILDBIRTH
description: W HEN Denise Breheny gave birth to a son last March, her 7-year-old daughter, Christine, cut the umbilical cord while her 4-year-old son, Paul, watched. An hour later Christine wrote a letter to the newborn brother she had helped deliver. ''I love you Sean,'' she began. ''You are a nice boy. Do you know that I made your belly button. It's a beautiful wonderful baby!''

title: 'SOFT SPOTS' ARE SEEN BY HAIG AMONG FOES OF SAUDI AWACS DEAL
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the list of 50 senators opposed to the sale of Awacs radar surveillance planes to Saudi Arabia was ''replete with soft spots'' and that he could name a dozen senators who were ''ready to reconsider'' their position.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A pitcher, with a man on first, goes through his pitching motion although he d oes not have the ball. As he finishes his motion,the runner on first steps off the bag and is tagged by the first baseman, who had the ball. What is the ruling ?

title: GROMYKO AND HAIG
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko are to meet soon at the United Nations in an encounter that could be of vast significance for the world.

title: Joyce Selznick, Actors Agent And a Casting Director, Dies
description: Joyce Selznick, the casting director who helped George C. Scott, Faye Dunaway, Tony Curtis and Candice Bergen begin their careers, died Thursday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1981
description: International An emergency meeting in Warsaw was held by Poland's leaders, the second in four days, and when it ended they issued a vaguely worded statement saying that they were prepared to take urgent measures. The Polish press agency said that the authorities were preparing major moves, but did not indicate what they might be. (Page A1, Column 6.) The execution of 149 dissidents in Iran was r eported by Iran's official media. According to a newspaper repo rt, the head of th e the Islamic revolutionary courts said that armed demonstrators may face afiring squad at the ''scene of their crimes'' in the futur e. (A1:4.)

title: Hawks Trounce Is landers by 9-2
description: Tim Higgins and Doug Wilson scored two goals each to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to a 9-2 exhibition victory tonight over the New York Islanders.

title: Suspect Seized In Drug Killings
description: A man wanted in connection with a series of murders that have been linked to the Colombian cocaine trade in New York and New Jersey was arrested yesterday in Woodside, Queens. The suspect , 23-year-old Carlos Arango of Miami, was arrested at 2 A.M. at 50th Street and Roosevelt Avenue after a detective spotted him leaving a bar at 76th Street and Roosevelt.

title: Title to Belgian
description: Dany Bertel of Belgium won the world water-skiing speed championship today, sweeping the three-race event.

title: Hull Gets Goal as Rangers Top Capitals
description: Bobby Hull's attempt to win a job with the Rangers edged forward tonight as he scored a goal to help New York defeat the Washington Capitals, 4-1, in a Swedish exhibition tournament.

title: U.S. WELFARE CUTS BEGIN IN NEW YORK, NEW JERSEY AND CONNECTICUT
description: The first letters have gone out. ''As a result of a new Federal law (P.L. 97-35) effective Oct. 1, 1981,'' they say, ''you are no longer eligible'' to receive payments under the Aid to Families With Dependent Children Program or Medicaid.

title: YANKS SIGN ELWAY
description: John Elway, Stanford's junior quarterback, signed a professional baseball contract with the Yankees Saturday night that will permit him to play out his college football career this season and next.

title: BOMB IN BEIRUT THEATER KILLS 4
description: The fourth terrorist bomb in as many days exploded in a motion picture theater in a crowded Moslem section of west Beirut today, killing at least four people and wounding 35.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt RICHARD NIXON. The Shaping of His Character. By Fawn M. Brodie. Norton. 574 pages. Illustrated. $18.95.

title: WANTED: MIDEAST POLICY
description: Prime Minister Begin left no ambiguity in Washington about his position on the future of the occupied West Bank. He told President Reagan that Israel was simply not going to give up its physical control of the territory; no formula to meet the Camp David promise of ''full autonomy'' could encroach on that political fact.

title: Sins of Commission
description: Governor Carey is stung by criticism of the fact that foreign governments helped pay for his recent belated honeymoon trip to Europe - and he's doing something about it. He has already made a large contribution to Greek charity, he says, three times what the Greek Tourist Board contributed to his trip.

title: NANCY G. LIPNER MARRIED TO JERRY STUART KAPCHAN
description: In the Mamaroneck (N.Y.) Beach and Yacht Club Nancy Greer Lipner, daughter of Mrs. Maxine Tobias of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Leonard Lipner of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Jerry Stuart Kapchan. Rabbi David Greenberg performed the ceremony.

title: CHAIRMAN OF M.T.A. WILL ASK FOR 25 RISE FOR BRIDGE TOLLS
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that within a year he would seek a 25-cent increase in the $1 tolls on the Triborough Bridge and four other East River crossings to help finance a new plan to pour billions of dollars into the region's mass-transit system.

title: BALLET: A PROMISING YOUNG TROUPE
description: A VISIT to Stamford, Conn., seemed in order Saturday night when it promised a look at a new chamber-sized ballet company with past or present members of American Ballet Theater, the New York City Ballet, the Joffrey Ballet and other major troupes as guests.

title: Browns 20, Bengals 17
description: At CINCINNATI - A 12-yard touchdown run by Mike Pruitt with 4:20 left enabled Cleveland to offset two fourth-quarter Cincinnati scores and win its first game while handing the Bengals their first defeat.

title: POLISH REGIME SAYS AN URGENT ACTION IS BEING PREPARED
description: Amid a sense that the economic and political situation was heading for a new crisis, the Government held a second emergency session in four days today and afterward issued a vaguely worded statement that it was prepared to take urgent measures.

title: Sports World Specials; Barrel of Fun
description: Although a popular song once urged ''Be a Clown,'' Ben Eby of the Stetson World's Toughest Rodeo is not so sure that his job is the most fun-filled line of employment. Thirty-three-year-old Eby is the chief clown in the show that will be appearing at Madison Square Garden Thursday through Sunday.

title: IN DEFENSE OF A STUDY OF SAFETY IN THE CHEMICAL INDUSTRY
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY CANDIDATES GREET THE VOTERS IN A FINAL PUSH
description: Candidates in tomorrow's primary in New York City, frustrated by a 12-day delay and uncertain whether voters would be discouraged by the judicial intervention that caused the delay, wound up their last weekend of campaigning yesterday with a flurry of appearances.

title: News An alysis
description: The A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the 200 organizations that yesterday turned out a stunningly large crowd for Solidarity Day now face an even more difficult problem: organizing a movement, keeping it together, and bringing pressure on the Reagan Administration and Congress.

title: FEW NEW CAR PLANTS FOR SOUTH
description: The General Motors Corporation gave the economy of northwest Louisiana a boost earlier this month when it opened a highly automated plant to produce a new line of light-duty trucks.

title: UNIT ON HANDICAPS FACING EXTINCTION
description: Its very name must have leaped out at White House budget cutters searching the Federal bureaucracy for targets. The United States Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board, a mouse of a Federal agency, is empowered by Congress to set guidelines and requirements to make all Federally financed, supported and leased facilities accessible to the handicapped.

title: PBS Board Receives Cluster Ad Proposal
description: The board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting was told last week that the proposed cluster method of broadcast advertising on pubic television could generate as much as $164 million a year for public TV and radio.

title: CBS Airs a Follow-Up T o Desegregation Story
description: CBS News broadcast a follow-up story today on the University of North Carolina's desegregation agreement with the Federal Government after a story on the agreement last Sunday was heavily criticized by local officials as being onesided.

title: THE NOES AND CONS OF TUITION TAX CREDITS
description: To the Editor:

title: Dreaming Up a Book
description: Apparently having concluded that two vivid imaginations should be better that one, Stephen King and Peter Straub, a couple of thriller writers who regularly turn out best sellers, are going to write a novel together.

title: DEAD SHARK ENLIVENS 'VILLAGE' SCENE
description: Nobody knows how it happens that a 300-pound, eight-and-a-halffoot blue shark makes its appearance in the East Village on Saturday night. But there it is, all of a sudden, sprawled on the sidewalk at Sixth Street and Avenue A.

title: THE NOES AND CONS OF TUITION TAX CREDITS
description: To the Editor:

title: White Sox 11, A's 3
description: The White Sox broke a four-game losing streak as Rich Dotson (9-7) allowed only two hits over six innings.

title: SALVADOR LEADER, IN THE U.S., OPPOSES ADDITIONAL ADVISORS
description: The head of El Salvador's ruling military junta said today that what his Government needed most was communications equipment to wage more effective war against guerrillas in the countryside and $300 million in economic assistance to bridge a balance of payments gap.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Minimum Feasible Participation
description: Critics who say Washington knows only how to throw money at s ocial problems miss the point of Lyndon Johnson's W ar on Poverty. Its innovation was cultivating local leadership f or programs in poor communities -''maximum feasible participation '' to fill gaps left by indifferent local government and private agen cies. Now the flagship of that effort, the Community Services Admini stration, is about to sink. President Reagan has persuaded Congress to let states choose the services they will support. The odds are they will choose minimumfeasible participation.

title: Gardiner W. White, 90, Won Many Amateur Golf Crowns
description: Gardiner W. White, an outstanding amateur golfer in the metropolitan area early in this century, died Saturday at Glen Cove (L.I.) Hospital.

title: LEXICON
description: Washington is a city of words. It continually generates new words and phrases to express old ideas and each generation of bureaucratic jargon seems more obtuse than the last.

title: OPERA: 'LADY MACBETH OF MTSENSK'
description: The San Francisco Opera under Kurt Herbert Adler's regime has been known for many virtues, and Mr. Adler has put most of them on lavish display during this, his final season as general director of the company. One of his main achievements has been a commitment to the renewal of the reper tory with vital examplesof 20th-century opera, and this season's repr esentative in that category is Dmitri Shostakovich's ''Lady Macb eth of Mtsensk,'' which received its first San Francisco Opera perfor mance - and its first American performance since the mid-1930's - l ast night.

title: U.S. to Attend Patent Meeting
description: The United States is sending a delegation to a conference in Nairobi, Kenya, that will discuss revision of regulations on the protection of industrial property by patents and trademarks.

title: BALLERINA AND NOTED TEACHER
description: Felia Doubrovska, a Russian ballerina who became one of the most respected ballet teachers in America, died Friday night while shopping in midtown Manhattan, apparently of a heart attack. She was 85 years old.

title: Panhandler Shot By Transit Officer
description: A Transit Authority police officer shot and wounded a young man who attacked him with his own nightstick outside an IND subway station on the Upper West Side, the police said.

title: Heavy Civilian Casualties Reported in Afghan City
description: Soviet-backed Afghan forces inflicted heavy civilian casualties and destroyed hundreds of buildings in Afghanistan's second largest city during nearly two weeks of fighting, Afghan sources said today.

title: Miami Hopes to Improve Postal Carriers' Driving
description: The United States Postal Service has enlisted a million ''back-seat drivers'' to keep an eye on Miami's mail carriers, who have the worst accident rate in Florida.

title: ANTHONY BRANDT WEDS LORRAINE DUSKY
description: Lorraine B. Dusky of Sag Harbor, L.I., daughter of Mrs. Harry W. Dusky of Dearborn, Mich., and the late Mr. Dusky, was marri ed in Westhampton Beach, L.I., yesterday to Anthony S. Brandt, also of Sag Harbor, son of Mrs. Axel E. Brandt of Westfie ld, N.J., and the late Mr. Brandt. The Rev. Armando G. Cuellar of Ch rist Episcopal Church inSag Harbor performed the ceremony at Kinkora, a private estate.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: Packers Meet With Jefferson
description: The Green Bay Packers and John Jefferson's agent had what a team official called ''a very good meeting'' yesterday, but no agreement was reached on a contract for the star wide receiver.

title: U.S. REPORTED PLANNING SUIT AGAINST FORMER C.I.A. CHIEF
description: The Justice Department plans to sue William E. Colby, a former Director of Central Intelligence, for publishing his 1978 memoir, ''Honorable Men,'' without clearing all editions with the Government, Newsweek magazine said yesterday.

title: Lindsay Betters Two Run Marks
description: Herb Lindsay set American records for the half-marathon and for 20 kilometers today in beating a field of 700 in the Maple Leaf Half-Marathon.

title: ELIZABETH WELLS WED TO DR. ALLEN ELKIN
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Mary Wells, director of training at Bellevue Hospital, to Dr. Allen Joseph Elkin, a clinical psychologist in private practice in New York, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Wells, parents of the bride, in Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Elkin of Toronto.

title: FIGHT IN BONNANO 'CRIME FAMILY' WITH THREE MURDERS IS DESCRIBED
description: A gangland fight for control of ''the Bonanno organized-crime family'' in New York City has been described by an undercover agent who infiltrated the organization and heard about three murders.

title: LEADERS OF NUCLEAR PROTESTS SEE A SHIFT IN STRATEGY
description: Small groups of backpacking citizens, pursued by the law, have been climbing over the rocky hills here vowing to penetrate several miles of rough terrain to reach the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant and prevent it from opening.

title: F.C.C. DELAY ON PHONE PLAN FORECAST
description: The Federal Communications Commission ''almost certainly'' will delay beyond March 1982 the planned implementation of its telephone deregulation program, according to one of the agency's members.

title: CHARLES COOMBS, RETIRED U.S. AIDE
description: Charles A. Coombs, who retired as a senior vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in 1975, died yesterday at his home in Green Village, N.J., after a long illness. He was 63 years old.

title: Cindy Wuss Wins
description: Cindy Wuss of New York City won the women's division of today's Peace Marathon with a time of 2 hours 51 minutes 22 seconds fo r the 42.195-kilometer course. The winner of the men's division was Jerzy Finster of Poland in 2:17:06. A field of 2,500 competed.

title: No Headline
description: Following are the principal contested races in tomorrow's primary elections in New York City. Asterisk (*) denotes incumbent. DEMOCRATS MAYOR Edward I. Koch* Frank J. Barbaro Melvin Klenetsky COMPTROLLER Harrison J. Goldin* John C. Dearie MANHATTAN BOROUGH PRESIDENT David N. Dinkins Andrew J. Stein* CIVIL COURT Sixth District Salvatore A. Fiorella Jeffry H. Gallet Harold Tompkins BROOKLYN DISTRICT ATTORNEY Elizabeth Holtzman Norman J. Rosen QUEENS DISTRICT ATTORNEY John J. Santucci* Irving Schwartz REPUBLICANS MAYOR John A. Esposito Edward I. Koch* MANHATTAN CIVIL COURT 9th District David B. Saxe No rman C. Harlowe STATEN ISLAND CIVIL COURT 2d District Michael J. Cilmi Frank Wall

title: Accenting the Positive
description: He had to overcome a cultural imperative to do it, but Denzel Washington has finally made it to the silver screen. ''I went to a private school that punched out a lot of doctors and lawyers, but no actors,'' explained Mr. Washington, a 26-year-old son of a minister.

title: JAPAN PLANS TO RESTRAIN VIDEO SALES
description: In a move intended to reduce the threat of serious trade friction with the United States and Europe, Japan is planning to c urb its rapidly rising exports of videotape recorders, the Governmen t confirmed today.

title: BRITON TEACHING IN U.S. IS LEEDS PIANO WINNER
description: An associate professor of music at the University of Illinois, Ian Hobson, last night became the second Briton to win the prestigious Leeds International Pianoforte Competition. The victory for Mr. Hobson, who is 29 years old, guarantees him international musical engagements and recordings worth an estimated $120,000.

title: Brazilians Find 10 Bodies In Amazon Boat Wreck
description: Only 10 bodies have been recovered so far in a search for 300 people missing here in yesterday's sinking of an overloaded Amazon riverboat.

title: AGO Makes a Bid For Life Investors
description: AGO Holding, of the Netherlands, said it was making a cash tender offer of $34 each for 1.5 million shares of Life Investors Inc. The Dutch insurance and financial services company already owns 41.5 percent of the 10 million Life Investors shares outstanding.

title: Flight Attendant Dies In Mishap on Jetliner
description: A World Airways flight attendant was crushed to death in a crew elevator today aboard a jumbo jetliner carrying more than 300 passengers across the Atlantic, United States aviation officials said.

title: Everybody's Man at the U.N.
description: It has been shrewdly remarked of Kurt Waldheim that he usually avoids the charge of doing too little and is almost never accused of doing too much. In his two terms as Secretary General of the United Nations, his outstanding success has been optical. He imparts a blur. He presides without leading, rarely giving his multitude of masters cause for genuine offense. And so they may well reward him next month with another, and unprecedented, five-year term. Austrian grayness endures.

title: VALUABLE ORE FOUND IN ROCKS ERUPTING INTO SEA OF OREGON
description: ''Significant amounts'' of zinc, silver, copper and lead have been found in metal-rich rocks retrieved from an area of six or seven hot springs erupting from the sea floor 250 miles west of Astoria, Ore., the United States Geological Survey has reported.

title: Inflated Literature
description: It's been 30 years since Doris Lilly wrote ''How to Marry a Millionaire,'' and inflation, she is the first to acknowledge, has taken its toll.

title: CAROLE ANZALONE, ART DIRECTOR, WED
description: The marriage of Carole Anzalone to Douglas Newman took place yesterday at the Braidburn Country Club in Florham Park, N.J. Superior Court Judge Murray Simon of Essex County performed the ceremony.

title: Manhattan Tops Sienna by 15-6
description: Lou Toscano ran 69 yards for a touchdown to open the fourth quarter, and Joe Rabaglia sprinted into the end zone from the 7-yard line later in the period to give Manhattan College a 15-6 victory over Siena yesterday at Kennedy High School in the Bronx.

title: ALEXANDER HESTERBERG
description: Alexander G. Hesterberg Sr., a lawyer and a Democratic district leader in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn from 1950 to 1972, died yesterday of a heart attack in New York Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: LAURA HOFFBERG, LAWYER, IS BRIDE OF BARRY S. RUBIN
description: The marriage of Laura D. Hoffberg to Barry S. Rubin, New York lawyers, took place yesterday at the Manhattan Beach Jewish Center in Brooklyn. Rabbi Joseph I. Singer performed the ceremony.

title: CITY OPERA: FALL SEASON'S FIRST 'MARIA'
description: THE first ''Maria Stuarda'' of the City Opera's fall season occurred on Saturday afternoon, once again pitting Ashley Putnam's Mary against Maralin Niska's Queen Elizabeth. Both sopranos tested out these two flamboyant bel canto assignments with the company last spring, and the experience born from repetition has proven to be beneficial in both cases.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: INDIANS

title: ACTION ON MAJOR PENSION BILL MAY BE PUT OFF
description: Sentiment is growing among Senate Republicans in favor of dropping any serious Social Security legislation in the current Congress in response to the refusal of House Democrats to share responsibility for probable reductions in benefits.

title: TROUBLING STEEL SALES BY CANADA
description: Imports of Canadian steel into the United States, though relatively small, are growing rapidly, causing concern in the sluggish American market.

title: POPE SEEKS SETTLEMENT IN POLAND WITHOUT VIOLENCE OR INTERVENTION
description: Pope John Paul II called on Poles today to resolve their country's problems without bloodshed and said that Poland has the right to decide its future without outside intervention.

title: A $23.5 BILLION OIL-TAX YIELD
description: WASHINGTON LAST April, a House subcommittee led by Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, a Queens Democrat, suspected that th e huge and extraordinarily complex ''windfall profits'' tax levied on oil producers a year earlier was for some reason not yielding the Treasury as much revenue as expected. It held a day of hearings, the main discovery being that it was still too ea rly to tell what was happening.

title: DR. IDIDA ABRAMOVSKY WED
description: At Temple Hillel in North Woodmere, L.I., yesterday Dr. Idida Abramovsky, senior resident in ophthalmology at the Edward S. Harkness Eye Institute of the Columbia Presbyerian Medical Center, was married to Dr. Stewart Kaplan, attending physician in pediatrics and allergy and immunology at the New York Hospital.

title: Miss Haynie Wins
description: Sandra Haynie, a 20-year pro, posted a four-under-par 68 today to overtake Marlene Floyd and capture the $165,000 Henredon Classic.

title: An Ex-Marine Hunger Striker Buried With Military Honors
description: A former Marine who joined a hunger strike last spring to protest the Government's treatment of Vietnam veterans was buried with military honors yesterday, five days after he apparently jumped 11 stories to his death.

title: EFFECT OF CONTROLLERS' STRIKE ON BUSINESSES IS SEEN EASING
description: At the Pittsburgh Hilton, Val Troy, the general manager, was a little concerned when he found out for sure Aug. 3 that the nation's air traffic controllers were about to begin a nationwide strike. Three weeks later all his worries had been confirmed: a lot of his rooms had gone unoccupied.

title: Cards 40, Redskins 30
description: At ST. LOUIS - Jim Hart, returning to the lineup after a knee injury kept him out of last week's game, completed 12 of 22 passes for 226 yards and moved into fourth place among the N.F.L. career passers while leading St. Louis to its first victory and handing Washington its third defeat.

title: People
description: * Jerry Calabrese named publisher of Games magazine, published by Playboy Enterprises.

title: zf BUSINESS PEOPLE; AS HARBERT SELLS ASSETS, IT CONSIDERS TAKEOVERS
description: Last week John M. Harbert 3d, the founder, chairman, chief executive officer and majority stockholder of the privately owned Harbert Corporation, completed the sale of some of its properties to the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) for stock worth about $300 million. Reached in his office in Birmingham, Ala., Mr. Harbert, who calls himself ''a private guy who prefers not to be in the public eye,'' told why he decided to sell his company's coal-mining and other assets.

title: CONFUSION ON OCT. 1 WELFARE CUTS IS EXPECTED TO DELAY THEIR IMPACT
description: With a major retrenchment in Government social programs scheduled to occur Oct. 1, millions of poor Americans are facing the imminent loss of some or all of their Government benefits. But the effects may be delayed somewhat by uncertainty and confusion among state officials who must enforce the changes.

title: Jets' Patience Not a Virtue
description: IF patience is a virtue, the Jets are the National Football League's most virtuous organization. And rather than lose their patience, those who make the Jets' front-office decisions apparently prefer to keep losing games instead. Either that or the front office has confused patience with the inability to make a difficult decision.

title: RURAL DWELLERS PREPARE TO BATTLE NATURE
description: Fall in the suburbs is what the leaves do. Much is made of the leaves' spectacular color and graceful descent, but to many suburban homeowners, autumn leaves are just so many enemy paratroopers littering their lawns and clogging the gutters.

title: A CITIZEN ASSEMBLY OPPOSES THE DRAFT 814>
description: A ''substantial majority'' of the prominent citizens brought together here by the American Assembly to discuss military manpower concluded today that a return to conscription ''was neither necessary nor desirable'' at this time.

title: U.S. CAPITOL'S MODIFIED 'FREEDOM'
description: To the Editor:

title: COAST KILLINGS TIED TO HOMOSEXUALITY
description: William G. Bonin, a 34-year-old truck driver, will go on trial here tomorrow on charges of murdering 12 men and boys in a case that the authorities say throws a spotlight on the little publicized, frequently dangerous world of the male sexual hustler.

title: A Yankee in First
description: Despite what some people might think of him, George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, is a popular personality, according to some recent magazine polls.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We need that kind of cooperation and those resources, that leadership, that diplomacy, that the Saudi Government has provided.

title: LITTLE THINGS COUNT IN A VERY BIG WAY
description: Joseph W. Canzeri, an assistant to President Reagan, has two original paintings by George Catlin hanging on his office wall.

title: A BOOK ON JOHNSON SAYS HE TOOK CASH GIFTS
description: In a forthcoming biography of Lyndon B. Johnson that is excerpted in the current issue of The Atlantic Monthly, Robert A. Caro, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author, asserts, without immediate documentation, that the former President accepted large amounts of cash from lobbyists as a Senator and Vice President.

title: RYAN HALTS GIANTS
description: When the Houston Astros staked Nolan Ryan to four runs in the first inning against the Giants at San Francisco yesterday, it looked as if the Astros were on their way to an easy victory. Ryan entered the game with a league-leading 1.77 earned run average.

title: A PRIMARY FAILURE
description: To the Editor:

title: CATHOLIC COURSES FOR LASTING MARRIAGES
description: ''We've been married 11 weeks and Paul has just told me he plans to spend four or five nights a month out with the boys, bowling, or just drinking and talking. He says we both need private lives and our own circle of friends a nd that I should make similar arrangements.

title: A Down-Under Gauche
description: Jane Howard, a New York City magazine writer and author, tells a face-reddening story on herself to support the truism that supposedly sophisticated and cosmopolitan New Yorkers can be among the most provincial people in the world.

title: POOR LANDS' '80 GROWTH SPURT CITED
description: Developing countries showed a ''remarkable'' economic growth of 4.6 percent last year, more than triple the growth rate of industrial nations crippled by inflation, recession and high energy and interest costs, the World Bank reported today.

title: BOOK DEFENDS PIUS'S FAILURE TO CONDEMN NAZI ATROCITIES
description: Pope Pius XII withheld condemnation of Nazi atrocities during World War II because he did not want to jeopardize the lives of thousands of Jews who were being concealed by the Vatican, according to a newly published book by a Roman Catholic historian.

title: News Analysis
description: The fourth meeting since March between President Reagan and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau, held in Grand Rapids, Mich., last Thursday, appears t o have done little to dissipate what the American Ambassador here h as called ''a gathering storm'' in United States-Canadian relations.

title: British Colony of Belize Independent at Midnight
description: Belize, Britain's last colony on the American mainland, becomes independent tonight. However, the festivities are overshadowed by a dispute with Guatemala, which says Belize is its own.

title: Lyle D. Goodhue, 77, Inventor Of Wartime 'Bug Bombs,' Dies
description: Dr. Lyle D. Goodhue, inventor of the ''bug bombs'' used in World War II to control malaria-carrying mosquitoes in the tropics, died late Friday. He was 77 years old.

title: St. John L.I. Victor
description: St. John the Baptist of West Islip, defending Division A champion in the Nassau-Suffolk Catholic High School Football League, defeated St. Dominic's of Oyster Bay, 41-21, today for its 11th straight victory over two seasons. It was the season opener for both teams.

title: MCCUTCHEON WINS
description: Jesse McCutcheon of Adelphi University won the Manufacturers Hanover New Harlem 10-kilometer run yesterday morning in 31 minuites 24.4 seconds. McCutcheon, who is 22 years old, scored by 70 yards over Anibal Riversa of the New York Track and Field Circuit, who crossed the finish line in the 6.2-mile event in 31.37. Merenette Simmons of Bermuda won the women's title in 37.29.

title: Buckingham Palace Arrest
description: A 17-year-old British youth carrying an air rifle was arrested outside Buckingham Palace today, the police said. A Scotland Yard spokesman said a search of the young man's clothing had produced the ''offensive weapon.'' The youth was held for questioning, the police said.

title: SYSTEMS PLANNING PICKS REIN TO LEAD COMPANY
description: At the Systems Planning Corporation, a diversified professional service firm with units in the engineering, architecture, landplanning and other fields, Harold E. Rein, 55 years old, has been appointed president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Stanley L. Ross, 60, who continues as chairman of the company, which has its headquarters in Los Angeles.

title: Solomon D. Altchek, Founder Of a Sephardic Jewish Center
description: Solomon D. Altchek, a printing company executive and founder and president of the Sephardic Jewish Center in Forest Hills, Queens, died Saturday af an illness of six months at Mount Sinai Hospital. A resident of Manhattan, he was 77 years old.

title: MICHIGAN G.O.P. HAILS EQUAL STANDING IN POLL
description: Michigan Republicans, pleased but not ecstatic about President Reagan's economic policies, today cheered the news that they now command as many supporters in this state as its once-dominant Democrats.

title: Raiders Set Back Seahawks by 20-10
description: Derrick Jensen, who came off the bench early in the game to replace the injured Mark van Eeghen, ran for 84 yards and scored a touchdown as the Raiders defeated the Seattle Seahawks, 20-10, yesterday in Oakland.

title: Bridge: Ban on R eese Had Roots In H is Writings on Game
description: When it became known recently that the credentials committee of the World Bridge Federation was refusing to accept Terence Reese of London as the nonplaying captain of the British team in the l981 world championship, it was generally assumed that some old history was at the back of it. But that assumption now seems to have been wrong.

title: JEANETTE EGAN
description: Jeanette Egan, a freelance writer and former Third Selectman of Westport, Conn., died of cancer yesterday at her home in Westport. She was 72 years old.

title: Associated Press
description: BOSTON TEACHERS VOTE AGAINST A STRIKE: A member of the Boston Teachers Union burning her union card yesterday after the group voted, 1,404 to 836, not to initiate a strike today that would have canceled classes for about 60,000 students. Classes began on schedule earlier this month after the union, whose ranks were thinned recently by nearly 1,000 layoffs, voted to give its leadership more time to negotiate with school officials. The card-burnings were an expression of some teachers' assertion that there ''is no union.''

title: DANCE: MEG EGINTON
description: TITLES of dances are not always to be taken literally. Yet if a choreographer decides to give a certain dance a certain title, that title presumably indicates something about the work's tone or atmosphere.

title: EDITOR'S USE OF CODY CRITIC'S NOTES FOCUS OF DISPUTE
description: While this city is preoccupied with the investigation into charges of financial impropriety against the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, John Cardinal Cody, another tale, a tantalizing story within a story, is making the rounds here.

title: NEW HOMES IN SAN DIEGO ARE EMPTY AS HIGH INTEREST RATES DETER BUYERS
description: Almost 7,000 new homes are for sale these days in San Diego County. They stand silent and empty, the new ghost towns of ''the American dream.''

title: FUED EMBROILS BOLSHOI BALLET
description: MOSCOW ALONG with cosmonauts and Olympic Gold Medal winners, few things bolster the pride of the ordinary Russian like the Bolshoi Ballet. Throughout the world, the company is synonymous with dance.

title: CLEMSON'S UP UPSET OF GEORGIA OPENS RACE FOR TOP RANKING
description: Danny Ford's first game and first victory as Clemson's head coach was in the 1978 Gator Bowl when the Tigers upset Ohio State, 17-15. That was Woody Hayes's last game as coach of the Buckeyes because he was dismissed for striking a Clemson p layer n ear the sideline late inthe game.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Bottoms Up, Chester By Philip H. Dougherty

title: A Weighty Decision
description: According to his superiors in Logan Valley Township, Pa., Joseph Lynch was a fairly good police officer, good enough, at least, for them to overlook the fact that at 500 pounds the six-foot officer exceeded the department's weight limits.

title: The Scope Of Food Series;
description: In a gray building about the size of a large movie theater here on the Colorado State University campus, the Federal Government is stockpiling several billion seeds - samples of all known varieties of the world's major food crops.

title: EVIDENCE ILLEGALLY OBTAINED BY POLICE
description: When a vicious criminal escapes punishment because evidence of guilt was kept from a jury, the public has a right to be outraged. A judge withholds incriminating evidence when there is overwhelming proof that a policeman violated the Constitution, either out of incompetence or arrogance. The Attorney General's Task Force on Violent Crime recently recommended a solution to the problem: The judge at a criminal trial should ignore a police officer's breaking of the law and instead should focus on the criminal -the one without the blue uniform.

title: CITY OPERA: THE FIRST 'FLEDERMAUS'
description: JOHANN STRAUSS'S ''Die Fledermaus'' which received i ts first performance o f the season on Friday night at the New York City Opera,was very like the ''Die Fledermaus'' that was seen last year at the New York City Opera. The production has the mark of its director, Gerald Freedm an and its stage director, Christian Smith, and though the singers u nder the costumes have changed, the effect has not.

title: WILBERT MONTGOMERY RUSHES TO THE TOP
description: WILBERT MONTGOMERY, the Philadelphia Eagles' exemplary running back starting off so well this season, is one of those football players who commits his body to the contact of the sport without any idea of compromise. And Montgomery, who is not very big in the context of the National Football League at 5 feet 10 inches and 195 pounds, runs so hard and so fast that the forces of impact seem certain to produce damage.

title: U.S. SHIFT ON BUSING PUTS SEATTLE IN THE SPOTLIGHT
description: Three years ago, under threat of a suit that would charge it with running a racially segregated school system, the Seattle school board began a mandatory busing plan to spread out the enrollment of members of minority groups, who were heavily concentrated in about a third of the schools in the district.

title: Mears Regains Driving Title
description: Rick Mears swept past Mario Andretti on the final turn today to win an accident-marred 150-mile race for Indy-type cars at Michigan International Speedway.

title: OUTDOORS: GOING INLAND FOR NEW ENGLAND SALMON
description: PARMACHENEE LAKE, Me. VISITING a remote lake for a few days is something like glimpsing the face of a lovely woman in a crowd: the encounter, albeit ephemeral, quickens the heart with wonder and delight.

title: RELIEF FOR THE CLEARING HOUSES clearing banks (page D5)
description: New York's leading bankers are likely to sleep better after Sept. 30. On Oct. 1, as a result of a technical change in the system through which international payments are processed, an overnight risk amounting to billions of dollars is expected to be eliminated.

title: DUMONT TO BE U.S. ATTORNEY IN JERSEY, G.O.P. CHIEF SAYS
description: W. Hunt Dumont, a 40-year-old former prosecutor, will be nominated by President Reagan to be United States Attorney for New Jersey, the state's Republican chairman said yesterday.

title: Advertising; Bates Acts To Regain Audiences
description: THE three major television networks could lose an estimated total of $100 million in annual advertising revenues if a tactic initiated by Ted Bates & Company is adopted by the other ad agencies.

title: BACKUP MAN FOR BRAZILIANS
description: As unwelcome as it was, the heart attack that has temporarily idled the President of Brazil, Joao Baptista Figueiredo, has produced an aftermath that represents another gain for the political liberalization program he has been leading.

title: A SENSE OF BELONGING
description: Daniel Yankelovich, the sociologist and pollster, has had yet another look at the way Americans feel about themselves and concludes we are groping for a new set of attitudes.

title: QADDAFI IS NEW CHIP IN HORN OF AFRICA POKER GAME
description: Somali officials and Western diplomats are concerned about a new involvement in the Horn of Africa by Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: 2 HOMERS FOR PEREZ
description: The Boston Red Sox, seemingly shorn of much of their talent last winter, continued today to make summer believers out of the winter doubters.

title: Keeping Wealth in the Family
description: When the torch is now passed to a new generation , the fire will burn a little brighter. With hardly a peep of protest, Federal estate and gift taxes have been virtually eliminated. By 1987, only three estates in a thousand will pay Federal taxes, vastly fewer than before. That's as it should be, says the Reagan Administration: estate taxes yield only $7 billion a year while enormously discouraging savings and encouraging legal finagles.

title: Tomahawk Missile Given Its First Nighttime Test
description: The United States conducted its first night test of a land attack Tomahawk cruise missile yesterday, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

title: OLYMPIC ISSUES TOBE WEIGHED
description: BADEM, West Germany, Sept. 20 - Representatives from the 147 nations that compete in the Olympic Games will open the 11th Olympic Congress Tuesday in this resort town.

title: JANE KENNIS WED TO ROBERT CRISTAL
description: Jane R. Kennis and Dr. Robert M. Cristal were married yesterday at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing Meadow Park, Queens by Rabbi Mark Winer. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Kennis of West New York, N.J., and her husband is the son of Etta Cristal of Brooklyn, N.Y., and the late Ben Cristal.

title: Miss Hoimes Bride of John Hirschfeld
description: Margaret Hoimes, daughter of Constantine Hoimes of Bethlehem, Pa., and Efemia Hoimes of New York and Peak's Island, Me., was married yesterday to John Duskin Hirschfeld, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Hirschfeld. The ceremony was performed in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University by Rabbi Roy Rosenberg and Bishop Gerasimo Vlasopoulos.

title: METS TOP CARDS IN NINTH, 7-6
description: Much has been written and said about the process called growing up. For some, the process takes years. For others, it is never complete. Then there are those who grow up quickly, under the pressure of the moment. Yesterday afternoon, in the Mets' most crit ical game since the players' strike ended Aug. 10, Mookie Wilson and Hubie Brooks, the red-hot rookies on whose shoulders the Mets f ortunes have fallen, grew up. Brooks led a 22-hit barrage against first-place St. Louis with four singles and Wilson hit a two-run, g ame-winning homer in thebottom of the ninth as the Mets stunned the C ardinals, 7-6, at Shea Stadium.

title: FALCONS REMAIN UNBEATEN
description: With a 34-17 victory over the San Francisco 49ers yesterday in Atlanta, the Falcons had won their first three games for the first time in the club's 16-year history. Bill Walsh, the 49ers' coach, said he thought the Falcons were ready to make a serious run for a spot in the Super Bowl game, but Leeman Bennett, the Atlanta coach, was not so sure.

title: PISARENKO WINNER OF WEIGHT LIFTING
description: Anatoly Pisarenko won the super-heavyweight (more than 2 43 pounds) titl e today to complete the Soviet Union's triumph in the 35th world and European weight-lifting championships.

title: Panel to Consider Plan For New City in Florida
description: A plan to hold a referendum on incorporating a 15-square-mile area of ghettos and housing projects into a single city next to Miami will be considered Tuesday by the Dade County Commission.

title: Dutch Policemen Fight Protesters at Atom Plant
description: Riot policemen battled thousands of demonstrators today to break up blockades outside a nuclear power plant, leaving 100 people injured in two days of protests, the organizers said.

title: Asia Media Network To Be Formed in U.S.
description: Duck Y. Song, an American-educated Korean native, who is also a senior vice president and management supervisor at Leber Katz Partners, is leaving the agency to set up the Song Communications Group, advertising reps for Oriental media in this country.

title: Student Killed in Texas Fire
description: A two-alarm fire in a dormitory at Texas College killed one student and slightly injured seven others early today, the authorities said.

title: DAVID EYES WEDS CAROLYN J. PAPPAS
description: Carolyn Jane Pappas, daughter of Nicholas Peter Pappas of New York and Ruth Reynolds of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to David Morgan Eyes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Eyes of Westport, Conn., at the Christian Community in New York by the Rev. James H. Hindes, pastor of the community..

title: TOWNSEND VICTOR
description: Peter Townsend of Britian shot a two-under-par 70 today to win the Belgin Laurent Perrier Golf Trophy by six strokes.

title: Lilco to Give Gas Users A Refund of $9 Million
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said today that its natural-gas customers would be receiving $9 million in refunds over the next 12 months.

title: MARUZEN TYPIFIES JAPAN'S OIL PROBLEM
description: In Japan, where appearances and face count for so much, there are certain measures that a company, no matter how serious its financial problems, tries to avoid.

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 21, 1981; The Economy
description: The Government's telephone deregulation program will ''almost certainly'' be delayed beyond next March, a Federal Communications Commission member predicted. At the program's cen ter is a plan by A.T.& T. to s et up a unit that would sell a wide range of communication s equipment on a deregulated basis. (D1.)

title: Brewers Lose, Fall From First
description: Lenn Sakata, a 27-year-old utility infielder from Hawaii, took over the starting shortstop position from Mark Belanger about 10 days ago and his presence in the lineup has helped the Baltimore Orioles' offense.

title: Urban League Seeking A Successor to Jordan
description: The search for a successor to Vernon E. Jordan Jr. as president of the National Urban League begins in earnest today with no clearcut candidate but with several names being mentioned as serious possibilities.

title: Outspoken Bishop Is Elected By East German Protestants
description: East Germany's Protestant churches today elected as their leader Dr. Werner Krusche, a bishop with a reputation for speaking out freely on the church's role in Communism.

title: WILL COLUMBIA'S LIONS ROAR AGAIN?
description: THE pictures of Lou Little, Columbia's legendary football coach, had been discovered in closets, dusted off and hung in the office of Coach Bob Naso. This was no time to talk about the cruel numbers, the decaying stadium, the acceptance of mediocrity, the losing syndrome, or the disappointments of a generation of Lions.

title: CAUTIOUS OPTIMISM ON BONDS
description: The trend t oward lower short-term interest rates has aroused some cautious opti mism in the bond market. Securities dealers are still concerned that heavy borrowing by the Government co mbined with a growing economy would mean higher interestrates, but a few suggest that the near-term outlook is for lower rates. Whethe r a rate decline can be sustained into 1982 is much disputed.

title: U.S. Is Urged to Cut Quota for Indochinese
description: The United States should cut its quota for refugees from Indochina by one-third to one-half next year and admit only those fleeing persecution and not simply seeking ''the land of milk and honey,'' a Senate staff report said today.

title: THEATER: DAVE ALLEN IN EVENING OF COMEDY
description: born, London-based comedian who brought his act to Broadway Saturday night, is a most appealing fellow. Though at the brink of middle age, he still has the innocent mischievousness of an errant choir boy about him; he doesn't have to work at being cute. Indeed, he successfully creates the illusion that he isn't working at all. ''I wander around, and I chat,'' he explains in his introductory remarks, and so he does. Not for him is the hostile, sweaty aggressor's stance of the archetypal American comic. Mr. Allen looks so comfortable and relaxed that the audience can't help but feel at home, too.

title: SUN ELECTRIC GETS A NEW PRESIDENT
description: Keith P. Mazurek, who is 57 years old and has been in the automotive industry for many years, has joined the Sun Electric Corporation, a major manufacturer of electronic diagnostic equiment for cars and other vehicles, as president. He succeeds Frank Perna Jr., who resigned from the Chicago-based company.

title: France Car Registration
description: New car registrations in France fell 20.4 percent in August, to 105,040 from 132,020 in July, but were slightly higher than the 103,560 registrations in August last year, the French car makers assoc iation said. Registrations for the first eight months of 1981 totaled 1.21 million, down 4.7 percent from the similar perio d in 1980, the group said Friday.

title: 76 LEADING WOMEN OF FASHION HONORED AT SHOW
description: ''War veterans,'' said Eleanor Lambert, founder of the Coty Awards, patting Geraldine Stutz on the shoulder. ''It's like a meeting of war veterans.'' ''Yes,'' Mi ss Stutz, president of Henri Bendel, replied with a laugh. ''We'r e the bustle brigade.''
