What these two prominent members of the fashion industry were talking about was a benefit last Thursday at the Fashion Institute ofTechnology to preview an exhibition entitled ''50 Years of American Women in Fash ion.'' They and 74 other ''veterans,'' past and present,were honored by the institute and by the Fashion Group Foundation, anorganization of women in the industry celebrating its 50th anniversary.

title: TV: IRISH CHARM ON AMERICAN CABLE
description: IRISH television - more precisely Radio Telefis Eireann (RTE) -has entered the American cable parade, joining a lineup of foreign programming that already includes French, Italian, British, Japanese, Chinese, Ukrainian and other nationalities. The Irish, like the British, have an immediate language edge in this market and, purely in terms of the joyous or playful uses of English, the Irish generally maintain their traditional edge over the British.

title: Polish Envoy Seeks Asylum
description: A Polish diplomat here has requested political asylum in Sweden, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today. Wit Wojtowicz, a first secretary at the Polish Embassy, was said to have sought asylum for himself and his family.

title: Beardless Wonder
description: The man at Gimbels in the light brown ensemble, complete with brown and yellow striped tie, was bac k in the limelight he loves, signing autographs be hind a glass-topped desk in the middle of the toy department on the sixth floor. Because of advertisements in the papers, the l ine to his desk was long on Saturday, stretching 30 to 40 yards. But some people had difficulty recognizing the object of their affecti on, despite his diamond-studded National Basketball Association c hampionship ring from 1973.

title: Broncos 28, Colts 10
description: ''I waited three years for my first touchdown and now they start coming in bunches,'' said Steve Watson, a wide receiver for Denver, after he caught three of Craig Morton's four touchdown passes.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: NATO VS. NATO
description: War and war games have one thing in common: the unexpected is an ever-present element. The manner in which troops handle the unexpected is a sign of their effectiveness. Units of the United States Seventh Infantry Division were pulled out of their base at Fort Ord, Calif., to particpate in NATO's Certain Encounter excercise.

title: Phone Number to Call For Voting Locations
description: City Democrats and Republicans who are in doubt about the location of their polling place for tomorrow's primary can call the Board of Elections at 267-9800 today from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. and tomorrow from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.

title: BRIEFING
description: K REMLINOLOGISTS are trying not to read too much into the fact that their own section of overt Soviet intelligence analysts is being moved off the grounds of the Central Intelligence Agency's main office campus in the Virginia suburb of Langley. A plot of sorts - a blueprint for additional office space - is the mundane reason given for the move to another C.I.A. site in the Virginia bedroom community of Vienna. Some of the more irrepressible analysts are wondering whether the change was dictated by William J. Casey, the new C.I.A.director and an old hand in the business.

title: Index; International
description: Qaddafi casts his shadow over Horn of Africa A2 Reporter's N o tebook: War games in West Germany A3 Bomb in a Beirut theater kills four and wounds 35 A3 Israeli says U.S. plans broad mili- tary cooperation A5 Salvadoran leader, in U.S., op- poses additional advisers A8 Around the World A9 Pope seeks settlement in Poland without intervention A12 14 Czechoslovak dissidents may be facing trials A13 Government/Politics U.S. board on handicapped access facing extinction A17 Michigan poll finds two parties neck and neck A19 Action on major Social Security bill put off A21 Washington Talk Briefing B12 The Calendar B12 Lexicon B12 African exile's visit a foreign policy flop B12 Rank has its privileges, but not without a struggle B12 General Around the Nation A16 Homosexuality playing a role in murders in California A16 Editor's use of a Cody Critic's papers focus of a dispute A16 Living quickens in New York City as autumns moves in B1 Suburban residents prepare to battle autumn B1 On Fifth Avenue, it was a day for browsing at the Book Fair B2 Workers tackle tons of trash left from Central Park concert B3 F.B.I. agent describes fight for control of crime ''family'' B15 New ghost towns of empty homes bespeak a crippled industry D13 SportsMonday Baseball: Brooks, Wilson lead Mets to 7-6 victory C1 Brewers lose to Orioles, 8-2, fall from first place C5

title: Henderson Receives 2 d Lanier Assignment
description: Henderson Advertising in Greenville, S.C., has received its second new product assignment from Lanier Business Products.

title: Springboks in Albany; Court Hearing Today
description: An orderly crowd of 50 protesters chanting ''Springboks go home, racists go home'' greeted the arriving South African rugby team tonight at the Albany County Airport.

title: WEISKOPF TRIUMPHS ON 68-278
description: Tom Weiskopf shot a four-under-par 68 in blustery winds today and won the $350,000 LaJet Classic to become the fourth man to earn more than $2 million on the pro golf.

title: GOOD DAY FOR BROWSING AT FIFTH AVE. BOOK FAIR
description: At 1:43 P.M . yesterday, one dark cloud passed between Fifth Avenue and a brillia nt September sun, and Wonder Woman - who was stationed with Batman i n front of the Warner Books booth - flinched as raindrops fel l on her bare shoulders.

title: Primary Campaign Is Winding Down
description: Candidates seeking votes yesterday for tomorrow's city primaries included Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, top left, and Assemblyman John C. Dearie, far left, his opponent; Mayor Koch, candidate for both Republican and Democratic mayoral nominations, and David N. Dinkins, who is running for Manhattan Borough President. Page B1.

title: Market Place; Merger Price Stirs Protests
description: THE American General Corporation and the Credithrift Financial Corporation announced Friday that they had agreed to merge. This followed word in Wall Street early last week that the Wickes Companies, the San Diego building supply enterprise, had sold its 9.8 percent position in Credithrift to American General.

title: BEGIN DENIES A LINK BETWEEN AWACS AND U.S. STRATEGIC TIES WITH ISRAEL
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today that in his talks with President Reagan and other American officials, no hint was given that any link existed between the sale of surveillance aircraft to Saudi Arabia and broad strategic cooperation with Israel.

title: TV-Side Judges
description: The three professional judges who sat at ringside during the welterweight unification championship fight between Sugar Ray Leonard and Thomas Hearns last week each had Hearns leading after 13 rounds before Leonard won by a knockout in the 14th. On a rounds-won basis, Charles Minker had Hearns ahead, 9-4.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: ON THE EDGE IN POLITICS
description: In a political campaign, all the high-priced consultants, the commercials, the rude awakenings before dawn to campaign at subway stations or the Staten Island ferry, the late-night meetings 15 hours later, the tense debates and the weariness of the same predictable questions and the same pat answers come down to one thing: trying to get the edge on the opposition.

title: BANKERS' HOURS TAKE ON NEW MEANING
description: At 2 A.M., it hardly seems like a bank. Only a handful of desks are occupied in the block-sized room, while during the day 134 people are kept busy there. A motorcyclist's helmet sits atop one desk, and radios quietly hum at one or two others.

title: CHARGERS TRIUMPH OVER CHIEFS, 42-31
description: The San Diego Chargers scored six touchdowns against Kansas City today, the last one by Gary Johnson, a defensive tackle, which finally secured a 42-31 victory over the Chiefs.

title: SSHH!-CROQUET CHAMPIONSHIPS UNDER WAY
description: David E. Skinner, an owner of the Seattle Seahawks football team, agreed with Stephen Hirst of Olean, N.Y., a former offensive tackle for Cornell, that playing tournament croquet could give them as much excitement as football. ''Even though,'' Mr. Hirst said, ''you keep all the violence and anger inside.''

title: WILKINS'S ROLE IN BROWN VS. BOARD OF EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: All That Jazz
description: The Utah Jazz has been deep in the shadows during its seven National Bask etball Association seasons, the first five in New Orleans. The Jazz has never qualified for the playoffs and last season won on ly 28 games while losing 54.

title: Commodities; A Federal Regulatory Turf Battle
description: COMMODITY futures traders have long conside red their market as a place where people buy what they don't want f rom those who don't have the goods they sell. Actually, a futures market is simply a place that provides trade hedgers with a mean s of transferring risk to willing speculators as well as serving as a ''price discovery'' mechanism rather than a medium for buying and selling physical goods.

title: ELAINE LEARSON, MODEL, MARRIED
description: Elaine Learson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. T. Vincent Learson of New York and Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Paul Charbin of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andre Charbin of Lyons, France. Justice Samuel J. Silverman of the State Supreme Court Appelate Division performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Cerf in New York.

title: DEBORAH BERNSTEIN IS BRIDE TO ARNE ABROMOWITZ
description: Deborah Lois Bernstein, a cash management coordinator for the Bank of Tokyo Trust Company in New York, was married yesterday to Arne Macy Abramowitz, director of training for the New York City Parks Department. Rabbi Sidney Greenberg, assisted by Cantor Charles Davidson, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bernstein, parents of the bride, in Pleasant Valley, Pa.

title: U.S. EASY WINNER IN RYDER CUP GOLF
description: Class will tell in the long run, as the United States team of professional golfers showed today in the third and final round of the 14th Ryder Cup matches. The Americans won seven matches, lost three and tied two; the day's score was 8 points to 4, and the cumulative score was 18 1/2 to 9 1/2.

title: Redford Gets 2d Billing
description: President Reagan may be proof that actors can become effective politicians, but if Robert Redford has similar ambitions, he may want to pass up next year's Senate race in Utah.

title: RUSTING FOUND IN KEY SECTION OF 17 REACTORS
description: A major component of the Consolidated Edison Company's eight-yearold Indian Point 2 nuclear plant is corroding far faster than original ly expected, and the utility fears the plant may have tobe shut down for a full year for repairs costing $100 million.

title: BROWNS SET BACK BENGALS
description: A defensive mistake cost Miami a touchdown against the Houston Oilers yesterday, but the Dolphins made up for it as they sacked Ken Stabler, the Oiler quarterback, eight times for 62 yards in losses and came away with a 16-10 victory in Houston.

title: LEADER IN EXILE PLEADS HIS CASE IN THE CAPITAL
description: A former Prime Minister of Zaire came to town last week, armed with documents and painting a picture of a nation drained by corruption and exhausted by repression. For seven long days he went from meeting to meeting, interview to interview, telling anyone who would listen that the people of Zaire had had enough of the regime of Mobutu Sese Seko and were on the point of insurrection.

title: IN METROPOLIS, LIVING SHIFTS TO A FASTER PACE
description: Fall will arrive at about 11:05 P.M. tomorrow - and the fact is it won't make a bit of difference. True, the sun will cross the equator then, thereby assuring an impe ccable autumnal equinox. But as everyone around here knows, fall in New York arrives the day after Labor Day. ''That's wh en they all come out of the woodwork, out of the ground, out o f the trees, out of I don't know where,'' says Alphine Stevenson, jo b placement counselor for Cosmopolitan Personnel Systemsof Wall Stree t, speaking of her clients, who come looking for jobs aslegal secreta ries.

title: VOLUME GROWS FOR NEW BOND ISSUES
description: This week's volume of new corporate bond issues could be the largest in two months, with securities firms reporting slightly more than $1 billion of new debt issues scheduled for public sale.

title: JETS LOSE, 38-10, TO STEELERS
description: Chuck Noll's Steelers won by 38-10 today from Walt Michaels's Jets, but the two coaches had something in common: both were expected to be back next week.

title: A Subduer of Hinckley Dies
description: Frank J. McNamara, who helped subdue the man accused of attempting to assassinate President Reagan, has died at the age of 62. He died Friday, three days after surgery for a bleeding ulcer. Mr. McNamara, president of the Ohio Carpenters District Council, was in Washington for a meeting the day of the attack on the President and was waiting to see Mr. Reagan leave the Washington Hilton.

title: 'ARMY' MOVES IN TO CLEAN PARK AFTER CONCERT
description: An army of Parks Department laborers backed by convoys of garbage trucks, bulldozers and vacuum sweepers scoured the Great Lawn in Central Park yesterday. The workers removed tons of garbage left by nearly half a million fans of Simon and Garfunkel, the singing duo, during a free concert Saturday evening.

title: Bread, Ice Cream and Peril in Poland
description: Poland seems to be crossing a new threshold of danger. The public has not been given a choice between bread or circuses. Beset by unrelieved shortages, the choice is more like bread or ice cream. Those, John Darnton reported in The Times the other day, were the only two items left on the shelves of one of Warsaw's largest supermarkets. And as daily life gets harder, increasing internal pressures, external political pressure also mounts.

title: GENERAL MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
BASKETBALL
description: Philadelphia (NBA) - Sale of franchise to Harold Katz was approved unanimously by National Basketball Association.; COLLEGE Western Connecticut State - Named Joseph Konlushesky as basketball coach.; FOOTBALL Philadelphia (NFL) - Signed Mickey Fitzgerald, fullback.

title: Japan Gold Imports Up
description: Japan imported a record 22.3 tons of gold in July, excluding coins, nearly double the 11.4 tons imported in June and about two-thirds of last year's total imports of 31.8 tons, according to Customs figures released today. In the first seven months of 1981, the Japanese imported 84 tons of gold, and total gold imports this year are expected to surpass 1973's record of 127.8 tons. Analysts said the recent low gold price and appreciation of the yen against the dollar brought the domestic gold price into the reach of salary earners.

title: Soviet Mission Visits Malta
description: A four-member Soviet delegation arrived here today to prepare for the opening of an embassy here. A Soviet spokesman said the visitors would look for a suitable building to house the embassy, and would meet with Maltese officials.

title: REVERSAL SOUGHT IN CONVICTION OF MRS. HARRIS
description: The lawyers for Jean S. Harris, who is serving a sentence of 15 years to life in prison for the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, are seeking a reversal of her conviction, citing what they say are eight trial errors.

title: BIOGRAPHER TO DOCUMENT CHARGES ON JOHNSON
description: Robert A. Caro, the author, said yesterday that his new biography of Lyndon B. Johnson would document, ''paragraph by paragraph,'' assertions that the former President accepted ''envelopes stuffed with cash'' as a Congressman and Vice Preside nt and had, as President, handled business affairs that were supposed to be in a blind trust.

title: New Terrorist Bombings Keep Lebanon on Edge
description: A terrorist bombing campaign continued in Lebanon today. The state radio said that an explosive charge rigged inside a gas cylinder went off prematurely in a store that sells bottled gas canisters in a residential neighborhood of Tripoli.

title: RULES WOULD REMOVE 10 PERCENT OF FAMILIES NOW ON WELFARE ROLLS
description: Richard S. Schweiker, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, issued new regulations today that he said would cut off benefits for approximately 10 percent of the 3.9 million families receiving welfare, while saving the Federal Government $1.1 billion in the coming fiscal year.

title: A Freshman President Greets N.Y.U. Class
description: He has degrees from Harvard and Oxford and honorary degrees from nearly a score of other colleges and universities, but, as John Brademas noted yesterday in an address to incoming students at New York University, he, too, is a freshman.

title: INDIANS TOP LACKLUSTER YANKS
description: The Yankees opened their final home stand of the season last night with a lackluster 5-0 loss to the Cleveland Indians, the only team in the American League East that has virtually no chance of making the playoffs.

title: Wells Fargo Gain
description: Wells Fargo & Company, parent of the Wells Fargo Bank, said it expected to report a tax-free gain of $7 million, or 30 cents a share, from an exchange of up to 600,000 newly issued shares of its common for certain of its notes and debentures. The company said it would exchange the shares for the $20 million principal amount of its outstanding 8 5/8 percent notes due 1998 and 8.60 percent debentures due 2002 owned by Morgan Stanley and Company.

title: 'FALSETOS' WILL MOVE
description: ''March of the Falsettos,'' the musical that has been playing since April at Playwrights Horizons, will move Oct. 13 to the Westside Arts Theater, 407 West 43d Street. The show, written by William Finn, tells the story of a man who leaves his wife and son for his homosexual lover, but still has longings for a family life.

title: PUNJAB TENSE AFTER ARREST OF SIKH MILITANT LEADER
description: Punjab was tense today in the wake of the arrest on murder charges of a Sikh militant whose followers carry spears and swords and live lives reminiscent of crusading knights.

title: Subterranean Search
description: The prospects for extracting geothermal energy from subterranean formations in most of Europe are less promising than in such recently volcanic areas as Lardarello in Italy, Wairakei in New Zealand or along active faults, as in California. Nevertheless, in a series of joint government-university projects in West Germany, holes have been drilled at several sites to explore ways to extract energy from deeply buried hot, dry rock.

title: TOP-RANKING SINGERS STAR IN EXTENSIVE RESTAGING
description: AS a rule, the Metropolitan Opera begins each season with a familiar production staffed with as many top-ranking singers as it can round up and/or afford. Last night's performance seemed on paper to be another such traditional opening. The opera, after all, was Bellini's ''Norma,'' in nominally the same production that dates back to 1970, when Joan Sutherland, Marilyn Horne, Carlo Bergonzi and Cesari Siepi were the principals. However, as it turned out, very little of the evening could be recognized from previous ''Normas'' in the house. The three leading singers were taking their parts for the first time at the Metropolitan and so was the condu ctor, James Levine. Moreover, the sets had been extensively redes igned by their creator, Desmond Heeley, and Fabrizio Melano had resta ged the entire production. The tenor, Placido Domingo, was a ppearing for the first time anywhere as Pollione, the unfortunate Ro man proconsul and fatherof Norma's two children. Mr. Domingo made a s plendidly heroic figure out of Pollione, who emerges in many performa nces as a male cipher between two female exclamation marks. His voi ce was equally heroic, though it was pressed to the limits of its en durance in Pollione's punishing first-act recitative and cavatina.

title: Olympic Leaders Report Gains to Avert Boycott
description: BADEN, West Germany, Sept. 21 (AP) - Olympic leaders claimed today to have made big strides toward heading off a possible African boycott of the 1984 Summer Games at Los Angeles.

title: Idaho and Oregon Crews Battle Four Forest Fires
description: By United Press International Firefighters battled thick smoke and flames yesterday from three forest fires in Idaho and one in Oregon.

title: ROPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After $5,000 loss for the qr and $171,000 income for the yr from discontinued operations...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $231,000 for the qr and $120,000 for the yr

title: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
GERMANS TRY TO SELL SUBMARINES TO U.S.
description: A West German shipbuilder, squeezed by the recession and Europe's shipbuilding slump, is trying to sell a diesel-driven submarine to the United States Navy.

title: SCHOOL PICTURES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including $1,890,350 goodwill writeoff...C-Net income

title: CHILEAN EXIL
description: ES APPEAL TO MRS. KIRKPATRICK FOR HELP BY RAYMOND BONNER

title: 'ISLANDS' ON BROADWAY BEING RECONSTRUCTED
description: About a third of the familiar islands of greenery along Broadway from Columbus Circle to 155th Street will be transformed between now and December in a $1.8 million Parks Department renovation project.

title: Lombardo & Willis Part of F. William Free
description: Two-year-old Lombardo & Willis has been acquired by F. William Free & Company, more to get its creative-team principles than its accounts, which reportedly bill more than $2 million.

title: McLain Takeover
description: Fleming Companies said it had reached agreement to acquire the McLain Grocery Company of Massillon, Ohio, in an exchange of stock worth $22.5 million to $24.2 million.

title: AMERICAN CAR MAKERS' M.P.G.  EDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEXICAN GOVERNMENT'S RED SCARECROW
description: To the Editor:

title: Scott to Delay Some Spending
description: The Scott Paper Company, citing the high cost of borrowing money, said it would delay for an unspecified period $400 million in utility projects at its plants in Mobile, Ala., and Chester, Pa.

title: RATES FIRM IN ERRATIC TRADING
description: Short-term interest rates, which have declined sharply in the last two weeks, stabilized in erratic trading yesterday. Traders said a reduction by the Federal Reserve of one percentage point in the discount rate surcharge was so slight that it created uncertainty about whether interest rates would continue to decline.

title: JAMES M. ZITO
description: James M. Zito, a Shakespearean scholar and a member of the literature faculty of Sarah Lawrence College in Bronxville, N.Y., died Saturday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 56 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: Columbia Considering Bid for Six Flags Parks
description: Columbia Pictures Industries has inquired about the possible purchase of the Six Flags Corporation, an amusement park subsidiary of the Penn Central Corporation, a Penn Central spokesman said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Motors Corporation, Detroit, has elected Jose J. Dedeurwaerder to the new post of executive vice president.

title: 'Rabbit Is Rich'
description: ALMOST everybody in a John Updike novel runs away from death and circles back. If the obvious exceptions are George Caldwell in ''The Centaur,'' Hakim Felix in ''The Coup'' and, perhaps, the minister in ''A Month of Sundays'' who quotes Barth and Tillich even as he couples, then the obvious exemplar is Harry (Rabbit) Angstrom. Once a decade Harry fails to escape; in ''Rabbit Is Rich,'' he merely moves across town. He jogs, and beneath his sneakers ''the dead stare upwards.'' They are family, friends, the famous and ''whole races like the Cambodians.'' They cheer on this ''king of the ghosts'':

title: Sting Gains Soccer Bowl
description: A goal by Franz Mathieu in the sixth round of a shootout tonight gave the Chicago Sting a 1-0 victory over the San Diego Sockers at Comiskey Park and a berth in the Soccer Bowl against the Cosmos.

title: Alice's Restaurant for Sale
description: Alice's Restaurant is for sale for $225,000, according to a local real estate agent. The building, a converted church in this tiny Berkshire Hills community, was made famous in the mid-1960's by the Arlo Guthrie song and movie entitled ''Alice's Restaurant.''

title: JAZZ PIANIST: DON EWALL
description: DON EWELL is a pianist who has played with Bunk Johnson and Kid Ory and who lived in New Orleans for several years. He has picked up the New Orleans idiom, particularly that of Jelly Roll Morton. But he is also an expert in the Harlem Stride who has played with Willie the Lion Smith and absorbed Fats Waller and James P. Johnson. The Chicago pianists -Teddy Wilson and Earl Hines and Jess Stacy - are also part of his background.

title: METS DEFEAT PIRATES, 4-3 ON A WILD PITCH IN 13th
description: The New York Mets lost a 3-1 lead over the Pittsburgh Pirates in the ninth inning last night then won the game in the 13th, 4-3, when John Stearns scored from third on a wild pitch by Mark Lee.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Arden Group Inc. said it had extended to Oct. 9 the expiration date of its exchange offer to the holders of its common stock.

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: STORIES of the development of new drugs and other medical advances often are told as if logic had dictated every step, as if the researchers had known from the beginning what they were looking for and exactly how to find it. In fact, the development of new drugs is a much more complicated process than some res earchers would have the public believe, and the new drugs that appear each year reach the market by many more paths than we realize.

title: DR. GREGORY BREIT, EARLY AUTHORITY ON ATOM WEAPONS, IS DEAD AT
description: 82 By PETER KIHSS

title: Happy Birthday, Coach
description: Coach Jim Hanifan of th e St. Louis Cardinals found that perhaps hisbest offense was on his defensive unit. With three injured receivers,Hanifan turne d recently to Roy Green, a defensive back, and gave him his first sta rt as a pro wide receiver Sunday at St. Louis.

title: News Analysis
description: The legal wrangle that culminated in yesterday's ruling overturning Governor Carey's cancellation of a rugby game involving the South African Springboks brings up a constitutional issue not previously addressed by the courts: whether an ostensibly apolitical sporting event is protected by the right to free speech.

title: Amoco Philippines W ell in Production
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) said that its Amoco Philippines Petroleum Company unit had begun commercial output from the Philippines' second offshore oilfield, theCadlao field.

title: EX-HOSTAGES SAY THAT MOST HAVE RESUMED NORMAL LIVES
description: Nine months after being freed, most of the 52 United States Embassy personnel held hostage in Iran for 444 days have resumed normal lives.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard RABBIT IS RICH. By John Updike. 467 pages. Knopf. $13.95.

title: NATPAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. ACCUSES 35 ON TOXIC WASTE IN SOUTH JERSEY
description: Thirty-five chemical companies and officials were accused today by the United States Attorney's office of depositing to xic substances in Atlantic County, in southern New Jersey.

title: Subway Crash Hurts 9 At Terminal in Newark
description: Nine persons, including two motormen, were injured during this morning's rush when a one-car City Subway trolley rammed the rear of a stationary car that had just unloaded passengers in the underground Penn Station terminal here.

title: FEMALE OFFICER CLEARED OF DERELICTION OF DUTY
description: A New York City police sergeant will be transferred and tried on disciplinary charges because, police officials said yesterday, he wrongly reported that a female police officer had panicked and failed to help her male partner when he was attacked by three youths. The incident occurred Sept. 12 at Manhattan Beach in Brooklyn.

title: DORSETT LEADS COWBOYS TO 35-21 VICTORY
description: In his five productive seasons as the Dallas Cowboys' leading running back, Tony Dorsett has gained 100 yards or more 24 times. In all but one of those games the Cowboys won which is indicative of the worth of Dorsett, whose yearly salary is $330,000.

title: Steel Output Down
description: Steel production was 2.21 million tons last week, down 1.6 percent from the previous week's 2.24 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Robot Output G rows in Japan
description: Sales of Japanese robots are expected to rise more than tenfold by 1990, and more technical agreements with foreign robot manufacturers are likely, industry sources said here today.

title: HELEN OF TROY (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Fappiano Retired, Syndicated
description: Fappiano, who won 10 of 16 races in his career, including the Metropolitan Handicap this season, has been retired and syndicated for $12 million, his owner, John Nerud, announced yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: DDT's Impact on Gulls
description: Between 1950 and 1970, contamination of the ocean off Southern California by the discharge of DDT from sewer systems resulted in the thinning of the eggshells of brown pelicans, cormorants and other seabirds, leading to extensive breeding failure in these species. But the pesticide did not affect the eggshells of the western and California gulls, even though their breeding success suffered a similar marked decline in that period.

title: IRAN REPORTS 45 MORE EXECUTIONS AS DRIVE AGAINST LEFTISTS GOES ON
description: Forty-five more executions were reported from Iran today as the Islamic Government continued its purge of leftist opponents.

title: U.S. REPORTER IN CHINA GETS OFFICIAL WARNING
description: The Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs accused a Washington Post reporter today of defying Government regulations in reporting a dissident's purported account of his imprisonment in a Peking jail and a provincial labor camp. It was the strongest admonition issued to a member of the foreign press here si nce American journalists were allowed to open newsgathering offices here two and a half years ago.

title: Haden Prognosis Good
description: Pat Haden, the Los Angeles quarterback, twice in his career has lost his starting role because of injuries, and it was feared that might happen again when Haden was injured in the second quarter of the Rams' 35-23 victory over Green Bay Sunday.

title: Need for Budget Cut Is Tied to Wall St.
description: Murray L. Weidenbaum, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that failure by Congress to approve the Administration's new round of budget cutting would have a serious effect on the financial markets.

title: ED MARINARO RECOUNTS THE LESSONS OF FOOTBALL
description: When Ed Marinaro was an all-America tailback at Cornell, the football team ran an I-formation offense that, it was said, was really Marinaro to the right, Marinaro to the left, Marinaro up the middle. With flair. That was on the football field. On campus, Marinaro seemed to drive and park his car in similar fashion - he saw a hole, and he hit it.

title: DOW ADDS 10.37 ON CUT IN PRIME
description: A reduction in the prime rate by several major banks touched off a rally yesterday in blue-chip stocks, sending the Dow Jones industrial average ahead by 10.37 points.

title: ENVOY WARNS OF NEUTRALISM
description: President Reagan's nominee as Ambassador to the Soviet Union appeared today for confirmation hearings before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and told the panel that the gravest danger in Western Europe was uninformed opposition to nuclear defenses.

title: Bridge: Some Peo ple Make Rules That Rea lly Won't Work
description: Many players make rules for themselves in the bidding that create more problems than they solve. A popular but very dubious rule of this type is the one that calls for four cards to raise a major-suit response to the two-level. This is a situation in which a three-card raise is appropriate.

title: 34 Are Hurt at Harvard As Chlorine Pipe Breaks
description: Thirty-four per sons were injured at Harvard University this morning after a pipe carrying chlorine gas to a swimming pool ruptured, filling an athle tic center with toxic fumes.

title: BRITAN PLANS CUTS IN SPENDING
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, after defeats in the last two years in attempts to cut the British Government's spending, is aiming with fresh vigor at prospective outlays in the coming year, particularly those for nationalized and publicly owned companies.

title: Uranium Accord
description: The European Economic Community has signed a 30-year agreement with Australia setting conditions for the sale of that country's uranium to the Common Market, the community said today. The accord bans military use of the uranium.

title: Soviet Seeks Gas Line Loan
description: The Soviet Union wants to buy about $7.4 billion worth of equipment from industrialized nations to build a natural gas pipeline from a western area of Siberia to supply Western Europe, Japanese Export-Import Bank officials said today.

title: Belize; Geography
description: Tucked into a niche of the Caribbean coast of Central America between Guatemala and Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, north of the Gulf of Honduras, Belize is 200 miles long with 8,688 square miles in area - slightly smaller than New Hampshire. Three-quarters of the country is covered by forest, but a large portion is thick jungle that is almost impossible to penetrate. There is a narrow coastal plain in the south, behind which is a high plateau fringed by mountains that are largely unexplored. Off the coast, a chain of islands rises from reefs that are the most extensive in the

title: U.S. Approves N ew Gulf Port
description: Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis today approved construction of a second deepwater port for oil tankers in the Gulf of Mexico. The $191 million port, designed to unload 500,000 barrels of oil a day, is to be built by a consortium of oil and chemical companies 12 miles south of Freeport, Tex.

title: U.S. JUDGE VOIDS CAREY'S BAN ON SSPRINGBOK RUGBY MATCH
description: A Federal District Court judge ruled today that Governor Carey could not prohibit a South African rugby team from playing an exhibition game scheduled here for 7 P.M. tomorrow.

title: Primary Election Choices
description: The primary election campaign ends today in silent voting booths. Here is a summary of our stated preferences for races in which the primary result is historically tantamou nt to election.

title: TAXPAYERS MAKE PEACE WITH U.S.
description: One letter is signed ''A Friend.'' Another is signed ''A Conscientious Taxpayer.'' A third, addressed to ''Uncle Sam,'' is signed ''One of Your Conscience-Stricken Nephews.''

title: TOPPS CHEWING GUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: B-Including tax credits of $52,000 for the qr and $481,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including tax credits of $1,039,000 for the qr and $1,289,000 for the 6 mos and $484,000 nonrecurring charge for the qr and $35,000 nonrecurring credit for the 6 mos relating to the company's Irish subsidiary

title: PRIME RATE IS CUT BY SOME BIG BANKS
description: A number of leading banks reduced their prime lending rates another notch yesterday, to 19 1/2 percent fro m 20 percent, and some bankers predicted tha t interest rates might finally be headed downward for the first tim e in months.
