title: Suez Canal Commences Use Of Computer Instead of Pilots
description: The Suez Canal entered the electronic age today, modernizing its century-old system of piloting ships through the waterway with a $17 million American-built computer network.

title: U.S. Company Plans Projects In Poland Worth $140 Million
description: Armand Hammer, chairman of Occidental Petroleum, said today that his company was ready to invest $140 million in two projects in Poland.

title: BELIZE CELEBRATES ITS INDEPENDENCE
description: Amid fireworks, champagne and reggae music, the tiny Central American nation of Belize became independent at midnight last night, bringing to an end more than 300 years of British colonial presence on the American mainland.

title: BUSINESS SCHOOLS FEAR SHORTAGE OF
description: TEACHERS By EDWARD B. FISKE

title: TEXAN SAYS ALIENS POSE NO BIG SCHOOL PROBLEM
description: Gov. William P. Clements Jr. of Texas said today that his state could provide free public education for illegal alien children without any ''serious problem.''

title: Market Place; AZL's Plan For Recovery
description: TURNAROUNDS are suspect because they are hard to do. But ailing AZL Resources has impressed some in Wall Street with a plan to deemphasize ranch and resort operations while moving heavily into energy exploration and development.

title: ARLEN REALTY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: B-After $554,000 gain on the sale of property...C-After $1,298,000 gain on the sale of property and $144,000 extra- ordinary credit from the restructuring of debt

title: DEATH IN THE AFTERNOON
description: To the Editor:

title: Typhoon Nears Hong Kong
description: A typhoon moved toward Hong Kong and the southern Chinese coast today, threatening the region with gale force winds, drenching rains and flooding.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Du Pont Shifts Staff In Conoco Merger
description: With the completion of its $7.5 billion acquisition of Conoco Inc., the most expensive corporate takeover in history, scheduled for the end of the month, Du Pont yesterday announced organizational changes effective at the beginning of October. The changes include the appointment of Conoco's top officer as a vice chairman of the merged company, the elimination of the post of president and the establishment of an office of the chairman.

title: Tenneco Gas Find
description: Tenneco Inc. said today that an exploratory well on its Vermilion block 75 in the Gulf of Mexico flowed 2.2 million cubic feet of natural gas and 317 barrels of condensate a day from depths of 15,067 to 15,073 feet.

title: EXPECT MILITARY RULE IN IRAN
description: .8,2SEATTLE, Wash. - The regime in Iran probably will not survive past 1982. But the most serious group opposing it, the radical Islamic People's Mujahedeen, will not necessarily benefit from its eventual collapse. Nor is the next government likely to be Communist or liberal; instead, dependence on military forces probably will lead to military rule.

title: Wallin Faces Surgery
description: The Rangers, in the middle of a five-game exhibition swing through Scandanavia, will play the last two games without Peter Wallin, a right wing.

title: DOLE TO TEST DEMOCRATS' BACKING FOR BROAD BILLS ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Republican Senators agreed today to make one test of Democratic support for major Social Security legislation before retreating to a minimum stopgap bill that appears to be acceptable to both parties.

title: DRESSING UP: GLITTER, DIVERSITY
description: Gilded knickers coexist with bouffant ball gowns. Chameleon-like separates brush against sequin-paved siren sheaths.Almost every night such juxtapositions are seen in New York and nobody winces or looks pained. The social season opened with remarkable brilliance right after Labor Day and will gain momentum until the year ends with the usual crush of holiday parties. The glitter and opulence that were foreshadowed by the fall fashion collections here and in Europe are already reflected in the clothes being worn.

title: NOBEL LAUREATE ACCUSES ARGENTINA ON PASSPORT
description: Adolfo Perez Esquivel, holder of the Nobel Peace Prize, said here today that the police had refused to return his passport.

title: Construction Dispute Over
description: Construction workers are back on the job after a two-m onth labor dispute that stalled about $2 billion worth of constructi on projects in the area. Under an agreement ratified yesterday by a vote of 1,992 to 257, some 5,000 members of Local 150 of the Intern ational Union of Operating Engineers will receive a $6.55-an-hour increase in wages and benefits over the next 35 months,union officia ls said.

title: Levi Strauss Net Off 11.7%
description: Levi Strauss & Company, the world's largest apparel manufacturer, reported yesterday that net income in the third fiscal quarter of 1981 ended Aug. 30 slipped 11.7 percent, to $54.6 million, or $1.32 a share, from $61.8 million, or $1.48 a share, in the three months a year earlier. Sales increased 6.7 percent, to $802.1 million, from $751.9 million.

title: COMPREHENSIVE CARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including $228,000 or 3 cents a shr net gain from elimination of a note payable and related accrued interest due the Small Business Administration as a result of the expiration of the statute of limitations; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect accounting for compensated absences in accordance with F.A.S.B. Statement No 43

title: Islanders Prevail
description: The New York Islanders opened a 3-0 lead in the first period tonight and went on to beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 7-3, in a National Hockey League exhibition game. Islander goals came from Duane Sutter, Bryan Trottier, Wayne Merrick, Hector Marini, Gord Lane, Dave Simpson and Bobby Nystrom. Chicago goals were by Glenn Sharpley, Rick Paterson and Grant Mulvey.

title: MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $1.8 million from the sale of real estate...C-Includes a gain of $1.1 million from the sale of real estate

title: Head of Columbia Gets $10 Million Contract
description: Frank Price, chairman and president of Columbia Pictures, has been given a new four-year contract, worth more than $10 million, the company announced yesterday in Los Angeles.

title: IC OFFERS $451 MILLION FOR SUNBEAM
description: IC Industries, which paid more than $400 million for Pet Inc. in 1978, disclosed yesterday that it had offered to buy the Sunbeam Corporation for $451 million in cash and stock.

title: U.S.-Soviet Trade Surges
description: The total value of trade between the United States and the Soviet Union increased 48.9 percent in the first half of this year, to $1.28 billion, according to figures released today by the United States Commercial Office.

title: Hinckley's Defense Overruled On Access to Doctors' Notes
description: A Federal judge ruled today that psychiatrists hired by the prosecution did not have to give defense attorneys their notes of interviews with John W. Hinckley Jr., accused Presidential assailant.

title: COALITION RESIGNS IN BELGIUM OVER AID TO A STEEL COMPANY
description: Belgium's center-left coalition Cabinet resigned tonight after it was unable to resolve an internal dispute over how to finance the nation's troubled steel industry.

title: LUBEC,Me.
description: AS the small outboard neared South Wolf Island, with its Canadian lighthouse, a Coast Guardsman appeared on the edge of a cliff high above the shore, pointed out to sea and shouted: ''Two whales out there!''

title: EFFORT TO CONVERT REACTOR WASTE TO MILITARY USE AROUSES ALARM
description: WASHINGTON WITHI N Buil ding 332 at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and at the Los Al amos National Laboratory, scientists are quietly experimenting with a nuclear alchemy intended to transform spent nuclear fuel fro m power plants into the atomic age equival ent of gold- pure plutonium for nuclear weapons.

title: Phils Lose In 17th, 1-0; Carlton Sets Mark
description: A bases-loaded ground ball by Andre Dawson with one out in the 17th inning tonight gave the Montreal Expos a 1-0 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies in a game in which Steve Carlton of the Phillies became the National lea gue's career strikeout lea der.

title: SHE WILL JOIN HIGH COURT FRIDAY
description: The Senate confirmed Sandra Day O'Connor tonight as an Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court. The vote was 99 to 0. Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, was out of town and did not vote. Judge O'Connor, who is to take the oath of office on Friday, will be the first woman to serve on the Supreme Court. President Reagan is expected to attend the ceremony in the courtroom. Hopes for 10 Years From Now

title: 1982 Wheat Curb Planned
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block, outlining more details of the Government's 1982 wheat program, said today that the Government would set up a plan under which farmers would be expected to reduce their planting by at least 15 percent.

title: Supporting Cast Strong
description: When State Senator Roy M. Goodman comes up for election to a full two-year term as chairman of the New York County Republican CommitteeFriday night, he may be upstaged by his two main runnin g m ates. They are Dina Merrill and Lionel Hampton, who will run for the posts of first and second vice chairmen.

title: ABRIDGED PRIMARY TO BE HELD TODAY IN NEW YORK CITY
description: After a final flurry of back-and-forth legal maneuvers - and accompanying alterations to voting machines - New York City prepared to hold a belated, truncated primary election today.

title: Primera Matadora
description: When Raquel Martinez thrust her sword between the shoulder blades of a bull Sunday in El Toreo de Tijuana ring, she erased tradition and ended a two-and-a-half-year struggle to become Mexico's first full-fledged female matador. Mrs. Martinez, who is 5 feet 5 inches tall and weighs 115 pounds, had fought more than 100 bulls and won more honors than any other novice in Mexico, but she had encountered difficulty in finding a sponsor.

title: Lockheed Offers Fixed Plane Price
description: The Lockheed-Georgia Company said it had offered the Air Force a contract to build 44 cargo aircraft at a fixed price.

title: School Pickets Arrested In Strike in Philadelphia
description: Nine pickets were arrested today as striking teachers prevented administrators from entering schools for seniors and handicapped students scheduled to open this week, the police said.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DA Y
description: "It's terribly sad to me that the windup of this has to be artic ulated i n such a small sum of money.

title: Talking Business with Balog of Drexel Burnham Lambert; In the Market And Surviving
description: Stock prices have reached 16-month lows in recent months. Despite yesterday's rally, many investors are concerned that the downtrend will continue. James Balog, senior executive vice president and chief investment officer of Drexel Burnham Lambert, believes that, before the market hits bottom, it must undergo a ''washout,'' a huge selling climax touched off by, say, a bankruptcy of major proportions. Here, Mr. Balog discusses his investment strategy and how it applies in the currently depressed market.

title: Middle Class on the March
description: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., took a big gamble by calling his rank and file to the nation's capital last weekend. But by the time he moved to the podium on the Mall, at least 250,000 had answered the call, and he could speak with the confidence of a winner.

title: Reagan Runs Third
description: In a new survey of conservatives most admired by their fellow conservatives, President Reagan has fallen from first place to third. No. 1 is Rev. Jerry Falwell, leader of the Moral Majority, and and No. 2 William F. Buckley Jr., the writer and television personality.

title: VIDEO CURB PLAN DENIED BY TOKYO
description: Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry today denied reports that it was planning to curb this nation's rapidly increasing exports of videotape recorders.

title: CHILDREN'S SHOWS FOUND WANING
description: Peggy Charren, seeking more programs on television for children, said today that such programs were minimal in number - especially on weekdays - and the supply was dwindling.

title: Coast Murder Trial Delayed
description: The trial of William G. Bonin, accused of killing 12 young men and boys in the so-called ''Freeway Murders,'' was postponed again today, pending an appeal to the State Supreme Court. Judge William Keene of Superior Court granted a delay until Oct. 19 so that the high court could consider Mr. Bonin's motion to change attorneys and postpone the trial for 120 days. If the motion is denied, the defendant plans to act as his own attorney.

title: Article 022844 -- No Title
description: Foremost-McKesson Inc. said it had been served with a $6 million lawsuit filed in New York Supreme Court arising from its repurchase of nearly 1.6 million of its common shares last May from the Sharon Steel Corporation.

title: Press's Warning
description: Former White House science adviser Frank Press, now president of the National Academy of Sciences, said today America's cancellation of its part of an international space mission may cause its allies to view the United States as an unreliable partner.

title: General Mills Up 46.2%; Jewel Soars
description: General Mills Inc., one of the nation's leading producers of packaged foods, reported yesterday that earnings in the first fiscal quarter of 1982 soared 46.2 percent as sales climbed 23.9 percent.

title: TOMReview; MET OPENS WITH NEW 'NORMA'
description: The Metropolitan Opera opened its season last night with a restaged, star-studded production of Bellini's ''Norma.'' It was a festive occasion, as Met opening nights tend to be. It was also an occasion on which sighs of relief and pleasure were almost audible, both in the crowded foyers and backstage. Everyone remembered last year at this time, when the house was dark from a labor dispute and not only the season but the company itself seemed threatened. The contrast from then to now was as extreme as the most dramatic of opera plots.

title: ATLANTA SUSPECT LOSES 2-TRIAL PLEA
description: In a significant victory for the prosecution, a Fulton County Superior Court judge today denied a request by Wayne B. Williams for separate trials in the deaths of two young black men here and refused to suppress evidence gathered by law enforcement officers who questioned the suspect on May 22.

title: ELECTROSOUND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including $52,000 tax credit...C-Net loss

title: EXCERPTS FROM HAIG SPEECH AT GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the speech yesterday by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to the General Assembly of the United Nations, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: WOMEN'S SHOP ATOP BARNEY'S
description: Barney's, the clothing store that began ''calling all men, calling all boys to Seventh Avenue and 17th Street'' in l923 and extended the call to women five years ago, has opened what it has named the Women's Duplex. The sixth and penthouse floors have been joined by a central Art Deco staircase and topped off with a giant paneled skylight.

title: By Sports of The Times; Another Baseball Blunder
description: BASEBALL has done it again. Not only did major league baseball interrupt what it started this year when the club owners provoked and prolonged a seven-week strike midway in the season, but now what is perhaps baseball's most respected minor league could not be bothered finishing what it started. The remainder of the International League championsihp playoffs were canceled abruptly last week, ostensibly because of repeated rainouts, with Columbus leading Richmond, two games to one. Columbus was declared the champion.

title: All American Nut
description: The International Multifoods Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the All American Nut Company, a West Coast processor of peanut butter and nutmeat snacks, for undisclosed terms. The purchase involves an exchange of Multifoods common stock for the net assets of All American Nut, Multifoods said.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: THIS may be the age of science everywhere except in American public schools. After a brief burst of activity in response to the first Soviet sputnik in 1957, elementary and high school science is again in a slump. The backsliding began in the mid-70's but current budget-slashing threatens a steep decline.

title: NU-WEST TO SELL OIL STAKE
description: Concern over the vehement opposition mounted by the Cities Service Company apparently helped to convince the Nu-West Group Ltd. to agree to sell its 7.2 percent stake in Cities Service to the American oil company, analysts said yesterday.

title: NAMIBIAN REBELS GIVEN GRANT
description: The World Council of Churches today announced that 46 groups in 17 countries would receive a $587,000 grant to ''combat racism.'' The South-West Africa People's Organization, a guerrilla group that is fighting to end South African rule in South-West Africa, also known as Namibia, got the largest sum.

title: Q. Are some people more susceptible to mosquito bites than others?
description: A. It is not understood exactly what it is about a particular person that attracts mosquitoes. They tend to like younger people more than older people, and are generally attracted to men more than women.

title: WITH HOPE AND NERVOUSNESS, WOULD-BE CHORISTERS TRY OUT
description: Standing beside the grand piano, the young woman smiled hopefully at the only two people in the auditorium seats. Nodding to the accompanist - whom she had never seen before - she launched into an Italian art song.

title: TV: A MUSICAL TRIBUTE TO CHILDREN, 7-13
description: TV offers a musical tribute to bright and chirpy middle-class kids tonight at 8 o'clock in ''How to Eat Like a Child.'' Fifteen boys and girls, between the ages of 7 and 13, have been recruited for this Project Peacock program, part of a series of specials designed for youngsters and their families. Dick Van Dyke is the only adult allowed to wander about the wide-open spaces of the studio set.

title: Burroughs's Memorex Bid
description: The Burroughs Corporation declined to comment yesterday on reports that its proposed takeover of the Memorex Corporation had been imperiled by the refusal of bank creditors to accept the terms by which Burroughs would acquire heavily indebted Memorex.

title: WACHOVIA REALTY INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
UNITED OVERTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Big Board Short Interest Down 5.9 million Shares
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell by 5.9 million shares, to 66 million, in the month ended Sept 15. Last year the short interest totaled 72.1 million shares.

title: JOSEPH HIRSCH, 71, A REALIST PAINTER
description: Joseph Hirsch, a member of the American Academy-Institute of Arts and Letters a nd a well-known realistic artist who came to national attention as a muralist for the Federal Works Progress Administrationin the 1930's , died of cancer at his home in Manhattan yesterday. He was 71 years old.

title: Marathon Oil Loan
description: The Marathon Oil Company said today that its Marathon Petroleum Ireland Ltd. subsidiary had arranged a $200 million production payment financing with a group of 10 banks led by the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Bank of Ireland. Proceeds will be used to repay a portion of advances received by Marathon Ireland from its parent, the company said. Marathon said the new facility supplemented a $100 million production payment financing that it arranged in 1977 to finance part of the development of the Kinsdale Head gas field.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 22, 1981
description: International Moscow stepped up warnings to Poles by giving wide publicity to an open letter from Soviet workers that invoked the Soviet and Polish Governments' obligations under the Warsaw Pact to defend Communism ''against any encroachment.'' Meanwhile, Pravda alluded to the situation in Czechoslovakia in 1968 and in Hungary in 1956, when Soviet troops crushed efforts for liberalization. (Page A1, Column 6.) Polish union locals defied Moscow, characterizing a warning letter issued last week as interference in Poland's internal affairs. A Polish official said that the union was becoming a political opposition. (A12:3-5.)

title: Tapping Antarctica's Winds
description: A major and rising cost item of the extensive American activities in Antarctica is the fuel needed for ships, planes, heating of the buildings and providing electric power.

title: CORRECTION
description: In a report Friday of the winners in the first category of the Gina Bachauer Memorial Competition for pianists at the Julliard School, the name of one winner was misspelled. He was Jeffrey Biegel of Plainview, L.I., who was one of the three top winners.

title: No Headline
description: An official of the Green Bay Packers said today that prominent differences had arisen in the team's negotiations with the all-pro wide receiver John Jefferson.

title: VISA PLANS MONEY FUND AND HIGHER LIMIT CARD
description: Visa International said yesterday that it would offer a premium card with higher spending limits than its regular credit card to compete against the American Express gold card. In addition, Visa announced preliminary plans to make a money market fund available to its cardholders.

title: Article 022654 -- No Title
description: A Presidential commission recommended today that the Federal Government pay each of the Americans held hostage in Iran $12.50 a day for their time in captivity.

title: Zapata Offer Ends
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said that it had formally withdrawn its $760 million offer to acquire the Zapata Corporation and that there were no new talks in progress.

title: FRANC UP ON ACTIONS BY PARIS
description: The French franc ros e in value against othermajor currencies today after the French Gover nment imposed new currency measures.

title: Nigel Patrick, 68, Dies; Stage and Movie Actor
description: Nigel Patrick, the versatile British actor of stage and screen, died of cancer in a London hospital yesterday. He was 68 years old. Mr. Patrick was best known for his portrayals of smooth, sophisticated English gentlemen, but he could also play the tightlipped scoundrel.

title: NEW PROTEST FAILS
description: Nuclear protesters failed in another attempt today to block access to the Diablo Canyon Nuclear Power Plant, just hours before the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in Washington unanimously granted the Pacific Gas and Electric Company a preliminary license to operate the first of two reactors on the site.

title: NEW YORK STATE GIVES 795 ACRES TO INDIAN TRIBE
description: New York State has turned over 795 acres of land, including 750 acres of parkland, to the Seneca Nation as part of a historic agreement that will allow the construction of the last segment of the Southern Tier Expressway through a tribal reservation here.

title: REPUBLICANS SHAKEN BY SUDDEN PROBLEMS IN VIRGINIA ELECTIO
description: N By BEN A. FRANKLIN FAIRFAX, Va., Sept. 21 - The race for the g overnorship of Virginia,between candidates similar in age, image and ideology, is becoming unexpectedly troublesome for the Republican P arty in the last six weeks before Election Day.

title: The Economy
description: Several big banks cut their prime lending rates to 19 1/2 percent from 20 percent. Analysts pr edicted most othe r major banks would moveto the new level today. Some bankers forecast that interest rates would fall still further, noting indications that the Federal Reservehad eased monetary policy somewhat and that t he economy had entered arecession. (Page A1.)

title: TYHE FUTURE OF SEWAGE TREATMENT
description: .8,2WASHINGTON - President Reagan and the Congress a re performing surgery on the gastro-intestinal system of Un ited States cities.

title: CONNECTICUT REGISTRY IS TREASURY OF DATA FOR CANCER RESEARCH
description: When the first studies indicated that there might be a link between artificial sweeteners and bladder cancer, researchers came to the Connecticut Tumor Registry to find data to confirm their findings. In another study, scientists are now using Connecticut data to determine whether there is a relationship between cancer and the use of birth control pills.

title: Perkins Unspoiled by Success
description: It's not that football coaches are pessimists. It's just that they worry a lot. For example, as Coach Ray Perkins of the Giants left the field after yesterday's 20-7 victory over the New Orleans Saints, he was not celebrating the day's successes but envisioning next Sunday's problems.

title: COURTS ACT ON THE EVE OF PRIMARY
description: The confusion that has marked the legal maneuvering over today's city primary election continued until the final hours before the polls opened. The state courts, which had been superseded by the Federal courts and the Justice Department, again reasserted at least limited jurisdiction yesterday.

title: NATIONAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The shrs outstndg and shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Feb 27, 1981

title: Oneida's 'Product Mix' Praised by New Chief
description: At Oneida Ltd., the big manufacturer of stainless steel tableware and other items, a member of the Noyes family has long run the company. Now Pierrepont T. Noyes, the 67-year-old grandson of John Humphrey Noyes, who founded the Oneida Community, the predecessor of the corporation, as a religious commune in 1848, is retiring on Oct. 1 as chairman and chief executive officer, to be succeeded by John L. Marcellus Jr., 58.

title: HELEN M. CLARK, LAWYER, DIES
description: Helen M. Clark, a lawyer and former president of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs, died Saturday at New York Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Energy Agency to Rule On Israel's Expulsion
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency opened its 25th general conference today facing a demand that Israel be expelled because of its attack on Iraq's nuclear reactor last June.

title: SOLIDARITY BRANCHES ACCUSE MOSCOW OF INTERFERENCE
description: Solidarity union locals issued resolutions today characterizing last week's warning letter from the Soviet Union as interference in Polish affairs.

title: SEABOARD ALLIED MILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 22
INFLIGHT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Including $812,000 or 31 cents a shr tax credit and $1,012,000 or 39 cents a shr nonrecurring income from the termination of a British Airways B-747 contract... C-Including $57,000 or 2 cents a shr tax credit

title: State Attorneys Sum Up Case Against Kleindienst
description: State prosecutors summed up their case today for the jury in the perjury trial of Richard G. Kleindienst, with one of them arguing that much of the former Attorney General's testimony was ''incredible.''

title: R.L. Burns to Sell Some Coal Assets
description: The R.L. Burns Corporation, an oil, coal and gas producer, said it had agreed in principle to sell a portion of its coal properties for $72 million to Costain Holding Inc., a wholly owned United States subsidiary of the Costain Group, a London-based construction and engineering company.

title: FLOOD AID FOR THE WORLD'S POOR IS STILL A MUST
description: To the Editor:

title: The Reich Enters the Primary
description: One of the demands we properly make on our political leaders is that they amuse and entertain us. Without such titillation, our spirits would be overcome by subway fires, gridlocks and blackouts, and we would fall into profound melancholy.

title: News Analysis
description: Because there is now little doubt that President Reagan's proposal to sell $8.5 billion in air defense materiel to Saudi Arabia is in significant difficulty in Congress, the Administration is confronted by a number of unappealing choices.

title: CONGRESS
description: The talk around Capitol Hill these days is about budgets and ballots, the cost of running a campaign and the issues that will dominate the elections next fall.

title: PARK ELECTROCHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
American to Offer Fixed-Fare Passes
description: American Airlines, in a marketing bid aimed squarely at the industry's cherished business customer, announced yesterday that it would offer fixed-cost flight passes for periods from five years up to a lifetime.

title: No Headline
description: Brooks was named the National League player of the week, the league president, Charles Feeney, announced yesterday. During the week ending with Sunday's games, Brooks batted .500, on 12 hits in 24 at-bats, including a double, triple and home run. He scored 4 runs and drove in 6.

title: Brazil's Chief Mends After a Heart Attack
description: The condition of Brazil's President, Joao Baptista Figueiredo, improved further today after his heart attack Friday. According to a medical bulletin, the 63-year-old President was allowed to sit in an easy chair next to his hospital bed.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: L AST week, New York seemed old-fashioned again with a quiet, steady rain and a talk in a kitchen in Hell's Kitchen with David Cohen, a 24-year-old designer of women's hats whose head is small enough to try on everything he designs.

title: STEWARDESS'S DEATH LEADS TO NEW SAFETY PROPOSALS
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, prompted by the death of a World Airways stewardess who became trapped by a moving food-cart elevator aboard a World Airways DC-10 jumbo jet Saturday, urged yesterday that the system be redesigned to relocate the safety switches.

title: A NEW HUNT FOR MARKETS AT REYNOLDS
description: David P. Reynolds, chairman and chief executive of the Reynolds Metals Company, sat behind his desk underscoring his stubborn confidence in the industry's future.

title: Regan Says I.M.F.  Should Be Stricter
description: The United States intends to ''raise a lot of questions'' about a proposed $5.7 billion loan to India being negotiated by the International Monetary Fund, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today. His statement signaled a policy on development issues that will stress greater reliance on the private sector. The Treasur y Secretary told a group of reporters in advance of the annual meetin g of the monetary fund and its sister institution, the World Bank, t hat the conditions imposed by the fund in lending to poorer countr ies had become lax in recent years and should be made ''more strict .''

title: THE TAX-CUT THEORY
description: Most politicians, surely including President Reagan, are well aware that God must love the common man, since he made so many of them. Yet the massive tax reduction the President would phase in over the next three years is heavily weighted toward the upper tax brackets - a striking reversal of tax-cutting tradition.

title: ANTIABORTION FORCES IN DISARRAY LESS THAN A YEAR AFTER VICTORIES IN
description: ELECTION By LESLIE BENNETTS

title: Canadian Officials in Lisbon
description: The Canadian Defense Minister, Gilles Lamontagne, and the Minister of State for Multiculturalism, James Fleming, were both holding talks with Portuguese ministers today. Mr. Lamontagne was meeting Deputy Prime Minister Diogo Freitas do Amaral and Mr. Fleming was received by President Antonio Ramalho Eanes.

title: DIODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. AND SOUTH AFRICA MEET ON NAMIBIA
description: United States officials said that Chester A. Crocker, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, opened talks with South African officials in Zurich today on a number of specific proposals for producing early independence for South-West Africa.

title: James River Seeks 70% Keuffel Stake
description: The James River Corporation, a producer of pulp, paper, packing, food-service products and coated film, said it had reached agreements with major stockholders of the Keuffel & Esser Company to acquire 70 percent ownership of the company in a deal that could be worth $55 million.

title: REPUBLICANS WARN REAGAN THAT CUTS WOULD BE BEATEN
description: Republican Congressional leaders warned President Reagan today that his $16 billion package of budget cuts would be defeated by Congress.

title: Lawyer Tied To Stock Data
description: A Wall Street securities lawyer has been charged with illegally using inside information concerning impending mergers of his firm's clients to buy and sell stocks at a profit of $450,000.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Associate d Madison Companies formally withdrew its proposal to acquire the V oyager Group Inc., based in Jacksonville, Fla., in an exchange of s hares valued at $45 million.

title: SARA HADEN, ACTRESS PLAYED CRABBY ROLES IN LONG FILM CAREER
description: Sara Haden, who played crotchety characters during her Hollywood career, died last Tuesday at the Motion Picture and Television Country House and Hospital in Woodland Hills. She was 82 years old.

title: DECONTROL OF INSURANCE FEES URGED
description: The chairman of a House small business subcommittee said today that insurance agents' fixed commissions were raising insurance costs for Americans by billions of dollars. Representative John J. LaFalce, Democrat of upstate New York and chairman of the Small Business Oversight subc ommittee, said the situation ''may very well be one of the most enduring price-fixing schemes ever perpetrated on the American publ ic.''

title: CATERING TO CAPITAL NEEDS, DISCREETLY
description: As members of the National Republican Senatorial Committee chatted over drinks last week at a White House gathering, and as diplomats and Congressmen danced and dined at another party at Mount Vernon, Jeff and Bruce Ellis moved quietly among the capital's power brokers, a part of the anonymous background.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GRAND POP

title: Goodrich Delays Resin Plant Work
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company said that it had delayed indefinitely work on a big new chemical plant in Convent, La., designed to produce polyvinyl chloride and vinyl chloride monomer, because of a drop in demand for the resins.

title: HAIG REBUFFS POOR NATIONS' PROGRAM FOR MORE AID
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that a third-world plan for a large increase in resources flowing from rich nations to poor ''is simply unrealistic.''

title: JEWEL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for 16 weeks to Aug 15
description: B-Including $15,940,000 or $1.38 a shr gain on the sale of 20 million shrs of Aurrera SA C-After losses from discontinued operations of $926,000 for the 16 weeks and $1,316,000 for the 28 weeks

title: Japan's Steel Goal
description: Japan's goal for steel production in this year's fourth quarter has been set at 25.95 million tons, up only slightly from the estimated 25.7 million tons being produced in the third quarter, the Government said today. The fourth-quarter target represents the third consecutive quarterly rise but is 1.4 percent below the 26.33 million tons produced a year earlier.

title: CALIFORNIA G.O.P. SEEKS TO VOID REDISTRICTING
description: Cries of ''foul'' and ''vote theft'' hang heavy on the land here as the Republicans prepare a referendum drive to reverse a law that reapportions the California Senate and Assembly as well as the state's 45-member delegation to the United States House of Representatives.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 22, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Direct Marketing Magazine Is Started
description: Imagine this, a magazine for devotees of direct marketing, not sellers, but people who just love to buy by mail. According to one source, 30 million Americans bought something via direct mail last year - and that does not include magazine subscriptions - and that six million of those people account for 80 percent of the purchases.

title: Jets' President Backs Michaels
description: Though what happened yesterday in Pittsburgh is certain to have the Shea Stadium fans clamoring for a change, any change, Coach Walt Michaels of the Jets said today that he would run things as usual this week.

title: Fighting Arrest 'Decay' - and Crime
description: In a year, the New York City Police Department is likely to arrest about 100,000 people and charge them with felonies. But less than a fifth of these are ever indicted - and fewer still ever see the inside of a prison. Such ''decay'' of felony arrests is a chronic national problem, and the usual response is to point fingers.

title: RACHEL ROBINSON RECALLS WHEN JACKIE WAS 'FIRST'
description: EVERYONE knows you can't do a musical about sports. ''Damn Yankees'' was an aberration, and it really wasn't about baseball, anyway. So, why are these people doing ''The First,'' a musical about Jackie Robinson? Even Rachel Robinson, Mr. Robinson's widow, once had doubts. ''I thought it was ridiculous,'' she said. ''I called my lawyer about it. Could you imagine Jack singing and dancing on Broadway?''

title: EVEN BLUE JAYS HAVE PENNANT HOPES
description: When the baseball strike began June 12, the Toronto Blue Jays were in seventh place, 19 games behind the division-leading Yankees. Yesterday in Toronto, Blue Jay executives met to discuss procedures for the playoffs and World Series.

title: SKYLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEWLY DARKENED LIVES OF SUBWAY RIDERS
description: To the Editor:

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEEDLESS ENHANCEMENT OF TAIWAN'S DEFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCK: BRITISH DURAN DURAN
description: DURAN DURAN is one of the bands in the so-called New Romantics movement currently fashionable in British rock. What this Birminghambased quintet offered at the Ritz on Friday and Saturday was a skillful though passionless synthesis of German synthesizer music, disco and mid-1960's pop.

title: WATT ACTS TO END BAN ON UTAH MINE
description: Interior Secretary James Watt said today that he had moved to permit strip mining next to Bryce Canyon National Park in Utah.

title: BRIEFING
description: S OMETIME last April, Senator Robert C. Byrd, the minority leader, sent off a letter addressed to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. expressing concern about the sale of radar planes to Saudi Arabia and raising specific questions. He's still waiting for a response.

title: THE MEXICAN GOVERNMENT'S RED SCAR ECROW
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearing on Sentencing Delayed for Utah Sniper
description: A judge today delayed a hearing on the penalty for Joseph Paul Franklin, a self-proclaimed racist who was convicted of first-degree murder in the sniping killing of two black joggers.

title: dzf WHY TH E SPENDING ESTIMATES HAVE BEEN SHORT OF THE MARK
description: Even under the Presidency of Ronald Reagan, the most determined budget-cutter, Federal spending is running higher than the President planned.

title: BENTLEY LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ISRAELI LAW DISRUPTS DRUSE LIFE IN GOLAN HEIGHTS
description: Occupied Golan Heights - A bewitching mix of simplicity and complexity has long cast a spell over life in these contested mountains. The Druse inhabitants, members of an Arab religious sect with secret ties and intricate clans, exist close to the land and practice an artful political camouflage.

title: Chess: Browne, With Score of 8-2, Wins Tourney in Santiago
description: Walter Browne of Berkeley, Calif., the United States co-champion, took first prize in the Codelco-Cuprum International Tournament in Santiago, Chile, with a score of 8-2. FINAL STANDINGS Player W. L. D. Pts. Browne 6 0 4 8 Garcia Palermo 3 0 7 6 1/2 Morovic 2 0 8 6 Cifuentes 3 2 5 5 1/2 Salazar 2 1 7 5 1/2 Alburt 3 2 5 5 1/2 Frias 3 2 5 5 1/2 Guimard 1 2 7 4 1/2 Van Riemsdyk 1 4 5 3 1/2 Velasquez 2 7 1 2 1/2 Campos 0 6 4 2

title: CONCERN OVER SIZE OF DEFICIT
description: Widespread fear that the budget deficit for the fiscal year 1982 may go beyond the Reagan Administration's projection has set off a rancorous debate over whether the excess spending would damage the nation's financial well-being and torpedo the President's economic program.

title: 76er Sale Official
description: The National Basketball Association board of governors has unanimously approved the sale of the Philadelphia 76ers by F. Eugene Dixon to Harold Katz, a Philadelphia businessman. ... The Baltimore Colts have reversed themselves and will open their dressing room to female reporters. The Colts' players has previously voted, 25-16, to bar them. ... Richard Noble, a London business executive, said his team would attempt to break the world land speed record on western Utah's Bonneville Salt Flats next month.

title: TRIAL TO BEGIN ON CHARGE OF SELLING CODES TO SOVIET
description: Jury selection for the trial of a former Army warrant officer charged with selling Soviet agents secret coding information in Paris in 1963 and 1964 began here today.

title: Carew Unlikely to Play
description: Rod Carew's shoulder is still extremely painful, and he will probably not play in the California Angels' seven-game homestand that began last night. Carew, a seven-time American League batting champion, badly bruised his right shoulder and suffered a slight concussion Se pt. 16 in a collison with Billy Sample of the Texas Rangers. ... The Kansas City Royals scratched Larry Gura from their starting rota tion, pending further examination of a hairline fracturein the little finger of his left, or pitching, hand. Gura had been scheduled to start last night against Minnesota.

title: Wildmon Plans to Call TV Boycott in 3 Weeks
description: The Rev. Donald E. Wildmon, who is leading a campaign against what he calls sex and violence on television, said today that he planned to call a boycott of certain advertisers in about three weeks. He refused to commit himself to a date or name the advertisers.

title: SALVADORAN TELLS OF CRACKDOWN IN THE ARMY
description: El Salvador's President said today that his Government had dismissed 600 National Guardsmen and imprisoned 64 for crimes against Salvadoran civilians. The statement, made in response to a question from Vice President Bush about reports of violence committed by Government troops, could not be independently confirmed.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption under the picutre in the television listings on Saturday incorrectly named the performer in the role of the Celebrant in Leonard Bernstein's "Mass." Joseph Kolinski appeared in the performance shown on Channel 13.

title: HINTS OF APPLE AND BANANA FOUND PLAYING A ROLE IN BEER
description: BEER has been called the working man's champagne, the baseball fan's indispensable companion, and the most palatable form of a vegetable diet.

title: Advertising; Big Butter Maker on The Move
description: IN three different areas of the country sales representatives of Land O'Lakes, the giant Middle West farm cooperative, are busy pushing products with names that are new to the 60-year-old Minneapolis-based organization.

title: Notes On People; In the No. 3 Spot
description: Larry Christiansen, a grandmaster from Modesto, Calif., has attained the third and last United States position for the next round of elimination matches leading to the 1984 world chess championship.

title: 26 KILLED AS TURKISH JET CRASHES INTO AREA SET FOR NATO EXERCISE
description: A Turkish Air Force jet fighter crashed and exploded today in a bivouac area prepared for a NATO exercise. Military sources said 26 bodies had been found.

title: SCOUTS REVAMP PROGRAMS TO BUILD UP MEMBERSHIP
description: The Boy Scouts of America, disturbed by declining membership in the last decade, announced new training programs yesterday for the 1980's to reflect youth's changing roles and interests in the modern family and community.

title: REGAN BARS ANY DELAY IN TAX CUT
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, the Administration's chief economic spokesman, today rejected the idea of balancing the Federal budget by delaying or modifying the 25 percent tax-rate cut for individuals enacted in August.

title: Tunis Curbs Chador Wearing
description: The Tunisian Government today banned the wearing of chadors, the robe that covers women from head to foot, in schools and government offices, apparently in a move against Moslem fundamentalists blamed for campus disturbances last spring.

title: BOOK SAYS HUSSEIN AND MRS. MEIR MET
description: As Prime Minister of Israel from 1969 to 1974, Golda Meir met 10 times with King Hussein of Jordan in a futile effort to negotiate the return of the populated areas of the West Bank, according to a new biography of Mrs. Meir.

title: THE RISE OF MINI-STEEL MILLS
description: A little more than a decade ago, the Nucor Corporation bought steel angles from the large steel companies, turned them into joists and sold them to commercial builders.

title: Blood, Sweat and Shame
description: Is the American economy in such desperate shape, and are the American people grown so callous, that the guaranteed pensions of the elderly must suddenly be cut by $5 billion next year - while the swollen Reagan military budget is being reduced by only $2 billion?

title: Caterpillar Tractor
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said it had registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission an amended proposed public offering of $150 million of notes due in 1986.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in yesterday's Metropolitan Report misidentified David N. Dinkins, candidate for Manhattan Borough President. He is the City Clerk.

title: REAGAN GETS PLEA: STAY FIRM
description: Pete Domenici slept fitfully last night. His anger with the Republican Congressional leadership persisted until the daylight hours, robbing him of a respite from his preoccupation with budgets and interest rates.

title: Letter: On Commodity Supports Reining In Sugar Prices
description: To the Editor: Now that the price of sugar has dropped 30 percent lower than the ''best guess'' offered in your editorial last May 19, perhaps you will agree that sugar producers have legitimate cause for concern. And this low price is not unalloyed good news for consumers, even though Representative Peter Peyser's Op-Ed article on Sept. 10 would have us believe otherwise.

title: CONSOLIDATED ACCESSORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Trudeau Shifts Cabinet, Naming 4 New Ministers
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau shuffled his Cabinet today for the first time since it was formed 18 months ago, bringing in four new ministers but leaving major portfolios unchanged.

title: LURIA, L, & SONS reports earnings for Yr to Jan 27
WINE CALENDER: AUCTION, CONFERENCE, SYMPOSIUM
description: Christie's Second Wine Sale, Madison Hotel, 15th and M Streets NW, Wash- ington.

title: LOSS LEADS AM TO SELL TWO UNITS
description: AM International Inc. announced yesterday that it would report a loss of $175 million in the 1981 fiscal year and that it planned to sell its Addressograph and Jacquard divisions to relieve its debtladen balance sheet.

title: No Headline
description: Russell Stover Candies Inc., a major producer of fine boxed candies, said yesterday that it would make a tender offer of $20 a share in cash to buy all of its outstanding common shares. The company's stock, which trades over-the-counter and closed Monday at 13 7/8 bid, jumped yesterday to 19 1/2 bid following the announcement.

title: SHARPSHOOTING SHERIFF VISITS
description: Dorothy Olmstead left her .38 revolver back in the hotel room but she wore the smart two-tone brown uniform and matching S tet son that marked her as a member of the Sun City Sheriff's Pos se.

title: FRANCE SEEKING CLOSER AFRICAN TIES
description: Almost unnoticed, France has developed a new and intense interest in Africa. While the Government of Prime Minister Pierre Mauroy has been involved - vigorously and visibly - in nationalizing industry and banks and pursuing other Socialist campaign goals, President Francois Mitterrand has been quietly at work fashioning a new policy toward Africa.

title: SCHOOL OFFICIALS EXPECT THOUSANDS TO FAIL TO GET THEIR SHOTS IN TIME
description: Tens of thousands of students in New York City public schools may fail to meet the deadline set for today to conform with the state's new regulations requiring immunization against childhood diseases, school officials said yesterday.

title: Pillsbury Net Off
description: The Pillsbury Company, a major producer of convenience foods and food mixes, reported yesterday that net income in the first fiscal quarter fell 12.9 percent, to $25 million, or $1.16 a share, from $28.7 million, or $1.43 a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: AN ELECTRIC OVEN
description: EVEN for someone who makes his living in the constant company of pots, pans and souffle dishes, as I do, the possession of a third oven may seem like conspicuous consumption. Nevertheless, I can justify it.

title: OUTSIDER BECOMES BRANIFF'S PRESIDENT
description: The ailing Braniff International Corporation reached outside its ranks yesterday to elect Howard D. Putnam, the 44-year-old president and chief executive officer of Southwest Airlines, as its president and chief operating officer. He succeeds John J. Casey, 62, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the Dallas-based airline.

title: AUTO INDUSTRY BIDS CONGRESS RELAX EMISSIONS REGULATIONS
description: The automobile industry asked Congress today for prompt relaxation of antipollution requirements for trucks and cars, saying current rules were expensive and not needed to reach public health goals.

title: INITIO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 7
description: Revs figures include capital gains of $702,000 and $1,182,000 for the latest qr and 6 mos, respectively, and $571,000 and $2,106,000 for the previous qr and 6 mos, respectively

title: H. GEORGE CASPARI, GAVE GREETING CARDS NEW QUALITY IN U.S.
description: H. George Caspari, retired founder of the greeting card company that bears his name, died Sept. 14 at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Norwalk.

title: Gulf Canada Financing
description: Gulf Canada Ltd. said it placed privately about $234 million (Canadian) of zero coupon, medium-term debentures, mainly with a group of Canadian institutional lenders. It added that the financing was the first such private placement by a major borrower completed in the Canadian market.

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Sports People; Ovett Out of Mile
description: Steve Ovett of Britain, who battled his countryman, Sebastian Coe, throughout Europe this summer for supremacy in the mile run, withdrew yesterday from Saturday's Fifth Avenue Mile because of a viral infection. The race, which will be run from 82d to 62d Street, still will feature some of t he world's top milers, among them Eamonn Coghlan of Ireland, whose time of 3 minutes 5 0.6 seconds is the best run indoors; John Walker of New Zealand, a fo rmer world-record holder, and Steve Scott, America's top miler.

title: U.S. CITIZENSHIP VOTED FOR SWEDE WHO AIDED JEWS
description: The House of Representatives voted 396 to 2 today to gran t honorary citizenship to Raoul Wallenberg, the missing Swedish diplo mat who saved thousands of Jews in Hungary from deportation t o death camps during World War II.

title: Todd Shipyards S eeks Its Shares
description: The Todd Shipyards Corporation, the country's largest independent shipbuilding company, offered to purchase up to 550,000 of its common shares at not more than $28 a share. Unless extended, the offer will expire at midnight, New York time, Oct. 13.

title: SAN DIEGO GAS NAMES CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER
description: Thomas A. Page, 48, president of the San Di ego Gas and Electric Company, has been appointed to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective Oct. 1. He will succeed Robert E. Morris, 59, who will remain chairman.
