Goldman: the Kremlin's grain disaster A31

title: Quebec Eurobond Issue
description: The province of Quebec is raising $50 million (Canadian) through a six-year Eurobond issue, the lead manager, Societe Generale, said today.

title: ANY SAUDI AWACS FLIGHT IS EXPECTED TO SHUN ISRAEL'S BORDER
description: United States officials said today that they believed Saudi Arabia had accepted United State s tactical principles used in flyin g Awacs radar early warning planes -principles that would normall y dictate that the subsonic, four-engine Boeing planes not fly in cl ose proximity to potentially hostile airspace.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SPEECH BY GROMYKO TO THE U.N.
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of the speech yesterday by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union to the General Assem bly of the United Nations, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: KLEINDIENST IS AQUITTED IN ARIZONA AFTER 5-WEEK TRIAL IN PERJURY CASE
description: A jury today found former United States Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst not guilty of perjuring himself before the State Bar of Arizona.

title: REAGAN APPEALS FOR BETTER TIES IN NOTE TO SOVIET
description: President Reagan sent a letter today to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, expressing the hope that, in high-level talks that begin tomorrow, the two countries can establish ''a framework of mutual respect'' that will lead to a more enduring relationship ''than we have ever had before.''

title: Addendum
description: * Changing Times magazine is increasing its advertising rates by 10 percent effective with the January issue.

title: Energy Push By Ottawa
description: Despite mounting criticism from American oilmen, the Canadian Government remains determined to put more of the energy sector into Canadian hands, according to Energy Minister Marc Lalonde.

title: NEW BRADLEY GAME TESTS FICKLE MARKET
description: The battle for the electronic game market is beginning to get intense, and Milton Bradley is showing its hand with all the hoopla of a highly orchestrated advertising campaign.

title: METS DEFEATED BY PIRATES, 5-3
description: The Mets got seven innings of two-hit relief pitching against the Pittsburgh Pirates at Shea Stadium last night, but one of those hits was a three-run homer by Jason Thompson and it stood up for a 5-3 victory.

title: SHUTTLE LIFTOFF DELAYED AS FUEL SPILL LOOSENS TILES
description: A spill of toxic propellants damaged one side of the space shuttle Columbia early yesterday, loosening dozens of the vehicle's protective tiles and causing a launching delay of at least five days, perhaps longer. No one was hurt in the accident.

title: EX-C.I.A. AIDE SEES 'NO WAY' TO PROHIBIT RETIRED AGENT DEALS
description: Vernon A. Walters, former Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, who was paid $300,000 this year for his role in a foreign weapons deal, says there is ''no way'' to bar retired intelligence officials from doing business abroad.

title: Working Mother Frequency Is Doubled
description: In magazine land, McCall's has decided to increase the publishing frequency of Working Mother to 12-a-year from six. Its advertising rate base is 300,000.

title: Economic
description: Declining interest rates in the last two weeks have quieted criticism -for the moment - of the Federal Reserve's tight monetary policy, but on Wall Street many analysts say that, in a fundamental sense, the Fed's policy has hardly been eased at all.

title: Sports People; Ray Passes Physical
description: Clifford Ray, a free-agent center with the Golden State Warriors, has passed a physical examination, clearing the way for his tryout with the Phoenix Suns. ... Doug Collins, the Philadelphia 76er guard, has undergone surgery for the removal of torn cartilage in his right knee. ... Pro basketball in Europe is a growing alternative not only for top male American collegians but also for women. Lynette Woodard, who averaged 26.2 points at Kansas last season and won the Wade Trophy as the nation's top player in women's collegiate basketball, has signed a one-year pro contract to play in Italy.

title: Federal Express
description: The Federal Express Corporation, an air package delivery service based in Memphis, said it was negotiating with the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company of Seattle to purchase 15 727-200F all-cargo aircraft at an undisclosed price. With agreement on the purchase, the company said it would begin taking delivery of the planes on a one-amonth basis beginning in July 1983.

title: Astros 3, Braves 0
description: HOUSTON (UPI) - Don Sutton pitched a three-hitter and Tony Scott had three hits for Houston. Sutton (10-8) allowed three singles and no runner past second base as he registered his third shutout of the season and 55th of his career.

title: Soviet, China Buy Grain
description: New sales of United States grain to the Soviet Union and China have been reported by private dealers, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: POLISH AIDE SAYS SOVIET MAY CUT KEY SUPPLIES
description: A senior member of the Polish Communist Party Politburo warned tonight that the Soviet Union might cut back on shipments of strategic raw materials, including oil, unless ''anti-Soviet'' activity in Poland stopped.

title: ALL CHICKENED OUT
description: In my dreams I have been eating out in Washington a lot lately and the menu is always chicken. In the very first dream it was poulet David Stockman, prepared by Stockman himself.

title: Interspace Corp.
description: The Interspace Corporation of Parsippany, N.J., announced agreement to acquire for an undisclosed amount of cash the business and certain assets of the Foster Pump Works Inc. of Westerly, R.I., a producer of sliding vane pumps used in the process industries. Interspace, a maker of concrete pipe, other building materials and dinnerware, said that Foster Pump would be operated as a part of its recently formed Pulsafeeder division.

title: Goodyear Bank Merger Sought
description: The National City Corporation, the holding company of Cleveland's second-largest bank, said it intended to buy the Goodyear Bank of Akron, a subsidiary of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, for an undisclosed price.

title: A PECULIAR INSISTENCE ON THE AWACS SALE
description: To the Editor:

title: Schmidt Hoping to Meet Reagan to Discuss Arms
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt is seeking a meeting with President Reagan to discuss arms control and the planned visit here by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, a West German Government spokesman said today.

title: I.M.F. Loan to Malaysia
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that it had approved a $218 million loan to Malaysia, which has been hurt by a decline in sales of its major exports. Financing is being made through the I.M.F.'s compensatory financing facility, which makes loans available for countries that suffer export losses because of poor weather and other factors. The I.M.F. said that, in the 12 months ended June 30, Malaysia's export earnings stagnated because of a 10 percent decline in exports of natural rubber, tin and timber.

title: Guardian Angels Begin Patrol on Boston Transit
description: After three months of training, street and subway patrols began today for the Boston chapter of the Guardian Angels, the unarmed volunteer organization.

title: GOLDIN TO FACE BERNSTEIN NOW IN THE ELECTION
description: Harrison J. Goldin easily won renomination yesterday for New York City Comptroller, defeating John C. Dearie for the Democratic line in November.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 23, 1981; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets to consider the admission of Belize to the United Nations at 10 A.M. and 5 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: DAVID KIDD, 68, DESIGNER OF SUITS FOR WOMEN
description: David Kidd, the designer of coats and suits best known for his work during the 1950's and 60's, when tailored clothing was the backbone of most fashionable women's wardrobes, died of cancer yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Nippon Phone, I.B.M. Set Deal
description: The Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Public Corporation said it will sign a cross-licensing technology agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation, probably in Tokyo next month.

title: AIDE SAYS REAGAN WILL NOT TRIM ARMS BUDGET BEYOND $13 BILLION
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger says Presiden t Reagan has assured him that planned increases in military spen ding will not be reduced beyond the $13 billion over three years t he White House has already announced.

title: Washington; THE IDEAL DIPLOMAT
description: For the seventh time in its turbulent history, the U.N. is now looking for the ''ideal diplomat'' to serve as its Secretary General for the next five years.

title: No Headline
description: Cubs Top Cards By 4-3

title: TO DISCOURAGE THE BORROWERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Gibson's Continental Was Used in Getaway
description: Acting on an anonymous phone tip, the police recovered Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson's 1981 Lincoln Continental after it was used in a getaway following a garage holdup last weekend, authorities said today.

title: RADIOACTIVE DUMPING SAID TO BE WIDESPREAD
description: Radioactive wastes were dumped off much of the Massachusetts coast after World War II, and some may have been deposited near the rich Georges Bank fishing grounds, a Congressional hearing was told yesterday.

title: New House Beautiful Publisher Named
description: D. Claeys Bahrenburg, 34-year-old vice president and associate publisher of Rolling Stone magazine, has resigned from Straight Arrow Publishers to become publisher of Hearst Magazines' House Beautiful magazine.

title: DECISION ON POSTAL RATE RISE PUT OFF AMID HINT OF DISCORD
description: The United States Po stal Service today postponed for at least a week its decision on postage rate increases amid reports that the board of governors had failed to agree unanimously on a new 20-cent letter rate. The rate is now 18 cents.

title: Saudi Ship Order
description: Kochums A.B., the Swedish stateowned shipbuilding concern, said today that it had been awarded an order valued at 1.3 billion crowns, or abo ut $238.8 million, to deliver four roll-on, roll-off cargo vessels to Saudi Arabia. The order, from the national shipping company of Saudi Arabia, calls for delivery of the first vessel in the first qua rter of 1983, Kochums said.

title: ORGAN: RENAISSANCE
description: THE American Guild of Organists called its Monday night concert in St. Paul's Cathedral at Columbia University ''A Celebration of the Imagination.'' The imagination that was celebrated turned out to be a peculiarly Baroque one - Baroque not by virtue of musical period but by virtue of irregularity and grotesque contrasts.

title: New Futures
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today gave its approval for the futures trading industry to set up its own self-regulatory body.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BUGGING OUT

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: In his tastefully beige campaign headquarters, William Woodward had big brown boxes full of literature, palm cards and posters. Some of them said at the bottom ''Vote Sept. 10 in the Democratic Primary.'' Some of them said ''Vote Sept. 22 in the Democratic Primary.'' Some of them did not have a date on them at all. Those are the ones no one groans at the sight of. The others are collector's items, as overly optimistic as that old ''Dewey Defeats Truman'' headline. ''I don't k now what we'll do with them,'' Mr. Woodward said yesterday. '' Maybe we can lop the bottoms off the palm cards. Or do something wit h tape. It might just be easier to print new ones.''

title: Variable-Rate Assurances
description: Two Federal regulators today sought to ease consumer concerns about variable-rate home mortgage loans, in which payments can rise or fall depending on prevailing interest rates.

title: A Man of Many Talents
description: Danny Kaye, the comedian, rehearsing yesterday for a benefit performance on ''Live From Lincoln Center'' to be televised tonight on Channel 13. Mr. Kaye will conduct the New York Philharmonic.; The New York Times/Jack Manning

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of inconsistent information provided by the Federal Reserve in Business Day last Thursday, the charts with a story dealing with the Fed's monetary policies were incorrect. The correct charts are published on D12.

title: INCUBATING INNOVATORS AT R.P.I.
description: INCUBATORS for fledgling industries are being provided at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., oldest of the nation's engineering schools.

title: PHOTOGRAPHIC SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
HAITIAN REFUGEES STILL LANGUISHING AT FACILITY NEAR EVERGLADES
description: Summer is the time when the sea between here and Haiti is calmest, and so most fit for crossing. Two or three thousand Haitians took advantage of the season and the flat sea this year, packing themselves 60 and 90 and sometimes 120 into a 30-foot boat that a seasoned captain would not trust in a cattle pond. Steering for freedom, they went straight to jail.

title: Advertising; Fall Opens Ski Season For Conrac
description: AUTUMN is here, and there have already been days with that particular fall sparkle. That kind of weather heartens many people who are tired of the soggy mugginess of summer, but there are some whom it positively elates.

title: AFGHANS FIGHT POLICE AT U.N.
description: About 125 Afghan nationalists tried to storm the front gate of the United Nations today to protest the speech by Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister. The protesters, some of them wielding knive s and clubs with nails, tried to climb over the cement wall and iron fence around the complexto cut down the Soviet flag.

title: EDWARDS, A G, & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Shr earnings have not been adjusted for a previously proposed 4-for-3 stock split which will be distributed on Nov 2

title: THAT'S NO MACHINE-IT'S A VOICE
description: LENE LOVICH is at Studio 54 tonight. The spacious disco, which reopened last week under new management, has presented a few rock concerts before, but tonight's is the first in a regular Wednesday night series, and the fact that Miss Lovich is the performer makes it doubly special. She earned her reputation in the late 70's with eccentric vocal improvisations - birdlike twittering, swooping sirenlike sounds - and brooding melodies that had a distinctly Slavic flavor. What one tends to forget is that she is more than an intriguing vocal improviser; she is an exceptional writer, arranger and singer of songs.

title: Iran Reports Execution Of 41 More Dissidents
description: Iran's Islamic regime has reported the execution of 41 more dissidents and the arrest of 17 others.

title: PRESIDENT FINDS A FRIEND AT CITY HALL
description: When the United States Supreme Court forced the postponement of New York City's primary elections, Mayor Koch, who prides himself on his good relations with President Reagan, called the White House.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: MOST charity benefits are worthwhile and a surprising number are even enjoyable. But anyone on the benefit merry-go-round can have a lot of fun even before he considers whether or not he will part with $100 or $150 to actually appear at the event.

title: LINDEN MAYOR FACES MISCONDUCT AND TAX CHARGES
description: State Senator John T. Gregorio, Democrat of Linden, was indicted by a state grand jury today on charges of conspiracy, state income-tax evasion and misconduct stemming from an interest in two bars.

title: Excerpts from speech, page 6.
description: Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, accused the United States today of promoting a nuclear arms race to counter what he described as a nonexistent Soviet threat. In a stern 75-minute address to the General Assembly, Mr. Gromyko attacked Amer ican policy around the globe, from its ''imperialist interference' ' in El Salvador to its ''undeclared war'' in Afghanistan.

title: FEEDING PROGRAM REPORTED AT RISK
description: The Reagan Administration is considering a cut of almost 40 percent in one of the Government's most successful supplemental feeding programs, according to sources in the United States Agriculture Department.

title: Notes On People; A New Chef at City Hall
description: Mayor Koch yesterday hired yet another chef, his fifth, Mitchel London.

title: FORTUNES ON RISE FOR MAYOR BYRNE
description: It is being billed as ''Chicago International - the largest cocktail party ever,'' and more than 20,000 people have paid $100 each to attend Mayor Jane M. Byrne's annual fund-raising event tomorrow night at the McCormack Place convention complex.

title: Market Place; Cautious View For Analysts
description: ONE trade secret for economists who want to stay employed consists of two words: ''Forecast often.'' Wall Street security analysts have borrowed this strategy lately by repeatedly lowering earnings estimates for such diverse stock groups as semiconductors, lodging and forest products. Even resear ch directors at large brokerage firms are not immune to changing thei r signals on the stock market. For example, Donald I. Trott of A.G. Becker & Company, when interviewed in late July, offered this outlook for stock prices: ''The underlying trend is still upward, and we continue to look for a summer rally that will carry stock a verages to new highs - perhaps 1,050 to 1,070 as measured by t he Dow Jones industrials - by the end of September.''

title: Bangladeshis' Plea Rejected
description: The Supreme Court today rejected the final appeals of death sentences for 12 Bangladesh army officers charged with mutiny and the assassination of President Ziaur Rahman last May. It is believed that the sentences will be carried out as soon as the verdict is officially relayed to Government authorities.

title: THEY EXAMINE SEXUAL POLITICS UNFLINCHINGLY
description: THE protagonists in ''We're So Cool,'' a song from the Au Pairs' album ''Playing With a Different Sex,'' are modern lovers. ''I don't mind your casual affairs,'' sings the man, ''because I know I'm the main man in your life.'' The woman responds: ''Your body I'm prepared to share at off-peak times/ Because we know that others have and do share mine.''

title: THE KREMLIN'S GRAIN DISASTER
description: Unlike President Reagan, Leonid I. Brezhnev probably has been having restless nights lately. In addition to a phone call or two about his over-eager military advisers in Southern Africa, the wild men in Poland, the falling rates of growth in his energy industries, and domestic distress over substantial increases in retail prices, the most serious source of insomnia probably has been agricultural shortcomings.

title: RANGERS TOPPLE SWEDES, 7-1
description: Before the Rangers drubbed a listless Swedish team, Vastra Frolunda, 7-1, tonight, Coach Herb Brooks acknowledged that his team was still in search of two or three men to play center. Although one of his aspirant centers, Mikko Leinonen,scored two goals, Brooks said after the game that the jobs were stillopen.

title: AILING CORCO ASKS ASSISTANCE
description: The Commonwealth Oil Refining Company said yesterday that it was seeking concessions that would stem the company's losses and permit the continued operation of its Penuelas refining facilities in Puerto Rico.

title: HOUSE SPECIALTY? YOU NAME IT
description: DENVER FOR a lot of students working their way through college, a parttime job in a restaurant means busing dishes or waiting on tables. But Tim Lind does something completely different.

title: JUDGE IN SPY CASE REFUSES TO DISMISS CHARGES
description: Despite finding that two interrogators had promised Second Lieut. Christopher M. Cooke immunity from prosecution if he would cooperate, a military judge today ordered the former missile control officer to stand trial for espionage.

title: Doyle Dane Bernbach Add s Millsport Affiliate
description: James R. Millman, who has been operating Millsport Inc., a sports marketing service, has joined Doyle Dane Bernbach and now is operating a unit of the same name for the benefit of the agency's clients.

title: CITY DEPLOYED GUARDS FOR ITS MID DLE SCHOOLS
description: School guards - 420 of them - are being deployed this term for the first time in New York City's junior high and intermediate schools. The move was made after it was found that half of the 1,673 assaults in the school system in the year ended last June occurred in such schools.

title: Acton to Shift Food Operations
description: The Acton Corporation of Acton, Mass., said it would spin off the company's food operations into the Acton Food Corporation by the end of the year, completing a previously announced plan to divide itself into two comp anies.

title: Dorsett Enjoying a Fast Start
description: Tony Dorsett's 75-yard touchdown run against the New England Patriots Monday night was a rare gem because the long run from scrimmage happens so infrequently in an era w hen teams find it easierto pass than run.

title: Danger for Presidents Seen in Political Moves
description: Secret Service agents trying to protect United States Presidents are frequently overruled by the White House staff for publicity reasons, a former agent and a Senator who once served as a Warren Commission lawyer s aid tod ay.

title: ECKERD, JACK, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: Yr-ago results have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split

title: More Banks Cut Prime to 19 1/2%
description: Most of the nation's major banks reduced their prime lending rate by one-half percentage point yesterday, to 19 1/2 percent, falling into line with an industrywide rollback started on Monday by New York's Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: House Group Dubious On Nuclear Cleanup Plan
description: Several members of a House Energy subcommittee said today that Congress would probably forbid the spending of Federal money to help decontaminate the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania.

title: BRINKLEY SIGNS 4-YEAR ABC CONTRACT
description: David Brinkley, who suddenly quit NBC News two weeks ago after 38 years with the network, confirmed yesterday that he had signed a four-year contract with ABC News to anchor a new hourlong Sunday morning news program, play a major role in ABC's political coverage and work on news specials. At a news c onference attended by friends of Mr. Brinkley, including for mer Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, the designer Molly Parnis and former Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut, Roone Arledge , president of ABC News and Sports, announced that ''This Week W ith David Brinkley,'' an expanded version of ''Issues and Answers,' ' would make its debut Nov. 15.

title: JAN F. ROSTWOROWSKI
description: Count Jan F. Rostworowski, a lawyer and financial consultant with offices at 405 Park Avenue, died Monday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: Sports People; Pintor Retains Title
description: Lupe Pintor of Mexico successfully defended the World Boxing Council's bantamweight title for a seventh time by knocking out Hurricane Teru of Japan in the 15th round at Nagoya, Japan.

title: Real Estate; A Flurry Of Deals in Manhattan
description: A FLURRY of transactions involving investment property in Manhattan suggests a continuing widening of investor pa rticipation in ownershipand financing here.

title: Last Teachers' Strike In Michigan Is Ended
description: By The Associated Press The last teachers' strike in Michigan ended yesterday, while Philadelphia principals asked a court to bar the school board from forcing them to work in place of striking teachers.

title: Notes On People; Call Me Mister
description: At a luncheon honoring him in the Helen Hull Room at Avery Fisher Hall yesterday, Carl A. Morse told how he was recruited as an unpaid consultant to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts 20 years ago.

title: COOKING FOR 1,500: SECRET OF A CATERER
description: ''IPREFER big parties,'' Martha Stewart remarked. By big she means several hundred, maybe a thousand guests. And what she enjoys about them would probably send most people running in the opposite direction. She prepares the food.

title: Leonard Yields A W.B.A. Title
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, who won the unified welterweight championship last week by defeating Thomas Hearns, today gave up the World Boxing Association junior-middleweight title he won from Ayub Kalule June 25.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: YANKEES (AL) - Signed Mike Siwiec, pitcher, and assigned him to Fort Lauder- dale of the F lorida State League. MONTREAL (NL ) - Signed a working agreement to field a Class A team in San Jose, Calif., for 1982. TORONTO (AL) - Signed Don Won Choi, pitcher .; BASKETBALL HOUSTON (NBA) - Signed Billy Paultz, center, to a two-year contract.; FOOTBALL CINCINNATI (AFC) - Placed Ray Griffin, free safety, on injured reserve and signed Greg Bright, defensive back, who

title: AVON AND COOPER HOLD MERGER TALKS
description: As part of a continuing diversification drive intended to spur earnings growth, Avon Products, the cosmetics company, disclosed yesterday that it was involved in talks with Cooper Laboratories, a leading producer of medical and dental products, about a possible business combination.

title: A Surmain Anecdote
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Frank Prial's recent article about Andre Surmain (''Surmain, Still the Restless Restaurateur,'' Sept. 2) recalls an occasion many years ago when my wife and I dined at Lutece on our wedding anniversary, May 18.

title: Will Labels Outlast Life?
description: Reading a section about turtles in Thoreau's journals, we noticed that several of the Latin scientific names he used have changed. Emys, painted turtles, have become Chrysemys.

title: FISH WITH AN IMAGE PROBLEM
description: CONSIDER the ratfish. Plagued by unprepossessing looks and a name that invites universal ridicule, his is a woeful life. The ratfish's misery is assuaged only by the company of other equally disadvantaged deep-sea aquaintances, such as the grunt, the gag, the hogsucker and the lizardfish.

title: HOW TO SCALE, FIN AND GUT FRESH FISH
description: FLOUNDER, or fluke, porgy, bluefish, stripers: these are the fish that are running these days and that many cooks, especially if they are related to a fisherman, are finding in their kitchens. With all of these fish, which are delicate and deteriorate rapidly, it is necessary to scale, fin and gut them quickly.

title: UNIONS AT PAN AM AGREE TO WAGE CUTS
description: Pan American World Airways' unionized employees, pledging to do ''whatever is necessary'' to guarantee the company's profitability, have agreed to a wage freeze through 1982 and a 10 percent rollback in salaries, company officials said here today.

title: AMERICA'S ACID RAIN MAKERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Deflate Auto Safety
description: Last April 21, Lawana Hansen lost control of her 1975 Oldsmobile on Interstate 15, near Salt Lake City. She plowed head-on into a tractor-trailer at a combined speed of about 100 m.p.h. The car was demolished, but she and an 81-year-old passenger survived. She didn't know it when she bought the used car, but it contained inflatable air bags.

title: 'Belize Is Ours!'
description: The ritual is familiar. The Union Jack is struck, the Queen is saluted with anthem and cannon, and yet another colony becomes yet another small country. So what happened Monday in tiny Belize - what used to be British Honduras - would normally deserve no more than a footnote. But this newest nation needs more than routine good wishes. It needs a guarantee of its territorial integrity. Guatemala says it owns Belize, and if its military rulers get even a wink of approval from Washington, they may assert that claim by force.

title: COSMETIC UNIT AIDS RESEARCH
description: Concerned about the rising costs and mounting criticism of the use of live animals to test the safety of toiletries and cosmetic products, the cosmetics industry gave Johns Hopkins University's School of Hygiene and Public Health a $1 million grant today to find laboratory alternatives to animal testing.

title: BOND SELLERS' PREDICAMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: REAGAN REVERSAL ON BENEFIT DELAY APPEARS POSSIBLE
description: President Reagan was reported today to have dropped his plan to defer cost-of-living increases in various Government benefit programs, including Social Security, in response to warnings from Republicans that the proposal would be defeated in Congress.

title: GOLDIN A WINNER BY 2-1; STEIN AND MISS
description: HO LTZMAN TRIU MPH By FRANK LYNN

title: EX-FEDERAL AIDE GETS FOUR YEARS IN ABSCAM CASE
description: A former Federal immigration investigator from Long Island was sentenced to four years in prison yesterday for his bribery conviction stemming from the Government's Abscam inquiry into official corruption.

title: COASTAL INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-No yr-ago comparable figures are available since the company did not become publicly owned until Oct 1980

title: BERKELEY BIO-MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After $513,000 loss from discontinued operations... C-Including $79,000 gain from discontinued operations;

title: Japan Sets Oil Stockpile Rise
description: The Japanese Government has decided to increase its floating crude oil stockpile by 30 percent through purchases from privately held stocks in Japan, the International Trade and Industry Ministry said today.

title: EGYPT AND ISRAEL REOPENING TALKS
description: Still far apart on an agreement, Egypt and Israel resume long-stalled talks here tomorrow on autonomy for the 1.3 million Palestinian Arabs living in the Israeli-occupied West Bank of the Jordan River and in the Gaza Strip.

title: Man in the N ews
description: Moments after Belize became independent from Britain at midnight Sunday, Prime Minister George Price found himself surrounded by delegates from Cuba, Nicaragua and Grenada.

title: Continental M eeting Veto
description: Directors of C ontinental Air Lines voted today against holding an Oct. 19 shareh older meeting that had been requested by Texas International Airline s to add its own membersto the board.

title: California Wines
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: The somewhat abrasive attack by Frank Prial (''A Dissenter's View of California Wines,'' Sept. 16) upon the wines of California merits a considered response.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "Washington is ever mor e often heard speaki ng about the American leadership of the world - though no one has e ntitled the United States to such leadership. Nobody." - Forei gn Minister Andrei A. Gromyko. (A14:1.)

title: Bush Friends Raise $124,700 For Redecorating Residence
description: Wealthy friends of Vice President Bush have raised $124,700 in tax-deductible donations to redecorate his official residence just six years after Nelson A. Rockefeller refurbished it.

title: A YEAR OF IRAN-IRAQ WAR SEEMS TO BRING IMPASSE
description: The war between Iran and Iraq is one year old today, and little change appears to have taken place in the positions of the opposing forces since the early months of the fighting.

title: False Alarm on a British Jet
description: A British Airways jumbo jet with 400 people aboard made an emergency landing in northern Japan today after the plane's warning system malfunctioned over the Pacific, falsely indicating there was a fire in the cargo hold. An airline spokesman said the Boeing 747 flew on to Tokyo after the routine diversion to Chitose Airport on the northern island of Hokkaido.

title: CALIFORNIA BUSINESSMAN EXCLUDED IN PROPOSAL ON FUNDS FOR HOSTAGES
description: A Presidential commission that has proposed compensation for the former hostages of Iran recommended that no Federal compensation be given Jerry Plotkin, a California businessman, because he was not a Government employee.

title: INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change for compensated absences

title: U.S. STATEMENT ON NOTE BY REAGAN TO BREZHNEV
description: Following is the text of a statement made in New York yesterday by Dean Fischer, State Department spokesman, about the letter sent by President Reagan to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader: Following i s the text of a statement made in New York yesterday by Dean Fischer, State Department spokesman, about the letter sent by President Rea gan to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader:

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Interest Rates Move Up Again

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AS one who remembers all the way back to the days when paper towels, plastic wrap and aluminum foil were nonexistent in the kitchen, I can still marvel at today's kitchen miracles. The chief new marvel, of course, is the food processor. There are, however, other minor but taken for granted appliances that I regard with considerable gratitude, and these include the automatic electric deep fryer.

title: Sports People; Gerulaitis Suspended
description: Vitas Gerulaitis has been suspended from the Volvo Grand Prix tennis circuit for 21 days for minor-offense fines accumulated over the last year. Gerulaitis has been fined a total of $5,800, including an assessment of $2,000 during the United States Open for abusing a fan during his fourth-round victory over Ivan Lendl, for verbal ly abusing an of ficial during his semifinal-round loss to John McEnroe and for missi ng a news conference. M. Marshall Happer, the administrator of the International Professional Tennis Council, also said that on a recommendation by Keith Johnson, the Grand Prix supervisor, h e had begun an investigation to determine if Gerulaitis should be cha rged with a major offense of aggravated behavior under the players' code of conduct.

title: West Berlin Police Fight Youths Over Squatters
description: Thousands of masked and helmeted youths fought police yesterday and early today in West Berlin after a teenager was killed as the authorities tried to evict housing squatters. Protests spread to the West German cities of Frankfurt, Bonn, Munich, Hanover and Bremen.

title: West Germany Tries Woman Linked to Killing by Terrorists
description: @Sieglinde Hofmann, accused of being a member of the outlawed Red Army Faction, went on trial today for the attempted kidnapping of Jurgen Ponto, a banker who was killed by terrorists in 1977.

title: PNEUMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
DANCE: TWYLA THARP'S NEW 'WHEEL'
description: The world is a mess. People have trouble communicating with one another. On every level. They even make war. It would be nice to have a golden apotheosis at the end of the world, a pot of gold, where peace reigns and beautiful, talented dancers take us away from the grubbiness and rage of our time.

title: CUT TO BE SOUGHT IN REFUGEE QUOTA
description: Attorney General William French Smith said today that the Reagan Administration would attempt to reduce markedly the number of Indochinese refugees admitted to the United States for resettlement in the next f iscal year.

title: World's Fastest Train Opens French Service
description: The world's fastest train, looking like a jet plane without wings, raced quietly like an orange flash through the French countryside today at speeds of up to 156 miles per hour on its inaugural run from Paris to Lyons.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE best buys this week are in vegetables. The current harvest has brought lower prices for onions, carrots, p otatoes and cauliflower. Meanwhile, pe ppers, eggplant, tomatoes and cabbage are selling for reasonable pr ices.

title: MERCHANT-IVORY FILM RETROSPECTIVE
description: A 20- year r etrospective of films produced by Ismail Merchant and directed by J ames Ivory will be shown at the Art Theater, 36 East Eighth Street , from Oct. 14 to Dec. 1. All but two of the 11 featuresand one short in the series have screenplays by Ruth Prawer Jhabvala.

title: Scott Paper Bid
description: The Federal Trade Commission said it had approved the Scott Paper Company's purchase of American Convenience Products Inc., a privately held, Milwaukee-based paper goods maker. Under a consent order, Scott Paper is required to seek approval of the F.T.C. to buy another company that makes paper products.

title: COACH TIED TO BEATING
description: A high school football coach participated in the team beating of one of his players to punish the youth for attending a postgame beer party, according to the father of one of the other players.

title: Notes On People; A Night Out
description: After the show starring Dave Allen opened on Broadway, select first-nighters were more than ready to have a drink with the Dublinborn comedian on Fifth Avenue. But what they found at Doubles, the private club in the Sherry Netherland, was more than many of them had bargained for.

title: Sports People; American Pastime?
description: August A. Busch 3d, the St. Louis Cardinals' owner, agrees with the United Auto Workers that Whitey Herzog, his manager, should not be promoting foreign cars in a television commercial.

title: Delhi Plans Statement Today
description: The Delhi International Oil Corporation asked the American Stock Exchange yesterday to halt trading in its stock pending an announcement it plans to make after the close of trading today.

title: FURRY LEWIS, A GENTLE GIANT OF BLUES
description: Walter (Furry) Lewis, the blues singer and guitarist who died last week in Memphis at the age of 88, got used to visits from rock stars during his later years. He treated them the way he treated everyone else - honestly and with an unpredictable but always telling wit.

title: PROTESTERS IN ALBANY SHOUT AS SPRINGBOKS TRIUMPH IN RAINFALL
description: After a day of Federal court decisions, a bombing of the sponsor's headquarters, arrests of radicals and mobilization of the city's police force, the touring South African Springboks rugby team played a rain-drenched match tonight on a floodlighted field in Albany's outskirts.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Albany International Corporation, Menands, N.Y., has named Michael C. Nahl to the new position of group vice presidentcorporate.

title: PRESIEDENT OF N. & W. ADDS TOP JOB
description: At the Norfolk & Western Railway, Robert B. Claytor, the 59-yearold president, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective Oct. 1. He will succeed John P. Fishwick, 64, who will retire and become chairman of the Roanoke, Va., railroad's new investment committee.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 23, 1981
description: International Moscow accused Washington of promoting a nuclear arms race to counter what it termed a nonexistent Soviet threat. In a stern 75-minute address before the United Nations General Assembly, Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, assailed United States policy around the world. (Page A1, Column 1.) Hopes for Soviet-American comity were expressed by President Reagan in a letter to Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, on the eve of talks in New York between Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Gromyko. (A1:2.)

title: Royals 2, Twins 1
description: Larry Gura, making his first appearance since Sept. 9, scattered four hits, struck out two and did not walk a batter in pitching the Royals to victory.

title: POPE EVANS & ROBBINS INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: As of July 1, 1980 the company acquired Gibraltar Industries on a proforma basis; the revs, net income and shr earnings of the combined companies for the yr ended June 30, 1980 would have been $58,229,000, $1,828,000 and 57 cents, respec- tively; the shr earnings reflect 100 percent stock divd declare June 30, 1981

title: Sports People; Passmore Recuperating
description: Bill Passmore, the leading jockey of the meeting at Bowie Race Course in Maryland, was recuperating yesterday, having fractured his pelvis the day before when he was thrown from a horse at the starting gate. His condition was listed as stable. ... Art Howe, the Houston Astros' top hitter this year, will undergo surgery to repair a torn Achilles tendon after the season. ... The Toronto Blue Jays have signed the first Korean-born player ever to be placed on a major league baseball team's 40-man roster.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Arrests at Diablo Canyon Pass Total at Seabrook
description: An eighth day of protests at the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant today brought the total number of arrests to 1,453, surpassing the number at the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear plant protest four years ago.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt ENGLISH PROSE STYLE. By Herbert Read. 216 pages. Pantheon. Hardcover, $11.95; paper, $4.95.

title: HARRY WARREN, SONGWRITER, IS DEAD
description: Harry Warren, the composer of more than 300 popular songs for more than 50 Hollywood films - the best known of which, ''42d Street,'' lives on in a Broadway stage version - died yesterday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 87 years old.

title: MILER TREADS SOFTLY ON FIFTH AVENUE
description: A blue city bus interrupted Eamonn Coghlan's reverie yesterday. He was running down Fifth Avenue, dreaming of a 3:50 mile, when the driver swerved into the right lane, forcing Coghlan to slow down.

title: SAFETY IN CITY SUBWAYS ASSAILED IN A U.S. STUDY
description: A Federal study of eight recent New York City subway fires issued today said that there were ''serious and pervasive safety problems'' in the subway system that ''could lead to the most tragic consequences.''

title: BAY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
DURABLE ORDERS SLUMP 2.5%
description: New orders for manufacturers' durable goods fell a sharp 2.5 percent in August, the Commerce Department reported toda y. It was the first decline since January and a new signthat the econ omy, already sluggish, was weakening further.

title: 1. Tied to Be Fit
description: A tailored shirt or a not-so-tailored blouse could be perked up with a little something at the neck. That something might be a bow tie made of a pretty fabric or lace. The West Side boutique called Streets & Co. has a collection of ties made in bright colored silks or paisley prints and very feminine ones of white lace. The bows are pretied and are fastened by a band that goes under a shirt collar. They're $10 to $16 at the shop at 2030 Broadway (between 69th and 70th Streets).

title: STEIN WINS BOROUGH PRESIDENT RACE
description: Andrew J. Stein, the incumbent, defeated City Clerk David N. Dinkins yesterday in the primary race for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan Borough President.

title: JUDGE ORDERS A NEW MAYORAL PRIMARY IN HARTFORD
description: A Superior Court judge today set aside the results of Hartford's Sept. 8 Democratic mayoral primary and ordered that a new primary be held on Oct. 13. The order came after lawyers representing city election officials and Mayor George A. Athanson, who won the primary, unexpectedly agreed to the new election.

title: M & T MORTGAGE INVESTORS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
WHEELABRATOR PONDERS A NEW RAIL UNIT
description: Wheelabrator-Frye Inc. announced yesterday that its board of directors was studying a proposal to create a subsidiary to be called the Pullman Transportation Company. Its financial results would no longer be included in Wheelabrator's statements.

title: SIMON'S 'ONLY WHEN I LAUGH'
description: USING reportedly no more than 15 lines from ''The Gingerbread Lady,'' his 1970 Broadway failure, Neil Simon has written what seems to be a new, upbeat, often funny and, on at least one occasion, harrowing comedy about an alcoholic, ''Only When I Laugh.''

title: TV: LIFE WITH AN ALCOHOLIC MOTHER
description: THE problem explored on today's ABC-TV ''Afterschool Special,'' at 4:30, is advertised right up there in the title, ''She Drinks a Little.'' Cindy Stott, a high-school student, has an alcoholic mother. Mrs. Stott insists that she can handle her drinking. Cindy insists on being protective, running the house and being a surrogate mother to her kid brother. But Mrs. Stott is getting worse, and her drinking is no longer a secret in the suburban town.

title: LETTERS
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Frank J. Prial's essay was a refreshing and long-needed analysis of the California wine bubble.

title: HOPE, AT LEAST, TAKES WING AT NEWARK
description: The young clerk behind the car-rental counter watched the smoke from her cigarette drift toward the ceiling of one of Newark International Airport's three grand terminals. Business was not booming.

title: CGA COMPUTER ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results have been restated to give effect to the acquisition of Allen Services Corp which has been accounted for on a poolin of interests basis

title: WHAT BELONGS IN A MEDICINE CABINET
description: WHEN did you last look - I mean really look - in your medicine cabinet? If you do look you will probably be amazed at what you find: leftover antibiotics from that strep throat you had five years ago, an assortment of outdated tablets and capsules, miscellaneous vitamins, a mostly evaporated vial of Merthiolate, the remains of various painkillers, decongestants, antacids, cough syrups, ointments and salves, the purpose of which you've long since forgotten.

title: G.M. OFFERING FREE AUTOS IN MOVE TO SELL ITS HOUSES
description: The house on the cul-de-sac at 3035 Newport Court here about eight miles north of Detroit has four bedrooms, a family room and central air-conditioning. It is priced at $122,000, and if someone buys it within the next five weeks General Motors will toss in a new $9,537 Chevrolet Cavalier to sweeten the deal.

title: Notes On People; Just in Time
description: Thrilled as she was at the prospect of being asked to come to New York with the Royal Shakespeare Company production of ''The Life and Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,'' Lila Kaye did not look forward to the trip. That because she refuses to set foot on an airplane.

title: FOR KOCH, A GLOWING DAY
description: They finally got around to holding an election yesterday, and Edward Irving Koch awoke well before a gray dawn to claim what intuition and his pollsters had already told him was his.

title: MISS HOLTZMAN BEATS ROSEN IN BROOKLYN'S D.A. PRIMARY
description: Former Representative Elizabeth Holtzman won the Democrati c nomination fo r Brooklyn District Attorney last night with a comfortable m argin over Norman J. Rosen.

title: Economic Scene; Wall Street In Wonderland
description: ''IN another moment,'' Lewis Carroll wrote, ''Alice was through the glass, and had jumped lightly down into the Looking-glass room. The very first thing she did was to look whether there was a fire in the fireplace, and she was quite pleased to find that there was a real one, blazing away as brightly as the one she had left behind. 'So I shall be as warm here as I was in the old room,' thought Alice: 'warmer, in fact, because there'll be no one here to scold me away from the fire. Oh, what fun it'll be when they see me through the glass in here, and can't get at me!' ''

title: Egypt's Coptic Church Synod Expresses Support for Sadat
description: The Coptic Christian Church voiced its support today for President Anwar el-Sadat and for his recent crackdown on religious dissidents and political opponents, many of them Copts.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Combustion Engineering Inc. said a Dutch subsidiary had been awarded a contract by Oxirane Chemie Neder land Ltd. to build a tertiary buty l alcohols plant at Rotterdam, the Netherlands.

title: RICHARD M. DORSON, HISTORIAN FOCUSED ON FOLKLORE OF U.S.
description: Richard M. Dorson, a historian who helped elevate folklore in the United States from an esoteric concern to a field for scholarly inquiry, died Sept. 11 in the Bloomington (Ind.) Convalescent Home. He had collapsed on the tennis court June 28 and since then had remained in a coma. He was 65 years old and lived in Bloomington.

title: INDIANS SEARCH FOR RESPECT
description: Wayne Garland stood on the steps of the visitors' dugout at Yankee Stadium recently and surveyed the field, where his team was preparing for a series that was unlikely to reverse its fortunes.

title: NORMAN SINGER IS RETIRING
description: Norman Singer has announced his resignation as executive director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, effective Jan. 1. Mr. Singer, who has been an arts administrator for 27 years and who is now 60 years old, will retire to pursue personal interests.

title: Q & A
description: Q. I have recently come upon a long-buried gift of one dozen silver marrow forks. They are the length of a luncheon knife, double-pronged at one end, narrow-pointed scoop at the other end, with a round, flat disk in the center for thumb balance. Where does one place marrow bones in a menu?

title: SADAT SAYS U.S. BUYS SOVIET ARMS IN EGYPT FOR AFGHAN REBELS
description: President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt said last night that the United States had been buying Soviet-made arms from his country for 21 months and fl ying them to rebel forces resisting Soviet troops in Afghanistan.

title: Jet Carrying 203 Safe As Engine Falls Apart
description: The rear engine of a three-engine Eastern Airlines jet plane carrying 203 persons broke into pieces yesterday shortly after taking off from Newark International Airport, Federal authorities said. No injuries were reported.

title: RADIOFONE CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Including $18,000 extraordinary credit

title: CURB ON RULES TO AID HANDICAPPED IS DELAYED
description: A little-known Federal agency today postponed a decision on whether to repeal stringent new guidelines for making public buildings accessible to the handicapped and agreed to try to reach a compromise with the Reagan Administration by Nov. 6.

title: PILLSBURY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: QUITE diligently, Elaine Sherman has been recording the T-shirt messages she's seen around town, and here are a few of her sightings: I LOVE MY GRANDMA (AD PAID FOR BY GRANDMA) NO SMO KING NEAR THIS T-SHIRT On an inf ant: TEETHING IS THE PITS I'M APATH ETIC, BUT WHO GIVES A DAMN FIREMEN STILL MAKE HOUSE CALLS INS ANITY IS HEREDITARY: YOU GET IT FROM YOUR KIDS EAT YOU R HEART OUT, I'M MARRIED TH E MORE I KNOW MEN, THE MORE I LIKE MY DOG PILOT'S PRAYER: LOSE NO T THY AIRSPEED LEST THE GROUND RISE UP AND SMITE THEE BR ACES ARE BEAUTIFUL

title: ANATOMY OF A BEAR MARKET
description: In the background of a cartoon currently making the rounds is a chart showing the recent market for stocks, with a line plunging down like the slope of Mount Everest. At his desk, a stockbroker is telling a client by telephone: ''Could I call you back. I'm taking a bath.''

title: Cuban Exile Group Says It Found Bug in Office
description: A Cuban exile organization, Abdala, said yesterday that an electronic eavesdropping device had been found in the ceiling of its office in Miami.

title: THE CHANGING IMAGE OF THE DISABLED
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: A Pro-Am Event Provides Entertaining Play in Jersey
description: A pleasant social event that seemed headed for extinction may be due for a revival. It is the pro-amateur tournament, in which experts are entertained at a country club and then play a session of bridge with members as partners.

title: The Economy
description: A half-point rise in interest rates on passbook savings accounts was cleared by Federal regulators. Under the new rule, described by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan as part of an effort to give the small saver a ''better break,'' thrift rates may rise to 6 percent, while commercial banks may pay as much as 5 3/4 percent. The move was sharply criticized by the savings industry. (Page A1.)

title: ICM REALTY (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including gains of $362,000 for the qr and $837,000 for the 9 mos on the sale of investments...C-Including $2,295,000 equity in partnership gain

title: DISPOSABLE COLLARS, A FASHIONANLE OPTION
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- R.S. Jackson, who broadcasts editorials, wears disposable collars. By R.S. JACKSON

title: THE CHANGING IMAGE OF THE DISABLED
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH FOOD: IN DEFENSE OF A TRADITION
description: IT'S fashionable and fun to put down British cooking. Americans love to make jokes about sodden brussels sprouts and dishes with names like Toad in the Hole. Well, the British are tired of hearing about the fabulous American nouvelle cuisine and fine wines from places like Oregon and New Jersey and how the only way to dine well in England is to eat breakfast four times a day. Especially when Americans are beastly enough to eat shrimps with pineapple and stick marshmallows on top of pumpkin pie.

title: People
description: * Lucien Kapuscinski has been elected president of Liller Neal Weltin Inc., Atlanta.

title: WINE TALK
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Eunice Fried writes regularly about wine. IT may be the price of La Tache, the pride of home crafts or the joy of seeing one's own label on the bottle. Whatever the reason, home wine making, one of the world's oldest skills, is enjoying new favor. And its season is now.

title: Bobby Grayson, Led Stanford In 3 Rose Bowl Appearances
description: Bobby Grayson, a football player who led Stanford University to three consecutive Rose Bowl appearances in the 1930's, died of a heart ailment at a hospital yesterday. He was 66 years old.

title: CONDEC CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: B-Including $1,196,000 or 33 cents a shr extraordinary credit attributable to the purchase of preferred stock of a subsidiary and a $2 million net recovery related to certain contract claims against the U.S. Government

title: LATTER-DAY SLAVERY
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYBOY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes a $2.2 million credit to reflect the fact that the actual annual tax rate was lower than anticipated in prior qtrs

title: RISE IN RATE ON PASSBOOK SAVINGS IS VOTED OVER INDUSTRY OBJECTIONS
description: Federal regulators decided today to permit an increase of one-half of a percentage point in the interest rates paid to an estimated 40 million Americans who hold passbook savings accounts. They acted after rejecting a proposal for an increase three times that size.

title: FOOD STAMP TRIMS SOUGHT BY REAGAN
description: The Reagan Administration said today that food stamp benefits would have to be cut 12 to 15 percent more in the fiscal year 1982, beginning Oct. 1, because the program would run out of funds before the year was over. The new cuts would come on top of $1.65 bil lion sliced from the food stamp program already authorized by Cong ress in its earlier round of budget-cutting last spring.

title: SYSTEMATICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
U.S. Realigning Policy On Job Discrimination
description: The Justice Department will not try to remedy employment discrimination by seeking preferential hiring, a top official says.

title: Soviet Pipeline Loan
description: The Soviet Union has agreed in principle on terms of a $1 billion loan from Japan to buy Japanesemade equipment for a proposed gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe, the Japanese Export-Import Bank said today.

title: YANKEES DROP 4TH STRAIGHT
description: Dave Righetti, who has pitched with stunning success since his promotion in May, had his poorest outing of the season last night as the Yankees lost their fourth straight game and their sixth in the last seven by falling, 6-4, to the Cleveland Indians.

title: Jefferson Agrees to Terms
description: The Green Bay Packers completed their trade with the San Diego Chargers for the all-pro receiver John Jefferson today when they announced agreement with his agent on a series of four one-year contracts. Jefferson, who with James Lofton will give the Packers one of the most powerful wide receiver tandems in the National Football League, was expected here tomorrow to sign the agreement, which wipes out the last three years of Jefferson's nine-year pact with San Diego.

title: MARKET DIPS AS VOLUME RISES
description: The stock market ended slightly lower yesterday in accelerated trading with some of the takeover candidates and transportation issues posting the biggest price moves.

title: Ted Bates Acquires British Search Agency
description: Through its British company, Ted Bates & Company, the world's sixth-largest ad agency, has acquired Moxon, Dolphin & Kerby, which bills some $30 million from recruitment advertising, management consulting and executive search in the high-technology field.

title: British Jobless Up to 12.4% This Month
description: British unemployment may be higher now than during the Great Depression, with 12.4 percent of the work force out of a job this month and grim predictions that the worst is yet to come, Government officials said today.

title: CONSTRUCTION OF NUCLEAR PLANT PROCEEDS
description: A 210-ton steel dome being lowered Monday to top off a 180-foot-tall structure at Seabrook, N.H. It will house the first of two planned nuclear reactors. Completion of the first reactor will be in 1984; the second will follow two years later.

title: BRIEFING
description: T HE Reagan-Bush Campaign Committee is trying to head off public disclosure of a critical Federal Election Commission audit, for fear that it unfairly raises the possibility of campaign law violations and the reimbursement to the Government of $1.5 million in campaign subsidies.

title: Applied Devices Facing Delisting
description: The Applied Devices Corporation, a defense contractor specializing in electronic instruments systems, said it would consent to the proposed delisting of its common stock by the American Stock Exchange.

title: MET OPERA: MISS SCOTTO SINGS NORMA AT OPENING
description: AS a rule, the Metropolitan Opera begins each season with a familiar production staffed with as many top-ranking singers as it can round up and/or afford. Monday night's performance seemed on paper to be another such traditional opening. The opera, after all, was Bellini's ''Norma,'' in nominally the same production that dates back to 1970, when Joan Sutherland, Marilyn Horne, Carlo Bergonzi and Cesari Siepi were the principals. However, as it turned out, very little of the evening could be recognized from previous ''Normas'' in the house.

title: VATICAN WILL INVESTIGATE U.S. SEMINARIES WITH AID OF BISHOPS
description: At the behest of Pope John Paul II, the Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States will announce today that they will assist the Vatican in an investigation of American Catholic seminaries.

title: 2 Ships in Philippines Fall Victim to Typhoon
description: A typhoon wrecked a Philippine Navy destroyer and sank a domestic freighter, leaving at least 21 people missing despite rescue attempts by American helicopters, authorities said today.

title: MUSIC: MERKIN HALL GALA
description: DURING the last 100 years, the waves of Jewish immigration to New York have changed our musical life -not just with the influx of talented performers, but also with the development of cultural centers such as the 92d Street Y. On Sunday night at the Abraham Goodman House - the city's most recently built Jewish center, on West 67th Street, housing the 29-year-old Hebrew Arts School - another significant development was celebrated.

title: ISLANDERS REUNITED AT CAMP
description: For the first time since May, when they skated round the Nassau Coliseum rink with the Stanley Cup, the complete Islander squad was together today.

title: Analyst Session Hurting Dome Stock
description: Few things on Wall Street are more a ritual than company sessions courting securities analysts. Free cocktails, and often free food, are at hand, and on some occasions the analysts carry away a modest gift or two. The company makes its pitch, but because of Federal disclosure laws, no true inside information is likely to be offered. At best, the company's stock will get greater notice and gain a point or two. At worst, nothing happens.

title: A.M.C. to Build 4-Cylinder Engine
description: The Amer ican Motors Corporation said it would build a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine at its Kenosha, Wis., plant for 1983 cars and trucks, largely replacing those it now buys from Pontiac.

title: Environmental Aide Resigns In Dispute With His Superior
description: Nolan Clark, assistant administrator for policy and planning in the Environmental Protection Agency, submitted his resignation today to the agency's administrator, Anne W. Gorsuch, citing ''irreconciliable differences of style'' with his superior.

title: Colby Blames His Publisher
description: William E. Colby, a former Director of Central Intelligence, says his publisher is to blame for allowing age ncy-censor ed information to appear in a French edition of ''Honorable M en,'' his memoirs. He said Simon & Schuster of New York had failed to inform the French publisher of changes ordered by the agency. Justi ce Department sources say the Government plans to sue Mr. Colby for breaching security.

title: Rains Kill 15 in Bombay
description: Torrential rains collapsed houses and caused earthslides today, killing at least 15 Bombay residents, the police reported.

title: Home Improvement; PERFORATED HARDBOARD FOR EXTRA STORAGE
description: ONE of the quickest, easiest and neatest ways to create additional storage space in any room - as well as in basements, garages and attics - is to cover a blank section of wall, or the inside of a closet or cabinet door, with panels of perforated hardboard.

title: AILING FINNISH CHIEF MAY QUIT
description: President Urho Kekkonen of Finland has been on medical leave since Sept. 11, and his close associates are said to believe that the 81-year-old leader, who is in his 26th year in office, may soon have to resign.

title: Index
description: INTERNATIONAL Israeli archeologist defends City of David dig A2 Senate backs move to link Salva- dor aid to rights progress A3 Egypt, Israel and U.S. resume talks on Palestinian self-rule A3 Ailing Finnis h President might quit A4 Around the Wo rld A7 Wave of viole nce troubling Thai- land A11 Exile of lawy er is linked to end of Letelier ca se A12 Bolivian chan ges linked to U.S. displeasure A13 2 U.S. milita ry advisers are shot in Honduras A14 GOVERNMENT/POLITICS Virginia gubernatorial candi- dates campaign unusually hard A23 Michigan Democrats see hope in new gubernatorial candidate A24 Planners see transit ''Dunkirk'' in plan to cut cities' aid B12 WASHINGTON TALK Briefing B10 Required reading B10 F.B.I. has a new TV show and a refurbished reputation B10 GENERAL Around the Nation A16 Navy ready to build disputed hos- pital in San Diego A16 Officer accused of selling secrets to Russians goes on trial A18 Army Secretary reassures Jersey on Fort Dix B2 HEALTH/SCIENCE Fuel spill may bring monthlong delay for shuttle flight A20 BITUARIES Chief Dan George, who appeared in film ''Little Big Man'' D27 Dr. James E. What's primary now Heat, light and oil Topics: siren songs Letters A26 Anthony Lewis: time for the P.L.O. to act A27 William Safire: "can-do" at Cancun A27 Jacek Kalabinski: extremism in Poland A27 Roger Fisher: on negotiationg - the U.S. and Soviet A27

title: LTV SEEKS CONTROL OF GRUMMAN
description: The LTV Corporation of Dallas made a surprise takeover bid yesterday for the Grumman Corporation, Long Island's biggest employer.

title: GENERALS TESTIFY IN ESPIONAGE CASE
description: The United States began its case against a former warrant officer charged with espionage today by calling two prominent retired Army generals, both of whom testified that top-secret coding materials he is accused of selling to the Soviet Union were crucial for national defense.

title: Proposed Drug Rules Debated
description: Pre-race medication of race horses became a disputed issue in New York yesterday as angry trainers and owners protested proposed state rule changes that would bar the administration of ''any foreign substance'' with ''pharmacological effect.''

title: LA QUINTA MOTOR INNS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
By Sports of The Times; The Truths of a Split Season
description: TO prevent the baseball club owners from ever again being tempted to install a split-season format, they should be vaccinated with the truth serum that the Mets and the Yankees have supplied.

title: OUTER BOROUGHS ATTRACT COUPLES SEEKING A HOME
description: Three years ago, Joseph Leo and his family moved from their Greenwich Village apartment to a century-old Queen Anne house on a quarter-acre lot in the St. George section of Staten Island.

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.S. PRESSING FOR UNITY OF DRUG AND F.B.I. AGENTS
description: The Federal Drug Enforcement Administration is disbanding its largest office - covering the the 10-state Northeast region - in a pilot program aimed at improving enforcement through increased supervision by headquarters in Washington.

title: A.T.&T.-CBS TIE IS REPORTED
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and CBS Inc. are planning a marketing test of home computer technology that would use A.T.& T.'s communication network to transmit shopping, advertising and other data developed by CBS to a consumer's living room.

title: 2 Soviet Jets Intercepted Flying Near East Coast
description: For the third time this year, two Soviet TU-95D reconnaisance aircraft were intercepted by United States jet fighters off the East Coast, air defense officials said today.

title: News Analysis
description: For the next month, the Democrats will be seriously facing the major reasons they give for their defeats of 1980: shortages in ideas and deficiencies of modern political skills.

title: OVERSTRESSED SONGS OF THE YOUNG RIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Horticulture Magazine To New Yorker Inc.
description: The New Yorker Magazine Inc., which has made three acquisitions in its 56 years, none of them magazines, is about to change its record. Its management has reached an agreement to acquire 60 percent of Horticulture Magazine, Boston, a monthly with 104,000 in circulation that is the official publication of the Massachusetts Horticultural Society.

title: POLISH REGIME SEES 'REALISM' IN A UNION PROPOSAL
description: Solidarity, the independent union movement, offered last night to compromise on the issue of worker self-management, and today the Polish Government called the action a ''step toward realism.''

title: STAGE: 'BADGERS' BY DONALD WOLLNER
description: ''BADGERS,'' a new play by Donald Wollner, opened the season at the Manhattan Punch Line on the same weekend that Simon and Garfunkel were offering a free concert in Central Park. In tandem, the two events were a kind of deja vu for the 60's, a time when all things seemed possible, even revolution. As we watch ''Badgers,'' we can hear a subliminal ''Sounds of Silence.''

title: TEMPLETON IN ST. LOUIS RETURN
description: Jerry White's pinch homer with one out in the ninth inning gave Montreal a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates last night and sent the Expos into first place in the National League Eastern Division, a half-game ahead of the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: DR. ROBERT FITZHUGH, AUTHOR AND EX-PROFESSOR, DIES AT 75
description: Dr. Robert Tyson Fitzhugh, author and professor emeritus of English liter ature at Brooklyn College, died Tuesday at Columbia Memorial Hosp ital in Hudson, N.Y. He was 75 years old and lived in Craryville, N .Y.

title: REVCO DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 22
description: The shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Aug 17, 1981

title: FIRST ARTISTS PRODUCTION CO LTD reports earnings for Yr to June 30
4-YEAR NOTES' 15.91% A RECORD
description: The Treasury sold 15 7/8 percent four-year notes yesterday at an average yield of 15.91 percent, a record for a new issue of that maturity.

title: The Economy
description: The Reagan Administration appeared ready to delay indefinitely the issue of decontrolling natural gas prices. Officials were said to have decided that Congress was too preoccupied with budget matters to take up gas decontrol now. (Page D1.)

title: GOOD RIDDANCE, SUMMER PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: BROOKS SEEKS A NO.1 IN GOALIE STANDINGS
description: The three goalies competing intensely for two Ranger jobs know that Coach Herb Brooks wants the real Ranger goaltender to stand up.

title: Thomson-CFS
description: Thomson-CSF S.A. said that it would bring out a low-cost, desk-top microcomputer in a venture with the Fortune Systems Corporation, a Foster City, Calif., company in which Thomson holds a 33 percent interest. The multipurpose 16-bit micromega system, based on 68000 microprocessor technology, will be produced in France and the United States next year, it said. Other shareholders in Fortune Systems are Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas, the First National Bank of Chicago, Brentwood Associates, the Greyhound Computer Corporation, Walter E. Heller & Company and the Asset Management Company, Thomson said.

title: Gambling With Age
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Concerning your article ''Old-House Decision: Restore, Renovate or Remodel'' (Sept. 3), I must commend those who are willing to invest so much time, money and tender loving care into restoring or renovating homes with architectural character instead of opting for a ''D eveloper's Delight.''

title: Notes on People; Sitting It Out
description: The Twyla Tharp dancers were at a disco, but they were not dancing. Jennifer Way was not dancing, Katie Glasner was not dancing, and Mary Ann Kellogg was not even showing her legs.

title: IN MILAN, THE BIZ ARRE BECOMES THE RESPECTABLE
description: MILAN, Italy IT seems like only yesterday when the annual Salone del Mobile Italiano, the Italian furniture fair, was a straightforward event. There were good designs, disappointing designs and the innovative furniture prototypes that everyone knew would never be produced.

title: The Region; Jersey Lottery Set Records for Year
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The New Jersey lottery set a sales record of more than $417 million in fiscal 1981, it was announced.

title: FULLER, H B, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The company experienced unrealized foreign currency translation losses of 5 cents a shr and 33 cents a shr for the latest qr an 9 mos and a 15 cents a shr loss for yr-ago qr and an 8 cents a shr gain for the yr-ago 9 mos

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arrow Airways, a new Miami-based scheduled and charter cargopassenger airline, has named Albert P. Wells executive vice president and general manager.

title: KEYSTONE FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: Shr earnings reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid Aug 10, 1981

title: Island Charm Wins in Upset; ISLAND CHARM WINS IN UPSET
description: Island Charm came from last in a field of six, running down some of the fastest sprinting fillies in training, and won the $54,000 Grey Flight Handicap over six furlongs at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: Canada Bank Bond
description: The National Bank of Canada is raising $40 million (United States currency) through a 6.6-year Eur obond, thelead manager, Manufacturers Hanover Ltd., said here today. The interest rate coupon on the issue is 16.50 percent semiannually, Manufacturers Hanover added, and will yield 17.06 percent annually priced at par .

title: PUBLIC-SECTOR ARBITRATION CAN FIT A DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: Briefing
description: W HITE HOUSE plans to appoint a conservative Texan to head the National Endowment for the Humanities are running into a storm of opposition from friends of another Texan, Vice President Bush. Liberal Republicans in Texas have phoned Mr . Bush to voice displeasure at the looming nomination of Prof . M.E. Bradford for two reasons. One is Mr. Bradford's philosophy -hi s writings have criticized Abraham Lincoln and he supported t he 1972 Presidential candidacy of former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama. Another reasonis Mr. Bradford's tough campaign tactics agai nst Mr. Bush last year when the English professor at the University of Dallas helped run President Reagan's Republican primary race.

title: Little Brown Jug Field Of 19 Includes One Filly
description: Fan Hanover, seeking to become the first filly to win the Little Brown Jug, races against 18 colts tomorrow in the final leg of the triple crown for 3-year-old pacers.

title: 3 Indicted In Fraud Case
description: An indictment that was unsealed in Manhattan yesterday accused the former chairman of a Costa Rican corporation of selling unregistered securities that defrauded American investors of more than $1 million.

title: Sports People; Packers Get Williams
description: One day after the Green Bay Packers had reached a contract agreement with John Jefferson, the team worked out a multiyear pact yesterday with Delvin Williams, a free agent running back who previously starred with the 49ers and the Dolphins. Williams, who ranks 23d among all rushers in National Football League history, was a training-camp holdout this summer while on the Dolphin roster and had asked to be traded.

title: Wells Fargo Offering
description: Morgan Stanley & Company said yesterday that it was offering for sale 538,480 Wells Fargo & Company common shares at $26.50 a share. The shares were acquired from Wells Fargo in exchange for $20 million of Wells Fargo 8 5/8 percent notes due in 1998 and 8.60 percent debentures due in 2002 that Morgan Stanley owned.

title: REAGAN RELUCTANT TO COMMIT HIMSELF TO $16 BILLION CUTS
description: President Reagan, hastily reshaping his new economic package to improve its chances of passage in Congress, was leaning today against committing himself to the full $16 billion in spending reductions that his aides said earlier would be included in his speech tomorrow night.

title: Semiconductor Plans Shutdowns
description: Blaming a worldwide slump in demand for computer ''chips,'' the National Semiconductor Corporation announced a second round of shutdowns at its United States and Scotland operations.

title: Treasury Note Futures
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today that it had approved the Chicago Board of Trade's proposal to trade futures in long-term Treasury notes.

title: GRUMMAN: PROFITABLE DEFENSE CONTRACTOR
description: The Grumman Corporation, Long Island's biggest employer, has a reputation for paternalism. Production workers have never staged a strike, they own more than a quarter of the company's stock and they each receive a free turkey on Christmas.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE FISH IS RED. The Story of the Secret War Against Castro. By Warren Hinckle and William Turner. Illustrated. 373 pages. Harper & Row. $15.50.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I bought a new butcher-block table made of oak and have been given different advice about caring for it. Some say I should rub oil into the wood to protect it against cracking, but others advise me to coat it with a polyurethane varnish to protect it against penetration by foods and water. What would you recommend? - H.K., Springfield, N.J.

title: DELAYS MOUNT IN NORTHEAST AIR CORRIDOR
description: Travelers flying in the Northeast air corridor, the nation's busiest, are reporting extensive delays in takeoff times at airports in Boston, Washington and New York City. The delays appear to have worsened in recent weeks.

title: JACKSON, DECKED BY PITCH, HOMERS AS BRAWL ENSUES
description: John Denny threw a brushback pitch at Reggie Jackson last night and paid for his impertinence when Jackson retaliated with a two-run home run. The Yankees ended a four-game losing streak by beating the Indians, 6-1, in a game that featured two bench-clearing episodes.

title: VIRGINIANS WAGING UNUSUAL CAMPAIGN
description: The excitement over Nancy Reagan's appearance at a Republican fund-raising event tomorrow night has not drowned out an uncharacteristic clatter of hard campaigning in Virginia's gubernatorial race.

title: Plan to Create New City Outside Miami Is Killed
description: The Dade County Commission voted overwhelmingly yesterday to kill a plan for a separate city in the racially troubled northwest section of the county.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ALTERED BUILDINGS
description: ''The Best Laid Plans: New York's Al- tered Buildings,'' Surrogate's Court, Main Lobby, 31 Chambers Street.

title: WEST GERMAN YOUTHS RIOT AFTER SQUATTER DIES
description: Youths smashed store windows and set fires in several West German cities last night and early today, causing about $1 million in damage, after a teen-ager was killed in a battle between policemen and squatters in West Berlin yesterday.

title: 1971 TAPE LINKS NIXON TO PLAN TO USE 'THUGS'
description: A newly disclosed White House tape recording shows that President Nixon, angered over widespread civil disobedience in Washington during demonstrations in May 1971 opposing the war in Vietnam, endorsed a suggestion that ''thugs'' from the teamsters' union be used to assault the protesters.

title: REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT PROPERTIES reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Pervasive Fear
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Laura Cunningham's ''Hers'' column (Sept. 3) asks whether it is possible ''for a woman to walk alone, footsteps echoing through the night city, without feeling as if she's performing in a Brian De Palma movie.'' The answer is no, as she points out, but is it any different for men? Women have no monopoly on fear. Just ask me, twice having a gun put in my face, or the able-bodied men in my apartment building who, when wanting to walk, go up and down the corridors because they are afraid to step outside. RALPH SLOVENKO Professor of Law and Psychiatry Wayne State University Law School Detroit

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Monday on W. Hunt Dumont, who will be nominated by President Reagan to be United States Attorney for New Jersey, incorrectly identified the law firm he is associated with in Newark. The firm is Robinson, Wayne & Greenberg.

title: Cubs Triumph Over Mets, 2-1
description: The Mets' unexpected shot at a divisional title became more of an outside one today when they were beaten by the Chicago Cubs, 2-1.

title: Auto Parts Makers Agree to Merge
description: Two of the nation's biggest suppliers of automotive replacement parts, the Atlanta-based Genuine Parts Company and the General Automotive Parts Corporation, based in Irving, Tex., said today that they had agreed in principle to merge in a share exchange transaction valued at $248 million.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Long Island Lighting Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer 2 million preferred shares, to be sold through a Bache Halsey Stuart Shields group.

title: REQUIRED READING; Compensating Factors
