description: Senator Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota, in the Congressional Record, Sept. 22: Mr. Pressler: I rise to say that I sent a letter to the President in opposition to paying those citizens who were hostages in Iran financial compensation in addition to their hardship pay and regular pay. This was a difficult decision, but I do it for a number of reasons.

title: A LEADER NO ORCHESTRA CAN RESIST
description: At around 4 P.M. yesterday, Danny Kaye was in intense preparation for the Pension Fund Concert of the New York Philharmonic. He was at his chiropractor's office, getting his muscles into shape.

title: Turkish Jet Crashes, Killing Two Crewmen
description: A Turkish F-4 Phantom jet fighter preparing for Atlantic alliance exercises crashed today, killing the two crewmen. It was the second crash of a Turkish warplane in as many days.

title: 1981; * To the Editor:$
description: Regardless of the merits or demerits of Mr. Giamatti's speech against the Moral Majority, Mr. Buckley still has his Jonah story wrong.

title: NAVY READY TO BUILD DISPUTED SAN DIEGO HOSPITAL
description: Over the opposition of San Diego city and county officials, the Navy is preparing to start building the nation's largest military hospital here.

title: IN MANHATTAN, AN AWFUL DAY FOR TRAVELERS
description: Traffic jams clogged Manhattan's streets yesterday, compressing taxis, automobiles, trucks and buses into creeping lines of metal. Frustrated drivers leaned on their horns, nerves frayed, passengers left stalled cabs in midstreet and the police could find no single cause for the delays. There were, they said, a variety of unrelated reasons.

title: G.S.A. Head Is Seeking Private Sector Advisers
description: Gerald P. Carmen, head of the General Services Administration, hopes to bring together ''the best minds from the private sector'' to supplement the staff of his $5-billion-a-year agency, which acts as business manager for the Government.

title: EXILE OF LAWYER TIED TO END OF LETELIER CASE
description: The dismissal of charges against Chilean security agents for involvement in the assassination of a former diplomat in Washington was due in part to the exile of a lawyer representing the diplomat's family, according to an exiled Chilean.

title: Advertising; The Selling Of the 1984 Olympics
description: TV Network, is currently presiding over the sale of the highest-priced sports package in the history of communictions. And the total price of $600 million will be raised on Oct. 1 by about 15 percent.

title: Anti-Abortion Groups Repudiate Hatch Plan
description: Seventy-two anti-abortion groups urged President Reagan today to use his powers in behalf of a proposal to make abortion illegal by defining life as beginning at conception.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET AGREE TO RENEW WEAPONS TALKS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union met for more than four hours today to discuss the issues dividing their countries. They agreed to make an announcement tomorrow on the start of a new round of talks on reducing each side's medium-range nuclear forces in Europe.

title: LLOYD B. HATCHER
description: Lloyd B. Hatcher, a specialist in municipal bonds and a former executive of White, Weld & Company, the investment banking concern, died Monday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived in North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 24, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: The Region; Bill Would Require Boat Training
description: HARTFORD (UPI) - Noting a boating accident on Long Island Sound last month that resulted in five deaths, a Connecticut State Senator said that he would introduce a bill requiring training for pleasureboat operators.

title: EXTREMISM IN POLAND
description: Since the workers' revolt in Baltic ports in August 1980, Poles often have been threatened with outside interference in their country's affairs and with the use of force by their own Government. But instead of moderating the behavior of the workers, these repeated threats have radicalized them. For instance, Soviet military maneuvers held around Poland at the time of Solidarity's first national congress three weeks ago prompted a defiant response: The congress called upon other Eastern European nations to set up their own free trade unions, modeled after Solidarity. Without doubt, this unnecessary, risky appeal, which infuriated the governments of neighboring countries, was triggered by what was perceived as the threat posed by the maneuvers.

title: BOLIVIA SHIFTS TIED TO U.S. DISPLEASURE
description: A virtual blockade of international economic aid led by the Reagan Administration is held responsible in large part for the fall of two Bolivian governments in one month.

title: "CAN-DO" AT CANCUN
description: No wonder we're all confused about foreign aid. When Secretary Haig set forth the U.S. position at the U.N. this week, the headline in The Washington Post was ''Haig Pledges Aid to Third World,'' while The New York Times headline read ''Haig Rebuffs Poor Nations' Program for More Aid.''

title: U.S. Holdings By OPEC
description: The world's major oil producing nations held about $62 billion in investments in the United States at the start of the year, a top Treasury official told Congress today.

title: Extortion Is Charged I n Rights to Race Horse
description: Two men were arrested today on charges of using extortion to obtain shares of breeding rights to Special Effort, the first horse to win the triple crown of quarter horse racing.

title: Gardening; MINIATURE ROSES: TOUGH OUTDOOR PLANTS
description: ROSE growers are learning that small is beautiful. In the last six or seven years sales of Lilliputian rosebushes have increased from limited production for hobbyists to a booming multi-million-dollar business. At first only a few wholesalers grew the plants; now even the large nurseries dealing in hybrid tea roses are expanding to market these little roses.

title: STUDENT INOCULATION LAG HELD NO PERIL
description: The likelihood that perhaps thousands of New York City publicschool children will not receive required immunization against a variety of diseases poses no immediate public-health threat, according to health officials.

title: JETS' LACK OF SWARM TACTICS ON DEFENSE CITED FOR POOR START
description: Has the Swarm buzzed itself out? ''Heck, no!'' Joe Gardi said today. Gardi is the coach who took over as the Jets' defensive coordinator this year and who during training camp screamed repeatedly at his players to become more aggressive, to swarm to the ball. But despite the constant mingling of badgering and encouragement, the Jets' defense has been lacking, a major reason the team has not won in its first three games.

title: POP: MANHATTAN TRANSFER
description: THE Manhattan Transfer's superb performances at Radio City Music Hall last weekend offered a winning blend of music and theatricality. In the last three years, the quartet has grown to the point at which it has no equals among harmony groups in either stylistic virtuosity or technique.

title: HOUSE EQUITY USED TO AID THE ELDERLY
description: Julia Schick has traded her housing worries for a new roof, free rent and an extra $52 a month while starting an experiment that some say could help elderly homeowners around the nation.

title: WAVE OF VIOLENCE IS TROUBLING THAIS
description: Armed with American-made weapons left behind at the end of the Vietnam War, gunmen are driving Thailand into a chronic state of violence. Murders have increased to 50 a day compared with 40 last year, while other violent crimes like armed robbery and rape are being committed at the rate of one every seven minutes, according to a senior police officer.

title: DR. JAMES E. MCCORMACK, 70, DIRECTOR OF MEDICAL ACADEMY
description: Dr. James E. McCormack, director of the New York Academy of Medicine since 1967, died Tuesday of coronary illness in the Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J. Dr. McCormack was named director after serv ing since 1960 as dean of the Seton Hall University College of Medic ine in Jersey City and then as president of the New Jersey College o f Medicine and Dentistry, which absorbed the Seton Hall coll ege.

title: Sports People; Tops in Thefts
description: Although Dallas ranks 13th among the 14 National Conference teams in pass defense, the Cowboys lead the N.F.L. in interceptions with 10. Three are by Everson Walls, a rookie cornerback from Grambling.

title: STAGE: 'LOUIS' (ARMSTONG, THAT IS)
description: FOR sheer, profligate waste of energy, it's hard to beat ''Louis,'' the new musical in a workshop presentation at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater. This show, an ostensible account of the early career of Louis Armstrong, boasts more talented, hardworking performers than some Broadway musicals - and not one of them is put to good use.

title: MORE OLDER WORKERS ARE SEEKING PART-TIME JOBS
description: Older people are turning to part-time work in increasing numbers as they seek activity in semi-retirement and find that they need more income because of inflation, the Regional Commissioner of Labor St atistics sa id yesterday.

title: A PARTY KICKS OFF STORE'S CELTIC VENTURE
description: IT was the sort of brightly lighted media bedlam that Governor Carey, his wife, Evangeline, and Marvin Traub, Bloomingdale's chairman, seem to thrive on, a dinner for 1,500 people last night on the store's third floor to kick off its latest promotion of merchandise from all over Ireland.

title: TREE-COLLECTING SEASON STARTS
description: SEPTEMBER means that activity in the garden is winding down for most people. But for tree collectors, their busiest season is about to begin. Now is the time - because dormant trees are the easiest to move - that such collectors start scouting the countryside for tempting specimens.

title: Who Will Pay?
description: When Jimmy Carter revised his economic program yet again in March 1980, the Boston Globe editorial had two titles. The first, an embarrassing prank, was ''Mush From the Wimp.'' It was quickly corrected to read: ''All Must Share the Burden.'' Tonight, when Ronald Reagan revises his economic program, not even pranksters will be tempted to revive the first headline. But there is ample reason to fear that the second won't apply either. This President seems determined to march in straight lines -but at whose expense? Who will pay? Who will share his burden?

title: Georgia-Pacific
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said that it had asked the Federal Trade Commission to approve its proposed acquisition of eight corrugated container plants from a unit of the Johns-Manville Corporation. Georgia-Pacific must get approval because of a 1972 order settling a case in which the F.T.C. challenged Georgia-Pacific's acquisition of 16 softwood plywood manufacturers in the South. Under the proposed acquisition, Georgia-Pacific will buy the plants from Manville Forest Products Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Johns-Manville, for an undisclosed price.

title: Flyers Beat Islanders
description: The Islanders, far from full strength, lost their second game of the exhibition season tonight when the Philadelphia Flyers beat them, 5-2, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: FOES CIRCLE PRESIDENT, SENSING HE'S SLIPPING
description: In early summer, the White House Chief of Staff, James A. Baker 3d, a veteran of the shifting political rhythms of Washington, was predicting that President Reagan would begin to encounter rough sailing in October as the impact of his budget cuts hit the country.

title: CONNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 23
Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MORTON S. WEBSTER
description: Morton S. Webster, a bond broker on Wall Street for more than half a century, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan.

title: News An alysis
description: When Congressional hearings on the sale of Awacs surveillance aircraft to Saudi Arabia begin Friday with a closed session of the Senate Armed Services Committee, a keystone argument of the Reagan Administration will undergo a crucial test.

title: UNITED AIRCRAFT PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Net income...C-Including $147,479 or 11 cents a shr credit from the cumulative effect on prior yrs of an accounting change

title: SECRETARY OF ARMY REASSURES JERSEY ON RETAINING FORT DIX
description: After studying the possibility of realigning the jobs it assigns to its bases, the Army has decided to maintain the Army Training Center at Fort Dix, N.J., it was announced today.

title: ARCHEOLOGIST DEFENDS WORK AS ISRAELI RABBIS RAIL
description: The stormy season of archeological excavation ended officially today in a potent mixture of history, religion and politics.

title: Exxon Delays Alaska Venture
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A. has concluded that an Alaskan petrochemical venture would not be economically feasible at present, R.D. Anding, president of Exxon's chemical division, said.

title: Mercedes Sets 1982 U.S. Models
description: Mercedes-Benz of North America said that it expects to sell 58,000 cars in the United States in 1981, compared with 53,790 in 1980.

title: Ohio Judge Drops Libel Suit Against 4 Akron Journalists
description: A judge has dismissed a libel suit brought by the city's police chief against The Akron Beacon Journal's editor, Paul Poorman, and three staff member s.

title: Harvester to Build Compact Tractors
description: The International Harvester Company announced that it had signed an agreement with a Japanese company to build three models of compact tractors to be marketed under the Harvester name. Terms of the agreement, with the Mitsubishi Agricultural Machinery Company, were not disclosed.

title: New U.S. Radio Station Will Beam Into Cuba
description: The Reagan Administration, accusing the Cuban Government of lying to its citizens, said today that it would set up a new broadcast station patterned after Radio Free Europe to transmit programs challenging Havana's version of the news.

title: STUDY SEES 'DUNKIRK' FOR TRANSIT IF CITIES LOSE MORE U.S. AID
description: Federal mass transit officials have warned the Office of Management and Budget that a proposal to cut aid to the cities by 12 percent across the board could be ''a Dunkirk for transit.''

title: DO CTOR, OUSTED IN RAPE, GOT PRAISE AND NEW JOB
description: The Massachusetts Medical Society plans to investigate three doctors at a major Boston hospital who wrote highly laudatory letters recommending a colleague only a few days after he had been sentenced to jail for raping a nurse.

title: Hers; TODAY'S SEXUAL MORES CAN POSE SEVERE HEALTH RISKS
description: THERE are scientists who speculate that long ago, when the human species was running around in the Pleistocene bush, a certain lust for sexual variety and promiscuity on the part of man was essential for keeping the species reproducing efficiently. The more females a strapping hunter could catch the potentially larger the human pack would grow.

title: DEMOCRATS BUOYED ON MICHIGAN RACE
description: Leaders of Michigan's divided Democratic Party are hoping that several of their enduring political problems will be allayed by the announcement from Representative James J. Blanchard this week that he will run for Governor next year.

title: Sears Forecasts Better Margins
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company expects to maintain its ''sales momentum'' during the balance of 1981 while stabilizing its gross margins after seeing them slip in the spring season, Edward A. Brennan, chairman and chief executive officer of the Sears merchandise group, said yesterday.

title: RALLY CUTS EARLY STOCK SLIDE
description: A strong recovery cut stock market losses yesterday afternoon after an ominous forecast by Joseph Granville, a prominent investment adviser, had sent prices sharply lower in the heaviest trading in four weeks.

title: White House Guard Arrested
description: A White House guard has been charged with the armed robbery of a bank in Laurel, Md., the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported. John A. Bachmann Jr., a 29-year-old employee of the Secret Service's Uniformed Division, was arrested Monday evening in Hyattsville, a bureau spokesman said.

title: Howell, Sharon Discuss Merger
description: Howell Industries, a manufacturer of automotive steel stampings and windshields, said that it was discussing a possible merger with the Sharon Steel Corporation, a company it sued six years ago in a stillpending breach of contract action.

title: Diagonal Designers
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: As an architect who also specializes in interior design, I have always been appalled by those architects and decorators who are so busy building monuments to themselves that their clients' needs, both physical and psychological, are almost, if not totally, lost in the process. Concerning ''An Odd Couple: the Client and the Decorator'' (Sept. 17), there are entirely too many designers whose primary concern seems to be publication.

title: SOVIET NUCLEAR EDGE IN EUROPE IS REPORTED TO GROW
description: The International Institute for Strategic Studies warned today that the balance of nuclear forces in Europe is continuing to move in favor of the Soviet Union and reiterated its support for North Atlantic Treaty Organization plans for new weapons.

title: Technology; Recognizing The Real You
description: WHAT makes each person unique? That is of more than philosophical interest to those in the field of biometric access control. The field concerns itself with using fingerprints, voice patterns or other physiological traits to verify a person's identity. If such techniques catch on, people might have to press their lips to a plate of glass to gain entrance to a military installation, computer room or bank vault. Computer terminal operators or consumers using automated teller machines might have to stick a finger in a slot to activate the machines.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 19.50 19.50 12.50 DISCOUNT RATE* 14.00 14.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 14.25 14.64 10.92 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.22 14.43 10.14 6-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.42 14.41 10.77 7-YR. TREASURY NOTES 15.59 15.46 11.66 30-YR. TREASURY BONDS 14.58 14.41 11.72 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 16.56 16.28 12.57 MUNICIPAL BONDS 12.80 12.88 9.40 6-MONTH SAVINGS 14.379 CERTIFICATES * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Sports People; Yepremian Booted
description: The glory days of Garo Yepremian are apparently over. Once the kicking hero of the Dolphins' Super Bowl teams, Yepremian was waived by the Tampa Bay Buccaneers and replaced by Billy Capece, who last year at Florida State broke the national collegiate record for the most points by a kicker in one season, 104.

title: Poll Finds City Voters Oppose Carey 3d Term
description: New York City primary voters do not want Governor Carey to run for re-election next year, according to an Associated Press-WNBC News poll.

title: Going Out Guide
description: OUT OF TIME

title: Sealectro and BICC to Join
description: The Sealectro Corporation and BICC Ltd., a British company, announced an agreement for a unit of BICC to buy the Mamaroneck-based company for $70.5 million.

title: ASSEMBLY SPEAKER GETS A LESSON IN RESEARCH
description: What began last week as an oral assault by the New York State Assembly Speaker on President Reagan's Budget Director ended this week in a lesson on what can go wrong when a state politician decides to take on a top aide to the President of the United States on the basis of slightly flawed research.

title: SIREN SONG; Alarming
description: Noise: it's the bane of the city dweller, but much of it is for a good cause -o r is supposed to be. The neighbo r across the hall explained recently about a new device in his apartm ent: ''Even if a burglar manages to get through my door,when he takes his first step on my carpet he'll set off an alarm so piercing it'l l break his eardrums in 30 seconds.''

title: REAGAN SHOULD GIVE CONTROLLERS A BREAK
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW CUTS TO CLAIM MISSILES, WARSHIPS AND ARMY DIVISION
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger told Congress today that Titan intercontinental missiles would be retired, an Army division would be reduced to skeleton status and 29 Navy ships would be stricken from the fleet to reduce planned military spending over the next three years by $13 billion.

title: MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
2 Boeing Officers Given New Posts
description: E.H. Boullioun, who has been president and, in effect, the chief salesman for the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company, is being named a senior vice president of the parent Boeing Company. Richard Welch, who had served as executive vice president of the Commercial Airplane Company, will replace him as president.

title: The City; Computer Audit Faults Hospitals
description: A state audit of the use of computers in hospitals run by the New York City government concludes that many of the people who receive hospital data have no use for the information.

title: Village Scene
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Ever since my taking up a Greenwich Village rental in l928, I have understood that Grove Court was the scene of the quite well-known O. Henry story ''The Last Leaf.''

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
THE ECONOMIC FALLOUT OF THREE MILE ISLAND
description: To the Editor:

title: SIREN SONGS; Liberation Liquor
description: The housewife with a bottle stashed behind the detergent, who provided plot and subplot for a hundred TV dramas, may turn out to have been a myth. But the working woman with the screwdriver business breakfast, the white wine lunch, the 6 o'clock martini, the red wine dinner and the midnight brandy is not.

title: ABC AND GETTY PLAN A SPORTS CABLE
description: ABC and Getty Oil announced plans yesterday for a joint venture to develop a pay-cable sports-television service that would offer subscribers a single ''blockbuster'' sports event each month, beginning next spring.

title: Fruit Fly Maggots Are Found Beyond Coast Spraying Zone
description: More Mediterranean fruit fly maggots have been found outside northern California's spraying zone and a lone insect at Los Angeles International Airport was found to be sterile, officials said yesterday.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ON BROADWAY, THE CLOCK READ 1954
description: On Broadway and 50th Street yesterday, it was 1954. The Packards and Buick Dynaflows and highbacked Checkers heading downtown on signal were Simonized, chromed and fintailed; the men walking on cue across the street wore felt hats with gangster-wide brims, the women were dressed in New Look calf-length skirts; some of the lads in leather jackets had their ducktails brilliantined; and, if anyone doubted that the clock was being set back, the newspapers on the corner stand included The New York Herald Tribune and The Daily Mirror.

title: Heat, Light and Oil
description: For six months starting every April, the United States opens a national savings account. It is not just sunshine that is saved, of course, but also energy.

title: PICCADILLY CAFETERIAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Civilian Assumes Powers Of Brazil's President
description: Antonio Aureliano Chaves today became the first civilian to exercise the powers of the presidency since Brazil's armed forces seized power in 1964.

title: Sports People; Blazers Sign Valentine
description: The Portland Trail Blazers have signed Darnell Valentine, a 6-foot-2-inch playmaking guard from Kansas and one of their two firstround draft choices, to a multiyear contract. Jeff Lamp of Virginia, their other first pick, remains one of the nine top choices in June's National Basketball Association college draft still unsigned.

title: News of Music; AN ENDANGERED SYMPHONY PLAYS ON
description: THE New Jersey Symphony Orchestra, which has not performed since August 1980 and which seemed in danger of disappearance, has returned to life. The orchestra will present a truncated, 14-week season starting Nov. 1, and hopes to resume more normal operations in 1982-83.

title: AT CRAFTS GALLERIES, POTTERY TO PAPER
description: ANEW crafts gallery, whose initial show features the works of Nancee Meeker, Bill and Leslie Herb and Mark Forman, opened at 1310 Madison Avenue (at 93d Street) last night.

title: 2 KILLED AS PLANE AND HELICOPTER COLLIDE
description: A twin-engine private plane and a helicopter collided in midair near Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands Sports Complex this morning, killing the two-man crew of the helicopter and injuring the pilot and passenger on th e plane.

title: Sports People; Concepcion Wants Out
description: Dave Concepcion, the Cincinnati Reds' five-time all-star shortstop, has broken off contract talks with the club and would enter the free agent re-entry draft after the season.

title: Pushing Solar
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: After reading Margaret O'B. Steinfels's article about Manhattan's West End solar collectors, ''History of a West Side Solar System,'' (Sept. l0) it is evident that like any other new technology, solar energy deserves more research and development. Yes, solar systems still have faults, but leaky roofs, melted plastic tubes and insufficient heating are mi nute difficulties when compared to the hazardous was tes and fallout created by other energy sources. MARIA J. RODRIQUEZ Solar Lobby Washington

title: Car Imports in Germany
description: Imports' share of the West German car market rose to 28.3 percent in the first eight months of 1981 from 27.7 percent a year earlier, the Government said today. Sales of all foreign cars actually fell to 468,010 from 481,950 as the total market shrank to 1.65 million from 1.74 million. Japanesemade cars, however, remained No.1 with a sales increase to 175,250, or 10.6 percent of the market, from 172,890, or 9.9 percent.

title: The Region; Water Company Wins Rate Rise
description: NEWARK (UPI) - The New Jersey Board of Public Utilities yesterday approved a $1.4 million rate increase for the Middlesex Water Company, raising a typical homeowner's bill by almost 10 percent.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Alleghany Corp. said that it completed the purchase of about 1.5 million shares of its common stock from Jacob M. Kaplan, Maurice C. Kaplan and several other shareholders for about $45 a share.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 24, 1981
description: International High-level U.S.-Soviet talks opened between Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko. They conferred for more than four hours in New York on the issues dividing the two countries and agreed to announce today that new negotiations would begin on reductions of medium-range nuclear forces in Europe. (Page A1, Column 2.) A Soviet nuclear advantage in Europe is growing, according to the Inter national Institute for Strategic Studies. In issuing the warning, the private London research group reaffirmed its support forAtlantic alli ance plans to deploy new missiles. (A10:4-6.)

title: STOKELY-VAN CAMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 30
Primary vote totals, page B7
description: Mayor Koch plans a full election campaign, which will include television commercials, despite his landslide victories in both the Democratic and Republican races in Tuesday's primary, his top campaign aides said yesterday.

title: GODDARD, STUDENTS BACK, SURVIVES FUND WOES
description: Students are back here for another semester at Goddard College, and their p resence means that this wellknown bas tion of experimental education, only recently thought to be on the financial ropes, has survived.

title: Big Board Continuing Futures
description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday denied published reports that it was considering abandoning its 14-month-old venture into commodity futures trading and closing its New York Futures Exchange.

title: GULTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $52,000 for the qr and $277,000 for the 6 mos

title: Judge Blocks Bid to Exhume Remains of Oswald in Texas
description: A state district judge temporarily blocked Marina Oswald Porter today from exhuming the body of Lee Harvey Oswald, the man who assassinnated President Kennedy.

title: 'WHEAT'
description: PETER KRIEG approaches the subject of wheat from every conceivable angle in his impressionistic documentary ''September Wheat,'' and wheat turns out to have a great many angles indeed. He details the farming, marketing and distibution of the grain, not to mention its political, social and culinary possibilities.

title: The Region; Theater Named Fo r Harry Chapin
description: The open-air theater in Eisenhower Park, where Harry Chapin, the singersongwriter, was to have performed the day he died, has been dedicated to his memory.

title: Nations' Credit Ratings
description: The United States and Japan are still good credit risks, but the creditworthiness of many other nations has slipped during the last six months, according to Institutional Investor, a magazine that rates countries for international bankers.

title: Quito V olcano Active Again
description: Ecuador's Government has warned residents of Quito that the Pichincha volcano overlooking the capital is showing signs of activity after being dormant for more than three centuries. A report issued last night said heavy smoke and gas was erupting from the 15,584-foot crater.

title: ELIZABETH TAYLOR TO GET FILMEX AWARD ON COAST
description: Elizabeth Taylor, who started her M-G-M film career as a c ompanion to Lassie in 1943, won Academy Awards as a trollop in '' Butterfield 8'' in 1960 and a shrew in ''Who's Afraid ofVirginia Wool f?'' in 1966, and became the toast of Broadway in ''The Little Foxes' ' this year, has been named the third recipient of the Los Angeles I nternational Film Exposition's Trustees Award.

title: CANDIDATES IN PRIMARY
description: Following are incomplete, unofficial results of Tuesday's New York City primary elections. Asterisk signifies incumbent. DEMOCRATS MAYOR Edward I. Koch*344,540 Frank J. Barbaro208,331 Melvin Klenetsky25,020 COMPTROLLER Harrison J. Goldin*353,886 John C. Dearie181,375 NEW YORK COUNTY B OROUGH PRESIDENT Andrew J. Stein*75,208 David N. Dinkins66,920 CIVIL COU RT Sixth District

title: Senate Moves to Link Rights and Salvador Aid
description: The Senate today tentatively endorsed a measure that would require President Reagan to certify that the Government of El Salvador was making progress in improving human rights, econo mic and political conditions before giving it American military aid.

title: 2 U.S. MILITARY ADVISERS ARE SHOT IN HONDURAS IN A TERRORIST ATTACK
description: Two unarmed United States military advisers riding in a sedan were shot and wounded by gunmen firing from a speeding taxi here today, the United States Embassy announced. Three other American military men in the car escaped injury.

title: Cosmos Wary of Sting's Sting
description: The Cosmos have every right to be wary of the Chicago Sting when the two meet for the championship of the North American Soccer League in the Soccer Bowl Saturday night.

title: OF HOLY ANGER AND FREE SPEECH
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE PASSES BILL ON AGENT SECRECY
description: The House of Representatives today adopted, 354 to 56, legislation that would make it a crime to disclose the identity of American intelligence agents working under secret cover, but the bill was immediately denounced by critics as unconstitutional.

title: Track Group Rescinds Ban
description: The Athletics Congress, governing body of amateur track and field in the United States, has rescinded the so-called contamination rule that blocked competition between amateurs and professionals in track and field and road racing.

title: Notes on People; A Blow to 'Roots'
description: In Annapolis, Md., on Monday, Alex Haley, author of ''Roots,'' took part in ceremonies to install a plaque honoring Kunta Kinte, his slave ancestor who reached this country in 1767 aboard a ship that docked in Annapolis.

title: Espionage Hearing Stops For Query on Evidence
description: A military judge today adjourned pretrial hearings on spy charges against a nuclear missile officer until the Justice Department gets a ruling on evidence obtained by electronic surveillance.

title: Notes on People; A Prince of a Rescue
description: When John Hendren, a British sailor, was swept from the deck of a submarine into the Scottish Firth of Clyde yesterday, it did not take long for the rescue helicopter to get him to safety.

title: RESEARCH AID E AT COLORADO U.
description: Rose Litman, associate vice chancellor for research at the University of Colorado, died last Friday in a hospital in Monterrey, Mexico, of injuries sustained last month in an automobile accident. She was 49 years old.

title: U.S. SAYS ITS PLANES DUMPED AGENT ORANGE NEAR ITS BASES
description: Newly discovered military records indicate that substantial numbers of servicemen on military bases in Vietnam were exposed to Agent Orange when planes on defoliatation missions had to jettison cargo, the Government said today.

title: TIME FOR P.L.O. ACTION
description: In the long drama of the Middle East the moment has come for a decisive policy choice by the Palestine Liberation Organization. The P.L.O. leadership should end its equivocation and accept the permanence of Israel: the right of the Jewish state to exist.

title: PROBLEMS IN DYEING A CARPET
description: Even the most successful dyeing job will not make a worn area rug or wall-to-wall carpet look new. ''People have great expectations; those cannot always be met,'' said Gary Darling of the Renotex Corporation, a Manhattan carpet and furniture cleaning concern.

title: I.B.M.'s New Voice System
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced that it had developed a system to record, store and forward voice messages by computer.

title: MUSIC: RARE PIANO DUO
description: THE versatile talents of Leonard Bernstein were omnipresent during the Lincoln Center Chamber Music Society's final Ha ydn-Stravinsky concert, held in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night. His ebullient musical prese nce as both conductor and pianist gave the occasion a distinctly bu oyant character -as Stravinsky himself reportedly remarked afte r hearing his ''Rite of Spring'' conducted by Mr. Bernstein: '' Wow!''

title: Rhone-Poulenc Unit Gets a Top Executive
description: Robert M. Verburg, 62, has been appointed president and chief operating officer of Rhone-Poulenc Inc., the American subsidiary of Rhone-Poulenc S.A., the French chemical company. He succeeds D. George Harris, 48, who resigned to become president ofthe chemicals division of the SCM Corporation.

title: MET OPERA: 'RHEINGOLD'
description: THE main victim of last season's labor dispute at the Metropolitan Opera was the cycles of Wagner's ''Ring of the Nibelung'' planned for this season. The company doesn't now know when it will be able to mount the complete tetrology. What remains of its ''Ring'' consists of ''Das Rheingold'' and ''Siegfried'' this fall, and Tuesday night the first of these music dramas lumbered onto the stage.

title: N.C.A.A. PUTS OFF VOTE ON TV DISPUTE
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has decided not to take up the issue of television property rights at its special convention in December, and that decision has drawn strong protests from member schools of the College Football Association and set the stage for a speed-up of a Federal trial on the issue.

title: REGAN TALKS TO BUSINESSMEN IN DRIVE TO MOBILIZE SUPPORT
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan met privately today with the heads of six big corporations as part of the Administration's continuing effort to mobilize the political support of the business community for its economic policies.

title: FUEL SPILL MAY DELAY LOFTING OF SHUTTLE MORE THAN MONTH
description: Technicians at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida removed more than 200 contaminated protective tiles from the space shuttle Columbia yesterday as they sought to determine how much damage was done by a propellant spill that has indefinitely delayed the craft's second orbital flight.

title: The City; Police Officer Hurt In Air-Shaft Fall
description: A 39-year-old city police officer, Robert Paz, was seriously injured when he fell 70 feet down an air shaft on the roof of the New York Public Library's Fort Washington branch at 535 West 179th Street, the police said.

title: CABINET IN FRANCE APPROVES TAKEOVERS
description: The French Government approved a sweeping nationalization law today that would cost it more than $9 billion - twice as much as expected - to take over five major industrial corporations and 36 French banks.

title: BUSH CAMPAIGNS FOR KEAN AS JERSEY GOVERNOR
description: Vice President Bush and Raymond J. Donovan, the Secretary of Labor, campaigned here today for the Republican gubernatorial contender, Thomas H. Kean. They said November's elections in New Jersey could become an important signal of the public's acceptance of the Administration's policies.

title: Sports People; No Room for Politics
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, warned that the Olympic movement would die unless sports organizations remained independent of government interference. Speaking at the opening of the 11th Olympic Congress in Baden-Baden, West Germany, Samaranch said it was vital for the Olympic movement to maintain good relations with all governments.

title: What's Primary Now
description: For an ordinary Mayor of New York, renomination by three-fifths of his fellow Democrats plus nomination by the city's moribund Republican Party would be quite a victory. But Edward Koch is no ordinary Mayor. He is a politician of extraordinary energy, honesty and dedication with a brash style that only partly conceals a capacity for reflection and growth.

title: EGYPT, ISRAEL AND THE U.S. RESUME TALKS ON SELF-RULE FOR PALESTINIANS
description: Egypt, Israel and the United States today resumed talks aimed at finding a feasible plan for self-rule for 1.3 million Palestinian Arabs living in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: Address by President To Be on TV Tonight
description: President's Reagan's address on the economy will be televised live tonight at 9 o'clock on the CBS, NBC and ABC networks, viewed on channels 2, 4, and 7 in New York.

title: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 UP 11.2%
description: Despite rebates and incentive programs, sales of new cars by the Big Three domestic auto makers rose by only 11.2 percent in the second 10 days of September, the manufacturers reported today.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: "We went through the mood of the 60's, when we were attacking the C.I.A. Now there's a realization that the C.I.A. is on our side, that we need good intelligence."

title: Market Place; Easing Burden Of a Mortgage
description: TO paraphrase Simon and Garfunkel, this period of high interest rates demands a bridge over troubled waters - particularly for those who seek housing in an 18 percent mortgage ma rket.

title: M & M Mars' Cost
description: M & M Mars Ltd., the candy maker, said that it had raised the wholesale prices of its candy bars by 3.4 cents because of higher costs.

title: Raiders Trial Put Off
description: Judge Harry Pregerson of Federal District Court today postponed the retrial of the antitrust suit brought by the Oakland Raiders and the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum against the National Football League. The date had been Sept. 30.

title: KHOMEINI CALLS FOR PURGE OF LEFTIST SCHOOLCHILDREN
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini called today for a purge of left-wing students and teachers as 10 million Iranians started the new school year.

title: Notes on People; Keep 'Em Flying
description: At his usual travel schedule of two flights a month between Detroit and New York, it will take Richard M. Kippen 425 years to use up the prize he won yesterday. But then, as Mr. Kippen was the first to point out, from now on he expects to do ''a lot of traveling.''

title: DATATRON INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Included a pretax gain of $321,080 on a leasehold settlement a pretax gain of $78,015 on the exchange of securities and a loss of$68,518 on the early retirement of debt...C-Net income and included a tax benefit of $135,000

title: Concern Over Thrift Units
description: The Federal Government permitted some new savings and loan associations to begin operations despite concern by some Federal officials that they might not succeed, the General Accounting Office said in a letter released today.

title: Critic's Notebook; CHAMPIONSHIP SEASON OF SPORTS IN THEATER?
description: ONE evening, a friend who works in the fashion industry completely stopped conversation at a dinner party by announcing, ''Fashion is the theater of life.'' The statement was a misrepresentation of theater, if not of fashion. Theater is, or should be, an active art; it is an event, not window dressing. When scenery and costumes supersede character and conflict, drama is immobilized. A more justifiable contention might be that sports are the theater of life. There was more drama in the John McEnroe-Bjorn Borg U.S. Open tennis final than in an average month on Broadway. It was a collision of styles, skills and even psyches. One could not imagine two stage characters of a more contrasting nature -the steely, apparently nerveless Borg and the highly charged, frenetic McEnroe. As in boxing or bullfighting, tennis at its most intense becomes a contest of wills.

title: CAESARS' POOR RUN OF LUCK
description: Opulence is the order of the day at Caesars World, a string of adult entertainment emporiums that turn fantasy into corporate profits. At its flagship Las Vegas operation, which it is trying to duplicate across the country, a high roller may drop $50,000 at the gambling tables, the rooms are reminiscent of Arabian Nights and Frank Sinatra is on the payroll to croon and mingle at private parties.

title: Bank Director Role Limited
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has ruled tha t bank dir ectors may not serve on the board of an insurance company if the two companies compete.

title: GAS PRICE DECONTROL PUT ASIDE
description: The Reagan Adminstration, which has long agonized over whether to propose that Congress speed up decontrol of natural gas prices, appeared ready today to shelve the issue, at least for the time being.

title: FRANCE BREAKS WITH U.S. ON THIRD-WORLD AID
description: France sharply diverged from the United States today, urging a large increase in aid to promote thirdworld developmemnt.

title: DANCE: NEIL GREENBERG
description: IT soon became clear that Neil Greenberg's Sunday night program at the Merce Cunningham Studio was going to be odd. It also soon became clear that his dances were intentionally odd, that he was reveling in being odd.

title: CONCERT: ENSEMBLE IS REUNITED
description: THE Revolutionary Ensemble was reunited Saturday night for a concert at the Public Theater. The group was founded 10 years ago and disbanded in 1977.

title: CONVICT-AUTHOR SOUGHT IN SLAYING IN NEW YORK IS SEIZED IN LOUISIANA
description: Jack Henry Abbott, the convict and author who fled from custody after a fatal stabbing on Manhattan's Lower East Side in July, was arrested by Federal and local authorities yesterday afternoon at an oil pipeline inspection yard outside Morgan City, La.

title: GRANDMA LEE'S INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Includes extraordinary gains of $134,353, or 3 cents a shr in latest yr and $259,492, or 5 cents a shr in 1980

title: DELHI OIL TO MERGE WITH CSR
description: The Delhi International Oil Corporation announced yesterday that it had entered into an agreement to merge with CSR Ltd. of Australia, under which a CSR subsidiary will offer $78 a share for all of Delhi's common stock. The deal, based on Delhi's 7.58 million common shares outstanding, would be worth $591.2 million.

title: News Analysis
description: It has been the insistent theme of Edward I. Koch that once he is able to run City Hall as both a Democrat and a Republican, New York will get a better Mayor because he will become a strong bargainer for city interests in Washington and Albany.

title: BARCO OF CALIFORNIA (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
SAUDIS SAID TO REIMBURSE 38 TREASURY SALARIES
description: A high Treasury Department official said today that Saudi Arabia had reimbursed the United States Government for the salaries of 38 Treasury Department officials working on a Saudi-American commission promoting contracts and ''good business relations'' between the two countries since 1974.

title: STEINBRENNER CRITICIZES CERONE
description: George Steinbrenner says he plans extensive changes for the Yankees if they do not go on to win the World Series, and the player most likely to be traded seems to be Rick Cerone.

title: EXCERPTS FROM WHITE HOUSE TAPE OF A NIXON-HALDEMAN TALK IN MAY 1971
description: Following are excerpts from a White House tape recording of a conversation between President Nixon and H.R. Haldeman, then the White House chief of staff, on May 5, 1971:

title: PREMIER INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
ON THE FLEA MARKET PROWL
description: WHEN Peter Noseworthy trucked his first batch of old clothes into New York from Columbus, Ohio, last year, he carried them into his rented corner of the Canal Street Flea Market and dumped them in a huge, unruly pile for eager customers to pick through.

title: Giants Aim to Blunt Dallas Front 4
description: Harvey Martin is 6 feet 5 inches tall and weighs 250 pounds. Randy White is 6-4 and 250, John Dutton 6-7 and 265, Ed (Too Tall) Jones 6-9 and 260. Martin is playing his ninth pro football season, White his seventh, Dutton his eighth and Jones his sixth.

title: A Container Terminal Dedicated in Brooklyn
description: Governor Carey, Mayor Koch and other dignitaries yesterday dedicated a new container shipping terminal on the Brooklyn waterfront that they hailed as a major sign of the rebirth of the city's piers.

title: BUREAU TO POLISH SHIELD IN A PRIME TIME SLOT
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is putting its image on the line at a tough time under some tough circumstances.

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
SNIPER SENTENCED TO LIFE FOR 2 UTAH MURDERS
description: Joseph Paul Franklin was sentenced today to life in prison for the 1980 sniper slayings of two young black joggers after a jury could not reach a unanimous decision on a sentence of death by firing squad.

title: Survey Shows Housing Off
description: Sales of existing single-family houses fell 10.3 percent in August to the lowest level in six years, the National Association of Realtors said today. It was the latest in a series of discouraging reports for the housing industry, which is going through one of its worst periods ever.

title: APPEARED IN 'LITTLE BIG MAN'
description: Chief Dan George of the Burrard tribe, who was best known for his role in the 1970 movie ''Little Big Man,'' died today in his sleep at Lions Gate Hospital. He was 82 years old.

title: OF HOLY ANGER AND FREE SPEECH
description: To the Editor:

title: MOTORMEN AND PATH AIDES REACH A TENTATIVE AGREEMENT
description: Motormen and the Port Authority Trans-Hudson line Tuesday reached a tentative contract agreement, averting a strike set for today. The proposal was announced yesterday in Washington by Francis J. Gorman, vice president and general manager of PATH. The union negotiators will present the proposal to the membership within two weeks. Detai ls of the offer were n ot disclosed. Contract talks had resumed on Tuesday in th e hope of reaching an agreement before a strike deadline set for ea rly this morning. It wasthe first meeting of negotiators with Federal mediators since negotiations broke off in July.

title: Bridge: Attacking Lead Suggested When a Small Slam Is Bid
description: A few years ago one of the world's best players offered the following tip, as part of a contest organized by the International Bridge Press Association: Make attacking leads against small slam contracts, especially if dummy will have a long suit to establish.

title: 12 Executed For Role In Bangladesh Slaying
description: Twelve army officers were executed today for complicity in last May's assassination of President Ziaur Rahman in an attempted coup, according to an official announcment.

title: News Analysis
description: The announcement yesterday that the Roman Catholic hierarchy of the United States will assist the Vatican in an examination of American Catholic seminaries raises several sensitive issues about the training for and function of the priesthood.

title: The City; Queens Teachers Break Off Talks
description: A mediation session between striking teachers and Christ the King High School in Queens broke off with ''no settlement, no progress,'' according to the union president, Robert Gordon. Mr. Gordon said the session involved the Lay Faculty Association, representing 90 teachers at Christ the King; the school, and William Glinsman, a mediator, at the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service office in Manhattan.

title: Helpful Hardware; KITCHEN WALL HOLDERS
description: TWO useful, high-quality kitchen products are now available from Leifheit International, a European housewares manufacturer. One is a kitchen roll holder with sliding paper cutters, which will house two standard kitchen rolls, such as wax paper, tinfoil or plastic wrap, and has width-adjustable brackets for holding paper towels.

title: XEROX TO 'RESTRUCTURE' AND CUT STAFF
description: In its most dramatic response yet to Japanese competition, the Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it would eliminate a number of jobs as part of a plan to significantly reduce costs ''on a permanent basis.''

title: Bonn Aide to Visit Israel
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher has accepted an invitation to visit Israel and will probably set a date early next year, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said today.

title: ALWAYS ON THE MOVE, ABBOTT MADE FLOPHOUSES HIS HOME
description: While on the run, Jack Henry Abbott sold hot dogs from a cart in the French quarter of New Orleans and worked on a succession of oil rigs and pipe yards along the Louisiana shore.

title: Option Case Sidetracked
description: A Federal judge here has dismissed a complaint filed by traders on the Chicago Board Options Exchange. They have accused Los Angeles investors of benefiting from inside information in the trading of Kennecott stock options.

title: No Headline
description: The AM General Corporation, the heavy-duty vehicle subsidiary of the American Motors Corporation, has been awarded a $130 million contract to build 14-ton cargo trucks for the Army, A.M.C. said. The contract calls for AM General to build 2,511 of the trucks and gives the Army the option to order an additional 2,511. The trucks will be delivered over a one-and-a-half-year period, it said.

title: Suit Is Filed in 15 Deaths Of Atom Test Workers
description: A multimillion-dollar suit was filed yesterday in Federal District Court charging that 15 Nevada test site workers died of radiation exposure from atmospheric nuclear bomb tests in the 1950's and 1960's. The suit was filed on behalf of 20 survivor s. About 300 suits have been filed against the Government by relatives of test site workers.

title: MARKET DIP: IMPACT ON THE BIG AND SMALL
description: Professional money managers, chastened by plummeting stock prices, are regrouping for what many of them believe will be a modest recovery in stock values sometime next year.

title: Senate Panel Fails to Reach Decision on Social Security
description: The Senate Finance Committee debated Social Security for two hours today but failed to reach a decision on whether to attempt serious long-range legislation in this session of Congress.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Includes income from discontinued operations of $127,000 or 2 cents a shr for qr and $330,000 or 5 cents a shr for the 9 mos; shr earnings for 1980 have been adjusted for a 100 percent stock divd paid in Dec 1980; revs and net income for both yrs have been restated to include the financial result of the Acro Weider Manufacturing Company and the Globe Tool and Engineering Company acquired in Aug and May 1981 respective

title: THE U.S. AND SOVIET
description: President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. have placed the Soviet Union at the center of our foreign policy, but they are still trying to formulate that policy. Faced with a continuing Soviet arms buildup, the military domination of Afghanistan, a potential invasion of Poland, and cruel violations of human rights in the Soviet Union, this Administration, like its predecessor, wants to do something.

title: Home Beat; A SHOWROOM THAT STEALS THE SHOW
description: ALTHOUGH it is normally open only to designers and architects, other visitors, particularly Europeans, have recently been sneaking into Sunar's Fifth Avenue showroom, designed by Michael Graves, the Princeton-based architect. A space that steals the show from the office furniture it is meant to set off, it is filled with the classical references, illusionistic tricks and pastel palette that are among the hallmarks of the postmodern style.

title: KODAK, BERKEY SETTLE SUIT FOR $6.8 MILLION
description: The Eastman Kodak Company and Berkey Photo Inc. announced yesterday a final settlement of the historic antitrust suit that Berkey filed against Kodak in January 1973.

title: American Airlines' Labor Agreement
description: American Airlines said that it had reached tentative agreement on a new contract covering more than 5,000 flight attendants. Terms of the agreement, reached with the Association of Professional Flight Attendants, were withheld pending presentation to the union's board of directors.

title: AN IRISH MIX OF FASHION AND FURNISHINGS
description: ''THE Irish,'' Sean O'Casey once wrote, ''began to go to America as soon as the door was opened.'' Now, Bloomingdale's has opened that door a little further with its current store promotion called ''Ireland: That Special Place,'' which officially begins today.

title: Belgian Aide Is Named To Solve Political Crisis
description: King Baudouin appointed the Economic Affairs Minister in the outgoing Belgian Cabinet today to find a solution to Belgium's political crisis, the royal palace announced.

title: SOVIET SAYS SOME POLES SEEK PURGE OF CONCILIATORY LEADERS
description: The Soviet press agency Tass reported from Warsaw today that a group of Polish Communists had demanded an immediate meeting of the party's Central Committee to purge those following a policy of appeasement toward Solidarity, the independent labor union.

title: Soccer Bowl Notebook; Clubs Are Angered by Lack of Live TV
description: The lack of live television coverage has become a major topic of conversation in the week before the Soccer Bowl game.

title: NEW YORK SCHOOLS SHUT OUT STUDENTS
description: Thousands of youngsters were turned away from New York City's public schools yesterday because they lacked either proof of immunization against childhood diseases or permission from their parents for the schools to give them the legally required inoculations.

title: UMET TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including net income of $54,000 for the qr and $142,000 for the 9 mos from accrued interest forgiven

title: People; Matter of Degree
description: She has been fighting the feminist fight for years now, and when Gloria Steinem came to Yale the other night, she had some triumphs to report.

title: ROUNDUP TIME FOR 'WORLD'S TOUGHEST RODEO'
description: Dan Dailey, one of the top cowboys in the world, sauntered into an office at Madison Square Garden the other day. It was easy to tell he was a cowboy because of his big black hat and his tight jeans and his soft Western drawl. That he was not just your run-of-the-mill cowpuncher was confirmed by his big shiny silver belt buckle, which said, ''1980 I.R.A. World Champion All-Around Cowboy.''

title: Penitence and Reconciliat ion To Be Theme for 1983 Syn od
description: Pope John Paul II has chosen the topic ''penitence and reconciliation'' for the 1983 world synod of bishops, the Vatican said today.

title: About Real Estate; NEW MANHATTAN APARTMENTS ARE BIGGER
description: Condominiums are nothing new in Manhattan. But now almost all new high-rise apartments in Manhattan are taking the condominium form, suggesting that a new era in housing has arrived. And with it is coming a fundamental change in the characteristics of the apartments themselves.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT ON NAMIBIA BY FIVE WESTERN COUNTRIES
description: Following is a joint statement issued today by the Foreign Ministers of Canada, France, West Germany, Britain and the United States after their meeting on South-West Africa at the United States Mission: Special to the New York Times

title: DEMOCRATS ARGUE 1984 CAMPAIGN RULES
description: The Democratic Party took its quadrennial exercise in reforming the Presidential nomina ting system on the road today and heard Middle Western politicians qu estion the desirability of shortening the Presidential campaign and o f giving elected officials more power in it.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP 0.8% IN AUGUST
description: The Consumer Price Index, the nation's most widely followed measure of inflation, climbed eight-tenths of 1 percent in August, helped by a moderation in the increase of housing costs, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Another Prisoner Ends Hunger Strike in Ulster
description: Another hunger striker abandoned his fast at Maze Prison this evening, but the decision was not seen as a setback for the Irish nationalist protest.

title: Wealth and the Wealthy
description: William Niskanen, member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, before the National Association of Business Economists, Sept. 23:

title: Seiko of America Has New President
description: Takayoshi Saito, 48 years old, has been appointed president of the Seiko Corporation of America, the United States subsidiary of K. Hattori & Company of Japan, which calls itself the world's largest watch manufacturer.

title: THE WRONG FLAVOR OF 'REAGANOMICS'
description: To the Editor:

title: PRICES ROSE BY 1% IN NEW YORK
description: Consumer prices rose 1 percent in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area in August, advancing the annual inflation rate to 10 percent, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. It marked the first time since February that the annual rate reached double digits.

title: L.I. Harvest Festival
description: A Harvest Farm Festival, with crafts demonstrations, nature walks and fresh produce, will be held on Sunday at Uplands Farm, at Lawrence Hill Road off Route 25A in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I. Sponsored by the Long Island chapter of the Nature Conservancy, the festival runs from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., rain or shine.

title: TRAIL OF CONVICT-AUTHOR ELUDED POLICE FOR MONTH
description: For the better part of a month, Jack Henry Abbott stayed a step ahead of Federal authorities, who were armed with information from the New York City police as they traced his path.

title: CERTIFICATES' IMPACT QUESTIONED
description: Home builders, among the leading advocates of the tax-exempt savings certificates created by Congress, appear unlikely to benefit very much from the money that banks will raise from the certificates after they go into effect on Oct.1.

title: Ex-Client Is Guilty Of Pestering Cohn
description: A man who had been accused of harassing Roy M. Cohn in an attempt to force the lawyer to represent him was found guilty on six counts yesterday, but was acquitted of the most serious charges - coercion and burglary.

title: No Headline
description: In the News of Music column yesterday, the broadcast date for a complete, 12-hour performance of John Cage's "Empty Words" on WNYC was given incorrectly. The performance will be broadcast tonight starting at 9:30

title: Sports People; Pastorini Rejects Rams
description: The quarterback Dan Pastorini has rejected a contract offer from the Los Angeles Rams, whom he impressed in a recent one-day tryout. ''Basically it was a problem of dollar and cents,'' said Bob Cohen, the lawyer for Pastorini, who was cut during the summer by the Oakland Raiders. ... Coach Bud Grant of the Minnesota Vikings has sent film clips to the National Football League office in an effort to have the league take action against what Grant sees as excessive violence.

title: Smith Fights With Spectator
description: Reggie Smith of the Los Angeles Dodgers was ejected in the sixth inning of tonight's 7-3 victory over the San Francisco Giants for entering the stands behind the Dodgers' dugout and fighting with a spectator.

title: GENERAL TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including $41.4 million or $1.72 a shr gain from the sale of a subsidiary's interest in Cablecom-General Inc

title: 5 Hurt in Blasts And Fire in Jersey
description: Five workers were injured yesterday when a series of explosions and a flash fire swept through United States Metal Pow ders Inc., a metal-powder manufactur ing company here. Three of the workers were taken by helicopter to th e burn center at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, where they were reported in critical condition.

title: The Evening Hours
description: A T this week's frenetic round of parties, o ne question could be heard over an d over: ''How was your summer?'' Most of the answers were somethin g like ''Terrific!'' or ''Fantabulous!'' with the respondent fl ashing a pair of white teeth through the remnants of a deep suntan.

title: Pop Jazz; WILLY DE VILLE AND THE MINK IN WEEKEND AT THE SAVOY
description: WILLY DEVILLE is tall and lean, sports two ear-rings and a pencilthin mo ustache and radiates an almost feline alertness. He sayshe grew up '' all over the place,'' but mostly on East Second Street, between Avenu es C and D. Willy was 13 when he joined a rock-and-roll band called t he Young Savages. He learned to play blues guitar and developed a r eedy but powerful singing voice. After the Savages went their separat e ways - some into musical careers and some, apparently,into petty cr ime - he played with a succession of bands.

title: India Reports Incident On Chinese Boundary
description: Chinese troops crossed into Kashmir in May but withdrew within a few hours, the Indian Government said today.

title: QUESTIONS ON THE REDISTRICTING ISSUE
description: On Tuesday, New York City's voters went to the polls in a primary election that had been postponed for 12 days by the courts. But the primaries did not include voting for members of the City Council, and that is at the heart of the controversy surrounding the election.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: India Steel Plant Set
description: The Indian Government announced today that it had selected a British concern, Davy McKee Ltd., to build a large steel plant in the eastern state of Orissa. An official statement said the decision had followed consideration of ''various offers'' for setting up the plant at Paradeep. According to a Government source, the British company outmaneuvered Demag-Mannesman of West Germany by offering an aid-and-loan package bid of $2.8 billion for the project, $200 million of which would come as a grant from the British Government.

title: Typhoon Devastates Fujian
description: Typhoon Clara caused ''serious loss of lives and state property'' in Fujian Province when it smashed into the south China coast this week, The Worker's Daily said today. It did not give specific casualty figures but said nearly 50,000 acres of rice fields and 300,000 acres of sugar cane were damaged or destroyed.

title: Longer Hours At Chicago
description: The Chicago Board of Trade will probably expand its hours, but is ''no longer seriously considering a 24-hour trading day,'' its chairman, Les Rosenthal, said today.

title: Hudson Bay Move
description: The Hudson Bay Mining and Smelting Company said it was withdrawing its previously announced $32-a-share (Canadian) offer to acquire the remaining shares of Francana Oil and Gas Ltd. that it does not already own. Hudson Bay Mining, which holds 58 percent of Francana, a Calgary, Alberta, energy exploration and production company, said it was withdrawing the bid because of unsettled market conditions. It said negotiations were continuing about acquiring the shares when Francana completes its previously announced reorganization.

title: KOCH PRAISES JUSTICE LEFF AT MISCONDUCT HEARING
description: Mayor Koch took the stand yesterday on behalf of Justice James J. Leff of State Supreme Court in the judge's misconduct hearing before the State Commission on Judicial Conduct.

title: BEATRICE FOODS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including $45,077,000 extraordinary credit

title: PLASTIC BATTERY IS GOAL OF NEW PROJECT AT ALLIED
description: The Allied Corporation yesterday announced licensing arrangements and a development program that it hopes will lead to the marketing of the first plastic battery by the end of this decade. The technology involved could represent the most significant advance in batteries since development of the lead-acid battery a century ago, the company said at a news conference in New York.

title: Sports People; Title Bout Claim
description: Officials of the Pittsburgh Civic Arena claim they have an oral agreement making the arena the location of the Nov. 6 heavyweight title defense by Larry Holmes against Renaldo Snipes. If the fight is held in Pittsburgh, it would be the first heavyweight championship bout in the city in 30 years.

title: EXPOSITION FOR URBAN SOLOISTS
description: The Richniks, a singles club, will be there. Not to mention the Christian Dating Service, B'Nai Zion Singles and Women's Roommate Referrals. Adopt-A-Pet and Bide-A-Wee will be present and accounted for. So will a gentleman named Mr. Karate, a lady billed as Savella the Fingernail Strengthener and the edible creations of Alexander the Crepe.

title: Briefs
description: * Aluminum Co. of America said it planned to discontinue operations at a subsidiary in Sylesbury, England, on Dec. 31 because of depressed demand for ingot.

title: DECISION ON MALPRACTICE PREMIUMS IS PUT OFF
description: The Superintendent of Insurance in New York State, Albert B. Lewis, said y esterda y that he had not decided whether to grant any rate increases to the two companies that underwrite medical malpractice coverage for most physicians in the state. An independent actuary, hired by the state, has recommended a 107 percent increase.

title: No Headline
description: Books: As Saigon Fell By Richard F. Shepard THE LAST AMBASSADOR. By Bernard Kalb and Marvin Kalb. 276 pages. Little, Brown. $13.50.

title: THEATER: WILLIAM SHUST BRINGS CHEKHOV TO LIFE
description: FOR ''Chekhov on the Lawn,'' a new one-man show at Theater East written and directed by Elihu Winer, William Shust dons Chekhovian whiskers, pince-nez and frock coat and addresses the audience as if it were the Moscow Art Theater visiting him in his country house at Yalta. During that troupe's engagement in Yalta in 1900, Chekhov was able to see his plays, some of them for the first time.

title: DON EWELL AND HIS CLASSICAL JAZZ PIANO ARE BACK
description: ''A LOT of jazz pianists look down on the old classic way of playing,'' says Don Ewell, who admires the classic jazz piano styles of James P. Johnson, Fats Waller, Joe Sullivan, Teddy Wilson, Earl Hines and Jelly Roll Morton. ''I'm not a reactionary, but I don't want to go too far out on a limb. I like the trunk of the tree. Jazz is a people's music and it should have at least a suggestion of melody.''

title: Cure the Blues, 1 to 20, Romps At Hialeah in 3-Year-Old Debut
description: Cure the Blues, making his first start in more than five months, solidified his credentials as a probable Kentucky Derby favorite by galloping home five lengths in front of five rivals in a seven-furlong allowance race at Hialeah today. He was timed in 1:23 over a muddy track.

title: CASEY URGES INTELLIGENCE AGENCIES BE EXEMPT FROM INFORMATION ACT
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, recommended today that intelligence agencies be granted ''total exclusion'' from the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act.

title: Advertising; Magazine Pages Up
description: Things were looking good for the magazine business in August, when it had the best page gain of the year - 7 percent (or 494 pages) up from August 1980, for a total of 7,585. That pushed ad revenues up 20 percent, to $210.9 million. These estimates by the Publishers Information Bureau of its member publications was issued by the Magazine Publishers Association, which was glad to do it.

title: CANADA INVESTMENT DECISION
description: In the face of mounting American criticism of Canadian policies limiting investment by foreigners here, the Government was reported today to have postponed plans to strengthen a much-criticized agency that passes on foreign investment applications.

title: No Headline
description: A news analysis yesterday on the examination of Roman Catholic seminaries in the United States incorrectly identified the president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops. He is Archbishop John R. Roach.

title: People; Trying to Keep Mrs. Onassis' Secret
description: The way Elizabeth Meyer and Twanette Tharp tell it, when their design company got an assignment to help build a new house for Jacqueline Onassis on Martha's Vineyard, Mrs. Onassis insisted on a contract clause forbidding any mention of the project in The Washington Post.

title: Boycott Still Rankles
description: Lord Killanin, former president of the International Olympic Committee, assailed former President Jimmy Carter in a speech at the Olympic Congress in Baden-Baden, West Germany. ''Little did we realize,'' said Lord Killanin, still angered over the boycott of the 1980 Summer Games by the United States, ''that the Olympic movement and Olympic competitors were to be sacrificed by the ill-advised, unprepared action of the President of the United States of America, who endeavored to sabotage the Olympic Games in Moscow - the Olympic Games, the property of us all here and not that of the Soviet Union. I am glad to say this failed.''

title: Philippines Loan
description: A $100 million syndicated loan raised by the Bankers Trust Company for the central bank of the Philippines will be signed next month in Hong Kong, a central bank official said today. The money, to be lent by 17 foreign banks, is for Government development projects, the official said. The loan is for 10 years, with a grace period of four years and an interest rate of 0.75 percent over the London interbank offered rate.

title: OFFICIALS SAY GREEN BERETS LACKED AUTHORITY FOR OPERATION IN LIBYA
description: Senior officers of the Army Special Forces permitted one of their staff sergeants to recruit a group of former members of the elite commando troops to train terrorists in Libya four years ago, even though they did not know whether the operation had Government approval, according to several Army officials.

title: THE ROCKY TRAIL OF A RODEO COWBOY
description: As a boy growing up in Okmulgee, Okla., in the late 1950's and early '60s, Clarence LeBlanc loved traveling with his father to weekend rodeos. Most of those they attended were organized by allblack roundup clubs - his father was a member of one of them - and the participants were black cowboys.

title: Auctions; Museum sale off ers oddities.
description: SEVERAL disappointments and surprises marked the end yesterday of the four-day auction of the contents of the World Museum in Tulsa, Okla. Collectors and dealers from many parts of the United States and from Japan, West Germany, Britain, the Netherlands and Puerto Rico were on hand or on the telephone, vying for the thousands of art works, automobiles and oddities that made up this unconventional sale.

title: THE BANKER WHO TURNS COMIC
description: The other night Al Rosenberg brought Earl C. Watkins, president of the Disco Investment Counseling Company, developer of the coinoperated pacemaker and the portable tollbooth, and creator of the Sigmund Freud School of Mass Marketing onto the stage of The Improvisation to see how he would like it in a nightclub.

title: PREMIER IN POLAND CALLS ON POLICE TO PUT END TO ANTI-SOVIET ACTIVITY
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish Prime Minister, told Parliament today that he had instructed the army and police to crack down on lawlessness and anti-Soviet activity.

title: BRITISH FILM OPENS FESTIVAL AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: IT began one rainy spring day in a little cafe on the Mediterranean. At two tiny square tables in the back sat a woman and four men, busy sipping coffee and kir and speaking in tones that were not meant to be overheard. For two hours they talked and argued and agreed and disagreed. Some took notes, somebody ordered a ham sandwich, many smoked. In the end, amid the muted tensions that inevitably accompany such endeavors, 11 of the 32 movies to be shown at the 19th New York Film Festival, which opens at Lincoln Center tonight, had been chosen.

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 25, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 9:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: STAGE: GARDNER MCKAY'S 'SEA MARKS' AT THE PLAYERS
description: THERE'S nothing wrong with retelling a familiar tale - provided the tale is good and that you tell it with fresh enthusiasm and style. In ''Sea Marks,'' the two-character play that opened last night at the Players, Gardner McKay unveils some very old goods, but he hasn't taken much trouble to spruce them up. The bare bones of his predictable story are visible so early that the evening seems over almost as soon as it begins.

title: FALL AMERICANA FAIR OPENS, NATION'S BIGGEST
description: VIRTUALLY every crammed booth at the third annual Fall Antiques Show has some outsized offering of compelling appeal. If it isn't the size of an object that proves arresting, there is some other unusual quality in the antiques to be viewed at this bazaar - the largest show of Americana in the country - which opened yesterday with 90 dealers at the Passenger Terminal Pi er, 12th Avenue at 54th Street. For some, the unusual quality might be the color-pulsing pattern of aquilt, or the novel shaping of a weathervane, the aristocratic bearing of a kas cupboard or the curious design of a multidrawer table. They'r e all there through Sunday.

title: Officer Accused as Spy Had Top Clearance
description: A former Army warrant officer accused of selling information to the Soviet Union had top security clearance and access to some of the United States' most delicate military secrets, his former supervisor testified today.

title: WAUSAU PAPER MILLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
At the Movies; Neil Simon as producer and promoter.
description: NEIL SIMON, the writer, and his wife, Marsha Mason, the actress, are fresh back from the Toronto Film Festival, where a crowd gave their new picture, ''Only When I Laugh,'' a standing ovation. Afterward, Mr. Simon and Miss Mason went to a press party, talked to some reporters and thoroughly enjoyed themselves.

title: FORECASTS SWING TO RECESSION
description: Business economists meeting here said today that their collective opinion had swung in the last two months to predictions of a recession before the end of 1981.

title: Money Funds' Assets Increase
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds climbed $3.75 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $159.96 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. This was the 17th consecutive weekly increase, the trade group said.

title: WHITE HOUSE RX FOR HIGHER FOOD PRICES
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: TORRES-GARCIA, URUGUAYAN WANDERER
description: PICASSO is said to have warned Horacio Torres-Garcia against leaving Paris for New York because it would be ''like leaping into a void.'' Nevertheless, in 1920, the Uruguayan arti st leaped. But if hefailed to make a living here and experienced the predicted emptiness,it was not for want of attention from the cit y's vanguard artists - some of whom later reflected his influence - and from their patrons.

title: Wytch Farm Bid
description: The London and Scottish Marine Oil Company Ltd. and five other independent oil companies said today that they had formed a consortium to evaluate and bid for the 50 percent stake in the Wytch Farm oil and gas field held by the state-owned British Gas Corporation.

title: COMPANY TO APPEAL
description: The Federal Trade Commission ordered today that Anacin advertisements cease contending that the product ''contains the pain reliever most recommended by doctors'' unless it also discloses that the pain reliever is aspirin.

title: Free Tests Demanded I n Agent Orange Case
description: An organization representing Vietnam veterans dema nded today that the Government offer free medical examinations to former servicemen who might have been exposed to Agent Orange in Vietnam when their own planes dumped the spray near United States bases.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: We are going through a period of difficult and painful readjustment.

title: Parents Backing Coach Suspended in Beating
description: A high school football coach in this Denver suburb who was suspended by the school district after having been accused of participating in the beating of one of his players is receiving growing support from parents. In addition, several senior members of the team have visited the coach's home to offer support.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1981; The Economy
description: President Reagan asked $3 billion in increased taxes for the fiscal year 1982 as well as $13 billion in spending cuts in an effort to save his budget goals despite lagging support in Congress. Mr. Reagan, in a nationwide television address, also revised upward his budget deficit target to $43.1 billion. The additional revenue, which the President said would be garnered by eliminating ''abuses and obsolete incentives'' in the tax law, would mostly be paid by business. (Page A1.)

title: People; This Lord Nelson Is at Home on Land
description: Britain's new Lord Nelson is not, like his famous forebear, a naval officer, but a policeman, and he has no intention of claiming his seat in the House of Lords.

title: A RETURN TO SALT
description: Secretary of State Haig and Foreign Minister Gromyko, meeting in New York, have taken the first step toward the resumption of strategic arms limitation talks (SALT). That's the ultimate meaning of their agreement to get on with negotiations to limit so-called theater nuclear forces (T.N.F.) in Europe.

title: Chase Cuts Broker Rate
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it had lowered its broker loan rate to 16 1/2 percent from 17 percent, effective immediately.
