On Wednesday, the Continental Illinois National Bank in Chicago cut its broker rate one percentage point, to 16 percent. Broker loan rates at major banks now range between 16 percent and 17 1/4 percent.

title: NEW SCENE STEALER: THE VIDEO CAMERA
description: The Executive Photo and Supply Corporation, a New York camera equipment retailer, used to order home movie cameras by the gross. ''When people came in, they had their mind made up,'' said Isaac Wolhendler, the store's vice president and sales manager. ''They wanted a certain brand of movie camera with certain features.''

title: Net Up Sharply At General Tire
description: The General Tire and Rubber Company said today that it earned $72.5 million, or $3 a share, in the third quarter of 1981, more than triple the $14.6 million, or 60 cents, it earned in the comparable period in 1980.

title: MAIN STREET IS WORRIED, TOO
description: In his speech in Denver last week, President Reagan ventured that if Wall Street would pay closer attention to Main Street, it would discover a ''rising tide of confidence'' about the future of America and its economy.

title: OLYMPIC GLORY IN 'CHARIOTS OF FIRE'
description: LOSING a dearly fought athletic contest may very well build character. But winning the contest can build self-confidence as well as character - there's no need to settle for less. This is one of the points made in ''Chariots of Fire,'' the unashamedly rousing, invigorating but very clear-eyed evocat ion of values of the oldfashioned sort that are today more easily satirized than celebrated.

title: SANDGATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After gains on disposal of segments of $31,400 in qr and $664,700 for the yr...C-After loss on disposition of segments of $27,000...D-After gain of $94,000

title: CUBS BEAT METS ON HOMERS, 10-9
description: The Mets and the Chicago Cubs, neither of whom had figured to have a chance for a division title this late in the season, struggled grimly to survive in the National League East race today at Wrigley Field. They played more than three hours, used nine pitchers, hit si x home runs and made 17 other hits before the Cubs won, 10-9.

title: GRUMMAN STUDIES BID
description: The Grumman Corporation, signaling that it will fight a $450 million takeover bid by the LTV Corporation of Dallas, disclosed yesterday that it was calling a board meeting to discuss the antitrust considerations of the proposed merger as well as LTV's labor relations.

title: East Side Walking Tour
description: Homes, churches and other historic structures on the Upper East Side will be visited on a walking tour Sunday sponsored by the Museum of the City of New York.

title: EDUCATOR FOUNDED ROOSEVELT UNIVERSITY
description: Dr. Edward J. Sparling, who founded Roosevelt University in Chicago as an institution to provide an opportunity for ''the culturally deprived,'' died Wednesday in Pleasanton, Calif., where he had been living in retirement. He was 84 years old.

title: STEVCOKNIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $481,000 in qr and $731,000 for the 6 mos

title: WITTER, DEAN, REYNOLDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
BONN IS NOW HELD UNLIKELY TO SELL ARMS TO SAUDI ARABIA
description: BONN. Sept. 24 - The West German Government has effectively dropped consideration of a Saudi Arabian order for advanced weapon systems, including the Leopard 2 tank, an authoritative source said today.

title: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in the method of accounting for compensated absences, adopted in the current fiscal yr

title: STSC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The 1981 figures restated to reflect accounting change to account for compensated absences

title: YANKEES LOSE TO ORIOLES
description: Peace but not tranquillity returned to Yankee Stadium last night. Unlike the night before, when Reggie Jackson and John Denny started a bench-clearing brawl, the Yankees and Baltimore played a rather routine baseball game that the Orioles won, 5-1. Ron Guidry, the Yankee starter, suffered two bruised toes on his left foot and had to leave the game after two innings.

title: Filly Wins Pacing Classic
description: Fan Hanover, testing colts for the first time in her career, became the first filly to win the Little Brown Jug, coming from behind twice today in the accident-marred final leg of 3-year-old pacing's Triple Crown before a record crowd of 45,907 watched the race at the Delaware County Fairgrounds.

title: ATTACK ON POPE A CONSPIRACY, COURT SAYS
description: An Italian court said today that the attempt on the life of Pope John Paul II was part of a conspiracy and not the work of a single person.

title: LABOR'S MESSAGE TO THE PRESIDENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Caribbean at Music Hall
description: The sights and sounds of the Caribbean will fill the stage at Radio City Music Hall during a three-day festival this weekend.

title: SOLIDARITY, THE POLISH UNION, IS OPEN FOR BUSINESS IN U.S.
description: An office was formally opened in New York yesterday to bring news of Poland's Solidarity trade union movement to the United States. At a crowded opening news conference, the org anization's president, Zy gmunt Przetakiewicz, said it would be ''wholly independent a nd self-governing'' instead of a direct representative of Solidarity , as he had announced earlier.

title: MOSCOW AND THE 'UNITING FOR PEACE' RESOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 Stabbed at Georgia Prison
description: Five white inmates and two guards were stabbed today when a group of black inmates scaled a fence used to segregate the groups at Georgia State Prison, the authorities said. Three inmates were hospitalized in serious condition and the other victims were treated for superficial wounds, according to Sara Englade, a spokesman for the Georgia Department of Offender Rehabilitation.

title: Sports of The Times; An American Soccer Ace
description: JEFF DURGAN heard a rumor this year. That he was born in Scotland. That he moved to Tacoma, Wash., when he was 13 years old. ''It was ridiculous,'' he says, ''because everybody knows I was born in Tacoma. What they were saying was that good soccer players don't come from this side. But it's happening more and more. I'm ahead of time.''

title: Briefing
description: S ENATOR Edward M. Kennedy and former Vice President Walter F. Mondale, members of the Democratic Party's battle-worn corps of once and future hopes, are planning to get together privately at a meeting that some of their aides view as the dawn of 1984. The two politicians had some harsh run-ins last year as Senator Kennedy roiled the party and challenged President Carter and his running mate, Mr. Mondale. The Vice President at one point questioned the Senator's patriotism.

title: Advertising; A Harder Sell for Fragrance
description: THE ad for Arpege Parfum that will begin running in the October issues of some fashion magazines is bound to attract attention with its subtle message of desire fulfilled. It shows th e same young woman in her pink satin gown seated on the same chaise l ongue in the same softly lighted Art Deco room on both pages of this two-page spread. There are only a few changes from one photo to the other - a jacket and earrings removed, empty champagne glasses, a ph one off the hook. A slight smile. The two captions: ''The Promise Made'' and ''The Promise Kept.''

title: ALBUS, ON 64-206, WINS MET PRO GOLF BY 5
description: Helped by a 29 under windy conditions on the back nine, Jim Albus of the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, L.I., shot a six-under-par 64 today over the Fresh Meadow Country Club course and won the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship by five strokes.

title: A BRITISH PARADOX
description: To the Editor:

title: Shad Assails Insider Abuse
description: John S.R. Shad, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, urged investment bankers yesterday to ''redouble efforts'' against the abuse of insider stock trading.

title: Margiotta Wins Re -election on L.I.
description: Joseph M. Margiotta has been unanimously reelected to a seventh term as chairman of the Nassau County Republican Party.

title: MOLLY POH CHENG TAN WED TO THOMAS PYLE
description: Thomas Hanson Pyle, an analyst with Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in New York, was married yesterday in Singapore to Molly Poh Cheng Tan. The civil ceremony took place at the Registry of Marriages Building and was witnessed by the registrar, Lim Hock Kim.

title: GEORGE SEGAL IN 'CARBON COPY'
description: ''CARBON COPY'' is by no means a sparkling comedy, but neither is it the uneasy melange of racial stereotypes that it might have been. George Segal plays a wealthy white Californian who unexpectedly learns that he has a 17-year-old black son, a discovery that might well have been the occasion for apoplexy, double takes and a very broad and dopey brand of comedy. Either that, or a prelude to mutual understanding and saccharine sentiments all around.

title: Scott Italian Mill
description: Scott Paper International Inc. said its Italian affiliate would build a new paper mill at Alanno on the east coast of central Italy.

title: LIVELY LICHTENSTEIN OF 70'S AT WHITNEY
description: THE American artist Roy Lichtenstein earned immense international renown in the early days of the Pop Art movement, in the 1960's, as the painter who specialized in turning comic-strip cartoons into paintings. But time passes, perspectives alter and artists develop in unforeseen ways. In the 1970's, Mr. Lichtenstein set about the task of turning images of paintings -some very famous paintings by Picasso, Matisse, Leger and sundry other eminences of the modern movement -into cartoons. They, too, have quickly won a place among the classics of contemporary art, and a large exhibition devoted to this work of the 70's has now come to the Whitney Museum of American Art, Madison Avenue at 75th Street (through Nov. 29).

title: TIMETABLE IS SET FOR NAMIBIA PACT
description: The United States and four other Western nations said today that after consultations with South Africa and black African nations they had developed a timetable for ''final negotiations'' on the independence of South-West Africa.

title: U.S. Plans to Send Helicopters to Colombia
description: The United States plans to send 12 UH-1H helicopters to Colombia to help the Bogota Government's armed forces fight left-wing insurgents, United States officials said today. The deal is subject to Congressional approval.

title: GUSTAV ECKSTEIN, PSYCHOLOGIST
description: Gustav Eckstein, a medical doctor, scientist, writer, teacher and philosopher, died Wednesday at the Holmes Division of the University of Cincinnati Hospital. He was 91 years old and had lived in the Vernon Manor Hotel near the university for 40 years.

title: POP-FUSION: GEORGE BENSON
description: IN the five years since his commercial breakthrough as a singer doing Leon Russell's ''This Masquerade,'' the guitarist George Benson has developed into one of the most accomplished pop-soul crooners in America. And on Wednesday at Carnegie Hall, where he appeared with a nine-piece band and a full orchestra, the singer took precedence over the jazz guitarist.

title: SHORT-RANGE PENSION BILL IS BACKED
description: The Senate Finance Committee today unanimously approved a Social Security bill designed to keep the retirement system solvent for the next five years, but a longer-range rescue mission appeared increasingly unlikely to win early Congressional approval.

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Results reflect foreign currency translation losses of 34 cents a shr and 81 cents a shr for the latest qr and 9 mos respectively, foreign currency translation gains of 16 cents and 11 cents a shr for the previous qr and 9 mos respectively, and an 8 cents a shr British tax credit for the latest qr

title: SYKES DATATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The shr earnings reflect the 2-for-1 and 3-for-1 stock distributions made Nov 14, 1980 and June 19, 1981

title: U.N. WIDENS INQUIRY ON CHEMICAL ARMS
description: A United Nations panel of experts has decided it must visit four Asian countries to determine the accuracy of American charges that the Soviet Union and its allies are using chemical weapons, officials here said today.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKS 3-YEAR INCREASE IN TAX REVENUE
description: The White House disclosed tonight that an important element in President Reagan's plan to balance the Federal budget by 1984 was to legislate additional tax revenues totaling $22 billion over the next three years.

title: Park West Street Fair
description: An array of entertainment, foods, crafts an d flea market items willbe found tomorrow at the second ''Celebrate A utumn'' street fair, found along Central Park West, from 101st to 106th Streets.

title: First Words With Moscow
description: The most important thing about Secretary of State Haig's meeting with Andrei Gromyko is that it finally occurred. After multiple new starts with Americans over 40 years, it must have seemed like a tedious revival for the accomplished actor from Moscow. But for Mr. Haig it was a nervous premiere, requiring even a dress rehearsal with a stand-in for the Soviet minister. The Reagan Administration should never have made such a drama of merely meeting. Eight months into a Presidency is too late for an exchange of truisms about better relations.

title: PETER MACNICOL CAPTURES KEY ROLE IN 'SOPHIE'S CHOICE'
description: Peter MacNicol, who opens on Broadway in November in the Pulitzer Prize-winning play ''Crimes of the Heart,'' has been awarded one of the most sought-after movie roles of the year.

title: Italy Holds 2 as Subversives
description: Two law yers were arre sted today on charges of belonging to an armed group and engaging i n subversive activities.The lawyers, Giorgio Arcangeli and Paolo Vita le, were jailed on warrants issued by an antiterrorism prosecuto r, Roberto Napolitano.

title: LOS ANGELES CORONER ENDS INQUIRY IN 29 DEATHS AFTER 3 EXHUMATIONS
description: The Los Angeles County Coroner has dropped an investigation into the deaths of 29 aged hospital patients after tests on three exhumed bodies showed no evidence of a drug overdose.

title: A U.S. AWACS ROLE PRESSED ON SAUDIS
description: A Saudi prince, the White House national security adviser and a key Democratic Senator today discussed proposals that would permit the United States to share a measure of control over the five Awacs surveillance planes that the Reagan Administraton wants to sell to Saudi Arabia, according to Senate and Administration sources.

title: STOCKS DROP TO YEAR'S LOW
description: Stock prices declined moderately yesterday, setting a new low for the year, as many investors adopted a wait-and-see attitude before President Reagan's television speech scheduled for last night. Investors expected him to announce further spending cuts in an effort to hold down the size of the Federal budget deficit.

title: U.S. A ND SOVIET SET NEW GENEVA TALKS ON MISSILE ACCORD
description: The United States and the Soviet Union pledged today ''to spare no effort'' to reach an agreement on reducing medi@um-range nuclear forces in Europe in negotiations that will begin on Nov. 30 in Geneva.

title: AUDIT QUESTIONS SANITATION DEPT. ON PRODUCTIVITY
description: Some of the productivity gains that the Koch administration claimed last fall for New York City's Sanitation Department were ''illusory,'' according to an audit released yesterday by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan.

title: WHITE HOUSE REDONE
description: Nancy Reagan has finished redecorating the White House, keeping to her donated budget of $822,641, and the result might inspire a color-TV commercial - the living room is yellow, with lemon yellow furnishings and a pale yellow rug.

title: Long-Term Bond Prices Off; Short-Term Rates Stable
description: Long-term bond prices declined yesterday amid concern that the President's proposals to shrink the budget deficit will not do much to lessen the Treasury's borrowing needs.

title: Market Place; European Stock Outlook
description: FOR years, institutional investors have found the Japanese equity market to be the most attractive one abroad. But if portfolio changes at a Boston-based international fund are indicative, European markets may be drawi ng off some money now com mitted in Japan.

title: A World to Feed Eighth article of a series appear-; ing periodically.
description: A blunt, gray vessel docked here the other day, its decks crammed with empty pens. Soon, trucks began to arrive through the heat haze from the parched uplands of the Horn of Africa, laden with sheep and goats. The animals were loaded into the pens, and the vessel sailed for Saudi Arabia, where the livestock will be slaughtered and used to feed Islam's faithful on their annual pilgrimage to Mecca, known as the Hajj.

title: West Berlin Will Study Problem of Squatters
description: West Berlin's Senate said today that it would begin an inquiry into the city's squatter problem.

title: THE VISITORS
description: Officials i n Washington, from the President down, receive a constant stre am of foreign and domestic visitors. Often who they see reveals a lot about the real business of Government. This is a sampleof who has be en talking to whom recently, and why.

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt PSYCHOANALYSIS: The Impossible Pro- fession. By Janet Malcolm. 174 pages. Knopf. $9.95.

title: 60,000 Hondurans; Protest 'Repression'
description: As many as 60,000 Hondurans held a demonstration here last night to protest ''repression'' by security forces. Security was tight and no incidents were reported.

title: 3 Feared Dead in Himalayas
description: Three members of a Japanese mountaineering expedition were believed dead after an avalanche in the Himalayas, an Indian official said today. The official told Indian reporters in Lucknow, capital of Uttar Pradesh Province, that the incident occurred on Jolly Peak. He did not say when it happened.

title: I.B.M. Makes A Denser Chip
description: The International Business Machines Corporation announced in Boston yesterday that it had produced a computer memory chip that can store 288,000 bits of information, four times the capacity of the industry's standard unit, but that it had no plans now to include it in its manufacturing program.

title: The Me xican Way
description: Even sensitive Government officials say it has become almost impossible to live in their capital. When I last lived here, 27 years ago, the population was a bit over two milli on. Now it is something between 15 and 16 million , in the same mountainringed valley.

title: Net Outflow At Thrift Units
description: Savers withdrew $3.3 billion more than they put into the nation's savings and loan associations in August, marking a record sixth consecutive monthly loss for the beleaguered thrift units, the Government reported today.

title: SENATE ASKS WIDER TAX BREAK FOR MEMBERS' HOMES
description: The Senate voted today to give members of Congress unlimited tax deductions to cover their need to maintain two residences, one in the capital and the other back home.

title: GIANTS, JETS FACE FORMIDABLE TEXAS FOES
description: The Giants will be taking on a Cowboy team at full strength in Dallas Sunday, with Tony Dorsett, the league's leading ground gainer, ready after suffering minor injuries Monday night. Like the Giants, the troubled Jets will be underdogs when they meet the Houston Oilers at Shea Stadium. Both games will be televised in the metropolitan area, the Jets on Channel 4 at 1 P.M. and the Giants on Channel 2 at 4.

title: TV Weekend; JOURNALISM, IN REALITY AND FICTION
description: RETURNING on Sunday at 7 o'clock to what will probably be still another season of smashing top-10 ratings, CBS News' ''60 Minutes'' turns the tables on itself and opens with a panel discussion, ''Looking at '60 Minutes.' ''

title: Broadway; An early contender for 1982-83: 'It's a Wonderful Life.'
description: THE new Broadway season is barely out of the starting gate, but it's not a minute too early to start thinking about contenders for next season. That is what Sheldon Harnick and Joseph Raposo are doing. They are working on a musical adaptati on of ''It's a WonderfulLife,'' Frank Capra's 1946 film that starred James Stewart as an amiable chap who is foiled in his attempt to break out of his smalltown life. Mr. Harnick is writing the bo ok and lyrics, and Mr. Raposo, the music. The producers are Mary Jo Slater and Eugene Wolsk.

title: Record Output Of Color TV's
description: Production of color television sets in the United States rose to a record in the first six months of 1981, but imports of color sets also increased, the Commerce Department said today.

title: People; A DIFFERENT APPROACH
description: As a leading contemporary composer, Hans Werner Henze has seldom been accused of boring the music-loving public. For example, when the New York City Opera performed his ''The Young Lord'' a decade ago, the audience was shocked to discover that a pivotal figure was a gorilla.

title: Index
description: INTERNATIONAL Somalis, enfeebled by hunger, still export food A2 Attack on Pope a conspiracy, court says A3 20 Iranians hurt in clashes with policemen in Saudi Arabia A3 Foreign aid legislation is stalled in the House A4 U.N. panel plans Asian visit on charges of chemical warfare A5 Around the World A9 Solidarity opens New York office A10 Timetable set for "final negotiations" on Namibia A13 GOVERNMENT/POLITICS A Democratic Party hearing considered 1984 campaign rules A14 House approves a "no-frills" highway program A17 Article about Johnson criticized for lacking documentation A18 Reagan planning to end A-10 production in 1983 A23 Senate urged to exclude C.I.A. from Information Act A24 Goldin criticizes bus companies owned by Dearie backer B3 Kean closes two-week tour of Jersey cities B3 Koch testifies at misconduct hearing of Justice Leff B3 Decision delayed on rated for malpractice insurance B4 WASHINGTON TALK Briefing A22 Edwin Meese 3d answers his critics A22 The visitors A22 Required reading A22 GENERAL Around the Nation A14 Convict-author stayed a step ahead of the law until arrest B1 FEATURES/NOTE S Notes on Peop le A27 Sports People D18 WEEKEND Weekender Guide C1 "Earl C. title: STRIKE BENEFITS FOR THE POLISH ECONOMY
description: To the Editor:

title: 12 PIANISTS COMPETING AT CARNEGIE FOR ONE OF MUSIC'S RICHEST AWARDS
description: Twelve pianists are competing for one of the richest awards on the musical scene - the fourth International American Music Competitions, worth $75,000 to the winner. This competition is jointly sponsored by the Rockefeller Foundation and Carnegie Hall.

title: Auto Layoffs Rise Sharply
description: The number of layoffs in the United States auto industry rose sharply this week, despite a 7.4 percent increase in domestic car production, according to industry reports released today.

title: 'Hot' Water Treated At Three Mile Island
description: Plant engineers have begun treating 600,000 gallons of highly radioactive water spilled at the Three Mile Island power plant 2 1/2 years ago in the nation's worst commerical nuclear accident.

title: Repaying the Hostage Debt
description: How much should the United States Government pay the Americans held as hostages in Iran to compensate them for their ordeal? A Presidential commission says $12.50 a day, and it is taking a lot of abuse.

title: AUTONOMY TALKS IN CAIRO ASK PALESTINIAN AID
description: Israel, Egypt and the United States pledged today to seek Palestinian cooperation in their efforts to work out a plan for autonomy for the 1.3 million Palestinian Arabs living in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and in the Gaza Strip.

title: EXPOS WIN, LEAD CARDS BY 1 1/2
description: Gary Carter drove in three runs, and Warren Cromartie had four hits, including a home run, to lead the Expos to a 7-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates last night in Montreal. It was the Expos' fifth straight victory and kept them in first place in the National League East. Montreal opened a 1 1/2-game lead over second-place St. Louis, which lost to Philadelphia. The Card s lost for the sixth time in seven games,

title: NO. 1 MAN ON REAGAN'S STAFF ANSWERS HIS CRITICS
description: Mention Ed Meese's briefcase to White House aides, and you are almost certain to get a laugh. The insiders' joke is that the briefcase is a ''bottomless pit'' into which schedules, programs or political careers can disappear without a trace.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Baker Drilling Equipment Company, Orange, Calif., has elected to its board Robert L. Parker Jr., president and chief operating officer of the Parker Drilling Company, and Richard H. Vaughan, executive vice president of worldwide exploration for the Occidental Petroleum Corporation.

title: 'TRUE CONFESSIONS' WITH DE NIRO AND DUVALL
description: NO need to pussyfoot. No need to mince words. Get straight to the point, even if it's not pretty or, for that matter, even if it is. Sometimes things do go right. It does happen. You know it first in the pit of your stomach. A nice feeling but unfamiliar - it's the bile vanishing as things look up. Like watching ''True Confes sions.''

title: BORG TO TAKE 5-MONTH LAYOFF
description: Bjorn Borg will take a five-month break from professional tennis, a layoff that will keep him from defending his Volvo Grand Prix Masters title at Madison Square Garden in January.

title: MEN GET INTO THE SWING OF AEROBICS
description: At the age of 69 Ted Tappen has become an addict. Twice a week he clothes his less-than-lithe body in baggy purple shorts, a gray sweat shirt and round-at-the-heel tennis shoes, and jumps around a small gymnasium swimming with his arms, dancing, leaping and jogging eagerly to such obscure shouted commands as ''Stop, kick, explode!'' or ''Hustle Jog!'' or ''Cha cha! Smile!'' or ''Jump into a Sweep!'' or ''Disco Swing!'' all to the accompaniment of music from the likes of Dolly Parton, Neil Diamond and Barry Manilow.

title: Energy Watch
description: CRUDE OIL INVENTORIES Crude oil stocks rose to 376.1 million barrels.

title: Execution Stay Due to End
description: A Federal judge's order that delayed the execution of a convicted murderer, Colin Clark, expires Saturday, permitting the state to carry out Mr. Clark's death wish within 45 days. Mr. Clark, 27 years old, dismissed his attorney last month and asked Judge John Parker to ''get on with'' the execution. Judge Parker complied, denying a motion for a new trial on Aug. 26 and ordering his previously issued stay of execution to expire one month later.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Brooklyn Union Gas Co. is offering 800,000 shares of new preferred stock at $25 each with a dividend of $3.95 and a yield of 15.8 percent, through an underwriting group led by Merrill Lynch.

title: 5TH AVE. MILE, AN INSTANT INSTITUTION
description: They will dash down Fifth Avenue tomorrow, elbowing for position, trying to get downtown first. But this will be no breakneck fight for a taxicab or a bus. Rather, it will be the debut of another instant-New York running institution - the Pepsi Challenge Fifth Avenue Mile.

title: AS BUSING BEGINS IN SCHOOLS, LOUISIANA CLEARS WAY FOR TEACHING IN HOMES
description: In East Baton Rouge Parish, where public schools began court-ordered busing this fall and private schools are booked solid, a small but growing number of parents are teaching their children at home.

title: Warsaw Prelate Issues C all for National Unity
description: Archbishop Jozef Glemp appealed today for a bloodless solution to Poland's crisis and for national unity as he was inducted as Roman Catholic Primate of Poland.

title: PILOTS IN CRASH WERE NOT TOLD ABOUT POSITIONS
description: Neither of the aircraft that collided yesterday morning over the Meadowlands Sports Complex had been told of the other's position, according to a transcript of their radio communications with the control tower.

title: NUCLEAR WEAPONS WON'T STOP BLACKMAIL
description: President Reagan is dealing with the defense budget as though internationally, as well as domestically, what is important is how much we spend, not what we get.

title: Johnny Perkins Is Receiving Good News
description: In his fo ur previous years with the Giants, between hamstring injuries, Johnn y Perkins caught 86 passes. This year, his rebellious hamstring h ealthy for a change, he has caught two passes against the Philadelphi a Eagles, one against the Washington Redskins and eight last Sunday against the New OrleansSaints.

title: Yanks Threaten to Sue on Knockdowns
description: In the aftermath of another knockdown incident involving Reggie Jackson, George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, has called for a change in baseball's beanball rule and says the team will film every Yankee game as evidence in lawsuits he threatens to file against pitchers suspected of throwing at Yankee hitters.

title: MASTER PLAN FOR THE CAPITOL UNVEILED
description: Justices of the United States Supreme Court can relax. Eviction from their marble palace on Capitol Hill is not imminent.

title: MUSIC: RAGAS TO COMPUTERS
description: COMPOSERS such as Dary John Mizelle, lacking the compositional lingua franca that made music at the turn of the 19th century a shared experience, are by necessity multilinguists. His evening of compositions at the Symphony Space Wednesday night skipped lightly from Indian ragas to I Ching to the computer's new world of acrylic sonority and superhuman complexity and finally to the kind of musical mysticism that stretches the duration of a single work over period of years rather than minutes.

title: Business People; Division Chief Quits Associated Dry Goods
description: John C. Seiler, 46, son of the late Lewis P. Seiler, a longtime head of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, has resigned as chairman and chief executive officer of Stewart's, which is Associated's department store division in Louisville, Ky., effective Dec. 31. No one has been named yet to succeed him, but Robert A. McConnell, 40, who joined Stewart's last October as president, continues in that post.

title: GOLDIN CRITICIZES BUS LINES OWNED BY DEARIE SUPPORTER
description: Two days after he defeated Assemblyman John C. Dearie in the Democratic primary, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin issued an audit yesterday strongly criticizing the business practices of private bus companies owned by one of Mr. Dearie's largest campaign contributors.

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Sept 5
'NO FRILLS' HIGHWAY PROGRAM VOTED BY HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives today passed a ''no frills'' highway program that would cut at least $16 billion from the huge Federal road-building effort before it is completed.As a result, some of the remaining new interstate highways will have fewer lanes and roadside amenities, and there will be less maintenance and repair money for existing roads.

title: FEDERAL CREDIT UNIONS GET 12% RATE CEILING
description: The National Credit Union Administration raised the interest rate ceilings on Federal credit union passbook accounts and interestbearing checking accounts yesterday to 12 percent from 7 percent, effective Oct.1.

title: CITY GIVES FINAL APPROVAL TO UPPER EAST SIDE HISTORIC DISTRICT
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday gave final approval to the Upper East Side Historic District, which encompasses 1,044 buildings from 61st Street to 79th Street. Any major changes in the buildings' facades must now be approved by the city.

title: No Headline
description: Topics Directions, New and Old Prohibition

title: GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
WESTERN DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PACIFIC COAST PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The 1980 figures are restated

title: STEWART SANDWICHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: B-Including unusual pretax income of $1,098,220 for the qr and $1,157,539 for the yr

title: BEELINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
News Summary; FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 25, 1981
description: International U.S.-Soviet arms control talks are to begin on Nov. 30 in Geneva. The schedule was arranged in meetings in New York between Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko. The two countries pledged ''to spare no effort'' to reach an agreement to reduce medium-range nuclear forces in Europe. (Page A1, Column 4.) Gunmen seized the Turkish Consulate in Paris, killed a guard and wounded the Vice Consul and four other persons. The four assailants, who said they were members of an Armenian nationalist organization, vowed to kill 60 hostages, including 8 women, unless all Armenian political prisoners were released from Turkish jails. The demands were refused, but, after 15 hours, the gunmen surrendered to the French authorities. (A1:3-5.)

title: Infant Girl Killed In Brooklyn Fire
description: A 3-month-old girl was killed and six firefighters were slightly injured in a two-alarm blaze in a Brooklyn apartment building, authorities said.

title: REAGAN VOWS 'FIRM COURSE': $3 BILLION INCREASE IN TAXES AND $13 BILLION BUDGET CUT
description: President Reagan, trying to save his budget-balancing goals despite weakening Congressional support, tonight proposed $13 billion in additional spending cuts and $3 billion in increased taxes for the fiscal year 1982.

title: Restaurants; Theater landmark, informal Asian.
description: ALTHOUGH it is never pleasant to have to reduce the rating of a restaurant, it is especially disturbing to have to do so with Gallagher's for three reasons. This restaurant was very good four years ago and well deserving of two stars. Now, however, a fair rating is the most it earns, the result of a decline in service and food that must be attributable to inept management.

title: Sports People; Marketing Murphy
description: Gavin Maloof, the owner of the Houston Rockets, has told Calvin Murphy, the free-agent guard, to pursue offers from other clubs under the right of first refusal so that the Rockets can gain some indication of Murphy's worth.

title: Nissan Price Rise
description: Nissan U.S.A., distributor of Datsun and Nissan vehicles in the United States, said it would raise prices on 1982 Datsun cars and trucks by an average of 4.6 percent from 1981 prices. The increase amounts to an average of $378 a car, Nissan said. The lowest-priced Datsun, the 210, will carry a base price of $4,799 for 1982 and the standard Datsun truck will cost a minimum of $6,149, the company said.

title: LEGISLATORS AGREE PRESIDENT FACES THOUGH BATTLE IN CONGRESS ON CUTS
description: Both Republican and Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill agreed tonight that President Reagan faced serious problems in gaining Congressional approval of his new round of budget cuts.

title: Koch Gives Warning On U.S. Budget Cuts
description: Mayor Koch warned last night that any new Federal budget cuts would have ''a gross adverse impact on this city and every other city.'' The Mayor told 200 people in the auditorium of Richmond Hill High School in Queens attending his first town meeting since the primary that the new initiative in Washington would force heavy spending cuts in the first half of next year.

title: Economic Scene; SIZE OF DEFICIT PREDOMINATES
description: THE agonizing problem President Reagan faced in preparing his television address last night was how to retreat and go forward at the same time.

title: Mobil Oil Weighs Canada Unit Sales
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation said it was considering the sale of its two recently acquired Canadian subsidiaries, Mobil-GC-Canada Ltd. and Mobil-TO-Canada Inc.

title: REPORT IS
description: EXCERPTED

title: MODEL OF FUTILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: 'SOUTHERN COMFORT'
description: WALTER HILL is a director who seems able to make only two kinds of films -quite good ones like the lean, spare ''Hard Times'' and the elegiacal ''The Long Riders,'' and films of an unbearably arty awfulness, like ''The Driver,'' ''The Warriors'' and now ''Southern Comfort,'' which opens today at the Gotham Cinema and other theaters.

title: Jury Acquits Whisenant On Charges of Fraud
description: A jury in State District Court today acquitted John Whisenant, former assistant basketball coach at the University of New Mexico, of charges of fraud and filing false travel vouchers.

title: Great Lakes Fish Warning
description: The State Department of Public Health has warned the public not to eat Great Lakes trout or salmon except as skinless filets because of possibly high levels of toxic PCB's, or polychlorinated biphenyls. Excess fat should be removed from the fish before cooking to guard against both PCB and the pesticide DDT, the department said yesterday.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: The National Parks Service estimate of the number of marchers in Washington on Solidarity Day was reasonably based on the amount of garbage the demonstrators left behind. The Parks Service had no way of knowing that the N.A.A.C.P. marchers, under formal instructions from branch chairmen, took all their garbage home. If we bring it back and dump it on the Mall, can we hope to correct this important figure for history? JUNE MELLIES RENO Nyack, N.Y., Sept. 20, 1981

title: ART: WHAT IT WAS LIKE TO BE KAFKA IN PRAGUE
description: ''KAFKA-PRAGUE,'' at the Jewish Museum, is not ''an art exhibition.'' Nor is it primarily a photographic exhibition, though Jan Parik's black-and-white photographs are of exceptional quality. It is a biographical exhibition in which photographs, first editions, corrected proofs and other memorabilia tell us what it was like to be Franz Kafka in Prague. We see where he grew up, where he went to school, where he took a law degree, where he made a living and - perhaps most important of all - where he learned what it meant to be Jewish in the ancient capital of Bohemia.

title: Japan Vehicle Output Off
description: Japanese vehicle production fell sharply last month from July, mainly because of a decline in exports, the Japanese Automobile Manufacturers Association said today. August prod uction of 689,200 vehicles was down 33.5 percent from July, when mo nthly production was the second largest on record, and just over 3 p ercent less than a year earlier, the association said.

title: Suspects Seized In Air Ticket Theft
description: A dozen persons were arrested as the police smashed a ring that stole millions of dollars worth of airline tickets and began selling them at discount prices, authorities said.

title: STATEMENT ON TALKS
description: Following is the text of the joint announcement today by the United States and the Soviet Union on the start of negotiations on controlling medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe:

title: Dean Witter Net Up 10.4%
description: The Dean Witter Reynolds Organization reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter, ended Aug. 31, rose 10.4 percent to $10.6 million, or 96 cents a share, from $9.6 million, or 95 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: TEXAS OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for 2-for-1 stock splits in Jan 1980 and Jan 1981 and for a 10 percent stock divd distribution in Oct 1980

title: Transit Report
description: About 2,000 commuters using the North Jersey Coast Line train service to New York and Newark were delayed for up to an hour after a tugboat rammed a drawbridge over the Raritan River, locking the span in an upright position. The bridge, which connects South Amboy and Perth Amboy, was struck at about 3 A.M. and was repaired by 7:55 A.M.

title: Sports People; Surgery for Fred Lynn
description: Fred Lynn, the outfielder for the California Angels, underwent minor surgery on his left knee and will probably miss the rest of the season. Lynn was injured May 8 while breaki ng up a double play and has played only sporadically since. ... The P ittsburgh Pirates, who are trying to negotiate a new agreement with Bill Madlock, have offered him a contract including a clause tha t would penalize him if he gains weight.

title: SUTHERLAND IN 'DISAPPEARANCE'
description: DONALD SUTHERLAND plays a nattily dressed hit man in ''The Disappearance,'' an unrelievedly solemn Canadian film given over to long pauses, contemplative strolls and mournful glimpses of the Montreal skyline. Mr. Sutherland's Jay Mallory is weary. As he explain s it to his glamorous wife, Celandine, while he makes a brief at-home visit between assassination jobs, he feels like a snake readyto shed his skin.

title: News Analysis
description: For weeks, President Reagan's advisers have been saying that tonight's economic message would display his Administration's resolve to balance the Federal budget by 1984.

title: Three-Day Beatlefest
description: Just about everything you wanted to see and hear about the Beatles, including the films they appeared in and the memorabilia they inspired, will be found at Beatlefest '81 this weekend in the New York Statler, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street. The three-day event will feature showings of 50 feature and promotion films, live music by Beatles sound-alike bands and panel discussions with rock journalists and authors of books about the Beatles. Today's activities take place from 5 P.M. to midnight, tomorrow's from noon to midnight and Sunday's from noon to 11 P.M. Admission is $8.50 today and $12 tomorrow or Sunday. Information : PE 6-5000.

title: OPERA: MET'S 'TRAVIATA'
description: VERDI'S ''La Tr aviata,'' in the Metropolitan Opera production introduced la st season, returned to the repertory on Wednesday night with a cast h eaded by Catherine Malfitano as Violetta, Giuliano Ciannella as Alfredo and Cornell MacNeil as the elder Germont.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS ON PROPOSED SPENDING CUTS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's address to the nation last night in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times: Good evening. Shortly after taking office, I came before you to map out a four-part plan for national economic recovery:

title: 32 Families Left Homeless
description: An apartment building fire left 32 families homeless yesterday and forced L.L. Bean Inc. - noted for being open 24 hours a day, 365 days a year - to close for the first time since 1967. The concern, which specializes in outdoors gear, is across the street from the site of the fire.

title: SUN TO SELL A REFINERY TO KOCH
description: The Sun Company, a major domestic oil company based in Radnor, Pa., said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to sell its Corpus Christi, Tex., oil refinery to Koch Industries, a privately held integrated oil company, for $265 million in cash.

title: PUBLISHING: THE SWEDISH HERO WHO DISAPPEARED
description: THE House of Representatives voted on Tuesd ay to make Raoul Wallenberg an honorary American citizen, a di stinction that the former Swedish diplomat will share with only Sir Winston Churchill. On Monday, Viking Press published ''Righteous Gentile: The Story of Raoul Wallenberg,'' by John Bierman.

title: END OF A-10 PLANE PRODUCTION IN '83 PLANNED
description: A Pentagon list of proposed reductions in military spending shows that the Reagan Administration plans to cut drastically the production of A-10 attack planes, made by Fairchild Industries on Long Island, over the next two years and to end production in 1983.

title: London Stocks Plunge
description: The value of stocks traded on the London Stock Exchange fell almost $4 billion today, as the market plunged deeper into a slide being attributed to a ''sell'' signal by Joseph Granville, a Wall Street analyst.

title: SELECTIVE PROTECTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLDEN NUGGET CASINO AND CHAIRMAN CLEAR JERSEY LICENSING HURDLE
description: Deputy Attorney General James F. Flanagan told the Casino Control Commission here today that the Division of Gaming Enforcement did not object to the licensing of the Golden Nugget and its chairman, Stephen A. Wynn, to operate a casino in Atlantic City.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; HUDSON GUILD BOOK FAIR
description: The Hudson Guild, which has been offering services to Chelsea residents for 86 years, collects thousands of books from contributors during the year, then offers them for sale - new, used and rare, hard cover and paperback - along with prints and records, many at bargain prices. The eighth annual book fair is on through the weekend at the guild's quarters, 441 West 26th Street. Admission is free, and on Sunday the price of all books will be cut in half. Information: 760-9800 PHOTO-AUCTION PREVIEW

title: Business People; Management Realigned At Towers, Perrin Firm
description: Towers, Perrin, Forster & Crosby, which was founded as an employee-benefits consulting firm but has since expanded into human resources, insurance and general management consulting, has a new top management lineup. James B. Kielley, 50, has been elected president, succeeding Quentin I. Smith Jr., 53, who was named to the vacant post of chairman while continuing as chief executive officer.

title: RYAN O'NEAL STARS IN 'SO FINE,' A COMEDY
description: ANDREW BERGMAN, who wrote the witty and inventive screenplay for ''The In Laws,'' makes his directorial debut with ''So Fine,'' another movie about a naive hero who runs afoul of gangster types and finds himself in a farfetched but highly amusing predicament. In this case, the story is that of Bobby Fine (Ryan O'Neal), a fussy, sheltered English professor at a college where the motto is ''Learn So Ye May Know.'' He is kidnapped and taken to New York to help out his father's garment business, where the employees surreptitiously use the dresses for napkins and the dresses come in colors like ''ecru, lemon and gingersnap.'' Business is awful.

title: 60 HELD 15 HOURS IN A SIEGE IN PARIS
description: Four armed Armenian nationalists seized the Turkish Consulate here yesterday and threatened to kill 60 people they took as hostages. But the gunmen, whose number was reduced to three after one was wounded in the takeover, surrendered early today.

title: Chrysler and Mi tsubishi Accord
description: The Chrysler Corporation and its Japanese partner, the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, said they had reached final agreement on a plan that would allow Mitsubishi to market its own cars and trucks in the United States.

title: Plea Lost in Sal Mineo Case
description: The California Supreme Court denied without comment yesterday a hearing sought by Lionel Ray Williams, who was convicted of second-degree murder in 1979 in the death of Sal Mineo, the actor.

title: Seales Stops Rivas
description: Sugar Ray Seales, the World Boxing Council's eighth-ranked middleweight, scored a first-round knockout of Juan Roberto Rivas of San Antonio at the Bakersfield Civic Auditorium last night. Seales, the 1972 Olympic welterweight champion, caught Rivas with a left to end the fight at 2:34.

title: SCIENTIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock divd paid in Nov 1980

title: CO-FOUNDER OF HEALTH CENTER
description: Dr. Alton Ochsner, an internationally known heart surgeon, teacher and early influential opponent of cigarette smoking, died yesterday in New Orleans at the age of 85.

title: SERRA WORK STIRS DOWNTOWN PROTEST
description: A recently installed sculpture by Richard Serra is stirring controversy in lower Manhattan. ''Tilted Arc'' is a subtly curved wall of three rusted steel plates that runs 120 feet long and 12 feet high across the broad plaza of the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building on Federal Plaza between Broadway and Lafayette Street.

title: Brahms at the Galleria
description: A free program of Brahms sonatas, played by two piano-violin duos, will be presented at noon today at the Galleria Building, 115 East 57th Street, near Park Avenue.

title: THE MANDATE
description: Have you noticed the increased sightings of strange creatures? The Loch Ness Monster in Scotland, a new beast in Lake Champlain, and in the nati on's capital, lurking in the Tidal Basin, The Mandate.

title: G.A.O. QUESTIONS PLAN FOR DEREGULATION OF BELL
description: New criticism of the Federal Communications Commission's ability to monitor the telephone industry was raised today in a Government report that was seen as an obstacle to the Administration's policy of deregulation for telecommunications companies.

title: CONGRESS TAKES A LONG HARD LOOK AT FOREIGNN AID
description: Foreign aid legislation, rarely if ever politically popular in Congress, appears to be stalled in the House of Representatives with no chance of passage before the new fiscal year begins next week.

title: BOSTON UTILITY HALTS NUCLEAR PLANT PLANS
description: The Boston Edison Company announced today that it would not build a second nuclear power plant, the Pilgrim 2 plant in Plymouth, Mass., saying it could no longer afford increasing construction costs and delays in Federal licensing.

title: Allstate to Give 250,000 Refunds
description: The Allstate Insurance Company will refund $26 million in excess premium payments to 250,000 New Jersey automobile policyholders, ending a 14-month dispute with the state, officials announced.

title: No Headline
description: Judge O'Connor Honored at White House: Judge Sandra Day O'Connor with Chief Justice Warren E. Burger yesterday in the Rose Garden at the White House. The occasion was a reception led by President Reagan for 150 Federal district and appellate judges. Today Judge O'Connor is to be sworn in as the 102d member of the United States Supreme Court.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FOR JETS, ALL IS QUIET ON LEADERSHIP FRONT
description: Perhaps the most remarkable aspect of the atmosphere surrounding the Jets at thei r camp here this week is that, after a day or so of turmoil concerning speculation that Coach Walt Michaels would soon be dismissed, calm prevails among the team's leader ship. Michaels remains, preparing his 0-3 team for Sunday's game against the Houston Oilers at Shea Stadium, with the full backing of Jim Kensil, the Jets' president. For Michaels and Kensil, busin ess is as usual.

title: KEAN ENDS URBAN TOUR, TERMING TRIP A LESSON
description: The Republican candidate for Governor, Thomas H. Kean, closed a two-week tour of New Jersey's cities here today by reaffirming his faith in his economic program.

title: New York Times March 1 1981 143 Lines P:810301; HOW SAUDI ARABIA MIXES WELFARE AND FREE ENTERPRISE; RIYADH, Saudi Arabia
description: SAUDI ARABIA's economy is an odd hybrid, a melange of social welfare programs grafted onto a system dominated by free enterprise. On one level, Saudi Arabia takes care of its own, But on another, the policy, which also includes severe economic discrimination against foreigners, leaves some Saudis fabulously wealthy, others moderately well-to-do and unskilled guest workers almost universally poor.

title: ARTICLE ABOUT JOHNSON FAULTED ON DOCUMENTATION
description: Two associates of former President Lyndon B. Johnson and the head of an editors' association have criticized the decision by The Atlantic Monthly and Robert A. Caro to withhold documentation of their charges that, as a Congressman and Vice President, Johnson accepted ''envelopes stuffed with cash'' that he used to help the campaigns of other politicians.

title: Board Wants to Bolster High School Standards
description: The College Board, long an arbiter of the top achievers in the nation's high schools, said today that it wanted to set the minimum skills all college-bound students should possess.

title: An Aide to Gibson I ndicted in Assault
description: NEWARK (AP) - The president of the Newark Board of Education, who is also a top aide to Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, was indicted by an Essex County grand jury on 12 charges, including aggravated assault.

title: 20 IRAN PILGRIMS AT SAUDI SHRINE REPORTED HURT IN CLASH WITH POLICE
description: Twenty Iranian pilgrims were reportedly injured in Medina, Saudi Arabia, today in clashes with policemen at Islam's second holiest site, the traditional burial place of Mohammed.

title: HELMSLEY DROPS TALKS TO LEASE ARMY TERMINAL
description: Harry B. Helmsley, the real-estate developer, said yesterday that he was withdrawing from negotiations with the Koch administration for lease of the former Brooklyn Army Terminal.

title: REAGAN CUTS: FAVORABLE VIEW
description: Business executives and top bankers generally applauded President Reagan's attempt to reduce the Federal deficit through an additional $13 billion spending cut and a $3 billion tax increase, calling the measures necessary and appropriate. But there was some concern that the call for increased business taxes might mean that the Administration's economic program was unraveling under political pressures.

title: Around the Nation; Three Arrested in Strike At Philadelphia Schools
description: Three persons were arrested today as striking public school teachers staged protests at special education centers set up for high school seniors.

title: William R. Leonar d, 77, D ead; Headed U.N. Statistics Of fice
description: William Ramsdell Leonard, former director of the statistical office of the United Nations, died Wednesday at Horton Memorial Hospital, Middletown, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived in Warwick, N.Y.

title: Last Friday in September
description: Justice Sandra O'Connor, confirmed in a breeze of Senate oratory and a 99-to-0 vote, took her oath of office yesterday and became the 102d person to sit on the United States Supreme Court.

title: Jerome H. Miller Dies; Builder on Long Island
description: Jerome H. Miller, a Nassau County builder and real-estate executive and a contributor to Jewish educational and medical causes, died yesterday at the Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 68 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Patents; Curtailing A Cause of Hepatitis
description: WASHINGTON WITH the aid of a dozen chimpanzees, physicians of the Department of Health and Human Services, in a laboratory at Bethesda, Md., have devised a method of inactivating the virus responsible for most hepatitis cases in the United States. The virus is treated with formalin, created fr om formaldehyde.

title: REPUBLICANS FEAR A REAGAN DEFEAT ON BUDGET CUTS
description: Republican Congressional leaders expressed doubts today that Congress would give President Reagan the package of budget cuts he seeks. They privately predicted the President could suffer a major defeat on Capitol Hill.

title: Texaco Cites Oil Find
description: Texaco Inc. said today that two test wells in the Tartan field in the British North Sea had yielded large quantities of crude.

title: Ohio Standard
description: The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said it had entered into a $2 billion revolving credit and term loan agreement with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company as agent for a group of 41 banks. The credit will be available for general corporate purposes including financing of the company's expanded capital expenditure program, the company said. The revolving credit period under the agreement extends through Sept. 1, 1985, with any outstanding loans at that time convertible at the option of the company into a term loan with a final maturity of Sept. 1, 1989, it said.

title: Productivity Chaff, and Wheat
description: How productive are negotiated efforts to increase worker productivity? Not very, judging by the current talks between New York's Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union.

title: DIAMOND INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 13
zf Fratianne Family Woes
description: Linda Fratianne's father, Robert Fratianne, says that it was the training costs involved in making her one of the world's best figure skaters that put him in debt and in trouble with the law. Mr. Fratianne, a California Superior Court judge, has been served with a contempt-of-court citation for unpaid alimony and child support.

title: 90,000 IN PHILADELPHIA CHEER ROLLING STONES' TOUR
description: From New York City, from Trenton and from Baltimore they came; from North, South, Northeast and West Philadelphia, and from all the area's colleges and suburbs.

title: Avon Halts Talks With Cooper
description: Avon Products Inc. withdrew its proposal for a business combination with Cooper Laboratories, which was announced only last Tuesday, Cooper said.

title: A COLT WITH A RUNNER'S NAME
description: A woman leaning over the paddock rail shortly before the first race at Belmont Park yesterday was looking for a winner. She quickly decided on a lively runner in the fifth stall, who looked taller and stronger than the others in the paddock. She apparently did not notice that the horse lacked a saddle and tack.

title: PETROX ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SAMUEL GISHMAN
description: Samuel Gishman, a financial analyst with the Securities and Exchange Commission and the World Bank before retiring in 1975, died Sept. 2 at the Washington Adventist Hospital in Takoma Park, Md. Mr. Gishman, who was a resident of Takoma Park, was 74 years old.

title: OLIVE BRANCH
description: This colloquy took place in heated tones on the floor of the House of Representatives yesterday morning between Robert H. Michel and the Speaker, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr.:

title: A Jury Convicts 4 In Copter Jailbreak
description: Two men and two women were convicted yesterday of air-piracy charges involving the hijacking of a helicopter in an attempt to free a prisoner from a Federal jail in Manhattan.

title: TENNECO IS ORDERED TO SELL MONROE
description: The Federal Trade Commission, reversing an administrative law judge's decision, ruled yesterday that Tenneco Inc.'s $182.5 million acquisition of the Monroe Auto Equipment Company in 1977 was illegal and ordered Tenneco to sell the shock absorber manufacturer.

title: JURORS DEADLOCKED ON PEOPLE'S TEMPLE CASE
description: Jurors in the murder-conspiracy trial of Larry Layton, a former People's Temple member, announced today that they were deadlocked, but the judge instructed them to continue deliberating.

title: NO ONE IS INDICTED IN DEATH OF 'BULLY'
description: A county grand jury declined today to indict anyone in the death of Kenneth Rex McElroy, who was shot 10 weeks ago amid a crowd of silent onlookers.

title: Consumer Saturday; LABEL BILL ON SODIUM DEBATED IN HOUSE UNIT
description: More than 50 percent of the salt that Americans consume each day is hidden, added to food before it reaches the dinner table. Because of the potential health hazards of a highsalt diet, including a link to high blood pressure, several members of Congress want food processors to state salt content on their labels.

title: A Ci ty Pola rized
description: The headlines said landslide but the message was racial polarization. Mayor Koch, in Tuesday's primary, rolled up one of the largest victory margins in city history and won the nomination of both major parties, something that had never been done before.

title: RICHARD F. SIEMANOWSKI
description: Richard F. Siemanowski, a writer and producer of television documentaries, died yesterday in Jersey City. He was 59 years old. Mr. Siemanowski was a critic and cultural-news writer for The Chattanooga Times before going to New York to work in broadcasting. Mr. Siemanowski wrote and produced many programs for ''Lamp Unto My Feet'' and ''Look Up and Live,'' according to Pamela Ilott, vice president and executive producer of CBS News.

title: DIETRICH RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: Dietrich Resources Corp was formerly known as Dietrich Exploration Co

title: Notes on People; Road-Weary Pianist
description: The roving life of a concert pianist is not all it is cracked up to be, Garrick Ohlsson was saying the other day.

title: Volcker Again Backs Policy
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the Fed had no plans to ease its tight monetary and credit policies that some contend have led to near-record interest rates.

title: Arthur M. Berger, 79, Headed Two Companies in Manhattan
description: Arthur M. Berger, a manufacturing and advertising executive who was active in philanthropies, died Tuesday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 79 years old.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 19.50 19.50 13.00 DISCOUNT RATE* 14.00 14.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 14.25 15.04 11.95 3-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.30 14.17 11.15 6-MO. TREASURY BILLS 14.68 14.41 11.80 7-YR. TREASURY NOTES 16.02 15.65 12.27 30-YR. TREASURY BONDS 15.06 14.66 11.88 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 16.76 16.66 12.89 MUNICIPALBONDS 12.92 12.90 9.40 6-MONTH SAVINGS 14.379 CERTIFICATES * Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CAROLINA FREIGHT CARRIERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 12
description: B-Including $2.5 million extraordinary tax credit

title: New Weapon Simulator For Training Marksmen
description: A weapon simulator for training a marksman to fire rockets against armored vehicles was patented this week for the Navy. A display screen shows pictures of the background, the target and the bursts of firing.

title: Around the Nation; Harvard Chief Regrets Letters in Rape Case
description: The president of Harvard University said today that he regretted that medical school doctors had written letters of recommendation for a colleague without mentioning his rape conviction, and he ordered that written guidelines be adopted to keep similar incidents from happening.

title: Federal Union Contests Decision on Abortions
description: A Federal employees' union asked a court today t o nullify a Reagan Administration decision to curtail the abortion coverage in the health insurance plans of 8.7 million employees and their dependents.

title: News Analysis
description: Less than a year ago, economists and city officials were exclaiming about the city's recovering economy, even asking if New York was becoming ''recession-proof.'' Now, however, some of those same people are saying that the local economy is sluggish, that it has stopped growing, started to slow and might slip somewhat in the next few years.

title: A FAST-FOOD BATTLE WITH THE TACO TASTE
description: Mexican fast-food restaurants, which offer an alternative to hamburgers, french fries and milkshakes, are in the midst of a tough battle for control of the California market.

title: Eller's Painful Memory
description: Carl Eller, defensive end on four Minnesota Viking teams that went to the Super Bowl, has joined a growing list of professional athletes who have acknowledged problems with drugs and alcohol. In conjunction with Chemical Awareness Week at the University of Wisconsin-Eau Claire, Eller told an audience of about 200 that he had a $2,000-aweek cocaine habit near the end of his career and was dependent on alcohol for most of his 15 pro football seasons.

title: SOUTH KOREA SAYS IT IS HOLDING 3,228 'CRIMINALS' WITHOUT CHARGES
description: In a carefully worded statement, the South Korean Embassy here said today that the Seoul Government was detaining more than 3,000 people under a law that permits the authorities to hold prisoners without trial and without charges.

title: Notes on People; A Soap Opera Fan Gets Her Wish
description: She has won two Academy Awards and appeared in dozens of movies and was a recent success on Broadway in ''The Little Foxes,'' but all along, Elizabeth Taylor says, she has had an abiding desire to appear in her favorite television soap opera, ''General Hospital.''

title: Notes on People; A Senator Has the Last Word on Ketchup
description: Someone who ought to know what he is talking about told the Senate yesterday that under no circumstances could ketchup be considered a vegetable.

title: AVCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CLEANSING IS BEGUN AT 3 MILE ISLAND
description: Two and a half years after the worst accident in the history of commercial nuclear power, officials announced today that the first significant decontamination of the Three Mile Island nuclear reactor had been successfully completed.

title: Pate 68-134, Leads by 2 Strokes
description: Jerry Pate shot a 3-under-par 68 today and took a two-stroke lead after two rounds of the $250,000 Hall of Fame Classic.

title: Tate's People Problems
description: Marvin Tate, who resigned Thursday as Texas A & M's athletic director, said yesterday that ''people problems'' had led him to quit. But Tate would not confirm newspaper reports that he had been forced out by members of the university's board of trustees because of the Aggies' losing football record .... The Atlanta Hawks signed Clyde Bradshaw, a second-round draft pick from De Paul.

title: CLARK, J L, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
NEW POLISH LAWS GIVE WORKERS ROLE IN RUNNING PLANTS
description: The Polish Parliament passed laws today to make factories and other enterprises more autonomous and to give workers mor e power in running them.

title: FAST DELIVERY, WHEN THE COST IS WORTH IT
description: Businesses are the primary users of quick-delivery services because, to them, time is money. When time becomes priceless, many people also use these relatively expensive services. An anniversary gift that must arrive the next day, a passport that must be arrive before a plane takes off, or a college application that must meet a deadline are some of the reasons people pay high rates for fast delivery of a package or a letter.

title: REAGAN'S HONEYMOON
description: .8,2WASHINGTON - President Reagan has shown remarkable skill in managing Congress on two significant economic issues: the tax and budget cuts. He convinced the lawmakers to cut more deeply than ever before, and thereby reversed half a century of steady expansion of Government.

title: PESSIMISM SPEEDS BRITISH STOCK SLIDE
description: Fear and pessimism have washed over the London Stock Exchange, causing huge declines in share prices in the last three days and widespread forecasts of still further drops to come.

title: Unitas Victim Of a Bad Call
description: WHEN the National Football League was developing into a colossus in the late 1950's and during the 60's, Johnny Unitas was the symbol of class and excellence.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SONY TO BUILD TV PLANT IN SOUTH
description: The Sony Corporation said it will build a $19.7 million color TV plant early next year in the suburbs of Columbia, S.C., with an initial output of 20,000 sets a month when production begins in late 1982. Sony said the plant would employ about 500 workers.

title: Tass Assails Solidarity Office
description: The Solidarity information office in New York City provides ''further confirmation'' of the independent Polish union's links to Western anti-Communists, the official Tass press agency charged today. ''What kind of 'interests' do the Solidarity leaders have in the U.S.A.?'' Tass asked. ''About whom and what does their New York bureau intend to inform?''

title: 'Day in Hollywood' Closing
description: ''A Day in Hollywood/A Night in the Ukraine,'' the musical with book and lyrics by Dick Vosburgh and music by Frank Lazarus, will close after the matinee tomorrow at the Royale Theater. The production, directed by Tommy Tune and co-choreographed by him and Thommie Walsh, won the 1980 Tony award for choreography. Produced by Alexander H. Cohen and Hildy Parks, the musical will have given 590 performances and 8 previews.

title: Around the Nation; Montana Backs Hunting I n Dispute on Waterfowl
description: The Montana Fish and Game Commission, overriding warnings from the Montana Department of Health, unanimously voted today to allow the migratory waterfowl season to open as planned on Oct. 3. The Health Department had warned of the possibility of human health hazards from a toxic pesticide found in some ducks and geese.

title: PATENTS
description: Tren V. Bui of Portland, Ore., came as a refugee from Vietnam six years ago, and has worked since as a dimensional inspector for an industrial company.

title: AEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: B-Net income after $369,000 loss from discontinued operations.. C-After $2,878,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: RED-CLAD DISCIPLES OF AN INDIAN GURU BUILD A FARM COMMUNITY IN OREGON
description: It seems an unlikely spot for a wispy, ailing Indian guru's dream of a ''city of god'' to take earthly form, but the physical evidence of that city is growing dramatically in the barren, lion-colored hills 20 miles southwest of here - and with it the fears of many residents of this tiny town that they will be inundated by the guru's red-clad disciples.

title: SOVIET SCIENTIST'S CANDOR EARNS U.S. PRAISE
description: In what was widely regarded as a daring gesture, the highest-ranking Soviet science official in this country met here today with 100 or so American scientists to discuss the plight of dissident scientists in the Soviet Union who are denied permission to emigrate.

title: BIG-POWER INTERESTS
description: Success in negotiation depends upon how we negotiate. Ou r purpose is to work out with the Soviet Union a way to live together on this precarious globe. We want to clarify existing restraints an d develop additional ones, because it is in our mutual interest to r espect verifiable norms of conduct.

title: DANCE: TWYLA THARP'S 'SHORT STORIES'
description: Love-hate relationships are on Twyla Tharp's mind this season, and in the premiere of ''Short Stories,'' in her dance company's second program Thursday night at the Winter Garden, she pulled off a powerful mood piece.

title: Your Money; 2d Mortgages Catching On
description: MOST parents are willing to make sacrifices to educate their children, but putting up the family home as collateral for a college loan might strike some people as going too far.

title: LONG LINES AT OUR NURSING HOMES' DOORS
description: To the Editor:

title: LONDON SUNDAY TIMES HALTED IN DISPUTE
description: The Sunday Times will not publish this weekend as a result of a new labor dispute that shattered a fragile, sevenmonth-old peace.

title: Going Out Guide
description: RETROSPECT

title: HOW TO FIX LEAKS IN A SALES-TAX PIPE
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Kenya's President Meets With Reagan on Namibia
description: Daniel arap Moi, the President of Kenya and chairman of the Organization of African Unity, was briefed today at the White House by President Reagan and Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. on new moves by five Western nations on independence for South-West Africa.

title: Milers Face Uncharted Course
description: ''From the starting line, we run into the great unknown,'' Craig Masback observed yesterday, speaking of what will await some of the world's top milers today in the first Pepsi Challenge Fifth Avenue Mile.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Tuesday on auditions for choristers incorrectly identified the director of St. George's Choral Society on Stuyvesant Square. His name is Calvin Hampton.

title: De Gustibus; A SURFEIT OF SERVICE
description: As hard as it may be to believe, there can be such a thing as too much service in a restaurant or, more precisely, misguided service that becomes intrusive. Good service, in the traditional idiom, should be virtually invisible, with captains, waiters and busboys at the ready but otherwise out of the diner's consciousness if not out of sight.

title: SOME STATES ACT TO REQUIRE WORK BY RECIPIENTS OF WELFARE MONEY
description: With encouragement from the Reagan Administration, welfare officials in at least 10 states, including New York and New Jersey, are devising rules that will prod or require welfare recipients to take jobs.

title: Northwest Set To Buy Stock
description: Northwest Industries, a conglomerate whose holdings include the Lone Star Steel Corporation, the Acme Boot Company, Union Underwear Inc. and the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Los Angeles, said it would buy back an additional 2 million shares of its common stock at $55 a share, bringing its total planned purchase to 5 million shares. The total value of the transaction would be $275 million.

title: No Headline
description: Letter: On the Guatemalan Conflict Britain Switched Signals on Belize To the Editor: Your Sept. 23 editorial on the Belize question is misleading and distorts the real situation. The slogan ''Belize is ours'' (Belice es nuestro) originated and became intensely popular in Guatemala during the Government of Dr. Juan Jose Arevalo (1945-51), and by no effort of the imagination can that Government be called a militaristic Government.

title: MELVILLE'S 'BOB LE FLAMBEUR'
description: Because the films of the late Jean-Pierre Melville, the French director whose spare, ironic work was much admired by the members of the Nouvelle Vague, are largely unknown in this country, his ''Bob le Flambeur'' (Bob the Gambler) should turn out to be one of the more delightful surprises of the New York Film Festival. The 1956 film, a festival retrospective selection, will be shown today in Alice Tully Hall at 12:30 P.M.

title: RAVITCH SAYS AID CUTS MAY PUSH FARES TO 80
description: Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, warned yesterday that bus and subway fares could rise to 80 cents before next June if President Reagan's plan for a 12 percent Federal spending cut was adopted by Congress.

title: Harold H. Cook, 77, Is Dead; A Retired Investment Banker
description: Harold H. Cook, retired senior vice president and director of the former investment banking firm of Spencer Trask & Company, died Wednesday in St. Luke's Hospital in Phoenix. A former resident of Montclair, N J., he was 77 years old and had lived in Scottsdale, Ariz., since his retirement in 1969.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 28.

title: Blood-Sucking Insects Target of a Repellent
description: Repellents effective against blood-sucking insects have been invented for the Department of Agriculture by Terence P. McGovern and Carl E. Schreck, who got patent 4,291,041 this week.

title: MILLER, HENRY S, REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SEGA ENTERPRISES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Includes losses from foreign currency translations of $769,000 in latest qr and $548,000 in earlier period... C-Includes foreign currency translation gains of $163,000 or 2 cents a shr in latest yr against losses of $1.3 million in 1980; Sega is 85 percent owned by Gulf & Western Industries

title: METS FALL TO EXPOS, DROP 5 GAMES BACK
description: Bill Gullickson and Jeff Reardon continued the outstanding pitching that has helped carry the Montreal Expos to the top of National League East by combining to beat the Mets, 6-3, tonight before a crowd of 41,251 at Olympic Stadium.

title: DPF INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
description: B-After $30,405,000 loss from discontinued operations and $51,000 extraordinary credit...C-Net income including $479,000 income from discontinued operations and $719,000 extraordinary credit

title: Notes on People; Rock Promoter Puts 'Dream House' Up for Sale
description: For Don Kirshner, the rock music promoter and television producer, his home on 29 acres of choice land in Harding Township, N.J., was a ''dream house.''

title: HOLLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Police Chief Shot to Death
description: Police Chief Richard Carrington, who gained national attention for wearing cowboy garb on duty, was shot to death today after he was called to investigate reports that a woman had been taken hostage, officers said. The alleged assailant was shot in a hand by another officer and was taken in custody of officers to Jackson-Madison County Hospital, officials said.

title: Bridge: Modern Transfers Can Fill Old-Fashioned Demands
description: Some modern bidding conventions can be applied in a wide variety of situations. An example is the Jacoby transfer bid, which was originally designed to apply to responses to openings of one notrump but is used nowadays in other no-trump situations.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Gertrude D. T. Schimmel, wife, mother, accomplished card player and a deputy chief of the New York City Police Department, took out a permit the other day for the pistol she packs in her handbag. Mrs. Schimm el, known as Gertie to her friends and Chief to her colleagues, h as had a special right to carry a revolver for the 41 years in whic h she has served as a police officer in this city, but that right ha s been revoked with her retirement. She says she does not mind.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Justice O'Connor, welcome to the Court." - Chief Justice Warren Berger. 8:2.

title: U.N. Welcomes Belize As Its 156th Member
description: The General Assembly admitted Belize to United Nations membership today in a 144-to-1 vote, with only Guatemala opposed.

title: INTEREST RATES SURGE OVER DOUBTS ON BUDGET
description: Interest rates rose sharply yesterday as the credit markets concluded that President Reagan's budget proposals would not be enough to prevent upward pressure on interest rates in the future.

title: LONDON AND TORONTO MARKETS FALL
description: Stock and bond prices fell sharply yesterday as investors expressed disappointment with President Reagan's latest economic proposals and concern that his Administration will not be able to bring down interest rates.

title: O'NEILL RECEPTIVE ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Despite some Democratic misgivings, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, appeared to be ready today to support President Reagan's proposal for a bipartisan panel to recommend a long-range solution to the financial problems of the Social Security System.

title: INNIS TO FACE COURT
description: Roy Innis, the national chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, was ordered to appear in State Supreme Court in Manhattan at 10 A.M. Monday to explain why he refused to stand in a police lineup yesterday afternoon.

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1981
description: International More autonomy for Polish industry and workers is in prospect under laws passed by Parliament that provide Poland with an opportunity to move away from the Soviet-style, tightly controlled economy. The approval of the laws after months of debate on the issue of workers' self-management also represents considerable erosi on in the CommunistParty's power to name all administrative personnel. This prerogative has been a ma instay of Communist rule in most Eastern bloc countries.(Page 1, Colu mn 1.) A successor to Mexico's President has been chosen by the ruling party. He is Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, a political moderate who is Planning and Budget Minister in the Government of President Jose Lopez Portillo. He reportedly was President Lopez Portillo's choice. (1:2.)
