title: NEW WAVE: LENE LOVICH
description: With two albums, an LP, and a couple of American tours behind her, Lene Lovich, the British-American rock singer who appeared at Studio 54 on Wednesday, remains one of the more bizarre and intriguing singers from the English New Wave. Miss Lovich possesses a strong, penetrating soprano, which she pushes to extremes of controlled hysteria via echo effects and by also exploring her own voice's physical limits in the way that some experimental art singers do.

title: BALDWIN SECURITIES CORP reports earnings for As of Aug 31
description: Asset figures represent net assets

title: Around the Nation; Soviet Planes Intercepted Off North Carolina
description: Air Force jets intercepted two Soviet reconnaisance planes off the North Carolina coast early today, in the second such incident in a week, officials said.

title: F.T.C. AD RATE PACT SET, BUT COAST PAPER OBJECTS
description: The publisher of The Los Angeles Times agreed today not to discriminate in price for some types of advertising space, the Federal Trade Commission announced Friday. But the publisher said later he wanted to contest the agreement.

title: WHAT IT TAKES TO QUIET A SUBWAY SYSTEM
description: To the Editor:

title: ENERGY DEPT. TASKS TO SHIFT
description: Functions of the Department of Energy, which is headed for institutional oblivion just four years after it was set up, could be dispersed among a half-dozen other Federal bodies, including a new one that could handle weapons production and other defense work.

title: FILM: 'WITNESS' HUNGARIAN SATIRE
description: Jozsef Pelikan (Ferenc Kallai), the hero of Peter Bacso's ''The Witness,'' has the sort of luck that occurs only in movies. His silliest transgressions land him in jail, and each of his many arrests is followed by an instant reprieve. Pelikan is the goodhearted dupe at the center of a web of intrigue, all of which is rendered with a nervy satirical edge by Mr. Bacso, and with playfulness too. His film, which was made in 1968 and supressed until last year, is as broadly entertaining as it is bold.

title: A SEARCH SUB IS BELIEVED TO HAVE FOUND KAREN E
description: After a two-week search bedeviled by bad weather and other problems, a Coast Guard search team late yesterday afternoon found what it believed to be the 36-foot cabin cruiser that sank in Long Island Sound on Aug. 9. Five persons died in the sinking.

title: Safety System Devised For Nuclear Reactors
description: A safety system invented for the Babcock & Wilcox Company, New Orleans, is designed to shut down a nuclear reactor if overload occurs.

title: Article 027710 -- No Title
description: British divers have recovered at least 225 gold bars worth more than $45 million from the H.M.S. Edinburgh, the British Navy cruiser lying 800 feet deep in Barents Sea, the Government said today.

title: NEW HARVARD CURB ON RECRUITERS
description: For second-year students at the Harvard Business School, choosing among an abundance of lucrative job offers has not always been a s pleasant as it may see m. These prospective executives faced extreme pressure to decide q uickly where to begin their careers, often before they knew all the ir options.

title: WAJDA'S 'MAN OF IRON' FINDS A U.S. DISTRIBUTOR
description: Andrzej Wajda's ''Man of Iron'' - the Polish movie that won the Cannes Film Festival last spring and will close the New York Film Festival Oct. 11 - snared an American distributor this week.

title: CONGRESS CAUTIOUS ON TAX REVENUES
description: The Congressional tax-writing committees indicated today that they were taken by surprise by President Reagan's request last night for several billion dollars of revenue-raising measures. Speedy passage seems doubtful.

title: ANNUITY TAX RULE CHANGED
description: The Internal Revenue Service ruled yesterday that taxes cannot be deferred on funds saved through life insurance annuity contract s thatare managed b y mutual fund companies.

title: Man With Pasty Face
description: Actually, this is meant only for the manufacturers of a new brand of shaving cream, whose company name I shall omit since I wish them well and want simply to give them some news that may help their business. You will know who you are, gentlemen, when I say that your product goes on the face like a slightly too thick coating of floor wax.

title: REAGAN'S USER FEE PLAN IS OPPOSED
description: President Reagan's announcement that he would seek user fees for various Federal services met with stiff opposition today from the owners of boats, barges, private planes and others who would have to pay the fees.

title: Benson T. Chertok, Professor And Physics Researcher, Dies
description: Dr. Benson T. Chertok, professor of physics at the American University and a research scientist in high-energy nuclear physics, died Monday of cancer at Georgetown University Hospital here. He was 46 years old.

title: The Talk of Lehman College
description: ''It just amazes me,'' said Dr. Leonard Lief, president of Herbert H. Lehman College in the Bronx. ''This is a borough of 1.4 million people - it's bigger than many states - and people just throw up their hands and say it's finished.''

title: Soccer Bowl Is Tonight
description: The Cosmos and the Chicago Sting, two teams with a slight German flavor and an accent on scoring, will meet in the Soccer Bowl game tomorrow night to decide the championship of the North American Soccer League.

title: KHOMEINI URGES IRAN TO VOTE
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini warned the people of Iran today that a low turnout for the presidential elections next Friday would be a defeat for the fundamentalist Islamic Government.

title: Gillman's Lament
description: Sid Gillman , the former coach whose Ram and Charger teams were noted for dee p passes, bemoans the rule that limits contact between the defender and the receiver to one bump, which can be applied only within 5 yard s of the line of scrimmage. ''When you've got good ends and a good pa sser, there is just no way to keep them from completing passes,'' sai d Gillman.

title: REDISTRICTING ISSUE FUELED BY RACISM
description: To the Ed itor: The most distressing and never mentioned, o r perhaps unmentionable,aspect of the entire City Council redistricti ng dispute may be this: It is assumed and accepted that in a ''minori ty'' district a member of that ''minority'' should and will be elect ed.

title: 36,000 MANHATTAN-BOUND COMMUTERS DELAYED IN SERIES OF MISHAPS
description: Rush-hour travel for 36,000 Manhattan-bound riders was snagged yesterday morning by a series of mishaps on the Long Island Rail Road, Conrail's commuter lines and the IRT.

title: MEXICAN PARTY PICKS MODERATE FOR PRESIDENCY
description: Mexico's governing party today chose Miguel de la Madrid Hurtado, a political moderate who serves as Planning and Budget Minister, as its candidate to succeed President Jose Lopez Portillo in December 1982.

title: Around the World; Italy's Cabinet Approves $8 Billion in Cuts for '82
description: Prime Minister Giovanni Spadolini won Cabinet approval today for a 1982 budget that cuts more than $8 billion from Government spending on health services, social security and local government.

title: WHITAKER CABLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including $776,000 tax credit...C-Net loss

title: JUSTICE O'CONNOR SEATED ON NATION'S HIGH COURT
description: Sandra Day O'Connor took her seat today as the 102d Justice and the first woman to serve on the United States Supreme Court.

title: FEDERAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Owen Begley, a Former Mayor Of Schenectady, Is Dead at 75
description: Owen M. Begley, a former Mayor of Schenectady and State Senator, died yesterday at his home here after a long illness.

title: OFFICIAL ASSERTS CUTS DEEPER THAN $13 BILLION WILL BE NEEDED
description: Congress will actually have to cut several billion dollars more than the $13 billion in reductions outlined by President Reagan to keep to the $43 billion deficit target for the fiscal year 1982, an Administration official said tonight.

title: MAX E. COOPER, RETIRED JUDGE WHO SERVED BROOKLYN COURTS
description: Justice Max E. Cooper of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn died Wednesday in University Hospital in Manhattan after a brief illness. He was 71 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Mannesmann Steel Pact
description: Mannesmann A.G., the diversified West German steel-making concern, said today that it had obtained an order from the Shell Oil Company, Houston, to deliver 112,000 tons of large-diameter steel pipe. It declined to disclose the value of the order.

title: OPERA: 'SIEGFRIED,' UNDER LEINSDORF, BACK AT MET
description: Eternity is a concept that no human mind can really grasp, but for a glimpse of what forever must be like, perhaps nothing can match an unsatisfactory performance of Wagner. The Metropolitan Opera offered an especially grim intimation of the abysmal beyond on Thursday night when ''Siegfried,'' the third work in the ''Ring,'' returned to the repertory. This is the darkly symbolic production, designed by Gunther Schneider-Siemssen and based on Herbert von Karajan's staging for Salzburg, that first appeared here in 1972. At that time, Erich Leinsdorf conducted and the cast included Birgit Nilsson, Judith Blegen, Lili Chookasian, Jess Thomas, Gerhard Stolze, Thomas Stewart and Gustav Neidlinger, all eminent or at very least worthy Wagnerians.

title: PROFITS OFF
description: The Avco Corporation, a diversified financial services and manufacturing company, yesterday announced the formation of a new management team headed by an outsider and also reported a sharp drop in third-quarter earnings because of high interest rates.

title: Briefing
description: F ORMER Attorney General John N. Mitchell works on M Street in downtown Washington. John Erlichman wants all letters to him sent to a post office box in Santa Fe, N.M. Charles Colson, the aide to President Nixon who spent seven months in prison, also lists his office address as a P.O. box, this one in Washington, D.C., in the name of Prison Fellowship, a project to help former inmates.

title: HARVESTER, BIG BANKS IN ACCORD
description: The International Harvester Corporation announced today that it had reached agreement with its eight lead banks to refinance $3.4 billion in short-term debt, principally through lower interest rates.

title: AMERICAN PUBLIC ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CITY IS GIVEN POWER TO BUY ITS OWN PHONE EQUIPMENT
description: The Board of Estimate yesterday authorized the purchase of telephone equipment for municipal offices. New York City officials said it was the first step toward severing ties with the New York Telephone Company and possibly reducing the city's $82 million-a-year telephone bill.

title: LEFF HEARING ENDS
description: The misconduct hearing of Justice James J. Leff of State Supreme Court ended after four days of testimony before the state's Commission on Judicial Conduct.

title: Prince Philip Speaks
description: Although allotted only five minutes, Prince Philip of Britain delivered one of the most outspoken speeches thus far at the Olympic Congress in Baden-Baden, West Germany. The Prince, speaking in his capacity as president of the International Equestrian Federation, said that those who provide funds for sport - whether government, commercial or charitable organizations - were inclined to want control of that sport. ''A way must be found,'' he said, ''for the voluntary democratic federations of sports to remain in ultimate control of their sport, no matter how it is financed.''

title: L.I. GEARS UP TO PROTEST GRUMMAN MERGER PLAN
description: Many Long Islanders are worried about the possibility that a Texas conglomerate might take over the Grumman Corporation. And they take it rather personally that Texas money might be used to meet Grumman's $448 million annual payroll.

title: 6 U.S. Scores Chosen For International Jury
description: Scores by six composers have been selected as winners of the national composers competition of the United States section of the League of Composers-International Soc iety for Contemporary Music. Thecomposers are Karl Edward Boelter, Daniel Perlongo, Charles Porter, Christopher R ouse, Sheila Silver and Arlene Zallman.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. Four Armenian nationalists seized the Turkish Consulate, vowing to kill their hostages unless all Armenian political prisoners were released from Turkish jails. The gunmen later surrendered, apparently without harming any captives.

title: The 'Evenhanded' Test in Chile
description: The document is entitled ''U.S. Commitment to Human Rights'' and it was published by the State Department on July 14. It declares: ''Ours is not a policy of 'selective indignation.' Rather, it is one of balanced and evenhanded condemnation of human rights violations wherever they occur.''

title: Saad Muhammad Risks Title
description: The honeymoon is over for Matthew Saad Muhammad. On his recent honeymoon, he had to run round the deck of a Caribbean cruise ship to train for his eighth defense of the World Boxing Council's light-heavyweight championship. Now he can share the suffering. And the triumphs.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amax Inc. raised its estimate for proved and probable tungsten reserves at its Mactung project in Northwest Canada to 13.6 million tons from 7.7 million.

title: REASONS FOR A LOPSIDED U.S.- CHINA EXCHANGE
description: To the Editor:

title: 25 Cars Pile Up in Fog
description: As many as 25 cars piled up in a chain of collisions on a fog-shrouded Interstate 10 bridge today, killing one person and injuring at least six, the police said. One car burst into flames, said Sgt. Ernest Young. The crashes, beginning about 7:30 A.M., clogged a nine-mile eastbound stretch of the highway in rush-hour traffic, the police said.

title: Around the World; French-Mexican Position On Salvador Supported
description: The Socialist International declared its support today for a French-Mexican statement recognizing the leftist opposition in El Salvador.

title: Sifford Shoots 66, Leads Se nior Golf by a Strok e
description: Charlie Sifford made five birdies on the back nine, four in succession, to shoot a six-under-par 66 and take the first-round lead in the $100,000 Merrill Lynch-Golf Digest pro-am today at the Newport Country Club.

title: 3 Cuban Refugees Freed
description: Three Cuban refugees who came to this country last year by sea were released today from the Federal Penitentiary here, officials said. This brought to 1 21 the number of refugees released under an order by Federal D istrict Judge Marvin Shoob, who directed the Government to release 304 Cubans as soon as sponsors could be found for them and to revie w the cases of 226 others.

title: Around the Nation; Pro-Nuclear Groups Sue Over California Protest
description: A coalition of pro-nuclear groups filed a $1 million lawsuit today against antinuclear activists who have been trying to blockade the Diablo Canyon atomic power plant.

title: INTERNATIONAL SEAWAY TRADING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-There were no earnings in the latest 6 mos period

title: HEATING OIL PRICE MAY SLOW ITS RISE
description: As autumn chills the air, there is comfort in the outlook for home heating oil. Prices are expected to climb no more than 5 cents a gallon this winter, and supplies seem plentiful.

title: A TURN-ON FOR PUBLIC-ACCESS TV
description: To the Editor:

title: PUNGENT CHINATOWN
description: To the Editor:

title: A. J. KELLY
description: A. J. Kelly, retired president of Butterworth Systems Inc. of Florham Park, N.J., an affiliate of the Exxon Corporation, died Tuesday at his home in Stuart, Fla.

title: 1981 COTY WINNERS
description: Geoffrey Beene received his fourth citation to fashion's hall of fame, Perry Ellis was honored for both his men's and his women's clothes, and after 14 years as a designer, Norma Kamali received her first Coty award. So did Ronaldus Shamask, who showed his first collection two years ago.

title: Entries for Today's Fifth Avenue Mile Run; Men
description: Mike BoitKenya Tom ByersU.S. Eamonn CoghlanIreland Steve CramBritain Tom DonaghueU.S. Vince DraddyU.S. Ray FlynnIreland Phil KaneU.S. Omar Khalifathe Sudan Sydney MareeU.S.Craig MasbackU.S. Steve ScottU.S. John WalkerNew Zealand Thomas Wessinghage W. Ger. Women Christine BoxerBritain Cindy BremserU.S. Kim GallagherU.S. Joan HansenU.S. Monica JoyceBritain Lynn KanukaCanada Maggie KeyesU.S. Britt McRobertsCanada Jan MerrillU.S. Cathie TwomeyU.S. Leann WarrenU.S. Brenda WebbU.S. Ellen WessinghageW. Ger.

title: FLORIO ASSAILS REAGAN PLAN FOR ADDITIONAL BUDGET CUTS
description: Representative James J. Florio, the Democratic candidate for Governor, today assailed President Reagan's latest proposals to cut Federal spending as ''another giant leap into the unknown.''

title: No Headline
description: Books of The Times A Different Kind of Love By ANATOLE BROYARD FISH. By Monroe Engel. 217 pages. Athene- um. $12.95.

title: REAGAN ABANDONS PROPOSAL TO PARE SCHOOL NUTRITION
description: President Reagan said today that he had withdrawn his Administration's recent proposal for reduced food and nutrition standards in the school lunch program.

title: AT THE U.N., KEY MEETINGS ARE IN PRIVATE
description: The private meetings and informal discussions that are being held among the 121 foreign ministers and 10 heads of government gathered here for the General Asembly session are where most of the real work is going on.

title: SOUTH AFRICA: BRINGING IT ALL BACK HOME
description: I used to imagine South Africa somewhere hidden as deep as the most unspeakable fears that I knew as a child. I used to think it must be a rather small hole of howling white savagery. It could not be beautiful or large or bright or able to grow peaches on a tree that someone would water and cultivate, day by day. There could not be people laughing there, or music. What would it mean to buy a new dress, or sip from a cup of coffee, in a place of such unimaginable, deadly intent and accomplishment?

title: Islanders Defeated, 5-3, By Bruins in Exhibition
description: The Islanders lost for the third time in four exhibition games tonight when theBoston Bruins defeated them, 5-3, at Providence Civic Center.

title: THE LAST MONTHS OF NICHOLAS RAY'S LIFE
description: Perhaps the worst thing that ever happened to Nicholas Ray, the director of ''They Live by Night,'' ''The Lusty Men,'' ''Rebel Without a Cause,'' ''Johnny Guitar'' and other films, was not his problems with drink and drugs, or his increasingly frequent inability to finish films he had started, or even his agonizing death from cancer in 1979. The worst thing was when, in the late 1950's, he began to hear himself acclaimed as ''an artist,'' and attempted to live up to the reputation that had been imposed on him, initially by European critics and film makers.

title: ELIXIR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
BASCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: B-Including $2,549,000 extraordinary credit

title: A HOMECOMING AT U.S.C.
description: Stanley Wilson could not contain his excitement. As the airplane carrying the University of Oklahoma Sooners began its descent here late yesterday afternoon, he could not help but yell. Wilson was back in the place where he had grown up watching the tradition of Southern Cal tailbacks and dreami ng of becoming a part of it, until he decided to go east.

title: FRANK B. WHITLOCK
description: Frank Beacham Whitlock, a retired vice president of the Hanover Bank, died Monday at the Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 87 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: BUDGET'S SHEPHERD IS TALKING TOUGH
description: Robert H. Michel, the Republican leader who must maneuver President Reagan's new budget cuts through the wary House of Representatives, politely calls himself ''the handmaiden'' of the President. But he is a servant who feels compelled to inject a sense of realism when the White House gets excessively ambitious.

title: PATSY KELLY, ACTRESS IS DEAD: PLAYED COMIC ROLES IN FILMS
description: Patsy Kelly, the pert, rumpled farceur of knockabout movie comedies of the 1930's and 40's who won a Tony Award for her performance as an irascible, wise-cracking maid in the 1971 Broadway revival of ''No, No, Nanette,'' died Thursday in the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif., after a long illness. She was 71 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: 24-Hour Sports Channel Shuts Down Operations
description: Enterprise Radio, launched last January as a nationwide around-the-clock sports network, went off the air last night because of financial problems.

title: PAKISTANIS SAID TO PRODUCE OWN REACTOR FUEL
description: Senator Alan Cranston, the assistant minority leader, said today that Pakistan had begun to use domestically produced fuel in its nuclear reactor near Karachi, a development expected to complicate the Reagan Administration's proposed $3.2 billion aid program for Pakistan.

title: A SURPRISE INTERVIEW BY ATLANTA SUSPECT STIRRING CONTROVERSY
description: Wayne B. Williams, the 23-year-old talent and music promoter recently indicted here in the murders of two of 28 young black persons slain in the Atlanta area over the last two years, has stirred up another controversy.

title: Around the World; Two Provincial Chiefs Resign in Yugoslavia
description: Two high-ranking Government officials in Kosovo Province resigned today, and provincial officials dismissed several executives of the state-controlled news media, the official Tanjug press agency reported.

title: MCGREGOR'S 6-HITTER BEATS YANKEES, 1-0
description: The Yankees have not been collecting many hits or scoring many runs recently, but last night they had an excuse: the annual Scott McGregor 1-0 shutout.

title: Verderosa Wins 1 7th by Decision
description: Johnny (The Heat) Verderosa, survived a ninth-round battering and scored a unanimous 10-round decision over Roman Contreras of Mexico last night at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

title: Convict-Author In Custody in City
description: John Henry Abbott, a convict and author, appeared in Federal District Court in Manhattan on an escape complaint. He was held without bail after being brought to New York from Louisiana, where he was arrested on Wednesday.

title: Tosco to Sell 60% of Oil Unit
description: The Tosco Corporation said it was negotiating to sell up to 60 percent of a shale oil facility in Utah whose development plans were announced last month.

title: UNITED MERCHANTS & MANUFACTURERS INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $3,462,000 income from discontinued operations of $959,000 and certain imputed interest of $5,400,000...C-Includes an extraordinary tax credit of $391,000 income from discontinued operations of $4,665,000 and certain imputed interest of $6,000,000

title: Grumman Plans Announcement
description: The Grumman Corporation, which has not responded formally to a $450 million acquisition bid from the Dallas-based LTV Corporation, said yesterday that it would make an ''important'' announcement at a news conference Monday.

title: TO CZECHS, THE POLISH CRISIS IS FAMILIAR
description: Memories of the ''Prague spring'' of 1968 are so strong here that Czechoslovaks are watching the crisis in neighboring Poland with a feeling of having seen it all before.

title: Rams Sign Pastorini
description: Dan Pastorini signed a two-year contract with the Los Angeles Rams today. After Georgia Frontiere, the team's owner, announced the signing, Don Klosterman, the general manager, said that the Rams had waived the defensive end Fred Dryer to make room on the roster.

title: DUAL-LITE INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-Net income after $214,000 loss from discontinued operations and $246,000 loss on the disposal of discontinued operations

title: EX-GUERRILLAS REMINISCE AT THE KING DAVID HOTEL
description: A few of the Jewish guerrillas who blew up the King David Hotel in 1946 came back to the King David yesterday evening - this time to sip champagne, reminisce and mix their pride and sorrow at the events of 35 years ago. Even now, in middle age, they had a stony toughness in their eyes.

title: REV. FRANCIS V. WIELAND
description: The Rev. Francis V. Wieland, assistant superior of the Vincentian Fathers and professor of theology at St. John's University, died Wednesday at the Vincentian residence on the university's campus in Queens.

title: SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 26, 1981; Markets
description: Stock and bond prices prices plunged as investors expressed disappointment with President Reagan's latest economic proposals and concern that the Administration would be unable to lower interest rates. Another factor was an ominous forecast by Joseph Granville, a well-known market adviser. The Dow industrial average fell by 11.13, to 824.01, closing at its lowest level since May 15, 1980. (Page 1.) The London Stock Exchange continued its slide. The Financial Times industrial index fell more than 40 points this week. (33.)

title: SAUDIS ARE SAID TO REJECT SHARING AWACS CONTROL WITH U.S. INTO 90'S
description: Saudi Arabia has told the United States that it cannot not agree to joint control of Awacs planes into the 1990's, although it is willing to permit United States training personnel to fly on all missions for three or four years once the planes are delivered in 1985 and 1986, authoritative sources said today.

title: Reagan Abandons Proposal to Pare School Nutrition
description: President Reagan said today that he had withdrawn his Administration's recent proposal for reduced food and nutrition standards in the school lunch program.

title: FEWER STUDENTS ARE EXCLUDED FROM SCHOOL FOR LACK OF SHOTS
description: The number of students excluded from the city's public schools fell to 60,326 yesterday, from 77,600 on Wednesday, as officials continued to collect consent forms from youngsters whose parents had granted the school system permission to give their children immunization shots.

title: TIGERS FALL INTO A TIE FOR FIRST
description: Robin Yount hit a three-run homer with two out in the ninth inning last night to give the Milwaukee Brewers an 8-6 victory over the Tigers in Detroit.

title: AGENTS SEIZE 4 AND 1,546 POUNDS OF HASHISH HIDDEN IN HANDBAGS
description: The Customs Service said yesterday that Federal agents had arrested four men on smuggling charges and had seized 1,546 pounds of Lebanese hashish hidden in women's handbags consigned to a luggage shop in midtown Manhattan.

title: REPAIRS TO DELAY SPACE SHUTTLE UNTIL LATE OCTOBER
description: Officials at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida announced yesterday that repairs needed on the space shuttle Columbia because of a propellant spill Tuesday would be done at the launching pad and that the craft could be ready for flight by late October or early November.

title: ROCK: STONES PERFORM AS AN INFORMAL TEAM
description: The Rolling Stones' 1981 American tour may turn out to be the biggest moneymaker in the 25-year history of rock and roll. But at their opening performance today at John F. Kennedy Stadium, the Stones were as informal, and occasionally ragged, as a neighborhood garage band.

title: Redskins Waive Bacon
description: The Washington Redskins waived Coy Bacon, the 38-year-old defensive end, one day after his heated quarrel with Coach Joe Gibbs. Gibbs became upset when Bacon, a 14-year veteran, continued to miss team meetings. Bacon was replaced on the roster by Trent Bryant, a rookie cornerback

title: Around the Nation; Fight Seen as Amtrak Votes to Drop a Train
description: The Amtrak board voted today to drop the last passenger train serving West Virginia and southern Ohio despite pressure from key Congressmen.

title: Children's Books
description: SHAPED HOUSE A Story in Rhyme. Adapted and Illustrated by Paul O. Zelinsky. Unpaged. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. $9.95. (Ages 4 to 7) By ELAINE EDELMAN

title: VENEZUELA'S POPULATION RISE AFTER 800 B.C. LINKED TO CORN
description: Archeological evidence indicates that from 800 B.C. to A.D. 400 a population explosion occurred in the Orinoco Basin of Venezuela. The number of inhabitants, from archeological evidence, seems to have increased 15-fold.

title: NEGLECTED BLACK WRITER OVERCOMES A STRICTURE
description: He is middle-aged now, an author and editor of 16 books. Most were at least moderately successful. His best-known novel, ''The Man Who Cried I Am,'' published in 1967, still sells in substantial numbers. Starting Tuesday his 1976 ''The Junior Bachelor Society'' will be the basis of a three-part NBC-TV series, ''The Sophisticated Gents.'' But his writing is marked by anger at what he regards as society's strictures on black writers. And, at the age of 56, John A. Williams is still angry.

title: The Downfall Season Is Upon Us Again
description: To the Sports Editor: Haven 't New York football fans suffered enough? As residents of ourfine city we must suffer the slings and arrows of the outrageous fortunes of o ur generally inept football teams. We suffer the jabs and barbs of our friends who live in such desirable cities as Pittsburgh, C leveland and Buffalo. We do it as steady usually supportive fa ns. But can't we be shown one interesting, and meaningful ga me involving competent teams each Sunday? Must we be forced to sit through two New York teams playing back-to-back for 16 straight week s? LAWRENCE STALCUP New York

title: U.S. PRESSES TWO-YEAR-OLD OMEGA 7 INQUIRY
description: A Federal grand jury has been investigating Omega 7, the anti-Castro Cuban terrorists, for two years, but has handed up only one indictment, for perjury.

title: MITTERRAND STARTS DRIVE TO STIR SUPPORT FOR HIS POLICIES
description: Through all the changes that have taken place in France since he took office four months ago, President Francois Mitterrand has all but kept out of public view. He has made no major television appearances and given only one substantial interview to a French newspaper.

title: HATALSKY LEADS BY ONE STROKE ON 68-204
description: Morris Hatalsky, who has struggled in his career on the professional golf tour, shot a three-under-par 68 today for a one-stroke lead after the third round of the $250,000 Hall of Fame Classic.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area
description: Senate

title: GREELEY HIGH CALLED ONE OF BEST IN U.S.
description: CHAPPAQUA ''YOU may not see any major differences between the way classes are conducted here and at other schools,'' a teacher at the Horace Greeley High School was saying to a visitor the day after fall classes had begun. ''You will see students who are motivated. But you will also see students who are not prepared for the day's lesson. You will see teachers who are excited about their work and others who are not.

title: Carol Catalano Bride of T. J. Martin Jr.
description: Carol Ann Catalano, a member of the technical staff at the Lincoln Laboratory of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, was married yesterday in West Roxbury, Mass., to Thomas Joseph Martin Jr., who is on the professional staff of Arthur D. Little Inc., the Cambridge, Mass., based consulting firm.

title: A THREE-PART QUIZ
description: Bridge is the only game or sport that people can - and do - play from the age of 10 to the age of 100. Those who start by specializing in more vigorous activities have an opportunity to transfer their allegiance and often do so.

title: PRIVATE SECTOR AID SOUGHT BY REAGAN
description: The Reagan Administration, as it pushes ahead with budget cuts, is turning to business and philanthropic leaders to stimulate support for a spectrum of community aid handled by the Federal Government until now.

title: The Nation; Another Day in The Oval Office
description: Last week came a fresh reminder that the extraordinary plotting and scheming of the Nixon Administration by no means began with Watergate. The transcript of a newly disclosed White House tape, published in The New York Times, revealed President Nixon and his chief of staff, H.R. Haldeman, discussing ways to punish protestors against the Vietnam War. At one point, they paused briefly to speculate whether the Chicago Seven conspiracy trial defendants were ''all Jews,'' as Mr. Nixon at first wondered, or ''about half'' were, as he concluded.

title: Three Electoral Aides Reported Killed in Iran
description: Guerrillas shot and killed three election officials in Teheran, the Teheran radio said today. The radio also reported that 22 more people accused of being opponents of the Islamic fundamentalist Government had been executed by firing squads.

title: THE ULTIMATE PRIZE
description: A person living on the border of a province is better able to decide which peaks inside it are the highest than an observer standing amidst the mountains themselves. - ESAIAS TEGNER, Director of the Swedish Academy in 1900.

title: Peggy Maxwell Wed To Kurt M. Anderson
description: Peggy L. Maxwell and Kurt M. Anderson were married yesterday in the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Dr. David H.C. Read performed the ceremony.

title: BABI YAR'S LEGACY
description: Barely four miles from the center of Kiev, the Ukraine's ancient and beautiful capital, is a place called Babi Yar. Once a deep, wooded ravine through which a small stream ran, Babi Yar is now filled in, an open space with brambly growth and a few lonely trees.

title: PATH Crime Rate Lower
description: The use of plainclothes police officers has reduced the crime rate on the Port Authority Trans-Hudson rapid transit system by 14 percent for the first half of 1981, a spokesman said today.

title: Major News; Koch Redefines 2 -Party Politics
description: Those who find history boring might have dozed off as they watched it being made at the New York City polls last week. In a political coup that capped weeks of utterly bearable suspense, Mayor Koch became the first city candidate to win Decmocratic and Republican nominations.

title: Glenn Bolton's Passing Sparks North Arlington
description: Glenn Bolton threw to Rich Zabowski for two touchdowns and ran for another to lead North Arlington to a 40-7 victory over Palisades Park yesterday in Palisades Park.

title: REAGAN HOLDS TO THE COURSE THAT BROUGHT HIM THIS FAR
description: THE pragmatist and the conservative true believer in Ronald Reagan fou ght over e conomic policy again last week. The true believer won. Calling for m ore slashes in domestic spending and just a nick out of defense, he d emanded that a weary Congress go back at the budget until they ge t it right.

title: N.H. Donald 3d Weds Miss Akers
description: The marriage of Mary Kathryn Akers to Norman Henderson Donald 3d, a New York lawyer, took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Edward T. Johnston perormed the ceremony.

title: CHOATE VANQUISHES KENT IN OPENER, 24-0
description: Choate, last season's best team in New England prep school football, opened this season with a victory yesterday by defeating Kent School, 24-0, in Kent, Conn.

title: YONKERS SEEKS $1.1 MILLION FROM WESTCHESTER
description: The financially troubled City of Yonkers has decided to ask Westchester County for a $1.1 million aid package that appears likely to encounter rough going with the County Board of Legislators.

title: TV View; AND NOW, AN IRISH VERSION OF 'ROOTS'
description: Take a thick slice of turbulent history, put it into the hands of the queen of American soap opera, and the result is bound to be like ''The Manions of America,'' the six-hour mini-series that ABC-TV will broadcast this Wednesday, Thursday and Friday at 9 P.M. Designed as the equivalent of ''Roots'' for Irish-Americans, the story was devised by Agnes Nixon, creator of the daytime serials ''All My Children'' and ''One Life to Live.'' The scripts were written by Rosemary Anne Sisson, whose television credits include several episodes of Britain's ''Upstairs, Downstairs'' as well as Australia's ''A Town Called Alice,'' the next offering on public television's Masterpiece Theater. The billing can get complicated. A novelized version of the story is being marketed in a Dell paperback as ''Agnes Nixon's 'The Manions of America' by Rosemary Anne Sisson.''

title: YALE TIGHTENS SECURITY AGAINST LIBRARY THEFTS
description: Yale University, where a stolen $10,000 antique microscope was discovered last week wrapped in newspaper in a trash can, has been struggling for years to protect its vast and valuable collections of books, manuscripts and artifacts.

title: TAKING AIM AT GRUMMAN
description: de-loops in a World War II fighter plane, and he still takes to the slopes although he once broke his leg in 16 places in a skiing accident. In his Dallas office, there is the sword he won as a golfing prize in Scotland, a collection of rifles, and a painting of Mr. Thayer in Ethiopia posing with Cecil, a newly bagged lion. Cecil, now stuffed, sits in a roaring pose in one corner of the room.

title: RABBIT RETURNS
description: RABBIT IS RICH By John Updike. 467 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: A.T.& T. DIVIDES TO CONQUER
description: MICHAEL JONES had been a Bell telephone salesman for 10 years when the company told him last spring that he would have to prove himself again. Mr. Jones, who requested his real name not be used, was told to write a report and submit other documents showing that he knew how to organize an account, knew the Bell product line, knew the Bell marketing strategies.

title: Breenburgh A group of Moslems had provoked a torm of protest among homeowners in a quiet residential neighborhood here with plans to convert a twofloor house into a place of worship and learning.
description: The Islamic Society of Westchester and Rockland bought the house at 220 Wortington Road last April for $210,000, intending to convert its three-car gorage into a sanctuary and to install quarters for a part-time religious school and caretaker's residence.

title: ONCE AGAIN, A CLASH OVER VOTING RIGHTS
description: Reginald A. Stuart is chief of The New York Times Atlanta Bureau. By Reginald A. Stuart he residents of tiny, rural and conservative Sumter County, Ala., and the huge, metropolitan and ostensibly liberal county of New York may have thought they had little in common, particularly when it comes to racial issues. But a relationship was established recently when the United States Supreme Court included New York City among the ranks of hundreds of Southern communities that had violated the 1965 Voting Rights Act.

title: Music; A TIME TO HARVEST CONCERTS
description: ''THERE is something in October sets the gypsy blood astir,'' wrote the poet Bliss Carman, and the October music schedule in Westchester could well have the same result for music lovers. An extraordinary harvest of concerts lies ahead for county residents, some of which will be previewed in this and next week's columns.

title: Carolyn R. Potter Is Bride Of Bruce W. Hennemuth
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday, Carolyn Roxanne Potter of New York, daughter of Capt. Edward Hartman Potter Jr., U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Potter of Houston, was married to Bruce William Hennemuth of London, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Hennemuth of Martinsville, N.J. The Rev. Gerard DeSenso performed the ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: Irish Caravan To the Editor: I am familiar with the phenomenon of the Irish caravan as describedby Eric W. Jo hnson in ''An Irish Idyll by Caravan'' (Travel Section, Aug. 23). As a child growing up in Ireland such vehicles were synonymous wi th tinsmith or feather buyer. Nowadays the tinkers whizzby in late-mo del cars, and the folk who pioneer in Cork and Mayo are German touris ts: city types who do not know the front end of a horse from the back .

title: STEEL-SHOT SHELLS STILL HARD TO FIND
description: SINCE the advent, several years ago, of steel-shot regulations in various areas of the country, waterfowlers have often had difficulty in finding shotgun shells loaded with steel pellets.

title: CURATOR OF ANCIENT ART AT MET
description: Vaughn Emerson Crawford, a curator in charge of the department of ancient Near Eastern art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died Friday at the United Hospital of Port Chester, N.Y. Dr. Crawford, a resident of Larchmont, N.Y., was 64 years old.

title: ITALY'S 100 CITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: GIRLS' SOCCER TEAM ON WINNING STREAK
description: STORRS WHEN the 29-member Edwin O. Smith High School girls' soccer team arrived last Saturday in Simsbury, its players may have observed a painted white sheet hanging near the entrance to the Simsbury soccer field. ''Watch out. Your No. 1 spot is not secure in Simsbury,'' the sign warned.

title: Ideas & Trends; Vatican's Eye On Seminaries
description: The principle of central authority is one of the rocks on which the Roman Catholic Church has stood; but these days, the rock is often shaken by democratic urges, as reaction to a Vatican plan last week illustrated. The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States announced that, at the behest of Pope John Paul II, they would assist the Vatican in an investigation of American Catholic seminaries, and Catholic educators were quick to register their apprehension.

title: N.Y.U. IS ORDERED TO ACCEPT MEDICAL STUDENT
description: A Federal judge has ruled that New York University's medical school must accept a qualified student who has a history of serious psychiatric problems.

title: Debuts: Music in Review; Patricia Liston, Pianist, Plays Beethoven
description: Choice of repertory can make a difference for a pianist with certain well-defined technical and musical limitations, as Patricia Liston's debut recital demonstrated on Saturday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: LEADING U.S. JEWS TO EXPLORE PAINFUL HOLOCAUST QUESTIONS
description: A commission of leading Jews in American life has been formed, under the chairmanship of Arthur J. Goldberg, former Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, to inquire formally into some painful questions left over from World War II.

title: THE PSYCHOLOGY OF DEBT
description: If you're looking for the cause of our economic miseries, one place to look is in th e mirror. The Reagan Administration is being blamed in the Congres s for cutting the budgettoo much and on Wall Street for not cutting i t enough, but very little is being said about the acceptance of debt by the people themselves.

title: THE VILLAGE THAT NUTURED COOLIDGE
description: BETSY WITTEMANN is a writer who lives in Connecticut. By BETSY WITTEMANN

title: A SYBARITIC INTERLUDE
description: A DECADE ago we would have been among the most envied women in Fairfield County. This morning we are gathering over coffee in my sun room to see if together we can shed some light on our mutual dilemma. What's more, and perhaps it is the worst part of our affliction, nobody will feel sorry for us.

title: HIGH-TECH EQUIPMENT COMES OF AGE
description: Sometime in the late 1960's, as color was saturating television, stereophony was capturing FM radio and Marshall McLuhan was himself becoming a mass medium, interior designers began promoting the concept of a media room to house a growing network of electronic entertainment and communications equipment. The idea attracted some interest then, but not much of a following. Today, however, advances in technology are inducing more and more electronics aficionados to set aside a separate room for high-tech entertainment.

title: STING WINS IN SHOOTOUT
description: The Sting, which had finished second in the overall point-standing to the Cosmos in the regular season, succeeded in its first appearance in a Soccer Bowl game. The Cosmos failed for the first time in four.

title: VIOLIN: RUTH WATERMAN
description: Ruth Waterman, the violinist who gave a recital at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday night, made a good case for taking a new look at Bach's writing for solo violin by performing the Partita No. 2 in D minor with ornamentation and what were said to be original bowings. Players have been adding ornaments to Baroque keyboard works for decades, but few violinists have tried this sort of thing with their music.

title: G.B. SHAW AND THE WOMEN IN HIS LIFE AND
description: ART By MICHIKO KAKUTANI

title: ADORABILITY AND FEISTY POLISH MINER
description: The program notes for the 19th New York Film Festival describe Kazimierz Kutz's Polish film ''The Beads of One Rosary'' (''Paciorki Jednego Rozanca'') as a ''microcosmic portrait of an adorable old couple'' and, for once, the program notes are quite accurate. This rather protracted, sentimental movie spends most of its time relating the story of the fight of a retired coal miner to stay in his humble cottage instead of being moved into one of the high-rise apartment houses that are springing up all around him.

title: Television Week
description: Noteworthy Reunion

title: VARIEGATED TUCHMAN
description: PRACTICING HISTORY Selected Essays. By Barbara W. Tuchman. 306 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.50.

title: Dance View; AN AVANT-GARDE MIME IN THE GREAT 19TH-CENTURY TRADITION
description: Bill Irwin is an extremely funny fellow. Part mime, part clown, part vaudevillian, part eccentric hoofer, part silent-film comic, part avant-garde dancer, Mr. Irwin is what one would call a postmodern comedian. Well-known in San Francisco and having appeared in the movie ''Popeye,'' this 31-year-old fresh talent has just scored a sensation at Dance Theater Workshop's ''New Mime'' series in New York. It is perhaps understandable that an experimental dance sponsor, not a theater group, presented him. By conventional standards, Mr. Irwin is neither strictly a mime nor a dancer. Yet it is the dance world that has been most sympathetic to the variety of nonverbal theater cropping up in recent years. Deprived of intelligible syllables, the theater critic frequently experiences getting-the-back-up symptoms. Dance critics, of course, know that gesture preceded speech not only in the history of the theater but in the history of mankind. It might also be suggested that the rise in nonverbal performance confirms again the richness of expression which a literary theater does not always possess.

title: Captain of Iranian Freighter Is Seeking Asylum in Europe
description: The captain o f an Iranian freighter left his ship here and headed to northern Europe to seek political asylum, sayin g he feared he was on an Iranian Government blacklist, his crew said today.

title: CITIES GROUP MEMBERS WARN ON TRANSIT CUTS
description: Members of the National League of Cities, touring New York City's transit system yesterday, warned that reductions in Federal transportation aid could jeopardize the country's mass transit systems.

title: YOUNG OFFENDERS OFFERED ALTERNATIVES
description: RIVERHEAD IT was a Saturday night, and a group of teen-age boys wanted to get more beer. They had enough money to go to a store and buy some, but instead they broke into the storage facility of a grocery store and helped themselves. They were caught by the police.

title: NADER EXPANDING CONSUMER EFFORTS
description: Ralph Nader hopes the Reagan Administration will be his next Corvair. At a two-day conference here celebrating the 10th anniversary of his consumer organization, Mr. Nader expressed a desire that the Government's ''disastrous, anticonsumer policies'' will galvanize citizens to rebuild the stalled consumer movement, much as his 1965 book on the automobile industry, ''Unsafe at Any Speed,'' heated up consumer issues for a decade.

title: The Nation; Symbolic Gesture Of $12.50 a Day
description: In spite of arguments that the uniqueness of their case entitled them to special compensation, the Americans held hostage in Teheran were seen by a Presidential commission last week as similar to prisoners of war in World War II, Korea and Vietnam. The commission recommended that 51 former United States Embassy personnel each be paid a tax-exempt benefit of $5,550, or $12.50 for each day spent in captivity - a sum (adjusted for inflation) similar to that paid by the Federal Government to captured military men as a ''symbolic gesture'' recognizing hardships endured.

title: Most to See Only Few Dollars Each Week From 5% Tax Cut
description: The first stage of the biggest tax cut for individuals in history takes effect Thursday, but for most people the cut will be only a few dollars a week.

title: Peters Valley Group Affected
description: EIGHT private agencies hold special-use permits in the Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area that will be terminated. Among them is Peters Valley Craftsmen, a group that occupies a former Minisink Valley community that the Natio nal Park Service vacated morethan a decade ago.

title: No Headline
description: China's Kunming To the Editor: Truly, Richard F. Shepard provides eloquent testimony on behalf of ''The Varied Charms of the Kunning Area of China'' (Travel Section, Aug. 30). Of particular interest to me was the reciprocal procedure permitting to urists to perform in their own language after being entertained b y natives of Shi Lin Village.

title: JAZZ SOUNDS
description: HIGH TIMES HA RD TIMES By Anita O'Da y with George Eells. Illustrated. 349 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $14.95.

title: MISSISSIPPI ST. ROUTS FLORIDA
description: Michael Haddix scored two touchdowns today as Mississippi State stopped Florida's passing game for a 28-7 victory.

title: Man's Greatest Library
description: Archeology has many uses. With it trade routes are trace d, a peopleemerge, possession is justified. ''Mine,'' one can say, tu rning ruins into politics, ''because these stones prove my kinsm en precededyours.''

title: Fluoride Rinse Program Is Defended by Dentist
description: In a recent letter critical of the new Supertooth fluoride rinse program, Mrs. E.G. Koziar labels the plan a ''hoax'' because, according to her, there were no follow-up studies to substantiate the significant cavity-reducing effectiveness of the procedure. She is wrong.

title: CARE OF AUTISTIC IN NEW YORK CALLED DEFICIENT
description: A special state commission has charged that New York is failing to provide adequate and appropriate care to thousands of children suffering from autism.

title: Rules on Weddings Issued
description: Concerned over the state's 40 percent divorce rate, Roman Catholic Church officials have announced strict new rules on marriage. Beginning Jan. 1, Catholics in the five Florida dioceses must be at least 19 years old to marry in the church. Engaged couples will be required to take a formal, four-month marriage preparation program, and parish priests will have the authority to delay a wedding if they think a couple is not ready.

title: MAKING ROOM FOR THE MEDIUM
description: DESIGNBy Paul Goldberger Television and most other pieces of home electronics - from the telephone to the typewriter - have always been considered, at least by a certain stratum of society, to be functional items more than es thetic ones. They are viewed as practical t hings, necessities like the plumbing or the file cabinet where the bi lls are kept, not as items of pleasure or cultivation. Part of thi s, of course, is pure snobbery. While books have always been consid ered acceptable things to display, indeed even as objects around whi ch the design of an entire room might be based, television has be en dismissed for so longas a kind of popular, mass entertainment that it is no surprise that in certain circles it has thus far been deeme d unfitting for the public rooms of a house.

title: THEY GIVE MOVIES THAT SPECIAL 'LOOK'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Francis Levy specializes in covering the arts. By FRANCIS LEVY

title: Army Decides Not to Close Old Fort Near Salt Lake City
description: Ending a three-year controversy, the Army has decided to keep the 119-yea r-old Fort Douglas on active military stat us.

title: IS THERE A BROOKLYN CLUBHOUSE AFTER LIZ HOLTZMAN
description: Ever since it lost its separate identity when it merged with the rest of New York City in 1898, Brooklyn has shed one after another of its home grown institutions. The Dodgers went west, the Eagle newspaper went under.

title: The Region; Carey Loses, as Does Home Team
description: The South African Springboks, who hail from a country where an unexplained edict can make it a crime for siblings to speak to each other, last week found themselves the beneficiaries of free speech guarantees.

title: Around the World; Twin Nuclear Explosion Is Detected in Soviet
description: An unusual twin underground nuclear explosion took place in the Soviet Union today, Sweden's Seismological Institute here reported.

title: Beth Stephens Is Married
description: Beth Enea Stephens, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Dailey Stephens of Tuscaloosa, Ala., was married yesterday to H. R. Petersen Niehoff, son of Mrs. H. Richard Petersen Niehoff of Gahanna, Ohio, and the late Mr. Niehoff.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: 1725), the towering, dynamic force who changed Russia from a somewhat somnolent semi-Asiatic country into a formidable European power. Our reviewer Kyril Fitzlyo n called it ''an enthralling book, as fascinating as anynovel and mor e so than most. It is likely to become the standard biography in English for many years to come.''

title: NEW DISKS GREET HAYDN'S ANNIVERSARY
description: Record companies can scarcely run out of ways to celebrate Joseph Haydn's 250th anniversary - his output was simply too large and too consistently interesting. Philips offers three new releases - ''L'Infedelta Delusa'' (6769 061), the latest in its series of Haydn operas prepared by Antal Dorati; a group of arias sung by the soprano Edith Mathis (9500 929); and a two-record survey of Haydn's music for solo violin and orchestra with Salvatore Accordo playing the violin and conducting the English Chamber Orchestra (6769 059).

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1981
description: International Poland refused to give visas to American labor leaders who were invited by the Solidarity union to attend the second phase of its congress in Gdansk. Three representatives of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., including Lane Kirkland, the organization's president, had been invited. The Polish Government had previously protested the financial support given by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to Solidarity. (Page 1, Column 6.) An analysis of the Soviet military will be made public this week by the Reagan Administration to bolster its contention that Western security is facing an increasing threat from the Soviet Union. The Administration's portrayal of Soviet military power is contained in a 99-page booklet, illustrated with charts and photographs and drawings that is expected to be presented by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger in a news conference. (1:4.)

title: UTILITIES OPEN TO IDEA OF POWER AUTHORITY
description: NEWARK NEITHER the Jersey Central Power and Light Company nor the Public Service Electric and Gas Company reacted negatively last week to a recommendation by the state's Department of Energy that a regional power authority take over construction of Public Service's Hope Creek II nuclear generating plant in Lower Alloways Creek Township and switch its electricity capacity to the financially floundering Jersey Central.

title: The Nation; Fewer Berths for The Boat People
description: Fewer people are said to be fleeing the political and economic turmoil of Southeast Asia, but if the Administration has its way, that will not necessarily ease the competition among them to get into the United States.

title: Geraldine Cotronei a Bride
description: Geraldine Diane Cotronei, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Cotronei of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral to Joseph Peter Connors, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Connors of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Thomas Nielson performed the ceremony. The bride is a kidney transplant coordinator for the New York Regional Transplant Program at the New York Academy of Medicine. Mr. Connors, a lawyer, is a bond associate with the New York law firm of LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby & MacRae.

title: On Language; Geezer Power
description: A gang of curmudgeonaries has taken after me for using the term ''geezer.'' I wrote about the ''geezer power'' confronting anyone seeking to change the Social Security system, and the reaction would be illustrated by cartoonists with cane-shaking and ear-trumpetbrandishing.

title: SHIFT TO BLOCK GRANTS RAISING ISSUE OF STATES' COMPETENCE
description: The United States will embark Thursday on what could eventually be a major change in its government: the return of substantial authority from the Federal to the state level. But there is widespread disagreement across the nation over whether the states will be able to exercise their new powers in a manner acceptable to the American people.

title: Elizabeth Sargent Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Elizabeth McKean Sargent, advertising director for the Washington Journalism Review, to Richard Joseph Montaner, who is enrolled in the property management program at the American University, took place in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday. The Rev. Thomas Stiers of the First Congregational Church performed the ceremony at St. Bede's Chapel.

title: N.Y.R.A. Security Is Working Hard
description: To the Sports Editor: The New York Racing Association must vigorously protest the statement in Red Smith's column of Aug. 12 that it is reluctant to investigate the possibility of fixed races.

title: Former Venezuelan President Is Hospitalized in New York
description: Former President Romulo Betancourt of Venezuela entered Doctors Hospital yesterday after suffering a stroke, according to a hospital spokesman.

title: Sound; PUTTING NEW LIFE INTO OLD RECORDS
description: The roster of the phonograph - unlike that of any ''live'' concert series - is not confined to artists currently before the public. Many musicians long vanished from the world's stages have left on record traces of what, for all practical purposes, amounts to immortality. Interest in such historic performances seem s to have revived lately, and, particularly in Europe, record c ompanies are issuing retrospective collections of singers and inst rumentalists long gone. Some of these releases - available here on su ch import labels as EMI, Odeon, and Electrola - also commemorate the past of the great opera houses of Vienna, Dresden, Berlin and M ilan, reaching back intothe 20's to revive and document past glories. And in anticipation of its centennial, the Metropolitan Opera is now preparing to issue recorded memorabilia dating from the period o f 1901 to 1903, when, inthe dim beginnings of phonography, a pioneer recordist named Lionel Mapleson rigged a tin-horned Edison machine a bove the Met's stage to capture parts of actual performances.

title: Nabokov on Dostoyevsky
description: Your publication of Vladimir Nabokov's article was timely, coming just as I was ensconced in Mr. Nabokov's excellent ''Lectures on Literature'' (''Nabokov on Dostoyevsky,'' Aug. 23). Everything that he says may be true, but it was disappointing that he made no allusion to what has made Dostoyevsky's work endure: He created a world and was able to place a prism over the cornea of his reader's eye so that this world could be seen.

title: Susan Alexander Is Bride of Allen Daniel, Lawyer
description: Susan Germaine Alexander and Allen Joseph Daniel were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Shrine Church of St. Anthony of Padua. The Rev. Patrick Boyle performed the ceremony.

title: CITY COUNCIL FACES NEW COURT ATTACK
description: New York City's system of electing two City Council members at large from each borough is being challenged as unconstitutional in the latest action against the Council in the Federal courts.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Around the Nation; Migrants' Crew Leader Is Arrested by F.B .I.
description: A crew leader for migrant laborers has been charged with conspiring to keep workers in involuntary servitude in eastern North Carolina, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: THE PEOPLE CAN'T AFFORD 'REAGANOMICS'
description: T o the Editor: James Resto n wonders whether the ''solidarity'' in Solidarity Day is ''for the unions or for the union of the nation'' as if these were two very different things, but his column (Sept. 20) should really have been headed ''My President, Right or Wrong.'' A number ofpoints must be made in response.

title: Susan Donna Best Married to Michael B. Greene
description: At the Norfield Congregational Church in Weston, Conn., yesterday, Susan Donna Best, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Jackson Best of Weston, was married to Michael Bernard Greene, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard M. Greene of Islip, L.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Edward A. Bernald, assisted by the Rev. T. Peter Ryan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Arizona Peonage
description: When he discovered the theft of $3,000 in tools from his ranch near Tucson, Walter M. Burris Jr. chained a ranch hand, Manuel Hernandez Garcia, in a bunkhouse and said he would keep him there until he confessed. A day later, according to court testimony, Mr. Burris freed Mr. Hernandez with an apology; someone else was the thief.

title: Sinatra-Pavarotti Bill To Aid Sloan-Kettering
description: Frank Sinatra and Luciano Pavarotti with perform in concert for the benefit of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center on Jan. 24 at Radio City Music Hall.

title: Soviet Press Publicizes Another Polish Appeal
description: The Soviet press agency Tass gave prominence today to a statement by Polish hard-liners demanding a ''resolute rebuff'' to what were described as the independent labor union's counterrevolutionary actions.

title: State and City to Match All-Saver Exemptions
description: New York State's Commissioner of Taxation and Finance said yesterday that the tax exemptions offered by the Federal Government on savings certificates beginning Oct. 1 w oul d be matched by the state and city.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: THE VOYAGE OF THE ARMADA The Spanish Story. By David Howarth. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: Shelley Rea Has Bridal
description: At St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church yesterday, Shelley Stevens Rea, daughter of Mrs. Wilton Treat Rea of New York and the late Mr. Rea, was married to Thomas Strong Gilbert of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Abner I. Gilbert of La Jolla, Calif. The Rev. Thomas D. Bowers performed the ceremony.

title: PURDUE SETS BACK NOTRE DAME
description: Scott Campbell completed a fourth-down, 7-yard touchdown pass to Steve Bryant with 19 seconds left in the game, then hit Bryant with a 2-point conversion pass to give Purdue a 15-14 upset of Notre Dame today.

title: Victoria M. Bartlett Is Wed
description: The marriage of Victoria M. Bartlett to Barry G. Donaldson, son of Col. William R. Donaldson, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Donaldson of Hanover, N.H., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis T. Preston, stepfather and mother of the bride, in Mount Kisco, N.Y. The Rev. Arthur Hargate performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: SCREEN: 'GRADUATE FIRST,' BORED FRENCH YOUTHS
description: On the evidence of his 1980 ''Loulou'' and now his 1979 ''Passe Ton Bac d'Abord,'' Maurice Pialat is more of an observer than a storyteller, with a particular interest in the way bored, pouty, voluptuous young people move around. His camera watches the way they walk, talk, dress, intermingle and shake their hair out of their eyes, but it never draws close to the characters it studies. The resulting aimlessness, prevalent enough in ''Loulou,'' is even more pronounced in the present film, which will be shown today at 2 P.M. as part of the New York Film Festival.

title: Future Events; Fashion a Popular Ploy
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Mixed Media Oct. 1 - Silver celebration to benefit the American Craft Museum starts with a reception and preview of ''Beyond Tradition,'' a retrospective of 20th-century crafts, at the museum, then moves on to the Tower Suite for dinner and an auction of master-works by 15 craftsmen. Included will be a rocking chair by Sam Maloof, a table by Wendell Castle and a weather vane by L. Brent Kington, as well as jewelry, glass, pottery and wearables. The auctioneer will be George Plimpton. Proceeds will be used to expand programs at the museum, which opened 25 years ago as the Museum of Contemporary Crafts. Tickets $150 from 397-0610.

title: HAMPTONS PRICES STRENGTHENING MONTAUK'S PULL
description: The man who turned a mangrove swamp into Miami Beach in the 1920's also had grand dreads for the tip of Long Island. But his fortune was wiped out after he had finished only three buildings here, and until recently no one else was tempted to pick up where forclosures forced him to leave off.

title: Long Island Journal
description: MINDFUL of the village's history back to the Revolution, the board of trustees of Lawrence has commissioned the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities to conduct a historical inventory of all village buildings built before 1940. The survey will cost $6,000.

title: Film View; RECYCLING BOOKS INTO MOVIES
description: Why take a piece of literature, especially a novel, one that is successful in its original form and that explores regions of the mind not easily penetrated by a 35 millimeter motion-picture camera, and attempt to turn it into a movie that can reproduce only that part of the narrative that can be related through an association of moving images? One answer is money, which comes as no surprise to those o f us who have c ringed through bowdlerized screen versions of everythingfrom the Bibl e to ''War and Peace,'' ''Ulysses,'' ''An American Tragedy,'' '' Decline and Fall'' and ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof.'' As faras I know, '' Tristram Shandy'' has remained unmolested.

title: SENATE APPOINTMENT: A DEAD END
description: SPECULATION about the likely successor to Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. now shares New Jersey's political center stage with the gubernatorial election.

title: Miss Faunce Is Betrothed To a Writer
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George Faunce 3d of Rye, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Rebecca Winslow Faunce, to Thomas Welstead McDermott, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald E. McDermott of New Canaan, Conn.

title: TIME-SHARE RESORT INDUSTRY EXPERIENCING GROWTH PAINS
description: Time-sharing, the new rage in vacation real estate, has attracted thousands of satisfied customers across the country. But left strand ed on the beaches and slopes are some unhappy buyers, who in the worst cases, lost all their money.

title: FURTHER ADVENTURES OF A LOSER
description: REINHART'S WOMEN By Thomas Berger. 295 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $13.95.

title: AN UNCONVENTIONAL SHOWCASE FOR COMPOSERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- John Gruen writes frequently about music and dance. His latest book, ''The World's Great Ballets,'' will be published next month by Harry N. Abrams. By JOHN GRUEN

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE This is the week to catch up on the modernists. Pauline de Groot, a Dutch choreographer about whom advance word has been intriguing, and Sincha Hong, a Korean choreographer of strong presence and simplicity, will get back to essentials in concerts, respectively, Tuesday through Thursday at the Merce Cunningham Dance Studio and Wednesday through next Sunday at La Mama ETC.

title: Personal Finance; WRITING YOUR OWN PAYCHECK
description: T HERE is probably nothing so aggravating to a successful entrepreneur as discovering that he cannot withdraw as much of the profits of his business as he would like without running afoul of the tax laws. Even though the new tax act will ease some of the restrictions, there nonetheless remains a thicket of regulations that make careful compensation planning a necessity for the owner of a small incorporated business. Sole proprietors and partners generally do not face the same problems, nor do executives of publicly held companies.

title: DELBELLO CALLS JAIL UPRISING REPORT 'DISTORTED'
description: A State Senate report critical of Westchester County's handling of an uprising in its County Jail last July drew an angry response from County Executive Alfred B. DelBello.

title: Around the Nation; Typhoid Fever Cases Up To 24 in San Antonio
description: The number of confirmed typhoid fever cases in San Antonio increased to 24 yesterday and a team of experts worked to find the fever's source, health officials said.

title: No Headline
description: Domiciles - especially the grand, the ancient, or the eccentric - hold a powerful attraction for travelers and historians alike. It is easy to understand why; more than any other remnants of the past, they reflect a highly personal image of how life was conducted on a daily, ongoing basis.

title: Economic Affairs; WHEN NOTHING WORKS, DO NOTHING
description: W HEN a complicated economic program promises all things good and bad, it is time to stop and get a fresh perspective. Reagan economics is supposed to eliminate the business cycle and restore high rates of economic growth. But its critics on the left say that it does so by first slowing down the economy so much that we risk a major recession, while those on the right warn that its budget deficits lead to high inflation.

title: U.C.L.A.  Is Upset By Iowa
description: Tom Nichol kicked two field goals and Mark Bortz recovered a fumble in the end zone for a touchdown to lift the Hawkeyes to a 20-7 upset of U.C.L.A. today.

title: Perez's Running Leads Pleasantville Past Hamilton, 32-2
description: Pleasantville High School, behind the running of Jim Perez, overwhelmed Alexander Hamilton, 32-2, in its opener yesterday. Perez, a senior fullback, rushed 30 times for 163 yards and three touchdowns.

title: QUEENS COLLEGE STARTS POSTGRADUATE JOB PLAN
description: Graduate students in the liberal arts, usually the most difficult to place in today's job market, will be the focus of a new program at Queens College designed to provide them with employment experience related to their academic fields.

title: North Rockland Triumphs
description: In a battle of undefeated teams, North Rockland, a third -place finisher last year, uprooted defending champion Clarkstown South, 10-6.

title: Elizabeth Wing Bride Of Nathan S. Newman
description: Elizabeth Garnett Wing, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Wing of Oxford, Ohio, was married yesterday to Nathan Scott Newman, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Newman of New York. Judge John B. Connaughton Jr., of the Butler County Area I Court in Ohio, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: The Region; Challenger Gets Rematch Against Hartford Mayor
description: Having failed, just barely, to upset Hartford Mayor George A. Athanson in t he Democratic primary, State Representative Thirman L. Milner last w eek did the next closest thing: He upset the primary itself.

title: ERIC MONEY TRIES COMEBACK
description: The dream of making it back to the National Basketball Association never ends for some.

title: L. L. Bright, Miss Dennis Are Married
description: Dianna Robin Dennis, daughter of Anne Pyle Dennis of Keene Valley, N.Y., and Thomas Gordon Dennis of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Lawrence Lowell Bright, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Bright of Islesford, Me. The Rev. David McAlpin Pyle, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony a t St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N.J.

title: REGENTS SET A DROPOUT LIMIT FOR HIGH SCHOOL
description: The State Board of Regents approved a proposal yesterday requiring that the state's approximately 1,200 public and private high schools limit their dropout rates to 10 percent or less.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN MELBOURNE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- ANDREW POTTER is a radio and TV reporter in Melbourne. By ANDREW POTTER

title: Gail Gillsepie Fiancee of Michael Garcia
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gillespie 3d of Harrison, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Gail Gillespie, to Michael V. Garcia, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Joseph Garcia of Mount Vernon, Me.

title: Investing; ORION: A LOOK AT AN ASSET PLAY
description: S PECULATORS who like stocks with rising earnings and a rising price trend - of which there have been precious few this summer -share a familiar problem: how to get in ahead of the crowd. There is another breed of player, however, that rarely has to worry about that.

title: >zf Gardening; THE NEW SEASON IS A FINE TIME TO PLANT
description: A FRIEND recently declared his front lawn to be a disaster and wondered why he could not plant the entire lawn to ground cover as they do in California. The answer, of course, is that he can. While such lawns are uncommon in this part of the country, one does occasionally come across a front lawn of pachysandra or English ivy. When accompanied by a brick or flagstone path so that passage to the front door or the backyard is possible without trampling the planting, they are perfectly acceptable.

title: Art; SOL LEWITT AND THE WALLS OF WADSWORTH ATHENEUM
description: HARTFORD DESPITE its early support of modernist art and its continuing commitment to it, the Wadsworth Atheneum has a reputation for being a conservative, even slightly stodgy institution. Its present exhibition of modern art should correct that misconception. Entitled ''Sol LeWitt Wall Drawings: 1968-1981,'' it contains a great many works that are stunning in their beauty, and not one that fails to fascinate.

title: TWO IMMORTALS FEATURED ON NEW SPORTS SERIES
description: Two of the reigning athletes of the 20th century, Bobby Jones, master golfer, and Babe Didrikson Zaharias, woman athlete nonpareil, have been accorded philatelic tribute by the United States on two newly-issued commemoratives. The stamps launch a new series honoring famous American sports figures.

title: CHILDREN'S WEEKLY READER IS NEWS FOR MILLIONS
description: IN March, news that the President had been shot sent hundreds of reporters into action and raised the normally frantic pace of newsrooms around the country to a fever pitch.

title: China's Army Is Conducting Major Exercises Near Peking
description: The Chinese Army, backed by tanks and planes, is conducting large-scale maneuvers, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: zf WHEN A RELATIVE GOES INTO P RISON
description: ERIKA'S round, pretty face is anxious, and she looks as though she might burst into tears any minute. Her life came apart one night last October when the police appeared at her door at two o'clock in the morning to arrest her husband. ''Thank God, the children were asleep when it happened, at least they didn't have to see the police taking him away, but it was almost worse the next day trying to explain to them why Daddy wasn't home.''

title: Gregorek, Marquette Cross-Country Winners
description: John Gregorek of Georgetown took individual honors and Marquette successfully defended its team championship by placing two runners among the top three yesterday in the National Catholic Cross Country meet.

title: ZIMBABWE IMPORTS INDIAN CRAFTSMEN
description: Victor Gurubatham, an experienced diesel mechanic from the south Indian state of Tamil Nadu, was issued his tools on Tuesday in the locomotive workshop of the National Railways of Zimbabwe.

title: Army Beats Brown
description: Having lost its four previous games, including two this season, Army's football team turned to Brown of the Ivy League today for some respite. The Cadets gained a narrow 23-17 victory over the Bruins, who more than matched them in yards gained but fumbled away their chances to win.

title: IT'S D-DAY FOR THE THRIFTY
description: ONLY four days to go. Anticipation mounts. Confusion abounds. To save or not to save? Come Thursday morning, savers one and all - accountants and artists, brokers and bakers, record company executives and race car drivers, bellhops and beauty parlor magnates - can trudge over to their neighborhood bank and plunk a bit of the fruit of their labors into the first-ever, one and only All Savers certificates.

title: Bay Shore Romps
description: Brian Williams scored four touchdowns and a 2-point conversion to lead Bay Shore to a 34-6 victory over Kings Park in a non-league opener for both teams.

title: Anne L. Harper, Buyer, Married
description: Anne Lynn Harper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Harper of Ridgewood, N.J., was married there yesterday to Jonathan Scott Schlieman, son of Joan McLeod Stephens of Bronxville, N.Y., and John W. Schlieman of Miami. The Rev. Richard B. Anderson performed the ceremony at St. Elizabeth's Episcopal Church.

title: Business Conditions; A RECESSION HOLDOUT
description: While many of the usual harbingers of a recession are falling into place -negative economic growth, high interest rates and sagging stock prices -one key ingredient is missing.

title: IF YOU BAN A BOOK
description: Are you distressed by the kinds of books and periodicals in your public schools and libraries? Ever tempted to do something about it? Consider this.

title: BALLET SEASON OPENS
description: NEW HAVEN ''LET'S go from five, six, seven, eight, nine down 10,'' Robert Vickrey, artistic director of the Connecticut Ballet, called, slipping out of his canvas chair to interrupt the rehearsal of the company's new full-length production of Dauberval's ''La Fille Mal Gardee'' in its Chapel Street studios.

title: Greenwich Trounces Rippowam
description: Four teams have firmly established themselves as contenders for divisional titles in the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference after two weeks of play.

title: MAREE RUNS 3:$47.52, WINS 5TH AVE. MILE
description: Fifth Avenue became Sydney Maree's showcase yesterday en route to the second fastest mile ever run -3 minutes 47.52 seconds. Ten other runners also finished in under four minutes as an enthusiastic crowd estimated by the police at between 100,000 and 150,000 formed a human funnel from 82d Street to 62d Street. But it was Maree, now a permanent United States resident, who concluded a brilliant first season of international competition, after having been banned in the past as a South African.

title: Music; MUSICAL HARVEST AHEAD
description: ''THERE is something in October that sets the gypsy blood astir'' wrote the poet Bliss Carman, and the October musical schedule in Connecticut may well have the same result for music lovers. What an extraordinary harvest of concerts lies ahead.

title: Politics; ROME IN NEW CAMPAIGN
description: LAST spring, after Lewis B. Rome let it be known that he did not plan to seek the Republican nomination for Governor next year, at least one of his law partners sensed that something was bothering the 48-year-old Bloomfield lawyer.

title: NEW BEETHOVEN DISKS ANSWER QUESTI ONS OF STYLE
description: The idea of a performance tradition - a favored style of interpretation passed from the composer through his disciples down to the present day - might seem tangible enough.
