But as several recently released and reissued recordings of Beethoven's piano sonatas and concertos suggest, that tradition is by no means straightforward or simple.

title: Evidence of Need For Preservation Unit
description: In Anthony Brandt's Sept. 6 article ''Preservation vs. Property Rights in One Small Place,'' he mentions that his old house was across the street from the public library in Shrub Oak.

title: NEW UTILITY PROPOSAL AWAITS FINAL STEPS
description: THE long and winding road that the county has been following toward a public power agency, one that would replace Consolidated Edison as the supplier of electricity and provide savings to consumers, takes what could be a final turn tomorrow at the semimonthly meeting of the Board of Legislators.

title: Crime
description: In about a half-dozen procedurals since 1976, the British author J ack S. Scott has been writing about the ups and downs of a detectivenamed Alfred Stanley Rosher. An experienced cop, Rosher is also a loner with a nasty disposition. He is unappetizing to look at and listen to, an d has a positive genius for screwing up a case. Give himroutine work and he is great. Set him to getting stuff out of an informer, and this sadistic, ex-heavyweight champion of the British constabulary will scare a demon in hell. But in a case that demands imagination, thought or intuition, well ...

title: YALE RALLIES TO DEFEAT UCONN
description: Rich Diana scored two touchdowns and rushed 140 yards on 26 carries today to lead Yale to a 27-18 victory over Connecticut. It was the Elis' eighth straight victory in the intrastate rivalry.

title: Sunday Observer; Love Me, Love My Bear
description: I have never been able to fire anybody and, as a result, promotions have always passed me by. This is why I sought out George Steinbrenner, the owner of the New York Yankees and probably the most successful firer in the annals of unemployment.

title: A SOPRANO TALKS OF HER MANY ROLES
description: FAIR LAWN IT WAS a st ultifying day, but Marisa Galvany was oblivious of the late-summer w eather. The living-room shades were drawn and an airconditione r whirred in the background as she talked with a visitorat her home h ere.

title: W. J. Melley 3d Weds Miss Tracy
description: Patrice Tracy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard B. Tracy of New Canaan, Conn., and William J. Melley 3d, son of Rita M. Melley of Windsor, Conn., and the late William J. Melley Jr., were married yesterday. The Rev. James P. Haggarty, the Rev. John J. Mur phy and the Rev. Lawr ence J. Bock performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholi c Church in Darien, Conn.

title: FOR RENT: NOMADIC ENGINEER (EXPENSIVE)
description: PHILADELPHIA OFF the top of his head, John Reider cannot recount the number of states in which he has worked as an electrical engineer. ''Somewhere between 12 and 15,'' estimates Mr. Reider, who is now in Denver at the Martin Marietta Corporation, designing electromechanical packaging for the MX missile's ground-support equipment.

title: TOP-LEVEL INQUIRY ORDERED FOR 20TH PRECINCT
description: The New York City Police Commissioner, in an unusual move, has directed the department's highest uniformed official and three socalled ''superchiefs'' to look into the recent breakdown of supervision at a Manhattan precinct where four officers were arrested last June on charges they took payments from an undercover agent posing as a cocaine dealer.

title: BRISTOL WASTE PLANT SOON TO BE 'WORST'
description: BRISTOL THE 32-year-old East Bristol sewage plant, which has been known to add pollution to the Pequabuck River, has gained a new lea se on life,to the dismay of many in this town of 55,000.

title: INFRARED PHOTOGRAPHY
description: ------------------------------- ------------------------------------- Jack Manning is a photographer on the staff of this newspaper, and the author of several books on photography.

title: SONS AND DAUGHTERS FEEL FEDERAL AID
description: In two unchangeably remote hollows of Appalachia, members of two mountain families interviewed in the mid-1960's and again in 1970 said recently that the recovery program mounted by the Appalachian Regional Commission had barely touched their lives. But slowly, if not grudgingly, they acknowledged that it might have helped their children.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: THE Moral Majority isn't the voice of the clerical majority, says the Bergen County Committee for Religious Tolerance, a coalition of clergymen opposing the Rev. Jerry Falwell's group. The committee held its first major conference at the First Presbyterian Church in Teaneck last Wednesday.

title: BURMA'S CHIEF TO GIVE UP JOB, BUT NOT POWER
description: A presidency that has endured for nearly two decades is to come to an end before the end of the year, but no one in the subdued and dilapidated capital of this country of 34 million people appears to expect any change in the life of Burma.

title: Dining Out; CLASSIC FRENCH, FINELY APPOINTED
description: CELEBRATING the completion of its fourth year of operation, Bistro 22 in Bedford Village is, surely, one of the better restaurants in the area. Housed in a cheerful roadside cottage, the dark-paneled dining room and charming bar have an inviting rec-room quality augmented by Mediterranean-style chairs. The dark wood makes a dramatic backdrop for the glowing table appointments - white linen, tall white candles, fresh daisies - and the provincial motif imparted by the draperies, paintings and wall ornaments.

title: Other Business; BORDEN CHEESE: IT COULD MAKE A COW CRY
description: A smiling Elsie will still grace the containers of its dairy products, but she really ought to wince. Borden Inc. has taken much of the milk out of its cheese. On Friday, the company discontinued packaging natural cheese for retail sale and began a $2 million advertising campaign for two new imitation cheeses, Country Meadow and CheeseTwin.

title: MARCOS AIMS A NEW AID PROGRAM AT THE POOR
description: The letters KKK are everywhere this week in Philippine newspapers, on brochures, over television. They are the initials of a new social development program being undertaken by President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Home Clinic; IT'S SIMPLE TO BUILD A RETAINING WALL
description: AHOMEOWNER faced with drainage problems because his house was originally bu ilt on sloping ground that was improperly graded, or because his n eighbor has added a raised driveway or elevated patio that now shed s water onto his property during every heavy rain, will often find th at the simplest solution to his problem is to do some minor regradi ng in order to create a ''split-level'' landscape. He can then buil d a low retaining wall to separate the two grade levels and hold the higher ground in place.

title: The Region; No Immunity, No Education
description: New York City's public school teachers, usually trying desperately to keep students in school, were barring tens of thousands of youngsters from class last week. The reason: The students had failed to satifsy the state's new regulations requiring proof of immunity against five childhood diseases.

title: THE BUSINESS OF MINDING THE GORERNMENT'S BUSINESS
description: HARTFORD FROM its Spartan office on Lewis Street, now surrounded by some of Hartford's largest office towers, the Connecticut Public Expenditure Council has been dispensing unsolicited advice since 1942.

title: A STEADY JOBLESS RATE
description: While recent upticks in initial unemployment claims could signal worse times ahead, high interest rates and economic sluggis hness havenot yet had m uch impact on the jobless rate, which has remained steady at aro und 7 percent throughout the year.

title: Dr. Sylvan M. Edmonds Dies; Retired Chemistry Professor
description: Dr. Sylvan M. Edmonds, professor emeritus of chemistry at City College of New York, died of a heart attack Friday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco. Dr. Edmonds, who was 72 years old, and his wife had been traveling to their home in Leonia, N.J., when he was taken ill.

title: SOVIET FEARS FOR EMPIRE IN POLISH CRISIS
description: MOSCOW WILL they or won't they? When Soviet tanks sat idling on Poland's borders in March and did not go in, and when Moscow brooded through the summer while its strictures to the Polish leadership went largely unfulfilled, Kremlin watchers here began to think that the Soviet rulers, for all their tough talk, were reconciled to some degree of political relaxation in their western neighbor. But developments of the past month - the first phase of the Solidarity congress and Moscow's harsh reaction to it - have created new apprehension. Not since digging out of the rubble of World War II and establishing their domain half across Europe, have Soviet leaders faced a situation so threatening to their power, and one fraught with such unpromising consequences whichever way they turn. As the second phase of the Solidarity congress began this weekend, the consensus among Western diplomats in Moscow was that the prospects for the Poles were as dark as they have been at any time since Solidarity's rise a year ago.

title: Carole Wellington a Bride
description: Carole Wellington, daughter of John Wellington of New York and the late Nancy Holmes Wellington, was married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University to Ralph Damone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Damone of East Islip, L.I. The Rev. Eugene Laubach of the Riverside Church performed the Protestant ceremony. The bride is an admissions counselor at Ithaca College, from which she and her husband were graduated.

title: SCHOLAR STILL FIGHTING HARVARD TENURE DENIAL
description: Six years ago, the case of Ephraim Isaac, an Ethiopian scholar who was denied tenure in Harvard University's fledgling Afro-American Studies Department, was a rallying call for students who protested that the university was not firmly committed to black studies.

title: U.S. COOPERATION WITH THE THIRD WORLD
description: The United States sells more goods to developing countries than to Western Europe and Japan combined. Third-world markets are growing faster than those in any other countries, and recently the Administration called for a new approach to third-world development, cutting back direct aid - grants and soft loans -while increasing trade and private investment. But if America is to maintain and expand exports to developing counties, we need to be more sensitive to their economic problems and to our relations with them. We should begin by recognizing the movement, encouraged by the United Nations, known as ''technical and economic cooperation among developing countries.''

title: OCEAN STUDY SHOWS EXTENT OF POLLUTION
description: LONG investigation to determine for the first time the true health of the North Atlantic has revealed that toxic contaminants from New Jersey's offshore waste-dumping operations, as well as pollutants heading seaward from the state's rivers and streams, are being found farther out at sea and in greater quantities than expected.

title: Westchester Guide; B y Eleanor Charles; JANE PFEIFFER TO SPEAK
description: Jane Cahill Pfeiffer, whose brief tenure as chairman of the board of the National Broadcasting Company was terminated during a toplevel shakeup, will speak at a Conference for Business Women Oct. 14 at the White Plains Y.W.C.A., 515 North Street.

title: ENTER THE COMPUTER
description: Myron Berger is a freelance writer who specializes in computers and other electronics subjects. By Myron Berger ffices, banks, airport terminals, schools, supermarkets and even corner candy stores have all opened their doors to the proletarian of the late 20th century: the computer. Now, it is the home that will put this intricate amalgam of silicon and copper to work in a way that appears destined to alter the fundamental interrelation between the home and its inhabitants.

title: Justice Agency Closes Sex Inquiry on Lobbyist
description: A Justice Department investigation involving a lobbyist, Paula Parkinson, has uncovered no evidence that any member of Congress exchanged votes for sexual favors or other inducements, the department has disclosed. Assistant Attorney General D. Lowell Jensen , head of the department's criminal division, sent a letter last week to Representativ Philip M. Crane, Republican of Illinois, informing him that an investigation of charges involving Mrs. Parkinson had been closed.

title: A HOME FOR WILDLIFE, TOO
description: STONY BROOK THE attractive ranch-style home jointly owned by Doretta Dick, a professor at the School of Nursing at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, and Colette Oldmixon, a professor of English at Suffolk Community College, is unobtrusive in a quiet, well-kept neighborhood northwest of Stony Brook's train station. But the backyard is crowded with visitors year round - and large quantities of food and drink are offered there daily, free of charge.

title: Debuts: Music in Review; Guitarist and Soprano Perform Joint Recital
description: John Marsh Bigelow, a guitarist and lutist, and Lorraine Hope Saltre, a soprano, gave a joint c oncert Tuesday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall. It was a venture that might have profitably been postponed for several years.

title: Music View; HOW MUCH AUTHENTICITY IS ENOUGH?
description: Suppose you saw a man walking down the street dressed in the latest urban-cowboy, lean-jeans fashion, except that he was not wearing boots or even jogging shoes but 18th-century silver-buckled dancing pumps. You might not pause to ponder what statement that person was trying to make about himself, clothing styles or the human condition, but at least you would notice his taste for the incongruous. It would certainly surprise both him and you if someone were to suggest that his eclectic getup represented a sensible solution to the eternal problem of wh at to put on in the morning.

title: DAYAN ON PEACE
description: BREAKTHROUGH A Personal Account of the Egypt-Israel Peace Negotiations. Illustrated with maps. 368 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY POLITICS: DO AS LITTLE AS POSSIBLE
description: Since Social Security was established 45 years ago, successive Congresses and Presidents have periodically been forced to reassure the system's retired but far from retiring beneficiaries that their Federal old age pensions were not in peril.

title: PATERSON BUILDING CABLE TV
description: PATERSON LATE last March, Paterson was widely praised when it became the first city in New Jersey to own and operate a hydroelectric dam and sell the power it produced. Now this old industrial city of 138,000 is taking the idea of public ownership one step further by building its own cable-television sys tem.

title: FOOD-STAMP CUTS ATTACKED BY CAROL BELLAMY
description: Cuts in the food stamp program by the Reagan Administration ''reflect how double-digit inflation has robbed us of compassion as well as our standard of living,'' Carol Bellamy, New York City's Council President, has charged in a scholarly publication here.

title: The Nation; A Bid to Insure Secret Agents Stay That Way
description: Though many would consider the disclosure of a secret agent's identity a crime, efforts to make it one have yet to succeed. But last week the House approved a bill that would send those convicted of betraying an operative to prison for up to 10 years, and passage of a similar measure in the Senate is considered likely.

title: DOBBS FERRY GETS FINANCING FOR NEW HOSPITAL
description: A new hospital for this Westchester County village, which has been a local dream for 10 years, has come one step closer to reality with the commitment of $5.5 million in financing.

title: A NEW PRESS MAKES WAVES WITH A FIRST NOVEL
description: PRINCETON THE California-style house overlooking an acre of woods, complete with pond, ducks and deer, bears little resemblance to anyone's picture of a publishing company's headquarters. However, fo r Raymond Smith and his wife - the novelist Joyce Carol Oates - who l ive here, it houses a press of their own, something theyhave dreamed about for years.

title: STEEL TURNED BRITTLE BY RADIATION CALLED A PERIL AT 13 NUCLEAR PLANTS
description: The thick steel shells of the Connecticut Yankee nuclear reactor and 12 other reactors around the country are being turned brittle by radiation so rapidly, nuclear regulatory officials say, that some of the plants may become unsafe to operate by the end of next year.

title: THE WILD FLOWERS OF AUTUMN'S FIELDS CAN BE TAMED
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Patricia Hubbell is a writer who specializes in growing wild flowers. By PATRICIA HUBBELL

title: Editors' Choices
description: Seven by the Irish master. THE GEOGRAPHY OF THE IMAGINATION. By Guy Davenport.

title: A JEWISH VIEW ON ETIQUETTE
description: Twenty-five years ago a rabbi friend about to be married asked Helen Latner to help him find a wedding invitation that would include a Hebrew text. ''I searched and searched, but I could not find any Fifth Avenue stationer willing to provide it, nor could I find a single book that described how to set up such an invitation,'' she recalled. Ultimately she convinced a department store to order the invitations and, in the process, she formulated the concept for ''The Book of Modern Jewish Etiquette'' (Schocken Books, $19.95).

title: Pamela S. Brown Married to Actor
description: Pamela Suzanne Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Douglas Brown of Quaker Hill, Pawling N.Y., was married there yesterday in Christ Community Church to Anthony William Sherer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert William Sherer of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Gordon Powell performed the ceremony.

title: The Region; An Indian Deal On Equal Terms
description: The Seneca Nation last week completed a swap of prime reservation land for a piece of New York State property that one tribal leader dismissed as ''a steep hillside,'' but most Senecas felt they had come out ahead on principle. For the first time since the early 1800's, they had successfully negotiated with the state as equal sovereigns.

title: THE HARE HAS A CHANCE IN JERSEY RACE
description: Though New Jersey's gubernatorial campaign is barely underway, it is already showing a decidedly Aesopian character.Representative James J. Florio of Runnemede, the Democratic candidate, has so far seemed content to play the tortoise, letting Thomas H. Kean, his Republican rival, play the hare. And while Mr. Florio is generally regarded as the favorite at the moment, some political obversers have begun to wonder whether the campaign will end as the fable did.

title: FEMALE ALCOHOLICS AND BASIC TRAINEES
description: Of the two fine documentaries on tod ay's ag enda at the New York Film Festival, Bonnie Friedman's ''The Last t o Know'' is the briefer and more straightforward. Miss Friedman's sub ject is the female alcoholic, and she approaches it from a sympa thetic, personalized viewpoint by interviewing four women of varyi ng backgrounds.

title: No Headline
description: What point could Nabokov have been trying to make by his sarcastic remark that Dostoyevsky, after undergoing four years of hard labor in Siberia and then being subjected to a mock execution, ''never got over it''? Surely, one must write from one's experience; there is no denying the identification with the alienated and the outast in Dostoyevsky's work. How does this discredit the depth and understanding with which he wrote about these experiences, arguably for the first time in literature?

title: RENEWING THE SPIRIT OF ROMANCE
description: Near right: Triple-tiered, handpainted silk taffeta dress. By Fabrice. $700. By special order at Saks Fifth Avenue. Lina Lee, Beverly Hills.

title: Robin Peake Bride of Alexander Stuart
description: The marriage of Ann Robinson Peake, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Wainwright Peake of Houston, to Alexander Douglas Stuart, an associate editor with Fortune magazine in charge of the Houson bureau, took place in Lake Forest, Ill., yesterday. The Rev. Herbert Anderson performed the Presbyterian ceremony at Topsfield Farm, home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Stuart Jr.

title: ART AUCTIONS: 'HALF THEATER, HALF CASINO'
description: Art auctions today command the largest following and the highest prices in history. From New York to Hong Kong the gaveling goes at an ever faster rate for virtually everything people collect. And, increasingly, collectors, dealers and institutions are taking the auction route to buy and sell precious wares. Why? The excitement generated in auction rooms in this country has proved contagious. It started more than a decade ago with, among other things, the sale of the first diamond that went for more than $1 million - the diamond that was eventually Eizabeth Taylor's.

title: M.I.T. Wants Closer Ties with Business
description: There are s igns on all sides that industry's involvement in university re search is growing. With this growth has come a spate of articles expr essing interest, raising questions, voicing concern.

title: Art; WHERE LARGENESS IS A DOMINANT FUNCTION
description: HEMPSTEAD BELIEVING that their art will not be noticed unless it is bigger, many contemporary artists have markedly increased the dimensions of their work. But big is not necessarily better. Most of the big works we have seen recently overwhelm only by magnitude and by little else. Once we've dismissed the sensationalism, we do not find sufficient substance or incident to warrant this kind of megalomania. Both Richard Pugliese and David Jacobs, whose works are on view at Hofstra University's Emily Lowe Gallery, may have their share of ego and need for recognition too, but their approach to big art is much more persuasive than is now usually seen. They use largeness to attract our attention as well as to keep it. Their art functions most effectively in big sizes, bols tered by an authority ofstyle and visual strength.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Spruce Goose
description: As an operable aircraft, the Spruce Goose was a turkey. Conceived by Howard Hughes in 1942 as a World War II transport that would carry 700 soldiers, the eight-engine wooden seaplane flew but once: a hop over water in 1947 that was only slightly higher and longer than an early Wright Brothers flight.

title: AGENT SAYS SPY SUSPECT TOLD OF SECRETS
description: Testifying as though reading from a spy thriller, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that Joseph G. Helmich Jr. admitted he had slipped topsecret codes to agents of the Soviet Union in France in 1963.

title: Cost of Coast Fruit Fly Battle Is Reported Near $50 Million
description: California's battle against a Mediterranean fruit fly is costing almost $10 million a month and now totals nearly $50 million, an eradication spokesman says.

title: Connecticut Housing; EFFORTS TO OPEN UP PUBLIC HOUSING
description: This is the second of two articles on public housing. WALLINGFORD

title: Susan Rosen Is Married
description: Susan Anne Rosen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Rosen of White Plains, was married there yesterday in the Community Unitarian Church to Edwin Joseph Curran, regional administrator of the Bronx Cross County Medical Group, an affliliate of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York.

title: AFTER 39 YEARS: GOODBYE RANGERS, I HATE TO SEE ME GO
description: I'VE been going to Ranger games since Wendell Willkie ran for President against Franklin Roosevelt. I never expected to stop.

title: Older people are pe nalized for living lo nger, psychiatrist t ells shore seminar
description: TOMS RIVER ECONOMIC security, affordable health care and adequate transportation, housing and nutrition were high on the list of priorities of the 58 delegates and 33 observers who attended a twoday seminar here last weekend.

title: STREET PEOPLE
description: ON THE STROLL By Alix Kates Shulman. 301 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: RETIRED EXECUTIVES PASS ALONG BUSINESS SKILLS
description: John Whittaker wanted to quit his job as a computer programmer and convert his Manhattan loft into a furniture workshop. But he did not know how to start a business, or what taxes he would have to pay or what insurance he would need. And he did not know whether he could make a profit.

title: DEBILLIS HELPS PACE BEAT FORDHAM, 21-7
description: Nick DeBellis threw a 31-yard touchdown pass to Bob Monti and ran 20 yards for another score, both in the second quarter, to help Pace to a 21-7 victory over Fordham yesterday in Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: Hoist the Jolly Roger
description: The Seattle Mariners have dropped their Spokane Indians Triple-A farm club after three years and signed a one-year player development contract with the Salt Lake City Gulls. Both teams play in the Pacific Coast League. The Gulls had been affiliated for 11 seasons with the California Angels.

title: Ship's Chief Accused Of Maltreating Crew
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted a fishing boat captain on charges of treating five crew members cruelly for failing to meet their quota for shucking scallops. The five-co unt indictment was returned yesterday in Providence, R.I., against Dale J. Hansley. He was charged in each count with imprisoning c rew members, withholding suitable food and nourishment and inflictin g cruel and unusual punishment while the vessel Mr. Lawrence was at sea between July 19 and 28.

title: SHELTER FOR WOMEN APPROVED BY COURT
description: THE New York State Supreme Court has cleared the way for northern Westchester's first shelter for abused women to open in Pleasantville. Justice Fred A. Dickinson overruled what he called an ''arbitrary and capricious'' decision by the Pleasantville Zoning Board of Appeals and ordered the village to accept the group home.

title: CONGRESSMEN BREAK RANKS
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. THE political maneuvering for the Federal appropriation battles this fall will be influenced, in part, by two Connecticut Congressmen who have formed an alliance with Representatives from the Northeast and Middle West to gain more political clout for their districts.

title: A LESSON IN A GAME OF SHIRTS VS. SKINS
description: WHEN I talk about my basketball accomplishments, people are always most impressed by my membership on the United States women's team for the 1981 Maccabiah Games in Israel last July.

title: Dr. Diana Bianchi Wed To Dr. T.F. Beckett Jr.
description: Dr. Diana Willa Bianchi, a resident in pediatrics at the Children's Hospital Medical Center in Boston, was married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday to Dr. Timothy F. Beckett Jr., a clinical assistant in medicine at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston and an instructor in medicine at the Harvard Medical School. The Rev. Owen W. Daley performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Memorial Church of Harvard University.

title: Basketball Player Hurt In Indiana Car Crash
description: John Hollinden, a 7-foot-6-inch former basketball player at Indiana State-Evansville, was seriously hurt last night when his car flipped on a slick curve of a county road.

title: Connors Defeats Sadri; Scanlon Also Advances
description: While upsets continue in the $200,000 tennis competition at the Cow Palace, it still seems likely that John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors will meet in Monday's final.

title: Around the World; British Might Offer Radar Planes to Saudis
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that Britain ''will have to consider'' selling its own radar planes to Saudi Arabia if the Arab nation's deal to buy five such aircraft from the United States falls through.

title: Ideas & Trends; Flight No.2 Is Delayed Pending Repairs
description: Practice has not se emed to make perfect when it comes to launching a space shuttle. Last week, the trouble was a valve, eithe r flawed or improperly installed, that leaked toxic propellants dow n the side of Columbia, which had been, but now isn't, scheduled for its second flight on Oct.9.

title: Nancy LaPook Betrothed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Sidney LaPook of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jane LaPook, to Robert Bruce Diamond, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Diamond of Tamarac, Fla. The wedding is planned for November. Miss LaPook is associate producer and writer for MTV: Music Television of the Warner Amex Satellite Entertainment Corporation. Mr. Diamond is with Bache Halsey Stuart Shields in Hallandale, Fla.

title: IN UGANDA, HIGH PRICES AND GUNFIRE AT NIGHT
description: Along the shore of Lake Victoria near Uganda's international airport, there are tall, stately trees and a rolling countryside of soft green hills.

title: Westchester Housing; THE 'ITALIANIZATION' OF DOBBS FERRY
description: ITALIAN immigrants, who began arriving in Dobbs Ferry in the late 1880's, brought memories of four medieval hill towns with them and today the cen ter of the village is dotted with grape arbors, stone walls, balust rades, stucco houses and even a four-story palazzo.

title: Hunger Strike in Spanish Jail
description: Prison officials said some 2,000 prisoners in Modelo Prison began a hunger strike today demanding better living conditions.

title: LIQUOR RETAILERS BRACE FOR DECONTROL
description: WEST HARTFORD WHEN most c ontrols on liquor pricing are dropped on Jan. 1, White House Liquors here plans to slash prices on many items in its large inventory and seek more business in a competitive market. Around the corner, the D eLuxe Package Store, a small neighborhood shop, doesn't plan any pric e cuts; it will simply try to avoid going out of business. Retailers acknowledge that many of the 1,50 0 liquor stores in the state will eventually go out of business as a result of the deregulation of liquor prices; if a free mark et in Connecticut comes to resemble the free markets in surrounding s tates, half the stores will close. Which ones may be determined in t he first few months of the new year.

title: Debuts: Music in Review; Arthur Lima Offers A ll-Chopin Piano Bill
description: When a pianist chooses to play an all-Chopin recital, the nagging question of personality asserts itself. Chopin's music, with its subtle mixture of aristocratic ease and interior unsettlement, rigorous contrapuntal play and harmonic freedom, public assertion and private dreaming, is almost a Rorshach test for the modern musician. Declare yourself, is its challenge.

title: Miss Turton Wed To C. M. Ams 3d
description: Mary Quarrier Turton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Turton of Southport, Conn., was married there yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church to Charles Max Ams 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ams Jr. of Pawlet, Vt. The Rev. Andrew L.C.C. Jones performed the ceremony.

title: News Analysis
description: In a 99-page report plus a preface, including photographs and artists' renditions of Soviet weapons, the Department of Defense paints a picture of a huge and dynamic Soviet military machine. But there is no new information, no conclusion, no systematic comparison with American forces, only the impression of relentless and almost overwhelming Soviet military power.

title: HOWATT IS EXPECTING A TRADE
description: The Islanders were beaten by the Boston Bruins, 5-3, in a preseason game last night at the Providence Civic Center, b) - One of thre e original Islanders remaining - the others are Billy Smith, a goal ie, and Bob Nystrom, a right wing - Howatt, who is in the final yea r of his contract, said he had asked to be traded because he fe lt he was not being played enough.

title: A CULTURED PATH TO CAPITAL POWER
description: Political power has traditionally been the key to success in Washington, but with this city's emerging interest in the arts there are new vehicles for making one's mark in the capital. Maurice and Joan Tobin have gone the cultural route.

title: JAZZ
description: In 1973, Jack Kleinsinger, a young lawyer and jazz fan, put on a jazz concert at the Theater de Lys that blossomed into the oldest continuing jazz concert series in New York, ''Highlights in Jazz.'' Since that first concert, the series has settled into New York University's Loeb Student Center (566 LaGuardia Place) where Mr. Kleinsinger presents a concert each month during the fall, winter and spring.

title: Margaret Lavelle Wed To George Benet Bradt
description: Margaret Lavelle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Oliver Lavelle of Bayside, Queens, was married yesterday in East Hampton, L.I., to George Benet Bradt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Bradt Jr. of New York and Amagansett, L.I. The Rev. Michael J. Connelly performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Trinity.

title: Architecture View; MOVING INTO A NEW REALM; HARTFORD, Conn.
description: Any visitor to the new headquarters of the Hartford Seminary in Hartford, Conn., will have no trouble recognizing the building. This glistening white structure makes its immaculate presence so inimitably clear that there is no question about which building one has come to see. It is just as clearly the work of Richard Meier, who has developed this clean, but complex style with dedicated consistency through a series of recent buildings that have already achieved a special significance on the international architectural scene.

title: RELIGIOUS LEFT AND RIGHT SPLIT ON ROLE IN SOCIETY
description: The debate over the role of religion in public policy, prompted by the rise of conservative Christian political action groups, is increasingly polarizing liberal and conservative Christians and challenging the nonfundamentalist churches to sharpen their positions on moral issues.

title: PROSPECTS
description: It's Reagan's Economy

title: Views of Families 'Caught in the Middle'
description: I am classified as ''upper middle class'' in statistics and share the same altruism and compassion for those less fortunate with my middle class counterparts, but, somewhere along the way, the meaning of ''caring and compassion'' in our society has taken the lesstraveled-by path.

title: VINEYARD LIFTS GOALS ON PRODUCTION
description: NORTH SALEM RANKED as the country's second-largest producer of grapes, New York State is steeped in a long and proud tradition of wine making. In 1827, the first big commercial vineyard in the Hudson Valley was planted here in the county - now the site of the 500-acre Croton Point Park.

title: KITCHAWAN HONORING 2 HARDY PE RENNIALS
description: ONE is a herb garden, designed in a medieval knot motif, redolent with the bittersweet, earthy scent of basil and parsely and rue. The other is a perennial border, rectangular in shape, planted with phlox, chrysanthemums and other brightly colored flowers that bloom year after year.

title: New Jersey Guide; GREEK FESTIVAL
description: Summer may be just a memory, but the festival spirit lives on. It will be elicited again next weekend by bouzouki music, Greek delicacies, dancing and other amusements at the 11th annual Greek Festival of St. George Greek Orthodox Church in Clifton.

title: Long Islanders; THE PERSON BEHIND A HOUSEHOLD NAME
description: THIS is a story about a little girl on a remote island off the coast of Alaska and the strange path her life took. Her name, in the days of her childhood, was Zenaida Gromoff, the eighth of 10 children of the Rev. Elary Gromoff, a priest of the Russian Orthodox church who was raised by an Aleut Indian family, and Elizabeth Lestenkoff, a full-blooded Aleut, who, like her husband, was born and raised in the isolated Pribiloff Islands.

title: A DANCER'S DISCIPLINE
description: REPRIEVE A Memoir. By Agnes de Mille. Foreword and notes by Fred Plum, M.D. 288 pp. New York: Doubleday. $14.95.

title: Duran Beats Minchillo On Unanimous Decision
description: Roberto Duran continued his comeback today with a unanimous 10-round decision over Luigi Minchillo of Italy.

title: Jersey City Noted
description: To the Editor:

title: Italy's 100 Cities
description: To the Editor:

title: Klan Leader Gets Jail Term
description: Federal District Judge Frank Kaufman sentenced a Maryland Ku Klux Klan leader to 15 years in prison Thursday for attempting to firebomb the Baltimore County headquarters of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People last May. Richard L. Savina, 29 years old, an unemployed Catonsville truck driver, was convicted Aug. 28 of making and possessing the bomb.

title: LURING LISTENERS TO THE MUSIC OF THE HARP
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Sam H. Shirakawa writes frequently about recordings. By SAM H. SHIRAKAWA

title: Art; SEARCHING FOR THE BEST OF L.I.'S GRAPHICS
description: GLEN COVE ONE must congratulate the Visual Arts Committee of the Glen Cove Council for the Arts for assembling the exhibition ''Best Graphics of Long Island 1980-81'' while conceding that the show falls short of the mark in some respects. Although there is a fine selection of works by many of the region's outstanding printmakers, the survey is by no means as complete as it should have been to justify its title.

title: The Region; Transit Riders Will Need Faith
description: It will be some time yet before passengers see the fruits of the $7.9 billion improvement program the Metropolitan Transportation Authority approved last week. Unfortunately, they may not have to wait so long before they see higher fares.

title: Sally Chapin Is Bride of Anthony Gifford Langham
description: Sarah J. Chapin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Sanders Chapin Jr. of Spring Lake, Mich., was married yesterday to Anthony Gifford Langham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest J. Langham of Rancho Bernardo, Calif., formerly of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. David H.C. Read performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: A TEACHER REFLECTS ON CLASSROOMS PAST
description: FOR another autumn of my working life, I am not going back to school. After nearly a lifetime of late-August palpitations, the intermingling of anxiety and anticipation, frantic gropings in the back of the file drawer for last year's lesson plans, the measuring out, by the growing numbers of brown edged leaves, of the precious time left of yawning summer, the sometime chill in the night air serving as a tonic to the somnolent brain, September has come and nothing is going to change.

title: Speaking Rhode Island
description: As a native of Rhode Island who returns fre quently to that interesting state, I enjoyed Mary Cantwell's reflections on the Rhode Island pattern of speech (''Parlor Parlance,' ' On Language, Aug. 9). It is a pattern which I still exhibit despite many years of living inthe Midwest and upstate New York.

title: SOCIAL AGENCIES UNSURE OF IMPACT OF BUDGET TRIMS
description: SOCIAL service officials in Nassau and Suffolk Counties say that existing state requirements will delay the impact of federally mandated cutbacks in welfare, food stamps and Medicaid payments on the Island.

title: Massapequa Victorious
description: Massapequa, the defending Nassau Rutgers Cup champion, defeated Mepham, 34-14, in the non-league opener for both teams, as Coach Bill Cutillo's Chiefs scored their 13th straight victory.

title: HERBICIDE POSES PROBLEMS FOR U.S. AND CANADA
description: There are 95,000 gallons of an American-made herbicide in a warehouse across the river from here in Windsor, Ontario. The Canadians want it out of the country, but the Americans will not allow it across the river.

title: SUMMIT FALLS, 27-7
description: Westfield rushed for 205 yards and defeated Summit, 27-7, yesterday in Westfield. Westfield scored three touchdowns in the second quarter to take a 20-7 lead. Kevin Morris, quarterback, scored on a 1-yard run to cap a 66-yard drive. Paul Leifer, the leading rusher with 87 yards over all, scored on a 12-yard run, and Morris then completed a 44-yard touchdown pass to Mike Murphy.

title: Stage View; A COMIC AT A LOSS, A PLAYWRIGHT AT SEA
description: Iliked Dave Allen best as a duck in a frozen pond. It's not just the pond that's frozen, mind you; the duck is frozen into the pond, and hungry. And Mr. Allen, doing a one-man stand-up evening at the Booth, takes time out from his run-on monologue to let us see the forlorn creature that - because of the dictatorial signs in a public park - no one is permitted to feed. Mr. Allen's mouth has looked rather like a duck's all along, with that rippling bill that closes down into a mournful smile, and when he adds to his eyes an almost piercing appe al, he makes you think he might be well advised to take up straight a cting. Of course, I don't suppose there are that many duck parts ar ound.

title: Antiques; MUSEUM OFFERS ART GLASS SHOW
description: of-the-century pieces made by Tiffany, Steuben, Durand, Quezal and several other companies.

title: Scanlon Beats McEnroe On Coast, 3-6, 7-6, 6-2
description: Bill Scanlon upset John McEnroe, 3-6, 7-6, 6-2, today in the quarterfinals of the $200,000 Transamerica tennis tournament.

title: Antiques; DANCE ITEMS KEEP COLLECTORS ON THEIR TOES
description: Collector's fever has hit the dance world. Auction houses and book shops that handle dance material are enjoying their busiest season ever. A large selection of dance books will be offered Nov. 24 at Sotheby Parke Bernet 84th Street Galleries, 171 East 84th Street. The annual dance auction of photographs, set and costume designs will be held at Sotheby's Madison Avenue Galleries, at 76th Street, on Dec. 15.

title: The World
description: Brazil's generals stuck to the political rules last week instead of making their own. By allowing the civilian Vice President, Aureliano Chaves, to take over temporarily for President Joao Baptista Figueiredo, who is recuperating from a heart attack, the generals showed a commitment to restoring democratic forms.

title: New York Political Notes
description: Assemblyman James L. Emery, the minority leader of the Assembly, and seven of his top aides will spend four days this week in the isolated and rustic Letchworth State Park, south of Rochester, in what one aide described as ''a retreat'' to plan Mr. Emery's governmental and political strategy for the coming year.

title: COURT REFORMS URGED TO CUT COSTS AND DELAYS
description: The Chief Judge of the State of New York has called for the consolidation of the principal trial courts in the state to cut costs and delays.

title: Behind the Best Sellers
description: This week two books by Stephen King sit high on the best seller lists -''Cujo'' for the seventh time on the hardcover fiction list, ''Firestarter'' for the seventh time on the mass market paperback list. Not a bad record for a man who less than 10 years ago was teaching high school English and spending his spare time writing novels in his native Maine.

title: SAAD MUHAMMAD STOPS MARTIN IN 11
description: Matthew Saad Muhammad survived another excercise in brin kmanship today, and for the eighth time successfully defended his World Boxing Council light-heavyweight championship. The end came at 28 seconds of the 11th round, when Referee Larry Hazzard decided that Jerry (The Bull) Martin, the challenger, c ould not go on.

title: MATTHEWS VIEWS G.O.P.'S RECORD AS PURCELL ISSUE
description: JOHN W. MATTHEWS, Democratic candidate for Nassau County Executive, says ''the arrogance of the Republican party with its corruption and taxation'' will be the main theme of his uphill campaign against County Executive Francis T. Purcell.

title: Art; CAN CULTURE SURVIVE IN THE STATE CAPITAL?
description: TRENTON OF THE several photographs in ''Eyes on Trenton,'' an exhibition divided between the State and City Museums and continuing through Oct. 5, the one at the right makes a particularly apt illustration. The photograph is of the building housing t he state's Department ofLabor and Industry - it also is known as the Marching Hotel - and the structrure is a modest one, compared with the capital's other governmental grandiosities. But it symbolizes well enough what the Trenton Artists Workshop Association is up ag ainst in its struggle toenginee r a cultural life here.

title: NEW WILDLIFE UNIT FACES MANY OBSTACLES
description: IF a crow with a sense of esthetics flew diagonally across the state from Greenwich to East Thompson, it would delight in the hundred-mile-long coastline, the rolling hills, the rivers, streams and lakes, and the pleasant green-and-white villages that dot the third smallest state in the United States.

title: AN INDUSTRIAL GIANT RELOCATES ITS EXTENDED FAMILY
description: ''I'll miss the restaurants and walking on Fifth Avenue at lunchtime,'' said Robey A. Howard, gazing out the window of his 44th-floor office on his last day at the Union Carbide headquarters on Manhattan's Park Avenue.

title: Safety Citations Noted At Blast Site in Jersey
description: The aluminum powder manufacturing plant where an explosion occurred Thursday had been previously cited for health and safety violations, Federal officials said.

title: WHITE REMEMBERS TO TAKE THE GIANTS SERIOUSLY
description: Danny White is handsome, bright, articulate and uncontroversial. He is the right man in the right place - quarterback of the Dallas Cowboys. He could be the star of television commercials, which he is. He might even be a movie actor.

title: Susan Barton Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edgar Allen Barton of Old Bethpage, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Margo Barton, to John J.M. Whyte, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Whyte of Miami Beach.

title: BREWERS MOVE INTO FIRST
description: A two-run homer by Ben Oglivie in the eighth inning today helped carry the Milwaukee Brewers into first place in the American League East with a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

title: NEBRASKA DEFEATED BY PENN STATE, 30-24
description: Brian Franco kicked a school-record five field goals and Curt Warner ran for 238 yards, but Penn State had to rally three times to beat Nebraska today, 30-24. There were 12 fumbles, seven turnovers and seven lead changes.

title: PREFACE FROM U.S. BOOKLET ON SOVIET MILITARY
description: Following is the preface, signed by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, to the 99-page booklet titled ''Soviet Military Power'':

title: IRISH CARAVAN
description: To the Editor:

title: LIVING WITH ELECTRONICS
description: Beginning in the first quarter of this century, electricity has been invading the American home in the form of labor-saving appliances, and home hasn't been the same since. Today, there are new wired invaders in the form of electronics, and these promise to change even more radically the way we live and work at home. People are able to work at home and still report to the office; soon, they will be able to shop and bank at home. They can now summon up education and entertainment with only a flick of the wrist or by tapping out coded instructions.

title: THE CASE OF THE LADY AND THE KILLER
description: Copyright c 1981 by Joan Barthel. Joan Barthel is the author of ''A Death in Canaan.'' This article is adapted from her new book, ''A Death in California,'' which is being published this week by Congdon & Lattes. By Joan Barthel At 10 minutes before noon on Friday, Feb. 23, 1973, a handsome, welldressed man carrying a carved pipe stepped into the reception room at Dailey & Associates, an advertising agency on Wilshire Boulevard in Los Angeles. He said he was a reporter for The Los Angeles Times. He said he had a lunch date with Bill Ashlock, an executive with the firm, to interview him for an article on the city's 10 most eligible bachelors. He said his name was Taylor Wright.

title: Money Can Be of Help To the Elderly
description: In answer to ''Money Alone Won't Solve Ills of the Elderly'': no, but intelligently spent to alleviate their boredom and deterioration, it can help.

title: VIRGINIA CADETS INVADE WEST POINT
description: WEST POINT IT was rumored that the extra contingents of military police on duty last weekend had orders to use riot-control techniques ''where necessary.'' But the West Point cadets had prepared their own measures to meet an invasion by the ''West Point of the South,'' including posters that proclaimed: ''A West Pointer by any other name just ain't the same. Xerox makes better copies.''

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 5 2 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with the Berrys, an eccentric family that sets up house in unlikely hotels, here and abroad. 2 1 7 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 3 2 21 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) British and Chinese businessmen struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 4 3 9 THE THIRD DEADLY SIN, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam's, $13.95.) Chief of Detectives (ret.) Edward X. Delaney on the trail of the elusive killer of out-of-town businessmen visiting New York. 5 4 25 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 6 1 BREAD UPON THE WATERS, by Irwin Shaw. (Delacorte, $14.95.) An unexpected bounty changes the life of Allen Strand's family and makes him perceive our culture's many paradoxes. 7 8 5 THE LAST DAYS OF AMERICA, by Paul Erdman. (Simon & Schuster, $13.95.)

title: U.S.-PRODUCED ANALYSIS OF TORAH IS PUBLISHED
description: The first J ewish commentary produced in the United States on the Torah has jus t been released and it makes use of modern methods of biblical scho larship, blending comments from non-Jewish writers into its scholarly analysis of the Scriptures.

title: No Headline
description: My years in Philadelphia and New York have lessened, but not eliminated, my Rhode Island accent, and a Paris overlay on my Providence ed ucation never got Rhode Island out of my French.

title: Winemaker Wisdom
description: Terry Robards's article on Beaulieu Vineyard was accurate and to the point (''A Premium Red From the West,'' Aug. 16). His acknowledgment of the various vineyard designations is a well-kept secret within the wine trade.

title: BAYMEN FEARFUL AS SEWER START NEARS
description: THE Island's remaining 10,000 independent baymen fear that the opening of the Southwest Sewer District next month will mark the beginning of the end of commercial shell-fishing in the Great South Bay.

title: Quentin A. Bossi, 74, Partner In McKay Publishing Concern
description: Quentin A. Bossi, retired partner in the David McKay Company, the publishing concern, and a former vice president of G. P. Putnam's Sons, died Friday at his home in Dennis, Mass. He was 74 years old.

title: Littl Shynin Man
description: In a letter to the editor (Aug. 9) about Russell Hoban's novel ''Riddley Walker,'' Joseph H. Morehead commended Mr. Hoban for his ''re-creation of language in which atomic energy becomes 'the Littl Shynin Man the Addom.' '' Mr. Morehead suggested that perhaps the novel's hero (Riddley) or Mr. Hoban had come upon a Department of Energy teaching pamphlet for children entitled ''The Energy We Use'' in which energy is portrayed as ''Mr. Atom,'' ''a very shiny neat man who bounced when he walked'' and ''explained how he could split and make energy.'' Mr. Hoban's reply follows. To the Editor: Coming home on August 26 after being away for a month I found waiting for me among other things a photocopy of part of your Letters page on which is a letter from Joseph H. Morehead of Albany. Riddley Walker's reply follows:

title: WATCHUNG HILLS WINS; Watchung Hills Wins
description: The Watchung Hills defense scored one touchdown and set up another yesterday in a 14-0 victory over Bridgewater East in Bridgewater Township.

title: Suspect in Slaying of 3 In Salvador Is Released
description: A suspect held for five and a half months in connection with the slayings of the head of El Salvador's land redistribution program and two United States advisers was released from jail yesterday after posting bond.

title: CITY AIDES DISPUTE FORECASTS ON EFFECTS OF NEW TAX LAWS
description: Putting together accurate forecasts of how much money New York City will take in and spend has traditionally been a difficult business, but the size, speed and complexity of the recent budget and tax cuts in Washington has sometimes rendered the task virtually impossible, specialists say.

title: Around the World; Atomic Energy Agency Considers Ousting Israel
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency voted today to consider suspending Israel next year if it does not open its nuclear facilities to inspection. The agency also suspended immediately all technical aid to Israel under agency programs.

title: ST. ANTHONY'S EXCELS
description: It should take a few weeks before a leader emerges among the state's high school cross-country teams this season.

title: No Headline
description: Roger Keizerstein reports on his experiences as a social worker. Mr. Keizerstein tells us of a client family who is receiving $15,924 in public assistance. Mr. Keizerstein is shocked. He feels this amount is inadequate for a family of nine. After reading the article, a thought kept nagging at me and I got out my husband's W-2 form from 1967. That year, our family consisted of eight people and our total income after taxes was $7,958. Our income rose only gradually during the next several years before it reached the amount that Mr. Keizerstein's client family is getting today.

title: Nancy K. Stanley Is Married
description: Nancy Kathryn Stanley, daughter of Robert C. Stanley Jr. of Red Bank, N.J., and Nancy Knothe Stanley of Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Brehon Somervell Griswold, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Wool Griswold of Yeamans Hall, S.C., and Hartland, Vt. The Rev. George J. Willis Jr. performed the ceremony at St. George's by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J.

title: Ipswich Defeats Leeds And Leads by 2 Points
description: Terry Butcher and Eric Gates scored second-half goals today as Ipswich Town rallied to defeat Leeds United, 2-1, and take a 2-point lead in the English First Division soccer standing.

title: ARMENIANS ASSERT SUICIDE SQUADS ARE READY
description: The Armenian Secret Army, which seized the Turkish Consulate in Paris Thursday, said today that it had two more ''suicide commando'' units ready for action.

title: JAPAN'S, AND ACADEME'S, COMPUTER LIMITS
description: To the Editor:

title: MONTAUK STRIPPED BASS CERTIFIED AT 76 POUNDS
description: Rochetta's catch, taken on a live eel, hold the all-tackle and 50-pound test line records. The all-tackle record means that Rochetta's bass is the heaviest fish of its species in any of the association's salt water line classes, which range from 6 to 130 pounds.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: HIS desk is clear. The in-out file is almost bare. The telephone rarely rings. ''It's like jumping off a moving train,'' Public Safety Commissioner Donald J. Long said of his duties, which are as meager as his new accommodations. Mr. Long can be found these days in a hastily furnished office on the fifth floor of the Department of Health Services building, about a half-mile from State Police headquarters.

title: No Headline
description: How can Vladimir Nabokov offer serious criticism if he does not touch upon the metaphysical and moral dilemmas present in Dostoyevsky's writings? In this case at least, I suspect that Mr. Nabokov's critical standards reveal more about his own highly refined stylistic tastes than about the inner meanings of Dostoyevsky's texts. If Mr. Nabokov had sacrified some of his cleverness for intellectual integrity, then maybe more fruitful insights would have been the result. LAWRENCE ORLOWSKI, Flushing, N.Y.

title: Steinbrenner's Roots Revisited
description: To the Sports Editor: George Steinbrenner setting himself up as a defender of ''these construction guys and cab workers'' is an amusing conceit (The New York Times, Sept. 20). But Mr. Steinbrenner's treatment of those around him can be summarized by a couple of c ynical bromides: ''Nice guys finish last'' and ''The end justifies th e means.''

title: JEFFERSON DEAL IS COMPLICATED
description: By WILLIAM N. WALLACE

title: NUCLEAR SAFETY ALSO ECHOES NUCLEAR POLITICS
description: Even as protesters made a last-ditch, and probably futile, attempt last week to prevent the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant in California from opening, Federal officials and utility executives made clear that vital machinery in at least 17 plants - from Consolidated Edison's Indian Point 2 in New York to the Consumers Power Company Palisades in Michigan - is rusting and may force plant closures for repairs. This was just the latest in a series of recent developments that suggest all is not well with the nation's 72 nuclear power facilities.

title: DIACONATE TRAINING IS BEING REVISED
description: NEWARK FOR the first time since 1973, no candidates for the Roman Catholic Church's permanent diaconate are in training in the Archdiocese of Newark.

title: David Webster Weds Elizabeth Drew
description: Elizabeth Drew, a writer for The New Yorker, a television commentator and an author, was married yesterday to David Webster of New York, director of the British Broadcasting Corporation for the United States and a member of its board of management. Judge Abner Mikva of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia performed the ceremony at the bride's home in Washington.

title: Wall Collapses, Killing Man
description: A workman was crushed to death Friday by a wall that toppled on him in a Queens home he was helping to remodel, the police said. Felix Carillo, 53 years old, was helping to build an addition to a home at 89-30 117th Street, in the Richmond Hill section. The victim's address was not known, officials said.

title: CONTROL BOARD AGREES CITY ECONOMY'S LAGGING
description: After a few years of appreciable growth, private employment in New York City will begin to level off next year and decline slightly in 1983 and 1984, according to a report prepared by the state's Financial Control Board. If the fore cast turns out to be correct, said Comer S. Coppie, the board's execu tive director, the city will find it more difficult to bridge the bu dget gap than in the last two or three years.

title: LEONIA PARENTS SUPPORT TEACHER IN MORALS CASE
description: LEONIA THE case involving John Anagnosti, who resigned his fourth-grade teaching post at the Anna C. Scott Elementary School here last April over an accusation that he had molested a pupil, is expected to go before a grand jury tomorrow.

title: Walter Morris, Teacher, Weds Miss McGrath
description: Kathleen Ann McGrath and Walter Franklin Morris were married yesterday by Msgr. Harrold A. Murray in St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Long Island Guide; ON THE RUN
description: In an effort to match the weather to the participants' enthusiasm, Nassau County has switched its Lifestyle Run from December to today at 9 A.M.. So those folks you see running 20 kilometers around Eisenhower Park in East Meadow are racing for fun and prizes awarded to men and women in various age categories. The entry fee is $4, and to find out if there are still slots open for late-starters, call 292-4285.

title: SMALLNESS PAYING OFF FOR SMALL COLLEGES
description: LONG Island's small liberal arts colleges are holding their own despite strong competition from the State University of New York and the community colleges of Nassau and Suffolk Counties, where tuition, in most cases, is nearly half that of the private schools and the fac ilities are newer.

title: Cards Defeat Pirates
description: Garry Templeton hit a game-tying single and Keith Hernandez drove in the go-ahead run with a triple in a three-run seventh inning today that gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 5-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: SOLIDARITY OPENS THE SECOND PHASE OF GDANSK PARLEY
description: The Solidarity union opened the second phase of its national convention here today with invited American labor leaders absent, with Soviet reporters watching like hawks and with moderates and militants clashing over the issue of workers' participation in the management of industries.

title: Other Business; PROTECTING YOUR SECRETS - AND YOURSELF
description: ''Maybe I'm just paranoid, but I think someone's tapping my phone.'' The speaker was a contractor who was making half a million dollars a year - until a competitor began stealing job after job out from under his nose. The listener was Carmine O. Pellosie, president of CCS Communications Control Inc. in New York, a maker of antiespionage devices.

title: Art Sampler
description: REALISM is the phoenix of art styles. Whenever it seems to have disappeared, it springs forth from the ashes, alive and thriving. For many years after World War II, everyone thought that realism had died the definitive death. However, it resurfaced in the 1960's and is now one of the most prominent art styles.

title: STUDY DISCOUNTS FEARS ABOUT LIBEL DECISIONS
description: Two 1979 Supreme Court decisions that press lawyers had feared would make it easier for plaintiffs to win libel cases have not yet had any significant impact, according to a Stanford University law professor.

title: Larry C. Morris
description: MISS WARREN AND MAREE WIN MILE RACES: Leann Warren and Sydney Maree breaking the tapes in the Women's and Men's Elite Miles on Fifth Avenue.

title: U.S.C. WINS, 28-24, IN FINAL 2 SECONDS
description: At the end of an afternoon filled with mistakes by the two highest-ranked college football teams, a game in which it was obvious that the winner would be the team that avoided the last blunder, Fred Cornwell redeemed himself today.

title: Sara Evans Bride Of Forbes Maner
description: Sara Ullom Evans, daughter of Capt. Philip Wharton Evans, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Evans, of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Forbes Maner, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Lawton Maner Jr. of Williamsburg, Va. The Rev. E. Pinkney Wroth performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Rock Creek Parish Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: THE HOMESPUN PLEASURES OF LANCASTER COUNTY
description: The bell on the second-floor porch railing clanged out its invitation and we trooped through the big farm kitchen and took our places at a rectangular table - a long one, for there were six adults and nine children sitting down to breakfast. Virginia Ranck, one of her three children in her arms, led us in grace and, as an Amish hired girl served, we began our meal with a choice of cranberry juice or spearmint tea, brewed from the leaves of a bush in front of the farmhouse. Plates heaped with poached eggs were passed, topped by slices of dark red Lebanon bologna, chewy and sweet.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Ke Kou Ke Le
description: Balloons were lofted and firecrackers exploded in Peking last April 15 as the Coca Cola Company opened its first bottling plant on the China mainland since 1949.

title: John Kazanjian, A Lawyer, Weds Jane Kohlmeyer
description: The marriage of Jane Mitchell Kohlmeyer, a second vice president with the international sector of the Chase Manhattan Bank, to John H. Kazanjian, an associate with the New York law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft, took place in the chantry of St. Thomas Episcopal Church yesterday. The Rev. Gary P. Fertig performed the ceremony.

title: Conn ecticut Guide; O'NEILL IN WESTPORT
description: ''Hughie,'' a two-character one-act play by Eugene O'Neill, will have three performances starring Jason Robards at the White Barn Theater in Westport on Oct. 16, 17 and 18. Jack Dodson will take the supporting role, as he has during the 17 years the two men have appeared in the play from time to time.

title: Conspicuous Absence
description: To the Editor:

title: State Spends $26,296 For Two Cars for Carey
description: The state has spent $26,296 for two top-ofthe-line Buick cars for Governor Carey's use in Albany and New York City.

title: U.S. Airman Killed in Italy
description: A United State Air Force sergeant, Andrew Shenton of Baltimore, was killed yesterday and four other American servicemen were injured when part of a building collapsed at an air base near Bari, the Italian news agency ANSA said.

title: Imlach Out of Hospital
description: Punch Imlach, general manager of the Toronto Maple Leafs, has been discharged from the hospital and returned home. Imlach spent three weeks at Toronto General Hospital after suffering from chest pains while attending the Leafs' rookie training camp at St.Catharines.

title: A MEDITERRANEAN TOUCH
description: We were fascinated to learn from a recent news account that the bottlers of Ricard and Pernod are making an effort to whet the American appetite for those beguiling aperitifs with a Mediterranean flavor.

title: HOME FURNISHINGS REPORT
description: Modern furnishings have never been the only merchandise available to consumers; antiques and reporductions have always had their share of the market. Today, however, with postmoderninsm rampant, many new designs ore traditional appearance. Style revivals, especially of those made popular in the 1920's and 30's, are proliferating. In addition, there is a new catagory of furniture making inroads into today's homes: electronic furniture. Although not itself wired, it has been designed to hold everything from home to computers to television sets and hi-fi equipment. Leather, which was used extensively as a furniture covering in the 18th and 19th centuries, is making a comeback as upholstery-even as flooring. The watercolor pastels of the past few years show no sign of peaking and now appear on everything from pillows to plastic furniture.

title: MEMOIRS OF A CHEAPSKATE
description: Mary Cantwell is a member of the editorial board of The New York Times. DESIGNBy Mary Cantwell eside my bed, along with a pile of books, a red plastic paperclip and a yellow pencil, is a spiral-bound notebook. In it I scribble telephone messages for my children (which I then forget to give them), tally columns of figures (will I make it to payday?) and additions to a page titled ''My Dream of Life.'' Listed under ''My Dream of Life'' are the month's wants. They are constantly changing and consistently modest.

title: YANKS WIN ON MURCER'S HOMER IN NINTH
description: Bobby Murcer sat in his wooden rocking chair in the clubhouse at Yankee Stadium last night, gently pushing himself back and forth with the balls of his feet. His three-run, pinch-hit home run in the bottom of the ninth inning had given the Yankees a 6-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: MOUNTAIN GROWN WINNERS
description: he sound of a chapel bell rings out across the remote hills high in the Santa Lucia Range as William Durney welcomes visitors to his Rancho del Sueno, a 1,200-acre spread that produces cattle and some of the finest wines in California.

title: Dining Out; QUALITY IN GREEK REVIVAL MANSION
description: THOSE who have been familiar with the Bridgehampton area over the past decade and have followed the decline of the Bulls Head Inn from popular nightspot to near ruin must now be cheered by its splendid restoration. Although work on the upper stories continues, three dining rooms and the bar on the main floor opened in August.

title: U.S. OLYMPIC HEAD ACTIVE DESPITE SNUB
description: An Olympic Congress meets about once each decade to provide these major Olympic elements the opportunity to speak out on policy issues, such as those dealing with illegal drugs, political boycotts, definitions of amateurism and the excessive size and costs of the Games.

title: SEASONAL PARK RESIDENTS FIGHTING OUSTER EFFORTS
description: "THIS is a guerrilla war," Charles S. Cushman, executive director of the National Inholders Association, told the 250 people packed into the local community hall. "Our job is to get them to worry about us, instead of us worrying about them."

title: Shirley C. Dugdale, Architect, Bride Of Peter Bauman Laundy, Designer
description: At St. John's of Lat tingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., yesterd ay, Shirley Carmen Dugdale, an architect with the Ehrenkrantz G roup in New York, was married to Peter Bauman Laundy, vice presiden t and graphic design director of Vignelli Associates, a New York desi gn firm. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony.

title: Ideas & Trends; Take Two Pills, Then Appeal
description: The American Home Products Corporation has a headache, and all because of aspirin. The Fed eral Trade Commission ruled last week thatthe company c o uld no longer advertise Anacin in phrases su ch as ''contains the pain reliever most recommended by doctors'' unless it specifies that the pain reliever is aspirin.

title: VIRGINIA AND DUNCAN AND CLIVE AND VANESSA
description: LOVE IN BLOOMSBURY Memories. By Frances Partridge. Illustrated. 244 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $14.95.

title: Art View; THE VISION OF AN EXPATRIATE; WASHINGTON
description: Few artistic careers of the past two decades have been more distinctive than that of the American expatriate painter R.B. Kitaj, whose work is currently the subject of a retrospective exhibition at the Hirshhorn Museum (through Nov. 15). He was born Ronald Brooks in Cleveland, Ohio, in 1932, acquired the name Kitaj when his mother remarried in 1941, and spent his high school years in Troy, N.Y. At the age of 18 he went to sea, and for four years divided his time between traveling the world as a merchant seaman and studying art - first at the Cooper Union in New York under Sydney Delevante and then at the Academy in Vienna under Albert Paris von Gutersloh and Fritz Wotruba. After two years in the American Army, spent mostly in France, he went to Oxford on the G.I. Bill, and then in 1960 he began two years of study at the Royal College of Art. It was at the Royal College in the early 60's that he became something of a celebrity in the London art world. David Hockney, among others, has testified to the influence that Kitaj exerted on his fellow students.

title: AN AMERICAN UPHEAVAL
description: To the Editor:

title: A TIME FOR OKTOBERFESTS
description: For travelers who are unable to get to Munich for the Oktoberfest, which began Sept. 19 and runs to next Sunday, there is still time to participate in some beer-drinking and sausage-eating events in the United States.

title: Selective Service Gets Chief
description: The Senate confirmed Maj. Gen. Thomas K. Turnage yesterday as director of the Selec tive Service. He was approved by the Armed Services Committee Thur sday after testifying that he would try to make the all-volunteer m ilitary force work but would not hesitate to recommend a draft if ne eded.

title: MISPRINTED BILLS TURNING UP IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Misprinted $10 bills have begun turning up in the New York City area and they could be the first of many such notes - possibly even numbering in the tens of thousands. If so, this would be one of the most dramatic currency errors in United States history from the standpoint of sheer numbers.

title: Westchester Journal
description: DEMOCRATS provided the wine and cheese last week, and Republicans helped to consume it as Stanley Fink's Westchester regional office opened officially in a burst of political bonhomie.

title: September 27, 1981
description: William Safire 11 On Language Geezer Power Russell Baker 18 Sunday Observer Love Me, Love My Bear Richard E. Cytowic 27 The Long Ordeal of James Brady Harold C. Schonberg 32 Cold War in the World of Chess Joan Barthel 46 The Case of the Lady and the Killer Lucy S. Dawidowicz 48 Babi Yar's Legacy Forty years ago this week, Nazis gunned down 33,711 Ukrainian Jews in two days and buried them in a ravine in Kiev. Today, Babi Yar speaks not only to the horrors of the holocaust but to the harsh record of Soviet anti-Semitism. Craig Clairborne with Pierre Franey 80 Food A Mediterranean Touch 82 Fashion Renewing the Spirit of Romance Terry Robards 86 Wine Mountain-Grown Winners Didi Moore 91 The Perils of a Two-Income Family Reginald Stuart 100 Once Again, a Clash Over Voting Rights 102 Puzzles Answers, Page 78 110 Letters Cover: Top photocopy by Leonard Kamsler/Courtesy CBS-TV News; bottom, photograph by Sebastiao Salgado Jr./Magnum. Copyright 1981, The New York Times

title: RUST IS ALSO A PROBLEM
description: The pressure vessel is one of two key parts of nuclear power plants that have been discovered to be deteriorating far faster than expected.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Art; SCULPTURE IN SPOTLIGHT AT RUTGERS GALLERY; 65 Greek and Roman pieces in New Brunswick exhibit - Bronze statues outstanding
description: NNEW BRUNSWICK IN A world that accepts too many trifles and gimcracks as art, it occasionally does the soul good to see something of supreme achievement. Whereas the trifles and gimcracks may tickle our fancy, great art touches our spirit, lifts our minds and awakens our senses.

title: Hardships of Co-oping
description: To the Editor:

title: SAVING APPALACHIA: WAS $15 BILLION WELL SPENT?
description: With $80 million in Federal and state funds, this little coal town is literally moving a mountain to detour a rail line and a river, build a new road and create 300 acres of valuable flatland in two steep hollows.

title: OPINION MOLDERS CROSS PENS AT PARLEY
description: Paul Greenberg is soft-spoken, funny and professorial. He chops at the air with long fingers, conducting to the rhythms of his speech. His grin is wide, nicely ironic and frequent.

title: Major News; President Moves Closer to the Budget Bone
description: President Reagan almost always looks like a winner on prime time, but it remains to be seen how well last week's call for patience and some sacrifice will play in Washington and beyond.

title: NEW HOUSING LAW CURBS BIAS AGAINST CHILDREN
description: REVISIONS in the state law that proh ibits o wners of large apartmentbuildings or their agents from discriminating against families with children are to go into effect Thursday. The revisions, which will make the state's law among the most stringent in the nation, will make the refusal to show or to rent apartment s to families with youngsters a crime punishable by a fine of up to $100 and prison sentence of 30 days.

title: FORMS OF ESCAPE; Prison Tales
description: A friend of ours familiar with prisons, called up after the arrest of Jack Abbott, the convict-author Norman Mailer helped promote, who is now a prime suspect in the stabbing of an East Village waiter.

title: HIS CONSTABULARY DUTY IS TO KEEP 'PIRATES' BUBBLING
description: He is one of those unmistakable theatrical presences. A tall, gaunt, rubber-jointed bundle of gyrating limbs that somehow suggest coordinated chaos, Tony Azito is a Punch-and-Judy figure come to life, a prancing, dancing clown who can lend acrobatic dazzle to a somersault and balletic grace to a pratfall.

title: No Headline
description: Buoyed by an eagle 3 on the first hole, Doug Ford went on to shoot a six-under-par 66 for 135 and a fourstroke lead after two rounds of the $100,000 Merrill Lynch-Golf Digest pro-amateur tournament.

title: TRIAL OF CULT MEMBER ENDS WITH JURY DEADLOCKED
description: The trial of Larry Layton on charges growing out of the cataclysmic last hours of the People's Temple cult ended in a mistrial in Federal District Court here this afternoon.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Battle for Access Persists
description: ''They thought it was going to be as simple as putting out the cat,'' Mason H. Rose, chairman of the United States Architectural and Transportation Barriers Compliance Board said last week, ''But we're not a cat, we're a tiger.'' Mr. Rose, a former Marine Corps pilot confined to a wheelchair since his jet fighter crashed in Vietnam, referred to the Reagan Administration's attempt to abolish the agency, created in 1973 to set uniform guidelines for making Federally supported and leased buildings accessible to the handicapped.

title: E.P.A. Loses Second Official In Three Days by Resignation
description: The second top official in less than three days has resigned from the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: UPDIKE ON UPDIKE
description: Some years ago, on the occasion of the publication of ''Rabbit Redux,'' John Updike was interviewed for The Book Review by Henry Bech - critic, aspiring author and hero of Mr. Updike's novel, ''Bech: A Book.'' Mr. Updike has consented to sit for another talk with his creation on the subject of his new novel.

title: HOUSING: PITTSBURGH IS CHEAPEST
description: While high mortgage rates continue to plague the housing industry, home sales in some American cities are bucking the trend. In a Federal Home Loan Bank Board report on sales of new and existing homes in major metropolitan areas, Boston, Kansas City, Mo., Miami and Seattle far outpaced the rate of inflation during the second quarter.

title: Streaking Expos Down Mets
description: The Montreal Expos won their seventh straight game, defeating the Mets, 4-2, before a championship-minded crowd of 38,821 today.

title: Speaking Personally; 'WHY DO THEY HAVE TO LEAVE?'
description: WE MET on the Delaware River in 1959. Doug was 17 and I was 16. We both spent summers, plus spring and fall weekends, at the river, he with his family in Dingmans Ferry, Pa., and I with my family at our cabin near Hainesville, in Sussex County.

title: Marilyn Frison Is Married In Colorado to James Hand
description: Marilyn Frison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore H. Frison of Englewood, Colo., was married at the Vail (Colo.) Interfaith Chapel yesterday to James Hand, son of Mr. and Mrs. James. R. Hand of Ossining, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Patrick Kennedy, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Disability
description: To the Business Editor: In Binghamton, N.Y., we have had a sheltered workshop for over 30 years.

title: Photo of the Tatras mountians; A POLISH RESORT WHERE MOUNTIANS MEET THE SKY
description: The tiny cable car rises swiftly over the towering pines and steep ravines leading up to the peak called Kasprowy Weirch - 6,522 feet above sea level - in Poland's Tatra Mountains. Inside, a dozen people are packed like passengers on the IRT at rush hour. To the old Polish grandmothers with babushkas on their heads, it seems just another weekend distraction. To three or four young children in the car it is high adventure.

title: John McEnroe Is Not Unbeatable
description: To the Sports Editor: With all the babble about whether John McEnroe can be beaten, I think the fact that he almost didn't even make it to the finals is forgotten. He was sorely tried and nearly defeated then by Vitas Gerulaitis, and we might very well have had Borg and Gerulaitis in the final.

title: Alabama 28, Vanderbilt 8
description: NASHVILLE (AP) - Benny Perrin returned an interception 78 yards for one touchdown, and Russ Wood took a fumble and ran 33 yards for another as the Crimson Tide defense stymied Vanderbilt.

title: 7 Judges Asked to Combine Air Controllers' Strike Cases
description: A panel of seven Federal judges has been asked to consolidate 99 civil complaints filed against the striking Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization.

title: ATTENTION FOCUSES ON CRITIC OF CODY
