description: The recent disclosure that John Cardinal Cody, head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago, is under investigation by a grand jury continues to shake this city. But increasingly the focus is shifting to the possible role played by the Rev. Andrew M. Greeley, a well-known diocesan priest, in bringing the situation to the surface.

title: ESSAY ART FOLLOWS LIFE
description: In the old days, Opening Night of New York's Metropolitan Opera was a grand occasion when dowagers could show off their jewels, singers could sing out their hearts and opera lovers could thrill to the return to the stage of America's claim to world-class culture.

title: Theater in Review; 'THE BUTLER DID IT'
description: EAST FARMINGDALE WHEN plans to present ''Something's Afoot,'' a musical send-up of Agatha Christie mysteries, went askew, Frederic DeFeis, the Arena Players producer, turned to ''The Butler Did It,'' a nonmusical sendup of Agatha Christie mysteries, and a far better one at that.

title: Dane Wins Star Race
description: John Dane, a 31-year-old oil merchant from New Orleans, was declared the winner of Friday's yacht race in the Star Class World Championship series. But 35 of the 84 skippers filed protests after they were disqualified for jumping the gun. The winner of the event, fifth in the six-race series, was not decided until four hours after Dane crossed the finish line.

title: 7TH IRISH HUNGER STRIKER ENDS PROTEST IN BELFAST
description: Another Irish nationalist hunger striker at the Maze prison in Belfast gave up his fast tonight. Liam McCloskey, 25 years old, who had gone without food for 55 days, became the seventh striker to give up his protest, but he was only the third to end it on his own.

title: AS COSTS RISE, CONVENTION CENTER GETS SCALED DOWN
description: From the beginning, skeptics doubted the New York Exposition and Convention Center could be constructed within its budget. After all, it is hard to find a major project in the state - from Yankee Stadium to the Albany Mall - that did not cost dramatically more than planned.

title: LA SCALA TOUR BRINGS OUT JAPAN'S FERVOR FOR OPERA
description: Forty minutes before the curtain went up for the evening's performance of Puccini's ''La Boheme'' there was not a libretto to be had. And the thick pile of copies on sale for the next night's performance of ''The Barber of Seville'' was thinning fast.

title: ROCK: STONES' INFORMAL TEAMWORK
description: The Rolling Stones' 1981 American tour may turn out to be the biggest money-maker in the 25-year history of rock-and-roll. But at their opening performance yesterday at John F.Kennedy Stadium, the Stones were as informal, and occasionally as ragged, as a neighborhood garage band.

title: NEW TOTTENVILLE COACH INHERITS SENSITIVE TASK
description: Charles (Chick) Ciccarelli's second game as head coach of the Tottenville High School football team was not a success like his first game - a 14-0 victory over Curtis - but it did revive memories for him.

title: Latin Majority Seen in Dade
description: In four years, Dade County's Latin-American residents will outnumber non-Latin whites by about 43 percent to 42 percent, according to a new study by the county planning department. Blacks and members of other minority groups will make up the 15 percent remaining.

title: Institute Can Use Ma ny More Volunteers
description: The article on ''Money Alone Won't Solve Ills of the Elderly'' (Aug. 30) conveyed the erroneous impression that the only volunteers serving at the Ruth Taylor Institute are the 20 to 40 employees who are part of our Employees Adopt a Patient Program. It was most unfortunate that the article gave that impression despite lengthy telephone conversations with me, James Davis, the director, and Betsy Weiner of public relations.

title: Christine Chrissotimos Wed
description: Christine Chrissotimos, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Chrissotimos of Dongan Hills, S.I., was married yesterday to Anthony Occhipinti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Occhipinti of Stapleton, S.I. The Rev. Spiro Macris performed the ceremony at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in Bulls Head, S.I.

title: ISRAE L TURNS AWAY A HIJACKE D JET
description: A hijacked Yugoslav jetliner with 101 people aboard landed in Cyprus early today after Israel refused to let the plane land in Tel Aviv as the hijackers had demanded, the official Yugoslav press agency Tanjug reported.

title: Tennessee 10, Auburn 7
description: Steve Alatorre ran for a touchdown, and Fuad Reveiz kicked a field goal to lift the Volunteers. Alatorre, the quarterback, directed Tennessee's offense after the freshman starter, Alan Cockrell, injured his left knee on a hit 2:23 into the first quarter.

title: Philharmonic Offering 24 Open Rehearsals
description: The New York Philharmonic will sell tickets to 24 Thursday morning rehearsals this season. All rehearsals are scheduled to run from 10 o'clock to 12:30, with a 20-minute break at 11:15.

title: 20 Food Outlets Cited For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 20 food establishments it said had violated the Health Code. The department also released the names of three establishments that reopened after correcting earlier violations.

title: Topics Forms of Escape
description: Child's Play

title: COLD WAR IN THE WORLD OF CHESS
description: Anatoly Karpov, the 30-year-old chess champion of the world, is a short (5 feet 7 inches), thin (120 pounds), polite man, always the complete diplomat in his dealings, a member of Communist Party and the Central Committee of the Komsomol, rather secretive and highly intelligent - the very model of the Soviet New Man. He goes around the world saying the right things and generally everyone is charmed in the process. Away from the chessboard, he gives people the idea he is a mild man. But there is one person in the world he actively dislikes, and that is the 50-year-old Viktor Korchnoi. They meet in Merano, Italy, this Thursday to play for the world championship, and if it is a repeat of their 1978 match in the Philippines, it will be much more than mere chess.

title: Military Manpower Climbs
description: The manpower of the armed forces increased by 2,210 in August to a total of 2,083,940, in excess of the Administration's goal of 2,080,000 for the 1981 fiscal year ending this month, the Pentagon has reported.

title: Headliners; The Law's Reach
description: For Jack Henry Abbott, the convict-author turned literary cause celebre, a brief stint of freedom ended last week when he was arrested at an oil-pipeline inspection yard in Morgan City, La. Mr. Abbott, whose release from prison was aided by author Norman Mailer, fled from custody on July 18, after a dispute with Richard Adan on the Lower East Side in Manhattan. Mr. Adan was later found dead on the sidewalk. According to law enforcement sources, who picked up his trail several weeks ago in New Orleans, Mr. Abbott has been living in flophouses and changing jobs every few days. ''He didn't have much to say,'' said Lieut. Daniel Dossett of the Morgan City police. ''He looked surprised, but he knew why we were there.'' Mr. Abbott's book, ''In The Belly Of The Beast,'' recounting his prison experiences from the age of 12, has apparently already earned $100,000 in royalties.

title: BOSTON BOOMS AMID MUNICIPAL DECAY
description: Boston these days is a fascinating contrast of boom and bust. All around the Boston Common and the adjacent Public Garden, which form the city's historic green and flowering heart, there is the sound and look of vibrance: hurrying crowds of office workers and lingering tourists and college students; double-parked cement trucks and trailers of steel girders and reinforcing rods, swinging cranes and spumes of dust from old mortar smashed to make way for renovated office space.

title: Cincinnati 10, Rutgers 0
description: CINCINNATI (AP) - The quarterback Dan Barrett ran 6 yards for a touchdown, and James Bettis, the tailback, carried 22 times for 148 yards for Cincinnati.

title: 'JUDICIAL RESTRAINT': NO FIXED PRINCIPLE
description: ''I do well understand the difference between legislating and judging,'' Sandra Day O'Connor told the Senate Judiciary Committee as her confirmation hearings began. ''As a judge, it is not my function to develop public policy.'' And last week, when the Senate voted 99-0 to approve her nomination to the Supreme Court, President Reagan expressed his pleasure in a statement praising her judicial philosophy as ''one of restraint.''

title: Around the Nation; Experts Blame Skywalks In Hyatt Hotel Disaster
description: Engineering experts say that two crowded skywalks that fell at the Hyatt Regency Hotel were too heavy to support themselves and would probably have collapsed eventually under their own weight, The Kansas City Times reported today.

title: KRYPTON'S TOURING GOLF PRO
description: Golf Digest Commemorative Pro-Am, they had a new story to add to all those other tales about Sam Snead that have created an ageless folk hero.

title: The Lively Arts; FOR THE STAGE, TRIED BUT TRUE
description: SURVEYING the new season's schedules of representative theaters on the Island reinforces old impressions. Brand new plays are chancy and seldom done. And the oldest, unestablished ones must be offset by the works of favored playwrights.

title: LABORITES TO SETTLE BITTER FIGHT TODAY
description: A bitter and divisive struggle for the deputy leadership of the Labor Party, which could result in a takeover by the extreme l eft, will be decided tomorrow on the first day of the party's annua l conference at the seaside resort of Brighton.

title: CAIRO BEGINNING ITS EFFORTS TO 'UPROOT INDISCIPLINE'
description: The Government of President Anwar el-Sadat has begun carrying out his demand to ''uproot indiscipline'' in various areas of Egyptian life as part of his crackdown on religious extremists and political opponents.

title: BILL SETS A MINIMUM FOR CO-OP RESERVE FUNDS
description: In response to growing concern about the adequacy of reserve funds in New York City co-op conversions, the City Council will soon be asked to consider legislation that would require sponsors to set aside a minimum fund equal to 3 percent of the building's purchase price.

title: Egbert C. Hadley Dead at 92; Headed Middlebury Trustees
description: Egbert C. Hadley, former chairman of the board of trustees at Middlebury College and a retired ballistics engineer, died Friday at Porter Medical Center in Middlebury, where he lived.

title: Jill Marion Efron Married
description: Jill Marion Efron, daughter of Mrs. Aimee Eden of New York, and Kal Efron of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday at the East 55th Street Conservative Synagogue to Neil Harris Tipograph, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Tipograph of Hewlett Harbor, L.I. Rabbi Reuven Siegel performed the ceremony. The bridegroom's grandfather, Henry Modell, is founder of the Modell's Sporting Goods store chain.

title: City Business
description: To the Business Editor: William Norris, who suggests ''Let's Let Business Help Run the Cities'' (Sept. 13), deserves the Mirage Award for his idea. Before business runs cities, it will have to quit running from them.

title: Other Business; THE BIG SURVIVORS OF THE BIG MERGERS
description: What happens to a chief executive when his company is taken over? He usually stays put, although often his underlings don't. Ralph E. Bailey, chairman and chief executive officer of Conoco Inc., has retained that job since E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company took over his company in the biggest acquisition ever. On Thursday, he will also become vice chairman and a director.

title: Children's Books
description: THE GATHERING By Virginia Hamilton. 179 pp. New York: Greenwillow. $8.95. (Ages 12 to 16) By JOYCE MILTON

title: THE BIRTH OF THE CONVENIENCE BLUES
description: In the beginning, say the 15th century, before there were video games, home entertainment centers, media rooms, computerized information-retrieval systems and electric shoe polishers, there was the kitchen. And, all things considered, it was pretty good. Never mind that the water was kept in a trough in the courtyard, that the fuel had to be hauled, the fires tended constantly, t he spits turned by hand - aft er all, what were serfs and women for? At least, the fire was cont ained within a fireplace rather than, as it had been a couple of cen turies earlier, blazing midroom with smoke freely wafting among the rafters until it drifted out through a ceiling hole. By the 15th century, relative delicacy prevailed - fragrant herbs strewn among the floor rushes helped combat the all-pervasive odor of greas e, and table linen, a recent introduction, was having a positive effe ct on manners. Indeed, a late-medieval householder who could boast a modern kitchen in which to feast and make merry must have consider ed himself a very lucky man.

title: Amanda Groves Becomes a Bride
description: Amanda Frances Tottenham Groves, daughter of Benjamin A. Groves and Mrs. John D.E. Orr, both of New York, was married at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest yesterday to Patrick MacIntyre Outerbridge. He is a son of I. Stuart Outerbridge Jr. of Hamilton, Bermuda, and the late Patricia Graham Outerbridge.

title: 'WORKERS, DO NOT EVEN THINK OF UNITING'
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining Out; COMING UP SHORT IN LONG VALLEY
description: RESTAURANTS can be chameleonic in their ability to change from one visit to the next. New restaurants are particularly prone to this inconsistency, which is why we usually allow time for a new establishment to settle down before it is reviewed.

title: September 27, 1981
description: NONFICTION

title: HANG TOUGH WHEN DEALING WITH HANDYMEN
description: HANG TOUGH. I love the way it sounds. Hard and callous, and as uncompromising as the Ayatollah Khomeini. Carnage Ensues. Another lilting admonition reminiscent of Attila the Hun, Jack the Ripper and Lizzie Borden.

title: 'I ALWAYS WANTED TO BE ON BROADWAY'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Ian McKellen, the Tony Award-winning star of ''Amadeus,'' will perform his one-man show ''Acting Shakespeare'' next Sunday evening at the Broadhurst. By IAN McKELLEN

title: WATER TROUBLING CAMDEN
description: CAMDEN THIS financially troubled, high-crime, high-unemployment city of 85,000 fears that polluted drinking water may be its next problem. Drought earlier this year reduced the flow of the Delaware River so much that salt concentrations from Delaware Bay crept upstream to within a mile of Camden's well-field, far beyond the usual limit of Chester, Pa. A dry August brought warnings that this winter might be worse.

title: Dining Out; INTRIGUING FARE, RIVER VIEW
description: GAYLORDSVILLE FRITZ & FOX, a restaurant on Route 7, north of New Milford, might more appropriately be named Fox & Fox. The Fritz of the partnership has now gone, and James Fox and his wife, Eileen, are running the three-year-old establishment by themselves. He does the cooking; she is as maitre d'hotel and manager.

title: NEW YORK CITY
description: The Tatekawa brothers, Walter and Alvaro, led George Washington to its second straight victory yesterday, a 28-6 trouncing of Truman. Walter Tatekawa, a fullback, scored twice and rushed for 105 yards.

title: A Bad Defense
description: To the Business Editor: ''Now It's Defense vs. the Deficit'' (Sept. 13). Wrong. It's defense against our economy, our very security as a viable world economic power.

title: Ideas & Trends; On a Clear Day You Can See ...
description: When Cecil D. Andrus, Interior Secretary in the Carter Administration, prohibited strip mining on 9,000 acres next to Utah's Bryce Canyon National Park, environmentalists as well as mining interests sued. Environmentalists sought protection for more acreage; industry, for less.

title: U.S. Jockeys Triumph
description: A team of American riders dominated the first two of three races to achieve an easy victory over a world team in the third Jockey International competition tonight at the Meadowlands.

title: VW Agrees to Notify Owners Of Liability on Certain Models
description: Volkswagen of America has agreed to notify 400,000 owners of diesel-powered Volkswagens and Audis that they may be eligible for reimbursements for engine repair costs, the Federal Trade Commission has announced.

title: 7-1 Shot Takes Super Derby
description: Island Whirl, a 7-1 shot, held off Summing, the 7-5 favorite, in the stretch drive today to capture the $300,000 winner's purse in the second running of the $500,000 Super Derby at Louisiana Downs.

title: REAGAN PLAN FAILS TO LIFT WALL STREET'S GLOOM
description: Market losses deepened despite President Reagan's plans for further budget cuts. Bond prices plunged and the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 824.01, losing 12.18 points on the week. Friday's 11.13-point drop was attributed in part to a prediction by Joseph Granville, the flamboyant forecaster with a wide following, of bad day for stocks tomorrow. Consumer pr ices rose eight-tenths of a percent in August, or at an annual, uncom pounded rate of 9.6 percent. Moderation in housing costshelped bring the figure down from July's torrid annual rate of 14.4 percent.

title: Lisa Mary Cullen Bride of Kevin Patrick Coleman
description: Lisa Mary Cullen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Ward Cullen Jr. of Plandome and Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Kevin Patrick Coleman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Coleman of Youngstown, Ohio. Msgr. John Barry performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I.

title: REAGAN SETS MISSILE DECISIONS
description: President Reagan is wrapping up work on the MX missile and B-1 bomber in a ''quiet but busy'' stay at Camp David and will reveal his decisions next week, possibly at a news conference, a White House spokesman said today.

title: UNPERSUASIVE CASE AGAINST 'FEDORA'
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPAN AGREES TO LET ARAFAT VISIT NEXT MONTH
description: The Japanese Government has agreed to allow Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to visit the country next month.

title: DELBELLO AND STATE AT ODDS OVER HOUSING AID
description: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Alfred B. DelBello announced agreements early last week with two state housing agencies for a ''multimillion dollar'' program to build new housing in Westchester and for $7 million worth of bonds to provide new mortgages.

title: FLORIDA ALLIGATORS THRIVING AT A SPA IN ISRAEL
description: Until the 1967 war, this narrow sliver of Israeli territory was believed to be indefensible. Flanked by Syria on one side and Jordan on the other, it was vulnerable to easy attack, and the Israelis finally stopped trying to send patrols in to exercise their claim.

title: zf Follow-Up on the News; Wells Well
description: Displaying some of the pioneering spirit of its deceased founder, tiny Wells College in Aurora, N.Y., plunked down $100,000 in speculative cash and began to drill for natural gas on its campus. Half a mile down, the driller struck a pocket.

title: THE PERILS OF A TWO-INCOME FAMILY
description: Didi Moore is a New York-based writer who recently became half of a two-income family. By Didi Moore When Claire Gruppo and James O'Brien, both 28 now, started dating, she was an assistant editor at a New York publishing house, and he was a freelance writer. Neither one had much money, and they shared all their expenses equally. When they married three years ago, Claire and Jim continued to keep their money separate. They went on splitting everything down the middle, from rent to dinner bills, even after Jim got a job at a large public-relations firm and began to earn more than Claire. ''It was unwieldy, a bookkeeper's nightmare,'' says Claire. ''We talked a lot at the beginning of our marriage about pooling our money, but it really made me nervous. I didn't want to do it. I believed it was important emotionally to pay my own way. I wanted so strongly to e stablish my independen ce -to prove I could take care of myself. I had memories of my mot her, who had to ask my father for money. I never wanted to ask anyon e.''

title: SOCIETIES PRESERVE THE CONDUCTOR'S ART
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Alan Rosenthal writes frequently on music subjects. ALAN ROSENTHAL

title: RANGERS ROOKIE A HOT PROSPECT
description: By JAMES F. CLARITY STOCKHOLM The talk of the New York Rangers' Scandanavian tour, even more discussed than the Swedish crystal the players bought and the cloudberr y ice cream they ate, was Reijo Ruotsalainen, the small, blond, Finnish defenseman who speaks little English, but is eloquent in body language.

title: Tinkering
description: The problem President Reagan went rushing onto television Thursday to patch up is not Wall Street's gloom or Democratic gloating. The problem is his program, in particular its centerpiece, the three-year cut in income tax rates.

title: Linda Bogdanoff Bride Of Marc M. Griggs Jr.
description: The marriage of Linda Bogdanoff to Marc M. Griggs Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. M. Michael Griggs of Pemaquid Harbor, Me., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. David Bogdanoff, parents of the bride, in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. The Rev. David Houston, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: ILLINOIS PRIMARY CREATES STRAINS WITHIN G.O.P.
description: In a race that could pit the White House against the Republican Governor here, a h andful of Republican state legisla tors are competing for the post of Lieutenant Governor, which has bee n vacant for two months.

title: CZECHOSLOVAKIA ALARMED BY RISE IN DIVORCES
description: Czechoslovakia, which has developed an extensive social system to promote family life, is now confronted with one of the highest divorce rates in the world.

title: NOW HEAR THIS: 222-COUNT 'EM - 222 GREAT CLASSICAL THEMES
description: Has it ever bothered you, while coming off an elevator, to be humming some curious classical ditty? Has it ever bothered you, while buying a TV dinner, to hear a familiar but mysterious melody piped in over the Muzak box? How about in a dentist's office before the drilling begins?

title: CIVIL SERVICE, BASTION OF MEDIOCRITY
description: WHEN the state's voters elect a new Governor on Nov. 3, whether it be Tom Kean or Jim Florio, the new administration will be faced with implementing the programs promised to the people. The success of those programs, be they conservative or liberal, will hinge largely on the attitudes, direction and cooperation of our state work force, some 80,000 strong.

title: Food; ON TAP, WINES FROM CALIFORNIA
description: OENOPHILES, both amateur and professional, have been spending the weekend in Glen Cove at a wine symposium. This year the emphasis in on California, previous symposiums having been devoted to the wines of France and Italy.

title: NOT MUCH HAS CHANGED SINCE FREUD
description: PSYCHOANALYSIS The Impossible Profession. By Janet Malcolm. 174 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $9.95.

title: Rock 'n' Retail
description: If Derek Sutton thinks that the music industry would go out of business if it weren't for expensive advertising campaigns like Styx's, he's wrong (''Rock 'n' Retail: Styx on Tour,'' by Tony Scherman, Aug. 16).

title: MANDATING HOMEWORK
description: STRATFORD ''DO you have any homework?'' Parents are still posing that question to their children at dinner tables throughout the state each evening as public schools get down to serious business. But they need not ask in Stratford. Y Homewo rk here has become a mandatory exercise for the ne arly 7,000 students in the town's 12 public schools under a policy ad opted by the Board of Education.

title: IF BLACK WANTS TO WIN
description: You can't routinely play to win with Black because all the routines favor White. Bobby Fischer, before his retirement, often used to ask incredulously, ''What are you doing trying to attack when you haven't yet equalized?'' And no one ever critized the former world champion for timidity at the board.

title: Disability
description: To the Business Editor: ''Aiding the Disabled'' (Sept. 6) speaks of a commitment to full employment for the disabled working populatio n. Two areas that need further exploration: the availability of a co mprehensive rehabilitation system and the sheltered works hops.

title: Murdoch in London in Effort To End Sunday Times Crisis
description: Rupert Murdoch, the publisher, arrived here today from New York to try to settle a new labor crisis that has halted publication of The Sunday Times.

title: TIMES have certainly changed since granddad and his football cronies posed on the college fence for yearbook pictures.  Decked out in turtleneck sweaters, with handlebar mustaches and hari parted down the middle, granddad's college team looked anything but professional.
description: Sure, there were under-the-table payoffs then, too, and some schools, as early as the 1890's, had football receipts of close to $100,000. Still, the idea that college athletes were amateurs engaged in a healthy extracurricular diversion was a bit more believable before the advent of multi-million dollar television contracts.

title: IRISH TROUBLES
description: THE PRISONER'S WIFE By Jack Holland. 177 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Co. $9.95. A BREED OF HEROES By Alan Judd. 288 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $13.95.

title: STABLER WOULD LIKE TO PASS ON PERFORMANCES AGAINST JETS
description: The New York Jets' defense is insulted. It stole four of Ken Stabler's passes last year and five the year before, and instead of marveling at the Jets, some people wonder: What could have been wrong with Stabler?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You have brought a renewal not only for Poland. You have renewed the spirit of workers around the world.

title: QUESTIONS SURROUND INDIAN POINT PANEL
description: WASHINGTON THE appointment this month of a three-member licensing board to investigate the Indian Point nuclear power plant in Buchanan brought to a close a protracted two-year ordeal that frustrated the plant's critics and re-emphasized the difficulties involved in determining nuclear safety.

title: MANY I-87 EMERGENCY PHONES TO BE REMOVED
description: New York State will remove about half of the emergency telephones next week on the Adirondack Northway, the 176-mile section of Interstate 87 that runs from Albany to the Canadian border, to save money.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Picture stories. During the past six years, we've reported at least a half-dozen unsuccessful attempts to provide Americans with Yankee equivalents of that favorite of the Latin countries - the fotonovela, the paperback book that tells its story through many pictures and a minimum of text. Some have been novelizations of popular movies that make use of scenes from the film. Some have been original romances, narrated through photographs posed by models.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Stephen King
description: This week two books by Stephen King sit high on the best seller lists -''Cujo'' for the seventh time on the hardcover fiction list, ''Firestarter'' for the seventh time on the mass market paperback list. Not a bad record for a man who less than 10 years ago was teaching high school English and spending his spare time writing novels in his native Maine.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES MAGAZINE / PART 2
description: SEPTEMBER 27, 1981 12 ENTER THE COMPUTER By Myron Berger The future home-computer network may deliver much of what it promised. 25 LIVING WITH ELECTRONICS By George O'Brien Wired invaders in the form of electronics are changing the way we live and work at home.

title: Man Is Convicted in Shooting After a Nassau Rock Concert
description: A 24-year-old former Long Island man was convicted today in Nassau County Court of the fatal shooting of a man and the wounding of a bystander after a rock concert in the Nassau County Veterans Memorial Coliseum in 1979.

title: LIFE AND DEATH: COMPREHENDING THE GREAT GIFT
description: YEARS ago when my grandmother died, the funeral procession passed a convent on the way to the cemetery. I remember the nuns in the garden stopping where they stood, a somber tableau of respect. They didn't know my grandmother, but they did take a moment to show her honor.

title: Mary Tauskey Is Married
description: Mary Anne Tauskey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Henry Tauskey of New Hope, Pa., was married there yesterday in St. Martin's Roman Catholic Church to William Alexander Parkhurst, son of William Man Parkhurst of New York and Mary Sherman Parkhurst of Gulfstream, Fla. The Rev. Paul J. Carey performed the ceremony. The bride was a gold medalist at the 1976 Olympic Games in Montreal as a member of the winning United States Three Day Event equestrian team.

title: SOL LEWITT HAS A HOMECOMING IN HARTFORD
description: Since Sept. 15, a team of draftsmen has been doing a balancing act on high ladders, crouching on hands and knees, and experiencing a few muscle spasms in carrying out the installation of the Sol LeWitt retrospective that will open on Tuesday at Hartford's Wadsworth Atheneum Museum. This School of LeWitt, in Renaissance terms, will have put in some 2,000 man hours, or more than 80 days' labor. They will have used approximately 2,000 pencil leads, which had to be sharpened and resharpened on sandpaper - enlisting the aid of relatives and friends and even local schoolchildren. Well over 1,000 crayons will have been worn down.

title: No Headline
description: Like my fellow Rhode Islander Mary Cantwell , I think of carton and cotton as homonyms, and like her father, I wo nder whether people willserve a collation. On one point, Miss Cantwel l is incorrect: The cabinet has little relationship to the semiso lid which is called a milkshake in partibus, and a true Rhode Islan d milkshake even less.

title: MANCHESTER BANK CUTS OFF MOR TGAGES
description: BECAUSE of unstable, high interest rates, the Heritage Savings and Loan Association of Manchester, with branches in four other communities, has stopped accepting mortgage applications ''for the present.''

title: Details of race in Sports section.
description: Melody Gilbert, who came to the city last week from Washington to seek her fortune in television production, found a way to spend her first Saturday in New York - stretched out in the bleachers abutting Central Park watching the first international mile race on Fifth Avenue.

title: Margo Amgot to Be Bride Of Craig Stern on Oct. 31
description: Milton Amgot and Janet Laib of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margo Dene Amgot, to Craig Stewart Stern, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Stern of Howard Beach, Queens. The wedding will take place on Oct. 31.

title: The Real Story
description: To the Editor:

title: LAYFAYETTE DEFEATS COLUMBIA
description: Lafayette won its third game withou t a loss, defeating Columbia University, 2 8-13, yesterday at Baker Field. The loss wa s Columbia's 10th straight; the Lions are 0-2 this season. Lafayette g ained 513 yards in total offense and scored 18 points in the second quarter to take an 18-10 halftime lead. Lafayette's powerful rushing attack was led by Rodger Shepko. Shepko, a jun ior, carried the ball 23 times for a career-high 214 yards and sco red two touchdowns. Lafayette's other running back, Craig William s, also scored two touchdowns. Shepko's best previous performance w as 82 yards on 16 carries against Maine in his freshman season.

title: Critics' Choices; MUSIC
description: The week in music begins with piano virtuosity in the grand manner and ends with pianism of quite a different kind.

title: Nader Urges Activism To Counter Reagan
description: Ralph Nader told his supporters yesterday that they must become full-time citizen activists if the consumer movement is to survive the Reagan Administration.

title: OCEAN MARATHONERS HAVING PROBLEMS
description: By JOANNE A. FISHMAN

title: The World; Haig, Gromyko Make a Start On Negotiations
description: Relations between the Reagan Administration and Soviet Union have been so strained that last week's announcement that the two sides would begin talks on limiting medium-range nuclear weapons in Europe, although long anticipated, was hardly anticlimatic.

title: IT'S BEAUTIFUL, LUSH AND CHARMING
description: IN this portable, compact and threateningly mobile society, people are beginning to stake geographical claims as though these were prime shares in a bull market. Heritage, family and land have become the life jacket of a civilization that rapidly seems to lose focus on its identity and ideals.

title: The Region; Deadly Threat to A City's Water
description: Though their wells aren't about to run dry, Atlantic City residents may soon be without their water. Toxic chemicals, many of them known to cause cancer, are seeping toward the the city's drinking supply and could rea ch it, Federal officials say, in a year or two.

title: Mailbox; Interference Penalty Should Be Increased
description: To the Sports Editor: On all defensive pass interference calls, the offended team has choice of accepting play or penalty, whichever is the biggest gainer.

title: FIGHTING FUEL COSTS
description: WHILE the cost of fuel oil continues to climb, little is being done to develop a comprehensive program to reduce energy use in singlefamily homes, says Robert Hoppe, an energy conservation specialist with the Brookhaven National Laboratory.

title: FOR HOW LONG CAN POLAND PRACTICE ITS BRINKMANSHIP
description: WARSAW LAST week for the first time, the Polish au thorities seriously considered declaring a state of emergency - a drastic step tantamountto imposing martial law that could well have led to street clashes between civilians and security forces and bro ught the year-old crisisto a bloody climax.

title: HOW TO AVOID AUTO-REPAIR RIPOFFS
description: The scenario is familiar: Thr ee hundred mil es from home your car suddenly begins to sputter and lose speed. Yo u reach a service station just as the engine dies. After a quic k inspection, a mechanic announces that the generator must be replaced, but that he cannot get one before morning. But you cannot wait, so you leave the car, hitch a ride to a bus stop and go home b y Greyhound. Two days later, you return, pay $58 for a rebuilt repl acement generator plus $60 for labor, turn around and go home, where the engine promptly dies again. You learn from your neighborhood mechanic, whom you have used for years, that the replacement was a du d.

title: Cuban Liberty, American License
description: What a splendid idea it must have seemed to someone on President Reagan's staff: establish a new broadcast service, patterned on Radio Free Europe, to carry information into Cuba. The White House has now duly proposed just such a station, ''to tell the truth to the Cuban people,'' and reporters were told it would be called ''Radio Marti,'' after Jose Marti, the father of Cuban independence and a hero in Latin America.

title: Book on Klan Violence Is Available to Many
description: We were very pleased to see the article, ''Schools Seeking to Counter Ku Klux Klan'' (Sept. 13). The curriculum mentioned, ''Violence, the Ku Klux Klan and the Struggle for Equality,'' can be used by colleges and universities, church groups, resource centers and others concerned with Klan violence and bigotry, as well as by secondary-school teachers, as reported.

title: TEHERAN DELAYING ITS U.N. DELEGATION
description: Iran disclosed today that it had postponed the arrival of a delegation to the United Nations General Assembly after receiving a warning that the United States would not allow anyone who took part in the takeover of the American Embassy in Teheran to enter the country.

title: PENTAGON PLANS TO PUBLISH STUDY DESCRIBING SOVIET ARMED STRENGTH
description: The Reagan Administration plans to make public a detailed description of Soviet military strength next week to document its contention that the West faces an increasing threat from the Soviet Union.

title: TOWARDS A NATION OF CONTROLLERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Reading and Writing; TRAVELING
description: The summer is over and we have all returned home, yet the travel books keep arriving. There is in men a ''centrifugal tendency,'' as Peter Quennell put it, a combination of curiosity, restlessness and need for novelty, that drives them out of the familiar into the strange.

title: City Restaurateur Convicted For Failing to Pay Sales Tax
description: A Manhattan restaurateur was convicted Friday of grand larceny for failing to pay $50,000 in state sales tax.

title: CALIFORNIA MUSEUM CAUGHT ITS THIEF, BUT U.S. INSTITUTIONS ARE VULNERABLE
description: In the final resolution of a crime story out of a museum director's nightmare, John Hellson, a graybearded, blue-eyed, 49-year-old confidence man, has been sentenced for stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars' worth of irreplaceable anthropological treasures from the University of California's Lowie Museum.

title: EYEING WARSAW, WEST GETS CAUTIOUS ON EAST BLOC LOANS
description: LONDON THE world banking community, still reeling from the stresses of stretching out Poland's debt repayments, registered disturbing new tremors on the creditors' Richter scale last week when Rumania announced it would seek to postpone repayment of more than a quarter of its $10 billion debts to the West. For bankers, Rumania's ''temporary payments incapacity'' reinforced growing concern about loans to Eastern Europe that now total an estimated $80 billion, not counting loans to the Soviet Union. Slow growth, energy shortages, and social and political uncertainties in the region have produced a burst of belated caution on the part of Western lenders.

title: 2 of Gov. Brown's Top Aides Are Cleared of Covering Up
description: Two of Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr.'s top aides have been cleared by the state bar of covering up allegations that the Governor's staff had misused state computers.

title: THE LONG ORDEAL OF JAMES BRADY
description: Richard E. Cytowic, M.D., a neurologist in Washington, D.C., writes on medical subjects. By Richard E. Cytowic It all began with a voice over the George Washington University Hospital intercom system: ''All physicians in the trauma team to the E.R. ... All physicians in the trauma team to the E.R.'' It was the hospital's Code Orange disaster plan.

title: Long Island Housing; NEW TAX BREAKS FOR SOLAR SYSTEMS
description: science teacher at Islip High School, installed kerosene heaters in his home last winter to cut down on his oil bills, but although they saved money, he disliked the odor and the extra work. This winter, he will be heating part of his 2,500-square-foot ranch house in Great River with solar energy.

title: RED BANK BEATS RARITAN
description: Red Bank sc ored on two short runs and a field goal in the second quarter yeste rday to defeat Raritan, 24-15, in Red Bank. Wayne Gutri dge scored on a 3-yard run to cap a 21-yard drive, and Wayne Smith f inished off a 35-yard drive with a 2-yard run for a 14-7 lead. Gr eg Montgomery, who kicked 3 extra points, added a field goal from 37 yards.

title: Thais Report Rebel Losses
description: Thai military officials said today that Government forces have killed more than 300 Communist guerrillas in southern Thailand this year.

title: Comment; EVIL EXPECTATIONS
description: Y OU can't inhale and exhale at the same time. Put differently, today's inflation and high interest rates are the result of a head-on collision between a tight monetary policy and a stimulative fiscal policy.

title: Environews
description: ONE of the corporations that the United States Attorney's office has charged with polluting the ground water of several communities in Atlantic County is, according to law-enforcement sources, under investigation by a Federal grand jury for alleged dumping at the Lone Pine Landfill in Freehold Township.

title: A Vocal Correction
description: I recently phoned Dwight Bolinger to compliment him on his article, ''Voice Imprints'' (On Language, July 26). I was disappointed only with his implication that my error in English was part of my normal speech pattern.

title: Politics; 2 LONGTIME ALLIES SQUARING OFF
description: IN THE 1971 legislative elections, there was some unexpected news out of Atlantic County. A Democrat, Dr. Joseph L. McGahn, a physician, defeated State Senator Frank S. ''Hap'' Farley, dean of the upper house and a longtime Republican leader in the state.

title: MARIST IS A 17-14 VICTOR AS VIN MUNN GAINS 163
description: Vin Munn, a junior halfback, rushed for 163 yards on 19 carries and scored two touchdowns to guide Marist (1-0) to a 17-14 victory over Hudson Catholic (1-1) yesterday at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City.

title: Critics' Choices; ART
description: Manhattan is foolproof as a photographic subject, with the result that we're all rather jaded about its imagery. Yet in ''Manhattan Observed,'' a show of 300 contemporary works by 14 photographers at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West (through Thursday only), we see that the possibilities are endless, after all, and that good photographers can always come up with something new and arresting.

title: CHILDREN BEARING GUNS: A GROWING PERIL IN THE CITY
description: A Harlem youth who is serving time for armed robbery said he got his first gun - a .45 automatic - when he was 8 years old. He said he broke into a store, found the .45-caliber gun and took it. When he wasn't using the .45 ''to stick up people,'' he said, he liked to shoot it late at night near the Polo Grounds housing projects - or out his own window. His parents could hear the shots. ''But what could they do about it?'' he asked.

title: Debuts: Music in Review; Yuri Lotakov, Pianist From the Soviet Union
description: Yuri Lotakov, a 36-year old pianist from the Soviet Union, made his New York debut Thursday evening at the 92d Street Y. He played music by Handel, Mozart, Schubert, Scriabin, Metner and Liszt. First, let it be said that Mr. Lotakov's technique is a commanding one.

title: REDMEN IS STILL A LATE CHARGER
description: Fans attending the 500-mile race at Pocono today shouldn't look for Brian Redman to lead the first few laps of the race. While all of the speedsters are contesting for the early lead, Redman's Lola T-600 will probably be hanging back in sixth or seventh place, his driver just keeping his eye on the goings on a straightaway ahead.

title: About Long Island
description: JAMES O'CONNELL'S basement is that of a boy who was a fireman when he grew up. There is a brass firemen's pole in the middle of the floor. In cabinets there are model fire trucks and antique toy fire trucks and modern toy fire trucks and decanters in the shape of fire trucks. In a corner ther e is an old New York fire hydrant and a fire alarm box and one of the tickertape machines that used to tell the firemen which alarm had been pulled.

title: NICARAGUA'S BEST PITCHER
description: DENNIS MARTINEZ understood why his mother was upset. She had worked hard to save enough money for his college engineering courses in Granada, Nicaragua, and she did not want him going to the United States to play baseball.

title: 'WILLIE STARK'- FROM OPERA HOUSE TO HOME SCREEN
description: Despite the severe critical drubbing it received earlier this year, ''Willie Stark,'' the controversial opera by Carlisle Floyd directed by Harold Prince for the Houston Grand Opera and Washington's Kennedy Center, has been filmed for public television and will be broadcast tomorrow night (8 P.M. on WNET/Channel 13) to launch the ninth year of PBS 's ''Gr eat Performances'' series.

title: AS HOUSE NEARS ACTION ON RIGHTS BILL, THE LOBBYISTS GET BUSIER
description: The songs and slogans of the civil rights movement are rarely heard here these days, but its spirit lives on among a small group of lobbyists fighting for renewal of the Voting Rights Act of 1965.

title: Around the World; Bonn Is Said to Decide To Free Brandt Case Spy
description: West Germany has decided to free Gunter Guillaume, the East German spy whose arrest brought down the Government of Chancellor Willy Brandt, Government sources reported today.

title: DUARTE'S STRATEGY MAY WORK BETTER IN U.S. THAN IN SALVADOR
description: El Salvador's President, Jose Napleon Duarte, swept through Washington last week, meeting privately with President Reagan and his advisers and grabbing every opportunity to argue the wisdom of United States support for his beleaguered regime. It was, even hiscritics conce ded, a fine political performance. In five days, Mr. Duarte also v isited the State Department, Congress, the Organization of American S tates, the A.F.L.-C.I.O., and appeared on television andradio talk sh ows. Far from the economic disarray and political violence of E l Salvador, this soft-spoken, sorrowful-faced man's message seeme d eminently reasonable: The junta is struggling against extremists of left and right to achieve peace and democracy through free election s in March.

title: MADAM AMBASSADOR
description: DIPLOMATIC IMMUNITY By Tad Szulc. 405 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. 4.95.

title: Prison Guards' Union Punished For '79 Strike
description: The state's Public Employment Relations Board today suspended dues checkoff privileges of the union representing state prison guards for the next 18 months, in punishment for its 17-day strike in 1979.

title: In Hardy's Footsteps
description: To the Editor:

title: AS H & R BLOCK SEES IT, THE NEW TAX ISN'T MUCH OF A BREAK
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. T HE new tax law has set H & R Block abuzz. Some 85,000 new students have signed up for Block's tax courses at offices around the country, the familiar yellow Income Tax Workbook is being drastically revised, and an advertising campaign is being hustled together in Chicago by Block's new agency, J. Walter Thompson.

title: Crafts; 'SACRED VOYAGE' IN MONTCLAIR
description: ''SACRED VOYAGE,'' an installation by Chris Martens now on view at the Montclair Art Museum, has converted the East Gallery into a ritual environment.

title: FRANCE SHADES MIDEAST POLICY JUST A LITTLE
description: France has an inveterately independent foreign policy and an inveterately interdependent economy. The second does not quite cancel out the first, but it shades it. Francois Mitterrand has managed, for the moment, to mark himself off from Valery Giscard d'Estaing on East-West relations (he shows more West) and North-South questions (he shows more South). On the Middle East, despite a high bound or two, he has tended to walk with one foot in his predecessors' ruts and one out.

title: PERU'S LEADER UNRUFFLED BY STRIKES AND BOMBINGS
description: The 13-month-old elected Government of President Fernando Belaunde Terry is being strained by strikes and by a wave of terrorist bombings, and some dissatisfaction with the situation has been voiced from within the military.

title: About Westchester
description: WHITE PLAINS AT first glance, the interior of the Westchester County Center does not seem felicitous for a singles event. There are no dim lights, no hanging plants, no intimate bar from which to order white wine and check out the person wedged next to you. With its huge open space, its mezzanine seats and varnished wood floors, the place, in fact, seems more appropriate to a basketball game or boat show.

title: NATIVE RAJA, $77.60, STUNS COWDIN FIELD
description: Stakes races for 2-year-old colts are supposed to suggest something about the following year's Kentucky Derby. Yesterday's $57,000 Cowdin at Belmont continued a pattern in this year's tests for juveniles of suggesting only one thing about next year's Derby: it appears that anyone with a healthy colt in his barn has a shot.

title: No Headline
description: An article on Connecticut cooking schools Sept. 13 incorrectly reported the telephone number of the Silo Cooking School in New Milford. The number is 355-0300.

title: Antiques; OBJECTS, FURNITURE, PRE-1840, AT ARMORY
description: THE 15th Annual Connecticut Antiques Show with 103 exhibits of authentic early American furniture and decorations, will be staged Friday through Sunday, Oct. 2-4, at the State Armory in Hartford on Capital Avenue at Broad Street.

title: New Jersey Housing; WHERE 'COLONIAL' REALLY MEANS IT
description: ROBERT K. SHAW is not a purist, but he does wince when he thinks of modern furniture adorning his homes. As head of Stratton Enterprises Inc. of Mountain Lakes, Mr. Shaw is in the business of building new ''old homes'' in Colonial style.

title: HEAVY WEATHER INTEREST RATES SEEM IN NO HURRY TO FALL
description: WASHINGTON THE long-awaited decline in interest rates, necessary to give President Reagan's economic program a chance, is still long awaited. Despite a drop in the prime lending rate last week, the rest of the economic signals were a reminder that there are as many forces holding interest rates up as pushing them down; and that Mr. Reagan is caught between these forces even as he adds to the pressures that keep rates up. His outline of future spending cuts, far from reassuring the financial markets, played into the fear that promises of a balanced budget in 1984 will not be made good by Congress.

title: WILDLIFE AND OUR WELL-BEING
description: I AM sometimes asked why we need another wildlife conservation program, and I usually answer that those who ask that question have not kept track of the impact of growing human numbers on the quality of life for all of us. Another answer was coined a long time ago when someone pointed out that ''Man does not live by bread alone.''

title: Theater; OPTIMISM ON FUTURE OF STAGE IN COUNTY
description: LOOKING back, the theatrical season of 1980-81 was not a particularly happy one in Westchester. Where there had been two professional dinner theaters, now there is only one. Where there had been two Equity production companies, now there is only one. The Westchester Regional Theater folded in midseason, and its subscribers were absorbed by the Main Street Theater in White Plains. Optimism is in the air, however, following the first performances of a new northern Westchester company, the Greeley Street Theater.

title: THE PRICE AND THE PRIZES OF COOPERATING WITH THE LAW
description: By disclosing that a Fe deral grand jury is investigating the financial act ivities of the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, John Cardinal Cody, The Chicago Sun-Times has pulled a journalistic coup. The off icial inquiry and its implications for a test of church and state rel ationships is a substantial story. But in going beyond the fact of t he Federal investigation to tell 650,000 readers what its own 18-mo nth inquiry had revealed, the newspaper has stirred controversy o ver its repertorial methods and motives.

title: Dacca Charges Indian Troops Raided Bangladesh Outposts
description: Bangladesh has accused Indian forces of crossing the frontier between the two nations and attacking four of its border outposts in a surprise morning raid that killed 18 people.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: BROKERS WHO SERVE BUYERS ONLY
description: When William Bartlett, an electronics technician, and his wife, Karen, an office manager for a pediatrician, went house hunting last summer, they felt that, as first-time home buyers, they needed a lot of guidance about neighborhoods, property values and determining whether a house was structurally sound.

title: Gardening; THE NEW SEASON IS A FINE TIME TO PLANT
description: A FRIEND recently declared his front lawn to be a disaster and wondered why he could not plant the entire lawn to ground cover as they do in California. The answer, of course, is that he can. While such lawns are uncommon in this part of the country, one does occasionally come across a front lawn of pachysandra or English ivy. When accompanied by a brick or flagstone path so that passage to the front door or the backyard is possible without trampling the planting, they are perfectly acceptable.

title: FAULT IN AIR CRASH IN JERSEY DISPUTED
description: The midair collision Wednesday between two aircraft preparing to land at Teterboro Airport has led to a dispute between Federal officials and striking air traffic controllers over who was responsible for keeping the aircraft apart: the pilots or the controller.

title: ITALY'S 100 CITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Law School Honors Ribicoff
description: Former Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff today was named the first recipient of the Raymond E. Baldwin award of the School of Law at the University of Bridgeport.

title: REFLECTIONS ON KREMLINOLOGY IN THE SHOE BOX ERA
description: It may be only a footnote in the world of real estate, but a report that the entire Soviet analysis division of the Central Intelligence Agency was moving from C.I.A. headquarters up the road about 10 miles to Vienna, Va., stirred a wave of reminiscence in Marion G. Shaw, who formerly headed the agency's Soviet internal policies branch.

title: IS A NEW FISHKILL ON THE WAY?
description: IN 1976, a combination of climatic and human conditions produced a massive fishkill that affected hundreds of square miles of the Atlantic Ocean off the coasts of New Jersey and Long Island.

title: Houston Looks at Cotton
description: The Greater Houston Bowl Association has offered the Southwest Conference $3 million to move the Cotton Bowl game from Dallas to Houston for three years. Lan Bentsen, president of the association, which sponsors the Bluebonnet Bowl, sent a letter to Commissioner Cliff Speegle saying his group would pay the conference $3 million over the next three years in return for moving the Cotton Bowl to Houston beginning with the 1982 season.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about a party at Bloomingdale's misidentified Anthony J. F. O'Reilly. He is president and chief executive officer of the H. J. Heinz Company, of which H. J. Heinz 2d is chairman.

title: WHEELCHAIR RACES TO BE HELD
description: THESE athletes do the mile in 4 1/2 minutes and lift weights of more than 300 pounds. They play no-holds-barred basketball, hurl javelins and compete in tennis tournaments.

title: Crafts; PURITY OF PURPOSE AND TRADITION INFUSED IN METALWORKS
description: SLIGHTLY crisp breezes and shorter days signal the onset of the new season, and for Long Island's Jewish population, the autumn heralds a period referred to simply as ''the holidays.'' This generalization encompasses Rosh ha-Shanah (the Jewish New Year) and Yom Kippur, (the Day of Atonement), followed five days later by Succoth (the Feast of Tabernacles) a nine-day celebration, the last day of which is one of the most joyous in the religion. This is a month of great activity, family gatherings, holiday meals - in short, a time to polish the family silver.

title: The World; Namibia Talks 'Back on Track'
description: Negotiations for South-West Africa's independence have been on a siding since January, but ''the whole train is back on the rails and starting off again,'' Lord Carrington, Britain's Foreign Secretary, said last week.

title: JOHN ELWAY: THE MAN WITH THE GOLDEN ARM
description: eyed Stanford quarterback-outfielder with a rocket launcher for a right arm, has lined up one of the nicest summer jobs any college kid could have. The New York Yankees are going to pay him more than $100,000 to play six weeks for Oneonta in the Class A New York-Pennsylvania League, which beats driving a beer truck or lugging suitcases in the Catskills, or even lifeguarding at a nude beach in Malibu.

title: KEY ARGUMENTS JAMMED IN THE DEBATE OVER AWACS
description: In conversation and in Congressional testimony, Air Force officers have glowingly described the capabilities of the Boeing E3A Advanced Warning and Control System aircraft as a ''force multiplier'' in aerial warfare.

title: Michelle Ney to Be Bride Of John Kilduff on Dec. 5
description: The engagement of Michelle Colby Ney to John William Kilduff has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Suzanne H. Ney of Darien, Conn., and Edward N. Ney of New York. Mr. Kilduff is a son of Mrs. Francine Kilduff of Cotuit, Mass., and the late Mr. Kilduff.

title: FOR KOCH, THE REAL PROBLEMS NOW BEGIN
description: There is a big price to be paid for a major political triumph - the winner must figure out what to do next. On the morning after his remarkable primary victories last week, the glow still on his face, Mayor Koch returned to his City Hall office with more than enough difficulties on tap to keep him busy for the next four years. (True, he must still get past the general election in November. But no one is likely to beat him.)

title: G.O.P. PANEL PICKS 4 DEMOCRATS IN COURT RACES
description: In an unusual political move, four Democratic Civil and Criminal Court judges have been nominated for State Supreme Court posts by Manhattan and Bronx Republicans.

title: The World; Mexico's Chief Ma
description: When it comes to picking presidents, Mexico's ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party is more institutional than revolutionary. The outgoing president selects his successor and the party embraces him, pretending he was its own idea.

title: NEW U.S. POLICY ON JOB BIAS DRAWS ANGER IN HOUSE PANEL
description: The Reagan Administration, breaking with the policies of the last three administrations, says it will no longer insist that employers found guilty of sexual or racial discrimination abide by quotas in their future job-hiring practices.

title: TRUE BLUES
description: DEEP BLUES By Robert Palmer. 310 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.95. THE ROOTS OF THE BLUES An African Search.By Samuel Charters. Illustrated. 160 pp. Boston: Marion Boyars Publishers. $15.

title: STUDY SEEN AS COMPROMISE
description: The Pentagon booklet on Soviet military power, which had its genesis in Bonn last April, is a compromise between the policy maker and the intelligence officer over the uses of sensitive data.

title: BILL WOULD LIMIT U.S. TUNA FISHING
description: A New Jersey Representative told a House panel today that overfishing by foreign fleets in American waters could lead to ''economic if not biological extinction'' of the commercially important bluefin tuna species.

title: No Headline
description: Styx and its brand of commercial miasma represent the true death of the original ideas and idealism of rock-and-roll.

title: BENGALS SET BACK BILLS, 27-24
description: Ken Anderson silenced his critics at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati yesterday by leading the Bengals to a 27-24 victory over the Buffalo Bills in overtime. Jim Breech kicked the decisive field goal, a 28-yarder.

title: A New Batter's Box
description: Mel Knopf is a 51-year-old aerospace engineer who has worked on the space shuttle, the Apollo project and the Cruise missile. He is also convinced he can help major leaguers put baseballs in the air, making .300 hitters out of most of them. The only trouble is that it would cost more than $5 million to convert his idea into reality.

title: PIANO: GARRICK OHLSSON
description: GARRICK OHLSSON paid a visit to Avery Fisher Hall yesterday and brought with him his customary graceful technique and elegant ear for musical detail. Brahms's Variations on a Theme by Handel pointed out both the virtues and the problems in Mr. Ohlsson's exceptional command of his instrument. Few other pianists could create the clear, light-filled pictures from Brahms's dark and convoluted virtuoso writing that Mr. Ohisson managed, and when the music waxed even more complex, he seemed to turn his tempos up just a notch - perhaps just to show us that he could. The slower variations, however, suffered long stretches of icy stasis - beautifully groomed phrases with neither tension nor any particular direction.

title: 'I'm Leaving It Up to You'
description: BEFORE the Jets leave their locker room for an opening kickoff, Walt Michaels always has addressed them for a few minutes. But yesterday he undressed them. Yesterday, before the Jets were to go out to play the Houston Oilers at Shea Stadium the coach ordered everybody but the players to leave. After the assistant coaches, the trainers, the equipment men and the club physicans had departed, Walt Michaels looked around at the 45 players hunched in the green-andwhite uniforms on the stools in front of their open lockers.

title: WALL ST. LAWYER FATALLY STABBED DURING ROBBERY
description: A 38-year-old Wall Street lawyer, strolling with a friend in a park on the Lower East Side, was stabbed to death Saturday night by one of three young robbers who took his wallet and wristwatch, the police said.

title: NEW YORKERS NOTIFIED OF AID LOSS IN REVIEW OF U.S. DISABILITY CASES
description: Under a new review of eligibility, 1,300 New Yorkers - 38 percent of the first group examined - are being notified that they will lose their Federal disability benefits.

title: Index; International
description: Labor dispute closes The Times of London A2 Tensions grow in Canada over constitutional issue A3 Zimbabwe's whites grow restless as privileg es erode A4 Around the World A5 Reagan ally in Senate urges joint Awacs control A7 Jamaicans get a bare glimpse of a new life A12 Government/Politics Relief official says Cuba would discuss taking refugees back A17 Sectional issue stressed in Jersey Governor race B2 Washington Talk Briefing A16 Calendar A16 Neoconservatives have uncertain alliance with Reagan camp A16 World's bankers gather in Capitol for a money bazaar A16 General Around the Nation A14 Jews mark start of Rosh ha- shanah tonight B2 Thousands attend Atlantic Antic festival in Brooklyn B3 Pennsylvania mental institution faces more legal problems B5 Education/Welfare N.Y.U.'s neighbors enjoy new sports building B3 Features/Notes Notes on People B5 Going Out Guide C15 PARKING REGULATIONS Alternate-side parking regulations will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Wednesday because of the Jewish New Year. SportsMonday Auto Racing: Laffite wins Cana- dian Grand Prix C5 Baseball: Yankees defeat Ori- oles, 5-2 C3

title: NICOLE VAMES IS BRIDE OF DAVID PETER SLOANE
description: Nicole Florence Vames and David Peter Sloane were married yesterday by the Rev. Theodore Nedelson, assisted by the Rev. Basil Gregory, in Sts. Constantine & Helen Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Brooklyn.

title: News An alysis
description: When Interior Secretary James G. Watt met Western governors earlier this month in Wyoming, he opened the session by announcing a major Federal concession on water policy.

title: Navy Keeps Ted Bates
description: Navy recruiting is re-enlisting at Ted Bates & Company, which has been its agency for the last six years. The entir e effort last year was in the neighborhood of $15 million but ne xt year's budget has not been approved by Congress. The contract i s for one year and includes two options to renew for one year.

title: Recruited - Again
description: When Villanova decided on April 15 to give up its 87-year-old football program, there were 79 Wildcat players -many on football scholarships - who had a tough decision to make: whether to continue their work toward a degree at Villanova without playing or to transfer to another football school.

title: Ainge Waits for Verdict
description: While the Toronto Blue Jays continued the last trip of a disappointing season, the infielder Danny Ainge planned to be 3,000 miles away, waiting for the decision on his future.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1981
description: International Street battles in Teheran between Mujahedeen guerrillas who oppose Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and his revolutionary guards lasted seven hours. It was reportedly the most violent outburst by dissidents since the revolution. Some were armed with machines guns and rocketpropelled grenades. Injuries, but no deaths, were reported. The fighting appeared to be a culmination of the opposition by the Mujahedeen to the presidential election to be held Friday. About 1,000 supporters of the Mujahedeen have been executed by the Khomeini revolutionary Government since June. (Page A1, Column 6.) Iran, in a surprise attack, reportedly lifted the Iraqi siege of Iran's oil-refinery center in Abadan, killing or disabling more than 600 Iraqi troops and capturing 1,500 others, along with hundreds of tanks and troop carriers. The report was broadcast by the Teheran radio. Iraq reported heavy fighting in the Abadan area and said that the Iranians had been driven back with heavy losses. (A1:4-5.)

title: LAFFITE FIRST IN CANADIAN GRAND PRIX
description: Jacques Laffite of France charged from 10th on the starting grid today to win the Grand Prix of Canada and move into third place in the Formula One world championship standing. Laffite, driving a Talbot Ligier, averaged 85 miles per hour for 63la ps around the 4.41-kilometer Ile Notre Dame course, which was made sl ick by heavy rains that fell throughout much of the race and de layed the start. He won by more than eight seconds from John Watsonof Northern Ireland.

title: FOR THE NETS: A NEW ERA
description: IT was early in the afternoon in a darkened New Jersey restaurant called The Seven Seas, and Maurice Lucas of the New Jersey Nets was trying to enjoy his meal. But after three straight mornings of workouts last week, about a month before the National Basketball Association season was to begin, the aches and pains made this a difficult task.

title: NEW VENTURE CAPITAL FIRM IS FORMED
description: L.J. Sevin, who broke away from Texas Instruments and cofounded the Mostek Corporation with venture capital backing in 1969, has decided to become a venture capitalist himself. He has teamed up with Benjamin Rosen of Rosen Research, an electronics analyst, to form Sevin Rosen Partners.

title: MISS AUSTIN WINS
description: Top-seeded Tracy Austin defeated second-seeded Mary Lou Piatek today, 4-6, 6-3, 6-3, to win the $75,000 Toyota Tennis Classic.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Opposes Talks With the P.L.O.
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who arrived in Kuwait today from Bahrain, said here that Britain had decided against meeting the Palestine Liberation Organization at the ministerial level because of what she called the P.L.O.'s association with terrorism.

title: BORG TAKES FINAL FROM SMID
description: Bjorn Borg of Sweden won his first tournament since losing the United States Open, defeating fourth-seeded Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia today, 6-4, 6-3, in the final of the $75,000 Martini Open. Borg, who lost just one set against five opponents on the clay courts here, earned $15,000.

title: A New Inquiry Su rrounding Kush
description: The Arizona Department of Public Safety says it is in vestigating new charges against Frank Kush, the former Arizona State University head football coach.

title: CENTER FOR RETARDED STILL ENMESHED IN LEGAL BATTLE
description: Gone is the stench that helped to make Pennhurst Center here notorious among institutions for the retarded, but its somber old buildings, which house nearly 900 southeastern Pennsylvanians, continue to crown a green hilltop, looking down on a valley of forests and meadows.

title: I.R.A. Asserts Fast Will Continue at Prison
description: Supporters of Irish nationalists on hunger strike in Maze Prison said today that the protest would continue despite two recent defections and reports that two of the remaining six protesters would be taken off the fast by their families.

title: COPING WITH POLISH ECONOMIC PROBLEMS
description: Whatever political satisfaction Poland's brush with revolution is bringing its people, in the economic sphere the dramatic events of the past year have only meant falling living standards and increased hardship so far.

title: NEOCONSERVATIVES AND REAGAN: UNEASY COALITION
description: The movement had been growing for years, of course, but last year they suddenly appeared at the forefront of the political scene: liberal Democrats in new conservative clothing who symbolized the political changes that were sweeping the country. These neoconservatives, the intellectuals who became known as the men and women who had changed their minds, found themselves at the center of the Reagan revolution.

title: UNION MILITANTS IN POLAND ATTACK LEADERS OVER GOVERNMENT ACCORD
description: Solidarity leaders defended themselves today against bitter accusations from the union's rank and file that the leadership had exceeded its authority in compromising with the Goverment over the right of workers to run factories.

title: BLACK LEADERS AND NEEDS
description: The coincidence of Roy Wilkins's death and Vernon Jordan's announcement of his resignation from the presidency of the National Urban League on back-to-back days forced questions about black leaders hip to the fore once more.

title: ZIMBABWE'S WHITES RESTLESS AS PRIVILEGES ERODE
description: In the formerly all-white suburbs, the bougainvillea and jacaranda still flower luxuriantly over manicured lawns. No houses stand empty there and, in the mornings, traffic jams are still created by whites driving downtown to their accustomed pl aces in business and government offices.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OUR TOWN

title: Joan Ruth Farber, Editor, Wed to Jay Topkis, Lawyer
description: Joan Ruth Farber, editor in chief of Delacorte Press, was married yesterday to Jay Topkis, a partner in the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison.

title: ANALYSTS SEE END OF RATE DROP
description: The optimism over interest rates in the credit markets appears to have evaporated, with many analysts now believing that the move toward lower rates has come to an end.

title: Ohio Archbishop Denies Reports of Cody Scheme
description: Archbishop Joseph L. Bernardin of Cincinnati has labeled as ''fantasies'' reports that a priest plotted to have him named Archbishop of Chicago as a step in rigging a papal election.

title: REDS TOP BRAVES BY 4-2
description: The Cincinnati Reds are in the fight for the National League Western Division pennant, so it was surprising that the star of their staff, Tom Seaver, asked to leave a game in the sixth in ning yesterday.

title: ARTS LEADERS PESSIMISTIC OVER FUTURE FINANCING
description: Pessimism about the economic future of the arts in this country and criticism of the Administration's planned cuts in the National Endowments for the Arts and Humanities were the overriding themes here this weekend as 53 artists, directors and patrons of Northeastern artistic institutions gathered to discuss plans for supporting various artistic endeavors.

title: DALE GREIF KARS, TEACHER, MARRIED TO CHARLES PANOFF
description: The marriage of Dale Greif Kars, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel S. Greif of Memphis, to Charles E. Panoff, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Irving E. Panoff of Brooklyn, took place yesterday.

title: H.J. GALLAGHER, 86, WILLKIE ASSOCIATE
description: Harold J. Gallagher, a senior partner for many years in the law firm of Willkie Farr & Gallagher and a former president of the American Bar Association, died Saturday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 86 years old.

title: Changes Looming for Cosmos
description: The magnitude of any changes the Cosmos may make appears greater now that the team lost to Chicago in a shootout in the Soccer Bowl here last night. Drastic changes, including the coaching job, could take place before the team leaves for a sevengame overseas tour on Saturday. ''It's prem ature to say what changes will be made and when,'' said Peppe Pinton, a club executive, ''but if I were you, I wouldn't stay away from the phone for the next few days.''

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 28, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: At Lois: Alexander's TV Bid, Warner Video
description: Alexander's, the department store chain, is going to seriously try television advertising for the first time. And George Lois and Lois Pitts Gershon will show it the way, with pleasure.

title: Commodities; Precious Metals in Transition
description: ONE of the ironies of last week's plunging prices of precious metals and financial instrument futures was that these two markets showed the most promise of reversing long downward trends.

title: Newfoundland Be st at Westbury
description: The biggest dog in the ring, a 155-pound Newfoundland, was named best of 1,932 dogs at the 59th annual Westbury Kennel Association Show today.

title: YOU CAN'T LEAD A PUPIL TO THE CAFETERIA
description: To the Editor:

title: Anna Gourevitch, 83, Is Dead;
description: Psychoanalyst and Teacher

title: BARBARA LIVENSTEIN WED TO RICHARD KALIN, LAWYER
description: Barbara Ann Livenstein, daughter of Mrs. Harold Shames of Ardsley, N.Y., and Martin Livenstein of Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Richard S. Kalin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kalin of Chicago. Rabbi Peter J. Rubenstein of White Plains performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York.

title: FIFTH AVENUE MILE TRIBUTE TO RUNNERS
description: When plans first were discussed earlier this year to stage a major mile race down Fifth Avenue, Adriaan Paulen, then president of the International Amateur Athletic Federation, threatened life suspensions for those who participated.

title: The Rev. Mark Kennedy, 85, Ex-President of Siena College
description: The Rev. Mark P. Kennedy, president of Siena College from 1943 to 1952, died Friday at St. Bonaventure University infirmary in Olean, N.Y., following a brief illness.

title: DISPUTE SHUTS TIMES OF LONDON
description: The Times of London will not be published tomorrow after failure to reach agreement today on a labor dispute involving The Sunday Times, a sister publication.

title: IOWA'S PERFORMANCE SURPRISES ITS COACH
description: Iowa's coach, Hayden Fry, is used to picking teams off a scrap heap and putting the pieces back together one way or another. But even he is surprised at the sudden turnaround in fortunes at Iowa, which has scored two big upsets in three games. With a strong defense and a ball-control of fense, Iowa shocked U.C.L.A., 20-7, Saturday two weeks after havi ng opened the season by toppling Nebraska, 10-7. The Hawkeyes were ca ught napping nine days ago, when Iowa State beat them, 23-12.

title: TONI BETH FINDER MARRIED
description: The marriage of Toni Beth Finder, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert B. Finder of Scarsdale, N.Y., to David Charles Liemer, son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin D. Liemer of Warren, N.J., took place yesterday at the Harmonie Club.

title: Tennis to Clarke
description: Top-seeded Adrian Clarke of Brooklyn, a 23-year-old tennis instructor, defeated seventh-seeded Olayi Ogunrinde, a Nigerian now living in Brooklyn, 6-2, 7-5, in the final of the Eastern Tennis Association New York City men's singles tournament yesterday at Starrett City Center in Brooklyn.

title: MICKEY MARCUS'S PLACE IN ISRAELI HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: DILLON READ APPOINTS NEW HEAD AND DIRECTOR
description: When John P. Birkelund, 51, and Charles L. Lea Jr., 53, left the New Court Securities Corporation, the primary investment vehicle for the Rothschilds in the United States, last July, they intended to establish their own venture capital and investment management conce rn. That business, however, was never fo rmed and now they have joined the investment banking firm of Dillon Read & Company.

title: SOME NEIGHBORS OF N.Y.U ENJOY ITS ELEGANT NEW GYM
description: New York University's new $16 million sports and recreation building near Washington Square, which opened to students on Sept. 14, opened to hundreds of lucky neighbors over the weekend.

title: FALCONS LOSE TO BROWNS, 28-17
description: Two of the better teams in pro football, the Atlanta Falcons of the National Conference and the Cleveland Browns of the American, played today and the Browns, the American Conference team, won. The Browns scored two touchdowns in the last minute of the first half, widened their lead to 18 points in the third quarter, and went on to win by 28-17.

title: GETTING TO BE GOOD FRIENDS, AFTER DIVORCE
description: They seem to be the most happily divorced couple on Seventh Avenue. Last week he attended her dinner party and she attended his the week before that. ''We even vacation together with our children, '' he said. ''I bring my girlfriend and she brings her boyfriend. Once you've been a family you're always a family.''

title: DANCE: TWYLA THARP'S 'UNCLE EDGAR'
description: ''UNCLE EDGAR DYED His Hair Red'' is one of the best dance works to surface here by any standard, and it shows Twyla Tharp at her most serious, most creative and most professional.

title: Bomb Threat to Queen
description: An anonymous caller threatened to blow up the church where Queen Elizabeth II was attending services today but a search of the neighboring church where the bomb supposedly was planted turned up no device, the police said.

title: 3 Croatian Hijackers Surrender in Cyprus
description: Three Croatians hijacked a Yugoslav JAT airliner last night but were thwarted after their 107 hostages staged a mock fire alarm and escaped while the plane was on the ground in Cyprus. The suspects, who surrendered peacefully, were flown here today under heavy guard, officials said.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: When did the National Football League drop the rule that a pass had to be thrown from a point 5 yards or more behind the scrimmage line?

title: The Candidate
description: Such National Football League coaches as Walt Michaels of the Jets,Jo e Gibbs of the Washington Redskins and Ron Erhardt of the New En gland Patriots probably hate to hear the name George Allen.

title: GRUMMAN BOARD REJECTS LTV'S BID
description: The Grumman Corporation, a leading manufacturer of military aircraft, and the largest private employer on Long Island, said yesterday that it had rejected a $450 million takeover offer made last week by the LTV Corporation. But LTV, a Dallas-based conglomerate that is also a major military contractor, said that it would continue its takeover attempt despite Grumman's opposition.

title: OUT OF COURT ACCORD SOUGHT TO SETTLE WILLOWBROOK CASE
description: Lawyers for New York State and residents of Willowbrook attempted to reach an out-of-court settlement yesterday - the day before a trial in Federal court was due to start - that would resolve a sixyear battle over how the institution for the mentally retarded should be reduced in size.

title: HATALSKY, ON 71-275, WINS FOR FIRST TIME
description: Morris Hatalsky shot a front-running round of par 71 today in the Hall of Fame Classic to score the first victory of his professional career.

title: PHILHARMONIC: SEASON OPENS
description: ZUBIN MEHTA has begun the New York Philharmonic's season with works by the two best-known West German contemporary composers. Karlheinz Stockhausen's ''Jubilee'' was heard in the opening concerts and will be repeated this week, and Thursday night the other shoe dropped in the form of the American premiere of Hans Werner Henze's ''Barcarolle.''

title: ROBERT MONTGOMERY, ACTOR, DIES AT 77
description: Robert Montgomery, the actor who after appearing on stage and in dozens of movies went on to become a director, producer and Presidential adviser, died of cancer yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived in Canaan, Conn.

title: A Sacred Cow Cartel
description: At a supermarket in northern New Jersey, a half gallon of milk costs about 99 cents. Across the river in New York, a half gallon from the same Pennsylvania cow averages $1.16.
