Don't blame it on the toll for crossing the George Washington Bridge. Blame New York State's milk distribution law, and the officials in the State Department of Agriculture who administer it.

title: MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1981; The Economy
description: Credit market optimism over lower interest rates has given way to concern about a possible rebound in money costs. Analysts now think the recent two-point drop in short-term rates marks the end of their decline, while long-term rates could set new records as the Treasury is forced to enter a market lacking buyers. (Page D1.)

title: Washington Watch; Olympic Coins: A Battle Brews
description: WASHINGTON THE United States Mint is in the center of a big battle involving megabucks, super lobbyists and a leading Wall Street banking house over commemorative gold and silver coins to be sold to raise money for the 1984 Olympic Games.

title: TENSION GROWS IN CANADA OVER CONSTITUTION ISSUE
description: With Quebec considering a form of civil disobedience and reviving talk of independence, tension is running high in Canada on the eve of a decision by the Supreme Court on the legality of federal proposals for a new constitution.

title: Relaxing Captures Ruffian
description: Relaxing, the 5-year-old mare who has spent most of the year running remarkably well against males, returned to the company of females yesterday long enough to insure herself an Eclipse Award by defeating an excellent small field in the $161,700 Ruffian Handicap at Belmont Park. ''This should show she's the best filly in the country,'' Angel Penna, her trainer, said. ''If we had lost th is race, we would come back against fillies in the Beldame, but now we are leaning toward the Jockey Club Gold Cup.''

title: LINDA GREEN MARRIED TO DR. HARVEY HIRSCH
description: Linda Karen Green and Dr. Harvey S. Hirsch were married yesterday by Rabbi Dr. Morris M. Goldberg at the Pierre in New York. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Green of New York.

title: New Leaders
description: Since major league baseball resumed play in the ''second season'' on Aug. 10 after a 50-day labor dispute, the American and National Leagues have regarded, and published, the post-strike team won-lost records as a special entity. But they have treated individual player records on a cumulative basis, treating pre-strike and post-strike records as a whole.

title: Cadwell Design Post
description: Herman Davis, executive vice president of Cadwell Davis Savage/Advertising, a subsidiary of Compton Advertising, is going to be taking on the additional responsibility for running a new packagedesign unit in the agency that has been named the Market Package. He knows what he's doing, having won awards in the field. So the job is in the bag.

title: BRIDGE
description: To say that records are made to be broken is a cliche, but there are a few records that seem likely to stnd forever.

title: Mets Suspend Hodges, Miller
description: Ron Hodges and Dyar Miller were suspended without pay for three days this morning by Joe Torre, the Mets' manager.

title: Y Chamber Symphony To Open Season Oct. 17
description: The Y Chamber Symphony, under the direction of its music director, Gerard Schwarz, will open its 1981-82 season Oct. 17, at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y. The series comprises eight pairs of concerts, given Saturday evenings and Sundays at 3 P.M.

title: STAGE: 'MAGGIE & PIERRE' TRUDEAU
description: POOR Canada! Other countries may produce national heroines who are the stuff of legend, but there's no such luck in recent times for our dear neighbor to the north. Instead of, say, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, Golda Meir, Indira Gandhi or Evita Peron, Canada has had to make do with Margaret Trudeau, a First Lady whose public antics are likely to live on in the archives of People magazine, not history books. To be sure, Mrs. Trudeau has been a mildly intriguing figure during her trot across the world stage - but no one could ever accuse her of having launched a thousand ships.

title: NEW ISSUES SLOWED BY HIGH PRICES
description: The volume of new corporate and tax-exempt bond issues remains modest as high interest rates discourage many borrowers. Among the scheduled issues is an unusual offering by the Alaska Housing Finance Corporation, which is selling $150 million of mortgage revenue bonds evenly divided between maturities in 1991 and 2001. Interest on the bonds is subject to Federal income tax even though the corporation is a state authority and has previously sold tax-exempt bonds not subject to Federal income tax.

title: MEXICO'S FUTURE PRESIDENT
description: Mexico will elect its next President on J uly 4, 1982. But everybody already knows his name. He is the c andidate of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, which never l oses in the unusual one-plus-fringes party system here.

title: FOR A 'DEAD' JAMAICA, A BARE GLIMPSE OF A NEW LIFE
description: The businessmen are back, talking profits and deals amid the wicker and greenery of the Pegasus Hotel. On the streets, the burned car hulks are gone, wooden skeletons are once again billboards, and stores are filled with goods. Finance has replaced murder as the daily staple of newspaper headlines.

title: COMBATING AN OIL CUTOFF
description: With the current oil glut, planning for a cutoff of oil imports lacks urgency. But in coming weeks, Congress will have to decide whether to extend the 1973 law that provides for emergency price and allocation controls.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Burndy Corp., Norwalk, Conn., has appointed Richard M. Silven group vice president-components.

title: DR. WERBLOOD BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Dr. Sherrell L. Werblood, daughter of Mrs. Gaye Werblood of Englishtown, N.J., and the late Samuel Werblood, was married yesterday in Westport, Conn., to Dr. Lawrence Hugh Birnbach, son of Dr. and Mrs. Emanuel Birnbach of New York. Rabbi Emil Hager performed the ceremony at the Longshore Inn.

title: Top Times Editor to Receive Lovejoy Award in Journalism
description: A.M. Rosenthal, executive editor of The New York Times, will be the 29th annual recipient of the Elijah Parish Lovejoy Award of Colby College, it was announced here.

title: BROOKS IS STILL EXPERIMENTING
description: As he brought the Rangers here for an exhibition game with the Philadelphia Flyers tonight, Coach Herb Brooks said that only a dozen players had assured themselves of places on his team and that seven or eight spots were still open.

title: Opposition to NATO in Spain
description: Santiago Carrillo, the Spanish Communist Party leader, said today that his party had gathered half a million signatures in favor of a referendum on whether Spain should join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. The Government of Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo has rejected a referendum, saying that the question would be decided by a vote in Parliament.

title: INEQUITY REPORTED IN WELFARE SURVEY
description: Destitute single parents are frequently denied welfare illegally, cut from the rolls for the wrong reasons and subjected to long delays in receiving help, according to a study commissioned by the Community Services Administration under the Carter Administration.

title: Market Place; New Options In Mergers
description: CREDITHRIFT FINANCIAL has been living with uncertainty since Orion Capital made a merger proposal backed by holdings of 9.9 percent of Credithrift's shares in the spring of 1979.

title: Viletta at Margeotas
description: The Viletta China Company, previously only the maker of collector plates, is now going into the tableware field and has hired Margeotas/Fertitta & Weiss to handle a $1.5 million ad campaign. Previously its ads were done in-house.

title: Mohammed Riad, Diplomat; Egyptian Ex-Official Was 57
description: Mohammed Riad, a top Egyptian diplomat and former Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, died today at a clinic in Yugoslavia where he was being treated after a stroke, the official Middle East News Agency said.

title: Mitterrand Holds Talks With Saudi King
description: President Francois Mitterrand of France met with King Khalid today for the first round of official talks expected to focus primarily on the Middle East.

title: Half on the Track to Namibia
description: Does the Reagan Administration mean it? Will South Africa heed it? Can black Africa buy it? What a remarkable coup for American diplomacy if the answer to all three of these questions turns out to be yes. For those are the big questions raised by the new plan to grant acceptable independence to the huge territory known as Namibia or South-West Africa. Long-stalled negotiations would be resumed on the basis of fresh ideas for constitutional and security arrangements.

title: Belgian Mediator Urges Calling a New Election
description: A royal mediator said today that King Baudouin should order Parliament dissolved and call new elections to settle the country's most serious postwar political crisis.

title: RETAIL-TRADE JOBS AT A LOW
description: Jobs in the retail trade in New York city h ave dropped to a record low of 363,000 since a 1969 peak of 440,000, according to Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Federal regional commissioner of l abor statistics.

title: CITY OPERA: 'TOSCA'
description: THERE were several new faces in the New York City Opera's production of ''Tosca'' Saturday night. Jacque Trussel, as Cavaradossi, so looked and acted the part that one often forgave him the harshness and slightly strangulated quality of his upper registers.

title: Income Limit Set In Harlem Lottery
description: Families who intend to enter a lottery for 13 city-owned brownstones in Harlem must have an annual income of at least $20,000, housing officials said.

title: Massachusetts to Halt Gas Sales for Risky Cars
description: The state fire marshal says he will order all service stations in Massachusetts to refuse to sell gasoline to drivers of 1981 Ford Escort and Lincoln-Mercury Lynx cars that may have faulty fuel devices. Joseph O'Keefe told the monthly meeting of the Massachusetts Fire Chiefs Association Friday that he would notify all local fire chiefs of his decision tomorrow and that he expected them to relay the order to service stations.

title: REAGAN ALLY IN SENATE URGES JOINT AWACS CONTROL
description: President Reagan's closest confidant in the Senate said today that the level of sophistication on Airborne Warning and Control System aircraft was so high that the United States ''would be derelict in our own security responsibiliies in not maintaining control, joint control, of that technology'' in selling five Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia.

title: DANCE: TWO DISCIPLES OF NIKOLAIS AND LOUIS
description: CHOREOSPACE, a new studio theater for dance, opened its doors on Wednesday night. And because ChoreoSpace is at 33 East 18th Street on the premises of the Nikolais/Louis Foundation for Dance, its inauguration is a reminder that Alwin Nikolais and Murray Louis have always recognized the importance of such workshop theaters.

title: St. Francis Prep Wins, 21-20
description: St. Francis Prep of Fresh Meadows, Queens, defeated St. John the Baptist of West Islip, L.I., 21-20, yesterday in a Catholic High School Football League game at St. John's University in Jamaica.

title: SURVEILLANCE BLIMP STIRS NEW INTEREST
description: About 35 men in blue and gray business suits convened here last week in a spartan room at the United States Naval Research Center to gather the technical information about a new Coast Guard procurement program.

title: MENNAN ANNOUNCES MANAGEMENT SHIFTS
description: Harold Danenberg, 50 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Mennen Company, an international consumer products company with estimated sales of about $250 million. He succeeds L. Donald Horne, 48, who was elected chairman and continues as chief executive officer of the Morristown, N.J., corporation.

title: 100 Miles After a Fast
description: His doctors think he may be overdoing it, but Dick Gregory, the comedian and political activist, plans to mark the end of a 70-day fast today by beginning a 100-mile walk from New Orleans to Baton Rouge, La.

title: JETS BEAT OILERS FOR FIRST VICTORY, 33-17
description: Continuing to defy logic, the Jets scored the first victory of their bizarre season yesterday by trouncing the Houston Oilers, 33-17.

title: ISLANDERS WIN, 2-1
description: Bryan Trottier scored on a deflection in the first period and set up Bob Nystrom in the second period for the game-winner as the Islanders beat the Buffalo Sabres, 2-1, in an exhibition game tonight.

title: AIRLINE DEREGULATION AT A HIGH PRICE
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Sunday about a new commission to explore some questions about American actions toward the Holocaust incorrectly described one of its members, Dr. Martin Meyerson. He is former president of the University of Pennsylvania.

title: BOOK OF THE TIMES
description: By John Leonard REINHART'S WOMEN. By Thomas Ber- ger. 295 pages. Delacourt/Seymour Lawrence. $13.95.

title: KATE ROSENBERG
description: Kate Rosenberg, who had been chairman of the Queens division of the March of Dimes and active in many philanthropic organizations, died Friday of cancer at New York Hospital. Mrs. Rosenberg, who was a resident of Forest Hills, Queens, was 70 years old.

title: HEALEY SCORES NARROWEST OF VICTORIES IN FIGHT WITH BENN FOR LABORITE POST
description: Denis Healey retained the deputy leadership of the Labor Party tonight, holding off a strong left-wing challenge by the narrowest of margins and avoiding, for the moment, what would have amounted to a takeover by extremist elements.

title: TV: CARLISLE FLOYD'S 'WILLIE STARK' ON PBS
description: ''WILLIE STARK,'' composed by Carlisle Floyd and based on the Robert Penn Warren novel ''All the King's Men,'' is the subject of some bickering among music critics. Is it opera, or is it closer to Broadway musical theater? While the arguments drone on, it can be discovered tonight on WNET-TV at 8 o'clock that ''Willie Stark'' indisputably provides ample opportunities for splendid television.

title: Unscheduled Songs
description: Sidney Zion is a tolerant man. When he took over the Broadway Joe steakhouse on West 46th Street a couple of weeks ago, he allowed his employees to listen to rock music on the bar radio, but only until the painters arrived.

title: MUSIC: ANTIC AND ECLECTIC
description: IT was immediately following ''Beulah 's Boobs'' at the 92d Street Yyesterday aft ernoon that the composer, Paul Schoenfield, most clearly displ ayed his stylistic ambitions. He has been heard in recitals befo re, as a pianist in solemn and well-received performances of Webern, Ives, et al.

title: David Cumberland, Ill, Misses City Opera Debut
description: David Cumberland, a bass who was to have made his New York City Opera debut yesterday as Sir Giorgio Walton in ''I Puritani,'' fell ill and was replaced by Paul Plishka. Mr. Plishka was making his City Opera debut, courtesy of the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Drill Bit Hits Gas Line; Blast Kills 3 Workers
description: An explosion at a drill rig today killed three workers and badly burned a fourth.

title: CONCERT: 'TODAY' SERIES BY SCHWARZ
description: GERARD SCHWARZ has emerged in yet another guise, as a champion of contemporary music. His vehicle Wednesday at the Abraham Goodman House was the first in a three-concert series called ''Music Today.'' By ''today,'' Mr. Schwarz is suitably loose. On Wednesday, he offered one new piece along with established music from throughout the century plus a postconcert panel discussion, and he indicated that he intended to adhere to that format.

title: PARTIES ARE SERIOUS BUSINESS AT FINANCIAL BAZAAR
description: The money men are displaying their wares in Washington this week as the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank hold their 36th annual joint meeting.

title: Advertising; Continental Quits B.&B. For Wells
description: WHILE the advertising business is quietly waiting for some word from Eastern Airlines as to whether it will go with Campbell-Ewald or stay with Young & Rubicam, Continental Air Lines, out in Los Angeles, announced Friday out of the blue that it was taking its advertising account to Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: Dr. Leon Dmochowski, Researcher in Virology
description: Dr. Leon Dmochowski, a specialist in virology and a cancer researcher, died of a heart attack Aug. 26 while vacationing in Mexico. Dr. Dmochowski, who lived in Houston, was 72 years old.

title: Tigers Top Brewers To Take Over First
description: The close race for the second-half pennant in the American League Eastern Division continued yesterday as the Detroit Tigers took sole possession of first place by downing the Milwaukee Brewers, 2-1, at Tiger Stadium. The Brewers fell from first place to second, half a game behind Detroit. The Boston Red Sox, who lost to Cleveland, are in third, one game behind Detroit with a week of games to go.

title: A TRIBE AGAIN, PAIUTES REWEW HOPES
description: Working quietly so as to not incur the wrath of the white man, a dwindling Indian tribe based here is in the process of selecting reservation land.

title: Sports World Specials; Icing the Players
description: For the first two days of their training camp deep in the forests of the lake country at Vierumaki, Finland, the New York Rangers looked at the ice-cold lake near their cabins, daring each other to jump off a 30 -foot high diving tower. None did.

title: People
description: * Edward M. Stevens has been named president of Dix & Eaton/Advertising, a unit of Dix & Eaton Inc.

title: POP: PIGBAG, AU PAIRS
description: TWO of the more interesting British rock bands to surface with imported disks recently made their New York debuts Wednesday night at the Ritz. Pigbag, the opener, consists of a driving rhythm section and four brass players who cavort about a lot and often switch off, individually or collectively, to percussion and, in one case, electric organ.

title: PROSECUTOR TRAINS SIGHTS ON NEWARK
description: The Essex County Prosecutor, who has vowed to pursue an investigation into possible official corruption in Newark wherever it may lead him, says he's ''certainly not an angel,'' but he figures he's accountable to a higher power than the Governor or the taxpayers.

title: IN BROOKLYN, A FESTIVAL WITH DIVERSITY AND UNITY
description: What distinguished them was race, ethnicity, politics, religion, taste in food and preference in music. What united them was an openhearted affection for Brooklyn, and that is what many thousands of people celebrated yesterday at the Atlantic Avenue festival.

title: Waltrip Triumphs
description: Darrell Waltrip took command when Harry Gant had to pit with tire problems and scored an easy victory today in the Old Dominion 500 stock car race.

title: Times Offers Data Service
description: The New York Times Information Service has begun marketing The New York Times On-Line, a computerized system that permits access to the full text of current news material from The Times. The system also contains data back to June 1, 1980.

title: Bell Project for Y.& R.
description: Ma Bell has decided that Young & Rubicam should do the major educational advertising effort aimed at informing the public about its coming Government-ordered structural change that will leave it with a regulated telephone company and an unregulated ''enhanced services'' electronics company. Also in competition were N.W. Ayer, American Telephone and Telegraph's major agency, and D'Arcy-McManus & Masius. The company describes the assignment as a customer instruction project and has no idea of what it might cost.

title: Springbok Protest Injures Policeman
description: A Port Authority police officer was seriously injured and five people were arrested at Kennedy International Airport Saturday evening when the police tried to disperse a crowd of about 60 people. The crowd was demonstrating against a South African rugby team, the Sprinkboks, which they thought was about to board a plane.

title: Nitz Wins Cycling In Central Park
description: Leonard Nitz, appearing to be hopelessly boxed in at the head of the stretch, outmaneuvered Terry Hammond of Australia and Ron Heyman of British Columbia to win the fourth annual Outside Magazine/Peugeot Motors Apple Lap 75-mile bicycle classic yesterday morning in Central Park.

title: COWBOYS STOP GIANTS, 18-10, STAY UNBEATEN
description: The Dallas Cowboys struggled to beat the Giants today, 18-10. And although a loss is a loss, the Giants seemed to grow as they fought back against a more experienced, more polished and much more successful team.

title: OIL BOOM TOWN IS FUGITIV'S HAVEN
description: About 35 years ago this area welcomed a kind of unflinching breed, often those men young and raw from the battlefields of World War II, cavaliers with a wilder sense of adventure, unafraid to accept any dare or to face the unknown.

title: BILINGUAL SELF-HELP BY PHONE
description: Japanese who phone Women-in-Self-Help want to know how to find a nursery school and a family doctor, what to do about furniture delivered with defects and how to express sympathy to a newly widowed friend.

title: MERGERS REPORTED
description: The North American Soccer League announced the merger of two teams and the intention of two others to merge at its annual meetings today. The league's directors approved in principle the merger of the Tampa Bay Rowdies and Dallas Tornado. And officials of the Calgary Boomers said that the team is being merged with the Edmonton Drillers.

title: FOREIGN POLICY
description: They used to charge the Carter Administration with amateurism in the conduct of foreign affairs. That was before Ronald Reagan and his men got into selling Awacs radar planes to Saudi Arabia. Now the critics must be nostalgic for the elegance of the Carter years.

title: The Joy of Money
description: Not so long ago, fashion magazines were shy of printing four-figure prices: that a certain dress cost, say, $3,000 was a species of dirty little secret. Readers rich enough to buy that designer's clothes could guess it; readers who weren't were spared cardiac arrest.

title: GUERRILLAS BATTLE KHOMEINI BACKERS IN TEHERAN STREETS
description: In the fiercest display of opposition to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini yet, Mujahedeen guerrillas, some firing machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades, fought street battles with revolutionary guards throughout central Teheran for seven hours today, according to reports reaching Beirut.

title: Erikstahl, a Swede, Takes Peking Run
description: Kjell Erikstahl of Sweden won the Peking International Marathon today in 2 hours 15 mi nutes 20 seconds. Thoughshort of his own best time of 2:13:44, it wil l be recorded as the record for the Peking Marathon, the first hel d in the Chinese capital.

title: Steelers Defeat Patriots, 27-21
description: Lynn Swann was a dual hero in the Pittsburgh Steelers' 27-21 overtime victory over the New England Patriots today.

title: VOLUNTEER SUPPORT FOR MENTALLY TROUBLED
description: CLIFTON, N.J. ''T HEY haven't had a friendship in so long that they just don't know how to have a good time,'' Lisa Daleo said. ''They've been with therapists and nurses and doctors, who are just not the same as friends.''

title: By B. Drumond Ayres Jr.; The Calendar
description: Monday

title: A Dumb Defense of Intelligence
description: The House of Representatives voted the other day to prohibit the identification of present and former American intelligence agents, even if the knowledge is gained from public sources. Fortunately this legislative folly is forbidden by the Constitution, which says Congress shall make no law abridging free speech and press. Unfortunately for freedom -and national security - such a law could inhibit a lot of worthy speech before the courts administer the final constitutional rites.

title: JEWS TO MARK ROSH HA-SHANAH
description: Tonight at sundown, Jews will celebrate Rosh ha-Shanah, which for them is the anniversary of the creation of the world. The festival, which this year marks the arrival of the year 5742, is observed for two days among Orthodox and Conservative Jews and for one day by Reform Jews.

title: Calene Acquires Kriegel
description: Kriegel/Fel dman/Stern, a 12-year-old industrial agency with some $2.5 million in billings, has been acquired by Kornhauser & Calene. The three fou nders, Robert A. Kriegel, Albert Feldman and Fred Stern,will all be s enior vice presidents at K.& C. The acquired agency's client list i ncludes Combustion Engineering, the Linde division of Union Carbide , Kawasaki and the Stal-Laval division of Asea Inc.

title: BESS TRUMAN ENTERS HOSPITAL AFTER STROKE
description: Bess Truman, the 96-year-old widow of President Truman, was admitted to a hospital today in serious condition after suffering a stroke.

title: Rams to Start Haden Tonight
description: Pat Haden is expected to start at quarterback for the Los Angeles Rams tomorrow night when they meet the Chicago Bears at Soldier Field.

title: RAVITCH WARNS CUT IN TRANISIT PAY RISE
description: Asserting that the transit unions had failed to cooperate in improving productivity, Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, warned yesterday that New York City bus and subway workers might receive only 16 cents of the 36-cent-an-hour cost-of-living increase they were expecting next month.

title: Ford Wins Playoff
description: Doug Ford won his first title on the senior circuit and earned $20,000, the biggest prize of his long golf career, by defeating Sam Snead on the first playoff hole in the Merrill Lynch-Golf Digest Commemorative Pro-Am today.

title: REAGAN WALKING TIGHTROPE ON FARM POLICY
description: In its basic outline, President Reagan's farm and food policy is quite simple: Do what most of your predecessors have done, only less, whenever possible.

title: CORRECTION
description: A headline Sunday incorrectly iden- tified a West Side police precinct where problems of supervision are coming under investigation by the Po- lice Commissioner. It is the 10th Pre- cinct.

title: THE SEASON PREVIEW
description: FALL is both glorious and frustrating for the Northeast hunter and angler. By early October, everything seems to be happening at once, and one hesitates between rod and gun.

title: Minton Sets Mark
description: Greg Minton, the San Francisco Giant relief pitcher, set a major league record for consecutive innings pitched without giving up a home run last night when he picked up his 19th save with two scoreless innings against the San Diego Padres. Minton has pitched 248 consecutive innings without a homer.

title: Gregory Abbott, Announcer With Paramount Newsreel
description: Gregory M. Abbott, a radio and television announcer who as chief commentator for the old Paramount Newsreel was called the ''Voice Known to Millions,'' died Friday at High Ridge House in Riverdale, the Bronx. Mr. Abbott, who was lived in Larchmont, N.Y., was 81 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: For an Administration that made the guerrilla war in El Salvador its first, most heralded anti-Communist cause, the Reagan Administration provided a decidedly low-key public reception last week for President Jose Napoleon Duarte, the Salvadoran leader.

title: HOW DESECRATION IS PUNISHED IN NEW YORK
description: To the Editor:

title: SEAN O'GRADY OUTPOINTS MORGAN
description: Sean O'Grady , in his first fight since he was stripped of his World Boxing Ass ociation Lightweight title, won a unanimous decision from John Mor gan of Houston in a 10-round light-weight bout last night.

title: LAXALT BACKS CUTS IN MILITARY
description: Senator Paul Laxalt, President Reagan's closest ally in Congress, said today that he could see making deeper cuts in military spending in the fiscal year 1982 than the President had proposed.

title: Giammona Leads E agles to Victory
description: For Louie Giammona, it has not been easy wearing green. Yesterday, however, made it all worthwhile. Giammona stepped in forthe injured r unning back Wilbert Montgomery and scored two touchdownsin Philadelph ia's 36-13 rout of the Washington Redskins in Philadelphia.

title: CONFLICT OVER RIGHTS OF ALIENS LIES AT SUPREME COURT'S DOOR
description: Veronica Palacios, smiling shyly in her navy blue dress, reading softly from her third-grade social studies book, is 8 years old.

title: JACKSON HOMER BEATS ORIOLES
description: For Reggie Jackson, much of his five years in New York has been filled with headaches. Yesterday, however, it was a hatful of money for the Yankees' most visible player.

title: A CAPITALISTIC SOCIETY'S IMPERILED BALANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: LEAD IS CUT TO 1 1 2
description: The Mets, beaten in their previous five games, ended the Montreal Expos' winning streak at seven games with a 2-1 victory today.

title: SERENA SARNOFF, A GRADUATE STUDENT, BRIDE OF THOMAS HARTLEY BENENSON
description: The marriage of Serena Warburg Sarnoff to Thomas Hartley Benenson took place yesterday at the Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the cerem ony.

title: Harris at J.W.T. Unit
description: The Brouillard Communications division of the J. Walter Thompson Company has a new client - the Harris Corporation, Melbourne, Fla., for which it will do corporate advertising and public relations and product advertising for the seven divisions that make up its Information Systems Group. According to Brouillard, these units spent $4 million for the services last year. Corporate went through Edward Harris & Company, and the seven divisions have never used a single agency before.

title: GEORGIA BLACKS JOIN BATTLE ON LEGISLATIVE REDISTRICITING
description: Georgia was added this week to the growing ranks of Southern states whose Congressional reapportionment plans are under attack from blacks.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This union was not created to make compromises, but to smash the totalitarian system in our country.'' - Jan Rulewski, a delegate at Solidarity's convention in Gdansk. (A1:4.)

title: SHAPING CHICAGO'S TOP BANK
description: In its own quiet way, the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company is entering a tumultuous period. A thrust to gain market share is giving way to a tenacious drive to increase profitability.

title: ECHOING FOOTSTEPS OF WALT WHITMAN ON A TOUR OF SOHO
description: Staring raptly at the plain, dark-brown door of a remodeled 127-year-old firehouse in SoHo, 300 urban explorers-on-the-hoof struggled yesterday to visualize the interior scene in 1855.

title: POOR LANDS ASSAIL U.S. ECONOMIC VIEW
description: The Reagan Administration's conservative economic policies, reflected in high interest rates and a tougher stand on aid to the third world, are coming under fire at a meeting of finance ministers and central bank governors from more than 140 countries.

title: The Ways Of Soccer
description: IMAGINE the seventh game of the World Series being decided by a home-run contest. Imagine a Super Bowl being decided by a field-goal duel. This is the dilemma the North American Soccer League found itself in Saturday night, when the Chicago Sting and the New York Cosmos played 105 minutes and never scored a regular goal while battling for the championship.

title: ORDERS UP FOR TOOLS IN AUGUST
description: Orders for machine tools rose 10 percent in August from July, to $214 million, the National Machine Tool Builders Association reported yesterday.

title: IRAN-IRAQ FIGHTING FLARES UP
description: Iran said today that its forces had broken the Iraqi siege of Abadan, a battered oil-refinery city that lies in the center of the war zone between Iraq and Iran.

title: WENDY SUE COHEN MARRIED TO STEVEN JAY PHILLIPS
description: Wendy Sue Cohen, daughter of Annette Weinstein Cohen of Bellerose, Queens, and Martin D. Cohen of Santa Monica, Calif., was married at the Pierre Hotel yesterday to Steven Jay Phillips, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Phillips of Fort Lee, N.J., and Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin performed the ceremony.

title: Blaze on East Side Rages for Hours
description: A four-alarm fire on Manhattan's Lower East Side raged for more than eight hours, filling the surrounding area with dense smoke and shutting the Manhattan-bound lanes on the Williamsburg Bridge, the Fire Department said.

title: FORD'S SUBSIDIARY IN WEST GERMANY SHOWS REBOUND
description: After four years of teaching high school in a Paris suburb, Daniel Goeudevert recalls, he decided he wanted to ''make some money.''

title: BUS RIDERS IN WHEELCHAIRS TO MAIL THEIR FARE
description: When wheelchair lifts on New York City buses go into operation, wheelchair-bound passengers will send their 75-cent fare for the ride through the mail rather than hand it to the bus driver, the Transit Authority announced yesterday.

title: BRIEFING
description: T HE seasoned bureaucrat who runs the Food and Nutrition Service is abject about the unsavory publicity that forced the Reagan Administration to withdraw its ''ketchup rule.'' Democrats are still chortling at what they hail as ''the Emperor's New Condiments'' - the attempt to declare ketchup a school-lunch vegetable.

title: H.F. JOHNSON, COLLEGE PATRON
description: Harold F. Johnson, a lawyer who gave the initial $6 million to found Hampshire College, an innovative liberal arts college in Amherst, Mass., died yesterday at Southampton Hospital on Long Island. He was 84 years old and lived in Southampton and Delray Beach, Fla.

title: HOVING CITES SECRET DEAL FOR THE MET
description: The clandestine removal of a stone relief from Italy for acquisition by the Metropolitan Museum of Art and a breakin into another museum's glass case to examine an ivory plaque are disclosed in a new book by Thomas Hoving, former director of the Met.

title: Ex-Hostages in Love
description: When Donald T. Cooke was introduced several months ago to Diego Asencio, former United States Ambassador to Colombia, the two men had a lot to talk about. Mr. Cooke was one of the 52 Americans held hostage in Iran, and Mr. Asencio was held hostage in Colombia last year.

title: JERSEY'S GOVERNOR RACE STRESSES SECTIONAL ISSUE
description: New Jersey's split personality has long been known to poli ticians. But this year, they say, the state's northsouth di fferences are likely to play an unusually important partin the race f or Governor.

title: Minolta Photo Shifted to Esty
description: Following a competition between its old agency, Bozell & Jacobs, and three other shops, the Minolta Corporation has decided to switch its photographic division account to one of the three, the William Esty Company. Billings are put at between $12 million and $15 million.

title: DON'T SKIMP ON NUCLEAR SAFETY DEVICES
description: To the Editor:

title: SOMALIA'S DIFFICULTIES
description: By signing a treaty of cooperation and friendship, w hich includes secret clauses, with Ethiopia and Southern Yemen, bothS oviet surrogates in the Horn of Africa region, the Libyan leader C ol. Muammar el-Qaddafi acquired a new enemy - Somalia.

title: Maine Nuclear Drill Held
description: Federal agencies gave the state high marks today for its conduct of a mock emergency drill at the Maine Yankee power plant in Wiscasset, the only nuclear plant in the state, utility officials say.

title: Settlement in Market Death
description: The family of a market manager who was mistakenly shot to death by a rookie policewoman said today that it would accept a $70,000 settlement from the city. Harry Walden, night manager of Johnny's Sak-Ful market, was killed Aug. 1 by Officer Joyce Faye Allen as he fled the store in an aborted robbery. Officer Allen, who was subsequently dismissed from the force, said she mistook Mr. Walden for a man she saw holding a shotgun on a customer.

title: Commuter Airline To Drop Rochester
description: ROCHESTER (AP) - Air North, a Vermont-based commuter airline that now flies to 13 cities in New York State, said it would cease its service to Rochester on Oct. 25.

title: NEW YORK LEGISLATURE BEGINS REDISTRICTING TASK
description: As the New York City Council continues to fend off criticism over its redistricting plan, the State Legislature has begun the task of redrawing its own districts and those of the state's Congressional delegation.

title: Henry Endress, Leader Of Lutheran Societies
description: Henry Endress, a former Lutheran Church official who headed of the Lutheran Resources Commission in Wa@shingon, died Sunday in San Leandro, Calif., of complications related to a heart ailment. He was 66 years old.

title: Faulkner in Love, a Poetic Memento; Faulkner in Love, A Poetic Memento
description: NEW ORLEANS (AP) - Sixteen poems written by William Faulkner when he was a lovesick young man mooning after Helen Baird are being published in a small but elegant book.

title: AUSTRIAN PRELATE ASKS ACCORD BETWEEN SCIENCE AND RELIGION
description: Science and religion should cooperate in establishing ethical limits to help solve some of the modern world's problems, Franz Cardinal Konig of Vienna said at a luncheon at New York University yesterday.

title: CSR Gets Loans To Acquire Delhi
description: CSR Ltd., the Australian sugar and energy group, said it had arranged unsecured loans totaling $600 million from six banks to pay for its $78-a-share, $591 million tender offer for the Delhi International Oil Corporation, of Texas.

title: COMMERCIAL ALLIANCE CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
description: There were provisions for possible losses of $4,950,000 for 1981 and $5.6 million for 1980; shr earnings figures are fully diluted; the company said that new investment tax credit rules under the 1981 Economic Recovery Tax Act were made retro- active to Jan 1, 1981 and have increased the results previously reported for the second and third qtrs of fiscal 1981

title: WEINBERGER SAYS SAUDI ARMS SALE WOULD HELP ALL MIDEAST NATIONS
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister, said today that his country's moderate oil pricing policy would remain unchanged whether or not the United States Congress rejected the sale of Awacs reconnaissance planes.

title: U.S. POSTPONES FILLING RIGHTS POSITION
description: The Administration said today that no effort would be made to fill the position of Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights until a major State Department reorganization study was completed.

title: THE STING ENDS CHICAGO'S SUFFERING
description: Whenever Lee Stern tried to interest a foreign soccer player in joining the Sting, he invariably received the same answer: ''No.''

title: PUSH to Get U.S. Funds After Agreeing to Audit
description: The Education Department, which had cut off $825,000 to the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson's PUSH for Excellence Inc., will release the money because the civil rights organization's leader has agreed to an audit, an official said today.

title: What's Fair on the Modern Air
description: The time may be at hand, or merely fast approaching. But Mark Fowler, the new chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, is surely right to suggest that Congress get ready to repeal the socalled fairness and equal-time doctrines for broadcasting. Whatever the risks, abandoning these codes follows logically from the rapid deregulation of radio and television. The emphasis so far has been on expanding consumer choice by removing barriers to technological progress. Editorial freedom is the obvious next step.

title: RAMS DEFEAT BEARS FOR 2D STRAIGHT, 24-7
description: LeRoy Irvin returned a punt 55 yards for a touchdown, and Wendell Tyler scored twice on short runs tonight to lead the Los Angeles Rams to a 24-7 victory over the Chicago Bears. It was the second straight victory for the Rams, who improved theirrecord to 2-2 . The Bears, who lost their starting quarterback, Vince Evans, and Ri ckey Watts, a wide receiver, in the first half because of injuries, fell to 1-3.

title: IRAQ CONCEDES PULLBACK, DENIES DEFEAT
description: Iraq denounced as ''lies'' today Iran's statement yesterday that Iranian troops had broken the Iraqi siege of Abadan. Iraq conceded, however, that its forces had made a tactical withdrawal in some areas north of the battered oilrefinery city under pressure from Iranian forces.

title: GIFTS FOR THE 2D TIME AROUND
description: It was all so easy way back when. When a divorce in the family was a skeleton in the closet and marriage was sti ll considered a singularnoun.

title: Nuclear Plant Guards Strike
description: Guards at the Pantex nuclear assembly plant near Amarillo went on strike today after rejecting a contract offer from the plant's management. The plant is to be used to assemble the neutron weapon when it goes into production.

title: Savings Units Cite Losses
description: Nearly 70 percent of the nation's savings and loan associations suffered losses in the first half of this year, double the proportion at the end of last year, the Government said today.

title: Inventor Named Head Of Anchor Conveyors
description: Ade Czarnecki, a 57-year-old engineer and inventor who developed 11 conveyor equipment and application patents, has been named president of Anchor Conveyors Inc., a Dearborn, Mich., manufacturer of industrial conveying and unit-handling systems, mostly for the auto industry. The previous president, William Shaw, 63, left the company, a subsidiary of Standard Alliance Industries, last April.

title: CARDINALS REDUCE EXPO LEAD
description: Darrell Porter doubled home two runs in a five-run fourth inning that helped the Cardinals to a 6-2 victory over the Montreal Expos last night in St. Louis. The triumph, in the first of a two-game series, cut the Expos' lead over the Cardinals in the National League East's second-half race to a half-game with six to play.

title: Sugar Import Fees Are Raised Again
description: For the second time in less than three weeks, an increase in sugar import fees was announced today by the Agriculture Department. The increase of just over a half-cent a pound, effective Thursday, is intended to keep the New York price of imported raw sugar at 15 cents a pound and refined sugar at 15.52 cents a pound, in the wake of continuing weakness in world prices.

title: WESTCHESTER TO HOLD A HEARING ON VOTE FOR A COUNTY UTILITY
description: The Westchester County Board of Legislators took a decisive step today toward creating a public power agency that would replace the Consolidated Edison Company as the local supplier of electrical power, presumably at lower cost to consumers.

title: REAGAN TO NOMINATE FLORIDA AUTO DEALER TO IMMIGRATION POST
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Norman Braman, a wealthy Miami Beach businessman, to be Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization.

title: 16 in Jersey Held On Drug Charges
description: ATLANTIC CITY (UPI) - Sixteen persons were arrested on drug charges in a series of predawn raids that capped a monthlong undercover investigation into heroin sales in the resort, the police said.

title: CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for 12 weeks to Sept 6
Volcano in Alaska Erupts
description: A large l ava flow spilled down the northern slopes of the Pavlof volcano on the Alaskan peninsula while ash and rocks flew from the crater in t he volcano's second eruption in a year, observers said yesterday. The 8,261-foot Pavlof volcano did not appear to be threatening any of the small fishing villages nearby, a National Weather Service s pokesman said.

title: Defensive Play Pleases Giants
description: For the Giants, who have split their first four games of the season, the next three games will be crucial, Coach Ray Perkins said today.

title: DOW IS UP 18.55 AFTER EARLY DROP
description: The stock market made a dramatic recovery following an early avalanche of heavy selling yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 18.55 points, to 842.56, its biggest daily gain in more than six months.

title: A PRINCIPAL BRINGS CALM TO A CHAOTIC CITY SCHOOL
description: Philip Cox is Matt Dillon in a three-piece, pin-striped suit, patrolling the corridors of Boys and Girls High School in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn as if they were the streets of Dodge City.

title: Talking Business with Stata of Analog Devices; Hard Choices In Electronics
description: Profits have evaporated this year throughout the customarily rich electronics industry. Indeed, it is the industry's worst year since 1974. This is forcing hard decisions on spending, especially on how to bolster the chronically thin ranks of engineers.

title: Football Casualty List
description: With a key game coming up against Atlanta at home next Monday night, the Ph iladelphia Eagles once more are in need of a healthy fullback. Per ry Harrington, who took over the position after Leroy Harris fractu red his wrist last summer, broke a leg in the Eagles' victory over Washington Sunday and is out for the season.

title: 2 Top Executives Promoted at Dime
description: Last month, the Dime Savings Bank of New York became the largest savings bank in New York State when its assets reached $5.8 billion and its deposits, $5 billion. And on Thursday the 121-year-old thrift institution, based in Brooklyn, will have a new president, John W. Sapanski.

title: Louisville's Bid to Get Cards' Farm Club Fails
description: A campaign to lure the Springfield (Ill.) Redbirds, a St. Louis Cardinal farm club, to Louisville collapsed today.

title: U.S. Radar Station To Become Prison
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - The Federal Government agreed yesterday to transfer an unused radar station near Watertown, N.Y., to New York State for conversion to a prison.

title: State Dept. Aide to Help Salvador With Election
description: Everett E. Briggs, Deputy Assistant Secretary for Inter-American Affairs, arrived in El Salvador yesterday to discuss American assistance in preparing elections scheduled for March 1982, according to Alan Romberg, a State Department spokesman.

title: SONIA GORE
description: Sonia Gore, an opera patron amd member of the National Council of the Metropolitan Opera Company in New York, died Wednesday at her home in Boca Raton, Fla. She was 93 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: Changes in the way lower-court judges are chosen to work temporarily in State Supreme Court have raised the hopes of some judges, caused concern among others and provided a rare look at the infighting for promotion that occurs on the bench.

description: Reagan holds off on second nomi- nation for rights post 3 Iraq denies that Iran scored a vic- tory in war 3 Around the World 4 West German state elections go against Schmidt's party 4 title: A SE NATE VOTE TO IMPOVERISH THE FAMILY DAIRY FARMER
description: To the Editor:

title: Lane Repair Planned On Bridge to Brooklyn
description: A $10.7 million rehabilitation project will begin today on the Williamsburg Bridge that is expected to disrupt the traffic flow on the bridge for the next 18 months, the city's Department of Transportation announced yesterday. Motorists are advised to use the Manhattan and Brooklyn Bridges or the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel as alternative routes.

title: THE RIDDLE OF DETERRENCE
description: It's axiomatic, among most military analysts, that nuclear weapons are never to be used. ''War-fighting'' by such means, to most of them, would result in the virtual destruction of the human race; hence the doctrine of deterrence, which holds that nuclear weapons must prevent nuclear war by making it too destructive for anyone to begin.

title: Bus Crash Kills 25 in Spain
description: A bus and a truck collided head-on near the town of Quintanar de la Orden in central Spain early today, killing at le ast 25 people on the bus and injuring 20 to 25, most of them seriousl y, the police said. All the victims were members of Spain's Commu nist Party who were on their way home to the city of Murcia after attending an annual party picnic in Madrid.

title: U.S. TRADE GAP SWELLS
description: WASHINGTON (AP) - The nation's foreign trade deficit ballooned to $5.6 billion in August, the biggest total in 18 months, as a strengthening dollar encouraged Americans to buy more from overseas, the Government reported yesterday.

title: PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Q & A
description: Q. What are plantar warts and how are they treated?

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 29, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: AT BLACK CAUCUS, ELATION AND HOPE
description: George A. Dalley stood beneath the bright yellow and white circus tent covering the backyard of Representative Charles B. Rangel's home here and observed the black New Yorkers mingling around him.

title: Death on the Highway
description: Bronislaw Malinowski of Poland, gold medalist in the 3,000-meter steeplechase at the 1980 Olympics, was killed Sunday night when his car collided head-on with a truck in the Polish town of Grudzaiz. Malinowski was the second East European Olympian to die in a car crash in recent weeks.

title: Gibson's Aide to Stay In School Board Post
description: Carl Sharif, a top aide to Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and president of the city's Board of Education, will remain in his post despite his indictment last week by a grand jury in Essex County, the Mayor said today.

title: LOSS AT RESORTS INTERNATIONAL
description: Resorts International Inc. announced yesterday that it expected to show losses of $2.5 million and $10 million, respectively, for the latest nine-month and three-month periods because of a sharp decline in Treasury bond futures contracts held by the company.

title: EX-TROPPER CLEARED IN THE FATAL SHOOTING OF SOUTH JERSEY MAN
description: A former state trooper was acquitted today of manslaughter in his third trial on charges stemming from the shooting of a man he had chased for speeding.

title: 2 Rockets Strike Belfast, Killing a Policeman
description: A policeman was killed and a second officer hurt in a rocket attack today in a Roman Catholic district of west Belfast.

title: PIANO: BELLA DAVIDOVICH PLAYS TCHAIKOVSKY
description: AT the 92d Street Y on Saturday night, Bella Davidovich presented a piano recital composed of musical images, displayed with the care of an acutely aware museum director. It was refined, cantabile playing, lucidly outlining shapes, alluding to contrasting textures and colors without making them the center of attention.

title: Analysts' Role Cited by Meese
description: Edwin Meese 3d, counselor to President Reagan, charged today that stock market analysts might be responsible for price drops.

title: HIGH COURT RULING ENCOURAGES OTTAWA AND ITS FOES
description: The Canadian Supreme Court ruled today that Ottawa's move to obtain a new constitution was legal but at the same time ''offends the federal principle'' because it was being carried out without overall provincial consent.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on Sept 21, 1981

title: Citicorp Ratings Cut
description: The ratings on long-term securities issued by Citicorp, the holding company for Citibank, were reduced yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation from its highest AAA rating to AA+, one grade below. It also reduced the rating of Citicorp's preferred stock to AA from AA+.

title: ISSUES TO BE DEBATED
description: Key enforcement provisions of the Voting Rights Act, which was enacted in 1965, will expire next August unless extended by Congress. There is little doubt that Congress will renew the law in some form, but the enforcement of the law in recent years has become very technical and has been a source of resentment, particularly in the South.

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
AFGHAN-PAKISTANI TALKS AT U.N. SEEM DEADLOCKED
description: Pakistan and Afghanistan have failed to make progress in indirect negotiations here on the issue of removing Soviet troops fro m Afghanistan, offi cials close to the talkssaid today.

title: BIG RALLY CALMS TRADERS' EARLY FEARS
description: There were cheers, whistles, flying confetti and scattered applause at the closing bell yesterday as brokers on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange celebrated the market's resounding recovery.

title: G.M. Discloses New Plant Plans
description: The General Motors Corporation said it planned to build ''an all-new generation'' of front-wheel-drive luxury cars in its two new assembly plants under construction in Detroit and in Orion Township, near Pontiac, Mich.

title: BAG LADIES
description: In the notorious section of midtown surrounding the Port Authority bus terminal, amid throngs of workers, transients, and tourists, lives a compact society of outsiders. Hustlers, hookers, three-card monte players, con men, drug dealers, jackrollers (thieves who specialize in robbing the poor of their welfare funds) work over their marks between Times Square and the Stroll, that strip of Eighth Avenue serviced by prostitutes and pimps. But there is another sort of outsider in the neighborhood, another group of resident streetwalkers, as inconspicuous as the others are often flamboyant. This is the swelling population of ''shopping-bag ladies,'' those solitary, impoverished women toting bags, picking over trash near the Ninth Avenue food markets, dozing in doorways, huddled among their possessions in the Port Authority's dreary public rooms.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Acton Corp. said it had sold Office Canteens, a division, to Food Concepts Inc. of Rutherford, N.J., for more than $1 million.

title: 250 DEMOCRATS STUDY ART OF WINNING
description: Forty Democrats c heered the description of a political campaign that carried all the earmarks of the New Right, In other sessions they were less excited but carefully took notes on how to choose target precincts or the importance of leaflets or preparation for odd questions in television interviews.

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1981
description: International The sale of Awacs planes to Saudi Arabia was pressed by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. In Senate testimony, he contended that the transfer would contribute significantly to the security of all nations in the Middle East, including Israel. Meanwhile, Richard W. Murphy, the newly confirmed ambassador to Saudi Arabia, flew there to begin discussions on the sale. (Page A1, Column 1.) Saudi oil prices will remain moderate whether or not Congress rejects the sale of Awacs plans, according to Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister. He predicted that the prices would not outpace inflation through 1986. (A1:2.)

title: MOSCOW SAYS U.S. IS SPURRING ON POLISH COUNTERREVOULTIONARY DRIVE
description: Barely a week after President Reagan urged LeonidI. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, in a letter to exercise restraint on Poland, the K remlin has given new emphasis to charges that the United States is fomenting ''counterrevolutionary'' activities in Poland.

title: HAIG AND GROMYKO TO MEET NEXT YEAR
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko met for five hours today for what were described as ''frank, businesslike and serious'' discussions on the major issues between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: GROMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including $50,000 tax credit...C-Net loss after $71,078 loss from discontinued operations

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: FROM coast to coast, from Harvard to Stanford, educators are toying with new definitions of a liberal education but coming up mostly with vague old ones. Last week, the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation issued a proposal for drastic change and an implied promise to help pay for it.

title: REPUBLIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
AUTOCLAVE ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 8
Muir Trustee Shifts Accounts
description: More than half of the 18,500 active customer accounts at the bankrupt John Muir & Company have been transferred to other brokerage houses or will be transferred within the week, while the remainder remain frozen until the details of their transfer are completed, the trustee for Muir said yesterday.

title: NEXUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
description: B-Net loss and after loss from discontinued operations of $753,023...C-After a loss from discontinued operations of $942,627; the shr earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock split in Oct 1980; the operations of Shirt Shed Inc have been included in the company's results since it was acquired as a purchase on Apr 1, 1980

title: Equimark Loss on Loans
description: The troubled Equimark Corporation, one of the least profitable bank holding companies in the nation, said yesterday that it would reduce its third-quarter profits by $10.3 million, the amount of a loss provision it was creating for loans outstanding to the FSC Corporation.

title: OHIO PIANIST, 26, WINS $75,000 AMERICAN MUSIC COMPETITION
description: Randall Hodgkinson, a 26-year-old pianist from Lindhurst, Ohio, has been named the winner of the 1981 International American Music Competition. The announcement was made Sunday night in Carnegie Hall, where the three finalists had played during the afternoon. The competition is sponsored jointly by the Rockefeller Foundation and Carnegie Hall.

title: THE MEASURE OF AN AMERICAN
description: PRESIDENTTo the Editor:

title: IT'S QUITE A STRUGGLE FOR SMALL VINTER IN THE NAPA VALLEY
description: As Jim Spaulding led the way through the chardonnay vines, he stopped and frowned, muttering under his breath. The source of his displeasure was a cluster of his most expensive grapes, missed by pickers and left to turn to raisins that would fall to the ground with the winter rains.

title: Wind Project Cut
description: The United Technologies Corporation said it intended to withdraw from the $350 million Kahuku Point wind energy project in Hawaii because Windfarms Ltd., its partner, had been unable to obtain financing. United said it would concentrate on other wind energy projects it considered more promising. It did not disclose its investment in the project.

title: Edward J. Deasy, Ex-President Of the Beneficial Finance Co.
description: Edward J. Deasy, retired president of the Beneficial Finance Company of New York, died Saturday at the Cinnaminson Manor Nursing Home in Cinnaminson, N.J. He was 76 years old and a former resident of Port Washington, L.I.

title: LOWER SAXONY VOTE RESULTS IN A SETBACK FOR SCHMIDT'S PARTY
description: Christian Democrats won more than 50 percent of the votes and Social Democrats suffered severe losses in municipal elections over the weekend that both parties said reflected changing national political moods. Final tallies today from the state of Lower Saxony, which elected ci ty officials for the first time in five years, showed the Ch ristian Democrats winning 50.2 percent of the statewide vote, a ga in of 2.2 percentage points, while the Social Democrats fell to 36 .9 percent, a loss of 6.6 percentage points. Chancellor Helmut Sc hmidt's Social Democrats won a majority in only one city.

title: STOCK PRICES FALL STEEPLY ABROAD, BUT NEW YORK SHOWS STRONG RALLY
description: In a day of frantic trading, world stock markets were swept with a wave of near-panic selling yesterday until the falling prices were finally checked with a strong rally on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: U.S. PRESSES JAPAN ON ARMS OUTLAYS
description: The United States is continuing in its effort to get Japan to increase military spending by emphasizing the Soviet threat to world security, but the Japanese response has remained cautious.

title: ACCORD REACHED IN CARE DISPUTE AT WILLOWBROOK
description: Lawyers for New York State and two public-interest groups told a Federal judge yesterday that they had agreed on a settlement in the long-pending case on the care of mentally retarded patients at Willowbrook on Staten Island.

title: G.O.P. HOPING JOGGERS WILL REACH THE VOTERS
description: The opening shot of the television commercial shows a group of good-looking young joggers charging through Central Park, their faces creased with strain. Are they supposed to be selling beer? Breakfast cereal? Deodorant?

title: PIANIST: MATY ANN HEYM
description: MARY ANN HEYM'S piano playing Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall could not always stand up to the pressures of the occasion; but despite intermittent lapses of memory and ensuing struggles to regain equilibrium, an authoritative and sincere musical personality made itself felt.

title: THE MYSTERY OF DAMASCUS STEEL APPEARS SOLVED
description: TWO metallurgists at Stanford University, seeking to produce a ''superplastic'' metal, appear to have stumbled on the secret of Damascus steel, the legendary material used by numerous warriors of the past, including the Crusaders. Its formula had been lost for generations.

title: NEW AIR CONTROLLER'S CROP AT MAKE-OR-BREAK POINT IN TRAINING
description: For David Ekstrom and Kevin Wollscheidt, the moment of truth draws near. That is the moment when it will be clear whether they are really able to envision in their heads a detailed three-dimensional picture of what is happening in the sky above, to visualize accurately how airplanes are moving in relation to each other.

title: Alfa Romeo Eurocredit
description: Alfa Romeo International is raising a $50 million Eurocredit, guaranteed by Societa Finanziaria Meccanica, the joint lead manager, National Westminster Bank, said today. The credit is for five years, with two and a half years' grace, at 5/8 of a percentage point above the London interbank offered rate, the bank said. The other lead manager is Fuji Bank.

title: PPG and Du Pont Set Joint Venture
description: PPG Industries and the E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said they would form a joint venture to produce ethylene glycol in Beaumont, Tex.

title: Kenneth Smith, 65, President Of a Yacht Building Concern
description: Kenneth W. Smith, former president of the United States Banknote Corporation, financial printer in Manhattan, died last Tuesday of a heart attack in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he lived. He was 65 years old, and was a former resident of Greenwich, Conn.

title: TROUBLED ACTOR IN 'MEPHISTO'
description: THE Hungarian director Istvan Szabo, represented in the New York Film Festival this year by ''Mephisto'' and last year by ''Confidence,'' is one of the most impressive of the festival's current contributors. But where ''Confidence'' was a small, delicate two-character drama, the ambitious ''Mephisto'' is both less and more. The story is much larger, with many subsidiary characters and a broad historical scope. But the cost of this expanded scale is some of the precision and intimacy Mr. Szabo brought to his more modest work.

title: Plankton Under Glass
description: In an experiment on possible life-support systems for future space colonies, a space agency scientist has established what appear to be totally self-sufficient communities of shrimp, algae and microbes capable of generating their own food, oxygen and water within the confines of sealed glass flasks. These laboratory communities have thrived now for more than 15 months.

title: 2 DOCUMENTARIES ON CITIES AND THE KLAN
description: PROBABLY not many people who will see ''Tighten Your Belts, Bite the Bullet'' and ''Resurgence: The Movement for Equality Versus the Klu Klux Klan,'' the two short documentaries that will be sh own at the New York Film Festival tonight at 9:30, w ill be advocates either of neglect of our cities or of the Klu Klux Klan.

title: BALLY AGREES TO BUY PENN CENTRAL UNIT
description: The Penn Central Corporation and the Bally Manufacturing Corporation said yesterday that they had reached agreement in principle for Bally to acquire Penn Central's Six Flags Inc. subsidiary for about $140 million.

title: Associated Press
description: CAR BOMB KILLS 15 PEOPLE: Pedestrians looking at damage caused by car that exploded near Zrariyeh, Lebanon.

title: TV: 'ANCIENT MARINERS'
description: MAN made a road out of the barrier of the sea by building ships, and this most adventurous and ancient pursuit opens the new season of ''Odyssey,'' the series that looks at history and life through the lens of anthropology. ''The Ancient Mariners,'' at 9 o'clock tonight on WNET-TV, achieves a fascination worthy of its topic in sound and picture.

title: Increase in Coal Mining Tax Sought for Black Lung Fund
description: The Reagan Administration plans to recommend increasing the tax that mine operators pay for the coal they mine, officials said today, in an effort to eliminate a Black Lung Trust Fund deficit that is now $1.2 billion and rising.

title: PRIVATE PENSIONS STRESSED IN STUDY
description: A research report calling for less reliance on Social Security for retirement income and more emphasis on private pension plans and personal savings has been made public here by the Committee for Economic Development.

title: THE BLUE-YONDER BLUES
description: This is an exchange between a resident of Ann Arbor, Mich., and an official of the Federal Aviation Administration's Office of Government and Public Affairs. The official asked that the lovelorn lad not be identified by his full name.

title: STERCHI BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
SADAT, AND THE U.S., VS. THE EGYPTIAN PEOPLE
description: To the Edit or: President A nwar Sadat's arrest of over 1,500 opposition leaders is indeed, as th e headline of a Sept. 10 Times editorial proclaimed, a ''Distress Si gnal From Egypt.''

title: THE DANCE: STREAM INC. AT LA MAMA
description: BECAUSE the world is imperfect and we are imperfect creatures in the world, it is easy for good theoretical ideas to have not so good practical consequences.

title: TOKYO STOCKS IN RECORD DROP
description: With investors selling shares at a hectic pace, the Nikkei Dow Jones average, representing 225 stocks, plunged more than 300 points yesterday. It was a record decline for the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

title: PRIVATE COLLECTION OF DEBTS TO U.S. IS SOUGHT
description: The Reagan Administration, faced with collecting more than $25 billion in delinquent debts owed to the Federal Government, is pushing a plan to permit private collectors to seek out Federal debtors and to let them use current addresses taken from tax forms.

title: CAN CRAVING FOR CARBOHYDRATES BE CONTROLLED? CHEMICAL STUDIES OF BRAIN POINT TO NEW APPROACH
description: an understanding that could be important to weight control for millions of Americans - has led to an experimental treatment to suppress these cravings.

title: Footwear Profit Off
description: The International Seaway Trading Corporation, a footwear company, said today that earnings in its fiscal second quarter, ended Aug. 31, fell 50 percent to $85,000, or 11 cents a share, from $169,000, or 22 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales declined to $8.5 million from $13.9 million.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DONORS

title: Health Officials Adopt Plan for the Americas
description: Health ministers from the 35 nations in the Pan American Health Organization approved a plan today aimed at insuring access to health care for all 900 million people expected to be living in the Western Hemisphere in the year 2,000.

title: 2 Airbus Orders
description: Airbus I ndustrie, the European aircraft con sortium financed by the Governments of Britain, France and West Germa n, said today that Egypt's international airline, Egyptair, had converted two options for A300-200 series aircraft into firm orders . The company said the planes will be delivered in the spring of 198 3 and will be powered by the General Electric Company's CF6-50C2 en gines. The value of the accord was not disclosed, but the series-200 Airbus typica lly sells for about $30 million when spare parts are included.

title: A Puzzle That Agonizes
description: The devilish puzzle known as Rubik's Cube has caused an untold amount of mental anguish, and now, it turns out, it can cause physical distress as well.

title: DAYTIME UNIFORM: THE SUIT
description: The most popular daytime style around New York these days is a suit invented by Gabrielle Chanal almost 60 years ago and, except for a period when she closed her couture house during the 1940's and early 1950's, seen almost incessantly since then.

title: When a Combination Works, It Stays Together
description: He will apparently always be known for ''Ladies in Retirement,'' and she fears she will never live down ''All About Eve,'' but after half a dozen collaborations and a number of other solo efforts, Reginald Denham and his wife, Mary Orr, are trying once again to upstage their greatest successes.

title: U.S. SCIENCE AGENCY'S NEW CHIEF PUSHES FOR CHANGES
description: WASHINGTON THE National Academy of Sciences, after a dozen sometimes controversial years under the stern leadership of Philip Handler, is entering a new phase in its 118-year history under a new president who is beginning to make some potentially significant changes in the way the venerable institution operates.

title: YANKS BEATEN BY INDIANS, 6-2
description: A crowd of 6,168 fans huddled against the Lake Erie cold tonight and watched the Indians beat the Yankees, 6-2, in a game that had virtually no bearing on the intense race for the American League East title.

title: THE RESEARCH AID IN NEW TAX LAW
description: Shortly after the Reagan Administration's tax program was passed by Congress, the General Electric Company's tax accounting and technology staff set out to examine just what G.E. stood to gain from provisions that were meant to stimulate research and development.

title: ARCHIBALD M. THOMSON
description: Archibald M. Thomson, who worked for the Shubert Organization for many years and was house manager of the Lyceum Theater for the last four years, died last Tuesday at his home in New York.

title: Steel Imports Were Up 62% in August
description: Steel imports for August rose 62 percent to their highest monthly level in nearly four years, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: It's Justice O'Connor's Turn to Send for Coffee
description: The nation's first woman to be seated on the United States Supreme Court, Sandra Day O'Connor, went to work yesterday, joining her eight colleagues for a week of closed-door conferences preceding the official beginning of the Court's new term on the first Monday in October.

title: New A.&P. Stores
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company announced a program for opening 10 new A.& P. supermarkets in its northern New Jersey division from Sept. 22 to Oct. 31. The stores were purchased in August from the Stop and Shop Companies of Boston, and have been refurbished. One store in Wyckoff, N.J., opened last week. Others will be opened in Bloomfield, Wallington, Clifton, South Plainfield, Edison, Saddle Brook, North Brunswick and Newark, all in New Jersey, and in New City, N.Y.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt PRACTICING HISTORY. Selected Essays. By Barbara W. Tuchman. 306 pages. Knopf. $16.50.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Altex Oil Corporation filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offer to owners of warrants expiring Dec. 7, 1981, an opportunity to exchange each warrant for a unit of common stock and a new warrant expiring Dec. 7, 1984.

title: West Germany Implicates 2 In Attack on U.S. Commander
description: The police have found fingerprints of two of West Germany's most wanted terrorist suspects during investigations into a grenade and gun attack on the commander of the United States Army in Europe, the federal prosecutor's office said today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS ON PROGRAM FOR FIGHTING CRIME IN U.S.  Following are excerpts from President Reagan's address to the International Association of Chiefs of Police in New Orleans yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News.
description: Crime is an American epidemic - it takes the lives of 25,000 Americans, it touches nearly one-third of American households, and it results in at least $8.8 billion per year in financial losses.

title: REDKEN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: The 1980 qr earnings were decreased 11 cents a shr due to losses associated with an independent distributor; the company said that at year-end it changed its method of accounting for substantially all inventories to LIFO from FIFO; the effect of the change reduced 1981 net by $332,000 or 15 cents a shr

title: TIMES OF LONDON WARNS DISPUTE COULD KILL IT
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian publisher who owns Times Newspapers Ltd., warned today that he would permanently close the 196-year-old Times unless protesting workers back down on demands for more men and more pay.

title: TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 29, 1981; Markets
description: Stock prices ended a tumultuous day with a strong rally on the New York Stock Exchange after plunging on markets from Tokyo to London. In early trading today, Japanese stocks rebounded sharply. The worldwide decline was attributed to uncertainty about the economic outlook, especially in the U.S. (Page A1.) The upshot of the day's frantic trading, economists said, is that despite the long slide in stock prices the world's economy does not seem to be on the brink of a severe recession. (A1.)

title: '60 MINUTES' LOOKS AT ITSELF AND ITS PRACTICES
description: In the aftermath of Sunday night's ''60 Minutes,'' during which some of the CBS program's journalistic practices were examined, its executive producer agreed with other television newsmen that certain of the practices should be subjected to reconsideration.

title: Convicted Sniper Given 2 Life Terms for Murders
description: Two more life prison sentences were imposed today on Joseph Paul Franklin by a judge who said he thought the death penalty would have been a more fitting punishment for the convicted killer.

title: CARDINALS REDUCE EXPO LEAD
description: Mark Brouhard hit his sec ond homer of the year in the seventh inning, and P ete Vuckovich pitched a three-hitter, leading the Brewers to a 1-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox last night in Milwaukee. Th e victory moved the Brewers into first place in the American Leag ue East's second-half race.

title: BRIEFING
description: W ITH only three years left until the next Presidential election, Edwin Meese 3d, the White House counselor, is quietly planning a meeting sometime in the next 10 days with top Republicans to discuss the convention site. Mr. Meese and others are leaning toward Dallas. Another possibility: Los Angeles.

title: RPS PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Coal Output D ecline Seen
description: The National Coal Association predicted today that a 72-day miners' strike and a slump in the steel industry will cause coal production to decline 3.5 percent this year.

title: Turner Broadcasting, Warner Sales Merger
description: As the result of an agreement announced yesterday the sales organization for the Turner Broadcasting Company's Cable News Network and Cable News Network 2 will be merged into the sales organization of the Warner Amex Satellite Entertainment Company, and Warner will lease to Turner its transponder on RCA's Satcom F-1 satellite for two years.

title: Petro-Lewis Gains
description: The Petro-Lewis Corporation, an oil and gas exploration company based in Denver, reported yesterday that net income in its fourth fiscal quarter, ended June 30, rose 31.8 percent, to $8.7 million, or 38 cents a share, from $6.6 million, or 30 cents a share, a year before. Revenues climbed 40.7 percent, to $48.4 million, from $34.4 million.

title: Relaxing Set For Gold Cup
description: Relaxing, the 5-year-old mare who won the Ruffian Handicap Sunday, will be entered in the Jockey Club Gold Cup, a mile-and-a-half race to be run Oct. 10 at Belmont Park, her trainer, Angel Penna, said yesterday.

title: PHILLIES DEFEAT METS BY 12-4
description: The Philadelphia Phillies showed distinct signs of reviving for next week's playoff when they battered seven pitchers tonight and routed the Mets, 12-4.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT SOVIET HOLDS JEW WHO RAN A MAKESHIFT SCHOOL
description: The Soviet authorities are reported to have closed down an unofficial ''Jewish university'' in Kharkov and arrested one of its organizers, according to information reaching Soviet emigres in Israel.

title: AIDING FLEEING HAITIANS
description: A newspaper photograph recently gave me a disquieting feeling of ''deja vu.'' It showed two helmeted riot policemen dragging off a Haitian at the Krome North detention center in Miami after ''disturbances in the camp.''

title: SGL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Railroad Benefits to Be Cut
description: Benefits will be reduced for 400,000 retired railroad workers and their families starting this week because of Federal budget cuts, the Railroad Retirement Board said today.

title: PARIS SHARES DECLINE SHARPLY ON A BROAD FRONT
description: Stocks on the Paris exchange, already badly battered by the Socialists' election victory in June, declined sharply today.

title: FEEBLE EXCUSE FOR BANNING A RUGBY MATCH
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 030750 -- No Title
description: Two grants totaling $4.5 million have been approved by the Federal Government, clearing the way for a long-planned pedestrian mall on two blocks of Broadway in the Times Square area, city officials said yesterday.

title: Teltscher and Teacher Reach Final on Coast
description: Eliot Teltscher and Brian Teacher moved into the final of the $200,000 Transamerica Open tennis tournament with straight-set victories last night over Bill Scanlon and Vijay Amritraj.

title: GRAPHIC SCANNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $7,209,000 gain on the sale of a division

title: POLL SHOWS CONCERN OVER ECONOMY CUTTING INTO PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR REAGAN
description: President Reagan's once solid grip on public support appears to be loosening somewhat because of worries about the economic situation, and his speech last Thursday calling for more budget cuts did little or nothing to reverse the slippage, the latest N ew York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: JETS LOOK AHEAD TO DOLPHINS
description: Will overconfidence spoil the New York Jets? The Jets permitted themselves smirks today while they watched the replay of yesterday's 33-17 trouncing of the Houston Oilers - not only because they looked impressive in gaining their first victory of the season, but because their next opponent is the Miami Dolphins, whom they have beaten six straight times.

title: Feuding Phillies
description: Paul Owens, general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, was taken into custody by the Chicago police over the weekend and after he and Dickie Noles, a Philadelphia pitcher, had quarreled at the hotel where the Phillies were staying. The police acted on a complaint from a hote l security guard, who, Owens said, simp ly ''overreacted.''

title: Canadian Bond Sale
description: The Finance Department said today that it was issuing $500 million of new government bonds with maturities of two and five years. The issue is dated Oct. 15, 1981, and will be made up of notes due Oct. 15, 1983, paying 18 3/4 percent, and bonds due Oct. 1, 1986, paying 18 percent. The five-year bonds are extendable, at the holders' option, up to June 30, 1986, into bonds of an equal par value due Oct 1, 1991, paying 18 percent.

title: VISION OUT OF VOGUE
description: To the Editor:
