title: REAGAN PROPOSES REVISION OF LAWS TO COMBAT CRIME
description: President Reagan today called for legal changes that he said would make it easier to detain and convict criminal offenders by denying them bail and by allowing prosecutors to use illegally seized evidence in court.

title: NEW MATH EXPLAINED
description: To dispel once and for all the confusion surrounding the City Council's redistricting plan, we are running here today the previously unpublished transcript of an interview conducted by an out-of-town reporter with a spokesman for the prestigious law firm that the Council has hired as its press agent.

title: Diablo Fuel Loading De layed by Design Fault
description: Builders of the Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant, where some 2,000 protesters have been arrested, announced today that fuel loading would be delayed because of a design problem.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Try a Dickens Cocktail? Milton Gold man, the theatrical agent, swears it happened just this way yesterday afternoon when he and his client, Roger Rees, the star of ''The Life & Adventures of Nicholas Nickleby,'' the dramatization of the Charle s Dickens novel, were having lunch.

title: ICOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $138,000 for the qr and $386,000 for the yr...C-Including tax credits of $82,000 for the qr and $130,000 for the yr

title: Belgian Premier Sets Elections for Nov. 8
description: Prime Minister Mark Eyskens announced today that Belgium would hold parliamentary elections on Nov. 8 to replace his fallen center-left coalition Cabinet.

title: BYRNE JOINS IN CAMPAIGN WITH FLORIO
description: -Governor Byrne made a rare campaign appearance today with the Democrat who hopes to succeed him - Representative James J. Florio of Camden. The Governor said later that it was understandable for Mr. Florio to want to keep a safe distance.

title: 16 in Norwalk Hurt By Chlorine Leak
description: Sixteen persons required hospital treatment after a 500-pound chlorine cylinder sprang a leak in the city sewage plant, producing a cloud of toxic fumes in a waterfront neighborhood.

title: WELFARE TRIMS HIT WORKING MOTHERS
description: Some working women who receive welfare checks here tend to agree with President Reagan's contention that people who can support themselves and their children ought to be required to do so rather than to depend on the Government for a handout.

title: COLLEGE TEST SCORES MAINTAIN 1980 LEVEL
description: College-bound high school students scored just as highly in this year's Scholastic Aptitude Tests as they did last year, the College Board said yesterday. It was only the second time in 18 years that such scores did not decline.

title: LABORITES, TORN BY PARTY ELECTION, PRESS AHEAD WITH LEFTIST PROGRAM
description: The Labor Party pressed ahead today with the adoption of a left-wing program at its annual conference despite the defeat last night of the left's standard-bearer, Tony Benn, in the contest for deputy leader.

title: Marketing Official Gets Post With Tonka Toy
description: Anticipating an expansion of its sales of toys and other children's products, the Tonka Corporation has hired J. William Petty, 49, a veteran consumer products marketing executive, as president of its toy division, effective tomorrow. The position, with responsibility for the portion of the company encompassing more than 90 percent of overall volume last year, has not been filled since 1978.

title: Toronto R ebounds Af ter Fall
description: Prices on the Toronto Stock Exchange bounced back to close strongly higher today after a first-hour drop that was the second-largest on record.

title: 5-Year-Old Queens Boy Dies, An Apparent Beating Victim
description: A 5-year-old boy - the apparent victim of a beating - died last night after he was found unconscious and covered with bruises in a private home in the Springfield Gardens section of Queens, the police said.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,000 in qr and $23,000 for the 9 mos; 1980 results restated for acquisitio

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Pad and Paper Company, Holyoke, Mass., announced that Francis J. Guiliano, chairman and chief executive officer, was assuming the additional title of president. Henry A. Fifield, formerly president, becomes vice chairman; Robert B. Antrasian, executive vice president-corporate, and Frank M. McHugh, executive vice president and general manager of the Ampad group.

title: LONG TERM RATES DECLINE SLIGHTLY
description: Long-term interest rates declined slightly yesterday, but not before the markets were whipsawed by wide gyrations with long-term bond prices fluctuating by more than two points.

title: Japan Growth Is Put at 5%
description: The Fuji Bank said today that Japan's real economic growth for the fiscal year 1981, ending next March, will be about 5 percent, with overseas demand accounting for 2.1 percent of the growth.

title: Charles Bowen Jr., 67; Booz, Allen Chairman
description: Charles P. Bowen Jr., former chairman of Booz, Allen & Hamilton, the management consulting firm, died Sunday at Greenwich Hospital in Greenwich, Conn. He was 67 years old.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Stone & Adler Gets New Top Executive
description: At Stone & Adler, the Chicago direct marketing specialists that was acquired by Young & Rubicam in 1978, Gerald Wood, 40, who transferred in from the parent a year ago, has become president and chief operating officer, Robert Stone, 62, chairman and chief operating office announced yesterday.

title: Panel Is Formed to Seek New Los Angeles Team
description: Hoping to settle out of court an antitrust suit by the Oakland Raiders and the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum Commission against the National Football League, Mayor Tom Bradley and the league's commissioner, Pete Rozelle, agreed today to the naming of a two-member negotiating panel to aid in this city's search for a new football team.

title: AINGE SAYS HE'LL QUIT BASEBALL
description: As a trial began in the dispute over whether he should be permitted to play professional basketball, Danny Ainge of the Toronoto Blue Jays said yesterday that he was retiring from baseball regardless of the trial's outcome.

title: Market Place; Have S tocks Hit Bottom?
description: THE question on everyone's lips now is whether the hard-hit stock market go lower still. Unfortunately, pundits to the contrary notwithstanding, the answer is that no one knows.

title: DiGregorio Tries Again
description: ''Basketball is something I did all my life, and it's awfully hard to put it aside.'' So says Ernie DiGregorio, who, it seems, begins talking of a comeback every year about this time and who is now working out with the Boston Celtic rookies at Hellenic College in Brookline, Mass.

title: Soviet Trade Deficit Up
description: The Soviet Union's trade deficit with non-Communist countries in the first half of this year was more than double the 1980 level while its surplus in trade with Poland almost matched that for all of last year, according to officialstatistics published today.

title: Chess: Henley of New York Wins Colombian Tourney by 1 1/2
description: Ronald Henley, a New York international master, won the Ciudad de Tunja International Tournament in Boyaca, Colombia with an 8-2 score. Jamie Ostos, a Colombian international master, shared second place, 1 1/2 points back. FINAL STANDINGS PlayerPts. Henley 8 Ostos 6 1/2 G.Garcia 6 1/2 Cuellar 5 1/2 Agudelo 5 Minaya 5

title: Poles Meet West Bankers
description: Bankers representing Poland's Western creditors met a Polish delegation today for talks on deferring repayment by Warsaw of $2.4 billion of commercial debt, banking sources said here today.

title: FEARS ON ECONOMY KEEP LOMDON DOWN
description: Prices on the London Stock Exchange fell again today as British investors continued to worry about the state of their economy.

title: ATHLETES' RIGHTS GROUP SET UP
description: The Center for Athletes Rights and Education, a new organization formed on behalf of college and scholastic athletes, today unveiled a bill of rights to protect athletes from what it termed educational, legal and medical abuses.

title: FUNDS AND STAFF FOR PROTECTING ENVIRONMENT MAY BE HALVED
description: The Reagan Administration is seeking to cut the staff and operating budget of the Environmental Protection Agency nearly in half over the next two fiscal years, according to documents circulating in the agency.

title: No Headline
description: Advertising; Ale-8-One Ad Drive Questioned

title: Two Faces of Awacs
description: It is now the view of President Reagan's closest confidant in Congress that ''we would be derelict in our security responsibilities'' not to maintain at least ''joint control'' of any Awacs planes sold to Saudi Arabia - or, for that matter, even a NATO ally. The problem, says Senator Paul Laxalt, is ''the matter of face'' in the sovereign House of Saud: ''They don't want signals to be sent ... that they're incapable of handling that type of equipment by themselves.''

title: HOUSE DISCUSSES MODIFYING THE VOTING RIGHTS ACT
description: The House of Representatives began consideration of the Voting Rights Act today, and the representatives immediately began to argue whether the act was too harsh on communities that made a successful effort to end racial discrimination.

title: Sports of The Times; Ryan's No-Hit Symphony
description: FOR seven years almost to the day, it had been baseball's version of Schubert's ''Unfinished Symphony,'' a 40-minute TV show titled ''The Nolan Ryan Story'' that in 1974 was suddenly outdated shortly after it had been put together. But, with his record fifth no-hitter, Nolan Ryan now has kept his promise to a friend as well as his appointment with history.

title: BETANCOURT, EX-VENEZUELA CHIEF DIES
description: Former President Romulo Betancourt of Venezuela, who worked to restore democracy to his country after years of military rule, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital in New York of complications from a stroke. He was 73 years old.

title: SOUTHERN GOVERNORS OF TWO MINDS ON VALUE OF REAGAN BUDGET PLAN
description: With the impact of sweeping cuts in Federal aid to state and local governments at hand, governors of some of the nation's poorest states, those in the South, voice mixed feelings about President Reagan's ''new federalism.''

title: People
description: * Nicholas Gisonde and Barry Lisee have been elected senior vice presidents of Backer & Spielvogel.

title: Steel Output
description: Steel production remained virtually unchanged at 2.204 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, compared with the previous week's 2.205 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported today.

title: POLISH DISSIDENTS DISBAND KEY GROUP
description: The Committee for Social Self-Defense, a dissident group that helped found the Solidarity labor union, formally dissolved itself today.

title: PERCUSSION: WENDY CHAMBERS CONDUCTS AT THE TRADE CENTER
description: THREE hours after the sun stood vertical in the heavens, on Saturday the 26th day of the ninth month, at the omphallos of lower Manhattan, in the exact center of the cement and metal canyon framed by the towering pillars of the World Trade Center - ''One World Percussion'' was born.

title: HINCKLEY TO ENTER A PLEA OF INSANITY IN REAGAN SHOOTING
description: Attorneys for John W. Hinckley Jr. today notified a Federal court they planned to contend that the accused Presidential assailant was not guilty by reason of insanity.

title: TV: BLACKS ON WAY UP IN 'SOPHISTICATED GENTS'
description: ALTHOUGH far from being an entirely successful production, ''Sophisticated Gents'' is one of the more fascinating television movies of the year. Completed in 1979, it is finally getting a showing on NBC-TV in three parts -the first two hours tonight at 9 o'clock, the third tomorrow at 10 and the fourth Thursday at 10.

title: OHIO-SEALY MATTRESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The 1980 shr earnings adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split paid July 31, 1981

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.00-19.50 ** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: CIVIL RIGHTS LAWYERS QUIETLY REBEL
description: William Bradford Rey nolds, the Justice Department official who is carrying out the R eagan Administration's hotly debated civil rights policies, called i n some of his staff on Sept. 11 to complain about an old Washington problem: ''leaks,'' or as he put it sourly, ''unauthorized disclosur e'' of information to the press.

title: CORE Head Faces Contempt Charge
description: Roy Innis, the national chairman of the Congress of Racial Equality, has been ordered to appear in State Supreme Court in Manhattan Thursday morning to tell the judge why he should not be held in contempt of court for failing to submit to a lineup last week.

title: NETS WAITING ON MCADOO AND BARNES
description: Early this afternoon 12 young basketball players boarded a bus at the Holiday Inn in Suffern, N.Y., to take the half-hour drive down Route 17 for physical examinations here. By this weekend, only about half of the group wi ll remain; the rest will be checking out.

title: PREGNANCY, ALCOHOL AND THE SAFE WAY
description: To the Editor:

title: Debt Limit Postpones Bill Sale
description: The Treasury postponed yesterday's regularly scheduled sale of three-month and six-month bills because Congress has not yet lifted the national debt ceiling.

title: FINANCE MINISTERS TROUBLED BY RATES
description: A perception that interest rates will stay high longer than anticipated, deepening the current world economic slump and compounding debt repayment problems, is casting a pall over a meeting here of world bankers.

title: Economic Analysis
description: After yesterday's close on the New York Stock Exchange, Wall Street breathed a lot easier. The upshot of a tumultuous day in the world's stock markets was to strengthen the belief of economists that the long slide in stock prices did not signify the start of a severe worldwide recession. Clearly, there was - and there still remains - deep concern over high interest rates in the United States. But as economists in this country see it, the world economy is not at the brink.

title: TV Address by Reagan Opens Local United Way Campaigns
description: President Reagan called for ''new, imaginative'' partnerships between local governments and voluntary organizations yesterday in a message marking the beginning of local United Way campaigns across the united States.

title: DODGERS' SMITH FINED, BANNED
description: Reggie Smith, the outfielder for the Los Angeles Dodgers, was suspended for five days and fined $5,000 today by Charles Feeney, president of the National League, for an incident last Friday night in which Smith entered the stands and fought with a fan in San Francisco.

title: Yiddish Musical Season Will Open on Oct. 25
description: The Shalom Yiddish Musical Comedy Theater will open its fourth season Oct. 25 at Town Hall with ''The Rumanian Wedding'' starring Mary Soreanu, Leon Liebgold and David Carey.

title: STATES LAG IN PLANNING FOR BLOCK GRANT PROGRAMS
description: Fifty-seven Federal programs are to be converted into nine broad block grants to the states beginning this week, but the process is so wrapped in confusion and red tape that many states plan to leave the programs in Washington's hands for the time being.

title: Chicago Bank Sets 19% Prime
description: The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company cut its prime lending rate a half-percentage point yesterday, to 19 percent, marking the third consecutive week of declines in the key business lending rate.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There has been a breakdown in the criminal justice system in America.

title: Columbia Receives G ift of $1 Million
description: Columbia University has received a $1 million gift from the Vincent Astor Foundation of New York. The fund will provide financial assistance to 40 needy undergraduate students a year.

title: One-Man Trucks, More or Less
description: While waiting to see President Mobutu one morning during a trip to Zaire, a diplomat we know watched a gardener push a hand mower across the vast lawns along the Congo River. To the gardener's exasperation, the mower kept sticking in the morning dew.

title: Mrs. Truman Remains Stable
description: Bess Truman, widow of former President Harry S. Truman, remained hospitalized in serious but stable condition today after suffering a mild stroke over the weekend, a spokesman at Research Medical Center said.

title: INTERVIEWS FOR LATEST POLL
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Sept. 22 through Sept. 27 with 1,479 adults around the United States. Of that number, 706 were interviewed before President Reagan spoke to the nation on television last Thursday night, and 773 were interviewed after the speech.

title: Mayor of Cleveland Is Favored in Primary
description: George Voinovich, this city's Republican Mayor, will find out tomorrow if voters believe his campaign slogan, ''Promises made, promises kept.''

title: Times Mirror to Fight F.T.C. on Discounts
description: Responding to the relaxing antitrust climate in Washington, the Times Mirror Company, which publishes The Los Angeles Times, has decided to fight a Government complaint about its discounts to big retail advertisers instead of accepting a tentative settlement it negotiated last year.

title: Bridge: The Distribution Can Help A Cause That Seems Lost
description: The City of Oxford in England, and its University, used to be known as the ''Home of Lost Causes,'' largely because it supported the Stuarts at times when the fortunes of that line of kings were at a low ebb.

title: RUSSIANS PLAN DRAMATIC EXPANSION OF EFFORT IN EARTH DRILLING
description: THE Soviet Union, apparently encouraged by the progress of its two deep probes into the earth's crust, has announced an expansion of its continental drilling program calling for some 20 holes up to seven miles deep.

title: WILDLIFE POLICIES ARE CRITICIZED
description: Conservation organizations have urged Interior Secretary James G. Watt to halt what they term the ''overall destruction'' of the nation's wildlife refuge system.

title: Worse Than Skin Deep TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: In ''Effects of Beauty Found to Run Surprisingly Deep'' (Sept. 9) it was indicated that as women have become more economically independent they have placed greater emphasis on a man's physical appearance in forming relationships. This conclusion by Dr. Ellen Berscheid, the researcher interviewed, has been borne out by my own experience. Over the past few years I have gone to a number of singles resorts. At these places, I have obse rved that those men who look like the models who appear in jeans comm ercials seem to fare better with the ladies than the rest of us me re mortals.

title: THE SLUMPING INDUSTRIAL BELT
description: Auto plants and their suppliers are laying off workers once again. Steelmakers are complaining anew about imports. Appliance manufacturers are liquidating inventories. And farm equipment companies are cutting back their expansion programs.

title: SENATORS' JURISDICTION DISPUTE: SPARRING HEATS UP
description: Two Republican Senators - Charles H. Percy of Illinois and John Tower of Texas - struggling over control of foreign assistance, have become embroiled in a classic dispute that, by Senate standards, is no longer gentlemanly.

title: ACCUSED SPY HALTS TRIAL TO PLEAD GUILTY
description: A former Army warrant officer interrupted his Federal trial today and pleaded guilty to conspiring to sell military secrets to the Soviet Union over a 17-year period. In return, the Justice Department dropped three counts of espionage.

title: EARLY RUSH HOUR CAUSES MANHATTAN TRAFFIC JAMS
description: Tens of thousands of motorists were snared in massive traffic jams getting into and out of Manhattan yesterday on what is traditionally one of the heaviest local-travel days of the year.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: J ERRY the Cat walked down the stairs without hesitation, regarded herself briefly in the mirror, then curled into place on an ottoman next to Jane Klein, who has just opened a cozy little salon for small women called Le Piccole at 132 West 88th Street.

title: CAPITAL'S 'SUBWAY' COLLEGE OPENS A CAMPUS
description: The University of the District of Columbia, the capital city's four-year-old land grant college-on-the-subway, staged the formal opening today of a $87.5 million campus on upper Connecticut Avenue, N.W.

title: THEATER: 'INTO THE ACT,' VAUDVILLE BY BOB OST
description: ''EVERYBODY'S GETTIN' Into the Act,'' a revue that is playing at the Actors' Playhouse, is billed as a contemporary vaudeville. Actually, it is a stroll down an overly familiar musical street. As the amiable quartet of performers, wearing hats and smiles, sings and dances the title tune, one remembers not only past revues but also the standard Hollywood conception of New York theatrical nightlife. Despite a facade of being socially and sexually up to date, from prologue to finale this ''Act'' is old hat.

title: Bystanders Attack Moslem Marchers
description: Bystanders throwing rocks and bottles attacked a group of about 100 demonstrators marking the first anniversary of the Iran-Iraq war in midtown Manhattan.

title: PARIS, ONCE KHOMEINI'S HAVEN, HARBORS HIS FOES
description: Three years ago, the center of the Iranian opposition movement was in the Paris suburb of Neauphle-le-Chateau, the headquarters of the exiled Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Coe Assails Drugs
description: Speaking on the last day of the Olympic Congress in Baden-Baden, West Germany, Sebastian Coe of Britain, a spokesman for 30 Olympic athletes who attended the Congress, called in a 20-minute address for a lifelong ban on all competitors who use drugs that are barred by international rules. ''We call also for a life ban on coaches and the so-called doctors who administer this evil,'' said Coe, holder of the world record in the mile run. The International Olympic Committee meets in Baden-Baden this week and is expected to tighten restrictions on drugs and increase penalties for abuses.

title: No Headline
description: Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. signed into law today legislation to protect professional athletes from dishonest agents.

title: Grumman Ads Attack Offer
description: The Grumman Corporation, target of a $450 million takeover offer from the LTV Corporation, said yesterday that it would take to the airwaves with 60-second radio spots to detail its opposition to the bid.

title: CHANGES IN THE OFFING FOR LAW S CHOOL TEST
description: IT was the fall of John Smith's senior year of college, and, since he planned to go on to law school, he made an appointment to spend a morning at the testing center run by his hometown bar association. Upon arriving, he presented the director with a portfolio consisting of some samples of his writing, a videotape of a five-minute speech he had made and documentation of his accomplishments as an amateur pianist and his work as a volunteer tutor in a local elementary school.

title: Letter: On a Reagan Mandate No Easy Cure for Price Supports
description: To the Editor:

title: Griffin Talks End
description: The Excel Energy Corporation and Griffin Petroleum announced that they had ended negotiations about the possible sale to Excel of 60 percent of the common stock outstanding of Griffin. The two companies cited irreconcilable differences in attempting to reach a definitive agreement in a transaction that would have been worth nearly $30 million. Earlier, the companies had agreed in principle to an exchange under which Excel would have acquired as many as 10.2 million shares of Griffin stock at $2.94 a share from certain Griffin officers and directors.

title: Officers Buy Bigelow Sanford From S.& H.
description: A group of senior managers at Bigelow Sanford Inc., the nation's oldest carpet company, has bought the company from the Sperry & Hutchinson Company, Bigelow Sanford officials announced today.

title: 2d Worker Dies In Jersey Blasts
description: The second of three workers burned in three explosions and flash fires at an aluminum powder plant last Thursday died yesterday, according to officials at the company, Atomized Metal Powders in Raritan Township, N.J.

title: MDS HEALTH GROUP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HUNGRY TIGER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: Shr earnings have been restated to reflect a f-for-3 stock split effective July 31

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard LOVE IN BLOOMSBURY. Memories. By Frances Partridge. Illustrated. 244 pages. Little, Brown. $14.95.

title: Kurtz & Tarlow Gains 3 New Jersey Clients
description: Kurtz & Tarlow yesterday announced three new accounts that collectively bill some $5.5 million.

title: U.S. TAPE MENTIONS A SENATOR
description: According to court records disclosed here yesterday, Roy L. Williams, president of the teamsters' union, contended in a conversation taped by investigators that he had an arrangement with an unidentified senator to work against a bill the union opposed.

title: Thyssen Reducing Jobs
description: Thyssen Industrie said today it intended to phase out 1,180 jobs at two steel plants in the Ruhr over the next several years. The company identified the plants as Schalker Verein, where 950 jobs would be eliminated, and Hilden, where 230 would be lost.

title: WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 30, 1981; International
description: President Reagan said developing nations must provide incentives to private enterprise so it can play a much larger role in building their economies. Mr. Reagan, addressing the 36th annual meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in Washington, said that, unless a nation acted to spur its own economic growth, no amount of outside aid would help. (Page A1.)

title: 20 POSTAL RATE VIEWED AS NEAR
description: The Postal Service's board of governors met today and reportedly moved closer to a decision to adopt a new 20-cent postage rate. An announcement is scheduled for tomorrow morning.

title: ANTONIONI'S ' MYSTERY OF OBERWALD'
description: MICHELANGELO Antonioni's ''The Mystery of Oberwald'' (''Il Mistero di Oberwald''), which will be shown at the New York Film Festival today at 9:30 P.M. and tomorrow at 6:15 P.M., is an almost perfect festival film. That is, it's a movie that probably wouldn't last five minutes in front of an audience in control of its wits and with no more than a passing interest in Art for its own sake.

title: Real Estate; Hicksville Site of New Offices
description: cost houses on a vast scale for the middle-class masses then populating Nassau County, Eli Tilles was thinking about shopping centers.

title: HISTORIC STATUS MAY AID LANDLORDS ON EAST SIDE
description: Landlords of buildings in one of the most expensive sections of Manhattan - the area between Fifth and Lexington Avenues from 59th to 79th Street - may soon qualify for substantial income-tax writeoffs.

title: A NEW SLAYING, MORE EXECUTIONS IN IRAN
description: Another Iranian clergyman-politician was assassinated today, and 43 anti-Government guerrillas were put to death by Iran's revolutionary authorities.

title: PEKING IS USING A WRITER'S FAME TO CONTROL ARTS
description: The Communist Party chose the occasion of the centennial of the birth one of China's greatest 20th-century writers, Lu Hsun, to warn the country's writers and artists that it will brook no opposition to its rule and tolerate no criticism of its dictates.

title: SOME REAGAN AIDES PREDICT DELAY ON AWACS
description: The possibility arose today that the Reagan Administration might delay giving formal notification to Congress of a plan to sell Awacs aircraft to Saudi Arabia, so as to allow more time to negotiate with the Saudis on modifications in the terms of the sale.

title: 28% Ineligible in New Jersey In Disability Benefits Check
description: New Jersey reported yesterday that it had found ineligible 363, or 28 percent, of the first 1,294 Federal disability benefit cases it had reviewed for the Social Security Administration in a new Federal economy drive.

title: FOR U.S. '81 OUTLAYS, THERE'S NO TOMORROW
description: Tonight at midnight - poof. Like Cinderella's carriage, the budgets of Federal agencies turn into pumpkins. For today is the last day of the Federal Government's 1981 fiscal year, and funds appropriated for this year but not spent must be returned to the Treasury. An agency can spend them today, but not tomorrow. Thus, civil servants are busily working - right now - to ensure that all of t heir fiscal 1981 monies are spent before midnight. Not only do agencies lose the funds they fail to spend; during the following fis cal year, they are vulnerable to additional cuts, for a Congressional committee is not likely to increase an agency's appropriation - or even to match last year's funding - if the agency failed to spe nd all the monies it was allocated for the previous year.

title: LABORITES' RIGHT WING SCORES GAIN IN BRITAIN
description: The embattled right wing of the Labor Party won an important victory today by taking control of the party's National Executive Committee, which the left wing has used for more than a decade as a power base in its campaign to impose its views on Labor Members of Parliament.

title: Key Rates
description: * Split rate, 19.00 - 19.50** Rates are before any surcharges on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THE CITY SLOWS ITS PACE AS JEWS GREET NEW YEAR
description: Traffic was light, trains and buses were full of seats and the fall air was brilliant with sunshine. Synagogues were crowded and some stores had fewer customers and were easy to shop in. And many other stores and businesses - as well as New York City's public schools - were closed yesterday on the first full day of 5742, the Jewish New Year.

title: CAMPBELL SEEKING A BETTER TOMATO
description: The Campbell Soup Company, one of the world's biggest producers of tomato products, has announced that it will invest $10 million to produce a tomato with better color, flavor and resistance to disease.

title: Alcoa Unit Agrees To Brazil Venture
description: A Brazilian affiliate of the Aluminum Company of America and a subsidiary of Shell Brasil said they have signed the final agreement establishing a consortium to own and operate a $1.2 billion bauxite refining and aluminum smelter plant.The facility, called the Sao Luis Alumina and Aluminum project, is under construction along the northern coast of Brazil.

title: Hong Kong to Restrict Water To 16 Hours a Day Next Week
description: The Government announced today that water would be available only 16 hours a day for Hong Kong's five million residents beginning Oct. 8.

title: Sports of The Times; A Feud the Yankees Would Envy
description: HENNES WEISWEILER says he will never quit. Giorgio Chinaglia says he will not travel with the Cosmos on Saturday if Weisweiler is still the coach.

title: Too Tall a Tale
description: A newspaper report in Toronto that Frank Kush would replace Tom Landry as head coach of the Cowboys next year was met with laughter in Dallas. Landry, the only coach the Cowboys have ever had, is in the last year of his contract, and the report had it that he was ready to move to the Dallas front office.

title: SOUTHERN GOVERNORS DEBATE STANCE ON VOTING RIGHTS ACT
description: Members of the Southern Governors Association, representing those states affected most by the Voting Rights Act, are expected to take a crucial vote here tomorrow expressing their position on extension of the law. The outcome of the sharply divided debate is expected to have influence in Washington, where extension of the law is being considered in Congress.

title: THE END OF A LONG OLYMPIC RACE
description: BADEN, West Germany, Sept. 29 - A Roy al Canadian Mountie in abright red tunic converses in German, and a C anadian Indian dressed in white deerskin and wearing a headdress of eagle feathers asks, ''Wie gehts?'', which means ''How are you?''

title: Coastal to Study Restructuring
description: The Coastal Corporation, a refiner and marketer of oil and natural gas and a producer of coal and chemicals, said it had retained Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc., investment bankers, for consultation and advice on a possible redeployment and restructuring of the company's operations and assets.

title: More Polish Talks on Debt
description: Talks between 21 Western banks and a Polish delegation here on deferring repayment of $2.4 billion of Warsaw's Western debt will go into an unscheduled third day tomorrow, banking sources said today.

title: MET OPERA: VINTAGE '58 'BUTTERFLY'
description: WHEN it was new way back in 1958, and for some years thereafter, the Metropolitan Opera's production of ''Madama Butterfly'' stood as one of the company's glories. Designed by Motohiro Nagasaka and staged by Yoshio Aoyama, it could well have been a study in the incongruous; instead, it succeeded in fusing two seemingly irreconcilable elements: Kabuki theater and Italian verismo opera. It had been so painstakingly prepared, both musically and visually, that even now, 23 years later, lovely details stick in the memory: the luxuriantly dreamlike quality that preceeded Cio-Cio-San's first entrance as the voices floated in from offstage, for instance, or even such minor touches as little fish-shaped pillows.

title: MRS. CODD ATTACKS BARBARO'S UNITY PARTY PETITIONS
description: Continuing a series of lawsuits involving the New York City elections, Mary T. Codd, the Liberal Party mayoral nominee, has challenged Frank J. Barbaro's independent candidacy. A week before Assemblyman Barbaro lost to M ayor Koch in the Democratic primary, he filed 40,050 names to get on the November ballot as an independent. Mrs. Codd attacked the Unity Party petitions for Mr. Barbaro as invalid, contend ing that the courtordered delay of the initially scheduled election had scrambled the state political calendar so as to make th e signatures questionable.

title: BIOTECH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: The company said that as of June 30, 1981 it had assets of $14,881,708 or $4.14 a shr, and assets of $1,538,289 or 97 cents a shr as of June 30, 1980

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
BIDDING WAR IS FEARED FOR RETIREMENT SAVINGS
description: Although it may be too soon to tell how high rates will go, spokesmen for commercial banks and thrift institutions assert that last week's decision to remove the interest-rate ceiling on the retirement savings accounts they offer might set off a bidding war for funds. The decision by Federal banking regulators is drawing fire from sa vings banks and savings and loan associations, which fear that a pr ice war would increase their cost of money. The move, however, has be en generally applauded by commercial banks.

title: 'FIT TO BE UNTIED'
description: ''FIT TO BE UNTIED'' is a messy, shambling Italian documentary about mental patients, intimating (though never successfully demonstrating) that their incarceration is a form of political oppression, and casting little other light on their situation. It was directed by a four-man committee, comprising Silvano Agosti, Marco Bellocchio, Sandro Petraglia and Stefano Rulli, which is to say that it has seams. They show.

title: McCloskey in Senate Race
description: Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. has declared his candidacy in the June Republican primary for the seat held by United States Senator S.I. Hayakawa of California.

title: G.W. Douglas Carver, A Denver Oil Promoter
description: G.W. Douglas Carver, an oil promoter and partner in the Carver Dodge Oil Company of Denver, developer of several Indonesian oil fields, died Monday in his sleep at his home in Woodside, Calif. He was 58 years old.

title: CITY CONCERNED AS REPORTS RISE ON CHILD ABUSE
description: Reports of suspected child abuse and neglect have increased recently in New York City, and the city has expanded its social service efforts to address the family problems involved.

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid Sept 10, 1981; yr-ago shr earnings and shrs outstndg have been adjusted for a3-for-2 stock split paid Feb 1981

title: Pastorini Is Itching To Get in the Game
description: The world along the football sideline is both awesome and terrible, suffused with a bizarre beauty reminiscent of the pomp and pageantry and havoc of plumed armies on scarred battlefields. That is how it was last night in front of the Los Angeles Rams' bench at Soldier Field here in a game against the Bears: the sight and sounds of huge bodies in bright uniforms crashing into each other; players hobbling and groaning off the field under the galaxy of lights; against the muted roar of the crowd, punts booming as if released from cannons. Dante Anthony Pastorini Jr., helmetless, wearing a mustache, ob served all this with a certain wistful air. He would like nothing be tter than to be in the thick of it. Hands in the pockets of his bl ue Rams warm-up jacket and wearing snug yellow football knickers, he was, however, happy to be back in football, if even, for the time be ing, relegated to the sideline.

title: REAGAN ARMS PLAN SAID TO INCLUDE 100 MX MISSILES AND 50 NEW B-1'S
description: Congressional sources reported tonight that President Reagan's new arms program is likely to include deployment of 100 MX mobile missiles in 1,000 silos in the West and the construction of 50 of the new B-1 bombers.

title: UNION AND THE LONDON TIMES REACH PACT TO END SHUTDOWN
description: The shutdown of The Times of London and The Sunday Times ended late tonight when protesting newspaper workers reached agreement with Rupert Murdoch, the papers' owner.

title: STOCKS UP BROADLY IN CALM DAY
description: After Monday's hectic trading and wide price swings, the stock market advance d broadly yesterday, with trans portation and some technology issues posting the biggest gains.

title: STAFF GOES ON RECORD IN ITS MAPS
description: Frequently at 3 A.M., J. Millard Burr sits bolt upright in his bed, lights a cigarette and worries. Lately, he's been worrying about a boundary dispute over the Wakhan Corridor of Afghanistan, where China fears the Soviet Union is attempting to extend its boundaries. At other times, he worries about the Straits of Hormuz or the Gulf of Sidra. Somet imes, while Dr. Burris worrying, other members of the Office of t he Geographer are popping up in their beds across town. They, t oo, are worrying.

title: PRESIDENT GRANT'S ANTICIPATION ON TRADE POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: POLISH CONVENTION CHASTISES WALESA
description: Lech Walesa and other leaders of the Solidarity union were reprimanded by the membership today on the ground that they acted undemocratically in reaching a compromise with the Government on the worker self-management issue.

title: THE KINKS, AT LONG LAST, MAKE IT TO THE GARDEN
description: and-roll institution as the Rolling Stones. They played their first engagements in 1962 in the vicinity of Muswell Hill, the working-class North London neighborhood where they grew up, and like the Rolling Stones, who got together around the same time, they played American rhythm-and-blues material before they began writing and recording their own songs.

title: 4 in Soviet Family Enter, Then Leave U.S. Mission
description: A Soviet couple and their two sons drove past Russian guards into the United States Embassy under cover of a mail truck today, then drove back out after talking to embassy officials. It was the second such incident in about a month.

title: 4 GROUPS URGE U.S. TO OUTLAW ENDRIN
description: Four large environmental groups called on the Federal Government today to ban the pesticide endrin, which was recently found in the flesh of Western game birds and caused Montana to consider canceling the duck hunting season.

title: NEW YORK CHEFS HAVE THEIR SAY
description: AMONG some of the finest Italian chefs of New York there is a considerable variance in opinion over whether their kitchens yield examples of a cucina nuova or new interpretations of historic culinary traditions.

title: NEITHER MUD NOR ICE CAN STOP A POLISH INVASION
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BUSY SWEATERS OF MANY LENGTHS
description: ANYONE casually strolling New York's fashion avenues, Fifth and Madison, is likely to be confronted with a riot of pattern and decoration on sweaters, coupled with the latest long and short lengths. The really bold patterns, drawing their inspiration from primitive designs, are almost always found on long sweaters.

title: Fed Publishes Guide to Rates
description: Have you ever been confused by the difference between simple interest and compound interest? Or by the calculations of yields on a Treasury security or home mortgage?

title: REAGAN TALK TO WORLD BANK AND I.M.F.
description: Following is the text of the address today by President Reagan to the 1981 annual meeting of the board of governors of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund:

title: BRIEFING
description: E VEN as President Reagan was in New Orleans vowing a new emphasis on swift retribution against crime, Administration officials were briefing Congressional specialists on plans for additional cuts in the Justice Department budget.

title: CALIFORNIA PROPERTY TAX CUT STARTING TO HAVE BIG EFFECT
description: After smoldering like a slow fuse for more than three years, Proposition 13 has begun to eat deeply into the services provided by both state and local governments.

title: WHEN ANIMALS MUST SUFFER IN DUBIOUS HUMAN QUESTS
description: To the Editor:

title: STARS LISTED FOR KENNEDY, CBS DRAMA
description: The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts and CBS-TV announced today that their new series of jointly produced plays would includ e such stars as Brian Bedford, Jean Stapleto n, Alan Arkin, Liv Ullmann, Len Cariou and Irene Worth.

title: AMPHITHEATER SOUGHT AT SITE NEAR BATTERY
description: New York City hopes to build a major outdoor performing-arts center on a 14-acre waterfront park at the north end of Battery Park City bounded by views of the Lower Manhattan skyline and the Hudson River. The city has allocated $300,000 for an immediate study to see if the project is feasible.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday incorrectly identified Ira J. Furman. He is deputy director of the Office of Government and Pub- lic Affairs for the National Transpor- tation Safety Board.

title: RECOGNIZING TROUBLE IN TEEN-AGERS
description: Since so much adolescent behavior seems bizarre to adults, it is sometimes difficult to recognize when a teen-ager is really in trouble and in need of help. Here are some signs:

title: T.W.U. Charged With Reneging
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union had reneged on an agreement that would have allowed special bus service to begin today for wheelchair-bound people on one route in Manhattan and two in Brooklyn.

title: U.S. Aid Refused For Sewage Plants
description: New York State's Environmental Conservation Commissioner refused to certify the Coney Island and Owls Head sewage-treatment projects for Federal funds to upgrade them.

title: AMERICAN IN KEY VATICAN JOB
description: Bishop Paul C. Marcinkus, one of the most prominent Ame rican prelates in the Vatican, was made an Archbishop today and nam ed the chief administrator of the Vatican city-state by Pope John Pau l II.

title: News Analysis
description: The first high-level talks between the Reagan Administration and the Soviet leadership have now ended. There was no surprise improvement in relations, but Secretary of State Alexander M.

title: N.A.M. Sees Investing Rise
description: Despite continuing high interest rates, the nation's manufacturers are expected to raise spending on new investments next year because of the stimulus of the Reagan tax program, the head of the National Association of Manufacturers said today.

title: NEW YORK WON'T AID CONTROLLERS, BUT OTHERS WILL
description: New York State has ruled that air traffic controllers who struck last month do not qualify for unemployment compensation, but Connecticut and New Jersey have ruled that they do.

title: Oman-Japan Oil Price Pact
description: Oman has lowered the price of its crude oil shipped to Japan between October and December by $1.50 a barrel, to $34, Government officials said today.

title: THE WHITE HOUSE; INVISIBLE MAN THRUST INTO SPOTLIGHT
description: Senator John Glenn couldn't help noticing the helicopter's THUMP THUMP THUMP overhead as he arrived at the White House last Friday for an urgent meeting with Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser.

title: YANKEES BOW OUT OF 2D-SEASON RACE
description: John Denny did not throw any brushback pitches tonight, Reggie Jackson did not hit any home runs. The only fireworks came from beyond the outfield fence after a home run by Andre Thornton of Cleveland in the second inning. That run, and two in the eighth, enabled the Indians to defeat the Yankees, 3-2, and eliminate them from the American League East race in the second season.

title: SOUTHMARK PROPERTIES reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: B-After extraordinary items of $17,175,111 in the latest yr and $1,094,973 in earlier period

title: HOW NOT TO SETTLE THE AFGHANISTAN ISSUE
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: The Reagan Administration's active support of Thomas H. Kean's campaign for Governor of New Jersey is creating some problems for the Republican candidate in addition to the expected benefits.

title: MAJOR PRICE RESTRAINTS ANNOUNCED BY CHRYSLER
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would increase the price of its 1982 model cars an average of 3.7 percent - about $300 a car - a smaller increase than either of its major domestic competitors or the two leading auto importers have announced.

title: Many Convicts in Spain Are on Hunger Strike
description: Almost 6,000 inmates of Spanish jails, about a quarter of the country's prison population, were on hunger strike today to protest prison conditions, officials said.

title: SANITAS SERVICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $19,000 in qr and $291,000 in the yr...C-Net income after gains from disconti operations of $1,199,000 in qr and $4,094,000 for the yr; the latest qr and yr losses include gain of $243,000 on sale of a division

title: CONFLICT IN LESOTHO
description: The Lesotho Government's attempts to crush support for a popular opposition movement has lead to a cycle of violence in the former British colony. But by blaming tiny Lesotho's troubles on South Africa, which surrounds it, the Lesotho Government has attracted international sympathy and support, and has been able to divert attention from its heavy-handed measures against its citizens.

title: Egyptian Party Urges Palestinian-Israeli Links
description: President Anwar el-Sadat's National Democratic Party urged the Palestinians today to establish a government-in-exile that would exchange diplomatic recognition with Israel.

title: Negotiating Team Set Up For Kaiser Steel Takeover
description: Daniel D. McCarthy, the managing directo r and executive vice president of Blyth Eastman Paine Webber, is one of four investors negotiating t o acquire the Kaiser Steel Corporation. The others are John Stoddard , the former chief financial officer of Blyth Eastman; Daniel K. Lud wig, a land developer and shipowner, and Ghaith Pharoan, head of a Saudi Arabian investment company.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
WHEN ANIMALS MUST SUFFER IN DUBIOUS HUMAN QUESTS
description: To the Editor:

title: 9 States Hold Talks On Waste Disposal
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Representatives from the nine Northeastern states met at the Governor's mansion here to open discussions on how the region will dispose of low-level radioactive wastes, but made no decisions.

title: Predictably, Kearns Moves Up at Xerox
description: The philosopher-king is giving way to the lord-in-waiting at the Xerox Corporation: C. Peter McColough, the company's chief executive since 1968, said yesterday that he would step aside next May and that his longstanding heir apparent, David T. Kearns, would take command.

title: Indians in Massachusetts Settle Claim on 238 Acres
description: Wampanoag Indians have approved a settlement that would return 238 acres of valuable shorefront property on Martha's Vineyard to the 300-member tribe, voting results showed last night.

title: BLACK CAUCUS IN CAPITAL WORKS TO DEVELOP COMMUNAL LEADERSHIP
description: They describe themselves individually as scientists, lawyers, educators and engineers, among other titles. The chairman of the Congressional Black Caucus calls them collectively the ''black leadership family.'' Many of them believe that the diversity of professions and perspectives in their midst is changing the definition of black leadership in America.

title: Economic Scene; A Reagan Plea For Self-Help
description: PRESIDENT Reagan, in his address to the International Monetary Fund and World Bank yesterday, told the developing countries that unless they put their own financial and economic houses in order, no amount of foreign aid would produce progress. However, he assured them that the people of the United States were ''as compassionate and caring as any on earth'' and would remain so.

title: LONG-SHOT OIL LEASE LOTTERY A BONUS IN WYOMING
description: Not a single one of the tracts contains a producing oil well, and on some of them the possibility of finding anything in the ground is zero.

title: EATING RAW FISH: THE DANGERS
description: THE reported dangers of illness brought on by eating raw fish and meat often cause fear and confusion in the minds of those who enjoy such foods, either for their esthetic or nutritional benefits.

title: Text of address, page 44.
description: President Reagan told developing nations today that they must provide incentives to private enterprise so it can play a much larger role in building up their economies.

title: JUST WAISTING AWAY
description: President Reagan made it clear from the start that Americans would have to tighten their belts and make sacrifices, and I approved. When the mass-transit subsidy was cut, however, I was startled because it meant shelling out 25 percent more for a bus ride.

title: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Including $690,000 tax credit...C-Net loss

title: THE PRESIDENT SPEAKS
description: Over the years, President Reagan has honed the one-liner to a sharp political edge. Some samples of his pith and wit.

title: News Analysis
description: President Reagan's tough anticrime speech yesterday touched a responsive chord in Congress at a time of great public concern about crime, but legal experts, including the Administration's own crime advisory group, agree that his proposals would do little, if anything, to make the streets safer.

title: GAMMA RAYS' BURST HINTS SPACE CATASROPHE
description: Examination of a backlog of recordings made in earth orbit four years ago by the first High Energy Astronomy Observatory has revealed a burst of gamma rays indicating a catastrophic event far out in space, though how far and in what direction remain unknown. The burst was followed by a half minute of 4.2-second reverberations, suggesting its probable association with a superdense neutron star rotating at that rate.

title: BRIDGE: Overtricks May Be Risked But Not in a Rubber Game
description: Games of bridge fall into two categories. One, the basic form of the game, includes rubber bridge and all contests scroed by international match points. In this the overtrick is of relatively little importance, although the player should obviously gather it in if he can do so safely.

title: Coach's Ouster Asked
description: School Superintendent Dick Koeppe recommended last night that the school board dismiss Kenneth Milano, Overland High School's football coach, who was suspended a week ago after having been accused of allowing the beating of a player by teammates. The board heard a report of Mr. Koeppe's investigation into the incident in a closed session last night and then said it would rule on the coach's future in about two weeks.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: FOR Manhattanite Ed Spitzer, it started one day when he began talking back to the television set. ''It was a commercial for a pain-reliever, and the announcer said, commandingly, 'Think about this.' Well, I found myself saying to myself: 'I will not think about this. Not on your life. No, sir. I will not think about it if it's the last product on earth. In fact, I can't even remember what product I'm supposed to think about.''

title: SIKH SEPARATISTS HIJACK INDIAN JETLINER TO PAKISTAN
description: An Indian Airlines plane carrying 111 passengers and a crew of six was hijacked yesterday by five knife-wielding advocates of a separate Sikh homeland. They forced the pilot to fly to Pakistan, where security forces captured them this morning and freed the 45 hostages remaining aboard unharmed.

title: Teltscher Wins Final
description: Eliot Teltscher, employing his seldom-used lob shot, defeated Brian Teacher last night, 6-3, 7-6 (7-4), in the final of the Transamerica Open tennis tournament. In the doubles final, the team of Peter Fleming and John McEnroe defeated Mark Edmondson and Sherwood Stewart, 7-6 (10-8), 6-4, to take its fourth consecutive Transamerica title.

title: DOUGHERTY BROS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Shr earnings and shrs outstndg have been restated to give effect to a 10 percent stock divd on Nov 14, 1980

title: 'SALUTE TO CHANO POZO,' PIONEER OF CUBAN MUSIC
description: IN 1947, Dizzy Gillespie met Chano Pozo, a Cuban conga drummer who had played mostly for Afro-Cuban religious rituals before he left his native Havana to settle in New York. Mr. Pozo's concert debut as a soloist with Mr. Gillespie's big band, which took place that year, was a milestone in the continuing fusion of Cuban music with North American jazz and pop. The two musicians went on to compose several jazz standards together, most notably ''Manteca.'' Mr. Pozo would sing the melodies and rhythms he wanted, and Mr. Gillespie would sketch in harmonies while an arranger wrote down their musical dialogues.

title: Accounts
description: * Shasta Beverages Inc., Hayward, Calif., to Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago.

title: UNIVAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Typhoon Bypasses Taiwan
description: The central weather bureau said today that Typhoon Elsie, with winds of 150 miles per hour, was bypassing Taiwan and heading for Okinawa. The typhoon, which had earlier been expected to hit Taiwan, changed course and was 550 miles southeast of Okinawa late today, forecasters said.

title: RHODES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Anaconda Industries has named presidents at five operating units: Marlan T. Boultinghouse, at Anaconda American Brass; John P. Foss, Centrifugal Inc.; Richard J. Rothen, General Casting; Gerald A. Scutt, Anaconda Metal Hose, and Harold M. Wenzel, Anaconda Magnet Wire.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: MARGIE had never been a talkative child, but as she entered adolescence she became almost silent, at least at home. Days would go by when she said only two or three short sentences to her mother and not much more to her father. Except for meals and piano practice, she spent nearly all her time at home in her room, slamming the door each time she entered it.

title: CARROLS DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: B-Including $493,000 tax credit...C-After $24,109 loss from discontinued operations and $672,000 tax credit

title: Journalism Dean Plans To Leave Missouri U.
description: Roy M. Fisher, the dean of the University of Missouri School of Journalism since 1971, announced today he would leave the post next August to concentrate on ''writing and teaching in the field of national communications.''

title: Tire Workers Vote Pay Cut
description: Workers for two major tire companies have approved contract changes and wage concessions to save jobs and enable a plant expansion.

title: FAMILIES SHIFT HOMES IN AN INFLAMED ULSTER
description: Bridget Eccles, a Roman Catholic bricklayer's wife, always thought there would be no risk in living among Protestants. But she does not think that anymore.

title: MOSCOW SAYS THE PENTAGON BOOKLET IS UNBALANCED
description: The Soviet Union said today that a Pentagon booklet on Soviet military might was designed to ''confuse, intimidate and misinform public opinion in the West'' about the relative strengths of Soviet and Western forces.

title: Ivy Curb Criticized
description: Bob Blackman of Cornell, in his 22d season as an Ivy League football coach, strongly criticized the league's refusal to conduct spring practice, just three days after seven of the eight Ivy teams were beaten by nonleague squads that hold spring practice. ''The excuse used that the Ivy League has never done it is ridiculous,'' said Blackman, who coached at Dartmouth from 1955 through 1970 and returned to the league in 1976. ''The Ivy League didn't have coeducational student bodies when I started in the league.''

title: ALBERT KING SITS AND WONDERS
description: On one end of the court at the Ramapo College gymna sium, Larry Brown, the new coach of the New Jersey Nets,ran half the 12 players in uniform through the fundamental pick-androll offensive move. At the other end, his assistant, Bill Blair, did th e same with the rest of the group on the first day of the rookie ca mp.

title: Three Unborn Calves Sold as Transplants
description: Three unb orn calves produced through embryo transplants have brought an av erage of $4,100 each at a Holstein sale here, according to an auction eer, Paul George.

title: Greed Lures Visitors to Mae West's House
description: The house in Van Nuys, Calif, is vacant these days, but according to Charlotte Gottenbos, who lives across the street, it has been receiving a steady stream of visitors.

title: INSURANCE POOL SEEKS TO SPLIT $52 MILLION AMONG MEMBERS
description: A state-sponsored fire insurance pool for high-risk areas, which has claimed deficits it says requires it to charge rates 20 to 40 percent above those for ordinary risks, has moved to distribute $52,235,127 in assets to 317 member companies.

title: HANGING POT RACKS
description: THE only error I admit to in my kitchen is the height of my pot racks, which are 83 inches off the floor. They should have been a trifle higher. I knew that for sure when the chef, Roger Fessaguet, who is about two inches taller than I am, came to visit and repeatedly banged his head into my pots.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: In the frail ligh t of morning, a young man stood at the corner of Broad and Wal l Streets, in front of the Bankers Trust building and across from t he New York Stock Exchange, and preached in a sonorous voice, half s tatement, half harangue. It was 9 A.M. yesterday, and the market th e day before had back-flipped from intimations of disaster into one of its finest trading days this year; the Exchange would open in an hour.

title: Market Place; Growth Spurt Seen for I.B.M.
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation, the most impressive growth stock of the 1950's and 1960's, has marked time for more than a decade. But a leap upward may be on the way.

title: Bossy Scores 2 Goals As Islanders Top Sabres
description: The New York Islanders beat the Buffalo Sabres, 6-5, at Nassau Coliseum tonight and made their exhibition record four victories in seven games.

title: EUROPEANS IN PACT ON SOVIET GAS
description: A joint venture of West German and French companies yesterday signed the first contracts to supply compressor stations for a gas pipeline in the Soviet Union, in what is expected to be the biggest East-West trade deal ever, it was disclosed today.

title: On the Fight Beat
description: Mike Jones, his co-manager, says Howard Davis was definitely affected by Sugar Ray Leonard's $11 million payday for his bout with Thomas Hearns. But Jones adds that Davis, Leonard's 1976 Olympic teammate and gold medal boxing champion, had ''renewed spirit'' even before that Sept. 16 bonanza.

title: NUCLEAR FOES SAY NEW FLAW SHOWS PERIL OF DIABLO PLANT
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company has delayed indefinitely the startup of its Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant after finding that the structure of one of its cooling systems does not conform to the approved design.

title: METS' FALCONE HALTS PHILS, 7-0
description: Pete Falcone, one of the mysteries of the Mets, baffled somebody besides his teammates tonight when he pitched the Mets to a 7-0 victory over the Philadelp hia Phillies.

title: U.S. Accuses 4 of Bribery
description: A Federal grand jury has charged a freight forwarding concern and two of its executives with paying $1,049,000 in bribes to two former Raytheon Corporation executives to win a contract to ship prefabricated homes to Saudi Arabia.

title: Change at ICI Americas
description: An engineer will replace a lawyer in the front office of ICI Americas, the Wilmington, Del., subsidiary of Britain's Imperial Chemical Industries. Harry Corless, 52 years old, becomes chairman and chief executive on April 1, replacing Robert P. Barnett, 60.

title: ASHLAND: NEW MAN, OLD WOES
description: For Ashland Oil Inc., the year has been a tough one. Earnings have plummented because of the company's slumping refinery operations. Wall Street analysts have turned investors away from what they consider an inflated stock price. And Standard & Poor's and Moody's have lowered the company's bond ratings.

title: 3 Guilty in Boatlift Case
description: A man and two women have pleaded guilty to violating the Trading With the Enemy Act after bringing undocumented aliens to the United States from Cuba by sea last year. Assistant United States Attorney Robert Rosenberg said Raul Eduardo Gonzalez, Nelia Adelfa Gonzalez and Sandra Franco pleaded guilty Friday to violating the act. They allegedly made repeated trips to Cuba to transport refugees for commercial gain and had dealings with Cuban officials.

title: LEGISLATURE GETS CHANCE IN OCTOBER TO ALTER M.T.A. AID
description: The New York State Legislature will meet next month in an unusual session that is expected to consider changes in at least two of the five taxes it passed less than three months ago to assist the financially troubled Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: STAGE: NEW CAST AT HELM OF 'PIRATES OF PENZANCE'
description: A LOT has happened to Joseph Papp's production of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' since it first sailed triumphantly into Central Park two summers ago. In January, this musical moved to Broadway's most problematic theater, the Uris, and survived the difficult sea change in such fine style that it ultimately received the Tony Award as the season's best revival. Last summer, ''Pirates'' vacated the Uris to make room for ''My Fair Lady'' -only to land in Broadway's second most antiseptic house, the Minskoff. Just before and after the latest move, four new principal performers joined the cast.

title: Amtrak Facing New Strugg le To Survive With Reagan C uts
description: Amtrak, which survived an earlier effort by President Reagan to kill most of its passenger service, now finds itself in an even greater battle for survival with the Administration.

title: Pratt & Whitney To Lay Off 1,500
description: Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group announced it would lay off about 1,500 employees because of continuing low demand for its products by the world's commercial airlines.

title: AROUND THE NATION ; Court Orders Abortion For a Rape Victim, 12
description: A 12-year-old girl, who became pregnant after being raped by three teen-agers, will be given a courtordered abortion to save her life despite the religious protests of her mother.

title: SALVADORAN LEADER RULES OUT TALKS UNLESS REBELS DISARM
description: President Jose Napoleon Duarte of El Salvador implicitly rebu ked France and Mexico today and firmly ruled out tal ks with armed leftist guerrillas.

title: Medical Association Sells Shares of Tobacco Stock
description: The American Medical Association, a longtime crus ader against smoking, has rid itself of $1.4 million of ''embarrassin g'' stock in tobacco companies, a spokesman said today.

title: Scott Lancaster Moves Offices to Connecticut
description: Scott Lancaster Jackman Mills Atha Inc., has transferred its headquarters from Century City in Los Angeles, to Westport, Conn., without losing a name.

title: Pennzoil to Supply Naphtha to Kodak
description: The Pennzoil Company has signed a 10-year, $1 billion agreement to supply an Eastman Kodak plant with naphtha to be refined into plastics and chemical intermediates, officials of the two companies said.

title: MARY MARTIN'S NEWEST ROLE
description: IT is difficult to think of Mary Martin as being old. Even though she is 67, with a pouf of white hair and a number of uncamouflaged wrinkles, she will probably always be remembered as Peter Pan because of her long association with that youthful role.

title: Poisoning the Peaceful Atom
description: For a generation the peaceful atom has struggled, like a reformed prisoner, to live cleanly, on the sunny side of the street, shunning any association with its dark, brooding cousin, the bomb. This effort to go straight has been largely successful, in part because of American efforts. So it is jolting now to hear the Secretary of Energy propose something that sounds like a parole violation.

title: 2 CALLS TO ACTRESS TAPED BY HINCKLEY
description: Jodie Foster, who previously denied talking to John W. Hinckley Jr., had two telephone conversations with the man accused of shooting President Reagan, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: RE-CREATING THE ERA OF VICTRORIAN SOCIETY
description: THE Rolling Stones threw Philadelphia into a tizzy last weekend. The same could not be said of the Victorian Society in America. There were occasional smiles and applause as women in Victorian costume walked through lobbies or stood in the street in front of trolley cars and hansom cabs, but a four-day symposium, especially on a subject as esoteric as ''Dining and Drinking in the 19th Century,'' which drew some 325 Victorian enthusiasts, was something the city could absorb without a ripple.

title: TIGERS TRIUMPH TO REGAIN FIRST
description: Lou Whitaker hit a two-run single, and the pinch hitter Rick Leach had a three-run triple as the Tigers rallied for two five-run innings last night and defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 14-0. The Tigers, who lost and fell from first place Monday night, moved back into the lead by a half-game over the Milwaukee Brewers in the American League East's second-half race.

title: EDWARD CHARLES SCULLY
description: Edward Charles Scully, an editor, teacher and writer on photography, died Saturday at Chilton Memorial Hospital, Pompton Plains, N.J., after a brief illness. He was 62 years old and lived in Oakland, N.J.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Castle & Cooke Inc. said it had entered into an agreement with Goldman Sachs & Co. under which Goldman may exchange at least $4 million and as much as $13 million total principal amount of Castle & Cooke's 8 1/2 percent debentures outstanding due 1997 for newly issued shares of Castle & Cooke's common stock.

title: A HELPFUL PASTRY COOKBOOK
description: There is one aspect of the professional kitchen of which the average restaurant patron se ems little aware. Many a distinguished chef can turn out the finest, most silken sauces, the most succulent and toothsome baro ns of beef, the most irresistible souffles of lobster, crab and fo ie gras, and yet, if asked to produce one fantasy or another in pa stry, he or she might well be reduced to quivering aspic. That is n ot to say that the greatest or most ordinary chefs have not obse rved the basic techniques for making vol-au-vents, Paris-Bre sts and paves au citron.It is simply that pastry making in general is consigned in the finestkitchen to a specialist known as the chef pat issier.

title: PACIFIC REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
IS THERE A NEW ITALIAN CUISINE
description: NO one denies that there has been a revolution in French food: It is less rich, with fresh ingredie nts put toge ther in new and different ways. In the last five years heavy sauces have become lightand classics such as canard a l'orange and be ef Wellington have givenway to rare duck breasts and medallions of be ef with cranberries. Since New Yorkers probably eat as much Italia n food as French, are they finding similar changes in Italian cooki ng?

title: Vicuna and Other No-No Gifts to Go on Block
description: During his tenure as Secretary of State, Henry A. Kissinger accepted beer steins, cigar boxes, coffee sets, Gucci handbags, and many other gifts from foreign governments, four of which presented him with busts of himself.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We who live in free market societies believe that growth, prosperity, and ultimately human fulfillment, are created from the bottom up, not the government down.'' - President Reagan. (D22:3.)

title: Reynolds Awards Building Contract
description: The Morrison-Knudsen Company said it had received a $1 billion contract from the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company to manage a 10-year construction program at the company's cigarette manufacturing facilities in Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: LEGAL AID LAWYERS TO VOTE ON A CONTRACT PROPOSAL
description: Legal Aid Society lawyers will vote tomorrow on whether to follow the recommendation of their union leaders to reject a proposed collective bargaining contract and strike.

title: Kennedy Campaign Payment For Excess Spending Urged
description: A staff audit for the Federal Election Commission recommended yesterday that Senator Edward M. Kennedy's 1980 Presidential campaign be ordered to repay $238,000 for exceeding legal spending limits in New Hampshire and Iowa.

title: Oxford's Net Doubles
description: Oxford Industries, an apparel maker, said today that earnings doubled in the first quarter, ended Aug. 28, to $3.7 million, or $1.29 a share, from $1.7 million, or 54 cents, a year earlier.

title: U.S. AIDES STUDYING PAKISTANI REACTOR
description: Administration arms control and intelligence officials and international atomic energy inspectors are investigating what they describe as ''suspicious'' activities at Pakistan's nuclear reactor, which is capable of producing plutonium for atomic weapons.

title: BOGNER, PRODUCER OF SKI WEAR, PLODDING ALONG
description: This used to be the time of year when people at Willy Bogner, the West German clothing manufacturer, eagerly looked for an early salmon run or other signs of a long, snowy winter. Bogner had made its fortune by revolutionizing ski clothing. It took skiers out of their fluffy sweaters and baggy knickers and put them into sleek wedge-shaped pants and trim anoraks.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average cost of feeding a family of four went up by 23 cents to $106.27 during the two-week period that ended Friday. According to the Department of Consumer Affairs market basket survey, shoppers paid $5.79 more for food than they did in the corresponding period last year.

title: PRESLEY'S DOCTOR ON TRIAL OVER PRESCRIPTIONS
description: Elvis Presley's doctor, who is accused of overprescribing thousands of pills to the late entertainer and others, goes on trial tomorrow in a case that could shed light on Mr. Presley's death four years ago.

title: PENNSYLVANIA EXONERATES IN BOYLE TRIAL
description: The Pennsylvania Attorney General's office today exonerated Richard A. Sprague of Philadelphia of any wrongdoing in his prosecution of W.A. Boyle, former president of the United Mine Workers.

title: U. S. Criticized in U. N.  On Its Anti-Soviet Aim
description: The nations calling themselves nonaligned today criticized the United States for its proposed strategic consensus against Soviet intervention in the Middle East.

title: Sunbeam Sues IC Industries
description: The Sunbeam Corporation has filed suit in Federal District Court seeking to block a $232 million takeover by IC Industries on grounds the bid raises ''serious questions under the Federal antitrust and securities laws.''

title: The U.N. Today; Sept. 30, 1981; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: B.B.D.O. Awards Executives New Titles
description: Richard B. White, a 51-year-old career man at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, where he is an executive vice president and board member, has been given the title of chairman of the executive committee.

title: Federal Agency Renamed
description: President Reagan has ordered the International Communications Agency's twin designations of 25 years restored: the headquarters in Washington as the United States Information Agency and in offices overseas as the United States Information Service.

title: 3 Deny Stabbing Ray
description: Three inmates of the Brushy Mountain State Penitentiary, all members of a black militant group, pleaded not guilty Monday in the stabbing of James Earl Ray, convicted in 1968 of assassinating the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The men entered the pleas individually in a brief hearing before Judge William S. Russell, who set trial for Nov. 23. The 53-year-old assassin, now being held in a state prison in Nashville, was stabbed 22 times on June 4 as he researched his case in the prison library.

title: MARKETS OVERSEAS REBOUND FROM PREVIOUS DAY'S SLUMP
description: Investors looking for bargains among stocks oversold in yesterday's dramatic plunge on many of the world's stock exchanges fueled a reversal today. Record comebacks on the London and Tokyo exchanges more than recouped the losses of Monday.

title: INTERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: 1981 results include operations of Broyhill Furniture Industries which was acquired Dec 1, 1980

title: Mexican Oil for Shell
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said today that a subsidiary, the Shell International Trading Company, had signed a contract with Petroleos Mexicanos to buy 50,000 barrels a day of crude oil, starting in October, the first oil the group has bought from Mexico. An announcement said Shell and Pemex, the Mexican state energy group, planned to discuss increasing the volume to 100,000 barrels daily during 1982 and to examine the scope for further increases in subsequent years.

title: ND RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-Net loss; the company said fourth qtr results were achieved primarily through recognition of gain on the sale of a 50 percent interest in the assets of one of its coal loading facilities which helped offset the effects of the 10 week coal miners' strike

title: BUSINESS-CHURCH ACCORD ON SOUTH AFRICA IS ELUSIVE
description: Church representatives and executives whose companies do business in South Africa have again failed in their most recent of a series of meetings to reach agreement on what to do when ethics conflict with financial considerations.

title: GOOFY AND FRIENDS SLIP OUT TO AIR COMPLAINTS
description: Some of the people who play the beloved characters at Disney World here - Goofy, Winnie the Pooh, Pluto and whatnot - are caught in a midlife career crisis, so to speak. Projecting themselves in roles designed by Disney to be played by young people, who in the best of worlds would have a good time for a couple of years being, say, Mickey Mouse, and then move on to a real job, they find themselves in love with attached to the fantasy and wishing to prolong it, but feeling abused by their employer. stuck in the fantasy.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Agency Rent-A-Car Inc. said it had increased its stake in the Spencer Companies to 679,855 shares, or 35.9 percent, by buying 20,600 shares on the American Stock Exchange between Sept. 21 and Sept. 24 at prices ranging from $12 a share to $15 a share.

title: Advertising; Magazines That Hit The Mark
description: THERE'S a year-old quarterly magazine with 4.6 million circulation that you probably never heard of. However, now that it's looking for national advertising you are sure to.

title: REAGAN ORDERS ALIENS STOPPED ON THE HIGH SEA
description: President Reagan issued an executive order today directing the Coast Guard for the first time to intercept and turn around ships on the high seas that are suspected of carrying illegal immigrants.

title: Index; International
description: China writers and artists told that criticism not to be tolerated A2 U.S. prelate named head of Vati- can administration A3 Arou nd the World A5 Plot suspects in Spain seek to im- plicate King A8 Sikhs hijack Indian jetliner to Pakistan A7 Fearful families shift homes in in- flamed Ulster A11 Reagan may delay formally noti- fying Congress on Awacs sale A15 Government/Politics Tax increase voted by 30 states is highest in 10 years A24 Barbaro Unity Party petitions for Mayor face court test B3 Washington Talk Briefing A26 State Department map makers draw the lines for the record A26 As Awacs go, so does Reagan's national security adviser A26 General Around the Nation A20 Pennsylvania exonerates prose- cutor in Boyle murder trial A20 Hinckley conversations with Jodie Foster disclosed A22 The Region B2 Legal Aid Society lawyers are to vote on a contract proposal B4 The City B5 Health/Science Burst of gamma rays hints cata- strophic space event A23 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of the Jewish New Year, al- ternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today. Other parking rules remain in effect. Living Section Food Is there a new Italian cuisine? C1

title: Cheap Talk About Crime
description: The new Federal crime strategy, which President Reagan outlined in a speech Monday, relies heavily on the jawbone. Mr. Reagan pledged that he would ''speak out'' on the subject and treated his audience of police chiefs to powerful blasts of law-and-order oratory. Crime is ''an American epidemic,'' he said. ''There has been a breakdown in the criminal justice system in America ... . T he people are sickened and outraged ....''

title: Addendum
description: * Perri Debes Looney & Crane is a new Rochester advertising agency.

title: Weinberger Criticized On Use of U.S. Planes
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger used military aircraft on trips to the summer resort of Bar Harbor, Me., at least five times over the summer, a critic of the Pentagon has charged.

title: A NEW LIFE MAY NOW BEGIN FOR CARIL ANN FUGATE
description: Twenty-three years ago the name of Caril Ann Fugate came to the shocked attention of the nation.
