Miss Fugate, then a 14-year-old junior high school student in Lincoln, Neb., accompanied Charles Starkweather, 19, on an interstate murder spree in which 10 persons, including Miss Fugate's mother and sister, were killed.

title: San Francisco Agency Takes D.D.B.'s Name
description: Schuller, Briggs & Mitchell, San Francisco, a Doyle Dane Bernbach subsidiary for two years, has taken its parent's name, and has gotten a new president and chief operating officer, Jerry Gibbons.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BLUES IN THE NIGHT

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: B-After $983,500 extraordinary charge for the qr and yr $411,300 net loss for the yr from discontinued operations and $2.6 million net loss for the yr on the disposal of discontinued operations...C-After net losses from discontinued operations of $137,700 for the qr and $309,900 for the yr... D-Net income

title: Massey-Ferguson Plant Shutdowns
description: Massey-Ferguson Inc. said it would suspend production at its Detroit tractor division during the first two weeks of November, idling 550 of its 700 hourly workers.

title: Inc. Magazine Names Randolph Publisher
description: C.C. Randolph 3d, known in the magazine publishing world as Jim, has surfaced in Boston Harbor as publisher of Inc., the highly successful, two-and-a-half-year-old magazine for small business.

title: Careers; The Race For Parity In Salaries
description: WITHIN corporations it may be unmentionable, but there is a problem that is making many company officials and their newer employes worry out loud. It is called salary compression.

title: RANGERS WIN, 6-1 AS ARENA OPENS
description: The Rangers defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 6-1, tonight in the first athletic event at the new Brendan Byrne Meadowlands Arena, which was named for the Governor, opened with a rock concert by Bruce Springsteen and recently housed the Disney on Ice show.

title: Permit Approved For Acid Dumping
description: A permit to dump 177,000 tons of hydrochloric acid in the Atlantic Ocean off New Jersey has been tentatively approved for the Allied Corporation, according to the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.

title: JIMMY CARTER AT 57
description: Jimmy Carter slipped out of Washington last Jan. 20 on Inauguration Day and has been very quiet ever since, but one wonders on his 57th birthday, which is tomorrow, what he will do with the rest of his life.

title: Conference Called On School Aid Cut
description: City and Board of Education officials will meet Friday to decide how to fight a cut in state aid that might be imposed because of new immunization rules, according to a spokesman for the City Council President, Carol Bellamy.

title: LLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Finnish Leader's Health Is Said to Worsen
description: The health of President Urho Kekkonen, who is on sick leave until Oct. 10, has worsened further, a medical bulletin said today.

title: Litton Must Pay Law Fees
description: Litton Systems was told yesterday that it would have to pay its own legal fees for its antitrust action against the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation even though it won the suit and $277 million in damages.

title: JOHN G. ENDERLIN
description: John G. Enderlin, retired secretary and treasurer of the former Delaware, Lackawanna & Western Railroad, died Monday at the Montclair Nursing Home in Glen Cove, L. I..

title: INQUIRY BOLSTERED ON EX-C.I.A. AGENTS
description: The Justice Department, criticized as being insufficiently aggressive in its investigation of two former American intelligence agents charged with illegally shipping explosives to Libya, has appointed a senior attorney to coordinate the inquiry and has mobilized agents to intensify it.

title: GIANTS AQUIRE ROB CARPENTER
description: The Giants, who wanted him last spring, traded yesterday for Rob Carpenter, a versatile 230-pound running back who became available partly becaus e of the Jets.

title: JAYNE WARD
description: Jayne Ward, director of Channel 13's office of viewer services, died of a circulatory ailment at Roosevelt Hospital on Monday.

title: BID FOR COLT IS OPPOSED BY HUNTS
description: The Penn Central Corporation disclosed yesterday that the Hunt brothers of Texas and two former executives of a Penn Central subsidiary had joined forces to oppose its pending $1.4 billion purchase of Colt Industries.

title: Husky Oil Scraps Shell Assets Deal
description: Husky Oil Ltd., of Calgary, Alberta, announced today that it had decided not to proceed with an agreement under which it was to have acquired certain Canadian assets of Shell Explorer Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of the Shell Oil Company, of Houston, for $430 million in Canadian currency.

title: Federal Express Sets Jet Purchases
description: The Federal Express Corporation said it had signed a contract with the Boeing Commercial Airplane Company to buy 15 new jetliners for more than $300 million. The first of the 727-200F planes will be delivered to the small-package airline in July 1983 and continue on a one-a-m onth basis . Federal Express plans to use 10 of the planes itself and lease the other five to other carriers.

title: MAYOR IN OHIO LEADS IN PRIMARY
description: By a ratio of more than two to one, Mayor George V. Voinovich outpolled his main opponent in the nonpartisan mayoral primary today, setting the stage for a runoff between the two on Nov. 3.

title: A Good Place for a Hamilton Party, After All
description: Aaron Burr's house might seem an unlikely site for a party celebrating a book about Alexander Hamilton, but, then, Robert A. Hendrickson's biography is entitled ''The Rise and Fall of Alexander Hamilton,'' and no one had more to do with the latter than Burr.

title: TAX RISES VOTED BY 30 STATES TERMED LARGEST IN 10 YEARS
description: Thirty state legislatures have already moved to rais e taxes a total of $2.5 billion this year, the highest annual increa se since 1971, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Conrail Workers to Defer Raises to Help the Line
description: Conrail workers have agreed to defer raises of up to 12 percent to help keep the struggling railroad running, union officials say.

title: Reagan Is Said to Reconsider 12% Cut in Revenue Sharing
description: President Reagan told county officials today that he would reconsider his proposal to include local revenue sharing in a 12 percent across-the-board reduction in Federal programs, a county official said at a news conference after a White House meeting with the President.

title: FROM COAST INDIANS, A SMOKED SALMON
description: Smoked Salmon usually comes in thin, rowy, delicately flavored slices arrayed on a platter or piled on a bagel. But now it's time to expand that definition. New, different types of smoked salmon have become availabe in New York shop.

title: PLOT LAWYERS CITE JUAN CARLOS
description: Defense lawyers for some of the officers accused of plotting the unsuccessful military coup in February have called on King Juan Carlos to testify in the officers' court-martial, claiming that he was in favor of the coup.

title: A RULE ON EVIDENCE READY FOR REFORM
description: To the Editor:

title: THE SUPERMARKET COUPON WAR
description: A few weeks ago, when the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company placed the ''Price and Quality'' label on its generics line in the metropolitan area, the troubled supermarket chain felt that the label was not enough -that the lure of a coupon was needed.

title: Q & A
description: Q. On a recent visit to Georgia, I was given a jar of Scuppernong ketchup, a relish made with grapes and spices. Can the Scuppernong grape be found in the North?

title: TV: 'TRAVIATA' AND 'THE MANSIONS'
description: TONIGHT'S ''Live From the Met'' presentation on WNET-TV at 8 o'clock is not live. This performance of Verdi's ''La Traviata'' was taped at a Metropolitan Opera matinee on March 28, a fact carefully noted several times during the broadcast by Peter Allen, the always capable and considerate announcer. Purist proponents of live ''event'' television will undoubtedly argue that the ''live on tape'' version does not quite measure up to the real simultaneous thing. The rest of us can simply enjoy.

title: FROM NIXON AIDE TO KURALT'S CO-ANCHOR
description: Tall, blond and undeniably glamorous, Diane Sawyer is 35 years old and has been at CBS News two years. During the previous eight, she had worked for Richard M. Nixon, first in the White House Press Office during his second Presidential term and then in San Clemente, Calif., assisting in the writing of his memoirs.

title: SEARS UNIT CREDIT LINE
description: The Sears, Roebuck Acceptance Corporation, the financing arm of Sears, Roebuck & Company, announced yesterday that it had arranged a $2 billion eight-year credit line from a group of foreign and domestic banks. The new agreement, for which the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company is agent, gives Sears the option of using the credit line as a backup for additional sales of commercial paper, or for outright borrowings.

title: Interest Rates Are Not the Problem
description: Populist Democrats used to be the ones who considered high interest rates to be the root of all evil; today it's a conservative Republican President. And when he and his advisers are not blaming the ''Chicken Littles'' on Wall Street for their refusal to believe in his program, they attack the Federal Reserve Board for keeping interest rates t oo high.

title: 1. Gourd Bags
description: Even in this season of unusual accessories, the designs of Margarita Popoza stand out. The California artist uses gourds as the base for the fascinating handbags and gigantic bracelets she makes. The gourds start out as ordinary squashes from which the insides are scooped out, leaving only the skin. They are dried, cut and polished. Then Miss Popoza applies gold leaf to the inside and eight to 10 coats of lacquer are applied in lovely iridescent effects. The bag is round, with a hinged top, a pearly clasp and a silk cord handle; the cuff bracelet is sliced from a smaller gourd. The bag ($120) and the bracelet ($34) can be special-ordered from the Sharon Bovaird Boutique, 927 Madison Avenue (73d Street).

title: Interest Rates Move Higher; 13 7/8% Bonds At New Low
description: Interest rates moved higher in listless trading yesterday as investors continued to shun the long-term bond market. By late in the day, the Treasury's 13 7/8 percent bonds due 2011 were offered at 91 14/32, down more than 1 1/4 points, to yield 15.18 percent. It was the lowest closing price ever for this bellwether Treasury issue.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Shr earnings and shrs outstndg have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in Apr

title: SENATE BACKS $1 TRILLION DEBT CEILING
description: The Republican-dominated Senate voted tonight by 64 to 34 to raise the Government's borrowing authority to more than $1 trillion for the first time in history.

title: MORRISON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: The 1980 revs restated

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ALTHOUGH I was born and spent my formative years in France, I have learned a good deal about European food that I did not know until I came to America. I have said before that I was largely unfamiliar with the many varieties of pasta known for generations in Italy until I came here. I have come to appreciate Greek and Spanish and Turkish food that was not known in my home region of Burgundy and which I did not find in Paris during my appren ticeship there.

title: Doctor Sentenced In Medicaid Case
description: A Manhattan physician has been sentenced to six months in jail and fined $12,500 for billing Medicaid more than $5,000 for tests that were never performed, according to the New Yo rk State Attorney General's office.

title: CITY OPERA: THE CONFLICTS OF 'I PURITANI'
description: IN Bellini's ''I Puritani,'' the battles of England's civil war in the 1650's are no mere problem of state. They resonate with family schisms, splits between lovers and the deranged madness of a Puritan daughter in love with a fugitive Stuart loyalist.

title: DR. MAX KLIGER
description: Dr. Max Kliger, an orthopedic surgeon, died Sunday at his home in the Bronx. He was 88 years old. Dr. Kliger, who retired earlier this year, had been on the staff of the Hospital for Joint Diseases and Mount Sinai, Montefiore, City, Bronx, Elmhurst General and Lutheran Hospitals during his career..

title: WEDNESDAY SEPTEMBER 30, 1981
description: International Nuclear investigations in Pakistan have been started by arms control and intelligence officials of the Reagan Administration and inspectors of the International Atomic Energy Agency. They are investigating what they term ''suspicious'' activities at Pakistan's nuclear reactor, which can produce plutonium. (Page A3, Column 1.) Violence continued in Iran. An Islamic clergyman-politician was assassinated in a grenade blast, and 43 more anti-Government guerrillas were executed by the revolutionary Islamic authorities. (A3:4-6.)

title: V OSNE-ROMANEE,France
description: SOMEONE said a fellow in this town named Henri Jayer owned pieces of both the Richebourg and Echezeaux vineyards and made good wines from both. So I called him up and he said to come on over.

title: A DEBT OF $1 TRILLION: ITS EFFECT ON ECONOMY
description: One trillion. A one followed by 12 zeros. It is a number almost beyond comprehension; so much so, that it is often referred to as a million million, or a thousand billion. But sometime soon, after Congress votes to raise the debt ceiling, the Treasury Department will sell one more issue of new Treasury securities, and for the first time the nation's debt will break through the $1 trillion mark.

title: Southeast Drought Persists
description: Dry weather in the Southeast continues to hamper crops there, the Agriculture Department reported today. But corn and soybeans throughout the Corn Belt and elsewhere are mostly rated in good to excellent condition, according to the weekly crop update from the Joint Agricultural Weather Facility of the Agriculture and Commerce Departments.

title: ARCATA BACKS $330 MILLION BID FOR ACQUISITION BY KOHLBERG
description: The Arcata Corporation, which produces a variety of forest products and is the nation's second-largest printing concern, said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to be acquired by a new corporation to be formed by Kohlberg, Kravis, Robert & Company.
